headline: Bent, Not Broken
text: THE young teacher knows every bump and pothole along the 10-minute ride to school. The entrance to the Bruckner Expressway is the worst. “Watch this one coming up,” she calls out to the Access-a-Ride driver.

headline: Changing How Qatar Sees the Blind
text: DOHA, Qatar

headline: Strategy for the Produce Aisle
text: Cecile Richards, 52, a onetime labor organizer and co-founder of America Votes, an umbrella organization of liberal groups concentrating on voter turnout,  has been president since 2006 of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America. Ms. Richards, the daughter of the late Ann Richards, who was governor of Texas, lives on the Upper West Side with her husband, Kirk Adams, 60, a health care organizer for the Service Employees International Union. Their three children no longer live at home; the couple recently downsized to an apartment near Central Park. ROBIN FINN

headline: Returning to College, Without the Beer
text: College takes forever to finish, then is over too soon and, like really good skin, it’s wasted on the young. For those who feel nostalgic — but only up to a point — One Day University offers classes taught by celebrated professors: “No tests. No homework. No stress.”

headline: Solution to Capping Well Stays Elusive
text: As cleanup crews struggled Friday to cope with the massive oil slick from a leaking well in the Gulf of Mexico, dozens of engineers and technicians ensconced in a Houston office building were still trying to solve the mystery of how to shut down the well after a week of brainstorming and failed efforts.

headline: NATO Investigates 3 Afghan Civilian Deaths
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The French military took responsibility on Friday for killing four Afghan children during a missile strike in early April, and NATO said it was investigating allegations of a military convoy gunning down two Afghan women and a girl in southeastern Afghanistan.

headline: On Names and Religion
text: Besides covering broader stories like immigration policy and the 2010 census, New York’s ethnic newspapers also run items more particular to their individual readership. In the past month, a Chinese newspaper looked at a debate swirling around the name of a play, a Mexican newspaper reported on the confusion caused when illegal immigrants give fake names upon arrest, and a Bangladeshi paper explored the younger generation’s drift away from religion. Here are excerpts, translated with help from the New York Community Media Alliance:  KIRK SEMPLE

headline: Patricia Wood, Edward Ney
text: Patricia Murray Wood and Edward Noonan Ney were married Saturday evening. The Rev. Ralph R. Warren, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of Hilary Ross, a daughter of the bride, and her husband, the financier Wilbur Ross, in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Christine Chen, Daniel Rogart
text: Christine Yiyin Chen and Daniel Caleb Rogart were married Saturday at the St. Julien Hotel and Spa in Boulder, Colo. The Rev. Beverly Fest, a Methodist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

headline: Naomi Seiler, Eric Columbus
text: Naomi Kate Seiler and Eric Randal Columbus are to be married Sunday at River Farm, the headquarters of the American Horticultural Society in Alexandria, Va. Cantor Ellen Stettner is to officiate, with Rabbi Jonathan Zimet, the bride’s uncle, taking part.

headline: Catherine Hunt, Jason Ryan
text: Catherine Marie Hunt and Jason Alexander Ryan were married Saturday at St. Peter’s on Capitol Hill, a Roman Catholic church in Washington. The Rev. William Byrne, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Courtney Lewis, Steven Schlow
text: Courtney Shane Lewis and Steven Eric Schlow were married Saturday evening at Cold Spring Country Club in Huntington, N.Y. Rabbi Jaimee Shalhevet officiated.

headline: Insurer Allowed to Sue Countrywide
text: MBIA can proceed with a lawsuit claiming that Countrywide Financial committed fraud in obtaining insurance on billions of dollars of mortgage-backed securities, a judge ruled. MBIA’s suit contends that Countrywide “falsely represented” to the insurer, and to trusts holding the securities, that Countrywide originated the mortgage loans in strict compliance with its underwriting standards. The insurer has covered more than $459 million of losses.

headline: Beyond Peanuts and Cracker Jacks
text: With culinary all-stars like Danny Meyer and David Pasternack in the kitchen, or at least behind it, it’s hard to think of the almost genteel dining plaza at Citi Field — the home of the Mets — as an ordinary food court. This spacious terrace behind left-center field not only offers Shake Shack burgers, Blue Smoke barbecue and pizza from the Original Cascarino’s of College Point; it does so, at certain tables, with a view of the field. At any given game, you are likely to find entranced Mets fans lining up for stadium grub that far surpasses the clichéd peanuts and Cracker Jack of song. If it happens to be a day game, you might even find a salesman and his customers playing hooky from work.

headline: Pembry Keller, Pedro Sáez
text: Pembry Keller, a daughter of Gail D. Keller and Richard H. Keller of Wilmington, Del., was married Saturday at her parents’ vacation home in Sheldon, S.C., to Pedro Alejandro Sáez, a son of Rosa M. Maza and Pedro P. Sáez of Miami. The Rev. Andrew C. Pearson Jr., an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Rachel Rosenstein, Joshua Weiner
text: Rachel Kushner Rosenstein and Joshua Isaac Weiner are to be married Sunday at Temple Beth Ahm Yisrael in Springfield, N.J. Rabbi Lester Bronstein is to perform the ceremony, with Rabbi John Schechter taking part.

headline: Ex-Worker Says Her Firing Was Based on Genetic Test
text: After one of her two sisters was found to have breast cancer, Pamela Fink rushed to have a genetic test to see whether she had a predisposition for such cancer, and the answer came back yes.

headline: Megan Miller, Frank Coleman
text: Megan Leigh Miller, a daughter of Pamela D. Miller and Craig N. Miller of Lexington, Ky., was married Saturday to Frank Stewart Coleman III, the son of Nancy B. Vittorini of Bronxville, N.Y., and Mr. Coleman Jr. of Preston, Wash. The Rev. Edward A. Malloy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Basilica of the Sacred Heart at the University of Notre Dame in South Bend, Ind.

headline: New Publisher Named for the Philadelphia Inquirer
text: The former Newsweek publisher Greg Osberg was named publisher of The Philadelphia Inquirer’s parent company after creditors won an auction to buy the business in bankruptcy. Mr. Osberg, 52, will also be chief executive of Philadelphia Newspapers, owner of The Inquirer, The Philadelphia Daily News and Philly.com, pending approval of the sale in bankruptcy court.

headline: Erica Brauer, Jason Navarino
text: Erica Alana Brauer and Jason David Navarino are to be married Sunday, with Rabbi Joshua S. Finkelstein officiating at the Stony Hill Inn in Hackensack, N.J.

headline: Elizabeth Bellis, Joshua Wolfe
text: Elizabeth Ogden Bellis and Joshua Flotte Wolfe were married Saturday at the Brooklyn Bridge Park. The Rev. Alice Ogden Bellis, a Presbyterian minister and the bride’s mother, officiated.

headline: Comfort Food, With a View
text: Some might remember Bridge View Tavern when it was called Goldie’s by the Bridge, in the 1990s. But, in fact, the Maceyak family has owned and intermittently operated a bar in this building at the river end of Beekman Street for 30 years.

headline: A New Take on Surf and Turf
text: THERE’S been little change in décor at  Caffé Azzurri, a wine bar and restaurant that opened five months ago in Hartsdale in the warm, clubby space once occupied by Café Meze and then Piave. And the few new touches have made the place even more welcoming than before. The area next to the bar has been reconfigured with soft sofas, and floor-to-ceiling sheers separate the lounge from the dining room, where customers are welcome to pause over a glass of wine and a few snacks or to enjoy a full meal.

headline: France: Ex-Minister Convicted
text: A special court convicted Senator Charles Pasqua, left, a onetime close ally of Jacques Chirac, on Friday on a corruption charge stemming from his tenure as interior minister in the early 1990s. Mr. Pasqua, 83, received a one-year suspended prison sentence for embezzlement of public funds in a case linked to the sale of police equipment abroad; he was acquitted on corruption charges in two other cases. He had been convicted in October for influence peddling in connection with illegal arms sales to Angola in the 1990s, a decision he has appealed. Mr. Chirac is to stand trial in November on charges that he embezzled public funds as mayor of Paris, before he became president in 1993.

headline: Aubry Nivens and Colin Parks-Fried
text: Aubry Lyn Nivens and Colin Michael Parks-Fried were married Saturday evening. David L. James, a minister of the Catholic Diocese of One Spirit, officiated at My Moon, a restaurant in Brooklyn.

headline: Leaked Memo Sees Bigger Oil Risk
text: Ben Raines, an award-winning environment reporter in Alabama, unearthed a two-day-old federal memo today proposing that the flow of oil from the wrecked exploratory well in the Gulf of Mexico could vastly increase. Quoting the memo, Raines wrote:

headline: China: World Expo Opens
text: Shanghai kicked off the 2010 World Expo on Friday evening with an extravagant opening ceremony and fireworks show and a pledge to be more open and inclusive. The two-hour performance at the new $270 million Expo Culture Center ended with a spectacular outdoor multimedia show punctuated by a parade of hundreds of national flags carried by boats along the city’s Huangpu River. The city has spent $45 billion, more than Beijing spent on the 2008 Olympics, to put on what it says will be the biggest Expo ever, and a showcase of China’s new economic might. Organizers are expecting 70 million visitors during the six-month-long Expo, mostly from neighboring provinces.

headline: Obsessive About Pizza
text: Robert Cino does not claim that his pizzeria is the only one in this part of New Jersey that uses a wood-burning oven. But he says that his 1,600-square-foot restaurant Ah’Pizz, which he has been gradually opening with two partners since February, is the only one using it correctly.

headline: Slurp, Bite, Slurp: Shanghai Favorites
text: SPOILER alert: A meal at Petite Soochow, the bracingly authentic Shanghainese restaurant in Cliffside Park, is likely to begin with a surprise. If you don’t want me to give it away, I suggest you skip the next few paragraphs, get yourself a table at this unassuming 82-seat gem and return to this review after you’ve ordered No. 10 on the “Break Fast” menu.

headline: R. Douglas Arnold and Alexander Quinn
text: R. Douglas Arnold and Alexander Michael Quinn were married Friday at the Town Hall in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Lawrence A. Whitney, a priest of the Lindisfarne Community, an ecumenical order, who is also a nephew of Mr. Arnold.

headline: Francesca DeLaurentis and Peter Calloway
text: Francesca Joelle DeLaurentis, a daughter of Susan DeLaurentis and Robert DeLaurentis of Santa Monica, Calif., was married Saturday evening to Peter Alexander Calloway, the son of Wendy S. Milner Calloway and David Calloway of Los Angeles. Estela Sánchez, an assistant justice of the peace in Playa del Carmen, Mexico, officiated at the Esencia Estate Hotel there.

headline: Designer Has Fan at Top, but Too Few at the Stores
text: CHICAGO — Fashion and politics are seasonal and unpredictable, yet the two came together quite well here for the hometown designer Maria Pinto and Michelle Obama, whose first memorable bursts onto the national scene were often in Pinto creations.

headline: Artful Treats, From Scratch
text: A shelf of ceramics made by an area potter runs high along a wall of La Palette Bakery, Cafe and Gallery in Watertown. But far more abundant, and every bit as artful, are the items displayed in the glass cases by the counter. Those include eye-catching fruit tarts, well-formed cakes and pies, chocolate-saturated éclairs, sundry cookies and diet-busting cream puffs.

headline: Local Food, French Flair and an Intimate Setting
text: IT’S the end of my second meal at Restaurant L&E in Chester. It was a good one, so I’m surprised to find that my coffee isn’t hot. Our waiter is suddenly at my elbow, reinforcement in hand. “Was your coffee a little cool?” he asks, exchanging the offending cup. “I thought so; I noticed that someone hadn’t replaced the top on the thermos.”

headline: Lessons From Catholic Schools for Public Educators
text: Within the 242 pages of Diane Ravitch’s lightning rod of a book, “The Death and Life of the Great American School System,” there appear exactly three references to Catholic education. Which makes sense, given that Ms. Ravitch is addressing and deploring recent efforts to reform public schools with extensive testing and increasing privatization.

headline: U.N. Official Fears Congo Is Overcome by Violence
text: MWENGA, Democratic Republic of Congo — As his plane cut through the clouds above eastern Congo on Friday, John Holmes, the United Nations’ top humanitarian official, looked down pensively at the miles and miles of thick forest covering one of the most chronically afflicted parts of Africa, if not the world.

headline: A Pinch of His and Hers
text: Russell Hearn has been the principal winemaker at Pellegrini Vineyards, in Cutchogue, since 1991. He is also a partner in the Premium Wine Group, a for-hire winery in Mattituck established in 2000. Now he and his wife, Susan, are producing a personal label, Suhru Wines, at Premium.

headline: Vibrant Flavors of South America
text: SABOR A COLOMBIA (Flavor of Colombia), which opened in December, is a ray of South American sunshine in Levittown. The newcomer occupies a spot behind Bally Total Fitness and, like the gym, has a cream-colored exterior. The simple dining room, however, vibrates with color: the brilliant yellow walls are dotted with giant three-dimensional figures of parrots and women with baskets of fruit on their heads.

headline: Mayweather’s Hands Stay Wrapped in Trust
text: LAS VEGAS — On his business card, Rafael Garcia lists trainer-consultant-cutman as his occupation. But his specialty, his artistry, lies in his hands.

headline: Antagonists Who Inspired Modern Lovers
text: Take us back to the glamour of Budapest between the wars. To the days when ladies dressed up to go shopping for perfume and cold cream in Art Nouveau palaces. To a world in which single men and women hoping to find true love made genteel letter-writing contact through lonely-hearts clubs.

headline: On the Street | Goodbye
text: Bill Cunningham says farewell to Carnegie Hall after living there for 60 years.

headline: Mayhem in Hamptons, but Only on the Page
text: INDA Fairstein, a onetime Manhattan sex-crimes prosecutor and the author of legal thrillers, was at her computer a couple of years ago when she got an instant message from a friend urging her to turn on the television.

headline: On Favorite’s Back, More Than Just Rider
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Garrett Gomez is riding the morning-line favorite Saturday in the 136th running of the Kentucky Derby, but he knows in many respects the odds are stacked against him. Yes, Lookin at Lucky is last year’s champion 2-year-old colt with six victories in eight lifetime starts.

headline: Hofstra Coach Is Suspended for D.U.I. Arrest
text: Hofstra has suspended its men’s basketball coach, Tim Welsh, indefinitely after he was arrested early Friday morning and charged with driving while intoxicated by the Nassau County police.

headline: Rare Breed Now: A Justice Who Wasn’t a Judge
text: WASHINGTON — In the spring of 2001, at a boisterous annual banquet of The Harvard Law Review, a 40-year-old professor named Elena Kagan introduced the main speaker.

headline: First Round Reaffirms It: If You’re in, You Have a Chance
text: In the press room at Madison Square Garden during the last days of the regular season, reporters covering the Rangers would speculate on which of the five teams would qualify for only three Stanley Cup playoff berths. Would it be the Rangers, Montreal, Boston, Atlanta, Philadelphia? Before too long, someone would say, “What’s the difference — they’re all going out in the first round anyway,” and all would agree.

headline: Hard at Work Charming Children
text: VERONA

headline: Dreams, Let Up on Us!
text: Will Shakespeare told us, in that line always misquoted with the word “of” — even by Bogey in “The Maltese Falcon” — that “we are such stuff as dreams are made on.” If they’re in fact what we’re made on, it’s a mixed blessing.

headline: Visions of the Eerie, the Wacky and the Whimsical
text: NEW ROCHELLE

headline: Lori Holmes, Benjamin Clark
text: Lori Michelle Holmes, the daughter of Patti Holmes of Cape Coral, Fla., and Larry Csonka of Anchorage, was married Saturday to Benjamin Thomas Clark, the son of Rebecca B. Clark and Thomas G. Clark of Deerfield, Mass. Laurie MacLeod, an associate justice of the Palmer District Court, a division of the Massachusetts Court System, officiated in Deerfield at Clarkdale Fruit Farms, the bridegroom’s family farm.

headline: Melissa Renzi, Robert Gustafson
text: Melissa Anne Renzi and Robert Peter Gustafson were married Saturday evening. The Rev. Peter J. McGuinness of the Federation of Christian Ministries officiated at the Abington Art Center in Jenkintown, Pa.

headline: Favre Comes in From Yard to Say He’s Still Thinking
text: Brett Favre said Friday that he might need minor surgery to relieve pain in his left ankle. The pain is one of the factors he is considering in what has become an annual N.F.L. rite of spring: waiting for Favre to decide whether he will play another season or retire.

headline: The Court as Mr. Fix-It?
text: Prohibition ended 77 years ago, yet Americans have still not kicked the habit of trying to fix social problems by banning things.

headline: Job Cuts at ABC Leave Workers Stunned and Downcast
text: If “Good Morning America” or “World News” look any different in the coming weeks, it might be because ABC News is employing nearly 400 fewer people.

headline: Love Means ... Well, It’s Hard to Say
text: Joan is the live wire in John Kolvenbach’s “Love Song.” We’ve got her number from the moment she walks into her apartment with her husband, home from a hard day at work, heading straight for the bar and complaining in her sarcastic but affable way about the office intern.

headline: Betrayal and Suspense in Remote West Africa
text: Everyone in “Battle of Black and Dogs” is nervous. Anxious. High-strung. Hanging onto sanity or civility by the thinnest of threads.

headline: Foot Soldiers of the Automotive-Repair Trade
text: “Yo, auto glass! Auto glass! I got it!” a man named Tony Rivera cried.

headline: Gabrielle Finley and Josh Abramson
text: Gabrielle Borden Finley and Joshua David Abramson were married Saturday evening at the Round Hill Hotel in Montego Bay, Jamaica. The Rev. Glenroy Clarke Jr., a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Alicia Hall and Jason Moran
text: ALICIA HALL MORAN is prone to bold pronouncements, and her wedding to Jason Moran in September 2003 was no exception. Where other brides might announce themselves with flutes and strings, she sashayed toward the altar to the pounding of African drums.

headline: Unanswered Questions on the Spill
text: President Obama has ordered a freeze on new offshore drilling leases as well as a “thorough review” into what is almost sure to be the worst oil spill in this country’s history  exceeding in size and environmental damage the calamitous Exxon Valdez disaster in 1989.

headline: Painter Traces His Start to World War II Service
text: During World War II, Stan Brodsky, then a 19-year-old soldier from Brooklyn, was in eastern France when his platoon came upon an Alsatian farmhouse that their commander ordered them to “liberate.” Mr. Brodsky, 85, now a prominent artist living in Huntington, recounts the episode, which took place in November 1944, in his new book, “The Uncertainty of Experience: An Artist’s Journey.”

headline: The Big Fix
text: In Albany, as the saying goes, politicians pick their voters, not the other way around. Politically driven redistricting — or gerrymandering — is one of the main reasons why despite the corruption, laziness and incompetence that are rife in the New York Senate and Assembly, the corrupt, lazy and incompetent keep getting re-elected.

headline: U.S. Sets Start of Mideast Peace Talks
text: WASHINGTON — Fifteen months after President Obama took office promising to kick-start the Middle East peace process, the United States finally plans to open talks between Israel and the Palestinians.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Comedy

headline: At Least 50 of City’s Senior Centers Expected to Close to Save Money
text: Convinced that the deteriorating budget situation in Albany leaves it no other choice, the Bloomberg administration plans to close as many as a quarter of the city’s more than 300 senior centers by July 1, with Manhattan being hardest hit.

headline: Cleaning Up Medical Advice
text: Professional medical societies play an enormously influential role in determining how medicine is practiced, but their activities and financing are a mystery. Outsiders can’t tell how independent the societies are from the companies that supply much of their financing.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Courage of the Sisters
text: In the fierce closing debate over health care reform, the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops charged that the legislation didn’t do enough to restrict insurance coverage of abortions. Many Catholic nuns and the Catholic Health Association of the United States, which represents hundreds of Catholic hospitals, looked at the same bill and concluded that it would have no effect on abortion financing. They signed a letter urging its passage, saying the reform was “life-affirming” and consistent with Catholic values.

headline: Off-Field Turmoil Causes Soul Searching at Oregon
text: EUGENE, Ore. — As the Oregon football team scrimmaged on a recent morning under overcast skies at Autzen Stadium, Jeremiah Masoli stood on the sidelines, his hands tucked inside the pouch on the front of his practice jersey and his helmet deposited under the bench behind him.

headline: Democrats Reframe the Debate on Immigration
text: The outline for an immigration overhaul unveiled by Democratic senators this week lays down a new starting point for any national debate: tough immigration enforcement. But perhaps more significantly it reveals how politics have shifted on the contentious issue.

headline: Woods Misses Fairways, Greens and the Cut
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The second round of the Quail Hollow Championship turned into a day of extreme rarities on Friday at Quail Hollow Club. Billy Mayfair, a pudgy 43-year-old who has not won in 12 years, shot his second straight 68 and took the lead. Tiger Woods, the No. 1-ranked golfer in the world, shot a 79 and took a hike, missing a cut for only the sixth time in his professional career.

headline: Teachers Always Show Up
text: Sometimes, in election season, I have the feeling that the entire audience at political events is made up of teachers.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Ballplayers Join Protest of New Law
text: A day after protesters rallied against Arizona’s new illegal immigration law outside Wrigley Field in Chicago, Major League Baseball thrust itself into the national debate.

headline: Atop the Ocean, a Sea of Untapped Energy
text: Bobbing in the Atlantic, about nine miles from the sandy beaches of the Rockaway peninsula, a yellow buoy clangs and blinks, rising and dropping on the ocean swells. Fixed to the nose of the buoy are two anemometers that spin in the wind. They read the direction and speed of the wind 24 hours a day, like a dog with its head out the window of a car on an endless highway.

headline: Rookie Lands in the Water but Above the Cut Line
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Before Friday, Garth Mulroy’s greatest claim to fame was finishing tied for 46th the only time he made the cut in a PGA Tour event.

headline: Los Angeles Archbishop to Lead a Rally Against the Arizona Measure
text: Cardinal Roger M. Mahony, archbishop of Los Angeles, will be a leader of Saturday’s march in downtown Los Angeles, where tens of thousands of people are expected to protest Arizona’s new immigration law.

headline: Abortion’s New Battle Lines
text: While we’ve been distracted by Tea Party antics, the government’s efforts to sack Goldman Sachs and the tawdry drama of John Edwards and his baby’s mama, a rash of states has rushed to restrict access to abortion.

headline: Citing Wall Street Reform, Dodd Backs Out of Fund-Raiser for Gillibrand
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, a leader of Congressional efforts to crack down on Wall Street abuses, announced abruptly on Friday that he was canceling a planned appearance at a fund-raiser attended by financial industry executives in Manhattan next week.

headline: Bloggingheads: Immigration Uncertainty
text: Ben Smith, left, of Politico and David Weigel of The Washington Post debate the politics of immigration.

headline: James and His Right Arm Are Valuable
text: INDEPENDENCE, Ohio — LeBron James will be awarded his second consecutive Most Valuable Player award on Sunday, according to The Cleveland Plain Dealer and other news media outlets.

headline: Illinois: No Subpoena for Obama
text: A federal judge denied a motion on Friday to subpoena President Obama to testify at the corruption trial for former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich. Judge James B. Zagel of Federal District Court said Mr. Blagojevich’s lawyers had not proved that Mr. Obama’s testimony would be significant. The lawyers had claimed that the president could provide insight into the accusation that Mr. Blagojevich tried to sell or trade the Senate seat once held by Mr. Obama.

headline: Who Lives in Sheik Jarrah?
text: AS a boy, I lived in Sheik Jarrah, a wealthy Arab neighborhood in East Jerusalem. Annexed by Israel in 1967 and now the subject of a conflict over property claims, my former home has come to symbolize everything that has gone wrong between the Israelis and Palestinians over the last six decades.

headline: Diplomat’s Arrest in Houston Spurs Complaint From China
text: HOUSTON — Three Houston police officers caused an international incident last weekend when they followed a Chinese diplomat into a parking garage at the Chinese Consulate and arrested him, injuring him in the process, the authorities said.

headline: Mets Take Trip to Right Places to Find Their Bats
text: PHILADELPHIA — After matching the club record for the best homestand in club history by going 9-1, the Mets proved they could definitely succeed in the spacious surroundings of Citi Field. But they have yet to demonstrate that they can handle more modest outfields like those in Philadelphia and Cincinnati.

headline: Response of Approval
text: “Most editors are failed writers — but so are most writers”— 43 Across

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Officially Undecided, Cuomo Is Still Star of an Early Primary Event
text: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. — Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo was greeted like the state Democratic Party’s star attraction at the start of a conference here on Friday organized by rural county leaders, but he still is not ready to say what office he is running for.

headline: More Pre-K Pupils Qualify for Gifted Programs
text: The number of students qualifying for gifted kindergarten programs in New York City public school districts rose by 10 percent this year, and those qualifying for the elite citywide program jumped by a third, raising the possibility that parents and their children have begun to master an admission process that was retooled three years ago.

headline: Saying Farewell to St. Vincent's Hospital
text: Six longtime employees of St. Vincent's hospital, which closed after 160 years, reflect on the institution they love.

headline: Shadow of Hurricane Katrina Hangs Over Obama After Spill
text: WASHINGTON — There’s a world of difference between the impact of an oil spill and a deadly hurricane. And the White House hopes it stays that way.

headline: Freddy's Bar & Backroom
text: A neighborhood bar closes to make way for development.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 30, 2010

headline: 596 Arrested in Sweep
text: Immigration agents arrested 596 immigrants who they said had criminal records in a three-day operation in the southeast and Puerto Rico, calling it their biggest sweep to date in that region. The immigrants included José Oscar Avalo Molina, from El Salvador, who was arrested in Florida; he had served a 20-year murder sentence. John Morton, head of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, said many of the immigrants had eluded deportation when they were released from prison after serving criminal sentences.

headline: 2 Ex-Brooklyn Men Charged in Terror Plot
text: Two former Brooklyn residents have been charged with conspiring to provide Al Qaeda with computer advice and other assistance, according to an indictment unsealed Friday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Bloomberg Names Former Mayor of Indianapolis to No. 2 Post
text: Reaching far beyond the walls of City Hall, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Friday appointed Stephen Goldsmith, a former mayor of Indianapolis and a management guru at Harvard University, to the powerful post of deputy mayor for operations.

headline: Guillen Echos Union, Criticizing Arizona Law
text: Ozzie Guillen, the manager of the Chicago White Sox, said “I am an immigrant” and spoke forcefully Friday about Arizona’s much-debated new law, which seeks to crack down on illegal immigrants.

headline: After Bullying Lesser Teams, Mets Beat Up One of the Best
text: PHILADELPHIA — After battering three slumping opponents during their recent 9-1 homestand, the Mets had to wonder what would happen when they took their act on the road against one of the National League’s elite teams.

headline: Verdict After Fatal Plastic Surgery Surprises a Victim’s Family
text: Kathleen Kelly Cregan left her home in rural Ireland early on a March morning in 2005, embarking on a journey she thought would end up surprising and delighting her husband. Ms. Cregan flew to the United States to get a face-lift from Dr. Michael E. Sachs, a media-friendly plastic surgeon. To hide the surprise, she told her husband, Liam Cregan, that she was going to a business course in Dublin.

headline: Overhead and on the Ground, Waiting for a Potential Environmental Disaster to Hit
text: ROBERT, La. — Heavy winds and stormy seas drove a spreading oil spill closer to the marshlands and reefs of the Louisiana coast on Friday, and government and BP officials continued a frenzied effort to throttle a gushing oil well before it could do widespread damage.

headline: White Sox Take Lead; Jeter Takes It Back
text: When the Yankees have a number of regulars struggling, as they currently do, they can usually depend on a timely performance from their captain, Derek Jeter.

text: AUGUST

headline: Clare Sabatini Dies at 77; Beat Trump in Land Fight
text: Pacific Avenue isn’t usually a sought-after property in the game of Monopoly, which uses real Atlantic City street names. But Clare Sabatini forced Donald Trump to triple his offering price for her Pacific Avenue restaurant after defeating New Jersey’s effort to take it by condemnation.

headline: Staff Says Goodbye to St. Vincent’s Hospital
text: It was a requiem not just for a hospital, but also for a vanishing part of Greenwich Village history — for an institution that tended to countless skinned knees and heart attacks, as well as once-in-a-lifetime disasters from the sinking of the Titanic to the toppling of the World Trade Center.

headline: Seeking Single Home for Triple Crown
text: If Bob Evans, the chief executive of Churchill Downs Inc., could turn his preference to reality, one television network would broadcast the three Triple Crown races starting next year, as NBC did from 2001 to 2005.

headline: Immigration Law Debate Resonates Far From Border
Visions of Beauty and Unease
text: Avigdor Arikha's work captured both the haunting beauty and the looming menace of everyday things.

headline: Avigdor Arikha, Artist of the Everyday, Is Dead at 81
text: Avigdor Arikha, an internationally renowned Israeli painter whose work captured both the haunting beauty and the looming menace of everyday things, a vision informed in no small part by his experience as a Holocaust survivor, died at his home in Paris on Thursday, the day after his 81st birthday.

headline: Furio Scarpelli, Screenwriter of Italian Comedies, Dies at 90
text: Furio Scarpelli, a screenwriter who wrote dozens of the Italian cinema’s most caustic and celebrated comedies in a 36-year partnership with Agenore Incrocci, earning three Oscar nominations, died on Wednesday at his home in Rome. He was 90.

headline: Angus Maddison, Economic Historian, Dies at 83
text: Some people try to forecast the future. Angus Maddison devoted his life to forecasting the past.

headline: Lakers Eliminate Thunder on Gasol’s Putback With 0.5 Left
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Kobe Bryant was 38 feet from the basket, with only Russell Westbrook and several seconds remaining between him and a trip to the Western Conference semifinals. There was a quick drive, a fadeaway shot and a clang on the rim.

headline: The Court as Mr. Fix-It?
text: Prohibition ended 77 years ago, yet Americans have still not kicked the habit of trying to fix social problems by banning things.

headline: Gulf Coast Towns Brace as Huge Oil Slick Nears Marshes
text: COCODRIE, La. — Oil gushed into the Gulf of Mexico unabated Saturday, and officials conveyed little hope that the flow could be contained soon, forcing towns along the Gulf Coast to brace for what is increasingly understood to be an imminent environmental disaster.

headline: Tracking the Oil Spill in the Gulf
text: The spreading slick, day by day, and a chart of how much oil has been spilled.

headline: Obama Calls for Campaign Spending Disclosure
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, warning of a “potential corporate takeover of our elections,” called on Congress on Saturday to undo the effects of a recent Supreme Court ruling by imposing strict disclosure requirements on campaign spending by companies, labor unions, trade associations and advocacy groups.

headline: In Russia, Women Compete for Right to Play for World Championship
text: The tournament is the third leg in a series that will determine the next challenger for the women’s title.

headline: What Does Dick Gephardt Know About Management?
text: When we sent out the agenda for our annual gathering of open-book practitioners that will be held next week in St. Louis, we caused a bit of surprise and confusion with our choice for a keynote speaker. People keep calling us and asking, “Why Dick Gephardt?”

headline: Classic Ad: Chevrolet Impala
text: Don’t be fooled by the Chevelle screen-grab above: this week’s classic ad features the 1964 Chevy Impala.

headline: Feagles’s Style Going Out of Style?
text: Two views of Jeff Feagles, who retired on Friday after 22 seasons:

headline: Oh Where Oh Where Has My Little Ball Gone?
text: If you have lost a golf ball recently — in other words, if you have played golf recently — it might make you feel better to know that there is an army of thousands looking for it. Finding and reselling lost golf balls at roughly a 50 percent discount is a $200-million-a-year industry, golf retail associations estimate.

headline: Urban Forager | Sweet Violets
text: I was recently at Greene Acres Community Garden in Bedford-Stuyvesant, giving a group of enthusiastic gardeners a tour of edible weeds, when I couldn’t help noticing a lovely patch of violets crouching along the edges of a soil bed. Like many of the city’s flowering plants, including dandelions, cherry blossoms and magnolias, wild violets appeared super early this year. Though many folks were unaware that the violets were edible, this group of urban gardeners hungrily nibbled on the delicate flowers that I passed around.

headline: Why Devalue?
text: As the debate over possible departures from the euro heats up, there seems to a lot of confusion over the possible uses of devaluation. The main argument I’m hearing goes like this: since Greece’s debt is in euros, devaluing won’t relieve the debt burden — so it won’t help.

headline: Ahead of Derby, a Triple Crown Dream
text: I am a Pollyanna. I believe I will live to see a Triple Crown. I state that every January 1 as I proclaim loudly to the heavens — “This IS the year of our Triple Crown winner.” So when I went to my first horse race, which was the Big Brown Belmont Stakes, I sat for an hour or more in the stands not wallowing in disappointment but pondering the Triple Crown trail. I wrote a story that night that said that in the future I would go to the Kentucky Derby to watch the beginning of a dream.

headline: The Pain In Spain
text: … isn’t nearly as severe as a casual reading of the news might suggest. Or more accurately: Spain’s economy is a mess, with immense unemployment, but there has actually been remarkably little contagion so far from Greek concerns. It comes as a bit of a shock, actually, to discover that the interest rate on Spanish 10-years is only 4.03 percent; it’s up about 25 basis points since Greece went pear-shaped, but that’s not bad, considering.

headline: U.S. Missed Chances to Act on Oil Spill
text: NEW ORLEANS — As oil edged toward the Louisiana coast and fears continued to grow that the leak from a seabed oil well could spiral out of control, the White House announced that President Obama would visit the region on Sunday morning.

headline: The Saturday Word
text: President Obama urged Congress Saturday to rewrite the rules governing campaign contributions in an effort to undo the Supreme Court’s ruling in the Citizens United case earlier this year.

headline: Best Tight Ends in N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, though the future isn’t ignored. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: Live From Buffettpalooza 2010
text: 11:24 a.m. | Updated DealBook has more on Warren Buffett’s defense of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Buffett Says He Backs Goldman’s Blankfein ‘100%’
text: Ahead of Warren E. Buffett‘s Q.&A. with shareholders at Berkshire Hathaway‘s annual meeting in Omaha, the biggest question on many people’s minds was: how does the billionaire investor feel about Goldman Sachs?

headline: Is There a ‘Feynman Fix’ for Leaking Well?
text: 12:23 p.m. | Updated with many new contributions below.

headline: Letterman: ‘A Walk Down Memory Lane’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Let’s take a walk down memory lane. On this date in 1789, George Washington was sworn in as the first president of the United States. And by the way, as a footnote, he is the only president who has never blamed the troubles of this country on the previous administration.

headline: Leno: ‘Nothing But Disasters’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Boy, there’s nothing but disasters in the news: Oil slicks in Louisiana; gridlock in Washington; the Dodgers in L.A.

headline: Bombs Hit Mosque in Somalia’s Capital, Killing Dozens
text: Dozens of people were killed on Saturday in a rare mosque bombing in Somalia’s capital, Mogadishu, in what may be a sign of increased bloodletting between Islamist insurgent groups.

headline: Buffett Defends Goldman at Berkshire Meeting
text: The first question asked during Berkshire Hathaway‘s 2010 shareholder meeting was unsurprisingly about Goldman Sachs, which is under fire from the Securities and Exchange Commission for an alleged act of securities fraud.

headline: Taiwan Flight Diverted by Threat
text: BEIJING — A 58-year-old American man forced a China Airlines jet to divert a flight to Shanghai on Saturday morning after he told a flight attendant that he had a bomb in his luggage, news agencies reported.

headline: The Morning Line: Derby Day Arrives
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

headline: British Paper Drops Labour Backing
text: LONDON — Prime Minister Gordon Brown’s faltering Labour government endured more bad news on Saturday, when the latest polls showed it had lost ground to the Conservative opposition with less than a week to go before Thursday’s general election.

headline: Wanted, Sudan’s President Can’t Escape Isolation
text: PARIS — On the international summit circuit, no one can clear a room more quickly than Sudan’s president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir.

headline: Willis Reed’s Hip and the Radio Daze of 1970 Knicks Fans
text: Welcome, graying fans of the quote-unquote Old Knicks, to our 40th anniversary week, the celebration of our greatest and guiltiest sports pleasure. Four decades ago, while the city and country convulsed with war protests and violence, we were obsessed with the pursuit of New York’s first professional basketball championship.

headline: Greek Wealth Is Everywhere but Tax Forms
text: ATHENS — In the wealthy, northern suburbs of this city, where summer temperatures often hit the high 90s, just 324 residents checked the box on their tax returns admitting that they owned pools.

headline: Human Trafficking, There and Here
text: On Friday I was on a panel at Bay Path College along with Somaly Mam, my friend and hero. Somaly is a Cambodian who was trafficked into a brothel as a little girl but managed to escape — and then started an anti-trafficking organization to fight the brothels and help other girls escape. She has been extraordinarily courageous in keeping up the fight when the brothel-owners just want to kill her, and she seems so unbelievably poised when she speaks in English — her fourth language — before large audiences under a spotlight. But on Friday, I saw a reminder of how that past haunts her and anyone who went through such a trauma.

headline: As Rain Falls, Horses’ Routines Are Interrupted
text: It’s Derby morning at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky. And the weather has not cooperated. As of 11 a.m. we do not know exactly what the weather will do for the remainder of the day, and consequently how this will affect the racing surface. The track superintendant, who is in charge of decisions regarding the state of the racetrack, has not made a decision regarding whether the track will be sealed, or opened up, at Derby time. This decision will be determined solely by the state of the track, and the weather, throughout the afternoon. Between the second and third race, the track was “floated,” which means it remained sealed. The rain seems to have eased off.

headline: Capt. Parmenter’s Diagramless
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — I mentioned in my previous post that solving is a personal experience. A lot depends on what you know. Brendan Emmett Quigley knows many things I don’t, as I’m often reminded. He has a deep understanding of pop culture, and he’s not afraid to fill the grid with questions like “1970s-’80s rock genre” and “1991 top 10 hit for Chris Isaak” and “Bygone N.Y.C. rock club.” We’ve had that last one before. It was supposedly the birthplace of punk. Whose puzzle was it in? I’ll give you one guess.

headline: Pope Reins In Catholic Order Tied to Abuse
text: ROME — Pope Benedict XVI on Saturday took control of the Legionaries of Christ, a powerful and wealthy Roman Catholic religious order whose founder, a friend of Pope John Paul II, was found to have molested seminarians and fathered several children.

headline: Turn Back the Clock to 1970
text: With the 40th anniversary of New York’s most cherished basketball occasion upcoming, it seemed like a good time to revisit May 8, 1970, a challenging night for the overwhelming majority of Old Knicks fans — most of us not too young anymore ourselves.

headline: India’s Catholics Plan to Report Abuse Claims
text: NEW DELHI — India’s Roman Catholic bishops are planning to institute a policy of reporting all abuse allegations against priests to the police for criminal investigations, rather than just handling the cases internally, a church spokesman said.

headline: Clouds Part Long Enough for a Memorable Ride
text: Louisville, Ky.

headline: Pictures From the Berkshire Meeting
text: Nati Harnik/The Associated Press Warren E. Buffett and Charlie Munger of Berkshire Hathaway, projected on the screen, preside over the firm’s 2010 annual meeting.

headline: Early Update From Churchill Downs
text: The track is sloppy but has shown no discernable bias in the early races, Joe Drape reports via Twitter. His last two tweets:

headline: An Unlikely Thorn Keeps Jabbing at the Phillies
text: PHILADELPHIA — The last time Rod Barajas stepped to the plate as a Philadelphia Phillie, he was instrumental in furthering the downfall of the 2007 Mets. He delivered a two-out, pinch-hit single that drove home the go-ahead run in the 14th inning of a 7-4 Phillies victory in St. Louis on Sept. 18 of that memorable month.

headline: Greeks Take to Streets in Protest of Deep Spending Cuts
text: ATHENS — Tens of thousands of demonstrators took to the streets across Greece on Saturday, including hundreds of black-clad youths who clashed with the police here, as Greeks vented their rage at tough new austerity measures aimed at securing aid and avoiding a debt default.

headline: Berkshire Posts $3.6 Billion 1st-Quarter Profit
text: Berkshire Hathaway has rebounded from last year’s first-quarter loss and earned $3.6 billion as the economic recovery began and the conglomerate absorbed the Burlington Northern Santa Fe railroad, The Associated Press reported on Saturday.

headline: Future Stars in the Spotlight at Three Student Tournaments
text: The dour economy seems to be hurting scholastic chess.

headline: Myanmar Junta Members Go Civilian
text: BANGKOK — It is an obvious move when generals in a military junta decide to step aside in favor of civilian rule: shed military ranks and uniforms and transform themselves into civilians.

headline: Attacks Rattle 2 Republics in Caucasus on May Day
text: MOSCOW — Violence broke out in two North Caucasian republics on Saturday, as militants attacked gatherings on May Day, a revered Soviet holiday that still draws flocks of Russians to public celebrations.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu: May 2
text: Topics from the Southeast to the Gulf Coast to the Southwest will dominate the Sunday talk shows: The Florida Senate race, the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico and Arizona’s new immigration law.

headline: A Slam Seems a Little Less Fanciful Than Usual
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The surprising spectacle of Tiger Woods’s missing the cut at the Quail Hollow Championship — shooting 79 on Friday by three-putting twice, four-putting once, hitting only two fairways, stringing together three straight bogeys and back-to-back doubles — showed how quickly things can change in golf.

headline: Length of Deal Highlights Howard’s Flaws
text: From 2006 to 2009, Ryan Howard had 198 homers and 572 runs batted in for the Phillies. Both figures were the best in baseball over that period and rank among the best in history for a four-year stretch. Only five players have hit more home runs over four consecutive seasons, and only seven have driven in more runners.

headline: Pitchers on the Farm, but Not for Long
text: In consecutive games last week involving the Class AA Reading Phillies, a starting pitcher allowed no hits. On Sunday, Reading’s Phillippe Aumont blanked Richmond for six innings. On Tuesday, Harrisburg’s Stephen Strasburg stifled Reading for five.

headline: A Goldman Observation
text: Am I the only one who sees the resemblance?

headline: Europe's Web of Debt
text: Banks and governments in these five shaky economies owe each other many billions of euros, and have even larger debts to Britain, France and Germany.

headline: In and Out of Each Other’s European Wallets
text: Despite the best efforts of the International Monetary Fund, the financial crisis in Europe seems full of suspense. Will Germany and the European Union actually cough up the money to help bail out Greece, which is on the edge of a financial meltdown? Will the contagion spread to other vulnerable countries, like Portugal and Spain?

headline: Prime Number
text: 34.5: The number of people, in millions, who spoke Spanish at home in 2007, up 211 percent from 1980, according to new Census Bureau report on the nation’s linguistic diversity. Of the nation’s 281 million people who are 5 and older, 55.4 million — about 20 percent — spoke a language other than English at home. Chinese ranked third, behind English and Spanish, with 2.5 million people speaking it at home. Five other languages had at least one million speakers: Tagalog, spoken in the Philippines (1.5 million), French (1.4 million), Vietnamese (1.2 million), and German and Korean (1.1 million speakers each).

headline: Grist
text: How tough is it to get an appointment at California’s Department of Motor Vehicles? Pretty tough, as Scott James explained on The Bay Area, The New York Times blog that covers San Francisco and its environs. Forced to retrench by the state’s fiscal crisis, the agency has reduced its customer-service hours by 15 percent. “Over the course of two weeks I used the D.M.V. online reservation system to try to snag an appointment,” he wrote. “I checked at different days and times. No luck. Not even for weeks in advance. During this same time, I was able to go online ... to get a coveted reservation at the popular new restaurant Frances, which is a finalist for the prestigious James Beard Award.” O.K., it was for 10 p.m. on a Friday night. But he did get a reservation.

headline: What We’re Reading: Facebook Privacy
text: The tech reporters and editors of the New York Times paused to read these articles:

headline: U.S. Defender Has Clear View of World Cup
text: LONDON — Jay DeMerit sat in the eye doctor’s office as a machine mapped the topography of his right cornea, the dome-shaped surface that covers the iris and pupil, and helps to focus vision. A digital printout resembled a weather map with its yellows and greens and dissipating reds.

headline: Indonesians Seek Words to Attract China’s Favor
text: LAMONGAN, Indonesia — When the regent of this coastal rice-growing region on the island of Java first toured China as part of an official delegation, his eyes went wide. Here was the future, he thought: skyscrapers and humming factories and grand highways.

headline: At Halfway Point, Champion Retains Lead of Title Match
text: Game 6 of the world championship match was drawn Saturday — the second consecutive draw and the first time that the challenger had not lost while playing Black.

headline: Children’s Tylenol and Other Drugs Recalled
text: A unit of Johnson & Johnson has voluntarily begun a recall of certain children’s over-the-counter liquid medicines because of manufacturing deficiencies, the Food and Drug Administration said on Saturday.

headline: The Spill vs. a Need to Drill
text: More than 40 years ago, a thick and pungent oil slick washed over the sandy-white beaches of Santa Barbara and went on to soil 40 miles of Southern California’s scenic coastline.

headline: Facebook App Brings Back Data
text: People who are in despair about Facebook’s recent removal of personal information from their profiles can dry their tears.
