text: WHO is Todd Pletcher? WHO is Calvin Borel?

headline: News Quiz | May 3, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Greece Takes Bailout, but Doubts for Region Persist
text: Greece announced on Sunday that it had reached agreement on a long-delayed financial rescue package that would require years of painful belt-tightening, but the deal might not be enough to stop the spread of economic contagion to other European countries with mounting debts and troubled economies.

headline: At the Scene of the Attempted Bombing
text: Diagram showing the neighborhood where a car bomb was found Saturday night.

headline: In New York, Tech Incubator Turns Collaborative Hub
text: In 2008, before most people knew what a tweet was, Iain Dodsworth, a programmer in London, cobbled together a software tool that reorganized his jumbled Twitter stream into neat columns. He named it TweetDeck.

headline: Senate Financial Bill Misguided, Some Academics Say
text: As Democrats close in on their goal of overhauling the nation’s financial regulations, several prominent experts say that the legislation does not even address the right problems, leaving the financial system vulnerable to another major crisis, Binyamin Appelbaum and Sewell Chan report in The New York Times.

headline: Stolen Facebook Accounts for Sale
text: Researchers at VeriSign’s iDefense division tracking the digital underworld say bogus and stolen accounts on the Facebook are now on sale in high volume on the black market, Riva Richmond reports in The New York Times.

headline: Morgenson: Repaying Taxpayers With Their Own Cash
text: As we inch closer to a clearer understanding of the products and practices that unleashed the credit crisis of 2008, it’s becoming apparent that those seeking the whole truth are still outnumbered by those aiming to obscure it. This is the case not only on Wall Street but also in Washington, Gretchen Morgenson writes in her latest column in The New York Times.

headline: Who Knew Bankruptcy Paid So Well?
text: More than $263,000 for photocopies in four months. Over $2,100 in limousine rides by one partner in one month. And $48 just to leave a message. Explanations for these charges? Priceless.

headline: Glencore Said to Eye Xstrata Merger
text: Glencore International, the European commodities trader, is studying a merger with Xstrata to create a mining and trading group worth £55 billion ($84.5 billion), a source close to the deal told Reuters.

headline: Is ‘Doing Nothing’ a Good Use of Your Time?
text: This question is inspired by an Op-Ed piece from Sunday’s paper in which Mark Edmundson, now an English professor, writes about the five years after college graduation that he spent “wandering around doing nothing — or getting as close to it as I could manage.” In an era when many high school and college students feel they need to spend their time building an impressive résumé focused on a future college or career, what is your reaction to his idea that young adults should, instead, “hang out a little, learn to take it slow”?

headline: China Bank Said to File for Huge I.P.O. This Week
text: Agricultural Bank of China, one of the country’s big four lenders, plans to file applications this week for its dual listing in Shanghai and Hong Kong.

headline: AMP Seeks Clearance on AXA Asset Bid

headline: The ‘Platonic Tonic’ for Greece
text: Today’s idea: What would the ancient Greek philosophers counsel in today’s Greek crisis? Plato might say heed the philosopher kings. On the other hand, the Greeks may prefer the Cynics’ prescription to the Epicureans’.

headline: Big Paydays for Media Chiefs
text: The media industry may be going through some rough times, with the landscape changing day to day, but at least one aspect is business as usual: big paydays for the people at the top, The New York Times’s Joseph Plambeck wrote.

headline: Norsk Hydro to Buy Vale Assets for $4.9 Billion
text: Norsk Hydro shares fell slightly in midmorning trading Monday after the Norwegian aluminum maker announced a cash-and-share deal of nearly $5 billion on Sunday for Vale‘s aluminum mining business in Brazil, a purchase it said would assure access to the material for the next century.

text: The months-long upheaval at The Washington Times is continuing, as the owners of the conservative newspaper have put it up for sale, Joseph Plambeck reported in The New York Times.

headline: UBS 1st-Quarter Profit May Top Forecasts

Business Standard reported Mr. Nair, who is managing director and head of Citigroup’s private equity arm Citi Venture Capital International‘s investment activities in Central/Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Africa, will immediately add India to his purview.

headline: HSBC Calls Dubai World Plan ‘Fair’

headline: China Tightens Money Supply With Reserve Ratio
text: In a terse statement on its Web site, China’s central bank raised mandatory reserve ratios Sunday by 50 basis points, up from its the 16.5 percent large banks had to hold until now, forcing lenders to keep more assets on hand as of May 10.

text: MUMBAI, India — The only surviving gunman in the 2008 terrorist attack on this city was convicted Monday of murder, conspiracy and waging war against India during a three-day assault that killed more than 160 people.

Actors and dancers from the United States, Britain, Germany, Italy, Japan, Belgium and the Netherlands will perform at more than 15 venues on the city’s European and Asian sides.

headline: My Week in Cash Flow: Monday
text: Note to readers: My five posts this week chronicle the events of the week of Feb. 15. I’m publishing them with some misgivings, as one might get the impression that my business is days from failure at all times. Fortunately, this is not so. That week was especially dramatic because of the timing of the payments in and out. Also, it marked the beginning of an uptick in sales. From where I sit today, the recovery has begun. We now have a normal backlog of work and sufficient cash on hand to complete it.

headline: European Central Bank to Accept Greek Bonds

headline: Sampler: Republican Candidates Debate, and Silicon Valley Rents Creep Up
text: G.O.P. Candidates for Governor Debate | With a little more than five weeks before the June primary, two Republicans vying to lead California debated on Sunday night. Meg Whitman, the former chief executive of eBay who is considered the front-runner in the race, and Steve Poizner, the state insurance commissioner, each sought to portray themselves as the more conservative of the two. Both candidates called for the repeal of the new federal health care law and the suspension of the state’s landmark global warming law. Ms. Whitman is now almost even in polls with Jerry Brown, the Democrats’ major candidate, who also is the state’s former governor. Mr. Poizner, who wore a blazer with no tie, tried to paint Ms. Whitman, a billionaire who has poured her own money into the race, as out of touch with ordinary people. Mr. Poizner, a former Silicon Valley entrepreneur, has also spent much of his own money on his campaign. [The New York Times]

It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, though the future isn’t ignored. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

He’s already a film actor, sometime soap-opera star and fiction contributor to Esquire magazine, and when he was asked to create a short documentary film for his M.F.A. program, he instead turned in a 93-minute nonfiction feature that chronicles the making of a 2008 episode of “Saturday Night Live” hosted by John Malkovich.

text: This week, Lyudmila Bloch, an international etiquette expert, protocol consultant, and author of “The Golden Rules of Etiquette at the Plaza,” (2004), responded to readers’ questions.

headline: Now Showing | Karl Haendel at Lever House
text: Karl Haendel’s breezy, virtuosic powers with a pencil have produced 34 large-scale works on paper that confront the limitations of drawing as a medium. The installation — a commission for Lever House — pits paper and pencil against the soaring, glass curtain wall of Gordon Bunshaft’s modernist icon. But if it’s a David and Goliath matchup, then Haendel comes out on top. After all, a modernist glass tower has, relative to its size, a thin skin and these drawings seem to take direct aim at that vulnerability. Cracks — both literal and figurative — are the leitmotif: smashed glass, shattered light bulbs, arresting images of broken eggs, snaking power cables and a gigantic fingerprint fractured into dash marks. Haendel takes pleasure in toying with the conventions of display — the drawings are hung on two specially built and intentionally unfinished walls — and his use of tacks and staples is a delightful affront to the works’ inherent fragility. Frank, handwritten comments on the walls and on annotated lists of absurd phrases and book titles bring the age of anxiety into focus.

headline: Bond Vigilantes: Where Are They Now?
text: A little over a month ago the newspapers were full of scare stories about interest rates. Debt Fears Send Rates Up, blared a headline in the WSJ. Ten-year rates had risen from 3.67 percent to 3.9 percent, and this was a signal of huge fears about US solvency. Time to slash spending now!

text: United Airlines and Continental Airlines agreed to a $3 billion merger that would create the world’s biggest airline, according to people briefed on the negotiations. United is buying Continental, and the combined company will keep the United name and be based in Chicago. Read more.

headline: ‘Orphans’ Home Cycle’ and ‘Scottsboro Boys’ Win Lortel Awards
text: The Signature Theater Company and Hartford Stage’s epic co-production of Horton Foote‘s “Orphans’ Home Cycle” was named outstanding play and the Vineyard Theater’s presentation of the John Kander and Fred Ebb musical “The Scottsboro Boys” was named outstanding musical on Sunday at the ceremony for the Lucille Lortel Awards, which are presented annually by the Off-Broadway League. “When the Rain Stops Falling,” a Lincoln Center Theater production, was the night’s biggest winner, picking up five awards including ones for outstanding director (David Cromer) and featured actress (Mary Beth Hurt). Michael Urie of “The Temperamentals” was named outstanding actor and Judith Ivey was named outstanding actress for “The Glass Menagerie”; the Roundabout Theater Company and Long Wharf Theater‘s production of that Tennessee Williams play was also named outstanding revival. Susan Stroman claimed the Lortel for outstanding choreography for “The Scottsboro Boys,” and Colman Domingo’s “A Boy and His Soul,” also presented at the Vineyard, was named outstanding solo show.

headline: How to Get Your Tylenol Refund

The company also put up a Web site that included instructions for safe disposal of the medicine in the trash.

headline: May Comes in Like, and With, a Lamb
text: These unnamed babydoll sheep have spent the first 11 months of their lives at a farm upstate. But they are finally ready for the big time: the farm menagerie at the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn, where they will make their debut at this weekend’s Fleece Festival and be relieved of their winter coats. The zoo is also taking votes for names. The choices: Raggedy Ann and Andy, Peep and Beau, Lucy and Ricky, Amy and Charlie, Ginger and Fred. What, no Megan and Jeff?

headline: Anne on the Move | Wave Organ
text: Recently I discovered a place in San Francisco that is apparently a very well kept secret — no one that I mentioned it to there had ever heard of it. It’s called Wave Organ, and it is one of those phenomena that could only exist in northern California. Originally created in 1986 by the environmental artists Peter Richards and George Gonzales and newly restored, Wave Organ, which is part of the Exploratorium, is a 10-minute walk toward the Marina and out onto a jetty. Approaching the white and gray stone multi-layered structure I felt like I had been transported to a Greek island if not for the amazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge. I stepped out on to the granite and marble stones (which I later learned were donated to the project from an old Gold Rush era cemetery that was demolished to make way for a housing development), tilted my ear onto one of the numerous PVC pipes sticking out of the floor, and began to hear poetically eerie sounds. Each pipe makes a different sound depending on the tide. I then sat in a 3-sided room, listening to the music bounce off of the walls while seagulls dipped in an out of view. It was peaceful and calming and by the time I left, I felt as if I had been on holiday.

headline: An Addicted Child
text: Katie Allison Granju wrote a book, some say the book, about attachment parenting. She writes a popular blog, mamapundit.com, about the ups and downs of her blended family of four children, who range in age from 3 to 18, with a baby girl due this summer. As she puts it, “I’ve blogged through marriage, the end of a marriage, a horrifically painful divorce, re-entry into the full-time work force, single parenting, working motherhood, falling in love, remarriage, blended family life, pregnancy, miscarriage, childbirth, breast-feeding, baby- and toddlerhood.”

headline: ‘Little Miss Sunshine’ Musical Heads to La Jolla Playhouse
text: While Abigail Breslin‘s Broadway debut in “The Miracle Worker” did not meet with much success, a stage adaptation of the movie that helped put her on the map (and earned her an Academy Award nomination at age 10) is inching ever closer to the Great White Way. The musical version of “Little Miss Sunshine” will be presented next year at the La Jolla Playhouse in San Diego, Variety reported [subscription required]. The film, which also starred Greg Kinnear, Steve Carell, Toni Collette and Alan Arkin, centered on a precocious young performer (Ms. Breslin) and her eccentric family’s do-or-die efforts to get her into a beauty pageant. It was a breakout hit at the 2006 Sundance Film Festival and went on to earn more than $100 million at the box office worldwide. A version of the musical was presented last year at the Sundance Institute Theater Lab at White Oak in Yulee, Fla. The La Jolla production, which will run from Feb. 15 through March 27, 2011, features music and lyrics by William Finn and a book and direction by James Lapine, who previously collaborated on “Falsettos.” No casting has been announced, though an ArtsBeat colleague churlishly asked if Kristin Chenoweth was available.

headline: Linda Stein’s Killer Sentenced to 25 Years
text: Updated, 12:26 p.m. | Natavia S. Lowery was sentenced Monday to 25 years to life in prison for the 2007 bludgeoning death of her boss, Linda S. Stein, a high-profile real estate broker. Ms. Lowery was convicted of second-degree murder in February.

headline: Skyfire Browser Flashes the Android
text: Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, has posted an open letter explaining why Flash, which makes it possible to view videos and animations on your computers, won’t be on iPhones. Short answer: He prefers a standard called H.264, in which Apple holds a stake.

headline: Numberplay: The Puzzles of Pickover
text: Today we have a veritable puzzle-fest, as we explore the kaleidoscopic work of a fascinating modern polymath, Clifford Pickover. “Add two doses of Isaac Asimov, and one dose each of Martin Gardner and Carl Sagan, and you get Clifford Pickover, one of the most entertaining and thought provoking writers of our time,” writes Michael Shermer, editor of “Skeptic” magazine. A prolific author and futurist, Pickover has published more than 40 books, exploring topics ranging from computers and creativity to art, mathematics, parallel universes, Einstein, time travel, alien life, religion, dimethyltryptamine elves, and the nature of human genius. All of today’s puzzles were either designed by Pickover or are based on his work. For our puzzle prize we offer his latest, stunningly illustrated work, “The Math Book,” which has the intriguing subtitle “From Pythagoras to the 57th Dimension: 250 Milestones in the History of Mathematics.”

headline: Nutrition: Added Sugars Appear to Affect Cholesterol
text: People who eat and drink high amounts of added sugars have lower blood levels of so-called good cholesterol and higher levels of harmful triglycerides than those with diets lower in such sweeteners, a new study reports.

headline: Iran Angrily Defends Nuclear Program
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United States and Iran used the United Nations General Assembly’s famous green marble podium on Monday to trade punches over the Islamic republic’s nuclear program, adding sudden drama to the normally staid opening of the international conference to review the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.

text: BANGKOK — Thailand’s prime minister, Abhisit Vejjajiva, sought to break the country’s debilitating political deadlock on Monday by offering a “reconciliation plan” that included elections in November.

text: If the world was not confusing enough, the N.B.A. is striving to make it worse. Because you could have flipped on your television this weekend and asked, “Is this the first round of the playoffs, or the second?” and the answer would have been yes.

headline: Feeling For…Neon
text: With summer quickly approaching, and our moods brightening at the thought of fun in the sun, I gathered some pictures of clothing and accessories reminiscent of those hazy days of the ‘80s when neon was king. I may not be wearing oversized tees by Body Map or bright rubber bangles; but these current reminders of the time when Spicoli ruled are a different story. I’m feeling (once again) for neon!

headline: Substantial Smoothies
text: Smoothies are a wonderful way to enjoy fruits of all kinds — not just the bananas and berries we’re used to throwing in a blender but also more unusual choices, like nutrient-dense kiwis. I like a smoothie that has more to it than fresh fruit, though, so lately I’ve been experimenting with adding oatmeal, nuts or nut butters and seeds. I think you’ll like the results.

headline: Framework Set in Mideast for Indirect Peace Talks
text: JERUSALEM — The prime minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, met on Monday with Egypt’s president, Hosni Mubarak, in the Sinai resort of Sharm el Sheik, and the Obama administration’s envoy arrived in the region amid final preparations for the start of indirect Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

headline: From Queens Roots, Cuomo Clan Branched Out
text: The Cuomos may be New York political royalty, but Andrew M. Cuomo and his father have always made note of their humble Queens roots.

headline: Toggling Between Fighting and Outreach in Afghanistan
text: However the Afghan war is faring over all, across the wide and varied expanse of Afghanistan, with all of its political and cultural complexity, one thing is abundantly clear: toggling between fighting and outreach can create head-spinning scenes. Some of these scenes underline the difficulties inherent in a counterinsurgency doctrine that mixes lopsided violence with attempts to make nice. But they also simultaneously demonstrate that the efforts to follow the doctrine far from Kabul, out on remote ground, have become a central part of how the war is waged, even as the merits of the doctrine are quietly debated.

On “Modern Family,” the hit ABC comedy, Mr. Ferguson plays Mitchell Pritchett, an uptight lawyer raising an adopted daughter with his partner, Cameron Tucker (Eric Stonestreet).

headline: Angus Maddison, Forecasting the Past

headline: The Shape of the Immigration Debate
text: This post by Cato’s Daniel Griswold, comparing the difficulties involved in border control to the failures of Prohibition, offers a useful way to understand the contours of the immigration controversy. Most supporters of “comprehensive” reform, conservative and liberal and libertarian alike, basically agree with Griswold that trying to secure America’s borders when so many people want to cross them is the equivalent of the Volstead Act — a fool’s errand no matter what resources you throw at it. In this theory, laws are no match for markets: So long as there’s a supply of workers south of the border and enough demand for their services north of it, roughly the same number of immigrants are going to enter the United States every year no matter what kind of enforcement measures you implement.

headline: Orange Date Shake
text: Dates are the sweetener here, and they contribute a rich flavor as well as calcium, magnesium, fiber and potassium to the shake. Look for fresh medjool dates. If your dates are hard, to soften them place in a steamer above 1 inch of boiling water for about five minutes. Use fresh orange juice for the best results.

headline: Banana Peanut Butter or Banana Almond Smoothie
text: I’ve always loved the combination of bananas with peanut butter or almond butter. As a swimmer, I’ve found that the combination provides me with sustained nutrition before a long workout.

headline: Kiwi Strawberry Smoothie
text: For this tangy smoothie, make sure you use a kiwi that is really ripe — it should give when you press the sides. Kiwis are higher in vitamin C than oranges (they have almost twice as much), and they’re a good source of potassium and magnesium. The flax seeds contribute omega-3’s; you won’t be hungry anytime soon if you add them.

headline: Video Shows Capture of Somali Pirates
text: Updated | Tuesday | 8:04 a.m. The video embedded below, from the the Dutch Defense Ministry’s YouTube channel, only seems to have come from a future world where military engagements can be viewed on live television from a safe distance. In fact, the images were shot last month by a camera mounted on the helmet of a Dutch commando taking part in a raid to free a German container ship held by Somali pirates, as Jason Kottke explains on his blog.

headline: Manhole Fires in Midtown
text: An exploding manhole on West 40th Street in Midtown shot flames three stories high at 1:40 p.m. Monday, and at least one other manhole cover blew off, fire officials said. No injuries were immediately reported. After the explosion, a firefighter yelled: “It’s not Disneyland, people. Get the hell out of the way.” The manholes are on 40th between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, on the southern side of The New York Times building. Both issued thick gray smoke. Fire officials said the cause was not immediately clear.

His cynicism changes once he meets Mercy (played by Wendy Glenn), a book critic who helps open him up to the benefits (and the complexities) of a meaningful relationship.

headline: Teaching Physicians the Price of Care

text: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology IT Sloan Sports Analytics Conference is regarded as a gathering of like-minded sports dorks pushing basketball statistics away from traditional measures, such as points and assists, and toward more advanced measures, including hockey-style plus/minus. But at this year’s conference in March a debate continued over whether plus/minus is relevant when evaluating individual players in basketball. Some critics contend it might work better in measuring the effectiveness of five-man lineups.

headline: Bjork DJs in Brooklyn: Pleated Burgundy, Questlove and More
text: ‘Bjork plays a parking garage’ sounds like a dreamy Michel Gondry video pitch, but this weekend, it was a sweaty reality. Above the Auto Parts is an accurately named space: literally above an auto parts store in Bushwick, Brooklyn, it is a parking garage for much of the week that’s lately doubled as a DIY club. Bjork liked it enough to DJ a show there on Sunday night, a benefit for the Haiti relief group Partners in Health. (She checked out another venue, the Market Hotel, which has since been shut down, but preferred Above the Auto Parts because it was rougher, said the promoter, Todd Patrick.) The other DJs were also a who’s who of the New York music scene: Dave Longstreth of the art-rock favorites the Dirty Projectors, Tyondai Braxton of the math rock-y Battles, Alex Ross of The New Yorker and Brandon Stosuy, an editor at the music blog Stereogum, who helped organize the event, all took turns or buddied up at the decks to play a mix of obscure tunes and pop hits. The crowd was mostly Brooklyners who turned out to dance despite the fact that the unventilated space had them sweating even when standing still.

headline: Point Counterpoint: How to Use (and Avoid Misusing) PowerPoint
text: Overview | Is PowerPoint a valuable tool, or does it stifle critical thinking and innovative presentation of material? How can information be presented visually using PowerPoint without falling into the trap of simplistic bullet-point prose? In this lesson, students examine perspectives on effective and ineffective uses of PowerPoint, then develop a set of rules for effective use of this tool for their class projects and presentations. They then create PowerPoint slides and a prose narrative on the same subject and compare the impact of each on the intended audience.

headline: Awards Night | Not Afraid of Color
text: This week, the paint company Benjamin Moore will present its Hue Awards for the best use of color in architecture and interiors, and the lifetime achievement award will go to the New York design team of William Diamond and Anthony Baratta, whose sophisticated, bold, and vividly-colored interiors have been featured in The New York Times Magazine. Although the choice of Diamond Baratta would seem a no-brainer, this is the first time that the award has gone to interior designers; past winners were the architects Steven Holl, Ettore Sottsass, and Ricardo Legorreta. Diamond Baratta is known for custom-designing everything from fabrics to braided rugs, and paint colors are no exception. But in an odd coincidence, the designers have always used Benjamin Moore paint bases. And when they told told the company that they were donating their $5000 prize money to the Center for Special Studies at New York-Presbyterian Hospital, which provides specialized care to people with HIV and AIDS, Benjamin Moore matched Diamond Baratta’s donation. Baratta credits Diamond with being the firm’s color maven. “Bill is really the maestro of color selection,” he said. “It’s like music–you have to have perfect pitch.” Above, a few of the firm’s colorful interiors.

headline: Germany Clears Rescue for Greece
text: Some of the uncertainty lingering around the financial rescue for Greece cleared Monday, as the German government approved its share of a huge bailout, and the European Central Bank said it would accept Greek bonds as collateral for loans, regardless of any future downgrades, The New York Times’s Judy Dempsey and Jack Ewing report from Germany.

headline: Mumbai Gunman’s Recanted Confession
text: As my colleague Vikas Bijaj reports, a court in Mumbai, India has convicted the lone surviving gunman who took part in the Nov. 26, 2008 attacks in that city of murder, conspiracy and waging war against India. The gunman, Ajmal Kasab, who was filmed taking part in the attacks, quickly confessed to the authorities from a hospital bed that he had been trained and sent by the Pakistani militant group, Lashkar-e-Taiba. Although he later recanted that confession, it was captured on video and broadcast on Indian television.

headline: Guilt on a Paper Plate

headline: My Left Foot: The High Costs of Fallen Arches

headline: Video of Ahmadinejad and Clinton at the U.N.

The Associated Press posted this video on YouTube showing the U.S. delegation leaving the General Assembly in New York as Mr. Ahmadinejad attacked American policy and complained about Israel’s nuclear arsenal.

headline: A Plus Side for Human Growth Hormone
text: Human growth hormone has acquired a bad reputation, thanks to athletes who have abused it in their quest for stardom. But for tens of thousands of children whose growth and development are stymied by a deficiency of growth hormone, daily injections of this biologically synthesized growth stimulant can put them on track toward normality.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Times Square and Elsewhere
text: The impact of a car bomb discovered Saturday night in Times Square could be felt underground on Monday. As Ray Rivera wrote in The Times, “For New Yorkers, it was an unsubtle and unsettling reminder that threats could be lurking in the trunks or back seats of any of the thousands of vehicles that push their way into the city every day” — on streets only a few feet over the subway lines.

headline: General Growth Considers New Simon Offer
text: 4:33 p.m. | Updated General Growth Properties said on Monday that it intended to stick with an investment plan led by Brookfield Asset Management as the cornerstone in its effort to emerge from bankruptcy.

headline: Starting Early, Swearing Often: A Smart Aleck’s Story

headline: Of Compost, Molecules and Insects, Art Is Born
text: The word organic means different things to different people. To the gardener it means compost heaps. To the chemist it means carbon compounds. To the artist Fabian Peña, it means American cockroaches, those chunky nocturnal charmers often seen skittering around drainpipes or on the street. “I have collected cockroaches from many different places,” Mr. Peña said. “From Cuba, Mexico, Miami, Houston, everywhere I travel.”

headline: The Concierge | Breakup Brunch
text: Christine Muhlke, T Magazine’s food editor and de facto concierge, is at your service. Have a dining or imbibing quandary for her? Leave your question in the comments section below.

headline: Surgery for Flat Feet
text: Today’s Cases column in Science Times shares the harrowing tale of actor Gbenga Akinnagbe, who underwent surgery for flat feet.

headline: Art That Was Once Alive
text: Images of art installations from the “Dead or Alive” exhibit at the Museum of Arts and Design.

headline: When the Ties That Bind Unravel
text: Therapists for years have listened to patients blame parents for their problems. Now there is growing interest in the other side of the story: What about the suffering of parents who are estranged from their adult children?

headline: Styles of Southern Black Music, Shouting Included
text: There was one moment during the Carolina Chocolate Drops’ end-to-end display of excellence at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem on Saturday that got a little spooky. Rhiannon Giddens, the band’s singer and banjo player, quickly described the connection between banjos and West African stringed instruments, then produced an akonting, a three-stringed ancestor of the banjo from Gambia. She played it for about two minutes, down-stroking it, claw-hammer style, as she had the American instrument, and sang in that region’s Jola language.

headline: Broadway Box Office Declines; Link to Bomb Scare Unclear
text: Almost all Broadway plays and musicals lost money at the box office last week, with some of the biggest declines occurring at theaters near the car that was found to contain a defective bomb on Saturday evening. The ensuing evacuation of Times Square could have been a factor in some of the box office declines, theater industry executives acknowledged, but they said they had no data to confirm such a correlation.

headline: Geography of a Recession
text: Updated: A map of unemployment rates across the United States, now through June

headline: State Senator Parker Apologizes for Outburst
text: ALBANY — State Senator Kevin S. Parker apologized Monday for an outburst last week in which he called Republicans white supremacists, saying that he realized his comments had become a major distraction for the Senate.

headline: Fete Accompli |  The Art of Elysium
text: What: The Art of Elysium Second Annual New York fundraiser with Donatella Versace and Christopher Kane for Versus.

headline: Scenes From Jazzfest
text: The 41st annual New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival ran from April 23 to May 2.

headline: The Return of ‘The Boondocks’
text: Sunday night may have included the 150th episode of “Family Guy” and a queasily timely — for New York, anyway — “Simpsons” story line about domestic terrorism and urban surveillance. But the real news in television animation was the long-awaited return of “The Boondocks.”

headline: Stravinsky, That Teller of Russian Fables
text: Avery Fisher Hall was more fully packed for the Sunday afternoon installment of the New York Philharmonic’s Russian Stravinsky festival than it had been for several of the orchestra’s recent subscription concerts. Part of the draw, no doubt, was Valery Gergiev, whose high-energy Stravinsky recordings held out the promise that this festival would be among the highlights of the season. Certainly the works at hand — two of Stravinsky’s enduring, acid-tinged fables, “Renard” (1916) and “L’Histoire du Soldat” (1918) — have ample partisans. And it probably did not hurt that the orchestra invited its new best friend from the world of popular culture, the actor Alec Baldwin, to narrate “Histoire.”

headline: Much Movie Title Meshugas
text: LOS ANGELES  It might take the reasoning powers, not to mention the vocabulary, of a Talmudic scholar to figure out what Paramount Pictures and DreamWorks are trying to say with the title of their new Steve Carell comedy.

headline: Like Sculptures Constantly in Flux
text: BEACON, N.Y. — To watch Trisha Brown’s best dances, particularly the early ones, is to be aware of how little a choreographer has to do to hold the stage: a single idea, developed with rigor and presented with clarity, is often all it takes.

headline: Boeing’s Social-Media Lesson
text: Harry Winsor, an 8-year-old from Boulder, Colo., loves airplanes. He flies with his father, John Winsor, the chief executive of the ad agency Victors & Spoils, to places like Europe and Africa regularly. Recently, he began designing his own airplanes, and decided to send one such drawing to Boeing with the suggestion that they manufacture his plane.

headline: At a Year Old, a Few Small Lessons Are Left
text: This is the final installment of the Puppy Diaries, which tracked the course of a dog’s life over her first year.

headline: Yanks’ Vazquez to Skip Start Against Red Sox
text: After pitching poorly in four of his five starts for the Yankees this season, Javier Vazquez will have his next outing pushed back. Instead of pitching Friday night in Boston, Vazquez is scheduled to start Monday night in Detroit.

headline: Growing Budget Deficit Haunts Hungary
text: Hungary’s budget deficit could grow by about a third this year despite the new government’s determination to “stick to a tight fiscal policy,” the country’s economy minister said Monday after being named to the post.

headline: When It Comes to Sex, Chimps Need Help, Too
text: The human ego has never been quite the same since the day in 1960 that Jane Goodall observed a chimpanzee feasting on termites near Lake Tanganyika. After carefully trimming a blade of grass, the chimpanzee poked it into a passage in the termite mound to extract his meal. No longer could humans claim to be the only tool-making species.

headline: Emotion, Spectacle and Songs Writ Large
text: Peter Gabriel has never shied away from grandeur or paused at the threshold of spectacle. But restraint is part of the package too: few figures in pop are as adept with dynamics, at building pressure in a song. On Sunday night, in his first of two sold-out concerts at Radio City Music Hall, Mr. Gabriel made some interior sentiments feel momentous, practically seismic, and kept others small but mesmerizing, like lightning bugs in a jar.

headline: Wielding Swords in a World of Sharp Tongues
text: As I explored the captivating world of Nier, unearthing its mysteries and reveling in its characters, I could not stop thinking about Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and his brethren on the Supreme Court of the United States.

headline: Apple Sells One Million iPads
text: Apple on Monday announced that it had sold one million iPads as of Friday last week, a faster sales pace than the iPhone.

headline: British Candidates Fight for Their Lives, the Future, Etc.
text: LONDON — With just three days to go before Britain’s still-up-for-grabs national election, the leaders of the three main political parties continued to trawl for votes, speaking in increasingly extravagant terms about stark choices and potentially disastrous futures.

headline: We Three Things | Bird Braids
text: I hear more birds than I see. Neither my patience nor my neighborhood seem conducive to watching birds and their enigmatic nesting rituals. With spring’s arrival, I hear them calling and chirping outside my window, but I rarely turn around to look. Instead my eye is drawn to designers and artists producing their own versions of ornithology.

headline: When East and West Collided, but Commingled to Make Music
text: The once constricted world of Western early music has opened to new — O.K., old — and exotic vistas in recent years as it explores the fertile ground it shares with Eastern, especially Middle Eastern, performance styles. And no one has played a more pivotal role in this exploration than Jordi Savall, the Catalan string virtuoso who now seems fully at home in the motley musical precincts of Jerusalem.

headline: That Continuing Radical, Balanchine
text: The ads for New York City Ballet’s season announce “Architecture of Dance — New Choreography and Music Festival — 7 New Ballets, 4 Commissioned Scores, 1 Renowned Architect.” You might assume — wrongly — that the season contained nothing but new works.

headline: It Started More Than One Revolution
text: The birth control pill has been called the most important scientific advance of the 20th century, and no wonder. Fifty years after its approval by the Food and Drug Administration, it is still one of the leading methods of contraception, in the United States and around the world.

headline: It’s Reopening Night at the Jane Ballroom
text: After months of back-and-forth with city officials, the Jane Ballroom is finally reopening tonight, according to one of the owners who declined to be named but emphasized the new quiet (shhh!) and private nature of the place.

headline: Tune In for the Tony Nominations
text: Will any Broadway show approach the record-tying 15 Tony Award nominations of last year’s “Billy Elliot: The Musical”? Will the cavalcade of Hollywood stars on the boards dominate the Tony acting nominations announced Tuesday morning, or will lesser-known theater veterans receive their fair share for critically acclaimed work? Will plays and musicals that opened and closed earlier in the 2009-10 theater season — like “Finian’s Rainbow,” “Ragtime,” “The Royal Family,” “Superior Donuts,” and “Time Stands Still” — receive much recognition compared to shows that are still running? Which shows were blanked among the nominees? Who wuz robbed? We’re live-blogging the Tony nominations starting at 8:30 a.m. here.

headline: Russian Orphanage Offers Love, but Not Families
text: MOSCOW — There is nothing dreary about Orphanage No. 11. It has rooms filled with enough dolls and trains and stuffed animals to make any child giggly. It has speech therapists and round-the-clock nurses and cooks who delight in covertly slipping a treat into a tiny hand. It has the feel of a place where love abounds.

headline: Second Stage’s Season
text: Off Broadway’s Second Stage Theater announced on Monday that its 2010-11 season would include productions of new plays by Lynn Nottage (below; the winner of the 2009 Pulitzer Prize in drama for “Ruined”) and Rajiv Joseph (“Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo”) as well as a revival of Arthur Kopit’s 1978 drama, “Wings.” Ms. Nottage’s play, a world premiere called “By the Way, Meet Vera Stark,” is scheduled to begin performances in April 2011. Second Stage described the work as “a 70-year journey into the life of Vera Stark, a headstrong African-American maid and budding actress, and her tangled relationship with her boss, a white Hollywood star desperately grasping to hold on to her career.” The director is to be announced. The Second Stage season will begin in the fall with the Kopit drama, about a female aviator’s recovery from a stroke; the work was nominated for the Tony Award for best play in 1979. It will be directed by John Doyle, who won the 2006 Tony for best direction of a musical for “Sweeney Todd,” and is scheduled to begin previews in early October, with an opening night to be announced. After “Wings” will be the New York premiere of Mr. Joseph’s new play, “Gruesome Playground Injuries,” described as a dark romantic saga about two childhood friends whose lives intersect over 30 years in damaging ways. The director will be Scott Ellis, with previews scheduled to begin in early January 2011. A fourth production for the 2010-11 season will be announced later.

headline: Car Bomb a Possible Factor in Broadway Declines
text: Almost all Broadway plays and musicals lost money at the box office last week, with some of the biggest declines occurring at theaters near a car that was found to contain a bomb on Saturday evening. The ensuing evacuation of Times Square could have been a factor in some of the declines, theater industry executives acknowledged, but they said they had no data to confirm such a correlation. The car with the bomb was found on West 45th Street, just west of Seventh Avenue and right outside the Minskoff Theater, where “The Lion King” is playing. Last week “The Lion King” had one of the biggest declines, of $113,440, although the hit show still grossed $1.3 million, third behind “Wicked” and “The Addams Family.” The largest week-to-week decline was for “Mary Poppins” at the New Amsterdam Theater on West 42nd Street, close to Seventh Avenue and some of the most heavily trafficked subway stops in Times Square; some theatergoers said they did not reach their shows on Saturday night because of subway delays and were exchanging their tickets. “Mary Poppins” was down $180,251 from the previous week, to a total of $704,541. No Broadway shows canceled performances because of the bomb scare and evacuation. Over all, Broadway box offices grossed $20.7 million, down from $22.1 million the previous week  but up from the $19.9 million for the same week last season.

headline: ‘Little Miss Sunshine’ Heads to La Jolla
text: While Abigail Breslin’s Broadway debut in “The Miracle Worker” did not meet with much success, a stage adaptation of the movie that helped put her on the map (and earned her an Academy Award nomination at age 10) is inching ever closer to Broadway. The musical version of “Little Miss Sunshine” will be presented next year at the La Jolla Playhouse in San Diego, Variety reported. The film, which also starred Greg Kinnear, Steve Carell, Toni Collette and Alan Arkin, centered on a precocious young performer (Ms. Breslin) and her eccentric family’s do-or-die efforts to get her into a beauty pageant. It was a breakout hit at the 2006 Sundance Film Festival and went on to earn more than $100 million at the box office worldwide. A version of the musical was presented last year at the Sundance Institute Theater Lab at White Oak in Yulee, Fla. The La Jolla production, which will run from Feb. 15 through March 27, 2011, features music and lyrics by William Finn and a book and direction by James Lapine. No casting has been announced.

headline: Columbia Receives Gorey Drawings
text: A large group of drawings, etchings, posters and more by the macabre master illustrator and writer Edward Gorey has been given to Columbia University Libraries. Andrew Alpern, an architectural historian and lawyer who published a collection of ephemera by Gorey in 1980, donated the more than 700 items, which include nearly every edition of every work that Gorey published. Gorey (above in a self-portrait), who died in 2000, ranged over a wide field, drawing the animated opening sequence for PBS’s television series “Mystery!,” designing costumes and sets on Broadway, writing more than 100 books and illustrating more than 60 others by authors that included Samuel Beckett and Edward Lear. He won a Tony Award for best costume and set design for the 1977 production of “Dracula.” When asked why he spent his time on murder and other violence, he answered: “Well, I don’t know. I guess I’m interested in real life.”

headline: $22.5. Million Gift For Kennedy Center
text: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington has received a $22.5 million gift from Betsy and Dick DeVos for its Institute of Arts Management, which will now be called the DeVos Institute of Arts Management at the Kennedy Center, the center announced. It also announced that David M. Rubenstein had been appointed the Kennedy Center’s chairman, succeeding Stephen A. Schwarzman. The arts management institute was created in 2001 by Michael M. Kaiser, president of the Kennedy Center. In addition to offering 10 full-time fellowships for arts managers annually, it brings 42 arts managers from around the world to Washington for a summer fellowship program. The Kennedy Center said Mr. Kaiser would remain as president through 2014 and then lead the DeVos Institute for another three years. The DeVoses’ gift will create an endowment that will support the institute indefinitely, the center said. Ms. DeVos, who is a Kennedy Center trustee, said in a telephone interview that while donating money to train administrators might seem less sexy than directly financing artistic creation, having good managers “leverages the creative talents of thousands of artists.”

headline: On ‘60 Minutes,’ Conan Is No. 1
text: There were no ratings problems for Conan O’Brien on Sunday night as an episode of “60 Minutes” featuring his first television interview since departing “The Tonight Show” was the night’s most-watched program, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The broadcast, in which Mr. O’Brien said he “got very depressed at times” after NBC reinstated Jay Leno at 11:35 p.m. and he left the network, drew 13.3 million viewers. CBS was No. 1 for the night over all with a lineup that included “The Amazing Race” (10.5 million) and back-to-back episodes of “Cold Case” at 9 (9.6 million) and 10 (10.1 million). ABC was runner-up on the night with “Desperate Housewives” (12 million), and NBC was third with “Dateline” (5.2 million), “Minute to Win It” (5.6 million) and “The Celebrity Apprentice” (7 million). Fox placed fourth with its comedy lineup, including an hourlong “Family Guy” (7.3 million) to mark the show’s 150th episode.

headline: Poll Shows Most in U.S. Want Overhaul of Immigration Laws
text: LOS ANGELES — The overwhelming majority of Americans think the country’s immigration policies need to be seriously overhauled. And despite protests against Arizona’s stringent new immigration enforcement law, a majority of Americans support it, even though they say it may lead to racial profiling.

headline: The Buzz Is All About BP at Oil Drillers’ Conference
text: 7:35 p.m. | Updated  Added information on BP’s presence at the conference.

headline: Readers Don’t Like Being Shortchanged
text: The copper-plated cousin of the more expensive dime and nickel is sometimes seen as a castaway in the change circle. How often have you shed yours in the “Take a penny, leave a penny” tray at the 7-11 counter?

headline: Mets Play It Safe and Send Pelfrey for M.R.I.
text: CINCINNATI — Mets pitcher Mike Pelfrey had a magnetic resonance imaging test on his right shoulder Monday, but it revealed no structural damage and Pelfrey is expected to make his next start Friday against the Giants.

headline: Slide Show: Four Decades of New Orleans Tradition and a Whole Lot of Jazz
text: The 41st annual New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival began on April 23 and ended Sunday with performances by Maze, with Frankie Beverly, above, and others.

headline: In Darwin Family, Evidence of Inbreeding’s Ill Effects
text: Charles Darwin, the author of the theory of evolution, may have been right to worry that his children’s health had been affected by the inbreeding in his own family, especially that of his wife, Emma Wedgwood, who was his first cousin.

headline: By the Architects, for the People: A Trend for the 2010s
text: NEWARK — Last week, when the city planning board here voted to approve construction of a four-block-long mixed-use development, the decision was barely noticed outside a small circle of civic boosters. But it was a turning point in the career of the project’s architect, Richard Meier.

headline: A New Poll Finds Support for Arizona’s Immigration Law
text: In the wake of Arizona’s new immigration law, a poll released today by The Times and CBS News finds that a slim majority of Americans support the legislation. An overwhelming majority of respondents also believe the nation’s immigration laws should undergo an extensive overhaul.

headline: A Rapid Security Check Could Be Revived at Airports
text: The idea of a monthly subscription service that allows people to jump to the head of airport security lines by submitting to a fingerprint or iris scan may be getting another chance.

headline: Watercress, as Fresh as a Gurgling Spring
text: WATERCRESS does not incite the kind of frenzy generated by ramps, those spindly wild onions that nobody bothered to pick until a few chefs began trumpeting their arrival as a major springtime event. But it is starting to show up in farmers’ markets, too, and those who know it, love it.

headline: Watercress Barlotto
text: Salt

headline: Watercress, Pear and Gorgonzola Salad
text: 1/3 cup coarsely chopped cippolini or other sweet onion

headline: Zucchini, Watercress and Squid Stir-Fry
text: 1/2 pound cleaned squid, in thin rings, with tentacles

headline: The Magic of Adobe’s Photoshop CS5
text: Update: May 6, 2010, 12:31 p.m.: The upgrade price of Photoshop CS5 was corrected.

headline: Mammoth Hemoglobin Offers More Clues to Its Arctic Evolution
text: For the first time in 43,000 years, a woolly mammoth has breathed again on earth.

headline: Times Square, Bombs and Big Crowds
text: Updated, 8:55 a.m. |  Jeffrey Rosen, a law professor and author of “The Naked Crowd,” joins the discussion.

headline: Grant Achatz To Open a Restaurant and a Bar
text: How many forthcoming restaurants are announced, Hollywood-style, with a trailer? Alinea, opened in Chicago by Grant Achatz and Nick Kokonas five years ago this week, featured a short “coming soon” film on its website many months before its kitchen was built. Today, Mr. Achatz and Mr. Kokonas did it again, releasing a trailer for Next Restaurant and a cocktail lounge called Aviary, both projected to open in Chicago this fall. (The exact addresses have not been announced.)

headline: Particle Detector Shows Promise, if Nothing Else
text: A new widely anticipated experiment underneath a mountain in Italy designed to detect a sea of dark particles that allegedly constitute a quarter of creation did not see anything during a test run last fall, scientists reported Saturday.

headline: Tax Break for Erotica? A Museum Favors It
text: A few years ago, when Ann Marie Coughlin, a New York dominatrix also known as Domina M., donated her brushed-steel bondage machine to be shown at the Museum of Sex, many people benefited.

headline: Hertz May Have Rival in Bid for Dollar Thrifty
text: The Avis Budget Group signaled on Monday a potential bidding war for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, saying it was considering a bid that would top the $1.2 billion offer by Hertz Global Holdings.

headline: A Faded Relic of Christendom Reappears
text: TURIN, Italy — The Roman Catholic Church is weathering another sex scandal, but it is impossible to tell here, where the faint image of a bearded man on a yellowing linen sheet provides the moment, if brief, for pilgrims to declare and reaffirm their faith. For some, it does not matter if the Shroud of Turin is authentic. It is the shared spiritual experience that counts most.

headline: Push to Insulate Deaf Students From Dissimilar School
text: The students at Public School 347 in Manhattan sit at round tables when they eat lunch — the better to see one another’s hands when they chat using sign language.

headline: Carrots Share Trait With Tiny Pea Aphid
text: There’s a reason your parents kept after you to eat your carrots. The vegetables (and lots of others, too) supply carotenoids, compounds that are good for vision and overall health. Animals, humans included, cannot manufacture them.

headline: What We’re Reading: Music, Pirated and Otherwise
text: What the tech editors and reporters of The New York Times took notice of Monday:

headline: Cavaliers Ask: What’s a Foul?
text: Some thought the fourth-quarter play Saturday on which Cleveland’s Shaquille O’Neal sent Boston’s Rajon Rondo sprawling to the court’s floor in Game 1 of their Eastern Conference semifinal series constituted a flagrant foul. So it was odd when Cavaliers Coach Mike Brown acknowledged that he sent tape of the foul to N.B.A. headquarters for clarification.

headline: Where Weedkiller Won’t Work
text: Farmers’ wide use of Roundup, also known as glyphosate, a popular herbicide, has led to the spread of Roundup-resistant weeds across the country. At least 10 species of Roundup-resistant weeds have infested millions of acres in more than 22 states since 2000.

headline: Toxin Tied to Illness Is Found in Baltic Sea
text: In the 1950s, the Chamorro people of Guam had a very high incidence of a neurodegenerative illness similar to amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or A.L.S. A neurotoxin called BMAA, which is produced by cyanobacteria found in the seeds of an edible plant and accumulates in the food chain, has long been suspected as the cause.

headline: And You Thought Iceland Was a Problem
text: One thing is clear from Tuesday’s “Nova” on PBS: Mount St. Helens is messing with us.

headline: Famine Persists in Niger, but Denial Is Past
text: NIAMEY, Niger — Outside the state food warehouses here, women sift in the dirt for spilled grains of rice. Seven hundred miles to the east, mothers pluck bitter green berries and boil them for hours in an attempt to feed their children. In urban slums and desert villages, one word is on all lips: famine.

headline: A Quandary in Restoring Bald Eagle Populations
text: For three decades, scientists have been trying with only limited success to re-establish breeding populations of bald eagles on the Channel Islands off the Southern California coast. The eagles disappeared from the islands in the 1960s, victims, like many other birds, of DDT, which affected their ability to reproduce.

headline: Why So Blue?
text: Q. Why do “Martha Stewart” chickens produce blue and green eggs?

headline: Advocacy Group Defends Ad in Arkansas
text: An advocacy group is defending one of its advertisements following criticism about how the spot claims a Senate candidate in Arkansas helped outsource jobs to India.

headline: Lynn Redgrave, in Black and White
text: Al Hirschfeld, the artist, did a series of illustrations of Ms. Redgrave in her theater productions.

headline: Lynn Redgrave, Actress and Playwright, Dies at 67
text: Lynn Redgrave, who as an actress upheld the tradition of her theatrically royal family on stage and on screen and as a playwright wrote about her family with probing affection and equally probing anguish, died on Sunday at her home in Kent, Conn. She was 67.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 28 through May 2 with 1,079 adults throughout the United States.

headline: Militia Members Released Until Trial in Michigan Plot
text: DETROIT — A federal judge on Monday ordered that nine members of an extremist militia accused of plotting to kill police officers be freed on bond until their trial, saying that prosecutors did not demonstrate that the defendants would pose a danger if released.

headline: Auto Businessmen Briefly at Bomb Inquiry’s Focus
text: In every terror inquiry, there are the investigators, the persons of interest and the targets of suspicion. Then there are the Wayne LeBlancs, who get rousted out of their beds by federal agents because of some connective tissue — tenuous or not — linking them to the culprits.

headline: Helpful Tips From Locals for New No. 2
text: Stephen Goldsmith, a former mayor of Indianapolis, has been named New York’s new deputy mayor for operations, which makes him the fellow who, figuratively speaking, is supposed to make the trains run on time. Mr. Goldsmith is said to be good at that.

headline: Saints Accused of Mishandling Prescription Drug
text: The Drug Enforcement Administration is investigating allegations made in a lawsuit by a former employee of the New Orleans Saints that the club tried to cover up the theft of Vicodin pills from its training facility by a senior member of the team’s staff.

headline: U.S. to Send Trainers to Afghanistan as Stopgap
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has signed an order sending 850 more American military personnel to Afghanistan as a stopgap measure to fill vacancies in the high-priority effort to train local security forces, Pentagon officials said Monday.

headline: No Place Like This for Soothing Care
text: NORWICH, Vt. — The renovated barn next to the family house was always one of Kevin Pearce’s favorite places. There is a skateboard ramp out back and a giant recreation room inside, with three loftlike bedrooms above.

headline: Iraqi Sunnis Frustrated as Awakening Loses Clout
text: FALLUJA, Iraq — Sheik Aiffan Saadoun al-Aiffan stepped across a scorched patch of farmland, raised his shotgun and fired once. A bird fell to the ground.

headline: New Paterson Policy May Reduce Deportations
text: ALBANY — Gov. David A. Paterson announced on Monday that the state would accelerate consideration and granting of pardons to legal immigrants for old or minor criminal convictions, in an effort to prevent them from being deported.

headline: Selig Can Send Message on Arizona Immigration Law
text: In 18 years as the head of Major League Baseball, Bud Selig has been fed a steady stream of fastballs. There have been labor fastballs and steroid fastballs, pitches he has learned how to hit. Lately, he has been taking his hacks at human growth hormone fastballs.

headline: Fast Start Surprises Even the Red Bulls
text: The play and decision-making of Red Bulls midfielder Dane Richards often can run hot and cold — but he always runs fast.

headline: When Is a Cross a Cross?
text: Also, when is a menorah a menorah, and when is a crèche a crèche, and when are the Ten Commandments directives given to the Jews by God on Mt. Sinai? These questions, which might seem peculiar in the real world, are perfectly ordinary in the wild and wacky world of Establishment Clause jurisprudence, where in one case (Lynch v. Donnelly, 1984) the Supreme Court declared, with a straight judicial face, that a display featuring the baby Jesus, Mary, Joseph and the wise men conveyed a secular, not a religious message.

headline: City Cuts Ties to Catholic Agency That Provides Foster Care
text: New York City’s child welfare agency said Monday that it would sever its foster care contracts with Little Flower Children and Family Services of New York, an 80-year-old Roman Catholic agency that has been troubled in recent years.

headline: Marea, Boulud, Colicchio and McNally Win Beard Awards
text: Monday night’s 21st running of the Beard awards, the annual anointing of chefs and restaurateurs by the James Beard Foundation, followed the pattern of most years: restaurants and chefs in New York under the umbrellas of Daniel Boulud, Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Danny Meyer, again took home awards.

headline: Army Examines Units Treating Injured Soldiers
text: A high-ranking general said Monday that the Army wanted to learn more about shortcomings at its Warrior Transition Units, which treat soldiers with physical injuries and severe psychological trauma and have come under criticism from service members and their families.

headline: Extra Security and Raised Alerts: ‘You Get Used to It, but You’re Not Used to It’
text: The acrid smell meant something was wrong, maybe dangerously wrong, and John Schneider, sitting at his superintendent’s desk on Monday in an office building on West 40th Street, just off Times Square, immediately looked outside. Flames from an open manhole shot three stories into the air.

headline: Google’s Venture Fund Steps Up the Pace
text: Google has been throwing money around the last few days. It bought a start-up called BumpTop, invested in wind farms and, on Monday, announced its 10th venture investment and some details about its year-old venture capital fund.

headline: Gulf Oil Spill Is Bad, but How Bad?
text: WASHINGTON — The oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico is bad — no one would dispute it. But just how bad?

headline: Unexploded Car Bomb Left Trove of Evidence
text: Among the enduring images left by car bombings, overseas or in the United States, is investigators on their hands and knees, crawling through the wreckage searching for clues: a blasting cap or a timing device, a piece of the explosive’s casing or a trace of the chemicals used.

headline: Canadiens’ Goalie May Not Be Familiar, but Theme Is
text: MONTREAL — When it comes to the Canadiens, there is always a proud tradition of one kind or another, like that of a young, relatively green goalie rising from obscurity to lead them on a surprising run through the playoffs.

headline: Weather Hampers Efforts to Burn Some of Oil Spill
text: ROBERT, La. — While a controlled burn of petroleum in the Gulf of Mexico was judged successful last week, strong winds and rain have hampered efforts to conduct additional ones to contain the spill.

headline: Ochoa Loses No. 1 Ranking Day After She Retires
text: Lorena Ochoa’s goal was to retire at the top, and she did, but barely. Ochoa’s reign as the No. 1 player in the world was like a long putt that ekes into the hole; it expired at the very end of her full-time career.

headline: Justices Agree on Detainee Death Case
text: WASHINGTON — A man who received what the government concedes was negligent medical treatment while held by immigration authorities may not sue the personnel who failed to treat him, the Supreme Court ruled Monday in a unanimous decision.

headline: The Way Out
text: President Obama made a convincing case last December for sending an additional 30,000 American troops to Afghanistan. Most of those new forces, plus 58,000 already in country, would fight the Taliban. A smaller number would mold Afghan recruits into an indigenous Army and National Police force that could in time assume responsibility for protecting their country so the Americans and NATO allies could go home.

headline: Step Away From the Courthouse Doors
text: WASHINGTON — In a decision ripe with symbolism about access to justice in the age of terror, the Supreme Court announced on Monday that visitors to its courthouse will no longer be allowed to enter through the front door.

headline: What’s in a Name?
text: We are skeptical that merging with Continental Airlines can solve the perennial woes of United Airlines, which has reported billions of dollars in losses and spent three of the last 10 years in bankruptcy proceedings. Continental also reported losses during most of the last decade. Leaving aside any business rationale, what worries us about the proposed merger is what it could mean for harried travelers.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Doors
text: In a sad bow to security concerns, visitors to the Supreme Court will no longer enter the Cass Gilbert building by climbing its marble steps and passing through its bronze doors and underneath the words that define the court’s mission: Equal Justice Under Law. The court announced on Monday that the public will now have to enter through a new reinforced area at the plaza level.

headline: Luck and Vigilance
text: New York City was lucky this time. The bomb-laden vehicle that pulled into Times Square Saturday night smoldered but didn’t ignite. Two nearby vendors warned a policeman. Officers quickly cleared the area and alerted bomb-squad specialists and investigators.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'High and Low'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Akira Kurosawa's film about a kidnapping in postwar Japan.

headline: Bloggingheads:  Is Obama a Socialist?
text: David Frum, left, of FrumForum and Jonah Goldberg of National Review debate whether the president is a socialist.

headline: Farmers Cope With Roundup-Resistant Weeds
text: DYERSBURG, Tenn. — For 15 years, Eddie Anderson, a farmer, has been a strict adherent of no-till agriculture, an environmentally friendly technique that all but eliminates plowing to curb erosion and the harmful runoff of fertilizers and pesticides.

headline: France: Synagogue Defaced and Jewish Man Is Attacked
text: Three attackers defaced a synagogue in Nîmes on Sunday, then threw tear gas at a 78-year-old Jewish man, the local police said Monday. Word of the attack came as 300 people gathered Monday in front of the Strasbourg synagogue in eastern France to express solidarity with the victim of another anti-Semitic assault, on Friday in downtown Strasbourg. There, a Jewish man was repeatedly stabbed. Two suspects were charged Sunday, the police said.

headline: France: Sentence Is Suspended for Former Interior Minister
text: A one-year prison sentence for corruption has been suspended against a former French senator and onetime close ally of former President Jacques Chirac, according to a court document released Monday. The Justice Court of the Republic last week found Charles Pasqua, 83, guilty of complicity in embezzling public funds when he was interior minister, but suspended his sentence on the basis of his age and “his past in service of France.” The case involved kickbacks paid to Mr. Pasqua’s son and other close associates in 1993 and 1994 in connection with sales of French police equipment abroad.

headline: Turkey: Parliament Rejects Plan to Protect Political Parties
text: In a surprise blow to the government and its plans to change Turkey’s Constitution, Parliament rejected a proposal on Monday that would have made it harder to ban political parties. Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said, however, that he would press on with the plan, which opponents see as a bid to expand his party’s grip on state institutions and undermine the country’s secular principles. More than 20 parties, have been closed on charges that they were linked to terrorist groups or had antisecular tendencies. Mr. Erdogan’s party, AK, which has roots in political Islam but denies ambitions to create an Islamic state, says the changes are needed to bring Turkey closer to European Union democratic norms.

headline: The Limits of Policy
text: Roughly a century ago, many Swedes immigrated to America. They’ve done very well here. Only about 6.7 percent of Swedish-Americans live in poverty. Also a century ago, many Swedes decided to remain in Sweden. They’ve done well there, too. When two economists calculated Swedish poverty rates according to the American standard, they found that 6.7 percent of the Swedes in Sweden were living in poverty.

headline: A Moment Kent State Won’t Forget
text: KENT, Ohio — Black pillars mark four sites on the east side of Kent State University — each memorializing one of the four college students killed by the Ohio National Guard during antiwar protests on May 4, 1970.

headline: Top New York Judge Urges Greater Legal Rights for the Poor
text: New York’s chief judge called on Monday for a new guarantee of a lawyer for poor people in civil cases, like suits over eviction and other disputes where basic needs are at stake, pushing the state to the forefront of a national effort to expand the right to representation for the indigent.

headline: Yankees Want to Fix Vazquez, but Not at Fenway
text: The Yankees would have almost nothing to lose by starting Javier Vazquez this weekend at Fenway Park. If the Boston Red Sox were to beat up Vazquez, it would be nothing new for him. But if Vazquez pitched well, it could be a springboard to recovery from an abysmal start to the season.

headline: For Obama, a Nonstop Juggling Act
text: President Obama’s spokesman promised for a second day on Monday that the administration would “keep our boot on the throat of BP” to get the company to resolve the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Yet, hours later, the president was hosting dinner at the White House with executives of the Business Council. Among the companies represented by the corporate club: BP.

headline: Rutgers Hires Coach From Robert Morris
text: Mike Rice, who coached a Robert Morris team that took second-seeded Villanova to overtime before losing, 73-70, in the first round of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, has agreed to become the next coach at Rutgers.

headline: Christie, Shunning Precedent, Drops Justice From Court
text: Once again showing that he means to shake up Trenton, Gov. Christopher J. Christie declined on Monday to reappoint a sitting justice to the New Jersey Supreme Court, instead appointing someone who he said would show the restraint that was missing from the court.

headline: In His 10th Season, Crawford Is Finally Enjoying the Playoffs
text: The last player to reach the interview podium Sunday at Philips Arena in Atlanta was the one who treasured the opportunity the most. And not just because Jamal Crawford likes to talk.

headline: No Charges for Ex-Head of Housing Under Bush
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has decided not to file charges against Alphonso R. Jackson, the former secretary of housing and urban development in the Bush administration, over allegations that he improperly steered federal contracts to friends, his lawyers said Monday.

headline: Jean-Louis Dumas, Chief of Hermès, Dies at 72
text: Jean-Louis Dumas, who revived the flagging fortunes of Hermès in the late 1970s and in his nearly 30 years as the company’s chief executive transformed it into one of the world’s most successful luxury brands, died Saturday at his home in Paris. He was 72.

headline: After an M.R.I. on His Shoulder, Pelfrey Is Set to Make His Next Start
text: CINCINNATI — Mets pitcher Mike Pelfrey is expected to make his next start Friday against the San Francisco Giants after a magnetic resonance imaging test on his right shoulder Monday revealed no structural damage.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,385 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,040 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: Patricia Rico, Proponent of Women’s Track and Field, Dies at 76
text: Patricia Rico, a central figure in women’s track and field for more than 50 years and the first woman to be the president of USA Track and Field, the sport’s governing body, died Sunday in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. She was 76 and lived in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

headline: Hired to Bring Order, Kings’ Adviser Brings Peace
text: ATLANTA — Just a few months ago, the three surviving children of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. were embroiled in an embarrassing public feud, accusing one another in court of stealing money and hiding their mother’s love letters.

headline: Terror Normally Steers Clear of Times Square
text: My sister, Ellen Dominus Broude, has been working in Times Square for the past 17 years — longer than she’s been a mother, longer than she’s been married. It’s an unyielding fact of her life that she rarely contemplates.

headline: Education Chief Vies to Expand U.S. Role as Partner on Local Schools
text: WASHINGTON — Education secretaries usually keep a low profile, in keeping with their agency’s backseat status to states and local districts, which control schools.

headline: Banjo Sound
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Many of us solve each day’s puzzle in the same place at the same time — in the evening when it first comes online, over breakfast, taking the train to work, maybe even in bed on a Sunday morning. Does doing it in a different environment make for a different experience?

headline: The Terrorist Next Door
text: While it’s possible that last weekend’s failed car-bomb incident in Times Square was part of a complicated international terrorist plot, the unsophisticated nature of the device has given rise to a much-needed discussion about the threat of “home grown” and “lone wolf” violence in the United States.

headline: From Buffett, Thought-Out Support for Goldman
text: OMAHA

headline: Ex-Councilman Is Fined $1,250 Over Oversight of Employee
text: Former City Councilman Kendall Stewart of Brooklyn has been fined for hiring the daughter of his chief of staff and allowing her father to act as her direct supervisor for more than five years, the city’s Conflicts of Interest Board said Monday.

headline: Oklahoma: Abortion Law Delayed for 45 Days
text: A state judge on Monday delayed for 45 days the putting into effect of a law requiring women to undergo an ultrasound and hear a detailed description of the fetus before having an abortion. The state attorney general agreed to the delay to give the state more time to prepare a defense of the law, which two abortion providers have challenged as violating the State Constitution’s clauses that protect privacy, equal protection and freedom of speech. The Legislature enacted the law last week over the veto of Gov. Brad Henry, a Democrat.

headline: Enhancing the Placebo
text: The placebo effect is, potentially, one of the most powerful forces in medicine. The challenge is to harness that power in a reliable and systematic way.

headline: Early Childhood Programs Expanded
text: Despite the recession, states continued to expand early childhood programs in the 2008-9 school year, according to an annual survey by the National Institute for Early Education Research at Rutgers University. Nationwide enrollment in state-financed prekindergarten programs grew by 82,000, to more than 1.2 million children, the institute said. But average state spending per child dropped, to $4,143 from $4,179 the previous year. Oklahoma has the best early childhood program, based on the percentage of children enrolled, program quality and other factors, the institute said. Other states in the institute’s top 10 ranking were Arkansas, West Virginia, New Jersey, Maryland, Georgia, North Carolina, Illinois, Louisiana and Tennessee.

headline: For One Night at Least, Yanks’ Depth Meets Test
text: The Yankees’ game ended Monday night with Joba Chamberlain pitching and Francisco Cervelli catching, and that was hardly by design. Their closer, Mariano Rivera, is ailing. Their catcher, Jorge Posada, left with tightness in his right calf. As long as they win, which they did, by 4-1 against the Baltimore Orioles, they cannot really quibble.

headline: State Senate Approves Bill to Increase Charter Schools
text: The New York Senate passed a contentious bill Monday evening that would more than double the number of charter schools in the state, a move seen as key to helping the state win up to $700 million in federal grant money, although the legislation is unlikely to pass in its current form in the Assembly.

headline: State Bill to Take on Public Corruption
text: ALBANY — Lawmakers will introduce legislation on Tuesday, written with the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., that would significantly expand the ability of local law enforcement officials to prosecute official corruption in Albany and around the state.

headline: Security Agents Wonder What’s in the Protein Shakes
text: BECAUSE I travel so much, I’ve developed a lot of routines. Sometimes people think I’m a little crazy, but it works for me.

headline: Window or Aisle? No, Fines or Flights
text: TEMPE, Ariz.

headline: For Vazquez, Next Start Is Delayed Three Days
text: As they continue to wait for the Javier Vazquez of 2009 to reveal himself in 2010, the Yankees took action Monday when they pushed back his next start.

headline: Food Crisis in Niger
text: The country is facing a major food crisis after erratic rainfall caused crops to fail last year.

headline: Assistant to a Celebrity Agent Is Sentenced for Her Murder
text: The harsh words rolled from their tongues, verbal volleys at the woman convicted of killing their mother.

headline: Suddenly, the Yankees’ Injury Report Is Getting Crowded
text: Joe Girardi has managed two types of teams: a young team, with the 2006 Florida Marlins, and veteran Yankees teams. His challenge is always to know when to rest players, but the reasons are different. With a young roster, he has said, a manager must know when a player needs a mental break. With an old roster, he must decide when a player’s body needs rest.

headline: Spain Seen as Moving Slowly on Financial Reforms
text: MADRID — A planned merger has stalled between two weak savings banks in Galicia, in northwestern Spain, illustrating the reluctance of the Spanish government to take a firmer hand to its financial problems.
