text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Stars Shine at Met Gala
text: Actors, designers and fashion luminaries stepped out for a night at the Costume Institute gala.

headline: Lottery Numbers
For the Mets, Losses and Frustration Start to Pile Up as the Runs Don’t
text: CINCINNATI — A string of victories and a giddy feeling elicited by a convincing victory in Philadelphia on Friday night has given way to a new streak. The Mets lost, 3-2, in 11 innings to the Reds on Monday and have now dropped three consecutive games in the wake of eight straight victories.

headline: Rondo’s 19 Assists Help the Celtics Avoid Another Letdown in Cleveland
text: CLEVELAND — When the Boston Celtics sputtered through the regular season, they were dismissed with descriptions appropriate for a high-mileage car. They were old, slow and unreliable.

headline: Helen Wagner, Longtime Actress on ‘As the World Turns,’ Dies at 91
text: “Good morning, dear,” the character Nancy Hughes said to her husband from her twin bed as the cameras rolled for the premiere of “As the World Turns” on April 2, 1956.

headline: Questions on Early News on Car Bomb
text: On Sunday morning, less than 15 hours after a car bomb had been found in a sport utility vehicle in Times Square, the homeland security secretary, Janet Napolitano, appeared on the NBC News program “Meet the Press” and said, “You know, at this point I have no information that it’s anything other than a one-off.”

headline: Immigration Law and the World Cup Bid
text: Complaints about Arizona’s controversial new immigration law and its effect on professional sports have until now focused mostly on Major League Baseball, since Phoenix is scheduled to host the 2011 All-Star Game. But the legislation, and a brewing fight in Congress over immigration policy, could also have implications for the United States’ bid to host the World Cup in 2018 or 2022.

headline: Elegance Is the Norm at Costume Institute Gala
text: It could have gone any way last night, considering the theme of the Costume Institute exhibition: “American Woman: Fashioning a National Identity.” There could have been neo-jazz babies, flappers, debutantes, feminists, disco queens, Hollywood sirens, Nouvelle Society matrons and Playboy bunnies.

headline: An Exciting Draw Kicks Off Second Half of Title Match
text: The world champion retains the lead after the third consecutive draw.

text: catcall •\ˈkat -ˌkȯl\\• noun and verb

headline: Germany Approves Assistance for Greece
text: BERLIN — The German government on Monday approved its share of a huge bailout, and the European Central Bank said it would accept Greek bonds as collateral for loans regardless of any future downgrades. The moves cleared up any lingering uncertainty over the financial rescue for Greece and took some pressure off the country’s interest rates on its debt.

headline: General Growth Is Examining New Takeover Offer by Simon
text: The mall operator General Growth Properties said on Monday that it was considering a new takeover offer from the Simon Property Group, although it was currently backing a plan led by Brookfield Asset Management to help it emerge from bankruptcy.

headline: In Greek Debt Crisis, a Window to the German Psyche
text: PARIS — A few weeks after Lehman Brothers went bankrupt and the world plunged into a financial crisis, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany offered some common-sense advice to reckless bankers, indebted consumers and profligate governments.

headline: F.D.A. Deal Leads to Recall of Infusion Pumps
text: Baxter International is recalling its Colleague infusion pumps from the American market under an agreement with federal regulators that sought to fix problems like battery failures and software errors.

headline: Fed Transcripts Stoke Debate on Rates
text: WASHINGTON — In 2004, the Federal Reserve began a slow and steady march toward higher interest rates, a quarter-point at a time. Many economists have questioned whether the Fed’s deliberate approach to tightening monetary policy, from exceptionally low rates in the aftermath of the dot-com bust in 2000, allowed a dangerous housing bubble to develop.

headline: In Deep Water
text: WHERE were people evacuated Monday because of the rising Cumberland River?

headline: Yankees’ Spark Comes From the Bottom
text: The Yankees’ starting pitching has been superb, and their lineup is stacked, obviously, and so it isn’t surprising that they’ve been able to win 17 of their first 25 games without receiving any sort of sustained production from Nick Johnson or Mark Teixeira, and limited offense from Curtis Granderson, who spent the last two weeks cooling off after his hot start.

headline: Proactiv Commercial With Katy Perry
text: A 60-second spot is part of a new campaign advertising the skin care line Proactiv like a mainstream brand.

headline: New Proactiv Commercials
text: Several commercials are part of a new campaign advertising the skin care line Proactiv like a mainstream brand.

headline: News Quiz | May 4, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Trying to Move Up From a Fast-Talking, Buy-Now Approach
text: MADISON AVENUE is a one-way street, but figuratively it goes two ways: for almost every trend in advertising, it seems, there is often a countertrend.

headline: Protesters Consider Truce Offer in Thailand
text: BANGKOK — Antigovernment red-shirt demonstrators said Tuesday that they welcomed a reconciliation plan offered by Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva but demanded more details before agreeing to end their seven-week occupation of parts of the capital.

headline: From Buffett, Thought-Out Support for Goldman
text: Why is Warren Buffett sticking his neck out so far in defense of Goldman Sachs?

headline: Leader Named for Climate Review
text: Harold T. Shapiro, the former president of Princeton University and the University of Michigan, has agreed to become chairman of a new 12-member panel that will review the practices of the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. The group will look into the policies of the panel on climate change that contributed to errors in a recent report, including a faulty estimate of the rate of melting of the Himalayan glaciers. Many scientists say they stand behind the panel’s findings.

headline: GMAC Financial Posts First Profit Since ’08
text: GMAC Financial Services, a lender majority-owned by the government, posted its first profit since the fourth quarter of 2008 as it starts to recover from billions of dollars lost on bad mortgages, Reuters reported.

headline: In United-Continental Deal, Birth of a Behemoth
text: Jeffery A. Smisek has held the top job at Continental Airlines for just five months — long enough to show he is not going to follow quietly in the steps of his predecessors, Jad Mouawad writes in The New York Times.

headline: Suspect, Charged, Said to Admit to Role in Plot
text: This article is by Mark Mazzetti, Sabrina Tavernise and Jack Healy.

headline: In Greek Crisis, a Window on German Psyche
text: A few weeks after Lehman Brothers went bankrupt and the world plunged into a financial crisis, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany offered some common-sense advice to reckless bankers, indebted consumers and profligate governments, Katrin Bennhold reports in The New York Times.

headline: Lihir Gold Takes $8.8 Billion Offer by Newcrest
text: In a deal that would create one of the world’s largest gold producers, Lihir Gold of Papua New Guinea on Tuesday agreed to a sweetened $8.8 billion takeover offer from Newcrest Mining of Australia — the latest in a succession of deals in the rapidly consolidating global mining sector.

headline: South Korea Vows Clear Response to Ship Sinking
text: SEOUL, South Korea — President Lee Myung-bak of South Korea, trying to figure out how to respond to the sinking of a South Korean warship in March, convened an unusual meeting of top military commanders on Tuesday in which he said the episode was “no accident” and vowed “clear and resolute measures” against those responsible.

headline: Pinstripes, Pitchforks and Profits
text: Many firms in Boston’s financial district invest in things you can’t touch: currency futures, index options, credit derivatives and so on.

headline: Voting Begins in Senate on Wall Street Reform
text: The Senate will cast its first votes on Tuesday on a sweeping Wall Street reform bill, with passage of a handful of uncontroversial amendments expected and a key procedural question still unsettled, Reuters reported.

headline: A Call to Separate Top Goldman Jobs
text: Separating the jobs of chairman and chief executive at Goldman would relieve some of the intense spotlight on the current chairman and chief , Lloyd Blankfein.

headline: Spain Seen as Moving Slowly on Financial Reforms
text: A planned merger has stalled between two weak savings banks in Galicia, in northwestern Spain, illustrating the reluctance of the Spanish government to take a firmer hand to its financial problems, Raphael Minder reported in The New York Times.

headline: Fed Transcripts Stoke Debate on Rates
text: In 2004, the Federal Reserve began a slow and steady march toward higher interest rates, a quarter-point at a time. Many economists have questioned whether the Fed’s deliberate approach to tightening monetary policy, from exceptionally low rates in the aftermath of the dot-com bust in 2000, allowed a dangerous housing bubble to develop, The New York Times’s Sewell Chan writes.

headline: Moderate Withdrawals at UBS After Strong Quarter
text: UBS‘s chief, Oswald Gruebel, said withdrawals by rich clients would stay at moderate levels near-term as the Swiss bank beat forecasts by posting its strongest quarterly net profit since the crisis began, Reuters reported.

headline: Enhancing the Placebo
text: The placebo effect is, potentially, one of the most powerful forces in medicine. The challenge is to harness that power in a reliable and systematic way.

headline: Goldcorp Sells Silver Deposit for $505 Million
text: Goldcorp will sell its Escobal silver deposit in Guatemala to Tahoe Resources, a private company headed by its former president and chief executive, Kevin McArthur, The Canadian Press reported.

headline: Mystery Startup Gets Kleiner Perkins’s Backing
text: A stealth startup called Flipboard has raised funding from Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, VentureBeat reported, citing multiple sources.

headline: Fish Hook Maneuvers and Moose Tests
text: Safety tests designed to assess the stability of a car.

headline: Six Flags Emerges From Bankruptcy
text: Theme park operator Six Flags emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy on Monday after wiping out more than a billion dollars in debt by turning the company’s ownership over to bondholders. The company exits bankruptcy under the control of hedge funds including Stark Investments, Pentwater Capital Management and Bay Harbour Management, Reuters reported.

headline: TV: Still Watched in Real Time
text: Today’s idea: Give people devices that allow them to record television shows easily, and they will still watch TV live at least four-fifths of the time — often with other family members.

headline: Pearson Sells I.D.C. Stake in $3.4 Billion Deal
text: 1:36 a.m. | Updated Michael J. de la Merced has more on how the I.D.C. deal is a sign of private equity’s revival.

headline: Goldman Discloses Shareholder Suits
text: Goldman Sachs has disclosed information about a half-dozen lawsuits filed against it by shareholders accusing the big Wall Street firm and top executives of misconduct and abuse in the wake of civil fraud charges brought by the government over mortgage securities deals, The Associated Press reported.

headline: For Tire Recyclers, a Holy Grail
text: From Leora Broydo Vestel at Green:

headline: Dubai World Creditors Agree on Technical Details
text: Dubai World‘s creditors have agreed in principle on the technical aspects of a debt restructuring agreement and should reach on an overall deal within two weeks, Reuters said, citing a report in an Arabic language newspaper on Tuesday.

headline: Simon Bids $5.8 Billion for All of General Growth
text: Simon Property Group has bid $5.8 billion for all of General Growth Properties, even as its offer to buy a minority stake in its rival was rejected, sources familiar with the matter said on Monday, according to Reuters.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Everything New Is Old Again
text: The Samurai Shopper and The Absent-Minded Professor often meet on the fly in the interstices of our hectic lives. Last week we met at Beyoglu, a Turkish restaurant on Third Avenue. Excellent grilled octopus prompted thoughts of exploring Istanbul, of seeing Topkapi Palace, the Blue Mosque, and shopping at the Grand Bazaar — carpets, spices, jewelry!

headline: Japanese Leader Backtracks on Revising Base Agreement
text: TOKYO — Backtracking on a prominent campaign pledge, Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama told angry residents of Okinawa on Tuesday that it was unrealistic to expect the United States to move its entire Marine Corps air base off the island.

headline: NYSE Euronext Quarterly Profit Up 26 Percent
text: NYSE Euronext said on Tuesday its quarterly profit rose 26 percent, matching expectations as its growing derivatives operation offset sluggish stock trading at the exchange operator, Reuters reported.

headline: Fortress Said to Plan Comeback in Asia
text: The Fortress Investment Group, one of the world’s largest publicly traded alternative asset managers, plans to rebuild its Asian operations and is in the process of setting up an office in Singapore, sources told Reuters.

headline: Lehman Set to Fight Bank Derivatives Claims
text: A team of Lehman Brothers bankruptcy administrators are gearing up to wage a series of legal fights against other banks this year, which have filed more than $50 billion in claims for losses related to derivatives contracts, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: What Is Your Favorite Summer Movie?
text: Dozens of movies are slated for release this summer. Which ones are you planning to see and why? What are your favorite films from past summers?

headline: China Shipbuilder Preparing $1.5 Billion I.P.O.
text: In a bid to make final preparations for its long-gestating initial public offering, Jiangsu Rongsheng Heavy Industries has enlisted Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase, Reuters reported, citing unidentified sources.

headline: Eight I.P.O.’s Could Raise $1.9 Billion This Week
text: In what could end up as the biggest week this year for I.P.O.’s, eight companies are gearing up for listings by Friday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Unleashing Secrets at Kensington Palace
text: Visitors to the newly renovated Kensington Palace (Kensington Gardens; 44-20-3166-6000; www.hrp.org.uk/kensingtonPalace) should suspend all expectations of a traditional experience. A team of creative talents have transformed the state rooms into an “Enchanted Palace” — a fairy-tale world that will remain on show until January 2012.

headline: Taller Buildings, Cheaper Homes
text: Taking issue with Jane Jacobs, an economist says tall buildings and high population density can be a virtue in urban life.

headline: Death Sentence Sought in Mumbai Case
text: MUMBAI, India — A day after a court convicted the lone surviving gunman in the 2008 Mumbai terrorist attack of waging war against India and other crimes, the prosecution on Tuesday demanded that he be executed.

headline: Google Puts Millions in Wind Farms
text: In a blog post, Google said it had invested $38.8 million in two North Dakota wind farms.

headline: Standard Chartered Posts  First-Quarter Profits
text: Standard Chartered, the British bank that generates the majority of its earnings in Asia, said it posted “very strong” profit and revenue in the first quarter on an improved performance from consumer and corporate banking, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Cowdery Secures Backing for a Prudential Deal
text: Clive Cowdery’s Resolution has secured bank backing to the tune of billions of pounds to finance a potential bid for the British assets of Prudential, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Q.&A.: iTunes Account Without a Credit Card
text: Q.

headline: My Week in Cash Flow: Tuesday
text: Note to readers: My five posts this week chronicle the events of the week of Feb. 15. I’m publishing them with some misgivings, as one might get the impression that my business is days from failure at all times. Fortunately, this is not so. That week was especially dramatic because of the timing of the payments in and out. Also, it marked the beginning of an uptick in sales. From where I sit today, the recovery has begun. We now have a normal backlog of work and sufficient cash on hand to complete it.

headline: Best Running Backs in N.F.L.: The Top 10 List
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, though the future isn’t ignored. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: Polaroid, Redux
text: The Polaroid instant film camera is back — and it looks very familiar.

headline: Anti-Wall St. Lawmakers Also Sold Stocks Short
text: A number of lawmakers, while critical of Wall Street practices like short-selling, also bet on a decline in stock markets in 2008, according to an analysis of their and their spouses’ financial disclosures conducted by The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Sampler: Governor Drops Drilling Plan, and Richmond Rape Inspires Bill
text: Governor Drops Plan to Pay for Parks With Oil Drilling | While the authorities contend with the vast oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California withdrew his support for a controversial offshore drilling plan in Southern California, which officials hoped would raise $1.8 billion for state parks in the next 14 years. “It will not happen here in California,” he said, referring to the Deepwater Horizon spill in the gulf. The proposal, known as the Tranquillon Ridge project, would have been the state’s first new oil lease in 40 years, bringing new wells to waters off Santa Barbara. Without the drilling project, state parks will need another source for $100 million this year. On Monday, the governor also vetoed a bill that would have banned smoking at all state parks and beaches. [The San Jose Mercury News, The Associated Press]

headline: Trader Quits Citi for Nomura, Citing Volcker Rule Fears
text: A Citigroup proprietary trader, Jay Glasser, quit to join Nomura Holdings, Japan’s biggest brokerage firm, as U.S. lawmakers pressure domestic banks to stop speculating with their own capital, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Government Weighing Possible Apple Antitrust Probe
text: The Federal Trade Commission and the Department of Justice are exploring whether to open an antitrust inquiry into Apple over its recent actions restricting developers writing apps for its iPhone operating system.

headline: Racer Seeks to Reclaim Family Legacy in Pikes Peak Hill Climb
text: The Hyundai Genesis PM580 looks capable of grinding out 24 hours at Le Mans or Daytona — and, given a few modifications, it probably could — but its mettle will instead be tested over just 10 minutes on Colorado’s Pikes Peak. There, the purpose-built machine will confront notoriously capricious weather, blacktop yielding to rutted gravel, vertiginous precipices and thinning atmosphere as it revs toward the checkered flag waving from the mountain’s 14,110-foot summit. No country for old coolant.

headline: Slogans and Facts

headline: Kimmel: ‘It’s Potentially Racist’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: The state of Arizona is the subject of a lot of controversy because of this new immigration law they passed. There were big demonstrations all around the country yesterday protesting it. Many people believe it’s potentially racist, but the state announced today that despite the controversy, they’re still planning to move ahead with their annual Cinco de Mayo party. I guess it’s sort of a going-away thing.

headline: Fallon: ‘The Whole Oil Disaster’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Have you guys been following the whole oil disaster? Yesterday, President Obama said: “Let me be clear. BP is responsible for this leak. BP will be paying the bill.” And BP was like: “Ah, bailout? Right?”

headline: Ferguson: ‘What’s Reasonable Suspicion?’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Over the weekend, there were huge marches to protest Arizona’s new immigration law. If you don’t know, Arizona’s new law says police have to ask anyone for immigration papers if reasonable suspicion can be found that they’re in the country illegally. But what’s reasonable suspicion? One Arizona lawmaker said, “Illegal immigrants are easy to spot because of their clothes.” Really? I know it was obvious with me when I got off the plane because I was wearing Speedos, of course.

headline: Letterman: ‘A Blowfish in the Gulf’

And today, a tourist thought they saw a blowfish in the Gulf of Mexico. Turned out to be a flounder holding its breath.

headline: Teaching Genetics in an Adoptive World

headline: Ning Planning to Remain Free for Teachers

Ning did not give any more information about the deal, which it disclosed as it outlined its plans to begin charging subscription fees to all of its users.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘High and Low’

Scott looks back at Akira Kurosawa’s 1962 film “High and Low,” about a business executive (Toshiro Mifune) who, through a dark turn of events, is forced to question his system of values. Mr. Scott points out that the extraordinary thing about the film is that it doesn’t just focus on one man’s drama, but “it’s the story of a whole society in a state of ethical crisis.”

headline: Spielberg Will Mount Film Version of ‘War Horse’
text: Steven Spielberg has decided to play the horses: the next film he plans to direct will be an adaptation of “War Horse,” Michael Morpurgo‘s young-adult novel about a boy and his steed, Variety reported [subscription required]. In December, Mr. Spielberg’s Dreamworks Studios announced that it had acquired the rights to the novel, which is told from the perspective of a British farm horse whose young human friend becomes a soldier in World War I. Mr. Spielberg said at that time, “Its heart and its message provide a story that can be felt in every country.”

headline: Letter: More on Kyoto

The Moss Garden was uniquely beautiful and serene. And the Sanjusangendo Temple, with its thousand life-size deities standing in rows and facing straight ahead with eyes closed in prayer, was haunting and surreal.

headline: Letter: Charleston Uncrowded?

headline: Letter: Ipad Versus Netbook
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Testing the iPad’s Trip-Worthiness” (April 25): The writer completely disregards netbooks, which in many cases are more versatile and useful than a tablet. They are also considerably cheaper.

headline: Vain Glorious | How to Get ‘Pampered in Paris’
text: The French are very good at not making things easy. Take something as banal as a manicure. In Paris, nail salons are few and far between, and when you do find one, Madam must make an appointment! Walk-ins are unheard of. And forget having your cuticles cut. It is simply not done! But if you know where to look, the French are extremely good at lavishing you with care. And that’s where “Pampered in Paris: A Guide to the Best Spas, Salons and Beauty Books” (The Little Bookroom, New York; available May 11 for $16.95 at littlebookroom.com) comes in. The author, Kim Horton Levesque, has scoured the boulevards and the back alleys. She’s soaked in hammams and had had her corns and calluses attended by a Chinese chiropodist. She’s been lathered and creamed, exfoliated and scrubbed to an inch of her life. This, so you can enjoy chocolate facials and bask in some of the most wonderfully designed spas on earth. F.Y.I.: body massage in France usually includes a chest massage. Madam may not like that. If so, simply say, “Pouvez-vous eviter le massage de la poitrine, s’il vous plait?”

headline: A Critic’s Take: A Fairly Intelligent List of Tony Nominees
text: I hope that there are people all over the world (other than the professionals waiting to hear if they had been nominated or not) who greet Tony nominations day as if it were Christmas morning. But even a mention of the Tonys has a soporific effect on me, and it has been this way for most of my adult life. I love the theater more than anything – except for books and a couple of people. But do I have to pretend to be excited about a prize-giving ceremony that usually registers as being as insular and provincial as the Junior League achievement awards for civic responsibility ?

headline: The Man Who Saved American Catholicism
text: His name is David Spotanski, and in the early 2000s he was the chancellor of the diocese of Belleville, in Illinois, where Wilton Gregory was bishop. Gregory was elected president of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops in the autumn of 2001, just as the wave of sex abuse revelations began breaking over the American church. Four months later, Spotanski wrote his bishop a 10-page memo on the abuse crisis, which he read aloud to Gregory in the bishop’s private study. In part, the memo was a blistering attack on the American hierarchy, from Boston’s Bernard Law on down, for their dreadful negligence, cover-ups and excuse-making. In part, it was a blueprint for action: To have any chance of restoring their credibility, Spotanski wrote, the American bishops needed to invite victims from decades past to come forward and act swiftly on their claims, adopt strict nationwide standards for handling new allegations of sex abuse, and then turn over as much responsibility as possible for implementing the rules to an independent board of laypeople (and parents), who could issue annual reports and hold recalcitrant bishops’ feet to the fire.
