headline: Why Endorse The Tories?
text: Yglesias is right. For sure, Gordon Brown — like the Rubinites here in America — made the great mistake of buying into the promises of high finance. But is there any doubt that a Tory government would have done the same?

headline: Answers About Student Loans: Part 1
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: It’s All Greek to Me: Understanding the Debt Crisis in Europe
text: Overview | Why is Greece experiencing a major financial crisis? How are its fiscal woes connected to the rest of the European Union, Europe and global financial markets? In this lesson, students complete a List/Group/Label activity to familiarize themselves with key terms, then research a single term further in order to teach their classmates about it. They then create a math or financial problem that demonstrates how the term “works.” They not only become conversant with the European crisis but also develop financial literacy by putting key economic terms in context.

headline: Numbers in the News | Greece
text: Patrick Honner, who is a Math for America Master Teacher at Brooklyn Technical High School in Brooklyn, New York, created the quiz below for us to complement today’s lesson plan on understanding the economic crisis in Greece.

headline: Arcade Games as Art
text: Melena Ryzik reports from the opening of Deluxx Fluxx, an interactive art arcade created by the street artists Faile and Bast, on the Lower East Side.

headline: Inside Out | Decorating Al Fresco
text: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

headline: Banking on Fuel-Sweating Flora
text: A start-up company has broken ground on a Texas pilot plant that is supposed to produce ethanol and diesel in a radical new way: with an organism that sweats fuel.

headline: An Early Assessment of the Granderson Trade
text: It’s still very early in the season, but so far, the Detroit Tigers have to be feeling O.K. about the Curtis Granderson trade.

headline: Your Jokes: ‘Celebrate Responsibly’
text: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Financial Tuneup: Review Your Life Insurance
text: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we’ve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

headline: Monserrate’s Ex-Chief of Staff Is Arrested
text: It looks as if former State Senator Hiram Monserrate may not be the only one with a temper problem.

headline: Polled Catholics Weigh Factors in Abuse of Children
text: While 35 percent of American Catholics said that celibacy plays no role in contributing to the sexual abuse of children by priests, 31 percent see the policy as a major factor and 28 percent characterize it as a minor factor in causing the abuse, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: Really Small-Time Crooks
text: As we’ve written before, the altitudinally challenged often get the short end of the stick in life, with lower earnings and happiness levels. Turns out, these disadvantages also predisposed shorter people to turn to crime in the 19th century.

headline: Developers Bet on Cargo Traffic at J.F.K.
text: A revival in global trade has spurred the first speculative warehouse development at Kennedy International Airport in almost a decade.

headline: Myths of the Supply Side
text: When I suggested recently that “conservative domestic policy would be in better shape if conservative magazines and conservative columnists were more willing to call out Republican politicians (and, to a lesser extent, conservative entertainers)” for advancing bad ideas and bogus arguments, I didn’t expect to summon up anything quite as controversy-generating Jim Manzi’s evisceration of Mark Levin’s views on global warming. For an example of what I did have in mind, though, read Kevin Williamson’s fine piece on supply-side economics from the last National Review, in which he goes after the panglossian misinterpretation of supply-side theory that’s become dogma among too many Republican politicians and activists — namely, that tax cuts generate so much economic growth (and with it, increased government revenue) that they more than pay for themselves. As Williamson notes, the most prominent supply-side theorists themselves don’t believe this, but they’re tolerant of politicians who do:

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bridgeport, Conn., and Elsewhere
text: In the aftermath of an attempted car bombing in Times Square on Saturday, many eyes turned to Bridgeport, Conn., where Faisal Shahzad lived. Mr. Shahzad was arrested Monday night and was expected to be charged with terrorism and attempted use of a weapon of mass destruction. Two of the pictures in our report were taken by Jessica Hill of The Associated Press. The last appearance of her work on Lens (Sept. 16, 2009) involved another high-profile forensic scene in Connecticut: a police officer preparing to enter the Middletown apartment of Raymond Clark III, an animal research technician at Yale who was charged with the murder of Annie Le, a graduate student. Julie Jacobson of The A.P. is also represented in this report (Slide 11). She recently produced an illuminating video essay, “A Military Chaplain’s Three Tenets.”

headline: The Morning Skate: Lucic, Versteeg Get Rid of Their Monkeys
text: Two good game-winning goals in two entertaining playoff games on Monday night, first Milan Lucic’s turnaround slapper with just under three minutes remaining in regulation…

headline: House Hunting in ... Spain
text: 10-BEDROOM 6-BATH TRADITIONAL FARMHOUSE WITH STABLES IN THE SEVILLE PROVINCE

headline: Country Living in Seville, Spain
text: A 10-bedroom six-bath traditional farmhouse with stables is on the market for 1.5 million euros ($2 million) in Seville, Spain.

headline: Pour Une Semaine, It’s Restaurant Week in France
text: New York’s Restaurant Week, which started back in 1992 with three-course lunches for $19.92, has continued successfully in the city and has spawned similar promotions in scores of other cities and regions, including London and Lisbon. Now, thanks to the efforts of Laurent Plantier, the director of Alain Ducasse Enterprises, France is following suit with a week of bargain menus.

headline: Going Green for Summer
text: It was a scenario that would have given Anthony Bourdain agita. Last month at Gobo, a vegan restaurant downtown, The Moment met up with a self-described “eco-model,” a healthy young woman who claims — not proudly, almost abashedly — never to have had a sip of alcohol or a cup of coffee in her life. Her name, because she was born during a June downpour, is Summer Rayne Oakes. “When I first went to a modeling agency, they thought I was a stripper,” she says of her two given names, which she prefers to be said in unison. Oakes is just 25, but she’s already written a book (“Style, Naturally“), contributed to an “eco-art” magazine (Above), served as a correspondent on Discovery’s Planet Green channel, and co-founded a business (S4 Style). “Is everyone who abstains from alcohol this productive?” we wondered briefly, before ordering a glass of organic Albariño.

headline: Thailand's Color Clash
text: Protesters clad in pink, yellow and multi-colored shirts take to the streets to  support the government besieged by the red shirt movement which has paralyzed Bangkok.

headline: News Corporation Earnings Beat Estimates
text: The record-setting success of  “Avatar” and growth in the company’s other segments carried the News Corporation to a stronger than expected performance in the quarter that ended March 31.

headline: Fairey Mural Gets Thumbs Down From Buildings Department
text: The street artist Shepard Fairey, who is no stranger to legal trouble, has now run afoul of the New York City Department of Buildings. The Department issued a stop-work order and an Environment Control Board violation this weekend to Elizabeth Houston Associates, the owner of a building on Houston Street near the Bowery on which Mr. Fairey recently installed a mural connected with his show at Deitch Projects in Soho. The mural was pasted onto a structure built on top of the original wall, preserving another mural by the Brazilian brothers known as Os Gemeos. According to Ryan Fitzgibbon, a spokeswoman for the Department of Buildings, the violation was issued for installing the structure and the mural without a permit. She said the Environmental Control Board court would hold a hearing soon on the violation; if it stands, it could carry a penalty of up to $25,000. She added that the Department was also considering issuing a violation for illegal advertising on the grounds that the mural constituted an advertisement for the Deitch Projects show. But Daniel Killinger, a managing director of Goldman Properties, an affiliate of Elizabeth Houston Associates, said that Goldman did not see the mural as an advertisement. “We see it as a continuation of the history of the art that’s always been on that site,” he said, referring to the Os Gemeos mural and a previous mural designed by Keith Haring. The Department of Building’s action was reported by the blog animalnewyork.com.

headline: Fit for a Queen of Hearts
text: DOWN the rabbit hole with you, Alice!

headline: F.D.A. Rejects InterMune’s Drug for Fatal Lung Disease
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday declined to approve a drug from InterMune that would have been the first treatment for a fatal lung disease that afflicts about 100,000 Americans.

headline: The Comprehensive Alcohol Regulatory Effectiveness Act
text: Just back from vacation, and I have so much to catch up on. I had some wonderful wines while I was gone, which I will tell you about in due course, and, since I know you all are wondering, I’ve completely recovered from my broken nose. In fact, my sense of smell seems improved, of all things. Guess an embarrassing tumble and a few weeks discomfort had to be good for something.

headline: Soho House Opens Berlin Location
text: If there were ever an indicator that Berlin has outgrown its image as untamed bohemian playground, this might be it. Soho House Berlin, a 40-room hotel and private club aimed at the young and affluent, is set to open on May 10 in Mitte, a district once dominated by squatters and unemployed artists.

headline: An Embattled Restaurant Reopens, Sort Of
text: The Cuban talent for “resolviendo” — improvising solutions to life’s hardships — is alive and well on another island.

headline: A House Without Walls in Costa Rica
text: Manuel Pinto built his home in Punta Uva, Costa Rica, with the bottom floor to be completely open to the outdoors.

headline: Jerusalem’s Vast Story, Conveyed in Music
text: Jordi Savall made his reputation by helping resurrect the viola da gamba, but he has refused to become a prisoner of the instrument. Though he still plays it onstage, and as beautifully as ever, these days he is mainly a hybrid musicologist, performer and entrepreneur with a specialty in assembling and directing thematic programs, typically on subjects that do not seem obvious until he has turned his hand to them.

headline: In Costa Rica, a Home Without Walls
text: PUNTA UVA, Costa Rica  One day in February 2002 Manuel Pinto and his real estate agent were hacking through the jungle here in southeast Costa Rica, near the surf town of Puerto Viejo, looking for a property for sale within the Gandoca-Manzanillo Wildlife refuge.

headline: Ex-Lehman Official Denies ‘Secret’ Barclays Discount
text: Barclays did not receive a “secret” $5 billion discount on a portfolio of securities when it bought the brokerage operations of Lehman Brothers after the firm collapsed, a former Lehman executive said Tuesday, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: BlogTalk: Miranda Rights for Terrorists
text: Just a few hours after Faisal Shahzad, a naturalized American citizen from Pakistan, was arrested this morning in connection with the attempted bombing in Times Square, politicians and bloggers were debating whether investigators were obligated to extend Miranda rights to Mr. Shahzad.

headline: One Man’s Hard Road, From Existing to Living
text: Wilbert Rideau was in eighth grade when, in the mid-1950s, he committed his first real crime. He robbed a Piggly Wiggly near his home in Lawtell, La. That went pretty well (he took $40, and some costume jewelry to give the girls at his school), so he tried it again. This time he was caught. So begins Mr. Rideau’s sprawling and hard-headed new prison memoir, “In the Place of Justice.”

headline: A Renewed Debate Over Suspect Rights
text: WASHINGTON — The arrest of a suspect in the attempted Times Square car bombing revived the volatile political debate over terrorism policy on Tuesday, as President Obama’s supporters and critics squared off over how the nation should handle those plotting against it.

headline: Latter-Day Stockhausen, Seen in a Different Light
text: Has any major composer disappeared from public view in the United States more completely than Karlheinz Stockhausen did during the last decades of his life? Once a seminal figure in the international avant-garde, Stockhausen all but reduced himself to a historical footnote in the decades before his death in 2007, through his increasingly esoteric output and with an ill-conceived statement ascribing aesthetic value to the 9/11 World Trade Center attack.

headline: Agency Told Tylenol Maker of Many Quality Concerns
text: The Johnson & Johnson unit that voluntarily recalled certain lots of children’s liquid Tylenol and Motrin over the weekend had numerous and wide-ranging quality control problems at the plant that made the products, according to a federal inspection report released Tuesday.

headline: Consumer Reports Offers Tips for Hotel Deals
text: Haggling for a lower room rate works about 80 percent of the time, and the walk-up rate at a hotels is about $20 less than advance bookings.

headline: Palestinians’ Emotions Run High After a Fire Destroys a Mosque in the West Bank
text: LUBAN AL SHARQIYA, West Bank — A fire swept through a mosque in this Palestinian village early Tuesday, angering Palestinians who said they were certain that extremist Israeli settlers were to blame, although investigators have found no proof. The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, echoed those sentiments and warned that the blaze “represented a threat to the efforts to revive the peace process.”

headline: New Death in Moscow Jail Renews Calls for Reform
text: MOSCOW — For months family members, lawyers and doctors of Vera V. Trifonova pleaded with officials to grant her furlough from prison to seek medical help. Suffering from severe diabetes, Ms. Trifonova, a businesswoman in jail awaiting trial on fraud charges, had only one working kidney, and her lungs were filled with so much liquid that there was a danger she could drown in her sleep, her lawyers said.

headline: At the Track I Pray
text: I can’t pray when I am visiting a church. The problem is that I am a singer and choir director.  I find myself analyzing the hymnal while “fantasy conducting” the choir.  I generally end up having a great time but I do not achieve a quiet prayerful solace and comfort that church provides for the masses. But take me to a racetrack and it’s another story.  At Santa Anita, there is a golden sunrise in the early morning when the horses are training on the track.  It is quiet and ethereally beautiful as the San Gabriel Mountains provide a glorious backdrop.  I climb the stairs and sit by myself. I am quiet and thoughtful. I empty my mind and let the images drift in front of me. Horses and exercise riders, trainers and jockeys, laughter and camaraderie.

headline: Trying Out Delivered Diet Meals
text: PAST 50 and pushing 230 pounds, I decided that this spring I would try to get down to a healthier 200.

headline: Remembering an Omnipresent Force at a Brooklyn School
text: If there was one person who didn’t need to wear a name tag at Edward R. Murrow High School, it was Saul Bruckner, Murrow’s founding principal, who guided the school in Midwood, Brooklyn, to national prominence over 30 years, from 1974 to 2004.

headline: A Chance to Trade Toasts With Champions
text: Though Anatoly Karpov, the former world champion, may face an uphill fight in his bid to be elected president of the World Chess Federation, his campaign is coming together.

headline: For Sushi at Home, Skip the Fish
text: YOU can make sushi at home, and easily. Just forget about fish.

headline: Majority of Americans Post Risky Information Online, Study Says
text: 6:30 P.M. Updated with response from Facebook.

headline: New World Symphony to Open in January
text: The New World Symphony, a Miami Beach-based training orchestra, said on Tuesday that it would celebrate the opening of its new home on Jan. 25. Six days of special programs will include the premiere of a piece composed for the occasion by Thomas Adès and videos by Tal Rosner, a filmmaker, and Casey Reas, a video artist. The building, designed by Frank Gehry, includes a concert hall, practice rooms, an outdoor wall for video projections and a music library.

headline: Cameras on Your Back
text: If you’re planning a summer vacation and need a new way to (lightly) pack and protect your camera gear, you might consider the new Bumblebee Ultra-Light 222 backpack from Kata. Every aspect of this $275 bag is meticulously engineered for durability, protection and economy of weight.

headline: Trailer: 'Metropolis'
text: A trailer for the restoration of Fritz Lang's "Metropolis," now on DVD.

headline: Debate Flares on Goldman’s Role as Market Maker
text: Goldman Sachs insists that it did nothing wrong and was just acting as a middleman when it sold billions of dollars of securities that are at the center of the Securities and Exchange Commission‘s fraud case against the firm. But John C. Coffee Jr., a professor of securities law at Columbia University, told a Senate hearing on Tuesday that Goldman was much more than a middleman and that it therefore had a duty to its clients that went beyond just filling orders.

headline: Players Is a Haas Family Reunion
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. – Jay Haas is competing this week in his 29th Players Championship, the arc of his career so majestic he is about to claim a piece of history smaller than the 17th green at TPC Sawgrass.

headline: Obama Interviews Judge Wood
text: Another potential Supreme Court nominee – Judge Diane P. Wood of the federal appeals court in Chicago – was interviewed Tuesday at the White House by President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Shiite Alliance in Iraq May Push Allawi Aside
text: BAGHDAD — The electoral coalitions of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki and the other major Shiite bloc in Iraq announced a postelection alliance on Tuesday night that cleared the way for a Shiite-dominated government for the next four years.

headline: Footage Restored to Fritz Lang's ‘Metropolis’
text: For fans and scholars of the silent-film era, the search for a copy of the original version of Fritz Lang’s “Metropolis” has become a sort of holy grail. One of the most celebrated movies in cinema history, “Metropolis” had not been viewed at its full length  roughly two and a half hours  since shortly after its premiere in Berlin in 1927, when it was withdrawn from circulation and about an hour of its footage was amputated and presumed destroyed.

headline: Ghent Altarpiece to Undergo Restoration
text: In the nearly six centuries since its completion in 1432, the Ghent Altarpiece, one of the world’s most renowned works of art, has not exactly been a stay-at-home kind of masterpiece. It was taken apart and hidden twice in the 16th century to protect it from iconoclasts and Calvinists. It was hauled to Paris two centuries later as a war trophy. In 1934 thieves stole two of its panels, and during World War II it was seized by the Nazis and kept in a salt mine.

headline: Speed Bumps and Potholes on the Road to Recovery
text: “I want to go home. It’s no fun here.” This cri de coeur erupting from an antsy teenager is likely to fall on receptive ears at the Lucille Lortel Theater, where the Beth Henley play “Family Week” opened on Tuesday night. Lighthearted diversions are definitely not on the menu at the treatment center where this wan, ineffectual comedy-drama is set.

headline: Dollar Thrifty Says It Will Consider an Avis Offer
text: 7:30 p.m. | Updated One day after the Avis Budget Group said it was prepared to offer a “substantially higher offer” for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group than the $1.2 billion proposal it had accepted from Hertz Global Holdings, Dollar Thrifty says it’s willing to listen.

headline: Ethics for Extraterrestrials
text: Remember the episode of “The Twilight Zone” where the earthlings discover only too late that a book brandished by extraterrestrial visitors, titled “To Serve Man,” is not, in fact, a philanthropic manifesto — but, sadly, a cookbook?

headline: Finalists Named For Turner Prize
text: Susan Philipsz, an artist whose installations explore the relationships between structures and sound, and whose works have used her own recordings of songs by Radiohead, Nirvana and the Velvet Underground, was among the finalists announced on Tuesday for the Turner Prize, the Tate Britain said. Ms. Philipsz was nominated for this prestigious award, presented annually to a British artist under the age of 50, for works presented at the International Festival of Visual Art in Glasgow and in the “Mirrors” exhibition at the Museo de Arte Contemporanea de Vigo in Spain. The other finalists are the painter Dexter Dalwood, nominated for a solo exhibition at Tate St Ives, and whose works (like “The Brighton Bomb,” above right) have focused on ominous landscapes and portraits of famous writers; Angela de la Cruz, a painter and sculptor nominated for her installation “After” at the Camden Arts Center in London; and the Otolith Group, consisting of the London artists Anjalika Sagar and Kodwo Eshun, who make documentary films, for a series of exhibitions called “A Long Time Between Suns.” Finalists will have their works presented at a Tate Britain exhibition that opens on Oct. 4, and a winner, who receives about $38,000, will be announced on Dec. 6.

headline: Nashville Sites Are Closed By Flood
text: The flooding in Tennessee has damaged some of Nashville’s most prominent music institutions, including the Grand Ole Opry House, at bottom of photo above, and the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum. Tuesday’s Grand Ole Opry show was moved to the War Memorial Auditorium, and this weekend’s shows will be playing at the Ryman Auditorium, former home of the Opry. “While we ourselves are shaken by the impact of the flooding of the Opry House and throughout the area, it is important that Nashville’s most treasured tradition continues with this week’s shows,” Pete Fisher, vice president of the Grand Ole Opry, said on the organization’s Web site, opry.com. Lisaann Dupont, a spokeswoman for the Ryman, said it was not known how long the Opry acts would perform at Ryman. She said that parts of the Hall of Fame had been flooded but none of the memorabilia had been damaged, and that the Nashville Municipal Auditorium had also closed. Many of the city’s honky tonks have fared better, said Rebecca Jones, owner of Robert’s Western World, one of the smaller clubs along Broadway. “We’re up and running,” Ms. Jones said. “The only part of our business affected is that fewer people are coming downtown.”

headline: Perfection for ‘Dancing’
text: Evan Lysacek’s tango with his dancing partner, Anna Trebunskaya, earned the first perfect score of the season on “Dancing With the Stars,” capping a near-perfect Monday night for ABC. An average of 19.3 million viewers tuned in for “Dancing,” followed by the new comedy “Romantically Challenged” (10.6 million) and the crime series “Castle” (10.8 million). Fox placed second for the night with “House” (9.7 million) and “24” (9.1 million). CBS was third and NBC ranked fourth.

headline: Jimmy Fallon to Host Emmy Show
text: The comedian Jimmy Fallon, right, will be the host of the Emmy Awards broadcast this summer, NBC announced Tuesday. It is the first Emmy hosting gig for Mr. Fallon, of NBC’s “Late Night.” John Shaffner, the chairman and chief executive of the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences, said Mr. Fallon “is a bright, insightful and energetic entertainer who made his name performing on live television, and we welcome him to host our annual celebration of great television as the show returns to broadcasting live coast to coast.” The prime-time Emmy show will be broadcast live on Aug. 29. The nominations will be announced on July 8.

headline: Summerstage Lineup
text: For its 25th season SummerStage is expanding beyond Central Park into parks throughout New York City. In Central Park, where SummerStage began in 1986, the season of free performances opens on June 1 with the New York Pops and Melody Gardot. It continues through September with highlights including the African singer Baaba Maal (June 14), Meshell Ndegeocello with Martha Wash (June 19), McCoy Tyner and others for George Wein’s CareFusion Jazz Festival (June 23), Gil Scott-Heron (June 27), Jimmy Cliff (July 11), a comedy night with stars from “The Daily Show” (July 21), the singer St. Vincent (Aug. 1), the British band the XX (Aug. 8), Public Enemy (Aug. 15) and the reunited ska band the Specials (Aug. 22). Benefit concerts, which are not free, include the Flaming Lips on July 26, the Black Keys on July 27 and 28, and one of Pavement’s four concerts there, on Sept. 21. The City Parks Foundation, which presents SummerStage, has for years also put on a separate series of free summer concerts in parks throughout the city but this year those shows are coming under the SummerStage aegis. They begin on June 1 with Jay Electronica in Red Hook Park in Brooklyn.

headline: From a Clan That Lives by Its Own Rules, a Tale Made for the Movies
text: The unruly extended family at the heart of “The Wild and Wonderful Whites of West Virginia” might have been the subject of an earnest, hand-wringing social-problem documentary. Or else an entire season of “Cops,” since the Whites’ propensity for violence, drug use and general cussedness makes plenty of work for the authorities in Boone County, W.Va.

headline: The Encores! Season
text: Encores!, the annual series at New York City Center that stages revivals of overlooked and underappreciated musicals from bygone eras, has announced the lineup for its 2010-11 season. It will begin with “Bells Are Ringing,” the musical by Jule Styne, Betty Comden and Adolph Green, which will run from Nov. 18 through 21. Judy Holliday starred in the original 1956 Broadway production, about a phone-answering service employee who gets involved in the lives of her clients. The next production will be “Lost in the Stars,” the musical version of the Alan Paton novel “Cry, the Beloved Country,” with music by Kurt Weill and book and lyrics by Maxwell Anderson. It was first presented on Broadway in 1949 and briefly revived in 1972; this version will run at City Center from Feb. 3 to Feb. 6, 2011. Finally, Encores! will present “Where’s Charley?”, the farcical George Abbott musical adapted from the Brandon Thomas comedy “Charley’s Aunt,” from March 17 to 20, 2011. The original 1948 Broadway production, directed by Mr. Abbott and choreographed by George Balanchine, starred Ray Bolger.

headline: At Italy’s Operas, Fat Ladies Are Quiet
text: No barber schemed in Turin; Butterfly stayed alive in Trieste; and Carmen remained chaste in Bologna.

headline: Moonshine Finds New Craftsmen and Enthusiasts
text: IN early April, Kris Comstock, a representative for the Buffalo Trace distillery in Kentucky, conducted a seminar on bourbon at Char No. 4, a bar in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that offers 150 kinds of American whiskey.

headline: Treats for Mom to Nibble on Her Day
text: High-heeled pumps or a picture hat for Mother on her day? Perhaps, if you select the stylish edible versions by Christophe Toury, the new pastry chef at Jacques Torres Chocolates, or Sébastien Rouxel, the baker at Bouchon Bakery. The shoe, one of three styles, is all chocolate. The pink bonnet, on a hazelnut cookie, is topped with chocolate hazelnut cake, frosted with dark chocolate and covered with pink fondant. The white bonnet has an almond cookie base, white cake infused with yuzu, strawberry filling and a coating of strawberry butter cream and white fondant. The flowers are not edible.

headline: Battle for New York Skies
text: All the major airlines have been looking for ways to regain the upper hand as air travel begins to rebound. And New York City is a major focus of their attention.

headline: An Eccentric Life, From Polio to Punk
text: Great musicians have uniquely fascinating lives, but their film biographies are all alike. The latest illustration of this paradox  definitively mocked in “Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story” a few years back  is “Sex & Drugs & Rock & Roll,” a dutiful and admiring film about Ian Dury, one of the more eccentric stars of British punk rock. The film, directed by Mat Whitecross and written by Paul Viragh, hits the usual narrative marks: childhood trauma, artistic struggle and triumph, family upheaval and substance abuse. Its flashes of style are sometimes lively but more often seem, like the slavish period décor, to be desperate attempts to overcome the built-in inertia of the genre.

headline: US Airways’ C.E.O.: We’re Not the ‘Ugly Girl’
text: In his exuberance at sealing a merger with United Airlines on Monday, Continental Airlines‘ chief executive got a little too colorful.

headline: The Vanderbilt and Kaz an Nou
text: THE service was slick, the room was handsome and the food reliably good at the Vanderbilt, a well-groomed gastropub that opened last fall in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. But something was missing.

headline: In Chicago, the Chef Grant Achatz Is Selling Tickets to His New Restaurant
text: BY this point, nearly everyone agrees that dining out has replaced going to the theater and that chefs are rock stars. So why don’t restaurants sell tickets?

headline: The Limelight Nightclub Becomes a Marketplace
text: Though it’s the sweet tooth that will get the most attention at this shiny new marketplace in the once notorious neo-Gothic Limelight, there are savories, too, including Peak Season, a farmers’ market in what used to be a churchyard, with 8 to 10 stands from nearby growers.

headline: Obama Tries to Mend Fences With American Jews
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama had lunch on Tuesday with Elie Wiesel, the Nobel laureate and Holocaust survivor, as part of an effort to mend fences with American Jews upset by the administration’s stance against the Israeli government’s construction of Jewish settlements in East Jerusalem.

headline: For New York, Summer on a Stick
text: Last summer it was artisanal ice cream from carts and trucks. This summer your frozen treats will be on a stick. You cannot do much better than the frozen gelato and sorbetto at Popbar, an Italian import in Greenwich Village. Small batches are made on the premises in more than a dozen flavors, with the suavest of textures. The coffee has the intensity of espresso, and mixed berry suggests mid-July. Embellishments include chocolate dips (below, on strawberry sorbetto). Drizzles and coatings of chopped nuts, coconut or granola are also available, some already applied to the pops, others for custom combinations. Popbar is the American franchise of Stick House, based in Turin.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: At the James Beard Awards, Marea Takes a Top Prize
text: Marea, on Central Park South, was named best new restaurant at the James Beard awards on Monday night. Timothy Hollingsworth, chef de cuisine of the French Laundry in Yountville, Calif., won the Rising Star Chef of the Year honor at the James Beard Foundation’s ceremony at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: The Lion in Greenwich Village Returns as a Tavern
text: Back in the 1960s, the Lion was a popular Greenwich Village hangout where Bette Midler and Barbra Streisand performed. Eventually this town house space, with its soaring ceiling and domed skylight, became Village, a bistro. Now, John DeLucie, on leave from the kitchen at Waverly Inn, is turning it into a tavern and restaurant.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Hail Native Plants

headline: Senate President Vows to Block New Jersey Court Nominee
text: The New Jersey Senate will block Gov. Christopher J. Christie’s appointment of a State Supreme Court justice by refusing to vote on whether to confirm the nominee, the Senate president said Tuesday, escalating a partisan clash between the governor and the Legislature.

headline: Commerce and Art Slug It Out
text: Broadway producers banked more than ever this theater season that stars onstage would fill seats, and in many cases were proved right. On Tuesday, though, the 2010 Tony Award nominations drew a sharp distinction between commercial interests and artistic success, with recognition going to several shows with few, if any, stars and small audiences.

headline: Art, and the Line to Get in, Take to the Streets
text: Jeffrey Deitch, SoHo gallery owner, gets a splashy send-off.

headline: Pam Grier’s Collection of Lessons Learned
text: Pam Grier, who manages to exude toughness and sensuality in equal measure, has also managed to embody many of the cultural shifts of the last 40 years.

headline: Another Opening: Cue the Crowds
text: FREUD said cultural achievement and sensual pleasure pull in opposite directions. He never met Keith McNally, who just introduced the insanely crowded Pulino’s Bar & Pizzeria on a formerly moribund corner of the Bowery and East Houston Street.

headline: Michigan High School Snags Obama as Speaker
text: WASHINGTON — Proving they have more to boast of than just their alumnus Derek Jeter, the graduating Giants of Kalamazoo Central High School in Michigan have beaten more than 1,000 public high schools in a national contest of academic self-promotion. The prize: President Obama as commencement speaker.

headline: McNallyland: A Review of Pulino’s Bar & Pizzeria
text: Sam Sifton reviews Pulino’s, Nate Appleman and Keith McNally’s new pizzeria on the corner of Houston and the Bowery.

headline: A Few More Moments, Please
text: Update, May 17 | It is now possible to search the “Moment in Time” interactive gallery by the name given in the photographer’s credit line (actual name, pseudonym or screen name, as the contributor chose). You’ll find the search box in the upper right corner of the opening page. If you believe your picture wasn’t posted, we urge you to give this a try.

headline: A Muslim Who Just May Be Jewish
text: Sometimes the best way to approach an inflammatory or scary subject  death, for instance, or corporate malfeasance  is through humor. That is what “The Infidel,” an amusing little film from Britain, does with one of the touchiest subjects of them all, the animosity between Jews and Muslims.

headline: A Teenage Canadian Bolshevik
text: The typical American high school comedy is more concerned with sex than with socialism, but leave it to Canada to reverse that balance. In “The Trotsky,” a study of teenage dementia set in Montreal, a privileged 17-year-old named Leon Bronstein (Jay Baruchel) is convinced he’s the reincarnation of Leon Trotsky.

headline: Who Benefits When Airlines Merge?
text: United Airlines and Continental Airlines agreed Sunday to a $3 billion merger that would create the world’s biggest airline, with 10 major hubs, dominating in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. If the deal wins antitrust approval from the Justice Department, the new company would replace Delta as the largest carrier after it merged with Northwest Airlines in 2008.

headline: Malaysian Talent Show Contestants With Problems
text: Even the Disney folks wouldn’t pile as much baggage onto a school talent show as the Malaysian director Yasmin Ahmad did in “Talentime,” her final film before her death last year. The young competitors not only have puppy love and dying relatives to worry about, they also have to be conduits for Ms. Ahmad’s commentary on the prejudices  religious, racial and otherwise  in her multicultural country.

headline: ‘Enron’ to End Broadway Run on Sunday
text: 4:58 p.m. | Updated With the field of Tony Award nominees sown this morning, the first underperforming show of the post-season has been claimed by the Grim Reaper this evening: “Enron,” the play by Lucy Prebble about the rise and fall of that notorious Texas energy company, will close on Sunday, according to a statement on the show’s official Web site. The Broadway production of the play, which opened last week after transferring from London’s West End, collapsed almost as rapidly as its namesake: though its cast included Norbert Leo Butz (“Dirty Rotten Scoundrels,” “Speed-the-Plow”) and Gregory Itzin (“24”) as the Enron executives Jeffrey Skilling and Kenneth Lay, as well as Marin Mazzie (“Kiss Me, Kate”) as a composite Enron employee, it was shut out of most major categories. Stephen Kunken was nominated as a featured actor in a play, but its lack of a nomination for best play likely sealed its fate. “Enron” could still be the rare play to win the Tony for best original score, another category in which it is also nominated.

headline: A Souk for Trust-Fund Hobbits
text: JADE JAGGER might shop here — that is, if she could tear herself away from her whitewashed finca at the north end of Ibiza. So might India Hicks, wafting in from Harbour Island to pad barefoot, as is her habit, across the expanse of rough-hewn herringbone parquet.

headline: Traveling an Indian Highway to Adventure
text: The open road. In American fiction and film, it stands for freedom, romance, escape from quotidian woes. In “Road, Movie,” an occasionally lyrical, occasionally confused indie, the director Dev Benegal translates those themes to modern India. His hero, Vishnu (the excellent Abhay Deol, not afraid to be unlikable), hits the road in a rattling antique of a truck, a Chevy with a traveling cinema (projectors, films) in back. Vishnu, a cool jerk in aviator shades and tight jeans, escapes his family, small city and fate  to sell Atma hair oil for his dad  for a week, driving from Rajasthan to the sea.

headline: Chicago Wins Prize as Home of Big Carrier
text: CHICAGO — Mayor Richard M. Daley and other politicians stood with the leaders of United and Continental airlines in downtown Chicago on Tuesday, proudly underscoring plans that the proposed merged airline — to be the largest in the world — will have its headquarters here.

headline: Picasso Sells at Auction for $106.5 Million, a Record for a Work of Art
text: 8:27 p.m. | Updated A painting that Picasso created in a single day in March 1932, “Nu au Plateau de Sculpteur (Nude, Green Leaves and Bust),” sold for $106.5 million, a world record auction price for a work of art, at Christie’s Tuesday night. The painting, more than 5 feet by 4 feet, shows Picasso’s mistress Marie-Thérèse Walter, both reclining and as a bust. Picasso’s profile can be discerned in the blue background.

headline: If Parliament Hangs, Queen Could Veto Fresh Election
text: She makes no speeches on the hustings; she remains aloof from the political fray. She admits no party affiliation and is not permitted to vote or stand for office. Yet, she addresses Parliament with bejeweled and regular fanfare; for more than half a century, she has held secret conversations with a cavalcade of 11 prime ministers; and, in a peculiarly British way, she could be cast in a central, yet largely powerless, role if Britain’s elections on Thursday stray into the gray zone known as a hung Parliament.

headline: Flyers’ Carcillo Plans to Get More Physical Against Bruins
text: VOORHEES, N.J. — Less than 18 hours after he claimed that Boston Bruins forward Marc Savard bit his finger, Dan Carcillo stood in the Philadelphia Flyers’ dressing room Tuesday and said he felt fine. He would not make a big deal of the incident.

headline: Celtics Expose Cracks in Cavaliers’ Facade
text: Cavaliers Coach Mike Brown’s demeanor after two games of the Eastern Conference semifinals reflected two different results, a transformation from relief to regret.

headline: E.P.A.’s Plan to Regulate Coal Ash Draws Criticism
text: The Environmental Protection Agency issued a long-awaited proposal Tuesday to regulate coal ash, the toxic byproduct of burning coal to produce power. But the agency deferred a decision on whether to treat it as hazardous waste, drawing criticism from environmentalists who had hoped for a stronger stance.

headline: A Coach’s Mistake, a Teaching Moment
text: Education comes in different forms, at all hours.

headline: Catholics Criticize Pope on Abuse Scandal, but See Some Hope
text: A majority of Roman Catholics in the United States are critical of the way Pope Benedict XVI and the Vatican have handled the reports of sexual abuse by priests, but have confidence in the Vatican to make changes to prevent abuse in the future, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll released Tuesday.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 28 through May 2 with 1,079 adults throughout the United States.

headline: For Homemade Sushi, It’s All About the Rice
text: I have not had as much fun doing a story as this one on making sushi at home in a long time. Cooking the rice itself is foolproof; the proportions in my recipe will work for you, and if you taste as you’re mixing the rice with sweetened vinegar, you can’t go wrong.

headline: Del Potro Sidelined by Surgery on Wrist
text: In September, Juan Martín del Potro won the United States Open, pounding his huge, flat forehand as he put a surprising end to Roger Federer’s five-year winning streak at Flushing Meadows.

headline: Who is the Baron?
text: Baron Ambrosia, the star of "Bronx Flavor," on Jamaican-style cow foot and more.

headline: Experts, Conflicts and the F.D.A.
text: The Food and Drug Administration relies on 49 expert committees to advise it on policy matters and on whether particular drugs or other medical products are safe and effective. The agency has made substantial progress in reducing conflicts of interest among members, and it is now pledging to search “far and wide” for neutral experts and to make more information public about any waivers it grants.

headline: And the Magic Number Is ...
text: Finally, the truth can be told. The United States has officially announced that it has 5,113 nuclear weapons in its arsenal, plus “several thousand” more waiting to be dismantled. The totals are so close to the unofficial estimates that have been publicly circulating for years, you might wonder what all the excitement is about.

headline: News Sessions With Woods Are Tenser
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Pretournament news conferences with Tiger Woods used to be fairly sedate, predictable events. No more. On Tuesday at the Players Championship, the general atmosphere and the questions and answers were in stark contrast to a year ago.

headline: Kyrgyzstan Opens an Inquiry Into Fuel Sales to a U.S. Base
text: MOSCOW — Prosecutors in Kyrgyzstan have opened a criminal investigation into whether, for the second time in a decade, a son of a president of this small Central Asian country illegally profited from contracts supplying jet fuel to an American air base.

headline: Pelfrey Has M.R.I.; Mets Say All Is Well
text: CINCINNATI — Mike Pelfrey said his shoulder felt fine, and the Mets said Pelfrey was still expected to make his appointed start Friday against the San Francisco Giants at Citi Field. That is good news for the Mets, considering he has been their best starter this season.

headline: No Fooling Mother Nature
text: There is only one meaningful response to the horrific oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico and that is for America to stop messing around when it comes to designing its energy and environmental future. The only meaningful response to this man-made disaster is a man-made energy bill that would finally put in place an American clean-energy infrastructure that would set our country on a real, long-term path to ending our addiction to oil.

headline: An Electrifying Start for the Rockies’ Jimenez
text: SAN DIEGO — As Colorado Manager Jim Tracy took a seat in the dugout late Monday afternoon to meet with reporters, he unfolded a piece of paper with handwritten notes detailing the latest developments concerning the Rockies’ long list of injured players, most of whom are pitchers.

headline: Giants’ Zito Living Up to the Expectations of His $126 Million Contract
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Barry Zito said something Tuesday that baseball players are not supposed to say.

headline: Lessons From the Lost
text: In Virginia, law enforcement officers are learning how to search for missing persons who may not know they are lost.

headline: Rumblings in the New York Skies
text: The combination of United and Continental Airlines would upend the balance of power at New York’s airports.

headline: Why Charter Schools Fail the Test
text: Burkittsville, Md.

headline: More With Dementia Wander From Home
text: ASHBURN, Va. — For generations, the prototypical search-and-rescue case in America was Timmy in the well, with Lassie barking insistently to summon help. Lost children and adolescents — from the woods to the mall — generally outnumbered all others.

headline: Liberal Democrat Relishes Central Role in Race
text: LIVERPOOL, England — Chris Garlick arrived a skeptic, but departed a convert.

headline: Our Deluge, Drop by Drop
text: Nashville

headline: Resources and Technology to Help Caregivers Cope
text: One Alzheimer’s wanderer in Arizona had lost much of his memory, but not, apparently, his interest in fashion: he never left the house without a beloved baseball cap on his head. So a trick the family used to keep the man around was to hide his caps.

headline: Tearing Away the Veil
text: Paris

headline: Paterson Offers Choice: Furloughs or Shutdown
text: ALBANY — Gov. David A. Paterson escalated his battle with the Legislature over the state’s financial crisis on Tuesday, saying that lawmakers could give him the authority to furlough more than 100,000 state employees or face the prospect of shutting down New York’s government.

headline: Readers’ Questions: Dementia and Wandering
text: The correspondent Kirk Johnson reports in Tuesday’s Times that frequent searches for people with dementia or Alzheimer’s disease are fueling a need to retrain emergency workers, police and volunteers around the country. They must throw out just about every generally accepted idea when hunting for people who are, in many ways, lost from the inside out.

headline: Darwin Got It Going On
text: The lights go down. The room fills with music — a pulsating hip-hop rhythm. And then, over the music, you hear the voice of Richard Dawkins reading a passage from “On the Origin of Species” by Charles Darwin: “Whoever is led to believe that species are mutable will do good service by conscientiously expressing his conviction. For only thus can the load of prejudice by which this subject is overwhelmed be removed.”

headline: Ernie Harwell, in His Own Words
text: Ernie Harwell died on Tuesday night, from cancer at age 92, and baseball lost one of its greatest ambassadors, a true gentleman and an icon in Detroit. The best words to sum up Harwell are his own, from the end of his speech at the Hall of Fame after winning the Ford C. Frick Award for broadcasting in 1981. There is no more fitting epitaph.

headline: The Hard Work on Financial Reform
text: The procedural vote in the Senate last week on financial reform did more than end a Republican filibuster. It set up the real test of the Democrats’ resolve to enact the kind of change that the nation’s financial system so badly needs.

headline: Automakers Seek to Delay Ethanol Blending Raise
text: WASHINGTON — Citing new test data, the auto industry says the federal government’s plan to raise the amount of ethanol mixed into gasoline will damage cars and increase the amount of pollution they emit.

headline: Algeria Names Provisional World Cup Squad
text: At first, even second blush, Algeria is considered the lamb of the first-round World Cup group that also includes the United States, England and Slovenia.

headline: Immigration Could Sway Coming Vote in Britain
text: LUTON, England — When Mohammed Qurban stood outside the Jamia mosque in the heavily Muslim Bury Park district on Tuesday and spoke anxiously about Britain’s record-high levels of immigration, he was reflecting a powerful undercurrent that could help tip victory in dozens of constituencies in Thursday’s general election to the main opposition groups vying with the governing Labour Party for power, the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats.

headline: A Reminder About American Values
text: Gov. David Paterson of New York made a brave  and startling  move on Monday to create a board to consider pardons for immigrant New Yorkers who are on a fast-track to deportation because of old or minor criminal convictions. He said he wanted to inject fairness into an “embarrassingly and wrongly inflexible” system that expels immigrants without discretion, without considering the circumstances of a person’s life or family, or even holding hearings to consider the possibility that deportation might be unwise or unjust.

headline: As the Oil Slick Spreads a Stain on the Gulf
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sudan’s Economy: A View From the World Bank
text: To the Editor:

headline: The New Chapter: A Times Sq. Suspect
text: To the Editor:

headline: Drug Use at Reed College
text: To the Editor:

headline: Black Hopefuls Pick This Year in G.O.P. Races
text: Among the many reverberations of President Obama’s election, here is one he probably never anticipated: at least 32 African-Americans are running for Congress this year as Republicans, the biggest surge since Reconstruction, according to party officials.

headline: Capturing the Vitality of Jackson Heights and Putting It on Stage
text: When Ari Laura Kreith moved to Jackson Heights, Queens, from California in 2005, it was not the 100 nationalities that are said to be represented in the neighborhood that captivated her. After all, California is a pretty diverse place, too.

headline: Fox and White House Tangle on Spill Theory
text: “Brownie” has a heckuva conspiracy theory blaming President Obama for the Gulf oil spill’s spread, and its airing had the White House and Fox News scrapping again on Tuesday.

headline: Lapses Allowed Suspect to Board Plane
text: WASHINGTON — Why was Faisal Shahzad permitted to board a flight for Dubai some 24 hours after investigators of the Times Square terrorism case learned he might be connected to the attempted bombing?

headline: Lottery Numbers
Bill Drops Fund to Shut Failed Banks
text: WASHINGTON — Leaders of the Senate Banking Committee said Tuesday that they had reached an agreement to limit the likelihood that big banks would be bailed out by taxpayers. But liberal Democrats said they also would push aggressively for an array of proposals that could force some of the nation’s biggest banks to reduce their size.

headline: Iran’s Leader Says Sanctions May Ruin Relations
text: UNITED NATIONS — President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran said Tuesday that relations with the United States might never be repaired if new sanctions were imposed against his country, that the United Nations atomic agency had no authority to poke its nose into matters like missiles and that despite his contested re-election last year, Iran had not become a republic of fear.

headline: Crisis Panel to Probe Window-Dressing at Banks
text: It’s an open secret on Wall Street that many big banks routinely — and legally — fudge their quarterly books.

headline: Stanley I. Greenspan, Developer of ‘Floor Time’ Teaching, Dies at 68
text: Dr. Stanley I. Greenspan, a psychiatrist who invented an influential approach to teaching children with autism and other developmental problems by folding his lanky six-foot frame onto the floor and following their lead in vigorous play, died April 27 at a hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 68 and lived in Bethesda.

headline: Smoking Car to an Arrest in 53 Hours
text: The keys found in the ignition of the sport utility vehicle that was left to explode in Times Square on Saturday evening did more than just start cars: one opened the front door to Faisal Shahzad’s home.

headline: Fears That a Lush Land May Lose a Foul Fertilizer
text: MIXQUIAHUALA, Mexico — Night and day, Marcelo Mera Bárcenas slops the fetid water that has coursed 60 miles downhill from the sewers of Mexico City and spreads it over the corn and alfalfa fields of this once arid land.

headline: Rabbi Moshe Hirsch, Israel Opponent, Dies at 86
text: Rabbi Moshe Hirsch, a leader of an ultra-Orthodox Jewish sect that opposes the existence of the Israeli state and a longtime adviser to the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, died Sunday at his home in Jersusalem. He was 86.

headline: A Suspect Leaves Clues at Every Turn
text: Here is a quest for the invisible life, rendered in less than 50 words.

headline: John Tarbell Jr., Bank Executive, Dies at 67
text: John Weatherbee Tarbell Jr., an investment banker who led Chemical Bank’s first leveraged buyout group, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 67 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Sushi-Rolling Accessories
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome to Thursday … a day early.

headline: Posada Heads to the Bench, Not the Disabled List
text: Yankees Manager Joe Girardi seemed to choose his words carefully Tuesday when discussing the injured catcher Jorge Posada and the possibility that Posada would be placed on the disabled list.

headline: France: Maori Remains to Be Returned
text: The French Parliament voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to repatriate some 15 tattooed and mummified heads of Maori warriors to New Zealand, ending years of debate over the restitution of the human remains. The heads are stored in several French museums.

headline: Primary Roundup
text: 10:20 p.m. |Wrapping It Up

headline: Ernie Harwell, Homespun Baseball Broadcaster, Dies at 92
text: Ernie Harwell, the neighborly Georgian who delivered Margaret Mitchell’s newspaper in the 1930s and then delivered the play-by-play of more than 8,500 major league baseball games over 55 years, died Tuesday at his home in Novi, Mich. He was 92.

headline: Can Babies Tell Right From Wrong?
text: Babies at Yale University's Infant Cognition Center respond to "naughty" and "nice" puppets.

headline: CNN and CBS in Talks to Gather News Together
text: CNN and CBS, two suitors with a long history of courtship, have engaged in direct talks in recent weeks about more extensive combinations of their news resources, according to several executives who have been briefed on the discussions.

headline: News Corp. Gets a Lift From Ads and ‘Avatar’
text: The record-setting success of “Avatar” and widespread gains in the company’s other businesses led the News Corporation to beat Wall Street expectations in the latest quarter.

headline: Suspect Charged With Bomb Plot
text: Faisal Shahzad, a Pakistani-American man living in Connecticut, was charged in the failed plot to detonate a car bomb in Times Square.

headline: Barajas’s Ninth-Inning Homer Takes Manuel and Mets Off the Hook
text: CINCINNATI — Rod Barajas has been a most welcome addition for the Mets, with his skills and savvy behind the plate and his timely power while standing next to it. His presence in the Mets’ lineup was even more pleasing Tuesday night, when Barajas’s meaty power helped erase the results of what could have been a costly decision by Manager Jerry Manuel.

headline: Concerns Up and Down the Food Chain
text: BRETON ISLAND, La. — As the oil spill from the Deepwater Horizon spreads across the Gulf of Mexico, environmentalists and government officials have been working frantically to protect shoreline habitat like this island in the Breton National Wildlife Refuge, eight miles off the coast of Louisiana.

headline: New Technology Generates Database on Spill Damage
text: A technology created to track political violence in Kenya with social media is now being used to log the effects of the oil spill on the Gulf Coast.

headline: Corrections
text: EDITORS' NOTE

headline: Malkin Steps Forward and Brings Penguins With Him
text: MONTREAL — The crowd was roaring throughout the first two periods, welcoming the Canadiens home for the first time since their opening-round upset of the Washington Capitals and their road split against the Stanley Cup champion Penguins.

headline: Forecast Dims for G.O.P. in New York
text: ALBANY — By any measure, Representative Timothy H. Bishop, a Democrat from Long Island, should be seriously worried about his political survival as the election season unfolds.

headline: Corrections
text: The Dining Briefs column last Wednesday misstated Pichet Ong’s position at the restaurant Village Tart. He is the chef, not the consulting chef. The column also gave an outdated reference to a dish called yuzu Eskimo at Spot Dessert Bar. It is served with passion fruit foam; it is no longer served with raspberry foam. And the column misstated the name of the cross street nearest the dessert bar, which is at 13 St. Marks Place. It is Third Avenue, not Fourth Avenue.

headline: N.Y. Court Expands Rights of Nonbirth Parents in Same-Sex Relationships
text: ALBANY — New York State’s highest court somewhat expanded the rights of gay and lesbian parents on Tuesday in a narrow ruling that said nonbiological parents in same-sex relationships should be treated the same as biological parents.

headline: Corrections
text: A profile last Wednesday about the restaurateur Donatella Arpaia misidentified the restaurants represented by her former principal publicist, Jennifer Baum. They are Kefi, in New York, and Eos, in Miami; not Mia Dona and Anthos in New York.

headline: Washington, D.C., Approves Medical Use of Marijuana
text: WASHINGTON — The District of Columbia Council approved a measure on Tuesday that would allow people with certain chronic illnesses to obtain medical marijuana from a handful of dispensaries regulated by the city.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on April 21 about Jidori chicken, a brand of poultry that has become popular with chefs in Los Angeles, referred incorrectly to the education of the company’s owner, Dennis Mao. He did not graduate from the law school at the University of California, Berkeley.

headline: Cervelli Gets Chance to Shine for Yankees
text: With catcher Jorge Posada out of the lineup Tuesday night resting a strained right calf, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi had good reason to embrace Posada’s backup, Francisco Cervelli.

headline: Milk’s Bullhorn, a Gay Unifier, Now Divides
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It is one of the most familiar emblems from the early days of the gay rights movement: an ordinary gray-and-red bullhorn — nearly 40 years past its point of purchase, faintly etched with the initials HM. It was used by Harvey Milk to rally crowds during his battles for gay and lesbian equality in the 1970s.

headline: Pension Fund Cleared to Sue Ratings Firms
text: A lawsuit against the large ratings companies filed by the California Public Employees’ Retirement System can proceed, a state court judge ruled.

headline: Turkey: Parliament Approves Court Restructuring
text: The Turkish Parliament on Tuesday ratified a controversial government proposal to restructure one of the highest courts in the country, despite strong opposition from critics who fear that the plan will increase political influence on the judiciary. The proposal calls for greater presidential authority in the selection of members to the constitutional court, which has long acted as the guardian of Turkey’s constitutionally protected secular principles.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,386 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following American this week:

headline: Honduras: Truth Commission to Study Coup
text: The Honduran government inaugurated a truth commission Tuesday, charged with investigating the events surrounding the coup last June that ousted former President Manuel Zelaya. The commission’s chairman, former Vice President Eduardo Stein of Guatemala, promised that the panel would interview both opponents and supporters of the coup. International human rights groups say that attacks on opponents of the coup have continued under the new government of President Porfirio Lobo.

headline: While Gulf Soils, Energy Quest Stalls
text: While the political fight over the now-vivid environmental threat attending offshore oil drilling plays out, it remains clear that the country’s lawmakers are not remotely engaged in the multi-pronged energy quest that would be required to move the world toward a non-polluting, yet prosperous future.

headline: Ex-Senator Coats, Seeking a Return, Wins G.O.P. Primary in Indiana
text: WASHINGTON — Former Senator Dan Coats won Indiana’s Republican Senate primary on Tuesday, fending off a Tea Party-backed candidate in his effort to return to Capitol Hill as three states chose Congressional candidates in the intensifying 2010 primary season.

headline: Recovery in Trading Helps UBS Post Profit
text: LONDON — While many governments struggle to get their debt under control, some banks are earning stronger profits because of a rebound in their debt-trading businesses.

headline: Q&A With Matt Getze, Wheelchair Adventurer
text: On paper, Matt Getze looks like any other budget traveler. In the past six years or so, he’s gone to Madrid and Prague, to Bangkok and Shanghai. He’s stayed in $10 hostels, eaten street food and haggled over trinkets in Thailand, ridden buses in Malaysia, gone scuba diving in the Philippines and marveled at Angkor Wat in Cambodia.

headline: Italy: Berlusconi Ally Quits Under Cloud
text: Italy’s Minister for Economic Development, Claudio Scajola, one of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s closest allies, resigned on Tuesday over reports linking him to a questionable real estate deal. Mr. Scajola denied any wrongdoing and said he quit to better defend himself against the allegations that he bought an apartment with money from a businessman who is under investigation in a corruption inquiry.

headline: Some Retirees Will Receive Aid to Pay Health Bills
text: WASHINGTON — The White House announced Tuesday that it would help pay medical bills for early retirees who have health insurance provided by their former employers.

headline: Ex-Producer in Letterman Plot Is Off to Jail
text: The former CBS News producer who pleaded guilty to trying to extort money from David Letterman was led from a courtroom in handcuffs on Tuesday to begin serving his six-month jail sentence.

headline: Consumer Groups Say Proposed Privacy Bill Is Flawed
text: A LONG-AWAITED draft of a Congressional bill would extend privacy protections both on the Internet and off line, but privacy advocates said the bill did not go far enough in protecting consumers.

headline: Deal for Data Provider I.D.C. Shows Revival in Private Equity
text: The Interactive Data Corporation, a financial market data provider whose largest stakeholder is Pearson of Britain, confirmed on Tuesday that it would sell itself to the private equity firms Warburg Pincus and Silver Lake for $3.4 billion.

headline: At $106.5 Million, a Picasso Sets an Auction Record
text: A painting that Picasso created in a single day in March 1932 became the most expensive work of art ever sold at auction on Tuesday night.

headline: ‘Idol’ Shows Its Weariness
text: Lee DeWyze > Michael Lynche > Crystal Bowersox > Casey James > Aaron Kelly

headline: Will Spain Miss Torres in 2010 as Much as France Missed Zidane in 2002?
text: Fernando Torres has been beaten and battered this season and he is worried the Premier League might not be good for his health.

headline: From South Side to West Side
text: In the fourth installment of Ozier Muhammad’s series, “Sounds From Uncommon Spaces,” we meet Tom Paronis, 51, who plays gigs with the 69th Street Band at Bar Nine, near his home on the West Side of Manhattan. He recalled his early days on the South Side of Chicago with the band Buddy Scott and the Rib Tips. His remarks, to Mr. Muhammad, have been condensed and edited for brevity and clarity.

headline: Word of the Day | refulgent
text: refulgent •\ri-ˈfu̇l-jən(t), -ˈfəl-\• adjective

headline: Topalov Wins to Tie Championship Match
text: The challenger manages to crack the champion’s defense for the second time in the match.

headline: News Quiz | May 5, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Trading Desks Keep on Humming
text: Traders have become magicians. Not only can they make crafty products appear practically from thin air, they are also churning out profit as easily as conjurors pull rabbits from hats.

headline: Derby’s Tv Ratings Increase
text: Super Saver’s two-and-a-half-length victory Saturday in the Kentucky Derby was seen on NBC by an average of 16.5 million viewers, up from 16.3 million for Mine That Bird’s win last year, and the most since 18.5 million watched Sunday Silence win in 1989. Viewership peaked at 18.8 million from 6:30 to 6:45 p.m. Eastern on Saturday. The common thread between Super Saver and Mine That Bird is the jockey Calvin Borel, who predicted that he would win the Triple Crown aboard Super Saver.

headline: Citysearch Gives Content to the Competition
text: Citysearch, as it falls behind other online vaults of local information like Yelp and Google, has been giving away its listings to any site that wants to use them, bundled with ads.

headline: Crisis Panel to Probe Window-Dressing at Banks
text: It’s an open secret on Wall Street that many big banks routinely — and legally — fudge their quarterly books.

headline: An Interview With Mahmoud Ahmadinejad
text: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran accuses the International Atomic Energy Agency of wandering well outside its mandate in raising questions about missile design and other military matters.

headline: Bill Drops Fund to Shut Failed Banks
text: Leaders of the Senate Banking Committee said Tuesday that they had reached an agreement to limit the likelihood that big banks would be bailed out by taxpayers. But liberal Democrats said they also would push aggressively for an array of proposals that could force some of the nation’s biggest banks to reduce their size.

headline: Stack Overflow Raises $6 Million
text: Stack Overflow, a site where users can find answers to programming questions, has raised $6 million in a first round of funding from a group of big-name investors led by Union Square Ventures, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Rumblings in the New York Skies
text: The combination of United and Continental Airlines would upend the balance of power at New York’s airports, Jad Mouawad and Patrick McGeehan report in The New York Times.

headline: After Calm Day, Anxiety Returns to European Markets
text: Europe’s nervous markets were calmed, at last, on Monday after the European Union and the International Monetary Fund broke their logjam and approved a long-delayed financial rescue package for Greece. But then Tuesday came, and that poise vanished.

headline: Après-Tea
text: Unlikely term for the après-ski scene in Afghanistan.

text: From Floyd Norris at his blog, Notions on High and Low Finance:

headline: Greek Stumble Follows Headlong Rush Into Euro
text: The economic challenges facing the European Union unsettled investors around the globe on Tuesday as hundreds of demonstrators took to the streets in Greece, unfurling banners over the Acropolis to protest the government’s new austerity measures.

headline: Ash Closes Scottish and Irish Airports
text: A fresh plume of ash from a volcano in Iceland closed airports in Scotland, Ireland and Northern Ireland for a second straight day Wednesday, but restrictions were expected to gradually lift Thursday as the densest part of the ash cloud was forecast to drift away.

headline: De Blonay to Be Lead Manager at Jupiter Hyde Park
text: Veteran manager Guy de Blonay is to become lead manager of the Jupiter Hyde Park Hedge Fund, Hedge Week reported.

headline: British Fund Encourages Borrowers to Refinance
text: Toscafund, a large London hedge fund, is offering to write off as much as a fifth of the value of British mortgage holders’ borrowings if they remortgage their property with a new lender, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Three Reported Killed in Greek Protests
text: ATHENS — Swarms of violent groups overtook a general protest against austerity measures in the city center on Wednesday, lashing out at the government and security forces and hurling gasoline bombs that, according to the police, set fire to a bank building and killed three workers.

headline: F.S.A. Talks Force Delay of Prudential Share Issue
text: 8:32 a.m. | Updated DealBook colleague Julia Werdigier has more from London on how the F.S.A. stepped in at the last moment.

headline: Pension Fund Cleared to Sue Ratings Firms
text: A lawsuit against the large credit ratings companies filed by the California Public Employees’ Retirement System can proceed, a state court judge ruled, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: UAL’s Tilton Will Trade Cash Severance for Shares
text: The chairman and chief executive of the parent company of United Airlines, Glenn Tilton, has agreed to give up cash severance of $4.6 million in exchange for restricted shares worth the same amount if his airline combines with Continental, United said in a filing Tuesday, according to The Associated Press.

headline: WaMu Creditors Want Company Liquidated
text: Noteholders of Washington Mutual asked a bankruptcy judge on Tuesday to liquidate the company as its reorganization was on the “verge of unraveling” due to “scorched earth” tactics by shareholders who left nothing in the plan, Reuters reported.

headline: Do You Worry About Terrorism?
text: The failed car bombing in Times Square raised security alerts in the area and reminded many people in New York and elsewhere to be vigilant about suspicious activity. Do you worry about terrorist attacks? Or do you generally feel safe?

headline: Citi Earmarks $200 Million for Small Businesses
text: The Citigroup chief executive, Vikram Pandit, has said the bank plans to start a $200 million fund earmarked for loans to small businesses in low- and moderate-income communities, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Is Jerry Bruckheimer Sitting on a Treasure Chest?
text: The producer Jerry Bruckheimer is said to have raised $300 million to $350 million in production co-financing to be used to fund films from Walt Disney‘s Touchstone label, local media reported.

headline: Klee, Under a Rigorous Eye, in Paris
text: The work of Paul Klee was denounced as “degenerate” in his lifetime, a frustration the artist vented on his tombstone, which reads: “I cannot be grasped in the here and now.” But Klee’s day has certainly come. Through July 19, at the Musée l’Orangerie in Paris, the artist is being rightly acknowledged as one of the major influences of the Expressionist movement in an exhibition that brings together 26 of the self-proclaimed poet and painter’s masterpieces.

headline: Best Receivers in N.F.L: The Top 10 List
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2009 season. It is not a prediction for the 2010 season, though the future isn’t ignored. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: Russian Warship Rushes to Aid Tanker Seized by Pirates Near Yemen
text: PARIS — A Russian warship was steaming toward an oil tanker that was hijacked at dawn with 23 Russian crew members aboard 350 miles off the coast of Yemen, the European anti-piracy naval force said Wednesday.

headline: The iPad vs. Enlightenment?
text: Today’s idea: New devices like the iPad may discourage the scholarly tradition of gathering passages of text — a tradition dating back centuries, to the personal “commonplace books” of the Enlightenment era, a writer says.

headline: So What About This Record-Setting Picasso?
text: Whatever the state of the global economy, there’s always a ton of discretionary cash floating around looking for some place to land. Tuesday night at Christie’s a chunk of it — $106.5 million to be exact — landed on a Picasso painting called “Nude, Green Leaves and Bust,” setting the record for any art sold anywhere at auction up till now.

headline: My Week in Cash Flow: Wednesday
text: Note to readers: My five posts this week chronicle the events of the week of Feb. 15. I’m publishing them with some misgivings, as one might get the impression that my business is days from failure at all times. Fortunately, this is not so. That week was especially dramatic because of the timing of the payments in and out. Also, it marked the beginning of an uptick in sales. From where I sit today, the recovery has begun. We now have a normal backlog of work and sufficient cash on hand to complete it.

headline: Société Générale Reveals Greek Exposure
text: Société Générale, the large French bank, said Wednesday that its exposure to Greece’s government debt was 3 billion euros ($3.93 billion) and that it had tightened credit at its Greek unit in response to the financial crisis there, The Associated Press reported.

headline: E.U. Said to Near ‘Black List’ Law for Funds
text: A lawmaker at the European Parliament indicated Tuesday that the E.U. was close to an accord on new hedge-fund legislation that would curb the ability of some offshore funds to raise money from E.U. investors, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: The S.E.C. vs. the Axis of Evil
text: Say what you like about synthetic collateralized debt obligations, but their explosions are figurative and their damage is financial.

headline: Sampler: District Attorney in Hot Seat; Tonga Room in Preservation Fight
text: Public Defender, D.A. Battle Over Police Records | Jeff Adachi, the San Francisco public defender, accused District Attorney Kamala Harris of unethical behavior on Tuesday. Ms. Harris fired back that Mr. Adachi’s comments were “irresponsible.” The district attorney’s office failed to research and disclose the criminal and misconduct histories of about 80 police officers who testified in trials, according to The San Francisco Chronicle. By law, the officers’ histories should have been revealed to defense lawyers, who could have used the information to challenge their credibility as witnesses in court. Ms. Harris called Mr. Adachi’s assertion that hundreds of convictions could be in jeopardy “wild speculation” and “playing politics with public safety.” Meanwhile, the SF Weekly reports that Ms. Harris now has the lowest felony trial conviction rate of any big-city district attorney in the state. She is the front-runner to become the Democratic Party nominee in the race for California attorney general. [The San Francisco Chronicle, SF Weekly]

headline: How Long Will Lloyd Blankfein Last?
text: Senior managers at Goldman Sachs are beginning to question how tenable Lloyd C. Blankfein’s position as chief executive is, given the bank’s public relations difficulties, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Sardines in Butter for Dinner
text: On a recent visit to Paris, my wife, Jackie, and I went shopping for Breton sardines. In the French region of Brittany sardines are still canned in the old-fashioned way, from fresh, whole (though headless) fish that are often fried before being arranged in the familiar tins.

headline: Switzerland’s ABB to Buy Ventyx for $1 Billion
text: ABB, the Swiss power and engineering company, said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy Ventyx, an American maker of software for energy companies, for $1 billion in cash.

headline: The Moral Life of Babies
text: Not long ago, a team of researchers watched a 1-year-old boy take justice into his own hands. The boy had just seen a puppet show in which one puppet played with a ball while interacting with two other puppets. The center puppet would slide the ball to the puppet on the right, who would pass it back. And the center puppet would slide the ball to the puppet on the left . . . who would run away with it. Then the two puppets on the ends were brought down from the stage and set before the toddler. Each was placed next to a pile of treats. At this point, the toddler was asked to take a treat away from one puppet. Like most children in this situation, the boy took it from the pile of the “naughty” one. But this punishment wasn’t enough — he then leaned over and smacked the puppet in the head.

text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Suicide bombers and militants armed with automatic weapons attacked government buildings in southern Afghanistan on Wednesday, striking a region where the United States has added thousands of troops as it tries to rout Taliban fighters.

headline: Q. and A.: The Dome and the Well
text: BP and the federal government are working frantically on solutions for plugging and containing the spill in the Gulf of Mexico. But shutting off a gushing well that lies under 5,000 feet of water will require a delicate feat of engineering.

headline: Time Warner Earnings Up 9.8 Percent in First Quarter

headline: ‘Vacancy’ Signs Still Posted in Front of Many Colleges

headline: ‘Time Stands Still’ to Return to Broadway in September
text: After its limited run earlier this year netted it two Tony Award nominations on Tuesday including one for best play, “Time Stands Still,” which stars Laura Linney as a photojournalist recovering from wounds she sustained covering the war in Iraq, will take another shot at Broadway. On Wednesday morning, press representatives for the play, which was written by Donald Margulies and is directed by Daniel Sullivan, said that it would resume performances on Sept. 23 at a Shubert theater to be determined.

text: BANGKOK — Anti-government protesters remained defiant in their fortified encampment here on Wednesday as the country’s king, Bhumibol Adulyadej, made a rare outing to mark six decades since his coronation.

headline: Evidence Mounts for Taliban Role in Bomb Plot
text: WASHINGTON — American officials said Wednesday that it was very likely that a radical group once thought unable to attack the United States had played a role in the bombing attempt in Times Square, elevating concerns about whether other militant groups could deliver at least a glancing blow on American soil.

headline: Fresh Off Deal, Telenor Has 36% Fall in Profit

headline: Russian Official Says U.S. Adoptions Have Not Been Halted
text: MOSCOW — After nearly a month of contradictory signals, a senior Russian official is now making clear that the government has not halted the adoption of Russian children by Americans.
