headline: As Oil Slick Spreads, Views on Next Steps

Below, you can read a few “Your Dot” highlights. I’ll be posting my view on where we go from here later this morning. What’s yours?

headline: Kimmel: ‘A Very Good Plan’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Oil is still leaking off the coast of Louisiana. Lots of oil. BP, the company responsible for it, has a very good plan. BP is hoping to create a giant vinegar spill to turn the Gulf of Mexico into a delicious salad dressing.

headline: Fallon: ‘He Acted Alone’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: It’s rumored that six pages from the script of the “Lost” series finale have leaked online. BP executives were like: “Oh my God! That’s definitely the worst leak of all time, right?”

headline: Schottcast: Vocab on Wisconsin Public Radio
text: Co-vocabularists may be interested to know of a radio feature on Schott’s Vocab that aired last Friday on Veronica Rueckert’s Wisconsin Public Radio show.

headline: Letterman: ‘Crude and Amateurish’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: This bombing plot here in Times Square is upsetting. Are we more upset about that than the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico? Which do we hate worse? I think you’ve got to go with the oil spill. British petroleum, these boobs running this operation, they said: “O.K., now wait a minute. It’s just going to be a P.R. nightmare. What can we do? We’ll give everybody a free tank of gas. All you have to do is drive your car right down next to the Gulf of Mexico.”

headline: TV for Toddlers Linked With Later Problems
text: Toddlers who watch a lot of television were more likely to experience a range of problems by the fourth grade, including lower grades, poorer health and more problems with school bullies, a new study reports.

headline: Fergus Henderson to Cook Lunch at Barbuto

headline: Leno: ‘Not the Brightest Terrorist’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Hey, great news. They made an arrest today in that failed Times Square bombing attempt. It turns out the suspect is a foreign-born, naturalized American citizen. You know what that means? He would have been fine in Arizona.

headline: The Calm, Cool and Collected President
text: David Brooks: Gail, would you mind if I praised Barack Obama today? I thought not. I’m feeling grateful to the prez these days because we happen to be in the middle of a bunch of midsized crises. There’s the oil spill in the Gulf (which is verging on a big crisis, I guess). There’s the Times Square bomber. There are various floods in Tennessee and elsewhere. The European Union is falling apart over the Greek debt crisis, and so on and so on.

headline: Wednesday Reading: A New Restaurant Pricing Model
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Video and Tweets From Athens
text: Updated | 3:12 p.m. As my colleagues Dan Bilefsky and Judy Dempsey report, three people have reportedly died inside a bank building in Athens set ablaze by protesters who took to the streets to oppose cuts the Greek government says are necessary to deal with the country’s debt crisis.

headline: Bloomberg Asks U.S. to Close ‘Terror Gap’
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is in Washington this morning, testifying before the Senate, as timing would have it, on terrorism. headline: How Do You Pick the Right Business Group?
text: There are many variables to consider before you join a business group. The harsh reality is that whether you spend $100 per year or $13,000, business groups can provide a mediocre experience. If you’ve read my other posts, you know I’m a veteran (and a dropout) of four groups, which I think leaves me well positioned to suggest some questions you should ask yourself and the group before you decide to join:

headline: Dustin Keller on the Jets’ Schedule and His Diet
text: Jets tight end Dustin Keller’s  last blog post for the Fifth Down was about how he hired the Jets’ executive chef, John Canniezaro, to prepare meals for him in the off-season. He answered a few questions from readers about football and food:

headline: Going to the Mountain
text: We finally left Tana on May 2, fully loaded with all our equipment and supplies. The packing is always high stress, as the omission of a single item can have terrible consequences in the field, when resupply is not an option.  For example, no formalin or alcohol (perhaps due to a leaking bottle top), or no spare flashlight bulbs, can bring research to a complete stop.  I had hoped we could have departed the previous afternoon, but my driver, Nicholas, was nervous about nighttime attacks  on vehicles between Tana and Antsohihy, so we left at first light.

headline: With Serenity, Julia Louis-Dreyfus Accepts Corrected Hollywood Star
text: It’s the sort of thing you’d expect to happen to, say, George Costanza: a longtime striver finally gets her name placed alongside some of the most distinguished people in her field — only to have her name misspelled in the process. Except in this case, it happened to Julia Louis-Dreyfus, who played George’s sometime-pal Elaine Benes on the hit comedy “Seinfeld.”

headline: Now Showing | American Woman at the Met
text: When I first heard that the theme of the new show at the Met’s Costume Institute was American women, I immediately thought of great American designers like Edith Head, Claire McCardell and Perry Ellis accompanied by images of sporty American women like Chris Evert, Brooke Shields and Cheryl Tiegs. What great timing, too, I thought, as American sportswear is having a moment right now in fashion — especially in the European collections. When I entered the galleries to preview the show, however, I realized that my thinking was somewhat off the mark.

headline: On Iberia, E.U. Reassures, but Markets Are Doubtful
text: The European Union dismissed rumors of an aid package for Spain or Portugal on Wednesday, as the financial markets continued for a second day to bet against the two countries’ debt.

headline: Katrina Revisionism
text: Reactions to the Gulf oil spill have, I suppose, been predictable. Sure enough, a substantial part of the right quickly jumped on the thought that since it seems to validate environmental concerns, it must be a dastardly plot by environmentalists. Meanwhile, much of the press floated the idea that this was “Obama’s Katrina” — despite the fact that the administration responded as quickly as anyone could reasonably have expected, and anyway there wasn’t much it could do.

headline: Which Restaurateur Most Resembles Pooh?
text: In my review of Pulino’s today I made reference to Keith McNally, the restaurant’s dour and slightly disheveled owner, as Eeyore, the dour and slightly disheveled donkey in A.A. Milne’s classic children’s book from 1926, “Winnie-the-Pooh.”

headline: How Serious Is Raynaud’s Phenomenon?
text: Millions of people, more women than men, suffer from a feeling of extreme coldness in the fingers and toes, a problem called Raynaud’s phenomenon. For some, the discomfort extends into the summer months, and even holding a cold drink or being in an air conditioned room can be unbearable. Here, Dr. Fredrick Wigley of Johns Hopkins Medical School responds to readers concerned about whether they have Raynaud’s, how serious it might be and what can be done to ease the discomfort. For more information, see Dr. Wigley’s earlier responses in “Ask the Expert: Raynaud’s Phenomenon” and The Times Health Guide: Raynaud’s Phenomenon.

headline: New ‘X-Men’ Movie Coming Soon – Very Soon – With a New Director
text: Is there a member of the X-Men whose mutant powers include the ability to create a Hollywood blockbuster in just over a year? If so, Matthew Vaughn would probably like to speak to him. Fox has named Mr. Vaughn, whose films include the comic-book action film “Kick-Ass,” the director of its next “X-Men” movie and announced a release date of June 3, 2011, for the film, Variety reported [subscription required].

headline: A Personal Note for Teacher Appreciation Week

headline: Since Bork, a Long War Over the Court
text: WASHINGTON — The modern war over the Supreme Court arguably began in 1987, when the selection of Robert H. Bork touched off a clash that continues to this day. Ever since his nomination collapsed in an angry ideological confrontation, conservatives and liberals have mobilized forces with regularity to advance or tear down would-be justices.

headline: An Unusual ‘Gift’ for Bloomberg
text: At its spring gala on Tuesday night, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts paid tribute to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg with an unusual gift. The center will move its Calder sculpture, “Le Guichet” (“The Box Office”), to any place in New York City the mayor chooses for a period of 90 days. In his remarks, Mr. Bloomberg said his deputy mayor Patricia E. Harris would find a good place for it. Ms. Harris said on Wednesday a site had yet to be determined. The sculpture, made of black steel plate, sits on the north plaza outside the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. It was presented to Lincoln Center in 1965. The philanthropist David M. Rubenstein, a Lincoln Center trustee, was honored at the gala.

headline: The Iraqi Hunting Club Flourishes
text: BAGHDAD — It was my day off, so, my mother invited me for coffee at the Iraqi Hunting Club. At first I was not very enticed, so as not to fall into the depressing comparisons of the place yesterday and today.

headline: Q. and A.: For Oceans, ‘Another Big Headache’
text: Sylvia Earle, a former chief scientist for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, is an oceanographer acclaimed for her pioneering deep-sea explorations and research. More recently she has become one of the world’s leading advocates for marine conservation, leading efforts to establish marine preserves around the globe.

headline: On Israel, Jews and Leaders Often Disagree
text: FARMINGTON HILLS, Mich. — Criticizing Israel has long been the equivalent of touching a third rail in many Jewish families and friendships, relegating disagreements to a conversational demilitarized zone where only the innocent and foolhardy go.

headline: Kerry, Edison and the Energy Quest
text: As oil flowed unabated from the Gulf of Mexico seabed, Senator John Kerry used a speech today at a green jobs conference in Washington, D.C., to press the case for an energy bill that speeds the country’s journey to a post-fossil future and constrains emissions of greenhouse gases.

headline: Council Easy, Dog Hard; and a Skilled Negotiator
text: It takes a certain amount of grit and tenacity to keep the City Council in line. But when it comes to handling her own dog, Christine C. Quinn admits defeat.

headline: Local Assistance | Tripping.com
text: As “The Simpsons” have taught us (in song, no less), a stranger is just a friend you haven’t met. Jen O’Neal, the co-founder and chief executive of Tripping International, is putting that philosophy to the test with tripping.com, a Web site devoted to connecting travelers with residents willing to show them a little hospitality. “I love hosting,” says O’Neal. “I used to live in Italy and I would host Italians to practice Italian.”

headline: TimesCast | May 5, 2010
text: Today, the Times Square bomb investigation extends to Pakistan, BP caps the first of three leaks in the Gulf of Mexico and three people are killed in Greece as violence erupts over economic reforms.

headline: Sufficiency Democracy
text: Nickname for the current political system in Thailand, which some say supports a social hierarchy.

headline: Checking In on Last Year’s Unemployed
text: The John J. Heldrich Center for Workforce Development at Rutgers has released its latest work trends report on the long-term unemployed, and the results are somewhat discouraging. (The title of the report — “No End in Sight: The Agony of Prolonged Unemployment” — was sort of a giveaway, though.)

headline: A Suspect’s Trip to a Fireworks Superstore
text: Around 12:30 on a Monday afternoon about seven weeks ago, Faisal Shahzad pulled into the parking lot at the Phantom Fireworks store in Matamoras, Pa., said Bruce Zoldan, the owner of the company.

headline: Executives Questioned on Demise of Bear Stearns
text: Members of a panel investigating the financial crisis on Wednesday challenged former Bear Stearns executives on their view of what caused the Wall Street firm to implode two years ago, The Associated Press reports.

headline: The Fate of Continental and United Credit Cards
text: Updated at 3:21 p.m. to note that there are some Continental Visas out there too.

headline: Newsweek Is for Sale
text: From Joseph Plambeck at Media Decoder:

headline: England Wary of a New American Revolution
text: London

headline: Travel Deals: Free Nights at InterContinental Hotels in Europe
text: Favorable exchange rates may help travelers save money in Europe this summer.  Another way to save? InterContinental Hotels & Resorts is offering one free night for every five consecutive nights booked at more than 15 properties in Europe. Plus, guests receive a 100-euro food and beverage voucher to use at the hotel. The deal is available for travel July 1 to Sept. 12.

headline: Craig Kilborn to Return With a New Syndicated Show
text: Craig Kilborn, the original host of “The Daily Show” and then a late-night host for CBS in its 12:35 a.m. “Late Late Show,” is about to return to television in a prospective  show for 20th Television, the syndication arm of Fox’s television stations.

headline: Making a Success of Her Messiness on Two Coasts
text: ELIZABETH MERIWETHER’S flair for writing comedy has landed her jobs on both coasts in theater, film and television. But it also got her fired as an Obama campaign volunteer.

headline: Young Rapper Tops Charts
text: Justin Bieber is not the only young protégé of a big Atlanta star to hit No. 1 on the Billboard album chart lately. B.o.B., a smooth-voiced 21-year-old under the wing of the rapper T.I., reached the top spot this week with his debut album, “B.o.B. Presents: The Adventures of Bobby Ray” (Rebel Rock/Grand Hustle/Atlantic), which sold 84,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. (B.o.B., whose real name is Bobby Ray Simmons, has had help from more than just T.I. to make his pop crossover: the album also features Eminem, Rivers Cuomo of Weezer and Hayley Williams of Paramore.)

headline: Two-Handers With Plenty to Applaud
text: PLAYWRIGHTS justly lament the incredible shrinking of the American theater. As the costs of producing have risen over the last few decades, the plays being regularly produced have been getting smaller and smaller. A cast of five actors now seems deluxe at an Off Broadway theater, and stories are rife of literary managers and dramaturges gently suggesting to playwrights that their work might be more marketable if they could airbrush out a few more characters.

headline: Do We Have the Horse Right Here? Let’s Talk Odds
text: We still don’t know all the horses that will show up in Baltimore to try to derail Calvin Borel’s prediction that he and Super Saver will capture the Triple Crown.

headline: Janet Malcolm on Journalism’s Long Con
text: In the May 3 issue of The New Yorker, Janet Malcolm takes on what she sees as a broken system of criminal justice in a story about the trial of a Queens doctor convicted of killing her husband, but as is often the case in her work, there is a baked-in critique of the craft of journalism.

headline: Government Tightens No-Fly Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Homeland security officials on Wednesday ordered airlines to speed up checks of names added to the no-fly list, a requirement that might have prevented Faisal Shahzad, the accused Times Square bomber, from boarding a flight to Dubai on Monday night.

headline: Facebook Security Flaw Publicizes Private Chats
text: 2:22 p.m. | Updated  Including new information about the security flaw and adding comment from Facebook.

headline: Art of the MetroCard, Unlimited
Preventing Cancer in Dogs
text: Recently, my friend and former colleague Melinda Beck lost her beloved golden retriever Cody to cancer. She wrote about the experience in her Wall Street Journal column this week:

headline: Snedeker Readies to Tee Off, but Nashville Is on His Mind
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — The first warning Brandt Snedeker got that his hometown, Nashville, had turned into a huge water hazard were the photos his wife, Mandy, sent Sunday morning from her camera phone during her drive to the airport for the plane trip here.

headline: Newsweek on Block as Era of the Newsweekly Fades
text: For generations, Time and Newsweek fought to define the national news agenda every Monday on the newsstand. Before the Internet, before cable news, before People magazine, what the newsweeklies put on their covers mattered.

headline: Chronicling Science as Journey
text: This is a shout-out to a great new blog at The New York Times: Scientist at Work. Science is, as often as not, as difficult a journey as that taken in this picture I took of Harry Bader, a researcher studying the thawing of Alaska’s North Slope tundra:

headline: Department of Back Issues | Magazine
text: Didier Lestrade is a bit flummoxed by all the attention he is getting lately for “stuff I did 20, 30 years ago.” Starting today, 12Mail — a new gallery in Paris — is presenting an exhibition about Magazine, the underground gay publication Lestrade founded in 1980.

headline: Another Low Night for ‘Idol’
text: In what has become a recurring pattern, television’s most popular show for most of the last decade, “American Idol,” hit another recent low in ratings on Tuesday night, perhaps signaling that the one-time powerhouse singing competition has finally begun to lose some of its mass appeal.

headline: What the Newsweek Sale Means
text: Here’s our story on what the sale of Newsweek means, including comments by Newsweek’s editor, Jon Meacham, and by Donald E. Graham, the chairman of The Washington Post Company.

headline: The Pro-Immigration Case for Border Security
text: Will Wilkinson raises an objection to my suggestion that even supporters of a liberal immigration policy have an incentive to see the border secured:

headline: Timeline: Faisal Shahzad
text: A timeline of key dates in the life of Faisal Shahzad, a naturalized American citizen from Pakistan who confessed to planting a car bomb in Times Square.

headline: Can’t Afford the Picasso? Buy the Home Where It Once Hung
text: Suppose you were only the second-to-last bidder on Picasso‘s “Nu au Plateau de Sculpteur” at Christie’s on Tuesday night, or you just didn’t have the additional $106.5 million lying around to add it to your collection. Is there another valuable item you could acquire, somehow connected to that painting, but for a fraction of the price? How about the home of the art patrons who previously owned it?

headline: A Taste Test to Remember, Any Way You Slice It
text: We know that when the moon hits your eye like a big pizza pie, that’s amore. But what is it when a gaggle of Madison Avenue mavens gather for a taste test of more than a dozen varieties of pizza pie?

headline: On Defense, James Is Closer Than He Appears
text: CLEVELAND — Do not get LeBron James wrong. He takes plenty of satisfaction in his rim-rattling dunks. There is another play, however, that James said he preferred: the chase-down block.

headline: North Korean Leader Can’t Avoid Scrutiny on a Stealth Trip to China
text: BEIJING — Much as in the children’s book “Where’s Waldo?” the proof that North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-il, is indeed traveling through China can be obvious, if somewhat headache-inducing to arrive at.

headline: ‘The Temperamentals’ to Close
text: The Off Broadway production of “The Temperamentals,” a play about five closeted gay men who built a pre-Stonewall gay rights group, will close on May 30 after three months of performances, its producers said on Wednesday.

headline: Now Showing | Ultrasuede: In Search of Halston
text: A lot of people expected the new documentary “Ultrasuede: In Search of Halston” to be a Kitty Kelley-style tell-all of the life of America’s first celebrity designer. But what the director, Whitney Sudler-Smith, presented on Friday at its world premiere at the Tribeca Film Festival was an affectionate, often kid-glove portrait — or make that ultrasuede-glove portrait — of the fashion legend.

headline: After Bullpen Session, Pelfrey Says He’s Fine for Friday
text: CINCINNATI – Mike Pelfrey said he would make his appointed start on Friday against the Giants at Citi Field. After Pelfrey’s so-called touch and feel session in the bullpen on Wednesday, he proclaimed himself ready.

headline: Massive Austerity Strike in Greece
text: Demonstrators protesting Greek austerity measures set fire to a bank building in central Athens.

headline: On Our Radar: Shunning ‘Drill, Baby, Drill’
text: Republican leaders disavow the “Drill, baby, drill” catch phrase.

headline: Was It Really a Bubble?
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: The Drill on the Spill: Learning About the Gulf Oil Leak in the Lab
text: Overview | In this lesson, students consider the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico and related cleanup efforts. They then design and execute experiments to learn more about the effects of oil spills, and apply their findings to the coastal communities in the gulf region. Finally, they explore the economic and political impacts of the oil spill as well as the technological progress toward stopping the leak.

headline: DeMint Backs Rand Paul
text: Another day, another endorsement in Kentucky.

headline: Who Draws the Borders of Culture?
text: London

headline: The Mistress’s Song
text: “I DON’T like the way mistresses are being maligned in the press today,” said Carole Mallory, her voice indignant as she looked up from her salad at Gallagher’s Steak House on West 52nd Street, where she and Norman Mailer frequently dined during their eight-year affair that began in 1983. At the time, Mr. Mailer was married to his sixth wife, Norris Church Mailer; Ms. Mallory’s affair with the writer is the subject of her new book, “Loving Mailer.”

headline: A Look at Bear Stearns Before Its Downfall
text: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission has released documents that show Bear Stearns appeared optimistic about its prospects a year before the rapidly growing subprime mortgage crisis caused the firm’s demise in March 2008.

headline: The Best Money Sites on the Web
text: The annual Webby Awards were announced on Tuesday and there were two categories that caught our eye here at Bucks, Banking/Bill Paying and Financial Services.For the second year in a row, Mint won for Best Financial Services Web site, and for the third year in a row it won the People’s Voice award. Mint, a personal finance Web site, beat CBS Moneywatch, which features video interviews with Jill Schlesinger; MicroPlace, a microfinance Web site; StockMapper, a site that specializes in stock heat maps; and wikinvest, an investment research portal.In the Banking/Bill Paying category, a money management site, moneyStrands, took the Webby, knocking last year’s winner Xero out of the category. The London-based online lender Wonga won the People’s Voice Award, which also went to Xero last year. The nominees in the category included The Morris Code, an interactive personal finance Web site sponsored by Bank of America and geared toward college students; Billeo, a bill paying site; and BillShrink.com, a Web site that scours the Internet for better deals on things like credit cards and cellphone plans.One additional note was in the Education category which nominated the Your Life, Your Money project. The project was produced by WNET-TV and Working Dog Productions and ran on the Public Broadcasting Service Web site.

headline: First and Foremost, a Mom
text: During this week before Mother’s Day, my bedside table is stacked high with stories that are directly or indirectly about mothers.

headline: Williamstown Theater Festival Names New Artistic Director
text: The Williamstown Theater Festival on Wednesday announced the appointment of its new artistic director: Jenny Gersten, a widely admired New York producer at the Public Theater who also worked as associate producer at Williamstown from 1996 to 2004.

headline: NATO and Europeans Plot Path Ahead
text: PARIS — An unusual online effort by NATO, the European Union, governments and research groups to ask a broader public for ideas on the future of Western security policy has produced a series of recommendations that call for NATO to develop a civilian arm and the European Union to create its own intelligence agency.

headline: Rick Owens | Making His Own Bed
text: The Paris-based fashion designer Rick Owens claims he fell into designing furniture simply because he needed something to sit on. And truth be told, the Art Deco and Robert Mallet-Stevens pieces he coveted were too big for his budget — and too polite in scale for the former French Socialist Party Headquarters that he now calls his home and office. “Like a typical American, I over-sized everything,” says Owens, a Los Angeles transplant. And he’s not kidding.

headline: Thinking Outside Rails and Runways, and Taking the Bus
text: DERRICK ROBERTS could drive, fly or ride the train on his weekly business trips to Washington from his home in Manhattan. Instead, he takes the bus, seemingly the least comfortable and most time-consuming of his commuting options.

headline: Cayne and Schwartz at Odds Over Bear’s Leverage
text: The former heads of Bear Stearns disagreed Wednesday afternoon over how much the firm’s huge reliance on borrowed money contributed to its demise, with James E. Cayne arguing that the firm was overleveraged, while Alan Schwartz, his successor as chief executive, arguing that the firm was adequately capitalized.

headline: 10 Days in a Carry-On
text: A flight attendant reveals her secrets on how to pack efficiently and wrinkle-free.

headline: Another Middle-Class Terror Suspect
text: On Wednesday a Reuters wire report on the background of Faisal Shahzad, the suspect in the Times Square bomb case, called him “educated and well-heeled.” That fact is stated as if it is something of a surprise that this young professional, a full-fledged citizen of Western society, might have attempted a terrorist attack. But haven’t educated sons of privilege been behind almost every recent terror attack on the West?

headline: New Woodward Book
text: Bob Woodward, the prominent investigative reporter, will have a new book on the Obama presidency in September, just two months before the midterm elections. The book will be released by Simon & Schuster, Mr. Woodward’s longtime publisher. Tracey Guest, a spokesperson for the publisher, said she had no other information about the content, and that it did not yet have a title. Mr. Woodward, whose reporting with Carl Bernstein on Watergate for The Washington Post first brought him prominence, is one of the few writers in recent years whose political books have consistently altered the talking points in Washington. The storyline in his four books about President George W. Bush’s administration changed dramatically, as the first one, “Bush at War,” described Mr. Bush as a strong leader and the third, “State of Denial,” described the administration’s troubles in handling the war in Iraq, a story continued in “The War Within,” the final Bush installment.

headline: Smartphones to Travel With
text: Here are three smart handsets that make good traveling companions:

headline: Where Kosher Beckons the Cool Crowd
text: Imagine kashrut — Jewish dietary law — as a kid in an elementary school. It would probably take on the role of hall monitor, enforcing restrictive rules that may or may not be important to the authorities: Sayonara, shrimp! Ciao, cheeseburgers! And for the love of G-d, stay away from pork!

headline: Has Apple Lost Its Cool?
text: On Tuesday I talked with John Berman, an ABC News correspondent, about Apple’s current image in the media, and with its fans and customers.

headline: Extra Innings and the Road Prove to Be Unfriendly Territory for the Mets
text: CINCINNATI — Extra-inning games have been treacherous for the Mets this season. The only one they won lasted 20 innings and left them exhausted. On Wednesday, they made it to the bottom of the 10th when Orlando Cabrera hit a solo shot off Pedro Feliciano to give the Cincinnati Reds a 5-4 victory and a second game-winning home run in extra innings in this three-game series.

headline: Would You Like Accessories With That iPad?
text: When Apple began selling the first iPods, millions of people were delighted with its ease of use. You’d pay for the songs you downloaded from iTunes and what else would you need?

headline: Look What I Bought (or Got Free)
text: MELISSA ROSE PONCE DE LEON, a 19-year-old bartender from the Bronx, had just gone shopping. When she got home she sat in her tiny peach-colored room, leaned into her Web cam and held up her swag: a few MAC lipsticks, a glittery black V-neck top, a snake bracelet and a new pair of Ugg boots.

headline: Another Auction, Another Trophy
text: Whatever the state of the global economy, there’s always a ton of discretionary cash floating around looking for someplace to land. Tuesday night at Christie’s a chunk of it — $106.5 million to be exact — landed on a Picasso painting called “Nude, Green Leaves and Bust,” setting a record for art sold at auction.

headline: Suspect Was Tracked Through Phone Numbers
text: WASHINGTON — Investigators discovered the name of the suspect in the failed Times Square bombing because of a telephone number he provided when he returned to the United States from Pakistan in February, a law enforcement official said Wednesday.

headline: Submit Your Photos of Election Day in the U.K.
text: The Lede will be live-blogging the vote count in the United Kingdom on Thursday and we would like to hear from readers who will be taking part in the election. Please send us your thoughts or, better yet, submit a photograph documenting your experience of the day, by e-mailing it to pix@nyt.com.

headline: Another Victory, and Another Injury
text: Aside from the struggles of Javier Vazquez, little has troubled the Yankees’ starting pitchers this season.

headline: Providing Loans Based on Cash Flow, Not Credit Score
text: With the recession having left many banks reluctant to lend, small businesses have struggled to find other sources of credit. One intriguing alternative is On Deck Capital, which promises to revolutionize lending to small businesses.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Athens and Elsewhere
text: Aris Messinis of Agence France-Presse, whose photograph from Athens begins Wednesday’s report, has been published frequently in Pictures of the Day recently.

headline: Is This the Way to Get Credit to Small Businesses?
text: In a small-business conversation we’ve just published, Mitch Jacobs, founder and chief executive of On Deck Capital, talks about what he hopes will be a revolutionary new  approach to getting credit to small businesses. Among those who believe in the approach are James D. Robinson III, former chairman and chief executive of American Express, and Alan Blinder, an economist and former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, both of whom serve on On Deck’s board.

headline: The Way We Were
text: Mike Konczal has an interesting post on how Wall Street and the role of the SEC were perceived in the late 1970s: back then, the securities abuses of the pre-New-Deal era were viewed as archaic evils, no longer part of the modern world thanks to effective regulation. Today, of course, regulation has been degraded, and the abuses are back in earnest.

headline: Answers About Etiquette in New York
text: Following is the first set of responses from Lyudmila Bloch, an international etiquette expert, protocol consultant and author of “The Golden Rules of Etiquette at the Plaza.”

headline: G.M. Recruits Marketing Executive From Nissan
text: After only a couple of months with Nissan North America, the marketing executive Joel Ewanick is headed for Detroit to help with the rebuilding of General Motors brands. Mr. Ewanick has been named vice president for  United States marketing, effective May 24, and will report directly to G.M. North America’s president, Mark Reuss.

headline: Some Are Partying Like It’s 2006
text: The year was 2006. That summer, Fidel Castro relinquished his control (temporarily) over Cuba. “The Da Vinci Code” was captivating audiences around the globe. And Kevin Richardson broke a million hearts by leaving the Backstreet Boys.

headline: Borat’s Designer Redresses Art
text: It’s fitting that Jason Alper’s first art show opened just blocks from the Dolce & Gabbana boutique on West Hollywood’s Robertson Boulevard. As the costume designer for the movie “Bruno,” (as well the Sacha Baron Cohen characters, “Ali G” and “Borat”), the London-based Alper has put the comedian in all sorts of outrageous get-ups — including a velcro suit for the Milan runway as well as accessorizing a National Guard uniform with a D & G belt, claiming the look on its own is just too “matchy-matchy.”

headline: House Republicans Criticize Response to Oil Spill
text: House Republicans pointedly questioned the speed of the Obama administration’s response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the day after British Petroleum executives said the ruptured well could spew sweet crude into the surrounding water 10 times faster than initially estimated.

headline: At Hotels, Making Wi-Fi as Standard as a Bed
text: FOR Yael Smadja and business travelers like her, a Wi-Fi connection in a hotel is nonnegotiable.

headline: Senate Voting on Regulation Amendments
text: The Senate has finally started voting on amendments to the financial regulatory legislation.

headline: U.C. Berkeley Drops Charges Against Some Students
text: After months of pursuing charges against students involved in the large-scale campus demonstrations last fall, the University of California, Berkeley has dropped charges against dozens of them. At the same time, it is undertaking an extensive review of its procedure for investigating and charging students.

headline: Pastor Involved in Job Scheme Is Back in New York
text: The Rev. Isidro Bolaños, a Brooklyn pastor who persuaded hundreds of people to hand over copies of their personal records through false offers of employment at an apparently nonexistent social service agency, has returned to New York, according to three men who say they confronted him this week.

headline: Shrimpers, Not Oil? A Dead Turtle Inquiry
text: About 35 endangered sea turtles have washed up dead on beaches along the Gulf of Mexico since Sunday, sowing fears that they were done in by the growing oil spill.

headline: Newsweek: Between The Week, Slate, and The Economist, Not Much Room for a Storied Brand
text: What do the Brits know that we don’t about publishing weeklies in America? The Week and The Economist, both owned by British publishing companies, continue to grow even as it was announced today that Newsweek is up for sale with very meager prospects.

headline: Greek End Game
text: Many commentators now believe that Greece will end up restructuring its debt — a euphemism for partial repudiation. I agree. But the reasoning seems to stop there, which is wrong. In effect, the consensus that Greece will end up defaulting is probably too optimistic. I’m growing increasingly convinced that Greece will end up leaving the euro, too.

headline: Nascar Rolls Out a Museum
text: How do you take a car race and make it interesting as a museum? Let the people drive.

headline: Shortcuts Define Self-Service Travel
text: TRAVELERS have accepted a trade-off in the do-it-yourself era: embracing the self-service technologies that airlines, hotels and car rental companies have developed in exchange for lower prices.

headline: Back on the Road, but on a Shoestring
text: BUSINESS travel has often been depicted with a dash of style and adventure. Think of Eva Marie Saint in “North by Northwest,” the various James Bond movies, or George Clooney in “Up in the Air.”

headline: Need a Little Nap in the Terminal? Get a Room!
text: NEVER have so many travelers needed a collective nap as they did in April when the ill winds blew across Europe from a spewing Icelandic volcano.

headline: Downward-Facing Dog’s Life
text: WHEN the world of the business traveler turns upside down — whether because of a missed connecting flight, lost luggage or an uncooperative volcano — Steve Boerema knows just what to do.

headline: Apps That Remove Bumps in the Road
text: THE smartphone can be a nearly perfect travel companion, a chum that is helpful, entertaining and knowledgeable, does not complain and, incidentally, fits in your pocket.

headline: Packing Tips From Travel Pros
text: From the archives: Here’s one of our favorite stories with helpful tips for Smarter Living.

headline: Air Security Gets Faster, but at Price of Privacy
text: WASHINGTON

headline: For Some Plying the Road, Two Wheels Are Plenty
text: PICTURE a Hollywood agent powering to a power lunch. “Entourage” has done it for us: an expensive convertible, an iPhone and dialogue devoted equally to schmoozing and screaming.

headline: Beaming Into the Big Meeting
text: FALLOUT from a recession and ash from a volcano drove more companies than ever to try videoconferencing. Once the skies clear on both fronts, will it be time to plan more business trips or will virtual meetings continue to get the job done?

headline: Food to Grab and Go, With Flair
text: WITH a Javits Center trade show scheduled to take up the majority of his day last month, Allen Marko, director of technical and plant operations for Obagi Medical Products, had no time to stop for a bite.

headline: A Swiss Secret, Tucked Away in the Alps
text: IMAGINE a mountain landscape speckled with rustic villages whose residents speak an ancient, isolated language. Centuries-old stone dwellings with mysterious renderings of wild men and mountain goats are etched into white facades. Panoramic views are so clear and stunning you have to rub your eyes to make sure you’re not in a Hollywood epic.

headline: Help in Shaving Minutes Off Your Underground Commute
text: A question for New Yorkers: How much would you pay for another 10 minutes with your family after work?

headline: Update on an Addicted Child
text: Last June, I ran a guest post from Janice Lynn Schuster, about her daughter’s drug addiction and her own despair at not being able to help. After following Katie Granju’s vigil by her son, who was critically injured after an overdose and a drug-related assault, it seemed a good time to check in with Schuster for a look at life farther down the recovery road.

headline: The Echoes of an Execution Reverberate Loud and Clear
text: In a small Southern town during the Jim Crow era, a black man is accused of raping a white woman. During his stormy trial there are threats of lynching, as well as intimations that the white woman had been the sexual aggressor.

headline: New Woe for Goldman as Blankfein Defends Firm
text: Another day, another bit of bad news for Goldman Sachs — even as Lloyd C. Blankfein, its chief executive, tried to shore up the firm’s reputation.

headline: My Mannequin, Myself: What Talking Heads Say
text: IN 1936, a glamour girl named Cynthia became a minor toast of the town. She went around with a guy named Lester, who took her to all the showoff places — the opera, El Morocco — and the next year she made the cover of Life. Cynthia would get fan mail, but if anyone ever got a reply, it was guaranteed to come from Lester.

headline: Rahm Emanuel Is Losing a Key Aide
text: Despite his reputation for hard-charging and profanity-spiced intensity, Rahm Emanuel has long kept a circle of loyal aides, both as a congressman and now as White House chief of staff. But he is about to lose the adviser who has been closest to him: Sarah Feinberg is leaving to join Bloomberg L.P. as a communications strategist.

headline: CUNY Imposes Cutoff for Freshmen Applications
text: Faced with record enrollments, the City University of New York has decided to place prospective freshmen whose applications arrive after Friday on a waiting list. It is the first time in memory that CUNY will impose an across-the-board cutoff for applications to its 11 senior colleges and six community colleges.

headline: Financial Tuneup: Spend Your Gift Cards
text: All of us need to take some time every so often to knock things off our financial to-do list. To help, we’ve created a series of articles and an interactive checklist to get you started.

headline: Bangs Like Justin’s (but Don’t Say So)
text: WHEN a boy of a certain age asks Cozy Friedman, the owner of Cozy’s Cuts for Kids in Manhattan, for a haircut with long, side-combed bangs, she is careful not to ask, “like Justin Bieber’s?”

headline: Bear’s Ex-Bosses ‘Shocked’ by Firm’s Collapse
text: The former bosses of Bear Stearns said Wednesday afternoon that they did not believe their firm was too big to fail or too big to manage and that they were “shocked” when it suddenly collapsed in March 2008.

headline: Works Made on the Wings of Inspiration
text: Deadlines, poverty and ambition have long been motivating factors for composers, as for many artists. But according to the program book for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s concert at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, the featured works were not driven by prosaic concerns but composed “on wings of pure inspiration.”

headline: Trying to Keep Up as the World Turns
text: It seemed that all but one in Tuesday night’s audience at the Baryshnikov Arts Center greeted “Gaff Aff,” the American debut of the Swiss duo Zimmermann & de Perrot, with rapt attention and ardent applause. I was, alas, the exception.

headline: Haim Saban Goes Into Brand Management
text: The media investor Haim Saban is moving into brand management and licensing. The Saban Capital Group will plow $500 million into Saban Brands, a new company dedicated to acquiring entertainment and consumer brands and exploiting them through retail, television and film channels.

headline: Flying Low, but Staying on Folk’s Radar
text: Josh Ritter has a way with metaphor. It’s one of the literary touches in his music that have established him among the cream of the young singer-songwriter crop, and it is all over his albums: romantic diplomacy in a missile silo; Columbus’s doomed fourth ship; a mummy whose curse is the realization that love is mortal.

headline: F.C.C. Push to Regulate Broadband Is Expected
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission will try to regulate broadband Internet service despite a recent court ruling that the commission had limited powers to do so.

headline: Russo & Steele Sues Tent Company
text: Classic cars weren’t the only things damaged when storms blew down the tents at the Russo & Steele auction in Scottsdale, Ariz., in January. The president of Russo & Steele, Drew Alcazar, said his company sustained serious damage — financially and to its image — and has filed a lawsuit against the tent provider, Tri-Rentals, in an effort to recoup at least the financial portion of those losses.

headline: Bon Appétit! Yelp Goes to France.
text: Expect to see more reviews of baguettes with brie and Bordeaux wine bars on Yelp. The site for local business ratings and reviews has opened in France at Yelp.fr.

headline: Shopping With Anna Sui
text: The fashion designer, who has put butterflies on her clothing, jewelry and cosmetics packaging, shopped for furnishings with a butterfly motif.

headline: A Drive for All Seasons
text: For computer users, Seagate has taken the concept of mix and match to a higher level.

headline: Who Was the High-Rolling Picasso Buyer?
text: It’s hard to ignore the $106.5 million price tag attached to the Picasso piece whose sale on Tuesday is the biggest-ever price tag for a work of art sold at auction.

headline: A Spirited Mood Conveyed by Both Soloist and Ensemble
text: The path to success as a classical musician is often narrow, with intense study from early childhood through conservatory training. Ryu Goto, a 21-year-old Japanese-American violinist and the younger brother of the violinist Midori, is taking a broader approach, balancing a busy performing career with full-time undergraduate studies at Harvard, where he is a physics major.

headline: Here’s the Dash... Hold On, What’s a Dash?
text: As the barrage of advertising should make quite clear, the new Sony Dash is here.

headline: Honoring a Mentor, Muse and Colleague All in One
text: The four composers who started Red Light New Music in 2005 intended the organization, with its resident ensemble, to be an outlet for works of their own and of like-minded colleagues. But its concert on Tuesday evening at the Leonard Nimoy Thalia at Symphony Space was a 60th birthday tribute to Nils Vigeland. All four Red Light founders were composition students of Mr. Vigeland, who supported their endeavor from the start and has composed several works for it.

headline: Two Days, Two Field-Running Fans, No Trend Yet
text: Despite consecutive incidents at Philadelphia’s Citizen Bank Park involving fans who ran onto the playing field during Phillies games, Major League Baseball is not yet reconsidering game security.

headline: Notebook: Yankees Ready to Take to the Rails
text: The Yankees are off Thursday before opening a three-game series in Boston on Friday night. They will travel Thursday by railroad — in a private three-car train — from New Rochelle, N.Y.

headline: Greek Protests Claim First Fatalities
text: Three people were reported to have died inside a bank building set ablaze by protesters during demonstrations against tough new austerity measures in Greece.

headline: How to Move Your Own Documents to Kindle
2 Votes Break Logjam on Financial Overhaul Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday approved two amendments to the financial regulatory bill that both Democrats and Republicans claimed would end the prospect of taxpayer-financed bailouts for companies deemed “too big to fail.”

headline: Balmy Microsoft ‘Commercial’
text: Video | From a PC World collection of funny old tech ads and promos:

headline: Song Visions, Large Scale and Small
text: Since founding the New York Festival of Song in 1988 the pianists Steven Blier and Michael Barrett have mostly avoided presenting complete song cycles. They prefer to mix and match diverse selections in imaginatively themed programs.

headline: Eco Labels and Dietary Advice
text: THIS has been the spring for looking back on American fashion, from the “American Beauty” show at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology that closed last month to the “American Woman” and “American High Style” companion exhibitions at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Brooklyn Museum. Amid this jingoist spirit, it would be easy to overlook a tiny show that opened Wednesday at Scandinavia House in Midtown to cheer the fashions of Sweden.

headline: 2 Votes Break Logjam on Financial Overhaul Bill
text: The Senate on Wednesday approved two amendments to the financial regulatory bill that both Democrats and Republicans claimed would end the prospect of taxpayer-financed bailouts for companies deemed “too big to fail.”

headline: Hopscotching the World in Headlines
text: On an epochal day in 2007 the newspaper staff in “The Imperfectionists” must deal with a huge story. “Thankfully,” Tom Rachman writes, “most of the editorial staffers are occupied piecing together copy on a shooting at Virginia Tech” when the other story, the really big one, breaks.

headline: A Pitch-Perfect Trip From Folk Days to 9/11
text: Her silver-blonde hair cascading around a face whose wide blue eyes inspired Crosby, Stills and Nash’s famous “Suite: Judy Blue Eyes,” Judy Collins cut a resplendent figure on Tuesday evening at the Café Carlyle, where she began her fourth season. Ms. Collins turned 71 on Saturday, but you would never know it from the unalloyed purity of her soprano. Her slightly unworldly voice is still an instrument that evokes angelic visions in an imaginary cathedral or a shaft of moonlight settling on a lake whose waters are barely quivering.

headline: Captured Leader Offers Insight Into the Taliban
text: WASHINGTON — Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar, the most senior Afghan Taliban leader in custody in Pakistan, is providing important information to American officials on the inner workings of the Taliban, pivotal insights as the United States looks ahead to negotiations to end the war in Afghanistan, according to senior American intelligence and military officials.

headline: France Won’t Extradite Iranian Sought by U.S.
text: PARIS — A French court on Wednesday refused an American request to extradite an Iranian businessman accused of violating an American embargo on exports to Iran. He had raised American suspicions by buying equipment for a front company in Malaysia that was then shipped secretly to Iranian military firms involved in Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: New Assistant Takes Over as Hofstra Basketball Coach
text: A tumultuous off-season for college basketball in the New York metropolitan area has yielded its share of bizarre coaches’ stories, from the implosion of Fred Hill at Rutgers to the arrest of Hofstra’s newly hired Tim Welsh to the rebirth of Steve Lavin at St. John’s.

headline: The Detective Who Spotted the Crucial Number
text: Detective John Wright was at home on Saturday night, rebuilding a bathroom, when the call came in: A smoke-filled vehicle in Times Square needed to be identified.

headline: New Orleans Asks U.S. to Help Police Department
text: NEW ORLEANS — Citing the need for “transformational change,” the city’s new mayor, Mitch Landrieu, announced on Wednesday that he was inviting the Justice Department to help restructure the troubled New Orleans Police Department.

headline: Suspect’s Gun Proved Easy to Obtain
text: The mammoth clock-to-wire-to-gasoline-to-propane car bomb that the authorities said Faisal Shahzad hoped would claim many lives in Times Square has been analyzed, diagrammed, prodded and examined. But not long before his arrest, Mr. Shahzad was also equipped with a less-eccentric — and yet more dependably lethal — weapon. And he owned it legally.

headline: Challenges Abound in 2-Week Tribute
text: The pianist Chick Corea, who always seems up for a challenge, is taking on another one. It’s not some region of music that’s new to him, or some techniquey Everest. It’s not even especially Bill Evans, although his music lies at the center of the jazz tradition over the last half-century and is the pretext for Mr. Corea’s current gig. The challenge is the drummer Paul Motian.

headline: On the Inside
text: At the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute ball, borrowed finery and a dinner no one has any intention of eating are the norm.

headline: War Zone Traumas Restaged at Home
text: SAN FRANCISCO — During her yearlong tour of duty in Iraq Maj. Elizabeth A. Condon saw all manner of horror and heartbreak, from dead bodies in the street and memorials for fallen friends to “little babies with holes in their backs.”

headline: War Stories, Restaged
text: Jennifer Karady’s photographs of veterans, on view in San Francisco, put a surreal twist on their war memories.

headline: Conjuring a Conjurer of Movement and Light
text: Alwin Nikolais was the magician of dance, the forerunner of now wildly popular companies like Pilobolus and Momix and a pioneer in multimedia effects. From the 1950s to the 1990s his work was celebrated both in the United States and internationally (he was particularly popular in France), and his company continued to perform for several years after his death, in 1993.

headline: Heart Surgery for Former Iowa Governor
text: Former Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad, who is among the Republicans across the country who are running again for their old offices this year, underwent heart surgery today. He is challenging Gov. Chet Culver, a Democrat, in one of the races that Republicans are among the most enthusiastic about.

headline: What Britain Should Hope For
text: On the eve of the British election, David Frum offers the case for optimism about David Cameron:

headline: Callup for Young Red Bulls Player
text: Juan Agudelo is going to Europe. … No, not jumping ship from the Red Bulls to a new club, but as part of the United States under-20 national team.

headline: ‘Idol’ Croons the Blues
text: Fox’s “American Idol” slid further in the ratings on Tuesday as the top 5 contestants performed ballads by Frank Sinatra. “Idol” drew 17.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates, down considerably from the nearly 30 million viewers who tuned in to the season premiere in January, but enough for Fox to finish No. 1 for the night. But “Idol” hit its lowest rating among 18-to-49-year-old viewers, the most-valued group by many advertisers (and most networks), since its first summer season on the air. CBS placed second for the night over all, with “NCIS” (14.8 million), “NCIS: Los Angeles” (14.2 million) and “The Good Wife” (12.9 million). ABC finished third, and NBC was fourth.

headline: Kilborn Is Returning
text: Craig Kilborn, the original host of “The Daily Show” and then a late-night host for CBS on its 12:35 a.m. “Late Late Show,” is about to return to television in a show for 20th Television, the syndication arm of Fox’s television stations. The show in development would not be a late-night show, according to executives who are aware of the proposed deal. But a memo sent by the show’s producer, seeking staff members, described it as a combination of a talk show and a “nonpolitical ‘Daily Show.’ ” The new show is likely to get a trial run on Fox stations this summer. It could be a daytime entry, along the lines of syndicated entertainment shows like the one hosted by Ellen DeGeneres.

headline: Flooding Damages Home of Nashville Symphony
text: Floodwaters in Nashville seriously damaged one of the city’s newest cultural gems, the Schermerhorn Symphony Center, above, home of the Nashville Symphony Orchestra. Disaster was averted when water that had filled the basement reached within a cello’s thickness — roughly five inches — of the concert hall after the Cumberland River crested, Alan D. Valentine, the symphony’s president and chief executive, said on Wednesday. The flooding caused the loss of two Steinway grand pianos, valued at more than $100,000 each. It also engulfed the console and blower room for the hall’s $2.5 million organ. The pipes — the costliest part of the organ — are in the hall and so were spared. In addition, concrete flooring in a storage area for the hall’s removable seats buckled and will have to be replaced. “It was like a river was running through our basement,” Mr. Valentine said. He said other sites will be found for the season’s remaining few concerts and for the summer series. Mr. Valentine said he hoped the hall, which opened in 2006, would be restored in time for next season.

headline: ‘Lost’ Finale Grows by 30 Minutes
text: ABC’s send-off for “Lost” is starting to seem as long as a flight on Oceanic Airlines, not that its fans will mind. The network is extending the finale by half an hour, giving the producers two and a half hours in all, and delaying local newscasts that night, May 23. A total of seven and a half hours of “Lost” is planned that weekend, according to ABC’s schedule. First the network will rerun the two-hour pilot on May 22, at 8 p.m. Then on May 23, “Lost” takes over the schedule, starting with a two-hour look back at 7 p.m. The finale starts at 9. Then at 12:05 a.m., Jimmy Kimmel will host a special episode of “Jimmy Kimmel Live” titled “Aloha to ‘Lost,’ ” featuring alternative endings to the show and appearances by the producers.

headline: Young Rapper On Top
text: Justin Bieber is not the only young protégé of a big Atlanta star to hit No. 1 on the Billboard album chart lately. B.o.B., a smooth-voiced 21-year-old under the wing of the rapper T. I., reached the top spot this week with his debut album, “B.o.B. Presents: The Adventures of Bobby Ray” (Rebel Rock/Grand Hustle/Atlantic), which sold 84,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. (B.o.B., whose real name is Bobby Ray Simmons, has had help from more than just T. I. to make his pop crossover: the album also features Eminem, Rivers Cuomo of Weezer and Hayley Williams of Paramore.) The pop-country group Lady Antebellum held at No. 2 with 76,000 sales of “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville), and Bullet for My Valentine  opened at No. 3 with its new album, “Fever” (Jive), which sold 71,000. Mr. Bieber’s “My World 2.0” (Interscope) dropped one spot to No. 4, with 69,000, while “Raymond vs. Raymond” (Jive) by Mr. Bieber’s Atlanta mentor, Usher, fell one to No. 6, with 48,000. AC/DC’s “Iron Man 2” (Columbia), a collection of old hits released in conjunction with the new film, was No. 5, with 52,000.

headline: A ‘Gift’ For Bloomberg
text: At its spring gala on Tuesday evening, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts paid tribute to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg with an unusual gift. The center will move its Calder sculpture, “Le Guichet” (“The Box Office”), right, for 90 days to any place in New York City the mayor chooses. In his remarks Mr. Bloomberg said that his first deputy mayor, Patricia E. Harris, would find a good place for it. Ms. Harris said on Wednesday that a site had yet to be determined. The sculpture, made of black steel plate, sits on the north plaza outside the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. It was presented to Lincoln Center in 1965.

headline: Honors and the End for ‘Temperamentals’
text: Despite winning a Lucille Lortel Award  for Michael Urie as outstanding lead actor  “The Temperamentals,” a play about five closeted gay men who built a pre-Stonewall gay rights group, will close on May 30 after three months of performances, its producers said on Wednesday. This Off Broadway production, written by Jon Marans and directed by Jonathan Silverstein, was one of about 10 major plays and musicals featuring gay characters and gay love stories that opened in New York this season. Unlike most of the other shows, “The Temperamentals” had only gay characters  all closeted at first  and threaded a love story between its leading men with a deep examination of the social, political and professional consequences of being gay in the 1950s. The Drama Desk Awards organization will present the five-man cast with an outstanding ensemble performance award this month.

headline: Yankees-Mariners to Be in 3-D
text: The Yankees will be the stars of the latest sports test of 3-D production when the YES Network  collaborates with DirecTV to produce two Yankees-Mariners games from Seattle in July using the burgeoning technology.

headline: Inside, Vertical Gardens
text: A look inside homes with walls on which plants grow.

headline: New York Military Academy
text: Photographs from one of the last military academies, which is suspending operations at the end of the school year.

headline: Rules, Revolving Doors and the Oil Industry
text: A BP executive told members of Congress on Tuesday that the ruptured oil well in the Gulf of Mexico could potentially spill as much as 60,000 barrels a day, more than 10 times the current estimate. With the spill growing worse by the day, questions about the adequacy and effectiveness of offshore drilling regulations have become more urgent.

headline: An Idiosyncratic Apartment in the Village
text: Kenny White, a musician, lives under the eaves, in a small, top-floor space strewn with instruments.

headline: Furniture and Lighting at Donzella 20th Century Gallery
text: For more than 20 years, Roberto Giulio Rida has been known as the go-to dealer in Milan for 20th-century Italian decorative arts.

headline: Butterfly-Patterned Furnishings
text: WHEN butterflies began appearing on home furnishings recently, the fashion designer Anna Sui wasn’t surprised.

headline: Kenny Scharf’s Chair at Auction. Those Lips and Eyes!
text: THE artist Kenny Scharf’s contribution to Unframed, the art auction held in Manhattan last week by ACRIA, the AIDS Community Research Initiative of America, was a duck-yellow B&B Italia chair he had ornamented with red lips and big blue cartoon eyes. The guest we thought would have the greatest affinity for it was a tall woman in a black tutu, whose lean upper body and long white-stockinged legs gave her a birdlike air.

headline: Intérieurs Furniture Moves to East Side
text: After 14 years downtown, Intérieurs, the TriBeCa furniture store, has moved to a new showroom on the East Side. “I was nervous about it,” said Francine Gardner, the owner. “But in this space, people seem to be looking at the furniture in a different way.” The 2,800-square-foot showroom, which is open to the public, is spread over two stories, with an additional 1,000 square feet of outdoor space — an ideal place for showing furniture and accessories for both indoors and out.

headline: Auction Set at Kluge Estate in Virginia
text: On June 8 and 9, Sotheby’s will auction the contents of Albemarle House, the 45-room neo-Georgian country home of Patricia Kluge, the philanthropist and vintner, near Charlottesville, Va. The two-day auction will be held in a ballroom on Mrs. Kluge’s estate, which is down the road from Thomas Jefferson’s Monticello.

headline: The Arc Table Designed by Foster & Partners
text: The new Arc table designed by Foster & Partners, the London architecture firm, achieves its bold looks by way of innovative materials. The tabletop (available in four sizes) is made of glass with a low iron content, so it appears completely clear (rather than slightly greenish, like most glass tabletops); an etched edge makes it look as if it’s floating. The base, which comes in white, mid-gray and dark gray, is made of Ductal, a material known for its exceptional tensile strength and its amenability to molding. “We wanted the table’s base to mimic the natural flow of lines created by tensile structures,” said John Small, who led the design team. “We’d been looking at Ductal for a while, and finally found the perfect application for it.” The table sells for $4,940 to $5,415 at the Molteni & C Dada Unifor flagship store, 60 Greene Street (Spring Street); information: (212) 673-7106 or molteni.it.

headline: Gardens That Grow on Walls
text: GIVEN the chance to accompany a team of botanists on a plant-collecting expedition to South America, most gardeners would probably be satisfied with the experience. They wouldn’t come home and try to recreate the rain forest in Manhattan.

headline: 20 Smartphone Apps for the Home and Garden
text: FOR a device that is designed to be used while on the go, the smartphone turns out to be a surprisingly adept aid to anyone working on a home or garden. And with mobile applications now numbering in the hundreds of thousands, the question is not “Are there apps out there to help my renovation/garden project/home-repair project?” but “Which ones?” Below, 20 mobile tools that will help make your smartphone a better “home” computer than, well, your home computer.

headline: Sales of Tibetan Rugs and Clodagh Design
text: Gary Cruz, an interior designer, is offering 20 percent off his new collection of hand-knotted Tibetan rugs through May 30 (the 8-by-10-foot Times Red wool-and-silk rug, above left, regularly $6,400, is $5,120). Information: (212) 243-3250 or garycruzstudio.com.

headline: In Greenwich Village, a Songwriter’s Garret
text: “THEY just played me on the radio — I could have impressed you,” the singer and songwriter Kenny White says, after this reporter, courting coronary collapse, hoofs it up four listing sets of stairs to his apartment on the top floor of one of Greenwich Village’s most idiosyncratic buildings.

headline: A Singer Comes Out; Now Will Nashville Let Her Back In?
text: By the time the country singer Chely Wright appeared on “Today” Wednesday morning, the secret was out. This minor star of the 1990s and early 2000s was coming out as a lesbian. During her early years in Nashville, “I knew that I needed to hide this to achieve my dreams,” she told the host Natalie Morales.

headline: Welcome to the Club
text: THE live 35-foot birch trees were shipped in from Aspen. The couture dresses were brought by couriers from Italy and France. The English movie people flew commercial from London. The American stars hitched rides on private aircraft with friends from Los Angeles. Somehow or other, heeding advice from the evening’s hostess to be prompt at 6:30 for cocktails, the glittering horde arrived punctually at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the annual Costume Institute ball. Or almost everyone did.

headline: Bold Brass and Glass, and the World Inside on Display
text: Change comes slowly, at least psychologically, to Greenwich Village, which, despite the double-decker tourist buses and the crowds (still) lining up for cupcakes in front of the Magnolia Bakery, persists in thinking of itself as a sleepy bohemian enclave.

headline: Woodward on Obama
text: Bob Woodward, the investigative reporter, will come out with a book on the Obama presidency in September, just two months before the midterm elections. The book will be released by Simon & Schuster, Mr. Woodward’s longtime publisher. Tracey Guest, a spokeswoman for the publisher, said she had no information about the contents, and that the book did not yet have a title. Mr. Woodward, above, whose reporting with Carl Bernstein on Watergate first brought him prominence, is one of the few writers in recent years whose political books have consistently altered the talking points in Washington. The story line in his four books about the George W. Bush administration changed dramatically, as the first one, “Bush at War,” described President Bush as a strong leader, and the third and fourth, “State of Denial” and “The War Within, described the administration’s troubles in handling the war in Iraq.

headline: A Folly, and Other High Spirits
text: The folia, an ancient Iberian dance, is said to have been frenzied and wild, in keeping with its namesake, folly. But the tune most often associated with the folia is wise, mournful and stately. It began to be recycled by composers in the 16th century and has since been woven into innumerable scores by Vivaldi, Corelli, Rachmaninoff and others.

headline: Facebook Glitch Brings New Privacy Worries
text: For many users of Facebook, the world’s largest social network, it was just the latest in a string of frustrations.

headline: Al Qaeda’s Nuclear Plant
text: Davidsonville, Md.

headline: Greek Parliament Passes Austerity Measures
text: ATHENS — The Greek Parliament passed a package of tough austerity measures on Thursday, trying to stave off economic collapse and help prevent debt contagion from spreading.

headline: Recovering From Corporate Default May Not Be Too Hard
text: Last June, analysts at Moody’s published a report examining whether recoveries on corporate debt defaults during the most recent cycle could be lower than the historical norm.

headline: Listen Up, but Good
text: S INCE the job of club D.J. seems to be every unemployed hipster’s fallback position, it was only a matter of time before headphones moved from the clubs to the street. Buyers looking to update their white ear buds — or just walk around the city with these accessories rakishly worn around the neck — can check out looks at AC Gears. The store stocks 14 colors of Urbanears Plattan ($59.99) and the Zumreed Dreams popular gold mirror model ($65.99). The AiAiAi Tracks Headset ($69.99) has a throwback shape with updated pop colors. (The explanatory card on the wall by the display model reads: “Remember those iconic Walkman headphones from last century?”) AC Gears, 106 Greenwich Avenue (at Jane Street), (212) 741-2106 (pictured), and 69 East Eighth Street, (212) 260-2269; acgears.com.

headline: As the Cavendish Begins, a Look Back to 2009
text: The Cavendish Invitational tournament began in Henderson, Nev., on Wednesday and will end on Sunday. The first event is the John Roberts Teams, the defending champions being Jim Mahaffey, Mike Passell, Sam Lev, Jacek (Pepsi) Pszczola, Fu Zhong and Jie Zhao.

headline: Built Upon a Link Worth Noting
text: THIS chunky chain necklace ($20) is a collaboration between Marc Jacobs and Maripol, a designer and stylist in the 1980s for Debbie Harry, Grace Jones and Madonna in her  “Like a Virgin”  incarnation. In an e-mail message from Japan, Maripol said the original necklace, worn by Madonna, was a “mix of punk style with dog collar.”

headline: Looking Back on a Great Week, and a 2nd-Place Finish
text: Paul Goydos, 45, has won two PGA Tour events, the 1996 Bay Hill Invitational and the 2007 Sony Open in Hawaii. He probably is best known for his plucky performance in a near-win: the 2008 Players Championship, which he lost to Sergio García in a sudden-death playoff. His Everyman demeanor and cool performance under pressure that week have helped make him a fan favorite. A 1988 graduate of Long Beach State University with a degree in Finance, Goydos is in his 19th year on tour. He is a member of the 16-member PGA Tour’s Player Advisory Council.

headline: A Bank’s Ads, Dressed Up in Historical Garb
text: EARLY in the first installment of “America: The Story of Us,” the 12-hour documentary series on the History cable channel that began on April 25 and covers 400 years of United States history, an actor depicting a British soldier bumps into another depicting Paul Revere, and the narrator Liev Schreiber says, “When revolution comes to North America, Revere will be at the center of it.”

headline: For Stepping Across a Bridge
text: A COMMON predicament for women is what shoes to wear in the irksome fashion season that falls between winter boots and summer sandals. The answer may be this turquoise pump, a collaboration between the nautical shoe company Sperry Top-Sider and Jeffrey Kalinsky of Jeffrey New York.

headline: CBS Posts Smaller Loss in Quarter
text: The CBS Corporation on Wednesday joined other media companies that are climbing out of the crater created by the recession.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Facebook Privacy
text: This week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast takes a look at Facebook’s new features for sharing information. They’ve set off concerns among privacy advocates and some elected officials. Bettina Edelstein speaks with Kurt Opsahl, a senior staff attorney at the Electronic Frontier Foundation, an online civil liberties group. He says it’s getting harder, and more complicated, to use Facebook’s privacy settings, and he objects to the site making personal data public by default.

headline: Freddie Mac Seeks Billions More After Big Loss
text: Freddie Mac is asking for $10.6 billion in additional federal aid after posting a big loss in the first three months of the year, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Time Warner Reports Gain of 9.8%, Beating Forecasts
text: Time Warner reported a 9.8 percent increase in earnings on Wednesday, beating expectations and providing more evidence that the largest media companies were rebounding.

headline: Waiting at the Top of the World
text: Katmandu, Nepal

headline: What We’re Reading: Cellphone Calls
text: What the New York Times tech reporters and editors have been reading the last couple of days:

headline: In Blow to Democrats, Influential Congressman Will Retire After Four Decades
text: WASHINGTON — Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the third-most senior member of the House and chairman of the Appropriations Committee, announced Wednesday that he was retiring after four decades in Congress, a decision that reflected both a generational shift and the difficult political environment for Democrats.

headline: A Cinco de Mayo Message From Obama
text: President Obama told several hundred Hispanics at the annual White House fiesta for Cinco de Mayo that “I want to begin work this year” on a comprehensive immigration law, reassuring them that he wants Congress to take up the issue even if it cannot be resolved in this election year.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: Congress, Up in Arms
text: There seems to be a strong sentiment in Congress that the only constitutional right suspected terrorists have is the right to bear arms.

headline: Violence in Sudan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Senate Liberals Push for Strict Financial Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Liberal Democrats in the Senate, emboldened by a wave of populism, are trying to make financial regulatory legislation far tougher on Wall Street, potentially restricting or breaking up the biggest banks and financial companies.

headline: Patience
text: Update, May 17 | It is now possible to search the “Moment in Time” interactive gallery by the name given in the photographer’s credit line (actual name, pseudonym or screen name, as the contributor chose). You’ll find the search box in the upper right corner of the opening page. If you believe your picture wasn’t posted, we urge you to give this a try.

headline: Analyzing the Markets
text: KAREN E. SEIGER’S love of markets began when she worked in international aid in Africa, Latin America and Haiti. “In places like Mozambique, markets were the only place to shop,” she said. Now stateside, Ms. Seiger has turned her passion into a new guide called “Markets of New York City: A Guide to the Best Artisan, Farmer, Food and Flea Markets.” Last week, Ms. Seiger was at The Market NYC, also known as the Young Designers Market, an incubator for fresh talent at St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral Church in NoLIta. While there, she chatted with Wendel Johnston (at left), who attaches hoodies to vintage blazers, a process known as upcycling. “I love the designers who do what they do so brilliantly and with such a passion,” she said. The book, to be released on May 11, will be available at Idlewild Books, 12 West 19th Street (near Fifth Avenue), (212) 414-8888; idlewildbooks.com and amazon.com, $16.95.

headline: Bloggingheads: Obama's Day of Prayer
text: Amy Sullivan, left, of Time and David Gibson of Politics Daily debate the National Day of Prayer.

headline: ‘Los Suns’ Join Protest, Then Stop the Spurs
text: PHOENIX — The Phoenix Suns’ decision to wear “Los Suns” jerseys Wednesday — as a celebration of Cinco de Mayo and as a political statement in opposition to Arizona’s new law dealing with illegal immigrants — drove another wedge into the contentious debate here.

headline: Bold Stroke May Be Beyond Europe’s Means
text: Europe may need a broad cure to its debt crisis, but the increasingly awkward pairing of the European Union and the International Monetary Fund makes such action unlikely.

headline: Saving the Teachers
text: Last year’s $100 billion education stimulus plan insulated the public schools from the worst of the recession and saved an estimated 300,000 jobs. With the economy still lagging and states forced to slash their budgets, Congress must act again to prevent a wave of teacher layoffs that could damage the fragile recovery and hobble the school reform effort for years to come.

headline: Closing Stretch at Sawgrass Is Still Full of Thrills
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — It did not take long for the final three holes at T.P.C. Sawgrass to become part of golf lore. At the first Players Championship in 1982, Jerry Pate’s first act as champion was to throw the course architect and designer, Pete Dye, and the PGA Tour commissioner, Deane Beman, into the lake.

headline: A Golfer and a Slugger Find Common Ground
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Heather Crane recently scrolled through the text messages on the phone of her husband, the golfer Ben Crane, and stumbled upon a few that raised her eyebrows. Sent to the same number, they were like echoes: “God before results. God before results. God before results.”

headline: Madison Square Garden to Slow for Construction
text: One type of renovation at Madison Square Garden will begin this summer when the Knicks try to sign players like LeBron James, Dwyane Wade, Chris Bosh.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. The British elections. What will happen to the sweet old lady who was described as “bigoted” by Prime Minister Gordon Brown? Four words: Lifetime’s “Susan Boyle Story.”

headline: A Campus Where Unlearning Is First
text: CAIRO — When Rafik Gindy graduated from high school, he knew he wanted to become an engineer. So he enrolled at the American University in Cairo and prepared to immerse himself in math and science.

headline: New Alarm Bells About Chemicals and Cancer
text: The President’s Cancer Panel is the Mount Everest of the medical mainstream, so it is astonishing to learn that it is poised to join ranks with the organic food movement and declare: chemicals threaten our bodies.

headline: The New School to Build a Multipurpose, 16-Story Building
text: The board of the New School approved plans on Wednesday evening to build a 16-story, $353 million University Center, the largest construction project in the university’s 91-year history in Greenwich Village.

headline: Long Shot for High Court Has Reputation for Compassion and Persuasion
text: Kathleen Morris was not thrilled to be working on a dry bankruptcy case. But when Ms. Morris, then a law clerk, shared her feelings with her boss, Sidney R. Thomas, a federal appeals court judge, his answer startled her.

headline: Groundhog Day for Oil

headline: Forging a Career in Carbohydrates
text: Gemma Matsuyama, 20, a baker at Sullivan Street Bakery, may have been culturally, if not genetically, predestined to end up in the culinary world. She was born near Tokyo to a Japanese father and an Italian mother and, surprise of surprises, grew up adoring food. The family moved to Fort Lee, N.J., 15 years ago, though Ms. Matsuyama spent much of her adolescence in Italy, attending a culinary high school. She moved back to the United States in March.

headline: Cancer Panels and Journalistic Panels
