headline: Russian Warship Rushes to Aid Hijacked Tanker
text: A Russian warship was steaming toward an oil tanker that was hijacked at dawn with 23 Russian crew members aboard as it was heading east into the Indian Ocean from Sudan, the European anti-piracy naval force said Wednesday. The tanker had been on its way to China with a cargo of crude oil worth an estimated $52 million. Its seizure seemed a setback for the European force, which has recently been claiming successes for a new strategy of intercepting pirate vessels far out at sea before they attack shipping lines. Reuters quoted a pirate identified only as Abdi as warning against any rescue attempt as the tanker sailed toward the Somali coast, saying it would endanger the crew.

headline: China: Government Considers New Rule for Online ID
text: China is exploring a system that would authenticate the identity of anyone who posts a message on an Internet bulletin board, expanding a policy that, since September, has required people to use their real names when posting comments. The current real-name policy can easily be subverted. The state-run Xinhua news agency, which reported the development on Wednesday, quoted the minister of the State Council Information Office, Wang Chen, as saying that the government was also considering real-name registration for cellphone users and a new law governing “Internet security.” Mr. Wang said new restrictions were needed to curb the online spread of “harmful information” and infiltration of the Internet by “hostile overseas forces.” Critics say the increasing crackdown on use of the Internet is a crucial element of the government’s effort to silence domestic political dissent.

headline: China: Aid Program Focuses on Xinjiang Region
text: The Chinese government plans to direct about $1.47 billion in aid from various provinces to the vast, restive region of Xinjiang in an effort to promote what it terms stability there, according to a report on Wednesday in China Daily, an official newspaper. In recent months, Chinese leaders have stressed the need to quickly develop the economies of Xinjiang and Tibet, huge areas of western China where ethnic minority groups have rebelled against Chinese rule. Last July, at least 197 people were killed and 1,700 injured in ethnic rioting in Xinjiang. Under the aid program, relatively wealthy provinces or cities in other parts of China would send money to designated counterparts in Xinjiang. The report said 82 cities or towns in Xinjiang would benefit. The government has been running a similar program in the region for 13 years, but is greatly expanding it now, the report said.

headline: At Virginia, a Vigil and the First Attempts at Healing
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — On a night that was supposed to be a quiet one, with final exams just a day away, more than 1,500 students at the University of Virginia put down their books Wednesday and paid tribute to a fellow student killed this week.

headline: Germany: Arms Dealer Convicted of Tax Evasion
text: A German court on Wednesday convicted the arms dealer and lobbyist at the center of a political fund-raising scandal that severely damaged the legacy of former Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The court, in Augsburg, sentenced Karlheinz Schreiber, 76, to eight years in prison for dodging $9.5 million in tax payments. Mr. Schreiber’s arms deals generated cash that went to Mr. Kohl’s Christian Democrats. Mr. Schreiber fought extradition from Canada, his adopted homeland, to Germany for 10 years, before he was sent back to Germany last summer.

headline: Flooding Damages Home of Nashville Symphony
text: Floodwaters in Nashville seriously damaged one of the city’s newest cultural gems, the Schermerhorn Symphony Center, home of the Nashville Symphony Orchestra. Disaster was averted when water that had filled the basement reached within a cello’s thickness — roughly five inches — of the concert hall after the Cumberland River crested, Alan D. Valentine, the symphony’s president and chief executive, said on Wednesday.

headline: Roger Waters Speaks!
text: Even as someone who didn’t let a day of high school go by without listening to some portion of “Dark Side of the Moon” (thank you very much, 1990s-era classic-rock radio), I am chagrined to admit that I had no idea what Roger Waters looks like these days or even sounds like when he speaks. That was quickly rectified by a rare television interview that Mr. Waters, the former Pink Floyd singer and bassist, gave to Jimmy Fallon on his “Late Night” program Wednesday night.

headline: Bloomberg Plans to Cut Number of Teachers
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: U.S. Shoppers Eased Off a Little in April, but the General Trend in Retailing Is Up
text: After a blockbuster March buoyed by brisk Easter shopping, sales growth at the nation’s retailers slowed in April.

headline: Will Premiums Fall for the Middle Class?
text: Q.

headline: Filling in Map Gaps With Waze Games
text: In the world of navigation software there has been an enormous push into “crowd-sourced” data, which is a fancy way of saying getting reports from people who are driving. Mostly it’s done by taking GPS data from people who volunteer to have their speed and position tracked through the GPS of a phone they own.

headline: Ristretto | Flat White
text: In Ristretto, Oliver Strand, the curator of the Times Topics coffee page, explores the world of coffee gadgets, coffee beans and why it’s never been easier to get a perfect shot of espresso.

headline: Burkle’s Americold Cancels I.P.O. as Markets Slide
text: Americold Realty Trust, the real estate investment trust controlled by Ron Burkle’s fund Yucaipa, on Thursday delayed its $660 million initial public offering, according to Bloomberg data, a day after it cut the pricing for what was set to be the biggest I.P.O. in the United States this year.

headline: Egyptian President Returns to Cairo, and to Public Eye
text: CAIRO — President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, facing spreading rumors of his failing health, stood to give a half-hour speech on Thursday, belatedly marking Labor Day as well as his return to the Egyptian capital after a two-month absence, the longest since he came to power in 1981.

headline: For BP, a Battle to Contain Leaks and an Image Fight, Too
text: VENICE, La. — As a crew prepared to lower a giant steel container 5,000 feet below the ocean’s surface Thursday evening to capture oil leaking from a ruptured well, the top executive of BP said he was not actually counting on it to work.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | Biologists and Flight Attendants
text: Today’s poem, chosen from nearly 200 submissions to our Found Poem Student Challenge, comes from Adam, who is 17 years old and lives in Uniontown, Pa.

headline: The Deal Goes Down: Elizabeth Perkins Out of ‘Weeds’
text: Even as the story lines on the Showtime comedy “Weeds” became increasingly byzantine and the series drifted away from its original premise about a suburban widow (Mary-Louise Parker) who sells pot to support her family, Elizabeth Perkins was a welcome presence on the show. As Celia Hodes, the neighbor and frenemy of Ms. Parker’s character, Ms. Perkins brought a ray of unmitigated malice to a merely cynical show whether she was doing time in prison, using her cosmetics sales group as a front for a drug ring or getting kidnapped to Mexico (and driving her kidnappers crazy in the process).

headline: U.S. Markets Plunge, Then Stage a Rebound
text: A bad day in the stock market turned into one of the most terrifying moments in Wall Street history on Thursday with a brief 1,000-point plunge that recalled the panic of 2008.

headline: The Post-Hispanic Hispanic Politician
text: In early December, Julián Castro, the newly elected mayor of San Antonio, visited the White House to attend President Obama’s national jobs-and-economic-growth forum. Castro was one of only five mayors in attendance and, at 35, the youngest. When his turn came to speak — the subject was the creation of green jobs — the president looked at him, midway down the long conference table, and said: “I thought he was on our staff. I thought he was an intern. This guy’s a mayor?” The other participants — world-famous economists, environmentalists and politicians — burst into laughter.

headline: Judge Blocks Transit Layoffs and Orders Hearing
text: Update, 12:14 p.m. | The hearing scheduled for Thursday morning on the transit layoffs was postponed until Monday because the judge was stuck hearing another case. The stay of the layoffs remains in effect until then.

headline: New York State, a Recycling Reprobate
text: New York State generates about the same amount of trash per capita today as it did 20 years ago, and its residents and businesses recycle only about 20 percent of it. Urging a shift in practices, state environmental officials have released a proposed plan to get New Yorkers to reduce their waste by 15 percent every two years.

headline: Ex-Compaq Chief Capellas Lands at Cisco-EMC Joint Venture
text: Cisco Systems, EMC, VMware and Intel have found their virtualization man. His name is Michael Capellas.

headline: Campaign Takes a ‘Shine’ to the Tonys
text: Now that the nominees for the 2010 Tony Awards have been selected, it is time for the organizations that oversee the honors to start promoting the CBS broadcast of the ceremony, scheduled for June 13.

headline: Thursday Reading: Getting Paid for Shopping and Sharing
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Baseball Fraud
text: I first heard of SpongeTech, whose executives were arrested on fraud charges on Wednesday, in commercials on Mets and Yankees radio broadcasts.  The product, a sponge with soap built in for washing cars, seemed unlikely to me. If you were going to spend that much for a product to wash the car, why not go to a car wash?

headline: Senate Passes Bank Insurance Amendment
text: In a sign of forward motion in its bid to revamp the nation’s financial regulatory system, the Senate on Thursday unanimously approved an amendment to change the way the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation calculates its assessment on banks to cover losses when banks fail.

headline: Now Showing | Roy McMakin
text: The exhibition “Roy McMakin: When is a chair not a chair?” opened on Tuesday at Cristina Grajales Inc. in SoHo, to coincide with the publication of a monograph with the same title published by Skira Rizzoli.  McMakin, an artist and designer whose work has been featured in T and The New York Times Magazine, is known for his embrace of ambiguity and subversive humor in the design of seemingly mundane objects: A chest of drawers, for instance, that has no drawers; a teapot with the vestiges of a broken handle; a headboard that takes a “pretty” 1940s-inspired design and deconstructs it. While McMakin designs perfectly functional interior and furniture, he does it with an artist’s eye, eschewing conventional ideas of perfection or comfort. The exhibition runs until July 2.

headline: That’s a Bingo: Quentin Tarantino to Head Venice Film Festival Jury
text: The Venice Film Festival runs this year Sept. 1-11, though its organizers might consider adding at least a few hours to that schedule: on Thursday they announced that Quentin Tarantino, the expansive and prolifically talkative filmmaker, would serve as chairman of the festival’s jury, which gives out the Golden Lion award and other prizes, Reuters reported. In an announcement on the festival’s Web site the organizers wrote that they had chosen Mr. Tarantino, whose films include “Pulp Fiction” and “Inglourious Basterds,” because “he has become a studied and imitated ‘point of reference,’ and he is perhaps the only American auteur to be adored worldwide like a rock star.” The announcement also praised Mr. Tarantino for rediscovering “overlooked actors in impressive roles,” and for his own work as “an atypical character actor” in films like Takashi Miike’s “Sukiyaki Western Django” (a 2008 Venice festival entry in which he played a mysterious gunfighter named Ringo). Not least of all, the festival organizers also noted Mr. Tarantino is “a great admirer and connoisseur of Italian genre cinema.”

headline: How Do You Keep Them Coming Back?
text: My mom and dad ran a successful small business for more than 35 years in Corpus Christi. I was visiting recently with my mom, a k a Patty P, and told her about this blog. “How about a post on getting customers to return?” asked Patty P.

headline: Alicia Alonso to Take Part in ABT Celebration
text: Since Alicia Alonso joined American Ballet Theater in 1941 her performances have been described as “breathtaking” and “eminently dainty and gracious.” Now the woman synonymous with Cuban dance is returning to the company and the Metropolitan Opera House. She’ll be there June 3 to celebrate her 90th birthday at an event that will include a film retrospective of her career and a special performance of “Don Quixote,” Ballet Theater’s artistic director, Kevin McKenzie, announced. The fete is part of a celebration of another milestone: the company’s 70th anniversary.

headline: Letterman: ‘They Don’t Like Immigrants’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: You folks been following the big British Petroleum oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico? I’m telling you, British Petroleum has put more birds in oil than Colonel Sanders.

headline: A Baedeker Tour, 100 Years Later
text: IT was a cold and overcast afternoon, and the Alexandra Hotel looked like a stern and gray matron. Close by the banks of Loch Linnhe on the west coast of Scotland, the traditional hotel had two steep gables, a brooding stone facade and 93 rooms, some of which looked out onto a grassy parade where bundled-up locals were negotiating the path beneath the town’s war memorial.

headline: Leno: ‘Los Suns’
text: Monologue |  Wednesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Hey, did you know about this? Tonight, to protest Arizona’s new immigration law, the Phoenix Suns are all wearing jerseys that read “Los Suns.” Thankfully, they can get the jerseys made quickly using an illegal sweatshop.

headline: The Besieged and the Beautiful in Languedoc
text: THERE’S nothing like a dose of medieval barbarism to give you a hearty appetite.

headline: Let’s Create a Magic Garden
text: Though you may not have noticed it for all the sirens, we are presently in the throes of NYC Wildflower Week, a nine-day celebration, running through Sunday, of the city’s 778 native plant species.

headline: Lawrence Taylor Charged With Rape
text: Lawrence Taylor, the former Giants linebacker, was arrested early Thursday morning and has been charged with third-degree rape and soliciting prostitution in a case involving a 16-year-old girl at a hotel in Rockland County, according to the authorities.

headline: Splendid Ruins: Hotels Built on History
text: ON a recent family trip to Italy, I had arranged for our final night to be spent at La Posta Vecchia, a quiet, seaside hotel in Ladispoli, about 25 miles north of Rome. The circa-1640 villa, once owned by J. Paul Getty, is now a 19-room inn furnished with Getty’s antique furniture and tapestries. With the open windows bringing in cooling breezes, little could be heard but the sound of the wind and waves. Yet the hotel also gave us an additional, unexpected gift: a fascinating glimpse into daily life as it was lived 2,000 years ago.

headline: With Apologies to Chapel Hill: An Empire (and NYU) State of Mind
text: The wait is over. After long stressful weeks filled with indecisiveness, what if’s and unforgettable weekends, I am proud to say that I’ve decided to become a member of the NYU Stern School of Business Class of 2014!

headline: Robin Roberts Dies at 83; Led Phillies’ Whiz Kids to Pennant
text: Robin Roberts, the Hall of Fame right-hander who won 286 games and pitched the Philadelphia Phillies’ 1950 Whiz Kids team to the National League pennant, died Thursday at his home in Temple Terrace, Fla., near Tampa. He was 83.

headline: Arts Bloom in South London
text: WHEN Harriet Harman, a member of Parliament and deputy Labour Party leader, donned a flak jacket in 2008 to tour her constituency of Camberwell and Peckham, two relatively high-crime neighborhoods in south London, flak is what she got  from the national press, local residents and opposing Conservatives.

headline: Now, Cultural Casablanca
text: ON the industrial outskirts of Casablanca, Morocco, feral dogs roam the grounds of an abandoned meatpacking plant. Today, the sprawling factory, still replete with dangling meat hooks and blood-stained floors, is the unlikely venue for Casablanca’s largest independent art exhibition space, Les Transculturelles des Abattoirs, or the Transcultural Slaughterhouse, which has featured unusual site-specific pieces: sets of sculptured feet placed side by side on the ground, for instance, and faces pasted directly on the white tiles lining the space’s walls.

headline: A Crooked Eye on Weekly Success?
text: Yesterday, I riffed on the weekly travails as evidenced by the sale of Newsweek. Along the way, I suggested that two New York-centric magazines, New York and The New Yorker, were making a go of it where others were not. I failed to mention the chronic success of People and Us Weekly, two big celebrity magazines that may have dipped along with all other media, but continue to storm along. And people at Time magazine were particularly unimpressed by that bit of analytics, pointing out that for all their allure, neither of those New York magazines make much money. Here’s one bit from a number of lemme-get-this-straight e-mail messages and phone calls I received:

headline: Tigers Fans Say Goodbye to Ernie Harwell
text: The Tigers are not playing at Comerica Park in Detroit on Thursday, but the ballpark is busy with activity, hosting the visitation of the beloved broadcaster Ernie Harwell.

headline: Now Showing | Swid/Kaufman
text: In their own ways, Nan Swid and Donald Kaufman have always been enablers. A founder of the design company Swid Powell, Swid worked with an A-list of artists and architects like Frank Gehry, Richard Meier and Ettore Sottsass to produce all manner of tabletop objects. The company archives — from a coffee maker to candlesticks — now reside at the Yale University Museum of Art. Kaufman — who with his wife and business partner, Taffy Dahl, founded Donald Kaufman Color in the ‘70s — has long been the go-to guy for architects and decorators looking for that elusive shade of not-quite-gray-not-quite-white or flaming red. Take a tour of Philip Johnson’s Glass House or grab a drink at the Julian Schnabel-designed Gramercy Park Hotel and you get the picture. But for four days this week, instead of making other people look good, Swid and Kaufman will bask in the spotlight as artists in their own right, when they show their personal work at Gallery 9E in Chelsea. Unsurprisingly, Kaufman — whose work has been in museums like the Whitney and the Hirshhorn, but who hasn’t had an exhibition in over 30 years — is a painter. His series of gouaches on paper, he says, are inspired by architectural color samples. And true to form, Swid is more object-oriented, layering pieces of old books, cellophane, legal files and other found materials into three-dimensional reliefs.

headline: Q&A: A 10-Day Tour of Ireland
text: Q.

headline: $15 Million for WNET.org, and Names for Its New Studios
text: WNET.org’s new studios at Lincoln Center will be named after James S. Tisch and his wife, Merryl H. Tisch, in honor of a $15 million gift, the single largest from individuals in WNET’s nearly 50-year history.

headline: Country Stars Take Stock After Nashville Flood
text: As the water recedes and Nashville recovers from the flooding that occurred when the Cumberland River became swollen from a weekend’s worth of thunderstorms, many of the city’s best-known musicians are assessing the damage to their property and making plans to help it get back on its feet. The country star Brad Paisley told The Associated Press that much of the staging and props for his coming concerts — called the H2O tour — were underwater during the floods, and that most of his guitars, amps and equipment had been destroyed. Ben Jumper, the owner of a storage plant called Soundcheck Nashville, where Mr. Paisley and other musicians kept their gear, said he expected his losses from the flood would amount to tens of millions of dollars. A publicist for Kenny Chesney told The A.P. that the musician’s home would probably be condemned after water rose above its first floor.

headline: House Panel Begins Work on Auto Safety Bill
text: Congress took the first steps Thursday toward a wide-ranging auto safety bill that would require devices like black boxes and brake override systems, and strengthen federal regulators’ enforcement powers.

headline: Losses Slow and Digital Sales Rise at Warner Music
text: Warner Music Group reported mixed results in the latest quarter, as it continued to lose money but had a 15 percent uptick in digital revenue. Over all, revenue at the company declined 1.3 percent, to $662 million, in the most recent quarter compared with the period a year earlier. The net loss was $25 million, or 17 cents a share, an improvement over its $68 million loss last year.

headline: Two Paths to the Preakness
text: The Preakness Stakes, the middle leg of the Triple Crown, is less than two weeks away. For those horses that ran in the Kentucky Derby, training up to the Preakness will be somewhat light.

headline: Free To Choose
text: Tuesday’s Times included a spot-on piece from Charles Murray defending the value of school choice in the wake of data showing that Milwaukee’s expansive program of vouchers and charter schools hasn’t raised test scores. Here’s Murray:

headline: Magic’s Playoff Run Has Been a Sprint
text: So who’s the hottest team in the N.B.A. playoffs right now?

headline: New Sestak, Specter Ads in Pennsylvania Senate Race
text: The Pennsylvania Democratic primary for the Senate is less than two weeks away, and the ad wars between Senator Arlen Specter and Representative Joe Sestak have begun to flood the TV screens of the state’s residents. Senator Specter has been leading in the state polls, but some recent ones suggest that Mr. Sestak has been narrowing the gap in recent days, putting him within 5 to 8 percentage points of Senator Specter.

headline: Battling Morning Sickness
text: Tanya Gross has been pregnant twice before — her daughter is now 4, and her son is 2. But this time around — she’s due in November — the morning sickness has hit with a force not felt the first two times. And she is looking for advice from Motherlode readers who have been there. She writes:

headline: Popcast: The New Pornographers, the Hold Steady and Josh Ritter
text: On this week’s Popcast, Jon Pareles and Ben Sisario discuss the New Pornographers, Ben Ratliff reviews the Hold Steady and Josh Ritter performs live. Sia Michel is the host.

headline: On Our Radar: The Oil Dome Arrives
text: The containment dome reaches the site of the oil leak but will not be fully operational for several days.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: Sometimes Older Really Is Wiser
text: Maybe Supreme Court justices, United Nations ambassadors, presidential envoys to troubled parts of the globe and divorce mediators should all be at least 60 years old.

headline: ‘Sweepstakes’ Cafes Thrive, Despite Police Misgivings
text: CASSELBERRY, Fla. — Rick Massa was spending this Friday afternoon as he does every week, sitting at a computer on the lonely end of a strip mall here inside Jacks Business Center and Internet Cafe. He was not checking his e-mail messages or sending a fax. And he was not interested in coffee.

headline: A Closer Look at the Times Square Bomb Suspect
text: Our colleagues James Barron and Sabrina Tavernise have a profile of Faisal Shahzad, a naturalized American citizen from Pakistan who was arrested on suspicion that he tried to detonate a car bomb in Times Square on the night of May 1.

headline: Mayor’s Budget Would Cut Teaching Jobs, Fire Companies and Senior Centers
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, proclaiming the need for prudence in a time of economic uncertainty, released a grim budget on Thursday that would substantially cut the city’s teaching force, close 20 fire companies and eliminate programs for seniors and children.

headline: The Morning Line: Who’s in the Preakness
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

headline: TimesCast | May 6, 2010
text: Topics in today's TimesCast include,  BP's efforts to cap a second oil leak, Congress seeks new auto safety rules and teaching financial literacy in high school.

headline: Name on No-Fly List Delays Emirates Flight
text: For the second time in less than three days, officials halted a commercial jetliner bound for Dubai only moments before it was to take off from Kennedy International Airport.

headline: An Eye on America Is Also Under Watch
text: ANY journalist working in a war-torn or politically unstable region knows the risks and headaches of the job: threats to personal safety, difficulties of access, interference from authorities. For the documentary filmmaker Laura Poitras, who has now made one film in occupied Iraq (the Oscar-nominated “My Country, My Country”) and another in the volatile Persian Gulf state of Yemen (“The Oath”), there is the added complication of being, she believes, on a United States government watch list.

headline: All Burbles and Gurgles as Life Unfolds
text: THE French documentary filmmaker Thomas Balmès has a decided taste for serious  one might even say wonky  subject matter. Mr. Balmès, 40, has trained his cameras on earnest topics like Kenyan warriors turned United Nations peacekeepers in Bosnia, the mad cow crisis as seen from the perspective of India, conditions at a Chinese factory where Nokia makes cellphone parts, and a Connecticut law firm that specializes in personal-injury cases.

headline: Private Equity Firms in Talks to Buy Fidelity National
text: 4:34 p.m. | Updated The Blackstone Group, THL Partners and TPG Capital are in talks to acquire Fidelity National Information Services, a services provider to banks, in what would be the largest leveraged buyout since the financial crisis, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

headline: H.P. Unveils a New Line of Laptops
text: Hewlett-Packard’s newly announced consumer lineup includes a pair of Envy “luxury” laptops, and there is some fun stuff going on with those Envys, which bear striking resemblances to the MacBook Pros sold by That Other Computer Company.

headline: Theater Talkback: YouTube on Broadway
text: There was a time, not so long ago, when if a Broadway diva – say, Carol Channing or Patti LuPone – wanted to watch somebody else singing her signature songs in her signature style, she had to leave her dressing room and find a drag show.

headline: Home Insurance and Bedbug Invasions
text: Bedbugs can be very expensive house guests. The costs of temporarily moving out while your home is debugged, steam cleaning fabrics and extermination can run up very quickly.

headline: Suit Over Legal Aid Advances in New York
text: New York’s highest court ruled Thursday that a broad class-action suit challenging the state’s system of providing public defenders can move forward because there are enough signs that the system is failing poor people.

headline: TimesCast: The Auto Safety Debate
text: Congress took the first steps today toward wide-ranging auto safety regulation.

headline: Gen Art Folds, a Victim of Recession
text: After 16 years of presenting film, art, fashion, music and parties, Gen Art, a showcase devoted to young talent and young audiences with branches in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago, has folded, a victim of the financial downturn. “After struggling for the past 18 months since the economic crisis, Gen Art has finally succumbed to the recession,” its founders, the brothers Ian and Stefan Gerard, wrote in a letter sent out late Wednesday and posted on the Gen Art Web site. “We have now halted all operations, have let go all of our amazing staff, and shuttered the business,” they wrote, adding that they hoped that Gen Art “in some small way was as close to your heart  as it was ours.”

headline: Obama Adds His Voice to Senate Debate
text: President Obama intervened on Thursday in the Senate’s debate over revamping regulation of the financial system, urging senators to reject a Republican amendment that he said “will gut consumer protections” in the Democrats’ legislation.

headline: Out of Africa | Bold Patterns
text: In Africa, kangas — colorful sarong-like pieces of fabric — are used by local women for everything from wrap dresses to papooses, but they have also served as inspiration for spring fashion. And while designers like Dries Van Noten, Thakoon and Balenciagia showed bold ethnic prints, the kanga designers in Nairobi take it one step further, creating cultural mash ups of patterns — Arab geometrics, sub-continent psychedelics, and lots of local iconography like mangos, cashews and plenty of flowers.

headline: Bayern Munich’s Success Bolsters Germany Roster
text: Several members of Bayern Munich have parlayed the German club’s success this season into a potential summer sojourn to South Africa with the national team.

headline: Crane Gets Serious, and It Shows in His Game
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — The seeds for Ben Crane’s opening five-under-par 67 Thursday at the Players Championship were planted two days earlier.

headline: The New Group Announces 2010-11 Season
text: The New Group has announced its three Off Broadway productions for the 2010-11 season. The actor Tommy Nohilly, a former Marine, will have his debut as a playwright with his dark comedy, “Blood From a Stone,” about a troubled working-class family in New Britain, Conn. One private reading of the script included the actors Roseanne Barr, Ethan Hawke and Philip Seymour Hoffman, but a spokeswoman for the New Group said no casting for the production was confirmed. It will be directed by the New Group’s artistic director, Scott Elliott, who is currently overseeing the company’s new musical, “The Kid,” at Theater Row.

headline: Do Women Make Better Doctors?
text: Recently, one of my patients, an elderly man, stopped me as I got up from my stool to leave his room. I had just finished examining him, offering my assessment and plan, and apologizing for his long wait since I had been running late that day. He listened patiently then hopped down from the exam table just as I turned toward the door, the ties of his flimsy hospital gown flapping around his thin legs.

headline: Do Men and Women Doctor Differently?
text: In Thursday’s Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen recounts the story of a patient who preferred female physicians.

headline: The Importance of Andy Pettitte
text: Identifying the force driving the Yankees’ early success is not difficult. The rotation’s earned run average stands at 3.17, which is all the more remarkable considering Javier Vazquez’s miseries. That is the second-lowest team E.R.A. in the American League behind Tampa Bay (2.61) and the fifth-best in baseball. The Cardinals, at 2.52, entered Thursday’s games with the lowest in the majors.

headline: A Night Out With the H.I.V. Positive
text: On a recent Thursday night at Vlada in Hell’s Kitchen, the conversations unfolding over house music and beneath portraits of shirtless muscle boys were similar to any others at the neighborhood’s gay hot spots.

headline: Hiking Up the Mountain
text: 4th May 2010, Madagascar

headline: After Criticism, a Bit of Backpedaling
text: Updated, May 7 | And now a mea culpa in the recent debate over cycling numbers in the city.

headline: Paulson and Geithner Back Calls for Tighter Regulation
text: WASHINGTON — Two Treasury secretaries, Henry M. Paulson Jr. and his successor, Timothy F. Geithner, on Thursday endorsed calls for stricter regulation of financial markets.

headline: Chemical Antidote Is Unnerving to Some
text: As I wrote today in The Times, scientists and politicians are in more or less uncharted territory in putting so much dispersant — chemicals that break down oil — into the Gulf of Mexico to contain the spill there.

headline: Agency Urged to Require Antilock Brakes on Motorcycles
text: The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety has asked the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to require antilock brakes on all motorcycles.

headline: Thank Mom, ASAP
text: I was born with a medical condition that’s required me to have several operations on my legs. Typically, I’ve stayed at my mother’s house while recuperating, and she’s taken great care of me. Now, at 23, I need one more operation, which I’d like to have in Europe, where the best surgeon is located. I asked my mother to postpone taking a new job to spend a month there with me while I recover. She refused, claiming she needed to start her training program. I am furious with her and want to retaliate by not speaking with her until after the surgery, but that would be pretty cruel. What should I do?

headline: New Ratmansky Work Added to Vail Dance Festival
text: A new work by the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky has been added to the program at the Vail International Dance Festival this summer. Mr. Ratmansky will create a solo piece for Wendy Whelan, a principal dancer with New York City Ballet, the festival has announced. The dance, which will be set to music by Boccherini and includes a costume by William Ivey Long, will have its premiere on Aug. 6.

headline: Police Officer Accused of Helping Gang Rob Drug Dealers
text: A New York police officer has been arrested on federal charges for his role in helping a violent robbery crew impersonate police officers so they could rob drug traffickers during bogus raids.

headline: Returning to Independent Ball, Millar Comes Full Circle
text: A decade before Kevin Millar implored his Boston Red Sox teammates to cowboy up, and 11 years before he helped the Sox end their long World Series drought, Millar began his professional baseball career with a first-year independent team that faced the same long odds to succeed as he did.

headline: Myanmar Opposition Party Formally Disbands Before Election
text: BANGKOK — The political party of Myanmar’s imprisoned opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, was officially dissolved at 12:01 a.m. Friday after more than 20 years as the core of pro-democracy resistance to Myanmar’s military junta.

headline: Get Your Texas Kicks on U.S. 281
text: CUTTING plumb through the heart of Texas, U.S. 281 runs from the arid plains of Wichita Falls at the Oklahoma border to the humid confines of Brownsville at the mouth of the Rio Grande. For most of its winding journey, it proves little more than that the state remains one very flat, dusty, empty place.

headline: Patent Pending: The Fast Track
text: My first job after college was as a patent examiner at the United States Patent and Trademark Office. I spent my days evaluating stacks of patent applications, most of them three to four years old because of the immense backlog the office faced. Today the office still struggles with a major backlog.

headline: Lawrence Taylor’s Demons, in His Words
text: Lawrence Taylor is expected to be charged with third-degree rape after the police said they arrested him early Thursday in Rockland County on suspicion of having sex with a minor.

headline: Batters’ Dawdling: Waste of Time, or Good Strategy?
text: Keith Hernandez admits to dawdling outside the batter’s box with the St. Louis Cardinals and the Mets.

headline: Celebrating the New World, Bravely
text: Scarlett Johansson is a very good actress, but since we don’t need any more articles about the brand kitten’s style, let’s enjoy a big gulp of the contemporary culture provided by 032c, the Berlin-based magazine that is published twice a year. The latest issue, the 19th, is just out.

headline: Unwrapping the Mummy
text: Images from the “Mummy Chamber” exhibit at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: F.C.C. Proposes Rules on Internet Access
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission outlined a plan on Thursday that would allow the agency to control the transmission component of high-speed Internet, but not rates or content.

headline: Bomb Scare on Maine-to-New York Bus

headline: Melvin the Mummy’s New Clothes

headline: The Man in the Iron Irony
text: “Iron Man 2,” the first superhero sequel of the summer, fulfills the basic requirements of the genre, which can be summed up as more of the same, with emphasis on more. Having introduced its physically and intellectually gifted, emotionally tormented protagonist in both his regular and alter egos, a comic book franchise will typically set out, in the second installment, in search of new villains, bigger suits, brighter gadgets and tendrils of plot that can blossom in subsequent sequels.

headline: Going Viral? Creating Dance Videos Across the Curriculum

In this lesson, students watch recent viral dance videos and explore their nature and role in contemporary culture. They then create their own curriculum-based dances (or live performances) to share at school and/or on the Internet.

text: Most people visiting the southern tip of Manhattan are on their way somewhere else, whether they are commuters hopping on or off the Staten Island Ferry, or tourists lining up for cruise tickets to Ellis Island or the Statue of Liberty. But Battery Park is worth more than a hurry-through. Dotted with more than 20 monuments, it has manicured lawns and ornamental gardens that rival Central Park’s. At its fringes are a wealth of museums, and all is set at the confluence of two rivers, the Hudson and the East.

headline: Alva Smith Vanderbilt Belmont as Impulse Buyer
text: Alva Smith Vanderbilt Belmont, an impulsive and imperious railroad heiress, defied convention in the 1890s by dumping her unfaithful husband and running off with a neighbor. Although her feminist streak led her to battle for women’s suffrage, she forced her daughter Consuelo into a stiflingly conventional marriage to a philandering English duke who needed Vanderbilt money. Mrs. Belmont, who lived in New York, Long Island, northern France and Newport, R.I., also collected antiques on impulse. At her Versailles-inspired Newport home, called Marble House (it contains 500,000 cubic feet of marble), she filled an 1890s Gothic reception room with pinnacled oak paneling, medieval stained glass, statues of saints, rock crystal watches and Roman cameos made of amethyst and carnelian.

headline: 15,000th Concert (but Who’s Counting?)
text: A bright red banner hanging over the entrances to Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday indicated to all that the evening’s program by the New York Philharmonic was the orchestra’s 15,000th concert. No other orchestra comes close to matching that number.

headline: Those Internal Demons, Awfully Hard to Shake
text: At the start of “Binding,” Jesse Zaritt moves in a flash: an arm whips out, a leg curls behind, and suddenly his body, virile and flamboyant, crashes to the floor. On the tiny stage of the first-floor theater at Performance Space 122, where Mr. Zaritt’s new work, seen Wednesday, is part of the soloNOVA Arts Festival, his long line is magnified to powerful effect.

headline: Man Sentenced for Selling Phony Goods to Military
text: HOUSTON — A Saudi man was sentenced Thursday to four years in prison for selling counterfeit computer parts to the Marine Corps for use in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Mulling Mortality, in the East and in the West
text: No one lives forever. We may carry on as if we were immortal — life has its own mysterious agenda. But sooner or later, the Grim Reaper will come for each and every one of us. This undeniable truth has inspired mountains of great art over the millenniums. Some of it is in “Remember That You Will Die: Death Across Cultures,” an exhibition at the Rubin Museum of Art that is equally entertaining aesthetically and philosophically.

headline: Existential Issues, Tunefully Addressed
text: There were times during the recital the German bass-baritone Thomas Quasthoff presented at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night when you wanted to put an arm around his shoulders and assure him that everything would be all right. Not that there were problems with his performance: anything but. Mr. Quasthoff is, to put it bluntly, one of the greatest vocal artists now performing, and Wednesday’s concert indicated that he is at the pinnacle of his powers.

headline: New Home for Jazz in San Francisco
text: With many businesses and nonprofit groups contracting in a sour economy, SF Jazz is making waves with a bold proposal for an expansion, as our sister blog, ArtsBeat, reports. The arts organization, which runs the San Francisco Jazz Festival, plans to open the SF Jazz Center in Hayes Valley in the fall of 2012.

text: After celebrations of the Mendelssohn bicentennial last year, the spotlight has shifted to this year’s Schumann and Chopin anniversaries. But the pianist Emanuel Ax, the cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the violinist Itzhak Perlman shifted attention back to Mendelssohn for much of their “Live From Lincoln Center” broadcast from the Kaplan Penthouse on Wednesday evening.

headline: ‘Life Would Be Perfect if I Lived in That House’
text: Prologue

headline: Obsessions | The Beauty-From-Within Market
text: Americans take pills to scrub our arteries, to relax us for airplane flights, to deforest our nasal passages of mucus and to remoisten our tear ducts. We take pills to sharpen our memory, to forget the awful things that have happened to us, to revitalize our libidos and to fall into a stuporous, amnesiac, refrigerator-clearing sleep.

headline: Home-Sweet-Home Obsessed
text: Given my previous line of work, I thought I had seen it all: the deranged longing, the addled judgment, the willful denial, the glazed eyes, the hyperventilating, the quickened pulse, the night sweats, the insomnia — all the depredations of a love affair gone wrong. Anyone over the age of 30 who lived, worked or breathed in any proximity to the real estate market in the last decade will immediately recognize the signs of house lust. But I spent years as the editor of House & Garden, and I don’t think I ever encountered a case like Meghan Daum’s. Cue up Nina Simone. Daum’s got it bad, and that ain’t good — for her. Readers of “Life Would Be Perfect if I Lived in That House,” though, are in for a memoir that adroitly manages to be funny, charming and shocking in its brutal frankness about an obsession that threatens to upend sanity and bank accounts. Luckily, as was not the case for so many caught in the national grip of cheap mortgages, Daum’s is the story of a love too big to fail.

headline: Ballet Theater To Honor Alicia Alonso at 90
text: After Alicia Alonso, left, joined American Ballet Theater in 1941 her performances were described as “breathtaking” and “eminently dainty and gracious.” Now the woman synonymous with Cuban dance is returning to the company and the Metropolitan Opera House. She’ll be there June 3 to celebrate her 90th birthday at an event that will include a film retrospective of her career and a special performance of “Don Quixote,” the Ballet Theater’s artistic director, Kevin McKenzie, announced. The event is part of a celebration of another milestone: the company’s 70th anniversary. Ms. Alonso, who became known for her interpretation of “Giselle,” also starred in original productions of George Balanchine’s “Theme and Variations” (1947), Antony Tudor’s “Undertow” (1945) and Agnes de Mille’s “Fall River Legend” (1948). In 1948 Ms. Alonso founded the Alicia Alonso Ballet Company, which became the government-supported National Ballet of Cuba in 1959. She went on to form the Cuban National Ballet School in 1960.

headline: New Artistic Director for Williamstown
text: The Williamstown Theater Festival has announced the appointment of a new artistic director: Jenny Gersten, left, a widely admired producer in New York at the Public Theater who worked as associate producer at Williamstown from 1996 to 2004. Ms. Gersten, 41, will succeed Nicholas Martin, who is leaving this summer after his third season at Williamstown, one of the nation’s premiere summertime theater presenters. Ms. Gersten will depart as the associate producer of the Public Theater, the acclaimed nonprofit company in New York founded by Joseph Papp. At the Public, she has most recently produced “The Book of Grace” by Suzan-Lori Parks, “The Brother/Sister Plays” by Tarell Alvin McCraney, “The Idiot Savant” by Richard Foreman and Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night,” which Daniel Sullivan directed last summer for the Public at Delacorte Theater in Central Park. Before joining the Public, Ms. Gersten was artistic director of the theater company Naked Angels.

headline: Artifacts | Wade Guyton’s Monument to Epson
text: In the 1960s, Andy Warhol made paintings as if on a printing machine, forcing colored inks through a silkscreen with a squeegee. “Paintings are too hard,” he said. “Machines have less problems. I’d like to be a machine.” Wade Guyton feels the same. Working in the digital age, he uses a more hands-off technique involving inkjet printers and flatbed scanners.

headline: Perkins Out of ‘Weeds’
text: Even as the story lines on the Showtime comedy “Weeds” became increasingly byzantine and the series drifted away from its original premise about a suburban widow (Mary-Louise Parker) who sells pot to support her family, Elizabeth Perkins, left, was a welcome presence on the show. As Celia Hodes, the neighbor and frenemy of Ms. Parker’s character, Ms. Perkins brought a ray of unmitigated malice to a merely cynical show, whether she was doing time in prison, using her cosmetics sales group as a front for a drug ring or getting kidnapped and taken to Mexico (and driving her kidnappers crazy in the process). But no more: Ms. Perkins, who was nominated for three Emmy Awards in her five seasons on “Weeds,” is leaving the series, The Hollywood Reporter said. She will instead take a role in a hybrid live-action and animated film called “I Hop,” directed by Tim Hill (“Alvin and the Chipmunks”), in which she will play the mother of a young man (James Marsden) who is forced to take care of the son of the Easter bunny (whose voice will be provided by Russell Brand). The Hollywood Reporter said Ms. Perkins was also developing a comedy series for herself.

headline: ‘Idol’ Sags Again
text: It wasn’t just Aaron Kelly, the 17-year-old “American Idol” contestant who was cut from the show on Wednesday, who had a bad night: despite a live performance from Lady Gaga, among other bells and whistles, “Idol” drew its lowest-rated Wednesday night audience since 2002, with 19.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. That was still more than enough to make the show and Fox No. 1 for the evening. CBS finished as runner-up for the night, garnering its best ratings with the procedurals “Criminal Minds” (12.2 million) and “CSI: NY” (10.2 million). NBC edged past ABC for third place, though its troubled hospital drama, “Mercy” (four million), hit a ratings low. ABC ranked fourth.

headline: Millions for WNET From the Tisches
text: WNET.org’s new studios at Lincoln Center will be named after James S. Tisch and his wife, Merryl H. Tisch, in honor of a $15 million gift, the largest from individuals in WNET’s nearly 50-year history. “I’m a great believer in public television and its mission and its importance,” Mr. Tisch, the chief executive of Loews Corporation and chairman of WNET.org, said in a telephone interview. “It’s an island of sanity among a thousand channels, and it isn’t free, and it needs support.” Neal Shapiro, the president and chief executive of WNET, said the donation would go toward the new studios and programming, including a half-hour program called “Metrofocus,” which is in development. “It’s a transformational gift,” Mr. Shapiro said. “This allows us to get to the next step, to develop new programming, to innovate new ways to produce. In a modern television age, that’s what you have to do to survive.”

headline: Proposal to Audit Fed Is Modified
text: Senator Bernard Sanders, independent of Vermont, has agreed to modify a proposal that would require public audits of the Federal Reserve in a potential compromise that would force a single audit of the central bank’s handling of the 2008 economic crisis.

headline: Gen Art Folds, Victim of Recession
text: After 16 years of presenting film, art, fashion, music and parties, Gen Art, a showcase devoted to young talent and young audiences with branches in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago, has folded, a victim of the financial downturn. “After struggling for the past 18 months since the economic crisis, Gen Art has finally succumbed to the recession,” its founders, the brothers Ian and Stefan Gerard, wrote in a letter sent out late Wednesday and posted on the Gen Art Web site, genart.org. “We have now halted all operations, have let go all of our amazing staff, and shuttered the business,” they wrote, adding that they hoped Gen Art “in some small way was as close to your heart  as it was ours.” With 80 percent of its revenue coming from corporate sponsorship, Gen Art was hit hard by the recession, Ian Gerard said in an interview on Thursday. After the fall of 2008 “we were losing money hand over fist,” he said. A $350,000 sponsorship deal with “a major financial institution” fell through at the last minute, in late March, and new investors could not be found quickly enough. “We had cash flow for about four weeks, and four weeks was just not enough for us to bridge that gap with the debt that we were already carrying,” Mr. Gerard said.

headline: Theater Listings: May 7 — 13
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: Country Stars Are Reeling After Nashville Flooding
text: As the water recedes and Nashville recovers from devastating flooding, many of the city’s best-known musicians are assessing the damage to their properties and making plans to help Nashville get back on its feet. Brad Paisley, right, told The Associated Press that much of the staging and props for his coming concerts — called the H2O tour — were under water from the flood and that most of his guitars, amps and equipment had been destroyed. Ben Jumper, the owner of a storage business called Soundcheck Nashville where Mr. Paisley and other musicians kept their gear, said he expected his losses would amount to tens of millions of dollars. A publicist for Kenny Chesney told The A.P. that Mr. Chesney’s home would probably be condemned, as water had risen above the first floor.

headline: Here a Moo, There a Moo, but Old MacDonald’s It’s Not
text: The first thing you hear in “Milk,” Emily DeVoti’s offbeat, flawed new play, is the mooing of cows. A strangely comforting sound, it represents the domesticated life of the Massachusetts dairy farm where the drama is set. But this is no peaceable kingdom: bankruptcy threatens the farm’s existence, and something wild lurks just beyond the fence.

headline: Digg Plans 10 Percent Layoff
text: In an e-mail message sent to employees on Thursday, the chief executive of Digg, the user-driven social news Web site, announced that the company planned to cut its staff by 10 percent.

headline: A Country Star Rakes Through Bluegrass
text: “It ain’t easy standing onstage with your heroes,” the country star Dierks Bentley said at the Highline Ballroom on Wednesday night. Still, he hadn’t dressed up for the occasion. His hair was maybe a bit more matted than usual, his 5 o’clock shadow a bit more honest. His black T-shirt had seen crisper days.

headline: A Ferry Ride Away From Seattle
text: THE Washington State ferry drones toward Bainbridge Island, whose evergreen-laden hills rise up from a rocky shoreline. Dozens of boats and clusters of houses come into view, evidence of the commuters, weekenders and retirees who have chosen Bainbridge Island to escape the buzz of Seattle, about 35 minutes away. This island city, about 5 miles wide and 10 miles long, has a push-pull relationship to decades of growth. In 1991 a growth plan was adopted, and one effect was to increase real estate values by limiting inventory.

headline: Pictures of the Day: England and Elsewhere
text: From today’s “There’ll-Always-Be-an-England” file (subdivision: “Wherever There’s a Cottage Small Beside a Field of Grain”), comes Ben Stansall’s photograph of a polling station in Cornwall. The tranquillity of this particular scene belied the fever of the close election campaign in Britain.

The mural, 16 by 41 feet, was restored to the artist’s original vision through a detailed, slow process of chipping off a yellowish coating applied in the 1970s.

headline: Potential Court Pick Faced Dilemma at Harvard
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — For nearly a quarter-century, Harvard Law School refused to help the nation’s military recruit its students, because the armed services discriminated against openly gay soldiers. But in 2002, the school relented to pressure from the Bush administration and agreed to allow recruiters on campus.

headline: United Tastes: An Asian Take on Crayfish
text: Georgia’s Crawfish Shack Seafood and Southern Seafood serve heaping bowls of shellfish that are a little bit Louisiana, a little bit Vietnam.

text: I have a somewhat different memory of Ernie Harwell, the affable and classy Detroit Tigers broadcaster who died Tuesday. I think of him as a newspaperman.

headline: Pastor Returns Documents to Job Seekers
text: The Brooklyn pastor who promised hundreds of people social service jobs after falsely claiming he had millions in financing has begun to return applications and other documents.

headline: A Gay Adoption Becomes a Musical
text: WHEN the musical librettist Michael Zam first read “The Kid,” a 1999 memoir about a gay couple adopting a baby, he was certain that he wanted to turn it into a musical. He loved the acerbic tone of the book’s author, the syndicated sex columnist Dan Savage, and the frank portrayal of a gay man’s dream for a family. But rather than plunge into adaptation, Mr. Zam made it a long-term project, because he felt it would take time  years, it turned out  to wrest a successful show out of this particular book.

headline: ‘Crisis Economics’
text: For the past half century, academic economists, Wall Street traders, and everyone in between have been led astray by fairy tales about the wonders of unregulated markets and the limitless benefits of financial innovation. The crisis dealt a body blow to that belief system, but nothing has replaced it.

headline: Bruno Avoids Jail, for Now
text: ALBANY — Joseph L. Bruno, the former Republican Senate majority leader who reigned for more than a decade as one of the most powerful politicians in New York State, was sentenced to two years on Thursday for concealing hundreds of thousands of dollars in payments he received from a businessman who sought help from the Legislature.

headline: 36 Hours in Houston
text: A SNARL of superhighways and skyscrapers, Houston is easily dismissed as a corporate campus  home to Fortune 500 giants like Halliburton and Waste Management and a company formerly known as Enron (currently known as Enron Creditors Recovery Corporation). And the view from an airplane isn’t exactly inviting: a flat and featureless plain of generic towers sprawling into the horizon. But in recent years, this Texas megalopolis has been inching back to its urban core. Cool art galleries have sprung up in once blighted neighborhoods. Midcentury modern buildings have been saved and restored. And former factories have been turned into buzzing restaurants and bars. Yes, oil money still reigns supreme, but it now competes with culture.

headline: Everybody Loves the Weird Kid
text: BURBANK, Calif.

headline: From a Prophet, a Call for Reform
text: He was known as “Dr. Doom” — a perennial pessimist in the often sunny world that is the dismal science of economics. And in 2008 his predictions of disaster — delivered two years earlier — came stunningly, frighteningly true, as the entire global financial system teetered on the brink of the abyss. Cassandra had belatedly become a much-celebrated prophet.

headline: Surveillance Footage of Faisal Shahzad
text: Surveillance footage from the Phantom Fireworks Showroom in Matamoras, Penn. shows Faisal Shahzad making purchases on March 8, 2010.

headline: Travelogues to the Nine Circles and Back
text: THERE is nothing quite as hypnotic as a travel show that suggests it’s better to stay home.

headline: Fireworks Shop Releases Video of Bombing Suspect
text: It’s not exactly riveting cinema, but it might be a help to investigators.

headline: Google Maps Is Fine for Finding Subways
text: Thursday’s Phone Smart column, on  apps for New York City commuters, alludes to the dearth of subway-related apps for Android phones.

headline: A Comeback, of Sorts, for Leona Helmsley
text: Yes, they know that people called her the “queen of mean.” Yes, they know that people remember how she bragged that “only the little people pay taxes.”

headline: A Google Tool to Translate a French Menu
text: Watch any science fiction television show, including “Star Trek” and “Doctor Who,” and you will likely hear about a little gadget called a “Universal Translator.” This fictitious device could instantly translate two languages from anywhere in the galaxy.

headline: Obsessively Seeking Original Occupant
text: THIRTY-ODD years ago, when I was a young architectural historian moving into the Cornwall, at Broadway and 90th Street, I began wondering who had first slept in my apartment. Four years later, I had emptied my bag of tricks in researching the building.

headline: Babies and Beyond
text: Thomas Balmès, the director of "Babies," discusses each of his subjects from the film.

headline: Foreclosure End Game
text: When a resident won’t leave a foreclosed house, a real estate agent comes knocking to persuade them to leave. It’s the next-to-last resort, before the sheriff.

headline: As Homeowners’ Dreams Die, He’s the Undertaker
text: LAKE VILLA, Ill. — If you see Joseph Laubinger on your doorstep, start packing. His courtly presence means you have exhausted all excuses, arguments and options for keeping your house.

headline: Invasion of the Superweeds
text: American farmers’ broad use of the weedkiller glyphosphate — particularly Roundup, which was originally made by Monsanto — has led to the rapid growth in recent years of herbicide-resistant weeds. To fight them, farmers are being forced to spray fields with more toxic herbicides, pull weeds by hand and return to more labor-intensive methods like regular plowing.

headline: Record Crowd Expected for U.S.-Germany Game
text: A record crowd for a hockey game was expected for Friday’s game between Germany and the United States, the opener of the 2010 International Ice Hockey Federation World Championship tournament.

headline: Awwwwww, Ewwww, Who’s a Good Baby?
text: The French globe-trotting documentarian Thomas Balmès has taken up a delicate and treacherous assignment in his new film. Fanning out around the world  to the plains of Mongolia, the dusty grasslands of Namibia, the high rises of Tokyo and the streets of San Francisco  Mr. Balmès and his crew set out, about three years ago, to probe a network of mysterious creatures who speak a common idiom barely comprehensible to the rest of us. The film’s subjects are hard to understand and nearly impossible to resist. They project weakness and innocence, yet they also possess almost terrifying powers. And they are just so gosh-darn cute!

headline: M.L.S. Expands to Montreal
text: 10:38 a.m. | Updated

headline: 2010 Mitsubishi Outlander
text: The GT further sharpens the Outlander’s handling by adding an active front differential to the all-wheel-drive system.

headline: Galleries Being Galleries, but More So
text: There are several ways to unpack the first New York Gallery Week, which will take place across the city in 50 art galleries, 5 alternative spaces and a park (the High Line) from Friday to Monday. Most obviously, this four-day “week” — with its coordinated solo exhibitions, special events and extended gallery hours — is a promotional ploy. But it’s also an impressive number of galleries doing what they usually do, only more intensely and overtly, in a legitimate effort to take back the spotlight too often hogged by art fairs and auctions. And it’s a somewhat off-putting assertion of hipness and exclusivity, what with only 50 of the city’s several hundred galleries invited to participate.

headline: Fashion Moments
text: New exhibits at two museums look at more than a century of evolving American fashion.

headline: The Art of Style, and the Style of Art
text: Real women don’t wear couture. Lacking the budgets or the bodies for it, they just watch. At best, they dress for short-term success, not posterity. That is, they don’t buy or commission lavish and costly garments from reigning design geniuses that they plan to wear a few times during the evening hours, fastidiously maintain and finally bequeath to a museum.

headline: Seeking Answers After Wall St.’s Wild Bungee Jump
text: So what in the world happened to the stock market?

headline: ‘Dimanche and Other Stories’
text: Dimanche [ Sunday ]

headline: ‘The Life of Irène Némirovsky’
text: Chapter 1: The Most Beautiful Country in the World (1903–1911)

headline: Claude Monet: Late Work
text: Images from a new exhibit at Gagosian Gallery.

headline: The Garden That Grew Into a Muse
text: The Gagosian Museum of Fine Art in Chelsea? Not yet, but Gagosian Gallery has definitely shaped itself into a periodic and ambitious kunsthalle over the past few years. In 2009 it gave us an invaluable retrospective of the proto-conceptualist Piero Manzoni and a survey of career-end Picassos. Now, moving closer to old master turf, it delivers “Claude Monet: Late Work,” a gorgeous “where on earth did this come from?” show of 27 Giverny paintings dating from 1904 to 1922.

headline: The Némirovsky Paradox
text: In the spring of 1942, the Russian-born novelist Irène Némirovsky, then living in France, began to suspect that her recent conversion to Roman Catholicism was unlikely to exempt her from Hitler’s plans for the Jews. Already considering her works-in-progress “posthumous,” she jotted this entry in her notebook: “Try to do as many discussions and things as possible . . . that may interest people in ’52 or 2052.”

headline: The Eye in a Hurricane of Corruption
text: “Jack Abramoff could sweet-talk a dog off a meat truck.”

headline: Katarina Auster and Wilson Jaramillo
text: IT takes a lot to impress New Yorkers. The hallmark attention-grabbers that might turn heads in other places — crazy hair, loud music, body art — are seen as expected.

headline: A Country Comedy a Russian Could Love
text: The setting is an estate in the Russian countryside in the 19th century. The dramatis personae include landed aristocrats, their bourgeois neighbors, peasants and servants. The story concerns the fate of a plot of land and the dissatisfactions of love.

headline: Teaching Financial Literacy at a Student-Run Bank
text: The city’s schools may be increasingly cash-starved, but at one high school in Harlem, the money is flowing in: Capital One Bank and the Abyssinian Development Corporation have opened a student-run bank inside it.

headline: Calif. Attorney General Sues 2 Calpers Ex-Employees
text: California’s attorney general, Jerry Brown, on Thursday charged two former officials of Calpers with fraud, alleging a system of kickbacks in exchange for outside firms winning a piece of the giant pension fund’s investment portfolio, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Down on the Commune, Where the Kids Run Wild
text: The wretched children born and raised on a rural hippie commune who flail through Adam Sherman’s new film, “Happiness Runs,” may not be as depraved as the members of the Manson family. But these teenagers, who were home-schooled in a climate drenched in sex and drugs, are a creepy lot. While the 40- and 50-something parents are fornicating and practicing new-age rituals, their aimless offspring spend their days drinking, smoking and dealing pot, ingesting any pharmaceutical they can get their hands on and having sex.

headline: In a Melancholy Los Angeles, ‘La Ronde’ of Motherhood
text: The bond between mother and child may be primal, but it is far from simple. That is both the premise and the conclusion of “Mother and Child,” Rodrigo Garcia’s dense and thoughtful  if also uneven  drama of maternal anguish and filial longing.

headline: In Washington, a Renewed Taste for Auto Safety
text: In the new world of auto regulation, cars could be required to have “black boxes” to record crash data and be able to stop even with the engine at full power. Automakers could be ordered to recall defective vehicles immediately and pay safety fees to cover the costs of federal oversight.

headline: Israelis and Palestinians Hail Writers and the Word, Just Not With One Another
text: JERUSALEM — There are moments in this splintered and hardhearted city when skeptics become believers. Thursday night — the ancient walls lighted up, the air filled with honeysuckle and jasmine — felt like such a moment. Distinguished foreign authors and talented local musicians threw themselves into a celebration of literature, music and international fellowship.

headline: Tigers Fans Bid Farewell to a Beloved Broadcaster
text: DETROIT — His voice was a unifying factor that often helped tie a fractured city together.

headline: Plagued by Midlife Malaise
text: As you watch “Multiple Sarcasms,” a reasonably intelligent, decently acted examination of a New York architect’s midlife crisis, starring Timothy Hutton, the question that arises is why? Why devote a single moment of your time to listening to his character, Gabriel Richmond, bellyache ad nauseam about having everything and still being miserable?

headline: Latino Groups Urge Boycott of Arizona Over New Law
text: Several large Latino and civil rights organizations on Thursday announced a business boycott of Arizona, saying that a tough anti-illegal immigration law there would lead to racial profiling and wrongful arrests.

headline: British Readers Document Election Day
text: Readers submitted their photographs and thoughts from around Britain.

headline: Two Paths From Al Qaeda in the Post-9/11 World
text: What she meant to do, Laura Poitras has said, was to make a movie about the homecoming of a Guantánamo Bay prisoner. That was before she met Nasser al-Bahri, known by his nom de jihad, Abu Jandal.

headline: Head of Atomic Agency Asserts Right to Scrutinize Iran
text: The new chief of the International Atomic Energy Agency on Thursday rejected Iran’s claim that international inspectors have no right to ask questions about research Tehran has conducted into missile technology and warheads.

headline: The Scramble to Cover the Bouncing Dow
text: From Brian Stelter at Media Decoder:

headline: In China, Strong Debut for Supplier of Heparin
text: HONG KONG — As stock market stories go, the listing of Shenzhen Hepalink Pharmaceutical in China came with a few special ingredients: two low-key founders who have been turned into multibillionaires overnight; a stake held by Goldman Sachs; and pigs’ intestines.

headline: Geriatric Delinquents, Rampaging Through Suburbia
text: In 1999 Harmony Korine began a video project called “Fight Harm,” in which he encouraged random people to beat him up. Because of his success (otherwise known as injuries), that project was abandoned, but it continues in spirit with “Trash Humpers,” a film that cries out for its maker to be bloodied, perhaps unfairly, by critics and audiences alike.

headline: Keeping Score: Earning Their Money, One Win at a Time
text: There are few baseball players who inspire a love-hate relationship among their team’s fans more than the Mets’ Carlos Beltran and the Red Sox’ J. D. Drew. Both are seen as fragile and nonchalant. Both have been All-Stars and garnered votes for the Most Valuable Player award.

headline: ‘Son of Babylon’ Opens in Baghdad
text: Iraqis attended the premiere of an Iraqi-made film starring Iraqi actors at the historic Semiramis Cinema.

headline: In a Baghdad Cinema, Celebrating a Return of Iraqi Culture
text: BAGHDAD — The carpet was red, but too frayed for the tape around its edges to matter much. A letter of the marquee was lost to the years, a little like the street of shuttered shops, crumbling curbs and relentlessly gray barricades around it.

headline: Market Drop Fueled by a Crisis, Anxiety and an Error
text: Combine one part nervous traders, one part Greek crisis and one part trader error. Stir in one part central bank complacency. Bring to boil. Panic.

headline: With Fighting Spirit, New Coach Takes Over at Rutgers
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — Watching Robert Morris battle heavily favored Villanova in the first round of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament in March, Tim Pernetti, the Rutgers athletic director, was intrigued by what he saw from the Colonials’ coach, Mike Rice.

headline: Surprising Guests in a Russian Parade: American Troops
text: MOSCOW — There is a lot about Red Square these days that would make Khrushchev squirm. Three-hundred-dollar Italian negligees pool in the windows of the State Department Store, that showcase of proletarian output; a 20-foot Mercedes-Benz symbol glints on the skyline across the Moscow River.

headline: Marking Off the Course to the Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — Even before he went to work for President Obama, Bob Bauer was plotting strategy for the next Supreme Court confirmation.

headline: Channel Crossing of the Urgent Kind
text: Philippe Lioret’s compelling, finely balanced immigration drama, “Welcome,” is set mostly in Calais, the port in northern France that is the closest French city to Britain. Here, where on a clear day the cliffs of Dover are visible like a glimpse of the promised land, is where Bilal (Firat Ayverdi), a 17-year-old Kurd, lands on a chilly, bleak February afternoon in 2008.

headline: Palin Backs Fiorina in California
text: Sarah Palin, the 2008 Republican nominee for vice president, is making her presence felt in California’s Senate race by backing Carly Fiorina, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard.

headline: Whose Originalism?
text: Used as an epithet, “activist judge” is almost always applied to a judge who has just issued a decision that the speaker doesn’t like. Conservatives affix the label to the Supreme Court of the 1960’s and 1970’s, as well as to anything they object to about the current court. The ink on Justice John Paul Stevens’s letter of resignation last month was barely dry before conservative political candidates and bloggers lined up to bid good riddance to “the liberal activist now leaving the court.”

headline: The Last Days of the Dragon Lady
text: FIFTY years ago today, the Soviet Union announced that it had shot down an American U-2 spy plane and that its pilot, Francis Gary Powers, was alive.

headline: Red China, Green China
text: WITH the disastrous oil spill in the Gulf, talk has once again turned to clean energy. What few people appreciate is that the demand for everything from solar panels to energy-efficient light bulbs is already booming. Worldwide, $162 billion was spent in new clean-tech investments in 2009 alone.

headline: Marriage Law Is Challenged as Equaling Discrimination
text: BOSTON — Nancy Gill has worked for the Postal Service for almost 23 years. But because she is married to a woman, she cannot provide the same health benefits to her spouse that her co-workers at the post office can provide for their families.

headline: A Money Too Far
text: So, is Greece the next Lehman? No. It isn’t either big enough or interconnected enough to cause global financial markets to freeze up the way they did in 2008. Whatever caused that brief 1,000-point swoon in the Dow, it wasn’t justified by actual events in Europe.

headline: Pain Gone, Walton Talks With Zeal Once Again
text: There was never any doubting Bill Walton’s passions, not while the ball was bouncing, the cameras were rolling and the microphone was on. Words and opinions flowed freely, to a boisterous rhythm that was instantly identifiable.

headline: As Agents Staked Out, Suspect Fled to Airport
text: The federal agent searching the streets of Bridgeport, Conn., at last laid eyes on Faisal Shahzad sometime Monday afternoon. The agent called for help, and soon there was a mix of federal agents and local police officers arrayed on the blocks around Mr. Shahzad’s apartment at 202 Sheridan Street, according to a federal official briefed on the events.

headline: Genzyme Moves to Fend Off Proxy Challenge From Icahn
text: The Genzyme Corporation, facing a proxy challenge from the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, said it would buy back $2 billion in stock and sell or spin off three units that were not part of its main business in rare-disease drugs.

headline: Too Much Information?
text: I get asked from time to time about how the game has changed since I played it. For me, it feels like yesterday that I was part of the inaugural season at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia, and this has lulled me into believing that change, if any, would be subtle. But that is far from the truth. For one thing, something as glaringly new as instant replay for home runs cannot be ignored.

headline: Leading With Two Minds
text: They say that intellectual history travels slowly, and by hearse. The old generation has to die off before a new set of convictions can rise and replace entrenched ways of thinking. People also say that a large organization is like an aircraft carrier. You can move the rudder, but it still takes a long time to turn it around.

headline: What?
text: Somewhere I read about a game in which you’re supposed to do the maximum damage to a famous piece of literature with the minimum typo. The winner was

headline: The Road Ahead Is Uncertain and Likely Difficult
