headline: As Spill Looms, City Plays the Waiting Game Again
text: NEW ORLEANS — Unsure what to do as oil continued to creep toward the Louisiana coast, the percussionist Shannon Powell left his shotgun house in the Tremé section this week and lighted five candles at St. Louis Cathedral on Jackson Square. He said prayers for New Orleans, then played his usual nighttime jazz gig at Preservation Hall in the French Quarter.

headline: Craft Work
text: In your latest book, “Martha Stewart’s Encyclopedia of Sewing and Fabric Crafts,” there’s a section that instructs the reader on how to turn her husband’s old shirts into decorative pillows. Do you think that is a good use of a woman’s time in the 21st century?  At Martha Stewart Living we are all about creativity. We are about recycling the vintage past, and an old shirt doesn’t have to end up in the rag bin. It really can make a beautiful pillow

headline: French Spy Spoof Set in Swinging ’67 Rio
text: Good James Bond spoofs, from Maxwell Smart to Derek Flint to Austin Powers, have always involved suffering copious indignities in the cause of sophomoric humor. Hubert Bonisseur de la Bath, the French spy code-named OSS 117, presents a Gallic variation on this formula: he can be arrogant, stupid, cowardly, sexist, xenophobic and anti-Semitic in search of laughs, as long as his hair and his accent stay shellacked in place.

headline: Market Drop Fueled by a Crisis, a Glitch and Anxiety
text: Combine one part nervous traders, one part Greek crisis and one part trader error. Stir in one part central bank complacency. Bring to boil. Panic.

headline: Risky Loans in Foreign Currencies Persist in Eastern Europe
text: FRANKFURT — No other region suffered more grievous economic damage from the financial crisis last year than Eastern Europe, and a main cause was extensive borrowing in euros and other foreign currencies.

headline: Group Fears Lower Rents Will Expire, Cutting Gains
text: The Bloomberg administration made a proud announcement earlier this week: It had reached the 100,000 mark in its ambitious plan to create or preserve 165,000 units of moderate- and low-income housing by 2014.

headline: What We’re Reading: Ransom Notes
text: Links to economic observations from around the Web.

headline: European Bank’s Assurances Fail to Placate Investors
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank disappointed investors hoping for decisive action on Thursday to contain the euro zone’s increasingly virulent debt crisis, pushing the euro to another low for the year.

headline: The Gun Lobby’s Long Shadow
text: While the rest of the nation comes to grips with fresh concerns about terrorism, domestic and foreign, Congress is wrapped up in the peculiar obsessions of the gun lobby  most of which are certain to make Americans less safe in their homes and on the streets.

headline: Surveillance Culture of the East German Secret Police
text: Now that “DDR/DDR,” Amie Siegel’s film essay on the legacies of the former German Democratic Republic and its surveillance culture, is receiving a one-week commercial release, she wants us to know that it’s not a “documentary.” She prefers the term “ciné constellations” for her movies, which show up in both film festivals and museum exhibitions (including the Whitney Biennial).

headline: Avatars Go to School, Letting Students Get a Feel for the Work World
text: ELIZABETH, N.J. — Even as work crews and scientists mobilized over a huge oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, high school students in this city were hard at work cleaning up another spill — in the virtual world.

headline: Blame Albany
text: An understandably irritated Mayor Michael Bloomberg on Thursday presented New York City’s $63 billion budget for next year with a huge question mark attached. How much of the state’s annual contribution to the city will be cut this year?

headline: Debate on Expanded Presence in Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON — The evidence of ties between the man accused of being the Times Square bomber and Pakistani militants has intensified debate inside the Obama administration about expanding America’s military presence in Pakistan, with some officials making the case to increase the number of Special Operations troops working with Pakistani forces in the country’s western mountains.

headline: When a Suspect Likes to Talk, and Talk
text: Days after his arrest, the Times Square bombing suspect has not been seen in court, though American law provides a right to be charged promptly before a magistrate, usually within 48 hours.

headline: Amazon and Sales Tax
text: Amazon.com is in court again, fighting what ought to be a losing battle to defend its longstanding practice of not collecting sales taxes in most states where it does business.

headline: Surge of Computer Selling After Apparent Glitch Sends Stocks Plunging
text: The glitch that sent markets tumbling Thursday was years in the making, driven by the rise of computers that transformed stock trading more in the last 20 years than in the previous 200.

headline: Private School Screening Test Loses Some Clout
text: For legions of 4- and 5-year-olds and their parents, the test known as the E.R.B. is the entree into the world of private schooling, its pressure and price a taste of the expensive years to come.

headline: Couldn’t They Just Tag Him?
text: The question is not whether Steve Consalvi should have jumped onto the field during a major-league baseball game in Philadelphia on Monday, waving a towel and running in circles like a toddler trying to avoid bath time. He shouldn’t have. Nor is it whether he should have been subdued and arrested. That seems obvious.

headline: Pakistani Taliban Are Said to Expand Alliances
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Taliban, which American investigators suspect were behind the attempt to bomb Times Square, have in recent years combined forces with Al Qaeda and other groups, threatening to extend their reach and ambitions, Western diplomats, intelligence officials and experts say.

headline: If the Golf Shoe Fits, You’ll Want to Wear It Everywhere
text: I remember when golf shoes were not only funny looking things with plastic flaps over the laces, but they hurt your feet, too. The rigid heel cuffs would give me blisters and the metal spikes created pressure points on the soles of your feet. But we wore them anyway. Hey, we had carrying bags without kick stands, too.

headline: Times Sq. Bomb Suspect Is Linked to Militant Cleric
text: WASHINGTON — The Pakistani-American man accused of trying to detonate a car bomb in Times Square has told investigators that he drew inspiration from Anwar al-Awlaki, a Yemeni-American cleric whose militant online lectures have been a catalyst for several recent attacks and plots, an American official said Thursday.

headline: Putting Blame on Albany, Mayor Unveils Budget With Heavy Cuts
text: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled a bleak $63 billion budget on Thursday, he warned that it would cause a lot of pain to many New Yorkers and he did not mince words about where to lay the blame: on Albany.

headline: Crowd Watches Woods, and Cheers for McIlroy
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — On the golfing stage, Rory McIlroy plays Kevin Durant to Tiger Woods’s Kobe Bryant. But the first round of the Players Championship was nothing like the first-round N.B.A. playoff series between Durant’s Thunder and Bryant’s Lakers.

headline: New York Officer Linked to a Violent Robbery Ring
text: The group of men stood outside a suspected drug dealer’s lair, just as they had done dozens of times before, about to conduct a raid.

headline: A Healing House
text: This movie is designated as a Critics' Pick.

headline: As Oil Threat Creeps Closer, a Rush on Seafood
text: NEW ORLEANS — Margie Scheuermann, who has lived here for 78 years, went over her list as she waited in line Tuesday to buy local seafood at the Crescent City Farmers Market: a pair of soft-shell crabs, a pound of lump crab meat and five pounds of unpeeled white gulf shrimp.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Stoudemire Making It Hard for Suns to Resist
text: PHOENIX — With each violent attack on the rim, each surprisingly sturdy defensive stand and each Phoenix Suns playoff victory, Amar’e Stoudemire’s stature is rising.

headline: On 5th Ave., a Grandmothers’ Protest as Endless as the Wars
text: The late-afternoon sun was beginning a slow retreat on Wednesday when the grannies took up their positions on Fifth Avenue at the eastern entrance to Rockefeller Center.

headline: China’s Energy Use Threatens Goals on Warming
text: HONG KONG — Even as China has set ambitious goals for itself in clean-energy production and reduction of global warming gases, the country’s surging demand for power from oil and coal has led to the largest six-month increase in the tonnage of human generated greenhouse gases ever by a single country.

headline: Transit Cuts Announced; Among Them, Announcers
text: Dirtier subways. Scratchiti-scarred windows. And fewer announcers to tell you when that late train will arrive.

headline: Simon Again Raises Its Bid for General Growth
text: 10:00 p.m. | Updated The Simon Property Group made what it called its best and final takeover offer for General Growth Properties late Thursday, proposing to take over its bankrupt rival for a total of $33.5 billion.

headline: British Voters Head to the Polls
text: Voters in Britain went to the polls and appeared to have swung sharply, though not necessarily decisively, against the ruling Labour Party.

headline: Steps Taken on a Farm?
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — STAGNES. That was the last answer I filled in, and I was pretty sure it was right. But what did it mean? Was it a what? Or a who? “Symbol of chastity” — STAGNES?

headline: Wrestling With One’s Conscience
text: Early in “Ocean of Pearls,” a kind of Sikh “Jazz Singer,” Amrit Singh poses a question: “Why would someone work so hard to come to a new world just to keep on living in the old one?” Amrit (a thoughtful Omid Abtahi), a Sikh whose parents emigrated from India to Toronto in the 1960s, lives among Sikhs governed by tradition and conservative mores. (Being alone with his girlfriend in her darkroom is risqué: her father might catch them.)

headline: Abducted Kurdish Writer Is Found Dead in Iraq
text: ERBIL, Iraq — A Kurdish journalist was kidnapped here in the capital of the semiautonomous Kurdistan region of Iraq, tortured and then found dead with two bullets in the head on a highway, his family and members of the security forces said on Thursday.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on the Personal Tech pages on Thursday about the new Photoshop release, CS5, misstated the price of an upgrade from previous versions. It is $199, not $599.

headline: A.I.G. Said to Dismiss Goldman
text: As its legal troubles mount, Goldman Sachs is losing a big corporate client: the American International Group.

headline: Man Convicted of Killing Immigrant, but Not of Hate Crime
text: A Brooklyn man was convicted of manslaughter on Thursday for his role in the killing of an Ecuadorean immigrant, but he was acquitted of more serious hate-crime charges.

headline: So Far, It’s Not the Same Old Red Sox
text: BOSTON

headline: Bruno Gets 2-Year Prison Term, but Stays Free
text: ALBANY — Joseph L. Bruno, for years one of the most powerful politicians in New York, was sentenced Thursday to two years in prison on federal corruption charges. But underscoring the serious doubts surrounding the constitutionality of the law used to convict him, Mr. Bruno was allowed to remain free until the Supreme Court rules on the statute.

headline: Bill Targets Citizenship of Terrorists’ Allies
text: WASHINGTON — Proposed legislation that would allow the government to revoke American citizenship from people suspected of allying themselves with terrorists set off a legal and political debate Thursday that scrambled some of the usual partisan lines on civil-liberties issues.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Senate Nod to Fed Audit Is Expected
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday rejected an effort by liberal Democrats to break up some of the biggest banks, defeating an amendment to financial regulatory legislation that would have imposed new limits on the size and scope of financial companies.

headline: Swagger and a Speech Before an Ex-Lawmaker’s Sentencing
text: ALBANY — Joseph L. Bruno arrived at the federal courthouse here on Thursday, not knowing whether he would be ordered to live out his remaining days behind bars.

headline: The Vatican: Pope Accepts Resignation of Irish Bishops
text: Pope Benedict XVI on Thursday accepted the resignation of two Irish bishops, bringing to five the number of bishops to resign since the abuse crisis hit the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland. In a statement, the Vatican said that Joseph Duffy, bishop of Clogher, and Francis Lagan, the auxiliary bishop of Derry, stepped down after reaching the retirement age of 75. Bishops are required to tender their resignations at 75, but the pope can decline to accept and, in some cases, he has kept bishops well past that age. In March, Bishop Duffy said that he had known about abuse allegations against a priest in his diocese but that he had not told the civil authorities at the request of the victim’s parents, Irish news media reported. The priest was later jailed.

headline: 5 More Suspects Identified in Dubai Killing
text: The Dubai police have identified five more suspects in the killing of a Hamas operative in a Dubai hotel in January, bringing the total number of suspects to 32, a person familiar with the investigation said. The new suspects carried passports from Britain, Australia and France. The case has put an unwelcome spotlight on Israel, whose intelligence service, the Mossad, is widely believed to have ordered the killing. The Dubai police released extraordinary security video of the killers in February, along with their passport information, which in many cases was obtained fraudulently from dual citizens living in Israel. The suspects can be seen on the videotape disguising themselves as tourists, and following the Hamas operative, Mahmoud al-Mabhouh, to his hotel room. Some of the killers used more than one alias, including one man believed to be Zev Barkan, an Israeli being sought by New Zealand authorities in a 2004 passport fraud case, the person familiar with the investigation said.

headline: Feelings of Donor’s Remorse Emerge After Politician Switches Parties
text: He sits atop a sizable campaign fund, more than $4 million collected over the years from loyal supporters. But these days, Steve Levy, a candidate for governor in New York, is hearing from some contributors that they want their money back.

headline: Iran: A Show of Strength in the Persian Gulf
text: Iran’s Revolutionary Guards began a new round of war games in the Persian Gulf for the second time in less than a month in an effort to show off the country’s military strength. A spokesman for the drills, Adm. Qasem Rstamabadi, said the navy deployed destroyers, missile launchers and submarines, and used Iranian-made systems capable of detecting those who might wish to slip into Iran by water.

headline: Chicago’s Open-Outcry Traders
text: There’s an elegiac poignancy in James Allen Smith’s “Floored,” a documentary about the changing face of the Chicago futures exchanges. Open-outcry trading  the practice of calling out buy and sell orders in soybeans and pork bellies from the floor (the pit)  has declined, like print media, a victim of computer culture and the urgent hunger for instant new information. As electronic trading spreads, and traders work in front of lifeless, antiseptic monitors, a generation of outcry traders finds itself increasingly obsolete. (By around 2008, only hog and cattle futures were trading primarily the old-fashioned way.)

headline: Robert Arneson: ‘Founding Funk: Sculpture and Drawing 1956-1966’
text: Any attempt to reduce New York’s ignorance of serious postwar art elsewhere should be applauded, especially a glimpse of the influential ceramic sculptor Robert Arneson (1930-92) working toward maturity. This applies even if, like me, you’re not crazy about mature Arneson.

headline: Lucio Fontana, Robert Beck and Donald Moffett
text: That the New York gallery world may be entering the phase of the ostentatious “project space” is signaled by the narrow, beautifully restored Victorian house on East 64th Street that Marianne Boesky has rented for exhibitions that juxtapose older art with work by artists she represents. Obviously, this may further sales, but the endeavor has benefits, like the chance to see more of the Argentine-born Italian modernist Lucio Fontana, and in a setting that is itself worth a visit.

headline: Co-Leader’s New Focus Is Strategy, Not Distance
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — J. B. Holmes, who has a share of the lead after the first round of the Players Championship, is not your garden-variety touring professional. Built like a lumberjack, bearded, with barrel staves for forearms and a neck like a hickory stump, Holmes looks more like a bouncer than a golfer.

headline: Mark Ryden: ‘The Gay 90s: Old Tyme Art Show’
text: Fathered by figures like Big Daddy Roth and Robert Williams, a movement affectionately called Lowbrow by its adherents has been percolating out of the quasi-underground pop culture of Southern California since the 1970s. Lowbrow paintings typically feature illustrative technique and comically weird imagery.

headline: Leslie Hewitt: ‘On Beauty, Objects, and Dissonance’
text: Leslie Hewitt aspires to make photographs that are both personal and social, flat and sculptural, archival and insistently contemporary. That’s quite a tightrope walk, and in her solo at the Kitchen, which includes work from the last two years, she’s still finding her balance.

headline: Max Palevsky, a Pioneer in Computers, Dies at 85
text: Max Palevsky, a pioneer in the computer industry and a founder of the computer-chip giant Intel who used his fortune to back Democratic presidential candidates and to amass an important collection of American Arts and Crafts furniture, died on Wednesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 85.

headline: Blackstone Said to Be in Talks to Buy Fidelity National

headline: Walter Sear, an Audio Engineer With a Passion for Analog, Dies at 80

He was 80 and lived on the Upper West Side.

headline: An American Bailout of Greek Proportions
text: The bailout of America’s failed housing finance giants is taking on Greek proportions. On Wednesday, Freddie Mac asked the Treasury for an additional $10.6 billion after posting first-quarter losses. Together, Freddie and its cousin Fannie Mae have drawn $136.5 billion from Treasury’s unlimited equity line since they were seized in September 2008. The European and International Monetary Fund rescue package for Greece, one that was supposed to shock and awe international markets, comes in at the same kind of figure, around $139.7 billion.

headline: Group Backs Ritual ‘Nick’ as Female Circumcision Option
text: In a controversial change to a longstanding policy concerning the practice of female circumcision in some African and Asian cultures, the American Academy of Pediatrics is suggesting that American doctors be given permission to perform a ceremonial pinprick or “nick” on girls from these cultures if it would keep their families from sending them overseas for the full circumcision.

headline: Losses Keep Mounting for the Angels
text: BOSTON – For a few minutes on Thursday night, the Angels were back. The pesky Angels, a playoff fixture for most of the last decade, were on display, drawing three walks, stealing three bases, and knocking two hits to blitz the Red Sox for four runs in the first inning at Fenway Park. It was just the start they needed after six consecutive losses on their road trip and an overnight flight to Seattle (where they will face Felix Hernandez on Friday) coming up.

headline: Tape Exposes Rich-Poor Tussle in Copenhagen
text: 1:05 a.m. | Updated  Here’s a quick note about a remarkable multimedia report in Der Spiegel (English) built around recordings made during the tumultuous back-room discussions by an array of world leaders in the final stages of climate talks last December in Copenhagen. Excerpts of “accidental” audio recordings of the discussions obtained by Der Spiegel vividly display the deep rifts between China and India, on the one hand, and European leaders and other industrialized powers on the other. (The photo below is from the White House Flickr feed.)

headline: Record Crowd Expected for World Championship
text: A record crowd for a hockey game is expected for Friday’s contest between Germany and the United States, the opener of the 2010 International Ice Hockey Federation World Championship tournament. Ticket sales for the match, at the Veltins-Arena soccer stadium in Gelsenkirchen, Germany, have reached 76,152, tournament organizers announced. That would exceed the current record for hockey, the 74,554 who attended the Michigan-Michigan State Cold War game played in East Lansing on Oct. 6, 2001.

But that was before opponents, who can no longer base their cases on fear of the health effects of radio frequency radiation, began to try a new approach. In El Cerrito, San Francisco and around the Bay Area, where there are about 2,900 sites for cellphone antennas, the idea is to prove that cellphone reception is just fine.

headline: Reinventing a Historic Space in Hong Kong
text: Given the speed with which Hong Kong’s colonial buildings have been torn down, it’s fortunate that the old British marine police headquarters survived at all. The 19th-century white-stucco structure had been neglected for more than a decade. Most visitors to the bustling Tsim Sha Tsui area probably did not notice its elegant curving staircase entrance, set back from the neon and noise of Salisbury Road. Late last year the complex, known as 1881 Heritage (1881heritage.com), began reopening in stages, first with a few luxury shops. The main building, Hullett House (hulletthouse.com) now has a number of restaurants, a bar and a boutique hotel that opened last month. Perhaps most impressively, the renovation has been done with care.

headline: My Week in Cash Flow: Friday
text: Note to readers: My five posts this week chronicle the events of the week of Feb. 15. I’m publishing them with some misgivings, as one might get the impression that my business is days from failure at all times. Fortunately, this is not so. That week was especially nail-biting because of the timing of the payments in and out. Also, it was the beginning of an uptick in sales. From where I sit today, the recovery has begun. We now have a normal backlog of work and enough cash on hand to complete it.

headline: Tip of the Week: Joining a Mail List
text: Want to join a mailing list or other e-mail group but don’t want the rest of the messages in your Gmail in-box to get lost? Gmail has supported “plus” addressing for years, and with it, you can get multiple addresses out of one @gmail.com account. All you need to do is stick a + sign and another word after your account name in your Gmail address when signing up for the mailing list or group.

headline: Q. and A.: Aboard the Plucky ‘Plastiki’
text: On March 20, the Plastiki, a 60-foot vessel made from recycled plastic bottles, set sail from San Francisco Bay on an 11,000-mile voyage to Sydney, Australia. The goal of the voyage, masterminded and financed by a banking heir, David de Rothschild, is to call attention to environmental issues like bottled water and plastic waste. Solar panels and windmills power the vessel, and the crew uses Skype, Twitter and blogs to stay in touch with the outside world. They’ve also posted regular video updates.

headline: Speed Read for Friday, May 7

headline: German Lawmakers Approve Greek Rescue
text: German lawmakers on Friday approved the country’s share of the rescue package for debt-laden Greece after a boisterous debate in which the finance minister told them they had no alternative to the unpopular measure, The Associated Press reported.

headline: The Rail Bookshelf: ‘Beyond the Homestretch’
text: Lynn Reardon is the founder and executive director of LoneStar Outreach to Place Ex-Racers (LOPE Texas), a nonprofit racehorse placement agency near Austin. Before founding LOPE, Lynn worked in nonprofit finance and administration in the Washington, D.C.-area for too many years. Lynn lives on the LOPE ranch with her husband, Sophie the dog, multiple cats and a herd of ex-racehorses up for adoption. Lynn has adopted three LOPE horses of her own: Tulsa Mambo, Sally and Lightening Ball.

headline: Whom Would You Interview? What Would You Ask?
text: The Times Magazine regularly runs a series called “Domains” in which famous people talk about their homes, possessions and domestic habits. Last week humor writer Dave Barry was the subject of the column, and he talked about his fridge pet peeve, his eye patch collection, and what he wanted to be at age 5. Whom would you choose to visit if you were writing a “Domains” piece, and what would ask that person to talk about?

headline: A.I.G. Posts $1.5 Billion 1st-Quarter Profit

text: Once upon a time — in the 1990s— e-books for children came on CD-ROMs, and for digital wizardry, offered only mouse clicks and hidden pop-up-like animations. Not anymore. Touch-screens and app stores have given new tricks to old books, and the number of new titles is blossoming.

headline: Sampler: Palin Endorses Fiorina, and Mondavi Estate Is for Sale
text: Palin Endorses Fiorina for Senate | Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska, announced on Thursday her support of Carly Fiorina, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, in California’s crowded United States Senate race. Ms. Palin, the 2008 Republican nominee for vice president, apparently does not hold a grudge against Ms. Fiorina for saying during that campaign that Ms. Palin could not run a major company. Ms. Palin, a favorite of the Tea Party movement, shared her choice on her Facebook page. The endorsement disappointed conservative DeVore supporters. On Thursday night, the three Republican candidates — Ms. Fiorina, former Congressman Tom Campbell and Assemblyman Chuck DeVore — clashed over immigration, gun control and the rights of terrorism suspects in their only debate before the June primary. They are hoping to unseat Senator Barbara Boxer in November. [The New York Times, The Los Angeles Times, The San Jose Mercury News]

headline: Nocturnalist | If Seeing Is Believing, What Is Tasting?
Bruno Is Sentenced but Stays Free
text: Joseph L. Bruno, for years one of the most powerful politicians in New York, was sentenced Thursday to two years in prison on federal corruption charges. But underscoring the serious doubts surrounding the constitutionality of the law used to convict him, Mr. Bruno was allowed to remain free until the Supreme Court rules on the statute. [NYT]

text: BRUSSELS — Leaders from the euro zone countries signed off on a support package for Greece on Friday night and pledged to take steps to stanch a spreading debt crisis before markets opened on Monday morning.

headline: For New Ailey Leader, It’s All in the Family
text: WHEN Robert Battle was 3 weeks old, his great-aunt and great-uncle couldn’t have imagined that one day he would become the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. To them, he was just a bowlegged baby in need of leg braces.

headline: Opera Companies’ Fraught Seasons
text: GEORGE STEEL has just completed his first season as the general manager and artistic director of the New York City Opera. That the company had a season at all — let alone one that offered an important revival of a challenging contemporary American opera, Hugo Weisgall’s “Esther,” and an inventively updated, sexy production of Mozart’s “Don Giovanni” — is a real achievement. A year ago the possibility that the City Opera, crippled by a gnawing deficit and a leadership crisis, might fail seemed all too possible.

headline: A Torrent of ‘Deepwater’ Comments
text: As the oil leak spread in the gulf, activists, elected officials, energy industry reps and scientific experts of all stripes kicked into opinionator mode. Readers of The Times have not hesitated to make their views known, either. In thousands of comments here and elsewhere on the paper’s Web site, they have weighed the causes and consequences of the spill and the implications for the environment and the nation.

headline: Regulator Deferred to Oil Industry on Rig Safety
text: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators warned offshore rig operators more than a decade ago that they needed to install backup systems to control the giant undersea valves known as blowout preventers, used to cut off the flow of oil from a well in an emergency.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: Wilson, Can You Still Have Fun?
text: Is it wrong to enjoy the company of a misanthrope so much? The title character of “Wilson,” a new graphic novel by Daniel Clowes, may be an unsympathetic guy, but that hasn’t prevented the book from landing at No. 2 on the hardcover list this week.

headline: Jury Demographics, and a Hate Crime Unit
text: New York’s criminal justice system is just a governor’s pen stroke away from starting to figure out just how much it truly adheres to the principle of a jury of one’s peers.

headline: Smoothies With Substance (and Style)
text: Smoothies are a delicious and easy way to boost your fruit and vegetable consumption. This week, Martha Rose Shulman offers five new ways to add extra nutrients to a smoothie by blending in nuts and grains.

headline: A Factory-Built Prius for Plug-In Intenders
text: TOYOTA may be the 800-pound gorilla of hybrids, but so far it has been well behind the leading edge of one trend. The company will not have a plug-in hybrid version of its popular Prius for sale to the public until 2012.

headline: Off the Well, if Only for One Week
text: Manhattan Beach, Calif.

headline: A Crossover That’s More About Sport Than Utility
text: TESTED 2010 Mitsubishi Outlander GT

headline: Will the Internet Kill Traditional Car Radio?
text: THE Internet’s tentacles seem to have no limit, reaching out and strangling CDs, bookstores, newspapers and magazines. Now it has its sights set on the car radio.

headline: Bad Dash Light, Grinding Shifts
text: AUDIS needing oxygen sensors and Cadillacs that will not go into gear are among the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: Oil Now and in the Long Haul
text: It’s clear that the risks of pursuing offshore oil matter more to Americans the closer the petroleum deposits are to American camera crews. There were a lot of proponents of offshore drilling, including President Obama, when the spills were half a world away. Even the prospect of drilling off Alaska’s Arctic coast has largely been an abstraction; after all, that exploratory work is to take place in icy waters that few Americans will ever see.

headline: A Designer Who Makes Impalas Do the Limbo
text: The byline for the Auto Ego feature last Sunday was omitted. It was by Richard S. Chang.

headline: Prosecutors Oppose Polanski’s Request for Sealed Testimony
text: The legal battle over Roman Polanski’s possible sentencing in the United States on a 33-year-old sex charge continues, as prosecutors on Thursday registered opposition to Mr. Polanski’s request that recent secret testimony in the case be unsealed. Mr. Polanski, who fled the United States before sentencing in 1978, and his lawyers have asked the Los Angeles County Superior Court to provide them with transcripts of testimony by Roger Gunson, the original prosecutor in the case. In court filings, Mr. Polanski’s lawyers have said Mr. Gunson described a plan under which Judge Laurence J. Rittenband intended to use Mr. Polanski’s time in prison for psychiatric evaluation as his punishment in the case. In their brief on Thursday, Los Angeles County District Attorney Steve Cooley and Deputy District Attorney David Walgren said that the testimony should remain sealed and noted that the authorities in Switzerland, where Mr. Polanski is being held pending possible extradition, have not requested transcripts of the sealed testimony. A hearing on the request is set for Monday.

headline: The Week in Pictures, May 7
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

headline: Friday Reading: Another Invitation-Only Travel Site
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Letters: Mind Over Meds
text: Is it possible that Americans are still inundated by mental-health professionals who peddle a one-size-fits-all therapy to anyone who walks in the office? Let’s hope that Daniel Carlat becomes both savior and saboteur of what has become a grossly misguided, albeit well-intentioned, field of practice.

headline: Inside the List
text: DOPPELGANGSTER: A decade ago, a young Rhodes scholar and Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Johns Hopkins named Wes Moore was conducting research in South Africa when he received a call from his mother. “She said, I have something crazy to tell you,” Moore remembered recently on National Public Radio. “She said, You know, the cops are looking for a man with your name in your neighborhood for killing a cop. . . . There are wanted signs all over your neighborhood for Wes Moore, and if you happen to see Wes Moore, do not approach because he’s assumed to be armed and very dangerous.”

headline: Theory, Literature, Hoax
text: We love stories as much as we need them, but a funny thing has happened to departments of literature. The study of literature as an art form, of its techniques for delighting and instructing, has been replaced by an amalgam of bad epistemology and worse prose that goes by many names but can be summed up as Theory. The situation seems to call for a story, and one written in the style of Jorge Luis Borges, the grand chronicler of the tragicomic struggle between humans and logic.

headline: Deaths in Venice
text: The much-admired atmosphere of Donna Leon’s mysteries derives from more than their pungent descriptions of Venetian life. Not that we don’t appreciate the scenic walks and vaporetto rides her detective, Commissario Guido Brunetti, takes from the police station in Castello to the apartment off the Grand Canal where he lives with his wife and two children. And what reader doesn’t savor those leisurely family dinners on the terrace or the stops at favorite coffee bars.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE IMPERFECTIONISTS,  by Tom Rachman (Dial, $25.) This intricate first novel is built around the personal stories of staff members at an improbable English-language newspaper in Rome, and the family who founded it for obscure reasons in the 1950s.

headline: Paperback Row
text: FOOL’S GOLD: The Inside Story of J. P. Morgan and How Wall Street Greed Corrupted Its Bold Dream and Created a Financial Catastrophe,  by Gillian Tett (Free Press, $16.) Tett explains clearly how a group of talented but shortsighted bankers at J. P. Morgan figured out, or so they thought, how to repeal the financial law of gravity and make risk disappear. They assembled credit derivatives, securitized them and marketed them aggressively. Our reviewer, Paul M. Barrett, questioned Tett’s view that the bold dream of Morgan financiers was corrupted by others but praised her ability to decipher “Wall Street mumbo-jumbo.”

headline: Ancient Chinese Art, in a Western Context
text: Acupuncture is a traditional Chinese medicine that has been in use for thousands of years.

headline: The Morning Line: Confidence in Super Saver
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

headline: Acupuncture Is Popular, but You’ll Need to Pay
text: WHEN Divya Kumar was having trouble getting pregnant four years ago, she meticulously tracked her menstrual cycles and found something was amiss. She was ovulating late, on Day 22, instead of on the more normal Day 14.

headline: F1 Returns to Old Europe
text: The Formula One circus returned to Europe,  and on Friday the first practice sessions were run for the first race of the European leg of the series – which will, as always, be cut in half by a trip to North America in June.

headline: The Cost of Acupuncture
text: Despite growing evidence that acupuncture benefits certain health conditions, most insurance companies still don’t pay for it, writes Lesley Alderman in today’s Patient Money column.

headline: Up Front: Harold Bloom
text: Harold Bloom is probably the most prominent — and the most formidable — literary critic and commentator in America today. Helen Vendler has called him “the foremost critic of his generation.” (For his part, Bloom, noting a physical resemblance to a figure as overwhelming on the stage as he is in the world of letters, has said, “I am Zero Mostel.”)

headline: The Jewish Question: British Anti-Semitism
text: Anthony Julius has written a strong, somber book on an appalling subject: the long squalor of Jew-hatred in a supposedly enlightened, humane, liberal society. My first, personal, reflection is to give thanks that my own father, who migrated from Odessa, Russia, to London, had the sense, after sojourning there, to continue on to New York City.

headline: Consumer Reports Lifts ‘Don’t Buy’ Warning for Lexus GX 460
text: Consumer Reports magazine says the recall to fix a dangerous handling problem on the 2010 Lexus GX 460 works , and so the magazine is lifting its “Don’t Buy: Safety Risk” designation for the vehicle.

headline: The Battle of Britain
text: I don’t see how last night’s British election results, which left David Cameron’s Tories a couple of dozen seats short of a working majority in Parliament, are anything but bad news for the United Kingdom. I defer to wiser heads on the ins-and-outs of the parliamentary maneuvering that’s about to begin, but two things seem clear. First, as The Telegraph puts it this morning, no matter what kind of government gets formed in the next few days, “the only certainty is another general election,” and sooner rather than later. And second, as The Economist’s Buttonwood suggests, the next election will probably be precipitated by resistance — from regional parties and the Liberal Democrats as well as Labour — to the hard budgetary choices a Prime Minister Cameron will be forced to make. Cameron campaigned as a change agent this time, but if he finds himself facing the voters again in a year or so, it will be as the face of fiscal austerity — which is a role that no politician wants to inhabit.

headline: In New York, Some Judges Are Now Skeptical About Debt Collectors’ Claims
text: As New Yorkers have tumbled into credit card debt in large numbers during the great recession, bill collectors have inundated the courts to get what they say is due. In turn, the courts have issued hundreds of thousands of orders against residents. Some consumer groups argue that by doing so, the courts have become little more than an arm of the debt collection industry.

headline: Book Shelf | The Definitive Wonder Woman
text: At the very top tier of the pantheon of heroes published by DC Comics are Superman, Batman and Wonder Woman. Wonder Woman, the Amazing Amazon who has been around since 1941, doesn’t seem to get quite the same amount of recognition as her caped comrades. But 2010 may be her year.

headline: The Jewish Question: Martin Heidegger
text: It may seem surprising that so many books continue to be written debating Martin Heidegger’s Nazi affiliations, since the fact that Heidegger was a Nazi has never been in dispute. How could it be, when the great philosopher took office as rector of Freiburg University in April 1933 specifically in order to carry out the Gleichschaltung, or “bringing into line,” of the school with Hitler’s new party-state? Didn’t he tell the student body, in a speech that November, that “the Führer and he alone is the present and future German reality and its law”? After the war, didn’t he go out of his way to minimize Nazi crimes, even describing the Holocaust, in one notorious essay, as just another manifestation of modern technology, like mechanized agriculture?

headline: Nietzsche: A Philosophy in Context
text: One of the pitfalls of writing a biography of a great philosopher is the temptation to reduce important ideas to mere psychology, an outgrowth of some fluke in the philosopher’s personal development. Julian Young, a professor at the University of Auckland and Wake Forest University, has for the most part avoided this trap by writing a “philosophical” biography of Friedrich Nietzsche (1844-1900) in which the life story provides context but ultimately not explanation for the ideas. In so doing he has provided a serious and readable, if not exactly ground-breaking, introduction to Nietzsche’s “philosophy with a hammer.”

headline: Hot Planet, Cold Facts
text: There ought to be a word, probably in German, for a book that makes the reader boil over with life-­changing eco-enthusiasm only to find himself, a month later, reverting to his old Hummer-­driving, planet-destroying ways. An informal survey of Germanists has failed to come up with anything. But Bill McKibben has found a planet where such books sell well. It is a world where environmental news goes from bad to worse, a place where ice caps vanish, crops fail, oceans acidify, activists rally and an oil company makes more money in three years “than any company in the history of money.” The place McKibben has discovered is an unpronounceable land called Eaarth. Where is Eaarth, you may ask? Unfortunately, you’re soaking in it.

headline: Not the First Time the ‘Dead-Man’ Switch Did Its Job
text: On April 27, as you may recall, a motorman on a G train apparently suffered a fatal heart attack at the controls, activating the so-called dead-man feature, which stops the train when the motorman takes his hand off the controller.

headline: When Jamaica Lost Its Chains
text: Andrea Levy, an English novelist born in 1956 to Jamaican immigrant parents, has made herself a pre-eminent chronicler of Britain’s tangled relations with its former West Indian colonies. In her best-known novel, “Small Island,” which was adapted into a BBC mini-series, Levy portrayed with often heartbreaking wit the hardships faced by her parents’ generation. Highly cultured and ambitious men and women raised to revere the Mother Country, they settled in Britain after the war, only to find themselves shunned, reviled and frequently assaulted by their white working-class neighbors and colleagues, to whom these arrivals from the Caribbean were “savages” come to rape their women and steal their benefits.

headline: Collision Course
text: Great Depression or not, the 1930s wasn’t such a bad time for writers. For some there was the W.P.A., with its government subsidies for artists; for others Hollywood was a cash cow. Magazines still paid pretty well, a Broadway play could set you up and a little money went a long way.

headline: Weekend Competition: Wedding Vows
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to submit wedding vows suitable for the times in which we live.

headline: Goldman to Review Its Business Practices
text: Faced with accusations of securities fraud and conflicts of interest, Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, asserted Friday that the firm was committed to its clients and said it would establish a committee to monitor its business practices.

headline: Hindsight History
text: To the Editor:

headline: From Kenya to America
text: To the Editor:

headline: Washingtonspeak
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lest We Forget
text: To the Editor:

headline: Peeling the Onion
text: “Spoon Fed” is an excellent example of a relatively new genre, one that considers food as therapy. In Kim Severson’s case, it’s not just cooking that helps her deal with life’s vicissitudes but writing about food — which she has done for The New York Times since 2004 and before that for The San Francisco Chronicle. Her subtitle, “How Eight Cooks Saved My Life,” is manifested partly in mini-profiles of Marion Cunningham, Alice Waters, Ruth Reichl, Marcella Hazan, Rachael Ray, Edna Lewis, Leah Chase and her own mother, Anne Marie Zappa Severson, but more in accounts of her dealings with these women. They are pegs on which she hangs her metaphorical garments, with the purpose of revealing a little more of herself each time one is removed. It’s a funny way to construct what is fundamentally a memoir with recipes.

headline: On Our Radar: The Smell of Oil?
text: A foul stench drifts over the Gulf region, with vapor from the oil slick the likely culprit.

headline: Jobs, Jobs, Jobs
text: An actually good employment report. A reminder: there are two separate surveys, one of employers — which is where the 290,000 jobs number comes from — and one of households, which is where the 9.9 percent unemployment rate comes from. Sampling error, seasonal adjustments, and other technical factors can make these reports give contradictory indications.

headline: Maestros, Music, Bows: Big Moments at the New York Philharmonic
text: 1:19 p.m. | Updated As the New York Philharmonic marks an astounding musical milestone — 15,000 concerts — three critics of The New York Times who have attended a good many of those performances — James R. Oestreich, Allan Kozinn and Anthony Tommasini — write about some of the orchestra’s moments that have remained most vivid to them. Readers, please chime in: What New York Philharmonic concerts did you find most memorable?

headline: The Performance-Enhanced Military
text: The military has received much scrutiny in recent years for allegedly overmedicating soldiers who suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder or from other mental illnesses associated with combat.

headline: A Bombshell Bomber
text: Given a few clues and fair warning, could a writer prevent the next terrorist bombing? After all, as David Goodwillie demonstrates in his hip and quick-paced literary thriller, “American Subversive,” which opens after an attack on the Barneys building in New York, the writer’s job is to notice things that other people might overlook and to string together seemingly random details into a coherent plot. Then again, writers are notorious for trying to see everyone’s point of view, and that kind of identification can be dangerous.

headline: Hung Over in Britain
text: UK, Yuck. Not only does no party have a majority, the two somewhat sensible coalitions — Tory-Unionist or Labour-Lib Dem — also lack a majority. Josh Marshall is right: it’s an election that all three parties managed to lose.

headline: Young Singer Just Wants to Act Her Age
text: NIKKI YANOFSKY was up early, and already on. “Mee-ee-ee-ee,” she sang one morning last month, warming up in a tiny dressing room of a Manhattan television studio. A makeup artist leaned in to apply some last-minute touches, and she paused, eyeing her reflection. “You know how everyone says, ‘I’m a morning person,’ or ‘I’m a night person’?” she chirped. “I’m just a person.” Her parents, seated on either side of her, smiled.

headline: If You Build It . . .
text: On Aug. 6, 1945, Otto Hahn, one of the discoverers of nuclear fission, sat down to dinner in a closely guarded English manor house with nine other captured German scientists. They switched on the radio at 9 p.m. to learn that an atomic bomb had been dropped on Hiroshima. Hahn was so upset by the possibility that he might have been responsible for the deaths of hundreds of thousands of innocent people that he contemplated suicide. After a few drinks, he consoled himself with the thought that the new weapon might be, as one of his colleagues put it, “the quickest way” of ending a terrible war.

headline: Backlash Over Bailout May Sway German Vote
text: BOCHUM, Germany — Germans have found themselves cast as the stingy villains in the financial drama over Greece. But in the struggling industrial cities in western Germany voting in state elections on Sunday, they see themselves as victims of endless demands inside and outside the country for dwindling resources.

headline: Hotel Review: East, in Hong Kong
text: THE BASICS

headline: Uncertainty vs. Risk
text: It is three years since the failure of two Bear Stearns hedge funds signaled the start of the biggest financial crisis since the Great Depression, and the air is thick with the sound of stable doors being shut long after the horses bolted. At some point this year a vast new picket fence will be built around the entire ranch, in the form of a new financial regulation act.

headline: The Sisterhood
text: Friction between sisters has served as a plot staple since the dawn of the novel — from “Sense and Sensibility” to “Housekeeping” — if not the inception of the written word (see: Rachel and Leah). Handled properly, it provides a near-perfect occasion for exploring the societal and familial expectations placed on young women, as Heather Clay does in her introspective first novel, “Losing Charlotte.”

headline: CKX’s C.E.O. to Resign and May Place Takeover Bid
text: CKX, which owns a majority stake in the “American Idol” brand, said on Friday that its chairman and chief executive, Robert F. X. Sillerman, had resigned as part of a possible takeover bid for the media company.

headline: Court Rejects Christie’s Limits on Campaign Donations From Labor
text: A New Jersey appeals court on Friday overturned an attempt by Gov. Christopher J. Christie to sharply limit campaign contributions by government employee unions, saying that he could not make such a change without the Legislature’s cooperation.

headline: Magic Noirism
text: It takes guts for a writer to give away his novel’s fundamental conceit in the title itself, yet that’s just what Thomas Mullen has done with his second book, “The Many Deaths of the Firefly Brothers.” In a novel that in every other respect is more 1930s noir than Marquezian fantasy, Mullen has his Depression-era bank robbers — Jason and Whit Fireson, popularly known as the Firefly Brothers — killed violently at least three different times, and then, as if waking from a long night’s sleep with a bad hangover, come achingly back to life. At which point it’s time to rob another bank. Or save a damsel in distress. Until they’re killed again, violently. And then. . . .

headline: Star-Spangled Story
text: Most historians dismiss the story about Betsy Ross making the first American flag. Yet despite a century of debunking, the legend ­endures. Across the country, schoolchildren still cut out five-pointed stars using the pattern that Ross, a Philadelphia flag maker, supposedly invented. The legend endures because publishers, souvenir sellers and patriotic boosters find it useful and because it fills a void in the American epic. Nations need heroines. Betsy Ross gives women a place in the national pantheon without disrupting our dominant myths.

headline: How to Quiet a Blabbermouth
text: Q.

headline: A Lovefest for Chris Knox at Le Poisson Rouge
text: Stay obscure long enough, and people might just cry when they finally hear you play.

headline: When Owners Evict Stabilized Tenants
text: Q.

headline: Protecting Sponsors Through Co-op Bylaws
text: Q.

headline: Why We Travel
text:
China
We were climbing all the way up to the mountain peak, hoping that the storm would stop and we could get a panorama view of the village at dusk.

headline: Another Sad Turn
text: The stories roll in as if propelled by some disturbing sports wave machine: Tiger Woods, Gilbert Arenas, Ben Roethlisberger, a college lacrosse murder and now Lawrence Taylor charged with rape. Each one prompted the Internet version of rubbernecking, vaulted to the top of search lists, stirred some measure of outrage and indignation about out-of-control celebrity, entitlement and so on.

headline: Caring for Micropreemies
text: Amanda Knickerbocker and her husband, Peter, will be spending Mother’s Day in the neonatal intensive-care unit at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia. Their daughter, Charlotte Amalie, arrived four months ahead of schedule, weighing 1 pound 4 ounces.

headline: Temp Jobs Still Rising, Though Not as Fast
text: For the seventh month in a row, temporary help services jobs posted strong gains in April. Since last September, the sector has added over 330,000 positions.

headline: Filmmaker ‘Shocked’ by Judge’s Order for Subpoena
text: Joe Berlinger, the director of the documentary “Crude,” said he was dismayed by a judge’s ruling to allow Chevron to subpoena the footage from his film but that he would comply with a subpoena if one is issued, after exhausting his legal remedies.

headline: Audi Pumps Up the R8
text: Just in time for swimsuit season, Audi has trimmed excess pounds and added extra muscle to its midengine R8 sports car. The 2011 Audi R8 GT is now 210 pounds lighter than the current R8 5.2 TSI. The GT also has 35 additional horsepower, for an even 560, that came from fine-tuning the naturally aspirated V-10 engine mounted behind the passenger compartment.

headline: The 1920 Dwyer: Man o’ War’s Test
text: Teresa Genaro grew up in Saratoga Springs and was well into adulthood before she realized that not all racetracks are like Saratoga. She’s the creator of Brooklyn Backstretch and freelances for a variety of publications. When she’s not obsessing about New York racing, she teaches high school English in Brooklyn. A year ago she wrote a post about the 1920 Dwyer Stakes at Belmont, which she has adapted for The Rail.

headline: TimesCast | May 7, 2010
text: Today, Britain faces a hung Parliament despite big gains for the Conservatives, the U.S. economy adds 290,000 jobs, and regulators investigate the cause of Thursday's steep stock market sell-off.

headline: Just Looking | Collective Identity
text: On a recent Saturday afternoon, a line of people waited to get into the Acquavella Gallery on New York’s Upper East Side. Inside, the usually serene halls were abuzz with decades-old gossip. People had come to see the legendary art collection of Robert and Ethel Scull; among the onlookers were those who knew the couple in their heyday as the Mom and Pop of Pop Art.

headline: Times Square Reopened After ‘Suspicious Package’ Report
text: Updated, 4:40 p.m. | The north end of Times Square was evacuated and shut down for about 90 minutes Friday afternoon after a “suspicious package” was reported just before 1 p.m.

headline: Blankfein, in Victory, Remains Goldman’s Chairman
text: 4:14 p.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Louise Story provides more details about Lloyd C. Blankfein’s relatively pleasant day at the Goldman Sachs annual meeting.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Heidegger, Irène Némirovsky and Anti-Semitism
text: This week: Adam Kirsch on the philosopher Martin Heidegger and the Nazis; Francine Prose discusses the life and stories of Irène Némirovsky; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Coffee to Go That Brews While You Carry It
text: Drip coffee can be a problem at even the best coffee bars. If it’s not stewing in an urn it’s creating long lines while it steeps in a press pot or dribbles from a pourover.

headline: Kimmel: ‘Let Him Out’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Hey, it turns out the prime suspect in the failed attempt to bomb Times Square is not the brightest. They figured out the events leading up to Saturday. First, Faisal Shahzad buys an S.U.V. off Craigslist, using a traceable email, and fills it with, basically, wedding sparklers. Then he drives two different cars into New York — the one with the bomb in it and a getaway car. He plants the bomb but leaves the keys to the getaway car in the car with the bomb in it. So he has to take the subway home. And then, once he gets home, he realizes he also left the key to his apartment in the SUV with the bomb in it, and has to get his landlord to let him in. If this isn’t the work of a stoner, I don’t know what is.

headline: Scare in the Square: Tracking the Failed Times Square Bomber
text: Overview | How did the authorities find and apprehend Faisal Shahzad, the man who confessed to placing a bomb in Times Square? In this lesson, students learn how one person passing through one of America’s busiest places can be tracked down through technology and detective work. They create a flowchart that shows each step—and misstep—in the process, then research how Shahzad’s experience with law enforcement. would differ had he not become a U.S. citizen. They finish the lesson by debating all sides of a related civil rights issue.

headline: Answers About Student Loans: Part 4
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: Three Stars Set Departure from Broadway’s ‘Race’
text: In the latest maneuver in a longstanding affair as tense as any courtroom case (and just as drawn out), the producers of the David Mamet play “Race” said on Friday that its Broadway production will remain open through Aug. 21, but three of its important cast members will not stick around as long.

headline: Fallon: ‘A Weird Call’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: I just heard this about the Times Square bomber. The suspect says he left a getaway car near Times Square but was unable to use it on Saturday because he left the keys in the Pathfinder. That had to be a weird call to OnStar, right? “Hello, OnStar. What is your emergency?” “Oh, man, you are not going to believe this. So, I’m trying to blow up Times Square, right? I am in such a hurry to escape I totally locked the keys in my car. It’s just one of those days.”

headline: O’Neal Having Little Impact Against Celtics
text: Logic would dictate that it should be impossible to make a 7-foot-1, 325-pound man disappear, especially if he’s standing on the floor of a packed basketball arena.

headline: Letterman: ‘I’m No Genius’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: How about that Times Square bomber? Now, I’m no genius, but this guy left his house keys in the bomb car. It was the one flaw in an otherwise perfect crime.

headline: Leno: ‘They Can Never Pay It Back’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Yesterday was Cinco de Mayo. Today, of course, was “Sinko the Dow Jones.”

headline: Old-School Rap and Reggaetón
text: Roc Marciano

headline: Calls for a ‘Blue Ribbon’ Panel on Spill
text: There are two big questions after any accident: Who is at fault, and how can future accidents be prevented?

headline: NBC Orders Up Three New Series
text: Hoping to spread the message that it has a strong slate of series in development, NBC announced today that it has already ordered three more new series for the fall, on top of the J.J. Abrams spy drama “Undercovers” which the network announced it was ordering last week.

headline: Maoists End Strike in Nepal
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — Nepal’s Maoists ended their general strike on Friday after crippling the nation for six days, but failed to achieve their goal of pressuring the prime minister and his coalition government to step down.

headline: The Complete Robin Roberts
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: Abuse Inquiry Expands in German Bishop’s Case
text: BERLIN — A German bishop who offered his resignation after admitting that he had physically abused children as a priest is now under investigation for sexual abuse, yet another shock to the Roman Catholic Church in Germany, which is reeling from a growing child-molestation scandal.

headline: Living in the West Village
text: The West Village has lots of people, and limited, expensive housing options. But on the plus side, it’s “the best place in the world to live.”

headline: Robin Roberts’s Winning Pitch
text: Robin Roberts threw his last pitch for the Philadelphia Phillies in 1961. But a different kind of pitch he made, 10 years later, made an impact on the team that is still felt today.

headline: Beauty and Variety vs. Crowds and Costs
text: LIVING in the West Village has its tradeoffs, just like living anywhere else. On the minus side, there are the tourist buses inching through the neighborhood each day, the near-farcical property prices, the creep of luxury stores up Bleecker Street, the 3 a.m. spillover from bars.

headline: Multicolored Balls, Circa 1980s, Are Fetching a Lot of Green
text: There was quite a stir at eBay last week when a former associate of Tiger Woods’s tried to auction a set of irons he said Woods had used to win four consecutive major championships in 2000-1. The asking price was $250,000. When Woods denied the irons were the ones he used in those events, eBay removed the item from its Web site.

headline: Ensign Investigators Spotted in Vegas
text: Investigators with the Senate Ethics Committee have been spotted this week in Las Vegas, where they appear to be interviewing associates and businessmen connected to the extramarital scandal involving Senator John Ensign, Republican of Nevada.

headline: With a Provocative Ad, Another Business Group Backs Lincoln in Arkansas
text: Last week we related how the United States Chamber of Commerce had bought television air time in Arkansas to support Democratic Senator Blanche Lincoln. Ms. Lincoln is in a tough primary fight with Lt. Gov. Bill Halter, who has the backing of more liberal Democrats in Arkansas, as well as labor unions and other progressive organizations. The primary is May 18, and the race is considered by at least one local observer a toss-up.

headline: Canucks Need a Turnaround, and Some Grit, Against Blackhawks
text: The time is now if the Vancouver Canucks want to get back into their second-round series with the Chicago Blackhawks.

headline: Summer Stages: Classical
text: Arizona GRAND CANYON MUSIC FESTIVAL Aug. 27-28, Sept. 3-4 and Sept. 10-12. With spectacular scenery and fine music making, this small festival is a treat for eyes and ears. The lineup in the Shrine of the Ages, near the south rim of the canyon, includes the adventurous string quartet Ethel and the American Indian flutist Robert Mirabal. (800)997-8285, grandcanyonmusicfest.org. California BERKELEY FESTIVAL AND EXHIBITION University of California, Berkeley, June 6-13. There's plenty to keep early-music buffs happy at this festival, where concerts this summer include Gesualdo's "Tenebrae Responsoria"; Baroque music played by the Marion Verbruggen Trio; and Monteverdi madrigals performed by the ensemble Artek. (510)642-9988, bfx.berkeley.edu.

headline: Lady Gaga vs. ‘American Idol': Nobody Wins
text: This hasn’t been an easy week to be a behemoth of either pop music or television. On the one hand, you have the colossally popular Lady Gaga, who got the gossip columns buzzing about the amount of time it may or may not have taken her to emerge from her dressing room at the Costume Institute Gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday night. On the other, you have the monstrously successful “American Idol,” whose ratings have seen worrisome declines this year amid complaints about a ho-hum lineup of contestants. (But not Crystal Bowersox!)

headline: Graham Calls for ‘Pause’ in Pursuing Energy Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Lindsey Graham, one of the chief sponsors of a nascent plan to address energy and climate change in the Senate, said Friday that the proposal had no chance of passage in the near term and called for a “pause” in consideration of the issue.

headline: A Toyland for Grown-Ups
text: AT Carteles, a Cuban sandwich shop on East Sixth Street, the scene was congenial on Saturday evening of last weekend. People lingered by the counter while “Buscando a Visa Para un Sueño” played on a large iPod disguised as a boom box. The first warm breaths of spring filtered in through the open door as the owners and brothers, Ravi DeRossi and Kubs Lalchandani, stood by, taking turns scurrying upstairs to check on Cienfuegos, the latest bar in Mr. DeRossi’s East Village craft cocktail empire, which includes Death & Company, Mayahuel and the Bourgeois Pig.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Heidegger, Irène Némirovsky and Anti-Semitism
text: This week: Adam Kirsch on the philosopher Martin Heidegger and the Nazis; Francine Prose discusses the life and stories of Irène Némirovsky; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: English Legends: That Robin Guy and Sir Ridley
text: RIDLEY SCOTT had seen better days. True, he was at the Four Seasons in Beverly Hills a few weeks ago while studio types fluttered about making sure that the fruit platters were just so. But he was about to be press-ganged, fed to roomfuls of reporters who would ask him how his latest film, “Robin Hood,” compares to “Gladiator” (it does and it doesn’t) and whether he and Russell Crowe bickered on the set. (Not really, theirs is just a full-contact collaboration.)

headline: Working for Workers
text: I have a friendly acquaintance with employees at a nearby market, immigrants from Nepal and Mexico. I suspect they make less than the minimum wage. One checkout clerk says he works 10-hour days, six days a week, with no overtime pay. I gather that they lack green cards and so are reluctant to complain. I want to report this to the authorities but do not want to get anybody fired or in trouble with immigration. What should I do? STUART GOLD, BROOKLYN

headline: Mother’s Little Helper
text: Mornings are not our best family moments. I am waffle server, vitamin and toothpaste dispenser, fashion consultant, backpack checker, sandwich maker, coat zipperer, winter-accessories pusher. The repeated reminders, foot stomping, tears — it’s as if we’ve never done this before, and I hate the sound of my own voice.

headline: Students of the Great Recession
text: The Great Depression did not have too many silver linings, but it did change the way Americans thought about education, clearly for the better. In 1930, only 30 percent of teenagers graduated from high school. By 1940, after a decade in which there often was nothing better to do than stay in school, the number had jumped to 50 percent. The Depression didn’t just make Americans tougher. It made them smarter.

headline: Art That Sells Itself
text: On Jan. 28, while on a business trip to Chicago, Terence Spies used his iPhone to monitor an eBay auction. He was trying to outbid a couple of rivals to win a black plastic box that was at the time on display at an art gallery in Seattle. Spies had read about “A Tool to Deceive and Slaughter,” as the piece is called, on a Reuters financial blog. That’s a strange-enough place for a collector to learn about art, but Spies’s interest seems even more curious given that the blogger Felix Salmon’s write-up of the piece’s sale was titled “The Uncollectible Artwork.” Even if Spies won the object, created by a young artist named Caleb Larsen, his ownership would be tentative: the technical innards of “A Tool to Deceive and Slaughter” carried a program that would relist the thing on eBay every week, forever. Indeed, the terms and conditions for submitting a bid clearly stipulated that the device must be connected to the Internet, constantly trying to resell itself at a higher price to someone else.

headline: The Plural of E-Mail
text: Ashley Mergen asks: "What is the proper plural of e-mail? When referring to snail mail, you would not say, 'I received a hundred mails,' but rather, 'I received a hundred pieces of mail' or 'I received a hundred mailings.' However, when referring to e-mail, one would say, 'I received a hundred e-mails.' Correct?"  The plural form of e-mail is, indeed, e-mails, even though there's no corresponding plural of mail as mails. This mismatch has rankled seekers of grammatical consistency over the years, but it has nonetheless settled into standard usage.  First some terminology. Nouns that can form plurals are called "count nouns." Mail, historically, is what is known as a "mass noun" — a noun that can't be enumerated and thus resists pluralization, much like mud and milk, patience and poppycock. Some nouns can be either count or mass, depending on the context. General Sherman used war as a mass noun when he said, "War is hell," while Benjamin Franklin used it as a count noun when he said, "All wars are follies, very expensive and very mischievous ones."  Many mass nouns have spawned countable spinoffs over time. Coffee is usually an undifferentiated mass ("Get me some coffee"), but in modern use it can also be treated as a count noun denoting a cupful of the beverage ("Get me a coffee") or a variety of the bean ("We serve the finest Arabica coffees"). The Stanford linguist Arnold Zwicky has dubbed this process "countification."  When the word e-mail first made its appearance in the early 1980s (often capitalized as E-mail), it was simply a shortening of electronic mail, and so it worked grammatically much like the mass noun mail. To itemize mail into its constituent parts you need to find a workaround like pieces of mail or letters. Similarly, individual pieces of e-mail came to be called e-mail notes or more commonly, e-mail messages. (Single terms like e-notes or e-letters never caught on.)  By the late '80s, e-mail message was slowly but surely shortened to e-mail. In the archives of the magazine InfoWorld, the earliest use of e-mail as a count noun that I can find is from July 20, 1987, in an advertisement for International Data Group (IDG). "Jane Lawrence, editor of IDG's PC Business World, receives an E-mail from [Ann] Wujcik requesting information," the ad reads. Though the magazine generally preferred e-mail message, by 1992 even InfoWorld's publisher Robert Metcalfe was using the short form: "I have to admit I am now getting so many E-mails I can only read all and answer a few of them."  The countable kind of e-mail(s) made further headway over the course of the '90s, despite complaints that it strayed from the founding model of mail, and by the turn of the millennium it had become widely accepted in mainstream usage. (The mass-noun version never went away, of course.) What happened? My theory is that the e- prefix no longer felt like such a transparent abbreviation of electronic, allowing e-mail to cast off the bonds that kept it close to mail of the snail variety. The word's new unitary feel was further strengthened by the trend of spelling it as email, without the hyphen. (The New York Times style guide continues to stick by hyphenated e-mail, and even advises using the older, longer form of the noun, e-mail message.)  The countification of e-mail mirrors some other recent developments in tech-talk. Unwanted e-mail, known as spam, is usually treated as a mass noun (just like the canned meat after which it is named), but individual spam messages now often get called spams. And the word blog, while always countable, has taken a new semantic turn: some use it to mean a single post to a Web site, rather than a whole site consisting of such posts. A recent survey by the Copyediting newsletter finds that most writers and editors reject this usage of blog as improper, but who knows? In a decade's time, it could be as unremarkable as countable e-mails.

headline: The Demise of Datebooks
text: I miss my Filofax datebook, with its six rings and dark red leather binder. I had a green one first, with a calendar that cast each week across two cream-colored pages. Back then, at age 30, I was not busy enough to need a whole page per day, which some Filofax calendars provide, but far too busy, or so I liked to imagine, to fit a week’s activities on a single page. I left that green one in a taxi and replaced it with a red one. Old reddie is still around, with my life during half of 2007 memorialized. Even when I started half-heartedly to use iCal, Apple’s personal-calendar program for the Mac, I lugged around the Filofax in case I needed — I don’t know — the address book? The dry-measure equivalent for “bushel”? The dialing code for Saudi Arabia? The size conversions for tailors (“Glove sizes are the same in every country”)? The centigrade temperature in Accra in May?

headline: Pregnant and Pained
text: Even sitting quietly in the hospital bed, the young woman looked out of breath. The muscles of her neck were pulled tight, and she lifted her shoulders as she inhaled, as if simply taking in air required work. According to the chart that Dr. Roxanne Wadia had glanced through, the patient was five months pregnant. But her arms and legs were thin and wasted-looking, and she had only a tiny hint of the expected baby bump. Her eyes were sunken, and her skin was sallow. Looking at her new patient, Wadia, a resident in her second year of training at Tufts Medical Center in Boston, felt her own heart quicken. The patient was clearly sick. The doctor gave her patient oxygen and then sat down to take a history.

headline: China’s Arranged Remarriages
text: THE NEWLYWEDS are perfectly happy, can’t you see?

headline: David Chang, Party Animal?
text: David Chang is not the first person you’d think to ask to host a party. In truth, he might very well be the last. Even though Time selected him as one of this year’s most influential people in the world, he scored a zero on the magazine’s social networking index.

headline: The New Money Rules for Recent Graduates
text: Graduation season is a time of oddly mixed emotions for the people finishing college and graduate school. On the one hand, there is pride in a job well done (or relief at simply getting through) and the satisfaction of having finished a long, hard slog. On the other, there is primal fear. Will anyone pay me to do something I’m good at? And will I actually have enough money to live on?

headline: Your Best Advice for New Graduates
text: In this week’s Your Money column, I review the big changes in the world of health insurance, banking, credit cards and student loans that are likely to affect people who are finishing school right now.

headline: Ric Burns Says Judge’s Ruling on Film Could Be ‘Killer Blow’
text: The director Ric Burns said that a judge’s decision to permit Chevron to subpoena the footage from the movie “Crude” could deliver a “killer blow” to how documentary filmmakers cultivate their sources and tell their stories.

headline: The Morning Skate: The Coyotes’ Lease, Montreal Ghosts and Strange Officiating
text: Three weeks ago, when the City of Glendale approved the lease agreement with a group led by Jerry Reinsdorf for the Coyotes’ Jobing.com Arena, it was noted that the agreement faced opposition from Arizona’s conservative Goldwater Institute. It contended the deal violated a state law that prohibits public subsidies of private enterprises.

headline: For Mortgage Shoppers, Less Can Be More
text: THE Internet can help simplify many financial transactions, though not always when it comes to home mortgages. Those who sign up for information at mortgage Web sites have found themselves receiving a flood of calls and e-mail messages from brokers and lenders soliciting business.

headline: Protecting Your Home, Part 2, or, What Readers Think

text: BATAC, the Philippines — At a mall food court here, where she was sitting with reporters covering her campaign for the House of Representatives, Imelda Marcos inserted iPod earbuds on either side of her bouffant coiffure.

headline: Ferragamo’s Apartment for Sale
text: CARE to buy a $2,350 bag? The Fiammetta calfskin tote by Ferragamo affords you that opportunity. And if you’d like a place to put it, Massimo Ferragamo might sell you his own apartment — if you had $16 million.

headline: A Celebration Is Haunted by the Ghost of Stalin
text: MOSCOW — As Russians prepare to celebrate the 65th anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany this weekend, an event hallowed here as the unalloyed triumph of good over evil, a major question still looms: What should be done about Stalin?

headline: More Untraditional Breakfasts
text: As I’ve said before, I have cravings. I woke up one morning this week wanting ful madammes (فول مدمس, for those of you who read Arabic, at least according to the Wikipedia spelling). But cooking whole favas, which is the basis for the “real” dish — or at least the dish the way I’ve had it cooked by Egyptians — is way too time-consuming for breakfast.

headline: New MyTouch Has a Nice Keyboard — but You May Never Use It
text: The myTouch 3G Slide adds a slide-out keyboard to the already familiar myTouch phone, even though the new version needs a keyboard less than the old one did. That is because the new version  has built-in voice command software.

text: WHO remembers that catchy ’N Sync song “Bye, Bye, Bye?” Turns out a former band member, Lance Bass, has decided to buy, buy, buy a condo at the Chelsea Mercantile.

text: HCA plans to raise $4.6 billion in its third initial public offering of common stock, more than three years after the hospital chain was taken private in a leveraged buyout by a group of private equity investors, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Russia Frees Somali Pirates It Had Seized in Shootout
text: MOSCOW — Two days after Russian marines captured 10 Somali pirates in a much-ballyhooed high-seas shootout, freeing Russian crew members who had barricaded themselves for 20 hours in the dank safety of an engine room, Russia’s Defense Ministry on Friday announced an anticlimactic ending to the saga.

headline: Woods Struggles Again, but This Time He Makes the Cut
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Tiger Woods shot his second straight subpar round in the Players Championship on Friday, a one-under-par 71 to go with his opening 70, which is better than last week, good enough to make the weekend but a $30 cab ride from leader Lee Westwood’s 36-hole total of 12 under.

headline: India’s Top Court Settles Dispute on Energy Prices
text: NEW DELHI — India’s Supreme Court on Friday settled a dispute between two billionaire brothers that had been as closely watched as a Bollywood melodrama, with an outcome that has potentially broad implications for this country’s struggling energy industry.

headline: Echoes of Florida as British Election Drama Goes On
text: Early on Friday, as it became clear that British voters had failed to give one party a majority of seats in the new Parliament, Ed Miliband, Britain’s secretary of state for energy and climate change, told The BBC, “The people have spoken, but we don’t quite know what they’ve said.” The remark echoed then-President Bill Clinton’s observation during an American election that headed into extra time, with the recount in Florida in 2000.

text: This week’s Wealth Matters column passes along tips from readers who were responding to last week’s column about home security systems.
