text: Mr. Lettire, 52, is the president and chief executive of the Lettire Construction Corporation, which he founded with his brother, Gerard, in 1979. He is also a founder and the president of the Urban Builders Collaborative, the company’s development arm. His current projects include the affordable-housing developments Via Verde in the Bronx and Hobbs Court and the Ciena in East Harlem.

headline: In Construction, Home Building Alone Struggles to Its Feet
text: THE residential construction industry, which plunged to its lowest level of activity since World War II in the wake of the credit crisis, now seems to have stabilized at a low level. But the nonresidential construction business is still declining and may be particularly vulnerable to government spending reductions.

headline: Lincecum Helps Reinvent the Giants
text: The San Francisco Giants come to Flushing on Friday, and for years that would have brought to mind one image: Barry Bonds. It was impossible to take your eyes off Bonds. Few players have ever been so talented. Few have ever seemed so angry all the time. And that was before the steroids saga distorted everything.

headline: Building the Next McEnroe
text: When John McEnroe considers the future of tennis, he imagines the height of his past. He can see a 21st-century version of himself, challenging the orthodoxy, combating the world, emerging from a laboratory that is named after him.

text: 3:35 p.m. | Updated A federal bankruptcy judge granted General Growth Properties’ motion to certify an investment plan led by Brookfield Asset Management as its “stalking-horse” bid. Minutes later, the Simon Property Group said it was withdrawing its $20-a-share bid.

headline: How Obama Sr. Came to Hawaii
text: In his review last month of “The Bridge,” David Remnick’s biography of President Obama, Garry Wills touched briefly upon the airlift that brought students from East Africa, among them the man who would become Obama’s father, to the United States.

headline: Long Island City Comes Into Its Own
text: IT’S got sushi bars. A teahouse. An upscale grocery store. A cocktail lounge where the word “mixologist” could reasonably be uttered. Multiple options for doggy day care. It’s one stop from Manhattan, the views are fabulous, and, joy to the world, there are no alternate-side parking rules.

headline: Now Showing | Neither Hollywood Nor Cannes, but Paris
text: Many models go on to become actors (Cameron Diaz, Famke Janssen); some become musicians (Carla Bruni, Nico); and others, moguls (Kate Moss, Tyra Banks). But not many can bust out the “model-turned-photographer” title as Ellen von Unwerth can.

headline: Tasting Chablis
text: I had dinner one recent night at Apiary with John Gilman, who writes the excellent newsletter View From the Cellar, and John brought along some Chablis from Patrick Piuze, a producer with whom I was unfamiliar. The wines were from the 2008 vintage, which I hadn’t tasted yet. If you recall how much I love Chablis, you would be correct in assuming that I was excited.

headline: BMW Recreates a 328 Kamm Coupé for the Mille Miglia
text: The Mille Miglia, the road race from Brescia, Italy, to Rome and back that began this week, marks the 70th anniversary of the year BMW swept the race’s top spots in 1940.   To commemorate, the company has entered what it describes as a contemporary replica of the so-called 328  Kamm Coupé.  The replica was unveiled at the recent concours d’elégance at the Villa d’Este on Lake Como.

headline: At Trumpeter’s Home, the Door’s Always Open
text: On Thursday evening, Joey Pero walked past Lincoln Center and stepped into the lobby of a luxury high-rise apartment building on West 66th Street and told the doorman, “We’re here to see Wynton.”

headline: The Last Days of Bruce Llewellyn
text: ALMOST everyone who visited J. Bruce Llewellyn three years ago in the Mary Manning Walsh nursing home in Manhattan heard the same refrain: Get me out of here.

headline: Pounding the Pavement on a Bryant Park Pedestal
text: The warm-weather sidewalks around Bryant Park are usually as packed as the stateroom scene in the Marx Brothers’ “Night at the Opera.” But beginning on Monday, if pedestrians plowing through raise their weary heads, they will encounter a vision of truly stunning Midtown Manhattan density in the air above them.

headline: In a Laboratory, Turning Traditional Notions of Opera Upside Down
text: In 1999, when Paul Kellogg, then the general and artistic director of New York City Opera, inaugurated the VOX project, a laboratory for new American operas, he asked George Steel, the executive director of the Miller Theater, to host the workshops there. The idea was to present sizable excerpts from new and recent operas, and in some cases works in progress, in concert performances. Mr. Steel, who had made the Miller Theater a hotbed of contemporary music, embraced the project. VOX was so successful that it moved to larger spaces for its later annual workshops.

headline: Volcker Says Derivatives Proposal Goes Too Far
text: Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, has voiced some concerns about Senator Blanche Lincoln’s proposal to regulate the derivatives market much more tightly, saying that he is not in favor of forcing banks to spin off their derivatives operations.

text: 5:44 p.m. | Updated Turbulence continued to rock the equity markets on Friday, as Wall Street closed out one of its most volatile weeks since the financial crisis of 2008, The New York Times’s Christine Hauser and Matthew Saltmarsh report.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Nepal and Elsewhere
text: No, this is not Athens. Nor is it Bangkok. On Friday, the city convulsed by civil unrest was Katmandu, Nepal, where a violent strike by the country’s Maoists has left most businesses shuttered, schools closed and transportation crippled. Paralysis of a different kind is feared in Britain after an election that denied an outright majority to any single political party. A triptych of the three party leaders begins with Slide 4.

headline: White House Deputy Counsel Resigns
text: 5:40 p.m. | Updated Daniel J. Meltzer, a top White House lawyer who has played a critical behind-the-scenes role in the administration legal team, is resigning next month and will return to his tenured position as a Harvard law school professor, the White House said on Friday.

headline: A Maverick Upends Colombian Politics
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Given the staid nature of the political establishment in Colombia, Washington’s top ally in the region, and the broad popularity of President Álvaro Uribe, it seemed a foregone conclusion to many here that his heir apparent would clinch the presidency in the coming elections without too much of a struggle.

headline: Adding a Dimension to the Frenzy
text: AT this moment, poised between the release of “How to Train Your Dragon”  seven weeks and around $200 million of domestic box office in the past  and the arrival of the next and final “Shrek” movie two weekends from now, we find ourselves in the middle of what film historians of the future may remember as the great 3-D frenzy of 2010. It is difficult, in the middle of any momentous historical event, to discern its true nature. Is this a revolution or a craze? Will the new 3-D, like sound in the late 1920s and ’30s, color and widescreen a generation later, or computer-generated imagery over the past decade, fundamentally alter the way movies are made and experienced? Or will it be more like the old 3-D: an intriguing but ultimately limited gimmick?

headline: The Perils of Sexual Roundelays
text: HOOKING up has been held responsible for a number of interpersonal woes, from the proliferation of sexually transmitted diseases to the withering of courtship and the death of true love. Now, according to a round of tsking headlines, hook-ups and their Gen X cousin, “friends with benefits,” have been associated with another risk: overlapping lovers or, in academic parlance, “concurrent partners.”

headline: Preakness Field Coming Together
text: Slowly, the gates are beginning to fill for the 135th running of the Preakness Stakes, and it appears that the Kentucky Derby winner Super Saver is going to have some formidable company, among them a colt who finished in front of him the last time they met, Schoolyard Dreams.

headline: The New York Philharmonic, Way Back When
text: The New York Philharmonic’s 15,000th concert, reviewed by Anthony Tommasini in The New York Times on Friday, set Mr. Tommasini and two other Times critics, James R. Oestreich and Allan Kozinn, to pondering other Philharmonic milestones and favorite concerts. Their thoughts follow.

headline: Autodesk for the People
text: Autodesk is having a consumer moment.

headline: Yes, Those Are Real Girls Doing Icky Science Things
text: Here’s hoping that one of the delightful young ladies on “SciGirls,” a new series under the PBS Kids Go! banner, grows up to be tech-savvy enough that she figures out how to remove annoying animated interlopers from otherwise excellent television programs.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: During medieval times, the hilltop castles in the Languedoc region of southwestern France were strongholds of the Cathars, a zealous religious group persecuted, sometimes horrifically, by the Catholic Church. Eight hundred years later, Tony Perrotet returns to the battlefield and finds a traveler’s playground.

headline: A Non-Mother’s Day
text: Pamela Mahoney Tsigdinos will be spending Mother’s Day with a group of friends who are not mothers. And not for lack of trying. Tsigdinos is the author of “Silent Sorority: A (Barren) Woman Gets Busy, Angry, Lost and Found,” about coming to terms with her own infertility. She also blogs at A Fresh Start, a communal site she created for women to share their stories. Mother’s Day looks different from where she stands, she writes in a guest blog today, as she does every other day of the year.

headline: Running a Prius From the Sun
text: Saving the world might not be as tough as it looks. In this weekend’s Automobiles section, I investigate what it’s like to drive a Toyota Prius converted to plug-in-hybrid status, a 10 kilowatt-hour, lithium-iron-phosphate battery pack hidden under its trunk carpet.

headline: Dispatch From Dubai | Mr. Armani’s Dream Hotel
text: I am probably the only journalist who was invited to the opening of the world’s first Armani Hotel, located in Dubai’s soaring Burj Khalifa, and wasn’t told that the event had been moved from the 21st to the 27th of April because of the volcano eruption in Iceland.

headline: Submitted for Your Approval, a Current TV Series Pays Tribute to a Classic One
text: For those viewers of the ABC sitcom “Modern Family” who thought there was something vaguely familiar about a moment in Wednesday’s episode, you are not living in “The Twilight Zone.” The scene paid homage, in a subtle way, to a well-remembered episode of “The Twilight Zone.”

headline: Can Michelle Obama Make You a Star?
text: LAST Saturday night, Michelle Obama walked into a staid Washington hotel ballroom wearing a striking red gown, and within minutes the fashion world was talking.

headline: Baffert Undecided About ‘Lucky’ in the Preakness
text: Bob Baffert’s Conveyance is not going to compete in the Preakness Stakes, but he has yet to decide whether his 2-year-old champion Lookin at Lucky will make the trip to Baltimore for the second leg of the Triple Crown.

headline: Bennett Braces for Difficult Day
text: For those interested, Saturday’s Republican convention in Utah could offer some hints about how dimly the country views both incumbents and Washington.

headline: Long Island City: A Neighborhood That's a Long Time Coming
text: Has Long Island City, 30 years after it was first labeled “hot,” finally become a self-sustaining neighborhood?

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Here, once again with some help from Dave Cook, is a weekend’s worth of food-related activities:

headline: Swashbuckling Glover Adjusts to TPC Sawgrass
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — His work with the print media done, Lucas Glover stepped outside for a television Q. and A. He stood smiling behind the camera until a member of the crew gently directed to a spot in front of the lens.

headline: F.C.C. Allows Movie Studios to Block Copying of New Video-on-Demand Releases
text: LOS ANGELES — In a significant victory for the major movie studios, the Federal Communications Commission on Friday approved a request to allow companies that sell movies via video-on-demand services to activate signals that would block the copying or other re-use in home entertainment systems of recent releases.

headline: Security Tour of Times Square
text: A former Secret Service agent gives a tour of Times Square in the aftermath of the failed car bombing.

headline: Summer Stages: Pop and Jazz
text: CaliforniaHOLLYWOOD BOWL June 12-Oct. 8. It's become somewhat de rigueur to pair a pop act with an orchestra (one gets a little extra bombast, the other a little extra edge), and each summer, the Hollywood Bowl plays matchmaker. On June 15 Sting will perform with the Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra; on July 2-4 Vince Gill will team up with the Los Angeles Philharmonic; on Aug. 13-14 Harry Connick Jr. and his Big Band will do the same; and on Oct. 2 Carrie Underwood will sing alongside the Hollywood Bowl Orchestra. Other notable bookings: the Playboy Jazz Festival (June 12-13), Femi Kuti and the Positive Force (July 7), Kings of Leon (July 12), B.B. King and Buddy Guy (Aug. 11), and the Neville Brothers (Aug. 18). (323)850-2000, hollywoodbowl.com.

headline: Rajaratnam Seeks to Throw Out Government Wiretaps
text: Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund billionaire accused of insider trading, sought on Friday to dismiss the government’s most powerful evidence against him: thousands of wiretapped conversations between him and family, friends and associates.

headline: Chic in Review | Met Ball Madness
text: American ApparelClaims none of the people in its campaigns are professional models. Even though some of them have agencies. Which I think must make them models. Oops.

headline: German Parliament Approves Greek Rescue
text: After one of its most heated debates in years, the German Parliament voted Friday to approve its part of the emergency package arranged by the International Monetary Fund and the European Union, The New York Times’s Judy Dempsey reported.

headline: Manet Self-Portrait: New Star on the Block
text: Paintings by Édouard Manet rarely come up for sale, let alone self-portraits, of which he painted only two. But “Self-Portrait With a Palette,” from 1878, which depicts the Impressionist master posed in an impeccably tailored jacket, will be a star of Sotheby’s Impressionist and Modern art auction in London on June 22, where it is expected to sell for $30.1 million to $45.2 million.

headline: Asparagus Pesto
text: Mark Bittman cooks asparagus pesto, which makes a tasty topping for fish.

headline: Caraoke, for When the Shower Is Too Far Away
text: Think of it as radio plus.

headline: Joe and Mika, the Odd Couple of Morning TV
text: LAST week on the North Lawn of the White House, the morning after the annual White House Correspondents’ Association dinner, Joe Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski held court on the grass, presiding over a special Sunday edition of their MSNBC daily news program, “Morning Joe.” As they sat beside one another in directors’ chairs — Mika in a black evening gown with a plunging neckline; Joe in a dinner jacket (sans tie), both of them wearing dark sunglasses — they exuded the reckless, easy glamour of old-style Hollywood stars: Rock Hudson and Doris Day (but Doris Day with a tan and killer abs).

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 7
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York City region. Subjects include pocket-size hotel rooms, a failed car bombing in Times Square, and the sale of a Picasso.

headline: Starving the Beast
text: In his Forbes.com column this week, Bruce Bartlett opines on the perniciousness of the “starve the beast” mantra. A former official in the Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations, Mr. Bartlett writes:

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 7
text: Images from this week in culture.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 7
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Containment Effort Inches Closer to Oil Target
text: ROBERT, La. — A giant steel container meant to capture oil leaking into the Gulf of Mexico was lowered to within 200 feet of the seafloor on Friday afternoon, officials said.

headline: Roasted Radishes: So Who Knew?
text: OF all the things you can do with a radish — slice it into salads, chop it into salsa, shred it into slaw or, better, top it with a thick layer of sweet butter and a sprinkling of flaky sea salt — the last thing I’d thought to do was cook it.

headline: Asparagus Pesto Packs Plenty of Flavor
text: THERE are few things that can be treated as simply as asparagus, which takes almost nothing to be delicious. But how many times can you eat lightly cooked, lightly seasoned asparagus before you tire of it?

headline: After Flooding, Nashville Musicians Assess Losses
text: NASHVILLE — The country music star Brad Paisley was one of hundreds of performers who feared for their instruments this week after the Cumberland River overflowed. The water covered large areas of Nashville, flooding the Grand Ole Opry stage with two feet of it, causing heavy damage to the symphony hall and forcing electricity to be cut in a tourist neighborhood of downtown.

headline: From Sarah Silverman, an Adorable Look, Followed by a Sucker Punch
text: EVEN with the Red Sox beanie pulled over the trademark mane of black hair, it’s not hard to spot Sarah Silverman in the lobby at the Bowery Hotel: she’s the grown woman dressed like a 14-year-old boy. Promoting her new memoir, “The Bedwetter” — which was No. 9 last week on The New York Times nonfiction hardcover list — Ms. Silverman saunters toward me in an American Apparel sweatshirt, Free City sweats, and worn Adidas. “In 18 months of working with her, I don’t think I ever saw Sarah in a shirt that didn’t have a number on it,” says David Hirshey, her editor at HarperCollins, which paid $2.5 million for her book. “She dresses as if she’s always ready for a touch football game.”

headline: Films of G.I.’s That Star Average Joes
text: Like many fictional works set during World War II, the film “Pastrami on Rye” is more than just a history lesson. The six-minute movie, about two American soldiers passing the interminable hours in their foxholes, musing about what they’ll do when they return home and debating whether it is wiser to bring a sandwich or a gas mask into battle, has a fundamentally existential tone. It is less about death than it is about the many trivial things the mind can contemplate while facing the certainty of it.

headline: A Cross Of Gold
text: Reacting to today’s column, Greg Mankiw points out another reason American makes a better currency union than Europe: high labor mobility, thanks to our cultural homogeneity. Indeed; that’s Mundell’s original optimum currency area argument. (It was actually in my first draft of today’s column, but length was a problem — I needed to cut another 200 characters — and it also doesn’t bear too directly on the current European issues.)

headline: Serious Play, and Notes on Paper, in This Salon
text: The days when choreographers had lofts in SoHo, where they lived, and friends came over and drank wine and watched works in progress, and threw some money into a bowl, and then everyone sat around talking about the dances, are over, no?

headline: ‘Survivor’ Lifts CBS
text: CBS won its eighth consecutive Thursday night in the ratings as “Survivor: Heroes vs. Villains” earned its best numbers since its season premiere. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the CBS reality show attracted 12.8 million viewers, leading the 8 p.m. hour and helping to lift the network into the lead for the night. CBS’s 10 p.m. crime show, “The Mentalist,” delivered the night’s largest audience with 14.7 million viewers, while “CSI” (14.2 million) helped CBS outperform ABC and “Grey’s Anatomy” (10.7 million) in the 9 p.m. hour as well. ABC was second on the night, garnering 8.3 million viewers for “Private Practice” at 10 but only 4.8 million at 8 for “FlashForward.” In third place, Fox broadcast “Bones” at 8 (8.9 million) and “Fringe” at 9 (5.8 million), while NBC finished fourth, garnering its best ratings at 9 for “The Office” (6.8 million).

headline: Polanski Transcript Plea Opposed by Prosecutors
text: The legal battle over Roman Polanski’s possible sentencing in the United States on a 33-year-old sex charge continues, as prosecutors on Thursday registered opposition to Mr. Polanski’s request that recent secret testimony in the case be unsealed. Mr. Polanski, who fled the United States before sentencing in 1978, and his lawyers have asked the Los Angeles County Superior Court to provide them with transcripts of testimony by Roger Gunson, the original prosecutor in the case. In court filings, Mr. Polanski’s lawyers have said Mr. Gunson described a plan under which Judge Laurence J. Rittenband intended to use Mr. Polanski’s time in prison for psychiatric evaluation as his punishment in the case. In their brief on Thursday, District Attorney Steve Cooley of Los Angeles County and his deputy David Walgren asserted that the testimony should remain sealed and noted that the authorities in Switzerland, where Mr. Polanski is being held pending possible extradition, had not requested transcripts of the sealed testimony. A hearing on the request is set for Monday.

headline: ‘Time Stands Still’ Returning to Broadway
text: After its limited run earlier this year netted it two Tony Award nominations on Tuesday, including one for best play, “Time Stands Still,” which stars Laura Linney, below, as a photojournalist recovering from wounds she sustained covering the war in Iraq, will take another shot at Broadway. Spokesmen for producers of the play, which was written by Donald Margulies and is directed by Daniel Sullivan, said that it would resume performances on Sept. 23 at a Shubert theater to be determined. The original run, presented by the Manhattan Theater Club at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater, ended on March 27. Ms. Linney, who received a Tony nomination as best actress for her performance, will return to the production, as will Brian d’Arcy James (“Next to Normal”), who portrays Ms. Linney’s partner, and Eric Bogosian, who plays her friend and former lover. The play’s publicists said “Time Stands Still” was taking a hiatus to accommodate Ms. Linney’s production schedule for a new Showtime television series, “The Big C,” which is to have its debut in August.

headline: Sundance Channel Pulls Film About Bomber
text: The Sundance Channel has decided against additional showings of a film about a young woman preparing to become a suicide bomber in Times Square. The film, from 2006, is called “Day Night Day Night,” and was written and directed by Julia Loktev. Sundance, a cable channel that specializes in independent films and movies that are out of the mainstream, has been showing “Day Night Day Night” as part of a celebration of the Cannes International Film Festival, which starts next week; the film won a prize at Cannes in 2006. “Day Night Day Night” was most recently shown on Sundance early Thursday  just days after an S.U.V. packed with explosives was found in Times Square. On a Time Warner Cable system channel guide, the film was described as being about a young woman preparing “to carry out her mission as a suicide bomber in New York’s Times Square.” It had been scheduled to appear on Sundance a couple of additional times this month. But “given the events of the past week,” Sundance said in a statement, the channel “has opted to suspend additional airings.”

headline: Three Stars to Leave Production of ‘Race’
text: In the latest maneuver in a longstanding affair as tense as any courtroom case (and just as drawn out), the producers of the David Mamet play “Race” said on Friday that its Broadway production would remain open through Aug. 21, but that three of its key cast members would not stick around that long. David Alan Grier, top right, who on Tuesday was nominated for a Tony Award as a supporting actor for his role as the lawyer Henry Brown, will depart the show after its performance on June 13  the day of the Tony Awards ceremony  as will his co-star Kerry Washington, center, who plays the law firm’s new recruit Susan. James Spader, left, who plays the lawyer Jack Lawson, will give his final performance on June 20. No replacements were announced for these roles. “Race,” which is at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, was Mr. Mamet’s Broadway debut as a director but he was not nominated for a Tony in that category and the show was not nominated for best play.

headline: Lady Gaga vs. ‘Idol’: Nobody Wins
text: This hasn’t been an easy week to be a behemoth of either pop music or television. On the one hand you have the colossally popular Lady Gaga, right, who got the gossip columns buzzing about the amount of time it may or may not have taken her to emerge from her dressing room at the Costume Institute Gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday night. On the other you have the monstrously successful “American Idol,” whose ratings have seen worrisome declines this year amid complaints about a ho-hum lineup of contestants. Put the two phenomena together, as happened on Wednesday night, and you should have a high-wattage hit. But instead, the pairing just made the week worse for both parties. Hours after Lady Gaga appeared on the show to perform her songs “Bad Romance” and “Alejandro,” she was on Twitter complaining about how she was presented on the show. “FOX POORLY + AMATEURLY edited+cut my performance/musical arrangement on idol,” Lady Gaga wrote. She also provided a link to the Web site PerezHilton.com, where she said the full unedited performance could be found. Even in its shortened form, Lady Gaga’s performance was not much help to “American Idol,” which posted its worst Wednesday-night ratings since 2002. Fox declined to discuss Lady Gaga’s remarks and a representative for Fremantle Media, which produces the show, did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

headline: How to Say ‘Greed Is Good’ in Hindi
text: Can you earn money and also earn respect? That’s the question in Parmeet Sethi’s “Badmaash Company,” a Hindi film about corruption and redemption.

headline: Why You Care About Britain’s Hung Parliament
text: Well, fellow Americans, I hope we’re all feeling a little smug today: jobs are being created, terrorists are being captured, and our democratic system isn’t some Rube Goldberg contraption  threatening to give us a government cobbled together through shameless political bribery followed by — good God! — a second national election in one calendar year. There will always be an England, or so it is said, but I doubt even the English are heartened by that sentiment at the moment.

headline: Selling Cape Wind’s Future Wares
text: Cape Wind, the huge offshore wind farm that recently won federal permission to build near Cape Cod, Mass., announced on Friday that it had signed a deal to sell half the project’s output to National Grid, a New England utility, for a price beginning at 20.7 cents a kilowatt-hour.

text: Time: 25 minutes

text: Portugal is not looking good: interest rates where Greece was only a few weeks ago.

headline: Pesto Works With Asparagus, Too
text: Looking for something new to do with asparagus? I was, which is why I decided that asparagus pesto was a long overdue addition to my repertoire.

headline: International House of Joe
text: The outdoor seating at the Coffee Trade, buffered from the road by a robust stand of arborvitae, a few white birch and a healthy spruce, makes an enjoyable spot in which to sip fresh-brewed coffee. Yet it is the interior of this white clapboard-sided building that truly sets the place apart from other coffee purveyors.

headline: Fritters to Paella, the Tastes of Portugal
text: NAMED for the river that flows across northern Portugal toward its outlet at Porto, Douro Restaurant and Bar, which opened in Greenwich about six months ago, calls its cuisine Portuguese-Mediterranean, but it is actually more the former than the latter.

headline: Congress Takes Aim at Wall St.’s Wild Trading
text: As the financial markets remain unnerved by Thursday’s wild trading on Wall Street, lawmakers are moving quickly to investigate what exactly went wrong.

headline: Charting Creativity: Signposts of a Hazy Territory
text: Grab a timer and set it for one minute. Now list as many creative uses for a brick as you can imagine. Go.

headline: Shell’s Kitchen
text: The $25 lobster roll at Day Boat Cafe in Irvington, reviewed at left, has inspired a lively debate in the blogosphere: Is it extravagantly expensive or worth every penny?

headline: Tastes of the Sea, Beach Not Included
text: WITH nature dropping heavy hints of summer, Day Boat Cafe, a whitewashed New England seafood restaurant that opened in Irvington in early March, is reeling in a popped-collared crowd ready for a weekend party. Based loosely on the beloved clam shacks and chowder bars that dot the shores from Maine to Rhode Island — I say “loosely” because the décor is more Newport than Freeport — Day Boat Cafe offers diners a day at the beach without the inconvenience of sand.

headline: R.N.C. Fires Finance Chief and Deputy
text: The heads are still rolling at the Republican National Committee.

headline: Save the Date, and Waste a Long Weekend?
text: SAVE the dates: Monica Lee and Kelly Milligan are marrying in Chicago on Memorial Day weekend. Jessica Mullens and Scott Engelman plan to wed on Independence Day weekend in San Francisco, and Ella Dutton and Alex Campbell have set their date for Labor Day weekend in Scarborough, N.Y.

headline: Irish Inspiration; French Twists
text: It’s tempting to make a meal of the crusty breads at Blue Rooster Bakery and Café in Cranbury — at least until you try a sandwich with fillings like chicken salad flecked with pears and walnuts ($10). Soups and salads are also among the offerings at this elegant yet casual cafe situated in a Victorian house.

headline: Locally Rooted Flavors That Belie Their Setting
text: WHEN you make a last-minute dinner reservation for a Saturday night, you take what you can get. At Elements in Princeton, we were offered two seats at the four-seat bar for an hour before another party was scheduled to claim them. We took them, gambling that there would be a no-show. We lost.

headline: Emily Grant and Scott Werthamer
text: Emily Beth Grant, the daughter of Madeleine Rudel Grant and Jeffrey S. Grant of New York, was married Saturday evening to Scott Matthew Werthamer, the son of Marilyn F. Werthamer and Rony Werthamer of Pikesville, Md. Rabbi Richard J. Jacobs officiated at Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in New York.

headline: In Southold, From 4 Rosés to 6

headline: Small-Plate Seafood Spot Gets Off to a Fast Start
text: WHAT kind of person opens a restaurant in a resort town in the dead of winter? In the case of Noah Schwartz, who started Noah’s in Greenport in January, the answer is: a brilliant one. He is a wizard in the kitchen and shows signs of similar talent in his debut as a restaurateur.

headline: When an Opponent Errs, Declarer Wins the Big Bucks
text: HENDERSON, Nev.  The John Roberts Teams opened the Cavendish Invitational tournament at the Green Valley Ranch Resort here, just outside Las Vegas. There were nine 9-board rounds, with international match points converted to victory points. A win by at least 32 imps produced a 30 to 0 blitz.

headline: God and Family, and the Changes to Come
text: As befits an actor playing Tevye, the Russian milkman in “Fiddler on the Roof,” Eddie Mekka has soulful eyes. He sometimes uses them skillfully to connect to the audience or while speaking to God, whom he considers a close friend.

headline: What Are You Seeing?
text: As the oil from the Deepwater Horizon reaches land, we would like your updates and photographs of what you’re seeing. Photos are optional but recommended. Please share your updates here.

headline: Trying to Make Mozart Youth-Friendly
text: LAST November, thousands of teenage fans mobbed Roosevelt Field Mall in Garden City for an appearance by the pop sensation Justin Bieber. The event was canceled because of the chaos. Now if only the Long Island Mozart Festival, taking place next weekend a few miles away at Old Westbury Gardens, would have the same drawing power.

headline: Pamelee McFarland and Raymond Murphy
text: Pamelee Marie McFarland and Raymond Finley Murphy Jr. were married Saturday evening at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. Thomas N. Synan, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Dot Shot: Leafcutter Ants on Parade
text: In my academic role, I’m visiting the La Selva Biological Station in Costa Rica. About two dozen young scientists from around the Americas who spent three weeks studying together last year are convening here again to explore the interface of tropical ecology and climate.

headline: Shari Braverman, Zachary Messing

headline: Jenna Mitchell, Michael Goldman
text: Jenna Rose Mitchell, a daughter of Nancy Brunell Mitchell and James H. Mitchell of Newton, Mass., was married Saturday evening to Michael Paul Goldman, a son of Mary Goldman and Jerry Goldman of Manhattan. Rabbi Jeffrey J. Sirkman officiated at 583 Park Avenue, a catering space in Manhattan.

headline: Pettitte Wanted Input in Decision to Skip Start
text: BOSTON — From the Yankees’ perspective, their decision to skip Andy Pettitte’s next start came easily. When a nearly 38-year-old pitcher complains of elbow tightness 27 games into what they hope is another championship season, they see no reason to take unnecessary risks. They are taking a similarly cautious approach with Jorge Posada, who was held out of the lineup Friday night for a third consecutive game, and with Mariano Rivera, who had not pitched in a week because of a muscle pull in his rib cage but was expected to be available Friday night.

headline: Late Troubles Deprive Jay Haas Chance to Set TPC Age Record
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. – The final 30 minutes of Jay Haas’s round on Friday reminded him why 29 years as a full-time member of the PGA Tour was enough.

headline: Elizabeth Grimaldi, Jonathan Kurpis
text: Elizabeth Susan Grimaldi, a daughter of Joan M. Grimaldi and William S. Grimaldi of New York, is to be married Sunday to Jonathan Adam Kurpis, a son of Judith S. Kurpis and Dr. Albert J. Kurpis of Saddle River, N.J. Msgr. Robert J. Fuhrman is to perform the ceremony at St. Gabriel’s Roman Catholic Church in Saddle River.

text: For baseball fans, 2009 was the year of the Yankees. For job seekers, it was the year of the Great Recession. And for people who track baby names, it was the year of the vampire.

text: Remember when you used to play catch with your dad? Or set up your Lionel train set together? How Gen X was that?

headline: New Justice to Confront Evolution in Powers
text: WASHINGTON — As President Obama prepares to nominate somebody to succeed Justice John Paul Stevens, his administration appears to be on a collision course with the Supreme Court in legal disputes that will test the limits of executive power.

headline: Fine Dining Where Strollers Don’t Invite Sneers
text: IT began at Fred’s. I was tucking into a lobster salad over a business lunch at the swanky eatery inside Barneys when I noticed, amid the sea of designer handbags and diners who define chic, babies dotting the room. And instead of grudgingly accepting them, the staff was doting.

headline: Elizabeth Tonorezos, Jeffrey Garnett
text: Elizabeth Jamy Tonorezos and Jeffrey Michael Garnett were married Saturday at the Chapel at St. Basil’s Academy in Garrison, N.Y. The Rev. Anthony Falsarella, a Greek Orthodox priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Oakland’s Braden Continues Unwritten Rules Discussion With Rodriguez
text: Although the Oakland left-hander Dallas Braden had said his issues with Alex Rodriguez ended on April 22, when Rodriguez irritated him by wandering across the mound on his way back to first base, he revived them by suggesting in an interview that he would seek revenge in their next series, July 5-7 in Oakland, Calif. When asked by CSNBayArea.com whether he would settle it “with knuckles,” Braden said, “Obviously there’s things that are going to have to happen — just out of respect for my teammates, out of respect for the game.”

headline: Kalen Karnes, Christopher Strickland

headline: In Britain, the Liberal Democrats vs. the Bankers
text: Nick Clegg, leader of Britain’s Liberal Democrats, has emerged as the likely kingmaker in the British election, and that seems sure to unnerve the bankers and traders operating in the City of London. Mr. Clegg has put forth a range of tough regulatory proposals to change the way the City operates, saying that bankers should “fear” the Liberal Democrats gaining greater influence over the government.

headline: Shell’s Alaska Oil Drilling Plan Draws New Scrutiny
