Goodman of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and the late Barbara S. Goodman. Rabbi David E. Greenberg officiated at the Pierre in New York.

headline: Avery Willis and Matthew Hoffman
text: Avery Tinch Willis and Matthew Walter Hoffman were married Saturday evening at the home of the bride’s mother, Anne Jones Willis of Hightstown, N.J. The Rev. Bryan Franzen, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

headline: What We’re Reading: iPad Addicts
text: Here’s what caught the interest of the tech editors and reporters of The New York Times the last few days:

headline: Spain Recovers, and Portugal Mulls Its Options
text: The Spanish economy, for all its troubles, came out of the recession last quarter, according to the Bank of Spain (PDF), with the country’s gross domestic product posting growth of 0.1 percent on the previous quarter and ending an 18-month contraction, shrinking 3.6 percent last year.

headline: Six Days of School, and Then a Day Not of Rest
text: David Levin, 40, co-founder of the celebrated KIPP charter school network and superintendent of KIPP’s New York City schools, works 75 to 90 hours a week training teachers, raising money and shuttling among six schools. Even Mr. Levin’s Saturdays tend to be consumed by KIPP, which stands for Knowledge Is Power Program. Sundays, though, are reserved for his wife, Nikki Chase-Levin, 38, a marketing consultant (they met speed-dating) and their 15-month-old son, Max. The family lives on the Upper West Side.

headline: Parking Meters and the Cursed Washerwoman
text: Q. Settle an argument, please. Those big nests in the upper branches of trees in Central Park and other city parks: are they crows’ nests or squirrels’ nests?

headline: A Black Abolitionist and Barbecue Diplomacy
text: Mention American abolitionists and David Ruggles rarely comes to mind. In “David Ruggles: A Radical Black Abolitionist and the Underground Railroad in New York City”  (University of North Carolina Press, $30), Graham Russell Gao Hodges goes a long way toward rectifying that oversight. Ruggles published what might have been the first black periodical in the country, sheltered a fugitive slave named Frederick Washington Bailey — later Frederick Douglass — at his home on Lispenard Street in Lower Manhattan, and led a committee that helped save more than 600 escaped slaves.

headline: California: Tax Receipts Disappoint
text: State revenue trailed Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger’s forecast by $3.6 billion in April, deepening the budget deficit. The revenue in April, when income tax payments are due, was 26 percent below the governor’s projection and more than offset an unexpectedly large intake in the previous four months, Controller John Chiang said Friday. California’s collections are $1.3 billion below estimates for the current budget year, which goes through June 30.

headline: Has the Big Apple Become the Big Eyeball?
text: There’s one, over by the Walgreens entrance, and there’s another, just below the King Tut banner — video cameras, installed by private companies to survey the public spectacle of Times Square. I would not have seen the countless electronic eyes had Christopher Falkenberg, the president of a firm called Insite Security, not pointed them out. But I felt pretty sure those cameras had a clear view of me.

headline: As Kyoto Attractions, Wave Pools vs. Temples
text: KYOTO, Japan — A dolphin pool, a penguin park and a giant wave pool could soon join the imperial-era townhouses and ancient Buddhist temples in Kyoto, Japan’s former imperial capital.

headline: On the Street | Flowery Millinery
text: At the annual Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon, splendor of an earlier age was captured by the 1,200 guests in flowery millinery and spring-summer clothes.

headline: Top White House Lawyer Resigns
text: Daniel J. Meltzer, who has played a crucial behind-the-scenes role in the White House legal team, is resigning in June and will return to his tenured position as a Harvard law school professor, the White House said Friday. He has worked on nearly every major legal issue the administration has handled and helped prepare Judge Sonia Sotomayor for her Supreme Court confirmation hearings. He might reprise the role in his final weeks by working with the next court nominee, expected to be named soon.

headline: Lea Lane Stern, William Lewis
text: Lea Lane Stern and William Cleaton Lewis Jr. were married Saturday evening in New York. Cary Lane, a son of the bride’s, who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated in the apartment of Randall Lane, also a son of the bride’s.

headline: Katherine Barth, Brett Huston
text: Katherine Morgan Barth and Brett Joshua Huston were married Saturday evening at Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald Broden officiated, with the Rev. Kathleen Garner, a Presbyterian minister, taking part.

headline: Debjani Bhaumik and Sandeep Rao
text: Debjani Bhaumik, the daughter of Dr. Juthika Roma Bhaumik and Dilip Kumar Bhaumik of Clarksville, Md., was married Saturday to Sandeep Prakash Rao, a son of Dr. Geetha Rao and Dr. Prakashchandra M. Rao of Orangeburg, N.Y. Pandit Prabhakar Sharma, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation, an arts and events space in Manhattan.

headline: The Trades of a Lifetime in 20 Minutes
text: Someone on Wall Street just made a killing.

headline: Leia Curcuruto, Jason Rodman
text: Leia Marie Curcuruto and Jason Anthony Rodman were married Saturday at St. John the Baptist Church in Yonkers. The Rev. Daniel Ulloa, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Walking Tentatively in Protesters’ Shoes
text: When the Phoenix Suns wore the name Los Suns on their jerseys Wednesday night, it was construed by many of their fans as a political statement against the new Arizona law regarding illegal immigrants.

headline: Tainted Lettuce Linked to Illness in Three States
text: A rare strain of E. coli never before associated with foodborne illness in the United States has sickened 29 people in three states, public health officials said Friday. The outbreak has been tied to romaine lettuce served in restaurants, school cafeterias and deli and supermarket salad bars.

headline: A Little Off the Top and Also the Mind
text: THE barber arrives on Tuesdays at 10 a.m. The men are already waiting in the hallways — some have been there for hours, knowing that the latecomers will have to idle past lunch.

headline: Jennifer Pearsall, Jordan Kobert
text: Jennifer Ann Pearsall, a daughter of Marianne N. Pearsall and Stephen R. Pearsall of Crystal Bay, Nev., was married Saturday to Jordan Ross Kobert, the son of Nancy A. Kobert and Joel A. Kobert of Hackettstown, N.J. The bride’s father, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at Lancaster Estate, a winery in Healdsburg, Calif.

headline: Lord of the Pythons
text: Bob Freer has gone from educating tourists about Florida's native alligators to feeding the public's obsession with the invasive Burmese python.

headline: Lease Deal Near for Empty Times Square Tower
text: A prominent law firm is expected to sign a lease next week for a new home in the vacant 40-story tower called 11 Times Square, ending months of speculation about the deal and providing another sign that the commercial real estate market may have hit bottom.

headline: Alan Ilagan, Andrew Van Wagenen
text: Alan Bennett Ilagan and Andrew Van Wagenen were married Friday in Boston. The ceremony in the Boston Public Garden was led by Christopher J. Vaeth, a friend of the couple’s, who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate at the event.

headline: Risk Seen for Europe’s Banks if Cuts Freeze Credit
text: FRANKFURT — Analysts and investors have begun to focus on the risks to European banks if severe budget cuts by debt-ridden countries freeze credit markets and cause a double-dip recession.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: PHILIPPE PETIT’S HIGH-WIRE CLASSROOM was unveiled on Thursday in the performance space that is S.L.A.M. (the Streb Lab for Action Mechanics), at 51 North First Street. Mr. Petit, a renowned high-wire artist and a subject of the documentary  “Man on Wire,”  has given some wire-walking clinics over the years. But he has decided to give master classes for the first time, at the behest of Elizabeth Streb, the choreographer and contemporary dance teacher who opened the space in 2003. “I’ve stalked Philippe for 10 years to get him to do this,” Ms. Streb said. Mr. Petit, 60, recently designed and installed a cable 23 feet long and 10 feet high. He will begin reviewing applications for six precious spots in the summer class, which will include slack-rope walking and street performing. Walking between skyscrapers is not in the curriculum. “This is for serious artists,” Mr. Petit said, “not for people who want something to talk about at cocktail parties.”

headline: Celebrating Artists Who Keep the Action in Abstraction
text: WHEN Dara Meyers-Kingsley was invited to curate ArtsWestchester’s annual exhibition of Westchester artists, she knew that the theme of the show was to be abstraction. By setting her focus on the last six letters of that word, she has assembled a collection of artwork that, she said, offers a new perspective on abstract art. Opening May 15 at the Arts Exchange in White Plains, the exhibition is titled “AbstrACTION,” with action in various guises its highlight.

headline: 2 at Faith-Based Bank Are Indicted Over Bribes
text: ATLANTA — When government regulators here shut down Integrity Bank at the height of the recession, in August of 2008, the bank was seen as just another failed lender that had overvalued the real estate market and collapsed.

headline: Pythons in Florida Stalked by Hunters and Tourists Alike
text: FLORIDA CITY, Fla. — Thousands of Burmese pythons, the offspring of former pets, have invaded the Everglades, eating birds, bunnies, even alligators. It has gotten so bad that Congress is considering an outright ban on buying or selling nine kinds of giant snakes.

headline: Bloggingheads: Was Bush Right?
text: Glenn Greenwald, left, of Salon.com and David Frum of FrumForum debate whether President George W. Bush was right on national security.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Soap Opera for the Ages
text: Does it seem like overstating things to say that “Friday Night Lights’’ is the greatest television soap opera of all time? The series, which returned to NBC Friday night for its fourth season after an earlier run on DirecTV, whispers its heartaches and longings; it is melodrama that always manages to steer clear of feeling melodramatic. Often the show seems like a lesson in resilience to those members of its audience who are Eastern and privileged and lap it up. The people who live in the series’ fictional town of Dillon, Texas, never seem undone by the swelter of deprivation; they just go about the business of getting by.

headline: All Around Us, the Threat of Cancer
text: To the Editor:

headline: Working to Preserve the Click, Stomp and Rat-a-Tat-Tat
text: BLOOMFIELD

headline: Red Sox Nation Grumbles Like an Entitled Empire
text: The Red Sox are off to a troubled start, and barely a sixth of the way into the season, the Web sites and comment boards in Boston are warning of a long and miserable summer. But to any longtime Sox fan — born before, say, 1990 — it just ain’t so. To us, this year promises to be a cathartic trip down memory lane and, maybe, a return to tradition, and sanity.

headline: A Landfill’s Closing Alters How a Neighborhood Views Freight Trains
text: For decades, the people of Middle Village observed a rough truce with the freight trains that rumble through their Queens neighborhood. They did not love the hulking, clamorous boxcars and locomotives, but they understood that the trains were as much a part of the working-class row-house landscape as they were.

headline: Yankees’ Johnson Leaves With Wrist Injury
text: Nick Johnson exited Friday’s game in the fifth inning because of a sore right wrist. The same wrist required surgery in 2008, when Johnson was limited to 38 games with Washington. It was unclear how Johnson was injured. Marcus Thames pinch-hit for Johnson, who was 0 for 2, in the fifth inning.

headline: Origin of Wall Street’s Plunge Continues to Elude Officials
text: A day after a harrowing plunge in the stock market, federal regulators were still unable on Friday to answer the one question on every investor’s mind: What caused that near panic on Wall Street?

headline: A Playwright Inspired by Teachers
text: A movie star walks into a small, run-down New York studio. Earning $6 million a picture, she feels like a fraud. She has come to seek the help of an acting teacher who was once a distinguished actor and now has a major chip on his shoulder.

headline: A Party, by Way of Africa and Holland
text: Each spring in 18th-century New York, Dutch colonists and their African slaves discarded their roles for a few days to observe a cross-cultural holiday. Next Sunday, visitors to Philipsburg Manor can relive the festivities at “Pinkster: An African-American Celebration of Spring.”

headline: Dominican Prospects Will Face Strict Rules
text: The top official for Major League Baseball in charge of overhauling its operations in the Dominican Republic said Friday that baseball would require top prospects as young as 15 to provide fingerprints and have testing for performance-enhancing drugs before they can sign with teams.

headline: Fixing Wall Street’s Autopilot
text: Chapel Hill, N.C.

headline: Erika Potter, Eric Edelson
text: Erika Astrid Potter and Eric Samuel Edelson are to be married Sunday at Alta Plaza Park, a public park in San Francisco. The bride’s brother, Benjamin A. Potter, who received permission from the county of San Francisco, is to officiate.

headline: Unclear Result in Britain Puts Focus on Electoral Rules
text: LONDON — The British public’s failure to elect a clear winner in Thursday’s national election appeared to be a mass expression of exasperation with a discredited government and an uninspiring opposition. It also showed the voters’ disillusionment with the increasingly creaky electoral system itself.

headline: Uncertainty in British Vote Adds to Economic Jitters
text: LONDON — The prospect of political stalemate after the indecisive British election sent the pound lower Friday and heightened fears that credit rating agencies, which have been quick to downgrade indebted economies in the euro zone, might do so to Britain.

headline: Immigration Status of Army Spouses Often Leads to Snags
text: Lt. Kenneth Tenebro enlisted in the armed forces after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, signing up even before he became an American citizen.

headline: Westwood Has Up-and-Comers in Line
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Golf has been abuzz about a youth movement again, especially this week after the fuzzy-cheeked duo of Ryo Ishikawa, 18, of Japan and Rory McIlroy, 21, of Northern Ireland shot record-low rounds to win on the Japan PGA and the PGA Tour last week. But here on Florida’s First Coast, where alligator hide is not always a reference to the primordial-looking reptiles in the water hazards at T.P.C. Sawgrass, things are a bit different.

headline: U.S. Orchestra Performs in China, in Echoes of 1973
text: BEIJING — Grant Xia had the misfortune of trying to take up violin as an amateur during the collective madness of the Cultural Revolution. Chinese officials banned classical music and sent musicians to re-education camps. Mr. Xia’s family collection of more than 1,000 vinyl records was destroyed. Mr. Xia soon stopped playing the violin.

headline: A Week in the Life of the Economy
text: For all the recent talk about recovery, the economy’s vulnerability was on full  at times stomach-dropping  display this week.

headline: Seeking Lower Property Taxes on a House of Sinking Value
text: IT seems as if every week I get a postcard or letter that reads something like this: “Save money by reducing your property tax. 100 percent risk-free. No Reduction, No Risk.”

headline: They Call It a Hung Parliament
text: Gordon Brown has lost his long-odds bid to lead the Labour Party in Britain to its fourth straight parliamentary majority, but it is not yet clear which party has won.

headline: In Insider Trading Case, a Move to Throw Out Wiretaps
text: Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund billionaire accused of insider trading, sought on Friday to dismiss the government’s most powerful evidence against him: thousands of wiretapped conversations between him and his family, friends and associates. Lawyers for Mr. Rajaratnam argued that the wiretaps violated federal statutes governing the use of surveillance techniques. A spokeswoman for the United States Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York declined to comment.

headline: Greek Debt Crisis Raises Doubts About the European Union
text: PARIS — Europe’s consistent inability to move quickly enough to get ahead of the financial markets during the Greece crisis is shaking the euro and the foundations of the European Union itself, as critics of the euro have long predicted would happen.

headline: How Should the Layoffs Work?
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York City said this week that fiscal woes could force him to lay off more than 6,000 teachers. We hope the number will not be that high, but there will have to be layoffs. The question is, how will they be done?

headline: Exposing Graft, but His Motives Are Murky
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia

headline: White Pages May Go Way of Rotary-Dialed Phone
text: The digital age may claim another victim.

headline: What Every Girl Should Know
text: A thousand years ago, popular birth control methods in the Western world included spitting into the mouth of a frog, eating bees and wearing the testicles of a weasel. In Córdoba, Spain, which was supposed to be on the scientific cutting edge, women were told to leap up and down vigorously after sex, and then jump backward nine times.

headline: Top Court in Canada Limits Media on Sources
text: OTTAWA — Journalists do not have a constitutional right to protect the identities of their sources, the Supreme Court of Canada ruled Friday.

headline: Cano Leaves Game After Being Hit by Pitch
text: The Yankees took a 9-1 lead against the Red Sox with a six-run sixth inning Friday, but it was a troubling inning for the Yanks in one respect. Second baseman Robinson Cano, one of the hottest hitters in the American League, left the game after he was hit by a Josh Beckett pitch. Cano tried to jump out of the way, but the ball struck his left knee. Cano walked to first base, but after a few moments he left the game. The severity of the injury was unclear.

headline: Corrections
text: A theater entry in the Listings pages on Friday about “Passion Play,” which opens Wednesday at the Irondale Center in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, misstated the telephone number for tickets. It is 866-811-4111.

headline: Bloody Urban Landscapes
text: Chicago

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Sheena Duncan, White Who Fought Apartheid, Dies at 77
text: JOHANNESBURG — Sheena Duncan, who led the Black Sash, a group of middle-class white women in South Africa who protested against apartheid and counseled blacks victimized by the racist laws of that era, died Tuesday at her home in Johannesburg. She was 77.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Story Born in a Journal Comes to Film Festival
text: “EVERYTHING your grandfather does this summer will be for the last time,” says Anna in Marc Meyers’s film “Harvest.” Anna (the Tony Award winner Victoria Clark) is trying to persuade her college-age son, Josh (Jack Carpenter), to stay at the family house in Madison for the whole summer, not just for the weekend. But that argument could be difficult to make, because Robert Loggia, as Anna’s father, Siv, looks so robust, so engaged and enthusiastic that you would swear he could put off any funeral planning until at least 2030.

headline: Capital of the Kingdom of Hawaii
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Time for a confession. I considered hiding the fact that I couldn’t finish today’s puzzle, but I think the truth is more interesting.

headline: New York State’s No. 2 Is Stewing on the Sidelines
text: ALBANY — While Gov. David A. Paterson met inside his office with aides to prepare for a recent news conference, his lieutenant governor, Richard Ravitch, was milling around outside, waiting for the appearance to begin.

headline: Trying to Outrun Race
text: Racist. Tea Party.

headline: Los Suns
text: We don’t often get a chance to congratulate athletes for truly being role models. But watching the Phoenix Suns’ players wearing their “Los Suns” jerseys this week made us proud.

headline: New Coach Keeps Princeton Winning as Usual, but With More Laughs
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — On April 1, the Princeton assistant men’s lacrosse coach Greg Raymond approached the starting goalkeeper, Tyler Fiorito, in the locker room before practice. Raymond informed Fiorito that he was to partake in a prank on the first-year coach Chris Bates by wearing a brace on his left knee. He was told to say that he had injured it while riding a skateboard and that he would need an M.R.I. exam to determine whether he could play in the next game against Brown.

headline: J. Bruce Llewellyn: Chapters in a Life of Influence
text: A look at how Bruce Llewellyn became one of the leading African-American entrepreneurs of his generation.

headline: Return of Gagne Is Difference for Flyers
text: PHILADELPHIA — Simon Gagne, the injured Philadelphia Flyers forward who had been cleared to play on Friday, did not seem to be hampered at all as he galloped toward his teammates after scoring a winning goal — and keeping their fragile Stanley Cup hopes alive.

headline: Workers on Oil Rig Recall a Terrible Night of Blasts
text: NEW ORLEANS — Nearly 50 miles offshore at the big oil rig floating on a glassy-calm sea, a helicopter landed early on the morning of April 20, carrying four executives from BP, the oil company. The men were visiting the Deepwater Horizon to help honor the crew for its standout safety record.

headline: Congress and Guns
text: To the Editor:

headline: Is the French Move to Ban the Full Veil a Good Idea?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Governor Paterson’s Decision on Legal Immigrants
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Singing So Bad Wasn’t So Good
text: Once upon a time, in a land far away from YouTube and “American Idol,” audiences actually had to make an effort to find entertainers so execrable that they were, well, entertaining. In the 1930s and ’40s, this not-so-desirable niche was filled by Florence Foster Jenkins, a New York socialite with lofty musical aspirations and no vocal ability whatsoever.

headline: Heroes’ Welcome for Two Times Square Vendors
text: A city with more than eight million people can occasionally feel like a small town, and Friday was one of those nights at Citi Field, when two street vendors were honored for the role they played in thwarting the effort to set off a car bomb in Times Square last weekend.

headline: Bombing Suspect’s Route to Citizenship Reveals Limitations
text: When Faisal Shahzad took his oath of citizenship a year ago, swearing to “support and defend the Constitution and laws of the United States of America against all enemies,” he seemed the model of a legal immigrant success story. Moving from one coveted visa to the next over a decade, he had acquired an M.B.A., a decent job, a wife and two children and a fine suburban home.

headline: Lottery Numbers
New Mets Make Home a Hitters’ Park
text: Before spring training, Rod Barajas and Ike Davis were uncertain of their major league status, but they were looking at their careers from different perspectives.

headline: Yankees Win but Take More Casualties
text: BOSTON — When Rob Thomson, the Yankees’ third-base coach, sits down to his daily task of filling out the lineup card on Saturday, he may want to consider changing his writing utensil. Pen is much too permanent right now. At the rate they are losing players, a pencil, preferably one with a heavy-duty eraser, would be more useful.

headline: White House Is Being Pressed to Reverse Course and Join Land Mine Ban
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, under intense political pressure from Capitol Hill and elsewhere, is engaged in a vigorous debate over whether to reverse course and join an international treaty banning land mines, administration officials said this week.

headline: G.O.P. Committee Leaders Fired
text: The finance chief of the Republican National Committee, Rob Bickhart, and his deputy were fired Friday by Michael Steele, the party chairman, after months of sluggish fund-raising punctuated by unwelcome publicity over some of the committee’s spending. “While we appreciate their service to the R.N.C. and wish them well in future endeavors, the chairman felt it was important to restructure the department in order to continue to improve on our strong fund-raising numbers,” Mr. Steele said in an e-mail message forwarded to the committee staff by his chief of staff. Mary Heitman, a former finance director for the Republican Governors Association, will replace Mr. Bickhart.

headline: After a Healthy Rout, Cleveland Exhales
text: BOSTON — For three anxious days, the greater Cleveland metropolitan area stressed about the soreness in LeBron James’s right elbow and the tender state of the Cavaliers. There were daily reports about diagnostic tests that James may or may not have had, and some degree of bewilderment at a tied playoff series.

headline: Russia: Motion to Ban American Adoptions Fails
text: Russia’s Parliament on Friday turned down a motion to halt all adoptions of Russian children by Americans, saying that it would not take action while the two countries were negotiating new adoption rules. Some members had called for the suspension in response to the case of a boy who was returned to Russia on his own by his adoptive American mother last month. Russian Foreign Ministry officials reacted to the case by saying that all adoptions by Americans would be stopped, but a senior Russian official said this week that they were continuing.

headline: Russia: Sentence in Ship Hijacking
text: A Moscow court gave a five-year sentence on Friday to one of the men charged with hijacking a cargo ship off the coast of Sweden last summer, the court said in a statement, the first verdict in a rare case of European piracy. Andrei Lunev, 44, an Estonian citizen, pleaded guilty to charges that he and eight other men commandeered the ship, the Arctic Sea, along with its Russian crew and ferried it through heavily monitored European waters out into the Atlantic Ocean. The Russian Navy retook the ship and arrested the hijackers last August. The navy’s involvement in an operation to track down a ship that was officially only carrying cheap timber fueled rumors that the vessel was being used to smuggle illicit cargo. Russian investigators said they found only timber on board.

headline: New Jersey Plan Calls for Bonuses for Effective Teachers and Schools
text: In an effort to compete again for federal education money that it recently failed to win, New Jersey unveiled an ambitious plan on Friday to award state-financed merit bonuses to teachers and schools based on the performance of their students.

headline: China: Schedule for Rebuilding
text: Chinese officials say reconstruction work in the quake-ravaged Tibetan area of Yushu in Qinghai Province will be completed within three years, Xinhua, the state news agency, reported on Friday. The central government will provide the money for most of the rebuilding, while some will come from private donations, Hui Liangyu, a vice prime minister, said Thursday at a meeting of the State Council, China’s cabinet, Xinhua reported. The government of Qinghai will oversee the reconstruction. At least 2,220 people were killed when an earthquake hit the area of Yushu in April. A pilot reconstruction program was scheduled to begin at two villages earlier this month.

headline: Louganis Becomes Mentor
text: Greg Louganis, a four-time Olympic gold medalist, will make his debut as a mentor to up-and-coming Americans at this weekend’s USA Diving Grand Prix at the Fort Lauderdale Aquatic Center in Florida. His involvement comes nearly 22 years after he defended his gold medals in 3-meter springboard and 10-meter platform at the 1988 Seoul Games.

headline: Jan van der Marck, Museum Administrator, Dies at 80
text: Jan van der Marck, a museum administrator who championed new art at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago, the Detroit Institute of Arts and other major museums — more than once at the cost of his job — died on April 26 at his home in Huntington Woods, Mich. He was 80.

headline: Vetting the Nets’ Suitor Is No Easy Task
text: The Mikhail D. Prokhorov era should start next week for the Brooklyn-bound New Jersey Nets.

headline: James Leeson Jr. Dies at 79; Taped Execution Scene
text: James Leeson Jr., whose taping of a May 1951 radio broadcast describing the atmosphere at a black man’s execution in Mississippi in a highly publicized rape case was drawn upon for a newly released book and a radio documentary, died Monday in Franklin, Tenn. He was 79.

headline: Resolved: Inmates Make Tough Debaters
text: The two debate teams sat across a large room on Thursday night waiting for their face-off to begin. On one side were the visitors, four undergraduates at the New School, and their equally young coach poring over documents and comparing last-minute notes. Across the room the home team, four men in their 30s and 40s, leaned back in their seats, pictures of poise, their neatly arranged index cards at the ready but untouched.

headline: Marcos Campaigns in the Philippines
text: Former first lady Imelda Marcos campaigns for her family to regain political control.

headline: Blood Profile Is Basis for Ban of Top Cyclist
text: When the Giro d’Italia, one of cycling’s three Grand Tours, begins Saturday, there will be a glaring absence at the starting line. One of the race favorites, the Italian cyclist Franco Pellizotti, will be nowhere in sight.

headline: Chronicling Steinbrenner and His Turbulent Tenure
text: In “Steinbrenner: The Last Lion of Baseball,” Bill Madden of The Daily News recounts George Steinbrenner’s blustery, profane, sometimes wacky ways, especially in his first decade as the principal owner of the Yankees.

headline: Eskendereya Is Sold and Retired
text: Eskendereya, once considered an early favorite to win the Kentucky Derby, was retired Friday after his owner reached a deal with Jess Jackson, the wine impresario who co-owns the reigning Horse of the Year, Rachel Alexandra.

headline: An Unlikely Candidate in Colombia
text: Antanas Mockus, who served two very colorful terms as Bogotá’s mayor, has made for one of Latin America’s most exceptional presidential races in recent memory, pitting an insurgent intellectual against an establishment that suddenly finds itself on the defensive.

headline: Photo Replay: May 7
text: A view of the day in sports, as the World Cup trophy began a tour of South Africa.

headline: What Some Pros Want to Know Before You Take a Lesson
text: Here is some advice from interviews with several top P.G.A. teaching pros about how to take to take a golf lesson:

headline: Fire and Chaos at Sea
text: Three crew members from the Deepwater Horizon recall the night the oil rig exploded, killing 11 of their coworkers.

headline: Walter Hickel, Nixon Interior Secretary, Dies at 90
text: Walter J. Hickel, who as governor of Alaska, United States secretary of the interior and then governor again of the nation’s last frontier state confounded critics by ricocheting from pro-business stalwart to ardent environmentalist and back again, died Friday in Anchorage. He was 90.

headline: A Mother’s Day Video
text: Video | Unqualified love for mom? Child begs to differ:

headline: Your Jokes: ‘Please Hold the Line’
text: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Winfield Is Moved by Memory of His Mother
text: The Hall of Famer Dave Winfield, 58, is an executive vice president and senior adviser for the San Diego Padres and an analyst for “Baseball Tonight” on ESPN. Winfield played for six teams, including the Padres and the Yankees, during a 22-year career in which he won a World Series with the 1992 Toronto Blue Jays.

headline: Lawrence Taylor and the Hall of Fame
text: Consider that O.J. Simpson is still in the Hall of Fame ….

headline: With Another Draw, Championship Match Remains Tied
text: Only two games remain in regulation, with each player having another chance to play White.

headline: The iPad Travels the World, via eBay
text: Leave it to the early adopters to find a way to get their hands on an iPad even if they live abroad, where Apple will not begin selling iPads until the end of May.

headline: First Home Runs, Day by Day
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: Staten Island Ferry Crashes Into Dock
text: 1:05 p.m. | Updated  Mechanical failure caused a Staten Island ferry to crash into the St. George terminal pier shortly before 9:30 a.m. on Saturday, police, fire and Coast Guard officials said. Thirty-seven people were injured, Janette Sadik-Khan, the city transportation commissioner, said at a news conference on Staten Island.

headline: In Address, Obama Praises Health Care Law
text: With the American public still very much divided over the new health care law, President Obama trumpeted Saturday its initial impact, saying the overhaul had already helped millions of individuals and small businesses.

headline: Fallon: ‘Sparked By a Typo’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: There’s speculation that the 1,000-point drop in the Dow may have been sparked by a typo, where someone entered “billion” instead of “million” on a trading order. Economists are saying a single letter hasn’t caused this many problems since the letter “Dubya.”

headline: Letterman: ‘Just Looking for Mexicans’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: The Arizona government is very defensive about its new immigration law. They are being accused of just looking for Mexicans. The Arizona government says, “No, earlier today we were rounding up Germans.”

headline: Leno: ‘The Spending is Necessary’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Although it seems like nothing is getting accomplished in the Gulf, and the situation is getting worse every day, the government has been involved in the clean-up effort since the beginning. They said that, as proof of their involvement, nothing has really been accomplished and the situation is getting worse every day.

headline: Slightly Atypical Qualifying in Spain
text: There was an interesting qualifying session in Barcelona today, with a few different changes: First, Mark Webber scored his second pole position of the season and the third of his career. He himself admitted that it was nice to be ahead of his Red Bull teammate, Sebastian Vettel, who he pointed out does have a better record than him in qualifying. The margin this time was so slim that it all came down certainly to what Jenson Button defined about this circuit: precision rather than aggression.

headline: Mother-of-Pearl Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — On a day when flowers, candies and greeting cards are lavished upon those who used to keep us clothed, bathed and sated with dinners of SpaghettiOs and fish sticks, I looked at the acrostic and immediately noticed a certain topic appearing repeatedly in the clues. It wasn’t too much of a leap to assume the quote would follow suit, one way or another. It did, and amusingly so, another assumption that’s often safe to make with a Cox and Rathvon acrostic.

headline: Electoral Demand Stalls Coalition Deal in Britain
text: LONDON — Talks about forming a new government resumed Saturday amid concern that continuing uncertainty would shake world financial markets when they reopen Monday, but the prospects of a deal between the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats by that deadline appeared slim.

headline: Republicans’ Calls for Offshore Drilling Have Grown Quieter
text: WASHINGTON — Two years ago, feisty Republicans commandeered the darkened House chamber during the summer recess to loudly demand that oil companies be allowed to “drill here and drill now.”

headline: Dozens Injured in Staten Island Ferry Crash
text: A Staten Island ferry involved in a deadly crash seven years ago lost its brake power on Saturday morning and slammed at a rapid clip into a pier at St. George terminal, sending passengers hurtling and touching off chaos on board. Nearly 40 people were taken to Staten Island hospitals with mostly minor injuries.

headline: U.S. Urges Action in Pakistan After Failed Bombing
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Obama administration has delivered new and stiff warnings to Pakistan after the failed Times Square car bombing that it must urgently move against the nexus of Islamic militancy in the country’s lawless tribal regions, American and Pakistani officials said.

headline: Yankees Call Up Russo, Allowing Them a Number of Options
text: BOSTON — The Yankees prepared to play Saturday’s game against the Red Sox with only one fully healthy player on their bench — the utility player Kevin Russo, who was recalled from Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre.

headline: Like His Bat, Ortiz’s Smile Is No Longer a Sure Thing
text: BOSTON — In grander times, David Ortiz would have given his word, and that would have been a virtual guarantee. That was then. This is 2010. The young female fan, taking her photo on the field with the player she endearingly called Papi, had to settle for a declaration of hope.

headline: A Friendship Built for Long Distance
text: In January, when the elite marathoner Kara Goucher found out she was pregnant, she knew exactly whom to ask for advice. Paula Radcliffe, the women’s world-record holder and mother of a 3-year-old daughter, had just arrived in Portland, Ore., to train with her.

headline: College Team Teaches a Lesson in Acceptance
text: ONEONTA, N.Y. — The Oneonta men’s lacrosse team marched two by two onto the field, sticks held with purpose for the final home game of the season. Beneath their helmets, the players flashed hard looks and cheeks smeared with eye black.

headline: U.S. Pressure Helps Militants Overseas Focus Efforts
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama decided last year to narrow the scope of the nine-year war in Afghanistan and Pakistan, he and his aides settled on a formulation that sounded simple: Eviscerate Al Qaeda, but just “degrade” the Taliban, reversing that movement’s momentum.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: South Africa Comes Far but Has Far to Go
text: Lucas Radebe grew up in South Africa playing soccer with a tennis ball, or a sphere made from old cloth and shopping bags. Lacking jerseys in the Diepkloof township, a part of Soweto, he and his friends gathered sacks of mealie meal, a grain staple. They cut out holes for their arms and heads and scrawled numbers on the bags or colored them with dye.

headline: Thursday’s Stock Free Fall May Prompt New Rules
text: WASHINGTON — The kind of bungee jump that stocks took Thursday, plunging abruptly before snapping partway back in a brief frenzy of electronic trading, has worried market operators and experts on trading for some time. Despite a surprising consensus about what needs to be done, federal regulators have not shown much urgency in rewriting the rules governing an increasingly fragmented, and computerized, trading system.

headline: In Times Square, Deciding When to Suspend Fear
text: Last Tuesday night, I had a date with my 13-year-old daughter to see the Imax version of  “Iron Man 2”  at a theater on 42nd Street. In a first for us, she would take the bus in by herself from our suburban New Jersey home to the Port Authority Bus Terminal. There would be a phone call before she got on, a text or two on the way in, and then a call when she arrived and walked across the street to my office. She is mature, quietly confident and careful, and had taken the trip with others many times before, so it seemed pretty straightforward.

headline: The Coy Art of the Mystery Bidder
text: If you follow art auctions even peripherally, you know that each one leaves a trail of question marks. Who bought the van Gogh? Who bought the Johns? We would very much like to know. Sooner or later we usually do.

headline: Heading out on the Win-a-Trip Journey
text: I’m at Kennedy Airport, just heading out to Gabon (via Frankfurt) with Mitch Smith, the winner of this year’s Win-a-Trip journey. Mitch, a Kansan attending University of Nebraska, flew in from Kansas City this morning.

headline: Staten Island Ferry Crash
text: Barbara Mill of the Coast Guard said the Staten Island Ferry crash, which injured 37 people, was caused by lost propulsion. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: Gates Takes Aim at Pentagon Spending
text: ABILENE, Kan. — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates challenged some sacrosanct Pentagon spending practices in a speech on Saturday, directing both military and civilian officials to find cuts in their overhead and operating costs and then transfer the savings to the fighting force.

headline: For President Obama, Many Gaps to Fill on the Bench
text: Many argue that the Supreme Court lacks diversity. As President Obama closes in on a nominee, 10 legal experts make their case for the kind of justice the court needs.

headline: James Resets Playoffs to His Cruise Control
text: Boston

headline: Funk Goes From Cut Line to Contender
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Last week 20-year-old Rory McIlroy made the cut on the number, then charged up the leader board with a third-round six-under 66 at the Quail Hollow Championship. On Saturday at the Players Championship, it was Fred Funk’s turn.

headline: Sincere Flattery With a Baseball Bat
text: Like any great mimic, Gar Ryness sees the same things everybody else sees, but recognizes them, retains them and repeats them. Ryness is the Batting Stance Guy, a YouTube star with the uncanny ability to imitate baseball players. He highlights their eccentricities as a way of paying homage to his favorite sport.

headline: Mets Wait, and Wait Some More, for Beltran
text: Saturday was a landmark day for the Mets, but not necessarily one they wanted to honor or acknowledge. It was the 100th game that Carlos Beltran had missed during two extended absences from the team over the last two seasons. A troublesome right knee has made him the forgotten man of Flushing.

headline: Problem for Containment Dome in Gulf
text: 4:41 p.m. | Updated Officials for BP on Saturday encountered a significant setback in their efforts to attach a containment dome over a leaking well on the seabed of the Gulf of Mexico, forcing them to move the dome aside while they find another method to cap the crude oil flowing into the Gulf since April 20.

headline: If the Hall Calls, Piazza Wants to Enter as a Met
text: The former Mets great Mike Piazza spends most of his time at home in Florida. He does not watch many games because most of his attention is focused on another challenge: being a father. He gets his exercise, he said, helping his wife, Alicia, run after his two young daughters.

headline: The British Voter, Adrift
text: More than a decade ago, the British voter’s love affair with hope began with an anthem. “Things can only get better,” the party that called itself New Labour sang. Last week, that era ended in a muddle, a mess — an election in which Gordon Brown’s Labour Party clearly lost, but nobody clearly won. If the confused outcome had a musical title, it might be: “Elegy for an Ideal.”

headline: Turn Off GPS. Drive Toward Serendipity.
text: BERLIN — Last month in Germany, a 45-year-old Bavarian man followed the directions of his GPS device onto the wrong end of a highway off-ramp near the city of Osnabrück, in what the newspaper Die Welt called a case of “blind trust” in his gadget.

headline: Bennett Ousted at Utah G.O.P. Convention
text: 5:50 p.m. | Updated  SALT LAKE CITY — Senator Robert F. Bennett, an 18-year veteran Republican who had been seeking a fourth term this fall, was stripped of his party’s nomination on Saturday at the state convention, becoming one of the first Congressional victims of the surging ferment of discontent from the Tea Party-infused Republican right.

headline: The Morning Line: The Business of Racing
text: Bennett Liebman is the Executive Director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

headline: Pope Accepts Resignation of a Bishop in Germany
text: VATICAN CITY — Pope Benedict XVI on Saturday accepted the resignation of a German bishop under investigation for sexual abuse, the latest high-profile resignation since a sexual abuse crisis erupted in the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Shootings of Afghans on Rise at Checkpoints
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Shootings of Afghan civilians by American and NATO convoys and at military checkpoints have spiked sharply this year, becoming the leading cause of combined civilian deaths and injuries at the hands of Western forces, American officials say.

headline: The Ghosts of Gandamak

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,044 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans last week:

headline: Fixing the Treaty
text: The world has a chance this month to send a powerful message about its determination to curb the spread of nuclear weapons. To do that, 189 nations, whose diplomats have gathered in New York, must strengthen the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.

headline: Why Merge?
text: Regulators pondering whether to allow the proposed merger between Continental and United Airlines must figure out the extent to which such a mix will lead to less competition and higher fares. To do that, they must answer a broader question: Why have airlines concluded that merging is their path to profitability?

headline: Uganda Panel Gives Setback to Antigay Bill
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — A special committee organized by the president of Uganda has recommended that a harsh antihomosexuality bill that has drawn the ire of Western governments be withdrawn from Parliament, a senior government official said Saturday.

headline: There Ought to Be a Bruno Law
text: So, add Joseph Bruno, New York’s former Senate leader, to the Albany List of Shame. On Thursday, a federal judge sentenced him to two years in prison for using his office for personal gain. This has to stop. New York needs a tough reform law and more honest lawmakers.

headline: The Gulf, Before the Spill
text: Even before the recent oil spill, the Gulf of Mexico was hardly pristine.

headline: An Expatriate Filipino Writes of a Parallel Life
text: HONG KONG — The story begins with the death of Crispin Salvador, an expatriate Filipino author living in New York, whose body is found floating in the Hudson River. He had been scathingly critical of his home country before his mysterious demise.

headline: ‘Hey, Governor!’ Paterson Rides the Ferry
text: As far as most people aboard the 1:30 p.m. ferry from St. George terminal to Manhattan seemed to know, the strangest thing that happened on the Staten Island Ferry on Saturday was that the governor of New York was riding it.

headline: Right Place and Time For a Bruin to Emerge
text: Some days, Miroslav Satan would be joined by only one other skater at the Islanders’ practice rink at Iceworks in Syosset, N.Y.: Lenny DiCostanzo, a former minor league goaltender who was the visiting locker-room attendant at Nassau Coliseum. Satan knew him only as Lenny.

headline: A Changing View on Scoring With Skates
text: The refereeing of some N.H.L. playoff games this spring has been oddly inconsistent, to the point where, during Thursday’s Game 4 between Pittsburgh and Montreal, “Hockey Night in Canada” took the unusual step of showing a compilation of missed calls that benefited the Penguins.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Last week, conservatives differed over whether Faisal Shahzad, arrested in the attempted car bombing in Times Square, should be interrogated without initially being read his Miranda rights.

headline: Life Outside the Ropes Can Be a Tough Course to Negotiate, Too
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — A golfer on the PGA Tour has 40 seconds to play a shot, sometimes a little longer. If he takes 72 strokes in a five-hour round, that means his mind has more than four hours to wander between hits.

headline: Mother Becomes a Devoted Team Player
text: Sports moms are parodied on television wearing flippy hair and unflattering jeans, or else portrayed as alpha women who phone the coach on the field, as in “The Blind Side.” They bear little resemblance to the ones I know, and especially the sports mom I have become.

headline: N.B.A. Postseason Ruled by Well-Worn Maxim: ‘The Game Slows Down’
text: In the fairy-tale world, a slow-and-steady tortoise once beat a quick-but-arrogant hare, who foolishly napped midrace. If they played basketball, this would be considered proof that turtles are better suited for the playoffs.

headline: Democrats See Hopes for West Dim in Colorado
text: DENVER — When Barack Obama stood before an admiring audience at Mile High Stadium here and accepted his presidential nomination 21 months ago, Democratic leaders crowed about turning Colorado into a reliable stronghold, another step toward building the party’s strength in the West.

headline: Imam’s Path From Condemning Terror to Preaching Jihad
text: WASHINGTON — In the weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, the eloquent 30-year-old imam of a mosque outside Washington became a go-to Muslim cleric for reporters scrambling to explain Islam. He condemned the mass murder, invited television crews to follow him around and patiently explained the rituals of his religion.

headline: Different Game, Different Catcher, Same Ending
text: For the second consecutive game against the San Francisco Giants, the Mets stuck to the same script. It was not a perfect plot, but if they can keep repeating it, the show could become a long-running hit.

text: The same boat involved in a serious 2003 crash slammed into a pier at St. George terminal.

headline: Date With a Neanderthal
text: Neanderthals mated with some modern humans after all and left their imprint in the human genome, a team of biologists has reported in the first detailed analysis of the Neanderthal genetic sequence.  The Times, May 6

headline: You’d Never Know He’s a Sun King
text: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.

headline: Test Flights Into the Google Cloud
text: JORDON WING is a devoted user of Google products like Gmail, the Chrome browser and Google Docs, the Web-based word processing program.

headline: The Ever-Widening World of Tiny Projectors
text: WAVING your hand to get the bartender’s attention may not be the only way to order a martini in crowded bars of the future — even if they’re as busy as the cantina in “Star Wars.”

headline: Ignoring the Elephant in the Bailout
text: IF you blinked, you might have missed the ugly first-quarter report last week from Freddie Mac, the mortgage finance giant that, along with its sister Fannie Mae, soldiers on as one of the financial world’s biggest wards of the state.

headline: Greek Debt Woes Ripple Outward, From Asia to U.S.
text: The fear that began in Athens, raced through Europe and finally shook the stock market in the United States is now affecting the broader global economy, from the ability of Asian corporations to raise money to the outlook for money-market funds where American savers park their cash.

headline: Woods Has Much to Do Before Pebble Beach
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Tiger Woods’s hold on the No. 1 world ranking, once as firm as a salesman’s handshake, is suddenly tenuous.

headline: Playing for the World Title, Minus Any Fireworks
text: Before a world championship match, players spend months looking at their opponent’s games and studying opening systems, often with the aid of computers and databases. They also hire trainers, who are called seconds, to help. It is a time- and labor-intensive process.

headline: Ms. Conceptions
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — On a day that celebrates those who brought us all into this world, Elizabeth Gorski presents a lineup of seven remarkable women who were responsible for bringing some other creations to life.

headline: They Don’t Report. You Don’t Have to Decide.
text: “DESPITE the major environmental disaster unfolding in the Gulf and the attempted terror attack on New York’s Times Square, President Obama spent his Saturday night laughing it up at the White House Correspondents Dinner,” griped Sean Hannity of Fox News last week. His complaint is not inaccurate. But it’s hardly the whole story. Also laughing it up at that dinner were many of the country’s television news potentates, including some of Hannity’s own colleagues. And unlike the president, they were caught napping on a night that could have been 9/11 redux.

headline: Celebrate: Save a Mother
text: Happy Mother’s Day! And let me be clear: I’m in favor of flowers, lavish brunches, and every other token of gratitude for mothers and other goddesses.

headline: A Celebrated Staten Island Name, and an Ill-Fated Ferryboat
text: Long before the Andrew J. Barberi ferry gained notoriety in two crashes, Andrew J. Barberi, the man, became legendary on Staten Island football fields, both as a lineman and as a coach of generations of young players.

headline: On Her Team, It’s All About Bench Strength
text: This interview with Sharon Napier, chief executive of Partners + Napier, an ad agency based in Rochester, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: A Changing View on Scoring With Skates
text: The refereeing of some N.H.L. playoff games this spring has been oddly inconsistent, to the point where, during Thursday’s Game 4 between Pittsburgh and Montreal, “Hockey Night in Canada” took the unusual step of showing a compilation of missed calls that benefited the Penguins.

headline: Trading Up: Buy a Base, Help Cut the Deficit
text: IN a previous column, I introduced the concept of a “paid lunch.”It’s better than a free lunch — which is often thought not to exist — because you’re paid to devour it.

headline: That Nagging Question of Mutual Fund Fees
text: PAUL SAMUELSON, the late Nobel laureate in economics, compared mutual funds to a saloon.

headline: Tell-All Generation Learns to Keep Things Offline
text: Min Liu, a 21-year-old liberal arts student at the New School in New York City, got a Facebook account at 17 and chronicled her college life in detail, from rooftop drinks with friends to dancing at a downtown club. Recently, though, she has had second thoughts.

text: London

headline: Comeback of the Year? Try Corporate Profits
text: THE market remains worried about plenty of things — including a sharp decline late last week, and the spreading debt crisis in Europe. But, recently, it has appeared that investors are ready to strike one item off their list of concerns: corporate profits.

headline: Applause, Please, for Early Adopters
text: WHY would anyone rush to buy a product knowing full well that it would be cheaper — and probably better — in a matter of months?

headline: The Refund That Circled Before Landing
text: WITH this episode, the Haggler celebrates the first anniversary of this column. After 12 months of cranky but polite consumer intercessions, what we have learned? A lot. Don’t buy anything from a company you don’t know until you Google its name along with the word “complaints.” If you must send a glass induction cooktop via FedEx, use plenty of packing peanuts. And, most important: Never make a collect phone call from Kennedy Airport. It’s way too expensive.

headline: After Bogey, a Burger Hits the Spot for Mickelson
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — One streak ended for Phil Mickelson in the third round of the Players Championship when his 12-foot par putt on No. 18 slid two feet past the hole.
