headline: Stroud, Tied for Third, Is No. 1 in Confidence
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Chris Stroud, tied for third after three rounds in his first Players Championship, has more confidence than might be expected of someone whose best finish of the year is a tie for 21st at the Zurich Classic, and whose best career finish is a tie for fifth at the same event.

headline: How His Garden Grows
text: MY grandfather started our mail-order company 100 years ago. In the early 1950s, customers were driving to Randolph, northeast of Madison, to see what they were purchasing by mail from us, and my dad saw an opportunity to start a local garden center.

headline: The Dish on Mom
text: Five artists draw and describe the dish they most think of when they think of their mothers.

headline: Stretch | Flow, Sweat, Stink: Nirvana
text: Full disclosure: I love the heat; I like humidity. It’s in my blood (Cuban) and my upbringing (in Miami). So it didn’t take long for me to fall for hot power vinyasa yoga, a vigorous class taught in a room steamy enough to simulate the tropics in summer.

headline: A Classic Outdoors
text: Speaking of hockey and soccer, the N.H.L. has something to learn from Friday’s Germany-United States game in the opener of the world championship. The teams played before a world-record crowd of 77,803 at Veltins-Arena, the big soccer stadium in Gelsenkirchen, Germany.

headline: Offering Help to a Troubled Colleague
text: Q. One of your co-workers has been acting strangely for a while, and you’re beginning to suspect that something may be seriously wrong — perhaps problems at home, mental health issues or substance abuse. What kind of behavior could point to a problem like this?

headline: Coyotes Deal in Chaos
text: The Phoenix Coyotes’ situation descended into chaos again Friday, as the arena lease deal between Jerry Reinsdorf and the city of Glendale, Ariz., reportedly fell apart. That forced Glendale to go back, hat in hand, to Ice Edge Holdings, the potential buyers the city rejected in favor of Reinsdorf last month.

headline: Filling a Day With Everything Nice
text: Mark Pincus, 44, is the founder and chief executive of Zynga, the fast-growing San Francisco company known for online games like Mafia Wars and FarmVille, in which players run a virtual farm. Every day, some 45 million people play Zynga’s games, which are popular on Facebook. His words have been edited and condensed. MALIA WOLLAN

headline: Leading the Coastal Commission for 25 Years, a Crusader and Lightning Rod
text: Peter Douglas has survived Nazi Germany, throat cancer, accidentally setting himself on fire, and what he counts as 11 efforts to unseat him in his quarter-century as executive director of the California Coastal Commission.

headline: Seeking the Fine Line of Where the Bay Ends
text: Typically in the Bay Area, a densely populated, transit-oriented development with schools, offices and grocery stores built near jobs and within walking distance of a mix of apartments and townhomes would be a big hit with environmentalists.

headline: N.A.I.A. Team Forfeits Season
text: The Bellevue University baseball team has forfeited its entire 2010 season after one of its players was deemed ineligible. The Nebraska college, which was 35-7, announced that the team had violated an N.A.I.A. rule, prompting its decision to forfeit all 42 games. (AP)

headline: New Setback in Attempt to Contain Gulf Oil Spill
text: ROBERT, La. — The latest effort to contain the oil spill that has poured millions of gallons of crude into the Gulf of Mexico encountered a setback 5,000 feet underwater, officials said Saturday, meaning oil will continue gushing into the ocean for at least several more days, and possibly months.

headline: Problems Even Before a Ferryboat’s First Voyage
text: The Andrew J. Barberi first set sail across Upper New York Bay in August 1981 after a pomp-filled send-off from Staten Island by Mayor Edward I. Koch. Its engine promptly failed, the steering mechanism went dead, and the vessel ran aground near Governors Island.

headline: Street Art Moves Onto Some New Streets
text: For a short while a few months ago, a mural by Eddie Colla enlivened an otherwise grubby stretch of wall in an alleyway in the upscale Hayes Valley neighborhood. The image, depicting two nearly naked and tattooed young women entwined in a sensual kiss, was a witty political message. The words “Just Married,” spray-painted in crimson above the couple, suggested the artist’s stance on gay marriage, while the six crushed beer cans dangling from strings attached to the women’s thighs like postmodern wedding garters conveyed his offbeat sense of humor. But like many street works — broadly defined as the stencils, murals, posters, tags and stickers that appear, often illegally, in public spaces — Mr. Colla’s mural didn’t last long.

headline: Mother’s Day at the White House
text: The White House is no stranger to generations of mothers, and this year, it even houses a grandmother.

headline: Yanks’ Offense Erupts, and an Injury Flares Up
text: BOSTON — Even as afternoon faded to dusk Saturday and downpours gave way to puffy clouds and back to downpours again, two constants remained for the Yankees. One, they would forge ahead, tattered lineup and all, and impose their will upon the Boston Red Sox for a second straight day. Two, whatever wacky witchcraft is felling their players at a staggering pace would somehow claim another victim.

headline: The $106.5 Million Anonymous Bid
text: Why spend a record-setting fortune on a painting and then keep your name out of the press? In this Sunday’s Week in Review, Roberta Smith explores the mystique of the mystery bidder:

headline: Leader Board in Disarray, but Westwood Remains on Top
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — When the sun was going down Saturday, it looked as if Lee Westwood was sinking with it. With his golf ball atop a storm drain in the woods right of the 18th fairway — a seeming portent of the direction his luck and lead might be heading — Westwood came up with the kind of shot that reverses trends and wins big tournaments like the Players Championship.

headline: New Union Leader Wants Group to Be More of a Political Powerhouse
text: WASHINGTON — As the eldest daughter among 10 siblings — and the third-eldest in all — Mary Kay Henry, the incoming president of the Service Employees International Union, says she was born to be an organizer.

headline: States Move to Allow Overseas and Military Voters to Cast Ballots by Internet
text: WASHINGTON — Nearly three million overseas and military voters from at least 33 states will be permitted to cast ballots over the Internet in November using e-mail or fax, in part because of new regulations proposed last month by the federal agency that oversees voting.

headline: For Priest, Intersection of Faith and Doubt
text: BOSTON — The questions were heartfelt, especially for women of faith, especially so late in life.

headline: Johnson Is Expected to Be Out Several Weeks
text: BOSTON — When the Yankees signed Nick Johnson in December to be their designated hitter, they knew precisely what they were getting: an on-base machine with a lengthy injury history. Johnson has lived up to that reputation on both counts, and now he is expected to miss several weeks after a magnetic resonance imaging test revealed an inflamed tendon in his right wrist.

headline: Bit of Disharmony in Alaska Over Adding to the State Song
text: JUNEAU, Alaska — It has been nearly a quarter-century since a former Alaska poet laureate composed a second verse for the Alaska state song, adding lines to celebrate the diverse indigenous people of the Last Frontier.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 9
text: A botched terror plot, Wall Street’s wobbly week, and the Gulf Coast oil disaster headline the Sunday talk shows.

headline: For BP, a History of Spills and Safety Lapses
text: After BP’s Texas City, Tex., refinery blew up in 2005, killing 15 workers, the company vowed to address the safety shortfalls that caused the blast.

headline: BP Is in the Spotlight for Now, but 3 Other Companies Could Share the Blame
text: As Congress prepares to hold hearings into the April 20 explosion that sank the Deepwater Horizon oil rig, a billion-dollar question is bobbing on the oil-slicked waves: Whose fault is it?

headline: For Mother’s Day: Organizations Making Motherhood Safer
text: Okay, you’ve handed over the flowers and taken your mother/wife/daughter/sister to brunch — and now you’re thinking about doing something for motherhood generally. My Sunday column suggests some steps to make motherhood safer, and here are some organizations active in this space.

headline: Utah Delegates Oust Three-Term G.O.P. Senator From Race
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Senator Robert F. Bennett, an 18-year veteran Republican who had been seeking a fourth term, was stripped of his party’s nomination on Saturday at the state convention here, becoming one of the first Congressional victims of the surging discontent from the Tea Party-infused Republican right.

headline: Peter O’Donnell, the Creator of Modesty Blaise, Dies at 90
text: Peter O’Donnell, the British writer who created Modesty Blaise, the sexy, resourceful action hero who was a distaff answer to James Bond, first as a comic strip character and later as the heroine of novels and short stories, died Monday in Brighton, on the south coast of England. He was 90.

headline: Infant Found Dead in Manhattan Hotel Room
text: The medical examiner was investigating after a 2-month-old boy was found dead at a budget hotel on East 28th Street on Saturday afternoon.

headline: Devra G. Kleiman, Biologist Who Helped Change Zoos, Is Dead at 67
text: Devra G. Kleiman, a conservation biologist who reintroduced into the wild the tiny endangered monkey known as the golden lion tamarin, and who learned so much about the lives of giant pandas that scientists could later help them reproduce in captivity, died on April 29 in Washington. She was 67 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

headline: Rhonda Copelon, Lawyer in Groundbreaking Rights Cases, Dies at 65
text: Rhonda Copelon, a human rights lawyer who played a major role in several groundbreaking cases, including one that allowed victims of abuses in other countries to seek justice in American courts, died Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 65.

headline: Muddy Road Molds Debate on the Future of Guyana
text: FIFTY EIGHT, Guyana — A battered, decades-old Bedford truck that would not look out of place in a “Mad Max” movie pulled off the road. Gold miners crawled out of its mud-splattered cab, sauntered into Peter Rajmenjan’s diner and asked if he had any bush hog for sale.

headline: The Conrad Black Style of Doing Hard Time
text: In the somber environment of a prison, most inmates do time. Baron Black of Crossharbour, however, does book reviews. Perhaps former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich should take note.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Deportation’s Brief Adios and Prolonged Anguish
text: When Sheena Perez walked into the federal detention center in Broadview just after dawn Tuesday, she carried $200 in cash and a backpack filled with two T-shirts, two pairs of jeans and underwear, all freshly ironed. Slung over her right arm was her boyfriend’s favorite leather jacket; in her left hand was a bottle of 212 cologne.

headline: The Pulse: Housing Authority to Open a Wait List for Units
text: The Chicago Housing Authority is preparing to open its family housing wait list for the first time in more than a decade. The city uses the list, which has been closed since 1999, to fill vacancies in its nearly 10,000 rental units designated for family housing, said Kellie O'Connell-Miller, a spokeswoman for the housing authority.

headline: The Pulse: Caremark Triumphs With Lucrative Contract
text: Caremark has won its bid for a huge deal to provide pharmacy services for local government employees.

headline: Tough and Smart and Behind the Plate
text: Muddy Ruel talked like a lawyer and thought like a ballplayer, which isn’t surprising given that he worked both jobs during his 67 years on Earth.

headline: A Mother’s Life
text: I first met Ethel Morgan Smith one year ago this weekend when she left an elegy of sorts in the comments section of a Motherlode post about Mother’s Day and consumerism. Hers was a stunning tribute to a woman who had done what she could with a hard life, and even though it was tucked into the comments, readers found her words and sent thanks for them.

headline: Winds Delay Travelers and Commuters
text: The New York area remained under a wind advisory early Sunday morning after a day of winds greater than 20 miles per hour caused inconvenience and frustration around the region, especially for travelers. The National Weather Service measured gusts of up to 38 m.p.h. in Central Park as a low-pressure system traveled toward the St. Lawrence River Valley.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Population Study Finds Change in the Suburbs
text: As the first decade of the 21st century comes to a close, more black, Asian, Hispanic, foreign-born and poor people live in the suburbs of the nation’s largest metropolitan areas than in their primary cities.

headline: The Man Behind the Coastal Commission and Other Highlights From Sunday’s Bay Area Report
text: Fighting for His Vision of California’s Coastline | Peter M. Douglas is strongly identified with the California Coastal Commission in part because he was a co-author of both the ballot initiative that created it and the 1976 law making the agency permanent. Over the years, commission actions have helped preserve much of Highway 1 as a two-lane road weaving through farmland, rocks and empty dunes. The question now is whether both Mr. Douglas, 67, and the 12-member commission can weather the state’s next budget and continue enforcing the 1976 Coastal Act. Mr. Douglas said he was deeply concerned that an item in Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger’s proposed budget could limit the agency’s access to state legal services. The commission, based in San Francisco, is one of the nation’s most powerful — and litigious — land-use authorities.When Is a Bay Not a Bay? | A major development proposed in Redwood City is, depending on whom you ask, either on the shore of San Francisco Bay — or actually in the bay itself. Which one it is may not ultimately have any legal bearing on whether the project can be built. But the developer and the project’s opponents are fighting over the question as if it will decide the matter.

headline: Betty White on ‘S.N.L.’
text: Video | Facebook? How about good ol’ phone book? “Golden Girl,” 88, finally does “Saturday Night Live.” Opening monologue:

headline: Vows: Avery & Matt
text: Avery Willis and Matt Hoffman met on a Brooklyn-bound F Train three years ago on Friday the 13th and went on an impromptu date. They soon discovered their markedly different backgrounds.

headline: Tate Modern in London Celebrates a Decade
text: As the first public gallery in London to be devoted entirely to modern art, the Tate Modern — housed in a once derelict power station on the South Bank of the Thames that was transformed a decade ago by the architectural firm Herzog and de Meuron — has become one of the most visited museums of modern and contemporary art in the world, with over 45 million visitors to date. The Modern (www.tate.org.uk) is celebrating its 10th anniversary this month, and a number of upcoming events are planned to celebrate the milestone.

headline: Qatar Holding Buys Harrods Store
text: LONDON — Mohamed al-Fayed agreed Saturday to sell the London luxury department store Harrods to Qatar Holding, adding another well-known brand to the emirate’s investments.

headline: Raiders, Rappers and JaMarcus Russell
text: An all-Raiders aggregation post, starting with a sneak peek at “Straight Outta L.A.,” which ESPN will show as one of its “30 for 30″ films next month.

headline: Bring Your Questions on the European Debt Crisis
text: In light of the fiscal turmoil facing much of Europe, we have asked a panel of experts to answer your questions about the Greek debt crisis, contagion worries, the future of the euro zone, how Europe’s issues might affect the United States, and the effect of all this on the markets.

headline: Betty White in the Mother of All ‘Saturday Night Live’ Episodes
text: All it took to reinvigorate a 35-year-old comedy show was the presence of an 88-year-old woman.

headline: Sweating the Details in Climate Discourse
text: The journal Science, which has long had an editorial stance pushing for action to cut emissions of greenhouse gases, published a piece of artwork last week that provided a nice bit of raw meat for foes of such steps.

headline: E.U. Details $957 Billion Rescue Package
text: BRUSSELS — European leaders agreed on Monday to provide a huge rescue package of nearly $1 trillion in a sweeping effort to combat the debt crisis that has engulfed Europe and threatened markets around the world.

headline: Twin Explosions at a Siberian Mine Kill 12 and Trap Scores
text: MOSCOW — Twin methane gas explosions killed 12 coal miners and trapped 80 underground in western Siberia under conditions so dangerous that officials called off all rescue operations for fear of sending additional men to their deaths.

headline: Holder Backs a Miranda Limit for Terror Suspects
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Sunday it would seek a law allowing investigators to interrogate terrorism suspects without informing them of their rights, as Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. flatly asserted that the defendant in the Times Square bombing attempt was trained by the Taliban in Pakistan.

headline: The Early Word: Congrats, Grads
text: It’s graduation season and the Obamas are making the rounds.

headline: Aquino Son One to Watch in Philippine Elections
text: MANILA — Senator Benigno S. Aquino III, the only son of the Philippines’ two democracy icons, was favored to win in the presidential election on Monday, as he and his main rivals wrapped up their campaigns over the weekend amid worries of widespread violence, cheating and the reliability of a new automated voting system.

headline: Webber Dominates Race, Schumacher Provides Show
text: BARCELONA — It was difficult to distinguish between what might be volcanic ash clouds or just light rain clouds over the Grand Prix circuit outside Barcelona during the Spanish Grand Prix on Sunday.

headline: Apollo Walk of Fame: An Idea Whose Time Has Come
text: Hollywood has the famous one, and New York already has at least three. But on Monday, the city will get another walk of fame.

headline: Minimizing the Risk of a Blowout
text: Just after midnight on March 15, 2001, a gas explosion ripped through the starboard aft of the P-36, a drilling platform anchored off the coast of Brazil.

headline: Woods Withdraws From Players Championship
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Tiger Woods withdrew on the seventh hole of Sunday’s final round at the Players Championship with a neck injury. He was two-over par through his first six holes and two under for the tournament.

headline: 'No Man's Land'
text: Time-lapse video of the installation of Christian Boltanski's work at the Park Avenue Armory. (Video courtesy of the Park Avenue Armory)

headline: Borel to Ride Super Saver on Monday
text: The Kentucky Derby champion Super Saver is going to get a half-mile workout Monday at Churchill Downs with his regular rider Calvin Borel up. The colt’s trainer, Todd Pletcher, had taken a-wait-and-see-approach to whether Super Saver needed a timed workout before next weekend’s Preakness Stakes, the second leg of the Triple Crown.

headline: The Morning Line: All Borel, All the Time
text: Bennett Liebman is the Executive Director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

headline: U.S.-Brokered Mideast Shuttle Talks Begin Again
text: JERUSALEM — The Obama administration announced Sunday that indirect, American-brokered talks had resumed between Israel and the Palestinians, capping a year of efforts by Washington to revive the peace process.

headline: Allies Join Russians in Victory Day Celebration
text: MOSCOW — As they always do, Russia’s finest infantrymen, sailors and airmen strode across Red Square on Sunday for the annual Victory Day parade, accompanied by a customary display of intimidating weaponry. Tanks rumbled by, planes zoomed overhead and missiles as long as subway cars were towed across the historic cobblestones.

headline: It’s 9:16 PM In Europe
text: And we’re still waiting for the rescue plan …

headline: Obama Asks Graduates to Close Education Gap
text: HAMPTON, Va. — For the first time as president, Barack Obama on Sunday delivered a commencement address to a historically black college, Hampton University, telling graduates that they have “a separate responsibility” to become mentors to other young African-Americans to help close a persistent gap in educational achievement.

headline: Mitch Triples his Continent Count…
text: Mitch Smith is a 19-year-old journalism student at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the winner of the 2010 Win-A-Trip with Nick contest. He and Nick arrived Sunday in Gabon, Africa–his first time ever outside of the country.

headline: Robust Opening of ‘Iron Man 2’ and Summer Films
text: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood is hoping that a barrage of sequels, newly increased ticket prices and the 3-D boom will power its crucial summer season, which kicked off this weekend, to a record $5 billion in North American ticket sales.

headline: The Hilbert Hotel
text: In late February I received an e-mail message from a reader named Kim Forbes.  Her six-year-old son Ben had asked her a math question she couldn’t answer, and she was hoping I could help:

headline: Obama Says Education Means Emancipation
text: Addressing graduates at Hampton University, a historically black college, President Obama said the college's founders once stated that education means emancipation. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: Who Wants a Contract in Hearts, South or East?
text: HENDERSON, Nev.  The Cavendish Invitational Pairs ended late Sunday afternoon with a victory for the defending champions, Bobby Levin and Steve Weinstein. They finished 128 international match points ahead of the Norwegians Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness, with Josef Piekarek and Alex Smirnov from Germany third.

headline: New CDs
text: THE DEAD WEATHER

headline: Found Objects and Other Percussive Items
text: Unpredictability is a quality that new music festivals prize, and the Look & Listen Festival has discovered an odd twist. Its mission is to present music of the 20th and 21st centuries alongside contemporary visual art. And on Saturday, at the second of its three concerts this year, that was partly what happened: So Percussion and Phyllis Chen, who plays the toy piano, performed new works at the Gary Snyder/Project Space, a gallery on West 26th Street, where they were surrounded by Beatrice Mandelman’s Abstract Expressionist paintings.

headline: Two Indie Bands, With Plenty of Three-Part Harmonies
text: A few strains of contemporary indie-rock orthodoxy converged at the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night. Local Natives, from Los Angeles, and Suckers, from Brooklyn, were passing through town together, not quite three weeks into their seven-week tour.

headline: The Man Who Broke Babe’s Record
text: I’m not sure what this says about America, or about publishing or baseball or sports writers, but it has taken 36 years for a proper full-dress biography of Henry Aaron, the man who, in 1974, broke Babe Ruth’s home run record, and did so as a black man playing for Major League Baseball’s first franchise in the Deep South. His is a great American life, and Howard Bryant’s “Last Hero: A Life of Henry Aaron” rises confidently to meet it.

headline: Exploring Mortality With Clothes and a Claw
text: At first sight, the monumental artwork being installed at the Park Avenue Armory suggests nothing so much as a crane claw, the frustrating arcade game in which a player tries to pull a stuffed animal from a pile of many, and to hold on to it, with a grapple controlled by a joystick.

headline: Some Air Pollution
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Have a seat. Anywhere. Today, you have plenty of choices; one in every long answer word.

headline: A Woman’s Flights of Fantasy and Fear
text: SEATTLE — For 27 years as its general director, Speight Jenkins has done very well by the Seattle Opera. But amid his many accomplishments, which include an extensive renovation of the company’s house, there was one glaring omission: Mr. Jenkins had never presented the premiere of a commissioned opera.

headline: On the Ferry, Gifts and Some Apprehension
text: It was almost like any other Sunday aboard the Staten Island Ferry.

headline: Those Old Gut Busters, War and Prejudice
text: Ah, togetherness! As the reassuring title of Tom Lehrer’s contemplation of nuclear annihilation puts it, “We Will All Go Together When We Go.” That jolly singalong, written in 1958, anticipated by more than a decade Randy Newman’s “Political Science,” whose narrator, a cranky misanthrope fed up with the rest of the world’s ingratitude for American beneficence, grouses: “They all hate us anyhow/So let’s drop the big one now.”

headline: A Bleak Story With a New Conductor as Its Caretaker
text: Among the many issues that James Levine’s health problems have raised at the Metropolitan Opera, his withdrawal from the company’s latest revival of “Lulu,” Berg’s bleak final opera, was probably not the most urgent. But “Lulu” is one of the pieces in the Met repertory most closely associated with Mr. Levine; before Saturday, he had conducted all but three presentations of the company’s efficient, intelligent John Dexter staging since its introduction in 1977.

headline: Interactivity, Inside and Out, Creates Informal Feeling
text: Not so very long ago, when contemporary composers had to hustle and scratch for places to present their work, art galleries provided a crucial outlet. Even now that modern music is welcome in concert halls and nightclubs alike, galleries can still be particularly congenial spaces — a point made by the Look & Listen Festival, which opened at the Chelsea Art Museum on Friday night.

headline: When the Drive for Power and Money Led to a Slaughter on the Sea
text: Whale lovers be warned: you will want to watch “Into the Deep: America, Whaling & the World,” even though there’s an awful lot in it that you won’t want to see.

headline: Giants Rally to End Mets’ Home Winning Streak
text: With the flags atop the upper deck at Citi Field pointing rigidly back at him, Jason Bay hit a ball into the teeth of an fierce wind. Instead of going over the fence in left field as Bay had hoped, the ball wilted against the blustery assault and dropped in front of left fielder Andres Torres for a bloop single.

headline: The Agenda Behind Electronic Health Records
text: In the nation’s drive to computerize patient records, Jonathan Bush surely qualifies as the most disgruntled beneficiary of the government’s largess – billions of dollars in incentives to accelerate adoption by doctors and hospitals.

headline: Youth Give Fresh Look to Robbins
text: There is a purified, elevated simplicity to Jerome Robbins’s “2 & 3 Part Inventions,” a paring away of extraneous detail that it’s tempting to regard as the wisdom of a master; after all, Robbins made the piece late in life, just four years before his death in 1998.

headline: Two Scandinavian Acts, Layering Electropop With Sharp Falsetto
text: In 1984, a fledgling band from Norway, A-ha, released a perky electropop single with a startling chorus: “Take On Me.” Morten Harket’s voice keeps jumping upward in that chorus until it has spanned over two-and-a-half octaves to arrive at a piercing falsetto. That leap into falsetto is a change from earthly to ethereal, from masculine to androgynous. And it has echoed through Scandinavian pop.

headline: More Met Opera in HD
text: The Metropolitan Opera has announced another summer of opera at the movies. The Summer HD Encores program will present screenings of popular operas from the Met’s most recent Live in HD series, which transmits live performances from the Met to movie theaters across the United States. From June 16 through July 28, six operas will be shown in more than 400 movie theaters across the country. This season’s presentations will include “Aida,” with Violeta Urmana, Dolora Zajick and Johan Botha (June 16); “Roméo et Juliette,” starring Anna Netrebko and Roberto Alagna (June 23); “Eugene Onegin,” featuring Renée Fleming and Dmitri Hvorostovsky, above, (July 7); “La Bohème,” starring Angela Gheorghiu and Ramón Vargas (July 14); “Turandot,” with Maria Guleghina and Marcello Giordani (July 21); and “Carmen,” starring Elina Garanca and Roberto Alagna (July 28). The Met Opera began screening live performances of operas in 2006. The events will take place on Wednesday evenings at 6:30 in each time zone. Theaters and ticket information: metopera.org/hdlive.

headline: The Sound of Julie Andrews, Onstage in London
text: Julie Andrews, right, sang with the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra at London’s O2 Arena on Saturday night in what was her first vocal performance in 13 years and her first stage appearance in Britain in more than 30 years, BBC News reported. The 74-year-old Ms. Andrews — whose voice was damaged in 1997 by surgery to remove throat polyps — mostly spoke during the performance, singing occasionally when accompanied by other vocalists and, in one case, the enthusiastic audience. She opened with “Getting to Know You,” from “The King and I,” and faded into the background as five other singers took over. That song began a tribute to Rodgers and Hammerstein, throughout which Ms. Andrews told stories about her work on stage and screen while video clips of her performances were shown above the stage. Though it was obvious that Ms. Andrews would not be hitting the high notes that helped define her career, she reassured her fans that she could “still sing the hell out of ‘Ol’ Man River.’ ” The audience, in turn, cheered for her rendition of “My Funny Valentine,” her one solo of the evening, and participated in a boisterous “Do-Re-Mi” singalong. During the second half of the show, Ms. Andrews narrated “Simeon’s Gift,” a children’s book she wrote with her daughter, Emma Walton Hamilton, while the supporting cast played the book’s characters. And a finale of classics from “South Pacific” and “The Sound of Music” drew the last of the night’s many standing ovations.

headline: Massachusetts Theaters Announce Seasons
text: Two theaters in Massachusetts are bringing premieres by award-winning playwrights to their seasons. The Huntington Theater Company in Boston has announced that its next season will include a debut from Stephen Karam (“Speech and Debate”), as well as productions of plays by the Pulitzer Prize-winning Lynn Nottage and a New York Drama Critics’ Circle honoree, Annie Baker. Ms. Baker’s “Circle Mirror Transformation” begins Oct. 15 and Ms. Nottage’s “Ruined” opens Jan. 7. “Sons of the Prophet,” Mr. Karam’s new comedy, opens March 25, with direction from Huntington’s artistic director, Peter DuBois. ... American Repertory Theater, in Cambridge, will present the premiere of a new rock musical by the Tony and Grammy award-winning playwright Steven Sater (“Spring Awakening”), as well as Sophocles’ “Ajax,” to be directed by the Soho Rep’s artistic director, Sarah Benson, in its coming season. Charles Connaghan’s new translation of “Ajax,” the story of a warrior recovering from a bout of madness, will have its premiere in February. “Prometheus Bound,” based on the Greek tragedy by Aeschylus, will open in March in a production with text and lyrics from Mr. Sater and music by Serj Tankian, from the band System of a Down. It will be directed by Diane Paulus, who led “Hair” on Broadway and is the artistic director of American Repertory Theater.

headline: Footnote
text: The actor Terrence Howard (“Hustle & Flow,” “Crash”), above, has been cast as Nelson Mandela in “Winnie,” a film based on the story of the South African leader’s former wife, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, according to The Hollywood Reporter. Jennifer Hudson, above, has already been cast to play the title role, with Darrell Roodt directing the $15 million production set to begin filming May 31 in Cape Town.

headline: John Guare to Judge New Drama Award
text: The playwright John Guare has been named the judge of the Yale Drama Series playwriting award for the next three years, according to the David C. Horn Foundation, which sponsors the competition. The award is given annually for an original, full-length play written in English that has not been published or produced. It comes with a prize of $10,000, publication of the manuscript by the Yale University Press and a staged reading at Yale Repertory Theater. Mr. Guare will choose the winners for the years 2011, 2012 and 2013. Past judges have included Edward Albee, for the series’ first two prizes in 2007 and 2008, and David Hare, who chose the 2009 award as well as this year’s winner, Virginia Grise, for her play “blu.”

headline: Betty White Helps Boost Ratings of ‘SNL’
text: All it took to reinvigorate a 35-year-old comedy show was the presence of an 88-year-old woman. On Saturday, after more than 70 years in show business, six Emmy Awards and one improbable Facebook campaign, Betty White, left, got her shot at hosting “Saturday Night Live.” With her, the show had its highest ratings in a year and a half, according to preliminary Nielsen figures provided by NBC. Despite Ms. White’s opening monologue, which made distinctions between her generation and that of the “SNL” fans who pushed for her to host, she seemed at home on the show. She appeared in every sketch, playing, among others, an inadvertently naughty muffin mogul and a loopy census interviewee. The Mother’s Day-themed episode, which brought back the past cast members Molly Shannon, Tina Fey, Amy Poehler, Maya Rudolph, Rachel Dratch and Ana Gasteyer, was also a rare occasion on which the mostly male “SNL” cast took a back seat to its women: Ms. Shannon and Ms. Gasteyer appeared in their NPR parody, “Delicious Dish”; Ms. Rudolph made a return appearance as Whitney Houston; and Ms. Poehler was temporarily reseated at the “Weekend Update” desk. The musical guest was Jay-Z. Support for Ms. White, who became host of the show after a Facebook campaign, was evident on Twitter, where she was a trending topic on Sunday and had praise from fans including the teenage singer Justin Bieber, who tweeted after the broadcast, “BETTY WHITE RULES.”

headline: Does the Climate Bill Have a Chance?
text: The oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has revived interest in long-stalled Congressional legislation aimed at addressing climate change and American dependence on fossil fuels.

headline: Chelsea (Emphatically) Wins Premier League
text: Chelsea is the best team in England, and anyone who disputes that need only look at the scoresheet from its final victory — an 8-0 thrashing of visiting Wigan on Sunday. Chelsea’s Premier League crown was its third in six years.

headline: Fatal Fighting Pits Villagers and Taliban in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Four men from a village militia set up by American troops in western Afghanistan were killed on Saturday, and they may have been beheaded by Taliban militants, an Afghan Army officer said on Sunday. Ten Taliban militants were killed in retaliation, he said.

headline: With Flyovers, a Solar Map of New York
text: While most residents were sleeping, a twin-engine Shrike Commander flew serial missions over the city recently, cruising low like Superman and back and forth like a lawn mower. Equipped with a laser system, the plane collected highly precise images of the city, its rooftops, trees, wetlands and much of what lies in between.

headline: For One Day, It Really Is Dallas Braden’s Mound
text: Dallas Braden’s handful of major league wins grew by one on Sunday. And it was one that will live in the annals of baseball.

headline: Imagine YouTube for Traders
text: For half an hour last Thursday afternoon, CNBC was the most exciting place on television. Watching Erin Burnett and Jim Cramer try not to freak out — they acquitted themselves nicely — while the market tumbled like a drunken rag doll down a long staircase was amazing television.

headline: Obama Jabs, and Democrats Flinch
text: President Obama made another effort last week to project fiscal discipline — and reminded Congressional Democrats why he sometimes exasperates them.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Along Gulf, Many Wary of Promises After Spill
text: GULFPORT, Miss. — People who live along the Gulf Coast know that a promise of money is not nearly as nice as it sounds. It means waiting and waiting, and raising a fuss, and then waiting some more, and consulting lawyers and talking to bureaucrats, and still waiting, and in some cases just giving up.

headline: Trading in Fantasy
text: IN the 1950s, onion growers were often shocked at the low prices they were getting. Casting around for a villain to blame, they alighted on derivatives traders, and they persuaded Congress to ban any futures trading in onions.

headline: Two Teenagers Killed by Party Intruders
text: Two teenagers were killed at a birthday party in the Bronx early Sunday after a group of uninvited men who had gotten into a fight at the party returned with guns and opened fire, the police and witnesses said.

headline: Wave Goodbye to W and V in Subway Signs; Make Room for More M
text: The signage of the New York City subway — stylish Helvetica, white-on-black type — is one of the most universally recognized design schemes in the world. By June 28, quite a bit of it will need to change.

headline: JetBlue Asks Its Fliers to Keep Spreading the Word
text: ALMOST 30 years ago, advertising for Pan American World Airways introduced a slogan, “You can’t beat the experience,” which was ahead of its time in prefiguring the 21st-century focus by marketers on customer experiences with their brands.

headline: Athletics’ Braden Pitches Perfect Game
text: Dallas Braden’s handful of major league wins grew by one on Sunday. And it was one that will live in the annals of baseball.

headline: Celebrity Guest Hosts Find Fans, and Some Fun, in ‘Raw’s’ Ring
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Will Forte, Ryan Phillippe and Kristen Wiig were looking to promote the forthcoming comedy “MacGruber,” they made an early visit not to Jay Leno or David Letterman, but a live prime-time program with an audience bigger than that of either of their shows, as well as “The View” and “Ellen.”

headline: What’s in a Name? A Lot, as It Turns Out
text: PASADENA, Calif. — With his frizzy hair pulled into forward-protruding spikes and his goggle-size glasses, Max Pauson resembles one of the futuristic comic-book characters he admires and draws. Ebullient and eager to show a sketchbook filled with startling portraits, he seems to have identity to spare.

headline: British Government in Limbo as Parties Bargain
text: LONDON — No sooner had the leader of the Liberal Democrats, Nick Clegg, said that he would consider forming an alliance with the enemy Conservative Party after last Thursday’s inconclusive national election, than the Twitter messages began.

headline: In Backing Clean Energy Start-Ups, Fund Looks for Longer Résumés
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Virgin Green Fund, an investment firm backed by Richard Branson, is not going after the hottest new clean energy start-ups. Instead, it wants the ones facing a midlife crisis.

headline: Guest-Teaching Chinese, and Learning America
text: LAWTON, Okla. — Zheng Yue, a young woman from China who is teaching her native language to students in this town on the Oklahoma grasslands, was explaining a vocabulary quiz on a recent morning. Then a student interrupted.

headline: Sex & Drugs & the Spill
text: “Obama’s Katrina”: that was the line from some pundits and news sources, as they tried to blame the current administration for the gulf oil spill. It was nonsense, of course. An Associated Press review of the Obama administration’s actions and statements as the disaster unfolded found “little resemblance” to the shambolic response to Katrina — and there has been nothing like those awful days when everyone in the world except the Bush inner circle seemed aware of the human catastrophe in New Orleans.

headline: In Mobile Age, Sound Quality Steps Back
text: At the ripe age of 28, Jon Zimmer is sort of an old fogey. That is, he is obsessive about the sound quality of his music.

headline: Mets, and Batters, Waiting for Strikes From Perez
text: Tim Lincecum of the San Francisco Giants may be the best pitcher in the major leagues. He threw 116 pitches on Sunday and allowed seven hits. Oliver Perez is struggling to stay in the Mets’ rotation. He threw 98 pitches on Sunday and allowed two hits.

headline: Fight Erupts Over Rules Issued for ‘Mental Health Parity’ Insurance Law
text: WASHINGTON — A huge fight has erupted over rules issued by the Obama administration to enforce a 2008 law that requires equal insurance coverage for the treatment of mental and physical illnesses.

headline: Woods Quits Final Round, Citing Injury to His Neck
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Between the helicopters circling overhead during his practice sessions and the tabloids digging into his private life, this year has been a pain in the neck for Tiger Woods.

headline: Where Iraq Meets Iran, Guards See Shifting Lines
text: SHULHA AL-ALGHWAT BORDER FORT, Iraq — In a barren stretch of desert in southeast Iraq, an American soldier recently waved to his Iranian counterpart pulling guard duty at a fort on the opposite side of the border.

headline: The Anthem Saga
text: Health insurers in many states have been seeking double-digit premium increases from people who buy their own policies directly from the companies rather than obtaining group coverage at work. In states where regulators have the power to curb excessive rate hikes, the increases are often rejected or negotiated down. In those where the regulatory laws are weak not much can be done beyond jawboning.

headline: A Good Election Would Help
text: With all that Haiti lost on Jan. 12  and all that it has to do to rebuild  it needs a strong and legitimate government. That means it needs national elections.

headline: Conservatives in Germany Suffer Defeat at Polls
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative bloc lost its grip on the upper house of Germany’s Parliament on Sunday, as voters in an important regional election dealt her party a strong setback seen as the first significant political fallout from the Greece crisis.

headline: They Don’t Agree Often
text: Politicians who do not agree on much else, agree that the nation’s broken criminal justice system needs to be fixed. A bipartisan group of House members introduced a bill recently that would establish a blue-ribbon commission to study the issues and propose solutions.

headline: Computer Trades Are Focus in Wall Street Plunge
text: Investigators seeking an explanation for the brief stock market panic last week said Sunday that they were focusing increasingly on how a controlled slowdown in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, meant to bring about stability, instead set off uncontrolled selling on electronic exchanges.

headline: Clark Rallies to Gain His First Tour Victory
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — After 205 tries in a career of coming up just short on the PGA Tour, the diminutive man from South Africa came up very big Sunday at T.P.C. Sawgrass, finishing the best round of the day with the putt of his career to win the Players Championship and earn his first victory in the United States.

headline: Charter Schools’ New Cheerleaders: Financiers
text: When Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo wanted to meet certain members of the hedge fund crowd, seeking donors for his all-but-certain run for governor, what he heard was this: Talk to Joe.

headline: Divorce Trade Fair Shows Changing Italian Culture
text: MILAN — The exhibitors at what was billed as Italy’s first divorce trade fair, held here over the weekend, were a predictable mishmash of lawyers, real estate agents, divorce planners, paternity testing centers and dating agencies.

headline: A Spreading Peril for Women’s Privacy and Freedom
text: Supporters of abortion rights held a lunch recently in honor of a momentous victory for their cause: 40 years ago, New York became the first state to fully legalize abortion.

headline: Red Family, Blue Family
text: Fifty years ago, American family structures were remarkably uniform. The rich married at roughly the same rate as the poor and middle class. Divorce rates were low for the college educated and high school graduates alike. Out-of-wedlock births, while more common among African-Americans, were rare in almost every region and community.

headline: Banks Lobbying Against Derivatives Trading Ban
text: Cory Strupp, who represents Wall Street in Washington, spent the last six months lobbying for more than two dozen changes in the derivatives chapter of the Senate’s financial legislation.

headline: Hunting for Clues in Staten Island Ferry Crash
text: The chief engineer aboard the Staten Island ferry that rammed into a pier on Saturday told federal investigators that no engine alarms sounded before the crash, at which point two of the ferry’s four engines stopped, officials said on Sunday.

headline: Consensus for Limits to Secrecy at the Fed
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve appears to have succeeded in fending off a challenge to the autonomy of its monetary policy decisions, but it is likely to face greater scrutiny of the actions it has taken since 2007 to prevent financial institutions from collapsing.

headline: Iran Executes Five Activists, Sending Message to Critics
text: The Iranian government hanged five Kurdish activists, including a woman, on Sunday morning in the Evin prison in Tehran in what appeared to be an effort to intimidate protesters from marking the anniversary of last year’s huge anti-government rallies after the June 12 election.

headline: Love Is Still Learning, and Still Having Fun
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Twice Davis Love III has won the Players Championship, in 1992 and 2003. He has 20 PGA Tour titles and is almost certainly bound for the Hall of Fame down the road in St. Augustine.

headline: Mayor Booker Favored, but Newark Is in No Mood to Celebrate This Year
text: NEWARK — Inside the soaring New Jersey Performing Arts Center, it was theater of the kind politicians crave. Days before facing re-election, Mayor Cory A. Booker and other luminaries announced a deal to build a 44-story apartment tower, bringing jobs and residents to this troubled city.

headline: An Indie That Believes in CDs
text: The waters might be choppy for the music business right now, but the Concord Music Group is happy to ride those waves.

text: While Twitter has nearly equaled Facebook in awareness among Americans — 87 percent now know of it, compared with 26 percent last year — it still lags behind in use.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include trade deficit for March (Wednesday); and retail sales for April, industrial production for April and the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer confidence index for May (Friday).

headline: Maybe Buyouts Aren’t So Bad
text: If HCA is any guide, the private equity industry could exit the leveraged buyouts of the boom years with surprising aplomb. HCA, an operator of hospitals, is planning to go public in a deal that could nearly double its backers’ investment and provide relatively robust annual returns. Perhaps there’s a place for gigantic leveraged buyouts after all.

headline: Mapping the City
text: A crew from Sandborn flies a mapping mission over New York City.

headline: The Battle Against AIDS Is Failing
text: The battle against AIDS in Africa is beginning to fall apart. Money is running out. While Middle-income countries like India and Brazil may be able to save themselves, the future here looks bleak.

headline: The Players Championship Wins Out
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Francesco Molinari of Italy, whom Lee Westwood described as one of the great up-and-coming players from Europe, posted a final-round 73 to place ninth in his inaugural appearance at the Players Championship.

headline: A Football Coach Used to Tests Insists Her Players Pass Theirs
text: WASHINGTON — When Natalie Randolph was named the head coach of Calvin Coolidge Senior High School’s football team in March, her players wasted no time in testing her.

headline: At Front Lines, AIDS War Is Falling Apart
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — On the grounds of Uganda’s biggest AIDS clinic, Dinavance Kamukama sits under a tree and weeps.

headline: In Rondo’s Hands, Celtics Regain Their Balance
text: BOSTON — They have cheered so many legends here that the chorus sometimes sounds like a lingering echo from another year, or another era. The M.V.P. chant, and the mantle itself, is merely passed along from one icon to the next.

headline: After Long Scientific Search, Still No Cure for AIDS
text: Despite decades of effort, no magic bullet for AIDS has been invented.

headline: Scott Spoke a Little Too Soon
text: On Saturday, Adam Scott, who won here in 2004, said he was really happy because he had played the par-3 No. 17, the hole where players take aim at an island green, in two under par in the first three rounds.

headline: As the Need Grows, the Money for AIDS Runs Far Short
text: Appeals to raise money for AIDS are ubiquitous — but the gap between what is needed and what is collected is enormous, and growing.

headline: Cultural Attitudes and Rumors Are Lasting Obstacles to Safe Sex
text: BWINDI, Uganda — In a nameless mud-walled bar, over a lunch of roast goat, bananas and Bell beer, a group of AIDS counselors gathers to discuss one question: Why is it so hard to practice safe sex here?

headline: Therapies to Soothe All Four Legs
text: Horse whispering? Too loud. Some top-level racehorse owners and trainers, seeking to heal injuries or keep their animals in top condition, use equine telepaths as psychic diagnosticians.

headline: Obama Picks Kagan as Justice Nominee
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama nominated Solicitor General Elena Kagan as the nation’s 112th justice, choosing his own chief advocate before the Supreme Court to join it in ruling on cases critical to his view of the country’s future.

headline: When Woods Leaves, Bohn’s Game Suffers
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — Jason Bohn, who was paired with Tiger Woods on Sunday for the final round of the Players Championship, was nervous at the start of his round because he wanted to play well in front of the large gallery that Woods always attracts.

headline: Kagan's Notable Statements and Writings
text: Read documents related to Elena Kagan's views and responses to issues including presidential power, the death penalty and abortion.

headline: Slow Start Does In Mickelson
text: Phil Mickelson needed to come from five strokes off the pace to make a run at his second Players Championship title. But Mickelson, the winner of the 2007 Players, was not able to take advantage of the firm and fast golf course.

headline: A Tough and Bloody Test Ends in the Suns’ Favor
text: SAN ANTONIO — The Phoenix Suns did not need any reminders of the past and their playoff game’s stakes, and Steve Nash could have done without the blood spilling down his face.

headline: With Burnett in Fenway Form, Yankees Fall
text: BOSTON — A. J. Burnett has so spoiled the Yankees this season that they expect excellence every time he pitches. When he stumbles, it is a surprise. But when he stumbles at Fenway Park, it is not. The Red Sox avoided a three-game sweep by thrashing Burnett for nine runs in a 9-3 victory that perhaps left him comforted that the Yankees do not return to Boston until the final weekend of the regular season.

headline: Lena Horne, Singer and Actress, Dies at 92
text: Lena Horne, who broke new ground for black performers when she signed a long-term contract with a major Hollywood studio and who went on to achieve international fame as a singer, died on Sunday night in Manhattan. She was 92.

text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Virginia men’s lacrosse coach Dom Starsia said Sunday night that a sense of normalcy might never return here.

headline: A Lesson About Lessons
text: This is the time of year when people often take golf lessons. Or at least they should. An awful lot of things get out of whack over the winter. For starters, you’re probably gripping your club like a snow shovel.

headline: David E. Apter, Yale Political Scientist, Is Dead  at 85
text: David E. Apter, a Yale professor who wove his expertise in political science and sociology into influential treatises on the often-tortured birth of developing nations, died Tuesday at his home in North Haven, Conn. He was 85.

headline: S. J. Ledogar, Who Shaped Arms Treaties, Is Dead at 80
text: Stephen J. Ledogar, a United States ambassador who played a major role in the drafting of three major international arms control treaties, died Monday in Edgewater, N.J. He was 80 and lived in Guttenberg, N.J.

text: This article is by Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Katharine Q. Seelye and Lisa W. Foderaro.

headline: Asian Markets Rebound on European Rescue Package
text: Stock markets in the Asia-Pacific region rallied early on Monday, and the beleaguered euro firmed against other leading currencies, after European leaders agreed to a giant rescue package in a bid to contain the snowballing worries about the debt levels of Greece and other European nations.

headline: Qatar Holding Buys Harrods Store From Al-Fayed
text: 9:05 a.m. | Updated Mohamed al-Fayed agreed Saturday to sell the London luxury department store Harrods to Qatar Holding, adding another well-known brand to the emirate’s investments, The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier reported.

headline: Details of European Union’s $957 Billion Rescue Package
text: European leaders agreed on Monday to provide a huge rescue package of nearly $1 trillion in a sweeping effort to combat the debt crisis that has engulfed Europe and threatened markets around the world, James Kanter and Landon Thomas Jr. write in The New York Times.

text: WHY have thousands of Burmese pythons invaded the Everglades?WHY do biologists consider it a problem that tourists are fascinated with these snakes?

text: FRANKFURT — European officials on Monday took steps to tackle the widening sovereign debt crisis that has destabilized the Continent.

headline: From Yankees Prospect to the Tigers’ Spark Plug
text: BOSTON — In spring training last year, Robinson Cano took a particular liking to one of the Yankees’ prize prospects. They would talk in the clubhouse and on the field, and one day the prospect asked Cano for some advice.

headline: News Quiz | May 10, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Fed Intervenes in European Debt Crisis
text: After months of quietly watching from the sidelines, the United States finally intervened in the European debt crisis on Sunday night, Sewell Chan writes in The New York Times.

headline: Rescuers Are Counted Among Dead as Toll Rises in Russian Mine Blasts
text: MOSCOW — The death toll in a double explosion at a Siberian coal shaft climbed to 43 on Tuesday, Russian news agencies reported, and among the dead were many rescuers killed trying to reach trapped comrades. Hope was fading for 47 others caught in a darkened subterranean maze of methane gas and floodwater in what appeared to be the worst Russian mining disaster in three years.

headline: Banks Lobby Against Ban on Derivatives Trading
text: Cory Strupp, who represents Wall Street in Washington, spent the last six months lobbying for more than two dozen changes in the derivatives chapter of the Senate’s financial legislation.

headline: Computer Trades Are Focus in Wall Street Plunge
text: Investigators seeking an explanation for the brief stock market panic last week said Sunday that they were focusing increasingly on how a controlled slowdown in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, meant to bring about stability, instead set off uncontrolled selling on electronic exchanges, Graham Bowley and Edward Wyatt write in The New York Times.

headline: Risk Seen for Europe’s Banks if Cuts Freeze Credit
text: Analysts and investors have begun to focus on the risks to European banks if severe budget cuts by debt-ridden countries freeze credit markets and cause a double-dip recession, The New York Times’s Jack Ewing writes.

headline: Coordinated Attacks in Iraqi Cities Kill More Than 100
text: BAGHDAD — A series of attacks in Baghdad and other cities across Iraq on Monday struck police and army checkpoints, as well as markets, a mayor’s office and a textile factory. The violence appeared to be a coordinated rebuttal of assertions by Iraqi and American commanders that Al Qaeda in Iraq and other extremist groups had suffered debilitating blows in recent weeks.

headline: Steve Cohen Puts Manet Trophy on the Block
text: Paintings by Édouard Manet rarely come up for sale, let alone self-portraits, of which he painted only two. But “Self-Portrait With a Palette,” from 1878, which depicts the Impressionist master posed in an impeccably tailored jacket, will be a star of Sotheby’s Impressionist and Modern art auction in London on June 22, where it is expected to sell for $30.1 million to $45.2 million.

headline: Your Jokes: ‘Most Popular Baby Names’
text: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Peabody Cuts Bid After Australia Tax Proposal
text: Peabody Energy lowered its all-cash bid for Macarthur Coal, the Australian miner, on Sunday, submitting an offer of 15 Australian dollars a share to value the company at $3.4 billion, as Australia prepares to impose a 40 percent tax on mining profits, a move that companies say will lessen investment.

headline: Moody’s Served Wells Notice by S.E.C.
text: Moody’s Investor Service said Friday in its quarterly report that it had received a Wells notice from the Securities and Exchange Commission, notifying the ratings agency that the S.E.C. was considering taking action against it because of “false and misleading” statements in Moody’s application to register as a recognized statistical rating organization.

headline: Aquino Son Takes Lead in Philippines
text: MANILA — Senator Benigno S. Aquino III, whose parents wrested the Philippines from autocratic rule a generation ago, took a commanding lead early Tuesday morning in the race to become the country’s next president, according to incomplete results from Monday’s election.

headline: China Pledges Help Amid Greek Financial Woes
text: China’s premier, Wen Jiabao, said that his country will support actions to help Greece overcome its sovereign debt crisis, state media reported Monday, according to Reuters.

headline: The Trades of a Lifetime, in 20 Minutes
text: Can you hear that crashing sound? Someone on Wall Street just made a killing.

headline: Joystick Division | Playing Deluxx Fluxx
text: Late Wednesday night, The Moment was in the mood for some old-school video arcade action, so we set our sights on 158 Allen Street, where street artists have engineered a blast from the analog past. Their art installation, “Deluxx Fluxx,” is a functional video arcade that harks back to a time between pinball and PlayStation, when Frogger and Pac-Man first put the joy in joystick.

headline: Traces of Explosive Found on Sunken S. Korean Ship
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Forensic experts investigating the wreckage of a South Korean warship that sank near the sea border with North Korea have found traces of an explosive component commonly used in torpedoes and mines, South Korea’s defense minister said Monday.

headline: Down With Internet Memes
text: Today’s idea: Enough with Internet memes already, the editor of The Onion says. They’re not so much organic cultural touchstones as reflections of insecurity-driven herd behavior.

headline: U.S. Diplomat Meets With Myanmar Opposition Leader
text: HONG KONG — A senior United States diplomat met with the leader of Myanmar’s principal opposition party on Monday, three days after it was disbanded after refusing to register for an election it considered to be undemocratic.

headline: Tough Deal for Chris Johnson and Titans
text: Vic Carucci of NFL.com offers excellent analysis on the Chris Johnson holdout in Tennessee. Carucci’s thesis is that this conflict lacks a bad guy. In other words, Johnson is right in demanding a new deal, and the Titans are right in refusing to give him one.

headline: A Rich New Poverty Measure
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: Amsterdam’s Old Days, in Photos
text: For evidence that Amsterdam has always been as picturesque as it is today, head to the Stadsarchief, or city archives, for an eye-catching exhibition that harks back to the humble beginnings of the art of photography. “Amsterdam 1845-1875, the First Photographs,” which runs through June 27, pulls together dozens of images by a handful of early practitioners of the craft.

headline: China Bans Two Rights Lawyers for Life
text: BEIJING — Two lawyers who represented a follower of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement have had their licenses permanently revoked, a move that prevents them from ever practicing law in China, the lawyers said Monday.

headline: Imagine YouTube for Traders
text: For half an hour last Thursday afternoon, CNBC was the most exciting place on television. Watching Erin Burnett and Jim Cramer try not to freak out — they acquitted themselves nicely — while the market tumbled like a drunken ragdoll down a long staircase was amazing television, David Carr writes in The New York Times.

headline: Making NYSE: Stock Exchanges Reconcile

headline: Durbin: Fixing Wall Street’s Autopilot
text: On Thursday afternoon, the Dow plunged 1,000 points within a few minutes, followed by an equally sudden recovery. We don’t know all the details about the drop, but it was almost certainly the result of computer or human error in a high-speed trading program, Michael Durbin writes in an Op-Ed in The New York Times.

headline: Hiring a Friend to Work in Your Business
text: When business owners visit our firm to discuss the sale of their businesses, they are often accompanied by another person. Typically that person is a spouse, lawyer, accountant, partner with an equity stake or family member who works in the business. But every so often the other person is introduced as “a friend.” At this point I hope for the best but prepare mentally for the worst.

headline: What’s the Story Behind Your Name?
text: An article today about a man who did not officially have a first name until he was 19 asks the question, “What’s in a name?” Do you like your name? How did you get it? How has it shaped you? If, like this man, you had to officially name yourself now, would you keep the name you’ve had all your life, or take another? Why?

headline: Another Low-Cost Car Coming to Indian Auto Market
text: Life at the bottom of India’s automotive food chain is soon going to get more crowded, and a lot more competitive.  France’s Renault and its partner, the Nissan Motor Company of Japan, and Bajaj Auto, India’s second-largest motorcycle manufacturer, announced details of a low-cost city car coming to the Indian market in 2012.   The goal: to take the fight to the Tata Nano, a jellybean-shaped sedan with a starting price of about $2,200.

headline: Sampler: Budget Cuts, Part XXIV, and Jumping Frog Turf War
text: Bracing for More Budget Cuts | Get ready to hear more bad news from Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger on Friday about the state’s finances. He is scheduled to release an updated budget plan, which is likely to include even deeper cuts to state services than those proposed in January, The San Francisco Chronicle reported. Governor Schwarzenegger included $6.9 billion in federal aid in his January budget, but so far, the state has received less than $3 billion. The state’s controller, John Chiang, reported last Friday that the state collected $3.6 billion less in tax revenue in April than had been projected. Despite a budget deficit that could run over $20 billion, both Republicans and Democrats in the Legislature have pledged not to seek new taxes this year. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

text: WASHINGTON — Fannie Mae’s request on Monday for another $8.4 billion in federal aid comes at a politically inconvenient time for the Obama administration, which is pressing to pass sweeping financial legislation without resolving the company’s future.

headline: Fannie Seeks $8.4 Billion After 1st-Quarter Loss
text: 11:34 a.m. | Updated Fannie Mae on Monday reported a $13 billion loss for its first quarter and requested an additional $8.4 billion in aid from the federal government, as the mortgage finance giant warned that it faced “significant uncertainty” over its future.

headline: The Rail Bookshelf: ‘Losing Charlotte’
text: Heather Clay grew up on Three Chimneys Farm, a family horse farm in Midway, Ky. She is a graduate of Middlebury College and Columbia University’s School of the Arts. She has published short fiction in The New Yorker. She lives in New York City with her husband and their two daughters. “Losing Charlotte” is her first novel.

headline: Shock at Hotel Where Baby Was Found Dead
text: On Sunday, the lobby of the Latham Hotel was busy with an eclectic mix of sights and sounds. European tourists, who occupied the upper floors, hauled their luggage and street maps; a stereo pounded out hip-hop music; and a bellhop slapped high-fives with the local children who lived on the lower floors.

headline: People and Accounts of Note in Advertising
text: Josh Abrams joined Bleacher Report, New York, in a new post, vice president for sales. He had been sales director for the East and Midwest at BBE, New York.

headline: Travel Deals: $10 JetBlue Flights
text: JetBlue is celebrating a decade of service by offering one-way tickets for $10. The sale is  available only on  flights originating in the United States on May 11 and 12. Book online today.
