headline: How Long Should BP Remain in Charge?
text: So far the oil and gas gushing from the well drilled nearly four miles into the seabed for BP has confounded all efforts by the company to put the genie back in its bottle. The list of options is expanding to “top hats” and “junk shots,” according to the Associated Press. [10:39 p.m. | Updated  You can submit alternative response proposals to BP and its team.]

headline: Greece Is the New France
text: So says Dave Weigel. And he’s right. Now, the complaint from the right about any effort to do anything about mass unemployment is that it’s turning America into Greece.

headline: Labor and N.A.A.C.P. Plan October Rally
text: Several labor unions and the N.A.A.C.P. are planning a rally in Washington this October to push for stepped-up job creation efforts and to counter what they say is a misguided perception that the Tea Party represents the views of America’s working people.

headline: U.S. Sees a Change of Attitude at Toyota
text: TOYOTA CITY, Japan — Toyota faced “very, very serious credibility problems” in the wake of its safety crisis, but changed its attitude toward American regulators after its president, Akio Toyoda, visited the United States, Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood said Monday.

headline: Chenoweth Fires Back at Newsweek for Criticizing Gay Actors in Straight Roles
text: Not that we have any beef with Kristin Chenoweth to begin with, but we’d think long and hard about picking a war of words with her after this. On Friday, Ms. Chenoweth, the Tony Award-winner and star of “Promises, Promises,” posted a lengthy online rebuttal to a Newsweek article that she called “horrendously homophobic” for contending that gay actors could not play straight characters, and citing her “Promises, Promises” co-star Sean Hayes as an example.

headline: Agonizing Wait for Oil Workers
text: The explosion on the Deepwater Horizon led to a night of terror for the men working on the rig, and it created a tense wait for their families. My colleague Ian Urbina and I reconstructed the events of that night in an article in Saturday’s paper.

headline:
Obama Picks
Kagan, Scholar
but Not Judge, for Court Seat
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama introduced Solicitor General Elena Kagan on Monday as his choice to become the nation’s 112th justice of the Supreme Court, hailing her as a “one of the nation’s foremost legal minds,” as he girded for a battle over whether it takes a judge to serve on the court.

headline: 'Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson'
text: An excerpt from the musical number "Rock Star." (Video courtesy of the Public Theater)

headline: Monday Reading: Fight Over Mental Health Insurance Rules
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Prosecutor in Nassau Looks Toward Albany
text: Kathleen M. Rice, the Nassau County district attorney, is one of a half-dozen or so Democrats vying for the nomination for New York attorney general.

headline: Your Television, Up Against the Wall
text: Wedged as it usually is between a wall and the back of a flat-panel television set, and normally invisible to a viewer’s naked eye, the wall-mounting hardware that’s installed in most homes isn’t a product consumers think about in terms of sexy or stylish.

headline: Early Surprises at Cannes, Man-Made and Otherwise
text: The Cannes Film Festival won’t officially open until Wednesday but the annual competition is already contending with a government boycott, more volcanic ash and — more manageable — the late entry of a new film.

headline: Goldman’s Very Good Quarter for Trading
text: Goldman Sachs‘s first-quarter earnings were overshadowed by the Securities and Exchange’s civil charges accusing the firm of fraud. But as Bloomberg News points out, there was plenty of good news in the report about Goldman’s trading business.

headline: When the Sandwich Is a Salad
text: When I’m preparing for a flight, I think about sandwiches. Since I’ve never seen a sandwich in an airport that I’d want to eat, I like to pack a lunch, something portable and easy. The problem: my homemade sandwiches used to get soggy.

headline: Sardine and Coleslaw Po’Boy
text: Aficionados will probably object to my calling this a po’boy, but the recipe is inspired by an oyster po’boy that L.A.-based chef Mark Peel makes with fried oysters and coleslaw. I’ll eat coleslaw just about any way it’s served. Here, the crunchy shredded cabbage in a creamy dressing is topped with canned sardines packed in olive oil, a great source of omega-3 fatty acids.

headline: Smoked Trout and Cucumber Sandwich in a Bun
text: I’ve always loved the combination of smoked trout and cucumber. I recently discovered canned smoked trout packed in oil at Trader Joe’s. It’s very nice fish, extremely moist. I also recommend smoked trout that’s packaged like smoked salmon (which you also can substitute for the trout, if it’s not available). Trout is another fish that supplies you with lots of omega-3 fatty acids.

headline: Spinach Salad, Roasted Red Pepper and Goat Cheese Bun
text: This looks like a lot of salad to squeeze between two hamburger buns — but persist. Once you wrap the sandwich, the salad will compress. It makes a beautiful and delicious lunch, and it keeps well. If you can find jarred sweet, thin-fleshed red piquillo peppers, use them. But regular roasted red peppers will suffice, too.

headline: Chicken or Sardine Sandwich With Black Beans and Avocado
text: This spicy sandwich is inspired by one often served in the city of Xalapa in the Mexican state of Veracruz. It’s called pambazo, which is also the name of the flaky roll it’s made with. The bread is spread with pureed black beans and traditionally filled with shredded chicken, chorizo or sardines (the sardine version is not easy to find today), as well as lettuce, tomato, avocado, onion and pickled chipotles. Since tomatoes aren’t yet in season, they’re optional here.

headline: Answers About Student Loans: Part 5
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: A Homecoming in a New Home
text: Tato Laviera may be a standard-bearer for Puerto Rican poetry and literature, but for most of this year he had no place to plant the flag — or hang his favorite Panama hat — after a medical emergency last December left him homeless.

headline: The Morning Line: Team Pletcher Targets Preakness
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

headline: Neck Injury Knocks Out Dudamel for a Night
text: The sound that Gustavo Dudamel heard on Thursday night while conducting the Los Angeles Philharmonic wasn’t necessarily the one he was hoping to make: during a performance of Dvorak’s Cello Concerto, Mr. Dudamel, who made his debut as the Philharmonic’s music director in October, injured his neck during Thursday’s performance but was back at the podium on Friday, The Los Angeles Times reported. Mr. Dudamel finished the concerto on Thursday but was replaced for the rest of the program by the associate conductor Lionel Bringuier. Deborah Borda, the president of the Philharmonic, told The Los Angeles Times that Mr. Dudamel had “heard a loud pop and lost sensation in parts of his body”; a medical consultation later showed that he had pulled a muscle in his neck area. After going home to rest Mr. Dudamel returned to conduct the same program on Friday. On Monday, he was scheduled to begin a national tour with the Philharmonic in San Francisco.

headline: The High Low | Mexican Friendship Bracelets, $50-160
text: What: Dezso by Sara Beltran Mexican BraceletsHow Much: $50–$160 at www.dezsosara.comWho: Melissa Ventosa Martin, T Magazine’s Women’s Fashion Market Director

headline: Remarks by Obama and Kagan
text: Following is a transcript of the remarks by President Obama and Solicitor General Elena Kagan on Monday, during which the president announces his nomination of Ms. Kagan to the Supreme Court, as released by the White House:

headline: Briton Convicted for ‘Menacing’ Tweet Against Robin Hood Airport
text: A British man who was arrested in January after joking on Twitter that he would blow Robin Hood Airport in Doncaster, England, “sky high” if his flight was delayed, was found guilty on Monday of the crime of sending a menacing message over a public telecommunications network.

headline: Perfect Timing
text: Sports needed Oakland’s Dallas Braden in the worst way. In fact, if he hadn’t stumbled along on his own, we might have had to make him up. But while Hollywood would have cast Kevin Costner as his manager and Betty White as his feisty grandmother, I’m not sure even screenwriters could have come up with the right details: his up-from-nowhere career, his setting up his climactic scene by popping off at the game’s premier prima donna a few weeks ago, his mom’s dying from skin cancer when he was in high school, his perfect game coming on Mother’s Day.

headline: Prisoners of the Superhero Movie
text: Chris Orr, who’s taken his movie reviewing from The New Republic to The Atlantic, has a question about “Iron Man 2″:

headline: A Pacifist Chaplain’s Soul-Searching Tour of War
text: Sheri Snively cautions her readers where they are headed on the first page.

headline: At the Summit
text: 9th May 2010, Madagascar

headline: Mark Webber Dominates Spanish Grand Prix
text: There’s no question that Red Bull Racing has had the fastest car in Formula One this year. But reliability is still a problem. In qualifying for the Spanish Grand Prix last weekend, the Red Bull cars of Mark Webber and Sebastian Vettel were by far the quickest on the grid.

headline: Tim McGraw and Faith Hill Plan Nashville Benefit Concert
text: Taylor Swift, Carrie Underwood and Miley Cyrus are among the country stars that Tim McGraw and Faith Hill have announced will perform at a benefit concert planned for June to aid victims of the recent flooding in the Nashville area. On Monday Mr. McGraw and Ms. Hill said in a news release that they would host the event, called “Nashville Rising: A Benefit Concert for Flood Recovery,” on June 22 at the Bridgestone Arena in Nashville. Other performers in the lineup include Brooks & Dunn, Lynyrd Skynyrd, Amy Grant, LeAnn Rimes, Miranda Lambert and Martina McBride. Jeff Fisher, the head coach of the Tennessee Titans, and Barry Trotz, the head coach of the Nashville Predators, are also scheduled as guests. Tickets will go on sale Friday at 10 a.m. Central time at ticketmaster.com and will range in price from $25 to $75. Proceeds from the event are to go to the Community Foundation of Middle Tennessee, a nonprofit group that provides philanthropic services.

headline: The Fine Print
text: In the 1979 movie “The Jerk,” Steve Martin plays a country idiot named Navin R. Johnson who has a paroxysm of joy when the telephone book is delivered with his name in it.

headline: A ‘Solar Map’ of New York City
text: Solar maps are all the rage these days.

headline: Here Comes the Recovery!
text: After spending the last six months on the road talking to hundreds of business owners around the country, I have come to a conclusion that might surprise you: the economic recovery is already well under way. And, if you don’t start putting a strategy in place to take advantage of it, you’re risking the future of your company.

headline: Risks: Birth Control Linked to Sexual Problems
text: Young women who rely on hormonal birth control like the pill are at significantly higher risk for sexual dysfunction than those who use nonhormonal methods, a German study suggests.

headline: Childhood: Overweight Children and Bullying
text: Schoolchildren are more likely to be bullied if they are overweight, and a new study suggests just how much more likely: 60 percent more, if they are obese (with a body mass index in the 95th percentile for children in their age group), and 13 percent more, if they are simply overweight (85th percentile or higher).

headline: TimesCast | May 10, 2010
text: Today, Obama nominates his solicitor general for the Supreme Court, markets on both sides of the Atlantic surge on the European debt deal, and American soldiers march in Moscow's Red Square.

headline: Patterns: Lighter Load for Nurses May Aid Patients
text: A state law in California requires hospitals to maintain certain minimal levels of nurses on duty. Now a study suggests that the requirement may be saving lives.

headline: Brown Says He’ll Resign to Help Labour
text: LONDON — Britain’s quest for a new government took a sudden turn on Monday when Prime Minister Gordon Brown announced that he would resign within months as Labour Party leader as part of a bid to lure the Liberal Democrats into rejecting the Conservatives and joining a rejuvenated Labour in a left-of-center governing coalition.

headline: The State Unveils a Cancer Map
text: ALBANY — New York unveiled what it billed as the nation’s first statewide cancer map, which became available on Monday at the State Department of Health Web site.

headline: Polls: Judicial Experience Matters
text: If the Senate confirms Elena Kagan to the Supreme Court, there will be three female justices on the court for the the first time, no Protestant justices on the court for the first time, and, for the first time in nearly four decades, a justice would join the court with no experience as a judge.

headline: The Claim: ‘White-Coat Hypertension’ Is Nothing to Worry About
text: THE FACTS

headline: Fat Finger Trades
text: Stock market term for unintended transactions caused by clumsy data entry.

headline: David Cromer to Direct Broadway Production of ‘Yank!’
text: The acclaimed director David Cromer (“Our Town,” “When the Rain Stops Falling”) has been enlisted to lead next season’s expected Broadway production of “Yank!,” a musical about two American servicemen who fall in love during World War II, the producers said on Monday.

headline: National Democrats Bow Out of Hawaii Race
text: Battles are under way in several Democratic primary contests around the country. But few are as intense – or symbolic – as the fight under way for a special election on May 22 in Hawaii’s First Congressional District.

headline: 'The Lady and Her Music'
text: David LeShay’s backstage photos from Lena Horne’s Broadway show.

headline: Backstage With Lena
text: Lena Horne, who died on Sunday at 92, won a special Tony Award in 1981 for her Broadway revue “Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music.”

headline: Vancouver Saves Series but Salo’s Prognosis Unknown
text: Don’t bury the Vancouver Canucks yet.

headline: Memories of a New York Dragstrip
text: For 15 years, from 1961 to 1976, a green light meant go at the Dover Drag Strip in Wingdale, N.Y., north of Brewster. For young racers like Al Baran, now a Connecticut financial adviser, Sunday was race day. In 1967, Mr. Baran built a Corvette-powered Model T using a pile of scrounged parts (including a ’49 Ford axle dragged out of a farmer’s field). He remembers low 12-second quarter miles at 111 m.p.h. in that long-gone car.

headline: Europe Moves Quickly to Carry Out Rescue Package
text: European officials took quick steps on Monday to tackle the widening sovereign debt crisis that has destabilized the Continent, The New York Times’s Jack Ewing and James Kanter report.

headline: A Day in the Life of a Groom
text: The New York Times published an article on Monday about traditional and alternative therapies for horses. The piece ties into the coming Preakness. I met the author of the story, Sarah Maslin Nir, during her visit to Fair Hill, which was part of her research for the article. I thought it would be a good segue to talk about the person who looks after our thoroughbreds on a day-to-day basis: the groom.

headline: Police Arrest Two Men in Shooting at Bronx Party
text: Two men have been charged with killing two teenagers who had been at a birthday party in the Bronx in the early-morning hours of Sunday.

headline: Why Bother With the Constitution?
text: It’s Supreme Court nomination time again, which means that it will soon be nomination hearing time, which means that Elena Kagan will soon be asked how she believes the Constitution should be interpreted. But just in time comes a new book — “The Living Constitution,” by David A. Strauss — that tells us not to bother about that question because, odd though it might seem, the Constitution does not play a central role in constitutional interpretation.

headline: 'The Kid'
text: Christopher Sieber and Lucas Steele in the number "Terry . . ." (Video courtesy of Jamie Buckner)

headline: Uruguay’s Visual Vanguard
text: Never mind the bikinis — the beach towns around Punta del Este, Uruguay, offer up a different kind of eye candy. A nascent art scene has sprung up all around the so-called St.-Tropez of South America, putting a more highbrow gloss on all the hedonism. The area’s latest endeavor is an oceanfront eco-retreat where guest rooms double as art installations.

headline: Video and Text of Statements by Brown and Clegg on Possible Coalition
text: In a dramatic move, British Prime Minister Gordon Brown announced on Monday that he intends to resign within months, but hopes to first try to broker “a progressive coalition government” on behalf of what he called the “progressive majority in Britain.”

headline: Numberplay: Order in the Ranks!
text: Last year on TierneyLab, we brought to you a puzzle involving a fictitious card trick carried out by President Obama on “The Daily Show” with Jon Stewart. Inspired by that scenario, a friend of mine named Mullah McCoy (think of him as an Irish cleric with a liking for Indian food) sent me a fictitious sequel that also involves an intriguing presidential trick done at “The Daily Show.”

headline: Menendez Urges Boycott of All-Star Game in Arizona
text: Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey and chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, is urging major league baseball players to boycott the 2011 All-Star game, which is scheduled to take place in Phoenix, to protest Arizona’s tough new immigration law.

headline: Campaign Offer Plenty of ‘Nothing’
text: The goal of a campaign that seeks to fight hunger is to make something of nothing.

headline: Rajaratnam’s Uphill Fight to Suppress Wiretaps
text: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBook’s White Collar Watch.

headline: On Our Radar: BP’s Lobbying Investment
text: BP’s Washington connections are scrutinized: the company spent $16 million lobbying Congress last year.

headline: Interpreting Traffic Signs and Mouse Grimaces
text: According to the mayor’s official Twitter feed, sometime today the city will receive its 100 millionth call to 311. Or maybe that landmark will occur online at http://www.nyc.gov/311, where New Yorkers can also file complaints or request information via the seven-year-old service on everything from “Interpreting Parking or Traffic Sign or Regulation” (8,421 calls in 2009) to “Lost Article in a Sidewalk Grating” (63 calls) to “Blocked Sidewalk or Street — Basketball Hoop or Personal Property” (2 calls). A full accounting of last year’s calls (pdf) offers a fairly accurate portrait of the things that annoy, interest or bedevil residents on a regular basis.

headline: Toomey Hits the Airwaves in Pennsylvania
text: Pat Toomey, who looks to be well on his way to capturing the Republican nomination for the Senate in Pennsylvania, is plugging himself as a job creator in his first television advertisement of the campaign.

headline: Killing of Journalist Inflames Iraqi Kurds
text: ERBIL, Iraq — Hundreds of university students tried to storm the local Parliament building here in the capital of the semiautonomous Kurdistan region on Monday during an angry protest against the recent abduction and killing of a Kurdish journalist.

headline: TimesCast: A New Supreme Court Choice
text: After a monthlong search, the president has chosen Solicitor General Elena Kagan to succeed Justice John Paul Stevens on the Supreme Court. Within minutes of the announcement, Republicans raised concerns about his pick, questioning Ms. Kagan’s judicial philosophy and lack of court experience.

headline: What Kagan Will Bring to the Court
text: President Obama, in introducing Solicitor General Elena Kagan as his nominee to succeed Justice John Paul Stevens on the Supreme Court, called her “one of the nation’s foremost legal minds.” Ms. Kagan was a White House official in the Clinton administration and has had a long academic career, most recently as dean of Harvard Law School. But she has never been a judge, an issue that will certainly be raised in her confirmation hearings.

headline: Obama’s Plan to Balance the Bench (Mets vs. Yankees)
text: Photographs by Doug Mills/The New York Times. Photo Illustration by The New York TimesThe first battle Elena Kagan, left, may have to fight is against Sonia Sotomayor  for New York’s baseball team.

headline: Take the Tomato 2 Stops to the Sunflower
text: The colors of the New York City subway map have been described as a rainbow. Turns out, they could also be described as a grove.

headline: ‘La Cage’ and ‘Fela!’ to Take Shows on the Road
text: 4:23 p.m. | Updated

headline: Frank Frazetta, Fantasy Illustrator, Dies at 82
text: 5:17 p.m. | Updated Frank Frazetta, an illustrator whose vivid colors and striking brushstrokes conjured up fantastic worlds of musclebound heroes fighting with broad swords and battle axes to defend helpless women from horrible beasts, died on Monday in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 82.

headline: Israel Will Join Economic Group of Developed Nations
text: JERUSALEM — The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a 31-country group often seen as an exclusive club of rich countries, voted unanimously on Monday to admit Israel.

headline: Regulators Vow to Find Way to Stop Rapid Dives
text: WASHINGTON — Federal financial regulators forged ahead on Monday to try to prevent a repeat of last week’s roller-coaster stock ride, though they had not determined the cause of the sudden, steep decline in prices on Thursday.

headline: Sympathy for Bob Bennett
text: Last week, National Review’s editors quoted my praise for Utah’s soon-to-be ex-senator, Bob Bennett, in the course of arguing that conservatives shouldn’t feel any regret over his Tea Party-abetted defeat. Since the case against Bennett emphasized his support for the bipartisan Wyden-Bennett health care bill, NR’s editorial focuses on that legislation’s drawbacks:

headline: Iran Sentences Newsweek Reporter in Absentia to 13 Years in Prison
text: A correspondent for Newsweek jailed in Iran for nearly four months last year before leaving the country has been sentenced in absentia by an Iranian court to an extended flogging and more than 13 years in prison for counterrevolutionary acts, the government there announced Monday.

headline: Are You a Fish Out of Water? Learning English Idioms
text: Overview | What do idioms and euphemisms tell us about our language and culture? What challenges do non-native English learners face as they try to master the English language? In this lesson, students consider the difficulties that English presents for the language learner. They then interview non-native English-language learners to learn about these struggles and to develop a deeper notion of their own linguistic challenges and how culture infuses language.

headline: Chrysler’s Chief Offers an Upbeat Assessment
text: DETROIT — Chrysler executives expect to increase the company’s profit forecast for the year and have a public stock offering “as quickly as we can,” chief executive, Sergio Marchionne, said Monday.

headline: Barbara Walters to Undergo Heart Surgery
text: Barbara Walters surprised her audience on “The View” Monday morning by saying that she would undergo surgery to replace what she called “a faulty heart valve” later this week.

headline: Zimbabwe Court Acquits Mugabe Opponent of Terrorism Charges
text: JOHANNESBURG — A High Court judge in Zimbabwe on Monday acquitted Roy Bennett — a leader of the party that has long opposed President Robert Mugabe but now governs the country with him — on charges of plotting to violently overthrow Mr. Mugabe, 86, who has been in office for three decades.

headline: The Morning Skate: Home Ice Advantage Melts in Stanley Cup Play
text: What has happened to home ice advantage in the Stanley Cup playoffs? So far this spring, home teams are 33-35.

headline: Separate Oversight for Offshore Safety?
text: As we reported over the weekend, the United States Minerals Management Service — the agency under the Department of Interior that presides over resource development — is under fire for what its critics say has been lax oversight of the oil industry.

headline: One Student’s Financial Aid Odyssey
text: Those families in the midst of the financial aid process — or those who will be embarking on it — should take a moment to click on an article about one high school senior’s journey on the Web site of The Chronicle of Higher Education.

headline: Titanic Awards is an Offline Book
text: Airline with the stingiest legroom? Qantas. Worst name for a car rental company? Rent-a-Bomb.  Those are among the winners in a new book that celebrates the worst of travel.

headline: Exchanges Agree in Principle on New Trading Rules
text: Federal regulators said Monday that the major stock exchanges had agreed in principle to a uniformed system that would allow for a controlled slowdown during volatile trading, The New York Times’s Graham Bowley and Edward Wyatt report.

headline: Zenyatta Is a Dodger
text: It’s official: Zenyatta is a crossover sports star. In fact, she’s a home-run horse. The undefeated mare is the newest Los Angelean to be featured in the “This Is My Town” marketing campaign for the Los Angeles Dodgers.

headline: Moody’s Stock Still Pressured by S.E.C. Inquiry Disclosure
text: Shares in the Moody’s Corporation remained down on Monday after the firm disclosed late on Friday that it received notice of a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation over its credit-rating policies.

headline: Quote Unquote | Purple Prose
text: – Olivier Zahm of Purple Magazine explains his business etiquette to New York magazine. Note to self: do not have meetings with Olivier Zahm.

headline: Schumer Urges Broad Use of Circuit Breakers
text: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, wants all the markets to use circuit breakers to prevent a repeat of last week’s wild trading in which the Dow Jones industrial average fell hundreds of points in minutes.

headline: The Calculus of Upgrades
text: Accumulating frequent-flier miles used to be relatively straightforward. You could add to your miles by flying or through a credit card affiliated with an airline. Pretty soon, you had enough miles to get free tickets or upgrades to business class, or even first class.

headline: Super Saver Looks Good, but May Face a Crowd
text: The Kentucky Derby champ Super Saver pleased his jockey and trainer on Monday morning at Churchill Downs with a three-furlong blowout in a crisp 36.60 seconds. As good as he looked, however, the colt is hardly scaring the competition away from the 135th running of the Preakness Stakes.

headline: State Workers Rally Against Furloughs
text: ALBANY — About 2,000 state employees staged a raucous and angry rally outside the State Capitol on Monday to protest Gov. David A. Paterson’s plan to furlough most of the state work force for one day next week.

headline: G.M. Aims for Zero Waste at Half of Its Plants
text: General Motors said last week that 62 of its manufacturing plants (representing 43 percent of its global production) no longer send any production waste to landfills. The company’s goal, first stated in 2008, is for zero waste at half of its operations by the end of 2010, and it’s 87 percent of the way there.

headline: He Stops for Red Lights: Bicycle Safety in the City
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama Nominates Kagan for Supreme Court
text: After a monthlong search, the president has chosen Elena Kagan, his solicitor general and a former dean of Harvard Law School, to succeed the retiring Justice John Paul Stevens.

headline: School to Parents: Volunteer, or Else!
text: Students are not the only ones at Adelante Dual Language Academy in San Jose who are graded on their classroom participation. Parents are, too.

headline: Memorial Tonight for Jarvis, Mets Organist
text: Jane Jarvis’s career in music — as the organist for Mets games at Shea Stadium from 1964 to 1979, a nightclub jazz pianist and a programmer for Muzak — will be recalled tonight at 7 p.m. at a memorial service in Manhattan at St. Peter’s Church at Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. St. Peter’s is renowned for its jazz ministry.

headline: After S.E.C. Suit Warning, Traders Flee Moody’s Shares
text: Shares of Moody’s fell sharply on Monday after it disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission had warned that it might sue the firm for making “false and misleading” statements as part of its application as a ratings organization.

headline: Cherry Jones and Doug Hughes Reunite at Roundabout
text: The actress Cherry Jones and director Doug Hughes, who both won Tony Awards in 2005 for the Broadway production of “Doubt,” will reunite for the first time this fall for Roundabout Theater Company’s revival of Shaw’s “Mrs. Warren’s Profession,” the theater announced on Tuesday.

headline: What to Do When a Newborn Can’t Hear
text: The 8-year-old boy already had hearing aids when I met him, back in the 1990s. He had been born before newborns were routinely screened for hearing problems, so the diagnosis had not taken place until he was a slow-to-talk toddler.

headline: Payment Offers to Egg Donors Prompt Scrutiny
text: As an undergraduate at the University of Washington in the late 1990s, Wendie Wilson noticed some striking ads in the campus newspaper: appeals to young women to sell their eggs for what seemed to her exorbitant sums of money. But she had no idea what was involved until she herself decided to go through the process a few years later.

headline: ‘Fences’ Breaks Box Office Record
text: Fresh off earning the most Tony Award nominations ever for a play revival, the new Broadway production of August Wilson’s “Fences” broke the box office record last week at the Cort Theater, earning $1,008,104 for eight performances and becoming the rare play to join the million-dollar club of Broadway commercial hits.

headline: Manhattan Federal Court, 11:23 A.M.
text: Six days after his arrest, Faisal Shahzad has yet to be taken to a courtroom and charged before a judge in the failed Times Square car bombing. So the reporters and photographers camped outside the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan had to content themselves with a lone marshal.

headline: Win a Piece of a Convicted Ponzi Schemer’s Spoils
text: If you have a yearning for high-powered sports cars — say, a 2008 Bugatti Veyron (right) or a Ferrari F430 Spyder — consider booking a ticket to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for early June.

headline: Never Able to Forget a Chronic Disease
text: I hate blood drives. But I didn’t always. As recently as last year, I was excited to learn that my office was holding one, in partnership with the Red Cross. Donors went around the office wearing little white stickers declaring they had given “the gift of life.” The gift of life! That’s much better than a gift of canned food, or old clothes. I definitely wanted to be a Life Giver.

headline: A Fed President for a Bank Tax
text: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis — Narayana R. Kocherlakota — came out in favor of a bank tax today:

headline: Back in Magazines, With Stars
text: When Magnus Greaves founded Doubledown Media, which published magazines like Trader Monthly, in 2004, the intersection of Wall Street and luxury advertising seemed like a can’t-miss proposition. Then they both simultaneously imploded, and Doubledown closed last year. But Mr. Greaves decided he was not yet done with the magazine game.

headline: The Temptation (and Danger) of Past Investment Performance
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner and the founder of Clearwater Asset Management. He answered questions from Bucks readers in November.

headline: Photo Mix-up With Obama Is Called Hoax
text: “Obama touts wind energy in Iowa,” a headline read on The Washington Post’s Web site in late April. But if a reader’s screen grab is to be believed, the headline ran with a photo not of the president but of Malcolm X. And in an age when any mistake is possible grist for a public flogging, this was a catchy gotcha.

headline: Sharp Turn for Miley Cyrus
text: When Miley Cyrus, 17, released her new music video last week, chatter about her attire (fetish gear), suggestive dance moves (writhing on her back) and setting (inside a black bird cage) spread like wildfire.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Siberia and Elsewhere
text: Rescuers found the bodies on Monday morning of 17 of their colleagues who were killed while trying to reach trapped coal miners in western Siberia, bringing the death toll in the disaster to 30, with 60 still missing, Ellen Barry reports from Moscow. Officials had suspended rescue operations for nearly a day after two explosions sealed the miners in caverns filling with water and smoke, saying they could not try to save the men until methane gas had dropped to safe levels. The agonizing wait marred Russia’s celebration of Victory Day (“For Russians, an Old Victory Lives On,” on Lens), which brought millions of Russians onto the streets for lavish parades and fireworks displays.

headline: Off the Menu: Le Pain Quotidien in Central Park
text: When Le Pain Quotidien won the contract to operate the Mineral Springs Pavilion near the Sheep Meadow in Central Park — which it plans to open on Saturday — there were complaints that it was a “chain.” But while the company of sandwiches, soups, snacks and sweets, based in Brussels, has more 140 locations worldwide, it’s not the average chain. The owner, Alain Coumont, has followed a vision of making his places green and using organic ingredients as much as possible. (Here is the menu.)

headline: Dustin Keller’s Hot Dog Tour in Manhattan
text: Jets tight end Dustin Keller, who is a budding restaurateur, will write a food column once a month for the Fifth Down.

headline: Bank Agrees to Forfeit $500 Million to U.S.
text: The Justice Department said Monday that the Dutch bank ABN Amro, which is now part of the Royal Bank of Scotland, had agreed to forfeit $500 million for helping move illegal funds through the American financial system, The Associated Press reports.

headline: City Selects 50 Senior Centers to Close
text: In Manhattan, the number is 16.

headline: A New Look for Google Mobile
text: You may have noticed a change in Google online, the addition of a column on the left side that lets you narrow your results to just images, videos, blogs, shopping and other categories. That change has come to Google mobile as well, although it is concealed.

headline: Second Thoughts?
text: Yes, I know — the point is not to lift the euro. Still, the exchange rate is a quick measure of the impact on eurozone confidence, which bounced with the policy announcement but doesn’t seem to be staying up …

headline: Vande Velde Crashes Out of Giro d’Italia
text: Christian Vande Velde of the Garmin-Transitions team broke his right collarbone in a crash during Stage 3 of the Giro d’Italia on Monday, making it two years in a row that he has dropped out of the race with a serious injury. Both times, he injured himself on the third day of competition.

headline: A Phrase for Safety After 9/11 Goes Global
text: The Times Square street vendors who alerted the police to a smoking Nissan Pathfinder on May 1 seemed to be acting on a combination of their streetwise instincts, their sense of civic duty, their military training and the advice of Allen Kay.

headline: Short? No Worries: Just Ask This Texan
text: People of normal height or taller might be inclined to assume, as that silly Randy Newman song put it, that “Short people got no reason to live.... Short people got nobody to love.”

headline: Boldness Comes With Manifesto
text: For proof that abstract painting can be as controversial as any other kind, look no further than Amy Sillman’s latest show at Sikkema Jenkins. Art blogs and other online forums are filled with both praise and jeers for Ms. Sillman, and while admirers outnumber detractors, the collective intensity is worth noting.

headline: Tall Tales About Being Short
text: In Tuesday’s Personal Health column, Jane Brody writes about life as a short person, and the many wrong assumptions made about people of below-average height.

headline: A New Twist on Pretzels
text: Around here, it seems like every day is National Pretzel Day. New Yorkers used to have two basic choices: a pigeon-worthy pedestrian softy from a Sabrett-umbrellaed cart or City Bakery’s haute pretzel croissant. Some housemade strays turned up here and there — one in the breadbasket at Commerce, another at Kurt Gutenbrunner’s Blaue Gans and, naturally, the expected Biergarten regulation. A few months ago, though, there was an explosion of artisanal twists and braids. Now, the salty risers tempt at every turn and are being incorporated into both sweet and savory culinary compositions.

headline: A Pianist Fills in, Saving the Day
text: The Peoples’ Symphony Concerts series was to have closed its season on Sunday afternoon with a recital at Town Hall by Ingrid Fliter, the Argentine pianist who won the Gilmore Artist Award in 2006. But when Ms. Fliter, down with the flu, bowed out of the engagement on Saturday evening, the Irving S. Gilmore International Keyboard Festival in Kalamazoo, Mich., offered a substitute: Kirill Gerstein, this year’s winner of the $300,000 quadrennial prize, who was in Kalamazoo to perform at the festival, and planned to fly to Europe on Sunday. With a slight juggling of his travel plans, Mr. Gerstein, a naturalized American who was born in Russia, performed instead of Ms. Fliter.

headline: 'Memphis'
text: Chad Kimball and cast members sing "Memphis Lives in Me." (Video courtesy of the production)

headline: Should Egg Donors Be Paid?
text: Demand for human ova has been growing in recent years, fueled by infertility treatments and increased investment in stem cell research, reports David Tuller in Tuesday’s Science Times.

headline: Correction
text: The cover article on May 2 about Cartagena, Colombia, referred incorrectly to the writer Gabriel García Márquez, whose fiction has been inspired by the city. As is customary in Latin America and in Spain, where a person carries both the paternal surname and maternal maiden name, the writer is Mr. García Márquez, not Mr. Márquez.

headline: U.S. World Cup Roster to Be Announced Tuesday
text: Tuesday, 10:22 a.m. ET |Capello Drafts Carragher

headline: Following Up on a Baby’s Hearing Test
text: In Tuesday’s 18 and Under column, Dr. Perri Klass, a pediatrician, reports on the problem of babies who get screened for hearing problems without proper follow-up.

headline: New Spending for a Wider Range of Sex Education
text: In a sharp departure from the abstinence-only message of the Bush years, the new health law pours hundreds of millions of dollars into sex education programs that aim to provide teenagers with comprehensive information about protecting themselves from pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases.

headline: Embracing Stravinsky’s Wild Side
text: Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring,” almost a century old, clearly has a tale to tell. It is suggested in the title. It is made explicit in the original dance scenario of 1913, which details a series of pagan rituals surrounding a human sacrifice. And it is borne out in the eruptive nature of the music, with hushed passages of exotic colorations and expectant mystery repeatedly cast aside by brutal, pounding rhythms or savage, brassy whoops.

headline: Europe’s Debt Crisis: Your Questions Answered
text: 7:29 p.m. | Updated

headline: ‘Yank!’ Announces a Change in Direction
text: The director David Cromer (“Our Town,” “When the Rain Stops Falling”) has been enlisted to lead next season’s expected Broadway production of “Yank!,” a musical about two American servicemen who fall in love during World War II, the producers said on Monday. Mr. Cromer will replace Igor Goldin, who has been with “Yank!” since its inception at the New York Musical Theater Festival in 2005 and who directed the Off Broadway production of the show this winter. But as theater directors go Mr. Cromer comes with star power, which will probably help the producers raise the $5 million they estimate as the cost of mounting the musical on Broadway. A spokesman for “Yank!” did not immediately respond to an inquiry about why Mr. Goldin was being replaced.

headline: Kristin Chenoweth Has Some Words for Newsweek
text: Not that we have any beef with Kristin Chenoweth, left, to begin with, but we’d think long and hard about picking a war of words with her after this. On Friday Ms. Chenoweth, the Tony Award-winner and star of “Promises, Promises,” posted a lengthy online rebuttal to a Newsweek article that she called “horrendously homophobic” for contending that gay actors could not play straight characters and citing her “Promises, Promises” co-star Sean Hayes as an example. In the original Newsweek article, published online in April, Ramin Setoodeh, a Newsweek contributor, wrote: “While it’s OK for straight actors to play gay (as Jake Gyllenhaal and Heath Ledger did in ‘Brokeback Mountain’), it’s rare for someone to pull off the trick in reverse.” Of Mr. Hayes’s performance in “Promises, Promises,” Mr. Setoodeh wrote: “Frankly, it’s weird seeing Hayes play straight. He comes off as wooden and insincere, like he’s trying to hide something, which of course he is.” In her response, published on Newsweek.com, Ms. Chenoweth wrote: “This article offends me because I am a human being, a woman and a Christian. For example, there was a time when Jewish actors had to change their names because anti-Semites thought no Jew could convincingly play Gentile.” She added: “Audiences aren’t giving a darn about who a person is sleeping with or his personal life. Give me a break! We’re actors first, whether we’re playing prostitutes, baseball players, or the Lion King.” About her co-star, Ms. Chenoweth said, “I’d put Hayes and his brilliance up there with some of the greatest actors period.”

headline: CBS Tops Sunday
text: “Jesse Stone: No Remorse,” the sixth in a long-running series of made-for-television movies on CBS, delivered the largest audience in prime time on Sunday as the two-hour Tom Selleck movie attracted 11.4 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS led the night over all in the ratings, garnering 10.9 million viewers at 7 p.m. for “60 Minutes” and 10.6 million at 8 for the season finale of “The Amazing Race.” ABC finished in second with the combination of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” at 8 (7.6 million), “Desperate Housewives” at 9 (11.2 million) and “Brothers & Sisters” at 10 (8.3 million). NBC was third with “Dateline” (3.6 million) and “Minute to Win It” (5.1 million), followed by a two-hour installment of “The Celebrity Apprentice” (7.3 million), while Fox ranked fourth with its comedy lineup. Over the weekend, NBC’s episode of “Saturday Night Live,” featuring the actress Betty White as host, attracted the sketch comedy show’s most viewers in a year and a half, according to preliminary ratings estimates.

headline: Tony-Winning Tandem Take on ‘Mrs. Warren’
text: The actress Cherry Jones and the director Doug Hughes, who both won Tony Awards in 2005 for the Broadway production of “Doubt,” will reunite this fall for the first time for the Roundabout Theater Company’s revival of Shaw’s “Mrs. Warren’s Profession,” the theater said. Ms. Jones, right, will star as Mrs. Kitty Warren, a mother who turns to the world’s oldest profession to pull herself out of poverty and support her daughter Vivie, whose reactions to her mother’s choices lead to many Shavian flourishes. It will be Ms. Jones’s first role on Broadway since the play “Faith Healer,” which closed in August 2006. No other casting was announced on Monday, but Mr. Hughes was named director. The production is scheduled to begin preview performances on Sept. 3 at the American Airlines Theater. In addition, the Roundabout said that the Academy Award-winning actress Olympia Dukakis (“Moonstruck”) would star in Tennessee Williams’s play “The Milk Train Doesn’t Stop Here Anymore,” to be directed by Michael Wilson (“The Orphans’ Home Cycle”). Previews are scheduled to begin Off Broadway in January at the Roundabout’s Laura Pels Theater.

headline: The Science of a Happy Marriage
text: Why do some men and women cheat on their partners while others resist the temptation?

headline: Walters to Undergo Heart-Valve Surgery
text: Barbara Walters surprised her audience on “The View” on Monday morning by saying she would undergo surgery later this week to replace what she called “a faulty heart valve.” Ms. Walters, who is 80, said she had always enjoyed excellent health but had been aware of this condition for some time and decided that the summer would be a good time to recuperate. The office of her personal publicist, Cindi Berger, later said that Ms. Walters would make no further comment about the condition and would give no interviews about it  even to her longtime employer, ABC News.

headline: Benefit Concert Planned For Nashville
text: Taylor Swift, Carrie Underwood and Miley Cyrus are among the country stars who Tim McGraw and Faith Hill have announced will perform at a benefit concert planned for June to aid victims of the recent flooding in the Nashville area. On Monday, Mr. McGraw and Ms. Hill said in a news release that they would host the event, called “Nashville Rising: A Benefit Concert for Flood Recovery,” on June 22 at the Bridgestone Arena in Nashville. Other performers in the lineup include Brooks & Dunn, Lynyrd Skynyrd, Amy Grant, LeAnn Rimes, Miranda Lambert and Martina McBride. Tickets will go on sale Friday at 10 a.m. Central time at ticketmaster.com and will range in price from $25 to $75. Proceeds from the event are to go to the Community Foundation of Middle Tennessee, a nonprofit group that provides philanthropic services.

headline: At Cannes, Controversy Makes Early Entrance
text: The Cannes Film Festival won’t officially open until Wednesday, but the annual competition is already contending with a government boycott and  more manageable  the late entry of a new film. Sandro Bondi, the Italian culture minister, said he would not attend the festival because it is showing a film on the 2009 earthquake in L’Aquila that he considers propaganda, Agence France-Presse reported. In the film, “Draquila: Italy Trembles,” which is being shown out of competition, the satirist Sabina Guzzanti impersonates Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian prime minister, and criticizes the government’s takeover of reconstruction projects in L’Aquila. Declining an invitation to Cannes, Mr. Bondi expressed regret and his concern over the film, which he said “insults the truth and the Italian people.” Meanwhile, The Guardian reported that “Route Irish,” a new film by Ken Loach, had been added to the competition’s lineup. Mr. Loach, whose movie is about two rival ex-soldiers who become private contractors in Iraq, won the Palme d’Or in 2006 for his film “The Wind That Shakes the Barley.”

headline: Britain Leaves Its Monetary Policy Unchanged Amid Political Uncertainty
text: LONDON — The Bank of England decided Monday to hold steady on monetary policy after last week’s election failed to give any party a governing majority and the recent turmoil in European markets remained a fresh memory.

headline: Brittney, Brittny and Brittneigh on What’s in a Name
text: “I have a major gripe with the trend of misspelling baby names. On purpose,” wrote Paul Schmidtberger in this week’s Complaint Box.

headline: Warm and Fuzzy Department | Tending the Fashion Flock
text: With cheap cashmere so ubiquitous even dogs are wearing it, whither the lowly sheep? Ranchers of the gentle creatures, whether for milk or for meat, can hardly give their wool away after their seasonal shearings. Wool is literally now considered a waste product in much of Britain. Perhaps what the hearty fiber needs is a pedigree, some T.L.C., a bit of pizazz and maybe a supermodel.

headline: A Storyteller Back at Her Craft
text: Three years ago the country-folk singer-songwriter Mary Chapin Carpenter was lying on an emergency room gurney, terrified by a sharp pain in her chest that was so bad that she had cut short a tour to return home to her farm near Charlottesville, Va.

headline: Mapping Ancient Civilization, in a Matter of Days
text: For a quarter of a century, two archaeologists and their team slogged through wild tropical vegetation to investigate and map the remains of one of the largest Maya cities, in Central America. Slow, sweaty hacking with machetes seemed to be the only way to discover the breadth of an ancient urban landscape now hidden beneath a dense forest canopy.

headline: Tehran Students Protest Ahmadinejad Visit
text: As my colleague Nazila Fathi explains, a surprise visit to the campus of Shahid Beheshti University in Tehran on Monday by Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, reportedly set off a protest by students. Jaras, an opposition Web site, posted a report with what it said was a slide show of photographs from the campus.

headline: Where Was the Mayor? On the Phone
text: Where was Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg when the ferry hit the dock?

headline: Casting News for ‘In the Heights’ and ‘Race’
text: Productions of the Tony Award-winning musical “In the Heights” are getting new stars. The Broadway production will add Jordin Sparks, the 2007 winner of the “American Idol” television competition, in the role of Nina Rosario from Aug. 19 through Nov. 14. And Lin-Manuel Miranda, the creator and original star of the Broadway production, will reprise his performance as Usnavi in the Los Angeles premiere of the musical at the Pantages Theater, scheduled to run from June 22 to July 11.

headline: Producing a Grandchild Before Grandma Dies
text: The dialogue in Ben Andron’s play “White’s Lies,” which opened on Thursday at New World Stages, is peppered with mentions of familiar titles like “Cheers,” “Mr. Belvedere,” “Alf,” “Punky Brewster,” “Growing Pains” and “Newhart,” suggesting a frame of reference rooted entirely in sitcom.

headline: Envisioning the Stark Expo
text: Aaron McBride, the art director for "Iron Man 2" at Industrial Light & Magic, discusses the designs behind the Stark Expo that appears in the film.

headline: Life and Death and Life in Iraq
text: This is a soldier’s story, a tale of life and of death and of life’s return.

headline: Tracing the Scourge of AIDS in Deadly and Banal Ways
text: In one of many epistolary interludes in “Letters to the End of the World,” the protagonist describes holding death in his arms in the form of an H.I.V.-infected Zambian infant’s ravaged body. The vivid horror of that image lingers even if the reams of talk surrounding it in Anton Dudley’s mannered play are considerably less evocative.

headline: Scientists Unite Against Climate Skeptics
text: Tuesday, May 11, 11:15 a.m. | Updated  The latest issue of Science carries a letter that calls recent political attacks on the work of climate scientists “McCarthy-like threats of criminal prosecution.”

headline: For Crime, Is Anatomy Destiny?
text: Poverty, greed, anger, jealousy, pride, revenge. These are the usual suspects when it comes to discussing the causes of crime. In recent years, however, economists have started to investigate a different explanation for criminal activity: physical attributes.

headline: Focus Turns to Well-Blocking System
text: HOUSTON — At 53 feet tall and 325 tons, the blowout preventer that occupies center stage in the worst American oil spill in two decades is a huge stack of equipment. But it is also a jumble of contradictions.

headline: The Sexual Revolution Dissected
text: This remarkably tedious new novel by Martin Amis is a sort of messy improvisation on Boccaccio’s 14th-century collection of tales known as “The Decameron,” which concerned a group of young people spending an interlude together in an Italian villa and explored the varieties and disappointments of love. Jane Smiley tried something similar in her tiresome 2007 novel, “Ten Days in the Hills,” and in “The Pregnant Widow,” Mr. Amis makes many of the same mistakes she did — most notably, assuming that readers will be interested in a bunch of spoiled, self-absorbed twits, who natter on endlessly about their desires and resentments and body parts.

headline: Absent a Moon or Mars, Recreating Space 65 Feet Under the Sea
text: Astronauts will not be sent by the United States to the Moon or Mars for at least a decade, but they can still get an idea of what it would be like by living 65 feet underwater.

headline: Union and City Extend Deal on Teacher Assistants
text: The city’s teachers’ union and the Education Department have extended their deal to permit the use of classroom aides whose salaries are paid by parent groups.

headline: A Diphtheria Cure, 1894
text: Until the late 19th century, diphtheria was a gruesome killer with no known cause and many ineffective treatments. In 1874, The New-York Times printed an advertisement for a medicine that would cure not only diphtheria, but also corns, bunions and “pains in the loins and back.” The same year, a news article began, “There has been spreading for some time an idea or hypothesis among the more philosophic medical men, and among the thoughtful ‘laity,’ that many species of disease have their sources in, and are scattered by, seeds or germs.”

headline: Kagan Constructs, for Now
text: When President Obama officially named Elena Kagan, the solicitor general, as his choice for a Supreme Court vacancy earlier on Monday, many of the themes that opponents and supporters will draw out in the coming weeks had already become palpable and were amply researched during the weeks that she’d been a frontrunner to replace Justice John Paul Stevens.

headline: China: A New Market Economy and Old Stigmas Lead to an Increase in Cases of Syphilis
text: Syphilis, which was nearly eliminated from China under Maoist rule, is now the most commonly reported communicable disease in the country’s largest city, Shanghai, according to an article in The New England Journal of Medicine last week.

headline: Gum Ads That Seek Longer-Lasting Chewers
text: IN a memorable scene in “Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory,” the 1971 film, Gene Wilder, who plays an eccentric confectioner, displays a piece of gum that changes flavor while being chewed, replicating a three-course meal by tasting first like tomato soup, then roast beef, then blueberry pie.

headline: In Boston, Balanchine Without the Frills
text: BOSTON — This season, after many years of performing at the Wang Center here, the Boston Ballet moved to the Opera House. The Wang, which seats 3,600 people, has always been a barn too large for most dance programs. The Opera House — which, seating 2,600, is still larger than almost any European opera house — has been through a checkered history since it opened as a vaudeville theater in 1928; last year it reopened after being dark for more than 10 years.

headline: Just Like Other Dads (Well, Almost)
text: Vibrators, leather bars and good old-fashioned sodomy have never looked more wholesome than they do in “The Kid,” the easygoing, sentimental new musical about a gay couple trying to adopt a baby. The homosexual partners at the center of this surprisingly unsurprising production, which opened Monday night on Theater Row, feel like truly ordinary people, folks you’ve met many times before in depictions of American spouses in pursuit of parenthood.

headline: In Dvorak’s Folk Works, Elegance, Too
text: Dvorak is the latest composer to seize the collective attention of the Emerson String Quartet, that brightest of stars in the American chamber music firmament. “Old World — New World,” the newest in the ensemble’s long string of distinguished recordings for Deutsche Grammophon, focuses on that Bohemian composer’s late string quartets, along with his “American” String Quintet and “Cypresses,” a quaint, charming early cycle. Most of these pieces are included in the group’s latest Lincoln Center residency, which opened on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall.

headline: Icahn and Lions Gate Duel Over Shareholders
text: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn and Lions Gate Entertainment skirmished once again on Monday before a special shareholders meeting that may or may not be moot.

headline: Pairings: White Sangria and Red Sangria
text: Cavas, often blessed with notes of citrus and spring blossoms, are genial sparkling wines, all the more so because of their modest prices. They can be called on for many occasions, and are the ideal finishing touch for sangria, either red or white. The white sangria is unusual and strong, though white wine in place of manzanilla sherry will moderate the alcohol. The red is clearly classic. Both are more refreshing than sweet.

headline: Cava, the Prosecco of Spain, Gets Its Due — at Last
text: YEARS ago I was a regular cava drinker. I couldn’t help it; cava was the cheapest sparkling wine around. Our graduate-student parties and celebrations seemed incomplete without numerous bottles of Freixenet Cordon Negro Brut scattered about the room, reflections of dancing candlelight absorbed by the black matte finish of the bottles.

headline: Company With Osteoporosis Treatment Wins the ‘Super Bowl’
text: The McCombs School of Business at the University of Texas, Austin, held its Global Moot Corp business plan competition over the weekend. Billing itself as the Super Bowl of business plan competitions, Moot Corp invites top teams from previous, qualifying competitions to compete for a grand prize of $25,000 cash and $70,000 of in-kind services. It began in 1984 and was the first competition of its kind.

headline: Art in the Rubble
text: Images of art works damaged during the earthquake in Haiti.

headline: Rescuing Art From the Rubble of the Quake
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Susan Blakney, a paintings conservator from New York, scrambled up a mound of rubble left by the collapse of the Episcopal Holy Trinity Cathedral here, searching for small shards of the cathedral’s murals.

headline: Judge Denies Polanski Request to Unseal Testimony
text: LOS ANGELES—Roman Polanski’s legal options narrowed, as a judge here denied his request to unseal testimony about a sentencing plan in his 33-year-old sex case. Lawyers for Mr. Polanski had hoped to use the testimony, by a retired prosecutor, Roger Gunson, to fight his extradition by authorities in Switzerland. Mr. Gunson’s conditional testimony was taken earlier this year, so that it could be used if he were not available to testify in a sentencing hearing, should Mr. Polanski be returned to the United States. In denying the request, Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Peter Espinoza said of the Swiss: “I’m satisfied that they have information that they need.” Mr. Polanski fled the United States in 1978, on the eve of his sentencing for having unlawful sex with a 13-year-old girl. His lawyers have argued that Judge Laurence J. Rittenband, who is now deceased, improperly used Mr. Polanski’s psychiatric evaluation in a California prison as his punishment, and that Mr. Gunson’s testimony, if provided to the Swiss, would show that Mr. Polanski does not qualify for extradition under a treaty between Switzerland and the United States.

headline: Twitter Software Bug Exploits Users’ Follower Count
text: If you have ever wanted Oprah Winfrey to follow you on Twitter, you might have been able to make that possible early Monday morning, when a software bug surfaced on Twitter’s Web site.

headline: Stephen Rosenfeld, Retired Columnist, Dies at 77
text: Stephen S. Rosenfeld, a retired columnist and editorial page editor of The Washington Post who wrote for many years on foreign affairs, died on Sunday in Springfield, Va. He was 77 and lived in Alexandria, Va.

headline: Toreador Works With Hess to Explore Paris Basin
text: Toreador Resources of France and the Hess Corporation said on Monday that they had agreed to form a joint venture to explore and develop Toreador’s 1 million gross acres in France’s Paris Basin, a potentially big resource of shale oil.

headline: BofA Merrill Hires 2 Clean Tech Bankers
text: Bank of America Merrill Lynch said on Monday that it had hired two executives from Deutsche Bank for its clean technology investment banking team.

headline: Tigers Salute Ernie Harwell
text: DETROIT — Comerica Park fell silent before the game as the Tigers paid tribute to their beloved broadcaster, Ernie Harwell, who called Detroit games for 42 years and died last Tuesday at 92.

headline: Bob Mercer, Executive Who Signed the Sex Pistols, Dies at 65
text: Bob Mercer, a music executive who signed the Sex Pistols, helped Jimmy Buffett set up his own record company and oversaw the popular compilation series “Now That’s What I Call Music!,” died on May 5 in Los Angeles, where he lived. He was 65.

headline: New York Legislature Approves 1-Day Furloughs
text: ALBANY — The Legislature approved an emergency budget bill on Monday that would authorize Gov. David A. Paterson to furlough about 100,000 state employees, roughly half the state’s work force, without pay for one day.

headline: Specter Ad Will Feature Obama
text: PHILADELPHIA – President Obama is about to be thrust firmly behind Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, the Republican-turned Democrat who is facing a very tough challenge for the Democratic nomination here in a primary next Tuesday. Mr. Specter announced tonight that he will begin airing an advertisement tomorrow that features a testimonial from the president.

headline: What We’re Reading: Android vs. Apple
text: The tech editors and reporters of The New York Times thought these articles merited a wider audience:

headline: Injured Woods May Miss U.S. Open
text: Tiger Woods insisted Monday that there was no connection between the neck injury that prompted him to withdraw from the Players Championship on Sunday and the injuries he sustained in the car accident in November that unraveled his image. He also called his schedule “up in the air” and said he did not know if he would be able to play in the United States Open in June.

headline: A Vista of War and Peace at a Lebanese Crossroads
text: WAZZANI, Lebanon — The rocky green hills on the outskirts of this southern town form one of the most volatile borders in the world. Tensions have been particularly high ever since Israel accused Hezbollah of obtaining Scud missiles from Syria last month, and many Lebanese say they believe it will not be long before war breaks out here again.

headline: Virginia Coach Says Playing Will Help
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — The Virginia women’s lacrosse coach, Julie Myers, spoke Monday for the first time about the death of Yeardley Love , saying that winning Sunday’s first-round N.C.A.A. tournament game against Towson, would greatly benefit the team as it goes through a slow, painful healing process.

headline: Financial Crisis Tests Germany’s Ability to Lead
text: BERLIN — At a defining moment for the European Union, its largest country, Germany, appeared divided and its leader absent, raising significant concerns about what kind of leadership Chancellor Angela Merkel can offer as the region tries to stabilize financial markets and shore up its common currency.

headline: Finland’s 100,000-Year Plan to Banish Its Nuclear Waste
text: It is, in the words of the Danish filmmaker Michael Madsen, “a place we must remember to forget.”

headline: Israel: 2 Israeli Arab Activists Arrested
text: Two Israeli Arab activists have been arrested and charged with spying and making contact with Hezbollah of Lebanon. The men, Ameer Makhoul, 52, director of a charity, and Omar Said, 50, active in the political party Balad, were detained over the past couple of weeks but the military censor forbade reporting on the arrests until Monday. Lawyers for the men said that Israeli espionage laws were overly broad and that e-mail messages and telephone conversations with anyone in Lebanon were seen as cause for arrest.

headline: Turkey: Opposition Leader Resigns
text: Deniz Baykal, the longstanding leader of the main opposition party, resigned Monday after an Internet video appeared to show him in a bedroom with a female lawmaker from his party. Mr. Baykal, 71, left, leader of the secular Republican People’s Party, neither denied nor acknowledged having an affair but called the distribution of the video “a conspiracy.” He said the recording had been obtained illegally by an intrusion on private property, and was distributed with the consent of the governing Justice and Development Party. Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan denied any involvement with the video, saying it was “not anything we would either accept or tolerate.”

headline: Super Saver Works Well, but Rivals Keep Lining Up
text: The Kentucky Derby winner Super Saver pleased his jockey and trainer Monday morning at Churchill Downs with a three-eighths-of-a-mile blowout in a crisp 36.60 seconds. As good as he looked, however, Super Saver is hardly scaring the competition away from the 135th running of the Preakness Stakes this Saturday.

headline: China: Murder Victim Turns Up Alive, and a Prisoner Becomes a Free Man
text: A man serving a 29-year sentence for murder was released Saturday after the man he had been convicted of killing a decade ago turned up alive, the Xinhua state news agency reported. The two men, from a village in Henan Province, had had a fight, the authorities later found a headless body in a village well, and Zhao Zuohai confessed to the killing. He had served 10 years in prison when the victim, Zhao Zhenshang, resurfaced last week. Zhao Zhenshang said he had gone into hiding because he thought he had killed Zhao Zuohai. It remained a mystery why Zhao Zuohai confessed, and whose body was found in the well.

headline: Nathan Serota, Developer in Suburbs, Dies at 90
text: Nathan L. Serota, a developer who scraped together savings by selling railroad tickets, built a few houses, then went on to help shape the face of postwar Long Island with more than 50 shopping centers, died on May 1 at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: On Not Wasting Waste
text: Q. I’ve heard that cow manure, but not human waste, can be used for energy production. Is it possible?

headline: Fruit Fly Gender Varies at the Cellular Level
text: Thirty years ago, the biologist Bruce S. Baker discovered that the gender of a fruit fly is determined not by a hormone, but by the expression of a gene called doublesex in individual cells. Female fruit flies express one form of the gene in their cells, while males express another.

headline: Map Tracks Incidences of Cancer Throughout New York State
text: ALBANY — New York unveiled what it billed as the nation’s first comprehensive statewide cancer map, which became available Monday on the Web site of the State Department of Health.

headline: Florida Suit Poses a Challenge to Health Care Law
text: As they constructed the requirement that Americans have health insurance, Democrats in Congress took pains to make their bill as constitutionally impregnable as possible.

headline: In Antarctica, Drilling for the Past’s Particles
text: The ice caps of Antarctica are largely untouched, clean, and — with the temperature around 60 below — very cold.

headline: Searching for Elena Kagan
text: President Obama may know that his new nominee to the Supreme Court, Elena Kagan, shares his thinking on the multitude of issues that face the court and the nation, but the public knows nothing of the kind. Whether by ambitious design or by habit of mind, Ms. Kagan has spent decades carefully husbanding her thoughts and shielding her philosophy from view. Her lack of a clear record on certain issues makes it hard to know whether Mr. Obama has nominated a full-throated counterweight to the court’s increasingly aggressive conservative wing.

headline: A Bottom Feeder Leaves Traces Below
text: The series of squiggles and little ovals were perplexing, at first.

headline: New Dome Is Prepared to Contain Leaking Oil
text: HOUSTON — After a 98-ton steel containment dome failed to stop a leak that continues to pour oil from a runaway well in the Gulf of Mexico, BP executives said on Monday that they would take another attempt at stemming some of the flow later this week with a far smaller containment device.
