headline: Determined to Make a Living Before Oil Arrives
text: POINTE-AUX-CHENES, La. — A week before the first day of shrimping season, Alton Verdin stepped right through his pier. It isn’t a pier, really, more a found-art sculpture of particle board, two-by-fours, lawn chairs and roofing shingles, but a trip through it can still do a job on your ribs.

headline: Democrats Express Praise for Kagan; G.O.P. Is Cautious
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama introduced Elena Kagan, the nation’s solicitor general and a former dean of Harvard Law School, as his nominee to the Supreme Court on Monday, praising her “fair-mindedness and skill as a consensus-builder,” as he implored senators to conduct a bipartisan confirmation free of election-year politics.

headline: ABN Amro Admits Wrong, and Will Pay $500 Million
text: The former ABN Amro Bank agreed to pay $500 million for violating the Bank Secrecy Act, the Justice Department said Monday.

headline: When Treating One Worker’s Allergy Sets Off Another’s
text: INDIANAPOLIS — It’s a case of King Solomon meets the Americans With Disabilities Act.

headline: Another Ouster at Top Deepens Fujitsu Mystery
text: TOKYO — By global standards, Japanese companies are seen as taking an idiosyncratic approach to corporate governance. But even by Japanese standards, a several high-level management changes at the technology giant Fujitsu have struck analysts and management specialists as unusual.

headline: Drug Use May Cost Cushing N.F.L. Rookie Award
text: Three days after the N.F.L. suspended Brian Cushing, the Houston Texans linebacker who was defensive rookie of the year last season, for four games for violating the league’s performance-enhancing drug policy, The Associated Press announced Monday that it would allow broadcasters and writers to recast their votes for the award.

headline: Debt Aid Package for Europe Took Nudge From Washington
text: PARIS — President Obama had just flown into Hampton, Va., Sunday morning to deliver a commencement address. But before he donned his silky academic robes, he was on the phone with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, offering urgent advice — and some not so subtle prodding — that Europe needed to try something big.

headline: Crew Did All It Could to Slow Ferry Before Crash at Pier, Officials Say
text: The mammoth orange ferry was less than 700 feet away from docking at the Staten Island ferry terminal on Saturday when its crew realized that something was very wrong: It was not slowing down.

headline: A Finer Formula for Assessing Risk
text: The credit crisis would not have been as bad if investment banks’ risk management systems worked well. But the systems rely on sophisticated mathematical models that have a fundamental flaw: they grossly underestimate a factor called “tail risk.” This problem can be solved fairly easily.

headline: Clippard’s Delivery Is Unusual, but It Works
text: At one point in Tyler Clippard’s delivery, he looks like a customer at a grocery store straining to reach for the highest shelf. The position is not usually comfortable, and not associated with pitching success.

headline: Kagan Nomination Leaves Longing on the Left
text: WASHINGTON — The selection of Solicitor General Elena Kagan to be the nation’s 112th justice extends a quarter-century pattern in which Republican presidents generally install strong conservatives on the Supreme Court while Democratic presidents pick candidates who often disappoint their liberal base.

headline: What It Takes
text: About a decade ago, one began to notice a profusion of Organization Kids at elite college campuses. These were bright students who had been formed by the meritocratic system placed in front of them. They had great grades, perfect teacher recommendations, broad extracurricular interests, admirable self-confidence and winning personalities.

headline: Callie Angell, Authority on Warhol Films, Dies at 62
text: Callie Angell, an authority on the films of Andy Warhol, died on Wednesday in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 62.

headline: The Perils of Promoting Schools as Amenities
text: Steve Shokouhi cannot help boasting. As he strides through billows of dust in his nearly finished luxury rental building, the Aire, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, he proudly points out the amenities like the tamo wood paneling from Japan for the lobby, the sun-drenched gym and the children’s outdoor play space. But one of the most coveted perks, he says, is the building’s location in the high-scoring Public School 199 school district.

headline: Upending Twisted Norms
text: Chicago

headline: No Dismissal in Terror Case on Claim of Torture in Jail
text: A federal judge in Manhattan declined on Monday to dismiss charges against a man accused in a terrorism case whose lawyers claimed his rights were violated when he was tortured in secret jails run by the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Suns Stop the Bleeding
text: SAN ANTONIO — Grant Hill always felt that something was lost in the move up from college basketball to the N.B.A., that team commitment and unity was not quite the same on the professional level.

headline: Agreement Will Alter Teacher Evaluations
text: The State Education Department and New York’s teachers’ unions have reached a deal to overhaul teacher evaluations and tie them to student test scores, brokering a compromise on an issue the unions had bitterly opposed for years.

headline: Pfizer to Cut Jobs, Risking Repayment of Tax Breaks
text: Pfizer, the world’s largest pharmaceutical company, plans to lay off or relocate up to 1,400 New York City employees, seven years after receiving millions of dollars in tax breaks to create jobs in the city.

headline: Europe’s Bailout
text: Europe’s leaders stared into the abyss and finally decided to act. The nearly $1 trillion bailout package, arranged over the weekend, is intended to head off Greece’s default and stop the crisis from dragging under other weak economies — Portugal, Spain, Ireland and Italy are all vulnerable.

headline: A Pragmatic New Yorker on a Careful Path to Washington
text: WASHINGTON —  She was a product of Manhattan’s liberal, intellectual Upper West Side — a smart, witty girl who was bold enough at 13 to challenge her family’s rabbi over her bat mitzvah, cocky (or perhaps prescient) enough at 17 to pose for her high school yearbook in a judge’s robe with a gavel and a quotation from Felix Frankfurter, the Supreme Court justice.

headline: Wright Is Keeping Quiet About His Struggles
text: Sure, David Wright said. He would talk. But just not now. After batting practice, he said, before the Mets opened a three-game series with Washington on Monday night at Citi Field.

headline: Suit Questions if Woman S.I. Cancer Doctors Treated Had Cancer
text: The Italian patient traveled to Staten Island in pursuit of a miracle cure, making the same desperate pilgrimage as 200 of her countrymen to receive a special type of cancer treatment.

headline: Vande Velde Is Injured
text: Christian Vande Velde of the Garmin-Transitions team broke his right collarbone in a crash during Stage 3 of the Giro d’Italia, making it two years in a row that he has dropped out of the race with a serious injury. Vande Velde, the team leader who turns 34 next week, will have surgery on his collarbone in Antwerp on Tuesday, leaving him with fewer than eight weeks to heal before the Tour de France. But Vande Velde, of Lemont., Ill., has a history of being resilient. He fractured vertebrae, ribs and his pelvis in a crash during Stage 3 of the 2009 Giro. He recovered to finish eighth at the 2009 Tour de France. More at nytimes.com/sports.

headline: New Ways to Drill, Old Methods for Cleanup
text: HOUSTON — As hopes dim for containing the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico anytime soon, more people are asking why the industry was not better prepared to react.

headline: Snakes on a Plane? Well, No, but Almost Anything Else Goes
text: I’M a pretty mild-mannered guy, and I love talking to people. So business travel is a good fit for me. I’m not hassled by much of anything since I often create my own havoc as I try to board a plane.

headline: Karzai’s Warm Reception Reflects New U.S. Approach
text: WASHINGTON — The last time Afghanistan’s president, Hamid Karzai, was in Washington — a year ago — he had to share the spotlight with his Pakistani counterpart, Asif Ali Zardari, who got the bulk of the attention from the White House, the Pentagon and the State Department. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton even made a personal, unscheduled visit to huddle with Mr. Zardari at his hotel.

headline: Citi Field’s Garbage Problem
text: At game time Monday night, the wind at Citi Field blew at 19 miles per hour, strong but not as gusty as it was Saturday and Sunday, when it blew trash in swirls across the field.

headline: The Elixir of Quietude
text: “No, I don’t hate [Rocky] Balboa, but I pity the 32 Across.”— Mr. T.

headline: Frank Frazetta, Illustrator, Dies at 82; Helped Define Comic Book Heroes
text: Frank Frazetta, an illustrator of comic books, movie posters and paperback book covers whose visions of musclebound men fighting with swords and axes to defend scantily dressed women helped define fantasy heroes like Conan, Tarzan and John Carter of Mars, died on Monday in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 82.

headline: Rules Let Youths Stay on Parents’ Insurance
text: WASHINGTON — The White House issued rules on Monday allowing young adults to remain covered by their parents’ health insurance policies up to age 26.

headline: Reshaping Court’s Culture, a Woman at a Time
text: WASHINGTON — In her confirmation hearings before the Senate Judiciary Committee in 1993, Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg predicted that she would eventually be one of “three, four, perhaps even more women on the high court bench.”

headline: As Cricket Grew in India, Corruption Followed
text: NEW DELHI — Founded three seasons ago, the Indian Premier League managed to make the sport of cricket sexy. India’s corporate titans bought teams, Bollywood stars infused matches with celebrity glamour and fans from Mumbai to Dubai to New Jersey followed the league on television as its value rose to more than $4 billion.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Plan B in the Gulf
text: Over the weekend BP learned that its latest effort at stanching the Deepwater Horizon oil spill — placing a huge metal dome over the leak — had failed. With the oil slick now washing up on the Louisiana shore, the Op-Ed editors asked five experts for their thoughts on what should be done now — and how we can avoid future catastrophes.

headline: On Deploying
text: Before leaving for a year in Afghanistan, soldiers from the 1st Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment of the 10th Mountain Division from Fort Drum, N.Y., reflected on their feelings about deploying.

headline: Obama Said to Be Open to New Miranda Look
text: WASHINGTON — David Axelrod, the top White House political adviser, said Monday that President Obama was amenable to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s call for a new law allowing interrogators to question terrorism suspects for lengthy periods without informing them of their rights.

headline: Nitrogen-Cement Mix Is Focus of Gulf Inquiry
text: In seeking to narrow the possible causes of the drilling disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, government investigators are focusing on the role of a tricky type of cement used in sealing the lower section of the oil well.

headline: At High-End Hotels, Business Is Looking Up
text: IN the depths of the recession, a cartoon made the rounds in the executive offices of the Ritz-Carlton hotel chain. “It showed a guy trying to change the name on the sign above his hotel from Ritz to Fritz,” said Simon Cooper, the president of Ritz-Carlton, which is the top luxury brand of Marriott International.

headline: Amid the Silence: ‘Ernie, We Love You!’
text: DETROIT — After nearly a weeklong wake, the Detroit Tigers said farewell to their veteran broadcaster Ernie Harwell with plenty of faces on hand from the Harwell era.

headline: Investor Group to Acquire Canadian Newspapers
text: OTTAWA — Most of Canada’s large English-language daily newspapers will come under the control of an investment group led by the former head of a rival publisher, Canwest Global Communications announced on Monday evening.

headline: Reality TV’s Annoyingly Perfect, Oddly Sane Mom
text: Reality TV is entertaining enough, but it also offers viewers a delicious self-righteous salve. Is there any easier way to feel better about your own moral grounding than flipping on, say, any episode of the “Real Housewives” franchise?

headline: Court Pick Can Still Rise on Her High School’s Alumni List
text: Tenth graders at Hunter College High School in Manhattan had a substitute teacher in their American history class on Monday for an unusual reason: Their regular teacher, Irving Kagan, was in Washington, watching his sister, Elena, accept President Obama’s nomination for a seat on the Supreme Court.

headline: California: Polanski Request Is Denied
text: Roman Polanski’s legal options narrowed Monday as a Los Angeles judge denied his request to unseal testimony about a sentencing plan in his 33-year-old sex-crimes case. Lawyers for Mr. Polanski, the Oscar-winning director, had hoped to use the testimony of a retired prosecutor to fight his extradition to the United States from Switzerland, where he is under house arrest. The conditional testimony of the retired prosecutor, Roger Gunson, was taken this year so it could be used if Mr. Gunson, who has cancer, is not available to testify in any future sentencing hearing. In denying the request, Judge Peter Espinoza of Los Angeles Superior Court said of the Swiss authorities, “I’m satisfied that they have information that they need.”

headline: Stephen Ledogar Dies at 80; Drafted Arms Pacts
text: Stephen J. Ledogar, a United States ambassador who played a major role in the drafting of three central international arms control treaties, died May 3 in Edgewater, N.J. He was 80 and lived in Guttenberg, N.J.

headline: A Trillion for Europe, With Doubts Attached
text: Like the giant financial bailout announced by the United States in 2008, the sweeping rescue package announced by Europe eased fears of a market collapse but left a big question: will it work long term?

headline: Damon Reminds the Yankees What They’re Missing
text: DETROIT — All those spring training games desensitized them. The Yankees played the Detroit Tigers so often that by Monday night, when the game actually meant something, the sight of Johnny Damon wearing the Old English D no longer jarred them. It looked normal. He looked normal, his new Mohawk notwithstanding.

headline: Home-Ice Advantage Sends Montreal Back to Pittsburgh

But they never seemed to have gathered inside the Bell Centre, as the Canadiens were eliminated from the playoffs at home on six straight occasions.

headline: Obama Sends Scientists to Meet BP Team
text: On the eve of Senate hearings examining the destruction of the Deepwater Horizon rig and the unabated release of oil from the damaged seafloor well, President Obama ordered a team of government officials and scientists led by Energy Secretary Steven Chu to head to Houston this week to confer with BP’s brain trust on next steps to stem the unfolding environmental disaster. He also requested that legislation be sent to Congress to toughen and update the law placing caps on damages from such incidents.

headline: Union Plans More Strikes Against British Airways
text: A union representing 13,500 British Airways cabin crew members voted Monday to hold an additional 20 days of strikes beginning later this month, part of a protest of cost-cutting plans that include a wage freeze and a reduction of in-flight staff.

headline: Mets Raise Their Voices but Go Quiet in the Big Moments

headline: The Moment You’ve Waited For
text: Update, May 17 | It is now possible to search the “Moment in Time” interactive gallery by the name given in the photographer’s credit line (actual name, pseudonym or screen name, as the contributor chose). You’ll find the search box in the upper right corner of the opening page. If you believe your picture wasn’t posted, we urge you to give this a try.

headline: Find the Cheapest Beer or Barber Near You
text: For people trying to figure out where to get a deal near their home, the sudden outpouring of options is a bit overwhelming. Web sites publishing local deals are popping up everywhere, from Groupon and its imitators to Twitter and Foursquare to super-local neighborhood sites. That’s on top of offers that appear in the mail and newspaper ads.

headline: Sebelius Trumpets Health Law’s Immediate Impact

headline: How Might Your Upbringing Influence Your Career Choice?
text: When Elena Kagan was introduced yesterday as President Obama’s nominee to the Supreme Court, both he and she remarked on her background and upbringing as part of her path to the nomination. Look ahead into your own future. How do you think your background may influence your own career and life path?

headline: Telefonica Rejected in $7.3 Billion Bid for Vivo

headline: Buffett’s Son Preaches Down-Home Values

text: Chase Stuart writes for the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog.

headline: Fidelity Reshuffle Boosts Abigail Johnson
text: Fidelity Investments, the giant mutual fund firm, has shuffled top management, expanding the duties of Abigail Johnson, the daughter of its chief executive, and hiring a top Bank of New York Mellon executive to run its asset-management business, Reuters reported.

headline: European Lawmakers Delay Vote on Fund Rules
text: Opponents of proposed European Union legislation that would increase regulation of the private equity and hedge fund industries won a reprieve Monday when lawmakers once again pushed back a vote on the rules.

headline: A Diverse Supreme Court?
text: Today’s idea: The Supreme Court looks diverse in terms of race, gender and ethnicity, but it’s still a pretty monolithic crowd from the educated elite, an article says.

headline: In Britain, Courts Stand Up for Bankers
text: British bankers, the butt of political and public criticism for getting taxpayer bailouts and large bonuses, at least have some friends in London’s courts.

headline: My Virtual Business Group
text: All of these posts about business groups have been interesting. I’ve never joined one or even considered joining one, even though my uncle was executive director of Young Presidents’ Organization for many years. (O.K., I considered it then but didn’t qualify.)

headline: A Cheerier Oil Blowout
text: As I write in an article in Tuesday’s Science Times, blowout preventers are a critical piece of oil-rigging equipment designed to help maintain pressure control in a well as it is being drilled. The aim is to avoid a catastrophic blowout like the kind the occurred on April 20 in the Gulf of Mexico. In that accident, the blowout preventer failed to work.

headline: Icahn Raises His Motorola Stake
text: Activist shareholder Carl C. Icahn raised his stake in mobile phone maker Motorola, according to a regulatory filing, Reuters reported.

headline: Pope Issues His Most Direct Words to Date on Abuse
text: LISBON — Pope Benedict XVI on Tuesday issued his most forceful remarks on the sexual abuse crisis sweeping the Catholic Church. He called it “truly terrifying” and, in a marked shift in tone, suggested that its origins lay with abusive priests and with highly placed church officials who for decades concealed or minimized the problem.

headline: Reed Seeks to Close Loophole for Small Funds
text: Senator Jack Reed, Democrat of Rhode Island and a member of the Senate Banking Committee, on Monday filed an amendment to the financial reform currently in the Senate that would require all hedge funds, private equity shops and venture capital firms to register with either a state regulator or the Securities and Exchange Commission, Politico reported.

headline: Drone Strikes Pound West Pakistan
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — American drone aircraft fired 18 missiles at militants in Pakistan’s North Waziristan tribal region on Tuesday, killing at least 14 fighters and wounding 4, a security official and a resident of the area said.

headline: Sampler: Dumb SmartMeters, and Bingo Troubles
text: SmartMeters Prove Not So Smart | The Pacific Gas and Electric Company acknowledged on Monday that tens of thousands of customers using its new SmartMeters might have received inaccurate utility bills. A few weeks ago, the company insisted that only “a few” customers had received the bungled bills. The California Public Utilities Commission is investigating the meters’ accuracy. P.G.&E. has installed 5.5 million of the meters throughout Northern California and continues to install about 10,000 a day. [The San Jose Mercury News, The San Francisco Chronicle]

headline: Car of the Future Could Include Personalized Dashboards
text: You can change the icons and the way they’re arranged on your personal computer at will. And you can change which applications appear on the initial screen of a smartphone. So why can’t you customize your car’s dashboard display? Cisco thinks you will able to do just that in future.

headline: Q.&A.: Uploading to Flickr
text: Q.

headline: Zale Gets $150 Million Loan from Golden Gate
text: Golden Gate Capital has ridden to Zale‘s rescue, following reports that the struggling American  jeweler was in talks with several private equity firms about an investment to help reverse the company’s fortunes.

headline: K.K.R. to Offer $500 Million in New Shares
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has filed to raise as much as $500 million by selling new shares once the buyout shop moves its listing to the New York Stock Exchange, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: A Mighty Trading Quarter for Goldman and JPMorgan
text: Goldman Sachs isn’t the only firm that made a trading gain every day last quarter.

headline: News, Not Chatter
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: News, Not Chatter
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: In the Mission District, a Great Cheap Lunch
text: Greetings from San Francisco, where I am on a dual assignment, one an overdue visit to my younger daughter and the other for The Times’s Travel section. On Monday, while hanging out with the first and ignoring the second, we sprinted to the Mission for lunch.

headline: Thai Protesters Refuse to Disband, Putting Deal in Peril
text: BANGKOK — A deal to end two months of protests in Bangkok appeared to be weakening on Tuesday as antigovernment protesters hardened their stance on one demand while the prime minister threatened to take “necessary action” if they failed to leave their barricaded encampment by Wednesday.

headline: The Potential Field, All in One Place
text: If you’re having a tough time keeping straight who’s in and who’s out for the Preakness, that’s probably because this year’s race is expected to have the first full 14-horse field since 2005.

headline: Cameron Takes Over as British Premier After Brown Resigns
text: LONDON — Britain’s Conservatives returned to power on Tuesday after 13 years in opposition when David Cameron, who has built his future on a claim to have recast the party of Margaret Thatcher for a new century as more compassionate and less class-bound, took over as prime minister from Labour’s Gordon Brown.

headline: Obama Proposes Splitting Oversight Agency for Oil Drilling
text: President Obama is proposing to split the agency that oversees offshore oil drilling into two parts, one to inspect oil rigs and enforce safety, the other to oversee leases for drilling and collect royalties, the White House said Tuesday.

headline: ‘Exile’ in Punkville: Green Day Does the Rolling Stones
text: It’s a double coup: First, “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” lines up a week’s worth of special musical guests to cover tracks from the Rolling Stones’ “Exile on Main Street,” to promote a coming re-release of that album. Then, NBC secures the clearances to those songs in time to post video of those “Late Night” performances the morning after they’re broadcast. What’s next? Keith Richards switches to pomegranate juice?

headline: Portugal Telecom Rejects Offer for Brazilian Stake
text: The Portugal Telecom board said late Monday that it had rejected an “unsolicited, binding and unconditional offer” from a partner, Telefónica, to buy its interest in their Brazilian joint venture, Vivo, for 5.7 billion euros ($7.3 billion).

headline: Speed Read for Tuesday, May 11
text: Highlights from today’s New York Times:

headline: Nocturnalist | At ‘The Kid,’ Two Debuts
text: A little past 7 p.m. Monday night, about 200 theatergoers learned of the birth of a baby named Keith Patterson, born at 6:48 p.m., weighing eight pounds.

headline: Swipely Enters the Social Shopping Field
text: The over-sharing movement gets a new player today with the debut of Swipely, another site that allows people to publish information and start conversations about their everyday purchases.

headline: How Will Hospice Care Change?
text: Q.

headline: The Early Word: The Senate’s Move
text: President Obama has made his choice for the Supreme Court. But what will the Senate think of Elena Kagan?

headline: The Oil Industry Takes Its Case to Washington
text: So many major events in this country repeat themselves, first as tragedy and then as Congressional hearing. The BP oil spill is a case in point: several major players will testify Tuesday morning before the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources before facing the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works in the afternoon. We’ll be live-blogging the first hearing.

headline: Just For Kicks | The Art of the Game
text: In anticipation of next month’s World Cup in South Africa, FIFA has commissioned 17 artists to create limited-edition soccer-themed prints. The Cup organizers initiated the art-for-athletics program back in 2006, printing posters by the likes of Andreas Gursky to promote the German games. This year’s portfolio includes a drawing by the South African artist William Kentridge of a player in midkick (above); a latex sculpture of an elephant, its trunk wrapped around the ball, by the German-born Isolde Krams; and a colorful embroidered work by the Sudanese artist Hassan Musa, who reimagines Jacob’s tussle with the Archangel as a center-field struggle. The original artworks were auctioned at New York’s Phillips de Pury, but the signed and numbered prints — 2,010 of each image — go for as little as $121. Go to 2010artedition.de.

headline: The Trouble With Schools as Selling Points
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: E.U. Laws Blamed for 2,600 Jobs Lost at R.B.S.
text: The Royal Bank of Scotland’s insurance and retail business has lost 2,600 more jobs, bringing the total jobs lost at the firm to 22,600 since the 2008 bailout, The Guardian reported.

headline: Reality Parenting and the Science of Temptation
text: Susan Dominus interviews Cortney Novogratz, above, who stars in Bravo’s new “9 by Design” with her husband, Robert. The couple design and sell high-end homes while raising seven children.

headline: Live-Blogging the Senate Hearing on Offshore Drilling
text: The Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources is holding a hearing on offshore gas and oil development, including the Interior’s Department’s recently announced plan to allow more drilling and the April 20 accident involving the Deepwater Horizon oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico. Green is live-blogging the hearing, with the most recent updates at the top of this post.

headline: After Lena Horne’s Death, Obama Offers Condolences
text: On Monday evening, President Obama issued a statement on the death of Lena Horne, the groundbreaking actress and singer who died at 92 on Sunday.

headline: ‘A Wall of Worry’ on the Street
text: The lingering uncertainty about the world economy on Tuesday led gold prices to surge to record levels and left major indexes on Wall Street searching for direction.

headline: Questions on Offshore Oil
text: In a hearing this morning, the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee is set to examine various issues related to offshore oil and gas exploration and to grill executives from BP, Halliburton and Transocean about the fatal and environmentally calamitous destruction of the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig.

headline: More Answers on Europe’s Debt Crisis
text: Our panel of economists is back with another installment of answers to your questions about the Greek debt crisis and its repercussions. The panelists are Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, an author of “13 Bankers: The Wall Street Takeover and the Next Financial Meltdown,” and a Daily Economist here at Economix; Carmen M. Reinhart, an economic historian at the University of Maryland whose recent book, “This Time Is Different,” chronicles 800 years’ worth of debt crises and sovereign defaults; and Yves Smith, the financial analyst behind the “Naked Capitalism” blog and “ECONned,” who heads Aurora Advisors, a management consulting firm specializing in corporate finance advisory and financial services.

headline: An ‘American Idol’ Hopeful
text: Henriette Lazaridis Power knows a little about ambition. A Rhodes scholar who taught English at Harvard for a decade, she is the founding editor of the new online literary magazine The Drum, which publishes audio versions of fiction writing.

headline: F.C.C. Weighs Plan to Warn of High Cellphone Bill
text: The Federal Communications Commission said Tuesday that it was seeking public comment on a plan that would require wireless phone companies to notify customers when they are running up unusually high charges for data usage, roaming or other uses beyond what is covered by regular monthly fees.

headline: Tuesday Reading: The New Calculus of Seat Upgrades
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: U.S. to Split Up Agency Policing the Oil Industry
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday proposed breaking up the agency responsible for both policing the oil industry and acting as its partner in drilling activities, seeking to end a decades-old relationship between industry and government that has proved highly profitable — and some say too cozy — for both.

headline: More Time Together? Facebook Starts Inevitable Carol Burnett ‘SNL’ Campaign
text: 1:53 p.m. | Updated Lorne Michaels, you’ve got no one to blame for this but yourself. You invite Betty White to host “Saturday Night Live” after hundreds of thousands of Facebook fans clamor for it — yielding a memorable show and strong ratings in the process — and you open the door for copycat campaigns to put other stars of a certain age onto your show.

headline: Today in Business Travel
text: The Calculus of UpgradesAirline travelers hoping to use frequent-flier miles to get better seats need to have a calculator handy while reading the fine print.
The Way Back Machine: when bucket shops were a financial scourge.

headline: On Design | Those Fabulous Finns
text: Finland is a sparsely populated country whose most famous exports are supermodels, textiles, glass and furniture — though not necessarily in that order.

headline: Atwood Says ‘We Don’t Do Cultural Boycotts’ and Accepts Israeli Prize
text: Margaret Atwood on Monday accepted the Dan David Prize at Tel Aviv University in Israel, telling an interviewer before the ceremony that to snub the honor would be tantamount to “throwing overboard the thousands of writers around the world who are in prison, censored, exiled and murdered for what they have published.”

headline: Davies Among International Stars to Miss Out on World Cup
text: 5:27 p.m. |France Without Benzema

headline: Cuomo Sues Bank of New York Unit Over Madoff
text: 3:32 p.m. | Updated Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York on Tuesday sued a fund-of-funds unit of Bank of New York Mellon for fraud over the $227 million that the unit’s investors had lost as a result of its investment in Bernard L. Madoff‘s Ponzi scheme.

headline: San Francisco Museum Selects Four Finalists for Expansion Project
text: The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has selected four architectural firms as finalists to design its expansion.

headline: Share Stories of Your Service in Afghanistan
text: The New York Times invites members of the military who are serving, or have served, in Afghanistan to help us document the daily life of this war in photographs, video and writing. Take us on a tour of the forward operating base, introduce us to your friends, describe the hardships and rewards of deployment and the humor that helps you pass the time.

headline: The Heart of a Rising Area Battles to Survive
text: The space is little more than a cramped room with teal-colored walls, a griddle, and a refrigerator filled with Mexican sodas. But this modest restaurant in the South Bronx has become the hub of the Melrose community, a place where police officers, construction workers, lawyers and local residents gather to eat tamales and gossip about the neighborhood. A visitor could see a group of musicians playing the drums one day, and the longtime local congressman eating a Cuban sandwich the next.

headline: Gulf Coast Benefit Concert Will Feature Lenny Kravitz and Allen Toussaint
text: Lenny Kravitz is among the musicians with ties to Louisiana who will participate in a benefit concert to assist residents affected by an oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Kravitz, who lives part-time in New Orleans, was the first performer to commit to the benefit, called Gulf Aid, which is scheduled for Sunday at that city’s Mardi Gras World River City. Other artists expected to perform include Allen Toussaint, Mos Def, Ani DiFranco, the Voice of the Wetlands Allstars (including Tab Benoit, Dr. John and Cyril Neville) and the Preservation Hall Jazz Band. Tickets are $50 and will be sold through Elevate Tickets. The event, whose proceeds will go to organizations that help Gulf Coast fishermen and the area’s seafood industry as well as those that address environmental issues, will also be broadcast on the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage radio station WWOZ 90.7 FM and wwoz.org.

headline: While Griffey Was Sleeping
text: These are dizzying days in the world of sports. Things change so fast, it is possible to take a nap and miss an entire era. Conventional wisdom passes through like a warm front. Dynasties last no longer than your average highlight clip.

headline: Looking for Job Openings
text: The number of unemployed workers per job opening barely changed from February to March, when the ratio was 5.57 jobless workers for each available position.

headline: The Friendship of Cancer
text: Two years after I found out that I had an aggressive Stage 3 prostate cancer, I’ve learned that, more than anything, cancer is about stories and friendships.

headline: The Morning Line: Preakness Field of 13 Includes ‘Lucky’
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

headline: Tasting Cavas
text: Due to the Internet’s wondrous ability to manipulate time and space, my column on cava is already posted.

headline: Thus Drank Zarathustra
text: Turin, Italy, was where the sun set on the mighty Friedrich Nietzsche. Some say that syphilis had gotten to his brain, but in the last lucid months before he was carted back over the mountains to a madhouse in Switzerland, he declared the regal city on the Po to be the first place in which he was “possible.”

headline: Detroit Hangs on Lidstrom Retirement Decision
text: Anxious Detroit Red Wings fans are trying to read the tea leaves, looking for clues to figure out captain Nicklas Lidstrom’s future.

headline: What We’re Reading: Estate Tax T.V.
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: We’re Getting Better All the Time
text: The future will be greener, we hope, both environmentally and for our personal finances. Yet getting there will take work, both architectural and mental, as old consuming habits give way to new habits of thrift, industry and pluck.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Grand Illusion’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Picks video, A. O. Scott look back at Jean Renoir‘s World War I drama “Grand Illusion.” The film follows a group of French officers who are imprisoned by the Germans and are plotting their escape. Mr. Scott says the film’s antiwar message still resonates today; that categories of “race, class, ethnicity, religion, nationality are not what matter. What matters is the individuality of each person.” Please share your thoughts on “Grand Illusion” and the work of Jean Renoir.

headline: Senate Backs Audit of Fed Bailout Role
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted unanimously on Tuesday to require an audit of the Federal Reserve’s emergency actions during and after the 2008 financial crisis as part of broad legislation overhauling the nation’s financial regulatory system.

headline: Could Damon Return to the Bronx?
text: DETROIT — A strong bullpen — its 2.22 earned run average is the lowest in baseball – a solid lineup and good starting pitching should keep the Tigers in contention deep into the summer in a shallow American League Central.  But what if the Tigers were to fall behind Minnesota? Would they start considering selling off some talent before the July 31 trade deadline? Someone like, say, Johnny Damon?

headline: World’s Fastest Roller Coaster? A Ferrari
text: Ferrari is rampaging through the spring tulips.

headline: TimesCast | May 11, 2010
text: Today, President Obama proposes new plans to regulate offshore oil drilling, Pope Benedict XVI says sins inside the Catholic Church pose a great threat, and Afghanistan's president gets a warm welcome in Washington.

headline: Odyssey Years
text: The period in a person’s twenties, before careers and relationships have settled.

headline: In New York’s Suburbs, Teachers Feel Budget Ax
text: Teachers are giving up raises in at least five Long Island districts, including Brentwood, where the 1,400 teachers will also take individual pay cuts of $900 that will be repaid to them without interest when they leave or retire.

headline: Hedge Funds Post Gains but Still Lag S.& P.
text: Hedge funds posted modest gains in April, drawing in more capital from investors. The HFN Hedge Fund Aggregate Index was up 1.55 percent for the month, according to a preliminary figures complied by HedgeFund.net. The index, made up of dozens of funds across different strategies, is up 4.35 percent for the year.

headline: Specter’s New Obama Ad
text: Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, facing an increasingly tough challenge in next week’s Democratic primary from Representative Joe Sestak, has released a new television ad featuring none other than President Obama.

headline: Why Some Owners Are Shy About Marketing
text: Even though I’ve worked with hundreds of business owners over the years, I recently learned something about them that took me by surprise: for many, self-promotion is as uncomfortable as wearing their underwear backward. I never realized how common this reluctance is — until I had a series of conversations.

headline: Why I Got Kicked Out of a Restaurant on Saturday Night
text: On Saturday night, for the first time in my life, I was kicked out of a restaurant — Restaurant Marc Forgione in TriBeCa.

headline: After Criticizing Gay Actors, Newsweek Writer Responds
text: After his column criticizing openly gay actors playing straight characters was widely jeered around the Internet and drew a passionate rebuttal from Kristin Chenoweth, Ramin Setoodeh has written a follow-up post for Newsweek in which he says he was trying to start a dialogue, and that he was verbally attacked and harassed over the essay.

headline: How a Horse Learns the Starting Gate
text: After the track renovation break Tuesday at Fair Hill Training Center, I had three horses left to ride for Michael Pino. All three were “babies,” or 2-year-olds, who were going to the starting gate for some schooling.

headline: Is Hertz’s Dollar Thrifty Deal Too Good – for Hertz?
text: The Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group may be up for sale — but now it’s slightly dented.

headline: Ferguson: ‘Skipping Afternoon Tea’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: It is a great day for America’s Supreme Court. President Obama just nominated Elena Kagan to be the next Supreme Court justice. He went against the advice of Joe Biden. Biden wanted Iron Man.

headline: Anand Is World Chess Champion Again
text: The world champion wins the last game of the championship match in Sofia, Bulgaria, to defend his title.

headline: Letterman: ‘Never Argued Before’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: The State Department now has warned against travel to the tribal regions of Pakistan. There goes my summer vacation.

headline: Head of Nokia’s Mobile Phone Unit Is Leaving
text: Nokia, the world’s largest maker of cellphones, said on Tuesday that the head of its main mobile phone unit was leaving the job for personal reasons after just six months, as the company announced its second high-level reorganization in less than a year.

headline: Q&A: The Southeast for a Birthday, by Boat or Not
text: Q.

headline: Comcast Expands On-Demand Movie Offerings
text: Trying to make good on its new Xfinity brand name, Comcast said Tuesday that it is ramping up its video on demand, or V.O.D., service by more than quadrupling the number of available movies.

headline: Leno: ‘Numerous Trips Back and Forth’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Hey, the government announced today they’re making big changes to the do-not-fly list. Apparently, asking terrorists to be on the honor system has not been working. So now they’re going to start cracking down.

headline: Inside the New Flight Rules
text: THE federal government is taking a stronger hand in regulating how airlines treat passengers, and new rules limiting long tarmac delays are just the first step.

headline: Ryan-Coburn, Wyden-Bennett and Other Animals
text: In my post yesterday on the role that the Wyden-Bennett health care bill played in Bob Bennett’s primary defeat, I linked to Michael Cannon’s free-market critique of the Paul Ryan/Tom Coburn proposal, which shared some features with Wyden-Bennett without inspiring any anti-Ryan or anti-Coburn backlash on the right. Ramesh Ponnuru points out that Cannon subsequently corrected and revised that critique. I regret missing that revision, not least because Cannon’s apparent misapprehensions about the Ryan-Coburn bill were similar to mine.

headline: At Stuyvesant, a Successful Push for Federal Money
text: To all the other economic indicators in the city, add Stuyvesant High School. For the first time in recent memory, the school, the crown jewel of the city school system, will qualify for federal financing reserved for the poorest schools.

headline: TimesCast: A New Oil Oversight Plan and a Visit from Karzai
text: President Obama is proposing to split the Minerals Management Service, the federal agency that oversees offshore oil drilling, into two parts, one to inspect oil rigs and enforce safety, the other to oversee leases for drilling and collect royalties. Meanwhile, on the foreign policy front, the White House prepares for a visit from Afghanistan’s president, Hamid Karzai.

headline: On Our Radar: The Spill, Viewed From Space
text: Florida lawmakers will weigh a constitutional amendment to ban offshore drilling.

headline: Violent Oklahoma Storms Kill 2 and Wreck Homes
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Residents and state officials picked through a path of destruction on Tuesday from violent storms that left homes toppled, trees uprooted, power lines down and personal possessions strewn for miles throughout central Oklahoma.

headline: Electric Motorcycles Are Not So Collectible, Yet
text: The 1974 Corbin Electric sold for just over $1,000.

headline: Amid Conflict, a Consensus on Efficiency
text: Those of you who follow energy and environmental issues with some regularity will surely know the McKinsey greenhouse gas cost abatement curve — but for those who are unfamiliar with it, it’s shown above.

headline: Minority Owner Sues Cuban, Calls Mavericks ‘Insolvent’
text: Mark Cuban’s financial management of the Dallas Mavericks was described as reckless in a lawsuit filed Monday in Texas by a minority investor in the team who accused Cuban of amassing net losses of $273 million and debt of more than $200 million.

headline: Britain Called Stingy on Euro Support
text: BRUSSELS — Britain’s neighbors accused it of shortsightedness on Tuesday for stinting on contributions to a rescue package aimed at staving off a broader financial crisis in countries that use the euro.

headline: Australian Fashion Week Spring/Summer 2010/11
text: Talk about fun in the sun. While those of us north of the equator are gearing up for fall’s camel coats and cargo pants, our fashion friends down under are just now warming up to the idea of bikinis, wedge sandals, suspender socks and reptilian makeup. Here, scenes from Rosemount Australian Fashion Week, which ran May 3-7.

headline: Senate Backs One-Time Audit of Fed’s Bailout Role
text: The Senate on Tuesday voted unanimously to require a one-time audit of the Federal Reserve’s emergency actions during and after the 2008 financial crisis as part of broad legislation overhauling the nation’s financial regulatory system, The New York Times’s David M. Herszenhorn reports from Washington.

headline: Magic Can Wait, Watch O’Neal Try to Advance
text: For N.B.A. die-hards, this would be the ultimate Eastern Conference Finals match-up: Orlando center Dwight Howard vs. Cleveland center Shaquille O’Neal.

headline: Finger-Pointing, but Few Answers at Hearings on Drilling
text: KENNER, La. — As the Congressional hearings into offshore drilling began in Washington, a more intimate inquiry into what went wrong three weeks ago on the fallen Deepwater Horizon drilling rig began in this suburb of New Orleans, with members of the Coast Guard and the Minerals Management Service demanding answers — often from within their own agencies.

headline: Answers on Europe’s Debt Crisis, Part 3
text: Our panel of economists is back with a final installment of answers to your questions about the Greek debt crisis and its repercussions. The panelists are Yves Smith, the financial analyst behind the “Naked Capitalism” blog and “ECONned,” who heads Aurora Advisors, a management consulting firm specializing in corporate finance advisory and financial services; Carmen M. Reinhart, an economic historian at the University of Maryland whose recent book, “This Time Is Different,” chronicles 800 years’ worth of debt crises and sovereign defaults; and Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, an author of “13 Bankers: The Wall Street Takeover and the Next Financial Meltdown,” and a Daily Economist here at Economix.

headline: Republican Prosecutor to Run for Attorney General
text: It looks like New York Republicans will have a candidate for attorney general after all.

headline: More on Red and Blue Families
text: Via Eve Tushnet, I see that Maggie Gallagher got there first on the point I made in yesterday’s column — namely, that a lot of the differences between “red” and “blue” family structures, as sketched in Naomi Cahn and June Carbone’s recent book, are driven by higher abortion rates in liberal states. And it really is striking, when you dig into the data, how much of the blue-state advantage in preventing teen births is made possible by abortion. Rhode Island’s teen pregnancy rate is identical to West Virginia’s, but West Virginia’s teen birth rate is 33 percent higher. California’s teen pregnancy rate is higher than Alabama’s, but California’s teen birth rate is 20 percent lower. Kentucky and Maryland have the same teen pregnancy rates, but Kentucky has almost 60 percent more teenage births. And so on …

headline: Hold Onto Your Vowels: Gyllenhaal and Sarsgaard Re-Team for Classic Stage Company
text: If the Park Slope neighborhood of Brooklyn seems a little less cool next January, it may be because Maggie Gyllenhaal and Peter Sarsgaard are simultaneously out of town, at least for part of the day: the wife-and-husband actors with Brooklyn’s highest per-capita concentration of vowels will once again appear together in a production at the Classic Stage Company, that East Village theater company said on Tuesday. This time, they will be in Chekhov’s “Three Sisters.” The production will reunite Ms. Gyllenhaal and Mr. Sarsgaard with the director Austin Pendleton and their co-star Mamie Gummer, from the production of “Uncle Vanya” that Classic Stage Company presented in 2009. The cast of “Three Sisters” will also feature Ebon Moss-Bachrach and Josh Hamilton.

headline: City Raises Glass to a Brewery in Brooklyn
text: Brooklyn’s proud history as a beermaking capital took a big bow Tuesday afternoon when for the first time, the city gave landmark status to a former brewery: the William Ulmer complex, four buildings constructed in the German round-arch style between 1872 and 1890 in Bushwick.

headline: Getting Kicked Out of a Restaurant
text: On Saturday night, at Restaurant Marc Forgione, the chef himself asked me and my party to leave the restaurant. Actually, it didn’t appear that we had much of a choice.

headline: Oil or Elephants
text: Mitch Smith is a 19-year-old journalism student at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the winner of the 2010 Win-A-Trip with Nick contest. He and Nick arrived Sunday in Gabon, Africa–his first time ever outside of the country.

headline: Sony Raises the Bar for Hybrid Cameras
text: Sony has just unwrapped its entrants in the mirrorless interchangeable-lens camera category, and they raise the bar — and lower the cost — for this evolving class of hybrid camera.

headline: Philippine Landslide Seen for Aquino
text: MANILA — Senator Benigno S. Aquino III, who appeared almost certain on Tuesday to become the Philippines’ next president, said he had never imagined running for the nation’s highest office until he was urged on by supporters grieving over the death of his mother last August.

headline: The Morning Skate: No Quit in the Canadiens, Honor for Orr
text: The Bell Centre has not yet turned back into a pumpkin. The clock has not yet struck midnight. In fact, the hands of the clock appear to be traveling in reverse, transporting us back to a time when playoff miracles were the rule, not the exception, in Montreal.

headline: Above 6,500 Feet, Two Rare Chameleons
text: 6th May 2010, Madagascar

headline: Lena Horne, in Black and White
text: Al Hirschfeld, the artist, did many illustrations of Lena Horne.

headline: Citi Field’s Fingerprints All Over Wright’s and Bay’s Numbers
text: If you were a baseball detective, assigned to the Mets, what would you make of the mysterious numbers now fastened to David Wright and Jason Bay? How would you try to explain Wright’s mushrooming number of strikeouts and Bay’s paltry home run total? Would Citi Field itself be a suspect, as it was a year ago, when Wright first seemed to veer away from his steady numbers at the plate.

headline: Biden’s Son Beau Is Hospitalized
text: 3:16 p.m. | Updated  The White House has just released a statement from Dr. Timothy Gardner, the medical director of the Center for Heart and Vascular Surgery at Christiana Care Health System, indicating that Attorney General Biden appears to have suffered a mild stroke. The statement says:

headline: Scent Notes | Ocean Currents
text: The smell of the beach is perhaps the most visceral, and wonderful, part of summer. Here are six scents that ingeniously tap into our experience of the ocean:

headline: Kagan’s View of the Court Confirmation Process, Before She Was a Part of It
text: WASHINGTON — In her trenchant and cheeky 1995 article on how Supreme Court confirmation hearings really work, Elena Kagan did more than provide pointed advice to both senators and nominees. She also discussed her thinking about the role a justice’s values play in deciding cases and argued that a nominee’s lack of judicial experience ought not matter.

headline: Davies Misses U.S. World Cup Roster
text: Charlie Davies, whose hopes of playing in the World Cup fueled his recovery from a serious car accident seven months ago, was left off the preliminary list of players for the United States roster Tuesday.

headline: Video of Gordon Brown’s Resignation Speech
text: As my colleague John Burns reports, Gordon Brown resigned as Britain’s prime minister on Tuesday and has been succeeded by David Cameron, who will lead a coalition government made up of his Conservative Party and the Liberal Democrats. Here are Mr. Brown’s remarks outside 10 Downing Street on Tuesday evening in London (from Britain’s Channel 4 News):

headline: Green Cards to Be Green
text: Everyone calls it a “green card,” but for many years the coveted identification that immigration authorities issue to lawful permanent residents has been variously pink, beige, blue, white — just about anything but green.

headline: On the Bench? Vetting Supreme Court Nominee Elena Kagan
text: Overview | Who is Elena Kagan? What questions surround her nomination to the U.S. Supreme Court? In this lesson, students reflect on the qualities and role of a Supreme Court justice. They then consider the issues surrounding Ms. Kagan’s nomination and determine whether they believe she should be appointed to the bench after learning about her experience, background and stances. They then develop a “game plan” for supporting or opposing the nomination. and even create one component of the plan.

headline: A Peek at Vanity Fair’s iPad App
text: “Magazines are actually pretty brilliant concepts the way they are,” said Vanity Fair editor Graydon Carter on Tuesday as he previewed his magazine’s new iPad app. “At the same time, we have a few bells and whistles that a magazine cannot provide.”

headline: Gensler Lays Out Timeline for Wild Wall St. Trading
text: Mark Wilson/Getty Images From left, Mary L. Schapiro, the S.E.C. chairwoman; Robert W. Cook, director of S.E.C.’s division of trading and markets, and Gary Gensler, the C.F.T.C. chairman, testified about the market’s plunge on Thursday during a House hearing.

headline: Will Gulf Fish Get a Break?
text: In 2005 conservation groups filed suit against the Gulf of Mexico Fishery Management Council, which regulates fishing in the gulf, over its stewardship of the red snapper, a favorite catch of commercial and recreational fishermen. The suit alleged that despite ample evidence of enormous declines in stocks of red snapper, the council had failed to institute catch limits and other protections required under federal law.

headline: More Americans Are Paying for Television
text: Tired of costly cable bills, many Americans have talked about “cutting the cord” and relying on the Internet’s patchwork of streaming television and movie services. Decoder admits it’s a tantalizing proposition. But a new report reminds us that more people than ever are forking over monthly payments for TV.

headline: Now Booking | East London Duo
text: The East End of London has been the focus of contemporary fashion, design and music in the the city for the last decade. But suitable places to stay have been slow in coming. The Hoxton Hotel arrived in 2006, and Terence Conran’s 17-room Boundary opened its doors last year. Now two new arrivals are vying for the attention of design-savvy travelers.

headline: Cushing Made His Choice; Voters Have an Easy One
text: Taking away Brian Cushing’s award is a no-brainer. He forfeited the right to remain defensive rookie of 2009 in the N.F.L. as soon as the bells and whistles went off in the laboratory.

headline: Insomniac City
text: I moved to New York a year ago and felt at once at home. In the haggard buildings and bloodshot skies, in trains that never stopped running, like my racing mind at night, I recognized my insomniac self. If New York were a patient, it would be diagnosed with agrypnia excitata, a rare genetic condition characterized by insomnia, nervous energy, constant twitching, and dream enactment. An apt description of a city that never sleeps, a place where one comes to reinvent himself.

headline: Off the Menu, Bay Area Edition: Corey Lee’s New Restaurant
text: Corey Lee, who was the chef de cuisine at Thomas Keller’s French Laundry until August, when he resigned to open his own restaurant in San Francisco, is now on track to do just that. In late July he plans to open Benu. The name means “phoenix,” or rebirth, in ancient Egyptian.

headline: Cartel Papers Show Bribes to Mexican Authorities
text: MEXICO CITY — Internal documents from one of Mexico’s largest and most profitable drug trafficking cartels help explain why the group’s leader remains at large, nearly a decade after he boldly escaped from a maximum-security prison by hiding in a laundry cart.

headline: Looking for a Hole in Tax-Cutting Law’s Armor
text: In San Francisco, since the passage of Proposition 13, the property tax burden has shifted from commercial to residential property owners. In 1975, commercial property owners paid 59 percent of property taxes. Today, they pay 43 percent, according to Phil Ting, San Francisco’s assessor-recorder. That’s true even, though San Francisco’s population has remained relatively flat, and the city has seen a downtown building boom.

headline: Video of Prime Minister David Cameron’s First Remarks
text: The new British prime minister, David Cameron, made these remarks on Tuesday evening in London after he arrived at 10 Downing Street, his new residence (from Britain’s Channel 4 News):

headline: Google-AdMob Deal Gets Extended Federal Review
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google may have gotten some help from its rival Apple in its attempt to acquire the mobile advertising start-up AdMob.

headline: Off the Menu: Go Burger, BLT Burger’s Successor
text: After splitting with the chef Laurent Tourondel, Jimmy Haber, who now owns the BLT Restaurant Group with a new partner, has shed the BLT name for a new series of restaurants patterned after the BLT Burgers in New York, Hong Kong and Las Vegas. The company held an online contest in April for a new name, offering $4,000 to the winner. Go Burger is the winner. It is also the name of the company’s burger truck.

headline: A Road Trip to the End of the Road
text: Sterlin Harjo’s spare, cosmically solemn film “Barking Water” follows the road trip across Oklahoma made by an American Indian man and the woman he loved and left, who has come back at the end of his life to help him die. Their destination: Wewoka, capital of the Seminole nation. As the story begins, Frankie (Richard Ray Whitman), who is in the final stages of cancer, is wheeled from a hospital bed to a battered station wagon driven by his best friend and former lover, Irene (Casey Camp-Horinek).

headline: Disney’s Movie Studio: the Mouse That Roared
text: The Walt Disney Company’s movie studio roared back to life in the most recent quarter, with operating income increasing to $223 million from $13 million in the year-ago period. The only problem: executives who have since been fired were largely to thank.

headline: A Modern Touch to a Rural Cottage
text: The Schooltinks added a modern extension to their historically-registered cottage in the Netherlands.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Siberia and Elsewhere
text: As the mining city of Mezhdurechensk began to bury its dead on Tuesday, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin flew to the site of the disaster in western Siberia, vowing to discover whether human error or lax safety standards had contributed to one of the most lethal mine disasters here since the collapse of the Soviet Union.

headline: Newspaper Industry’s International Trade Group Cancels Its Annual Conference
text: PARIS — For the troubled newspaper business, another disappointment.

headline: The Bling Factor | ‘American Woman’ at the Met
text: The new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum’s Costume Institute, “American Woman: Fashioning a National Identity,” examines the evolution of style in this country and the appreciation of the breeze-easy female. Replacing the cosseted woman with a spirited American paradigm trumpeted more than the exchange of a corset for a shift dress, however. It sparked an upheaval in social etiquette: Women of independent means began buying their own jewelry. Fashion may have rattled the cage for change, yet it was gems and precious metals that broke the chains of Europe.

headline: Recycling With a Vengeance
text: Melena Ryzik reports from "Glassphemy," an interactive installation in Brooklyn that turns recycling into an experiment in therapy.

headline: Spun by Hoaxes
text: Video | Yo-yo faker who reportedly fooled Midwest TV stations …

headline: Manhattan Theater Club Announces 2010-2011 Productions
text: “The Pitmen Painters,” the hit British play about a group of miners who find a creative outlet that doesn’t involve ballet dancing or stripping off their clothes to music, will open the new season at Manhattan Theater Club in September. The play by Lee Hall (the screenwriter of “Billy Elliot” and a Tony Award-winner for its musical adaptation) will begin previews at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater on Sept. 14 and open on Sept. 30, the theater company said on Tuesday. As its producer Bob Boyett said in January, the play will transfer with its London cast as well as its director, Max Roberts.

headline: Bill Clinton Woos Donors on Wife’s Debt
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential race is long over, but her debt lives on.

headline: Einstein Looks Back, With Help From Puppets
text: The best thing I can say about “Breath on the Mirror,” now playing at La MaMa E.T.C., is that the show’s puppets are more expressive than its people. The worst part, as you may have guessed, is that the people have set the bar pretty low.

headline: CNN Pundit Draws Ire From All Sides
text: MACON, Ga. — In his seven weeks as one of CNN’s newest contributors, Erick Erickson has made scarcely more than a dozen appearances on the network.

headline: New Palin Book Set for November
text: Sarah Palin has chosen a title for her upcoming second book, her publisher announced on Tuesday: “America By Heart: Reflections on Family, Faith and Flag.”

headline: Does Poetry Matter?
text: Sometimes the planets align and you start seeing the same idea discussed by different people everywhere you look, as if your brain had stumbled late at night across a niche cable station broadcast by the universe itself. For me lately the show has been all about the relevance of poetry, as in: Is poetry relevant? Even among poets there seems to be a nervous consensus that it’s not.

headline: Starz to Produce ‘Spartacus’ Prequel
text: While the actor who plays the title character in the Starz drama “Spartacus: Blood and Sand” undergoes cancer treatments, the channel will produce a six-episode prequel to the series.

headline: Table Hopping | Ralph’s in Paris
text: Let’s just say I saw it coming. When the waitress at the furiously fashionable Ralph’s, the restaurant at the new Ralph Lauren boutique in Saint-Germain-des-Prés, threaded her way through the tight maze of brown leather armchairs in the snug, beamed dining room — complete with hunt-themed oil paintings and a gas fire — and placed a small bowl of deep-fried olives on the table, my friend Marie-Odile, a châtelaine in town for the day from Bordeaux, rolled her eyes. “Deep-fried olives!” she said. “Only you Americans would think of doing such a thing. You deep-fry everything, don’t you?”

headline: Iraqi Deal to End De-Baathification
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqi politicians have reached an agreement to halt a four-month campaign to bar candidates from politics for ties to the Baath Party, American and Iraqi officials said, papering over the sectarian tensions it unleashed, at least for now, and removing an obstacle in the long-delayed process of forming a new government.

headline: Classic Children’s Stories, With a Little Gender Bending Thrown In
text: It’s always nice to see a show that’s kid- and gay-friendly  why should audiences have to choose between bedtime stories and Lady Gaga, especially in Brooklyn, a borough that in recent years has had the dubious distinction of offering happy hours for moms?

headline: Kagan’s Video on White House Blog
text: White Houses usually keep their Supreme Court nominees under wraps, shunning all interviews. With Elena Kagan, the Obama White House made an exception.

headline: An Austrian Vacation Home
text: A seven-bedroom vacation home with a bell tower in the Salzkammergut region of Austria is on the market for 2.25 million euros ($2.85 million).

headline: A Software Fix for iPad Troubles
text: A software update to solve wireless network connectivity issues with some iPads will be forthcoming from Apple, but the company has not offered a time frame for the fix.

headline: House Hunting in ... Austria
text: A SEVEN-BEDROOM VACATION HOME WITH A BELL TOWER IN THE SALZKAMMERGUT REGION

headline: ‘Operation Mincemeat’
text: Chapter 1: The Sardine Spotter

headline: Floating a Wild Plan and a Dead Man to Defeat the Nazis
text: Excellent westerns have been composed by people who could barely ride a horse, and the best writers of sex scenes are often novelists you wouldn’t wish to see naked. But when it comes to spy fiction, life and art tend to collide fully: nearly all of the genre’s greatest practitioners worked in intelligence before signing their first book contract.

headline: Properties for $300,000
text: Properties in San Antonio, in Asheville, N.C., and Chicago.

headline: What You Get for ... $300,000
text: SAN ANTONIO

headline: Doubt Is Cast on Many Reports of Food Allergies
text: Many who think they have food allergies actually do not.

headline: In the Netherlands, When Modern Meets Fairy Tale
text: BAAK, the Netherlands  Melissa Schooltink-Hubers and Leon Schooltink’s cottage here in the rural Gelderland province, about a 20-mile drive from the city of Arnhem, sits in the middle of a fairy tale scene.

headline: Letters: Mind Over Meds
text: We agree with Daniel Carlat (April 25) that psychotherapy has an important place in the comprehensive treatment of individuals with psychiatric disorders. The divide between “brain-based” and “mind-based” training of young psychiatrists, however, is not always as wide as Carlat contends, even in research-focused departments like ours at Mass General.

headline: Just Looking | Edward Kienholz’s Roxys
text: When people say the art world is full of pimps and whores (which they do a bit less frequently now that hard times have struck), they’re usually referring to the slick dealers and artists who prostitute their talents for money. But there’s a whorehouse in Chelsea right now, and it doesn’t involve the well-oiled machinery of artistic success — the cavernous, pristine spaces of galleries where the staff’s sublime indifference suggests a substantial waiting list for the works on display.

headline: She Doesn’t Put Her Feet Up, but a Proper Woman Makes Herself at Home
text: Nancy Wilson, now 73, made her way slowly to the stage at the Blue Note on Monday, with the help of an assistant. She had a broken ankle, she explained; she sat on a chair to sing, and looked a little drained.

headline: In Japan, the Children Are Buying Bugs
text: While American children are buying Japanese action figures, Japanese children are buying bugs. That’s one lesson to be drawn from Jessica Oreck’s documentary “Beetle Queen Conquers Tokyo,” a guided tour of a national predilection that introduces us to insect stores, insect fairs, insect video games, insect vending machines and insect viewing areas.

headline: Poster Boy Sentenced to 11 Months in Prison for Vandalism
text: The street artist known as Poster Boy, who cuts up and rearranges subway posters, often to witty effect, won’t be riding the subway anytime soon. He’s at Riker’s Island, sentenced to 11 months for vandalism, the blog animalnewyork reported.

headline: Many Voices on the Road to Damascus
text: It must have been a rare alignment of the planets that produced a performance of Mendelssohn’s oratorio “Paulus” on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall, where the Boston Symphony Orchestra had performed its better-known sibling, “Elijah,” just five weeks before. Kent Tritle conducted the venerable Oratorio Society of New York, which had not performed the work since 1947, to close its 137th season.

headline: Tavern Talks Resume
text: Can Tavern on the Green be resurrected in our lifetime? Tuesday, for the second day, the designated new operator of the landmark restaurant in Central Park, Dean J. Poll, conducted negotiations with the Hotel and Motel Trades Council, which represents some 400 employees who have been looking for work since the restaurant shuttered early on Jan. 1.

headline: Facebook Executive Answers Reader Questions
text: Last week we asked readers to submit questions about Facebook and its approach to privacy, which Elliot Schrage, vice president for public policy at the company, had agreed to answer.

headline: A Composer Arguing With Plato
text: The composer Louis Andriessen’s pugnacious and exhilarating piece “De Staat” has a reputation as a milestone of avant-garde music in the later decades of the 20th century. Yet you hear about the work, composed in 1976, more than you actually hear it. For whatever reasons, it does not turn up often in concert.

headline: Black Men in America as Stressed-Out Strivers
text: “Run, black man, run,” Daniel Beaty says fiercely. “Run to your children  hold them tight.”

headline: New Help to Free Legs From a Web
text: LEG-BARING weather inspires come-out-of-hibernation rituals. The fake tan. The depilation of winter hair. The springtime jog, when even layabouts acknowledge that the season of calf definition is nigh.

headline: Dystopia Animated
text: The distinctive voices of Vincent Gallo and Juliette Lewis emerge from the lead characters in “Metropia” but provide no comfort: Tarik Saleh’s dystopian vision of a depleted, smog-engulfed, financially collapsed Europe in the year 2024 seems a touch too close to home. In any case, the real star here is the film’s eerily unsettling animation, a digitally manipulated photomontage that makes everyone look almost human  in a heavily medicated, genetically suspect kind of way.

headline: Strangers Find Solace From Riots Against U.S.
text: In the distinctive world of the Japanese playwright Toshiki Okada, actors do not perform a scene so much as circle it warily, introducing their roles, narrating and commenting on them, comparing notes on what happened before finally settling into a yarn.

headline: He’ll Find Something That’s Wrong With You
text: What if life itself were a pre-existing condition?

headline: Obama and Cameron: Vacation Dreams
text: President Obama made a call of congratulations on Tuesday to newly minted British Prime Minister David Cameron, saying that he “reiterated my deep and personal commitment to the special relationship between our two countries, a bond that has endured for generations and across party lines.”

headline: Finding Meaning in Cleaning
text: “The Immaculate Conception of Little Dizzle” is like “Clerks” reimagined by William S. Burroughs. Looking as if it were devised on acid and executed on mushrooms, this imaginative debut feature from the Seattle artist and filmmaker David Russo finds meaning in cleaning and life in dead ends.

headline: New Credit and Debt Tools From Jean Chatzky
text: Having trouble figuring out how exactly to improve your credit score or best pay off your debt? The personal finance author and television personality Jean Chatzky introduced two new tools Tuesday  to perform those functions.

headline: A Smashing Idea: Eco-Friendly Aggression
text: How do you one-up a Dumpster pool?

headline: British Election Tweet of the Day
text: In the end, a British election campaign that included many twists and turns concluded as so many have before, with a defeated prime minister walking out of 10 Downing Street to resign and a newly-minted one walking in through the same famous front door.

headline: Britain’s Coalition of Pain
text: London

headline: Environmental Action
text: If shopping for an examination of the science of climate change, or of the political and economic debates surrounding it, be warned: the title of this documentary is misleading. It concerns environmental action, yes, but only tangentially refers to the effects of global warming. Instead, the director, Brian Hill, has traveled the planet to assemble portraits of citizens who are thinking globally and acting locally.

headline: 4 Big Banks Score Perfect 61-Day Run
text: It is the Wall Street equivalent of a perfect game of baseball — 27 up, 27 down, the final score measured in millions of dollars a day.

headline: Drug Cases Are Scrutinized After Crime Lab Shortcuts
text: The apparent shortcuts taken by a New York Police Department criminalist in testing suspected drug samples left prosecutors throughout the city scrambling on Tuesday to find out how many cases might be affected and what to do about them.

headline: Artist Struts Her Stuff in Others’ Shoes
text: With “Walk the Walk,” a piece being staged during office hours in Bryant Park through Friday, the artist Kate Gilmore expands beyond the solo act that has characterized her performance work so far. In this it represents a big, courageous move, but that doesn’t keep it from feeling transitional and not quite up to her usual level.

headline: Dean Baker on the Housing Bubble
text: Dean Baker, co-director of the Center for Economic and Policy Research in Washington, D.C., on the Federal Reserve's response to the collapse of the housing market in 2007.

headline: What We’re Reading: The Future
text: The tech editors and reporters at the New York Times found these articles worth passing on to others:

headline: Ladies Loved
text: The British romantic comedy “My Last Five Girlfriends,” loosely based on the novel “On Love” by Alain de Botton, is all concept and very little comedy, beyond the occasional chuckle. Julian Kemp, the writer and director, tries to deflect attention from a thin script with a constant stream of storytelling devices: fake commercials, Barbie-doll dioramas, old movie clips, a talking stuffed elephant. Recurring scenes show the sad-sack hero, Duncan (Brendan Patricks), at a theme park based on his life, where the rides are named after his former lovers.

headline: Splashing Through Comedy
text: What is it about men and synchronized swimming that so reliably brings the funny? Many “Saturday Night Live” fans have never forgotten the 1984 sketch with Harry Shearer and Martin Short as brothers pursuing a dream of Olympic gold. (It was going to take some time, they conceded, especially since, the Short character noted, “I don’t swim.”)

headline: Lawsuit Against Cuban Calls Mavericks ‘Insolvent’
text: Mark Cuban’s financial management of the Dallas Mavericks was described as “reckless” in a lawsuit filed Monday in Texas by a minority investor in the team who accused the flamboyant billionaire owner of amassing net losses of $273 million and debt of more than $200 million, The New York Times’s Richard Sandomir reports.

headline: Off-Kilter and British
text: THEY buried Malcolm McLaren in a suit, a new one. At least, that’s what he’d asked for. Mr. McLaren, who died last month at 64, spearheaded punk music and style in London in the 1970s by cutting the Sex Pistols, jaggedly, more or less from whole cloth and by operating, with Vivienne Westwood, the boutique Sex, which offered the lifestyle to go — when the store could be bothered to open, anyway.

headline: ‘Glee’ Co-Creator Seeks Boycott of Newsweek After Article Criticizes Gay Actors
text: 3:35 p.m. | Updated

headline: Burger Blends That Taste Like Steak
text: For a burger blend like the ones that fussy chefs use, Dickson’s Farmstand Meats in Chelsea Market grinds a mix of short ribs and other cuts from Wrighteous Organics in Schoharie, N.Y. Dry aged, with about 20 percent fat, it makes for a burger with the flavor of a good steak and less shrinkage than other ground beef. For major grilling, Jake Dickson, above, sells it in what he calls a weekend burger pack. Another weekend package comes with Dickson’s own sausages and bacon, as well as the ground beef. And a barbecue package has several smoked cuts, ready for a quick reheating. All come in an insulated bag.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Openings

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Beer and Cheese

headline: Canteen 82
text: 467 Columbus Avenue (82nd Street), Upper West Side; (212) 595-4300.

headline: Rick Bayless, the Chicago Chef, to Prepare a State Dinner
text: FOR the Obama administration’s second state dinner, the White House has once again turned the cooking over to a guest chef. Rick Bayless has been asked to prepare the elegantly balanced, many layered Mexican food for which he has become famous at the dinner on May 19 that will honor President Felipe Calderón of Mexico.

headline: French-Press Coffee to Go
text: It’s unusual enough that the rough-hewn African coffee bar BKoffie freshly grinds beans only from Rwanda, Tanzania, Kenya and Ethiopia, and a house blend, and brews them to order. The real surprise comes when you get coffee to go, in a disposable French press cup with a sippable plunger lid. There are also African teas, including rooibos; fair trade chocolates; and condiments like chutneys, peri peri and a nicely funky fish spread from Cape Town called Peck’s Anchovette. BKoffie is the third outpost on West 51st Street from Tanya Hira, who, with her partners, opened the South African wine bar Xai Xai and Braai, a restaurant specializing in exotic meats like ostrich on the grill.

headline: A New Chocolate Sorbet to Savor
text: The latest addition to the menu at Dessert Club ChikaLicious is a silky, deeply intense yet refreshing chocolate sorbet, made with a new 80 percent cacao Coeur de Guanaja chocolate from Valrhona. It is a worthwhile indulgence plain, but to paint this lily with an ever-so-delicate hand, it is also served as a sandwich, between two snowy almond macaron shells, which add texture to the confection.

headline: Pairing a DVD and a Drink Takes Care
text: I COULD blame Don Draper, but if it was anyone’s fault, it was Robert Mitchum’s.

headline: Benefits
text: Helping Rwanda

headline: The Rise of Company Gardens
text: PURCHASE, N.Y.

headline: The White House Pastry Chef Revamps Sweets
text: Washington

headline: 21st-Century Mamie Eisenhower Cheesecake
text: Adapted from “The Perfect Finish” by Bill Yosses and Melissa Clark (W. W. Norton, 2010)

headline: Betel
text: 51 Grove Street (Bleecker Street), Greenwich Village; (212) 352-0460.

headline: Seminal Jasper Johns Painting Draws $28.6 Million Bid
text: One of Jasper Johns’s seminal Flag paintings, from 1960-1966, that had belonged to Michael Crichton, the best-selling writer, became the star of Christie’s post-war and contemporary art auction on Tuesday night when it brought $28.6 million.
