That figure was a record for the artist at auction, though the painting did not manage to beat the record for a work by a living artist, as many had speculated it might. (That record is held by Lucian Freud’s painting “Benefits Supervisor,” which sold for $33.6 million at Christie’s in New York two years ago.)

headline: Employees Only Bottles Its Cocktail Mixers
text: The folks at Employees Only have been working to improve your cocktail hour, at home and at the restaurant. The nonalcoholic syrups that Dushan Zaric and Jason Kosmas, the mixologists, are making for some cocktails are now sold retail. There’s a suitably tart lime cordial, a mix of lime juice, kaffir lime leaf and agave nectar for gimlets and lime rickeys. Their grenadine, used in a drink called the Billionaire, is dark and intense.

headline: Needing Offense, Mets Again Place Call to Buffalo
text: When Chris Carter entered the Mets’ clubhouse Tuesday, he became the third left-handed-hitting Buffalo Bison to be promoted to the major league roster this season.

headline: Flyers Counting on Backup Goalie
text: VOORHEES, N.J. — Michael Leighton said he thought he was 7 or 8 when he was called up to his older brother’s hockey team in Petrolia, Ontario, and was asked to play goaltender. He recalled that his team lost his first game, 8-0, but he told his parents how much he loved the position. So he stuck with it.

headline: Fatty ’Cue
text: FATTY ’CUE, Zakary Pelaccio’s funky new barbecue joint on South Sixth Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, looks like a biker bar for the kind of bikers who don’t ride Harleys in leathers and boots, but stripped-down Schwinns in boat shoes and skinny jeans.

headline: Will Increased Viewership Reach Beyond the Triple Crown?
text: Patrick Patten, author of the blog Handride, is part of a group called the Thoroughbred Bloggers Alliance.

headline: All Is Not Well in Rwanda
text: To the Editor:

headline: Who’s a Good Teacher?
text: To the Editor:

headline: On the Subject of Fatty ‘Cue
text: This week, Sam Sifton reviews Fatty ‘Cue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the chef Zak Pelaccio’s latest.

headline: The Door to Private School
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jewish Disagreement About Israel? Nothing New
text: To the Editor:

headline: Japan Starts to Shop Its Bullet Train Technology
text: TSURU, Japan — The experimental MLX01 maglev is the world’s fastest train. But it is confined to a 12-mile track. And like the train itself, its technology has been trapped in Japan.

headline: Decline Is Seen in NASA’s Research Side
text: WASHINGTON — The decline of basic research at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration jeopardizes the agency’s ability to study and explore the cosmos, a review panel of scientists and engineers said Tuesday.

headline: Ohio: Analysis Reopens Kent State Controversy
text: New analysis of a student’s audio recording from the shootings in which four student were killed at Kent State University in 1970 shows that Ohio National Guard troops received orders to fire into a crowd of unarmed students, according to two audio forensics experts. Six seconds before shots were fired, a National Guard officer is heard giving the command “All right, prepare to fire,” said Stuart Allen, one of the experts involved. The Cleveland Plain Dealer, which obtained a copy of the tape, asked Mr. Allen and a colleague to review it. The Ohio National Guard declined to comment. Terry Strubbe, the man who made the recording, disagrees with Mr. Allen’s findings. “It was a really bad recording,” Mr. Allen said. “It’s pure mud.”

headline: The Latest Score: Four Banks Played a Perfect Game
text: It is the Wall Street equivalent of a perfect game of baseball — 27 up, 27 down, the final score measured in millions of dollars a day. Despite the running unease in world markets, four giants of American finance managed to make money from trading every single day during the first three months of the year, The New York Times’s Eric Dash reports.

headline: At the Morgan, Gently Restoring a Treasure-Filled Building
text: When the Morgan Library & Museum reopened four years ago after undergoing a widely praised $106 million renovation and expansion, it seemed as if its problems had ended. Renzo Piano’s design, with its gleaming steel-and-glass entrance on Madison Avenue, soaring atrium, new gallery spaces and 280-seat auditorium, provided much needed space. It also gracefully linked the Morgan’s three disparate buildings and erased its awkward 1991 glass atrium.

headline: J. P. Morgan's Library
text: A look inside the building designed by Charles McKim in 1906 to house J. P. Morgan’s personal office and library. The Morgan Library & Museum is embarking on a $4.5 million project that will gently restore it.

headline: Drinking While Viewing
text: The Sazerac played a role in “The Curious Case of Benjamin Button.” Martinis abounded in the “Thin Man” movies. The Dude enjoyed his White Russians.

headline: Introducing the Really Green Card
text: It’s called a “green card,” but the identification that the authorities issue to lawful permanent residents has been white, pink, blue and beige — almost anything but green. Now it will be green, though that is the least high-tech feature of a redesign announced Tuesday by United States Citizenship and Immigration Services. The new card, which will replace those now in circulation as they are lost or renewed, incorporates holographic images, laser engraved fingerprints and radio frequency identification chips that will allow Customs and Border Protection officers at ports of entry to read the card from a distance.

headline: For Chernin, an Empire of His Own
text: LOS ANGELES — Ever since Peter A. Chernin left the News Corporation as Rupert Murdoch’s second in command, the media world has wondered what he would do next.

headline: Four Nerds and a Cry to Arms Against Facebook
text: How angry is the world at Facebook for devouring every morsel of personal information we are willing to feed it?

headline: A Derby Victory Is Nice, but at WinStar Farm, Business Is Business
text: They love their horses at WinStar Farm. The owners, Bill Casner and Kenny Troutt, have played at every level of horse racing. The farm’s top management, Doug Cauthen and Elliott Walden, grew up in the horse business. When Super Saver galloped home first in the Kentucky Derby on May 1, WinStar had reached horse racing’s mountaintop.

headline: Thrills and Traps, Lurking on the Web
text: To the Editor:

headline: I.M.F. Plays Deal Maker in Europe
text: ZURICH — The International Monetary Fund is ready to do deals.

headline: Filling a Roster Is Easier Than Filling the Net
text: And the United States thought things were gloomy, given that forward Charlie Davies has not recovered sufficiently from a serious car accident to play in the World Cup.

headline: Cross at Center of Legal Dispute Disappears
text: LOS ANGELES — A seven-foot-tall Latin cross in the middle of both the Mojave Desert and a Supreme Court case on the separation of church and state has been stolen, federal officials said Tuesday.

headline: Egyptian Emergency Law Is Extended for 2 Years
text: CAIRO — After years of the government’s promising to end Egypt’s state of emergency, Parliament on Tuesday approved a government request to extend for two years its right to arrest people without charge, detain prisoners indefinitely, limit freedom of expression and assembly, and maintain a special security court.

headline: Rivera Is Still Watching and Waiting
text: DETROIT — One of these days, Mariano Rivera will pitch again. He has not pitched since April 30, a stretch of nine games, and he missed another opportunity Tuesday when the Yankees’ game against the Tigers was rained out.

headline: In Newburgh, Gangs and Violence Reign
text: NEWBURGH, N.Y. — It started with adolescent taunting near a frozen pond on a January afternoon and soon escalated into a brawl.

headline: Gyllenhaal and Sarsgaard Work Together Again on Chekhov Play
text: If the Park Slope neighborhood of Brooklyn seems a little less cool next January, it may be because Maggie Gyllenhaal and Peter Sarsgaard, both at right, will simultaneously be out of town, at least for part of each day: the wife-and-husband actors will once again appear together in a production at the Classic Stage Company, that East Village theater company said on Tuesday. This time they will appear in Chekhov’s “Three Sisters,” reuniting Ms. Gyllenhaal and Mr. Sarsgaard with the director Austin Pendleton and their co-star Mamie Gummer from Classic Stage Company’s 2009 production of “Uncle Vanya.” The cast of “Three Sisters” will also include Ebon Moss-Bachrach and Josh Hamilton. The theater company will begin its season in September with Sarah Ruhl’s adaptation of Virginia Woolf’s “Orlando,” directed by Rebecca Taichman. Other productions include “Double Falsehood,” a play that scholars believe includes reworked material by Shakespeare, to be directed by Brian Kulick; and “School for Lies,” described as a “free-form, modern riff” on Molière’s “Misanthrope,” adapted by David Ives and directed by Walter Bobbie.

headline: Gulf Benefit to Feature Kravitz and Toussaint
text: Lenny Kravitz, left, is among the musicians with ties to Louisiana who will participate in a benefit concert to assist residents affected by the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Kravitz, who lives part time in New Orleans, was the first performer to commit to the benefit, called Gulf Aid, which is scheduled for Sunday at the Mardi Gras World River City there. Other artists expected to perform include Allen Toussaint (below), Mos Def, Ani DiFranco, the Voice of the Wetlands Allstars (including Tab Benoit, Dr. John and Cyril Neville) and the Preservation Hall Jazz Band. Tickets are $50 and will be sold through Elevate Tickets. The event, whose proceeds will go to organizations that help Gulf Coast fishermen and the area’s seafood industry, as well as those that address environmental issues, will also be broadcast on the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage radio station WWOZ-FM (90.7) and wwoz.org.

headline: Texas Officer Is Acquitted in Shooting
text: HOUSTON — A jury on Tuesday acquitted a white police officer accused of shooting a young black man in a case that attracted widespread attention in Texas because the victim’s family accused the police of racial profiling.

headline: Senators Demand Tighter Rules on No-Fly List and Addition to Terror Group List
text: WASHINGTON — After a briefing on the Times Square bombing attempt, the top Democrat and Republican on the Senate Intelligence Committee called Tuesday for improvements in the no-fly list and the addition of the Pakistani Taliban to the government’s official list of terrorist organizations.

headline: Before a Bridge Slices Through Vineyards, It Divides German Winemakers
text: ÜRZIG, Germany — Compared with Robert Eymael, Markus Berres is a new kid on the block. The vineyards that Mr. Eymael’s family works were first documented as early as 1177. Mr. Berres’s forebears are registered as vineyard owners only since 1510.

headline: Phoenix Counts Big Boycott Cost
text: Boycotts threatened or carried out over Arizona’s new immigration enforcement law could cost the Phoenix metropolitan area $90 million in hotel and convention business over five years, Mayor Phil Gordon said Tuesday.

headline: San Francisco Museum Picks Design Finalists
text: The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has selected four architectural firms as finalists to design its expansion. The finalists are Adjaye Associates; Diller Scofidio & Renfro; Foster & Partners; and Snohetta. In addition to tripling the museum’s gallery and public spaces, the expansion will showcase the Doris and Donald Fisher Collection of Modern and contemporary art. The project will also support enhanced exhibitions and educational programs, and improve public amenities. The final choice of architect will be announced in September, and initial design concepts will be unveiled in 2011. The expansion is slated for completion in 2016. In February the museum announced that it had raised more than $250 million toward its projected $480 million campaign goal to finance the expansion and build its endowment.

headline: Easy Win for ‘Dancing’
text: With its finalists narrowed to Erin Andrews, Evan Lysacek, Niecy Nash, Chad Ochocinco and Nicole Scherzinger, “Dancing With the Stars” topped the ratings on Monday as 19 million viewers tuned in to the ABC contest, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The network led the night over all, and its crime series “Castle” (11.4 million) finished ahead of both CBS’s “CSI: Miami” (11.1 million) and NBC’s “Law & Order” (6.2 million). CBS was the runner-up, drawing its largest audiences for its comedies “Two and a Half Men” (13.8 million) and “The Big Bang Theory” (13.6 million). Fox ranked third as “24” (8.5 million) inched closer to its series finale. NBC placed fourth as a new episode of “Chuck” (5.3 million) hit a ratings low for the series.

headline: Margaret Atwood Accepts Israeli Prize
text: Margaret Atwood, below, accepted the Dan David Prize at Tel Aviv University in Israel on Monday, telling an interviewer before the ceremony that to snub the honor would be tantamount to “throwing overboard the thousands of writers around the world who are in prison, censored, exiled and murdered for what they have published.” Ms. Atwood, the Canadian author of “The Year of the Flood” and a vice president of International PEN, the literary human rights group, shared the $1 million prize with the Indian writer Amitav Ghosh (“Sea of Poppies”). Before the awards ceremony, Ms. Atwood had been urged by Palestinian groups and writers from other countries not to accept the prize as a protest of Israel’s policies toward the Gaza Strip and its artists. But Ms. Atwood was not persuaded, telling Bloomberg News, “We don’t do cultural boycotts.” She added: “Artists don’t have armies. What they do is nuanced, by which I mean it is about human beings, not about propaganda positions.” The Dan David Prize, which its organizers describe as an award for people “who have made an outstanding contribution to humanity, in each of the three time dimensions: past, present, and future,” has previously been given to Tony Blair, Al Gore, Tom Stoppard, Amos Oz and Yo-Yo Ma.

headline: Revamped Microsoft Office Will Be Free on the Web
text: Microsoft has created a chimera in its new Office 2010 software, part desktop software and part Web app.

headline: Side by Side, but Divided Over Immigration
text: ALBUQUERQUE — As the Arizona Legislature steamed ahead with the most stringent immigration enforcement bill in the country this year, this state’s House of Representatives was unanimously passing a resolution recognizing the economic benefits of illegal immigrants.

headline: Carol Burnett to Host ‘SNL’? Fans Want It
text: Lorne Michaels, you’ve got no one to blame for this but yourself. You invite Betty White to host “Saturday Night Live” after hundreds of thousands of Facebook fans clamor for it  yielding a memorable show and strong ratings in the process  and you open the door for copycat campaigns to put other stars of a certain age onto your show. Already off and running is a Facebook page called “Carol Burnett to Host SNL (Please?)!” that is closely modeled on the site that helped Ms. White land a hosting spot on “SNL.” Its creator (who posted an image with Ms. Burnett and the “SNL” logo, above) writes that Ms. Burnett, the sketch comedian, Broadway star and author, “would be an outstanding choice to host ‘SNL,’ ” adding, “Icing on the cake would be a cameo appearance by Tim Conway!” As of Tuesday afternoon, more than 32,000 like-minded fans had signed on in agreement. But there’s not much influence they can exert right now: the “SNL” season finale, hosted by Alec Baldwin, is Saturday.

headline: ‘La Cage’ and ‘Fela!’ Take Shows on the Road
text: The Broadway revival of “La Cage aux Folles,” which racked up 11 Tony Award nominations last week  including one for best revival of a musical  will hit the road for a national tour starting in the fall of 2011, the show’s producers have announced. The revival of Jerry Herman and Harvey Fierstein’s musical, which opened April 18 at the Longacre Theater, stars Kelsey Grammer as Georges, Douglas Hodge as Albin and Robin De Jesús as Jacob. There is no word yet on the casting for the tour, said Jim Byk, a spokesman for the producers. The producers of “Fela!,” the story of the Nigerian activist and musician, which also earned 11 Tony nominations, plan to take it abroad and to Chicago; Dallas; Houston; Los Angeles; Minneapolis; Miami; Philadelphia; San Francisco; Tempe, Ariz.; and Washington. Overseas, look for engagements in Amsterdam; Paris; Toronto; Rotterdam, the Netherlands; and Sydney and Melbourne in Australia. Those stops for “Fela!,” which opened last November at the Eugene O’Neill Theater, are in addition to a previously announced special engagement at the National Theater in London this November.

headline: Golfer’s Death Stuns Friends and Family
text: MOBILE, Ala. — The practice range is where the women of the L.P.G.A. Tour gather early in the workweek to exchange gossip and girl talk. It is their water cooler, a usually festive place where beautiful swings compete with buoyant personalities for attention.

headline: Kissing Cousins
text: The past comes to us in tantalizing fragments — a bone here, a footprint there. But of all the fragments yet discovered, perhaps none is so tantalizing as the one published in the journal Science last week: the Neanderthal genome.

headline: Greece’s Newest Odyssey
text: Athens

headline: Dallas Braden: Mouth That Roared (Perfectly)
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Class A Stockton Ports opened a new ballpark in 2005, but the players still parked at the old one. The day of the first practice, Daric Barton and Richie Robnett, both first-round draft picks, rolled into the old lot and dropped off their cars: a Tahoe for Barton, a Range Rover with 24-inch rims for Robnett.

headline: Cameron Faces Challenges Beyond His Coalition
text: LONDON — The Conservative Party that David Cameron inherited in 2005 was a disoriented shadow of its once mighty self, riven by ideological disarray, wounded by endless power struggles and facing the bleak prospect of long-term unelectability.

headline: Regulators Dissect Trades, Searching for Cause of Plunge
text: WASHINGTON — Regulators examining the causes of the brief stock market free fall last Thursday are looking closely at heavy selling in the market for stock-index futures by a single trader, beginning 10 minutes before stock prices began to plummet.

headline: Where Gang Violence Devours Youths
text: In a small, run-down city on the Hudson, the murder rate is startling, and so is the young age of many of the victims and perpetrators.

headline: Rachael Ray and Senator Lobby for School Lunch
text: WASHINGTON — Rachael Ray’s signature smile evaporated during a car ride to the Capitol on Tuesday. None of her trademark catchphrases — “Yum-o” or “fantabulous” — tumbled from her mouth.

headline: The Path of the Jaguar
text: Animal conservation groups are working to establish pathways for big cats to travel through human-populated areas. One such corridor is in place for Costa Rica's jaguars.

headline: Common Thread in Failed Drug Tests Raises New Questions
text: The drugs tripped up Dodgers outfielder Manny Ramirez a year ago and just last month ensnared a young pitcher named Edinson Volquez. Then, last Friday, the same drugs derailed another athlete when the N.F.L. suspended Houston Texans linebacker Brian Cushing.

headline: Disney Movie Unit Drives Strong Results in Quarter
text: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company appears to be having some success in repairing its movie operation, but now its television business is springing a leak.

headline: A New York Bloc on the Supreme Court
text: The Supreme Court has some justices who are liberals and some who are conservatives. It has some who see themselves as strict constructionists and some who probably do not.

headline: The Evil of Lesser Evilism
text: WASHINGTON

headline: The Making of a Terrorist
text: One fate the conservative commentator Daniel Pipes doesn’t have to worry about is drowning in conceptual complexity. He keeps his theories simple. His theory about why Faisal Shahzad tried to blow up a bomb in Times Square last week is “jihadi intent.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Cuomo Sues Hedge Fund Over Madoff
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York on Tuesday charged a unit of Bank of New York Mellon and two former executives with fraud, saying they failed to disclose information that pointed to problems at Bernard L. Madoff Investments.

headline: Broader Horizons for South Dakota Senator
text: OXON HILL, Md. – Six years ago, he toppled a political giant. So what’s next for Senator John Thune?

headline: A Canadiens Rookie Emerges as a Stopper
text: PITTSBURGH — The moment was almost vintage Sidney Crosby. He was working the puck along the Montreal Canadiens’ end boards against the rookie defenseman P. K. Subban. Crosby then carried the puck up the side boards, abruptly changed directions and headed back into the corner and, finally, darted up the boards again.

headline: Our Inner Neanderthal
text: If things had gone differently, this editorial might have been written by a Neanderthal contemplating the discovery that a small but significant portion of his or her DNA was derived from ancestral humans, who lost out in the struggle for survival some 30,000 years ago. Things went the other way, and this editorial is being written by a human musing on the recent discovery that 1 percent to 4 percent of our human DNA is derived from Neanderthals.

headline: Specter, After Shift, Faces Fire From Both Sides
text: ALLENTOWN, Pa. — One year after leaving the Republican Party in the face of crumbling support, Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania is now fighting to avert rejection — and presumably the end of his career — at the hands of Democrats.

headline: In Greek Debt Crisis, Some See Parallels to U.S.
text: It’s easy to look at the protesters and the politicians in Greece — and at the other European countries with huge debts — and wonder why they don’t get it. They have been enjoying more generous government benefits than they can afford. No mass rally and no bailout fund will change that. Only benefit cuts or tax increases can.

headline: Dallas Braden Soaks in His Perfect Moment
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. – It was business as usual for Dallas Braden on Tuesday, if a routine workday includes reciting the Top Ten list for David Letterman. Yes, there were some jokes about A-Rod.

headline: Without Haney, Where Does Woods Turn?
text: With Hank Haney stepping down as Tiger Woods’s personal coach — a gracious move that spared both player and coach weeks of awkwardness as Woods reconfigures his game and moves on to another tutor — the next question becomes who will supplant Haney.

headline: To Help Jaguars Survive, Ease Their Commute
text: LAS LOMAS, Costa Rica — Héctor Porras-Valverdo tried to adopt a Zen attitude when he discovered recently that jaguars had turned two of his cows into carcasses.

headline: Some Surprises
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle works a little better in the newspaper. Six shaded boxes make more sense of the theme, but since neither Across Lite nor the New York Times Java applet can do shading, electronic solvers get circles instead. It still works. There’s also a difference in the 47 Across clue because Across Lite doesn’t handle superscripts either. My geeky XPF initiative is an attempt to reduce these restrictions by extending the digital definition of crosswords in a standard way. We’ll see how far I get.

headline: Mineral Agency’s Split Follows Nations’ Lead
text: When Interior Secretary Ken Salazar said Tuesday that he would insulate safety and environmental enforcement from the revenue-raising side of the agency that regulates offshore drilling in the United States, he was following in the footsteps of several other countries with extensive drilling operations.

headline: A Deal for Better Schools
text: When school officials and unions work together, students have a real chance to come out on top. That was clear this week when the State Education Department and New York’s teachers’ unions announced agreement on a rigorous teacher evaluation system.

headline: Is It Safe to Go Back In?
text: What could be worse than a 20-minute, 1,000-point drop in the stock market? A 20-minute, 1,000-point drop that defies explanation.

headline: A Proposal to End Shady Car Dealers
text: The tussling in Washington over financial regulation has focused on the merits and dangers of derivatives, establishing a procedure for the orderly liquidation of failed banks and setting up a new consumer protection agency.

headline: Booker Is Re-elected Newark Mayor
text: NEWARK — Declaring “a thunderous victory,” Cory A. Booker easily won re-election as Newark’s mayor on Tuesday, and at least seven of his allies on the nine-member Municipal Council appeared headed to victory.

headline: Industry Doesn’t Step Up
text: Who is to blame for last month’s catastrophic oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico? The other guy. At least that’s what three oil executives, predictably and cynically, told a Senate hearing on Tuesday.

headline: As Clinton Aide, Kagan Recommended Tactical Support for an Abortion Ban
text: WASHINGTON — Elena Kagan, President Obama’s nominee to the Supreme Court, once recommended to President Bill Clinton that he support a Democratic-sponsored ban on some late-term abortions as a way to defeat a stronger measure gaining momentum in the Senate.

headline: Court Nominee Figures in Midterm Campaigns
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court confirmation hearings for Solicitor General Elena Kagan are weeks away, but her nomination is already becoming a flash point in midterm Congressional campaigns as candidates in both parties try to exploit the coming court fight.

headline: Lakers and Suns Sweep Drama Aside
text: Nothing can contain Kobe Bryant or neutralize Steve Nash, except perhaps the Gregorian calendar and the N.B.A. itself.

headline: Veteran House Democrat Loses Seat in Primary
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Alan B. Mollohan of West Virginia, a veteran Democrat, on Tuesday became the first House incumbent to lose his seat this year when he was handily defeated in a hard-hitting primary by State Senator Mike Oliverio.

headline: Relatives of Kurds Executed in Iran Are Denied the Remains, and 2 Are Arrested
text: The authorities in Iran have refused to allow the families of five Kurdish activists hanged on Sunday to bury them, and have arrested the sister and mother of the only woman among the executed, one of the activists’ lawyers said Tuesday.

headline: A Tough Observer of Climate Prescriptions
text: The latest online column from Richard Black of the BBC demonstrates why he’s at the top of the heap among those of us trying to make sense of global climate trends and diplomacy. He deconstructs the merits and drawbacks of the Hartwell Paper, an endeavor by a variegated crew of economists, political scientists and others to chart a reality-based path toward limiting risks from climate extremes while, in the long haul, curbing emissions of greenhouse gases.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Despite Recalls, Toyota Reports $1.2 Billion Profit
text: TOKYO — Despite being mired in recalls and inquiries into its safety record, Toyota roared back to a profit in the fiscal year that just ended and forecast on Tuesday a further increase in earnings.

headline: An Indian Chess Grandmaster, the World Champion Since 2007, Retains His Title
text: The chess world has a new king, and he is the same as the old king.

headline: Mets Ask for Offense, and a Newcomer Answers
text: During spring training, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel nicknamed Chris Carter the Animal because Carter arrived for work by 7 a.m. and displayed relentless desire.

headline: Job Offer for Noted Spanish Judge
text: Spain’s well-known investigating magistrate, Baltasar Garzón, left, who is being prosecuted in a case filed by far-right Spanish groups, has been offered a temporary post as an external adviser to the prosecutor at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, a court official there said. The judge gained an international reputation as a fearless prosecutor of cases including those on Basque and Islamist terrorism, drug traffickers and the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet. Mr. Garzón was indicted last month on charges of abusing his powers. He has denied the charges.

headline: Sleeping Under the Stars in Brooklyn
text: As a frequent traveler, I’ve spent many, many hours in airports: departing, arriving, eating and enduring layovers. Generally, though, I’ve been lucky. Never have I had to spend the entire night in an airport — no snuggling up on hard plastic benches, no sprawling in an unused corner, no erecting a makeshift tent out of blankets, dead-battery iPods and plastic bags.

headline: Indian Official to Visit Pakistan
text: In another sign of expanding diplomacy between India and Pakistan, the Indian external affairs minister, S. M. Krishna, will travel to Islamabad, the Pakistani capital, in July to address the “trust deficit” between the nuclear-armed neighbors. Mr. Krishna’s trip is scheduled for July 15. Mr. Krishna will meet his Pakistani counterpart, Shah Mehmood Qureshi, as the two countries try to address a long and contentious list of issues ranging from terrorism to water rights to the contested region of Kashmir.

headline: Conservatives for Higher Taxes
text: Change often happens slowly.

headline: Chile: Pakistani Still in Custody
text: A Santiago court on Tuesday extended the detention of a Pakistani man arrested Monday after traces of explosive material were found on his belongings as he entered the American Embassy there. Embassy officials initially detained Mohamed Saif ur-Rehman, who is 28 years old, after security-screening equipment detected the explosive residue on papers he was carrying, said Paul E. Simons, the American ambassador to Chile. The man had gone to the embassy to deal with a “visa issue,” Mr. Simons said.

headline: Arlen Specter’s Advertisement
text: Senator Arlen Specter started running this advertisement on Tuesday. It will be shown in Pennsylvania.

headline: An Unusual Housing Opportunity
text: San Francisco will soon have a 154-unit luxury apartment building inside the Presidio, a former military base that is now a 1,500-acre national park.

headline: Luxury Rentals Help National Park Pay Its Own Way
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Renters here will soon have an unusual housing option: a 154-unit luxury apartment building inside a national park. For the last 30 years, the property was an abandoned hospital covered in graffiti, where trespassers caroused in operating rooms and shot photos of empty drawers in the morgue.

headline: Joe Sestak’s Advertisement
text: Representative Joe Sestak started running this advertisement last week.

headline: Karzai Visits Washington, With Smiles All Around
text: WASHINGTON — Beneath twinkling chandeliers and amid tables of pastry and crudités, the Obama administration set out Tuesday to charm President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, rounding up cabinet members and other V.I.P.’s to welcome him and his ministers at a State Department reception.

headline: South African Youth Leader Is Given a Mild Punishment After a Series of Gaffes
text: JOHANNESBURG — Julius Malema, the inflammatory president of the governing party’s youth league, was given a mild punishment by party elders on Tuesday after a disciplinary hearing that many here once expected to yield a far harsher comeuppance.

headline: Cleveland Boos James as Celtics Dominate
text: CLEVELAND — If this was goodbye, it lacked any sentiment, affinity or warmth. If LeBron James is destined to leave the Cleveland Cavaliers, he will have departed in a fog of disappointment, to a shocking chorus of boos.

headline: Photo Replay: May 11
text: A view of the day in sports, including the opening of the Nascar Hall of Fame in Charlotte, N.C., tennis in Madrid and ice hockey in Germany.

headline: At Christie’s, a $28.6 Million Bid Sets a Record for Johns
text: It was an all-American moment at Christie’s on Tuesday night. One of Jasper Johns’s seminal “Flag” paintings, from 1960-66, which had belonged to the writer Michael Crichton, became the star in the auction house’s postwar and contemporary art auction, selling for $28.6 million.

headline: Shifting Fortunes of Cellphones
text: Video may have killed the radio star. But in the cellphone wars, it’s the computing industry that is destroying the former leaders of the handset sector, namely Nokia and Motorola, whose roots lie in the wireless radio business.

headline: Andor Lilienthal, a Chess Grandmaster, Dies at 99
text: Andor Lilienthal, the last of the original 27 chess grandmasters, who played 10 world champions and beat 6 of them, died Saturday at his home in Budapest. He was 99.

headline: Outdoor Concert
text: In the sixth installment of Ozier Muhammad’s series, “Sounds From Uncommon Spaces,” we meet Chris Washburne, a trombonist and an assistant professor of ethnomusicology at Columbia University. He often practices in Morningside Park. His remarks, to Mr. Muhammad, have been condensed and edited for brevity and clarity.

headline: Mets Get to Nationals’ Clippard
text: 11:43 p.m. | Updated The Mets brought Nationals reliever Tyler Clippard back to earth on Tuesday.

headline: Iran: Diplomat Is Attacked
text: Pakistan’s ambassador to Iran, Mohammad Bakhsh Abbassi, was wounded and taken to a hospital in northern Tehran on Tuesday after a 21-year-old Afghan man assaulted him with a knife, the ISNA student news agency reported, quoting the Foreign Ministry spokesman, Ramin Mehmanparast. Reports about the attack were contradictory and it was unclear how seriously Mr. Abbassi was hurt; the semiofficial news agency Fars said he was at home and in good condition; earlier reports said he was in the hospital. ISNA reported that the assailant was arrested. His motives were unclear.

headline: Mother Tosses Child Into River and Then Jumps In, Police Say
text: A 33-year-old Upper West Side woman was charged with attempted murder after she threw her 19-month-old daughter into the Hudson River on Tuesday and then jumped in herself, the authorities said.

headline: Super Bowl Bid Exalts New York, and Winter
text: There could be the commissioner’s party at the American Museum of Natural History and another party with a view of the Statue of Liberty from Liberty State Park. Maybe a breakfast at Tiffany & Company for team owners and their families. Perhaps even a Super Bowl float in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.

headline: The Euro in 2010 Feels Like the Ruble in 1998
text: MOSCOW — As the financial markets try to absorb news of a rescue package for Greece and other teetering euro-zone economies, some bankers and economists see parallels to Russia’s default in 1998.

headline: Program to Combat Asthma Would Lean on Landlords
text: For decades, public health experts have tried — and mostly failed — to contain an asthma epidemic that afflicts many New Yorkers living in the city’s poorest neighborhoods.

headline: Word of the Day | gamely
text: gamely •\ˈgam-le\• adverb

headline: Fifth Deadly Attack on a School Haunts China
text: BEIJING — Gates and cameras have been installed at schools. Security guards have been trained to fend off knife-wielding attackers. China’s top security official convened a nationwide conference call, ordering underlings to protect children when they attend classes.

headline: A Scenic Village That Knew What It Wanted, and Got It
text: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y. — A decade ago, this suburb in southern Westchester County, where well-kept 1920s Tudor and colonial houses command some of the highest prices in the county, was home to a blighted industrial area bordering the Bronx to the south and Mount Vernon to the west.

headline: Mistrial in Brooklyn Hate Crime Case
text: After more than three days of jury deliberations, a holdout juror prompted a mistrial Tuesday night in the hate crime trial of a Brooklyn man accused of beating an Ecuadorean immigrant to death.

headline: Robust Economy, Back to Prerecession Levels, Forces Beijing Into a Balancing Act
text: SHANGHAI — Data from China released on Tuesday showed explosive growth in some segments of the country’s economy, renewing concerns that Beijing may have to do more to prevent it from overheating.

headline: Serving Up Musical Comfort Food
text: MADISON AVENUE is alive with the sound of “The Sound of Music” — and other mainstay musicals like “Carousel,” “The King and I,” “Oklahoma” and “South Pacific” — as more than a dozen marketers use songs by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein II in commercials.

headline: News Quiz | May 12, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Terra Firma Is Expected to Avoid a Debt Default
text: Terra Firma, the private equity firm that owns EMI, is confident it will meet its debt obligations to Citigroup into next year, forestalling a default by the music company, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: I.M.F. Plays Deal Maker in Europe
text: The International Monetary Fund is ready to do deals.

headline: Market Inquiry Focuses on One Trader
text: Regulators examining the causes of the brief stock market free fall last Thursday are looking closely at heavy selling in the market for stock-index futures by a single trader, beginning 10 minutes before stock prices began to plummet, Edward Wyatt and Graham Bowley report in The New York Times.

headline: Doris E. Travis, Last of the Ziegfeld Girls, Dies at 106
text: For a quarter century, Florenz Ziegfeld auditioned hundreds of thousands of young women vying to become chorus girls, the Ziegfeld Girls, those lace and chiffon visions of glamour who were as much a part of the Jazz Age as Stutz Bearcats, the Charleston and F. Scott Fitzgerald.

headline: The Euro in 2010 Feels Like the Ruble in 1998
text: As the financial markets try to absorb news of a rescue package for Greece and other teetering euro-zone economies, some bankers and economists see parallels to Russia’s default in 1998, Andrew E. Kramer reports in The New York Times.

headline: In Greek Crisis, Some See Parallels to U.S. Debt
text: It’s easy to look at the protesters and the politicians in Greece — and at the other European countries with huge debts — and wonder why they don’t get it. They have been enjoying more generous government benefits than they can afford. No mass rally and no bailout fund will change that. Only benefit cuts or tax increases can.

headline: Britain Called Stingy on Euro Support
text: Britain’s neighbors accused it of shortsightedness on Tuesday for stinting on contributions to a rescue package aimed at staving off a broader financial crisis in countries that use the euro, James Kanter reports in The New York Times.

headline: Terra Firma Is Expected to Avoid Debt Default
text: Terra Firma, the private equity firm that owns EMI, is confident it will meet its debt obligations to Citigroup into next year, forestalling a default by the music company, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Possible New Coach For Woods
text: With Hank Haney stepping down as Tiger Woods’s personal coach, sparing player and coach weeks of awkwardness as Woods reconfigures his game and moves on to another tutor — the next question becomes who will supplant Haney. One name that has quickly surfaced is Sean Foley, a golf teacher based in Orlando, Fla., not far from Woods’s home.

headline: Prokhorov to Take Over Nets
text: As expected, the N.B.A. board of governors approved the Russian billionaire Mikhail D. Prokhorov’s deal to be the new majority owner of the Nets. The approval was unanimous among the teams that voted. One team, the Chicago Bulls, did not vote.

text: Crystal Bowersox > Michael Lynche > Casey James > Lee DeWyze

headline: Spansion Gets Investment From Silver Lake Sumeru
text: Silver Lake Sumeru, the middle-market investment group of private equity firm Silver Lake, said Tuesday that it invested in the flash memory drive maker Spansion, which just completed a reorganization related to its filing for bankruptcy protection more than a year ago. The size of the investment was not disclosed, The Associated Press said.

headline: Bangkok Protest Leaders Appear Divided
text: BANGKOK — Protest leaders appeared deeply divided late Wednesday over whether to end their long occupation of Bangkok’s commercial center, in the face of a warning by the government that it might soon use force against them.

headline: A Martian Moment

You’ll find the search box in the upper right corner of the opening page. If you believe your picture wasn’t posted, we urge you to give this a try.

headline: Gold Hits Fresh High as Uncertainty Prevails
text: Gold hit another record high on Wednesday, while Asian stock markets slipped further and the euro remained under pressure — all signs of the intense nervousness that continues to dog the global financial markets despite the massive rescue package to combat the European debt crisis.

headline: Google-AdMob Deal Gets Extended Federal Review
text: Google may have gotten some help from its rival Apple in its attempt to acquire the mobile advertising start-up AdMob.

headline: Jet Crashes in Libya; Boy Is Said to Be Sole Survivor
text: PARIS — A young boy appeared to be the only survivor on Wednesday after a Libyan airliner crashed while landing at the airport in Tripoli, Libya, killing 92 passengers — most of them Dutch tourists — and 11 crew members, Libyan and Dutch officials said.

headline: Samsung Life Bucks I.P.O. Trends in Debut

headline: A.I.G. Reassures on A.I.A. Deal, Report Says

text: The sales of 15 venture capital-backed companies last week suggests that the I.P.O. market has finally begun to twitch back into life, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing research from VentureSource.

headline: Chinese Education Company Plans $100 million I.P.O
text: Global Education & Technology Group, the Chinese education company, is planning an initial public share offering of about $100 million on the Nasdaq by the end of the year, Reuters reported, citing a source with direct knowledge of the deal.

headline: Which Photo is One in Ten Thousand?
text: More than 10,000 people around the world snapped a picture at 11:00 a.m. EST on Sunday, May 2, as part of the Lens blog’s “A Moment in Time” project. What do the photos convey to you about the world? Which is your favorite?

headline: Morgan Stanley Said to Face C.D.O. Scrutiny
text: The investigation into post-crisis Wall Street has expanded as federal prosecutors have begun examining whether Morgan Stanley misled  investors and bet against mortgage-derivative deals that it had  helped create, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Zlotys From Heaven: PZU Soars After Record I.P.O.
text: PZU, Poland’s biggest insurer, saw its shares pop its market debut Wednesday morning, after investors clamored for a piece of Europe’s biggest initial public offering since 2007, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Partaking of Istanbul’s Spring Bounty
text: There’s seasonal cooking and, at least during spring in Turkey, there’s micro-seasonal cooking. As if waiting for the arrival of summer and its bounty of fresh fruit is too much to bear after a long winter, this time of year sees Turkey’s fruit and vegetable stands filling up with produce — tangy, unripe green plums, fresh almonds still in their fuzzy pods, loquats both tart and sweet — that offers a glimpse of coming attractions.

headline: Was There Good Reason for a Housing Boom?
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.Several factors regarding housing supply and demand have changed since the turn of the century and will change in the years to come, in the direction of increasing the nation’s housing inventories. As a result, at least part of the construction boom of the last 10 years served a legitimate economic purpose.

headline: Spain Outlines New Budget Cuts
text: MADRID — Calling for a “collective national effort” to restore investor confidence in Spain’s finances, Prime Minister José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero presented sweeping spending cuts Wednesday, reversing past promises to spare pensions and public-sector salaries from the knife.

headline: Double-Down Hypocrisy
text: Today’s idea: When a fast-food chain comes out with a bacon-and-glop sandwich with fried-chicken patties as buns, we’re outraged. But when a mom-and-pop diner does the same thing or worse, we say, ”What a quaint slice of Americana.”

headline: Fidelity National Deal Could Be $15 Billion
text: A private equity deal for Fidelity National Information Services, currently being negotiated, could be worth around $15 billion if a buyout is agreed, Bloomberg News and Reuters reported, each citing a source familiar with the situation.

headline: Net-Worth Obsession
text: Joey Kincer is the kind of guy who likes to keep records. Kincer is a 32-year-old Web developer who lives in San Juan Capistrano, southeast of Los Angeles, and among the things he tracks on his personal home page at kinless.com are his collection of action figures based on the Mega Man video games (“Not for sale,” the site warns sternly), the piano awards he received as a child (“My mom kept track of them all,” he says) and a photo gallery of female celebrity crushes that he refers to as his Dream Team.

headline: Sampler: Audit Criticizes Muni Overtime Pay, and Palin Fallout
text: Audit Finds Considerable Overtime at Muni | Muni could save $3 million annually by reining in overtime, according to an audit by the San Francisco Board of Supervisors’ budget analyst. Muni experiences a high level of absenteeism among its drivers, making service less reliable, in part because of incentives in the way that they are paid. Now, drivers can work overtime – earning time-and-a-half pay – even if they have not worked 40 hours in a week. That rule creates a financial incentive for drivers to skip work on regular workdays and to work overtime on other days, the audit found. The beleaguered transit agency recently cut service 10 percent. The Transport Workers Union’s contract expires on June 30, 2011. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

headline: The Private and Public Side of Goldman’s New Digs
text: “Strictly enforcing one’s privacy — at a time when so much goes public as fast at it happens — may be the ultimate public display of power, and thus the most erotic,” The New York Times art critic Roberta Smith mused in a Week in Review piece about the mystery bidder who paid $106.5 million for a 1932 Picasso last week.

headline: Will Harbinger Make a Play for Inmarsat?
text: Speculation is growing among British traders that Harbinger Capital Partners, the New York hedge fund run by Philip Falcone, may make a play for Inmarsat, the British satellite group, The Guardian reported.

headline: Britain’s Improbable New Leaders Promise Big Changes
text: LONDON — The leaders of Britain’s bold new experiment in coalition government flung off their differences and stood side by side on Wednesday, promising to act in concert to promote economic stability, reform the country’s frayed political system and demonstrate that their unlikely arrangement is more than just a hasty marriage of necessity.

text: Thomson Reuters and the company that owns Politico are among the potential suitors that have expressed interest in buying Newsweek from The Washington Post Company, The New York Observer reported, citing unnamed sources.

headline: Update: Fishing Shrivels as Slick Advances
text: The area of the Gulf of Mexico that is off limits to fishing grew yet again on Tuesday as federal officials invoked emergency powers to close down thousands of additional square miles in advance of the oil slick spreading from an undersea well blowout.

text: Talk that that market for mergers and acquisitions may be headed for a revival is no doubt cheery news for banks that advise such deals.

headline: A Piece of Racing History, Under a Tarp
text: A rusty racecar that has been sitting under a tarpaulin in the yard of an Arlington, Va., home for close to 47 years is apparently a long-lost classic. The auction house Bonhams says its research shows that the vehicle is a Vauxhall 30-98, which once raced with distinction at the Brooklands circuit in England.

headline: Places Where Metal Behaves Strangely: The Twitterverse Responds to ‘Lost’
text: One of the more enjoyable experiences that Twitter makes possible is seeing a conversation come together around a cultural moment – like, say, the third-to-last episode of “Lost,” which in recounting the back story of its god-like characters Jacob and the Man in Black left a lot of viewers feeling alternately baffled and disappointed. (Surely the Germans have a single word to describe the sensation.)

headline: The Loveliest Humps West of Abu Dhabi
text: “Before oil, people used to depend on camels for milk, meat, transportation — and even currency; there was nothing without camels,” said Salem al Mazrouie, the director of the Mazayna (or Camel Beauty Contest), part of the Al Dhafra Festival, held annually in the United Arab Emirates in the desert about two hours west of Abu Dhabi.

text: What will Britain’s Conservative-Liberal Democrat coalition government mean for the country’s finance industry?

headline: Taking a Look Inside a Family Business
text: I have been introduced to a woman named Marilyn Jones who owns Consolidated Printing in Chicago. She has been credited with being a pioneer in the “green” printing industry. As a matter of fact, Debra Jacobson of the Printer’s National Environmental Assistance Center has called her the “mother of the green printing movement.”

headline: Gold Jumps as Wall Street Steadily Rises

We asked readers to share photos of amusingly translated or otherwise quirky signs that they’ve found during their travels. Browse through the collection.

headline: Full Text of British Coalition Agreement and Video of Cameron and Clegg News Conference

headline: Wednesday Reading: Fresh Vegetables as Office Perk
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: A Lower East Side History Show, in the First Person
text: Thursday night at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, there will be a show of Rebecca Lepkoff’s gorgeously gritty photographs of daily life in the neighborhood in the 1930s and ’40s. The occasion is the publication of the paperback edition of Ms. Lepkoff’s 2006 book “Life on the Lower East Side.”

headline: Accommodating Differing Tastes at a Single Meal
text: A single set of aromatics can be the foundation of two parallel dinners – or as many as you have skillets: a useful principle for anyone who might need to accommodate differing tastes at a single meal.

headline: Learning to Live With Big Cats
text: As I note in my article in The Times today, some large threatened species need mobility — a chance to roam far and wide. Preserves or sanctuaries are not enough to ensure long-term survival. My article focused mainly on jaguars, but the cheetah is another good example.

headline: Diet and Exercise to the Extremes
text: I went running with Scott Jurek on a clear, chilly morning last month, an easy four-mile loop in Central Park. He ran another few miles with 50 or so adoring fans, then another few by himself, for a total of about 15. After that he showered and came to my house to cook lunch before going for a late-afternoon jog of another 10 miles or so.

headline: Wal-Mart Gives $2 Billion to Fight Hunger
text: The Wal-Mart Corporation announced plans Wednesday to contribute $2 billion in cash and food to the nation’s food banks, one of the largest corporate gifts on record.

headline: Comedy Central Won’t Renew ‘Sarah Silverman Program’
text: Unlike some of her Comedy Central brethren Sarah Silverman never made an episode of her show that elicited ominous messages from shadowy groups – her only sin was producing a series that grew too expensive for that cable channel to produce. (O.K., and possibly showing a man deriving illicit pleasure from a toy train. And casting Ed Asner as a Nazi officer.) But those days are no more: Comedy Central said on Wednesday that it was not picking up “The Sarah Silverman Program” for a fourth season, confirming a report that appeared in The Hollywood Reporter.

headline: On Capitol Hill, Kagan Makes the Rounds
text: Elena Kagan began the time-honored ritual of Supreme Court nominees on Wednesday, making courtesy calls to senators without saying a word, at least not in public.Ms. Kagan, the solicitor general, arrived shortly before 10 a.m. at the office of Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic leader, where the two posed briefly for the cameras in Mr. Reid’s elegant Capitol Hill suite, just steps from the Senate chamber.

headline: ‘Worst Toy of the Year’ Goes to a Nickelodeon Web Site

headline: The American Power Act

headline: The Phenomenon of Child-Headed Households
text: In response to Nick’s April 10 column featuring a family of orphans in Zimbabwe, over 100 readers wrote in asking what they could do to make a difference. Many readers, for example, wanted to send a bicycle to the oldest brother to expedite his nine-mile trek to school. Organizations like World Bicycle Relief are trying to make this dream a reality.

headline: Hertz Plugs Into the Nissan Leaf
text: Hertz is adding the Nissan Leaf battery electric-vehicle to its rental fleets in the United States and Europe beginning early next year, shortly after the car rolls out internationally.

headline: Telling Patients the Whole Truth
text: During a recent shift, I decided to call “a code,” which brings in the rapid response team. My patient’s heart was racing and his breathing had become intensely labored. Also he’d just moaned: “I’m gonna die in this bed.”

headline: Beauty Spots
text: FRAGRANCE TEST A new report found 38 undisclosed ingredients in 17 name-brand fragrances. Lab tests of the fragrances were commissioned by the Campaign for Safe Cosmetics and analyzed by the Environmental Working Group. The report’s authors cautioned that some perfumes and colognes contain secret ingredients that are “not assessed for safety.” The report can be found at ewg.org/notsosexy. CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS

headline: Trashing Day in Cleveland
text: Normally, aside from a Game 7, a single game in the playoffs means little on its own. Sure, people freak out when a star player stumbles or a favorite blows a lead, but usually things stabilize over time and the bandwagon-jumping looks ridiculous in hindsight.

headline: Canon Puts a Bright Lens in Your Pocket
text: Somehow, every time I’ve read online reviews of Canon’s PowerShot S90 I’ve found myself hovering over the “Buy” button at Amazon. The reason? The S90’s lens has a maximum aperture of F/2.0, a remarkably wide aperture for a point-and-shooter. (It’s also gotten a lot of great reviews.)

headline: New York-Based ATO Pictures Turns to Distribution

headline: Batter Up: PBS Sets Dates for Ken Burns’s Follow-Up to ‘Baseball’
text: As a baseball great once said, “It ain’t over till it’s over,” and in the case of the Ken Burns documentary “Baseball,” it ain’t over yet. In September PBS will broadcast a new documentary called “The Tenth Inning,” directed by Mr. Burns and Lynn Novick, that will continue the story begun by Mr. Burns’s 1994 film about the great American pastime. “The Tenth Inning,” which will be shown in two parts on Sept. 28 and 29, will track baseball’s history from the 1990s to the present, including the 1994 strike; the home-run-record  chases of Mark McGwire, Sammy Sosa and Barry Bonds; the use of performance-enhancing drugs in the sport; the re-ascenscion of the New York Yankees; the long-awaited World Series victory of the Boston Red Sox; and the sport’s reaction to the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

headline: And the Banana Goes To...

headline: Another Challenger for Espada

headline: The Midwest of Africa

headline: Elena Kagan, Creature of the System
text: Most of what I’d be inclined to say about the nomination of Elena Kagan to the Supreme Court was said quite eloquently by my colleague David Brooks in his Monday column. As a supplement to Brooks’ assessment of Kagan as “a person whose career has dovetailed with the incentives presented by the confirmation system, a system that punishes creativity and rewards caginess,” I recommend Matt Yglesias’s post comparing Kagan to John Roberts, another pick whose career was tailored to the current confirmation process — and then Yglesias’s follow-up post making the case for a very different system, featuring term limits for justices rather than lifetime tenure. Under the current system, he notes:

headline: South Koreans Put In Most Hours
text: South Koreans work the longest hours of any industrialized country’s labor force, according to a report from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

text: Today, Britain forms its first coalition government since World War II, nine are killed in another attack on Chinese schoolchildren, and Facebook is under pressure over its privacy policies.

headline: New York Minorities More Likely to Be Frisked
text: Blacks and Latinos were nine times as likely as whites to be stopped by the police in New York City in 2009, but, once stopped, were no more likely to be arrested.

headline: We Interrupt Your Western Conference Playoffs for a Delay

headline: The Price of Stardom
text: A sure-fire formula for success on Broadway has been as elusive as the recipe for eternal youth. In recent years, though, it has emerged that the most reliable equation for a big box office demands a big name as one of its integers.

headline: A Childhood Shaped by the Bay Area and Its Food
text: “Cakewalk,” a new sugar-infused memoir by Kate Moses, is a collection of snapshots from her bittersweet childhood. From the smells of Sonoma to the unique treats of San Francisco, the book captures the culinary experience of the Bay Area in the 1960s and 1970s from the perspective of a child hungry for all things sweet and crumbly.

headline: HBO Plans Film of ‘The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks’
text: Henrietta Lacks, the Baltimore woman who died never knowing that her cancer cells would become the building blocks for countless medical studies and treatments, will live on in a film being developed for HBO. On Wednesday the cable channel said that its HBO Films division had acquired the rights to “The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks,” the nonfiction book by Rebecca Skloot, for a movie whose executive producers will include Oprah Winfrey and Alan Ball (“Six Feet Under,” “True Blood”). In her book Ms. Skloot chronicles the life of Ms. Lacks,  whose cancerous cervix cells were cultured without her permission, and travels with her daughter Deborah from the former slave quarters where Henrietta grew up to the “colored” ward of the hospital where she received scarring radiation treatments for her cancer. No casting or debut date for the HBO film was announced.

headline: On Our Radar: A Whale in the Atlantic?
text: A gray whale appears off the coast of Israel. (The first seen outside the Pacific for centuries, it may have reached the Atlantic through an ice-free Northwest Passage before arriving in the Mediterranean.)

headline: Pompidou Center Opens Branch in Metz
text: The Pompidou Center in Paris — home to France’s National Museum of Modern Art — opened the doors on Wednesday to its first provincial branch, in Metz, a small city 170 miles east of Paris. The new museum, which cost $89 million,  according to the Pompidou Center, is part of an effort to expand the display of government-owned art beyond Paris’s large museums. With no permanent collection, Pompidou-Metz will depend on loans from the mother house and other institutions. Its first show, “Chefs-d’Oeuvre?,” is meant to trace the meaning of masterpieces from the Middle Ages through a large swath of the 20th century.

headline: From Atlanta to Europe to ‘Fela!’
text: SAHR NGAUJAH was a stranger to Broadway when he and “Fela!” arrived at the Eugene O’Neill Theater in October. Seven months later, with a Tony Award nomination for best actor in a musical now under his belt, he seems fully immersed in that milieu but still not quite of it, almost like a Times Square tourist trying to absorb everything going on around him while maintaining a safe distance.

headline: Disappointing Season for Broadway Women
text: IF anyone should be thrilled with this year’s Tony Award nominations, it’s Sheryl Kaller, who was singled out for her direction of “Next Fall.” But for all the pleasure she took in the recognition, Ms. Kaller said, she was taken aback by a certain artistic dissonance in the overall list of nominees.

headline: Senate Backs Fed Oversight of State Banks
text: The Senate on Wednesday voted to amend its major financial regulatory legislation to allow the Federal Reserve to retain its supervision of state-chartered banks and bank-holding companies with less than $50 billion in assets rather than transfer that supervisory authority to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

headline: BP Sees Hope for Solution in Capping Spill in the Gulf
text: After days of deepening gloom, BP and two Obama administration officials suggested on Wednesday that the company was closer to a solution that might halt the seemingly uncontrollable oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: The Resurrection of the Bow Tie
text: FIVE or six years ago, men made a deal. In the name (and spirit) of dressing well (and up), they would embrace the soigné glamour of the tuxedo. Velvet and satin details, shawl and peak lapels: bring it on. But they would deep-six the entire lot of maddening tuxedo minutiae, which are as easy and festive to manage as a year’s worth of tax receipts. Cummerbunds. Studs. Cuff links. Patent-leather slippers. Piqué bib-front shirts. Bow ties.

headline: Latin Flair
text: Ten years ago, Alex Atala’s D.O.M. broke the tradition in São Paulo of culinary colonialism — French, Italian and Japanese were good; Brazilian was bad. Now, after so many bowls of feijoada, a young class of chefs is mixing cuisines and techniques and taking Brazilian cooking to a higher level. Checho Gonzáles, 44, the heavily tattooed chef at the year-old restaurant Ají (Rua Bela Cintra, 1709; 011-55-11-3083-4022; entrees $17 to $27), fuses the flavors of his native Bolivia with the classics of Brazilian cooking. (Each of his knuckles is inked with the image of a popular local bar snack.) The meat stew cozido, for example, is made with tender chunks of picanha braised in red wine, and the caipirinhas are flecked with bright red ají peppers from the mountains of his homeland. At Marakuthai, tucked away in a house in Jardins (above; Alameda Itu, 1618; 011-55-11-3062-7556; entrees $20 to $29), the 21-year-old Renata Vanzetto takes inspiration from Thai food for her cooking, which is based on fresh local fruit and produce, for dishes like shrimp in curry sauce with coconut-crusted banana. And at Kaá (Avenida Presidente Juscelino Kubitschek, 279; 011-55-11-3045-0043; entrees$22 to $37), a high-design Jardins hot spot, Paulo Barros uses Amazonian ingredients like star fruit and bacuri to localize his French-Italian menu. ‘‘Brazil is now being looked to as a global economic player,’’ says Barros, 37. ‘‘So why not bring its power into the kitchen, too?’’

headline: Obama Blasts Auto Dealer ‘Loophole’
text: In an unusually forceful foray into Senate floor debate, President Obama on Wednesday issued a statement opposing a proposal by Senator Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, to protect auto dealers from new consumer protection provisions in a major financial regulatory bill.

headline: Introducing She Owns It: ‘I Didn’t Know There Were Women Out There Like Me’
text: When I first considered blogging about women who are business owners and entrepreneurs, I wondered whether they really needed to be singled out any more than business owners with green eyes or entrepreneurs whose names begin with the letter “M.” I was leery of addressing a vast and varied population of women as if they were all the same but somehow different — in a bad way — from their male peers. As a former editor with Fortune Small Business, I was aware that many businesses owned by women did not grow as quickly as those of some of their male counterparts — the result of complex factors that include financing challenges, the lingering effects of centuries of gender discrimination and the vastly different socialization of women and men.

text: Big holidays often give sales bumps to certain albums, and Mother’s Day is no different, often helping performers like Michael Bublé or Neil Diamond reach No. 1.

text: The Preakness lost a starter on Wednesday after Hurricane Ike was found to have an injured left hind leg while training at Churchill Downs. He had been scheduled to fly from to Baltimore on Wednesday.

headline: Avoiding Tensions, Obama Reassures Karzai
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama promised President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Wednesday that the United States would remain in Afghanistan for the long haul, even as he vowed to stick to his timetable to begin withdrawing troops by July 2011.

headline: Personal Identity in a War Zone
text: A call to active duty soldiers and officers: Capt. Timothy Hsia is leaving active duty after nearly a year of being the main writer of our “A Soldier Writes” feature. We thank him for all his insightful posts and wish him the very best. At War would like to experiment with the feature, asking any active duty service member, especially those posted in Afghanistan and Iraq, to send in postings for publication. Below we are printing a piece from Capt. Henry Brewster, who sent in a post about religion and identity in Iraq.

headline: Delta Adding Flights from New York to 30 Cities
text: Seeking to bolster its flights out of New York City, Delta Air Lines announced plans to expand service from there  to nearly 30 cities worldwide, including major business destinations like Chicago, St. Louis, London and Tokyo.

headline: In the Seattle Area, an Assortment of Treats
text: EVERY weekend, my husband, children and I trundle off to the “red bakery”  our unofficial moniker for the Columbia City Bakery, named for its south Seattle neighborhood  and sit down near people in eccentric hats, cyclists, dog walkers and other families with small children who share our scone-and-coffee routine.

headline: Answers About the Legacy of Robert Moses
text: Following is the first set of responses from Roberta Brandes Gratz, who is responding to readers questions about her book, “The Battle for Gotham: New York in the Shadow of Robert Moses and Jane Jacobs,” which looks at New York’s urban recovery from the 1970s through the lens of the clashing visions of Robert Moses and Jane Jacobs.

headline: Q & A: Joerg Koch
text: After reading the summer issue of 032c  (which I wrote about in an earlier post), featuring William T. Vollmann and photographs by Danko Steiner, I rooted out my few copies of Nest. I hadn’t thought about them in a while and wasn’t surprised that their look and sense of freedom continued to inspire. A frustration voiced a lot these days — by art directors, writers, bloggers and others — is that people aren’t actually creating new things today. They are repeating, mimicking, collecting, downloading, endlessly commenting upon — activities that may be interesting and that may reflect the present moment but  are not about creating anything. One could even argue that they are the opposite of creativity and produce the feeling of being in a prison. Of course, when you consider the very real problems that many people in the world face, like hunger and shortages of medicine, these sorts of complaints sound silly. But creativity in the arts and in applied arts like fashion obviously does matter, and the ways that people insist on being outside the prison are interesting. Perhaps that was the essence of my conversation with Joerg Koch, the editor of 032c, which is based in Berlin. Here are some excerpts:

text: The likelihood that patients in the United States may some day receive heart defibrillators that can operate without electrical wires connected to their hearts has moved a step closer, according to a study published Wednesday.

headline: Asked and Answered | T.J. Lavin
text: Don’t let the incredibly long name of this show turn you off: “The Real World/Road Rules Challenge: Fresh Meat II,” airing Wednesdays at 10 p.m., is the perfect union of two long-running MTV series. The challenge provides the naval-gazing (and fabulous real estate) of “The Real World” with the globe-trotting and physical challenges of “Road Rules.” Up for grabs is a cash prize of $300,000 for the last team standing.

headline: The Costs of Obamacare
text: As long as I’m talking about alternative health care bills, it’s worth lingering over some of the latest news about the bill we actually got. First, the C.B.O. has released a new estimate of how much additional discretionary spending — on implementation costs, further subsidies for new and existing programs, etc. — health care reform is likely to generate over the first 10 years. The total comes to $115 billion above and beyond the official price tag, a sum that would almost wipe out the bill’s projected deficit savings in the first decade.

headline: Our Crazy Supreme Court Nomination Process
text: Gail Collins: David, your column about Elena Kagan had a wonderful description of “Organization Kids” who succeed upward, ever upward without ever taking a risk or displaying passion — intellectual or otherwise. That sounds pretty boring, but you also said that you’ve yet to meet anyone who knows Kagan who isn’t an admirer. So let’s call her careful. Really, really careful.

headline: Penetrating the Process of Obama’s Decisions
text: With relentless 24/7 media coverage of President Obama and a floodlet of books about him, the reader might well ask: Why another study of him and his White House, when his presidency is less than a year and a half old? And yet the Newsweek columnist Jonathan Alter’s book “The Promise” actually does give us a new perspective on the 44th president by providing a detailed look at his decision-making process on issues like health care and the Afghanistan war, and a keen sense of what it’s like to work in his White House, day by day.

text: WASHINGTON — The long delayed and much amended Senate plan to deal with global warming and energy was unveiled on Wednesday to considerable fanfare but uncertain prospects.

headline: Republicans Pick Tampa for 2012 Convention
text: Republicans selected Tampa, Fla., on Wednesday as the site of their 2012 presidential nominating convention, party officials said, with the Gulf Coast city triumphing over Salt Lake City and Phoenix.

text: The $195 million Nascar Hall of Fame opened Tuesday with considerable fanfare in Charlotte, N.C., the de facto capital of stock-car racing, and thousands showed up in the rain to salute a sport that has a colorful history, but a much sketchier future.

headline: Good Effort Is Followed by Great One
text: DETROIT — Jorge Posada noticed a difference in Javier Vazquez from his very first pitch Wednesday. After getting ahead of Austin Jackson, the leadoff hitter for the Detroit Tigers, Vazquez grabbed the ball and went directly to the pitching rubber. He wanted to dictate the tempo. He wanted to control the game.

headline: New Type of Heart Defibrillator
text: The new device, which uses a sensing wire that can conduct a life-saving jolt, is implanted under the skin rather than threaded through a blood vessel and implanted inside the heart.

headline: 36 Hours in Kansas City, Mo.
text: KANSAS CITY is known for its barbecue, bebop and easy-does-it Midwestern charm. But a decade-long effort to revitalize the city’s downtown has transformed this former jazz mecca, which straddles the Kansas-Missouri border, back into a culturally rich metropolis. The city’s standing will be further bolstered next year when the much-anticipated Kauffman Center for the Performing Arts opens, giving a sleek new home to the symphony, opera and ballet. True, Kansas City is no backwater, but don’t expect high polish. In fact, it’s the city’s unvarnished grit that may be its best asset.

headline: The Mighty Colorado at a Glide
text: THERE we sat, five paddlers in three canoes on the Colorado River in northern Arizona, simply observing. The setting sun washed the 1,500-foot canyon walls in hues of coral; cotton-puff clouds dotted the pink-tinged sky. The still surface of the river so perfectly mirrored the cliffs and sky that it was hard, at a glance, to know where the river ended and the cliffs began. Except for a few ducks dallying on the shoreline, we were alone.

headline: Letter: Memories of Burundi
text: To the Editor: Christopher Vourlias’s report on “Burundi’s Freewheeling Nights” (May 2) brought back memories of Bujumbura in the mid-1980s. The country’s last genocide lay 12 years in the past, and the next great bloodletting wouldn’t happen for another decade. AIDS still lurked quietly below the surface, not quite ready to take its toll on Burundi’s population. In those fin d’époque days, patrons packed clubs like Africa Nights or the Black & White run by Buddy, a portly and far more congenial version of Casablanca’s Rick. Like some doomed Victorian heroine, Bujumbura’s attraction has always been its combination of the tragic and the tempting.

headline: Where Wetsuits and Art Meet in Maui
text: IT was just after 10 a.m. and the Paia Contemporary Gallery was getting ready to open. The sun was streaming through the glass storefront, giving everything inside a warm glow. Alejandro Goya, the gallery’s owner, was adjusting a small glass sculpture just a fraction of an angle.

headline: Hunting and Gathering: Finding Evidence About Neanderthals
text: Overview | In this lesson, students reflect on what they know about Neanderthal Man. Then, in light of new genetic findings, they investigate how and what we know about Neanderthals by searching online for archaeological, structural and genetic evidence about our ancient relatives. They then reflect on what the information in Neanderthal DNA tells us about ourselves, and what it means to be human. Finally, they conduct additional research for further consideration of our ancient relatives.

headline: Dallas Gets Its Groove Back
text: THERE’S a sun-baked, low-rise neighborhood in Dallas where urban pioneers have staked out a bling-free zone, set against the glittering backdrop of downtown skyscrapers. Deep Ellum  that’s Texas-ese for “Deep Elm,” the neighborhood’s original name  has historically been a scruffy working-class area.

headline: Obama Aide Sees Higher Taxes for Carried Interest
text: Peter R. Orszag, the White House budget director, said Wednesday that he expected Congress to change the tax treatment of carried interest income at investment firms and that the impact of higher tax bills would not be as dire for Wall Street as some have suggested.

headline: Letter: Luberon, Lost and Found
text: To the Editor: I greatly enjoyed Laurie Winer’s “Happily Lost in the Luberon” (May 2). About eight years ago my wife and I were on an Overseas Adventure Travel trip to Provence and one of our activities was a half-day hike into the Luberon National Park. Two fellow travelers were unable to make the hike, so our tour leader stayed behind and gave us instructions. About an hour into the hike it became painfully clear that we had strayed from the trail and were unhappily lost in the Luberon. At about that time we heard the ringing of a bell and soon saw a small beagle arrive that had been sent by the park superintendent to find us and lead us back. The beagle did an admirable job and reunited us with our tearful but relieved tour leader.

headline: Restaurant Review: Gather, in Berkeley, Calif.
text: Ari Derfel and Eric Fenster were not yet born in 1971 when Alice Waters opened the seminal Chez Panisse, paving the road that brought local, seasonal cooking into the mainstream. But with Gather, their 148-seat restaurant, these self-described “pathological optimists” are turning that road into something of a four-lane highway.

headline: Getting Close to the Last Liftoff
text: THE crowd, all facing the same direction, waits nervously. Some fiddle with cameras on tripods while others sit in camp chairs, slapping at mosquitoes and checking their cellphones for updates. A voice comes over a loudspeaker: “T minus 9 minutes and counting.” After hours of excruciating anticipation, the final checks for the space shuttle launching have been made and all systems are go.

headline: A Quick Stop in Old Cuba
text: FOR most Americans, Havana remains  as a Cuban tourism official recently quipped to a reporter  “the forbidden city,” subject to a United States travel ban and enticingly off-limits. A steady trickle of American visitors continues to slip into the city via flights from Cancún and Nassau, quietly testing the Obama administration’s de facto “don’t ask, don’t tell” Cuban travel policy at overseas customs desks. But why risk a steep fine when you can instead wing on down to Miami for next weekend’s 12th annual Cuba Nostalgia fair at the Miami-Dade County Fair Expo Center? Organizers expect a crowd of 30,000 for three days of Cuban art, music, food and, not least, shopping.

headline: Bending Melodies Into Unorthodox Shapes
text: Heading into her encore at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Tuesday night, Nnenna Freelon gave her audience the illusion of a choice. “Are you guys feeling frisky or sentimental?” she asked. Frisky, came the reply. Well, all right, then: the band struck up a light-funk groove, and Ms. Freelon plunged into one last song, parsing lyrics with syncopation. “Dreeeaam,” she sang, “beside me. In-the-mid-night-glow. The lamp. Is low.”

text: Deanna Zandt has spent the last three years explaining to people why they should join Facebook and the last week wrestling with the urge to delete her own account.

headline: Cisco Sales Rise, Beating Estimates
text: Cisco Systems, the maker of networking equipment, on Wednesday reported third-quarter profit that topped analysts’ estimates. The results were helped by orders from corporate customers that had surging video and Internet traffic.

headline: Dose of Nostalgia for What Never Was
text: “Any Place I Hang My Hat Is Home” isn’t just the title of the easygoing standard by Harold Arlen and Johnny Mercer that describes the vagabond life of a happy-go-lucky drifter. It could be the theme song of Johnny Rodgers, a bandleader, singer-songwriter, pianist and traditional jazzman, who suggests the tow-headed boy next door striding down a country road as he travels from one style to another.

headline: Oscar Winners Back Filmmaker in Dispute With Chevron

headline: The Calvin Klein Underwear Model
