headline: U.S. Clears a Test of Bioengineered Trees
text: Federal regulators gave clearance Wednesday for a large and controversial field test of genetically engineered trees planned for seven states stretching from Florida to Texas.

headline: Art in Heaven, Bless Be Thy Name
text: It is neither the business nor the aim of fashion to accommodate the mortal realm, the sinning, drooping, sagging world of the 9 to 5, the Double Down and Spanx. You show me a woman who can pull of Givenchy’s antimacassar-like black gowns and I’ll show you an apparition, and probably an uncomfortable one at that. High fashion is like Elizabeth Barrett-Browning, too delicate and sensitive a constitution for wrinkles and Coke Zero, of means and averages. And this is how it should be, for in fashion, imagination trumps gravity and fancy utility. These long-legged beasts from Chanel’s silver ZiggystarDusty Springfields to Galliano’s Ninotchka nomads do not belong to this world; They are instead ambassadors from the minds of Messrs Galliano, Tisci and Lagerfeld. Klaatu barada nikto!

headline: Saban Reacquires ‘Power Rangers,’ Moves Show to Nickelodeon
text: The media investor Haim Saban said Wednesday that he had bought back the rights to his biggest franchise, “Power Rangers,” from The Walt Disney Company, and had licensed the show to Nickelodeon, the children’s cable channel owned by Viacom.

headline: In Revote, Cushing Keeps Award
text: Brian Cushing won the N.F.L.’s defensive rookie of the year award in January. Last week it was learned that Cushing, a linebacker for the Houston Texans, tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug in September. And on Wednesday voters gave the award to Cushing anyway.

headline: Cooking Tools: Digital Meal Planning
text: The idea at the heart of E-Mealz is incredibly simple: Each week, when grocery stores publish their weekly sale items, an email arrives in subscribers’ mailboxes with a list of dinners to prepare for the week, recipes whose ingredients are tied directly to specific store chains.

headline: Sonata and Nanosonata in Varying Velocities
text: The British pianist Nicolas Hodges is best known as an astute interpreter of contemporary works, no doubt because his discography is weighted heavily toward new music. But his program biography points out that as a teacher — he is a professor at the Staatliche Hochschule für Musik und Darstellende Kunst, in Stuttgart, Germany — he encourages his students to avoid specializing in either new music or the standard repertory.

headline: Reyes Struggles While Rookie Puts Away Mets
text: In the Washington Nationals’ clubhouse at Citi Field, Roger Bernadina spoke softly while sitting next to a stereo blaring rap music.

headline: Arriving at Monaco’s Work-in-Progress
text: MONACO — Arriving in Monaco today by bus from the Nice airport I felt that not only was the city a little bit of a work in progress before the first practice sessions tomorrow — of course, the track is ready — but also the paddock itself.

headline: Ad: Calvin Klein Commercial
text: Kellen Lutz is featured in Calvin Klein's most recent underwear commercial.

headline: Find Out Where Your Income Ranks
text: A story on MainStreet.com (linked from the Yahoo home page this morning) points to something called The Global Rich List. The concept is simple. Enter your annual income and see how you rank against everyone else on earth.

headline: Banker’s Suit Says She Was Fired for Questioning Account
text: A former private banker at JPMorgan Chase & Company has sued the bank, claiming that she was fired after alerting superiors to possibly questionable dealings by a top client.

headline: Flashback: A Broken-Up Band Reunites, Briefly
text: The Golden Palominos was a band name attached to most of the music overseen by the drummer Anton Fier from the beginning of the 1980s to the end of the ’90s. To be any more specific involves a long list of personnel and a passing reference to almost every kind of pop music played in America during that time; it’s no wonder, really, that they didn’t make a lasting dent in the culture. But enough New Yorkers remember the breadth of what the band once represented to pack two clubs for Golden Palominos shows over the past week, Friday night at Le Poisson Rouge and Tuesday night at the Living Room.

headline: The Education of 2-Year-Old Horses
text: On Tuesday I wrote about the gate-schooling process for babies (2-year-olds.) The post was inspired by our work that day at Fair Hill; we had three sets of babies gate-schooling.

headline: Dressed Up for His Bomb Squad Audition
text: Perhaps the most memorable image from the Times Square car-bomb attempt was those men in the bulky green suits who walked right up to the smoking, sparking Pathfinder on West 45th Street and peered into it to find an elaborate assemblage of explosives.

headline: Celebrating Mexico With Works of Its Own
text: Alondra de la Parra, the young Mexican-born founder and music director of the Philharmonic Orchestra of the Americas, spent more than a year researching little-known scores by Mexican composers to perform for the Mexican bicentennial. But there were no identifying national characteristics in many of the works that received their United States premieres at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening, when Ms. de la Parra led the ensemble in a sold-out event, “Mi Alma Mexicana.”

headline: Now Booking | Cannes Gastronomique
text: Even if you’re not part of the set that is about to jet off to Cannes to sit in the dark for 10 days — the 63rd Cannes Film Festival runs from May 13 to 23 — the palmy resort town unfailingly fascinates with some of Europe’s best beauty-and-the-beast people-watching.

headline: That Film May Be Trash, but You Can Still Recycle It
text: Suppose your introduction to show business, at the tender age of 10 ½,was a starring role in a low-budget horror movie that, for a time, was deemed by the users of the Internet Movie Database to be the worst movie ever. Some people might handle that embarrassment by omitting the credit from their résumé and hoping it never was discovered; others might be shamed out of the industry altogether. But one man made a film about this experience to share it with as many people as possible.

headline: Abortion Rights Group Backs Sestak
text: Naral Pro-Choice America waded into Pennsylvania’s Democratic primary for Senate on Wednesday, as its political action committee endorsed Representative Joe Sestak’s bid to unseat incumbent Arlen Specter.

headline: Judge Temporarily Blocks Furlough of State Workers
text: ALBANY — A federal judge on Wednesday temporarily blocked a one-day furlough of state workers scheduled by Gov. David A. Paterson for next week, reversing a plan that Mr. Paterson has said is necessary to keep the state from running out of money at the end of the month.

headline: The Intersection of Fantasy and Faith
text: Some roles can really get under an actor’s skin. Playing Hamlet would surely put you in an existential mood. Macbeth could bring out a guy’s paranoid streak, even without that fabled curse said to attend productions. But playing the son of God has got to be the trickiest assignment of all. Hanging up there on the cross every night  twice on matinee days!  could give a guy a serious persecution complex, no?

headline: On Dance: Movement to the Sound of Light
text: In the collaborative piece “Necessary Weather,” light, not music, serves as the score. Created between 1992 and 1994 by the respected lighting designer Jennifer Tipton and the dancer-choreographers Dana Reitz and Sara Rudner, the piece instantly became a seminal work that was hailed by critics for its interplay between light and dance.

headline: Day After Chess Championship, Victor and Vanquished Reflect on the Match
text: One day after their title match in Sofia, Bulgaria, ended, Viswanathan Anand, the once and still champion, and Veselin Topalov were tired, but proud.

headline: Turkey’s Pact With Russia Will Give It Nuclear Plant
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey and Russia signed 17 agreements on Wednesday to enhance cooperation in energy and other fields, including pacts to build Turkey’s first nuclear power plant and furthering plans for an oil pipeline from the Black Sea to the Mediterranean.

headline: At the Met, Portraits of Grief, Written in Stone
text: They are so cute, these 16-inch-tall fellows in their floppy robes. Shuffling two by two, 36 strong, behind a choirboy on a black runway in the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s cavernous Medieval Hall, they’re like a troop of fairy-tale dwarfs turned to stone by an evil sorcerer. Unhappy campers, they weep, sigh, gesture sadly and pray, mourning the demise of their liege, John the Fearless, Duke of Burgundy (1371-1419).

headline: Amendments Target Credit Card Industry
text: As the Senate powers through dozens of proposed changes to the Democrats’ financial regulatory legislation, lawmakers have proposed at least three amendments designed to protect consumers and businesses from high credit card interest rates and fees.

headline: When Parents Remarry (Each Other)
text: Ross Kenneth Urken is going to a wedding next week. His parents’. There aren’t many etiquette books that cover this one. And the bride and groom aren’t the only ones whose history is being rewritten with remarriage.

headline: You Never Know Where Her Gallery Will Pop Up Next
text: WHEN the downtown gallery owner Amy Smith-Stewart gave Kate Gilmore a solo show two years ago, the artist paid her back by leaving the space in apparent ruins. Ms. Gilmore had divided the gallery with walls, then ripped giant holes through them, creating jagged portals for visitors to enter the exhibition. Inside, a video loop showed the artist struggling to claw and kick her way out of similar walls.

headline: Mapping Birds Without Boundaries
text: A new survey has found that 148 land bird species in North America are facing rapid decline, the majority of them in Mexico.

headline: Office 2010: A Tale of Decadence and Hand-to-Hand Combat
text: Arriving at Google’s main campus the other day, I flipped my keys to the valet and hopped out of my car. I noticed a  modified RV  over on the right side of the parking lot where employees could get quick, free hair cuts.

headline: Slide Show: Playing at Cannes
text: More Photographs

headline: Pope, Praying for Priests, Visits Shrine
text: FATIMA, Portugal — A day after acknowledging the church’s responsibility for the sexual abuse crisis, Pope Benedict XVI on Wednesday traveled to this popular pilgrim shrine and prayed for priests not to fall short of their “sublime vocation” or “succumb to the temptations of the evil one.”

headline: Elder Statesman’s New Story
text: THAT the director Monte Hellman is at the Cannes Film Festival isn’t really a news flash. As the elder statesman of the idiosyncratic, independent and overlooked American filmmakers that the French treasure, Mr. Hellman  best known for 1971’s “Two-Lane Blacktop”  has long been a fixture at this annual gathering along the Mediterranean. But this year Mr. Hellman comes to Cannes with something he has rarely brought with him on his previous trips: a movie to sell. Mr. Hellman’s influence may be widespread, but his Hollywood career has been in a state of perpetually arrested development.

headline: The Greece Analogy
text: Neal Conan at Talk of the Nation, the public-radio show, just asked me about today’s New York Times debate over the deficit. I compared Greece’s fiscal problems to the long-term ones facing this country. Paul Krugman thinks the comparison is overblown.

headline: Travel Deals: Northeast Getaway with Lobster Dinner
text: Some hotels offer spa credits. Others offer room upgrades. This summer, four northeast resorts are offering a different sort of incentive: waterfront accommodations and a lobster dinner for two, starting at $179 a night.

headline: They Stalk the Banded Mink
text: HUNG from the doorknob of a modest brick house in Flushing, Queens, is a laminated government flier advising the homeowner, “It’s not too late to mail back your census form!”

headline: Sale Veterans
text: A couple who have a regular booth at Brooklyn Flea have mastered the art of collecting and selling.

headline: Growers Feel the Squeeze to Sell a Pinch of Saffron
text: NAVELLI, Italy — The families in this medieval town are so devoted to saffron, the precious spice they painstakingly cultivate and process by hand, that they stash the dried flower stigmas it comes from in the safest, driest place in the house: the matriarch’s wardrobe.

headline: Corzine Starting Small in Bid for Redemption
text: For Jon S. Corzine, it has come to this: a bare Manhattan office still littered with mementos from the previous occupant, at a company few outside Wall Street have heard of.

headline: Critical Cannes Film Angers Italian Official
text: ROME — Movie stars, politicians and sundry glitterati mugged for the red-carpet cameras on Wednesday at the start of the Cannes Film Festival. But Sandro Bondi, the Italian culture minister, was not among them.

headline: Cavendish Showdown Stays Close to the End
text: The Cavendish Invitational Pairs in Henderson, Nev., had a very close finish on Sunday.

headline: Silverman’s Schlep on Comedy Central Ends
text: Unlike some of her Comedy Central brethren, Sarah Silverman never made an episode of her show that elicited ominous messages from shadowy groups. Her only sin was producing a series that grew too expensive for that cable channel to produce. (O.K., and possibly showing a man deriving illicit pleasure from a toy train. And casting Ed Asner as a Nazi officer.) But those days are no more: Comedy Central said on Wednesday that it was not picking up “The Sarah Silverman Program” for a fourth season, confirming a report in The Hollywood Reporter. The series was barely renewed for its third season after Comedy Central sought to lower its budget, and Ms. Silverman, right, and her fellow producers said they would walk away from the show if they did. Ultimately a deal was struck in which Logo, the gay-theme cable channel, helped pick up some of the production costs. When many of those episodes were broadcast earlier this year they were shown by Comedy Central in a midnight time slot. Representatives for Ms. Silverman did not immediately reply to a request for comment.

headline: Pompidou Center Opens Branch in Metz
text: The Pompidou Center in Paris — home to France’s National Museum of Modern Art — opened the doors on Wednesday to its first provincial branch, in Metz, a small city 170 miles east of Paris. The new museum, above, which cost $89 million, according to the Pompidou Center, is part of an effort to expand the display of government-owned art beyond Paris’s large museums. With no permanent collection, Pompidou-Metz will depend on loans from the mother house and other institutions. Its first show, “Chefs-d’Oeuvre?,” is meant to trace the meaning of masterpieces from the Middle Ages through much of the 20th century. The museum’s building, designed by the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban and his French associate Jean de Gastines, has a curving and asymmetrical pagoda-like roof topped by a spire and punctured by upper galleries that stick out like airport pods.

headline: Two Ways to Find Yourself
text: Two Ways

headline: Quebec Family Dies as Home Vanishes Into Crater
text: OTTAWA — Richard Préfontaine and his wife, Lynne Charbonneau, were watching a playoff hockey game with their two daughters on Monday night when the ground beneath their house gave way suddenly and without warning.

headline: Moms Love Godsmack?
text: Big holidays often give sales bumps to certain albums, and Mother’s Day is no different, often helping performers like Michael Bublé or Neil Diamond reach No. 1. By that logic, though, the album on the top of the new Billboard album chart is a bit of a head scratcher: “The Oracle” (Universal Republic), by the long-running, heavily tattooed metal band Godsmack. It sold 117,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and is the band’s third album to open at No. 1. But mothers — or those who shop for them — may have helped a number of other acts reach high on the chart. The Christian soft-rock group MercyMe opened at No. 3 with “The Generous Mr. Lovewell” (INO), which had 88,000 sales; “Live at the Troubadour” (Hear Music), by Carole King and James Taylor, bowed at No. 4 with 78,000; and sales of Mr. Bublé’s “Crazy Love” (143/Reprise) nearly doubled from the week before, to 29,000, lifting it seven spots to No. 15. Also on this week’s album chart, the pop-country band Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville) holds at No. 2 with 97,000 sales, and Justin Bieber’s “My World 2.0” (Island) falls one spot to No. 5 with 64,000. Last week’s top seller, “The Adventures of Bobby Ray” (Rebel Rock/Grand Hustle/Atlantic) by the 21-year-old rapper B.o.B., dropped to No. 12, giving it the dubious distinction of being the first No. 1 this year to fall straight out of the Top 10 the following week.

headline: Landmark Designation Is Upheld for Church
text: The New York City Council on Wednesday upheld the landmark designation of West Park Presbyterian Church at Amsterdam Avenue and 86th Street, rewarding preservationists for their 20-year effort to save the Romanesque Revival building. The ruling disappointed the church leadership, which wanted to develop part of the site, a plan that involved tearing down part of the building. “Forced landmarking has the effect of imposing the governmental idea of mission on the congregation,” the church’s pastor, the Rev. Dr. Robert L. Brashear, said in an interview on Wednesday. “There is a profound church-state issue here. Religious liberty has not been well served by this decision.” Dr. Brashear estimated that it would cost $11 million to $12 million to restore the church, which has been closed about two years because of physical deterioration. The congregation, which has dwindled over the years, has been meeting at the nearby Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew. The 116-year-old West Park Church was designated by the Landmarks Preservation Commission in January. Gale A. Brewer, a city councilwoman from the Upper West Side, who helped lead efforts to preserve the church, acknowledged on Wednesday, “There is a lot of work to be done.”

headline: A Win for ‘Idol,’ but Not for Fox
text: Ratings for Fox’s “American Idol” recovered somewhat on Tuesday after falling to an eight-year low last week, but CBS won the night over all by a thin margin. According to Nielsen’s estimates, a movie-theme episode of “Idol,” with guest-mentoring (and T-shirts) from Jamie Foxx, remained the night’s top-rated show, earning 18.7 million viewers at 8 p.m., up from 17.5 million a week ago, but CBS’s “NCIS” was close behind in the time slot with 16.9 million viewers. The CBS shows “NCIS: Los Angeles” (15.9 million) at 9 p.m. and “The Good Wife” (12.9 million) at 10 won their time slots as well. ABC placed third on the night and NBC was fourth.

headline: Illness of Star Prompts ‘Spartacus’ Prequel
text: While the actor who plays the title character in the Starz drama “Spartacus: Blood and Sand” undergoes cancer treatment, the channel will produce a six-episode prequel to the series. Starz said Tuesday that the prequel is now in pre-production, with a tentative premiere date of January. Andy Whitfield, right, who plays Spartacus, has non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma; he will appear “in a limited capacity” in the prequel, Starz said, and the focus will be on two other characters from the show’s first season, played by Lucy Lawless and John Hannah. The Starz president and chief executive, Chris Albrecht, said that Mr. Whitfield was “responding to his treatments,” and that “as soon as he’s able, we look forward to continuing the Spartacus story.”

headline: BlogTalk: Calls for Repealing Don’t Ask
text: A group of military bloggers has put out a joint statement calling for the military to repeal the “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell” law. Now, as you know, in February  the top two Pentagon officials, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and Adm. Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs, went before Congress and called for an end to the policy. President Obama also wants to see the end to Don’t Ask, but Congress has not yet acted.

headline: Batter Up: Ken Burns’s Follow-Up to ‘Baseball’
text: As a baseball great once said, “It ain’t over till it’s over,” and in the case of the Ken Burns documentary “Baseball,” it ain’t over yet. In September PBS will broadcast a new documentary, “The Tenth Inning,” directed by Mr. Burns and Lynn Novick, that will continue the story begun by Mr. Burns’s 1994 film about the great American pastime. “The Tenth Inning,” which will be shown in two parts, on Sept. 28 and 29, will track baseball’s history from the 1990s to the present. The series is produced by Florentine Films and WETA television of Washington, and is narrated by Keith David.

headline: Different Nationals Outfielder, Same Mets Result
text: Another Mets victory died in the glove of a Nationals outfielder Wednesday. This time, however, the glove did not belong to Willie Harris.

headline: Indie Film Distributor Sentenced in Film Festival Scam
text: A word to the many indie film types headed for the annual film festival just getting under way in Cannes: Let the seller beware. The United States attorney’s office in Los Angeles on Wednesday said that an independent film distributor, Harel Goldstein, was sentenced to four years in federal prison after having pleaded guilty to bank fraud in  a scheme that bilked Comerica Bank of more than $7 million.

headline: Would a MiFi-and-iPad Combo Save You Money?
text: Computerworld has an excellent breakdown of how to manage data consumption on your iPad 3G so you can stay within the confines of AT&T’s 250-megabyte data plan (at $15 monthly) and avoid the $30 charge for unlimited monthly data use.

headline: Corzine Starting Small in Bid for Redemption
text: For Jon S. Corzine, it has come to this: a bare Manhattan office still littered with mementos from the previous occupant, at a company few outside Wall Street have heard of. It is a long way from Goldman Sachs, which he once ran, or Drumthwacket, the New Jersey governor’s mansion, from which he was booted by the voters in November.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Ancient PCs
text: In this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein revisits the early days of personal computing with Jason Bitner, the creator of the How I Met Your Motherboard Web site. It celebrates “the time when computers were beige and business-y” by collecting stories and photos of early home computers like the Sinclair, Osborne, Kaypro and Commodore.

headline: Stretching a Six-Pack
text: “I COULD only hope and pray that I could have a career like Mark Wahlberg,” said Kellan Lutz, the abdominally gifted young actor whose recent career highlights include the roles of ancillary vampire sibling and yet another Freddy Krueger victim.

headline: A Digital Boot Camp to Groom Talent for Agencies
text: WHEN she founded the digital ad agency Exopolis nine years ago, Kat Egan wasn’t worried about finding good talent. Although the Internet was young, she figured trained technologists would soon be pelting her with résumés.

headline: ‘Getting the Pretty Back’
text: Early on during my first pregnancy, a female acquaintance of mine told me, "you better hope she isn't a girl, 'cause she'll suck the pretty out of you!"

headline: With 42 Candles, Grown-Up Advice
text: FEW actresses want to admit hitting 40. Molly Ringwald wrote a book about it.

headline: Underwater Video Shows Oil Gushing From Damaged Pipe into Gulf
text: Video shot nearly a mile beneath the surface of the Gulf of Mexico on Tuesday shows oil and gas streaming from the damaged riser of the Deepwater Horizon well.

headline: Upload a Prom Dress Photo, and Hope
text: COLETTE DONG thought she had bulletproofed her prom dress. Hours after buying the white BCBG gown, she uploaded a photo of it to Don’t Steal My Prom Dress 2010, a Facebook group for girls attending the Yorktown High School prom in Westchester on June 24.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Sonia from the Bronx, Ruth from Brooklyn, Elena from Manhattan. This could be the all-star cast of Saturday Night Live’s “Coffee Talk.”

headline: Polanski Legal Team Says He Will Continue Court Fight
text: LOS ANGELES–Roman Polanski’s legal team here, in a statement issued on Wednesday, said he would continue his court fight on returning to the United States if authorities in Switzerland ultimately decide, based on a full account of the case, to extradite him for sentencing on a 33-year-old sex charge. But they again insisted that Swiss officials were given a misleading description of Mr. Polanski’s intended sentence, and noted a French news report in which a Swiss justice ministry spokesman, Folco Galli, on Wednesday said his office had asked for, but had not received, “supplementary information” from the U.S.

headline: The Twilight of the Welfare State?
text: The debt crisis in Greece may have been temporarily eased by the European Union’s infusion of aid, but many analysts think that Europe’s debt problems and America’s are just beginning. Several analysts have noted that the welfare states in Greece, Spain and Portugal were greatly expanded in the 1990’s, leading to an extraordinary rise in the standards of living in those countries but also unsustainable spending. David Leonhardt of The Times and Robert Samuelson of The Washington Post this week compared the welfare state obligations in Europe to the entitlement burden in the United States.

headline: Five Fronts in the War in Afghanistan
text: American military leaders have had to devise multiple strategies to deal with Afghanistan’s complex terrain and an array of enemies. Here is a look at five areas of focus for the American military.

headline: Club Penguin Misses Goals, Giving Disney a Half-Price Deal
text: LOS ANGELES — Club Penguin, the subscription-based online community acquired by the Walt Disney Company in 2007, has failed to meet profit targets that were tied to $350 million in payouts to the Web site’s creators.

headline: Super Saver Is Early Preakness Favorite
text: BALTIMORE — He ran away with the Kentucky Derby and has trained in the days since like his mile-and-a-quarter victory on the first Saturday in May has taken little out of him. So why is Super Saver merely a lukewarm 5-2 morning-line favorite to capture the 135th running of the Preakness Stakes?

headline: Facebook Privacy: A Bewildering Tangle of Options
text: Pop quiz: Which is longer, the United States Constitution or Facebook’s Privacy Policy?

headline: A Priest’s Legacy Survives, and Divides, in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — Roberta Garza, a Mexican newspaper editor from a prominent family, recalls how the Rev. Marcial Maciel Degollado would stare into the eyes of Mexico’s elite and go into a very persuasive fund-raising pitch: God himself expected them to share their wealth.

headline: Purple Warhol and Red Rothko Go for Lots of Green at Sotheby’s
text: 8:01 p.m. | Updated  At Sotheby’s on Wednesday night all eyes were on a 1986 painting by Andy Warhol, “Self Portrait,” which sold for $32.6 million, more than twice its $15 million high estimate.

headline: Price of Facebook Privacy? Start Clicking
text: Pop quiz: Which is longer, the United States Constitution or Facebook’s Privacy Policy?

headline: Video Shows Oil Gushing Into Gulf
text: Video shot nearly a mile beneath the surface of the Gulf of Mexico on Tuesday shows oil and gas streaming from the damaged riser of the Deepwater Horizon well.

headline: From Oysters to Oil Rigs, a Host of New Rules
text: Energy and Environment

headline: A Day in the Life of a W.P.S. Player
text: Midfielder Yael Averbuch helped lead Sky Blue F.C. to the championship of Women’s Professional Soccer in the league’s first season. Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., product by way of the University of North Carolina, will be filing to the Goal blog during the defending champions’ 2010 season.

headline: With Obama, Regulations Are Back in Fashion
text: WASHINGTON — In a burst of rule-making, federal agencies have toughened or proposed new standards to protect Americans from tainted eggs, safeguard construction workers from crane accidents, prevent injuries from baby walkers and even protect polar bears from extinction.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,388 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,051 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: Weighing the Costs in Asian Trade Talks
text: YONGKANG CITY, Taiwan — In a dimly lighted factory off a dusty road in southern Taiwan, Liao Li-hsin, 29, smacks a leather sandal into shape.

headline: Quiet Resistance to Women on Subs
text: WASHINGTON — Midshipman Jessica Wilcox, who graduates from the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis this month, said she first pictured herself aboard a submarine when she was a “dreamy young person,” long before women were allowed to join the nation’s nuclear submarine service.

headline: New Data on 2008 Election
text: Ninety-three percent of blacks who were registered voted in the 2008 presidential election, a greater proportion than any other racial or ethnic group measured by the Census Bureau, according to an analysis released Wednesday. Non-Hispanic whites were second, at 90 percent. The bureau, which is rarely prone to hyperbole, said it was “remarkable” that when the impact of age, region, sex, income and educational attainment were taken into account, “the odds of voting in 2008 were about twice as high for blacks” as they were for non-Hispanic whites. While whites who did not vote cited busy schedules more than any other reason, blacks listed illness or disability the most.

headline: California: Los Angeles Approves a Boycott of Arizona
text: The Los Angeles City Council voted Wednesday to ban official travel to Arizona and block future contracts with companies there in protest of that state’s new immigration law. Some members of the Council have repeatedly spoken against the law since its enactment, and several marched with immigrants-rights activists and thousands of protesters on May 1 in downtown Los Angeles to oppose the law. The Council has asked officials for the city’s port, airport and utilities to review all contracts with companies based in Arizona.

headline: April Isn’t The Cruelest Month
text: I’ve been hearing some muttering about the April tax receipts, which are well below those of a year ago. Doesn’t that mean that all hopes of recovery, either in the economy or in the budget, should be abandoned?

headline: And Here’s How It Got on Your Head
text: BOYFRIEND jeans. Boyfriend shirts. Now boyfriend hats. At Block Headwear in NoLIta, women cut out the middleman (i.e., the boyfriend) and buy the hats for themselves (left, a range from $35 to $85). For the Cuban-born designer Ciomi McCabe, hatmaking is a family tradition; she perfected her craft at Kangol, where her father was chief financial officer, before founding her brand 10 years ago. “Block” refers to the manufacturing, which includes molding and steaming material around a block of wood. Antique equipment will be set up for clients to see the process. Block Headwear, 10 Prince Street (between Elizabeth Street and the Bowery); (212) 219-2328; blockheadwear.com.

headline: Colleges Seeing No Downturn in Freshman Acceptances
text: One measurement that selective colleges use to compare themselves is their respective admissions yields: the percentage of applicants offered acceptance who ultimately decide to enroll. A few institutions — including Harvard, Dartmouth, Cornell and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill — have begun to report those figures for the freshman class that will take its seats next fall, and so far none have experienced any downturn in the midst of the sluggish economy. At Harvard, for example, more than three of every four applicants who received an acceptance letter had committed by the May 1 deadline to enroll, a slight increase over last year. (The university said it still expected to offer acceptance to as many as 75 applicants on its waiting list.) At Dartmouth, the yield for the new freshman class was 55 percent, an increase of seven percentage points; the increase was so large that the college said it might not have room for anyone on its waiting list. North Carolina said its yield was 53.3 percent (compared with 53.9 percent at this time last year). But that figure is likely to rise, as it does not include all responses to the nearly 350 wait-list offers the university made and whose replies are due next week. Cornell said its yield rate was relatively flat, 49 percent, as was that of the University of Pennsylvania, at 63 percent. Neither institution said it had decided its waiting-list offers.

headline: In Harlem, a Minister Serves Those Who No Longer Can
text: It was about 20 minutes after lunch at the Northern Manhattan Nursing Home on 125th Street in Harlem, and the sounds of feet shuffling and wheelchairs squeaking in a ninth-floor hallway seemed to fade as the Rev. Olevia Stewart-Smith began to read aloud the Lord’s Prayer.

headline: Art? Jewelry? Fashion? Maybe All Three
text: A SHLEY HANOSH, of Honey in the Rough, is merchandising the new jewelry collection from Florian, called Zulu Soiree, by displaying it on the wall of her Lower East Side women’s-wear store like works of art. The hand-done pieces include ones made entirely of glass beads with silver findings (above, $380). The more-eccentric statement pieces are concentric loops; the wearer can poke her head through the loop of her choice and drape the rest across the chest, or let it drop down the back. Prices range from $175 to $840. Ms. Hanosh also introduced an improved e-commerce site this week.

headline: She Never Outgrew These Shoes
text: A S a child, Gabriela Lanardonne (above) would spend vacations in her father’s native Buenos Aires, where she became obsessed by the alpargatas, a version of the espadrille. In her line MYMU, Ms. Lanardonne updated the humble shoe, making it slimmer and sleeker, and offering it in vibrant colors like fuchsia and in fabrics like silk, nylon and leather ($98 to $175). The shoes are unisex. Her new pop-up shop will be at the David Lawrence Studio, 14 East 63rd Street, May 19 to June 2, Monday to Saturday from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Sunday, noon to 6 p.m.; mymuworld.com.

headline: Afghans’ Distrust Threatens U.S. War Strategy
text: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — Nearly a year into a new war strategy for Afghanistan, the hardest fighting is still ahead, but already it is clear that the biggest challenge lies not on the battlefield but in the governing of Afghanistan itself.

headline: Education of a Point Guard Comes Full Circle
text: Second chances are harder than first chances.

headline: Nets Deal Closes; Rebuilding Can Begin
text: One day after N.B.A. owners approved him as the new majority owner of the Nets, Mikhail D. Prokhorov closed Wednesday on his deal to pay the Forest City Ratner Companies $200 million for an 80 percent stake in the team and 45 percent of the Barclays Center arena near downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Small New York Town Makes English the Law
text: JACKSON, N.Y.

headline: Sales at Clio and Others
text: Two’s Company, a wholesaler of decorative accessories, is having a warehouse sale May 14 to 16, with hundreds of products marked down by as much as 90 percent (a metal-top 60-inch table, originally $720, is $150; the Biarritz etched mirror, originally $600, is $150); 275 Clearbrook Road, Elmsford, N.Y., (914) 345-2222.

headline: Flos Arrives in SoHo
text: The Italian lighting manufacturer Flos is opening its first American store in SoHo on May 15. It will carry the company’s most popular fixtures, including classic models like the Arco floor lamp and the Taccia table lamp, by Achille and Pier Giacomo Castiglioni, as well as more recent pieces like Philippe Starck’s table lamp modeled after an AK-47. Piero Gandini, chief executive of Flos, said he hopes the lighting will deliver “the feeling of joy and a little bit of irony and enthusiasm.” His enthusiasm will be reflected in a special installation for the opening — a giant Kelvin LED task lamp, designed by Antonio Citterio with Toan Nguyen, which will tower over visitors at 15 times its normal size. The showroom takes over a space on Greene Street previously used by the design store Moss. Mr. Gandini said that he searched for a New York location for years, but that when he heard about the availability of the corner space from the retailer Murray Moss, “this decision took five seconds.” Flos, 152 Greene Street (Houston Street), (212) 941-4760, flosusa.com.

headline: Road Test: Garden Shears
text: The Process

headline: Furniture by Chris Rucker at Industry Gallery
text: Chris Rucker, a New York designer, is a fan of the work of Donald Judd, something that is apparent in “If I Told You One Time ...,” a show of furniture made of oriented strand board opening May 15 at Industry Gallery in Washington.

headline: Discussing Public Gardens in New York and Paris
text: “Public Gardens in Paris and New York,” a panel discussion at the French Institute Alliance Française on May 17, will include Darrel Morrison, a Manhattan landscape architect; Alexandre Chemetoff, an architect and urban planner in Paris; and Adrian Benepe, the commissioner of parks and recreation for New York City. The discussion will focus on transforming cities with green spaces. It will be moderated by Paula Dietz, the editor of the Hudson Review, and subjects discussed will include Fort Tryon Park, above, and the Brooklyn Bridge Park, designed by Michael Van Valkenburgh Associates. The event is at 7 p.m., at 22 East 60th Street (Park Avenue); admission is $20 for members and $25 for nonmembers. Information: (212) 355-6160 or fiaf.org.

headline: Products From Portugal at the MoMa Design Store
text: With summer almost here, the time to stock up on hostess gifts is now. But when that urge to impose upon your friends with country houses is upon you, you need not trouble yourself with shopping. Today, the MoMA Design Store unveils “Destination: Portugal,” a line of more than 100 new products from that country, including tableware and serving pieces.

headline: Terrarium Artist Moves Into Tableware
text: Paula Hayes, the artist and gardener who creates fantastical environments like hand-blown terrariums, blobby silicone planters and otherworldly crystal-strewn landscapes for art world heavies, is now making objects for the rest of us. Her handmade tableware is sculptural and tactile and comes in the biomorphic shapes that are her signature: a deep blue wineglass is like a hobbit’s boot ($140); a glass plate looks like a jellyfish ($575); a cranberry-red water glass could be a vibrating bean ($160). Napkins ($75) are silk-screened with images of roots, houses and communications satellites, as are “repositionable art squares” — a k a self-adhesive wallpaper panels (set of nine, $150).

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: Flower Beds: A Shovel and a Plan
text: How to plant a garden, from treating the soil to planting the seeds.

headline: Remaking Flower Beds From the Ground Up
text: A LITTLE more than a year ago, I bought a house with a garden that had fallen into neglect. Its outline was still visible, marked by a stone wall running the length of the garden and a listing metal fence that enclosed a few wilted peonies and one spindly rosebush. It had once been beautiful, and I wanted to restore it, but I wasn’t sure where to begin.

headline: Oversize Felt Rugs, Born in a SoHo Loft
text: IN Mongolia, felt-making is a communal affair: women and children beat freshly sheared wool with sticks and sprinkle it with water, then horses drag it through a field. It’s a centuries-old tradition that takes hours, sometimes days, considerable skill and much hoof- and manpower.

headline: Nothing Up His Sleeve, but on It
text: THE Parisian curator Samuel Gassmann became intrigued with the materials and history of the button while researching a documentary. He used that research in designing cuff links (left) using gray and tinted mother-of-pearl (both $110) and French Jet ($250). They are sold at No. 8b, 38 Orchard Street (at Hester Street), (212) 925-5599; projectno8.com.

headline: Court Rules That File-Sharing Service Infringed Copyrights
text: A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that LimeWire, the popular file-sharing service, was liable for copyright infringement, the latest in a growing list of decisions against services that allow users to easily distribute music and videos around the Internet at no cost.

headline: Foster Children Mistreated, Suit Against City Claims
text: A federal lawsuit is seeking to bar New York City from allowing troubled foster-care children to be kept in psychiatric hospitals after doctors have recommended their release, a practice that routinely adds months to a hospitalization despite laws that require such children to be placed in the least restrictive environment possible.

headline: A Loft Filled With Felt
text: A look inside Dana Barnes’s home in SoHo, where she creates her rugs and other pieces.

headline: Astronauts Attack Obama’s NASA Plan
text: WASHINGTON — Neil A. Armstrong, the most famous man in the history of NASA and the first man to walk on the moon, on Wednesday sharply criticized President Obama’s plan to cancel the space agency’s program to send astronauts back to the moon.

headline: A Bad Bet on Carbon
text: Washington

headline: Growing Up, Kagan Tested Boundaries of Her Faith
text: Elena Kagan was a star pupil in her Hebrew school on the Upper West Side. So it was not too surprising after she turned 12 that she wanted to mark her coming of age with a bat mitzvah.

headline: You Have the Right to Remain Constitutional
text: SINCE its adoption after a landmark 1966 Supreme Court decision, the Miranda warning has worked its way into not only everyday police procedure, but American culture as well — even if you’ve never been arrested, you probably know the words “anything you say can and will be used against you.”

headline: New York High School League Is Posting Pitch Counts
text: The pitching arm is considered the most valuable and vulnerable of baseball commodities. At the game’s highest levels, it is treated with tender loving care, often limited to prescribed game usage, with rest strictly enforced between outings.

headline: Republicans Settle on Florida for 2012 Presidential Convention
text: WASHINGTON — The Republican Party selected Tampa, Fla., on Wednesday as the site of its 2012 presidential nominating convention, with the city winning out over Phoenix and Salt Lake City as the place to kick off the party’s quest to defeat President Obama.

headline: Disney Sells a Franchise That Mothers Didn’t Like
text: The media investor Haim Saban said on Wednesday that he had bought back the rights to his biggest franchise, “Power Rangers,” from the Walt Disney Company and had licensed the show to Nickelodeon, the children’s cable channel owned by Viacom.

headline: Pakistan and Times Sq.
text: If we want Times Square to be safer from terrorists, we need to start by helping make Pakistan safer as well.

headline: A Fashion Show Where Candy Is Worn, Not Eaten
text: Take 82 ambitious students, one adored art teacher, a few mousetraps, dozens of Capri-Sun juice pouches and 50,000 beads. Add one plastic picnic table cover, Legos, a stack of Sports Illustrated magazine covers and some beach balls. Toss in fake money, real money, Pokémon cards, metal washers, roof insulation and 1,700 condoms.

headline: Britain Tries Coalition
text: Britain’s new coalition government — its first since World War II — honors the mixed verdict of last week’s election. The voters rejected the Labour Party of former Prime Minister Gordon Brown. But they denied David Cameron and the Conservative Party a majority. The third place Liberal Democrats have become Mr. Cameron’s junior partner.

headline: On Capitol Hill, Kagan Gets to Know Her Voters
text: WASHINGTON — Elena Kagan’s lack of judicial experience and her stance on the military’s “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell” policy emerged Wednesday as potential flashpoints in her confirmation hearings. The top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee said he was not satisfied with her explanation of why she had briefly barred military recruiters from using Harvard Law School facilities when she was dean.

headline: Cleveland Ponders the Unthinkable
text: CLEVELAND — The questions have moved beyond the suspect elbow to LeBron James’s head, his slumped shoulders, his pulse, his spirit and his legacy. A playoff defeat this devastating, and a performance this inexplicable, practically requires a full body scan.

headline: Pssst, Over to You
text: The United States Senate was supposed to have dropped its insidious tradition that let members put endless secret holds on nominations and other important matters. The abuse continues, more murky than ever.

headline: New Age Political Player
text: As we all know, in the arid world of Arizona, political temperatures have been rising about a new law that makes it a crime to be without immigration papers, and relies heavily on “reasonable suspicion.” The reaction within the professional sports world would have been unheard of in my playing days, and underlines a real generational gap. In an unprecedented show of solidarity, players, owners and front-office personnel are uniting, disgusted by Arizona’s approach to addressing concerns over the undocumented.

headline: The Annual Fieldston Fashion Show
text: Students at the Ethical Culture Fieldston School in the Bronx staged a fashion show with outfits created out of anything except fabric.

headline: On the Red Carpet at Cannes
text: Actors and directors hit the red carpet at the 63rd Cannes Film Festival in France.

headline: Phillies Are Accused of Stealing Signs Illegally
text: The Philadelphia Phillies have been one of the best teams in baseball over the last two seasons, capturing two straight National League pennants and the 2008 World Series. Now, they are dealing with accusations that they are, and have been, stealing signs with methods that violate baseball’s rules.

headline: The Gulf Oil (and Gas) Gusher Up Close
text: Just in case you were wondering if it was appropriate to use the phrase “oil spill” to describe the unrelenting seabed gusher in the Macondo prospect 50 miles off the Gulf coast, have a look at the video shot on Tuesday and released today:

headline: Sunbathing, and Keeping an Eye Out for Tar Balls
text: DAUPHIN ISLAND, Ala. — When David and Darla Lindsey arrived for a day at the beach with their paperbacks and crab nets and towels, they found a mysterious line of hay bales stretching along the water, taking a heavy beating from the waves.

headline: 2 Downed Cyclists, 2 Videos, 2 Officers, 2 Outcomes
text: A video of a New York City police officer shoving a bicyclist to the ground in Times Square became a viral presence on the Internet. A video of a similar encounter in Times Square, recorded about a year earlier, also found its way online.

headline: U.A.W. Wants to Share in Big 3’s Financial Success
text: DETROIT — As better times return, the United Automobile Workers is not the union it was before Detroit’s carmakers hemorrhaged billions of dollars.

headline: Slide Show: On the Red Carpet at Cannes
text: More Photographs

headline: Mets Consider Adding the Islanders, a Soccer Team and an Arena
text: Jeff Wilpon, the Mets’ chief operating officer, said he talked to the Islanders’ owner, Charles Wang, about building an arena near Citi Field and possibly buying the money-losing Islanders.

headline: The High Bridge
text: The High Line in Manhattan was a seedy elevated railway until some powerful people helped turn it into a bijou of a public park. When it opened, you needed to wait in line just to climb up and walk a few blocks above the chic meatpacking district. The challenge for Mayor Michael Bloomberg is to make the High Bridge, the city’s oldest standing bridge, as successful.

headline: Construction Site  Owner Is Acquitted in Day  Laborer’s Death
text: The owner of a Brooklyn construction site who was charged with manslaughter after a day laborer was killed at his site two years ago was acquitted on all counts on Wednesday.

headline: Glamour on the French Riviera
text: 6:09 p.m. | Updated

headline: Lottery Numbers
Dodgers and Angels Try to Shake Sluggish Starts
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Torii Hunter and Matt Kemp, who share Gold Gloves, center field and center stage in Los Angeles, have developed a close friendship in recent years. Yet when they talk, it is rarely about the state of their teams, the Angels and the Dodgers.

headline: Walgreens Delays Selling Personal Genetic Test Kit
text: Walgreens said late Wednesday that it would postpone selling a personal genetic test through its drugstores after the Food and Drug Administration challenged the legality of the test.

headline: Leg Lost to Land Mine, Boy, 11, Moves Israel
text: JERUSALEM — On his junior year abroad here in 1984, Jerry White, a student at Brown University, stepped on a buried land mine while hiking with friends in the Golan Heights. The explosion tore off part of his right leg and nearly killed him. It also set the course for his life’s work — leading him to help found what is today called Survivor Corps, an organization that shared the 1997 Nobel Peace Prize, and persuade scores of countries to clear their lands of antipersonnel mines and ban their production and use.

headline: Kagan’s Link to Marshall Cuts 2 Ways
text: WASHINGTON — In the spring of 1988, Justice Thurgood Marshall assigned a clerk, Elena Kagan, to write a first draft of his opinion in a case considering whether a school district could charge a poor family for busing a child to the nearest school, which was 16 miles away.

headline: Mr. Obama and Mr. Karzai, Take Two
text: After months of rancor, President Obama made nice to President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Wednesday, and Mr. Karzai made nice back. At a White House press conference, the two men painted a sunny, improbable picture of cooperation and mutual respect. There was no mention of the many failings of Mr. Karzai’s government or his resentment of American pressure.

headline: Somalia: U.N. Revamps Food Program
text: The World Food Program in Somalia is addressing flaws in its distribution system exposed earlier this year by a United Nations Security Council report, which concluded that half the $485 million in food aid in 2009 was diverted by corrupt contractors, Islamic militants or United Nations staff members. The United Nations team in Somalia is developing a database of all service providers and revising its control system for the delivery of aid and cash transfers, according to the latest council report.

headline: China: Confession Obtained by Torture
text: Officials in the city of Shangqiu in Henan Province have admitted that police officers tortured a man to get him to falsely confess to a murder that he did not commit, official Chinese news organizations reported Wednesday. The man who confessed, Zhao Zuohai, spent 10 years in jail but was released when the supposed victim reappeared in their village on April 30. The police arrested Mr. Zhao, beat him and forced him to drink a toxic substance, he told Chinese reporters this week. Mr. Zhao said he feared he would be killed if he did not confess.

headline: China: Quake Memorial on Internet
text: On Wednesday, the second anniversary of the Sichuan earthquake, Ai Weiwei, left, a prominent Chinese artist, posted an Internet audio project in which volunteers read the names of nearly 5,000 children who were killed when the quake struck several provinces in western China. Mr. Ai, a frequent critic of the government, is trying to call attention to shoddy construction that led to the collapse of many schools during the quake.

headline: Putting a Price on Words
text: Last year, Sam Apple got the idea into his head that what the world needed was a new kind of newspaper. This was, to put it mildly, at odds with the consensus of the marketplace. At the time, several large media companies were in bankruptcy, others were trading at penny-stock levels and analysts were seriously asking whether some venerable publications — including this one — might soon cease to exist. The recession was only worsening a fundamental problem: the industry’s physical product, printed paper, was going the way of the rotary phone, and no one had yet figured out how to generate comparable revenues online. But Apple, a 34-year-old writer, wasn’t ready to give up on journalism as a profit-making enterprise. He began telling friends about his plans to start a Web publication called The Faster Times.

headline: The Annals of Arlen
text: “I love you, and I love Arlen Specter,” Barack Obama told a crowd in Philadelphia last fall. If you happen to be in Pennsylvania, you can relive this incident many times a day, thanks to campaign ads that Senator Specter hopes will save his hide in next week’s Democratic primary.

headline: Greetings From Tampa, Where Hopes Soar — or Die
text: TAMPA, Fla.

headline: Canadiens Continue Their Role as Giant-Killer
text: PITTSBURGH — There are so many glorious chapters in the century-long annals of the Montreal Canadiens, so many unforgettable playoffs. They added another indelible memory Wednesday night, this time as valiant underdogs.

headline: The Price and Who Pays: Updates From the Gulf
text: An explosion and fire on a drilling rig on April 20 left 11 workers missing and presumed dead. The rig sank two days later about 50 miles off the Louisiana coast. Since then, attempts to shut off the flow of oil streaming into the Gulf of Mexico have been unsuccessful and the search continues for a cause and for ways to prevent such blowouts in the future. Questions persist about who will be liable for damage from the spill and the risks to local wildlife. Following is an updated oil spill primer. A previous Q. and A. can be found at nytimes.com/national.

headline: To Defendant, a U.S. Success Story; to Prosecutors, a Money Broker to Iran
text: In many ways, Mahmoud Reza Banki’s experience in America has been a classic immigrant’s success story: He obtained his American citizenship, graduated from Berkeley, earned a Ph.D. from Princeton.

headline: In Job Market Shift, Some Workers Are Left Behind
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Many of the jobs lost during the recession are not coming back.

headline: Simplify Things at a Ricotta Factory
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — This puzzle is by Patrick Merrell. That name rings a bell somehow.

headline: SAP to Buy Sybase, Ally in Software
text: SAN FRANCISCO — SAP’s top executives, who have recently talked about making bolder and more decisive moves, did just that on Wednesday by agreeing to buy a fellow business software maker, Sybase, for $5.25 billion.

headline: Jets and Giants Bid for the Bowl
text: The bid to host the 2014 Super Bowl in the new Meadowlands stadium was submitted to the N.F.L. on Wednesday, giving owners two weeks to decide whether to play the first open-air cold-weather Super Bowl or return to warm-weather stalwarts like Tampa and South Florida, the other bidders.

headline: Before and After: Making Room for a Nursery
text: An interior designer took a home office in a Chinatown apartment and carved out space for a nursery on a budget of $5,000.

headline: Fitting a Nursery Into a Home Office
text: WHEN Chris Buck broached the idea of starting a family several years ago, his wife, Michelle Golden, responded with a question that will be familiar to many New Yorkers: Where would we put the baby?

headline: Toxic Weed Control
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nuclear Plant Security in an Age of Terrorism
text: To the Editor:

headline: Strikes by Drones: Better to Capture Than to Kill?
text: To the Editor:

headline: What Kind of Justice Would Kagan Be?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pretrial Detention
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Judge Blocks State Worker Furloughs
text: ALBANY — A federal judge on Wednesday temporarily blocked a one-day furlough of state workers scheduled by Gov. David A. Paterson for next week, reversing a plan that the governor has said is necessary to keep the state from running out of money at the end of the month.

headline: Estonia’s Adoption of Euro Advances, Despite Concerns From Central Bank
text: FRANKFURT — The European Commission on Wednesday recommended that Estonia be allowed to adopt the euro next year despite a critical report from the European Central Bank.

headline: Chile: Detainee Not Linked to Attempted Attack in Times Square, Official Says
text: A Pakistani man who was arrested by Chilean police on Monday after traces of explosive material were detected on his belongings during a check at the United States Embassy in Santiago is not believed to be connected to the attempted bombing in Times Square earlier this month, a State Department official said Wednesday. The man now under investigation in Santiago, Mohamed Saif ur-Rehman, 28 , was put on a watch list by American intelligence services “prior to the Times Square event, so we don’t see any connection,” said Virginia Staab, a State Department spokeswoman. “We have explored that angle and law enforcement so far sees no connection between the two incidents.”

headline: Shopping With Steven Tupu
text: The award-winning landscape architect shopped for lights that can transform even the smallest forgotten outdoor space.

headline: Shopping With Steven Tupu: Outdoor Lighting
text: IF you’re fortunate enough to have outdoor space, lighting it properly “can make a big difference,” said the landscape architect Steven Tupu. “Even a small amount of lighting,” he said, can “change an outdoor space in a really dynamic way.”

headline: Dave Fisher, Member of the Highwaymen, Dies at 69
text: Dave Fisher, who in 1958 joined with four other freshmen at Wesleyan University to form the Highwaymen, one of the most popular, and improbable, folk music groups of the early 1960s, died on Friday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 69.

headline: Senate Beats Back Efforts to Ease Regulation Bill
text: WASHINGTON — In a defeat for major Wall Street banks, the Senate on Wednesday rejected a Republican effort to ease some of the tight new rules included in the bill for trading derivatives, the complex financial instruments that were at the center of the 2008 financial collapse.

headline: Inna H. Grade, Fierce Literary Guardian, Dies at 85
text: Inna Hecker Grade, the widow and a translator of the great Yiddish novelist and poet Chaim Grade, who earned her own literary niche for her zealous guardianship of her husband’s legacy, died on May 2 in the Bronx, where she lived. She was 85.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: The Flyers Show Fight and Avoid Elimination
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Philadelphia Flyers, a battered team seemingly held together only by an inexhaustible supply of athletic tape and resolve, defeated the Boston Bruins, 2-1, on Wednesday to tie their Eastern Conference semifinal series, which looked all but over seven days earlier.

headline: Francisco Aguabella, Percussionist Who Crossed Genres, Dies at 84
text: Francisco Aguabella, a Cuban-born master percussionist whose impeccable rhythmic sense and drive enriched the recordings and live performances of jazz, salsa and pop artists for five decades, died on May 7 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.

headline: Dustin Shuler, Sculptor Known Best for ‘Spindle,’ Dies at 61
text: Dustin Shuler, a sculptor known for impaling things, flattening things and putting things on top of other things — resulting in works of public art made all the more striking by the fact that the things in question were often full-size automobiles — died on May 4 at his home in Inglewood, Calif. He was 61.

headline: Rob McConnell, Musician and Big Band Leader, Dies at 75
text: Rob McConnell, a jazz trombonist, composer and arranger who led one of the few successful big bands to emerge in the 1960s, died on May 1 in Toronto, where he lived. He was 75.

headline: An Artist of the Martial Kind, Teaching Peace
text: Abdul Aziz, a martial arts practitioner for 45 years and a karate sensei for 25, likens his hands to two protective, potentially deadly weapons. Mr. Aziz, 53, who grew up in Claremont Village in the South Bronx, began practicing at age 8. For the last decade he has taught karate to children at the Harlem Children’s Zone’s Truce Nutrition and Fitness Center. (“Truce” stands for The Renaissance University for Community Education.) He also teaches for the New York City Housing Authority. He lives in the Bronx.

headline: Warhol and Rothko Lead a Big Night at Sotheby’s
text: Classic American images — a Warhol self-portrait, a Rothko red canvas and a Pollock painting rich with the artist’s sinewy drips — blew the lid off Sotheby’s sale of contemporary art on Wednesday night.

headline: Yankees Hoping to Play Thursday; Wouldn’t Mind if They Don’t
text: DETROIT – The tarp is already on the Comerica Park infield, and that is never a good sign. Rain, and lots of it, is in the forecast for Thursday, when C.C. Sabathia is scheduled to oppose the Tigers’ ace, Justin Verlander.

headline: Rosalind Solomon’s Singular Journey
text: We strongly suggest viewing this show in “Full Screen” mode.

headline: BP Says Leak May Be Closer to a Solution
text: After days of deepening gloom, BP and two Obama administration officials suggested on Wednesday that the company was closer to a solution that might halt the seemingly uncontrollable oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Prosecutors Ask if 8 Banks Duped Rating Agencies
text: The New York attorney general has started an investigation of eight banks to determine whether they provided misleading information to rating agencies in order to inflate the grades of certain mortgage securities, according to two people with knowledge of the investigation.

headline: Word of the Day | harangue
text: harangue •\hə-ˈraN\• noun and verb

headline: Perils of Finance for a Carmaker
text: Ed Whitacre just can’t seem to help himself. The executive who rebuilt AT&T from the Ma Bell breakup now appears to be considering doing the same at General Motors. The carmaker he leads, which is 61 percent owned by the government, is weighing a return to the finance business, possibly by acquiring its former unit, GMAC. Such recidivism is troubling on many levels.

headline: Photo Replay: May 12
text: A view of the day in sports, with tennis in Spain and hockey in Germany.

headline: A High Calorie Chess Set
text: The May 4th episode of “Little Chocolatiers,” a TLC show, featured a chess set that people could really sink their teeth into — that is, one made of chocolate. The set was made by Steve and Katie Hatch, the show’s stars, to help raise money for Kayden Troff to play in the World Youth Championships in Greece in October.

headline: Net-Worth Obsession
text: Joey Kincer is the kind of guy who likes to keep records. Mr.  Kincer is a 32-year-old Web developer who lives in San Juan Capistrano, southeast of Los Angeles, and among the things he tracks on his personal home page at kinless.com are his collection of action figures based on the Mega Man video games (“Not for sale,” the site warns sternly), the piano awards he received as a child (“My mom kept track of them all,” he says) and a photo gallery of female celebrity crushes that he refers to as his Dream Team.

headline: News Quiz | May 13, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Cuomo Asks if 8 Banks Duped Rating Firms
text: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, has started an investigation of eight banks to determine whether they provided misleading information to rating agencies in order to inflate the grades of certain mortgage securities, according to two people with knowledge of the investigation, Louise Story reports in The New York Times.

headline: Walgreens Delays Selling Genetic Test Kit
text: Walgreens said late Wednesday that it would postpone selling a personal genetic test through its drugstores after the Food and Drug Administration challenged the legality of the test, Andrew Pollack writes in The New York Times.

headline: Bloggingheads:  Madam Justice
text: Emily Bazelon, left, of Slate and Ann Althouse of the University of Wisconsin Law School debate how women's appointments to the Supreme Court affect the goals of feminism.

headline: The Sound of Breaking Glass
text: WHAT is “Glassphemy!”?

headline: Banker Says Questioning Account Had Her Fired
text: A former private banker at JPMorgan Chase & Company has sued the bank, claiming that she was fired after alerting superiors to possibly questionable dealings by a top client, Lynnley Browning writes in The New York Times.

headline: Senate Beats Back Efforts to Ease Regulation Bill
text: In a defeat for major Wall Street banks, the Senate on Wednesday rejected a Republican effort to ease some of the tight new rules included in the bill for trading derivatives, the complex financial instruments that were at the center of the 2008 financial collapse, David M. Herszenhorn writes in The New York Times.

headline: Fashionalistas
text: A term used in the Philippines to describe those who are both fashionable and nationalistic.

headline: Gold Jumps as Wall Street Steadily Rises
text: Wall Street indexes climbed higher on Wednesday amid new evidence that the United States economy could be staging a recovery, The New York Times’s Christine Hauser reported.

headline: What Assumptions Do People Make About You?
text: In her Personal Health column this week, Jane Brody writes about short people and the false assumptions people make about them. What assumptions do people tend to make about you — whether based on how you look or dress, how you speak, where you live or any other aspect of who you are outwardly? What facts would you like to offer them to refute these assumptions? Why?

headline: Lululemon Raises Stake in Australian Venture
text: Lululemon Athletica, a Canadian maker of high-end workout clothes, said Wednesday it has increased its equity interest in its Australian joint venture partner, New Harbour Yoga, from 13 percent to 80.3 percent, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Mysterious Blight Destroys Afghan Poppy Harvest
text: Up to one-third of Afghanistan’s poppy harvest this spring has been destroyed by a mysterious disease, according to estimates revealed Wednesday by United Nations officials, potentially complicating the American and NATO military offensives this summer in the country’s opium-producing heartland.

headline: Wall Street’s Small-Town Fees
text: Vulture investors like Wilbur Ross and small-town community bankers aren’t alone in cashing in on America’s steady flow of bank failures. While the mergers business remains in the doldrums, a coterie of advisers outside the bulge bracket is minting fees from the banking crash, Breakingviews writes.

headline: Express Prices I.P.O. Below Expected Range
text: Express, the clothing chain, priced shares in its initial public offering below the expected range on Wednesday, Reuters reported.

headline: Perils of Finance for a Carmaker
text: Ed Whitacre just can’t seem to help himself.

headline: Worries About Europe Fade, Lifting Asian Stocks
text: Stock markets in the Asia-Pacific region on Thursday solidified a rally that had spread in Europe and the United States during the previous session amid positive economic and corporate data, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener reported.

headline: Davis Is Making the Spectacular Routine
text: The Mets’ eight-game trip, which begins Thursday night, will introduce the rookie first baseman Ike Davis to three new stadiums: in Florida for four games, in Atlanta for two and in Washington for two.

headline: Lazard President Said to Look for New Job
text: The president of the investment bank Lazard, Charles G. Ward, a protege of the former chief executive Bruce Wasserstein, is looking for a new job, Bloomberg News reported, citing people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Tullett Suitor Walks Away
text: Tullett Prebon, the British interdealer broker that announced in March it was in preliminary deal talks, said Thursday that those discussions had broken down.

headline: Search for 24 Miners in Siberia Halted
text: MOSCOW — The search for 24 coal miners still missing at the site of a disaster in western Siberia was called off on Thursday because levels of methane have risen so high that emergency officials fear a third explosion.

headline: Disney Sells Franchise Mothers Didn’t Like
text: The media investor Haim Saban said Wednesday that he had bought back the rights to his biggest franchise, “Power Rangers,” from the Walt Disney Company and had licensed the show to Nickelodeon, the children’s cable channel owned by Viacom.

headline: I.B.M.’s Future: The Same, Only More So
text: From Steve Lohr at Bits:

headline: Prudential Poised to Price $21 Billion Offering
text: Prudential, the British insurer, is likely to begin its $21 billion rights issue as early as next week, a person with knowledge of the matter said. The company is raising funds to finance its $35.5 billion takeover of American International Group‘s Asian life insurance arm, A.I.A., but the deal was put in doubt when Prudential postponed pricing its offering last week.

headline: Grade Inflation: Your Questions Answered
text: Last week we solicited your questions for Stuart Rojstaczer, a former Duke geophysics professor who has researched trends in university grading over the last few decades and found that private colleges have experienced more grade inflation than public colleges have. Below are his answers to your questions.

headline: In Berlin, Private Art Collections Go Public
text: When Thomas Olbricht needed a place to display his extensive private art collection, he simply had a building constructed (it also houses several apartments) next to the KW Institute for Contemporary Art. The result is the Me Collectors Room Berlin (Auguststrasse 68; me-berlin.com), a two-story showroom that opened to the public on May 1.

headline: 2(x)ist Will ‘Xist’ Again in Print
text: The underwear brand 2(x)ist is returning to print advertising, and beefing up its marketing budget, for a campaign to promote a new line of products.

headline: Ford, Mazda and China Firm to End ‘Garage à Trois’?
text: Ford Motor and its China venture partners, Mazda Motor and Chongqing Changan Automobile, are seeking Chinese government approval to end their three-way tie up, Reuters reported, citing two sources.

headline: Con-Way Gears Up for Share Sale

headline: Sampler: Gas Prices to Fall, and 94-Year-Old to Graduate
text: California Gas Prices Are Expected to Fall | Plan to pay less at the pump by Memorial Day. Prices for a gallon of gas in California will dip below $3 a gallon and are likely to remain there through June, according to petroleum analysts. On Wednesday, gas was selling for an average of $3.15 across the state, but it’s expected to slip to between $2.90 and $2.65 soon. Despite the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, other factors, like the economic turmoil in Europe, have pushed wholesale prices down recently. Some locals won’t need to buy gas at any price on Thursday: Tens of thousands of Bay Area commuters will strap on their bike helmets for the 16th Bike to Work Day. [The San Jose Mercury News]

headline: Christina Ricci Snaps Up Broadway Debut in ‘Time Stands Still’
text: Whether or not “The Addams Family” is still running on Broadway in September, one of the franchise’s most famous alumnae will be making her Rialto debut that month: Christina Ricci, the “Monster” and “Ice Storm” star whose Hollywood career got a ghoulish push from her performances as Wednesday in Barry Sonnenfeld‘s “Addams Family” movies, will join the cast of “Time Stands Still” when it returns to Broadway on Sept. 23, its producers said. Ms. Ricci will enter the cast of that Donald Margulies play as the friend of a photojournalist played by Laura Linney. Brian d’Arcy James and Eric Bogosian, who appeared with Ms. Linney when the play was presented earlier this year by Manhattan Theater Club, will also rejoin the production when it resumes performances at a Shubert Theater to be determined. “Time Stands Still” is nominated for a Tony Award for best play, and Ms. Linney is nominated for best leading actress in a play.

headline: Ahab Sings! (The Whale Does Not)

Mr. McNally withdrew after undergoing successful treatment for lung cancer; he did not withdraw because he had lung cancer.

headline: Correction
text: A theater entry for Massachusetts in the Summer Stages listings last Sunday misspelled the surname of the playwright who wrote “The Taster,” which will be presented by Shakespeare & Company in Lenox. She is Joan Ackermann, not Ackerman. Another theater entry misidentified the company that is presenting “Susurrus” at the International Festival of Arts and Ideas in New Haven. It is Fire Exit  not the National Theater of the United States of America, which is presenting “Chautauqua!” at the festival. And a picture credit for a scene from “Richard III,” another Shakespeare & Company production in Lenox, omitted the name of the photographer. The picture, supplied by a publicist for the company, was taken by Kevin Sprague.

headline: Correction

headline: Letter: The Data-Driven Life
text: Before psychotherapists reject the notion of using electronic devices to track human emotions while treating mood disorders, like those described by Gary Wolf, and before advocates for such devices reject the need for psychotherapy, let us consider these two seemingly separate interventions synergistically. Imagining electronic devices without recognizing the power of relationships — the live human connection — is a fallow notion. Yet considering them as tools to support cognitive and behavioral change may hold potential. The automatic e-mailing of friends when a mood-tracking score signifies a lowered mood is a novel idea, but it left me wondering how this information is then integrated by the individual with the illness beyond the quick feedback from the friend. Hunter College School of Social Work, New YorkLORRAINE R. TEMPEL, PH.D.Hunter College School of Social Work,New York

headline: Letter: What Makes Marion Jones Run?
text: It is very interesting to watch the press coverage, by Maggie Jones and others, of Marion Jones’s attempt to re-enter the sports world. I first met Marion Jones at a benefit in early 2001, fresh off her Olympic victories. The applause for her was loud and prolonged. How could she have shown such pride, knowing that she cheated? All of the rightful winners saw another person get their medals and heard another anthem played and saw another flag raised at the Olympics instead of their own. That is a travesty. Jones does not deserve another chance at sports. Everything she does now is subject to the highest scrutiny.

headline: The Voices of Thyroid Disease

headline: Letter: The Real World 44
text: Ashley Parker’s well-written article acts as a nice antidote to the drivel that is usually written on the subject of Generations X and Y. The article reinforces what I have seen for myself: there are many talented, devoted and hard-working young people in this country, and its future is in good hands.JOHN MANNHAUPTCarrollton, Tex.

headline: Green Economics
text: Paul Krugman (April 11) does an excellent job of explaining climate-change economics but omits one important factor: the immediate and local human health benefits of the cleaner air that most climate-change-mitigation measures will also provide. When reducing carbon dioxide emissions (e.g., by reducing the burning of coal), other air pollutants, like particles and ozone, that are associated with increased risk of asthma attacks, hospital admissions and mortality will often also be reduced at the same time.

headline: The Eternal Godmother of ‘La Bayadère’
text: ONE by one, clad in diaphanous white, they enter to a flowing adagio musical phrase. One arm is stretched forward toward infinity, one leg stretched back to create a glorious arabesque line; then each ghostly figure arches backward, arms framing the head like a halo. The phrase is repeated over and over, the line of dancers winding across the stage in seemingly never-ending serpentine progression: a poetic image of eternity, of order, symmetry, harmony, of classical ballet itself.

headline: Would They Sound as Sweet by Other Names?
text: REVIEWING Juilliard415 recently, my colleague James R. Oestreich puzzled over the name of this new period-instrument band and that of another Juilliard group, Ensemble ACJW. The meaning of the names didn’t stop him: as someone with a longstanding passion for early music, he would immediately have recognized 415 as an allusion to Baroque pitch. (The note A is believed to have been tuned, on average, to something closer to 415 cycles per second than to today’s standard, 440 cycles; the letter A is highlighted in the Juilliard415 logo as a clue.) And ACJW refers to the Academy, supported by Carnegie Hall, the Juilliard School and the Weill Music Institute.

headline: Riding Herd on the Wild Orchestra
text: SEIZED during the 1990s with the notion of creating a complex, large-scale symphonic work yet lacking a commission to facilitate it, the French composer Pascal Dusapin came up with a novel solution in his Seven Solos for Orchestra, a cycle composed in individual installments yet organically linked in ways evident or not. Introduced by various orchestras between 1992 and 2009, the pieces finally appear together on a new two-disc set by the conductor Pascal Rophé and the Liège Philharmonic Orchestra, issued by the French label Naïve (MO 782180).

headline: The 2.0 Report
text: There’s been some bad blood between Athens and Berlin lately, with the latter city holding the economic fate of the former in its less-than-forthcoming hands. ‘‘Berlin-Athens, Why So Much Hate?’’ read a recent French headline. Could there be an element of jealousy? Despite being in the red (or perhaps because of it — cheap rents!), the Greek city is starting to steal the cultural spotlight from the increasingly gentrified Berlin, which seems more interested in spawning an outpost of London’s Soho House than in nurturing the careers of creative types.
