headline: Sunday Magazine Preview: A New-Style Newspaper Entrepreneur
text: In an article in this Sunday’s issue of The New York Times Magazine, Andrew Rice writes about Sam Apple, a writer and Web site director who quit his job to become a latter-day newspaper entrepreneur. Using customized open-source software, he started an online publication he calls The Faster Times, an attempt to keep newspaper-style journalism alive in a Web-only version. Instead of paying his writers a salary or a flat freelance fee, Mr. Apple shares advertising revenue with them — a small amount at the moment, but potentially more lucrative if the enterprise takes off.

headline: The 2010 Ex-Yankees
text: With the Yankees playing the Detroit Tigers this week, there has been a lot of talk about the former Yankees Austin Jackson and Johnny Damon shining with their new club. It got us thinking about whether you could fill a respectable 25-man roster entirely with Yankees castaways just by going back a few seasons. It turns out you can, sort of, if you can live with Jason Giambi as your starting first baseman.

headline: Letterman: ‘A Smaller Containment Device’

It’s a smaller containment device called the top hat. They get the top hat on the well, and then they’re going to get John Wilkes Booth to shoot at it.

headline: The Penguins’ Plummet
text: When the year is over, we may be looking back and calling it the year of the flop, a sports scene dominated by the mighty who did not just fall, but actually swan-dived from great heights. The Pittsburgh Penguins became the latest to take the plunge. The Penguins, the defending Stanley Cup champions, who suit up two of the greatest players on Earth, were summarily shoved from the playoffs by a Little Engine That Could Montreal team fresh off summarily shoving top-seeded Washington out of the playoffs.

headline: Preventing Future Debt Crises in Europe
text: The European Union’s nearly $1 trillion pledge of support for its over-indebted members still leaves open the question of how to better impose fiscal discipline on euro zone nations and avoid future crises. One novel proposal comes from Jacques Delpla of the Conseil d’Analyse Économique in Paris and Jakob von Weizsäcker, a fellow at Bruegel, a research organization in Brussels.

headline: A Word Is as Good as a Hug
text: Mothers’ words have healing powers. That’s the conclusion released Wednesday by researchers at the University of Wisconsin, Madison. More specifically they found that a stressed-out daughter will calm down as effectively after talking to her mother on the phone as from getting a hug from Mom in person.

headline: My Legal Lesson (Continued)
text: My last post created a bit of a stir. As you may recall, I’m subletting new office space and was referred to a firm that specializes in real estate law by another lawyer who had done some personal work for me. My legal needs were simple: I just needed a lawyer to review a standard sublease agreement given to me by my new landlord. The post recounted how the real estate lawyers requested a $2,500 retainer and said that the total fee probably wouldn’t exceed that amount. In the end, however, the fee was $6,450 — including $60 for sending me this courtesy e-mail: “I hope everything is O.K. Take your time.”

headline: New York Is the Next Greece Is the New Black

headline: Grass Fed | Fiddling
text: After enough years of leaping out of bed and scampering up the Bowery to the Union Square Greenmarket to load up on ramps and fiddleheads – which are currently high on the precipice of their short, seasonal apex – my relationship with these two first wild-grown signs that spring is upon us and summer is on its way is waning. They’re good vegetables with real appeal, but they’re not as flexible as some produce.

headline: They’ll Meet in St. Louis

headline: Theater Talkback: Premium Seats, at a Price
text: 7:12 p.m. | Updated For theater critics, acquiring tickets to the hot new show, or the cold new turkey, is as easy as falling off that proverbial log. You make a phone call (or send an e-mail message) in response to an invitation, you show up at the theater and find the publicist standing helpfully outside the doors with your tickets in hand, and you head on in. If you are not attending a designated press performance, you may have to endure the indignity of standing in line at the box office for a minute or two.
