The brothers Noah and Logan Miller discuss how they came to write, direct, produce and star in their first feature film, 
"Touching Home."

headline: U.S. Grants Visa to Singer of Castro’s Praises
text: The singer and songwriter Silvio Rodríguez, the Cuban artist who is probably most closely identified with the Cuban Revolution and Fidel Castro’s half-century in power, has been granted a visa to perform in the United States for the first time in more than 30 years, according to his American immigration lawyer. Mr. Rodríguez plans to tour the United States next month, the lawyer, William Martinez, said, and is scheduled to perform at Carnegie Hall on June 4 with his seven-piece band.

headline: Monaco and the Driver Factor
text: MONACO — It is well known that Monaco is one circuit where the driver can make a difference. That is to say, if at most of the high-speed circuits of the Formula One calendar the car accounts for 95 percent of the lap time and the driver’s skill accounts for the other 5 percent, at Monaco the driver might account for a larger percentage of what will make a car do a good lap.

headline: TimesCast | May 13, 2010
text: Tensions grow in Thailand as a renegade general is shot during an interview with The New York Times, pressure builds against new offshore drilling projects, and a famous skateboard park is shuttered.

headline: The Cardinal Must Go
text: In a week that’s seen strong comments from Pope Benedict and a wonderfully clear-eyed address from Dublin’s Archbishop Diarmuid Martin on the sex abuse scandal and the future of Catholicism, Joseph Bottum’s call for a house-cleaning within the Vatican deserves particular attention, because it cuts to the heart of what remains undone in the church’s response to the scandal.

headline: Upfronts: How Do You Say ‘McDreamy’ in Spanish?
text: The Spanish language broadcast network Telemundo is not waiting until the 2010-11 season starts in September to offer its viewers something new. Beginning on Monday, Telemundo will be all telenovelas in prime time, replacing a game show that has been running from 7 to 8 p.m. with a Spanish-language version of the ABC series “Grey’s Anatomy.”

headline: Under Pressure, Swiss Whittle Away at Bank Secrecy
text: As Swiss lawmakers lock horns over a bill to resolve a thorny tax dispute between UBS and Washington, one thing is becoming clear: an end to absolute banking secrecy will change the country’s pre-eminent financial sector, The New York Times’s Matthew Saltmarsh reports.

headline: Do Americans Spend Enough Time Researching Mortgages?
text: Americans spend more time researching a car purchase than they do researching a home mortgage, according to a survey that the online lending marketplace Zillow Mortgage Marketplace recently released.

headline: Answers About Robert Moses, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of responses from Roberta Brandes Gratz, who is responding to readers questions about her book, “The Battle for Gotham: New York in the Shadow of Robert Moses and Jane Jacobs,” which looks at New York’s urban recovery from the 1970s through the lens of the clashing visions of Robert Moses and Jane Jacobs.

headline: To Fix Bridge, Skateboard Mecca May Be Lost
text: To most people, the area under the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge, in the shadows of the off ramps and against the hulking stone structure of the famous East River crossing, is not a place to stop. It is a place to leave.

headline: Popcast: Michael Bolton, Zs and Jonsi
text: On this week’s Popcast, Jon Caramanica and Ben Sisario discuss Michael Bolton; Ben Ratliff reviews the New York experimental group Zs; and Jonsi, the lead singer of the Icelandic band Sigur Ros, performs live in the studio. Sia Michel is the host.

headline: A New Entry Into the World of Location-Based Games
text: On Thursday, Scvngr (pronounced scavenger) introduced a new set of features and mobile applications that it hoped would become a location-based game for consumers.

headline: Liu Nomination Advances
text: The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday approved the nomination of Goodwin Liu to be a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, sending him to the full Senate for consideration after a party-line vote of 12 Democrats in favor and seven Republicans opposed.

headline: Seeing Things | Shanghai Expo 2010
text: Once upon a time, back when international travel was a novelty rather than a nuisance, and the Internet was nothing but a sci-fi fantasy, world expositions had a certain cachet. Countries competed to showcase the latest advancements in technology, science and culture in swanky national pavilions. As a young child visiting Expo ’67 in Montreal, I was dazzled by the U.S. Pavilion, a sparkling geodesic dome designed by Buckminster Fuller. Perhaps those expos were so exciting because they were all about the promise of the future. But now that we’re living in that future, the idea of an international exposition doesn’t have the same allure.

headline: TimesCast: Oil Pressure Builds
text: Today’s TimesCast takes an early look at the political fallout of the oil rig explosion and its potential implications for offshore drilling beyond the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Want to Talk to Kagan’s Family? Permission Denied
text: White Houses traditionally put a muzzle on their Supreme Court nominees, to keep them from saying anything that might jeopardize Senate confirmation. But the Obama White House has taken it one step further. It is limiting, if not blocking, access to the nominee’s family.

headline: Uma, Alfa. Alfa, Uma.
text: Here’s one more reason to bemoan Alfa Romeo’s absence in the United States: as part of an ambitious Italian advertising campaign “that will be revealing the multifaceted soul” of the new 2011 Alfa Romeo Giulietta, the actress Uma Thurman will star in a sensuous (we’re told by Alfa) television spot that will be shown in Europe starting next week.

headline: A Long Wednesday for Jeter
text: DETROIT – The strong pitching by Javier Vazquez and Phil Hughes in Wednesday’s doubleheader overshadowed a long day at the plate for Derek Jeter. He went 0 for 8 to fall deeper into a weeklong slide.

headline: A Mash-Up on Behalf of Mother Africa
text: STEPPING out of a shiny black SUV in a baggy denim suit, his dreadlocks so long they nearly brushed his boots, Damian Marley came to the Fillmore at Irving Plaza in March on a stealth mission. This Jamaican dancehall star, also known as Jr Gong, and the New York rapper Nasir Jones, also known as Nas, planned to surprise the audience gathered for a show by the hip-hop artist K’Naan with a song from their new album, “Distant Relatives.”

headline: Writing to Explain: Creating How-to Scripts and Demonstrations
text: Overview | What are the qualities of good expository writing? What is process analysis, and how can it help us write for clarity? In this lesson, students examine and evaluate a Times slide show that explains how to pack 10 days’ worth of clothes in a carry-on suitcase. They then generate qualities of good process analysis or procedural writing and create their own physical, video or explanatory, audio demonstrations or explanations.

headline: Delivering Better Primary Care
text: What is clear is this: primary care is hurtling toward a crisis point. Once lauded as health care’s frontline clinicians, primary care practitioners — general internists, family physicians, geriatricians, general pediatricians, nurse practitioners and physician assistants — are instead struggling with growing paperwork demands, inadequate and misaligned reimbursement and dwindling numbers of providers.

headline: Hearing From the Community Doctor
text: Much has been written lately about the impending primary care crisis, with everyone from presidential advisers to political pundits offering scores of suggestions on how our country’s front-line health care providers can tackle the growing paperwork problem, deal with inadequate reimbursements and inspire a new generation of practitioners, all while caring for more and more patients.

headline: Get Meditative with Korean Air
text: Maybe it’s because air travel has become so stressful: Korean Air is now offering meditation, chanting and a Buddhist temple sleepover as part of a new “Templestay” tour.

headline: Seven Rivers Less Paddled
text: Looking to get far from the paddling crowds? We consulted kayaking experts around the country, and came up with seven less-trafficked places to hit the water this spring and summer. One of them is sure to float your boat.

headline: After Friend’s Death, Cho Finds Solace on the Course
text: MOBILE, Ala. — At 10 minutes before 7 on Thursday morning, Irene Cho struck her opening shot of the Bell Micro L.P.G.A. Classic, her tee time so early that not a single ticket-holding fan was there to applaud her perfect drive.

headline: The Nature and Destiny of the Tea Parties
text: Just when you thought the well of anti-Tea Party sentiment had been drained by months of liberal broadsides, along come two of the most stinging critiques of the movement yet published — one from Mark Lilla in The New York Review of Books, and one from Michael Kinsley in The Atlantic. I may have more to say about their pieces later, but for now, as a partial counterpoint, here’s a Tea Party-related clip from a bloggingheads conversation I just recorded with Reihan Salam. (Hopefully you’ll forgive my tendency to throw around the phrase “good for the republic” like an extra in a Julius Caesar biopic.)

headline: Service Members in Afghanistan: Send Us Your Photos
text: The New York Times invites members of the military who are serving, or have served, in Afghanistan to help us document the daily life of this war in photographs, video and writing. Take us on a tour of the FOB, introduce us to your friends, describe the hardships of deployment and the humor that helps you pass the time.

headline: Cuomo and the Broad Power of the Martin Act
text: The banks made hundreds of millions of dollars marketing mortgage-backed securities to their clients during the boom times, but Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, who is questioning the actions of eight banks, is giving them cause for second thoughts.

headline: Seeing Double With Noah and Logan Miller
text: Directors, actors, screenwriters, producers: with their first film project, the twin brothers Noah and Logan Miller have checked off just about every box on the credits list. Their movie, “Touching Home,” is a semiautobiographical look at the brothers’ relationship with their father (played by Ed Harris). In addition to the film, the brothers wrote a book about their experience called “Either You’re In or You’re In the Way.” Here, the two talk about their unlikely journey from working at a car wash in Tucson to making a feature film with no experience or industry contacts. View a trailer for “Touching Home” here.

headline: The Men Who Made ABC’s ‘Lost’ Last
text: BURBANK, Calif.

headline: Supporters of Ex-Leader Seize Offices in Kyrgyzstan
text: MOSCOW — Opponents of the interim government in Kyrgyzstan stormed administration buildings in three southern cities on Thursday, forcibly installed a new governor and seized an airport apparently in an attempt to take power in the south a month after the country’s president was ousted in an uprising.

headline: A City in Bloom
text: Click on Gallery to Enlarge

headline: Greater New Yorkers | Lucy Raven
text: The Moment homes in on 5 artists from Greater New York, which runs May 23–October 18 at PS1 in Queens.

headline: Philadelphia Still Playing the Field in Coaching Search
text: Let’s put the 76’ers coaching search in terms of the cheesy reality show “The Bachelor.”

headline: ‘The Capeman’ Continues Its Comeback This Summer
text: Are theatergoers ready to forgive – or, at least, revisit – “The Capeman”? Students of Broadway probably know its back story better than its music by now: this notorious musical about the gang member Salvador Agron, with a book and lyrics by Paul Simon and Derek Walcott, and music by Mr. Simon, went through five directors en route to its opening at the Marquis Theater in 1998, where it lasted all of two months. But a concert production, “Songs From the Capeman,” presented by Mr. Simon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 2008, drew better notices, and now the Public Theater will provide the musical with another step on its road to rehabilitation.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: Makayla Moore squirms away from a cold bucket of water as she is buried in sand on a beach in Galveston, Tex.

headline: Internet Advertising Keeps Growing
text: The first quarter of 2010 saw a 7.5 percent increase in Internet advertising revenue over the same period last year, growing to $5.9 billion, the Interactive Advertising Bureau and PricewaterhouseCoopers said this morning.

headline: Arms Pact Submitted for Senate’s Consent
text: President Obama on Thursday formally kicked off his campaign to win Senate approval of a new arms control treaty with Russia, sending the pact and various additional papers to the Senate for consideration.

headline: Growing Up With Dad, Distilled With Bite
text: IN making an autobiographical film, the brothers Josh and Benny Safdie had the advantage of a well-documented childhood. On a recent afternoon in their office on lower Broadway, the Safdies sifted through boxes of videotapes and photographs preserved in scrapbooks, all of it emotional raw material for their new fiction feature “Daddy Longlegs.”

headline: Pope Decries Gay Marriage in Portugal Visit
text: FÁTIMA, Portugal — Pope Benedict XVI used a famous Portuguese shrine to the Virgin Mary on Thursday as a stage to denounce abortion and gay marriage, just days before Portugal is expected to join five European countries that have legalized same-sex weddings.

headline: Obama, in Buffalo, Is Upbeat on the Economy
text: BUFFALO – President Obama defended his economic policies on Thursday, declaring “beyond a shadow of a doubt’’ that job growth would continue and that his recovery package had broken the ”economic free fall’’ he faced when he took office 16 months ago.

headline: G.M. President Gives 2011 Chevrolet Cruze One Final Test Drive
text: Mark Reuss slipped behind the wheel of the metallic-red Chevrolet Cruze, buckled his seat belt and adjusted the seat and mirrors. Surveying the car’s instrument cluster and control console, he ran his fingertips across the dashboard, checking its surface texture and the consistency of fit between trim panels.

headline: The Rise and Fall of the G.D.P.
text: Whatever you may think progress looks like — a rebounding stock market, a new house, a good raise — the governments of the world have long held the view that only one statistic, the measure of gross domestic product, can really show whether things seem to be getting better or getting worse. G.D.P. is an index of a country’s entire economic output — a tally of, among many other things, manufacturers’ shipments, farmers’ harvests, retail sales and construction spending. It’s a figure that compresses the immensity of a national economy into a single data point of surpassing density. The conventional feeling about G.D.P. is that the more it grows, the better a country and its citizens are doing. In the U.S., economic activity plummeted at the start of 2009 and only started moving up during the second half of the year. Apparently things are moving in that direction still. In the first quarter of this year, the economy again expanded, this time by an annual rate of about 3.2 percent.

headline: Cass Sunstein Wants to Nudge Us
text: The professors in Hyde Park believe in something called the University of Chicago mind. It runs cold and analytical when the rest of the culture runs hot. Chicago scholars tend to be social scientists at heart, contrarian but empirical, following evidence to logical extremes. They are centrally interested not in what it is like to be an individual within society but in how society washes over individuals, making and remaking them. During the campaign, when his former Chicago colleagues were asked to detail Barack Obama’s intellectual evolution, many of them described him in these terms. But they knew Obama, at best, only partly exhibited this tradition. His friend Cass Sunstein, who is certainly the most productive and probably the most influential liberal legal scholar of his generation, inherited it in full. “Cass has,” says Saul Levmore, a former dean of the law school, “the quintessential University of Chicago habit of mind.”

headline: Eminem and Jay-Z Team Up for Two Concerts
text: Eminem and Jay-Z will be tag-teaming at baseball stadiums this fall.

headline: The Legacy of Jacob Wrey Mould
text: The 1870 Central Park Precinct building, on 86th Street, is part of the legacy of Jacob Wrey Mould, one of New York’s most talented and versatile architects.

headline: Grand Jury: Bicyclists, Motorists, Dial Down the Anger and Obey the Law!
text: Just in time for Bike to Work Day, the San Francisco Civil Grand Jury has issued a report calling on drivers and bicyclists to get along.

headline: The Architecture of Jacob Wrey Mould Is a Study in Contrasts
text: THE reconstruction of the 1870 Central Park Precinct building, on 86th Street, is under way, and only the decoratively tiled dormers peep out over a plywood fence. These are traces of the work of Jacob Wrey Mould, one of New York’s most talented and versatile architects. He described himself as “hell on color,” but his striking polychrome legacy is mysteriously mixed.

headline: Rob the Rich? Give to the Poor? Oh, Puh-leeze!
text: Who was Robin Hood? As with any long-lived figure in the popular imagination  and the legend of the outlaw of Sherwood Forest and his Merry Men goes back to the Middle Ages  the answer changes with the times. In the movies he has been played most memorably by Errol Flynn, most forgettably by Kevin Costner and now, least merrily, by Russell Crowe.

headline: Senate Votes to Tighten Rules for Rating Agencies
text: 5:02 p.m. | Updated The New York Times’s David M. Herszenhorn has more details of the Senate’s action on The Caucus.

headline: Savoy’s Pièce de Résistance Is Going Palatial
text: He has opened a restaurant in Las Vegas and three others around Paris. Now, Guy Savoy is upgrading his flagship restaurant.

headline: It’s Not About You
text: So Republicans are coming out to oppose US participation in a bailout of Greece — which is interesting, given that nobody is asking us to participate. (Yes, we’re part of the IMF, which will provide part of the money — but that’s a fraction of a fraction, and it’s a really bad idea for IMF members to start picking and choosing which programs they’re part of.)

headline: Eddie Izzard Joining Cast of ‘Race’
text: Apparently the theater gods and goddesses were listening when we noted earlier today that there was still one more gavel yet to fall in the re-casting of the Broadway play “Race”: When James Spader leaves that David Mamet drama after June 20, he will be replaced by Eddie Izzard, its producers said. Mr. Izzard, the comedian and actor who will take over in the role of the lawyer Jack Lawson, made his Broadway debut in the 2003 revival of “A Day in the Death of Joe Egg,” the Peter Nichols comedy; he’s also an Emmy Award winner for his comedy special “Eddie Izzard: Dress to Kill,” and looks smashing in drag (which he won’t be doing for “Race,” alas). “Race” is slated to run through Aug. 21 at the Ethel Barrymore Theater with a cast that will include Dennis Haysbert and Afton C. Williamson, as well as Richard Thomas, who has been in the play since its opening.

headline: Vain Glorious | Tom Ford’s Luxe Lips
text: Who: Tom Ford

headline: LED Bulbs Light Up
text: Osram Sylvania says it will be the first major light bulb maker to sell an LED lamp that produces the same amount of light as a 60-watt incandescent lamp. It expects to sell the LED bulb, as part of its Ultra line, this August.

headline: Tax Exemption Sought for Venture Capital Firms
text: Four Senate Democrats and a Republican, Scott Brown of Massachusetts, are seeking to exempt venture capital firms from a proposed tax increase on managers of investment partnerships, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Boehner: Efforts to Highlight Law’s Implementation Are ‘Propaganda’
text: It’s fair to say that time hasn’t softened Representative John A. Boehner’s take on the new health care law.

headline: ZenCity Resort
text: WHAT Caribbean residential development.

headline: Where Every Seat Is Front Row Center
text: Most Broadway producers would be crushed if only one person showed up for a performance. But an audience of one is exactly what Christine Jones wants.

headline: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
text: The sight of a jetliner’s proud tailfin — still in full livery as it rises from a scene of wreckage — is one that can send especially mournful chills through New Yorkers of a certain age; reawakening the blurred outlines of a nightmare never completely forgotten. When that sight (an Afriqiyah Airways Airbus, in Slide 2) is accompanied by news that the only survivor was a young boy, the memory grows irresistible.

headline: Western Senators Propose Ban on Pacific Drilling
text: WASHINGTON — The political ripples from the Gulf of Mexico oil disaster spread in the capital on Thursday as six West Coast senators proposed a permanent ban on drilling in the Pacific and another group tried to raise oil company liability in a spill to $10 billion from the current $75 million.

headline: Lesser Lineup for Yankees Is No Match for Verlander
text: DETROIT — The Yankees challenged the Detroit ace Justin Verlander on Thursday with a lineup ending with Juan Miranda, Randy Winn and Greg Golson. They rested the banged-up Nick Swisher, and Derek Jeter, their leadoff hitter, is slumping, not that he would call it that. It was all a blueprint for trouble, and the outcome played true.

headline: Strolling Old Halls and Streets With Ghosts of Civil War
text: ALTON, Ill.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: The Morning Skate: Penguins Stanley Cup Reign a Short One
text: There will be a new Stanley Cup champion for the 11th consecutive season. Once again, the Canadiens have eliminated an N.H.L. power and in Pittsburgh and elsewhere, disbelief reigns.

headline: Recording Customer Service Calls to India
text: Last month, I wrote a Bucks post, “When and Why You Should Record Customer Service Calls,” with resources and guidelines for recording customer service calls.

headline: Here to Deliver the Gloomy, Mesmerizing News
text: Drones, throbs, somber vocals and, every so often, a dance beat orchestrated a dire world when Massive Attack performed at Terminal 5 on Wednesday night. Massive Attack, a group from Bristol, England, that defined trip-hop in the early 1990s, has only grown gloomier, artier and more politicized through the years. Onstage, even its (typically glum) songs about love took on a topical overlay from the concert’s centerpiece: a wraparound backdrop of LEDs spelling out quotations, statistics and headlines. The concert was singlemindedly dour. But it was also frequently mesmerizing.

headline: A California Island, Ready for Its Face-Lift
text: Santa CATALINA ISLAND, Calif.

headline: A Master Returns With a Firm Grip
text: Kurt Masur seemed deeply gratified by the warm applause and bravos he received when he appeared onstage at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night to conduct the New York Philharmonic. This was his first return to the podium since Alan Gilbert became the orchestra’s music director.

headline: Tony Nomination for Costume Design Withdrawn From ‘Ragtime’
text: The overseers of the Tony Awards announced on Thursday that they had withdrawn the 2010 Tony nomination given to the costume design work for the Broadway revival of “Ragtime” because those designs were predominantly the same as those used in the original 1998 production of “Ragtime.”

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: THE BIG DRAW

headline: A Post-Punk Band From Australia Reunites, in a Way
text: I need to review the laws of reunion concerts. What are they, again? At least three-quarters of the original lineup is needed to guarantee authenticity? The original lead singer must be present? The band can’t have stopped and restarted several times in its working years, because then a reunion is just another start?

headline: Local Stop: Flatiron District
text: The area surrounding the district’s acutely angled namesake building is rich with history and offers opportunities to shop, dine and enjoy nature.

headline: Voices of the Brooklyn Banks
text: The Brooklyn Banks are a skateboarding space under the Manhattan side of the Brooklyn Bridge. Riders are preparing for the closing of this area.

headline: An Evolution to a Hot Spot for Cuisine
text: The Flatiron district, home of its namesake skyscraper and the jewel-like green space known as Madison Square Park, is a place of endless reinvention. Later this year, for example, Mario Batali’s Eataly, an emporium of gourmet restaurants and food markets, is scheduled to open at 200 Fifth Avenue, and the owner of the iconic Flatiron Building plans to convert it into a luxury hotel. For a close look at this always-morphing area, take the N, R or W line to the 23rd Street subway stop. And come hungry. In another of its incarnations, the district is a restaurant destination.

headline: Air Products Names Candidates for Airgas’s Board
text: 4:38 p.m. | Updated with Airgas response Air Products and Chemicals, the industrial gases company, on Thursday named its three candidates for the board of Airgas, the rival it is seeking to acquire.

headline: Brown Says Kagan Supports Military
text: Senator Scott Brown of Massachusetts, one of the Republicans seen as a potential vote in favor of Elena Kagan’s nomination to the Supreme Court, did not wait long in his meeting with her Thursday to raise her role in barring military recruiters at Harvard Law School.

headline: A Father Who Needs Some Supervision
text: Things that might come easily to other people seem to pose special challenges to Lenny (Ronald Bronstein), the Manhattan movie projectionist whose personality is explored in “Daddy Longlegs” as though it were a mountainous landscape or a daunting mathematical problem. To purchase and consume a hot dog is, for most New Yorkers, a fairly straightforward proposition, but for Lenny it is a gantlet of complications involving money, taste, social norms and the laws of gravity. Lunch does not quite work out as planned, but his response to this minor catastrophe is laughter.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Senate Acts on Credit-Rating Agencies
text: 5:22 p.m. | Updated  The Senate on Thursday approved two amendments to the financial regulatory bill aimed at addressing the role that major credit ratings agencies played in the 2008 financial collapse, including one proposal that would force federal officials to come up with alternative methods for judging securities and other investments as a way of limiting the reliance on companies like Moody’s Investors Service and Standard & Poor’s.

headline: Next Round in the Adobe-Apple Fight
text: Adobe, the software company, began a nationwide, multi-Web site advertising campaign on Thursday criticizing Apple’s refusal to allow the Adobe multimedia Flash software on the iPhone and iPad.

headline: Promoting the Preakness, 1960’s Style
text: Eric Banks is a writer and degenerate handicapper in Brooklyn.

headline: High Above Queens, the Dirt Is Deep, and Good
text: Brooklyn Grange, one of the biggest farms to start in the city since the days when Brooklyn and Queens were the nation’s leading vegetable producers, began to take shape Thursday as a crane hoisted bag after enormous bag of dirt — each weighing more than a ton — onto the roof of an industrial building in Long Island City.

headline: Twins Trying to Reverse Yankee Stadium Futility
text: MINNEAPOLIS – The topic got old for Minnesota Twins Manager Ron Gardenhire years ago. And because the Twins keep losing at an alarming rate in the Bronx -– Minnesota takes a 10-game losing streak there into Friday’s series opener against the Yankees -– a question about that futility on Wednesday abruptly swung Gardenhire’s mood from sunny to surly.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Joy of Being Groupies in Lofty Halls of Ballet
text: Each year, in the spring and early summer, New York becomes a world capital of balletomania. The ultimate American example of this genre of obsession can be found during American Ballet Theater’s annual eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House (which begins with a gala on Monday night). What’s a balletomane? Someone who thinks dancers matter more than choreography.

headline: Boulud Opens His First European Restaurant
text: For his first foray into Europe, Daniel Boulud, a French chef who has conquered the New York dining scene, has opened an outpost of Bar Boulud in the Mandarin Oriental Hyde Park in London.

headline: Dude! Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof Answer Your Questions About ‘Lost’
text: “There are many small questions in life that confound me and no one is providing me with answers,” says Carlton Cuse, an executive producer and show runner of “Lost,” in an upcoming interview in The New York Times. But who’s to say we have to let him off as easy?

headline: Ms. Wright Meets Mr. Right, but Will They Be a Pair?
text: The heroine of “Just Wright,” a formulaic sports romance with the texture of a strawberry smoothie, isn’t just any old Hollywood Cinderella in search of Prince Charming. As played by the redoubtable Queen Latifah, this full-figured Cinderella  an unmarried 35-year-old physical therapist and avid New Jersey Nets fan named Leslie Wright  is, in her own self-effacing words, “the perfect homegirl.”

headline: Sweetness From Adversity?
text: Isn’t there an old saying that if it rains on your wedding day, you’ll have a good marriage?  Well, I’m hoping my normal dose of bumbling will lead to prosperous hives.

headline: Setting Up a Rooftop Farm in Queens
text: Over on City Room, Diane Cardwell writes about Brooklyn Grange, a new farm setting up its beds on a 40,000-square-foot rooftop in Queens.

headline: The E.P.A. Announces a New Rule on Polluters
text: The Environmental Protection Agency unveiled a final rule on Thursday for regulating major emitters of greenhouse gases, like coal-fired power plants, under the Clean Air Act.

headline: An Assault on Hearts and Minds
text: Just about the last thing you would expect to see on a New York stage today  or maybe want to see on a New York stage today  is a juicy romantic melodrama set during World War II. The musty attractions of the genre are best savored in the wee hours of the night, surely, when sleeplessness torments and Turner Classic Movies beckons. Or maybe in a downtown drag bar, where the plucky heroine is portrayed by a biological male outfitted with Joan Crawford shoulder pads.

headline: Now Showing | The Selby for Louis Vuitton
text: Tickled as we were by the sight of Mikhail Gorbachev in a Louis Vuitton ad, we’re glad that LV stopped using world leaders as luxury pitchmen before Ban Ki-moon showed up in a monogrammed thong. In its latest promotional essay, out today, the French juggernaut teams up with the at-home photographer Todd Selby, who calls himself just “The Selby.” Given that name, and considering all the Louis Vuitton bootlegs, one could easily have called this project “The Genuine Article Meets the Definite Article.” Alas, “The Journey of a Man’s Wardrobe” showcases the fall/winter collection through Selby’s portraits of Vuitton-ified style icons in New York (Ruben Toledo, André Balazs and Waris Ahluwalia), along with others from Shanghai, London and Tokyo. Perhaps most interesting for diehard Vuitton fans are Selby’s photos of the Vuitton family home in Asnières, France, the place where Monsieur Vuitton moved his workshop in 1859. Visit the site for a peek.

headline: In Pursuit of a Long-Distance Romance, Abandoned Long Ago
text: “Letters to Juliet” represents an interesting paradox: it is a movie that is very nearly perfect without being especially good. Directed by Gary Winick from a script by Jose Rivera and Tim Sullivan, the film fulfills every one of its ambitions with the same kind of brisk efficiency that its heroine brings to her job of magazine fact-checking. But its goals are so modest, so tiny, so timid that fulfillment is exactly what it does not provide. No hard feelings are risked, no feathers of audience sensitivity are ruffled, and as a result no memorable lines are uttered, no startling scenes unfold, and no character emerges toward whom you feel anything more than tepid good will.

headline: Uzi Ben-Abraham Duplex on the Market
text: THE nice thing about buying an apartment is that you can customize your space. If you like to cook, you can wave goodbye to that ancient rental stove, with its indelible evidence of steak charred during the Reagan administration. You can stop staring at the bright white rental walls and choose a color. And if clothing is your thing, you can build closets.

headline: Condos in Former Hotels on the Market
text: HOW much room service could you get if you lived in a hotel and had $15 million to spend?

headline: By Any Means Necessary: An Activist’s Life as Opera
text: New York City Opera has always prized the “people’s opera” image that it cultivated in its early days, and when an opportunity to extend that reputation arises, the company invariably takes it. In recent years City Opera has collaborated with the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem on a series of concerts devoted to excerpts from operas by black composers.

headline: Joseph Moinian Cuts Co-op Price
text: FOR much of the last 20 years, the real estate mogul Joseph Moinian has been on a shopping spree, buying up some 20 million square feet of residential, industrial and office space. Now he’s looking to sell. His five-bedroom Park Avenue apartment has been on the market for over a year, and last weekend it hit the sale rack.

headline: ‘America’s Mayor’
text: Images from a new exhibition about John V. Lindsay, the former mayor of New York City.

headline: You Can Fight City Hall
text: What on earth happened? We enter the fine new exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York and see that handsome patrician, boyishly grinning on posters and magazine covers: John V. Lindsay, Park Avenue-born son of privilege, graduate of Yale and Yale Law School and, in 1965, newly elected mayor of New York City. He is just out of his early 40s and is so charismatic, striding through the city streets with such casual authority, that he might have been a gift of the Fates to replace another boyish, privileged political leader, a president assassinated just two years before.

headline: ‘61 Hours’
text: Chapter One

headline: He Needs Only His Wits and the Shirt on His Back
text: In “61 Hours,” the 14th, craftiest and most highly evolved of Lee Child’s electrifying Jack Reacher books, we find out about a metal desk in a musty old office that Reacher once occupied in Virginia. “There’s a big dent on the right hand side,” says the office’s current resident, the sultry-voiced woman who holds Reacher’s old job with the military police. “People say you made it, with someone’s head.”

headline: BlogTalk: McCain’s ‘Danged Fence’
text: Senator John McCain has a new ad out to show Arizona voters that he is serious about stopping the flow of illegal immigration, and it has drawn snickering from many quarters. The ad, which Steve Benan at Political Animal wrote about the other day, shows Mr. McCain walking along the border in Arizona, with a sheriff in uniform complaining about illegal immigrants. Mr. McCain says, “Complete the danged fence.”

headline: Condos Dominate North Brooklyn Sales
text: IF you’re thinking of buying in Williamsburg or Greenpoint, Brooklyn, maybe you envision life in an old warehouse, or perhaps one of those brownstones the borough is so famous for.

headline: Avis Seeks Antitrust Approval of Likely Dollar Bid
text: The Avis Budget Group moved closer on Thursday to making a bid for the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, saying it was seeking federal antitrust approval of its potential acquisition. The move is somewhat unusual in that Avis has not yet made a formal offer, while Dollar Thrifty has already agreed to be acquired by Hertz Global Holdings for $1.2 billion in cash and stock.

headline: Stars or Not, Cannes Finds Glamour
text: CANNES, France  “That’s a lot of French.” When these words, uttered with palpable alarm, came out of the mouth of one of the characters in Ridley Scott’s “Robin Hood,” the inaugural attraction at the 63rd annual Cannes Film Festival, it was hard not to sympathize. Nothing seems to strike fear into hearts like the sight of French hordes, a sentiment that will be familiar to those who have elbowed their way through the masses who congregate near the red carpet hoping to catch sight of Russell, Cate and the other boldface names who make the pilgrimage to the Côte d’Azur for one of cinema’s last glamorous kingdoms.

headline: Shedding New Light on Old Friends
text: Alexander Calder and Yves Tanguy — old friends, drinking buddies and Connecticut neighbors — are together again. Or rather, their art is, in a delightful, immersive exercise in mutual illumination at L&M Arts on the Upper East Side. Surprisingly, this has never happened before.

headline: Service Disruptions: Half or Whole Hog?
text: City and state watchdogs wanted to know why late-night and weekend subway disruptions were so common, and whether the service changes were justified.

headline: ‘Why Design Now?’
text: Images from the National Design Triennial at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum.

headline: Thinking Green: Function Over Form
text: As we know, everything is connected. So what happens when the butterfly in Brazil, whose fluttering wings are creating wind-power in Texas, dies off because of pollution or deforestation? Somewhere on the planet, wind drops, energy stalls, lights go out. And whether we know it or not, we’re all in trouble.

headline: Auction House Leaves Without a Farewell
text: Tepper Galleries has folded quietly, without much of a public goodbye.

headline: Matthew Barney Series Now Has Two Homes
text: The Museum of Modern Art recently bought a 50 percent interest in “Drawing Restraint Archive,” Matthew Barney’s epic chronicle.

headline: Where Beauty Collides With Creepy
text: Here is a novel proposition: Henry Darger (1892-1973), the self-taught Chicago recluse who painted big, lurid watercolors of bands of little girls violently persecuted by adult male soldiers, was an art collector. That is what “The Private Collection of Henry Darger,” a revelatory exhibition at the American Folk Art Museum, is supposed to show.

headline: Mark Gertler
text: Economist Mark Gertler reflects on how the Ben S. Bernanke as Fed chairman handled the financial crisis.

headline: EMC Now Performing Data Contortion Act
text: EMC has sent big data to a yoga seminar and made it more flexible.

headline: Senate Considers Credit Card Fee Relief for Merchants
text: Small businesses may have caught a break in the swiftly moving negotiations over the Senate financial reform bill. On Wednesday, Senator Richard Durbin of Illinois offered an amendment to the reform bill that would loosen the hold that credit card networks like Visa and MasterCard now have over merchants. Senate leaders are expected to bring the amendment up for a vote — an important milestone, because in major bills, most amendments never get this far.

headline: In Russia, One Grand Prix Is Over, but Another Is Underway
text: Tatiana Kosintseva easily won the third women’s grand prix tournament in Nalchik, Russia, over the weekend. Then on Monday, the sixth men’s grand prix tournament began in Astrakhan, Russia.

headline: Dissident Thai General Shot
text: A renegade Thai general was shot in Bangkok on Thursday as the military prepared to encircle the barricaded encampment of antigovernment protestors.

headline: Time for Regulators to Impose Order in the Markets
text: If your machine makes a mistake that the dumbest human would never make, then maybe you don’t have a very good machine.

headline: Life in a Congolese Border Town
text: Mitch Smith is a 19-year-old journalism student at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the winner of the 2010 Win-A-Trip with Nick contest. He and Nick arrived Sunday in Gabon, Africa–his first time ever outside of the country.

headline: An Evolution to a Hot Spot for Cuisine
text: The Flatiron district, home of its namesake skyscraper and the jewel-like green space known as Madison Square Park, is a place of endless reinvention. Later this year, for example, Mario Batali’s Eataly, an emporium of upscale restaurants and food markets, is scheduled to open at 200 Fifth Avenue, and the owner of the iconic Flatiron Building plans to convert it into a luxury hotel. For a close look at this always-morphing area, take the N, R or W line to the 23rd Street subway stop. And come hungry. In another of its incarnations, the district is a restaurant destination.

headline: Mark Gertler
text: Economics professor Mark Gertler on the Fed's decision to bail out AIG and Bear Sterns.

headline: Jobs That Aren’t Coming Back
text: I had an article today about structural unemployment — the idea that some people are out of work not only because demand is relatively weak, but because their skill sets don’t match what employers want (for example, they are highly specialized auto workers, but the only local job opening is for an oncologist). The typical causes of structural unemployment are the three T’s: trade, technology and changing tastes (e.g., consumers want more iPods and fewer C.D. players).

headline: The Years Do Go Fast
text: The older sister of a childhood friend has become part of my social circle through a new marriage. She’s lovely. I just received an invitation to a lavish 40th birthday party in her honor. Trouble is, I’m 44, and she’s older than me. Our mutual friends are now asking when I’ll turn 40. I don’t want to cause trouble, and I’m guessing that her new husband doesn’t know her real age. But I’m not sure how much new math I can keep track of. Must I rewrite my history just because she’s rewritten hers?

headline: Excavating What Dad Left Behind
text: What do you do with the detritus of your dead? All those hauntingly, definitively empty clothes; the papers that fill box after box; the books and the knickknacks; the forbidding, uninhabited furniture. The performance artist Cynthia Hopkins has provided her own solution for this emotionally fraught storage problem: she wears what her father left behind. It has become her theatrical costume.

headline: TowerBrook to Work With Evergreen on Industrial Deals
text: TowerBrook Capital Partners, a private equity firm, said on Thursday that it had retained executives from Evergreen Capital Partners, an advisory firm, to help it find potential industrial investments.

headline: Mark Gertler
text: Economics professor Mark Gertler reflects on how Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, handled the financial crisis.

headline: Bronx Flavor
text: "Bronx Flavor" was originally produced and developed by BronxNet and is offered by New York City's government owned and operated television station, NYC Life, through a licensing agreement.

headline: Footballer as Life Coach (the Imaginary Kind)
text: There are two Erics in “Looking for Eric.” One is Eric Bishop (Steve Evets), a middle-aged Manchester, England, postal worker whose existence has been a chronicle of hardship and disappointment, much of it self-inflicted. We first see him driving the wrong way around a traffic circle, as if trying to outrun decades of accumulated anxiety. The inevitable accident is almost redundant, since he was already pretty much a wreck.

headline: From Budding Poets, an Ode to Water
text: Where do New York City’s budding poets find inspiration?

headline: Gabrielle Rubinstein and Anthony Cheong
text: THE coffee served at a wedding is typically an afterthought.

headline: Joe Drape’s Preakness Picks
text: The horses in Saturday’s Preakness Stakes. The morning-line odds were set by the Pimlico oddsmaker Frank Carulli. The horses are listed in order of preference by Joe Drape, who provided the comments.

headline: For Dad, There Are 2 Outs in the Bottom of the 9th
text: In “Touching Home” Ed Harris, an actor almost incapable of sounding a false dramatic note, gives a deeply affecting portrayal of a homeless alcoholic with a gambling habit living in Northern California.

headline: Is ‘Law & Order’ About to Be Canceled?
text: People close to “Law & Order” were told Thursday afternoon that the pioneering NBC drama had been canceled. But the network has not yet confirmed the decision, and there were indications late Thursday that talks about its fate were continuing.

headline: Facebook Moves to Thwart Cybercrooks
text: Facebook has unveiled new features to help protect your account from getting taken over by cybercrooks, bitter ex-boyfriends or anyone else who might want to impersonate you to do you wrong.

headline: 2010 Ford Flex
text: In addition to its distinctive style and versatile accommodations, the Flex is engaging to drive.

headline: Imminent End of Secrecy to Shake Up Swiss Banking
text: As Swiss lawmakers appear poised to resolve a tax dispute between UBS and Washington, one thing is becoming clear: an end to absolute banking secrecy will change the country’s pre-eminent financial sector.

headline: China’s School Killings and Social Despair
text: For the past two months, Chinese authorities have been trying to deal with a string of vicious attacks on young children in rural elementary schools. They have clamped down on news coverage, citing fears of copycat crimes and called for heightened school security. But on May 12, a man stormed a village school in Shaanxi Province and hacked to death seven children and two adults. It was the fifth attack since March, all involving middle-aged men using knives, cleavers or tools. Seventeen people have been killed and nearly 100 wounded in the attacks.

headline: In 1953 Iran, Sisterhood Sought During a Coup
text: Every frame of “Women Without Men” and every image within those frames attest to the background of its first-time director, Shirin Neshat, as a photographer celebrated for her explorations of Islamic gender issues. This visually transfixing film, which originated as a video installation, has the feel of an exhibition of Ms. Neshat’s work whose figures have stirred to life to play out a tragic feminist allegory.

headline: MGM Gets Another Reprieve
text: Another day, another plea from MGM to its creditors.

headline: A Nod to History in Tale of a Hawaiian Aristocrat and Romance
text: After playing Pocahantas in “The New World,” Q’orianka Kilcher has moved about 5,000 miles west and three centuries ahead for her next feature, “Princess Kaiulani,” thereby cornering the market on indigenous American princesses who sojourned in England, while also dangerously typecasting herself. At least her role as the pampered, Westernized niece of Hawaii’s last king in the late 1800s does not require her to dance expressively in buckskin, though there are a few uncomfortable moments involving hula.

headline: Moelis Adds 2 Tech Bankers and a Brokerage Firm
text: Moelis & Company, the boutique investment bank, continued its recent expansion on Thursday, announcing the hiring of two senior technology bankers and the purchase of an Australian brokerage firm.

headline: ‘I Capped the Well Competition’
text: Could it be that BP read my post seeking a “Feynman fix” for the unrelenting seabed oil gusher? There’s a new YouTube clip promoting a nationwide competition the oil giant is holding, offering prizes (Lady Ga Ga tickets and a $50 BP gas card) for the winning proposal to cap the leak.

headline: What We’re Reading: Happiness
text: Here is what the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times have been reading over the past two days:

headline: Despite Lower Sales, Sony Trims Annual Loss and Predicts a 2010 Profit
text: TOKYO — Sony narrowed its losses last year and forecast a return to profit this year as an ambitious rollout of 3-D technology, as well an aggressive revamping push, start to buoy its bottom line.

headline: MGM Gets Another Debt Reprieve
text: From Brooks Barnes at Media Decoder:

headline: Affluent Qataris Seek What Money Cannot Buy
text: DOHA, Qatar — Citizens of Qatar appear to have it made. They tend to drive big cars, live in big houses and get big loans to pay for big watches and an outsize lifestyle. They have an army of laborers from the developing world to build a sparkling skyline and to work whatever jobs they feel are beneath them. And their nation has enough oil and gas to keep the good times rolling for decades.

headline: Life, Death and Other Subjects
text: Larger than life and headed for death, K. Roth Binew (Mike O’Connell), the self-aggrandizing antihero of “The Living Wake,” is about to succumb to a mysteriously punctual illness. A failed artist and successful alcoholic, Binew aims to spend his last hours tying up his affairs and planning a pre-expiration party: he wants a full house for his final curtain.

headline: A Thriving Business Built on Geeks’ Backs
text: Barb Staples makes geek dreams come true.

headline: Leaders Put Different Face on Afghan Drive
text: WASHINGTON — In an unusual public conversation about Afghanistan on Thursday, the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton went to some lengths to depict a looming coalition offensive around Kandahar as not a full-fledged military assault, but, in Mr. Karzai’s words, “a process.”

headline: A Sci-Fi Love Story
text: “Timer,” a charming comedy written and directed by Jac Schaeffer, leaves you free to ponder moderately pithy questions afterward, if you choose. For instance: if you knew in advance the exact day you would meet your soul mate, would you be more likely to spend the intervening weeks or years remaining chaste for that future partner, or would you try to squeeze in as many one-night stands as possible beforehand? Which is worse, knowing that your soul mate is still many years in your future, or meeting him or her while you’re still in junior high?

headline: Under the Pink Carpet
text: One of the shows offered by NYC Life, the television station owned by the city.

headline: Secrets of New York
text: One of the offerings on NYC Life, the city's television channel.

headline: Money Matters
text: The Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago pays some of the highest government salaries in the state, with 16 district officials receiving more this year than Mayor Richard M. Daley ($198,881.38). The number of highly paid officials in the agency has increased sharply in recent years.

headline: Photo Replay: May 13
text: A view of the day in sports, with shuttlecocks and saves.

headline: Online Talk, Suicides and a Thorny Court Case
text: The seemingly empathetic nurse struck up conversations over the Internet with people who were pondering suicide. She told them what methods worked best. She told some that it was all right to let go, that they would be better in heaven, and entered into suicide pacts with others.

headline: Bleep or No Bleep, Bolder Words Blow In
text: HOW much more frank is the language used in everyday advertising getting? Look, or listen, no further than a print, online and radio campaign for that most prosaic of products, Frank’s RedHot sauce.

headline: An Actor’s Not-So-Big Break
text: “Best Worst Movie,” a funny-sad documentary about the 1990 horror movie disaster “Troll 2,” tries to pin down the alchemy that transports a film from reject bin to cult favorite. When that goal proves elusive, the director, Michael Paul Stephenson, settles for one closer to home: a touching and at times uncomfortable portrait of people making peace with an unwanted past.

headline: Ground Shifts Strongly in a Democrat’s District
text: LOWELL, Mass. — Just two years ago, not a single Republican stepped forward to run against Representative Niki Tsongas, a Democrat, whose late husband, Paul, was a senator from Massachusetts and a presidential candidate.

headline: Court Backs Oil Project
text: A federal appeals court on Thursday rejected an effort by environmental and Native American groups to stop exploratory oil drilling off the coast of Alaska that could begin this summer.

headline: Teachers’ Fiscal Sacrifices
text: To the Editor:

headline: School Reformers?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A City of Warehoused Souls
text: In “Here and There,” a rough-edged first film written and directed by Darko Lungulov, Robert (David Thornton) is a down-and-out saxophonist from New York so clinically depressed that he can barely interact socially.

headline: K.K.R. Posts $674.8 Million Profit in Q1
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts reported a $674.8 million profit for its first quarter on Thursday, as it benefited from a rise in the value of its portfolio companies and in fees.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Like Spain, Portugal Hopes to Make Cuts, but It Is Mired in Structural Weakness
text: LISBON — José Gago da Graça owns a Portuguese real estate company and has two identical apartments in the same building in the heart of Lisbon. One rents for 2,750 euros ($3,480.21) a month, the other for almost 40 times less, 75 euros ($94.91).

headline: Surfer’s Slaying Exposes Gang Tensions in a Beach Area
text: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — A wooden cross nailed to a palm tree at the beach is the only physical remnant of Robert Burke Simpson, who spent much of his 44 years surfing here. His blood no longer stains the picnic benches, and his ashes have been sprinkled among the waves.

headline: Senate Amends Financial Overhaul Bill
text: WASHINGTON — In the latest sign of the zeal in Congress to get tough on Wall Street, the Senate approved two initiatives on Thursday aimed at addressing the role that major credit rating agencies played in the 2008 financial collapse, including a proposal to end the reliance on companies like Moody’s Investors Service and Standard & Poor’s.

headline: Texas: State Says Company Promising I.R.S. Aid, at a Price, Has Misled Its Customers
text: A national company that claims it can help people in trouble with the Internal Revenue Service has been misleading its clients, charging them hefty fees and failing to deliver on its promises, the Texas attorney general charged Thursday. The attorney general, Greg Abbott, said he was filing a civil law suit against Taxmasters Inc., a company based in Houston that advertises on cable television, claiming deceptive trade practices. The lawsuit says the company persuaded clients to pay thousands in fees through an Internet installment plan and told them that work would begin immediately on their cases. The clients later discovered that no action had been taken. A Taxmasters spokesman said the company would work with the state to resolve the complaints.

headline: A Case for Gold at $5,000 an Ounce
text: It sounds like a gold bug’s dream. But looking back to the last inflation-adjusted peak price in 1980, it’s far from impossible that the gold price could soon go above $5,000 an ounce.

headline: U.S. Approval of Killing of Cleric Causes Unease
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s decision to authorize the killing by the Central Intelligence Agency of a terrorism suspect who is an American citizen has set off a debate over the legal and political limits of drone missile strikes, a mainstay of the campaign against terrorism.

headline: An Immigrant Story
text: Mariana and her two children, Gabriel, 10, and Andrea, 6, have been abandoned by Mariana’s husband after leaving their native Colombia to join him in Jackson Heights, Queens. Now Mariana  unemployed, not knowing English, kicked out of her apartment and pregnant again  is starting to crack under her mounting misfortunes.

headline: With Banks Under Fire, Some Expect a Settlement
text: It is starting to feel as if everyone on Wall Street is under investigation by someone for something.

headline: Regular-Season Form Hasn’t Held Up in East Playoffs
text: One by one the favorites have fallen: the Penguins, the Capitals, the Red Wings, the Devils. All practitioners of creative, attacking hockey, and all knocked out by regular-season strugglers now playing a creative, attacking hockey of their own.

headline: Disputed Judicial Nominee Advances on Party-Line Vote
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday approved the nomination of Goodwin Liu to be a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, sending him to the full Senate for consideration after a party-line vote of 12 Democrats in favor to 7 Republicans opposed.

headline: Twice Accused
text: “How, my heart shrieks, how can I be doing this again?” asks Judge Rusty Sabich, the hero of Scott Turow’s cunning, intricate legal thriller “Innocent.” And it’s a fair question, for both the character and his creator. Twenty-three years ago, in Turow’s best-selling novel “Presumed Innocent,” Sabich cheated on his wife, was charged with the murder of his mistress and, after a long and exceptionally messy trial, walked. “Innocent” finds Sabich — just turned 60 and still living, uneasily, with his wife — once more violating his marriage vows, now with a woman young enough to be his daughter: hence the shrieking heart, the italicized self-interrogation. It’s only natural that he feel a touch of foreboding in this situation. The age difference between him and his eager lover, a lawyer named Anna Vostic, is of course worrisome, as is the effect this new infidelity might have on his campaign for election to the state supreme court. Sabich has become wary of himself, spooked by the intensity of his late-life desire. But the greatest cause for concern while he’s conducting this affair is his wife, Barbara, who is, he knows all too well, dangerously unstable: bipolar and prone to rage.

headline: 35 Years On, Islanders See Themselves in the Flyers
text: On April 26, 1975, a 26-year-old rookie Islanders goaltender named Glenn Resch, better known as Chico, leaned down to kiss the goal posts several times during a Stanley Cup playoff game at Pittsburgh Civic Arena, better known as the Igloo.

headline: To Nurture Boulder, Back-to-Basics Venture Capital
text: BOULDER, Colo. — Like students who choose to go to college in a small town to avoid the distractions of big-city life, the venture capitalists at Foundry Group have shunned Silicon Valley or New York for Boulder.

headline: Boulder, Colo., a Magnet for High-Tech Start-Ups
text: BOULDER, Colo. — Sixty engineers, entrepreneurs and financiers were sipping yerba mate tea at a coffee shop down the street from a bong-and-lingerie store on a recent sunny Tuesday in Boulder, and discussing how Boulder — usually seen as an enclave of hippies, marijuana dispensaries and rock climbers — has become a hotbed of capitalism.

headline: Size of Oil Spill Underestimated, Scientists Say
text: Two weeks ago, the government put out a round estimate of the size of the oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico: 5,000 barrels a day. Repeated endlessly in news reports, it has become conventional wisdom.

headline: Can We Get You Anything Else?
text: The feckless Federal Election Commission has done it again. It is supposed to enforce campaign finance laws and protect elections and voters from the worst money abuses. Instead, it has tailored another loophole in the ban on unlimited “soft money” politicking — allowing Congressional candidates unrestricted war chests to try to influence the redrawing of electoral maps.

headline: Renewed Fight Looms Over Ending Role of Political Parties in Elections
text: In the opening salvo of what could become a major political battle, a dozen New York City activist and civic groups are urging the commission reviewing the structure of city government not to pursue a proposal that would eliminate the role of parties in elections, an idea long favored by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: The Wavering War on AIDS
text: The global war on AIDS has racked up enormous successes over the past decade, most notably by providing drugs for millions of infected people in developing countries who would be doomed without this life-prolonging treatment. Now the campaign is faltering.

headline: In New York Trip, Obama Is Optimistic on Economy
text: BUFFALO — President Obama delivered an upbeat economic forecast and a defense of his economic policies on Thursday, telling a crowd at a manufacturing plant here that job growth would continue and that “next year is going to be better than this year.”

headline: ‘Law & Order’ Series Said to Be in Jeopardy
text: NBC is having trouble making up its mind about “Law & Order.”

headline: Obama Lets Campaign Metaphors Roll
text: President Obama has a metaphor for Republicans: they are like bad drivers, he says, who still want the keys the car.

headline: Nominee Scrutinized for Hiring on Race
Mets Lead the Majors in Declining Attendance
text: A year after moving into a sparkling new $800 million stadium, the Mets have the most home victories in the major leagues, but neither their stadium nor their record is translating into box-office success.

headline: In India, Hitching Hopes on a Subway
text: NEW DELHI — The trains arrive with a whisper. The doors slide open and a puff of refrigerated air confronts the city’s summertime miasma. A bell dings, the doors close and the train whisks its passengers to the next stop.

headline: Citing Individualism, Arizona Tries to Rein in Ethnic Studies in School
text: Less than a month after signing the nation’s toughest law on illegal immigration, Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona has again upset the state’s large Hispanic population, signing a bill aimed at ending ethnic studies in Tucson schools.

headline: The Aliens Among Us
text: FOR centuries, speculation about the existence of life elsewhere in the universe was the preserve of philosophers and theologians. Then, 50 years ago last month, the question entered the scientific sphere when a young American astronomer named Frank Drake began sweeping the skies with a radio telescope in hopes of picking up a signal from an extraterrestrial civilization. Initially, his quest was considered somewhat eccentric. But now the pendulum of scientific opinion has swung to the point where even a scientist of the stature of Stephen Hawking is speculating that aliens exist in other parts of our galaxy.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Growth of CUNY Chancellor’s Salary Outpaces Rise in Faculty’s Pay
text: In his 11 years as chancellor of the City University of New York, Matthew Goldstein has been credited with increasing enrollment, helping raise more than a billion dollars and restoring rigor and energy to a system that had seeped both for decades.

headline: U.S. Said to Allow Drilling Without Needed Permits
text: WASHINGTON — The federal Minerals Management Service gave permission to BP and dozens of other oil companies to drill in the Gulf of Mexico without first getting required permits from another agency that assesses threats to endangered species — and despite strong warnings from that agency about the impact the drilling was likely to have on the gulf.

headline: A Rescue for Affordable Housing
text: The recession has dealt a devastating blow to the federal tax credit program that encourages investors and developers to build affordable housing across the United States. Unless Congress moves quickly to restructure the program, billions of dollars in investment will be lost, along with thousands of affordable housing units and tens of thousands of desperately needed construction jobs.

headline: Metric Mania
text: In the realm of public policy, we live in an age of numbers. To hold teachers accountable, we examine their students’ test scores. To improve medical care, we quantify the effectiveness of different treatments. There is much to be said for such efforts, which are often backed by cutting-edge reformers. But do wehold an outsize belief in our ability to gauge complex phenomena, measure outcomes and come up with compelling numerical evidence? A well-known quotation usually attributed to Einstein is “Not everything that can be counted counts, and not everything that counts can be counted.” I’d amend it to a less eloquent, more prosaic statement: Unless we know how things are counted, we don’t know if it’s wise to count on the numbers.

headline: The Bear Market
text: You’re the former chairman of Bear Stearns, the once-revered investment firm that self-destructed in 2008. How do you feel about your successor, James Cayne, who just testified before the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission in Washington and conceded that he had taken on too much risk?  Enough has been said about Jimmy. There is little I can add.

headline: Profit Sharing
text: I live in the United States, and my sister lives in Canada. Last year I needed to borrow $5,000, and she was kind enough to send me the money. At the time, the two countries’ currencies were nearly at par, so she was out only about 5,020 Canadian dollars. I am now in better shape, but the Canadian dollar is not: it has fallen. To repay her 5,020 Canadian dollars will cost me only $4,267. Assuming the exchange rates hold, may I “make” $733, or should she be the “winner” in our inadvertent currency speculation? By the way, she’s an accountant, so it’s not like she’s not going to notice. DAVID FOSTER, CHARLESTON, S.C.

headline: Valuing $0
text: Lewis Hyde wrote  “The Gift”  decades ago for an audience of artists, writers and other people who create. He advised these readers that for their expression to endure — to become what we might think of as art — it could not be “tailored to the demands of the market.” Rather, such work must be made within the context of what he called “a gift economy,” distinct from the “market economy.”

headline: Quants
text: For the uninitiated, financial writing can sometimes sound like science fiction. Take this sentence from “The Quants,” a new book by the Wall Street Journal reporter Scott Patterson: “To the quants, beta is bad, alpha is good.” Out of context, that could easily be mistaken for dialogue from the  “Star Trek”  franchise.

headline: Credit-Card Message Boards
text: For his everyday credit card, a man with the online handle Mogul of Pineapples says he uses American Express Blue Cash, but for special occasions he will break out American Express’s Simply Cash, Bank of America’s Financial Rewards Visa Platinum Plus, Chase’s rewards Visa and Amazon.com Visa and Discover’s More card.

headline: Bottom Line
text: In early 2008, when the Portland-based artist and designer Tsilli Pines began experimenting with the metrics of money, she did so out of fascination with her personal finances: she was trying to figure out whether she had enough in the bank to quit her full-time design job and go out on her own. By the time the economy began melting down some months later, her series of collages, "The Figures," started evoking a more collective state of mind. Pines uses stitching, pages from an old bookkeeping manual and the traditional black and red of profit and loss to explore what she has called "the topography of money in human consciousness." In her work, missing assets fall through Swiss-cheese-like holes and risk tolerance appears as complicated as a Pentagon PowerPoint. According to Pines, the piece she created for this issue of the magazine, above, titled, "Corporations," isn't just about the way accounting practices are "wacky on such a large scale for so many businesses." To her, "everything, from the way we are trying to make up for personal losses to the way the economy is being propped up, feels like it's being put back together imperfectly."

headline: Texans’ Cushing Denies Taking Drug That Prompted Suspension
text: Brian Cushing, a Houston Texans linebacker, offered his first public comments Thursday about his failed test for performance-enhancing drugs, but his explanation is unlikely to convince many that he was wrongly flagged.

headline: 'Lost': A Character Gallery
text: An interactive primer to help sort out the state of "Lost" characters as the series nears its end.

headline: Obama Expands Modernization of  Nuclear Arsenal
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama promised Thursday to spend $80 billion over 10 years to maintain and modernize the nation’s nuclear arsenal, a commitment that could help win Republican support for his new arms control treaty with Russia.

headline: While the Senate Fiddles
text: You don’t have to look far for proof that this country must cut its dependence on fossil fuels and develop cleaner sources of energy.

headline: Judge Asks U.S. to Consider Forgoing Death Penalty in Imprisoned Mobster’s Trial
text: A federal judge overseeing the trial of a notorious mobster already serving life in prison is asking the Justice Department to reconsider seeking the death penalty on the new charges.

headline: Police Say They Smashed  a Major Bronx Drug Ring
text: They knew what the unmarked police cars looked like, down to their license plate numbers and the dents in their bodies. An apartment building tucked away on a one-way street in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx was their guarded fortress: They could see every car coming their way and brandished guns when they sensed trouble approaching.

headline: A Theater in Times Square With Seating for Just One
text: Most Broadway producers would be crushed if only one person showed up for a performance. But an audience of one is exactly what Christine Jones wants.

headline: We’re Not Greece
text: It’s an ill wind that blows nobody good, and the crisis in Greece is making some people — people who opposed health care reform and are itching for an excuse to dismantle Social Security — very, very happy. Everywhere you look there are editorials and commentaries, some posing as objective reporting, asserting that Greece today will be America tomorrow unless we abandon all that nonsense about taking care of those in need.

headline: Six Stories Above Queens, a Fine Spot for a Little Farming
text: The stretch of Northern Boulevard near 36th Street in Long Island City, Queens, is about as far from bucolic as it gets: Old industrial buildings loom, traffic whizzes by, car dealerships line the street. Off in the distance, Manhattan’s skyscrapers glitter, the trains rumble, and the closest thing to a meadow is a small patch of plants the Parks Department has named Triangle 37.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,053 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Charlie Francis, Coach Linked to Steroids, Dies at 61
text: Charlie Francis, the Canadian coach whose star sprinter, Ben Johnson, was the first Olympic champion to be stripped of a gold medal after testing positive for anabolic steroids, and whose unapologetic admission that his athletes used performance-enhancing drugs forced Olympic officials to confront a widespread problem, died on Wednesday in Toronto. He was 61.

headline: Stonewalled by the S.E.C.
text: On President Obama’s first full day in office, he struck a much-needed symphonic chord in favor of press freedom, openness and a willingness to err on the side of sharing too much information rather than too little.

headline: Cellphones Now Used More for Data Than for Calls
text: Liza Colburn uses her cellphone constantly.

headline: Prosecutors Seek Longer Term for Ex-Senator Who Tried to Withdraw Guilty Plea
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan are seeking a significantly longer prison sentence for former State Senator Efrain González Jr., claiming that he lied when he told a judge he wanted to withdraw his guilty plea because he was innocent of the charges.

headline: New Delhi’s Metro Nears Completion
text: New Delhi’s subway system, known as the Metro, is on track to finish its 118-mile network by fall, right on schedule and within its $6.55 billion budget.

headline: At U.S.-Afghan Meetings, Talk of Nuts and Bolts
text: WASHINGTON — On Wednesday, as a delegation of eight Afghan ministers took seats across a polished oval table from President Obama in the Cabinet Room, the leadoff speaking role went to Muhammad Asif Rahimi, an articulate, burly fellow with salt-and-pepper hair.

headline: Farmers’ Markets
text: In the past few years, farmers’ markets have had a resurgence in the Bay Area and across the United States as consumers seek both a way to connect with their meals and an alternative to large grocery chains. The generation of “going green” wants to know where its food comes from, how long it is in transit and what techniques are used to grow it — information individuals can get from their grower but not from their local chain store.  RACHEL GROSS

headline: An F.B.I. Raid in Newburgh
text: Law enforcement officers raided dozens of homes in the city of Newburgh, about an hour north of Manhattan, in a major show of force against street gangs.

headline: A High-Tech Mogul’s Low-Tech Wine Trail
text: Some have grumbled that Silicon Valley moguls have helped turn the Napa Valley from an agricultural paradise into a winery theme park.

headline: Kenyan Constitution Opens New Front in Culture Wars
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The push to pass a new constitution in Kenya, a cornerstone of the effort to correct longstanding imbalances of power and prevent the kind of upheaval that followed deeply flawed elections here, has attracted some unexpected interference — from more than 7,000 miles away.

headline: Fighting a Tax Appraisal (and Perhaps Something More)
text: January 2009 was pretty close to rock bottom for home sales prices in San Francisco in recent years. Few would contend that a home’s value was soaring.

headline: Legal Ticket Scalping Law to Lapse as Albany Debates a New Provision
text: A bill to extend New York’s three-year-old experiment in legalized ticket scalping hit a roadblock this week as state lawmakers were unable to agree on whether to regulate paperless ticketing.

headline: Glimmers of Hope
text: If you’re elected president or prime minister in pretty much any country in the developed world today, you’re faced with the same set of challenges: to reduce national deficits without choking off a fragile recovery; to trim the welfare state and raise taxes while still funding the things that lead to long-term growth; to try to enact brutally painful measures at a time when voters don’t trust their leaders; to do it at a time when politics are polarized and a hundred different interest groups have the ability to block change.

headline: Kurds Stage Strike in Iran to Protest Executions of Activists
text: Iranian Kurds staged one of their largest strikes in recent years, closing shops and bazaars in nearly all Sunni Kurdish cities and towns in western Iran to protest the executions of five people, including four Kurdish activists, on Sunday, according to opposition Web sites and witnesses.

headline: At Phillips de Pury, the Hammer Falls on the Spoils of a Spree
text: After watching millions and millions of dollars being dropped for Warhols and Rauschenbergs, Picassos, Calders and Johnses at the spring auctions in the last two weeks, it might seem that the money troubles of the recent past were little more than a bad dream — in the art world anyway. But a distress sale that took place Thursday night at Phillips de Pury, the struggling third-place auction house, was a reminder that the ghosts of the recession have not been fully exorcised.

text: The news of Cappie Pondexter’s desire to be traded was passed along to Carol Blazejowski, the Liberty’s president and general manager, in midwinter, and she was immediately warmed by the thought. Pondexter’s agent, Boris Lelchitski, let Blazejowski know that she wanted a one-way ticket out of Phoenix and bound only for New York.
