headline: China: Vice President Turns to Speech Editing
text: Vice President Xi Jinping is urging Communist Party officials to rid their speeches and documents of “empty words” and political jargon, according to Xinhua, the state news agency. Official documents and speeches are infamous for their empty blather. Mr. Xi, left, who is widely expected to be the next president, told more than 900 officials and students at the Central Committee’s Party School on Wednesday that they should study party theory and learn from ancient Chinese literature to simplify their writings, Xinhua reported. The content should have “substance,” he said, and any “unhealthy” writing could undermine efficiency.

headline: Pakistan: Lake Flooding Forces Evacuations
text: Flooding from a lake formed by a landslide in northern Pakistan has submerged dozen of villages and roads and forced a mass evacuation, the army said. The lake stretches for 10 miles across the picturesque Hunza Valley and is rising by three feet a day. The army said flooding could affect 36 villages. Army engineers have built a spillway and expect to drain the lake by the end of the month.

headline: A New Life for Dia’s Old Chelsea Space
text: The red brick building at 548 W. 22nd St., which was home to the Dia Art Foundation from 1987 to 2004 and more recently to a temporary project called the X-Initiative, is about to enter a new era.

headline: Russia: Bombing Against Police Kills 5 in Dagestan
text: A bomb attack on a police convoy in the southern Russian region of Dagestan killed at least five people on Thursday, the prosecutor general’s office said. Most of the dead were repair workers traveling under police escort to fix a cellphone tower that had been damaged the previous evening, apparently in a sabotage attack.

headline: Corrections
text: A theater review on Wednesday about “Five Days in March,” at La MaMa E.T.C. in the East Village, referred incompletely to the casting of the role of Minobe. In addition to Mike Mikos, Wil Petre plays the role. The review also misidentified the character who explains why he likes bad movies. It is Azuma (played by Sean Donovan), not Minobe.

headline: Russia: Judge Who Kept Dying Woman in Jail Resigns
text: A judge who denied repeated requests to release a seriously ill businesswoman who died in a Moscow prison last month has resigned, a spokeswoman for the Moscow Region Court said Thursday. The judge, Olga Makarova, stepped down Saturday “on her own initiative,” the spokeswoman said, though she could not say whether the judge would face charges in the death of the businesswoman, Vera V. Trifonova. A Moscow court ruled this week that Ms. Makarova’s April ruling to extend Ms. Trifonova’s custody was illegal. The death of Ms. Trifonova, who was suffering from severe diabetes and kidney failure, was the latest of several recent cases to underscore corruption and abuse in Russia’s prison system.

headline: New Members Elected for Human Rights Council
text: The United Nations General Assembly elected 14 new members to the Human Rights Council on Thursday, including several countries accused of human rights violations. Dozens of human rights organizations criticized the selection of Libya, Angola, Malaysia, Thailand and Uganda. The American ambassador, Susan E. Rice, expressed “regret” that a number of countries with “problematic” records had gained seats. Washington still views the council as “flawed,” she said, but will stay on it to help shape its agenda.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in the Escapes pages last Friday about a car trip on U.S. 281 in Texas and an accompanying picture caption misidentified the site of Glen Rose, Tex., in describing a 300-mile stretch of the highway south to San Antonio. It is about 25 miles east of 281, not on it. The article also misstated the name of a park near the Fossil Rim Wildlife Center, which is close to Glen Rose. It is Dinosaur Valley State Park, not Fossil Rim State Park.

headline: Mexico: Trafficker’s Wife Arrested
text: Federal officials took into custody this week the wife of Joaquín Guzmán Loera, one of the country's most wanted drug traffickers, who is known as El Chapo or Shorty, according to Mexican news media reports published Thursday. Griselda López Pérez was detained on Wednesday in Culiacán, the capital of the state of Sinaloa, where Mr. Guzmán's drug trafficking operation is based, unidentified federal officials were quoted as saying.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Pitching Duel Ends With a Wild Pitch
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — The Florida Marlins and the Mets are division rivals, but they found some common ground Thursday night at Sun Life Stadium by having a little fun at the expense of the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: No-Hitters Become Rarer, Perfect Games Less So
text: Dallas Braden’s perfect game for Oakland has generated plenty of press, and only partly because of his feud with Alex Rodriguez. A perfect game is celebrated with bold headlines because it is one of baseball’s rarest achievements. But somehow, without anyone noticing, the perfect game has started to become more common, while no-hitters over all have become harder to come by.

headline: Jasper Johns: ‘Ink on Plastic’
One Officer Seeks Bail as Ex-Officer Pleads Guilty

headline: Chrisopher Payne: ‘Asylum’
text: Christopher Payne’s photographic book “Asylum: Inside the Closed World of State Mental Hospitals” was a memorable arrival from M.I.T. Press in 2009. And this small selection of pictures gives some sense of what made it so moving. A photographer with architectural training, Mr. Payne spent six years, from 2002 to 2008, tracking down and documenting more than 70 mental hospitals across the country, several dating from the 19th century, all from before the mid-20th.

headline: A Candidate Shaped in Crucible of Facebook and Privacy Issues
text: Chris Kelly made a relatively abrupt entry into California politics. Mr. Kelly, a former Facebook executive, decided to run for attorney general less than a year ago, and since then has pumped nearly $10 million into his largely self-financed campaign.

headline: ‘Same Sight Slighter’
text: “The Same Sight Slighter” gathers together small, delicate and unassuming works while taking its title from “Tender Buttons,” Gertrude Stein’s 1914 prose-poem inventory of easy-to-miss moments of transcendence. Both title and works seem predicated on opening art viewing and possibly world viewing to the subtle, the transitory and the unexpected.

headline: Conrad Shawcross: ‘The Nervous System (Inverted)'
text: Part sculptor, part inventor, the young British artist Conrad Shawcross has conjured a remarkable rope trick under the 50-foot-high glass ceiling of 590 Madison Avenue’s airy atrium.

headline: Program Offers a Lifeline to Struggling Homeowners

headline: Salaries at Water District Keep Rising Despite Poor Economy
text: In an era of layoffs, unpaid furloughs and reduced benefits at most levels of government, workers for the little-known, taxpayer-financed agency that deals with Cook County’s waste and storm water are a throwback to far better times: They continue to enjoy high salaries, big overtime checks and annual cash payouts for unused sick-leave days.

headline: Leon Golub: ‘Live & Die Like a Lion?’
text: Leon Golub seems to be grappling with the whole idea of late art. The hand-lettered texts on his drawings deflect mortality, and maturity, with a blend of humor, defiance and absurdism.

text: If someone was an important figure in American culture in the 20th century, chances are he or she was interviewed by Studs Terkel.

headline: Rumors of Conspiracies Rattle Madagascar
text: ANTANANARIVO, Madagascar — A few weeks ago, 22 provocateurs — among them five connivers from the military itself — planned a predawn mission to murder the prime minister. Fortunately, their seditious scheme was discovered before the plot could unfold.

headline: After Leaving the Kitchen, Stepping Into the Limelight
text: BALTIMORE — He grew up on a ranch in Mexico and spent his first year in the United States making shrimp-salad sandwiches at a delicatessen in Northern California. It took a show horse to pull him out from behind the counter, and the patience of a great many horsemen, but now Martin Garcia is one of the hottest jockeys in the nation.

headline: Cavs’ Run Ends; Uncertainty Starts
text: BOSTON — The pride of Akron, Ohio, walked away in silence Thursday night, moving swiftly and purposefully away from profound disappointment and into the great unknown.

headline: Art Auction Highlights a Financial Downfall
text: After watching millions and millions of dollars being casually spent on Warhols and Rauschenbergs, Picassos, Calders and Johnses at the spring art auctions of the last two weeks, it might seem that the money troubles of the recent past were little more than a bad dream. But a distress sale that took place at Phillips de Pury, the third-place auction house, on Thursday night was a reminder that the ghosts of the recession have not been fully exorcised.

headline: Lifesaving Devices Can Cause Havoc at Life’s End
text: When her father’s cancer became terminal, Carol Filak realized that making his final days comfortable involved something she had never thought about — turning off his heart defibrillator.

headline: Unwilling Subjects in the Algerian War
text: Stationed against his will in Algeria, during a war for independence that lasted from 1954 to 1962, Marc Garanger avoided direct combat with the Algerian people by maneuvering his way into service as the personal photographer for one of his superiors in the French army.

headline: Toughest Division? Tougher to Say Now
text: The American League East this season appears to be one of the strongest divisions since baseball went to the wild card in 1994. The Tampa Bay Rays and the Yankees are 1-2 in the American League in wins, with the Toronto Blue Jays fourth. Four of the five teams are above .500 and even the struggling Baltimore Orioles (10-24) are playing better outside of the division.

headline: Cars’ Computer Systems Called at Risk to Hackers
text: Automobiles, which will be increasingly connected to the Internet in the near future, could be vulnerable to hackers just as computers are now, two teams of computer scientists are warning in a paper to be presented next week.

headline: Top Lender to Rangers Has a Warning for Baseball
text: The top lender to the Texas Rangers has told Major League Baseball owners in a letter that the lengthy stalemate over the team’s sale could lead to the team’s bankruptcy or “costly, distracting and messy” litigation.

headline: Unstable Madagascar
text: After a coup in 2009,  humanitarian aid to Madagasar continued but other funds were withheld; the nation’s 20 million people were the collateral damage.

headline: Rogue General Shot During Thai Protests
text: Gen. Khattiya Sawatdiphol, who is allied with the red shirt protesters, was shot during an interview as the military planned to encircle the protesters.

headline: Bomb Scare Briefly Closes Union Sq.
text: The police cleared a portion of the Union Square area late Thursday after a Consolidated Edison employee reported seeing two gasoline canisters in the back of an Oldsmobile Cutlass that was parked in front of the utility company’s headquarters, law enforcement officials said.

text: prophetic •\prə-ˈfe-tik\• adjective

headline: Pound Ridge: A Public Course With a Private Touch
text: The Pound Ridge Golf Club became the first Pete Dye-designed golf course in the New York area when it opened in 2008. It was a public daily fee golf course just over the New York border from Stamford, Conn., which put it in the heart of an area replete with well-known and established private golf courses.

headline: A New York Outpost For Italian Design
text: A little bit of Italy is coming to West 53rd Street in Manhattan. In September the building at 40 West 53rd Street that formerly housed the Museum of Arts and Design, across the street from the Museum of Modern Art, will open as the Triennale di Milano New York, an exhibition-and-events center focused on Italian design. The building (above, a computer rendering), which is being renovated by the Italian architects Michele de Lucchi and Pierluigi Cerri, in collaboration with New York Studio CUH2a, will have a 9,000-square foot gallery as well as a restaurant, espresso bar, bookstore and shop. The original Triennale was founded in 1923 and is now a Milan foundation with a museum and library dedicated to design. In addition to its New York branch it recently established an outpost in Seoul, South Korea, and will open one in Shanghai. Its expansion is being supported by the Italian Ministry of Economic Development, and, in New York, by Artlivingny, a private company that will operate the commercial elements. The Triennale New York’s first exhibition will focus on the architect and designer Gio Ponti and will be organized by Germano Celant, the director of the Prada Foundation.

headline: Final Three for ‘Idol’
text: It all comes down to Crystal Bowersox, Lee DeWyze and Casey James, after Michael Lynche, below, didn’t make the cut Wednesday night on “American Idol.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, 19.1 million viewers tuned in for the “Idol” results episode, the night’s most-watched show over all. CBS was runner-up on the night with its procedurals “Criminal Minds” (12.9 million) and “CSI: NY” (11.4 million). NBC placed third as Sharon Stone continued her run on “Law & Order: SVU” (8.5 million). ABC finished fourth as “Modern Family” (10.1 million) used a tried and true sitcom storyline: the Hawaiian vacation episode.

headline: ‘Ragtime’ Is Stripped of Tony Nomination
text: The overseers of the Tony Awards announced on Thursday that they had withdrawn the 2010 Tony nomination given to the costume design work for the Broadway revival of “Ragtime” because those designs were predominantly the same as those used in the original 1998 production. The theater and film designer Santo Loquasto created the costumes for the original “Ragtime” and for this season’s revival, and several of the costumes in both productions bore similarities. Costume designs that “substantially duplicate” work from a previous production are not eligible for Tony Awards, according to the Tony rulebook, but no one involved with “Ragtime” or the Tony Awards made a determination about Mr. Loquasto’s designs before they were announced on May 4 as among the four nominees for best costume design for a musical. In a statement on Thursday, Tony Award Productions  a joint venture of the Broadway League and the American Theater Wing, which oversee the Tonys  said that the revival’s costume designs were too similar to the original designs to be eligible. “We learned this too late to remove the costumes from consideration by the nominators but feel that we cannot allow the designs to remain in contention this year, and we must regretfully withdraw them from consideration as a nominee in the best costume design of a musical category,” according to the statement. “There will be no replacement made for the nomination, and voters will vote for one of the three remaining nominees.” The other nominees are Marina Draghici for “Fela!,” Paul Tazewell for “Memphis” and Matthew Wright for “La Cage Aux Folles.”

headline: News Quiz | May 14, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

text: It is starting to feel as if everyone on Wall Street is under investigation by someone for something, Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash report in The New York Times.

headline: Portugal Mired as It Attempts Budget Cuts
text: José Gago da Graça owns a Portuguese real estate company and has two identical apartments in the same building in the heart of Lisbon. One rents for 2,750 euros ($3,480.21) a month, the other for almost 40 times less, 75 euros, Raphael Minder reports in The New York Times.

headline: Rocky Mountain High — Tech
text: Sixty engineers, entrepreneurs and financiers were sipping yerba mate tea at a coffee shop down the street from a bong-and-lingerie store on a recent sunny Tuesday in Boulder, and discussing how Boulder — usually seen as an enclave of hippies, marijuana dispensaries and rock climbers — has become a hotbed of capitalism.

headline: Thai Forces Move on Protesters as Tension Grows
text: BANGKOK — Thai troops on Friday fired tear gas and bullets at protesters, who responded with stones, slingshots and homemade rockets, turning parts of downtown Bangkok into a battlefield as the military tried to tighten its cordon around a broad area where the protesters have camped for weeks.

headline: Facebook Background a Mixed Political Blessing and More From Friday’s Bay Area Report
text: Does a Stint as Facebook’s Sheriff Help or Hurt a Politician? | Social media companies like Facebook are at the heart of intense debates over what privacy means in the 21st century, and how well Facebook users can be protected from predators of all sorts. As a Facebook executive, Chris Kelly confronted these policy choices daily. But the changes in online practices may be out of synch with public attitudes. If so, reports Chase Davis of California Watch, Mr. Kelly, a Democratic candidate for Attorney General who used to be charged with protecting security and privacy on Facebook, may soon be confronting some backlash. And while high-tech politicians are not much of a novelty these days, Mr. Kelly is among the first to emerge from the lightly regulated world of social media, where companies that collect and disseminate huge amounts of personal data from millions of users have been the focus of highly publicized privacy and security controversies.A Vineyard-Centric Bike Trail Is Born | One mile down, 43 to go.The Vine Trail in Napa is taking off thanks in large part to the leadership of Chuck McMinn of Vineyard 29, who spent 25 years in Silicon Valley at Intel and running start-ups. At a cost of roughly $1 million a mile, it will take years to complete the full length from the ferry terminal in Vallejo north to Calistoga. Mr. McMinn is applying the same energy to this project as he did to leveraging his high-tech skill and start-up fearlessness to build a gravity-flow winery with microturbine technology allowing it to generate its own electricity with extreme efficiency. Vineyard 29 became one of the hottest high-end wine brands. Then he turned his attention to philanthropic projects like the Vine Trail. It turned out that Mr. McMinn’s vision and expertise were the exact requirements to build the low-tech Vine Trail, which Mr. McMinn hopes to see finished within 10 years.

text: This week’s column is about a San Francisco man who found himself in the hot seat after he was outspoken about the questionable policies of Phil Ting, the city’s assessor-recorder.

But a distress sale that took place at Phillips de Pury, the third-place auction house, on Thursday night was a reminder that the ghosts of the recession have not been fully exorcised, The New York Times’s Carol Vogel writes.

headline: What Would Your Dream House Be Like?
text: The photo above is from an article about a man from Miami who decided to buy property in Costa Rica and build a house that was perfect for both his family and the location, though the property was in such a remote place they had to build a road to it first. If you could custom-build a dream house to your specifications, what would it look like? Where would it be? What special features would it have?

headline: Afghans Protest Deadly U.S. Raid
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A night raid by American troops in the eastern province of Nangarhar left at least 10 Afghans dead, and within hours, on Friday morning, protests by their relatives and friends turned violent, killing at least one other person, according to accounts from witnesses and Afghan officials.

headline: Ackermann Doubts That Greece Can Pay
text: Josef Ackermann, head of Deutsche Bank, said on German television he wasn’t sure if Greece would be able to service its debt as it now stands. “Whether or not Greece, over time, is in a position to perform that well — I dare to doubt it,” Mr. Ackermann said.

headline: SEB Confirms Search to Divest German Unit
text: SEB, a major Swedish bank, said Friday that it was in talks with several parties over the sale of its German retail banking network.

text: The beleaguered euro touched a new 14-month low on Friday, and global stocks were mostly lower, amid lingering nervousness about the state of Europe’s finances and the pace of the global recovery.

headline: Korean Steelmaker Set to Buy Daewoo International
text: South Korea’s Posco is set to clinch its biggest acquisition with a $3 billion deal to buy Daewoo International, as the world’s No.4 steelmaker tries to grab raw materials and boost sales overseas, Reuters reported.

headline: Ex-Lehman Executives Open a Hedge Fund
text: Former Lehman Brothers Asia executives, who headed the bank’s structured products division and its syndicate business, have opened their maiden hedge fund investing in distressed structured credit assets, called Oracle Capital, Reuters reported.

headline: Chrysler Concerned On G.M.’s Financing Plans
text: Chrysler raised concerns Thursday about reports that rival General Motors is interested in buying back the auto financing business from the former GMAC Financial Services, The Associated Press reported.

headline: ‘Night of Museums’ Adds Twitter
text: On Saturday, hundreds of museums across France — not to mention much of the rest of Europe — will stay open late, free of charge, offering a mix of guided visits, concerts and other special events in an annual program known as the Night of Museums. A total of 2,000 museums in 42 countries will join in the fun, but Paris, where the annual event started in 2005, will be the epicenter.

headline: For Foundry, V.C. the Old-Fashioned Way
text: Like students who choose to go to college in a small town to avoid the distractions of big-city life, the venture capitalists at Foundry Group have shunned Silicon Valley or New York for Boulder, Colo., The New York Times’s Claire Cain Miller writes.

headline: Companies: What Are They Good For?
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline: Prudential Plc Is Said to Outline Asia Asset Sales
text: Prudential Plc is expected to outline divestments of some Asian assets in its upcoming rights offering prospectus in an effort to appease shareholder concerns about its planned acquisition of American International Assurance, Reuters reported, citing a source familiar with the process.

headline: Is SAP Overpaying for Sybase?
text: SAP‘s planned purchase of Sybase for $5.8 billion to move ahead of archrival Oracle in the mobile data market has raised concerns the German software maker is paying too much, Reuters reported.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: The sheriff’s back in town, and the Wild West is fading. In a manner of speaking, these days are more Pat Garrett than Billy the Kid. Regulators on all fronts are encroaching on a free-wheeling, high-rolling industry for which some are, no doubt, already feeling nostalgia.

headline: Private Schools: Hope for the World’s Poor
text: Today’s idea: Low-cost private schools are outperforming government-run schools in poor neighborhoods around the world, an article says.

headline: After Long Ban, Western China Is Back Online
text: BEIJING — Full Internet service was restored to the vast western Chinese region of Xinjiang on Friday, 10 months after it was blocked following deadly ethnic rioting that convulsed the regional capital, Urumqi. The blockage was the longest and most widespread in China since the Internet became readily available throughout the country a decade ago.

headline: El-Erian Says U.S. Inflation May Accelerate
text: Although price pressures in the American economy are currently muted, inflation could accelerate in the United States in the next three to five years, the world’s biggest bond fund management company said Thursday.

headline: Responding to My Week in Cash Flow
text: I’d like to thank everyone who took the time to comment on my posts about cash flow. Here are some of those comments and a few further thoughts:One suggestion: use a credit union instead of a bank. Banks like to hold funds to make money off of the float.

headline: Stray Questions for: Joshua Cohen
text: Joshua Cohen is the author of three story collections and three novels, including, most recently, “Witz.”

headline: S.E.C. Said to Investigate Wall St. Muni Bets
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether Wall Street banks used their own money to bet  against municipal bonds  they had sold, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Changing the Narrative: Goldman Helps Illinois Bank
text: Goldman Sachs has agreed to invest $20 million in ShoreBank, a Chicago bank that aims to expand lending in poor communities, in an effort to help keep the bank from being seized by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline: Europe Hedge Fund Vote Is Expected to Go Against Britain

headline: Clegg’s Prize May Be New Voting System
text: What a difference a month makes. On April 7, one day into this year’s general election campaign in Britain, Nick Clegg, the leader of the Liberal Democrats, was heckled and nearly drowned out by laughter when he stood up in the House of Commons to discuss changing the electoral system in the United Kingdom (as the raw video embedded above shows). Struggling to make himself heard, Mr. Clegg had pointed at both Gordon Brown and David Cameron and accused the leaders of the two larger parties of “trying to fool people that they are serious about political reform.”

headline: The Local Talent on the Next Season of ‘Top Chef’
text: Among the contestants on Bravo’s seventh season of “Top Chef,” starting June 16, there will be a couple of names that should be familiar to New York City diners — Ed Cotton and Angelo Sosa.

headline: Tip of the Week: Jazzier Status Lines
text: Running out of hip things to say in your Facebook status line? If words escape you, try mixing things up with alt-code characters like hearts, music notes, and weather symbols. Alt codes provide alternative characters on a keyboard and are typically activated by turning on the NumLock key, holding down the Alt key and typing a number from 0 to 255. The Facebook Symbols site  has a full explanation, videos and characters you can cut and paste into your status line.

headline: Warming Imperils Lizards, Scientists Warn
text: Global warming is driving lizards in Mexico and across the globe toward extinction, according to a new study being published in the journal Science.

headline: Dad, Ice Box, Super Saver and the Triple Crown
text: In a “bucket list” moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont Stakes. She hasn’t stopped going to the races since — when she isn’t taking on a wildfire, hurricane or volcano as the nation’s leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

headline: China’s Premier Discusses School Attacks
text: BEIJING — Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China said Thursday that the Chinese government would examine the deeper social problems that might have led to the recent string of deadly attacks on schoolchildren.

headline: U.S. Retail Sales in April Beat Expectations
text: Sales continued to rise at American retail stores in April, an indication that the economic recovery was progressing.

headline: What if My Employer Decides Not to Offer Insurance?

headline: We Three Things | Grazing for Lamb
text: I’ve been spending early spring in Berkeley, Calif., where butchers, bakers and beeswax candle makers are greenwashing farm life for city folk. All movements include plenty of contradiction, and the Bay Area’s enthusiasm for animal advocacy lives cheek by jowl with its passions for do-it-yourself  butchery. This spring, all of the menu boards in the Gourmet Ghetto (a stretch of restaurants and purveyors offering the latest in food fashions) are listing Goldbergian variations of lamb, an animal I like in the fields and on my fork.

headline: The Finale, Perhaps, of ‘Law & Order’
text: People who work on the pioneering crime drama “Law & Order” were told Thursday afternoon that the show had been canceled after 20 seasons. But there were indications late Thursday that talks were continuing and that the show might still avoid cancellation, although NBC declined to comment. [NYT] (See also Metropolis.)

headline: Wall St. Slides, Fearing Return to a Recession
text: Investors, who had started the week reassured by the huge rescue of Europe’s indebted nations, expressed second thoughts on Friday, sending markets lower and further devaluing the euro on concerns that the austerity measures required by the bailout would stunt the Continent’s already anemic economic growth.

headline: Ben Bernanke’s Field Trip to Philly
text: PHILADELPHIA — When the government closed the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard in 1995 after two centuries of service, eliminating more than 7,000 jobs, the forlorn site was an emblem of the erosion of industrial production.

headline: Complaint Box | Ambulance Chasers
text: Getting involved in a minor auto accident can be a hassle, what with juggling alternate transportation and insurance claims, but even more annoying is the aftermath: the deluge of letters and calls from lawyers and medical professionals seeking to profit from your trouble.

headline: The Early Word: Spill Size
text: President Obama is scheduled to meet with cabinet members and other advisers on Friday concerning the oil disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, with questions now circulating over just how much oil is gushing from the stricken undersea well.

headline: Video Shows Violent Crackdown in Bangkok
text: Updated | 3:18 p.m. As my colleagues Thomas Fuller and Seth Mydans report from Bangkok, “Thai troops fired on antigovernment protesters on Friday, turning parts of downtown Bangkok into a battlefield as the military used gunfire and tear gas to try to seal off a broad area where demonstrators have camped for weeks.”

headline: Terra Firma Prevents EMI Default on Citi Loans
text: EMI said on Friday it has received confirmation that its owner, Terra Firma, has raised enough money to help the music company avoid defaulting on its Citigroup loans.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: Manga for the Bieber Set
text: What’s happening on the manga list this week would normally be news to celebrate at VIZ Media. There are nine new books on the list and eight of them belong to VIZ.

headline: Terra Firma Says EMI Won’t Default
text: Our friends at Dealbook report that Terra Firma has told EMI that it has raised the capital necessary to repay loans to Citigroup and that the storied music company will not default on its loans. Read the full post here.

headline: For Boomers, Sunblocks Come Late
text: I’M fair and blond, and one of my first memories as a toddler was the joy of peeling off my flaking skin in long strips after a sunburn. Growing up in the 1950s and ’60s, from spring to fall, we lived outdoors, and my face was often scorched a healthy red like the ruddy Marlboro Man on the TV commercials. Long after my body had turned brown, my face shone bright.

headline: Friday Reading: Tax Help Firm Accused of Misleading Clients
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Food Allergies Take a Toll on Families and Finances
text: A DEBATE has broken out over how many people in this country really have food allergies. But whatever the numbers, parents whose children have serious reactions to certain foods can attest to the distress — and high financial costs — such allergies can cause.

headline: Sampler: Drilling Ban Proposed, and Fugitive Pit Bull Found
text: Senators Propose Ban on Drilling Off the Pacific Coast | Six West Coast senators, including both of California’s, proposed on Thursday a permanent ban on coastal drilling in the Pacific. “We simply cannot afford the risk posed by oil drilling of our magnificent coast,” Senator Barbara Boxer said in a statement. The proposal is largely symbolic because there are no plans right now to open the West Coast to drilling. After the spill in the Gulf of Mexico, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger shelved an offshore drilling proposal that would have provided money to the state’s struggling park system. [The New York Times, The San Francisco Chronicle]

text: There were no surprises on Thursday as Air Products and Chemicals began its long-awaited campaign to unseat directors on the board of  Airgas.

text: On May 1, I expressed concern that BP’s choices in dealing with the unrelenting seabed oil gusher might be more shaped by corporate interests than the public interest.

headline: Word For Word: The Apple & Adobe Letters
text: As I reported on Thursday, Adobe is beginning a full-force print and Web advertising campaign to criticize Apple’s refusal to allow its Flash multimedia software on its iPhone operating system.

headline: A Circuit for the Silent Racers
text: ELECTRIC motorcycles may appeal mostly to the eco-conscious, but they also capture the imagination of the competition minded. Last June, the famed road races on the Isle of Man included a one-lap event for electric motorcycles called the TTXGP.

headline: After Complaints, Federal Agency Opens Investigation on Ford Windstars
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has opened an investigation into broken rear axles on 1999–2003 Ford Windstars.

headline: New Funding Proposed for Adult Day Centers
text: I wrote recently about the way adult day centers can provide health monitoring, social contact, meals and activities for older people who don’t thrive alone at home, while allowing participants to return to familiar surroundings at the end of the day.

headline: Palestinian Youth Shot Dead in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — A 16-year-old Palestinian boy who had been throwing stones at Israeli cars passing his West Bank village near the city of Ramallah was shot dead on Thursday after an Israeli settler whose car was hit opened fire.

headline: Silent and Green, but Not Quite There
text: THOUGH electric vehicles have been on the road in small numbers for more than a century, they have remained just over the horizon for mass market applications. But with automakers pledging to begin delivering E.V.’s in significant numbers in coming months, this year could prove a turning point.

headline: Twenty-Nine Imperials for One ‘Green Hornet’
text: TO film scenes of the car used by the Green Hornet, the picture car coordinator had to provide the production with 29 1964-66 Chrysler Imperials. Some of the cars had to be modified with roll cages, several were cut in half and another had to be made strong enough to survive jumps. Here’s a rundown on how the 29 cars were used for  “The Green Hornet”  :

headline: The Man Who Never Was
text: In February of 1943, a cast of colorful oddballs developed and carried out one of the most elaborate deceptions of World War II, a plan to disguise the impending Allied invasion of Sicily, framed around the body of a dead man. The deceased, who would wash up on the Spanish coast, was a complete fraud, but the lies he would carry from Room 13 of the British Admiralty all the way to Hitler’s desk would help win the war. “The defining feature of this spy would be his falsity,” Ben Macintyre writes in “Operation Mincemeat.” “He was a pure figment of imagination, a weapon in a war far removed from the traditional battle of bombs and bullets.”

headline: ‘Operation Mincemeat': The Man Who Was
text: In “Operation Mincemeat,” reviewed in this Sunday’s issue by Jennet Conant, Ben Macintyre tells the story of how British intelligence used a corpse with a trumped-up military identity to convey spurious documents to fool the Nazis ahead of the Allied invasion of Sicily. The tale is perhaps best known from the 1956 movie “The Man Who Never Was,” starring Clifton Webb and Gloria Grahame. The title refers to “Maj. William Martin,” the nonexistent officer wrapped in the corpse.

headline: Bear Down
text: Video | This goes to show you that a mother’s cub doesn’t fall too far from the tree:

headline: One Man Bats for Himself, and One Switches Sides
text: Every now and then we get a defendant who does not trust the system and deems himself best suited to play the role of his own lawyer in court — better suited, that is, than someone who went to law school.

headline: Where the Stars Are Built, Not Born
text: THE makers of “Bullitt” reportedly put together that film’s legendary car chase in 1968 using two 1968 Dodge Chargers and two 1968 Ford Mustangs. In 1977, the director Hal Needham recalls, all of the mayhem in “Smokey and the Bandit” was accomplished with five black 1977 Pontiac Firebird Trans Ams.

headline: Jobless Recovery
text: Once upon a time, not so very long ago, Dominique Browning had the world at her feet. She had written two inspiring and widely admired books that combined tantalizing fragments of memoir with graceful meditations on the healing power of place. She had — so the first of those books, “Around the House and in the Garden,” told us — allowed her own home to salve the wounds caused by the brusque ending of a 15-year marriage. “Paths of Desire,” Browning’s follow-up book, applied the same treatment, with the same entrancing combination of humor and humanity, to a beloved garden. What Browning scarcely mentioned in either book was that for nearly 13 years she was also the editor in chief of House & Garden magazine. Work, she now confesses, was “the scaffolding of my life.”

headline: Ford’s Twin-Turbo V-6: It’s All Gain, No Pain
text: OF all the conundrums faced by car-shopping friends, this spurs the most calls for my advice: “We need room for the family, but we don’t want a giant S.U.V. And no matter what, do not tell us to get a minivan.”

headline: ‘Nothing to Do but Kill and Wait’
text: For five years American soldiers manned a series of outposts in what was perhaps the most hostile corner in all of Afghanistan. The place was the Korangal Valley, which unfolds beneath the crags and terraced ridges of Kunar Province about 25 miles from the border with Pakistan. The idea was to put Americans on the ground to intercept Taliban fighters who were passing through to fight in other parts of the country.

headline: Obama Points Finger on Oil Mess
text: 2:30 p.m. | Updated  President Obama delivered a statement on BP and the seabed oil gusher today, decrying the “ridiculous spectacle” of the three main companies involved in the mess pointing fingers at each other in congressional hearings.

headline: Picture Cars
text: movie cars

headline: Stopping Pain Without Drugs
text: As a non-surgeon practicing at the busiest orthopedic surgery hospital in the country, Dr. Vijay Vad stands out. Instead of sending his patients to surgery, his goal is to keep them out of it. A sports medicine specialist at New York’s Hospital for Special Surgery who regularly works with professional golfers and tennis players, Dr. Vad is a believer in the power of the mind-body connection and regularly prescribes yoga exercises and other alternative strategies for his patients. He is also the author of the new book “Stop Pain: Inflammation Relief for an Active Life,’’ which is packed with practical advice and self-care options to help chronic pain patients reduce their dependence on narcotics and avoid additional medical procedures.

headline: An Oblique Life
text: Margaret Mayfield is 5 years old when her brother ­Lawrence takes her to see a public hanging. The year is 1883 and the place is Darlington, Mo., 300 miles from St. Louis. The rest of her family has other concerns that day: her mother is at home giving birth and her father, known to all, even his children, as Dr. Mayfield, is attending. Margaret will later claim not to remember much at all about what she saw, allowing only “a ghostly recollection of this bit or that bit — of her hand reaching up into Lawrence’s hand, or of him handing her a bit of a crab apple, or of her bonnet hanging over her eyes so that she couldn’t see anything except her feet.”

headline: Celtics’ Revival Lost in the Fixation on James
text: This just in: there were other players on the floor besides LeBron James during the Cleveland Cavaliers loss in Game 6 at the TD Banknorth Garden.

headline: Truce in Gay Actor Debate?
text: After calling for a boycott of Newsweek, Ryan Murphy, a creator of the Fox television series “Glee,” has invited the writer of a piece about gay actors published on the magazine’s Web site to watch the show’s writers and its casting process at work. Mr. Murphy called for the boycott after Ramin Setoodeh wrote that gay actors should not portray heterosexual men because they were not believable in such roles. According to Entertainment Weekly, Mr. Setoodeh contacted Mr. Murphy and is going to meet with the show’s writers to discuss why they found the piece so offensive and watch the creative process. In a letter Mr. Murphy sent to EW, he said that Mr. Setoodeh felt misunderstood and was receiving anonymous attacks.

headline: The Ecstasy and the Ecstasy
text: What is it about church that is so damn sexy? The question has bugged me for a long time. An erotic current runs just below the displays of rectitude and purity, despite the hard pews and organ repertory. I suspect it has to do with the congregants’ concerted effort to suppress carnality in favor of distant heavenly rewards. Denying the flesh only makes it throb harder. It’s tricky to defeat one’s own biology, especially when young. It bubbles up during sermons as eyes and thoughts wander. The nape of a boy’s neck sitting two rows up — that modest strip of naked flesh between hairline and suit jacket — can surprisingly arouse.

headline: The Morning Line: Got a Preakness Winner?
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

headline: James’s Off-Season Begins
text: It’s official now that the Cavaliers have lost. It is no longer the National Basketball Association. It’s the National LeBron Association. There are four teams left playing? Really? Will anyone notice? Or will they all be staring mindlessly at the LeBron James free-agency countdown clock so helpfully posted on ESPN’s New York site? Absorbing the endless stories of which direction King James glanced on his way to Krispy Kreme?

headline: The 411 on 311
text: Facts and figures about 311, New York City’s phone number created to field complaints and questions of any kind about the city.

headline: Endangered Species: The Telephone Call
text: I hate talking on the phone.

headline: Henry Rising
text: “The Dead Republic” tells of the later life of Henry Smart, an Irishman born in 1901: a “handsome man” to all the women, an I.R.A. hit man as a teenager, a con man after he arrives in the United States in 1924, and almost a dead man when the director John Ford finds him in the Utah desert in 1946. These events were recounted in Roddy Doyle’s novels “A Star Called Henry” and “Oh, Play That Thing.” But if you don’t already know Henry, “The Dead Republic” is an excellent place to meet him — because it’s the best of Doyle’s trilogy and because in it Henry reviews his past while serving as Ford’s consultant for a movie about the Irish revolution.

headline: This Really Happened: ‘Don’t Stop Believin” Performed by Elton John, Lady Gaga, Sting and Bruuuuuuuce
text: We heard rumblings of this on Twitter last night, but we didn’t believe it until we saw it with our own eyes (after being pointed to it by The Awl): a Thursday-night benefit concert for the Rainforest Fund brought together Sting, Lady Gaga, Elton John, Shirley Bassey, Debbie Harry and Bruce Springsteen on a Carnegie Hall stage. So what does this all-star lineup sing? “Don’t Stop Believin'” by Journey, which is the mathematical average of the six performers, we guess? In any case, it’s like the best episode of “Glee” ever.

headline: The Education of Diane Ravitch
text: Attending high school in Houston in the 1950s, Diane Ravitch came into contact with a teacher named Ruby Ratliff. A passionate lover of literature and a fierce editor of homework, Ratliff, following Tennyson, told Ravitch “to strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield.” The student evidently followed the teacher’s advice. Ravitch, a historian of American education and assistant secretary of education under the first George Bush, has long sought to find out what makes schools work. She has now found what that is, or at least what it isn’t: choice and testing. Her case against both is unyielding.

headline: Insights From a Week as a 311 Operator in N.Y.
text: THE lovely sounding gentleman on the other end of the line was simply trying to improve his corner of the world. Instead, he was rapidly losing faith in city government. As I placed him on hold for the third time, I heard him mutter: “She’s having a hard time finding it! It was on 1010 WINS this morning!”

headline: Older Moms, Grandparents and Hand-Me-Down Highchairs
text: The first time I had even a fleeting thought of my own grandchildren came last weekend, as I lobbed most of the contents of my garage into a rented dumpster. (Yep, that’s what I asked for on Mother’s Day. Best gift ever!) Cracked bike helmets, followed by rain-stiffened mitts, followed by sand-filled boogie boards, followed by bent tennis rackets. As I purged my boys’ pasts I didn’t look back.

headline: Odd Smells in New Orleans, Thoughts of the Gulf
text: NEW ORLEANS — At almost 300 years old, somewhat moldy from the remnants of Hurricane Katrina and surrounded by muddy water and swamps, this city is not exactly known for being lemony fresh.

headline: Keef Speaks!
text: It’s Keith Richards! Of the Rolling Stones! On “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon!” He’s mostly intelligible! Charming, even! What more do you need to know?

headline: Love 'em or Hate 'em, New York's White Brick Buildings
text: Manhattan’s white-brick buildings have never exactly been anyone’s dream house. But they are hard to beat for value, and their clean lines are drawing midcentury design fans.

headline: From Destruction Comes Beauty, Sometimes
text: The other day there was a pretty sunrise, and we wondered whether it might be a belated gift from our old friend Eyjafjallajokull.

headline: The Pretender
text: Over the past 10 years, Paul Berman has been exploring a theme: the repudiation by liberal intellectuals of their values and ideals. The theme has been elaborated in several books — “Terror and Liberalism,” “Power and the Idealists” and now “The Flight of the Intellectuals.” Berman himself is a man who identifies “with the liberal left.”

headline: Q&A | Tom Dixon
text: At this year’s ICFF, the British designer Tom Dixon will present his new INDUSTRY line, as well as the first in a series of limited-edition, self-published books to be updated and re-released every few months. Dixon will also host the Flash Factory, a hands-on booth where his $175, digitally-manufactured Etch lamp will be made on the spot.  Conceived for the ICFF and last month’s Milan Furniture Fair, Etch demonstrates Dixon’s hopes for the design industry of the future, wherein individual designers will control the entire design process, from concept to consumption, offering mass customization to consumers.

headline: Death of a Dream
text: When asked what he hopes to achieve with a book, the nonfiction writer James B. Stewart likes to say that his goal is to “inform and entertain,” a premise that might raise eyebrows in fustier quarters. But this is a worthy balance for popular history, I think. After all, mounds of new material don’t do much good if a book is too dull or dense a slog. Slighting fresh research in favor of entertainment, however, means you end up with Abe Lincoln the vampire hunter.

headline: Inside the List
text: FATHER KNOWS BEST: Last August, Justin Halpern was a 28-year-old semi-employed comedy writer living with his parents in Los Angeles when he decided to start posting his 73-year-old father’s irascible, foul-mouthed wisdom on a Twitter feed that we’ll call “Stuff My Dad Says.” Nine months later, he has more than a million followers, a deal for a sitcom starring William Shatner (tentatively titled “Bleep My Dad Says”) and a book at No. 8 on the hardcover nonfiction list. It’s tough to quote from the book in a family newspaper, but a few recent nuggets from the Twitter feed give a bit of the flavor. On being a proud papa: “A parent’s only as good as their dumbest kid. If one wins a Nobel Prize but the other gets robbed by a hooker, you failed.” On marriage: “Pressure? Get married when you want. Your wedding’s just one more day in my life I can’t wear sweat pants.”

headline: NBC Cancels ‘Law & Order’
text: NBC confirmed Friday that it had canceled the original “Law & Order,” bringing an end to a 20-year-old television drama that jump-started an era of television production in New York City.

headline: Up Front: Anthony Julius
text: If a public intellectual is someone who can discourse knowledgeably on a wide variety of subjects, then Anthony Julius is surely one of England’s leading public intellectuals. A visiting professor at London University, he has written books on T. S. Eliot, on modern art and, most recently, on anti-Semitism in England (which Harold Bloom, last week in the Book Review, described as “a strong, somber book on an appalling subject”).

headline: New Rules for Congressional Travel
text: The House Democratic leadership took steps Friday to curb the costs of accommodating globetrotting members by putting new restrictions on Congressional travel — one of the favorite perks of House membership.

headline: New Qaeda ‘War Minister’ Warns of ‘Days Colored in Blood’
text: BAGHDAD – A man purporting to be the new military commander of the Islamic State of Iraq, the front for Al Qaeda in Iraq, has warned of “a long gloomy night and dark days colored in blood,” according to a statement circulated on Friday.

headline: The Financial Burden of Food Allergies
text: In this week’s Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad explores the heavy financial burden parents face when a child is given a diagnosis of food allergies. She tells the story of the Delgadillo family in San Diego, who spend about $400 a month on costs associated with son Andrew’s food allergies.

headline: Weird Tales of GP2 Winners
text: MONACO — Friday is traditionally a down day in Monaco for Formula One. I have come to the paddock anyway to do some interviewing and catch up on a few things, and it is the perfect time to tell a story that I had been intending to talk about since last week in Barcelona, but which I’m glad I didn’t have the time for.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: TRIALS OF THE DIASPORA: A History of Anti-Semitism in England,  by Anthony Julius (Oxford University, $45.) Julius’s fiercely relevant book is particularly strong on Shylock, Fagin and the whole cavalcade of anti-Semitism in English literature.

headline: Paperback Row
text: FORDLANDIA: The Rise and Fall of Henry Ford’s Forgotten Jungle City,  by Greg Grandin.  (Picador, $16.) Henry Ford needed rubber to make tires for his cars, and Europeans controlled the Asian markets. So in 1927, he bought 2.5 million acres on the banks of a tributary of the Amazon. The plan was not only to grow rubber but to share the benefits of Ford-style capitalism (high wages, moral improvement) with American managers and Brazilian workers alike. To that end, a replica Midwestern town was built in the jungle. It didn’t turn out well, Grandin (inset) explains. “ ‘Heart of Darkness’ resonates through every page,” our reviewer, Ben Macintyre, said. A quarter-century earlier, American workers in the Panama Canal Zone lived in settlements that resembled gated communities. In THE CANAL BUILDERS: Making America’s Empire at the Panama Canal  (Penguin, $18) , Julie Greene recreates the lives of the 60,000 people who actually built the canal — the unskilled laborers from Jamaica and Barbados who did the dirty, dangerous jobs, and the Americans in segregated neighborhoods who found themselves “as comfortable here as in Illinois,” in one visitor’s words.

headline: Censors Without Borders
text: The Chinese-Canadian writer Denise Chong’s 1994 book “The Concubine’s Children,” a memoir of her maternal grandparents, won admiring reviews and spent more than a year and a half on The Globe and Mail’s best-seller list. But when her later book, “Egg on Mao,” came out in 2009, many people responded with trepidation. “What I heard most often was, ‘Is this a China-bashing book?’ ” Chong told me over the phone. When I saw the cover, I understood. It features a photo of Chairman Mao’s paint-splattered face underneath the bold type: “The Story of an Ordinary Man Who Defaced an Icon and Unmasked a Dictatorship.” The book tells the true story of Lu Decheng, who threw paint-filled eggs at Mao’s portrait in Tiananmen Square during the 1989 protests.

headline: Robert Hass’s Empathy and Desire
text: The publication of a volume of selected ­poems is an appropriate occasion to appraise a poet’s career, and an equally appropriate occasion to wonder why we use the word “career” in connection with poetry at all. Many readers would agree with Randall Jarrell’s definition of a poet as someone “who manages, in a lifetime of standing out in thunderstorms, to be struck by lightning five or six times.” This assumes that writing poetry is mostly a matter of waiting and hoping, which in turn raises questions about how confident we can be in discussing (to say nothing of criticizing) a poet’s development. As long as the writer in question makes a valiant effort to prepare himself for revelation — as long as he greets every raindrop by waving a putter, like Bishop Pickering in  “Caddyshack”  — is it really his fault if the lightning striketh not?

headline: TimesCast | May 14, 2010
text: Today, more deaths as police move in on anti-government protesters in Bangkok, growing questions about oil drilling permits in the Gulf of Mexico and a Preakness Preview ahead of Saturday's race.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: THE CHANGELING  By Kenzaburo Oe. Translated by Deborah Boliver Boehm. Grove, $26.

headline: Talking Preakness With Alex Brown
text: Join The Rail’s Alex Brown for his weekly radio show as he talks about the Preakness with two other exercise riders, Andy Durnin and Bob Hatfield, and a guest handicapper, Lisa Grimm.

headline: What Percentage of Your Employee Health Plan Do You Cover?
text: In today’s post, Paul Downs gets at an intriguing question. One of his readers was under the impression that Paul was covering 100 percent of his employee health plan costs. Actually, Paul said, he’s paying 70 percent, and his employees pay the rest.

headline: Sharks Hope Momentum Is Not Lost While They Wait
text: Hello, San Jose Sharks … are you still there?

headline: Weekend Competition: Punch Lines in Search of a Joke
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to suggest punch lines for jokes they can’t be bothered to write.

headline: Europe’s Turmoil Weighs on UBS and Credit Suisse
text: Richard X. Bove, the banking analyst at Rochdale Securities, downgraded the Swiss banks UBS and Credit Suisse to “neutral” from “buy” on Friday, citing “a deteriorating situation in Europe’s financial community” for the cut. The move comes as European markets continued to slide amid growing uncertainty over the stability of the euro, which traded at an 18-month low to the dollar on Friday.

headline: What Is Art? Considering and Creating Artistic Works
text: Overview | What is art? Do contemporary installations challenge student notions of what art is “supposed” to be and do? In this lesson, students experience various works of fine and performance art in the classroom and online as well as consider artists’ and critics’ definitions of art. They then create their own definitions and express them in the form of original works for an evening gallery opening.

headline: Alex Abrams
text: Mr. Abrams, 44, is an executive vice president of the Real Estate Disposition Corporation, or R.E.D.C., of Irvine, Calif., one of the country’s largest real estate auction companies.

headline: Obama’s Remarks on Oil Spill Response
text: Following are President Obama's remarks on the response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, as provided by the White House.

headline: Liquor License Procedures Return to Normal as Backlogs Decline
text: And now, stunning news from Albany: the demise of a program that was so successful it will soon cease to exist.

headline: NBC Cancels ‘Law & Order’
text: In a blow to New York actors looking to build their résumés, NBC confirmed Friday that it had canceled the original “Law & Order,” bringing an end to a 20-year-old television drama that jump-started an era of television production in New York City, according to our colleagues at the Media Decoder blog

headline: Animal Crossing
text: Looking at different picture books can feel like taking different kinds of walks in the wood. As you turn the pages the pictures influence the pace at which you read and the attention you give to the images. Some books may feel like being in a forest with tree branches beckoning forward, encouraging you to move at a steady pace down the path. (William Steig is the master of this kind of book, his drawings, easy-going and efficient, so inextricably linked to his words that they lead effortlessly to the conclusion.) An­other kind of book may feel more like a great allée of oaks where you are inclined to stop and admire the whorls and indentations of particular trees. In yet another, the experience is more akin to walking through an arboretum, where every turn brings you face to face with an exciting new specimen of bush or flower.

headline: Choosing Sides
text: Robert Lipsyte’s superb young adult novel “Center Field” makes you wonder if it’s possible to be neglected and smothered at the same time. Mike Semak, the hero, is basically home alone. His parents, at once overly solicitous and absent, fret over every detail of his high school career while spending all their time at their new flooring store. A passing altercation in a hallway with another student draws threats of lawsuits and criminal charges. Mike’s baseball team, and apparently much of his school, Ridgedale High, is run by Coach Cody, a mysterious former Army Ranger hired as dean of discipline because “there had been gang violence and drug dealing in nearby New Jersey towns. The school board was afraid it would spread to Ridgedale.”

headline: Bridge Between Generations
text: Twelve short chapters into Louis Sachar’s young adult novel “The Card­turner,” a whale appears. The whale is an inch long, gray and centered above the text; its job is to indicate that the next few paragraphs consist of what the novel’s protagonist, Alton Richards, calls “bridge gibberish,” the uniquely dotty lingo of the card game bridge.

headline: Life After the Mississippi
text: What if your child wrote a book about your life? How would the story of your days read when channeled through those shrewd, ­judgmental eyes? Would you seem like God when God walked in the garden, or would you seem like Papa Doc, the tyrant, the crafter of rules and breaker of ­treaties?

headline: Inside, Looking Out
text: Reese Anderson lives in a 93-inch-square jail cell. At 14, he’s spent the past 22 months locked away for stealing prescription pads and selling them to a drug dealer. He’ll be up for release soon. But it’s hard to keep your mind on freedom when everyone around you seems bent on self-­destruction. Even the name of the jail, the Progress Center, sounds darkly ironic. What could progress possibly mean in a place like this?

headline: Blood, Sweat and Teeth
text: If it is a rite of passage to become your most unattractive self when you first hit adolescence, what would it be like if you added traumatic dental surgery on top? Raina Telgemeier knows because it happened to her, and she tells the story in witty and harrowing detail in her graphic-novel memoir, “Smile.”

headline: My Life in Pictures
text: Memory is an act of preservation. To remember, you have to do something: pay attention, take a picture, nab a souvenir. Laurel Croza’s “I Know Here” is a simple and profound book about a child who, on learning her family is moving, draws pictures of her home as keepsakes.

headline: Living Large
text: Written especially for the vertically challenged, John Schwartz’s “Short: Walking Tall When You’re Not Tall at All” identifies a well-known coping strategy among those of us who were half-pints. In a world of alpha dogs (bullies at skating rinks, high school girls making slighting comments) we became the smart alecks, the sidekicks, the class clowns. Later in life, Schwartz observes, the related verbal skills can wonderfully pave the way to a career in, say, the upper echelons of journalism (Schwartz is the national legal correspondent for The New York Times and an occasional contributor to these pages). Given that logic, you may wonder whether the newspaper you are currently reading was prepared primarily by those known during their school days as “shrimp.”

headline: Our Preakness Picks, Down to the Wire
text: The Rail’s contributors make their Preakness selections.

headline: Seedorf Responds: Doping, Champions League and the World Cup
text: Q.

headline: Google Admits Defeat in Selling Nexus One Direct
text: Google’s flagship Nexus One phone debuted earlier this year to much fanfare. The phone was not only flashy — evocative of Apple’s iPhone in many respects — but Google was also using it to try to change the dynamics of the wireless industry by selling it directly from its Web store and bypassing the powerful wireless carriers.

headline: Letterman: ‘Brown is Out’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: They got a new prime minister in Great Britain. Name is David Cameron, and he has pledged to protect the country from terrorism. So today, he met with the nation’s top T-shirt vendors.

headline: Obama Vows End to ‘Cozy’ Oversight of Oil Industry
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday angrily assailed the finger-pointing among the three companies involved in the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico as a “ridiculous spectacle,” even as his own administration came under criticism for failing to do enough to prevent an environmental calamity.

headline: Waddell Named as Mystery Trader in Market Plunge
text: 6:58 p.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Nelson D. Schwartz provides more details about Waddell & Reed’s role in the market plunge.

headline: Living in Wakefield, the Bronx
text: Wakefield, one of the northernmost places in the Bronx, and therefore the city, shares a suburban character with Westchester, its neighbor across the border.

headline: After Flood, Repairs at Opry
text: Damaged by a flood two weeks ago, country music’s mecca, the Grand Ole Opry House in Nashville, is in the midst of major repairs. The hall has been stripped to its concrete foundation, The Associated Press reported. The famous six-foot circle cut from the floorboards of the Opry’s old home at the Ryman Auditorium and incorporated into the Opry’s stage has been salvaged, Steve Buchanan, president of the Grand Ole Opry, said, adding that it would receive a few new coats of varnish.

headline: Flation
text: Ever since the economic crisis began there have been two schools of thought about inflation prospects. One school basically has a Phillips curve, aggregate demand view: because major economies are operating far below full employment, we should expect disinflation, and possibly deflation. The other is basically monetarist with a touch of Austrianism: look at all the money central banks are printing and governments are borrowing, it says, inflation — maybe even hyperinflation — is just around the corner.

headline: Leno: ‘Tar Balls Have Started Washing Ashore’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: At a stop in Buffalo today, a woman walked up to President Obama and said, “You’re a hottie with a smokin’ little body.” I’ll tell you, Betty White is out of control.

headline: An Enclave at the Bronx’s Border With Westchester
text: THE elevated subway line that clatters northward through the Bronx on White Plains Road comes to an unceremonious stop, just before the city line, at 241st Street. After the hulking metal tracks end, there is nothing overhead but sky. Two more blocks up, at 243rd Street, the street signs change from green to blue, and Westchester County begins.

headline: High Season | Montauk’s Navy Beach
text: Even with the raucous Surf Lodge (locals tend to sidestep it) and summer visitors Robert De Niro and Gwyneth Paltrow on the scene, the vibe in Montauk is  still decidedly laid-back.

headline: Why Libertarianism Doesn’t Work, Part N
text: Thinking about BP and the Gulf: in this old interview, Milton Friedman says that there’s no need for product safety regulation, because corporations know that if they do harm they’ll be sued.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Scott Turow
text: This week: a conversation with novelist Scott Turow about his long-awaited sequel to “Presumed Innocent”; The Times’s legal reporter John Schwartz discusses his new children’s book about the perils of being short; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Blown Up Yet Again, to Movie Size
text: HAS any Hollywood institution shown more dogged persistence than the “Saturday Night Live” spinoff movie? Over the past 30 years team after team of directors, screenwriters and comedians has tackled a vexing task: turning a successful sketch into a successful feature film. Meanwhile audiences have wondered why “SNL” even keeps trying.

headline: Doctors Found Guilty of Malpractice, but Not Wrongful Death
text: A civil jury found two doctors committed malpractice in their treatment of an Italian cancer patient but were not responsible for her death, a mixed verdict that did little to resolve larger questions about a controversial cancer treatment program at Staten Island University Hospital.

headline: A Country Retreat in Brooklyn
text: The artist Joan Snyder and her partner, Maggie Cammer, live in a two-story building with a graceful front porch in Brooklyn.

headline: The Climate Bills, Side by Side
text: Many of the differences between the House and Senate climate and energy bills are so slight that you could almost call them similarities, judging from a side-by-side comparison put together by the National Commission on Energy Policy, a bipartisan advisory group.

headline: A Brooklyn House With Country Roots
text: THE artist Joan Snyder has lived in many places in her 70 years.

headline: The Struggle to Preserve the Brooklyn Navy Yard
text: FOR three years, some of the most powerful forces in New York real estate — including the federal and city governments, developers, preservationists and community advocates — have fought over the fate of a cluster of historically significant turn-of-the-last-century houses known as Admiral’s Row in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

headline: Focusing on Dublin, With the Help of an Informant
text: The creator of the acclaimed HBO series “The Wire,” David Simon worked at The Baltimore Sun for 12 years. His latest show, a post-Katrina look at New Orleans called “Treme,” airs on Sunday nights on HBO.

headline: What We’re Reading: Intelligent Night Owls
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Seeing White Brick Buildings in a New Light
text: WHEN Lori Berger began looking for a Manhattan pied-à-terre three years ago, she came armed with a list of priorities. The West Side was preferable to the East because it would simplify the drive into the city from her family’s primary residence in Fairfield, Conn. She wanted outdoor space, which took most prewar buildings off the table. And because she and her husband had lived through kitchen and bathroom renovations at home, they wanted an apartment that they could move into right away.

headline: The Tangled Vine Opens on the Upper West Side
text: By any measure, the Tangled Vine is a welcome addition to New York’s thriving community of wine bars. But by the special calculus required to assess restaurants on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Tangled Vine is manna from heaven.

headline: When Salad Meets Sandwich
text: “Since I’ve never seen a sandwich in an airport that I’d want to eat, I like to pack a lunch,” writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: A Compatible Apartment, With Charm
text: ANDREA SYRTASH realized one day why she should marry her good friend Michael Paoli. Because he was the one person she wouldn’t mind being stuck in a foxhole with.

headline: Brokers Divide on Utility of Public Open Houses
text: THE thought of holding a public open house makes Paul A. Falla wince: strangers traipsing through his five-bedroom contemporary in White Plains, peering into his closets, opening the kitchen cabinets and checking out the equipment in his home theater.

headline: A Tough Time for Self-Employed Borrowers
text: MOST borrowers are facing a much tougher mortgage environment than a few years ago, but for those who are self-employed or own small businesses, maneuvering through a loan application can be even more arduous.

headline: Film-Shoot Homes Generate Buzz and Buyers
text: THE tulips in front of Debbie Regan’s 1907 Old Westbury colonial were temporarily camouflaged by boxwoods. Her living room sofas had been moved to the attic to make room for more traditional couches. Heavy chintz drapes had been hung over her sheer white curtains. Though it was May 6, a winter garland festooned her porch and a Christmas wreath hung on her front door.

headline: In Newark, Housing for Artists and Others
text: NEWARK
