text: This week: a conversation with novelist Scott Turow about his long-awaited sequel to “Presumed Innocent”; The Times’s legal reporter John Schwartz discusses his new children’s book about the perils of being short; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Is Clinton in Goldman’s Corner?
text: Goldman Sachs has gained more than a few critics lately, especially in light of the Securities and Exchange Commission‘s civil charges.

headline: He’s Big, He’s Green, and He’s Gone
text: SOONER or later every fairy tale reaches its happily ever after. For “Shrek,” the long-running animated fantasy franchise about a curmudgeonly ogre (voiced by Mike Myers), his human-turned-ogre wife, Fiona (Cameron Diaz), and his pals Donkey (Eddie Murphy) and Puss in Boots (Antonio Banderas), that time is now. On Friday, DreamWorks Animation and Paramount will release “Shrek Forever After,” the fourth  and, the studios say, final  installment in the series, in which the titular green guy is thrown into an alternate version of his Far, Far Away kingdom where he never existed and life turned out much differently for his pals. Before the storybook shuts for good, Dave Itzkoff asked some of the “Shrek” stars about the series and what its ending means to them. These are excerpts from the conversations.

headline: Protesters Clash With Troops in Thailand
text: At least four people were killed in fighting as the military moved to seal off a broad area of the capital where antigovernment protesters have camped for weeks.

headline: Linked In | The Curious Case of Samuel’s Button
text: Samuel Gassmann readily admits to being a curator, art consultant, photojournalist and audiovisual portraitist. One title he will not accept: designer. How, then, did he happen to launch a collection of cufflinks last fall?

headline: Shuttle Atlantis Lifts Off for Final Planned Flight
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — The space shuttle Atlantis, carrying a crew of six, a Russian docking module and critical spare parts, vaulted into orbit Friday on a 12-day space station assembly mission, the orbiter’s 32nd and final planned flight after a quarter century of service.

headline: Moral Babies and Painters on High
text: Babies telling right from wrong. A county with 13 prisons. A defense of acting. And a look at the vanishing art of sign painting.

headline: Malevolent Design
text: In his tragicomic first novel, “The Dream of Perpetual Motion,” Dexter Palmer takes elements from Nabokov, Neal Stephenson, Steven Millhauser and “The Tempest,” tosses them into a retro-futuristic blender and hits “purée.” The result is a singular riff on steampunk — sophisticated, subversive entertainment that never settles for escapism.

headline: A Star (Charmingly) Sells the Goods at Cannes
text: CANNES, France — My 10 minutes with Michael Douglas ran precisely 13:58. That, at least, is the time on my recorder, though the hovering, smiling, apologetic if insistent publicist tried to cut it short. Mr. Douglas and I shared our 13 long minutes together on Thursday afternoon on the roof of the Palais Stéphanie, a hôtel de luxe facing the Mediterranean that was recently spiffed up with striped carpeting and a giant palm frond – as in Palme d’Or, the highest prize at the Cannes Film Festival – which juts up like an obelisk in the yawning lobby. We were there to discuss his return to his most famous character, Gordon Gekko, the Wall Street don who made us feel so good about greed. “Everybody,” Mr. Douglas said with a laugh, “likes a bad guy.”

headline: The Accidental Mom
text: More than once in Marina Endicott’s new novel, “Good to a Fault,” you might wonder if you’ve wandered into the world of Barbara Pym and her “excellent women.” There’s the poetry-quoting Anglican vicar who lacks a proper helpmeet. And the wittily rendered minutiae of a meddlesome community. And, of course, an inquisitive spinster, Clara Purdy, defined by the absence of Event in her life. Even the metaphors seem plucked from lavender and mothballs. “Her self,” we are told of Clara, “was an abandoned sampler, half the letters unstitched, the picture in the middle still vague.” Yet we’re not in postwar England but in contemporary Saskatchewan, and Clara’s life is about to be filled with Event. It comes in the first paragraph.

headline: The Morning Skate: Mitchell Calls Campbell’s Rulings Into Question
text: Canucks defenseman Willie Mitchell, who missed the balance of the N.H.L. season and the playoffs after suffering a concussion on a January 16 hit by the Penguins’ Evgeni Malkin, spoke for the first time yesterday about the hit. The fact that Malkin was not suspended by the N.H.L. caused Mitchell to say he was “disappointed in the league” and “disappointed in Colin Campbell,” the N.H.L, senior vice president of hockey operations who handles player discipline.

headline: Chameleon Fever, but No Malaria
text: 8th May 2010, Madagascar

headline: I Do. I Do. I Do. I Do.
text: Golden Richards, the “lonely polygamist” of Brady Udall’s second novel and third published work of fiction, is not only lonesome but also many other things that, ideally, a patriarch and apostle of the Lord would not be: indecisive, feckless, withdrawn and hesitant. All of which puts his four wives in the excruciating position of having to beg him, often, to “embrace his God-given patriarchal authority” and “make a decision once in a while.” At one time it seemed as if Golden, a mammoth, unkempt man referred to as Sasquatch by one of his sons, might be the One Mighty and Strong, a venerated figure in the poly­gamist society that broke off from Mormonism in 1890 after plural marriage was banned, to be “delivered from on high to set in order the house of God.” He is still a leading figure in this particular not very well-off community in the far south­western corner of Utah, near both Arizona and Nevada, as a member of the Council of the Twelve that now, rather sadly, comprises only eight.

headline: Practically Speaking, Stocks May Be a Good Bet
text: AFTER a nice run, the stock market looks a lot like the movie “Jaws 2”: just when you thought it was safe to go back into the water... (cue the menacing music). But before the concern about Greek debt and the wild ride the stock markets took at the end of last week, I had begun to hear people talking up stocks again.

headline: The Call in the Middle of the Night
text: As I reported in Friday’s paper, serious questions are being raised about the government’s estimate of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. The estimate of 5,000 barrels per day has not changed since April 28, and many scientists and environmental groups argue that it cannot be right, given the seemingly rapid flow from the undersea well, as seen in this video of the gushing fluid released on Wednesday.

headline: A Toolkit for Women Seeking a Raise
text: Even now, when women represent half the work force, they’re still paid considerably less than men — and part of that pay gap may be a result of what happens at the salary negotiation table.

headline: Answers About the Legacy of Robert Moses, Part 3
text: Following is the third and final set of responses from Roberta Brandes Gratz, who is responding to readers questions about her book, “The Battle for Gotham: New York in the Shadow of Robert Moses and Jane Jacobs,” which looks at New York’s urban recovery from the 1970s through the lens of the clashing visions of Robert Moses and Jane Jacobs.

headline: Share Your Tips for Women Seeking Pay Raises
text: This week’s Your Money column discusses the challenges women face when negotiating a higher salary.

headline: The War Beneath the Sea
text: Hitler called Fritz Todt, who ran the state company that built the German autobahns and other monuments of the Thousand Year Reich, “our dear Master Builder.” Some of Todt’s most impressive achievements still stand in French ports along the Bay of Biscay: massive concrete bunkers, constructed with slave labor, to shelter the Unterseeboote, the U-boats, of the Nazi navy. The bunkers’ blast doors were a yard thick, the roofs 25 feet thick. The British tried to destroy these submarine pens with hundreds of air raids and 12,000-pound bombs, but instead wiped out the town of Lorient. Only three houses were left standing by 1945, one of them a chateau occupied by the U-boat fleet commander, Adm. Karl Dönitz. “When, in 1987, filmmakers needed a set for the popular submarine movie ‘Das Boot,’ they simply moved into La Pallice” — one of the occupied French ports — “where the old machinery stood intact and dim Gothic lettering still proclaimed its exhortations and prohibitions from the unmarred walls,” Richard Snow tells us in “A Measureless Peril,” his evocative and at times moving account of the American role in the Battle of the Atlantic.

headline: Luxury Golf Resort Opens in Sicily
text: The southern coast of Sicily is better known for its medieval fishing villages and ancient archaeological sites. But now, thanks to the Rocco Forte Collection, a luxury hotel chain mostly in Europe, you can add high-end golfing.

headline: New Award for Sports Books
text: PEN American Center has teamed up with ESPN to create a new $5,000 award to honor the best nonfiction books about sports.

headline: Creeping Back Into Stocks
text: This week’s Wealth Matters column notes that money is dribbling back into stocks and quotes  professional investors about the choices they’re making right now.

headline: Grazing in Union Square
text: So I went down to 14th Street to see Nordstrom Rack, “the year’s most hotly anticipated department store,” as New York magazine said in a blaze of modifiers for a dinosaur, and cruised the merch.

headline: A Surge in Trade in Some Countries, but Others Lag
text: WORLD trade is rising rapidly around the world, providing more evidence of a global recovery led by emerging economies. But some European countries are lagging, in part because they are not competitive with their neighbors.

headline: A New Spin on Google Maps: Bike Routes
text: Just in time for Bike-to-Work Week, May 17 to 21, Google has added bicycling directions to its Maps application.

headline: Daisy, Daisy, Give Me Your Answer Do: Care to Ride a Virtual Bicycle?
text: A new agency whose name, Purpose, signals the kind of campaigns it hopes to produce is creating for Livestrong, the Lance Armstrong initiative that fights cancer, a virtual version of an annual bicycle race.

headline: In Recount, Iraqi Commission Finds Little Fraud
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s election commission announced Friday that it had completed a partial recount of ballots from the country’s election two months ago and found no widespread fraud or irregularities.

headline: Monster Burgers in San Francisco
text: I don’t eat as many burgers as I used to, but I’m in a bit of a frenzy, burger-wise, developing recipes for a Mini that will run in a couple of weeks. Which I suppose is my excuse for visiting San Francisco’s Upper Haight yesterday to eat at Rosamunde Sausage Grill, which does burgers Tuesday only. As one of the people who took me said, “Sometimes you just want a burger, and one without a farm’s name attached to it.”

headline: Reyes Could Move Back to the Leadoff Spot
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. -– The experiment of batting Jose Reyes third could be coming to a merciful end soon. Mets Manager Jerry Manuel said before Friday’s game that he was open to the idea of moving Reyes back to the leadoff spot, where he probably belongs.

headline: Commission Seeks to Revoke Licenses of 633 Cabbies
text: Updated, 4:02 p.m. | The city’s Taxi and Limousine Commission will try and revoke the licenses of 633 drivers for routinely overcharging customers as part of a scheme that cost passengers $1.1 million, it was announced on Friday.

headline: Gay Rights Group to Choose a New Leader
text: New York’s leading gay rights group, the Empire State Pride Agenda, is poised to select a senior aide to Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein as its next executive director.

headline: Stars Sing to Save Rain Forests (and Maybe Redeem the ’80s, Too)
text: Camping in the rain forest got a new meaning on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall. It was the annual benefit for the Rainforest Fund that features Sting and is produced by his wife, Trudie Styler. The fund supports the preservation of rain forests worldwide and the rights of their indigenous peoples. The camp was in this year’s lineup — including Elton John, Lady Gaga and the diva of James Bond movie scores, Shirley Bassey — and some wry production numbers.

headline: Asked and Answered | Shirin Neshat
text: Shirin Neshat’s “Women Without Men,” which opens Friday in New York, represents this experimental photographer and video artist’s first venture into feature filmmaking, and it’s already proven to be an auspicious start. Neshat won the Silver Lion for Best Director at the Venice Film Festival last year for her exploration of political and religious oppression in her native Iran. And given the increased international attention to Iranian politics in recent months, the New York-based artist’s work — much of which deals with gender and identity in the Muslim world — is more in demand than ever. A comprehensive monograph of her work is out this month from Rizzoli, and she has just optioned the novel “The Palace of Dreams,” by Ismail Kadare, for her second film.

headline: Farmers’ Markets by the Numbers
text: In the past few years, farmers’ markets have experienced a resurgence in the Bay Area and across the United States as consumers have sought ways to connect with their meals and an alternative to large grocery chains. A new generation wants to know where its food comes from, how long it is in transit and what techniques are used to grow it — information individuals can get from their growers but not from their local chain stores.

headline: Selig Widens ‘Best Interests’ View in Rangers Bid
text: For decades, commissioners have invoked the “best interests of baseball” clause, to exile Pete Rose, to stop Charles O. Finley’s sale of his Oakland A’s players and to try to realign the National League, among other things. In each instance, the actions focused on owners, players or teams.

headline: On Climate, Food and Security
text: I recently moderated a conversation on climate, food and security at the Asia Society involving some informed and influential figures, including Maria Blair, who’s directing analysis of climate adaptation for the White House Council on Environmental Quality. Here’s the summary:

headline: Russian Miners Say Low Pay Fosters Safety Risks
text: MOSCOW — Protesters blocked railroad tracks at the site of a western Siberian mine disaster on Friday night, demanding to meet with the management of the Raspadskaya Coal Company and complaining that low salaries and financial incentives were pressuring miners to cut corners on safety.

headline: Royals Fire Hillman, Then Let Him Manage
text: The Royals fired Manager Trey Hillman on Thursday morning, but that didn’t stop Hillman from managing the team later that day.

headline: How Do You Say ‘Lazy, Hazy, Crazy Days of Summer’ in Spanish?
text: The weather in some parts of the country has barely been springlike, but Crown Imports is already fast-forwarding the calendar to summer with what the company is calling its largest summer promotion ever for Corona Extra and Corona Light beers.

headline: Times Honors LeFranc With Playwright Award
text: The playwright Dan LeFranc was awarded the New York Times Outstanding Playwright Award on Thursday for his play “Sixty Miles to Silver Lake,” about a divorced father and his teenage son on an emotional car ride together. The prize comes with $5,000 award.

headline: Florida Republicans Now Back Arizona Immigration Law
text: MIAMI – Two of the state’s most prominent Republican candidates have gone from critics to supporters of Arizona’s controversial new immigration law. Senate hopeful Marco Rubio and gubernatorial candidate Attorney General Bill McCollum are now saying that amendments to the law make it a valid approach to immigration.

headline: Bill May Spare Mets’ Owners in Madoff Clawback
text: The New York Mets benefited from one bailout from Congress. TheStreet.com wonders whether the team’s owners could be in line for another bailout — this time, from Bernard L. Madoff‘s vast Ponzi scheme.

headline: Where the Debt Is Coming From
text: Source: International Monetary Fund staff estimates based on the April 2010 World Economic Outlook. Chart taken from “Navigating the Fiscal Challenges Ahead.”

headline: As Ash Falls on Reykjavik, Icelanders Shrug
text: Although a fresh plume of volcanic ash has shut the main airport in Iceland again, reports from the nation’s capital suggest that Icelanders have adopted a stoic attitude to the crisis.

headline: A Looming Shortage of Oil Boom?
text: As a vast oil slick threatens waterfront from western Louisiana to the Florida Panhandle, BP and the Coast Guard are engaged in a frantic effort to secure millions of additional feet of oil-containment boom, supplies of which are spread thin across the coast of the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangkok and Elsewhere
text: Thai troops fired tear gas and bullets at protesters, who responded with stones, slingshots and homemade rockets, turning parts of downtown Bangkok into a battlefield on Friday, Seth Mydans reported, as the military moved to seal off a broad area where the protesters, known as red shirts, have camped for weeks. Agnes Dherbeys, a freelancer working for The Times, caught one of the life-and-death moments (Slide 2). “I am curious and thirsty for situations that shake me — the journalistic ones,” she said on her Web site.

headline: We Made It Ourselves | Alpine Wine
text: Got Fumin? Andrea Barmaz does. The Italian milk industry’s regional director of agricultural research has been making wine in the Alpine village of Valle d’Aosta under the Di Barrò label since 1998 with his wife, Elvira. She, too, has a full-time gig: ski patrol.

headline: The Summer Before
text: Gary Condit was a congressman and a serial adulterer with a taste for younger women. Chandra Levy, the 24-year-old Washington intern who was having an affair with him, thought he looked like Harrison Ford. She was also naïve enough to believe that a 52-year-old representative who had served 11 years in the House was planning to give up his seat and his wife of 34 years to start a new life with her.

headline: Back on Big Stage, a Fighter Envisions a Better Ending
text: Paulie Malignaggi’s latest news conference took place Wednesday inside the Theater at Madison Square Garden, an appropriate setting for a boxing showman of his ilk.

headline: Reviewers of Climate Panel Seek Public Input
text: The panel assembled by the world’s scientific academies to examine the workings and next steps for the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change began its work with a hearing earlier today in Amsterdam. There’s . The BBC has run a solid summary:

headline: An Eater’s Tour of Brooklyn
text: An artists’ collective approach to community and an artisanal approach to food are emerging.

text: Audio commentary by Frank Bruni on eight of the artisanal pizzerias that have sprung up in recent years around New York City — a town obsessed with pizza.

text: On Friday, Google made a stunning admission: for over three years, it has inadvertently collected snippets of private information that people send over unencrypted wireless networks.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Napolitano Chides New York on Terror Aid
text: 7:33 p.m. | Updated  7:24 p.m. | Updated  In a sharply worded letter to Representative Peter T. King, Republican of New York, the secretary of Homeland Security, Janet Napolitano, pushed back on criticism that her department had cut federal anti-terrorism aid to protect the city’s ports and transit systems and chastised city officials for not using hundreds of millions allotted to them.

headline: ‘The Hangover’ Mercedes Among 61 Movie Cars on the Auction Block
text: The racecars never spun victory burnouts at Indy. The Shelby Cobras never menaced Ferraris at Le Mans. And the only hauling the El Camino did most likely involved a Barcalounger and a municipal dump. Still, the vehicles being auctioned at the Mecum Original Spring Classic are charged with a spirit that some collectors will find irresistible: the mystique of showbiz.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: For kayakers, a trip down the Colorado River through the Grand Canyon is a once-in-a-lifetime adventure. But it requires a special permit that can take years to win. Just as majestic is a little-known stretch, upriver from the Grand Canyon, with mirror-clear water and no one in sight.  And, as Kate Siber discovers, it’s almost laughably easy to get to.

headline: Microsoft’s C.F.O. Sees Upturn in Tech Mergers
text: More technology deals are on the way as the industry recovers from the recession, but Microsoft is not poised to make a big deal soon, its chief financial officer, Peter Klein, told Reuters on Friday.

headline: Rhubarb Crisp
text: Mark Bittman makes a simple rhubarb crisp — no strawberries required.

headline: Fabulous Dead People | Decorator Bill Willis
text: For four decades, the architect and decorator Bill Willis was the unlikely point man in Morocco for voluptuous houses redolent of concubines and the woozy, opium-fogged dreamscapes of 19th-century Western painters like Georges Clairin. Nothing in his background — Willis was from Memphis and spoke French with an unforgettable Delta drawl — suggested that one day he would be reviving zellij mosaic work or polishing rendered walls with river stones and waxing them with savon noir to an alabaster sheen.

headline: U.S. Embassy Shuts Down As Bangkok Violence Worsens
text: As clashes between protesters and the Thai military have escalated in a central area of Bangkok, the U.S. embassy, located near the protest area, has shut down, at least until Monday.

headline: In Houston, 2 Cases Raise Tough Racial Questions
text: HOUSTON — This is a town that prides itself on being among the most diverse and tolerant cities in the country, but two recent cases of alleged police brutality against young black men have stirred anger among civil rights leaders and left some residents wondering just how far race relations in their city have come.

headline: Picking the Preakness? Look to the Derby
text: BALTIMORE

headline: Big Shots on Campus, Some Putts Too
text: Chipping and putting around campus with Brendan Doyle, a member of Columbia University's golf team, fresh off its third straight Ivy League Championship.

headline: Chic in Review | Hamster Heels
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: ‘We Are LeBron’ Video: A Tongue-in-Cheek Plea from Cleveland
text: At one point in the waning N.B.A. season, Mike Polk, a lifelong Cavaliers fan and video producer, had an idea to produce a video to help convince LeBron James to stay in Cleveland after he becomes a free agent on July 1. He convinced Break Media to go along with his idea, and when the Cavaliers were unceremoniously bounced from the playoffs Thursday night, the video had its opening.

headline: When the Toast Is: ‘To Your Health’
text: THE night after President Obama’s health care bill passed, my mother had me on the phone, taking me through her panic attack. She loved her health insurance; it was hard won and she didn’t want to cash it in for what she viewed as some “schleppy government issue.” Then she turned her anger on me: “How long are you going to let Ronny pay for yours?”

headline: A Concert Made More for Eyes Than Ears
text: The big reveal came at the last possible moment on Thursday night at the Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side. A backdrop lifted, and behind it, still hovering over their work stations, were members of the Joshua Light Show, which had created the shape-and-color-morphing visuals in a psychedelic concert experience. This moment of demystification was both welcome and warranted, after the hazy exertions of the two bands on the bill, Woods and MV & EE. There was a man behind the curtain, after all.

headline: Young and Younger: Children Playing
text: The fresh-faced musicians of the Young Symphonic Ensemble suddenly became elder statesmen when they were joined onstage by pint-size percussionists during the Children’s Orchestra Society’s annual benefit concert on Wednesday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

headline: Rhubarb Crisp That Stands Up to Pie
text: WHEN you think of rhubarb you probably think of strawberry-rhubarb pie, a quintessential spring dessert, especially if it’s made by someone who makes good pies. I usually manage around one pie crust annually, so I need alternatives. Thus, when the spring’s first rhubarb showed up, I adjusted the execution and produced a crisp.

headline: BlogTalk: The Cost of Arizona’s New Law
text: Even as many conservative politicians running for office all over the country are trying to jump on the bandwagon in support of Arizona’s tough anti-immigration law, the state itself is apparently suffering the consequences of a growing economic boycott. The Arizona Republic is reporting today that Gov. Jan Brewer and tourism-industry leaders are so worried about the loss in convention and tourism business that they are setting up a task force, funded by $250,000 from the state’s commerce department, to counter what they say is “misinformation’’ about the new law.

headline: Shaking in Circles Around a Mystery
text: X, as we all know, marks the spot. But of what exactly? Melinda Ring leaves the object of her desire tantalizingly ambiguous in “X,” a new dance created in collaboration with her five female dancers.

headline: It’s No ‘Secret’ This Agency Has Lost a Client
text: It is rare in advertising for an agency to disclose a loss of a client, much less to announce it publicly. But an agency in Santa Monica, Calif., has actually sent out a news release to tell the marketing world it was losing an account.

headline: Goldman Sets Up Business Standards Committee
text: Goldman Sachs on Friday named the members of the business standards committee that Lloyd C. Blankfein, the firm’s chief executive, promised after Goldman was accused of securities fraud and its legal problems deepened.

headline: Happier Ending for Artist’s Jilted Love
text: The Underworld Productions Opera Ensemble is intent on finding interesting ways to present opera on a microscopic budget while also making a social point or two about the war of the sexes that animates so many plots.

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 14
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in the New York region. Subjects include the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis and a friend; a prison debate team; a plane using a laser system to map the city; and clothing made of anything but fabric.

headline: A Restless Rebel Trading in Sex and the Absurd
text: AMONG the Japanese directors who came of age after World War II, Nagisa Oshima is perhaps the most provocative. Mr. Oshima achieved worldwide fame with the 1976 release of his sexually explicit art-house hit “In the Realm of the Senses.”

headline: ESPN Gets Big Numbers for Celtics-Cavs
text: The Boston Celtics’ win over the Cleveland Cavaliers to capture the Eastern Conference semifinals Thursday night attracted an average of 8.9 million viewers, the second-most ever for a basketball game on ESPN. It fell short of the 9.8 million for Game 4 of last year’s western conference final between the Los Angeles Lakers and Denver Nuggets.

headline: Sun’s Chief Still Sunny After Drubbing From Ellison
text: Jonathan Schwartz, Sun’s former chief executive, thinks Larry Ellison, Oracle’s chief executive, is just swell. Or as Mr. Schwartz put it in an e-mail message to me, “Larry Ellison is a completely flawless, lovely man.”

headline: Another Way to Use Rhubarb
text: Strawberry-rhubarb pie is a classic spring dessert. But here’s an alternative: ultra-tart rhubarb makes an unbelievably good crisp. Check it out in this week’s Minimalist column.

headline: Beef Stir-Fry, Smiling Cow Style
text: IN the past, my preferred method for finding the ideal dish of stir-fried beef and snow peas would be to order in from all the Chinese restaurants in my neighborhood, and sample my way to the best.

headline: Nothing’s Dry Here: Formality, Life and Color
text: Why did David Parker and Jeffrey Kazin call their West End Theater dance series Soaking Wet? Could they have been waiting for the moment that has just arrived? One of their current shows is called “Soaking Wet Shorts.” Research (that is, asking Mr. Parker) turns up a more prosaic reason; it’s a play on the initials of the theater’s name. And that theater is a New York City curiosity: a small space with a soaring ceiling, framed by curtained galleries, in the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, on the Upper West Side.

headline: They Have Made a Desert
text: And called it successful adjustment.

headline: Carrying the Burden of a Great History Modestly
text: For a musical ensemble with a famous name, legacy is a double-edged sword. On the one hand, a storied name can grab attention. On the other, an illustrious history can be burdensome when it sets up expectations that are difficult to live up to. The Pro Arte Quartet, which performed at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday evening, is presumably acquainted with both sides of the issue.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Oceana will be serving a clambake — a pot of lobster, mussels, clams, corn and potatoes at $37 per person — on its new patio in front of the restaurant each Sunday this summer, weather permitting. It will also be available indoors: 1220 Avenue of the Americas (49th Street), (212) 759-5941.

headline: Where Light Replaces Sound, and Movement Offers Comfort
text: At one moment in the hourlong “Necessary Weather,” Sara Rudner and Dana Reitz are dancing simultaneous solos, each in a separate pool of light created by Jennifer Tipton. Even if you disliked dance, the show — a revival of a 1994 collaboration by these three women at the Baryshnikov Arts Center — would be worth seeing for Ms. Tipton’s astounding contribution; and even if you already knew from many other productions that Ms. Tipton has long been the world’s most remarkable creator of lighting for dance, you haven’t seen her most miraculous ideas until you’ve seen “Necessary Weather.” But this particular moment is memorable because of the quite different ways the two dancers react to the light.

headline: Arts Groups See Mayor’s Budget Plan and Shudder
text: It has become a New York version of Washington’s cherry blossoms: the springtime tussle over the city’s culture budget. The mayor puts forward his plan for the coming fiscal year, as he did on May 6; arts institutions insist they will be ruined by the cuts to their allocations; and the City Council puts in additional funds — sometimes more than the mayor has taken out — to ease the pain.

headline: One ‘Law & Order’ Gets a Death Sentence, as Another Joins the Force
text: The Dodgers. “The Tonight Show.” Now “Law & Order.”

headline: Icahn Reported in Talks With Lions Gate to End Bid
text: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn and Lions Gate Entertainment have held talks about awarding him board seats and ending his hostile takeover bid for the film studio, Bloomberg News reports, citing two people with the knowledge of the matter.

headline: In the Iraq War, People Acting Like Animals, and Vice Versa
text: LOS ANGELES  “It’s alarming, this life after death,” muses one of the many ghosts that haunt a ravaged city in Rajiv Joseph’s play “Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo.” Of course, life before death was no ticker tape parade for Mr. Joseph’s cast of characters, either. Set in the chaotic first days of the American invasion of Iraq, this boldly imagined, harrowing and surprisingly funny drama considers the long afterlife of violent acts, as well as the impenetrable mysteries of the afterlife itself.

headline: How to Win the Cavendish? Play Aggressively
text: You pick up this hand:

headline: ‘Top Hat’ Out, Insertion Tube In
text: May 15, 6:30 p.m. | Updated  The new approach hit an unspecified snag, according to Interior Secretary Ken Salazar. But BP officials remained confident on Saturday night that they could start capturing most of the leaking oil.

headline: Custom-Made Clothes to Match Your Kicks
text: MARK SERRANO says he spends 98 percent of his money on sneakers and the rest on food. He looks it. Thin as a skeleton, he sports spotless black Nikes — one of more than 200 pairs he owns.

headline: And Matching Nikes
text: A Bronx storefront operation cranks out custom T-shirt designs color-coordinated with the latest sneakers to hit the streets.

text: The tech editors and reporters of The New York Times were reading these items on Friday.

headline: Kansas Mutual Fund Is Linked to Market’s Plunge
text: The flash crash on May 6 that transfixed investors — and has been the source of finger-pointing ever since — may not have originated in the canyons of Wall Street or a hedge fund manager’s European lair.

headline: Toasting Graduation and Making the Scene
text: It is all about chatty group dining at this Lower East Side restaurant and lounge that specializes in small bites, almost like cocktail-party fare, tailored to the number of people in the group — no dish of three dumplings for four people, said Chris Santos, the chef-owner and a judge on “Chopped” on the Food Network. Five years after its opening, Stanton Social is usually packed with a mix of creative types — models, musicians, photographers, foodies, cast members of “Gossip Girl” — and the people who like to watch them. On Thursday night, under a throbbing backbeat, university students at several tables celebrated graduation and the end of exams.

headline: Debit Fee Cut Is a Rare Loss for Big Banks
text: WASHINGTON — Retailers have begged Congress for years, in vain, to limit the fees they must pay to banks when customers swipe credit or debit cards. Bills never reached a vote. Amendments were left on the table. The Senate did not even grant the courtesy of a committee hearing.

headline: Business Group Joins Suit on Health Law
text: With the aim of depoliticizing a largely Republican assault, the leading lobbying group for small businesses has joined officials from 20 states in their legal challenge to the new health care law.

headline: Camp for a Cause at Carnegie Hall
text: Big names including Sting, Elton John, Bruce Springsteen and Lady Gaga performed at Carnegie Hall to raise money for the Rainforest Foundation.

headline: Green Juice and Twitter Prayer
text: Russell Simmons, 52, hip-hop pioneer and founder of Rush Communications, helped bring the rhymes of Public Enemy, LL Cool J and the Beastie Boys to the masses as a partner in Def Jam Recordings. He injected his hip-hop sensibility into clothing with Phat Fashions and moved into television with “Russell Simmons’ Def Comedy Jam.” Mr. Simmons recently created GlobalGrind.com, a Web site for the hip-hop community. A native of Queens, he has since migrated to a penthouse in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Trying to Take a Bite Out of Crime via Felons’ Dogs
text: When drug agents in southeast Tennessee tried to arrest people suspected of dealing methamphetamine last month, they ran into an all-too common obstacle: a large, snarling dog on the front porch.

headline: U.S. Makes Bid for World Cup but Isn’t Picky About the Year
text: Three days after the United States soccer federation announced its preliminary World Cup roster, its president led a four-member team to Switzerland to attempt to win the right to host the tournament for the second time.

text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google said on Friday that for more than three years it had inadvertently collected snippets of private information that people send over unencrypted wireless networks.

headline: At the Garden, Hope Springs From the Cavaliers’ Misery
text: Erik Mirrow knew where he would be going Friday morning the moment he saw LeBron James pull off his Cavaliers jersey Thursday night — before James was inside the Cleveland locker room and out of the network camera’s view.

headline: Strict Reading of Visa Rule Trips Up  More Couples
text: They met on the eHarmony dating site — the pretty, dark-haired psychologist from Los Angeles and the blond German theologian at Kings College, London, writing his Ph.D. dissertation on why Protestants had stopped believing in miracles.

headline: City Libraries Say Cuts Will Mean Closings and Layoffs
text: It is something of an annual budget ritual: Public libraries, always among the first city services to be threatened with substantial cuts in financing, are forced to face the abyss, only to be saved in the end, in whole or significant part.

headline: Igarashi to Pitch in a Minor League Game
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Mets relief pitcher Ryota Igarashi is expected to pitch one inning in a Class A Florida State League game Saturday night, Manager Jerry Manuel said.

headline: Student’s Arrest Tests Immigration Policy

headline: Hawks Cut Loose Coach
text: The Atlanta Hawks made significant improvement under Coach Mike Woodson, but he lost his job Friday, four days after the team was swept by the Orlando Magic in the second round of the playoffs. General Manager Rick Sund, after consulting with the ownership group, decided not to offer Woodson a new contract. So ended a six-year coaching tenure in which the Hawks won just 13 games in Woodson’s first season, then improved every season since — including three straight playoff appearances.

headline: ‘There’s Something About Art School Girls’
text: Spring is here and, with it, the damp heat of desire — a substance that, while invisible, can still be felt like pollen in the air. The following poems about desire were “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.  ALAN FEUER

headline: Up Next, How I Outran the Giant Fireball
text: “There are roughly 101 reasons a man can end up blindfolded and hogtied in the trunk of a car,” says Baron Ambrosia, dressed as usual in the manner of a Blaxploitation-era pimp. “Believe me, I’ve tried them all. However, this particular circumstance stemmed from one of the most beloved of Latin foods, the pastel.”

text: PARIS — The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the parent of Airbus, said Friday that its first-quarter profit fell 39 percent, hurt by costs associated with its A380 superjumbo jet.

headline: Subway Signal Design Has Old-School Origin
text: Q. I’ve noticed that on my subway line, the rail signal lights are arranged so that the red light is on the bottom and the green light is on the top, which is the opposite of street traffic lights. Any special reason for this difference?

text: WHEN did Tommy Hilfiger become cool again?

headline: Ron Fimrite, Stylish Sportswriter, Dies at 79
text: Ron Fimrite, a writer and author whose wry take on sports made him a fixture at Sports Illustrated for more than 34 years, died April 30 at his home in San Francisco. He was 79.

headline: Proposal Would Delay Hearings in Terror Cases

headline: Dropping of ‘Law & Order’ Leaves Hole in Economy
text: In 20 years of production on the streets and soundstages of New York, “Law & Order” served as a springboard and a meal ticket for hundreds of actors. It did the same for the careers of other New Yorkers, like David Dreishpoon, the caterer.

headline: Several Top Riders Skipped Giro for Tour of California
text: SACRAMENTO — When organizers of the Tour of California, the most prestigious professional cycling race in the United States, decided to move their event to May from February this year, they took a calculated risk.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: A Hole in the Spring Sky
text: Twenty-five years ago this month, a small team of scientists discovered that the ozone layer above their Antarctic station was thinning more and more every spring. The layer protects life on earth from the sun’s ultraviolet light. The response to that discovery is a rare, happy environmental morality tale.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Worshiping at the ‘Idol’ Church
text: IT’S 10:01 p.m., and my mother, who has learned the art of the text message for this express purpose, is weighing in with her feelings on the latest “American Idol” results-show telecast. “So glad Aaron Kelly survived,” she writes, her fandom for the polite, pint-size teenager unwavering in the wake of his deeply unconvincing cover of “Blue Suede Shoes” the night before.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: In Search of Adorable, as Hello Kitty Gets Closer to Goodbye
Old Music, via New Technology
text: The Sag Harbor-based filmmaker Joe Lauro knows there is no shortage of time-tested music to be heard, and seen, on TV.

headline: City Seeks to Revoke Licenses for Cab Overcharges
text: New York City moved on Friday to revoke the cab licenses of 633 taxi drivers who it said routinely charged customers higher out-of-town rates for trips within the five boroughs. The city said some of the overcharging was so egregious that it had asked prosecutors to investigate.

headline: Acting Happy Wins Black-Eyed Susan; Leparoux Injured
text: 10:18 a.m. | Updated Julien Leparoux has no broken bones after being examined at a hospital, according to his friend Fanny Salmon. He is sore and bruised but is expected to ride. He has eight mounts Saturday, including Pleasant Prince in the Preakness.

headline: In East Hampton, Art and Craft in Motion
text: The line between art and craft is relaxed at three exhibitions mounted this season at LongHouse Reserve in East Hampton, a 16-acre sculpture garden and preserve founded by the textile designer Jack Lenor Larsen. Mr. Larsen’s own creations have included, among others, curtains for Lever House and seat fabric for Braniff International Airways.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 14
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Jobs for Albany’s Do-Nothings
text: Here are two important dates to keep in mind. April 1. That’s when New York State was supposed to have a new budget. And June 1. That’s when the state is scheduled to make a payment to local schools that is about $1 billion more than the cash on hand.

headline: Want Cheese With That?
text: At With Cheese Please!, a 10-month-old fast-food place in Rockville Centre, you can order a simple grilled cheese on white ($3). Or you can go all out and have a “bun” made of grilled cheese sandwiches, with a six-ounce Angus cheeseburger between them ($9.25).

headline: Study Pokes Holes in Air Bag Standards
text: New research into front air bags in automobiles is raising troubling questions about their effectiveness for drivers wearing seat belts.

headline: Still Homeless in Haiti
text: Of the more than 1.5 million Haitians left homeless by the Jan. 12 earthquake, about 7,500 have been moved from the most dangerous areas of crowded tent cities to new resettlement sites. The conditions in those tent cities are grim. Thunderstorms are fierce, and the plastic sheets and tarps distributed after the disaster are fraying, along with the people’s patience.

headline: Whose Best Interest?
text: Among the disastrous moves that turned Wall Street into the Wild West was a 1999 ruling by the Securities and Exchange Commission that let stockbrokers call themselves “advisers” without making them abide by the law that requires investment advisers to put their clients’ interests first.

headline: The Windows of the Soul Need Cleaning
text: I’m bowled almost over by how many readers replied so intelligently, and revealingly, on this subject: the mystery of dreams and dreaming.

headline: James’s Free Agency Puts a Premium on Conjecture
text: LeBron James was lathering up when the frothy speculation began.

headline: Rustic Barbecue With a City Twist
text: THOUGH it has made strides in recent years, New York hardly qualifies as a barbecue Mecca on the order of, say, Kansas City or Memphis. Still, New York was the namesake chosen by the five co-owners of Big Apple BBQ, who include the executive chef, Roy Bruce, formerly of Rothmann’s Steakhouse in East Norwich. The rustic spot in Glen Cove opened in April in the quarters that were last home to Wild Harvest.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Haitian Influx Startles the North Country
text: BURLINGTON, Vt. — The United States District Court here hired a Creole translator on an on-call basis in February. Three months later she is putting in 10-hour days, working so much that she does not have the time to search for a full-time job.

headline: Your Industrial Decay Is Her Inspiration
text: MORRIS TOWNSHIP

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 14
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Food to Go From Places on the Move
text: HOBOKEN

headline: Then Comes the Marriage Question
text: HERE we go again.

headline: Made to Order
text: When Zeytinia, a specialty market with branches in Manhattan, New Jersey and Connecticut, opened in Croton-on-Hudson nearly six years ago, it filled a hole in northwest Westchester’s culinary landscape. Customers have been drawn ever since by the 30-plus choices at the salad bar ($6.99 a pound) and the vast array of grocery items and prepared foods.

headline: Independent Inquiry Into Oil Spill Is Urged
text: WASHINGTON — As the Obama administration moves to end a conflict-of-interest problem in the operation of the Minerals Management Service, a rising chorus of experts is demanding that it rectify a similar conflict and appoint an independent blue-ribbon commission to investigate the gulf spill.

headline: Setting the Mood With Dramatic Flair
text: MUCH thought has gone into the ambience at Finalmente, a handsome, sophisticated restaurant and wine bar in Sleepy Hollow. Careful touches of Baroque and Venetian Byzantine have created a dramatic vibe, with Moorish pierced-metal lighting fixtures and a pair of lantern sconces that look as though they came straight off a gondola dock or the doorway to a palazzo on the Grand Canal.

headline: In South Africa, an Unlikely Leader on AIDS
text: CAPE TOWN — In a nation ravaged by AIDS, a disease still hidden in shadows of stigma and shame, President Jacob Zuma of South Africa has begun to engage in an extraordinarily open conversation about sex, AIDS and H.I.V. prevention, one ignited in part by his own recent admission that he had unprotected sex during an extramarital affair.

headline: ‘Junk Shot’ Is Next Step for Leaking Gulf of Mexico Well
text: HOUSTON — Can golf balls save the gulf?

headline: In Cleveland, Sports Fans Cheer Until It Hurts
text: CLEVELAND — The three sports bars on Coventry Road, in the eastside Cleveland suburb of Cleveland Heights, are among the places that Northeast Ohio’s sports fans congregate by the hundreds for important games. In galvanizing moments, the roar of their simultaneous cheers can be heard blocks away.

headline: G.I.’s Find Bullets Still Flying at Outpost in Iraq
text: ASH SHURA, Iraq — Technically, American soldiers have stopped fighting in Iraq. But they can fire back when attacked, which happens frequently in this village of wheat and barley farmers, as well as an uncomfortable number of Baathist insurgents.

headline: Jazz as a Global Language, Captured on Film
text: Pleasantville

headline: A TV Cook’s Next Serving? Cuomo Family Style
text: Sandra Lee, a sunny on-screen chef with a homey Midwestern manner, has built a media empire around how-to advice.

headline: Hey, Hey, They’re the Monkees
text: THE four members of Big Time Rush — the boy-band-within-a-TV-show that Nickelodeon has been pumping — were being their usual adorable selves at the Chelsea Piers sports center: making a racket, chatting with strangers and cracking lame jokes. A female staff member wondered aloud just who these guys were.

headline: Where the Table Is at the Farm
text: Meals at Bush Meadow Farm embrace the farm-to-table concept to its fullest: Nearly everything on the breakfast and lunch menus is raised and processed within the confines of this family-run enterprise.

headline: Italian Flavors, With Water Views
text: CONNECTICUT’S magnificent coastline may be littered with restaurants, but it’s not that easy to eat well by the water. Assaggio Ristorante, subtitled “On the Harbor,” does a better job than most. Under the shadow of Interstate 95, Assaggio has an urban water view with soundtrack to match: the hum of highway traffic punctuated by the occasional growl of a train.

headline: ‘A Doll’s House’ in Contemporary Suburbia
text: When Henrik Ibsen’s Nora Helmer first took off her wedding ring, emptied her purse and slammed the door, it caused a sensation. Some audiences at “A Doll’s House” reviled her for abandoning her husband, Torvald, and their three children. Others recognized in her desperate act a first, necessary step to adulthood after a lifetime of allowing men to define her.

headline: Arms and the Airport
text: “Do you support allowing people to carry loaded guns into an American airport?” Senator Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey asked the attorney general at a recent Appropriations Committee hearing.

headline: Corrections
text: A film column on Friday about the Cannes festival misstated part of the title of a film shown at last year’s festival (the composer of the film’s music, Alexandre Desplat, is on this year’s jury). It is “A Prophet,” not “The Prophet.” The column also referred incorrectly to a film being shown this year, “Tournée” (“On Tour”). In the movie, a troupe of performers tours provincial France, not “provisional” France.

headline: Hartford to Play a Native Son’s Works
text: WHEN Edward Cumming became the Hartford Symphony Orchestra’s music director in June 2002, he was determined to give Charles Ives a prominent place on his programming list. European colleagues had long asked him why more Americans did not champion Ives, a native son of Connecticut and one of Cumming’s personal favorites.

headline: An Overdue ‘Welcome Home’
text: Watching a new documentary about Vietnam War veterans, I was surprised at how old they looked and how worn their faces had become. These were fellows who had once laughed and danced to the music of the Beatles and Motown.

headline: Church Crisis Shakes Faith of German Town
text: OBERAMMERGAU, Germany — The residents of this Bavarian village have connected with the Roman Catholic Church in a particular and persistent way: every 10 years since 1634, they have brought the crucifixion of Jesus Christ to life in a Passion play that has earned them worldwide renown but no small amount of criticism.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Brazil’s Iran Diplomacy Worries U.S. Officials
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — As President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva heads to Tehran this weekend to make what many Western diplomats consider a last-ditch attempt at persuading Iran to temper its nuclear ambitions, officials in Washington have expressed concern that the effort could backfire, helping the Islamic republic to block — or at least delay — the United States and its allies from imposing sanctions.

headline: Fed Up, Greece Lists Tax Dodgers
text: Trying to crack down on rampant tax evasion, the Greek authorities have made good on promises to name — and shame — some of the worst offenders.

headline: Senate Panel Acts to Bar Changes to Human Spaceflight Program
text: President Obama’s effort to reshape the nation’s human spaceflight program encountered another obstacle Friday as a Senate committee sought to block any changes to the program through the end of the current fiscal year, Sept. 30. The Senate Appropriations Committee has added the clause to a supplemental budget package that includes money for troops in Afghanistan, and Senate staff members doubt that the House will make any changes or that Mr. Obama would reject the bill. Last year, Congress passed a measure that prohibited ending or changing NASA’s Constellation program to return astronauts to the moon. The new clause affirms that prohibition and adds that the money allocated to the Constellation program “shall be available to fund continued performance of Constellation contracts.”

headline: Rotarix Vaccine Approved for Children
text: The Rotarix vaccine made by GlaxoSmithKline is again recommended for use in children, two months after some samples were contaminated with a virus found in meat products. The Food and Drug Administration said Friday that it had no evidence that the virus posed safety concerns and that the vaccine’s benefits outweighed any potential risk. The agency urged suspending Rotarix use on March 22 after an academic research team found pieces of porcine circovirus virus type 1, or PCV-1, in materials used to make more than 69 million doses globally.

headline: Turkish Party Asks Court to Reject Changes
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s main opposition party asked the Constitutional Court on Friday to declare unlawful proposed changes to the Constitution that the opposition says would undercut some of the nation’s most staunchly secular institutions, including the court itself.

headline: New Restrictions Are Imposed on House Members’ Air Travel
text: The House Democratic leadership took steps Friday to curb the costs of lawmakers’ globetrotting by putting new restrictions on Congressional travel, one of the favorite perks of House membership. Under new rules announced by Speaker Nancy Pelosi, representatives and their committee aides will be required to fly coach or economy instead of business class on flights of less than 14 hours. The speaker also required more documentation for the rationale of the committee-arranged trips known universally as Codels, short for Congressional delegation. The rules do not apply to the Senate.

headline: Liberals in Limbo
text: Is “Left” becoming a four-letter word?

headline: Lena Horne, Who Moved Barriers and Emotions, Is Remembered
text: To thousands of black soldiers in World War II, she was, as one put it on Friday, “our pinup girl.”

headline: Staging the Lessons of Literacy
text: On stage at Symphony Space, the actress Rita Wolf narrated the story of a birthday gathering of a Dominican family in the South Bronx. The plot twist: a visit from the police.

headline: Pulse
text: An art seller blends the classic and the creative; styling tips for the slicked-down wet look; and more items.

headline: Paperless Reading Materials
text: Je te plumerai la têteJe te plumerai la tête

headline: Karpov Finds Support in a Surprising Place: Russia
text: In an unexpected development, Anatoly Karpov, the former world chess champion who is running for the presidency of the World Chess Federation, seems to have secured the endorsement of the Russian Chess Federation.

headline: Genetically Engineered Distortions
text: A REPORT by the National Research Council last month gave ammunition to both sides in the debate over the cultivation of genetically engineered crops. More than 80 percent of the corn, soybeans and cotton grown in the United States is genetically engineered, and the report details the “long and impressive list of benefits” that has come from these crops, including improved soil quality, reduced erosion and reduced insecticide use.

headline: Companies We Keep, and Pay For
text: Just about 10 years ago, the Condé Nast publishing company moved into 4 Times Square, and newly minted No Parking signs declared that the spaces out front were reserved for “FHVs” — that is, they were the exclusive domain of for-hire vehicles, the black town cars that waited in tight ranks for the company’s senior officials. The FHV signs, planted in front of new skyscrapers in Midtown and Lower Manhattan, flew as the standards of the gilded age. They were the least of it.

headline: Bloggingheads:  Confirmation Error
text: Glenn Greenwald, left, of Salon.com and Lawrence Lessig of Harvard Law School debate Elena Kagan's confirmation hearings.

headline: Bloomberg Plan Would Simplify Gun-Permits
text: The Bloomberg administration announced on Friday that it was moving to simplify the process for New Yorkers to obtain gun permits, thus speeding up a set of byzantine licensing requirements that gun-rights advocates have long criticized as among the most restrictive in the country.

headline: Magic’s Van Gundy: Cavaliers Looked Bad Because of the Celtics
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — The playoffs are a marathon, and, for some teams that marathon has a slow pace. The Orlando Magic is set to resume its march against the Boston Celtics on Sunday in the Eastern Conference finals. Because it has swept through the first two rounds, Orlando will have played eight games in four weeks when it meets the Celtics.

headline: Details Emerge About 3 Men Detained in Bomb Case
text: The three Pakistani men detained by federal authorities who are investigating the failed Times Square car bombing came from varied backgrounds: one was a computer programmer, one a gas station attendant and one a cabdriver.

headline: A Passion Play Where Devotion Wanes
text: The dedication of Catholics who participate in a centuries-old ritual in Oberammergau, Germany, is being dampened by their disappointment.

headline: Dinky or Bus? A Town Is Torn
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — The run of the train known as the Princeton Dinky is both impressively long and unusually short. For 145 years, this rail link in a college town has ferried students and commuters over the briefest of distances. But Year 146 has not been kind to the nation’s shortest regularly scheduled commuter route, which travels a four-minute, 2.7-mile stretch of track between a small station at Princeton University and a larger one at Princeton Junction.

headline: When Signs Are Stolen, Managers Mostly Shrug
text: MILWAUKEE — Except for a brief look at ESPN’s coverage, Willie Randolph, the Milwaukee Brewers’ bench coach and a former Mets manager, said he knew little about the latest sign-stealing controversy involving the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: Panel Upholds Infringement in Optical Device Case
text: Avago Technologies won a patent-infringement case against the Emcore Corporation and can seek an order to block imports of Emcore’s opto-electronic devices used to connect computers in a local area network, the United States International Trade Commission said Friday. The commission it would let stand Judge Theodore Essex’s finding that Emcore’s products infringe on one Avago patent, and not a second patent, according to a notice on the agency’s Web site. The six-member commission ordered both sides to submit arguments on whether an import ban should be imposed. Avago, based in Singapore, filed the complaint a year ago, seeking to block fiber optic components like transmitters, receivers and transceivers made by Emcore in Thailand. The patent found to be infringed, issued in 1994, is related to features of optical communications systems that transit digital information using light waves. Shares of Emcore, which is based in Albuquerque, fell 11 cents, or 9 percent, to $1.15.

headline: In Game and Series, a Rally to Remember
text: BOSTON — The players on the Philadelphia Flyers’ bench, which had been a dark place as they tumbled into a three-goal abyss in Game 7, suddenly jumped up and down, slamming their sticks against the boards. The Bruins had too many men on the ice, they shouted. The referees, too, had noticed.

headline: Granderson Tests His Timing but Measures It in Weeks
text: In the batting cage beneath the stands and behind the Yankees’ dugout Friday night, center fielder Curtis Granderson hit a baseball off a tee. As athletic feats go, it was not a big deal.

headline: China: U.S. Engineer Is Released
text: The Chinese authorities have released an American engineer who had been detained since November 2008 on accusations that he violated trade secrets, the United States Embassy in Beijing said Friday. The engineer, Hu Zhicheng, was released late last month and is still in China, but plans to return home soon. Mr. Hu was detained for 17 months in the city of Tianjin over what appeared to be a dispute involving automobile technology. Detentions of foreign citizens in China are common in commercial disputes.

headline: Portugal: Pope Wraps Up Visit
text: Wrapping up a four-day visit to Portugal aimed at shoring up Christian belief in increasingly secular Europe, but in which he also spoke out against the sexual abuse crisis in the church, Pope Benedict XVI on Friday appealed to Catholics to spread the faith “not only to non-Christians in faraway lands” but also in “socio-cultural environments” closer to home. Celebrating Mass in the northern city of Porto, he added that the church was “ready to dialogue with different cultures and religions.”

headline: CBS Leads With Crime
text: With its Thursday-night crime shows and the season’s second-to-last episode of  “Survivor,”  CBS easily led the ratings in prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “The Mentalist” delivered the largest audience of the night as 14.6 million viewers tuned in at 10 p.m. for the CBS procedural. At 9, CBS’s “CSI” drew 13.3 million viewers, slightly more than the 13 million who watched “Survivor” at 8. ABC ranked runner-up, largely due to “Grey’s Anatomy” at 9 (10.9 million) and the third-season finale of “Private Practice” at 10 (9.3 million). Fox finished third for the night and NBC was fourth.

headline: Claims Of Safety Issues at Los Angeles Opera
text: Opera singers periodically lash out at directors and their productions, and now the Los Angeles Opera has taken its turn. Two performers in the company’s new “Ring” cycle, created by the visual artist and director Achim Freyer, have criticized the production as dangerous for the singers and of dubious artistic value. “This entire production has been a trying and difficult time,” the tenor John Treleaven was quoted as saying by The Los Angeles Times on Friday. He also said, “The character development that I bring to the part is almost expunged by this clownlike makeup.” Mr. Treleaven, who plays Siegfried, said he had suffered two minor injuries on the raked stage. The Times quoted Linda Watson, who sings Brünnhilde, as calling the set “the most dangerous stage I’ve been on in my entire career.” She added, “It takes years to be able to sing a ‘Ring’ and to just toss this all away — he doesn’t say it in words, but his gestures speak louder than words.” Christopher Koelsch, head of artistic planning for the company, said in a statement on Friday that the company “places the highest priority on safety in our onstage environment, and takes every precaution to prevent incidents” and that “we are proud of the overall work, as well as the contributions of each individual within it.” Individual operas in the $32 million production have been performed since last season, and the full cycle will be presented starting late this month as the centerpiece of a Wagner festival.

headline: Rosa Rio, Organist From Silent Films to Soap Operas, Dies at 107
text: On Oct. 6, 1927, the day “The Jazz Singer” splashed noisily across American movie screens, Rosa Rio broke down and wept. Al Jolson was talking, and the very sound of him, she knew, would put her out of business.

headline: Craig Kauffman, Sculptor in Plastic, Is Dead at 78
text: Craig Kauffman, who in the 1960s helped put Los Angeles on the art map with audacious experiments in molding industrial plastic to create ethereal wall-mounted sculptures — some resembling giant pieces of jelly candy — died Sunday in Angeles City in the Philippines. He was 78.

headline: Twins Test Rodriguez, but He Has the Answer
text: Few moments in sports are more scintillating than a grand slam in a close baseball game, and that was what Alex Rodriguez provided for 45,195 fans in Yankee Stadium on Friday night.

headline: With Perez and Offense Plodding, April Gains Are Gone
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Oliver Perez went into Friday night’s start against the Marlins knowing a lot was at stake for him. If he had another poor performance, there would be no further mitigating reasons to explain it away.

headline: David Randolph, Conductor of Many Fleet ‘Messiahs,’ Dies at 95
text: David Randolph, a choral conductor whose performances of Handel’s  “Messiah”  with the Masterwork Chorus were for decades a mainstay of New York’s holiday season, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

headline: Favorites Begin Quickly at U.S. Championship
text: There were eight decisive games in Round 1 of the United States Championship and the top players all won.

headline: On the Street | Luminous
text: Harlem lost one of its most stylish and most respected residents in Evelyn Cunningham.

headline: Germany: Preliminary Inquiries in Sex Abuse Claims Are Dropped
text: Preliminary investigations into sexual abuse allegations against a German Roman Catholic bishop, Walter Mixa, 69, left, have been dropped, prosecutors in Ingolstadt said in a statement on Friday, citing lack of evidence. Pope Benedict XVI accepted the bishop’s resignation last Saturday, following separate allegations of physical abuse of children and financial irregularities at a children’s home.

headline: Is College for Everyone?
text: In a piece for the Sunday Week in Review section of The Times, which has just been posted online, I examine a third-rail question within the education world: whether some of those students struggling in college might be better served in other settings, academic or otherwise.

headline: Plan B: Skip College
text: WHAT’S the key to success in the United States?

headline: Your Jokes: ‘His Playlist Gets Deleted’
text: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Michael Bolton’s School of Michael Bolton
text: Video | The music academy where kids learn to croon unforgettably:

headline: Classic Ads: Through the Decades With Ford Station Wagons
text: Seems like it’s Ford family hauler week, for better or worse. The 2010 Flex crossover and its twin-turbo V-6 engine get a thumbs-up from Lawrence Ulrich in Sunday’s Automobiles section. Meanwhile, Christopher Jensen reports that 1999–2003 Windstar minivans have become the subject of an investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Jets Need Top Salesman. How About Brad Benson?
text: The Jets need closers to sell their remaining personal seat licenses. Maybe they could take some advice from the former Giants lineman Brad Benson, who runs a successful auto dealership in New Jersey and who uses a madcap and risque advertising strategy.

headline: Thai Government Takes Harder Stance as Clashes Continue
text: BANGKOK — The Thai government struck a combative tone on Saturday, saying it would continue its efforts to cut off antigovernment protesters from the rest of the city despite a rising death toll and determined resistance from the demonstrators.

headline: Ignoring The Elephant In the Euro
text: When the idea of the euro was first broached, there was extensive debate about whether Europe constituted an “optimum currency area”; the key question was whether European nations would have an adequate way to adjust to “asymmetric shocks”, which left some economies more depressed than others. When countries have their own currencies, they can deal with such shocks, at least in part, by devaluing — an argument made most eloquently by none other than Milton Friedman (pdf). Lacking that alternative, something else is needed.

headline: The Saturday Word: Financial Regulations and Budgets
text: President Obama on Saturday urged swift passage of Democrats’ financial regulatory legislation, saying it would prevent future recessions, while protecting small businesses, community bankers and credit card consumers.

headline: Nolan Ryan’s No-Hitters and No-Walk Games
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: 15 Yards for Character Abuse
text: Can a network television series be brought up on charges of character abuse? And if so what kind of penalty should it get? “Friday Night Lights” is right back to refusing to let Riggins get his happy on: Lyla is gone; last week Riggins got beat up by his brother, and Friday’s episode opened with him awaking in his pick-up truck–another hangover, another round of temporary homelessness. Last time Riggins was at such a low point, Coach Taylor, patriarach to all of Dillon, east and west, took him in. And here again is Taylor, in charge of another resuce effort: a vague whiff of plot recycling. Riggins, at a loss for anything else to do, takes on an informal job helping Taylor rally the troops on the gridiron at East Dillon High.

headline: Letterman: ‘Smart, Really, Really Smart’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Do you know about the newest Supreme Court nominee from New York City. Elena Kagan is her name? Kagan is smart, really, really smart. I’ll tell you how smart she is. She knew back in the 90’s that Ricky Martin was gay.

headline: Leno: ‘Preach it From the Pulpit’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: I tell you, this has not been a good day if you’re a British Petroleum stockholder with playoff tickets for game seven with the Cavaliers.

headline: Spain’s Jobless Find It Hard to Go Back to Farm
text: PUERTO SERRANO, Spain — During Spain’s construction boom, Antonio Rivera Romero happily traded long hours and backbreaking labor in the fields for the better-regulated building trades, earning four times as much as a bricklayer. He took out a mortgage and enlarged his house on a quiet side street in this small city in southern Spain.

headline: Munich Imam Tries to Dull Lure of Radical Islam
text: MUNICH — Hesham Shashaa looked twice at the display on his cellphone, staring at the number. “It’s either a person who needs help or someone who wants to kill me,” he said.

headline: The Morning Line: Looking to Super Saver
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Urban Forager | A Purse With Herbal Remedies
text: A few weeks ago, Louisa Shafia, a chef and author of “Lucid Food,” contacted me after encountering a middle-age Chinese couple foraging for an unidentified green in a desolate area of Williamsburg, Brooklyn. When I met up with her a few days later, I took one look at the plant’s heart-shape seedpods, basal rosette formation and white, four-petal flowers and knew it was shepherd’s purse.

headline: Looking for a Championship, and Some Good Italian Food
text: Running back LaDainian Tomlinson, who signed with the Jets in March, did not need to drink Gatorade’s G Series Pro to be energized when he promoted the beverage last month in Manhattan. Tomlinson, 30, has a chance to play on a Super Bowl contender after spending the first nine years of his career with the San Diego Chargers. JOE BRESCIA

headline: Tomlinson Looking for a Championship, and Some Good Italian Food
text: Running back LaDainian Tomlinson, who signed with the Jets in March, did not need to drink Gatorade’s G Series Pro to be energized when he promoted the beverage last month in Manhattan. Tomlinson, 30, has a chance to play on a Super Bowl contender after spending the first nine years of his career with the San Diego Chargers.

headline: In Bangkok, Gunfire Outside a Reporter’s Window
text: BANGKOK

headline: Petty Remains Nascar’s Once-and-Always King
text: Down on the street, heavy metal stanchions were in place for President Obama’s visit Thursday night.

headline: Google Tells Sites for ‘Cougars’ to Go Prowl Elsewhere
text: IF you’re a woman who would like to date younger men, you can find lots of articles about these relationships by doing a Google search.

headline: The Guy the Red Bulls Should Get
text: Begin dream sequence. …

headline: MisIMFormation?
text: The IMF has a new report (pdf) on fiscal troubles ahead; it’s characteristically full of useful information. But the way it’s written, it’s actually quite hard to figure out what’s going on — and when you do decipher it, the story is quite different from the impression most people will get.

headline: A Touchdown for Girls' Flag Football
text: Ever since Florida became the first state in the nation to add flag football as a varsity sport for girls eight years ago, it has exploded in popularity.

headline: No Tackling, but a Girls’ Sport Takes Some Hits
text: JUPITER, Fla. — Flag football, long relegated to family picnics and gym class, has quietly become one of the fastest-growing varsity sports for high school girls in Florida. A decade after it was introduced, nearly 5,000 girls play statewide — a welcome development in a state that, like others, has struggled to close the gender gap in high school athletics.

headline: No Vote-Trading Here
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Mary Ferguson, Robert Parrinelli
text: Mary Kathryn Ferguson, a daughter of Karen Ferguson and John J. Ferguson of Greenwich, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Robert Thomas Parrinelli, a son of Jane Parrinelli and Robert T. Parrinelli of Franklin Square, N.Y. Cardinal Edward M. Egan performed the ceremony at St. Mary Parish in Greenwich, with Rev. Mark A. Connolly, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

headline: Get Your Crab On
text: BALTIMORE — Horse racing has long been a tradition in Maryland. So has eating blue crabs. And perhaps nobody does it better than Obrycki’s Crab House in Baltimore. Oprah likes their crab cakes so much, she put them on her inaugural favorite things list.

headline: Seeing Path to the Top, Kerr Turns Reflective
text: MOBILE, Ala. — It is as if a towering tree in Cristie Kerr’s sightline was uprooted this month, leaving her with a less-obstructed path to the world No. 1 ranking.

headline: A Healthy Garnett Puts Another Title in the Celtics’ Reach
text: When the Boston Celtics were sent packing by the Orlando Magic last spring — extinguishing their title defense, stirring doubts about their future — Kevin Garnett was a bystander. A tall, ferocious, foul-mouthed, finely tailored bystander making odd gestures on the sideline.

headline: Google Data Admission Angers European Officials
text: BERLIN — European privacy regulators and advocates reacted angrily Saturday to the disclosure by Google, the world’s largest search engine, that it had systematically collected private data since 2006 while compiling its Street View photo archive.

headline: Putting a Ring on Any Finger
text: Last season, Lakers forward Adam Morrison sat on the Los Angeles bench in a suit while his team won its 16th N.B.A. championship, putting him up, 1-0, over players like Patrick Ewing and Charles Barkley in career championship rings. As with every postseason, this year offers another chance for some unexpected players to win their first titles and take home a ring.

headline: Will 2010 be 1948?
text: There are hints in the polling data (see this one, not yet in the Pollster average above) — and, more generally, in the tone and feel of the news — that November may not be quite the Republican blowout everyone is expecting.

headline: Obama Thanks Families of Slain Police Officers
text: WASHINGTON – President Obama paid brief tribute Saturday to police officers killed in the line of duty last year, telling thousands of their families, friends and colleagues who gathered for a memorial service on the west front of the Capitol that he wanted simply to thank them.

headline: I Can’t Eat That. I’m Allergic.
text: WHEN Robert Aronowitz sees friends he grew up with, he braces himself for their usual greeting. “Hey, Snot Nose. How are you doing?”

headline: Putting a Ring on Any Finger
text: Last season Adam Morrison, the Lakers’ forward, sat on the Los Angeles bench in a suit while his team won its 16th N.B.A. championship, putting him up, 1-0, over players like Patrick Ewing and Charles Barkley in career championship rings. As with every postseason, this year offers another chance for some unexpected players to win their first titles and take home a ring.

headline: Violent Clashes Continue in Thailand
text: The military declared a neighborhood of Bangkok a “live-fire zone” and said it was calling in reinforcements as the death toll rose to 17 in a three-day offensive against protesters.

headline: Ode to Hex
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — We’re going to talk a little statistics, but bear with me. When I started XWord Info, I was looking for patterns in the grids, and I was curious about what words were most common and how they fit together. I also wanted to track statistics by author to see what I could learn. For example, who do you suppose is the most prolific  constructor for The New York Times?

headline: On Speech, Kagan Leaned Toward Conservatives
