There are indications in those writings that her views on government regulation of speech were closer to the Supreme Court’s more conservative justices, like Antonin Scalia, than to Justice John Paul Stevens, whom she hopes to replace.

headline: The Mets’ Japanese Reliever Has an Immersion Progam in Spanish
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. - Before Hisanori Takahashi left Japan for the United States to play baseball for the Mets, he did a little light studying of English words and phrases from a CD he bought, so by the time he arrived at spring training he was able to wish teammates and reporters a good morning in their native language and express his thanks.  At the time, Takahashi assumed that one of the keys to his adjustment to a new country would be to learn the new language of his teammates. What he did not realize was that perhaps he was studying wrong language. For Takahashi, the native language of his closest teammates, the ones he has spent the most time with during games, is not English, but Spanish. Since opening day on April 5, the left-handed Takahashi has been stationed in the bullpen, where he is surrounded by six other pitchers, all of whom grew up speaking Spanish in places like Venezuela, the Dominican Republic, Cuba and Puerto Rico. He has picked up almost as much of their language as English, and lately Spanish seems to be gaining dominance.  "He can really speak some Spanish," said Pedro Feliciano, a reliever from Puerto Rico. "His English is good, too, but I think in the last few weeks he has learned a lot of Spanish words."  Since his fellow Japanese reliever Ryota Igarashi was injured April 20, and soon after went to Florida for rehabilitation work, Takahashi was forced into a kind of bullpen Spanish immersion program. Now that he could be replacing Oliver Perez in the rotation, his next Spanish lessons may come in the dugout.  "The English is a little bit ahead of the Spanish right now," Takahashi said through his interpreter, Yoichi Terada. "But only a little bit ahead."  Of course, since this is baseball, a vocation dominated by young men, some - but certainly not all - of the words Takahashi is learning are of the crude variety. Takahashi never could have predicted it that within three and a half months of his arrival in the United States, he would be able to hurl slang like a Caracas cabdriver.  "He hears some words in the bullpen and asks me about them," the Venezuelan relief pitcher Fernando Nieve said with a smile. "Some bad words. But it's the same with us in English. That's what we learned first, too."  Before a recent game in St. Louis, Takahashi was standing near the dugout with the Dominican reliever Jenrry Mejia as they waited for batting practice to begin. At the urging of a reporter, Mejia looked over at Takahashi and said, "Habla Español?" and Takahashi replied without hesitation.  Mejia laughed and shook his head, then repeated the words in English to the reporter, words that could not be used in front of children or a television camera.  But Takahashi, who regularly greets his Latino teammates with proper Spanish salutations, is also learning language suitable for mixed company. He has a little black book that he takes with him to the bullpen. The book is primarily used to study the tendencies of opposing hitters, and when he is finished pitching he will write the results of each pitch, each at-bat in the book.  He also has a section in the back where he writes down new phrases he has learned in Spanish, like buen trabajo (good work), buena suerte (good luck) and even the saucier and even the saucier cállate, which means shut up.  When Takahashi and Terada went to Santo Domingo in the Dominican Republic in March to get his work visa, they came back raving about one aspect of the city. "Cerveza Presidente," Takahashi said, referring to the popular Dominican beer.  As far as baseball terminology, many of the words like fastball, slider and bullpen are universal, so Takahashi has not had trouble with them. When catcher Rod Barajas, who is fluent in English and Spanish, goes to the mound, he speaks to Takahashi in English, and there is an understanding. But so far, those conferences have not been complicated.  "Luckily, I haven't had a serious situation yet with all the infielders coming to the mound to discuss the situation," Takahashi said. "Maybe that will come. But in Japan, when those situations came up, I wouldn't listen anyway. I didn't care about what they were saying."  Takhashi's obvious sense of humor and his willingness to learn has endeared him to his teammates, especially in the bullpen, where they appreciate the circumstances he is facing. Feliciano, who played in Japan in 2005, is facile at languages and can speak some Japanese with Takahashi. But he knows it can be lonely at times.   "I went through that in Japan, and I don't want him to go through the same thing," Feliciano said. "No matter where you are from, I want everyone to be bullpen buddies."  Or, as Takahashi might put it, compañeros del bullpen.

headline: Thailand’s King Sees His Influence Fading
text: BANGKOK — A battle over Thailand’s future is raging, but the one man who has been able to resolve such intractable conflicts in the past has been notably silent: King Bhumibol Adulyadej, long a unifying father figure for his nation.

headline: Salary-Cap Machinations Prove Costly to the Penguins
text: With the Canadiens’ ouster of the Penguins last Wednesday, there will be a new Stanley Cup champion for an 11th consecutive season. Repeating as champion has been difficult since the end of the Oilers’ dynasty in 1990, and in the last 20 years only the Penguins (1991 and 1992) and the Red Wings (1997 and 1998) have managed to repeat.

headline: An Incident Between Schumacher and Rosberg

headline: Nick Johnson May Need Surgery on Wrist

If the shot solves the problem, Johnson could return in three weeks.

headline: Uncertainty Buffets Japan’s Whaling Fleet

headline: Ethiopian Runner Sets Record in Central Park
text: Gebre Gebremariam of Ethiopia set a course record in the Healthy Kidney 10K race in Central Park, sprinting to the finish in 27 minutes 42 seconds. Gebremariam, 25, the 2009 world cross-country champion, battled Peter Kamais of Kenya from the start of the 6.2-mile loop course, and edged him by seven seconds with a burst in the final 200 meters. Kamais won the New York City Half-Marathon in March.

headline: Woods’s Split With Haney Was Probably Inevitable

headline: Search Engine of the Song Dynasty
text: BAIDU.COM, the popular search engine often called the Chinese Google, got its name from a poem written during the Song Dynasty (960-1279). The poem is about a man searching for a woman at a busy festival, about the search for clarity amid chaos. Together, the Chinese characters băi and dù mean “hundreds of ways,” and come out of the last lines of the poem: “Restlessly I searched for her thousands, hundreds of ways./ Suddenly I turned, and there she was in the receding light.”

headline: Twins’ Visits to Bronx Keep Turning Out Badly
text: The topic got old for Minnesota Twins Manager Ron Gardenhire years ago. And because the Twins keep losing at an alarming rate in the Bronx — Friday night’s 8-4 loss was their 11th consecutive defeat there over four seasons — a question about that futility last week swung Gardenhire’s mood from sunny to surly.

headline: The Show Does Go On for Byrnes
text: When the Seattle Mariners released the veteran outfielder Eric Byrnes this month, Byrnes declined their offer to help him find a new team. Byrnes was ready to retire and promptly joined a friend’s slow-pitch softball team in Menlo Park, Calif.

headline: A Web Smaller Than a Divide
text: AT first glance, there’s a clear need for expanding the Web beyond the Latin alphabet, including in the Arabic-speaking world. According to the Madar Research Group, about 56 million Arabs, or 17 percent of the Arab world, use the Internet, and those numbers are expected to grow 50 percent over the next three years.

headline: The Content of Their Characters
text: This month, the organization that governs Internet domain names began allowing addresses without any Latin characters. Countries that use Cyrillic and Arabic characters were the first to change, with others on the way. Has the World Wide Web just become a little wider? Three writers offer their answers.

headline: Make ’Em Toe the Line (if They Can Find It)
text: Corner Office asked a writer at The Onion to imagine, with tongue firmly in cheek, an interview on leadership and management with the company’s fictional C.E.O., T. Herman Zweibel. According to Onion legend, the Zweibels founded the company in 1765 or 1988 or some other year, in the belief that their publication should always be a one-way conduit of information — and that if not for the almighty greenback and the interests of advertisers, it would not be necessary to have readers — riff-raff — at all.

headline: The Threat to Miranda
text: For nearly nine years, the threat of international terrorism has fueled a government jackhammer, cutting away at long-established protections of civil liberties. It has been used to justify warrantless wiretapping, an expansion of the state secrets privilege in federal lawsuits, the use of torture, and the indefinite detention of people labeled enemy combatants. None of these actions were necessary to fight terrorism, and neither is a dubious Obama administration proposal to loosen the Miranda rules when questioning terror suspects and to delay presenting suspects to a judge.

headline: Justice for Child Abuse Victims
text: The Catholic Church is working against the interests of child abuse victims in state legislatures around the country. In recent weeks, lobbying by the church has blocked measures in Wisconsin, Arizona and Connecticut intended to widen the legal window for victims to file lawsuits against hidden predators.

headline: Relief for the Gulf, Again
text: No one knows how long it will take to seal off the well that is still gushing oil into the Gulf of Mexico, or how much long-term damage will be done to the gulf’s fishery. But the spill has thrown thousands of people out of work and threatened the viability of communities that were already reeling from one of the worst hurricane decades on record.

headline: Free Kentucky’s Forgotten 44
text: Most people in Kentucky are unaware that “seducing or enticing slaves to leave their lawful owners” was once such a grievous crime that scores of abolitionists suffered long years behind bars for their common-sense daring. One of them was forgotten in his cell until five years beyond the end of slavery and the Civil War. Others emerged to tell of bleeding under the warder’s lash in a “jaws of hell” torment delivered by the state as the appropriate penalty for urging blacks to find freedom.

headline: Fear of a Double Dip Could Cause One

headline: A Heaven-Sent Rent Boy
text: OF all wars, only culture wars offer the hope of sheer, unadulterated hilarity. Sex and hypocrisy were staples of farce long before America became a nation, and they never go out of style. Just listen to the roaring audience at the new hit Broadway revival of the perennial “La Cage aux Folles,” where a family-values politician gets his comeuppance in drag. Or check out the real-life closet case of George Rekers, who has been fodder for late-night television comics all month.

headline: British Diplomat Takes Key Afghan Role
text: WASHINGTON — When military officers and diplomats gathered in a secure room in the Pentagon on a recent Friday to get a video briefing from the Afghan battlefield, they were startled to see a youthful British diplomat in an open-neck shirt, rather than the familiar face and camouflage fatigues of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the American commander.

headline: Supremely Girly Girl
text: From: Joe Biden [info@barackobama.com]

headline: Double Crossers
text: Note: The main Sunday puzzle is available only as a printable PDF. There is no Across Lite or Java applet version. If you go to the Java Applet from the Premium Puzzles page, you can time yourself on this weekend’s Second Sunday puzzle — a cryptic crossword by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.

headline: A Question From Lydia
text: Athens

headline: Pennsylvania Race May Show Democrats Which Way Midterm Winds Blow
text: WAYNESBURG, Pa. — Sam Boyd has been a Democrat his entire adult life, just like many here in this mostly rural, economically impoverished southwestern corner of the state, where the party’s roots run as deep as the coal underfoot.

headline: In Tough Stance, Democrat Finds Few Allies
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Federal Reserve opposes it. The country’s chief banking regulator dislikes it. The secretary of the Treasury has been unsupportive, at best, and Paul A. Volcker — no one’s idea of a best friend to Wall Street — calls it unnecessary.

headline: Visiting Africa’s Eden
text: GAMBA, Gabon

headline: For Times Sq. Suspect, Long Roots of Discontent
text: This article was reported by Andrea Elliott, Sabrina Tavernise and Anne Barnard, and written by Ms. Elliott.

headline: Metal Thievery Evolves, in Scale and in Technique
text: PIERCE, Colo. — Scrap metal thieves are not known for sophistication. From drug addicts in the 1970s ripping copper plumbing from walls to scrap-yard regulars of more recent years who proffer whatever fell off a truck, stealing hunks of coil or reinforcing bar has mostly been about having a strong back and a willingness to get dirty, law enforcement experts say.

headline: Sweat | Who Needs Grass?
text: There’s not a whole lot of grass in Manhattan, so the men’s golf team at Columbia University has to be resourceful in finding practice space.

headline: Mets, Out of Patience, Send Perez to the Bullpen
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — The struggling pitcher Oliver Perez was taken out of the Mets’ starting rotation and moved to the bullpen Saturday, Manager Jerry Manuel said, leaving the team in need of a starter for Wednesday’s game against the Nationals in Washington.

headline: Armstrong Is Confronting Something New: Doubts
text: SACRAMENTO — When Lance Armstrong rolls to the starting line of the Tour of California on Sunday wearing the uniform of his new RadioShack squad, some things should look familiar.

headline: Giant Plumes of Oil Forming Under the Gulf
text: Scientists are finding enormous oil plumes in the deep waters of the Gulf of Mexico, including one as large as 10 miles long, 3 miles wide and 300 feet thick in spots. The discovery is fresh evidence that the leak from the broken undersea well could be substantially worse than estimates that the government and BP have given.

headline: Something Else
text: What to do and when to do it — the signs are all there.

headline: U.S. Is Still Using Private Spy Ring, Despite Doubts
text: WASHINGTON — Top military officials have continued to rely on a secret network of private spies who have produced hundreds of reports from deep inside Afghanistan and Pakistan, according to American officials and businessmen, despite concerns among some in the military about the legality of the operation.

headline: Semantic Minefields
text: IF the Obama administration takes out a radical Muslim cleric hiding in Yemen, would it be a “targeted killing” or an “assassination?” Was the flooding of New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina a “natural disaster” or a “man-made” one? Should new construction authorized by Israel in East Jerusalem be called Jewish “housing” or “settlements”?

headline: A Day at the Races
text: Lookin at Lucky won the 135th Preakness Stakes and Kentucky Derby winner Super Saver placed eighth.

headline: No Triple Crown, but Young Rider Is King
text: BALTIMORE — He is a kid. Martin Garcia has been in this country for less than seven years and looks at the United States with a sense of wonder, whether from behind the counter of a Northern California delicatessen or now, through his racing goggles atop a thundering racehorse. On Saturday, as he led Lookin at Lucky onto the track for the Preakness Stakes, Garcia let loose a smile that would have been blinding atop a lighthouse.

headline: Hard Times for Spanish Farm Workers
text: Farmers have been reluctant to take back Spanish workers who left for more lucrative work — unsure whether they will work as hard as the foreigners who have been picking their crops.

headline: New List on City’s Web Site Opens Window on the News Media, Not on Daley
text: Mayor Richard M. Daley shrugged and insisted to reporters last week that his latest effort at “enhanced Web transparency” — publishing Freedom of Information Act requests as they are filed — was all about better government. As the mayor tends to say so often: Let’s be realistic.

headline: An Immigration Story, and a Love Story
text: The tale of Luigi and Rita Bragaloni is an immigrants’ love story. But so is that of Luigi and America. It merits telling amid the caustic policy debate exacerbated by the new immigration law in Arizona.

headline: Seeking to Assure Students’ Safety Outside School
text: When parents in some Chicago neighborhoods talk about keeping their streets safe for schoolchildren, they often refer to the times “before Derrion” and “after Derrion.”

headline: Providing a Soundtrack for Baseball Fans
text: A cellphone message that said his father had called was a bit unsettling to the broadcaster Len Kasper nearly two weeks ago as he worked the early innings of the Cubs-Pirates game from Pittsburgh.

headline: Taking Away Toys to Help Fight Obesity
text: In their quest to fight childhood obesity, California politicians have required chain restaurants to post nutrition information on their menus, banned trans fats from restaurant meals and taken soda vending machines out of the schools. Now they are turning their attention to fast-food marketing.

headline: Mets’ Old Nemesis Is Available
text: Any interest in Pat Burrell?

headline: Your Comments on My Gabon Column
text: My Sunday column is the first from this year’s Win-a-Trip journey, and is about Gabon’s efforts to preserve its amazing natural heritage. I really wish I had brought my kids on this trip: they would have loved Gabon’s wildlife. (They think I just drag them through impoverished villages, and so the odd elephant makes a nice reward….)

headline: Gang Injunction Names Names, and Suit Follows
text: Lucio Gonzalez, a 33-year-old unemployed truck driver from a tough part of Fairfield, said he was scared to look out the door at night, but not because of the area’s gangs. He thinks he will be a casualty of police efforts to control gang activity.

headline: Working It Out Through Walking
text: After working all day on projects for the Green Science Policy Institute, which she started in 2006 to focus on issues involving chemical flame-retardants in consumer products, Arlene Blum heads to the hills near her Berkeley home. She walks the Big Springs trail in Tilden Park, a mere stroll compared to her ascents of Annapurna in Nepal and Mount McKinley in Alaska and her yearlong, 2,000-mile trek across the Himalayas.

headline: Sleepy Jazz Scene Shows Signs of Awakening
text: A recent Sunday afternoon jazz matinee at Café Royale was a sleepy affair. About 15 people, most of them middle-aged, sat around this ramshackle downtown San Francisco bar sipping tea and wine while a saxophone, drum and bass trio played a mellow mixture of mostly standards. The noise of rustling bags of pistachios and yogurt-covered pretzels, which several audience members had taken along for snacks, accompanied the polite applause at the end of each number. Anyone who stopped by the Café Royale that afternoon to take the pulse of the local jazz scene would have reason to declare it faint.

headline: Gang Injunction Names Names, and Other Highlights From Sunday’s Bay Area Pages
text: Fighting Gang Violence | Is he a gang member or isn’t he? What might have been a question confined to police investigative units is now ricocheting around a far larger arena, as Fairfield and dozens of other California cities have become proving grounds for the latest legal assault on gang violence: the gang injunction.

headline: Lottery Numbers
With One Blunder, Challenger Lets Champion Keep Title
text: Some consider chess an art form, others a math problem to be solved, but at its heart it is a competition. Anyone who watched the more than 2,000 children competing at the National Elementary School Championships in Atlanta last weekend could see that.

headline: Pakistani Man Charged in U.S. Embassy Chemical Case in Chile
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — A judge charged a Pakistani man with illegal possession of explosives, but released him after finding no evidence linking him to terrorist networks.

headline: Bud Mahurin, Fighter Pilot in 2 Wars, Dies at 91
text: Walker Mahurin, one of the leading American fighter pilots of World War II, who downed enemy planes in Europe and the Pacific, and, later, in the Korean War, died Tuesday at his home in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 91.

headline: K. Dun Gifford Dies at 71;  Started Group to Promote Healthy Eating
text: K. Dun Gifford, who started an influential nonprofit organization to combat obesity and promote healthy eating around the world, and whose well-connected life put him in celebrated company and at the scenes of many newsmaking events, died on Sunday in Exeter, N.H. He was 71 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Mildred E. Orton, a Founder of Vermont Country Store, Is Dead at 99
text: Mildred Ellen Orton, who with her husband, Vrest, turned an 1828 building in Weston, Vt., into the Vermont Country Store and created a mail-order catalog that has offered old-fashioned goods and sundries to millions of buyers for more than 60 years, died May 6 at her home in Weston. She was 99.

headline: Richard LaMotta, Creator of Chipwich Ice Cream Sandwich, Dies at 67
text: Richard LaMotta, who turned his childhood passion for dunking cookies in milk into the Chipwich — two chocolate chip cookies embracing a chunk of vanilla ice cream dotted with chocolate chips — died Tuesday at his home in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 67.

headline: Deborah Remington, Abstract Artist of Classic Technique, Dies at 79
text: Deborah Remington, a New York painter who countered the accepted trends of her time by incorporating a sense of real light and space into her abstract images, died April 21 in Moorestown, N.J. She was 79 and had homes in New York and Chester, Pa.

headline: Mets Make a Change in Rotation but Not in Luck
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — A little more than two hours after Manager Jerry Manuel discussed why he removed Oliver Perez from the Mets’ rotation, the next pitching crisis unfolded before his eyes.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Gabriel García Márquez’s Cartagena, Colombia
text: Mr. García Márquez drew heavily on the reality of Cartagena, Colombia, for his novels.

headline: After Verbal Sparring, a Lopsided Title Fight
text: The boxer Amir Khan spent late April and early May in Vancouver, British Columbia, his entry into the United States delayed while he obtained a work visa. By Saturday, Khan had gone to work here for the first time, and his opponent, Paulie Malignaggi, wished the stopover had been longer.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about deportation of illegal immigrants quoted incorrectly from comments by Fred Tsao, policy director of the Illinois Coalition for Immigrant and Refugee Rights. Mr. Tsao said, “It’s far from being the case that individuals flagged through the criminal justice system are in fact criminals.” He did not say, “It’s far from being the case that criminals flagged through the criminal justice system are in fact criminals.”

headline: On Darwin’s ‘On the Origin of Species’
text: Evolutionary biologists and historians of science comment on Charles Darwin’s “On the Origin of Species.”

headline: Vows: Gabby & Anthony
text: Gabrielle Rubinstein opened a coffee shop in 2003, when she started setting up customers and friends on blind dates. Years later, she finally found her own love, Anthony Cheong.

headline: Restaurants at Spanish Hotels Sparkle
text: Lately it seems much of the news out of Spain has to do with chefs and hotels and the various ways to combine them. Some star chefs are opening their own boutique hotels, while others are hitching their culinary wagons to the stars (typically five) of new luxury hotels. Here is a look at some of the new and exciting entrants to the Spanish hotel-restaurant scene.

headline: Iraqi Insurgent Group Names New Leaders
text: BAGHDAD – The Islamic State of Iraq, the insurgent group that serves as a front for al-Qaeda in Iraq, announced Sunday that it had replaced two senior leaders killed in a raid last month.

headline: Beware Greeks: an Update
text: News Parody | From the Borowitz Report:

headline: Farm Aid
text: Video | With an old tractor in the band, no drummer needed:

headline: Delay on Cushing Decision Was a Problem on Many Levels
text: The failed drug test, the suspension, the decision to have a revote, the results of the revote,  Brian Cushing’s lame response — it all led to a lot of controversy and criticism.

headline: George Steinbrenner: Almost Cleveland’s Boss
text: The city of Cleveland’s latest quest for a championship ended in familiar heartbreak on Thursday night when the Boston Celtics ousted the favored Cavaliers from the N.B.A. playoffs. No Cleveland team has won a championship since the 1964 Browns.

headline: Renegade Thai General Dies as Chaos Continues
text: BANGKOK — Heavy fighting and explosions were reported in one area of Bangkok early on Monday in the deadliest and most prolonged conflict in Thailand in many years.

headline: Sounds of New Orleans, and Far Beyond
text: ‘Treme’

headline: Grand Ole Opry Gets Touch-Ups
text: Damaged by a flood two weeks ago, country music’s mecca, the Grand Ole Opry House in Nashville, is in the midst of major repairs. The hall has been stripped to its concrete foundation, The Associated Press reported. The famous six-foot circle cut from the floorboards of the Opry’s old home at the Ryman Auditorium and incorporated into the Opry’s stage has been salvaged, Steve Buchanan, president of the Grand Ole Opry, said, adding that it would receive a few new coats of varnish. “It’s going to need a little attention by a skilled craftsman, but we expect that it will be ready to go back in place pretty soon,” Mr. Buchanan said. According to The Nashville Business Journal, the Opry is working with several restoration firms to restore videos, audio recordings, photographs, string instruments and other material that was damaged in the flood. Next month Tim McGraw and Faith Hill are planning to host a benefit concert for victims of the city’s flooding, including musicians who lost their instruments, at the Bridgestone Arena in Nashville.

headline: New Adventure For Old Dia Building
text: The red brick building at 548 West 22nd Street, which was home to the Dia Art Foundation from 1987 to 2004 and more recently to a temporary project called the X Initiative, is about to enter a new era. The art dealer Zach Feuer signed a lease this week for half of the ground floor; CRG Gallery is in negotiations for the other half. Mr. Feuer, who is currently on West 24th Street, will more than double his space in the new building. He said that he needed more room to show his current artists, including Dana Schutz, Nathalie Djurberg and Phoebe Washburn, and also planned to take on new ones. The building’s other three floors and the roof have been leased by Dan Kobin, a former restaurateur who now runs a company called Absolute Events. Mr. Kobin said his floors would be used for corporate events, trade shows and fashion shows during Fashion Week. The art dealer Elizabeth Dee, one of the organizers of the X Initiative, will also present two museum-scale exhibitions a year in the building using space leased by Mr. Kobin.

headline: Rappers To Hit the Ball Field
text: Eminem, far left, and Jay-Z, left, will be tag-teaming at baseball stadiums this fall. Both rappers were at Comerica Park in Detroit on Wednesday when the Tigers and the Yankees played and announced that they would be doing two big concerts together: at Comerica on Sept. 2 and at Yankee Stadium on Sept. 13. At this stage in their careers, though, neither star is an opening act, so they were careful in their statement to call the concerts “co-headlining” shows. But Jay-Z clarified the lineup: Eminem will be the headliner in Detroit, his hometown, and Jay-Z will do the same in New York. Last year, Jay-Z played his hit “Empire State of Mind” at Game 2 of the World Series at Yankee Stadium.

headline: ‘Little Fatty’ Signs Deal With Sony Music
text: Here is why being saddled with the nickname Little Fatty and told that you sing like a girl is the best thing that could ever happen to you. On Thursday Sony Music Entertainment said that it had signed a recording deal with Lin Yu-chun, right, the 24-year-old reality show contestant who was pegged as Taiwan’s answer to Susan Boyle, The Associated Press reported. Yes, some of us may have had a good laugh at the expense of Mr. Lin, the bow-tie-wearing, bowl-cut coiffed shop worker when he performed a dead-on rendition of Whitney Houston’s “I Will Always Love You” on Taiwan’s “One Million Star” show back in April. (We’re talking Ms. Houston circa 1992, not Ms. Houston today.) But who’s laughing now? Sony said it would release a debut album by Mr. Lin in July, on which he will perform songs in English and Chinese. “I still can’t believe this is real,” said Mr. Lin, who should now be earning enough to get himself a proper haircut.

headline: ‘Glee’ Creator Reaches Out
text: After calling for a boycott of Newsweek, Ryan Murphy, right, a creator of the Fox television series “Glee,” has invited the writer of an article about gay actors published on the magazine’s Web site to watch the show’s writers and its casting process at work. Mr. Murphy called for the boycott after Ramin Setoodeh wrote that gay actors should not portray heterosexual men because they were not believable in such roles. According to Entertainment Weekly, Mr. Setoodeh got in touch with Mr. Murphy and is going to meet with the show’s writers to discuss why they found the piece so offensive. In a letter Mr. Murphy sent to EW he said that Mr. Setoodeh felt misunderstood and was the subject of anonymous attacks.

headline: Foreign Companies Chafe at China’s Restrictions
text: HONG KONG — Foreign companies doing business in China are increasingly feeling as if the deck is stacked against them.

headline: Upfronts 101
text: The word “upfronts” is shorthand for an annual rite of passage for television networks and the industry that operates in orbit around them.

headline: Upfronts: NBC’s Fall Schedule
text: NBC will add a total of 11 hours of new programs to its prime-time lineup over the next television season, with 7.5 new hours in the fall.

headline: Teacher Held as Spy in Iran Is Sent Home to France
text: PARIS — A young French teacher arrested in Iran on spying charges last July for photographing demonstrations there flew home on Sunday, as French officials repeated their denials that the release of Clotilde Reiss, 24, was part of a prisoner-exchange deal with Tehran.

headline: Stopping in New York, on a Nine-Year Pedal
text: Even among the Nepalese –- who always seem to be attempting strenuous feats to promote world peace — a 33-year-old former teacher named Lok Bandhu Karki stands out.

headline: Webber Wins Mad Monaco Race to Lead Series
text: MONACO — Twenty minutes before the start, the stars flocked to the grid of the most illustrious, glamorous race of the season, among them Mick Jagger. As the crowd got progressively larger, tighter and more rambunctious, the Rolling Stone turned to his companion and exclaimed with a laugh: “What a madhouse!”

headline: Belmont Will Be Without Super Saver and Lookin at Lucky
text: BALTIMORE — Neither the Preakness winner, Lookin at Lucky, nor the Kentucky Derby champion, Super Saver, will run in the Belmont Stakes on June 5.

headline: The Sunday Word: Pennsylvania Pre-Show
text: Senator Arlen Specter and Representative Joe Sestak heat up the talk shows as the deadlocked competitors for the Pennsylvania Democratic Senate primary try to get a leg up before Tuesday’s vote.

headline: Insurers Take Aim at New Regulations
text: Lobbyists for the insurance industry are trying to blunt the impact of new health care regulations being developed by federal and state agencies, Robert Pear of The New York Times reports today:

headline: The Morning Line: A Redemptive Win, With a Little Bit of Luck
text: The win by Lookin At Lucky in the Preakness Stakes on Saturday brought out a number of superlatives from the news media. Ed Gray wrote in The Boston Herald, “Lookin At Lucky is the best 3-year-old thoroughbred in the country, and he has been the No. 1 colt all year.” The winning trainer, Bob Baffert, proclaimed, “He’s a great athlete, one of the best horses I ever had.” Andy Beyer noted “The best horse won, and Lookin At Lucky re-established himself as the leader of his generation… [H]e left no doubt that he is a better horse than the Derby winner, Super Saver, who benefited from a perfect trip at Churchill Downs but finished a badly beaten eighth at Pimlico.

headline: Recount in Iraq Preserves Victory for Maliki Rival
text: BAGHDAD — A dispute over the counting of ballots in Iraq’s parliamentary elections in March came to a tentative end on Sunday, with the country’s election commission saying that a partial recount had preserved the narrow victory of the leading rival to Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

headline: Recognizing a King’s Flaws
text: We have heard all the musing and ranting about what LeBron James needs to win a championship, the right conditions for the ring-less King: a better coach, a new general manager, a stronger supporting cast, a grander stage – of course, all of it the responsibility of others.

headline: Warner Brothers Inks Syndication Deal for ‘The Big Bang Theory’
text: Prepare to see “The Big Bang Theory” on television a lot more often. Repeats of the popular CBS sitcom have been picked up by the cable channel TBS and by local stations owned by Fox in what is believed to be one of the most lucrative TV syndication deals ever.

headline: Sri Lanka Forces Blamed for Most Civilian Deaths
text: NEW DELHI — Tens of thousands of Tamil civilians died in the last, bloody months of Sri Lanka’s civil war, the International Crisis Group said in an investigative report to be released Monday, most of them as a result of government shelling of areas that were supposed to be safe zones.

headline: 2 Officers Die and One Is Gravely Hurt in 2 Accidents
text: Updated, 12:11 a.m. | A more recent version of this story, as appeared in the Monday editions of The New York Times, can be read here.

headline: BP Reports Some Success in Capturing Leaking Oil
text: NEW ORLEANS — After more than three weeks of efforts to stop a gushing oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico, BP engineers achieved some success on Sunday when they used a milelong pipe to capture some of the oil and divert it to a drill ship on the surface some 5,000 feet above the wellhead, company officials said.

headline: ‘Paradise Under Glass’
text: The Plant at the Top of the Stairs

headline: Renewing Rivalry, Nadal Tops Federer in Madrid
text: After a trying year, the King of Clay is back. Back on his favorite surface and back in his comfort zone, Rafael Nadal is 15-0 this year on clay, winning all three tournaments he has played ahead of the French Open.

headline: Universal Health in Deal for Psychiatric Solutions
text: 7:35 a.m. | Updated Universal Health and Psychiatric Solutions announced their merger agreement early on Monday. Terms are largely as DealBook reported: about $2 billion in cash, with the assumption of $1.1 billion in Psychiatric Solutions debt.

headline: Way Down Deep in the Wild, Wild West
text: The leading edge of interactive media has a new face. It is filthy, crudely scarred and belongs to John Marston, the protagonist of Red Dead Redemption, the sprawling and sublime new western from Rockstar Games.

headline: Lookin at Lucky Proves a Worthy Winner
text: Another Triple Crown quest ended after Super Saver finished eighth at the Preakness Stakes on Saturday, beaten by more than 10 lengths. Before the race his connections had assured us he was training well coming into his second start in two weeks. I was at the stakes barn as they left to walk over for the Preakness. Super Saver looked light. He looked like the Kentucky Derby may have taken a toll on him. Other observers noted that he always looks light and perhaps it was not an indication of things to come. But it raises the question, can a horse that is typically less robust return after such a short break and run his best?

headline: Valdes Being Considered for Wednesday’s Start
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — The Mets may turn to Raul Valdes to pitch Wednesday’s game against the Washington Nationals in place of Oliver Perez, who was demoted to the bullpen after his last start.

headline: The Emotional Toll of Putting on the Show
text: CANNES, France— The French actor Mathieu Amalric has appeared in at least one movie at the Cannes Film Festival every year since 2006 (among them major attractions like Alain Resnais’s “Wild Grass” and Julian Schnabel’s “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly”). Best known as the longtime muse and alter-ego of the director Arnaud Desplechin, Mr. Amalric is a live-wire screen presence and a habitual scene stealer who has enlivened a few Hollywood movies as well (he played a Bond villain in “Quantum of Solace”). But he has also had a quieter parallel career as a director, and his fourth feature, “Tournée” (“On Tour”) — the first in which he also stars — had its premiere Thursday as part of this year’s competition lineup.

headline: Here, a Careful Body Slam Is as Vital as Deft Dialogue
text: After five minutes of groin stretches and jumping rope, the actor Desmin Borges was ready to start morning rehearsal with a bit of choreography known as the sit-fall. A standard theater dance this was not: The sit-fall is a professional-wrestling technique whereby Mr. Borges would pretend to go down  hard  after a fake hit from an opponent. Mastering the move is crucial to avoid injury, especially for a wiry actor like Mr. Borges who lacks the beefy muscles that help wrestlers absorb body blows.

headline: ‘Iron Man 2’ Beats ‘Robin Hood’ at Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES  Ridley Scott’s expensive, dour and critically drubbed “Robin Hood” prequel opened to a soft $37.1 million in ticket sales and second place at the North American box office, though it did better overseas.

headline: Third Day of Fighting in Bangkok
text: Three days of street fighting between protesters and troops in Bangkok has left 29 people dead and hundreds wounded.

headline: White House Seeks Release of Kagan Documents
text: Get ready for the Kagan document dump.

headline: Introducing ‘The Stone’
text: Even before Thales fell into the well, and the ancient Greeks laid the foundation for Western philosophy, humans were engaged in the search for wisdom — a deeper understanding of their world, the universe and their own minds. Despite the rapid changes to our society and daily life, that pursuit continues. But what does philosophy look like today? Who are philosophers, what are their concerns and what role do they play in the 21st century?

headline: What Is a Philosopher?
text: There are as many definitions of philosophy as there are philosophers – perhaps there are even more. After three millennia of philosophical activity and disagreement, it is unlikely that we’ll reach consensus, and I certainly don’t want to add more hot air to the volcanic cloud of unknowing. What I’d like to do in the opening column in this new venture — The Stone — is to kick things off by asking a slightly different question: what is a philosopher?

headline: Rivera Yields Grand Slam as Twins Win
text: Mariano Rivera had not given up a grand slam since 2002, had not allowed a bases-loaded walk since 2005 and had not blown a save at home since 2007. But in a matter of seconds Sunday, all of those streaks came to an end.

headline: Mets Add to Their Losing Streak
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — An injury, some poor defensive play and another loss combined to make Sunday afternoon look like a brief review of last year’s horrors for the Mets, and that is not good for Manager Jerry Manuel.

headline: Dot Shot: Ferns in Spring
text: Here’s a brief mental break from unrelenting oil. I’ve periodically shared some images of the little patch of secondary forest adjacent to our house in the lower Hudson River Valley. It’s a region that was all cow pasture a century ago and the forests growing now are a tangle of young trees, vines and introduced species (barberry, garlic mustard, etc.). But they still provide a quiet space for enjoying the march of the seasons. Here’s our local fern patch, which I photographed yesterday (that’s my wife and favorite environmental educator in the background):

headline: Fortunately, Winning Was Hardly the Point
text: The world’s most successful single-session charity bridge event was played on May 11 at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan. Organized by Peggy Schwartz and Marci Miron, the event raised more than $100,000 for the UJA-Federation of New York.

headline: How Does Her Garden Grow? Lessons From a Greenhouse
text: Glass house, greenhouse, sunroom, winter garden, stove, conservatory, orangerie. By whatever name, the heated, glass-enclosed structures designed to facilitate the growth of tropical plants in nontropical climates have been a feature of Western architecture since the 17th century. For 150 years no wealthy estate was complete without one. By the 1860s they were included in half the new houses built in England. Today you can build one from a kit.

headline: ‘Law & Order’: Soon to Be Gone but Not Forgotten
text: “Law & Order” was supposed to live forever, so the fact that it almost did  20 years is an eternity in network years  doesn’t mitigate the shock of NBC’s announcement last week that it had pulled the plug.

headline: Last Stop in Exploration of Beethoven’s Sonatas
text: As part of its season-long concentration on Beethoven, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has been presenting a survey of the 10 violin sonatas with a shifting cast of players. The violinist Ida Kavafian and the pianist Gilles Vonsattel finished it at the intimate Rose Studio on Thursday evening.

headline: Making Flamenco Modern With Pain and Playfulness
text: The thought of an evening of flamenco dance at Theater 80 usually sends the mind reeling — quite happily — to the fierce and invincible Soledad Barrio, who headlines the company Noche Flamenca. She’s the sort of performer you never forget. By the end of a show, it’s as if she had been attacked by a storm and successfully beat it back into the sky. The troupe’s other female dancers can’t help but be overshadowed.

headline: Different Approaches and Grand Designs in a City Ballet Premiere
text: In “Outlier” — an impressively flashy, agreeably unconventional but expressively empty new ballet by the British choreographer Wayne McGregor — movement is often big, fast, multifocal and emphatic. Legs sweep up into hyperextended positions; individual body parts are given their own thrusts. In particular — so unusual in ballet — the head is suddenly jerked sideways or forwards, so that a step that might otherwise appear classically harmonious if extreme becomes eccentric. Certainly there’s something refreshing about the way this body-popping takes “Outlier” far outside the rarefied atmosphere of the ballet studio.

headline: Marathon of Music From Behind the Iron Curtain
text: Since Symphony Space inaugurated its “Wall to Wall” marathons with a salute to Bach in 1978, the series has usually focused on one composer’s works presented in a variety of ways. But occasionally these popular free events have embraced broader themes, like the Baroque era, folk music or opera. “Wall to Wall Behind the Wall,” presented on Saturday, fell into the second category, trying to compress into just 12 hours — 13 1/2, as it turned out — a representative sampling from 75 years of musical activity behind the Iron Curtain.

headline: Place for Camels to Water
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Jim Horne and I should have a catchphrase sign-off at week’s end, something like the “Parting words from the Terminator.” “Ahnold” has a stranglehold on that line, however, and on “Hasta la vista, baby” as well. “I shall return” is nice, but also taken. Maybe I’ll think of something before the end of this post.

headline: Ronnie James Dio, Rock Singer, Dies at 67
text: Ronnie James Dio, a singer with the bands Rainbow, Black Sabbath and Dio, whose powerful, semioperatic vocal style and attachment to demonic imagery made him one of the best-loved figures in classic heavy metal, died on Sunday morning, according to an announcement on his Web site by his wife, Wendy. He was 67.

headline: How Will They Spin This?
text: So, via Joe Romm, the NASA-GISS data show that the past 12 months were the hottest 12-month period on record. Here’s my plot of the temperature anomaly — the difference, in hundredths of a degree centigrade, from the average over 1951-80:

headline: At Cannes, the Economy Is On-Screen
text: CANNES, France  Anyone who doubts that the movie industry is still partly a handshake business had only to watch the glad-handing, backslapping and double-cheek air-kissing at the Vanity Fair-Gucci party at the Hôtel du Cap on Saturday night. This is where, some 30 minutes by private car or pricey taxi from Cannes, you could find after midnight the likes of Jeff Skoll, the first president of eBay and the founder of the busy company Participant Media, remeeting and greeting the likes of Michael Barker, who with Tom Bernard runs Sony Pictures Classics and who could later be seen in an intense tête-à-tête with the director Brett Ratner.

headline: Legal Threat for ‘Winnie’ Film
text: Production on a film based on the life of Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, right, the former wife of Nelson Mandela, is set to begin despite threats of legal action, Reuters reported. A letter from Ms. Madikizela-Mandela’s lawyers to the producers of “Winnie” stated that she would like to approve the script before production begins at the end of this month, according to André Pieterse, a producer of the film. “It was a benign letter and yet it contained the threat of an indictment, an interdict that could stop the picture,” Mr. Pieterse said. The producers have refused Ms. Madikizela-Mandela’s request, saying the screenplay, which was based on Anne Marie du Preez Bezdrob’s biography, “Winnie Mandela: A Life,” was thoroughly researched. Jennifer Hudson is set to star in the movie as Ms. Madikizela-Mandela, along with Terrence Howard, who will play Mr. Mandela. The director, Darrell Roodt, said he was sure Ms. Madikizela-Mandela would support the film, which he called “an amazing love story.” He added, “we have such a perception of her, but it’s entirely the incorrect one, because she was one of the few saviors of South Africa.”

headline: Footnotes
text: Grand Central Publishing has announced that it will publish the memoir of the movie critic Roger Ebert in fall 2011, its executive editor, Mitch Hoffman, said Friday, according to The Associated Press. The as-yet-untitled book will cover his relationship with his friend and fellow “At the Movies” co-host, Gene Siskel, as well as his struggle with thyroid cancer. ... Another television personality, the model and television host Tyra Banks, has landed a book deal. She can now add “author of young adult fantasy novels” to the special skills section of her résumé. According to Variety, Ms. Banks has agreed to a three-book deal with Delacorte Press to write the series “Modelland,” which centers on a teenager who is accepted into an exclusive academy for models and may harbor unknown powers. The first book is scheduled for release next summer.

headline: Rattlestick’s New Season
text: Rattlestick Playwrights Theater has announced its next season, which is to feature work by the theater everyman Adam Rapp, the filmmaker Dan Klores and the singer-songwriter Suzanne Vega, right, the theater’s producers announced. Rattlestick will open the season on June 11 with Mr. Klores’s (“Black Magic” and “Crazy Love”) first script written for the stage, “Little Doc,” a story set in 1970s Brooklyn. The actress and playwright Heidi Schreck’s “There Are No More Big Secrets,” inspired by her work as a reporter in Siberia and St. Petersburg, will follow, with performances beginning Sept. 1. On Nov. 3, Florencia Lozano, best known for her role as Tea Delgado on “One Life to Live,” will stage her second full-length play “underneathmybed,” and on Jan. 19 Mr. Rapp will present his “Hallway Trilogy,” a compilation of three plays set in three time periods: 1953, 2003 and 2053. Ending the season will be Ms. Vega’s first theatrical work, “Carson McCullers Talks About Love,” in which she alternates between spoken word and song, in the role of the author as she reminisces about love, art and life. Performances begin on April 20. The Rattlestick’s current production of Annie Baker’s critically acclaimed “The Aliens,” was recently extended to run through May 29. For information and tickets: rattlestick.org.

headline: Downtown Theater Company Faces Eviction
text: The Metropolitan Transit Authority has threatened to evict the experimental media and theater group 3-Legged Dog from its Lower Manhattan building. The authority notified the group on Friday that it would begin eviction proceedings on Monday if 3-Legged Dog did not pay the more than $306,000 it owes the authority in back rent and interest. The group signed a 20-year lease in 2002 for space at 80 Greenwich Street, now known as 3LD Art & Technology Center, agreeing to pay $21,666.67 per month there after its former location at 30 West Broadway was destroyed in the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, The Wall Street Journal reported. Kevin Cunningham, 3-Legged Dog’s executive artistic director, confirmed that the company had fallen behind in payments when foundations withdrew financial support because of the recession. He also said the theater had been forced to spend its own money on building maintenance, including asbestos abatement, without reimbursement from the authority. Though he said he had offered to negotiate a payment plan, the two companies have been unable to reach an agreement. The authority’s spokesman, Jeremy Soffin, told The Journal, “I don’t know how anyone can justify letting this tenant rack up hundreds of thousands of dollars in back rent at a time when state cuts and deteriorating tax revenues have forced the M.T.A. to lay off station agents and cut service.”

headline: ‘The Big Bang Theory’ Gets Syndication Deal
text: Prepare to see “The Big Bang Theory” on television a lot more often. Repeats of the popular CBS sitcom have been picked up by the cable channel TBS and by local stations owned by Fox in what is believed to be one of the most lucrative TV syndication deals ever, executives announced Saturday. The parties would not disclose the terms of the deal, but Variety reported that it “set a record price for a cable off-network sitcom purchase.” Warner Brothers, the producer and distributor of “Big Bang,” said stations’ interest in the series had risen steadily as it prepared to sell the repeats, in part because there are few traditional, multicamera comedies that attract a broad audience. “Big Bang,” which features Jim Parsons (above, with Mayim Bialik) is now in its third season and the highest-rated sitcom on television among adults aged 18 to 49. The repeats will start being shown on local stations and on TBS in the fall of 2011. TBS may schedule the episodes at 10 p.m. so that they lead into Conan O’Brien’s coming talk show on that channel.

headline: Free Days for Members of Armed Forces
text: Many museums, historical sites and other cultural institutions across New York’s five boroughs will give free admission to veterans and active-duty members of the United States Armed Forces over Memorial Day weekend, an idea conceived by Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, the Alliance for the Arts and the Museums Association of New York. The Museum of Modern Art, the American Museum of Natural History, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and the Whitney Museum of American Art are all participating. (The Metropolitan Museum of Art is, too, although technically you can always get into the Met free; the $20 ticket price is recommended.) The full list of the 54 institutions offering free admission will be posted on Ms. Gillibrand’s Web site later this week.

headline: Award for Sports Books
text: PEN American Center has teamed up with ESPN to create a new $5,000 award to honor the best nonfiction books about sports. “Sports have inspired some of America’s best writers, including Norman Mailer, Joyce Carol Oates, George Plimpton, David Halberstam and many others,” said Steven L. Isenberg, PEN American Center’s executive director. “PEN’s Literary Awards Program is one of the most comprehensive in the country, but we’ve never honored this corner of America’s great literary heritage. In ESPN, we found the perfect partner to help us begin doing so.” The winner will be chosen by a panel of three judges. The deadline for submissions for 2009 titles is June 15. Instructions are available at pen.org/espn.

headline: Fascinated With Loss but Reviving Traditions
text: “All of this can be broken,” the English songwriter Laura Marling sang in “Devil’s Spoke,” which started her set at City Winery on Friday night. Her lyrics are often mournful; they ponder loss, fear, separation, heartbreak, war and death. Yet even as Ms. Marling sang about mortality and ruin, her music attested to something durable: the British folk traditions that were renewed by trad-rock of the 1960s. Ms. Marling has chosen a heritage of modal, Celtic-rooted melodies and intricate yet unassuming guitar parts, and she uses them to write songs that face the worst.

headline: An Upward Trend
text: A funny thing has been happening on Capitol Hill: lately, the Democrats have started exceeding expectations. Health reform, pronounced dead by all the usual suspects, happened (all hail Nancy Pelosi, arguably the greatest Speaker ever.) Now financial reform seems set to pass, in a stronger version than almost anyone expected:

headline: The Squishy Science of Food Allergies
text: A federal report released last week found that while many more children and adults are reporting food allergies, no clear agreement exists on what a food allergy is or how to test for one. An article in Pediatrics in November 2009, for example, indicated that doctor visits for food allergies among children tripled from 1993 to 2006.

headline: City Stops Rooftop Farm in Queens
text: It had been a week of furious dawn-to-dark activity building a farm high above an industrial stretch of Queens: directing traffic along Northern Boulevard, hoisting truckloads of growing mix up to the roof and raking it over drainage and protective material. Once the eight-inch layer of engineered soil stretched over the 40,000-square-foot space, the volunteers could begin planting the 9,000 seedlings awaiting their new home.

text: Viacom’s MTV Tr3s, which is aimed at Hispanics in the United States, wants to be more to more people, so it’s broadening its prime-time programming.

headline: Quick Exit by President of UConn
text: No one was going overboard in putting a happy face on things when the University of Connecticut’s president, Michael J. Hogan, abruptly packed his bags for the University of Illinois last week less than three years into his tenure.

headline: 40 Years Later, a Proper Graduation
text: BOSTON — The telltale clues at this weekend’s festivities, 40 years late, included the tie-dye T-shirt on a woman who also wore a peace symbol necklace and a garland in her hair (“I thought everyone would be dressed like this,” she said).

headline: Fans of Gourmet Magazine Accept No Stand-Ins
text: Loren Shlaes, a pediatric occupational therapist in Manhattan, is the kind of amateur cook who bakes cakes for her friends’ weddings and makes her own spaetzle. She’s an avid reader of food magazines, and, over the years, has subscribed to Cook’s Country, Cook’s Illustrated, Saveur, Everyday Food and, beginning in the early 1990s, Gourmet.

text: The rocket that President Obama wants to kill is not dead yet.

text: CARSON, Calif. — Herculez Gomez, like each of his four siblings, was named after a Greek hero. Edson Buddle was named after a Brazilian one — Pelé, the soccer deity whose given name is Edson Arantes do Nascimento.

headline: Ash Cloud Shuts Airports in Parts of Europe
text: A cloud of dense ash from the volcano in Iceland resumed its havoc-making disruptions of European air travel early Monday, forcing aviation authorities to temporarily close important airports in the Netherlands and British Isles, including London Heathrow, Europe’s busiest.

headline: Europe to Offer 5-Year Plan for Telecom Industry
text: BERLIN — On Wednesday, Neelie Kroes, the new European commissioner for the digital agenda, plans to introduce a five-year plan for the telecommunications industry in Europe, encompassing issues like digital copyright, data protection, net neutrality and e-commerce.

headline: TV Networks Go on a Pilot Buying Spree
text: After a season of disappointing ad revenue, the further loss of viewers (and prestige) to cable networks, the end of popular series like “Lost” and “24” and the Jay Leno disaster at NBC, the broadcast networks are going back to an expensive drawing board.

text: Grab the flak jackets: Allan Mayer, a partner in the public relations powerhouse 42 West, has joined in a lawsuit against his old associate Michael Sitrick, the Hollywood crisis king.

headline: Taliban Hold Sway in Area Taken by U.S., Farmers Say
text: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — Farmers from the district of Marja, which since February has been the focus of the largest American-led military operation in Afghanistan, are fleeing the area, saying that the Taliban are terrorizing the population and that American troops cannot protect the civilians.

text: It reads much like a newspaper article.

headline: Grenade Attacks Shake Capital of Rwanda
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — Nearly simultaneous grenade attacks in the Rwandan capital, Kigali, killed at least two people and wounded 32 on Saturday evening, the police said Sunday.

headline: Lightning Hits Twice, but Eight Years Apart
text: The grand slam is baseball’s ultimate burst of runs. Mariano Rivera is baseball’s ultimate run preventer. Naturally, in his 15 sterling seasons as a full-time reliever, Rivera has rarely felt the sting of allowing four runs on one pitch.

text: Washington

headline: Astellas to Buy OSI Pharma for $4 Billion
text: OSI Pharmaceuticals said on Sunday that it had agreed to sell itself to Astellas Pharma of Japan for $4 billion in cash, after its suitor raised its takeover offer.

headline: In Trenton, Issuing IDs for Illegal Immigrants
text: TRENTON, N.J. — Since moving to this city from her native Guatemala a decade ago, Herlinda, an illegal immigrant, has supported her family with restaurant work, but has had no way of proving that she lives here. Without government-issued photo identification, like a driver’s license or a passport, she said, she could not get treatment at most medical clinics, borrow a book from the library, pick up a package from a mail center or cash a check.

headline: Ronnie James Dio, Rock Vocalist, Dies at 67
text: Ronnie James Dio, a singer with the heavy-metal bands Rainbow, Black Sabbath and Dio, whose powerful, semioperatic vocal style and attachment to demonic imagery made him a mainstay of the genre, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 67.

headline: Complex Struggle: Prelate’s Record in Abuse Crisis
text: In 2002, at the height of the sexual abuse crisis confronting the Roman Catholic Church in America, Timothy M. Dolan arrived in Milwaukee as the new archbishop, succeeding a prelate who had been caught up in scandal. To abuse victims who had felt rebuffed by the church, Archbishop Dolan — warm, down to earth — seemed a bright beam of hope.

headline: Auto Dealers Campaign to Fend Off Regulation
text: WASHINGTON — After nearly a quarter-century of selling pickup trucks and cars in North Dakota, Donovan Berscht had to shut one of his dealerships last year as Chrysler downsized. Now he is worried that a second financial jolt — this time the push for toughened economic oversight in Washington — could batter his remaining Chevrolet-Buick dealership.

headline: Amid Cup Fervor, Revisiting Pain of Apartheid
text: My introduction to Hugh Masekela came in 1968. Amid great turbulence, assassinations and riots, Masekela’s hit single “Grazing in the Grass” became the breezy anthem of a hot summer.

headline: Sign of Afghan Addiction May Also Be Its Remedy
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Hospital for Interior Ministry Addicts is both a symptom of how bad this country’s drug addiction problem is, and a possible solution for one of its worst aspects.

headline: 2 Officers Die in Crash; Third Is Badly Hurt in Chase
text: Two off-duty police officers were killed and four women were seriously hurt in a one-car accident on the Bronx River Parkway on Sunday morning, the police said.

headline: Going to Extreme
text: Utah Republicans have denied Robert Bennett, a very conservative three-term senator, a place on the ballot, because he’s not conservative enough. In Maine, party activists have pushed through a platform calling for, among other things, abolishing both the Federal Reserve and the Department of Education. And it’s becoming ever more apparent that real power within the G.O.P. rests with the ranting talk-show hosts.

headline: Fears Intensify That Euro Crisis Could Snowball
text: After a brief respite following the announcement last week of a nearly $1 trillion bailout plan for Europe, fear in the financial markets is building again, this time over worries that the Continent’s biggest banks face strains that will hobble European economies.

headline: The Great Consolidation
text: This feels like a populist moment. Americans are Tea Partying. Greeks are rioting. Incumbents are being thrown out; the Federal Reserve is facing an audit; Goldman Sachs is facing prosecution. In Kentucky, Ron Paul’s son might be about to win a Republican Senate primary.

headline: Brazil and Turkey Near Nuclear Deal With Iran
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Brazilian and Turkish government officials said Sunday that their leaders had brokered a tentative compromise with Iran in the international standoff over Iran’s nuclear program, a development that could undermine efforts in the United Nations to impose new sanctions on the Iranians.

headline: Mr. Gates and the Pentagon Budget
text: There has been a feeding frenzy at the Pentagon budget trough since the 9/11 attacks. Pretty much anything the military chiefs and industry lobbyists pitched, Congress approved — no matter the cost and no matter if the weapons or programs were over budget, underperforming or no longer needed in a post-cold-war world.

headline: Broadband and the F.C.C.
text: The Republican attack on the Federal Communications Commission’s proposal to classify broadband Internet access as a telecommunications service sounded a lot like the G.O.P. talking points on health care reform.

headline: Resisting Roundup
text: A vast majority of soybeans and corn planted in this country, and in much of the world, are genetically engineered, and the technology is rapidly pushing its way into many more crops.

headline: British Labour Party Looks to Rebuild
text: LONDON — Only days after yielding to a new coalition government, Britain’s Labour Party has begun to reconstruct itself from the wreckage of a failed election campaign, hastening to choose a new leader and move away from the “New Labour” days that won it 13 years of power before they ended last week in disillusionment and internal recrimination.

headline: The Right to, and Need for, Counsel
text: New York State’s highest court has affirmed the state’s constitutional duty to provide effective legal counsel to poor criminal defendants. It comes at a moment when public defender offices across the country are perilously short on financing and struggling with overwhelming caseloads.

headline: U.S. Troops Suffer More Stress Than Britons, Study Says
text: British troops who have fought in Iraq or Afghanistan suffer far lower rates of post-traumatic stress than Americans do, according to the most rigorous psychiatric study of Britain’s military so far.

headline: At Queens Libraries, a Passion for Japanese Comics Endures
text: Michael Jones, 15, is fiercely curious about all things Japanese. He is trying to teach himself the language. He reads about Japan’s mythology. And he wears his love for the country’s pop culture on his breast, literally — topping off an outfit of orange Nikes and jeans with a stuffed Japanese cartoon character, a toothy monster that dangles from the chest strap of the hulking backpack he rarely removes.

headline: Pakistani-Americans and Police Sharing, and Trying to Spread, Trust
text: STRATFORD, Conn. — Last month, a resident of Avon, Conn., received a threatening letter full of religious references. The police chief there, Mark Rinaldo, wondered whether the letter implied a broader threat from a Muslim militant.

headline: Virginia Women’s Team Embraces the Moment
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Parny Hagerman sat in the bleachers at Klockner Stadium on Sunday and wiped away tears with both hands. The Virginia women’s lacrosse team had scored a goal 12 seconds into its first-round N.C.A.A. tournament game against Towson, and the emotions of the moment were set free.

headline: Leap to Tracks for Dropped Item? Think Again
text: Late one night, waiting for the subway after a Mets game, Sean Frawley dropped his cellphone and promptly watched its battery pop out and land, with an unhappy plunk, on the tracks.

headline: Big Risks in China for Equity Players
text: China remains attractive to buyout shops, because when returns are good, they are very good. But in few countries do buyout firms have to work so hard.

headline: Photo Replay: May 16
text: A view of the day in sports, with Rafael Nadal defeating Roger Federer, the Superbike World Championship and Tyson Gay breaking a 44-year-old record.

headline: Two Ex-Cellmates Disoriented by Time
text: Even without reading Einstein, anyone who lives past the age of 2 figures out that time and space are relative. (When did my bedroom shrink? How did last year disappear so fast?) But rarely do you get to see this law of physics demonstrated with the artistry and emotional impact that Edie Falco and Alison Pill bring to it in “This Wide Night,” Chloë Moss’s deceptively slim two-character play at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater.

headline: Pressure Grows on Spain to Curb Digital Piracy
text: MADRID — Danko has shot to fame among online movie fans in Spain. The trouble is, nobody actually knows anything about Danko.

headline: Sandler O’Neill Analyst Garners Award
text: Richard Repetto, an executive at the boutique investment bank Sandler O’Neill, was named as “analyst of the year” by The Financial Times and StarMine, the firm said on Friday.

headline: After Suitor Raises Bid, OSI Agrees to Sell
text: After a two-month battle, OSI Pharmaceuticals said Sunday that it had agreed to sell itself to Astellas Pharma of Japan for $4 billion in cash, after its suitor raised its takeover offer.

headline: Giuliana Camerino Is Dead at 89; Designed Coveted Handbags

headline: To Top Golfers, a Trusted Coach Is Invaluable, but Expendable
text: When Hank Haney resigned last week as Tiger Woods’s coach, he said he had spent 110 days a year with Woods, including 50 nights at Woods’s home. Haney kept this schedule for six years.

text: PHILADELPHIA — Arlen Specter stopped by black churches on Sunday, paying homage to a vital bloc in his suddenly desperate race for the Democratic nomination for the Senate seat he has held for 30 years.

headline: In the Middle in Arkansas, and Hit From Both Sides
text: MAGNOLIA, Ark. — Time was, being a moderate Democrat in Arkansas was a safe bet. After all, this is the state that produced Bill Clinton, master of the midstream.

headline: Edward Uhl, Who Helped Invent Bazooka, Dies at 92
text: Edward G. Uhl, an aerospace executive who as a young soldier during World War II helped invent the bazooka, a devastatingly effective weapon against German tanks, died on May 9 in Easton, Md. He was 92.

headline: Hospital Operator Said to Win Clinic Chain
text: Universal Health Services has signed a deal to buy Psychiatric Solutions, one of the nation’s biggest operators of mental health clinics, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday. Universal Health is said to be paying about $2 billion in cash, or about $33.75 a share.

headline: Chomsky Barred From West Bank by Israel
text: Updated | Monday | 2:40 p.m. Noam Chomsky, an American linguist and political thinker who has been critical of Israel, was denied entry into the West Bank on Sunday by Israeli immigration officials when he tried to cross into the Palestinian territory from Jordan to deliver a lecture.

headline: Cavendish Confines His Boldness to a Finishing Sprint

headline: Suns Can Still Bring Out Snarl in Bryant and Lakers

headline: Positive Results for Online Government

headline: Rhetoric Is Ratcheted Up in Fight for Presidency
text: One day after the Russian Chess Federation endorsed Anatoly Karpov, the former world champion, for the presidency of the World Chess Federation, his opponent, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov attacked the decision in a public letter to the federation.

headline: Rina Castelnuovo and the Unending Story

headline: Regulators Close Four Banks

headline: The Bear Market: A Chat With Ace Greenberg
text: Bear Stearns‘s former chairman, Alan C. Greenberg, sat down with The New York Times Magazine’s Deborah Solomon for one of her trademark witty, acerbic (and condensed and edited) interviews.

headline: At YouTube, Adolescence Begins at 5
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Early this year, the most popular YouTube video of all time — a 2007 clip of a British toddler gleefully biting the finger of his older brother — was supplanted by a brash newcomer.

text: Street fighting spread to new areas as the deadliest and most prolonged conflict in Thailand in many years continued.

headline: Euro Hits 4-Year Low and Asian Stocks Slide

text: WASHINGTON — The United States, Europe and Russia responded with extreme skepticism to Iran’s announcement on Monday that it had reached an agreement to ship roughly half of its nuclear fuel to Turkey, saying they would continue to press for new sanctions against Tehran.

headline: What Are Your Attitudes Toward Money?
text: Are you a spender or a saver? Do you budget? Do you often wonder how much money others have? Are you more likely to choose a career because it pays well or because you love doing the work? He and Nick have spent the last week traveling in Africa, in Gabon, Republic of the Congo, and Democratic Republic of Congo. This is Mitch’s first time ever outside the United States.

headline: Hong Kong’s Celebration of the Bun
text: While the rest of East Asia erupts in celebrations to honor the Buddha’s birthday, residents of the small dumbbell-shaped island of Cheung Chau — less than an hour’s ferry ride from Hong Kong’s Central district — literally march to their own tune. The annual five-day Cheung Chau Bun Festival culminates this year on May 21. Nearly 40,000 people are expected to flood this fishing haven, then to make merry and enjoy the holiday’s namesake steamed buns, filled with sweet paste and stamped with the crimson Chinese character for “peace.”

Finley’s sale of his Oakland A’s players and to try to realign the National League, among other things. In each instance, the actions focused on owners, players or teams, The New York Times’s Richard Sandomir writes.

headline: N.F.I.B. Joins Suit Against Health Reform
text: The National Federation of Independent Business, never a fan of Democratic-inspired health care reform, announced Friday that it would join 20 states that are suing to have the law invalidated. “The fundamental mission of our organization is to promote and protect the rights of small businesses and the self-employed to own, operate and grow their business,” said Dan Danner, N.F.I.B. president, in a statement, “and this health care law directly undermines this core value.”

text: You need to be in two places at once, waiting for the cable guy at home and picking up your daughter at ballet class. The solution? Send Junior.

headline: Speed Read for Monday, May 17
text: Here are some highlights from Monday’s editions of The New York Times:

headline: Media Equation: Taylor Momsen, Google Bait
text: In his Media Equation column on Monday, David Carr mentions Taylor Momsen, whom he doesn’t know, except that she is a mean character on “Gossip Girl” and one of the most frequently used search terms on the Web. His real subject is the way that Google and other search engines are changing the way media companies think about headlines. Once upon a time, headlines were used to attract readers by conveying simple, clear information about what was in the story. Now, on the Web, they are used to attract the attention of search engines and social networking sites, using buzz words (“Taylor Momsen!”) and double entendres. He writes:

headline: Is Ben Bernanke Having Fun Yet?
text: Nine days ago, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, caught a Friday-night flight so he could address 1,100 graduates at the University of South Carolina the next morning about “The Economics of Happiness.”

text: As the Senate prepares to vote as early as this week on legislation rewriting the rules for Wall Street, the financial industry is holding fund-raisers for lawmakers at a rate of almost one every business day this month, Bloomberg News reported.

text: Senate Democrats hope to win approval this week of major legislation enacting new rules for the financial industry, while incumbents in both parties keep a wary eye on primaries in Arkansas, Kentucky and Pennsylvania.

text: With the network upfronts beginning — the events at which the networks trot out their new shows in hopes of snagging more advertising — a buying spree is under way in Hollywood.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: A Vegan Main Dish of Indian Green Beans
text: This succulent green bean dish, in a gently spiced sauce of coconut milk,  is from Bihar, a state in India. “It is an everyday, simple dish that is several hundred years old,” said Julie Sahni, a cooking teacher, and author of eight cookbooks, including “Classic Indian Cooking” (William Morrow, 1980), which is in its 38th printing.

headline: Sampler: Bay to Breakers, and Nitrates in Drinking Water
text: Record-Breaking Bay to Breakers | Lineth Chepkurui, a 22-year-old Kenyan, broke the women’s world record for a 12-kilometer run with a time of 38 minutes 7 seconds on Sunday in the ING Bay to Breakers. She beat, by three seconds, the world record she set on May 2 in Spokane, Wash. Sammy Kitwara, who is also Kenyan, won the men’s competition for the second year in a row, this time in 34:15. Some 60,000 other participants, who ran, walked and rolled in wheelchairs and strollers, followed the winning runners. Many of them wore zany costumes; some wore nothing but shoes. [The San Francisco Chronicle, The Oakland Tribune]

text: A moment of silence, please, for “Heroes.” NBC confirmed on Sunday that it had cancelled the once-buzzworthy superheroes show, the one responsible for the slogan “Save the cheerleader, save the world.” The dominant reaction from the entertainment press: “Finally.”

text: The closing line of Martin Fackler’s weekend article about fading passion for whaling in a Japanese whaling town is stark and telling:

headline: Afghan Teams Search After Plane Vanishes With 43 People Aboard
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An antiquated Soviet commercial plane carrying 43 people disappeared in the fog-shrouded peaks north of the capital here on Monday, with no word on where it had crashed or whether anyone had survived.

headline: Real Gifts for Your Virtual Friends
text: I’ve always thought that sending someone a virtual gift on Facebook was a little lame. Especially when you had to pay money to send it — I mean, a buck for a picture of a heart?

headline: Upfronts: Fox’s Fall and Midseason Schedule
text: Fox will add four sitcoms and three dramas to its schedule come fall, and it will move “Glee” to 8 p.m. to buttress a new Tuesday night of comedy.

headline: Archbishop Has Spent Decade Coping With Scandal
text: As the abuse scandal has reignited in recent months, Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York, one of the church’s most visible leaders, has focused scrutiny on bishops from Ireland to India, and has used his influential post to defend Pope Benedict XVI from criticism that he was slow to move against priests. A closer look at his record when he served in Milwaukee and St. Louis shows how he tried — not always successfully — to assuage the parties in the scandal. [NYT]  Government & Politics

headline: The Lighter Side of Ronnie James Dio
text: For a guy who sang about tigers, demons, wizards, evil and hell, Ronnie James Dio had a pretty good sense of humor about himself. Mr. Dio, the onetime lead singer of Black Sabbath and front man of his eponymous heavy metal band, died on Sunday at 67. But over the years he threw his devil’s horns in approval of a few satirical tributes in his honor.

text: Q.
