text: Despite dubious political maneuvering, especially an attempt to eliminate Sunni candidates, the recount of Iraq’s parliamentary elections was encouraging.

headline: Officer in Crash Is Still in Grave Condition
text: As one police officer battled for his life after being struck by a motorcycle, investigators on Monday were awaiting toxicology results in an unrelated accident hours later that killed two off-duty officers and seriously injured four women.

headline: One Final Evening
text: Nearby, I can hear the sound of the 10, a waterfall of asphalt and rubber. A helicopter putters past overhead, and there is the sudden, tubular flare of a motorcycle — a big one — climbing the on-ramp just a few blocks away. Mockingbirds swoop from fence to wire down the long line of backyards in this part of town, and the small, gray bird nesting in an angle of my porch-roof has bedded down with her eggs for the night. The twilight sky has reached the moment when, if I could, I would break a shard from it to light my way in the darkness.

headline: In Afghanistan’s North, Ex-Warlord Offers Security
text: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan — In a country still gripped by war, the families picnicking around the azure-domed shrine in the central square here are perhaps the clearest sign that this northern provincial city has distinguished itself as one of the most secure places in the country. An estimated one million people visited Mazar-i-Sharif for Afghan New Year celebrations in March and in the weeks after without incident.

headline: Security and Development in Afghanistan’s North
text: Mazar-i-Sharif, a northern provincial city in Afghanistan, has distinguished itself as one of the most secure places in the country.

headline: What We’re Reading: Strategy and Back Story
text: The tech editors and reporters of the The New York Times began this week with reading about a Twitter loss, a Microsoft strategy and the HP-Palm back story — and of course, about Facebook privacy settings too.

headline: Russian Journalists, Fighting Graft, Pay in Blood
text: KHIMKI, Russia — Mikhail Beketov had been warned, but would not stop writing. About dubious land deals. Crooked loans. Under-the-table hush money. All evidence, he argued in his newspaper, of rampant corruption in this Moscow suburb.

headline: U.S. to Press Pakistan on Bomb Plot Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — The White House is dispatching two senior national security aides to Pakistan this week to press the government there to intensify efforts to investigate the failed Times Square bomb plot and prevent others like it, administration officials said Monday.

headline: Children of the ’70s
text: Today you can walk around the Upper West Side of Manhattan in such ease and safety that you could get the impression it was always this way. But it wasn’t.

headline: Prudential Announces Terms for a $21 Billion Stock Issue
text: Prudential, the British insurer, announced the terms of its $21 billion stock issue on Monday, a move that keeps it on track to finance its acquisition of the Asian life insurance unit of the American International Group.

headline: $2.8 Million Settlement in Galleon Insider Case
text: A former executive at McKinsey & Company agreed Monday to pay $2.8 million to settle civil charges filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, after he pleaded guilty to criminal fraud charges related to the Galleon Group insider trading case.

headline: A Very Bright Idea
text: We hear a lot of talk about the importance of educational achievement and the knee-buckling costs of college. What if you could get kids to complete two years of college by the time they finish high school?

headline: TV Room
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — We have a special guest star stopping by at the end of the post, but first today’s puzzle by Peter Collins, a star to many here. An explanation of the theme is revealed below.

headline: Bloggingheads:  Sex Writers
text: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The Daily Beast and Rebecca Traister of Salon.com discuss women writing about their personal lives.

headline: A Lawyer Known Best for Losing Capital Cases
text: WASHINGTON — A good way to end up on death row in Texas is to be accused of a capital crime and have Jerry Guerinot represent you.

headline: After Meeting, Mets End Skid
text: ATLANTA — With his team sinking into last place and striding toward irrelevancy, Jeff Wilpon, the Mets’ chief operating officer, flew here Monday to hold a very public meeting, even if it was behind closed doors.

headline: N.H.L. Playoffs on Versus Find a Growing Audience
text: In the nearly five years since Versus acquired N.H.L. rights, the network has dealt with a sport fresh from a season-long lockout; fans saying they couldn’t find it on their televisions; comparisons with ESPN, the league’s former cable home; and a six-month dispute that kept the network off DirecTV until mid-March this year.

headline: Democrats Shifting Focus Back to Jobs Creation
text: WASHINGTON — Perhaps the only thing slower than the economy in creating new jobs is the process by which the White House and Congress are creating new jobs bills.

headline: Broken Lamps, Fried Computers and Other Adorable Things
text: To this day, Julie Haas Brophy maintains that the top was on the can of Rust-Oleum glossy black paint that started it all.

headline: Illegal Immigrant Students Protest at McCain Office
text: In an escalation of protest tactics, five immigrants dressed in caps and gowns held a sit-in on Monday at the Tucson offices of Senator John McCain, calling on him to sponsor legislation to open a path to legal status for young illegal immigrants.

headline: Journalists as Targets
text: A spate of attacks on journalists in the Moscow suburbs in the past few years has left many victims.

headline: N.B.A. Lottery to Set Order, but Not Much Will Be Settled
text: The N.B.A. draft lottery — that quirky festival of Ping-Pong balls, lucky charms and oversize envelopes — comes attached with certain assumptions.

headline: Nets Will See if a Billionaire Can Bring Good Fortune
text: Rod Thorn is not the superstitious type, or at least the rabbit’s-foot-carrying type. When he attends the N.B.A. draft lottery, he leaves the lucky tokens at home.

headline: Somalia: Shifts in Government
text: Somalia’s speaker quit on Monday and the president, Sheik Sharif Sheik Ahmed, said he would appoint a new prime minister to succeed Omar Abdirashid Ali Sharmarke. Analysts said that it was likely the moves were decided earlier in a deal with the speaker and Mr. Sharmarke to save the government from total disintegration. The war-torn country has been paralyzed this year, with many legislators living in Kenya, Europe and North America because of security fears.

headline: China: Knife-Wielding Woman Suffered From Schizophrenia
text: Police officials in Hangzhou, the capital of Zhejiang Province, said Monday that a woman who was detained last week when she walked into a youth center brandishing a rusty knife had been diagnosed with schizophrenia four years ago. The police said the woman’s family had told officers her name was Xing. She was seen last Thursday using the knife to carve into a tree outside a youth center. Xing, 35, then wandered into the center, where guards and police officers stopped her. She did not harm anyone. The episode took place a day after a man with a kitchen cleaver hacked to death seven kindergartners and two adults at a school in Shaanxi Province. China is reeling from a series of attacks on schoolchildren that have resulted in the deaths of 17 people.

headline: Rise and Fall of a Hedge Fund
text: The hedge fund group GLG Partners got its New York stock market listing when Freedom Acquisition Holdings, a blank check company, bought a stake in mid-2007. Then, Freedom’s stock traded above $10. Now, the Man Group, listed in Britain, is buying GLG for $4.50 a share. Sure, Freedom’s owners are getting a price they haven’t seen since last August. But longer term, it looks like a bounced check for investors.

headline: For Sports Wager, Mayors Have Fun With Immigration Law
text: LOS ANGELES — It is not uncommon for mayors of cities represented in major sporting events to make friendly wagers that might cost the loser some pride.

headline: Corrections
text: A film review on Friday about “Touching Home” misidentified the state where the character Charlie Winston, played by Ed Harris, lives. He lives in Northern California, not rural Colorado.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Yanks Top Red Sox With 2 Ninth-Inning Homers
text: Marcus Thames has spent much of his career on the bench, and that is where he would have been, should have been, in the ninth inning Monday night. If Nick Swisher were healthy, he would have been playing right field. If Jorge Posada were able to pinch-hit, no doubt he would have ambled to the plate with the score tied and two outs.

headline: Today’s Primaries Offer New Clues
text: It’s decision day for voters in Pennsylvania, Arkansas and Kentucky, where the outcome of Senate primary contests on Tuesday will deliver more clues to the puzzle that is the midterm election of 2010.

headline: A Generation Gap Over Immigration
text: MIAMI — Meaghan Patrick, a junior at New College of Florida, a tiny liberal arts college in Sarasota, says discussing immigration with her older relatives is like “hitting your head against a brick wall.”

headline: A Second Death in a Haitian Cemetery
text: Correction appended | These are not beautiful photographs. Maybe they are morbid. They stand as evidence of what is gone and as indictments of a grim declaration that dismisses the history and culture of an already-beleaguered Haitian people.

headline: Word of the Day | quell
text: quell •\ˈkwel\• verb

headline: Suns Have No Answer for Bryant or Odom
text: LOS ANGELES — If a report earlier in the day about Kobe Bryant’s knee being drained recently turned out to be slightly off target, nothing else about the Lakers’ star was amiss Monday night when Los Angeles opened the Western Conference finals with a 128-107 thrashing of the Phoenix Suns.

headline: Deborah Remington, Abstract Artist, Dies at 79
text: Deborah Remington, a New York painter who countered the accepted trends of her time by incorporating a sense of real light and space into her abstract images, died April 21 in Moorestown, N.J. She was 79 and had homes in New York and Chester County, Pa.

headline: Robert J. Serling, Aviation Writer, Dies at 92
text: Robert J. Serling, an aviation writer known for the best-selling novel “The President’s Plane Is Missing,” died on May 6 in Tucson, Ariz. He was 92 and a longtime Tucson resident.

headline: Dead Player Had Sickle-Cell Trait
text: A University of Mississippi player who collapsed during a February workout carried the sickle-cell trait, which contributed to his death, the Lafayette County coroner said Monday. The player, Bennie F. Abram, a 20-year-old junior, had tested positive for the trait during a routine screening by the university, said Kyle Campbell, a Mississippi spokesman. Campbell said Abram, who already knew he was positive, received basic counseling about the risk factors associated with the trait.

headline: News Quiz | May 18, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Shell Offers Reassurances on Drilling
text: Responding to a federal request to increase safety measures for its plans to drill for oil in the Arctic Ocean, Shell Oil on Monday vowed an “unprecedented” response in the event of an oil spill, including staging a pre-made dome in Alaska for use in trying to contain any leaking well.

headline: Asian Markets Mixed, but Calmer
text: Asian stock markets were mixed on Tuesday, with only muted rises and falls by midmorning, as investors took heart from a nearly flat finish overnight on Wall Street and a calmer performance by the beleaguered euro, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

headline: Central Bank Buys Billions in European Debt
text: The European Central Bank disclosed on Monday that it had bought 16.5 billion euros in bonds in the first week since taking the unprecedented step of intervening in markets to halt a sell-off of Greek and other European debt, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

headline: E.U. Approves Rules for Foreign Hedge Funds
text: The growing power of European Union institutions has long been anathema for many British Conservatives. Now those institutions could be a lifeline for the Tories as they battle to keep the hedge fund industry based in London, James Kanter writes in The New York Times.

headline: Violence in Bangkok
text: WHERE on a world map is Bangkok?

headline: Bobbing as the Taxman Weaves
text: No law without a loophole, no tax without an exemption the size of Ohio.

headline: Doglers
text: Dogless dog-lovers who ogle other people’s pooches.

headline: Macarthur Coal Rejects Peabody Bid as Too Low
text: Macarthur Coal on Tuesday rejected as too low a trimmed $3.3 billion takeover bid by the American company Peabody Energy, causing the Australian miner’s shares to plummet 12 percent in Sydney, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

headline: Europe’s Debt Crisis Casts a Shadow Over China
text: The pain of the European debt crisis is spreading as the plummeting euro makes Chinese companies less competitive in Europe, their largest market, and complicates any move to break the Chinese currency’s peg to the dollar, Keith Bradsher writes in The New York Times.

headline: Taliban Car Bomb Strikes U.S. Convoy in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban struck here at the heart of the Afghan capital Tuesday, with a suicide bomber steering his explosives-laden Toyota minibus into an American convoy as it moved through the thick of rush-hour traffic. The attack killed 18 people, including 5 American soldiers and an officer from Canada, and wounded at least 47 civilians.

headline: Marsh: The Euro’s Lost Promise
text: From David Marsh on The New York Times’s Op/Ed page:

headline: Huddle Nabs $10.2 Million for U.S. Expansion
text: From Anthony Ha at VentureBeat:

headline: France Frees Man Who Killed Iran Official
text: PARIS — Two days after Tehran freed a young French academic accused of spying, France freed an Iranian serving a life sentence for assassinating an exiled former Iranian prime minister in August 1991.

headline: The Fat-Cat Hypothesis
text: From Nancy Folbre at Economix:

headline: WaMu Tweaks Bankruptcy Plan
text: Washington Mutual proposed an amended plan of reorganization on Monday that would return $7 billion to creditors, but it was unclear if the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation would support the plan, Reuters reports.

headline: Lobbyist Is Said to Supply Fund Names to Congress
text: A Washington hedge fund lobbying group has given names and contact information about its members to Congressional investigators, The Wall Street Journal  reported.

headline: China’s One-Time Richest Man Jailed For 14 Years
text: China’s one-time richest man and the founder of a major retail chain was jailed for 14 years on Tuesday for bribery, insider trading and illegal business dealings, state media reported.

headline: F.A.A. Clears Cape Cod Wind Farm
text: One of the last remaining hurdles to a proposed wind farm off Cape Cod was cleared Monday when the Federal Aviation Administration said the farm’s developer, Cape Wind, had agreed to fix the air traffic control radar system at nearby Otis Air Force Base.

headline: Mine Director Replaced After Rebuke From Putin
text: MOSCOW — The Raspadskaya Coal Company announced on Tuesday that, Igor I. Volkov, the director of the mine where 90 people were killed in twin methane explosions, has left his post after a public reproach from Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, who said the mine’s management should be held accountable for safety violations.

headline: Informant Urges Australia to Investigate Goldman
text: An informant for United States regulators investigating fraud claims against Goldman Sachs has urged Australia’s markets watchdog to also investigate the American bank, The Australian reported.

headline: What Era Do You Wish You Had Lived In?
text: In 1970, the country was experiencing such political turmoil that some colleges, including Boston University, canceled commencement. Yet those graduates have found that some students today long for the activism of the Sixties. If you had the opportunity to travel through time and live in (or at least visit) a different era, which would you choose and why?

headline: Thoma Bravo to Buy Double-Take for $242 Million
text: Double-Take Software, a maker of data protection software, said on Monday that it has agreed to sell itself to a portfolio company of Thoma Bravo for $242 million in cash.

headline: Court Approves $1.1 Billion Sale of Canwest
text: Canwest Global Communications, Canada’s insolvent media giant, said Monday that the Ontario Superior Court had approved the sale of its publishing division to a group of the company’s creditors, The Associated Press reported.

headline: GLG Partners: Rise and Fall of a Hedge Fund
text: GLG Partners, the hedge fund group, got its New York stock market listing when Freedom Acquisition Holdings, a blank-check company, bought a stake in mid-2007. Then, Freedom’s stock traded above $10. Now, the Man Group, listed in Britain, is buying GLG for $4.50 a share. Sure, Freedom’s owners are getting a price they haven’t seen since last August. But longer term, it looks like a bounced check for investors, Breakingviews argues.

headline: Estee Lauder Adds Smashbox to Its Kit
text: Estee Lauder, owner of cosmetic brands like  Clinique and MAC, has announced a deal to add Smashbox to its dressing table, according to press reports.

headline: Making the Simple Complicated
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

headline: A Paris Museum Puts Focus on Prisons
text: An exhibition at the Musée Carnavalet gives visitors a look into a world normally hidden from the general public. “Impossible Photography, Paris Prisons,” which runs at the museum through July 4, features 350 photos taken in Paris’s prisons over the last 159 years.

headline: Follywood: When Hollywood Meets Finance
text: Two years after the collapse of the  investment bank Lehman Brothers helped set off  a meltdown of the global economy, a trio of films at Cannes offer very different, but complementary perspectives of why everything went so wrong, The Hollywood Reporter writes.

headline: Healthy Timing in Psychiatric Solutions Options?
text: Executives at Psychiatric Solutions, a chain of mental health clinics, have done well for themselves, Breakingviews says. The chain’s top four managers were awarded rich options packages in February. Just a few weeks later, news leaked of a leveraged buyout with the chief executive on board.

headline: Google Buys Norwegian Audio-Video Provider
text: Google is buying Oslo-listed Global IP Solutions for $68 million to build its real-time audio and video Internet capabilities, the two companies said in a joint statement on Tuesday.

headline: Grove Backs an Engineer’s Approach to Medicine
text: From Andrew Pollack at Bits:

headline: Canada to Oppose International Bank Tax
text: Canada’s prime minister has dispatched his top ministers around the world to wage a campaign against a proposed international bank tax that he said would unfairly penalize Canadian banks, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Consumer Reports vs. QVC
text: Today’s idea: Consumer-product testing is down to a science, but then again, so is shopping-network pitchmanship. Your call which prevails.

headline: Groupon Makes a Deal for Citydeal
text: Groupon, the online coupon provider, said Monday that is acquiring Citydeal in a move to expand its reach beyond North America into Europe, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Henry ‘Dr. Doom’ Kaufman Bids Adieu to Lehman
text: A prominent Wall Street economist, Henry Kaufman, has resigned from the board of directors of bankrupt Lehman Brothers Holdings, Reuters said, citing a regulatory filing.

headline: Axa Private Equity to Control Go Voyage
text: Axa Private Equity has agreed to take a majority stake in Go Voyage, in a deal that values the online travel agent at 400 million euros ($493 million), Reuters reported.

headline: Bomb Kills Pakistani Police Officer
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A bomb planted on a bicycle exploded in northwest Pakistan as a police convoy passed, killing a senior police officer and at least 11 other people, police officials said Tuesday.

headline: Calpers Votes to Split Top Roles at JPMorgan
text: The California Public Employees’ Retirement System, the largest American public pension fund, has voted for a shareholder proposal to separate the roles of chairman and chief executive at JPMorgan Chase, roles currently held by the veteran banker, Jamie Dimon, Reuters reported.

headline: Thai Army Moves to Confront Protesters
text: BANGKOK — Thai armored vehicles on Wednesday morning rammed through the barricades put up by antigovernment protesters, and infantry troops stormed into the protest zone, as the government moved aggressively against demonstrators who have occupied Bangkok’s central retail district for more than six weeks.

headline: Jermichael Finley Will Be the Best, and He Knows It
text: Jermichael Finley is going to be the best tight end in football.

headline: ‘This Is Our Time, Ladies!”
text: Thanks to everyone who read my first blog post and contributed thoughts, questions and advice. It was exciting reading through them.

headline: Questions About Cellphones and Brain Tumors
text: A long-awaited study of cellphone use and brain health has finally been released, but the data are raising more questions than answers.

headline: E.U. Sends First Installment to Greece
text: PARIS — The European Union transferred a first installment of funds to Greece on Tuesday, even as differences erupted among member states over how to manage the much bigger support package for the entire euro zone.

headline: Q.&A.: Charging the iPad
text: Q.

headline: Honda Delays the Next Civic
text: The arrival of the ninth generation of the Honda’s Civic compact will be delayed from fall 2010 to at least summer 2011, it was reported Monday in Automotive News. The redesign will also carry a 2012 model year designation, instead of the originally planned 2011.

headline: Speed Read for Tuesday, May 18
text: Here are some highlights from Tuesday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: The European Union  just approved its draft law on hedge funds.  What will it mean for London as a financial center, and for funds in the United States?

headline: Wider Circuit Breakers Mulled for U.S. Markets
text: United States regulators and exchanges are considering marketwide circuit breakers that would temporarily stop trading when it falls 5 percent, Reuters reported, citing two sources familiar with the talks.

headline: Animal House to Your House
text: Parody | From “Shouts & Murmurs” in The New Yorker, by Simon Rich:

headline: Former R.B.S. Banker Cameron Agrees to Ban
text: Johnny Cameron, the former head of the Royal Bank of Scotland‘s investment bank, said he had agreed not to work as a senior manager in the financial industry, as part of a deal with Britain’s Financial Services Authority, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: More FAQs on Style
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

headline: More FAQs on Style
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

headline: A Spur-of-the-Moment Artichoke Dish
text: Some people obsess over ramps and fiddleheads in the spring. I seem to be perennially taken with artichokes and asparagus. And I’ve written plenty about the latter this spring, including last week’s Minimalist on asparagus pesto.

headline: Sanchez and Latos Ready for Round 3
text: When naming the great pitching rivalries in the history of the N.L. West, the names Don Drysdale and Juan Marichal are likely to be the first mentioned. Less likely would be those of Mat Latos and Jonathan Sanchez. But if their first two head-to-head matchups are any indication, it may be time to talk about them soon.

headline: Houlihan and Knight Form Partnership
text: Houlihan Lokey, the boutique investment bank, and Knight Capital Group, the market execution firm, said on Tuesday that they would team up to provide capital markets services to clients.

headline: The Oil and the Loop Current
text: An article on Tuesday in The Times examines the prospect that oil from the gulf spill could reach the so-called loop current, which could carry it into the Florida Keys and the Atlantic Ocean.

headline: Texting While Driving? Put a Sock on It
text: Jeff Winger really must be the coolest guy on campus; how else to explain the run on thumb socks?

headline: Upfronts: Cable’s Influence on Display
text: More than ever, cable channels are crashing the upfront week traditionally dominated by broadcast networks. Five cable channels have presentations or other events this week, including TBS (with Conan O’Brien on stage touting his new talk show) and MTV (with a “Jersey Shore” party for media buyers).

headline: Upfronts: ESPN Adds Ad Creation Arm
text: In Tuesday’s New York Times, Stuart Elliott and Brian Stelter report that ESPN, a unit of The Walt Disney Company, has something new to share with media buyers at its upfront presentation Tuesday morning:

headline: Is College Overrated? (Cont.)
text: My colleague and friend Floyd Norris continues the discussion about going to college, and he disagrees with my earlier post on this topic. Over at The Choice blog, Jacques Steinberg also has a new related post.

headline: Negative Linkage
text: Tim Duy has an interesting point about the impact of the euro crisis on the United States: in the short run, it may help, not hurt, our prospects for recovery.

headline: Reason No. 2,372 Why We’ll Miss ‘Law & Order’
text: Let’s compare and contrast: Here’s the actress Anna Gunn in a not-atypical scene from her AMC television series “Breaking Bad,” on which she plays the frustrated wife of a man she has only recently learned is a maker and dealer of crystal methamphetamine:

headline: Wal-Mart Posts Slower Growth as Luxury and Home Goods Rebound
text: It was an encouraging start to the year for a broad swath of the nation’s retailers. Major chains like Home Depot and Saks reported earnings on Tuesday that suggested the beginnings of a rebound in categories hit hard by the recession, like home improvement and luxury goods.

headline: The Early Word: Pivotal Primaries
text: Some primary days can be sort of ho-hum. This one, however, looks like it will have plenty of excitement to go around.

headline: Making the Grade
text: Posting will be limited for the next 27 hours and 10 minutes, as I try to get my grades in on time.

headline: Forgotten Sibling Among Schools for the Gifted
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: The Wow Factory
text: As the world rediscovers the allure of city living, abandoned districts that once would have met with the wrecking ball are being revamped into cultural hot spots. From Cleveland to Hong Kong, artists, gallery owners, hoteliers and chefs are turning erstwhile areas of urban blight into thriving destinations, reclaiming factories, docklands, even entire industrial zones. It’s the meatpacking-district-Tate Modern-Bilbao effect, and it’s reached critical mass.

headline: How Will Insurance Be Made More Affordable?
text: Q.

headline: Upfronts: ABC’s Fall Schedule
text: ABC is debuting new series on four of five weeknights next season, with a focus on five new dramas.

headline: The Phone Whisperers
text: Video | Ad-supported smartphones are cheap and annoying:

headline: Chinese Business Mogul Sentenced to Prison
text: BEIJING — A high-school dropout who built the Chinese home appliance chain Gome into a multibillion-dollar empire was sentenced to 14 years in prison on Tuesday after being convicted of insider trading, bribery and other crimes, government prosecutors reported.

headline: E.U. Nations Override U.K. on Hedge Fund Rules
text: European Union governments overrode British objections — and United States worries — by agreeing Tuesday to tighten rules for hedge funds, a move some fear will block American funds from the region and cause the lucrative industry to flee London’s financial district, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Two More Years for Charlie Sheen on ‘Two and a Half Men’
text: In a move that will equally relieve comedy fans, the CBS network and armchair numerologists, Charlie Sheen said he would remain with his long-running sitcom, “Two and a Half Men,” The Hollywood Reporter said.

headline: CME Absolves High-Frequency Traders in Flash Crash
text: CME Group, in a detailed investigation into the flash crash of May 6, has put together evidence that suggests that the events might be traced to “divergent trade practices and price protection mechanisms” across the many trading venues that make up the National Market System.

headline: When Pests Are Cute
text: Out at the University of Victoria, in British Columbia, rancor is rising over how to handle an expanding colony of feral, and largely tame, rabbits that I wrote about and videotaped last year. Here’s my YouTube mini-report on the issue:

headline: Upfronts Explained
text: Television networks in the United States are announcing new programming this week and jockeying for an estimated $9 billion in advertising commitments. It is ABC’s turn today; NBC and Fox already presented their new shows.

headline: Citing Affair, Congressman Souder Resigns
text: Updated:  Representative Mark Souder, a conservative Indiana Republican, said Tuesday that he was resigning as of Friday after having an extramarital affair with a staff member in his district office, as events continued to roil the midterm election landscape.

headline: Austin City Limits Festival Announces Lineup
text: The Eagles and Phish will be making their only festival appearances of the year at the ninth annual Austin City Limits Music Festival in Austin, Tex., from Oct. 8 to 10.

headline: Fallon: ‘Relatively Tiny’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: In a new interview, BP’s C.E.O. said that the Gulf Coast oil spill is relatively tiny compared to the “very big ocean.” That’s like telling someone who’s just been shot not to worry about the bullet because they’re really, really fat.

headline: Letterman: ‘A One-Mile-Long Suction Hose’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Have you folks heard about the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico? Here’s what they’re doing now. They got a one-mile-long suction hose. It was flown down to the gulf on Friday by Superman.

headline: Leno: ‘Runs on Water’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: For the first time ever, an Arab-American woman has been named Miss U.S.A. Her name is Rima Fakih from Dearborn, Mich. She says she hopes winning this title will finally help get her name off the no-fly list.

headline: Hearings Gush Like Oil
text: The oil is flowing in the Gulf of Mexico, and the hearings are flowing at the United States Senate. There was one on Monday and there are three on Tuesday, the first of which I will live-blog.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Misconceptions About Fuel Economy
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Mother, Daughter and the Delicate Dance of Decision-making
text: “Mom, let’s leave. Let’s skip the info session,” Nicole whispered in my ear, as our guide escorted us down manicured paths leading from one gorgeous Gothic building to another. “I just don’t feel it in my soul.”

headline: Major Powers Have Deal on Sanctions for Iran
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration announced an agreement on Tuesday with other major powers, including Russia and China, to impose a fourth set of sanctions on Iran over its nuclear program, setting the stage for an intense tug of war with Tehran as it tries to avoid passage of the penalties by the full United Nations Security Council.

headline: Elvis Costello Cancels Concerts in Israel
text: Elvis Costello has canceled two concerts he was planning to perform in Israel this summer, citing the complexeties of the continuing Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Agence France-Presse reported.

headline: Chinese Stocks Retreat Abruptly From 2009 Gains
text: SHANGHAI — After a spectacular rise last year, China’s stock market has plummeted on what analysts say are growing concerns about Europe’s debt crisis and expectations that Beijing is about to take strong action to slow the nation’s booming economy and prevent it from overheating.

headline: If You Climbed Down for Something, Say Something
text: It is a particularly vivid brand of urban nightmare: the cellphone, iPod, wallet, umbrella or miscellaneous family heirloom that falls from our grasp and lands in that murky morass of the subway tracks.

headline: Grim Milestone: 1,000 Americans Dead
text: He was an irreverent teenager with a pregnant girlfriend when the idea first crossed his mind: Join the Army, raise a family. She had an abortion, but the idea remained. Patrick S. Fitzgibbon, Saint Paddy to his friends, became Private Fitzgibbon. Three months out of basic training, he went to war.

headline: The Old Guard
text: The ''Old Guard'' Caisson Platoon, the equestrian unit assigned to Arlington National Cemetery, honors veterans for their military service one final time.

headline: Live-Blogging a Senate Hearing on the Spill
text: The Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources held a hearing on Tuesday on offshore oil drilling, including the recent Deepwater Horizon explosion and spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Interior Secretary Ken Salazar testified before the panel. Green live-blogged the hearing, with the most recent updates at the top of this post.

headline: Oswaldo López Arellano, 88, Two-Time Honduran President
text: Oswaldo López Arellano, who twice served as president of Honduras and was its top military leader for nearly two decades, died on Sunday in Tegucigalpa, the country’s capital. He was 88.

headline: Sampler: Oakland Beating Case, and Dick Cheney’s Endorsement
text: Men Plead Not Guilty in Fatal Oakland Beating | Two 18-year-old men from Oakland pleaded not guilty on Monday in Alameda County Superior Court to murder charges in the fatal beating of Tian Sheng Yu, 59. Lavonte Drummer and Dominic Davis are both being held without bail in Santa Rita Jail in Dublin. Mr. Yu and his son, Jin Cheng Yu, 27, were attacked near the Fox Theater in Oakland around 3 p.m. on April 16. [The San Francisco Chronicle, KTVU]

headline: More on the Free Credit Score Amendment
text: Yesterday, the Senate approved an amendment to the financial regulatory bill that would provide free credit scores to some consumers in some circumstances.

headline: U.S. Stocks Fall Amid New Concern About Europe
text: Stocks on Wall Street fell on Tuesday and the euro retreated to a new low, in part after Germany moved to impose tighter regulation of financial markets.

headline: Paragallo Sentenced to Two Years in Jail
text: Ernie Paragallo, a prominent horse owner and breeder, was given the maximum sentence of two years in jail and a $33,000 fine on Tuesday, after his conviction on 33 counts of animal cruelty for starving and neglecting horses on his farm in the Hudson Valley.

headline: Dust Jacket Optional
text: Sometimes it’s hard to tell where book promotion ends and self-promotion begins. And sometimes it’s very easy indeed. Nudity is generally a tip-off.

headline: Home Building Gained in April, Strengthened by the Tax Credit for Buyers
text: Home building rose in April, government figures showed on Tuesday, as activity was possibly spurred by an $8,000 government tax credit for new buyers. But the data suggested that builders might also be slowing their future construction plans.

headline: Steve Jobs: Strong, Not-So-Silent Type
text: Many have had the experience of staying up late after one too many cups of coffee, or perhaps an adult beverage or two, and sending out a rocket on e-mail that they may or may not come to regret.

headline: Fidelity National Confirms End to L.B.O. talks
text: Fidelity National Information Services on Tuesday confirmed that it had ceased talks over a potential leveraged buyout, after DealBook and others reported on Monday that a group led by the Blackstone Group had withdrawn from negotiations.

headline: Obie Awards for ‘Circle Mirror Transformation’ and Its Author
text: Annie Baker‘s play “Circle Mirror Transformation,” a comic look at a group of strangers who come together in a creative drama class, was among the most celebrated productions at this year’s Obie Awards, which are presented annually by The Village Voice to honor Off-Broadway theater.

headline: Campaign in Damage Control Over ‘a Few Misplaced Words’
text: HARTFORD — Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, a Democrat running for the United States Senate, said on Tuesday that he took “full responsibility” for saying he had served in Vietnam when he actually had received five military deferments before enlisting in the Marine Reserve, enabling him to avoid combat overseas.

headline: White Bean Soup With Carrots, Celery and Roasted Red Peppers
text: You may associate bean soups with winter, but in my house a bean soup with seasonal vegetables is welcome any time of year. This one is based on a Greek recipe, with much less olive oil than the authentic dish calls for.

headline: Fishing Ban Is Expanded as Spill’s Impact Becomes More Evident
text: WASHINGTON — The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration greatly expanded the fishing ban in the Gulf of Mexico on Tuesday in response to spreading oil from the BP well blowout. The prohibited area now covers 19 percent of the gulf, nearly double what it was, according to the agency.

headline: European Powers Managing Personnel Crises Large and Small
text: Drama over the personnel choices of European World Cup contenders — whether because of injury or poor form — dominate online headlines on Tuesday.

headline: Life of Bryant
text: It is tempting to begin thinking of the Los Angeles Lakers’ Kobe Bryant as a Monty Python character, the knight who keeps getting his limbs cut off with a sword but yells, “It’s just a flesh wound!” The main difference between Bryant and the knight, of course, is that when Bryant is missing a couple of limbs, he may still score 40 points in a playoff game.

headline: Spinach and Tomato Soup With Rice
text: Perusing Clifford A. Wright’s wonderful new cookbook, “The Best Soups in the World,” I came across a recipe for something called “spinach-stem soup of the Turkish Jews.” In the traditional soup, only the spinach stems are used, while the leaves are reserved for another dish. Using that recipe as a starting point, I’ve added a few ingredients — most notably the spinach leaves. This is an easy soup to make.

headline: Why Is Her Paycheck Smaller?
text: An interactive chart that shows the stark wage differences between men and women within the same occupations.

headline: Off the Menu: Bar Artisanal Restaurant and Tapas Bar
text: The big space struggled as Bar Artisanal, a downtown sibling to Terrance Brennan’s cheese-centric Murray Hill restaurant, so the chef-restaurateur has crossed the Pyrenees and made it Spanish, adding the tag line Spanish Restaurant and Tapas Bar to the name.

headline: Asparagus Soup With Green Garlic and Eggs
text: This is a beautiful spring soup, high in protein because of the eggs — but light. Seek out green garlic at your farmers’ market. When you whisk in the eggs at the end, don’t let the soup reach the boiling point; that way you’ll get a beautiful creamy broth without curds. For a more substantial bowl of soup, add cooked pasta or rice.

headline: A Numbers Game
text: The Afghan soldier was giddy. Only seconds before he had spotted the improvised explosive device lying along the roadside. His sharp eye had ensured that the convoy was called to a halt before rolling through the blast zone. Yet his enthusiasm was such that he jogged up to the I.E.D. and triumphantly picked it up.

headline: Chicken Soup With Bulgur and Yellow Squash
text: Although squash isn’t ready yet locally, there’s some beautiful organic yellow squash from Mexico in my local supermarkets and at Trader Joe’s. I couldn’t resist using it for this Greek-inspired chicken soup with bulgur. Make your own chicken stock if you can; use the stock that resulted from poaching the chicken breasts.

headline: Pep Boys Settles Clear-Air Suit
text: In what the Justice Department has described as “the largest vehicle and engine importation case brought by the United States to date under the Clean Air Act,” the Pep Boys automotive parts and repair chain has agreed to pay a record $5 million fine.

headline: Drawing Inspiration, and Other Keys to Success
text: After the “epic” bombing of Shepard Fairey’s much blogged about — and previously attacked — piece of agit-advertising on Houston Street over the weekend, now it seems that no world famous street artist is safe from attack by his less famous brethren. Overnight, the British artist Banksy saw his new pieces similarly altered.

headline: Bernard Schoenbaum, New Yorker Cartoonist, Dies at 89
text: Bernard Schoenbaum, who in hundreds of cartoons in The New Yorker needled the relatively affluent, the media-conscious, the irony-besotted and the socially competitive — in other words, the readers of The New Yorker — died on May 7 at his home in Whitestone, Queens. He was 89.

headline: Upfronts: ESPN Gets Into the Game
text: Although ESPN has for several years made presentations during the annual television upfront week, it does not consider itself a typical entertainment network, forgoing announcements like “ESPN has picked up 12 new series” or “ESPN has signed a famous producer for a show for its prime-time lineup.” But during a busy presentation on Tuesday morning at the Nokia Theater in Times Square, ESPN made enough newsy announcements to pass for a network whose programs turn up on the cover of TV Guide.

headline: The Crisis of Liberal Zionism

Here’s his central claim:

headline: TimesCast | May 18, 2010
text: Today, a suicide attack in Kabul sends the U.S. death toll in Afghanistan over 1,000, China and Russia join a new round of Iranian sanctions and opposition journalists are attacked in suburban Moscow.

headline: The Morning Line: No Tarnish on Triple Crown
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School.

headline: Mercedes Will Not Appeal Schumacher Incident
text: It was probably just a way for Mercedes to give itself another chance to talk about its interpretation of what it instructed Michael Schumacher to do at the end of the Monaco Grand Prix. In any case, Mercedes Grand Prix announced Tuesday that it would not appeal the penalty against Schumacher, who was relegated to 12th position from sixth, with the loss of all available points that entailed.

headline: Turning 70, With Stars and Strobes
text: Because ballet has a tremendous capacity for virtuosity, it seems, in theory, to lend itself to galas. Witness the opening-night celebration of American Ballet Theater’s spring season on Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House. The audience came dressed to the nines. The dancers, dressed no less splendidly, did their jumps, their turns, their spectacular lifts, their dramatic gestures, their noble curtain calls. Was that wonderful for you, darling? It was wonderful for me too. Eager applause all round.

headline: A Cooler Hotmail?
text: At this point, Microsoft must have developed its own seminar for employees called something like Apologizing With Optimism: How to Persuade People to Give You Another Try.

headline: Political Heat Builds as Oil Spreads
text: Obama administration officials faced growing challenges over the unabated oil gusher on the Gulf of Mexico seabed on Tuesday as analysis of ocean currents appeared to raise the odds that Florida reefs and beaches could be tainted before the month is out. Senator Charles Grassley, the Iowa Republican, has sent a letter pressing the Department of Interior for more information on its questionable oversight of offshore oil drilling. At the same time, Senator Bill Nelson, the Florida Democrat, has intensified his criticism of BP.

headline: Case Study | Looking East
text: If you missed your favorite barkeep last Monday or Tuesday, it was quite possible he or she was packed into the Hiro Ballroom at the Maritime Hotel for what constituted the can’t-miss event of the year for the shake-and-stir set, a gathering that had cocktailian tongues wagging for months beforehand. Kazuo Uyeda, the reigning patriarch of Japanese bartending and self-professed inventor of the controversial “hard shake,” was making his first United States speaking appearance at a two-day seminar on Japanese bartending methods. As American cocktail culture has exploded over the past decade, cycling through every trend — from resurrecting 19th-century recipes and ingredients to molecular reinterpretation of drinks — a communal grasping has remained to understand the fastidious Japanese scene, which is focused in the tiny bars that dot Tokyo’s nightlife centers like Roppongi and Ginza, where Uyeda’s bar, Tender, is located. In the more recessed aeries of cocktail culture, an intense curiosity about and mimicry of the Japanese interpretation of the cocktail exists. It is safe to say that this fixation is almost entirely due to Uyeda’s reputation, and collective puzzlement over the hard shake.

headline: Taymor Says ‘Spider-Man’ Needs to be a Huge Hit to Cover Costs
text: The director Julie Taymor said on Tuesday that her upcoming Broadway mega-musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” would need to be a massive audience hit on par with her Disney musical “The Lion King” to cover its significant costs and ultimately turn a profit.

headline: White House Presses Senate to Approve Russia Arms Pact
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration encountered some Republican skepticism on Tuesday about its new arms control treaty with Russia but little outright opposition that might threaten the chances of ratification by the Senate.

headline: Ruined Stuff, Soured Friendships
text: Two articles in today’s paper that might be of particular interest to Motherlode readers.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Last week, Newsweek faced calls for a boycott and demands for an apology by a gay rights group after a recent column by Ramin Setoodeh questioned whether openly gay actors can play straight characters.

headline: As Violence Continues, Thai Tourism Falls Sharply
text: BANGKOK — Some of the city’s grandest hotels are shut and ringed with coils of glittering razor wire. Foreign visitors have deserted its temples and backpacker haunts. Military roadblocks hem in some of its famous nightspots.

headline: A Jazzman’s Final Refuge
text: Update:  Corey Kilgannon, who wrote this post, responds to some of the criticisms made by readers. It is comment number 34.

headline: Staged Accidents Are Big Business, and Business Is Good
text: The number of questionable claims for fraudulent, staged accidents went up 46 percent from 2007-9, according to a new report from the National Insurance Crime Bureau.

headline: Gay Couple Convicted in Malawi
text: JOHANNESBURG — A gay couple in Malawi were found guilty on Tuesday of unnatural acts and gross indecency, the consequence of their holding an engagement ceremony in an insular nation where homosexuality is largely seen as nonexistent or something that must be suppressed.

headline: You Don’t Need a Mr. Big
text: NEVER mind the plot. When “Sex and the City 2” arrives in theaters on May 27, scores of women will be paying as much, if not more, attention to the clothes — right down to Carrie Bradshaw’s $800 heels.

headline: At Cannes, Naming the Perpetrators of an ‘Inside Job’
text: CANNES, France— A political scientist turned Silicon Valley tycoon turned filmmaker, Charles Ferguson is making a specialty of a genre that might be called the disaster documentary. His first film, “No End in Sight” (2007), was a meticulous accounting of the bungled occupation of Iraq. “Inside Job,” which had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival last weekend and is scheduled for a fall release in the United States, offers a similarly lucid and outraged analysis of another complicated catastrophe: the global financial crisis of 2008.

headline: Ex-Congressman Saw Blumenthal’s Claims Evolve
text: HARTFORD — Former Representative Christopher Shays of Connecticut, a Republican who says he is a good friend of Richard Blumenthal’s, said in an interview Tuesday that he had watched with worry as Mr. Blumenthal gradually embellished his military record over the years.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Stalking the Wild Comme des Garçons
text: The Samurai Shopper is a woman of myriad talents: I may be all thumbs when replacing worn shocks and struts on my arthritic VW, but I can make a mean osso bucco and recite La Fontaine’s “The Grasshopper and the Ant” in French. Above all, I can shop vintage clothing shows with the precision and expertise of an astrophysicist.

headline: 36 Hours in Learning: Creating Travel Itineraries Across the Curriculum
text: Overview | How can looking at curricular material through the lens of travel illuminate crucial themes and ideas in any subject? In this lesson, students consider the elements of The New York Times travel series “36 Hours,” and then do their own “36 Hours” projects. They conclude by holding a “travel fair” to share their real or virtual itineraries.

headline: Polls, Before Polls Opened, Show Tight Races
text: It is primary day for two Democratic senators, and polls indicate a tough battle for re-election, underscoring the electorate’s anti-incumbent mood this election season.

headline: Student Crossword | New York City History
text: Test your knowledge of everything from famous landmarks to infamous disasters with our new Student Crossword. You can find the answers here.

headline: More Answers to Your ‘Lost’ Questions
text: The penultimate episode of “Lost” will be shown tonight on ABC. In advance of Sunday’s two-and-a-half hour series finale, the show’s executive producers, Damon Lindelof and Carlton Cuse, are answering questions about the show from Times readers.

headline: Bustle at JPMorgan’s Annual Meeting; Calm at Morgan Stanley’s
text: The two main descendants of the House of Morgan, JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley, held their annual shareholder meetings on Tuesday. But the two gatherings couldn’t have been more different.

text: The no-fishing zone doubles in the Gulf of Mexico, with nearly one-fifth of American waters there closed because of the oil leak.

text: Corrected LITTLE ROCK — The challenger, Lt. Gov. Bill Halter, in the race for the Democratic Senate nomination, was resting at home Tuesday after an all-night campaign swing that included stops at a pool hall and a Waffle House.

headline: Kith and Kin | Microsoft’s New Phone
text: Gala Darling is not the kind of girl who would normally sell you a smartphone. She imagines herself as a “a psychedelic picture show,” with platinum (formerly blue, then hot pink) hair, trippy Alexander McQueen bondage heels and Chloé 2148 sunglasses. A Kiwi by birth, a New Yorker by inclination, the 26-year-old is a devotee of the byzantine echo chamber known as “social media,” with 10,320 followers on Twitter and 4,357 friends on Facebook. She signs her blog posts — on fashion and also on “how to live magically” — with “love letters and feather headdresses.” Her next book, on “radical self-love,” is only “partially about masturbation.” People read her — lots of people, judging by the hundreds of comments her posts routinely generate.

headline: Doctor Accused of Doping Is Linked to N.F.L.
text: A Toronto-based doctor provided human growth hormone to a retired N.F.L. player and an unapproved drug to a current player, according to a criminal complaint filed Tuesday in federal court in Buffalo.

headline: Expecting Low Attendance at Belmont? Think Again
text: This year’s Belmont Stakes will mark only the third time since 1970 that the third leg of the Triple Crown will be run without at least one winner of the previous two legs.

headline: Britain Won’t Deport Suspected Qaeda Operative
text: Updated | Wednesday | 8:35 a.m. What do you do with a suspected Qaeda operative you think is a threat to your country, but who has not been charged with any specific crimes, and can’t be deported? That’s the quandary that the British government now faces, after a special immigration commission ruled that a Pakistani believed to be an agent of Al Qaeda could not be returned to Pakistan because he faced the possibility of torture there.

headline: Beau Biden Released From Hospital
text: Beau Biden, Delaware’s attorney general and the son of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., has been released from the hospital, a week after suffering what his doctor called a “minor stroke.”

headline: From U2: A Song for Spidey
text: The rock band Carney on Tuesday unveiled a new song by U2, “Boy Falls From the Sky,” an emo-like mix of ballad and hard, aching energy that is intended as a major number in Act II of the coming Broadway mega-musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.” Bono and the Edge wrote “Boy” and a dozen more songs for the show, their first Broadway musical, which has suffered production delays because of financial problems but is expected to begin performances in New York this fall.

headline: Thames Filling In With a Flair for the Dramatic
text: Marcus Thames hadn’t had many memorable moments as a Yankee before Monday night’s game-winning home run against Red Sox closer Jonathan Papelbon. There was, of course, that one back on June 10, 2002.

headline: South Korea to Accuse North of Torpedo Attack
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea has concluded that a North Korean torpedo sank one of its warships in March, killing 46 sailors, according to government officials and domestic news reports on Tuesday. South Korean officials are preparing to announce the results of their investigation later this week.

headline: A News Radio Soundtrack, Remade

headline: An Entente With the Tree Cutters
text: After negotiations with nine environmental groups, several forestry companies operating in Canada agreed on Tuesday to temporarily stop cutting in about 175 million acres of the country’s boreal forest.

headline: U.S. Still Seeks Binding China Steps on CO2
text: At a Brookings Institution conference on climate and energy policy, President Obama’s lead climate diplomat, Todd D. Stern, gave the keynote talk, restating the administration’s unbending demand that any legally binding provisions emerging in treaty talks must apply to all substantial contributors of greenhouse gases. The clear focus was on China, which has been locked in an Alphonse-Gaston standoff with the United States for years on the issue. The subtitle of the meeting was drawn from the movie “Back to the Future” but another choice could easily have been “Groundhog Day.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kabul and Elsewhere
text: A man driving a minivan crammed with explosives steered into an American convoy, Dexter Filkins of The Times reported from Kabul, killing 18 people, including five American soldiers and one from Canada. At least 47 people were wounded, nearly all of them civilians caught in heavy traffic during the morning rush. The blast sent a fireball billowing into the air, set cars aflame and blew bodies apart. Limbs and entrails flew hundreds of feet, littering yards and walls and streets. The survivors, many of them women and children, some of them missing limbs, lay in the road moaning and calling for help.

headline: Kagan Documents Sent to Senate
text: The White House sent hundreds of pages of documents to the Senate on Tuesday as it kicked off efforts to confirm Solicitor General Elena Kagan as the next associate justice of the Supreme Court.

He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: Uncertain Future for a School Already in Limbo

Up in the Bronx, however, the teachers and students at Kappa International High School were in decidedly simpler surroundings as they awaited the ruling that will guide their fate.
