headline: Correction: In the Seattle Area, an Assortment of Treats
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about sweets in Seattle misspelled the name of the neighborhood in which Theo Chocolate, a chocolate factory, is located. It is Fremont, not Freemont.

headline: Dealing With the Chill in the Tech I.P.O. Market
text: Investors in technology companies should get set for a “new normal” when it comes to initial public stock offerings, according to the 451 Group, a technology investment research firm. While the number of technology I.P.O.’s is expected to be higher than last year, the amount of money that they could raise will not be anywhere near as high as it was during the boom times.

headline: Kentucky Voters Weigh Senate Choices
text: BOWLING GREEN, Ky. — In Kentucky, the spotlight was on the Republican primary, which has been cast nationally as a race between the establishment Republicans — represented by Trey Grayson, the secretary of state – and the Tea Party – by Rand Paul, an ophthalmologist who describes himself as a product of the movement, and is the son of Congressman Ron Paul of Texas, the libertarian who ran a quixotic campaign for president in 2008.

headline: For Baltimore, Arts District Offers Hope
text: BALTIMORE — On a recent Sunday afternoon, the Camden Yards complex, containing Oriole Park and the Sports Legends Museum, was crowded. So was the 1st Mariner Arena, where the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey circus was performing. But a few blocks from the arena, on North Eutaw Street, the sidewalks and most of the storefronts were empty.

headline: Louisiana Politician Drops Defamation Suit
text: Steve J. Theriot, the interim president of Jefferson Parish, La., who this month filed a lawsuit to find out the identities of anonymous commenters who he thought had defamed him on the Web site of the The Times-Picayune of New Orleans, has asked his lawyers to drop the suit, Mr. Theriot said on Tuesday.

headline: Revisiting the Psyches of Troubled Women
text: As the title character in the film “Rachel Getting Married,” Rosemarie DeWitt played a bride who was constantly being upstaged by her emotionally damaged sister, a recovering addict. And on the Showtime series “United States of Tara,” Ms. DeWitt, again playing a sister, is even more marginalized by mental illness  by a factor of five, the number of attention-hogging alternate personalities of her younger sibling, Tara.

headline: When Two Airlines Tie the Knot
text: AS soon as Continental and United announced their proposed merger, news media outlets began reporting on how the union might affect travelers  less competition and higher fares being the primary concerns.

headline: Dispatch | Captiva Island, Florida
text: Captiva, Fla., has long been a place of refuge for no-nonsense Midwesterners — the anti-Palm Beach, even the anti-Naples. But the understated charm of the island off of Florida’s Gulf Coast (which I’ve been assured has seen no effects of the oil spill) is not for lack of achievement. When I was there for a week not long ago, I met international litigators, art directors for major ad agencies and artisanal cheese sellers, all drawn to Captiva’s gorgeous beaches and profound sense of ease. The island has no celebrity chefs, no flashy main drag, no late night boîtes — and that’s exactly how locals and regular visitors like it.

headline: ‘Leo and His Circle’
text: Chapter 1: Around the Hall of Merchants

headline: Judging Women
text: If Elena Kagan is confirmed by the Senate, there will be three women on the Supreme Court for the first time. This is a measure of how far women have come. Two will be single and childless. This may be a measure of something else entirely.

headline: The Price of Justice
text: So begins an essay I wrote for this Sunday’s issue of the New York Times Magazine. It’s a look at whether mothers somehow make better judges. And why we would never dream of asking that same question about men. And whether it’s just coincidence that all the men on the court have children, while so many of the women who have been asked to serve do not.

headline: Rain Hampers Pennsylvania Turnout
text: A chilly rain continued to sweep across Pennsylvania Tuesday, keeping turnout light in the afternoon.

headline: Faisal Shahzad Arraigned on Terror Charges
text: Updated, 5:36 p.m. | Faisal Shahzad, the man accused of trying to set off a car bomb in Times Square on May 1, was arraigned before a federal magistrate in Manhattan on Tuesday evening on five felony counts.

headline: In Brooklyn, an Empty Lot Is Revived by a 1946 Spartan Trailer
text: Forget food trucks. Picking up on a staple of the hipster dining scene in cities like Austin, Tex., Brooklyn will now have its own trailer restaurant, Goods. Located in Williamsburg on an empty lot on the corner of Metropolitan and Lorimer – abutting the Lorimer L-train station – it’s a project of 3rd Ward, a nearby arts organization, whose founders spent a year restoring a 1946 Spartan trailer they found in a junkyard in Ithaca, N.Y.

headline: A Blend of New Pieces and Old Suits a Sextet
text: String quartets are the glamour ensembles in the chamber music world, but sextets are actually more natural. Far more than the top-heavy quartet, with its two violins offset by a single viola and a cello, a sextet offers perfect symmetry, balance and flexibility.

headline: A Past Love and a Little Wine in a Vineyard in Greece
text: The spirit of Dionysus inhabits “Lascivious Something,” set in a vineyard on a remote Greek island, where the thorniest confrontations are fueled by wine. But Sheila Callaghan’s frustrating play, produced at the Julia Miles Theater by the Women’s Project and the Cherry Lane Theater, is too intoxicated by its own mysteries. Like a host with a limited booze supply, it withholds when it should pour freely.

headline: The Beauty of Diversity, and Sea Slugs
text: Saturday, May 15

headline: First Came the Tweets, and Then the Sitcom
text: The biggest surprise on next season’s CBS schedule is a sitcom tentatively called “Bleep My Dad Says,” not just because its title disguises an expletive, but because it was inspired by a page on Twitter.

headline: Yahoo Buying Associated Content Web Site
text: Yahoo said on Tuesday that it was buying Associated Content, a Web site that hires freelance writers and video producers to share their expertise on a wide variety of subjects, The Associated Press reports.

headline: James E. Burnett Jr. Dies at 62; Led Safety Board in 1980s
text: WASHINGTON — James E. Burnett Jr., who, as chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board in the 1980s, led a campaign against drunken driving and fought to curb drug and alcohol use by railroad workers a, died Saturday at a hospice in Clinton, Ark., his hometown. He was 62.

headline: AAA Release iPhone App with Voice Navigation
text: Within the past year, AAA has released three iPhone apps – all free. While none of them will fix your flat, its latest app — TripTik Mobile — offers voice guidance for drivers looking for shortcuts, compares fuel prices at gas stations and finds AAA-approved restaurants and hotels.

headline: Jessica Hecht, Tony Nominee, Buys a Co-op
text: TO fans of the television comedy  “Friends,”  Jessica Hecht is Susan, the life partner of Carol, the ex-wife of Ross Geller, one of the lead characters. And as almost everybody knows, she made broadcast history in 1995 when Susan and Carol became the first lesbian couple on TV to become parents.

headline: Welcome to P.S. 87, or Not
text: More than 50 parents of kindergarten children wait-listed for popular Public School 87 on the Upper West Side got great news on Monday. They all received letters saying that their child’s alternate placement for kindergarten was none other than… P.S. 87.

headline: High-End Retailers Are Scouting Sites in Brooklyn
text: Brooklyn, the new bastion of cool for many New Yorkers, is poised to go mainstream chic. The announcement that Barneys Co-op will open its first store in Cobble Hill has cleared the way for other nationally recognized high-end retailers to make a similar move across the bridge, according to brokers who specialize in representing luxury clothiers.

headline: Searching for Hidden Treasure
text: If you’re looking for an activity for your children or grandchildren, you might try geocaching, a treasure-hunting game played by using GPS devices to find hidden containers, or geocaches, outdoors and then sharing the experiences online. A typical geocache treasure is an inexpensive but intriguing object, like a tiny Rubik’s cube, a postcard or a coin from a different country. Sometimes the caches contain a Travel Bug with a code that can be tracked, so you can see where it’s been.

headline: Axl Rose Sues His Former Manager for $5 Million
text: Perhaps no day in the life of Guns N’ Roses is complete without news of both a new “vook” and a mud-slinging lawsuit.

headline: Dorgan Is Retiring but Not Relenting
text: Never underestimate a retiring senator with nothing to lose.

headline: New Rules Would Limit Trades in Volatile Market
text: WASHINGTON — The Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday that it would temporarily institute circuit breakers on all the stocks in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index after the huge market gyrations on May 6.

headline: Rules to Limit Trading in Highly Volatile Markets
text: 6:52 p.m. | Updated The Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday proposed a trial of individual circuit breakers on all of the stocks in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index in response to the May 6 market disruption, The New York Times’s Edward Wyatt reports from Washington.

headline: Artifacts | Christian Boltanski’s Bonfire of Humanity
text: Clothes may perform as fashion statements but that’s hardly all they’re good for. On a live body they also shelter and expose, enhance and diminish, challenge and flatter, instantly telegraphing taste, class, style and sense of self. Discarded garments tell another story — especially when 30 tons of them are tossed willy-nilly into a twenty-five-foot high, bonfire-like pyramid surrounded by a mass grave of 60,000 pieces of apparel in every size, shape and color. Then they speak for the dead.

headline: Until We Meet Again
text: Mitch Smith is a 19-year-old journalism student at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the winner of the 2010 Win-A-Trip with Nick contest. He and Nick spent the last week traveling through Africa, with stops in Gabon, Republic of the Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo…and now, South Africa. This is Mitch’s final post from Africa.

headline: On Brooklyn Homefront, the Women Are Restless
text: “Don’t you sometimes catch yourself being happy you’re on your own?” May Black asks her friend Alice. “What a terrible thing to say,” Alice answers.

headline: ‘Scottsboro Boys’ to Begin Performances in October at the Lyceum
text: The producers of the Broadway-bound “Scottsboro Boys” musical plan to begin performances in October at the Lyceum Theater, shortly after the show concludes an out-of-town run at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, according to Barry Weissler, one of the lead producers.

headline: A Smooth Operator, at the Vanguard of the Gallery World in the 1960s
text: In 1967, writing in The New York Herald Tribune, Tom Wolfe described an art opening at the Leo Castelli gallery on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. It was a big, crazy night. Castelli was showing new work by Jasper Johns, his favorite, the groundbreaking painter he’d discovered and championed nearly a decade earlier.

headline: European Businesses Hit in Credit Squeeze From Greek Crisis
text: When Tadeusz Nowicki visited his local bank in early May looking for credit to expand production at his profitable and fast-growing plastics processing company in Warsaw, Ergis-Eurofilms, he got a lecture instead.

headline: Do You Have a Mother? Then You Have Someone to Blame
text: You’ve probably heard it said that some people just shouldn’t have children. But consider this: if the people who shouldn’t have children didn’t have children, where would Western literature be? Half the memoirs on best-seller lists, it seems, are about surviving monster parents, as are too many first novels to count.

headline: Protecting Us With Guns and Chuckles
text: Hardly anybody enforces the law with a straight face anymore. Jack Bauer is on his last mission on “24,” and “Law & Order” was just canceled. NBC shook off “Southland” after only one abbreviated season, and the show ended up on TNT. Crime dramas are in a mannerist phase  almost all the top-rated network dramas about murder and mayhem have a flippant overlay, from “NCIS” and its spinoff, “NCIS: Los Angeles,” to “The Mentalist” and “Bones.”

headline: Marijuana Fuels a New Kitchen Culture
text: EVEN preschool teachers unwind with a round of drinks now and then. But in professional kitchens, where the hours are long, the pace intense and the goal is to deliver pleasure, the need to blow off steam has long involved substances that are mind-altering and, often enough, illegal.

headline: Two Daring Directors Who Changed Film History
text: In Emmanuel Laurent’s new documentary, “Two in the Wave,” the “two” are the filmmakers François Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard. The wave, needless to say, is La Nouvelle Vague, a journalistic name that not only stuck to Truffaut, Mr. Godard and their colleagues, but that also changed the way film history is understood.

headline: Bordeaux Loses Prestige Among Younger Wine Lovers
text: THE hyperbole over 2009 Bordeaux began building even before the harvest last fall. Ripples of praise grew into waves this spring as critics and the trade descended on Bordeaux for the annual ritual of tasting the most recent vintage from barrels. Their ecstatic reviews reverberated through Britain, which takes its claret extremely seriously. They rang out in Hong Kong, the leading edge of what Bordeaux hopes will be a huge Asian market.

headline: An Urban Farming Pioneer Sows His Own Legacy
text: JOHN AMEROSO didn’t hoe the rows of vegetables that help feed the Bronx at the Padre Plaza Success Garden in the borough’s Mott Haven section. He didn’t pick any tomatoes from the vines at the Brooklyn Rescue Mission’s farm. And he didn’t turn the composting bins that kept East New York Farms! fertile ground for collards, cilantro and chard.

headline: Working Under the Water, in a Job Measured in Minutes
text: “Delta Divers,” a two-parter that begins Wednesday night on the National Geographic Channel, looks like just another entry in the increasingly tedious collection of reality programs about obscure jobs that are rarely as glamorous as they sound. But the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has suddenly made the show more interesting than it might have been.

headline: Be Wary the Rush to Gold
text: Most of us have seen advertisements to buy gold or offering cash for gold. With the economy still unsettled and gold prices steadily rising, you may be tempted.

headline: Fried Chicken and Position Players on the Menu
text: On day two of his visit to Atlanta, Jeff Wilpon, the Mets’ chief operating officer, had lunch in the team hotel with other Mets executives. The menu included fried chicken. The agenda focused on the team’s position players.

headline: Strange Trip for a Piece of Nazi Past
text: BERLIN — Robert Edsel, author of “The Monuments Men,” came to town the other day with a heavy album bound in green Moroccan leather. “Gemäldegalerie Linz XIII” was embossed on the spine. Inside were black-and-white photographs of mostly obscure 19th-century German paintings.

headline: Blogging the Primaries
text: 11:19 p.m. |Wrap Up

headline: A Wall Street Presence in the World of Chess Politics
text: The masters of the universe gathered around the small stage in the Hudson Square Ballroom of the Trump SoHo Hotel on Monday night to bid in an auction. Sprinkled among them were a dozen thin models in backless dresses, but the businessmen seemed not to notice.

headline: Lucas Fine Foods to Open in Brooklyn
text: A former photo director who moonlighted as a caterer, Misty Kurpier, above, gave up her day job and is opening a prepared-food store dressed up with sparkly little chandeliers and a few seats. Her mostly seasonal menu will include gazpacho with grilled shrimp, grilled chimichurri steak on ciabatta, orecchiette in a light toss of plum tomatoes, and assorted salads. Brian Smith will make his new Ample Hills Creamery ice cream in the store. Among the flavors: maple with candied bacon, coconut mojito and bubblegum tinted with beet juice.

headline: Land Rover Is Working on a Diesel Hybrid and Two-Wheel Drive
text: Land Rover, a storied British brand that is virtually synonymous with four-wheel drive, has announced a two-wheel drive option for its new compact Range Rover, based on the LRX Concept. The new vehicle, which a Land Rover news release described as “the lightest, most fuel-efficient Range Rover ever,” is scheduled for 2011 availability.

headline: Thick White Asparagus a Spring Specialty
text: No amount of fiddleheads, ramps or anything else in the United States generates the springtime frenzy that white asparagus does in some places in Europe. The thicker the spears the better, because they tend to be fibrous and must be peeled. The bottom inch or so should also be sliced off. They should be cooked until very tender. At Seasonal, Wolfgang Ban simmers his in milk to diminish any hint of bitterness. A few stores are selling the jumbos, with stalks at least an inch in diameter, imported from France and the Netherlands. You’ll need no more than one per person. For a twist, serve them for lunch or a picnic like hot dogs, still warm, in toasted buns, with a slather of ravigote sauce and a little sauerkraut.

headline: Goat Milk Caramel From France, Not Mexico
text: Goat milk caramel is known as cajeta in Mexico. But who knew that it’s also made inroads in France? A caramel company in Beauvais, north of Paris, gives its firm but luscious goat milk caramels a little crunch with the unusual addition of roasted buckwheat grains. The candies, individually wrapped, come deceptively packed in a plain wooden box stamped with the head of a goat, the kind you’d expect to contain cheese, not sweets.

headline: Why We Travel 2008
text: “I was trying to be a little bit more creative, but the jury’s out on whether I succeeded or not.”

headline: Why We Travel 2009
text:
Bonaire
“There were a few spots where a huge school would completely surround you.”

headline: Mr. Blumenthal’s Misdirection
text: There are few sins less forgivable in American politics than claiming unearned military valor. Richard Blumenthal, the attorney general of Connecticut, may consider his false claim to have served in Vietnam to be “a few misplaced words,” as he put it on Tuesday, but, in fact, this deception seems to have been part of a larger pattern of misleading voters.

headline: Oil Sands as a Source of Energy
text: Canadian oil sands are expected to become the top source of imported oil, surpassing other conventional oil imports.

headline: 'Cremaster Cycle' Returns
text: A look inside the artist Matthew Barney’s film series “Cremaster Cycle,” which screens this month.

headline: Last Day of School, but Cutback Assignment Incomplete
text: The school year may be wrapping up, but local school districts are still working to complete a difficult assignment: hammering out their budgets for next year, under the pressure of ongoing state budget cuts and financial uncertainty.

headline: Platter Keeps Foods Cool
text: Keeping platters of seafood, sushi, cut fresh fruit or other perishables cool can be a challenge as the weather warms. The simple new white ceramic platter at the Museum of Modern Art stores provides a clever and convenient solution. The platter sits on a black melamine base that comes with a flat gel insert. Freeze the insert and place it on the base, with the platter on top, and whatever you are serving will keep its cool for a couple of hours. It works even better if you also chill the platter. It’s quite flat, so a big whipped cream cake can also go on it.

headline: The Counting Behind a Grim Milestone
text: Exactly how many American service members have died in the war in Afghanistan? The question is not as simple as it might seem.

headline: The Slow Route to Homemade Pizza
text: THERE’S little point in trying to match the horsepower available to a pizzaiolo. Their professional pizza ovens, especially the models that burn wood or coal, are the muscle cars of kitchens: when blazing at temperatures that range from 800 degrees to an infernal 1,000 degrees, they can turn raw dough into a blistered, bubbling pizza in as little as 75 seconds. It puts the home cook, whose oven typically reaches 550 degrees, at a permanent disadvantage.

headline: Tips for Making Pizza at Home
text: You can produce pizzeria-quality pizza with the perfectly normal stove in your kitchen.

headline: Toyota Pays Its $16.4 Million Fine Over Pedals
text: The Transportation Department said Tuesday that Toyota Motor had paid a $16.4 million civil fine, the largest allowed, over a recall of sticking accelerator pedals on 2.3 million vehicles.

headline: A Plea for Honesty in Photo Specs
text: I’m a big fan of photography magazines. There’s nothing like seeing someone’s successful photo and reading, right next to it, how they did it. You learn so much so fast.

headline: Inspectors Find Fraud at Centers for Children
text: Federal undercover investigators found workers at federally financed child care centers frequently misrepresenting information about applicants’ job status and earnings to fraudulently register ineligible children, the Government Accountability Office said in a report issued Tuesday.

headline: Conspiracy Seen to Rig Bids in Muni Market
text: More than a dozen banks have been accused of taking part in a nationwide conspiracy to rig bids in the $2.8 billion municipal bond market, Bloomberg News reports. They included Bank of America, Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase, Lehman Brothers and Wachovia.

headline: Somalia: Prime Minister Refuses to Step Down
text: The prime minister of Somalia’s weak transitional federal government on Tuesday rebuffed a move by the president to replace him, further deepening the bitter dispute within the government. Prime Minister Omar Abdirashid Ali Sharmarke said he would leave office only after a no-confidence vote by Parliament. On Monday, the president, Sheik Sharif Sheik Ahmed, had said he would appoint a new prime minister in an effort to end the longstanding rift within the government. That move immediately drew support from the United Nations special representative for Somalia, Ahmedou Ould-Abdallah. Somalia has been without an effective central government since 1991, when the former government was toppled by clan militias and later turned against each other. The current transitional government, which was formed in a 2008 deal brokered by the United Nations, has failed to restore security and been weakened by constant attacks, roadside bombs, corruption, disputes, suicide bombers and piracy. Many analysts caution that the latest strife within the government institutions could result in a total breakdown.

headline: The Lost Linz Album
text: A look at the recently rediscovered Volume XIII of Hitler’s Linz albums.

headline: Grant Lets ‘Frontline’ Expand PBS Programming
text: At a time when many news organizations are cutting back, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting is continuing its efforts to bolster in-depth journalism in public media. The corporation said on Tuesday that it was giving “Frontline” a $6 million, two-year grant that would allow it to expand its investigative programming to a year-round schedule on PBS stations.

headline: Mia Dona
text: A FRIDAY night on East 58th Street; the long, low dining room of Mia Dona, an Italian restaurant run by the ambitious young food personality Donatella Arpaia. The restaurant is neither full nor empty, but pleasant with date-nights and after-workers drinking primitivo and listening to Counting Crows’ first album playing on the stereo up by the bar, Adam Duritz singing, “We all want to be big stars.”

headline: In Vietnam, Recreating French Roots
text: HO CHI MINH CITY, VIETNAM  In Valerie Gregori McKenzie’s childhood home in Toulouse, France, the exotic was never far. Family lore was rooted in colonial Algiers, where three generations of Gregoris had lived until Algeria’s war for independence forced their return to France in 1961.

headline: Russia: Jailed Oil Tycoon Announces Hunger Strike
text: An imprisoned former oil tycoon, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, has declared a hunger strike to protest a court decision made earlier this month that extended his term in custody while he stood trial for large-scale money laundering and embezzlement. Mr. Khodorkovsky was the owner of the now bankrupt Yukos oil company. In a letter to the chairman of Russia’s Supreme Court, published on his Web site on Tuesday, Mr. Khodorkovsky said the decision violated amendments to Russian law recently signed by President Dmitri A. Medvedev.

headline: The Technicality Generation
text: THE problems faced by Richard Blumenthal, Connecticut’s attorney general, over his depiction of his military service are indicative of a broader disease in our society. The issues of integrity in business and politics that plague us today — the way elites are no longer trusted — are rooted in the dishonesty that surrounded the Vietnam-era draft.

headline: Obama Tells Ohio, ‘Our Economy Is Growing Again’
text: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio — President Obama came Tuesday to this area long synonymous with economic distress to take a few strides on a victory lap for the policies he credits with helping create jobs and to knock Republicans for standing in the way.

headline: Donatella Style: Mia Dona in Midtown Reviewed
text: A look at the Italian restaurant’s menu and soundtrack.

headline: Inside Pies ‘n’ Thighs
text: The Williamsburg, Brooklyn, restaurant has a new location.

headline: Q. and A. With John Ameroso on Growing Food
text: Since 1976, John Ameroso has been showing New Yorkers how to grow what they eat. As the first and, probably last, extension agent in the city focused on farming, Mr. Ameroso is more responsible than anyone for the rise of urban agriculture in the city and the tons of produce now raised in plots big and small. He’s recently retired, but is still winding down his work in the five boroughs, making sure his legacy will continue. While he’s at it, he will also answer questions from Diner’s Journal readers about city farming and growing food. Post your question as a comment below he’ll respond in later posts this week.

headline: At 2nd State Dinner, a Wish for No Drama
text: WASHINGTON — The last (and first) time President Obama hosted a state dinner at the White House, for Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India, it resulted in a quasi-national-security crisis, hours of Congressional testimony and the eventual departure of the White House social secretary, Desirée Rogers.

headline: A Haven in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
text: After stints in Paris, Los Angeles and Nevis, in 1992, Valerie Gregori McKenzie settled in Vietnam and renovated a two-story, 940-square-foot structure and its fifth-of-an-acre grounds into a lush, barefoot-friendly haven.

headline: Reliance on Oil Sands Grows Despite Environmental Risks
text: CONKLIN, Alberta — Beneath the subarctic forests of western Canada, deep under the peat bogs and herds of wild caribou, lies the tarry rock that is one of America’s top sources of imported oil.

headline: Homes Built as Statement Razed to Make Another
text: RAFAH, Gaza — Nidal Eid was praised by Hamas officials as an example of anti-Zionist resistance when he managed to build a house here last year despite an Israeli blockade that barred the import of any building materials. But earlier this week, his house was the first to be demolished by the Hamas government, which said it had been illegally built on public land.

headline: Karpov Raises Money (With a Little Help From His Friends)
text: A fundraiser for Anatoly Karpov’s campaign for the presidency of the World Chess Federation drew a crowd of financiers and chess players Monday night in Manhattan. The main attractions were Karpov, his old rival, Garry Kasparov, and Magnus Carlsen, the 19-year-old from Norway who is now the world’s top-ranked player.

headline: Pies ‘N’ Thighs
text: ONE of the most fervently discussed new restaurants of the year is the reincarnation of a seedy biker-bar offshoot that served fried chicken and pulled pork until it suddenly closed up shop in 2008, just one step ahead of the Department of Health.

headline: Senate Republicans Call Reform Bill a ‘Takeover’ of the Banking Industry
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republican leaders on Tuesday unleashed a barrage of criticism at the far-reaching financial regulatory legislation being debated on the Senate floor, indicating that many of the party’s leaders were prepared to vote against the bill.

headline: Protecting Kemp’s Ridley Sea Turtles
text: Scientists are closely monitoring the endangered turtles as a major oil disaster threatens their habitat.

headline: The Young Are Different, Justices Rule
text: To the Editor:

headline: He Didn’t Serve in Vietnam, but Said He Did
text: To the Editor:

headline: Killing Taints Iraqi Kurdistan’s Image
text: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq — Kurdish writers and human rights advocates are protesting the torture and slaying of a young journalist, challenging what they say are oppressive restrictions to free speech in a part of Iraq that presents itself as safe and democratic.

headline: Restoring the Grandeur of the City’s High Bridge
text: To the Editor:

headline: Times Square Bombing Suspect Appears in Court
text: Over the last two weeks, the naturalized Pakistani immigrant charged with driving a crude car bomb into Times Square settled into something of a strange daily routine: He signed a piece of paper waiving his right to a lawyer and a speedy court appearance. Then he continued to talk to federal authorities, providing what they have called valuable intelligence.

headline: Industry Strives for Cleaner Oil From Oil Sands
text: As Elisabeth Rosenthal and I discuss in an article appearing Wednesday in Business Day, oil sands — or tar sands, as their detractors like to call them — have a serious image problem, even among fossil fuels.

headline: The Hurdles of Foster Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Senate at the Finish Line
text: It is a bad sign, as the Senate enters the home stretch on financial regulatory reform, that there are so many unresolved issues since weaknesses and ambiguities in the legislation play into the hands of opponents of reform at this late date. It is especially disturbing that the vital area of reform — the regulation of derivatives trading — is being left to last.

headline: Symantec Nears Deal for VeriSign’s Security Unit
text: 9:46 p.m. | Updated Symantec is near a deal to buy VeriSign‘s authentication services unit for $1.3 billion, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday.

headline: Close to the Beach
text: A 530-square meter (5,700-square-foot) farmhouse in Plettenberg Bay is on the market for 6.5 million rand ($856,000).

headline: Crane Owner Pleads Guilty to Bribery
text: The owner of a crane company pleaded guilty on Tuesday to charges that he had bribed the former chief crane inspector for the city’s Department of Buildings.

headline: A Follow-Up to Home-Delivered Diet Meals
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gulf Oil Again Imperils Sea Turtle
text: PADRE ISLAND NATIONAL SEASHORE, Tex. — It is nesting season here, and just offshore, Kemp’s ridley sea turtle No. 15 circles in the water before dragging herself onto the sand to lay another clutch of eggs.

headline: Iran, the Deal and the Council
text: Every time it looks as if the big powers have finally run out of patience with Iran’s nuclear misdeeds, Tehran’s leaders suddenly decide they’re in the mood to compromise. And every time the big powers let up on the pressure, Tehran’s compromises turn to smoke.

headline: Life in the Third Realm
text: It’s that time of the month again. Yes: it’s time for Life-form of the Month. In case you’ve forgotten, this coming Saturday is International Day for Biological Diversity, a day of celebrations and parties to appreciate the other occupants of the planet. So if you do nothing else this weekend, drink a toast to “Other Life-forms!” In honor of this event, my nomination for Life-form of the Month: May is a group of abundant and fascinating beings that are undeservedly obscure: the archaea.

headline: Yvonne Loriod, Pianist and Messiaen Muse, Dies at 86
text: Yvonne Loriod, the French pianist whose musical exactitude and intensity inspired numerous masterpieces by her husband, the composer Olivier Messiaen, died on Monday at a retirement home in Saint-Denis, on the edge of Paris. She was 86.

headline: Off the Menu
text: East End Openings

headline: 2 Officers, 2 Courts and Charges of Eliciting Sexual Favors
text: Both cases started the same way, with a woman’s complaint that she had been coerced into performing sexual favors for a police officer. The ensuing investigations reached the same alarming conclusion: These women were not the only victims.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Chicken on the Agenda

headline: Spidey’s Song Is Sung
text: The rock band Carney on Tuesday unveiled a new song by U2, “Boy Falls From the Sky,” an emolike mix of ballad and hard, aching energy that is intended as a major number in Act II of the coming Broadway mega-musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.” Bono and the Edge of U2 wrote “Boy” and a dozen more songs for the show, their first Broadway musical, which has suffered production delays because of financial problems but is expected to begin performances in New York this fall. Reeve Carney, the singer-frontman of the band that bears his name, is set to play Peter Parker and Spider-Man on Broadway, though he did not act in character while performing “Boy” at a luncheon honoring the musical’s director, Julie Taymor. In the musical, Peter Parker sings the number after his love interest, Mary Jane, has been abducted and his super-powers are gone. Before the luncheon, Ms. Taymor described the financial stakes of the musical as extraordinarily high, saying “Spider-Man” would need to be a huge audience hit on par with her Disney musical “The Lion King” to cover its significant costs and ultimately turn a profit. But she sounded a note of confidence, adding: “I’m not doing this for a small audience. I’m doing it for a world audience.”

headline: Education Secretary Steps Into a Minefield in Brooklyn
text: It was meant to be a cheerful visit to put the spotlight on successful teachers and charter schools — an event that more-cynical observers tend to call a dog and pony show.

headline: Charlie Sheen Returning to ‘Two and a Half Men’
text: Charlie Sheen, below, said he would remain with his long-running sitcom, “Two and a Half Men,” The Hollywood Reporter said. In a statement, Mr. Sheen said, “To put a fitting end on the two and one-half months of whirlwind speculation, I’m looking forward to returning to my CBS home on Monday nights.” Mr. Sheen, whose contract expired last month, set off a wave of speculation about his status with the show by stating that he was prepared to walk away from it. The comedy continues to perform strongly in its seventh season, drawing nearly 15 million viewers an episode, and there was speculation that Mr. Sheen’s willingness to leave the show was a renegotiation ploy. The Hollywood Reporter said Mr. Sheen had re-signed for two more seasons. A jury trial for Mr. Sheen is scheduled to begin on July 21 in Aspen, Colo., where he will face domestic violence charges stemming from an altercation with his wife, Brooke Mueller.

headline: Colleague Says Blumenthal Claims Grew in Time
text: Former Representative Christopher Shays of Connecticut found it puzzling: over time, his friend Attorney General Richard Blumenthal kept revising how he talked about his military service during the Vietnam War. At first, in the 1980s, he was humble. He played it down, Mr. Shays recalled, characterizing it as humdrum desk work.

headline: Elvis Costello Cancels Concerts in Israel
text: Elvis Costello has canceled two concerts he was planning to perform in Israel this summer, citing the complexities of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Costello was scheduled to appear at the Caesarea Amphitheater on June 30 and July 1. But in a statement on his official Web site, he wrote, “It is after considerable contemplation that I have lately arrived at the decision that I must withdraw from the two performances.” Mr. Costello went on to write that “there are occasions when merely having your name added to a concert schedule may be interpreted as a political act that resonates more than anything that might be sung,” and he added, “I must believe that the audience for the coming concerts would have contained many people who question the policies of their government on settlement and deplore conditions that visit intimidation, humiliation or much worse on Palestinian civilians in the name of national security.” Mr. Costello, above right, also said that he was “keenly aware of the sensitivity of these themes in the wake of so many despicable acts of violence perpetrated in the name of liberation.”

headline: Clients Worried About Goldman’s Dueling Goals
text: “Questions have been raised that go to the heart of this institution’s most fundamental value: how we treat our clients.” — Lloyd C. Blankfein, Goldman Sachs’s C.E.O., at the firm’s annual meeting in May

headline: Guns N’ Roses Gets Its Own ‘Vook’
text: A video-enhanced digital book chronicling the exploits of the rock band Guns N’ Roses will be released on Wednesday by Vook, the multimedia company. The video-enhanced book, or “vook,” “Reckless Road,” will include the text of the book of the same title by Marc Canter, the band’s historian, accompanied by videos, pictures and behind-the-scenes interviews with “strippers, roadies, ex-bandmates and rock insiders,” Vook announced on Tuesday. Vook has joined with publishers and authors to make enhanced editions of electronic books, including a short story by Anne Rice and a children’s book by Rudyard Kipling, that can be read on iPhones, iPads and other digital devices.

headline: A New Chance in New Orleans
text: The Justice Department described the New Orleans Police Department earlier this year as one of the nation’s worst. There is no doubt about that. The city suffers from one of the country’s highest rates of violent crime and unsolved murders. Its police force is currently the subject of at least eight federal investigations into accusations of brutality and unjustified killings of citizens at the hands of armed officers.

headline: ‘Dancing’ Scores Again
text: The final four couples on “Dancing With the Stars” competed on Monday night as that ABC reality show drew 18.8 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC was No. 1 for the evening while CBS placed second.

headline: College Bound, DNA Swab in Hand
text: Instead of the usual required summer-reading book, this year’s incoming freshmen at the University of California, Berkeley, will get something quite different: a cotton swab on which they can, if they choose, send in a DNA sample.

headline: Early Census Is Found in a New Jersey University’s Files
text: Talk about being late with your census forms. Curators at Kean University in New Jersey recently found a population count of the United States from an “actual enumeration” conducted at least four years before the country’s first official census in 1790.

headline: Lottery Numbers
What You Get for ... $725,000
text: LIVINGSTON, MONT.

headline: Wizards Go From Chaos to the Top Draft Choice
text: SECAUCUS, N.J. — The machine that swirls the Ping-Pong balls does not have a conscience or sympathy, just a rush of air and a low hum. Occasionally, however, a little karma seeps out when the motor starts for the N.B.A. draft lottery.

headline: Obie Awards Presented
text: Annie Baker’s play “Circle Mirror Transformation,” a comic look at a group of strangers who come together in a creative drama class, was among the most celebrated productions at this year’s Obie Awards, which are presented annually by The Village Voice to honor Off Broadway theater. In a ceremony on Monday night the “Circle Mirror Transformation” cast (Reed Birney, Tracee Chimo, Peter Friedman, Deirdre O’Connell and Heidi Schreck) was given an award as an ensemble in the Obies performance category. Sam Gold, who directed the production for Playwrights Horizons, also won an Obie as director of “Circle Mirror Transformation” and “The Aliens,” a play by Ms. Baker that is being presented by Rattlestick Playwrights Theater. “The Aliens,” about a group of young men who gather outside a coffeehouse, and “Circle Mirror Transformation” shared the award for best new American play. Other performance awards were given to Dane DeHaan (“The Aliens”), Jonathan Hammond (“The Boys in the Band”), Marc Damon Johnson (“The Brother/Sister Plays”), Laurie Metcalf (“A Lie of the Mind”) and Juliet Rylance (“As You Like It”).

headline: Donovan Pushes Ahead, Looking Inside
text: PRINCETON, N.J.

headline: All the Single Ladies
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Leipheimer, 3-Time California Winner, Finds Familiar Rivals in His Way
text: SANTA CRUZ, Calif.— As expected, Levi Leipheimer, the man who came into the Tour of California as the overall favorite to win, made a move to take the lead Tuesday.

headline: Properties for $725,000
text: Properties in Livingston, Mont., Boonton Township, N.J. and St. Paul, Minn.

headline: Jackson Keeps Them Guessing and Laughing
text: LOS ANGELES — Phil Jackson moved the way one would expect someone with two artificial hips to move, ambling from side to side as he climbed several stairs to the platform where he addressed reporters Monday before the opening game of the Western Conference finals.

headline: Obama and the Oil Spill
text: President Obama’s handling of the gulf oil spill has been disappointing.

headline: The Battle Over Taxing Soda
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Thesis Is Window on Roots of Kagan’s Legal Creed
text: WASHINGTON — As a young graduate student, Elena Kagan wrote that it was “not necessarily wrong or invalid” for judges to “try to mold and steer the law” to achieve social ends, but warned that such rulings must be rooted in legal principles to be accepted by society and endure.

headline: Knuckleballer Is Rare to See and Harder to Handle
text: ATLANTA — In their almost 50 years of existence, the Mets have had more knuckleheads than knuckleballers, but the gap will be closed slightly Wednesday when R. A. Dickey throws his version of the pitch for the Mets against the Washington Nationals.

headline: A Simple Swab Can Make You a Lifesaver
text: The cure for someone else’s terrible illness could start with a swab rubbed in the cheek of a stranger. Here’s a Someone Else: Sophia Lopez, now 6 months old, of the Bronx. When she was 10 weeks old, she came down with a fever of 104. Her parents ran her to the emergency room at Mount Sinai Hospital and learned that she had a rare blood disease with a long biochemical name and the initials HLH. It is a catastrophe rolling downhill.

headline: With Elite Monmouth Meet, New Jersey Hopes to Make Money by Spending Money
text: OCEANPORT, N.J. — Horse racing has long been criticized for being unable to make meaningful changes and for clinging to unworkable formulas. So when the horsemen and management at Monmouth Park took a look at the future, they didn’t like what they saw and decided to do something different.

headline: This Time, Vazquez Slammed the Door
text: It was a sight that must have amused Red Sox fans from Cape Cod to Connecticut: in from the Yankee Stadium bullpen Monday night jogged Javier Vazquez, entrusted with keeping the Yankees’ deficit at two runs.

headline: Wide U.S. Failures Helped Airliner Plot, Panel Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate Intelligence Committee on Tuesday issued a sweeping indictment of a chain of failures at American intelligence agencies that permitted a Nigerian man with explosives sewn into his underwear to board a flight from Amsterdam to Detroit on Christmas Day.

headline: Grants Focus on Regional Issues
text: The Ford Foundation on Tuesday announced plans to spend $200 million over the next five years on programs aimed at better connecting cities and suburbs to create cohesive metropolitan areas. The foundation will support efforts to expand affordable housing, build and enhance public transportation systems, and extend the use of regional land banks to address the problems of abandoned urban neighborhoods. Additionally, Ford, which has long supported various community development efforts, will now direct any money it grants for urban revitalization toward building integrated urban-suburban regions. “Metropolitan areas that manage to interweave urban and suburban development, everything from transportation to arts and culture, attract more people and more investment,” Luis Ubinas, Ford’s president, said in an address to a conference of local, state and federal officials concerned about the redevelopment of cities that have relied heavily on the auto industry, which is now shrinking.

headline: Education Official Departing
text: Robert Shireman, the deputy under secretary of the United States Department of Education, is leaving Washington in July. Mr. Shireman, founder of the Institute for College Access and Success in California, put into effect much of that advocacy group’s agenda at the Department of Education — including the end of the bank-based student lending program, a change that redirected billions of dollars of bank subsidies into Pell Grants for low-income students. Mr. Shireman has been seen as such an important figure in the department’s effort to regulate for-profit higher education that the word of his departure, late Monday, caused stocks of the publicly traded higher education companies to soar.

headline: Canadian Leaders Fighting Global Bank Tax
text: OTTAWA — Cabinet ministers from Canada’s Conservative government fanned out across the world on Tuesday to lobby against proposals for a global tax to cover the cost of bank bailouts.

headline: Q&A With the Let’s Go Guides’ Executive Editor
text: All across the United States, college students are graduating and, in many cases, planning summer trips. Some will go abroad; some will road trip through the States; most, it seems safe to say, will be on a low budget. Which is where the Let’s Go guidebooks step in. For 50 years, the series has been aimed at  college students setting off to see the world, whether for a semester, a summer or the indefinite future. What’s more, the books — more than 50 guides covering six continents — are written and edited by the people who understand college students best: other college students.

headline: Delaware: Biden’s Son Leaves Hospital
text: Joseph R. Biden III, the Delaware attorney general and a son of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., was discharged from a Philadelphia hospital on Tuesday after treatment since May 11 for what his doctor said was a minor stroke. The state’s Department of Justice issued a statement quoting Dr. Robert Rosenwasser of Jefferson Hospital for Neuroscience as saying that tests showed Mr. Biden’s “neurological status perfect in all areas, including motor skills, language function and cognitive assessment.”

headline: For Children, a Social Network With Training Wheels
text: Mandeep Singh Dhillon’s son, Zoraver, learned how to take pictures of himself with his father’s computer when he was 4 years old, and he immediately wanted to share the results with relatives online. Mr. Dhillon liked the idea of his son developing skills at an early age that he would use for a lifetime, but was also hesitant to let Zoraver loose on the open Internet. He began working on an alternative.

headline: Drumming for Fela
text: By now, every theatergoer on Broadway has heard of the Nigerian musician Fela Anikulapo-Kuti. Jojo Kuo, 50, an Afropop drummer from Cameroon, played with Fela — twice. He shared his recollections with Ozier Muhammad for the seventh installment of “Sounds From Uncommon Spaces.” His remarks have been condensed and edited for brevity and clarity.

headline: Phys Ed: Do Our Genes Influence Our Desire to Exercise?
text: Is the urge to exercise bred in our bones? That’s the intriguing question that European researchers recently set out to examine by looking at the activity habits of 37,051 sets of twins. Twins are popular with geneticists, because they provide a neat statistical model for determining whether a behavior is influenced by genetics or exclusively by environment. Identical twins share 100 percent of their genome, fraternal twins share 50 percent. All twin pairs, if raised together, share approximately the same early environment. So if a behavior is more common between identical twins than between fraternal twins, it is presumably being directed to some degree by genes.

headline: Paul Vows to Remain True to the Tea Party
text: BOWLING GREEN, Ky. — Rand Paul arrived at his victory party on Tuesday night to the booming lyrics of the Rush song he often quoted on the campaign trail: “Glittering prizes and endless compromises/shatter the illusion of integrity.”

headline: German Short-Selling Ban Sows Confusion
text: The short-selling ban just announced by Germany misses the point. The country’s plan to stop naked shorting of some financial stocks and European government bonds as well as related credit-default swaps, starting Wednesday, may score political points. But it sows confusion, and will hardly help tackle the causes of Europe’s financial woes.

headline: Specter Defeat Signals a Wave Against Incumbents

headline: Battlefield And Church Among Threatened Sites
text: The battlefield where Robert E. Lee and Ulysses S. Grant faced off for the first time in the Civil War is among the 11 most endangered historic places in the country, the National Trust for Historic Preservation is to announce on Wednesday. Wal-Mart plans to build a 240,000-square-foot store within the historic boundaries of the Wilderness Battlefield and adjacent to the Fredericksburg and Spotsylvania National Military Park, which protects only a portion of the battlefield. The 51-acre Wal-Mart development would include a supercenter store and other chain retail stores. “We know from experience this will draw other sprawl,” the trust’s president, Richard Moe, said in a telephone interview. “It’s total saturation at the expense of history.” Mr. Moe is to announce the 2010 list at the Metropolitan A.M.E. Church in Washington, above — the national cathedral of African Methodism and a landmark. The Wilderness site is famous for two days of bitter fighting in May 1864 that left nearly 30,000 casualties — dead, wounded or missing. Other sites on this year’s roster are Hinchliffe Stadium, in Paterson, N.J., one of the last remaining Negro League ballparks; the Merritt Parkway in Connecticut, known for its decorative bridges and natural landscaping; and the Metropolitan A.M.E. Church in Washington, which held the funerals of Frederick Douglass in 1895 and Rosa Parks a century later.

headline: City Tells Carriage-Horse Stable It’s Time to Close

headline: Justin Bieber Nabs a BET Nomination
text: His swagger coach  deserves a bonus. Justin Bieber, the 16-year-old Canadian singer, has been nominated for a BET award. The teen pop star and hair-spiration, will compete for a best new artist prize with Wale, a rapper from Washington, and Young Money, the rapper Drake’s group, among others. The awards, from the Black Entertainment Television cable channel, usually honor African-American artists and performers like Jay-Z, Beyoncé and Alicia Keys, who lead the nominations this year. But Stephen Hill, BET’s President of Music Programing and Specials, said he considered Mr. Bieber a crossover artist, according to Reuters.

headline: Authorities Say Passenger Voices Were Recorded in Cockpit of Doomed Polish Plane
text: MOSCOW — Aviation authorities offered new details of the plane crash that killed Poland’s president and dozens of other top officials last month, including the revelation that two or more passengers were in the cockpit shortly before the pilots tried to land the aircraft in dense fog.

headline: Academies (Again) Seek Climate Action
text: The National Academies, fulfilling a congressional request, have issued a trio of invaluable reports affirming the scientific case for a growing and largely harmful human influence on climate; proposing a path and strategies for curbing American emissions of heat-trapping gases; and urging the country to work to cut risks attending life with no new “normal” climate patterns or coastlines.

headline: What We’re Reading: A New Flash, and Less Money
text: On Tuesday, the tech editors and reporters of The New York Times read about the new version of Flash and about how Apple’s chief executive gave up a chance to make $10 billion more.

headline: Hangzhou Heats Up
text: WHY IT’S HOT The Chinese city’s willow-fringed West Lake and terraced tea plantations have long inspired painters, poets and travelers. New hotels and the fall debut of a high-speed train from Shanghai (travel time: 38 minutes) are putting Hangzhou on travelers’ must-see lists.

headline: ‘Lost’ Watch: Ben the Avenger
text: This post contains spoilers.

headline: Fallon: ‘Renewing His Walk’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: The Coast Guard is now saying that 20 of these things called tar balls have been found off the Florida Keys. They’re not sure if the tar balls are from the Gulf Coast spill. Seriously? It’s like finding a giant clock necklace and not being sure it’s from Flavor Flav.

headline: National Research Council Calls for Climate Action
text: In its most comprehensive study so far, the nation’s leading scientific body declared on Wednesday that climate change was a reality and was driven mostly by human activity, chiefly the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation.

headline: Letterman: ‘Big Globs of Tar’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Have you been following the big oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico? Or as we call it now, the Dead Sea.

headline: Leno: ‘He May Sue Arizona’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: The Lakers trounced the Phoenix Suns last night, 128-107. Phoenix was so bad, today the Arizona Legislature voted to deport them.

headline: Mortgage Data Leaves Bankers Uncertain of Trend
text: Any way you look at it, extraordinary numbers of people are having trouble paying their mortgage. What is less clear is the extent to which the problem is getting worse, better or is simply holding its own.

headline: Wednesday Reading: The Big Business of Staged Accidents
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Does Exercise Make Raynaud’s Worse?
text: Can typing on a keyboard make coldness in the fingers feel worse? How about biking or vigorous exercise? Those are among the questions posed by readers about Raynaud’s phenomenon, the mysterious ailment that causes painful feelings of coldness in the fingers and toes. Here, Dr. Fredrick Wigley of Johns Hopkins Medical School explores the links between exercise and Raynaud’s. For more information, see Dr. Wigley’s earlier responses in “How Serious Is Raynaud’s Phenomenon?” and “Ask the Expert: Raynaud’s Phenomenon,” as well as The Times Health Guide: Raynaud’s.

headline: BMW’s Hybrid Future May Include 3 Series
text: BMW was initially slow to build hybrid cars, but now it is turning just about everything into a hybrid. In a speech to shareholders on Tuesday in Munich, Norbert Reithofer, chairman of the BMW AG board of management, not only confirmed the rumored production version of the 5 Series ActiveHybrid concept, but also said a 3 Series hybrid is likely coming, too.

headline: Upfronts: Conan O’Brien Mixes Jokes and Sentiment at TBS Event
text: Exactly one year ago – on May 19, 2009 – Conan O’Brien was on stage in New York promoting his much-anticipated new late-night talk show. He did the exact same thing Wednesday morning, but this time for TBS, not NBC.

headline: Lingering Questions Over Deception at Harvard
text: The case of Adam Wheeler, the Delaware man accused by Massachusetts authorities of fabricating much of the transfer application that earned him acceptance to Harvard in 2007, is sure to reverberate through admissions and guidance offices over the next few weeks and months.

headline: On Fear
text: Before leaving for a year in Afghanistan, soldiers from the First Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment of the 10th Mountain Division from Fort Drum, N.Y., reflected on their fears about deploying.

headline: Kagan Confirmation Hearings Start June 28
text: Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, the Democratic chairman of the Judiciary Committee, announced this morning that he has scheduled the confirmation hearings for Elena Kagan, the Supreme Court nominee, to begin on June 28.

headline: Bids Total $11 Billion for Wireless Spectrum in India
text: NEW DELHI — Further ratcheting up the stakes in the fast-growing and intensely competitive Indian wireless market, telecom companies bid nearly $11 billion for spectrum designated for high-speed data services, the government said on Wednesday.

headline: On Sean Bell’s Birthday, a Street Gets His Name
text: On a dreary and rainy evening Tuesday, Alvertis Alve-Alexander put on face paint and dressed as a clown, bringing color to a street blackened with the blood of Sean Bell.

headline: Fort Drum Soldiers Reflect on Deployment
text: The New York Times invites members of the military who are serving, or have served, in Afghanistan to help us document the daily life of this war in photographs, video and writing. Take us on a tour of the forward operating base, introduce us to your friends, describe the hardships and rewards of deployment and the humor that helps you pass the time.

headline: McConnell Blasts Financial Bill as ‘Takeover’
text: Whatever Congressional Democrats and President Obama do, according to the Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, it must be a “government takeover.”

headline: Caption Contest | What Are They Saying?
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had Jay-Z over for breakfast at Gracie Mansion this morning. Also at the table were the developer Bruce C. Ratner and the Russian oligarch Mikhail D. Prokhorov. Presumably the main topic of conversation was Atlantic Yards and/or the Nets. But who knows? Perhaps you have an idea. Put yourself in an empire-building state of mind and let us know in the comments box below. And, please — hard as this may be to believe — no profanity.

headline: Shares Fall as Germany Moves to Restrict Trades

text: IS nothing sacred? Once, this neo-Gothic landmark in Chelsea was the Church of the Holy Communion, with Gilded Age titans like Cornelius Vanderbilt among its high Episcopal parishioners.

headline: A Program Guide for the Web, Designed for TVs
text: Trying to navigate Web video using a computer that is hooked up to a television can feel a little like taking a driving test. You are forced to squint and strain to see each video thumbnail and link.

headline: Nvidia Finds a Friend in I.B.M.
text: Nvidia opened the technology industry’s standard procedure playbook, turned to the section on roiling Intel and followed the instructions by signing up I.B.M. as a partner.

headline: Let the Polarization Begin
text: David Brooks: Gail, I’m trying to figure out what Washington is going to look like in one year. The combined message that has been sent over the past two weeks is that there is entirely too much bipartisan cooperation going on in Washington and voters want to see an end to it.

headline: A Fresh Menu of Climate and Energy Priorities
text: I sent a host of climate and energy specialists my post on the “America’s Climate Choices” reports from the National Academies and the first response comes from Mike Hulme, a professor of climate studies at the University of East Anglia and author of “Why We Disagree About Climate Change” and the recent “Hartwell Paper” on climate policy. He proposes a different way to break down the agenda:

headline: Play Canceled After Wiesel Objects
text: A Jewish theater in Washington, Theater J, has canceled a play that included a character based on the author Elie Wiesel after Mr. Wiesel objected, The Washington Post reported. The play, “Imagining Madoff,” by Deb Margolin, included a fictional meeting between Bernard L. Madoff and Mr. Wiesel, the Holocaust survivor and writer, who lost several million dollars of his personal wealth, as well as all of the assets of his foundation, in Mr. Madoff’s huge Ponzi scheme.

headline: Better Acting Through Chemistry
text: DENZEL WASHINGTON and Viola Davis were little more than professional acquaintances when they began rehearsing in March to play husband and wife in the Broadway revival of August Wilson’s Pulitzer Prize-winning drama “Fences.” They had worked together briefly on the 2002 film “Antwone Fisher,” Mr. Washington’s directorial debut, but there had been no bonding. “Polite and formal” was how Ms. Davis described their interaction back then.

text: Collective Hardware, a five-story arts and event space on the Bowery, may be closing because of unpaid rent.

text: Adobe, the software company, showcased a new HTML5 addition to its Creative Suite software on Wednesday at the Google I/O developer conference.

text: THERE are moments in the new musical “The Burnt Part Boys,” opening Tuesday at Playwrights Horizons, that mirror recent events with haunting verisimilitude.

text: Organized labor says it plans to go all-out to defeat Blanche Lincoln, the Democratic senator from Arkansas, in a June 8 runoff election against Lt. Gov. Bill Halter.

text: The euro may still be dropping, but thus far, flights to Europe have been expensive enough to keep travelers looking elsewhere.

text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School. He also serves on the board of the New York Racing Association.

text: Few political spectacles are as scripted as bill-signing ceremonies: the Oscar-length thank-you speeches from politicians, the final airing of grievances from the public, the mayor’s inevitable reach for a stack of pens.

R.S.V.P. for one of the remaining nine in, say, Washington (May 23) or Atlanta (June 6). Dresses are hand cut, and the fabric remnants are used to make veils and silk flowers for your updo.

headline: Teachers Facing Weakest Market in Years
text: PELHAM, N.Y. — In the month since Pelham Memorial High School in Westchester County advertised seven teaching jobs, it has been flooded with 3,010 applications from candidates as far away as California. The Port Washington District on Long Island is sorting through 3,620 applications for eight positions — the largest pool the superintendent has seen in his 41-year career.
