text: If Wall Street denizens thought they could escape the specter of Justice Department inquiries by decamping to the Hamptons, it appears they’re wrong.

headline: An Artistic Director Who’s All Business
text: IN the fall of 2005 the venerable Women’s Project theater company faced a severe financial crisis. The board reached outside the nonprofit world, choosing instead a leader with years of experience in commercial theater management: Julie Crosby.

headline: Parade Names Maggie Murphy as Editor
text: Parade magazine, which has been without an editor for several months, today named the Time Inc. veteran Maggie Murphy as editor.

headline: I Hope I Feel Better Tomorrow
text: Where would you be if you felt like this: feverish, nauseous, intermittent stomach cramps, low energy and cranky? I’m at my desk, just like every other day.

headline: Networks and Anchors to Join Again to Fight Cancer
text: ABC, CBS and NBC have agreed to broadcast a cancer research fund-raiser in September to be hosted by the evening news anchors at each network. The event, “Stand Up To Cancer,” is a sequel; the first such telethon took place in September 2008 and helped to raise more than $100 million, according to the organizers at the nonprofit Entertainment Industry Foundation.

headline: Jill Abramson Temporarily Steps Aside as Managing Editor to Focus on Digital Side
text: In an unusual and temporary management shuffle, Jill Abramson, the managing editor for news at The New York Times, will step aside for six months to focus on digital operations and strategy.

headline: Women, Work and the Supreme Court
text: Periodically I write something that gets taken in a way that is a complete surprise to me. That’s what is happening with the essay, posted below, looking at the question of why successful women are less likely to be mothers.

headline: Rain Followed by 4-Hour-9-Minute Game Delay
text: Fans have come to expect the Yankees and the Red Sox to play time-consuming games, and Tuesday night’s game did not disappoint.

headline: President of Intrepid Museum Quits
text: Bill White, the longtime president of the Intrepid Sea Air and Space Museum, resigned abruptly Wednesday morning for reasons that were not immediately clear.

headline:
A 13-Year-Old Takes 
On Everest, and Sets Off a Debate
text: For many 13-year-old boys, the journey from childhood to manhood begins with their first job, shaving feathery whiskers or discovering girls. But for Jordan Romero, it is unfolding in an attempt to become the youngest person to reach the summit of Mount Everest. On Saturday he departed base camp with his father, Paul Romero, and Paul’s companion and professional adventure racing teammate, Karen Lundgren.

headline: Upfronts: ‘Community’ Creator Fires Back at ‘Big Bang Theory’ Move to Thursday Night
text: Behold one of the benefits of Twitter: the producers of television shows can now react immediately and publicly to every twist and turn of the television season.

headline: Coffee Pedalers in McCarren Park
text: Kickstand, a collapsible coffee stall that’s wheeled around on a pair of salvaged bikes, made its public debut last Saturday in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, at the Market in McCarren, the outdoor arm of Artists and Fleas. The brainchild of Aaron Davis and Peter Castelein, both employees of Gimme! Coffee, and Neal Olson, formerly of Gimme! Coffee, Kickstand brings fresh, hand-crafted coffee to the grassy splendor of a public park. Weather permitting.

headline: Worst Week for Album Sales Since 1991
text: Combine the downward trend of album sales with a week of no major releases and what do you get? The fewest number of total album sales, 5.3 million, in a single week since Nielsen SoundScan started its tracking in 1991. Topping this week’s Billboard chart is Justin Bieber’s “My World 2.0” (Island), its fourth time in the spot, with sales of just over 60,000, barely escaping the specter of being the lowest selling No. 1 album in SoundScan’s history. (The “Dreamgirls” soundtrack sold about 300 fewer copies in January 2007.) Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville), the year’s most consistent seller, stayed at No. 2 for the fourth straight week, moving 54,000 copies.

headline: Goldman’s Responses on Relations With Clients
text: As The New York Times conducted reporting for an article examining how Goldman Sachs handles conflicts with its clients, the newspaper submitted a list of questions to Goldman on May 13-14, along with a follow-up on May 18. The inquiries dealt with Goldman’s philosophy and practices in serving its clients’ interests. Here are the questions and the responses received from Lucas van Praag, a Goldman spokesman.

headline: Geek Chic | Power Ranger
text: Considering how long stylish travelers have had to cart around less-than-beautiful electrical doohickeys, it’s a wonder that fashion hasn’t come to the rescue sooner. The Yves Saint Laurent travel adapter ($450) is a one-piece electrical dual-voltage plug adapter that connects gadget to outlet in any combination in more than 150 countries (Japanese cellphone to American outlet, German shaver to Australian socket). The circular device swivels to each region’s plug, and a leather bag available in fuchsia, black and violet provides the panache.

headline: ‘Exercise Caution,’ the Drilling Permit Said
text: The permit issued to BP by the Minerals Management Service for the well that blew out on April 20 in the Gulf of Mexico carried a notation: “Exercise caution while drilling due to indications of shallow gas and possible water flow.’’

headline: British Coalition Offers Reform Plan
text: LONDON — Defying those who said it might be paralyzed by internal divisions, Britain’s new coalition government of Conservatives and Liberal Democrats on Wednesday unveiled the most ambitious plan in decades for upending the highly centralized and often intrusive way the country is governed.

headline: Last Night’s Elections
text: It wasn’t a good night for Republicans. Yes, the G.O.P. can theoretically retake the House of Representatives without winning races like Pennsylvania’s 12th district (which has been solidly Democratic for years, after all). But at the very least Mark Critz’s relatively easy victory in yesterday’s special election should throw some cold water on the more optimistic conservative visions for how this November will shake out. Yes, Pat Toomey polls almost as well against the victorious Joe Sestak as he did against against Arlen Specter. But given the mood in the country these days, I bet that Toomey would have preferred to campaign against a turncoat five-term incumbent this autumn, rather than a fresh-faced (by political standards) former rear admiral. And yes, Rand Paul will probably be the next United States senator from Kentucky — but he’s clearly less of a shoo-in for the G.O.P. than Trey Grayson likely would have been, had matters been arranged differently.

headline: Google Pitches a Web-Centric Future
text: Google delivered its vision of a Web-centric future on Wednesday in front of around 5,000 software developers at its annual Google I/O conference.

headline: Democrats See Hope for Fall in Victory in House Race
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional Democrats on Wednesday seized on their special election victory in a Pennsylvania House district and other primary results as evidence that they can stem Republican political momentum, as both parties sifted through Tuesday night’s returns for lessons to learn and mistakes to avoid heading to November.

headline: Obama Turns His Back On the Press
text: At a ceremony to sign a bill promoting press freedom around the world on Monday, President Obama refused to take questions from reporters. “I’m not doing a press conference today,” he told Chip Reid of CBS News, “but we’ll be seeing you guys during the course of the week.”

headline: Two New Species of Sea Slugs, a Great Start
text: Sunday evening, May 16 — The first night dive.

headline: Threatened Historical Sites Include Battlefield
text: The battlefield where Robert E. Lee and Ulysses S. Grant faced off for the first time in the Civil War is among the 11 most endangered historic places in the country, the National Trust for Historic Preservation is to announce on Wednesday. Wal-Mart plans to build a 240,000-square-foot store within the historic boundaries of the Wilderness Battlefield and adjacent to the Fredericksburg and Spotsylvania National Military Park, which protects only a portion of the battlefield. The 51-acre Wal-Mart development would include a supercenter store and other chain retail stores. “We know from experience this will draw other sprawl,” the trust’s president, Richard Moe, said in a telephone interview. “It’s total saturation at the expense of history.” Mr. Moe is to announce the 2010 list at the Metropolitan A.M.E. Church in Washington, above — the national cathedral of African Methodism and a landmark. The Wilderness site is famous for two days of bitter fighting in May 1864 that left nearly 30,000 casualties — dead, wounded or missing. Other sites on this year’s roster are Hinchliffe Stadium, in Paterson, N.J., one of the last remaining Negro League ballparks; the Merritt Parkway in Connecticut, known for its decorative bridges and natural landscaping; and the Metropolitan A.M.E. Church in Washington, which held the funerals of Frederick Douglass in 1895 and Rosa Parks a century later.

headline: Feeling Deflated
text: I’m baaack, with grades in. So can we talk about deflation again?

headline: Visual Learning x 2: ‘The Metal Children’
text: The poster art for Adam Rapp‘s new play “The Metal Children,” which opens tonight at the Vineyard Theater, shows one of its stars, a sad-looking Billy Crudup, with gold paint smeared across his face. (More on that later.)

headline: Don’t Bring Home the Bacon
text: A new Harvard study that found no increased risk of heart disease among meat eaters is generating a lot of buzz for red meat. “A Guilt-Free Hamburger,” reads one headline. “Order the Steak,” begins another.

headline: Lawsuit Challenges Stop-and-Frisk Database
text: To the Police Department, its database of stop-and-frisk interactions is an invaluable tool, providing quick access to data that can solve crimes and save lives.

headline: G.M. OnStar Hooks Up With Android
text: Ford is doing it. Mercedes-Benz is doing it. Now General Motors is going to be doing it — using smartphones to add new features to its cars.

headline: Tennis Player Banned for Having Growth Hormone
text: The tennis player Wayne Odesnik has been banned from competing for two years after the International Tennis Federation announced Wednesday that he had committed an anti-doping violation for possessing human growth hormone.

headline: Upfronts: CBS Move Takes Warner Brothers By Surprise
text: The fall CBS schedule, announced Wednesday, took many people by surprise — including Peter Roth, the president of Warner Brothers, which is the second biggest supplier of programs to CBS and other networks.

headline: Gregory Krum | Practicing Photographer
text: Photographic evidence — say, the kind of indefatigable proof that one has, in fact, visited the Great Wall of China — typically suffices as testament to having actually been there and done that. The photographer Gregory Krum (who is also the director of retail for the shop at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum) has been to the base of the Matterhorn and has seen the tombstones erected there in a climbers’ cemetery. The photos he took are on display as part of his first solo exhibition, “…Practice…,” at Jen Bekman Gallery in SoHo. These images, along with shots of flowers, dust, still-lifes and interiors also seek to illuminate something inherently more tenuous: devotion. “The idea behind the show is those things that become true solely by belief,” he says.

headline: Novell Set to Consider Takeover Bids From Suitors
text: Novell is back in the takeover news. About two months after the business software maker said it would consider an outright sale of itself, Novell is planning to receive offers from potential bidders.

headline: Lincoln Center to Open More Spaces to the Public on Friday
text: The construction maze around Lincoln Center will become a lot more navigable on Friday, when several areas will be opened to the public. Visitors can once again use the Grand Stair, the primary entry from Columbus Avenue, which will now have informational LED displays; the new Benenson Grove, which allows access from 62nd Street; and the Jaffe Drive/Toll Porte-cochère, a fancy name for a driveway. The new spaces are part of Lincoln Center’s $1.2 billion renovation, which began in 2006 and is scheduled to be completed in the next two years, according to center officials.

headline: Obama and Calderón Decry Ariz. Immigration Law
text: WASHINGTON — At the White House on Wednesday, President Obama and the visiting Mexican president, Felipe Calderón, discussed the finer points of border policy. At a nearby school, their wives were unexpectedly confronted with the human face of illegal immigration.

headline: Federal Reserve Ponders a Plan for Asset Sales
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve indicated that it would wait until after it started raising interest rates before selling the huge store of assets that it acquired in response to the financial crisis. The goal would be to gradually complete the sales about five years after they begin.

headline: Freshkills Inspires 17-Syllable Musings
text: How to rebrand a former world-class trash dump with fantastically sylvan ambitions? A haiku contest can’t hurt. For the second year, the Park Department asked citizen poets to pen 17-syllable odes to Freshkills Park, 2,200 big-sky acres of rolling hills in west-central Staten Island created by decades of urban dross. The winners have been announced. Here they are.

headline: Democrats Caucusing on Regulation Bill
text: Senate Democrats are holding a special caucus meeting to discuss efforts to finish the big financial regulation bill.

headline: Florida Worries About Effect on Tourism
text: MIAMI — Off Florida’s Gulf Coast, the seas are calm and the king mackerel are running. Capt. Joe Meadows’s telephone should be ringing with bookings for his 42-foot sport-fishing boat for the summer season. Instead, the calls are from reservation holders wondering if they should cancel.

headline: New Accusations of War Crimes in Sri Lanka
text: One year after Sri Lanka’s president, Mahinda Rajapaksa, declared victory and hailed his military for ending a decades-long separatist rebellion by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, a British news organization aired new accusations that the country’s soldiers committed war crimes during the war’s final months.

headline: Theater Talkback: Scenes With Streams (and Squirts)
text: The subject today is bodily fluids, and their use and abuse in the theater. Blood, sweat and tears have of course been staples of world drama for centuries. What would “Macbeth” be without a few buckets of stage blood? Or Ophelia without tears, be they real or glycerine? As for sweat, well, you try standing under a ceiling of thousand-watt bulbs in full costume and keeping your powder dry. (I have been dripped upon by heavily perspiring actors in intimate environmental productions.) Add to this trio of effluvia projectile spitting, which often accompanies fierce diction in emotional scenes and can be a hazard for front-row audience members.

headline: The David Wright Mystery, Continued
text: So how is it that David Wright now leads the major leagues with 55 strikeouts? He whiffed three more times in Tuesday night’s loss to Atlanta, the last one coming with the go-ahead run on third base in the top of the ninth and one out.

headline: Even the Dalai Lama Has a Point Man
text: IMAGINE a boarding-school-educated young man, fluent in several languages and gifted with a camera, telling his beloved grandmother that he was becoming a Tibetan Buddhist monk.

headline: A Quick Dinner With Garlic Chives
text: From my standpoint, New York City’s farmers’ markets are in a holding pattern, even though there’s plenty to eat on the growers’ stands. I’ve had the early thrill of ramps, asparagus and spring onions of various colors, and now I’m waiting for the first peas — which, for me, are the big event on the cooking calendar. Although my wife, Jackie, and I buy, cook and eat leafy greens with pleasure, we get no similar kick from them, even the first ones of the season.

headline: Watch Out for a Credit Card Act Loophole
text: Before many provisions in the Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility and Disclosure Act took effect earlier this year, credit card companies routinely applied customers’ payments first to balances with the lowest interest rates.

headline: Rebels Hope New Austerity Rekindles Spirit of Greece’s Activist Heart
text: ATHENS — On a recent summer night, Pyrros Falekas took a break from his restaurant job to stop by Parko Navarinou, near the heart of the lively middle-class Athens neighborhood of Exarcheia, a breeding ground for generations of student activists, anarchists and other rebel souls.

headline: Democrats Caucusing on Financial Bill
text: From David M. Herszenhorn at The Caucus:

headline: Jokes Aside, Prokhorov Talks of Reviving Nets
text: In a broad, brightly lit Manhattan ballroom, the new owner of the N.B.A.’s worst team made an entrance befitting a Hollywood star. Lights flashed, shutters snapped in rapid-fire fashion and cameras rolled.

headline: In the Field: Developing Questions for Scientists at Work
text: Overview | How are scientific discoveries, such as the discovery of a new species, made? Have you ever wondered about the adventures of scientists working “in the field”? In this lesson, students explore their associations with the phrase “Scientist at Work,” and then read the digital field notes of researchers in the field on The New York Times’s new blog by the same name. Students develop questions for featured scientists by drawing on information in the text as well as their personal experiences and connections to the world around them. Finally, students apply what they learn about field research to other scientific topics of interest or their own investigations.

headline: A Bit of Borscht From Nets’ New Owner
text: The list of famous Russian-born comedians might start and end with Yakov Smirnoff. But after his first news conference as the majority owner of the New Jersey Nets, people might start calling Mikhail D. Prokhorov “Shecky.”

headline: Warning: Reading Can Be Hazardous to Your Health
text: Who says the novel is doornail-dead, irrelevant, a moribund art form incapable of holding the attention of the chronically distracted in the digital age?

headline: More ‘Lost’ Answers
text: Tuesday night’s episode of “Lost” put the pieces in place for Sunday’s finale, seemingly setting up a final clash between several of the series’s core characters.

headline: In Ambush, a Glimpse of a Long Afghan Summer
text: BALUCH, Afghanistan — Minutes after surviving the first ambush, Cpl. John M. Boone, a Marine sniper, called over his radio. “We’ve got a civilian here who got shot in his gut,” he said.

headline: Knicks’ Chandler Charged With Drug Possession
text: Wilson Chandler of the Knicks was charged with criminal possession of marijuana during a traffic stop in Queens on Tuesday night, according to law enforcement officials.

headline: An Oil Gusher Webcam
text: 11:50 p.m. | Updated  Representative Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts has convinced BP to start streaming live video from the seabed oil gusher, he announced on his House Web site tonight.

headline: Sad News Highlights Service to Country for Bradley
text: PRINCETON, N.J. – The United States World Cup training camp turned somber for Coach Bob Bradley on Wednesday, when he learned that a family friend had been killed a day earlier by a roadside bomb while serving in the military in Afghanistan.

headline: Fulton Stall Market Is Opening Soon for the Season
text: The Fulton Stall Market at South Street Seaport will open on May 30 for the second year. It will operate noon to 6 p.m. every Sunday and Wednesday through Oct. 3. Some new vendors include:

headline: Do Score’s Counselors Know the Score?
text: There are not a lot of places to go for small-business advice. One of the places most frequently mentioned on this blog and in other business venues is Score, an organization that is affiliated with the Small Business Administration. If you go to the Web site, you will find that Score is a nonprofit 503c organization that was started in 1964 and has 364 offices and about 12,400 volunteers who help small businesses succeed. Its slogan is “Counselors to America’s small business.” If you go through the Web site, you will find an impressive board of directors, a variety of ways to get advice and lots of success stories.

headline: Wisdom in the Palm of Your Hand
text: What’s the meaning of life? There’s an app for that.AskPhilosophers.org, a Web site that makes philosophers available to answer questions, is going mobile, creating a free downloadable app for mobile devices.

headline: Preakness Can’t Keep Derby Viewers
text: Lookin at Lucky’s Preakness Stakes victory on Saturday attracted an average of 8.4 million viewers on NBC, down 23 percent from the 10.9 million who watched the filly Rachel Alexandra’s win at Pimlico last year.

headline: And Then the Clothes Come Off
text: “DO I look like a Pomeranian?” Cary Curran, a k a Cherry Dazzle, asked on Sunday. Inverted over a velvet pouf in a backstage area of a party space on lower Fifth Avenue, Ms. Curran was grooming her peroxide hair into pert little ponytails.

headline: Answers About Free Events in New York’s Parks
text: Following is the first set of responses from David Rivel, the executive director of City Parks Foundation, a nonprofit group that organizes free arts, sports and education programs and activities in New York’s parks.

headline: IPad Apps: Tweaking the Keyboard
text: Typing documents on the iPad’s touch screen keyboard can be a chore. As I wrote in an article earlier this month, one solution is to pair up an Apple Bluetooth wireless keyboard with the iPad.

headline: On Patrol in Marja
text: Marines and Afghan soldiers have been taking fire regularly as they try to eliminate pockets of resistance around Marja, a town that was largely wrested from the Taliban earlier this year.

headline: Lincoln Center Finally Gets a Lawn
text: Do walk on the grass.

headline: This Grand Cherokee Is Presidential
text: “I really feel it was a bargain,” said John Reznikoff.

headline: Movie Time at the C.F.T.C. Draws Heated Debate
text: Hollywood clashed with Wall Street on Wednesday at a government hearing about the potential sale of futures contracts linked to box office receipts of major motion pictures.

headline: Booker Prize Awarded – for 1970
text: It’s a little late, but the best book of 1970 has finally won its Man Booker prize. “Troubles,” by J. G. Farrell, was anointed the winner of the “Lost Man Booker Prize,” a one-time-only award intended to honor the books that “missed out an opportunity to win the Booker Prize in 1970,” the Booker Prize Foundation announced on Wednesday.

headline: Developer May Proceed With Apthorp Conversion
text: After an extensive investigation into the renovation of the storied Apthorp apartment building on Manhattan’s Upper West Side, the New York attorney general has given the developer approval to move forward and start closing on luxury apartments there.

headline: ‘Old School’ Gregg Araki at Cannes
text: CANNES, France — A onetime enfant terrible and a central figure of the 1990s New Queer Cinema, Gregg Araki seemed to inaugurate a new phase of his career in 2004 with “Mysterious Skin,” a tender story about two young men haunted by a formative sexual trauma. He followed that film, which many critics considered his best and most mature, with the eccentric stoner comedy “Smiley Face” (2007), which has become an underground hit on DVD.

headline: Men in Tights | A Brief History
text: Sadly, for me at least, the new Robin Hood movie is bereft of tights. It’s got grit. It has a vibrant undertone of socioeconomic injustice. Russell Crowe and Cate Blanchett are great; praise the Lord and pass the Oscar campaign. But there are no tights in this Nottingham, alas. Despite being an unapologetic old school swashbuckler, Crowe recently apologized in The Chicago Tribune, “to everybody who wants tights.” They, he said, “never made sense to me…you’re a bloke, you live in the forest, and you wear tights?” Well, yeah, what’s the problem? Tights were developed precisely by blokes on horses in forests. (They are cousins of riding breeches.) What’s the worst that can happen? You pass a briar, a burr is buried and you get a run in your tights? Man up, Robin Hood, you live life on the run. Crowe should not have cowed from the challenge of tights but since he has, we’ve compiled some great moments of men in tights.

headline: Organic Feed? Birds Say No Thanks
text: Birds may prefer conventionally grown seed over organic seed, according to a new study in the Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture. Wild birds visiting more than 30 gardens across the north of England consciously chose to stick with conventional seed after eating both varieties, said Ailsa McKenzie, the study’s lead author and a research associate at the School of Biology at Newcastle University.

headline: Keeping It Simple, the Flyers Zip Along in the Playoffs
text: PHILADELPHIA — Pinning down Philadelphia Flyers defenseman Chris Pronger these days for his grizzled perspective seems to be as difficult as checking him into the boards. The 35-year-old Pronger, 6 feet 6 inches and 220 pounds, gets a kick out of dodging big-picture questions.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangkok and Elsewhere
text: A crackdown on antigovernment protesters begun by the Thai military on Wednesday degenerated into riots, firebombing attacks, looting and street battles after militants allied with the protest movement resisted the army’s onslaught with grenades and assault weapons.

headline: ‘When It’s Important, It’s Paper’
text: Never let it be said that the world of fine personal stationery is without its drama.

headline: Club for Growth Endorses in Nevada
text: The Club for Growth has endorsed Sharron Angle in Nevada’s Senate race, a move that could give the former state assemblywoman a boost in the Republican primary.

headline: Sea Lion Population at Pier 39 Stages Comeback
text: Hark: What’s that barking sound?

headline: Symantec Confirms $1.3 Billion Deal for VeriSign Unit
text: Symantec announced on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy VeriSign‘s authentication services business, which encrypts online payments, for $1.28 billion in cash.

headline: Pactiv’s Shares Climb as 2 More Bidders Are Seen
text: Shares of Pactiv, the maker of Hefty trash bags, rose as much as 7 percent on Wednesday after a report that two more companies are interested in buying it.

headline: Upfronts: CBS’s Moonves Sounds an Especially Upbeat Note
text: Virtually everyone in the TV industry is expecting this year’s upfront to draw millions of dollars more in advertising commitments than the one last year, which was beaten down by the recession.

headline: M.T.A. to End Relationship With Goldman Sachs
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to sever its relationship with Goldman Sachs, the transit agency’s longtime financial adviser, according to two individuals with knowledge of its decision.

headline: Photo Replay: May 19
text: A view of the day in sports, including soccer players on snowy mountains and dirt fields.

headline: Building a Network of Gay Entrepreneurs
text: Lots of entrepreneurs would like to pick Chip Conley’s brain. But when several dozen gathered in November to meet the founder of Joie de Vivre, a boutique hotel chain that he said had $220 million in revenue last year, their questions were not just about the nuts and bolts of running a company.

headline: Who Are They, Indeed
text: THE latest teen-fashion-focused store to set up shop on the block of 34th Street east of Macy’s, the one that is quickly becoming Manhattan’s version of the Mall at Short Hills, is called WHO.A.U. That’s text-ese for “who are you?” — which is surely what a lot of people must be thinking when they see a giant stuffed bear wearing patchwork madras shorts in the window.

headline: A Sneak Peek of 2011 Jeep Grand Cherokee
text: 8:06 a.m. | Updated

headline: Senate Fails to Advance Financial Reform Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday rejected an effort by Democratic leaders to complete work on a sweeping financial regulatory bill as two key Democratic holdouts said it still did not tighten rules on Wall Street enough.

headline: Handle With Care | The Campanas Get Creepy
text: If you’ve ever looked askance at a piece by the Brazilian designers Humberto and Fernando Campana and wondered what they were thinking —or what you’re supposed to be thinking — you’re not alone. Their new monograph, Campana Brothers: Complete Works (So Far), which is published by Rizzoli, may help explain the method behind what often seems like madness. The hefty book was published with three different covers, each of which is a different color and embellished with circular patterns that look hand stitched. “Our work is very texturized, so we wanted to bring an element of this to the book — to make it an object in itself, to make it feel handmade,” Humberto explained. He likes the black cover best because it “shows the lines, the color becomes much more alive.” His brother Fernando prefers the green.

headline: Democratic Holdouts Block Financial Bill
text: 5:42 p.m. | Updated The Senate on Wednesday rejected an effort by Democratic leaders to complete work on a sweeping financial regulatory bill as two key Democratic holdouts said it still did not sufficiently tighten rules on Wall Street, The New York Times’s David M. Herszenhorn reports from Washington.

headline: Letter: The Cathar Threat
text: To the Editor: The cover article, “The Besieged and the Beautiful”; (May 9), on the crusade against the Cathars, does not present the full story. A much more serious issue than religious fanaticism was involved. The Cathars’ Gnostic belief that the physical world was so evil that children should not be brought into it was a major threat to the prosperity and even the very survival of the secular governments. A depopulated Europe would have been at even greater risk at a time when every sword was needed to defend Christian countries against Islamic invaders.

headline: Another C.C. in the Yankees’ Future?
text: With the Tampa Bay Rays making their first appearance of the season at Yankee Stadium, it was only natural to wonder about the future of Carl Crawford, their star left fielder. Crawford has tormented the Yankees and the rest of baseball in his nine-year career, and he will be a free agent after the season.

headline: Letter: Scotland Seasons
text: To the Editor: Regarding “A Baedeker, 100 Years Later” (May 9): Married to Pat, a Scottish lass, for over 44 years, I’ve visited Scotland almost every year since 1966, including a few visits to Hamilton and Mallaig. To visit in January, as the author Simon Akam did, would be akin to riding around Manhattan on the upper deck of an open-top tour bus during a winter blizzard at midnight. No small wonder that “the Alexandra Hotel looked like a stern and gray matron.”

headline: Revisiting ‘Main St.,’ Rethinking the Myth
text: A LESSER-KNOWN version of the Rolling Stones’ “Loving Cup,” found on the bonus disc of the new reissue of the band’s 1972 album, “Exile on Main St.,” seems to me the best thing the Stones ever did.

headline: Beneath the Surface, More and More Layers
text: A really big man takes a very long bath in “Restoration,” the leisurely new comedy written by and starring Claudia Shear, and he’s not the only one who comes clean. In this girl-meets-statue story, Giulia (Ms. Shear), a lonely Brooklyn art conservator, lands the plum job of scrubbing down Michelangelo’s 17-foot statue of David at the Galleria dell’Accademia in Florence.

headline: Frugal Europe, on Foot
text: ONCE upon a time, a young man went for a walk. It was December 1933, and an 18-year-old Englishman named Patrick Leigh Fermor put on a pair of hobnail boots and a secondhand greatcoat, gathered up his rucksack and left London on a ship bound for Rotterdam, where he planned to travel 1,400 miles to Istanbul  on foot. He had virtually no money; at best, he’d arrive in, say, Munich to find his mother had sent him £5. But what he did have was an outgoing nature, a sense of adventure, an affinity for languages and a broad network of friends of friends.

headline: Inside 'Le Grand Macabre'
text: The director Douglas Fitch and the producer Edouard Getaz discuss the New York Philharmonic's staged production of "Le Grand Macabre."

headline: Memories of Gino
text: Ping went the in-box here at Diner’s Journal and there was a message from John Pizzarelli, the great bandleader, guitarist and entertainer. Mr. Pizzarelli’s letter was a lament at yesterday’s news that Gino, the East Side Italian restaurant, would close on May 29. We publish it below because the memories are sweet and worth ventilating.

headline: Finding a More Serene Vietnam
text: AS the sun’s last rays streaked the sky bubble-gum pink and tangerine, the residents of Con Dao Island were calling it a day, and the mile-and-a-half-long beachfront promenade that serves as this small Vietnamese island’s social hub was filling up as the heat of the day finally relented.

headline: Hotel Review: CitizenM Hotel in Amsterdam
text: THE BASICS

headline: The State Dinner’s Menu and Guest List
text: As President Obama and Michelle Obama host their second state dinner, this one for President Felipe Calderón of Mexico, they may be without the company of the gatecrashing Salahis, but they have a few other notables on the guest list.

headline: Videophiles | Earth Matter
text: Videophiles features a series of clips curated for The Moment by cutting-edge directors, artists and other creative types.

headline: ‘The Invisible Bridge’
text: Chapter 1: A Letter

headline: Saving Towns by Filling Rooms in Italy
text: ONE spring afternoon in the early 1980s Giancarlo Dall’Ara, an Italian hotel marketing consultant, was wandering the streets of a tiny village near Maranzanis, in Friuli, a rural mountainous region in the northeast corner of Italy.

headline: Saint Ann’s Chooses New Headmaster
text: Saint Ann’s School, the prestigious and progressive Brooklyn Heights school, has selected Vincent Tompkins, the deputy provost of Brown University, to be its new headmaster.

headline: Big Sensor, Tiny Camera, Nice Results
text: Centuries ago, a young boy in Japan was preparing for a long journey. “You will need much drinking water,” said his master. “Construct a barrel that will catch the rain.”

headline: An Arts Enclave in Cape Town
text: JUST southeast of downtown, Woodstock was one of few Cape Town communities to, in part, avoid South Africa’s Group Areas Act. That strict apartheid policy demarcated regions by race, forcefully removing residents; Woodstock, however, managed to maintain aspects of its multiethnic character. While it’s still shedding the coarse complexities of an impoverished past, Woodstock is evolving into the media hub of the country’s “Mother City.”

headline: Friends Gathered Around in Celebration of Bechet
text: The gig by the clarinetist Evan Christopher on Monday night took place in a theater, but the language of the show was house party. It was sponsored by the Sidney Bechet Society, which since 1997 has promoted music associated with Bechet — which is to say New Orleans and Chicago jazz of the 1920s.

headline: Landing in New York After Circling It for 60 Years
text: For stars who have devoted their careers to flaunting hard-edged glamour, there often comes a time when the urge to pull back the tinselly curtain and be “real” is irresistible. But how real is “real” if what is exposed is show business reality?

headline: Getting Muddy in the Netherlands
text: WE’RE driving on top of a dike in the northern province of Friesland in the Netherlands, with a sliver of pink-hued sunrise slicing through an otherwise gray sky. We zoom past verdant pastures full of cows and sheep, past centuries-old churches, and past windmills, both old and modern. I notice the blades on the newer machines are spinning fast. That’s a bad sign: more wind means more water. That is, more water in the Wadden Sea, a thin and shallow stretch of the North Sea that separates the Dutch mainland from a series of islands, including Ameland, a narrow slip of pristine land that’s home to four villages.

headline: Store Review: Greece Is for Lovers, in Athens
text: The tourist-packed streets at the base of the Acropolis in Athens are a vibrant if somewhat kitsch-laden extension of the achievements of ancient Greece. Kiosks overflow with posters and guidebooks, and the roads are jammed with shops selling everything from pricey marble busts of Athena to gaudy Parthenon refrigerator magnets.

headline: Architects at Play, Dangling Medals
text: THE veterans debated over which was more memorable: the Versailles dinner, with fountains and all, for Tadao Ando, or the gilded reception for architecture’s queen bee, Zaha Hadid, in St. Petersburg. Rem Koolhaas had his shining moment beneath the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, while the Clintons brought out the White House welcome mat for Renzo Piano in that heady, pre-dot-com-bust year of 1998.

headline: Revolutionary Militant as Thug
text: CANNES, France — The Cannes Film Festival has become the go-to event to see premieres of backbreaking biopics about far-left (and far-out) Latino warriors: in 2008, Steven Soderbergh’s 286-minute “Che” played here and on Wednesday, Olivier Assayas’s 333-minute “Carlos” did. Long before the festival opened, this 5 hour 33 minute movie about the Venezuelan-born terrorist, international man of mystery and brutishly committed ladies’ man, Ilich Ramírez Sánchez — i.e., Carlos the Jackal — was a must-see. The movie, which screened just once, and out of competition, is scheduled to play on French television this week. It is likely to pop up in the United States this fall at the New York Film Festival before it plays on-demand and in good old-fashioned theaters.

headline: A Game That Thinks It’s an Eerie TV Drama
text: Among the more interesting aspects of the video game world is that the sequels are often better than the originals. After all, continual creative iteration is the heart of game design. Most of that process should take place before the game is released to the public, but there are plenty of franchises that have not come into their own until a second title addresses the flaws of the first. (My favorite games of 2009, Assassin’s Creed II and Uncharted 2, provide recent examples.)

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. The Harvard scammer. Harvard is being karmically punished for having foisted Facebook and Alan Dershowitz on the world.

headline: ‘Idol’ Wins the Night
text: Lee DeWyze, Crystal Bowersox and Casey James performed in the semifinal round of “American Idol” on Tuesday as the Fox reality show attracted 18.3 million viewers and the largest audience in prime time, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Fox won the night’s ratings over all thanks largely to “Idol” at 8 p.m. CBS finished close behind Fox as its complementary crime shows “NCIS” (15.6 million) and “NCIS: Los Angeles” (15.2 million) remained strong opposite the competition. ABC ranked third, and NBC was fourth.

headline: Theater Cancels Play With Wiesel Character
text: A Jewish theater in Washington, Theater J, has canceled a play that included a character based on Elie Wiesel after he objected, The Washington Post reported. The play, “Imagining Madoff,” by Deb Margolin, included a fictional meeting between Bernard L. Madoff and Mr. Wiesel, the Holocaust survivor and writer, who lost several million dollars of his wealth as well as all of the assets of his foundation, in Mr. Madoff’s huge Ponzi scheme. Ms. Margolin told The Post that she had used Mr. Wiesel as a foil for Mr. Madoff because “his name is synonymous with decency, morality, the struggle for human dignity and kindness.” But Mr. Wiesel apparently saw the representation differently. After reading the script, he called the play “defamatory” and “obscene” and threatened to have his lawyer try to stop the production. Theater J’s artistic director, Ari Roth, suggested that Ms. Margolin revise the play and replace Mr. Wiesel with a fictional character. She ultimately declined. “Imagining Madoff” was to open Theater J’s season in August; it has been replaced with “Something You Did,” by Willy Holtzman.

headline: TV Networks Plan Cancer Fund-Raiser
text: ABC, CBS and NBC have agreed to broadcast a cancer research fund-raiser in September to be hosted by the evening news anchors at each network. The event, “Stand Up to Cancer,” is a sequel; the first such telethon took place in September 2008 and helped to raise more than $100 million, according to the organizers at the nonprofit Entertainment Industry Foundation. This year’s telethon, on the night of Sept. 10, will be hosted by Brian Williams of NBC, Diane Sawyer of ABC and Katie Couric, above, of CBS. “The broadcast is a way of saying, ‘Together, we can do this,’ ” Ms. Sawyer said in a statement. The three networks are donating an hour of prime time for the commercial-free, celebrity-heavy event, and they will be joined by HBO, E!, Discovery Health and the MLB Network, among others. The original event in 2008 wound up being shown in 170 countries, the foundation said.

headline: Oil Is Fouling Wetlands, Official Says
text: VENICE, La. — Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana said Wednesday that sheets of heavy crude oil from the offshore spill had seeped deep into the delicate marshes around the mouth of the Mississippi River. He called on the federal government to approve a plan to build sand berms to protect the bayou country.

headline: Now in Berlin, Tastes of Mexico
text: WHEN Maria Bonita opened in Berlin’s Prenzlauer Berg district in August, the rundown, eight-barstool restaurant created a sensation. In a city where seeded rolls accompany ketchup-based salsa, and burritos are doused in mayonnaise, Maria Bonita was serving up fresh Mexican street food: thick Oaxacan corn tortillas filled with salted meat and cactus salad, homemade chorizo, deep-fried pork skins and egg-filled tortillas baked in a creamy habanero-pumpkinseed sauce.

headline: 36 Hours in Santa Fe
text: THE Plaza, the heart of old Santa Fe, hasn’t changed much since the Spanish settled here 400 years ago. But surrounding the Plaza is an increasingly cosmopolitan city. Sure, it’s possible to focus entirely just on the historic center, where Native American handicrafts are for sale on every corner.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast
text: On this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein talks to Brad Stone about YouTube’s past, present and future. Five years after its debut as a quirky repository of online videos, YouTube says that more than two billion videos a day are viewed on the site. Its owner, Google, plans to expand its reach to the television set, and as Mr. Stone explains, YouTube is expected to play a important role in that effort.

headline: In Petipa’s Tragedy, a Meeting of Dreams, Devotion, Death and Opium
text: After a work of theater art is over, two different ideas of it can form in your mind. There’s the actual impression it has made, which becomes mysteriously connected to your imagination and can grow powerfully. (In ballet, this effect can be remarkably like that of drugs. This is why some people need to keep returning to the same work several times in quick succession, in need of a fix.) But there’s also the theory of it, so that we find ourselves starting to engage anew with what Shakespeare wanted to express in “As You Like It,” or Mozart in “The Magic Flute.”

headline: Amid War, Destinies Are Found and Lost
text: In the first half of “The Invisible Bridge,” Julie Orringer tells the evocative, coincidence-strewn, oddly theatrical story of Andras Levi, a young Hungarian Jew who travels to Paris in 1937 to study architecture.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: The coming-of-age novel is a perennial favorite, and this month’s list of new books is rich with examples. Whether in the hothouse environment of an arts school or in Iraq in the 1940s, adolescents struggling toward adulthood offer moments of tenderness and amusement. And, of course, there are killers, too.

headline: The Insider | Jonathan Caouette
text: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts.

headline: Three Lighthearted Debuts From a Familiar Classicist
text: Since Beethoven’s death in 1827, musicians and academics have pored over his life, letters and documents with a fine-tooth comb; even his hair was the subject of an entire book. By now a new scholarly treatise analyzing his fingernails seems likelier than an evening of Beethoven premieres.

headline: Putting New Faces on Islamic History
text: ONE balmy evening this month, a glamorous crowd was packed into the tiny Leila Taghinia-Milani Heller Gallery on the Upper East Side for the opening of  “Icons,”  a show of video installations by the Iranian-born filmmaker Shoja Azari that runs through Friday.

headline: Against Juristocracy
text: Writing for National Review Online, Robert F. Nagel offers a critique of the right-wing hope that the Supreme Court will overturn Obamacare, and a brief against the judicial usurpation of politics in general. Here are some of the arguments he musters for a judicial system that knows when to leave well enough alone:

headline: M.T.A. to End Relationship With Goldman Sachs
text: From Michael M. Grynbaum at City Room:

headline: Worried Girl Asks Michelle Obama if Her Mother Will Be Deported
text: Updated | Friday | 10:40 a.m. Michelle Obama fielded an awkward question on the immigration debate on Wednesday. It came from a worried young girl who seemed to say that her mother is an illegal immigrant. The encounter, caught on video, came during a visit by the first lady and Margarita Zavala, the wife of Mexican President Felipe Calderón to a second-grade class in Silver Spring, Md.

headline: Celluloid Tribute to a Painter Who Gave Life to Dinosaurs
text: Charles R. Knight is not much of a household name these days. But his work is thrillingly familiar to anyone who’s ever stood entranced before his murals of grazing mastodons and rampaging tyrannosaurs at the American Museum of Natural History or other museums, or leafed through certain grade-school science textbooks.

headline: Back to Rage Anew, Fires Smoldering Still
text: “For your dubious pleasure!” John Lydon proclaimed as Public Image Ltd. started its set on Tuesday night at Terminal 5. That was Mr. Lydon’s famous cynicism. His corrosive mockery made him the voice of anarchy and nihilism for the brief, indelible punk flare-up of the Sex Pistols and then, from 1978 to 1992, a provocateur and post-punk pioneer as the leader of Public Image Ltd., abbreviated to PiL for the band’s logo.

headline: Upfronts: CBS Shows Off ‘Hawaii 5-0’ and ‘Mike & Molly’
text: “We don’t have a million new shows,” the CBS entertainment president Nina Tassler said Wednesday at her network’s upfront. “And we’re not asking any of them to be self-starters.”

headline: Politicians and Their Fake War Stories
text: This week, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut found himself in the hot seat. A Times article reported that Mr. Blumenthal, a Democrat running for the United States Senate, had not fought in Vietnam, and yet in a speech in 2008 he said, “We have learned something important since the days that I served in Vietnam.” In fact, he received five military deferments between 1965 and 1970, when he landed a coveted spot in the Marine Reserve, which allowed him to avoid combat overseas.

headline: What’s Up, Doc? New Looneys
text: LOS ANGELES  Ask a first grader to identify Bugs Bunny and the response more likely than not will be a blank stare. Dora, sure. Mickey, alive and kicking. But Porky who?

headline: Lincoln Center Updates Plaza and Maybe Its Liability
text: In the brightness of morning, when the sun glints off the gushing fountain, or at twilight, as people cross the travertine on their way to performances, the plaza at Lincoln Center can be one of New York’s tranquil oases.

headline: Khaki With an Urban Edge
text: More dressed up than jeans without getting all fancy-pants, khaki can go to the office, then go to the dogs.

headline: Real Stuff Referendum
text: Sex, lies, and hypocrisy: does an election day get any more entertaining? And that was before Republicans in Kentucky voted against the advice of the top Republican in Kentucky, and voters in Pennsylvania sent a Democrat to Congress who vowed to take on Democrats in Congress.

headline: Khaki Gets Street Cred
text: THE country may not be in the midst of a great color conciliation, what with Red and Blue paint balls flying as furiously as ever, but fashion is. In the last few seasons, even arch-cosmopolites, whose tastes normally range from asphalt to charcoal, have dipped into enough preppy All-American colors to make a three-piece madras suit.

headline: Not at All Shy About Taking the Plunge
text: When you can see that your contract depends on, say, guessing a suit correctly or a finesse, what is your approach? Do you delay the evil trick as long as possible by cashing other winners, or do you decide immediately?

headline: João Pinto: ‘My National Team’
text: LISBON — I almost did not make it to the Portugal national team’s official player presentation. I had flight delays resulting from technical difficulties and then the volcanic dust cloud. The airport was absolute chaos. I just made it in time, but my bags arrived a day later. That is another story for another day.

headline: Awkward Question for First Lady
text: Michelle Obama fielded an awkward question from a young girl on the immigration debate on Wednesday. The encounter, caught on video, came during a visit by the first lady and Margarita Zavala, the wife of Mexican President Felipe Calderón to a second-grade class in Silver Spring, Md.  Watch the video, and comment on the exchange, at our sib-blog, The Lede.

headline: Turning a Catskills Cabin Into a Midcentury Retreat
text: LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y.

headline: Tour: A Catskills Fishing Cottage
text: A publicist makes over a cabin with a mix of global influences and an indoor-melting-into-outdoor style.

headline: As American as Cherry Pie
text: I imagine there are plenty of people who travel around the country going to baseball games, and that those people can tell you everything there is to know about the motels near the various stadiums and the quality of the chili dogs. What they know of America’s cities they know insofar as it relates to the game: the convenience of the parking, the freshness of the popcorn. Over time, the things that make us travel can also give us a certain kind of expertise. It could be amusement parks, Civil War battlefields, marinas, museums.

headline: Divorce, Apartment Style
text: I LOVED my neighbors.

headline: Poggenpohl’s New Kitchen System
text: Poggenpohl’s latest kitchen system, +Artesio, was designed to be open to the rest of the home, blending into the living space around it. It’s not only a “workshop for preparing dishes,” said Hadi Teherani, the Hamburg architect who created the kitchen in collaboration with the German design company. “It is the place where you would also read a book, paint a picture or receive guests.”

headline: Maria Pergay, 79, Furniture Designer
text: Last weekend, while New York City was overrun by design enthusiasts in town for the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, Maria Pergay, a 79-year-old Parisian furniture designer relatively unknown in this country, was ensconced in a nautical modernist room at the Maritime Hotel. She was in New York not for the furniture fair — an event, it turns out, that she has never heard of — but to show her latest work at the Demisch Danant gallery in Chelsea (including a sofa of broken bricks she is shown sitting on). Those expecting a woman of her age to produce soft, feminine, upholstered pieces appropriate for a Paris pied-à-terre may be surprised by what has been Ms. Pergay’s material of choice for decades: stainless steel.

headline: Industrial-Style Furniture at Strawser & Smith
text: For years, Fred Strawser has been drawing renovators to FS-20, his Asbury Park, N.J., emporium for all things midcentury modern. But when a gallery space near the L train in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, came on the market, Mr. Strawser decided to bring his mod mix to the city, forming a partnership with David Smith, with a new store called Strawser & Smith, in a loftlike space with concrete floors and exposed joists that set the tone for the industrial-strength furniture.

headline: Sales at John Derian and Ligne Roset
text: At John Derian Company’s three-day sale, beginning today, decoupage pieces are 30 to 50 percent off and other merchandise is 20 to 50 percent off (Astier de Villatte hand-painted earthenware dogs, originally $375, are $263; Royal Boch pitchers, above, originally $34 to $54, are $18 to $27; John Robshaw hand-painted pillow covers, originally $66 to $77, are $46 to $54); 10 East Second Street (Bowery), (212) 677-3917 or johnderian.com.

headline: Student Work at a Rhode Island School of Design Exhibition
text: If you wish to strike up a meaningful relationship with a design star of tomorrow — surely a better investment option than playing the stock market — you might want to stop by the Rhode Island School of Design’s graduate thesis exhibition.

headline: Growing Vegetables Upside Down
text: IF pests and blight are wrecking your plants, it might be time to turn your garden on its head.

headline: The Cross Medicine Cabinet
text: First Aid, a medicine cabinet decorated with the Red Cross symbol, was modeled on Thomas Ericksson’s 1992 Cross Medicine Cabinet for Cappellini, a simple cross-shaped lacquered metal cabinet that comes in five colors, including red and white.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,058 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

headline: Inside Cannes
text: A look at some of the films premiering at the 2009 Cannes International Film Festival.

headline: Fashion Shines at Cannes
text: Creative red-carpet dressing was in full force at the 62nd International Film Festival at Cannes, France.

headline: ‘The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest’
text: Chapter 1

headline: Stoking a Music Fan’s Fancy With Apps That Rock
text: The big knock against smartphones, iPods and iPads is that no one really needs one. There is no question you can get by without any of the nearly 300,000 mobile apps on the market.

headline: Solving a Dress-Design Sudoku
text: THE designers Jeffrey Costello, right, and Robert Tagliapietra (shown with Sam) embarked on their collaboration with Uniqlo, the Japanese fashion retailer, as a brain teaser. “We approached it as problem solving: how to come up with an untricky way of doing dresses,” Mr. Tagliapietra said in a joint phone interview. (Asked to confirm that it was Mr. Tagliapietra speaking, there was laughter, and a reference to their 16 years of living and working together: “We’re interchangeable.”) Known for their own uniform of plaid shirts and suspenders, the team produces elegant dresses, with details like French seams. “We knew we were going to leave that behind,” Mr. Costello said. What they cleaved to was their trademark draping and a modernist minimalist take. A muted palette includes a range of spring colors from gray to rose to cornflower blue. And a bright mustard yellow. The capsule collection has 14 styles in prices ranging from $29.50 to $39.50. At 546 Broadway (between Prince and Spring Streets); (917) 237-8811 and uniqlo.com.

headline: British Invasion, Only This Time It’s in Retail
text: ALLSAINTS SPITALFIELDS, the British chic rock ’n’ roll line (but no relation to the 1990s British girl group of the same name), is opening in SoHo this week. The store has searchlight fixtures recovered from the Suez Canal, sewing machines from Chatham Dockyard, a loom from a mill in Sheffield. Even the Keelhaul Bikini evokes Britain’s naval history (pictured, top and bottom, $45 each).

headline: Sony’s Hybrid Camera
text: Sony enters the competition to make the smallest camera with the biggest sensor with its  Alpha NEX-5, which will be available in July.

headline: Rivera Human, After All
text: After Mariano Rivera served up a grand slam to Minnesota’s Jason Kubel on Sunday, Manager Joe Girardi said that Rivera “showed that he’s human today.” After Rivera allowed two unearned runs in the Yankees’ loss to Boston on Tuesday, sustaining his first loss of the season, Joba Chamberlain again invoked his mortality: “He’s a human being. I know it’s crazy to say that, but he is.”

headline: The Engineered Shoe
text: THE store’s signature shoe is inspired by the Möbius strip. Another by the furniture design classic, the Eames chair. Materials are high tech. And the shoes are displayed at the United Nude’s new dark flagship store lighted like works of art. Clearly, an architect’s hand is in the details. Rem D Koolhaas, the creative director, is indeed an architect (and second cousin of Rem Koolhaas). The avant-garde Amsterdam brand plays with gravity with unorthodox designs like centering the heel on the foot bed. The Cosmo (pictured, $485) is made of a hand-molded carbon fiber. The store is on the same block as Daryl K and Oak. United Nude, 25 Bond Street (between Lafayette Street and Bowery); (212) 420-6000, unitednude.com.

headline: Everyone Into le Pool!
text: The French are so good at drilling down, at paring and distilling, that hardly anyone thinks twice when a saffron farm in Provence opens its doors to paying guests these days. On what seemed like an absurd hunch, the owners of l’Aube Safran gambled correctly that there are enough people in the world whose idea of heaven is to spend their vacation harvesting crocuses, tweezing out the stigmas and eating bouillabaisse.

headline: Germany Investigates Google’s Data Collecting
text: BERLIN — Prosecutors in Hamburg opened a criminal investigation of Google on Wednesday over its collecting of private Internet data from unsecured Wi-Fi networks in Germany.

headline: Confessions of a Soukaholic
text: Don’t be like me. Don’t fly to Damascus; book a room in one of the exquisitely restored Ottoman-era boutique hotels in the Old City, wheedle an address from a local for the best place to buy embroidered aghabani tablecloths, push through the labyrinth of the Souk al-Hamidiyeh and beyond to find said naperer (Abdalla and Dubbane) . . . and then fail to buy your mother the most perfect aghabani on earth, because you’ve been marathon shopping for three days and are too whipped to hunt down an A.T.M. Know that you may never see that tablecloth again — all 14 feet of cream-colored cotton, filigreed with scrolling garlands stitched by seamstresses in a molten shade of amber, 16 napkins included, for 9,000 Syrian pounds (about $190).

headline: Designs From the 2010 International Contemporary Furniture Fair
text: Award winners at the ICFF, held in Manhattan, emphasized handwork and the rough and tumble.

headline: Inside the 2010 ICFF
text: PATRICIA URQUIOLA, the Spanish designer, was standing beside her new collection of bath fixtures at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair last Saturday, when she was approached by a trio of women holding clipboards, tiny cameras dangling from their wrists. The three embraced Ms. Urquiola, asking after her children and cooing over her gleaming hardware and decadently proportioned tubs for Axor.

headline: Five Ways to Keep Online Criminals at Bay
text: THE Web is a fount of information, a busy marketplace, a thriving social scene — and a den of criminal activity.

headline: Checking Vista for Updates
text: Q. I can’t seem to get security updates on my Windows Vista computer. Is there a setting I need to adjust?

headline: Yankees’ Protest Looks Destined to Fail
text: The Boston Red Sox placed Josh Beckett on the disabled list Wednesday, a move that appears to undermine any hopes the Yankees held of succeeding with their protest.

headline: As Calculated as Tie-Dye Can Get
text: SHABD SIMON-ALEXANDER, a Brooklyn-based artist, also designs lush tie-dyed clothes, including scarves for Barneys (pictured, $175, 22 inches by 90 inches). Before starting, Ms. Simon-Alexander experimented with color, saturation and proportions, making detailed notes.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: The Green Cliffs of Dorset
text: It was easy, for a brief delusional moment, to feel as if I were among the very few people on Earth to discover Mudeford Spit, a sandbank jutting off Dorset county in the south of England. Getting there, for starters, was no easy task. Though sailboat or sea kayak might provide the most direct mode of transport, being among the nautically impaired meant having to resort to a not unpleasant combination of automobile, ferry and bicycle — I did not encounter a single human during my circuitous two-hour journey through dune grass and groves of wild raspberry bushes. Once I arrived, I found myself meandering along the most charmingly eccentric stretch of beach I’ve ever seen: a half-mile crescent surrounded by water (the crystalline calm of Christchurch Harbor to the north, the infinite whitecaps of the English Channel to the south) and peppered with salt-bitten beach huts the size of camping tents. It was late August, the height of vacation season, yet aside from a woman in a bathrobe walking her poodle along the shore this morning, the place was splendidly deserted. Taking it in, I couldn’t help but revel in my sense of accomplishment: here, on my first day in Dorset, no less, I’d stumbled upon an idyllic swath of coastline that even the British, it seemed, had managed to overlook.

headline: NASA and Justice Assist Toyota Inquiry
text: NASA scientists and federal law enforcement officials are assisting with the safety investigation into Toyota’s recalls of millions of vehicles, federal regulators said Wednesday.

headline: Symantec’s VeriSign Asset Buy: a Long Time Coming
text: To Symantec‘s chief executive, Enrique Salem, finding the perfect solution to expanding his vision of the company as an omnipresent shield for users’ sensitive information was just a matter of looking.

headline: True Fish Tale: Angler, 70, Still Casts With the Best
text: EVANS, Ga. — The president of the United States was leaning over the edge of the bass boat, in pain because one of the fish hooks from a crank bait was caught in his index finger. He was trying to control a writhing bass, which made it difficult to extract the hook.

headline: 2 Officials Say They Face Retaliation for Addressing Sexual Misconduct
text: Two veteran swimming officials have filed a complaint with the United States Olympic Committee, saying they are the victims of retaliation by USA Swimming for speaking out against what they characterize as a culture of sexual misconduct by coaches certified by the organization.

headline: Is the Fed Missing Early Signs of Recovery?
text: The corridors of wealth and finance are alive with new optimism. The trouble is, if the Fed is behind the game, there’s a good chance everyone will suffer.

headline: American Citizen Sent Money to Al Qaeda
text: WASHINGTON — A Moroccan-born naturalized United States citizen pleaded guilty Wednesday to charges that he sent money to Al Qaeda, in the latest terrorism-related case to arise involving an American.

headline: Fatal Ethnic Street Fighting Erupts at Kyrgyz University
text: MOSCOW — A deadly ethnic riot broke out Wednesday in a major southern city in Kyrgyzstan, where the country’s interim government has only tenuous control and where the police have largely stopped working rather than take sides in a political conflict.

headline: Fighting About the ’60s All Over Again
text: To the Editor:

headline: Investors Ease Strain on F.D.I.C.
text: After contending with nearly 240 bank failures since the financial crisis struck, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is finally getting some help from private investors.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Wall St.’s Chosen Few in Obama’s Good Graces
text: Given the Obama administration’s harsher tone toward Wall Street, it is no surprise to find that only a few financial executives were on the guest list for the White House state dinner on Wednesday night. Among those who made the cut were Brian T. Moynihan, the chief executive of Bank of America, and James P. Gorman, the chief executive of Morgan Stanley.

text: To the Editor:

headline: An Old Chip Cartel Case Is Brought to a Swift End
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union fined a group of computer chip makers 331.3 million euros ($409 million) on Wednesday for price fixing in the first use of a new procedure that allows settlement of cartel cases in Europe.

headline: Criteria to Consider in New York City Teacher Layoffs
