text: Mark Hurd, Hewlett-Packard’s chief executive, called on Tuesday in a pretty good mood.

headline: Voter Insurrection Turns Mainstream, Creating New Rules
text: Americans have been cursing their incumbents — and periodically rising up to eject them from office — since angry Bostonians took a bucket of tar and some feathers to their customs commissioner in 1774. Such uprisings have become an almost cyclical occurrence in Washington, and after this week’s primaries in Arkansas, Kentucky and Pennsylvania, 2010 seems destined to be one of those years.

headline: First, He Built Treehouses
text: Stephen Martin, 25, an architect and Frank Gehry-phobe, was raised in the suburbs of Denver and graduated from Cooper Union’s architecture school in 2008. He works for Franklin D. Roosevelt Four Freedoms Park L.L.C., which is building a memorial park designed by Louis I. Kahn at the southern tip of Roosevelt Island. His work there includes organizing construction documents, building scale models and helping with fund-raising.

headline: A Waning Star of Air Travel Struggles as a Solo Act
text: FORT WORTH — Has American Airlines, for decades the industry’s leader, been backed into a corner?

headline: Lenox Hill Joins Hospital Group
text: Brooke Astor, the philanthropist and socialite, was whisked to Lenox Hill Hospital after charges that she had been neglected. Deborah Voigt, a Wagnerian soprano, shed her bulk there.

headline: Germany Acts Alone to Protect the Euro and Big Banks Against Speculators
text: BERLIN — If Germany’s efforts to rein in speculation in European markets were meant to surprise investors, they succeeded — just not quite in the way officials in Berlin might have intended.

headline: A Bitter Spring for Mongolia's Nomads
text: A drought last summer followed by an unusually cold winter has killed more than eight million animals, about 17 percent of the country’s livestock.

headline: Head of the Intrepid Resigns as Fleet Week Approaches
text: Bill White, the ebullient president of the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum, resigned abruptly on Wednesday morning, just days before some of the museum’s biggest annual events are to take place.

headline: New York State Voters Approve 92% of School Budgets
text: New York voters passed 92 percent of the school budgets across the state on Tuesday, stamping out any concerns of a backlash against districts that are seeking to raise property taxes and reduce their staffs and programs next year.

headline: If You Build It …
text: For 15 years, Kevin Costner has been overseeing the construction of oil separation machines to prepare for the possibility of another disaster of the magnitude of the 1989 Exxon Valdez spill.

headline: A Vision of the City as It Once Was
text: Back in 1960, Barbra Streisand — then still Barbara — was 18 and unable to find acting work when a friend told her about a weekly talent contest at the Lion, a gay club in the West Village. Uninterested in singing but hungry, she gave it a try, as much for the free dinner (they had a great London broil, she recalls) as for the paid gig that came with placing first. She won that prize, a standing ovation and her first big break.

headline: Paul’s Victory Poses Test for Tea Party on Defining Principles
text: BOWLING GREEN, Ky. — Rand Paul’s win in the Republican Senate primary here is the first authentic Tea Party victory — a candidate from the movement, powered by it.

headline: Creative Feet of Texas Key for U.S. in S. Africa
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — He prefers bass fishing in the United States to carp fishing in England. Otherwise, Clint Dempsey, a young man from East Texas, is quite comfortable in southwest London.

headline: CBS Shakes Up Rivals With ‘Big Bang’ Switch
text: CBS shook up the upfront week on Wednesday with the most startling moves of any network for the coming season, centered not on picking up new shows but on shifting several of its most popular series to new nights.

headline: Winter Leaves Mongolians a Harvest of Carcasses
text: SOUTH HANGAY PROVINCE, Mongolia — They call it the zud, a prolonged period of heavy snows and paralyzing cold that adds to the challenges of living on a treeless expanse nearly the size of Alaska. But this year’s zud followed a punishing summer drought that stunted the grass and left Munkhbat Lkhagvasuren’s herds emaciated and his family in debt after borrowing money for fodder.

headline: Judge Loses Patience With a Bronx Landlord
text: The 49-unit apartment building in Bronx River has a tally of woes almost impressive in magnitude. It has 663 open violations. Its walls shed lead paint, rain seeps through collapsing ceilings, and cockroaches and rats scuttle across its buckled floors.

headline: Courage in Arizona
text: Four young immigrant students risked everything on Monday when they sat down in Senator John McCain’s office in Tucson and refused to leave. They were urging passage of the Dream Act, a bill offering a citizenship path to illegal immigrants who, like them, were brought to the United States as children, too young to have willfully broken the law.

headline: Prurience and Politics
text: A show of hands for lawmakers favoring pornography was requested in the House last week. “C’mon, raise your hand!” cried Representative Bart Gordon, furious that a major $85 billion measure to renew national science research financing had run afoul of a mischievous Republican amendment against federal bureaucrats watching pornography on the job.

headline: Report Faults Use of Restraint at a Charter School in Harlem
text: The use of physical restraint at a Harlem charter school that serves special education students was not reported properly and “could be considered condoned assaults and abuse of schoolchildren,” a city investigation released on Wednesday said.

headline: The Courage of Russia’s Journalists
text: Russia is a notoriously dangerous place to be a journalist. The list of reporters who have been murdered while uncovering organized crime in Moscow or reporting on the war in Chechnya is chillingly long. An article by Clifford Levy in The Times this week describes the bravery of journalists who have been brutally attacked for reporting on local corruption.

headline: Will Cooperation Benefit Times Square Bombing Suspect? Experts Disagree
text: For more than two weeks, the suspect in the Times Square bomb case had been held at an undisclosed location, voluntarily offering so much information that several law enforcement officials have noted the extraordinary level of cooperation.

headline: Whistle-Blowers Become Investment Option for Hedge Funds
text: Hedge funds have found a new market to invest in: whistle-blowers.

headline: Figures Suggest Japan’s Recovery Gaining Strength
text: TOKYO — The Japanese economy grew at a healthy clip of 1.2 percent in the first quarter, the government said on Thursday, hinting that Japan’s recovery from a crippling recession was finally gathering momentum.

headline: Yankees’ Bridge to Rivera Is Still Under Construction
text: Growing up in Lincoln, Neb., Joba Chamberlain rooted for the team he saw most often on television: the Atlanta Braves, whose games beamed through on cable. So when John Smoltz, the former Cy Young Award winner for the Braves, approached him last month at Fenway Park, Chamberlain was star struck.

headline: Health Care Reform and the Courts
text: The number of states jointly suing to overturn the new health care reform law on constitutional grounds swelled to 20 last week. It is the latest example of conservatives’ determination to thwart reforms that will do enormous good — and the latest reminder that politicians will continue to posture and demagogue the issue through the November elections and beyond.

headline: Diplomatic Storm Brewing Over Korean Peninsula
text: WASHINGTON — South Korea’s formal accusation that a North Korean torpedo sank one of its warships, killing 46 sailors, will set off a diplomatic drumbeat to punish North Korea, backed by the United States and other nations, which could end up in the United Nations Security Council.

headline: For Rodriguez, Galea Issue Refuses to Fade Away
text: Two hours before the Yankees took on the first-place Tampa Bay Rays on Wednesday night, Alex Rodriguez signed autographs for children in the Yankees’ dugout.

headline: The Lion Reopens
text: A West Village restaurant with a taste for preserving the past.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Parsing a Narrow Win by an Arkansas Senator
text: SHERIDAN, Ark. — When word circulated early Tuesday evening that Senator Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas had won the early and absentee vote in Pulaski County, the county that includes Little Rock, her supporters took it as a sign that she would pull off a decisive win in the Democratic primary.

headline: Adrift at Midseason, Celtics Prove Playoff Mettle
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — The Boston Celtics can be magnificent or moody or sometimes both. Their emotional swings force Coach Doc Rivers to take the team’s temperature each night. Before Game 2 of the Eastern Conference finals, Rivers wondered: would his players be complacent after stealing Game 1 against the Orlando Magic, or would they come out and take command of the series?

headline: Obama’s Second State Dinner Attracts No Gate Crashers
text: WASHINGTON — Some of them were still clutching their embossed invitations, proof that they belonged. They had already been asked their names once, twice, three times to make sure they were actually on the list.

headline: Police Accused of Ignoring Law on Sealing Stop-and-Frisk Records
text: To the New York Police Department, its database of people who have been stopped and frisked is an invaluable tool, providing quick access to information that it says can help solve crimes and save lives.

headline: LeBron’s Next Leap
text: Philadelphia

headline: ‘Main Street’ Revisited and Rethought
text: “Exile on Main Street,” the Rolling Stones’ 1972 album, has been reissued, accompanied by black-and-white pictures by Dominique Tarlé of the band at Nellcôte, France.

headline: Don’t LEED Us Astray
text: TODAY Al Gore is expected to join some of the city’s top developers and bankers for the grand opening of the luminous office tower known as 1 Bryant Park — the second-tallest building in New York City and, with a handsome foyer and a roster of prominent tenants, a ray of hope in a gloomy commercial real estate market.

headline: A Swarm Gives Way to Sprinters in Stage 4
text: MODESTO, Calif. — With the finish line in sight after a tiring 121.5-mile ride from the coast, Francesco Chicchi crouched over his bike, gritted his teeth and churned his legs as he zoomed ahead.

headline: The Limbaugh Victory
text: THERE are many theories for why very conservative Republicans seem to be doing so well lately, taking their party’s Senate nominations in Florida, Kentucky and Utah, and beating Democrats head-to-head in Massachusetts, New Jersey and Virginia. Some attribute this to a generalized anti-incumbent mood. Others say it reflects the tendency of parties in power to falter in midterm elections. Recently it has been fashionable to ascribe right-wing success to the Tea Party movement.

headline: France: Draft Veil Ban Approved
text: The French government approved a draft bill on Wednesday that prohibits the wearing of full facial veils in public places, which is expected to lead to a vote in Parliament in July. According to the draft bill, anyone wearing a garment “designed to hide the face” would be subject to a $185 fine, and anyone who forced a woman to cover her face could be fined as much as $18,500. While it is likely that Parliament will approve the bill, the Council of State, France’s highest legal authority, has signaled that it may be unconstitutional.

headline: Scientists Fault Lack of Studies Over Gulf Oil Spill
text: Tensions between the Obama administration and the scientific community over the gulf oil spill are escalating, with prominent oceanographers accusing the government of failing to conduct an adequate scientific analysis of the damage and of allowing BP to obscure the spill’s true scope.

headline: Lessons From a Lacrosse Field Echo From West Point to Afghanistan
text: WEST POINT, N.Y.

headline: Canada: Bank Branch Firebombed
text: Security was increased at some Canadian banks on Wednesday after the firebombing of a Royal Bank of Canada branch in a residential neighborhood of Ottawa on Tuesday. A previously unknown group calling itself FFFC-Ottawa claimed responsibility for the attack. In an online posting, the group said it had attacked the bank to protest its sponsorship of the Winter Olympics in February, as well as its role in financing the oil-sands projects in western Canada. No one was injured in the bombing, but the bank branch sustained extensive damage.

headline: A New Owner Makes a Winning Impression
text: We may never see this man again, but for one shining moment Mikhail D. Prokhorov gave hope — not necessarily for the star-crossed Nets basketball franchise, but for the entire species of sports owners.

headline: Pakistan: Court Blocks Facebook
text: An Islamic lawyers association in Lahore, Pakistan, won a court injunction on Wednesday against the popular social networking site Facebook, after someone suggested online that other users should post drawings of the Prophet Muhammad. Islamic law prohibits images of the prophet. The government ordered Internet service providers to block Facebook for the rest of the month. It was shut down on Wednesday evening.

headline: After Swings and Misses, Wright Hits the Bench
text: WASHINGTON — One of the last things David Wright told reporters on Tuesday night after his deflating performance in Atlanta was that the worst thing for him would be to have a day off on Wednesday. Later that night, Wright learned that that was exactly what was coming.

headline: Poverty and the Pill
text: KINSHASA, Congo

headline: Russia: Hunger Strike Canceled
text: After a 24-hour fast, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the jailed former oil tycoon, called off a hunger strike on Wednesday, saying he was satisfied that President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia had been informed of the reasons for his protest. Mr. Khodorkovsky, left, declared the hunger strike on Tuesday to protest his continued detention while on trial for a second time on charges of money laundering and embezzlement. He said then that he would not eat until the president had been made aware of his protest. “I am pleasantly surprised by the efficiency of civil society in supporting my cause and the transparency of the president’s information services,” Mr. Khodorkovsky said in a statement.

headline: Italian Bread
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s not often the theme entries in a crossword puzzle can be made to interlock in an octothorpe pattern, but they do today. The key is the fixed positioning of the word AND toward the beginning and end of each of those entries (with a single letter before and after). The result is pretty cool and perfect for a Thursday.

headline: Preakness Ratings Plummet
text: Lookin at Lucky’s Preakness Stakes victory on Saturday attracted an average of 8.4 million viewers on NBC, down 23 percent from the 10.9 million who watched the filly Rachel Alexandra’s win last year. The Kentucky Derby, won by Super Saver, attracted 16.5 million viewers — and the Preakness lost 8.1 million of them in two weeks. Without the possibility of a Triple Crown winner, viewership for the Belmont Stakes on ABC next month is likely to be small.

headline: Nets’ Owner Takes a Tour
text: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Russian billionaire who recently bought the Nets, took a half-hour tour of Yankee Stadium on Wednesday afternoon. Prokhorov, whose team is building an arena in Brooklyn, saw several areas of the stadium, including the home clubhouse.

headline: Bloggingheads: Visas For Sale?
text: Dayo Olopade, left, of The Daily Beast and Noah Millman of The American Scene debate auctioning off the right to work in America.

headline: Mets Pull Off 2 Rare Feats, but Not a Third (a Win)
text: WASHINGTON — There may be no better way to assess the Mets’ current inability to win than this: In a game in which they hit an inside-the-park home run and converted a triple play, they still lost.

headline: On TV, a New Refuge for Stage Actors
text: When NBC announced last week that it planned to cancel the original “Law & Order,” many people lamented the effect on New York theater actors, for whom a spot on the show has long been a résumé staple. But another New York-based production, “The Good Wife,” is already filling the void for moonlighting stage performers seeking TV credits.

headline: Obamas Hold Second State Dinner
text: President Obama and the first lady Michelle Obama held their second state dinner in honor of President Felipe Calderón of Mexico.

headline: London Mascots Are More High Tech Than Warm and Fuzzy
text: For decades, Olympic mascots have been jolly animals with links to their host country, like Sam the Eagle during the 1984 games in Los Angeles and Waldi the dachshund from the 1972 Munich games. The ideal medium for conveying their cuddliness was the plush doll.

headline: Lazio Picks Rural County Executive as Running Mate
text: Rick A. Lazio, the former Long Island congressman who is in a close and contentious three-way race for the Republican nomination for governor, has selected a county executive from a rural corner of the state as his running mate.

headline: Sanctions Effort May Open Door to Press Iran Central Bank
text: UNITED NATIONS — Buried in the sanctions resolution now being debated in the United Nations Security Council lies the possibility of a new effort to pressure Iran over its nuclear program: a call for countries to “exercise vigilance” in dealing with Iran’s central bank.

headline: White House Embraces Upstart Who Beat Specter
text: This article is by Katharine Q. Seelye, Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny.

headline: From Navy Admiral to Senate Candidate
text: Representative Joe Sestak won an improbable victory over Senator Arlen Specter in Pennsylvania’s Democratic Senate primary.

headline: Use of Mob-Linked Firm Shows M.T.A. Problem  Vetting Subcontractors
text: On most weekdays in recent years, giant tractor-trailer and dump trucks loaded with tons of rocks, earth and sludge have been rumbling out of the Sunnyside, Queens, railyards in low gear and turning onto Northern Boulevard.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: U.S. Science Body Urges Action on Climate
text: WASHINGTON — In its most comprehensive study so far, the nation’s leading scientific body declared on Wednesday that climate change is a reality and is driven mostly by human activity, chiefly the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation.

headline: Arctic Drilling Proposal Advanced Amid Concern
text: A proposal to drill for oil in the Arctic Ocean as early as this summer received initial permits from the Minerals Management Service office in Alaska at the same time federal auditors were questioning the office about its environmental review process.

headline: New Strategy for Soda Tax Gives Diet Drinks a Break
text: Gov. David A. Paterson is considering a new strategy in his effort to pass a soda tax, hoping to win over reluctant lawmakers and the beverage industry by pairing the proposal with a state sales tax exemption on diet sodas and bottled water.

headline: California: DNA Tests Criticized
text: The Center for Genetics and Society, a nonprofit group based in Berkeley, is calling for the University of California, Berkeley, to suspend a project in which freshmen and transfer students will be asked to provide samples of their DNA for analysis. Jesse Reynolds, a policy analyst at the center, said that direct-to-consumer genetic tests are not ready for mass consumption, providing information that is best handled with a doctor or genetic counselor. The university’s program, he said, would normalize the use of direct-to-consumer tests.

headline: Reasons for Balking at Swine Flu Shot
text: Americans who did not get swine flu shots avoided them either because they did not think the virus was a serious threat or they were nervous about the vaccine itself, according to a review of 20 national opinion polls done by the Harvard School of Public Health and published online Wednesday by The New England Journal of Medicine. Parents, in particular, feared the vaccine. Millions of children got the shots, and side effects were very rare.

headline: Kagan Hearings Scheduled
text: The Senate Judiciary Committee will begin hearings June 28 on the confirmation of Elena Kagan to the Supreme Court. The committee chairman, Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, said Wednesday that “it is in the best interests of the court, and of course of the country,” to confirm her before the next court session begins in October. Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama, the panel’s top Republican, said Mr. Leahy turned down his request to delay the hearings until after the July 4 recess.

headline: Rays Flaunt Power and Top Yankees
text: Jorge Posada tried to convince himself. Whenever he took a step, he would tell himself that a bone bruise, nothing more, was causing the pain radiating through the bottom of his right foot. Posada wanted to believe that, but he couldn’t. He knew something was wrong.

headline: In Arizona’s Latest Twist, Voters Follow G.O.P. Governor and Approve Tax Increase
text: PHOENIX — It is not every day that a Republican candidate for governor promotes and celebrates a tax increase here in the state many believe helped give rise to the modern conservative movement.

text: 8:38 a.m. | Updated

headline: Moshe Greenberg, Biblical Scholar, Is Dead at 81
text: Moshe Greenberg, one of the most influential Jewish biblical scholars of the 20th century, died Saturday at his home in Jerusalem. He was 81.

headline: Arakawa, Whose Art Tried to Halt Aging, Dies at 73
text: Arakawa, a Japanese-born conceptual artist and designer, who with his wife, Madeline Gins, explored ideas about mortality by creating buildings meant to stop aging and preclude death, died Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 73.

headline: Mortgage Data Leaves Bankers Uncertain of Trend
text: Any way you look at it, extraordinary numbers of people are having trouble paying their mortgage. What is less clear is the extent to which the problem is getting worse, better or is simply holding its own.

headline: Who Made the Cut at the State Dinner?
text: For Wednesday night’s state dinner, the White House crafted a comprehensive list of notable politicians and celebrities to join President Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama in honoring President Felipe Calderón of Mexico. There were the usual notables like Whoopi Goldberg, and also some high-profile Mexican-Americans, like Eva Longoria and Jets quarterback Mark Sanchez.

headline: Phoenix’ Defense Is No Match for Lakers
text: LOS ANGELES — Provident. Divine. Blessed. Whatever the Lakers are — and no doubt, Amar’e Stoudemire is home at night thumbing through his thesaurus — this much is clear through the first two games of the Western Conference finals: there is no stopping them.

headline: News Quiz | May 20, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Whistle-Blowers Become an Investment Option for Funds
text: Hedge funds have found a new market to invest in: whistle-blowers.

headline: Investors Ease Strain on F.D.I.C.
text: After contending with nearly 240 bank failures since the financial crisis struck, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is finally getting some help from private investors, Eric Dash reports in The New York Times.

headline: Federal Reserve Ponders a Plan for Asset Sales
text: The Federal Reserve indicated that it would wait until after it started raising interest rates before selling the huge store of assets that it acquired in response to the financial crisis. The goal would be to gradually complete the sales about five years after they begin, Sewell Chan writes in The New York Times.

headline: Germany Acts Alone to Protect Euro and Banks
text: If Germany’s efforts to rein in speculation in European markets were meant to surprise investors, they succeeded — just not quite in the way officials in Berlin might have intended, Judy Dempsey and David Jolly report in The New York Times.

headline: Old Chip Cartel Case Is Brought to Swift End

headline: Bangkok Is Tense as Order Returns
text: The Thai military declared Thursday that it had recaptured control of central Bangkok, but Thailand remained on edge after the worst urban violence in the country’s modern history.

headline: Alleged Basque Rebel Leader Arrested
text: MADRID — The Spanish government said Thursday that it had dealt a major blow to the Basque separatist group ETA with the arrest of its suspected military leader in neighboring France.

headline: How Young Is Too Young to Climb Mount Everest?
text: Thirteen-year-old Jordan Romero wants to become the youngest person to reach the summit of Mount Everest as part of his quest to climb the highest mountains in all seven continents. Do you think someone that age has the physical and emotional maturity to take on an extreme altitude endeavor like this? In general, do you think there should be age limits for extreme sports?

headline: Landis Admits Doping, Accuses Top U.S. Cyclists
text: VISALIA, Calif. — After four years of maintaining his innocence about doping charges that ruined his reputation and caused him to be stripped of his 2006 Tour de France title, the American cyclist Floyd Landis has sent e-mail messages to several cycling officials in the United States and in Europe in which he admits using performance-enhancing drugs for most of his career.

headline: Ex-UBS Banker Pleads Guilty to Muni-Bond Fraud
text: Mark Zaino, a 35-year-old former UBS employee, became the first Wall Street banker to admit to a role in a conspiracy to pay public agencies below-market returns on investment deals, according to his guilty plea to fraud and conspiracy charges Wednesday and Justice Department records filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Building a Network of Gay Entrepreneurs
text: Lots of entrepreneurs would like to pick Chip Conley’s brain. But when several dozen gathered in November to meet the founder of Joie de Vivre, a boutique hotel chain that he said had $220 million in revenue last year, their questions were not just about the nuts and bolts of running a company, The New York Times’s Jessica Bruder writes.

headline: Why Recoveries Can Be as Difficult as Recessions

headline: Marathon Sells Minnesota Assets for $800 Million
text: Marathon Oil said Wednesday it planned to sell most of its refining and convenience store assets in Minnesota for an estimated $800 million, The Associated Press reported.

headline: BC Said to Mull $1.5 Billion Sale of Picard
text: BC Partners has tapped Rothschild to advise it on a possible sale of Picard Surgeles, which could fetch about $1.5 billion in a sale, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people with knowledge of the plan.

headline: Deal Seems Near on U.S. Base in Japan
text: TOKYO — Major Japanese newspapers reported Thursday that Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama has decided to reverse himself and accept nearly all of Washington’s demands that he honor an existing agreement to relocate an American air base on Okinawa, in an attempt to end a damaging dispute that had sown confusion and mistrust between the longtime allies.

headline: U.K. Said to Eye ‘Living Wills’ for Big Banks
text: The Financial Services Authority has been collecting massive amounts of financial and organizational data from Barclays, HSBC Holdings, Royal Bank of Scotland Group and Standard Chartered, as Britain conducts its first look at how to create “living wills” in the event of a bank failure, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: A Battery That Stores Wind Juice
text: Mountaintop wind turbines produce most of their energy at night, when electricity demand and prices are low. That limits revenue and makes it hard for utility companies to meet state goals for high percentages of renewable energy.

headline: FIA Announces Examination of Overtaking Rule
text: Well that’s fun. I just spent half an hour creating a poll that I was going to put up on my About.com F1 site on whether Formula One fans thought that the penalty against Michael Schumacher in Monaco was unfair. No sooner did I finish creating the poll than the International Automobile Federation put out a statement that acknowledges that the rule was less than clear. So it looks like the highest rule-making authority in the sport is basically saying that it was not really fair in the end. Here is the FIA statement:

headline: Dear FloFab: The Dangers of Distracted Dining
text: Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Sampler: Whitman’s Lead Over Poizner Shrinks, and Rooting Roosters Out of Danville
text: Whitman’s Lead Over Poizner Dwindles | The race for the Republican nomination for governor is getting tight. Meg Whitman, the former chief executive of eBay, is leading Steve Poizner, the state’s insurance commissioner, in a new poll by just nine points. As recently as March, her lead was 50 points. Ms. Whitman, who is a billionaire, has spent $68 million of her own fortune on the campaign, while Mr. Poizner has spent $24 million of his. If the election was held today, Attorney General Jerry Brown, the Democratic candidate who has spent no money on ads, would beat both Republicans, according to the same poll by the nonpartisan Public Policy Institute of California. The survey also found that Californians were evenly divided on legalizing marijuana. [The San Francisco Chronicle, The Oakland Tribune]

headline: Cooling Fear of a Malaria Surge from Warming
text: As various arguments for action on global warming have failed to blunt growth in emissions in recent years, environmental groups and international agencies have sometimes tried to turn the focus to diseases that could pose a growing threat in a warming world — with malaria being a frequent talking point.

headline: Faith in Eli Manning
text: Jason Cole of Yahoo Sports called Eli Manning an enigma in ranking him ninth on his list of best quarterbacks. But his teammates don’t seem to see any mystery.

headline: The Early Word: Politics as Unusual
text: With the results of Tuesday’s primaries still setting in, Washington is bracing itself for a new political order in which voter insurrection upends national party power and incumbency represents liability.

headline: Pakistan Widens Online Ban to Include YouTube
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani authorities broadened what started as a ban on a social networking site on Thursday, blocking YouTube and about 450 individual Web pages over what they described as “growing sacrilegious content.”

headline: Federer Warms to Springtime in Paris
text: PARIS — Nearly a year later, with a bottle of sparkling water in front of him and the full weight of Roland Garros no longer on his back, Roger Federer was in the same hotel in central Paris, the memories of his first French Open victory now “a slide show” in his head.

headline: F.S.A. Fines Heart of ‘Rotten’ Scheme $3.7 Million

headline: The Night Belongs to Patti Smith
text: Patti Smith serving as the headline act at Saturday’s benefit for the American Folk Art Museum seemed a bit incongruous at first— the high priestess of downtown Manhattan entertaining the friends and patrons of an institution known for their exhibitions of bird decoys and needlepoint?  But the night also happened to be a celebration of the birthday of the artist Henry Darger, who died an unknown Chicago custodian leaving behind one of the most impressive collections of fantastical scroll paintings and writings. Part of his private collection is on display at the museum until September 5th.

headline: Stocks Fall Amid Concern About Europe
text: Fears that the fragile economic recovery in the United States might be threatened by the financial and political crisis in Europe gripped Wall Street on Thursday, sending the stock market into a sharp decline and leaving anxious traders wondering where the pain might stop.

headline: British Coalition Releases Plan for Government
text: On Thursday in London, senior members of the Conservative and Liberal Democrat parties, including the prime minister, David Cameron, and the deputy prime minister, Nick Clegg, released a 34-page document declaring the new coalition government’s plans. The document, called “The Coalition: Our Programme for Government,” essentially replaces the separate campaign manifestos issued by the two parties last month.

headline: BAM to Celebrate Charles M. Knight
text: On Thursday night the Brooklyn Academy of Music is kicking off a miniature film festival as a tribute to Charles R. Knight. The artist, whose murals featuring wildlife and prehistoric beasts are displayed at the American Museum of Natural History and other museums, influenced not only generations of schoolchildren but also the movie industry.

headline: First Trip Abroad Takes British Leader to Europe
text: PARIS — With a dinner in Paris and a journey to Berlin, Britain’s new prime minister, David Cameron, head of a party known for its aversion to closer European integration, planned Thursday to devote his first overseas trip since coming to power last week to smoothing ties with continental Europe.

headline: On Reading Test, Mixed Results Under Bloomberg
text: New York City’s fourth graders are doing significantly better in reading since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took control of the schools, but eighth graders have shown little improvement, according to the results of a national reading test released on Thursday.

headline: What We’re Reading: Viruses and Etiquette

headline: S.E.C. Investigating Whether Brokers Fulfilled Obligations in May 6 Plunge
text: WASHINGTON — The enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether market makers and brokerage firms fulfilled their legal obligations to provide liquidity in the markets by buying and selling stock during the sharp market drop of May 6, the chairwoman of the agency said Thursday.

headline: Toll in Kabul Suicide Attack Included U.S. and Canadian Officers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The suicide bomber who struck in Kabul on Tuesday killed four high-ranking NATO officers who had been on a brief visit, military officials confirmed Thursday. They said the victims included two full colonels, an American and a Canadian, and two American lieutenant colonels.

headline: China Aims to Stifle Tibet’s Photocopiers
text: BEIJING — The authorities have identified a new threat to political stability in the restive region of Tibet: photocopiers. Fearful that Tibetans might mass-copy incendiary material, public security officials intend to more tightly control printing and photocopying shops, according to reports from the Tibetan capital, Lhasa.

headline: Thursday Reading: A Tax Exemption for Diet Soda
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: World Science Festival to Start With a Big Bang
text: It will be vaudeville such as never seen before, at least in this galaxy. The opening-night gala of the World Science Festival at Alice Tully Hall on June 2 will feature a medley of songs, dances and musical performances revolving around science like moons around a planet. Among the numbers, members of Lincoln Center’s “South Pacific” production will sing Tom Lehrer’s “Derivative Song,” a bit of equation-solving patter, organizers said. Danny Burstein, also of “South Pacific,” will perform Monty Python’s “Galaxy Song.” Kelli O’Hara, another Broadway star, will sing “Stardust.” Tiler Peck of New York City Ballet and David Hallberg of American Ballet Theater will dance the Adagio section of Balanchine’s “Apollo.” Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Project will render a Persian musical version of the Icarus story.

headline: Sabbatini Basks in Homeland’s World Cup Opportunity

headline: Rezo Gabriadze Cancels New Lincoln Center Festival Show
text: Bad news for those who were hoping to see a new theatrical work by the Georgian puppeteer Rezo Gabriadze at the Lincoln Center Festival this summer. Because of  health problems, Mr. Gabriadze who is in his 70s, has not finished “Ermon and Ramona”— billed as a “tragic tale of two trains in love”— which had been scheduled for July 20-25, the festival announced. However, there is a silver lining: to replace the canceled show, Mr. Gabriadze’s company, the Tbilisi Municipal Theater Studio, will revive a past work, “The Battle of Stalingrad,” about the Nazi siege. That piece sold out when it was performed at the Lincoln Center Festival in 2002. People who bought tickets for “Ermon and Ramona” can either use them for the performance of “The Battle of Stalingrad” or request a refund.

headline: A New Coach for France, but Not Until After the World Cup
text: France has not yet faltered in its World Cup bid, but already the country’s soccer federation has announced a new coach: Laurent Blanc will take over Les Bleus after Raymond Domenech leads the team this summer in South Africa. Blanc, who coached Bordeaux to the Ligue 1 title in 2009, resigned from the club last week.

headline: Bangkok Grows Calm, but Social Divisions Remain

headline: Upfronts: The CW’s Fall Schedule
text: The CW network is making changes on every weeknight next season, beginning with a new night for “90210,” its two-year-old remake of the classic Beverly Hills drama.

headline: What Is Stieg Larsson’s Secret?
text: Michiko Kakutani reviews Stieg Larsson’s final novel, “The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest,” in the Friday Weekend section. Since the first book in the so-called Millennium Trilogy, “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” was published in Sweden in 2005, the books have become a global publishing phenomenon. They’ve sold more than 3.5 million copies in the United States, and people who couldn’t wait for “Hornet’s Nest” to be published here have been going so far as to buy the British edition, which came out in late 2009. Ms. Kakutani says the novels’ central appeal is their heroine, Lisbeth Salander, “a damaged sprite of a girl who becomes a goth-attired avenging angel, who can hack into any computer in the world and seemingly defeat any foe in hand-to-hand combat.”

headline: 18 Orgies Later, Chinese Swinger Gets Prison Bed
text: BEIJING — In public, he was a twice-divorced computer science professor dedicated to his students and to caring for an elderly mother who suffers from Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: Strangers: A Problem That Won’t Go Away
text: Several famous street artists may be lurking around town, but their work hasn’t resonated nearly as strongly as the simple line-and-text message one anonymous stencilist recently put down near 23rd Street. It has the simplicity of an urban walker’s muttered refrain: Please, get out of my way.

headline: On Our Radar: The ‘Anthropocene’ Era
text: Humanity leaves its mark on the planet: the Holocene epoch is giving way to “the Anthropocene.”

headline: Deep Impact: Considering Personal Connections to Writers and Artists
text: Overview | Why and how do literature and the arts promote personal connections? What writers’ and artists’ lives and works have spoken to us and helped shape us? In this lesson, students identify and investigate a writer or other artist with whom they feel a strong connection and express their relationship with this person, his or her life and works in writing.

headline: Sizing Up Divorce Risk
text: We’ve all heard the statistic that 50 percent of marriages end in divorce, but recent data on marriage and divorce rates show that isn’t true. Divorce rates have actually declined since peaking in the 1970s, and 10-year divorce rates have dropped dramatically with each generation.

headline: Calderón Calls for Restoring Assault Weapons Ban
text: Updated: President Felipe Calderón of Mexico argued before a joint meeting of Congress today that his country was making extraordinary investments in confronting drug-fueled crime – a problem that also affects the United States — as he implored lawmakers in Washington to restore a ban on the assault weapons often used by traffickers.

headline: On (Surprisingly Quiet) Parisian Night, a Picasso and a Matisse Go Out the Window
text: PARIS — A lone hooded man who squirmed through a broken window and evaded security alarms stole five paintings by Picasso, Matisse and other artists overnight Wednesday from the Paris Museum of Modern Art in a brash theft of art valued at $114 million to $127 million.

headline: A Movable Beast
text: The only indication that I was outside a slaughterhouse was the blood dripping from a pipe jutting out of a pristine white trailer. I’d driven right past the Lego-like set-up — a refrigerated semi-trailer with a half-trailer and a delivery truck stuck onto it — parked behind Eklund’s old farm-machinery shop in Stamford, N.Y. With a former Hollywood trailer situated nearby, I took it for a movie set. But I was looking at the first mobile slaughterhouse for large animals in the Northeast.

headline: TimesCast | May 20, 2010
text: Today, the E.P.A. orders BP to use a less toxic approach in the Gulf, fallout from Republican Senate candidate Rand Paul's remarks and columnist Nick Kristof on assignment in Africa.

headline: A Treatment for Declining Sales
text: Epidavros Day Spa, in Mt. Kisco, N.Y., bears the name of the ancient Greek coastal town known as a healing sanctuary. But by the end of 2009, owner Sandra Rovira says the spa’s atmosphere was anything but restorative.

headline: I Meant to Do That: ‘The Pee-wee Herman Show’ Coming to Broadway
text: The next time you hear Pee-wee Herman snidely ask, “I know you are but what am I?,” the correct answer is: Broadway-bound.

headline: Big Infusion for a Solar Builder
text: Alstom, the French energy giant, has taken a $55 million stake in BrightSource Energy, a solar power plant builder backed by Google, Morgan Stanley and other investors.

headline: Calling on Sony and Others, Google Makes a TV Move
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google recruited a solid lineup of high-tech companies on Thursday to help it introduce Google TV, a new service that merges the predictable world of television programming with the more chaotic expanse of the Web.

headline: Man Charged With Scalding Infant

headline: The Identity Theft Threat From Copiers
text: While it’s common knowledge that leaving sensitive personal information in trash bins or on computers raises the risk of identity theft, many consumers may not be aware that copying sensitive information on certain copy machines could also put them at risk.

headline: As MF Global Posts Loss, Corzine Promises Change
text: Jon S. Corzine may not be running an enterprise on the scale of New Jersey or Goldman Sachs anymore. But as his new firm, MF Global, reported a $96.5 million loss attributable to shareholders on Thursday, the former politician and banking executive acknowledged he had a lot of work to do.

headline: Edwin E. Kintner, Nuclear Power Pioneer, Dies at 90
text: Edwin E. Kintner, who played a role in early efforts to harness nuclear power and later witnessed its destructive potential while heading the decontamination of the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant after a partial meltdown, died on May 7 in Exeter, N.H. He was 90.

headline: At Old Friends, Rekindling Memories
text: Michael Blowen, a former Boston Globe movie critic, runs Old Friends, a thoroughbred retirement facility in Georgetown, Ky., with a branch outside Saratoga Springs in Greenfield Center, N.Y. Old Friends, home to more stakes winners than any other farm in history, is the thoroughbred version of the Motion Picture and Television Country House and Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif.

headline: Choose Your Own Fiscal Adventure
text: Good news, America: Using the online budget simulator created by the good people at the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, I’ve successfully reduced our debt to a relatively stable 60 percent of G.D.P. by the year 2018. All it took was means-testing Social Security and raising the retirement age to 68, keeping health care reform in place but slashing its insurance subsidies by 20 percent, increasing cost-sharing and premiums for Medicare and raising the retirement age to 67, passing tort reform, returning food stamp spending to 2008 levels, slashing subsidies for agriculture and biofuels, cutting the federal workforce by 5 percent across the board, cutting earmarks by 50 percent, converting the home-mortgage deduction to a smaller credit, replacing the tax deduction for employer-provided health care with a flat credit, increasing the gas tax by 10 cents a gallon, cutting foreign aid and military spending by $200 billion, drawing down troop levels in Iraq and Afghanistan to 60,000 in 2016, taxing life insurance benefits, letting the Bush tax cuts expire for high earners and partially phasing them out for the middle class, eliminating the state and local tax deduction, and cutting out a lot of smaller things as well.

headline: University of California Tries to Trim Down
text: After scrutinizing its financial profile in the mirror of its budget, the University of California has decided it’s time for a makeover.

headline: City Jobless Rate Is Lowest Since Last June
text: In the latest sign that New York’s economy is on the rebound after a long recession, the city’s unemployment rate fell below 10 percent last month for the first time since August, to its lowest rate since June.

headline: A Dictator in His Own Words and Images
text: CANNES, France — As the title suggests, “The Autobiography of Nicolae Ceausescu” is hardly a conventional historical documentary. Andrei Ujica’s three-hour-plus found-footage epic, screening out of competition at the Cannes Film Festival, recounts the life of the Romanian dictator as Ceausescu himself saw it — or, as was often the case, stage-managed it. Devoid of explanatory titles and voice-overs, the film assembles a composite portrait of Ceausescu solely through the existing visual record: the speeches he gave, the parades thrown in his honor, the state visits he made (to the United States, China, Britain and, most memorably, North Korea) and the home movies of family vacations and hunting expeditions.

headline: How the Magic Can Bounce Back
text: Wayne Winston is a professor of decision sciences at Indiana University’s Kelley School of Business.

headline: Corker Questions Need for 2 Market Regulators
text: Senator Bob Corker (left), Republican of Tennessee, says he believes that Congress has “lacked the courage” to deal with what he believes is a core issue of the financial crisis: the separation of market regulation authority among two agencies.

headline: Old and New Wests Meet in Arizona Desert Foothills
text: CAVE CREEK, Ariz.

headline: Making a Scenic Splash
text: When we bought the house in 1999, there was a pool. Just not this one. We’d get our friends to visit by mentioning “the pool,” but when they’d arrive, it was an inflatable pool from Target. This pool went in later as part of the very major renovation and landscaping job we did. We took the house down to its studs and rebuilt it completely. And we put the pool on the horizon line so when you’re in it, you see nothing but the wineries and state parks that surround us.

headline: Researchers Say They Created a ‘Synthetic Cell’
text: The genome pioneer J. Craig Venter has taken another step in his quest to create synthetic life, by synthesizing an entire bacterial genome and using it to take over a cell.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: Video: First TTXGP Electric Motorcycle Race at Infineon
text: The first electric motorcycle race in the American TTXGP series was held at Infineon Raceway in Sonoma, Calif., on Sunday. Shawn Higbee, a competitor in the AMA Superbike series, won the 11-lap event aboard a bike built in a collaboration between Zero Motorcycles and Agni Motors, the electric motor manufacturer responsible for the winning machine in last year’s electric race on the Isle of Man.

headline: A Punk Pixie’s Ominous Past
text: Lisbeth Salander, Stieg Larsson’s fierce pixie of a heroine, is one of the most original characters in a thriller to come along in a while — a gamin, Audrey Hepburn look-alike but with tattoos and piercings, the take-no-prisoners attitude of Lara Croft and the cool, unsentimental intellect of Mr. Spock. She is the vulnerable victim turned vigilante; a willfully antisocial girl, once labeled mentally incompetent by the state’s social services system, who has proved herself to be as incandescently proficient as any video game warrior.

headline: When Patients Don’t Fill Their Prescriptions
text: Not long ago, a doctor friend recounted the story of a patient who had recently died from complications stemming from the treatment of a chronic bleeding problem. “I felt terrible about it,” said my friend, who had cared for the patient for several years. “Something didn’t add up in this case, and I had to wonder if it was my fault, if I had done something wrong.”

headline: Judge Orders Arrest of Lindsay Lohan
text: A judge issued a warrant for Lindsay Lohan’s arrest and set bail at $100,000 on Thursday after the actress failed to show up for a mandatory court hearing in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lohan had gone to Cannes for the film festival there and, according to her lawyer, Shawn Chapman Holley, her passport was stolen, preventing her from returning to the United States in time for her hearing. Judge Marsha Revel of Los Angeles County Superior Court also revoked Ms. Lohan’s probation, which she had been on after two arrests in 2007 on charges of drunken driving. Mr. Holley said Ms. Lohan would be back in the United States by Friday evening. If she makes bail, the judge has stipulated that she will be prohibited from drinking alcohol and required to wear an alcohol monitoring bracelet and undergo weekly drug testing.

headline: Civil Rights | Brand New Dandies
text: This week marks the debut of Social Primer for Brooks Brothers, a collection of bowties created in collaboration with the ultimate WASP-y men’s store and K. Cooper Ray, the dapper Southern-born men’s-wear blogger.

headline: Do You Take Your Medicine?
text: Doctors often are criticized for prescribing too many drugs. But the reality is, many patients don’t bother to take them anyway.

headline: Expedia Opens Gay Travel Store
text: Starting today, travelers booking hotels through Expedia.com can search for “LGBT-welcoming” hotels or visit Expedia’s new LGBT store.

headline: The Afterlife of Stieg Larsson
text: THE THIRD VOLUME in Stieg Larsson’s immensely successful Millennium trilogy, “The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest,” finally goes on sale here this month. Except for “Harry Potter,” Americans haven’t been so eager for a book since the early 1840s, when they thronged the docks in New York, hailing incoming ships for news of Little Nell in Charles Dickens’s “Old Curiosity Shop.” That was before Amazon. This time, particularly impatient readers simply paid a premium and ordered the new book from England, where it came out months ago (though with the apostrophe in a different place, making the “Hornet” plural).

headline: Bennett Won’t Wage Write-In Campaign
text: Senator Robert F. Bennett, the Utah Republican, announced Thursday that he would not wage a write-in campaign to retain his seat after being toppled at a state convention earlier this month.

headline: Agency Orders Use of a Less Toxic Chemical in Gulf
text: GRAND ISLE, La. — Local and state officials here voiced desperation on Thursday as their fears became far more tangible, with oil from the BP spill showing up on shore as tar balls, sheens and gooey slicks.

headline: The Morning Skate: Flyers Look to Put Habs on the Ropes
text: You know things are going well for the Flyers, winners of six straight games, when Ville Leino emerges as a playoff hero. With Detroit, Leino played so softly that, according to The Detroit News’s Chris McCosky, Red Wings Coach Mike Babcock converted his name into a verb for a player who was easily taken off the puck, as in “he got Leinoed on that play.”

headline: More Cabdrivers May Lose Licenses, City Says

headline: Some Novel Ideas for Improving Retirement Income
text: Employees have increasingly been forced over the last few decades to take responsibility for ensuring they have enough savings to last through retirement. But many of them are making inadequate saving decisions and finding themselves facing financial difficulty in retirement.

headline: Home Cooking | Your Apartamento or Mine?
text: Marco Velardi, Omar Sosa and Nacho Alegre, the trio of twenty-somethings behind the Milan- and Barcelona-based indie design magazine Apartamento have a flair for celebrating the reality of everyday life. And for just plain celebrating. The magazine is an invitingly DIY affair, and so was Tasca, Apartamento’s three-night pop-up food event at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, which, true to form, seemed to take its cue from an inescapable reality of all design fairs: that while it’s stimulating to take in the latest Kartell creation or to shake hands with a Bouroullec, the most pressing issue on everyone’s overloaded mind — particularly after a forced march through an arena-sized exhibition hall — isn’t rapid prototyping or just how post postmodernism is. It’s dinner: Where it’s going to happen, when and with whom.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: A Hindu devotee walks down stairs leading to the Ganges River in Varanasi, India.

headline: In ‘Lost,’ Mythology Trumps Mystery
text: As the end of “Lost” approaches  an extravaganza that will stretch from Sunday night into Monday morning on ABC  the natural urge is to join in the final frenzy of speculation. Who will live, who will die, and what did it all mean?

headline: Toxic Substances Agency Draws Fire
text: The federal Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry has been under tough Congressional scrutiny over the last two years for what critics assert are flawed evaluations of health risks at the nation’s worst contaminated sites. Now the Government Accountability Office has issued a report detailing some problems with the agency’s internal policies and inconsistent monitoring by its management.

headline: Bill Passed in Senate Broadly Expands Oversight of Wall St.
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday approved a far-reaching financial regulatory bill, putting Congress on the brink of approving a broad expansion of government oversight of the increasingly complex banking system and financial markets.

headline: High School Athletes Detail Troubles With Concussions to a House Panel
text: While her fellow high school freshmen in Alexandria, Va., might travel to Washington or stage a mock congress to connect with government affairs, Sarah Rainey joined the real thing Thursday when she testified before the House Committee on Education and Labor about her harrowing experience with sports concussions.

headline: Financial Bill Clears Crucial Hurdle in Senate Vote
text: The Senate voted Thursday afternoon to close debate on a far-reaching financial regulatory bill, putting Congress on a  path to approving a broad expansion of government oversight of the increasingly complex financial markets that is intended to prevent a repeat of the 2008 economic crisis, David M. Herszenhorn of The New York Times reports from Washington.

headline: Synthetic Cells and the Energy Quest
text: A remarkable paper published online today by the journal Science could — emphasis on could — signal the start of an energy revolution, and more generally a manufacturing revolution. By “start” I mean this could be akin to the first twitch of a runner’s leg as she positions herself for the opening pistol shot of a marathon, not a sprint.

text: The journalist turned crime-thriller writer died in 2004, shortly after submitting the “The Girl With a Dragon Tattoo” and its two companion novels to his publisher.

headline: Fact-Checking the Résumé of a Student Accused of Lying
text: The article by my colleague Katie Zezima and me in Wednesday’s Times about Adam Wheeler, who is accused of gaining admission to Harvard using fabricated transcripts and references, concluded with a reference to a résumé that The New Republic says it recently received from him. In the document, part of an internship application, Mr. Wheeler claimed proficiency in Old English, Classical Armenian and Old Persian.

Ditto Nick Nolte’s, which resulted in possibly the best mug shot ever. The area is also where a Swedish game developer in 2006 totaled a Ferrari Enzo at a reported 162 miles per hour.

headline: Dublin Is Out; Ice Box and at Least One Dude Are In
text: Dublin, who was seventh in the Kentucky Derby and fifth in the Preakness Stakes, was withdrawn from consideration for the Belmont Stakes on Thursday, the trainer D. Wayne Lukas said. It is the first time since 2006, when Barbaro broke down, that no horse will have run in all three Triple Crown races.

headline: Correction
text: A picture caption with a dance entry in the Week Ahead report last Sunday misidentified a choreographer whose work Mikhail Baryshnikov was scheduled to perform from Wednesday through Saturday in the program “Unrelated Solos” at the Baryshnikov Dance Center. She is Susan Marshall  not Steve Paxton, who is a dancer and choreographer scheduled to perform his own work. The caption also imprecisely described the program. Mr. Baryshnikov is performing works by Ms. Marshall, Alexei Ratmansky and Benjamin Millepied; he is not performing any other works.

headline: Gay Couple in Malawi Get Maximum Sentence of 14 Years in Prison
text: JOHANNESBURG — Two gay men in Malawi, convicted this week of unnatural acts and gross indecency, were sentenced Thursday to the maximum penalty allowed by law, 14 years of hard labor in prison.
