headline: A Mediterranean Village on the East River
text: Astoria, perhaps best known as the Mediterranean hub of Queens, brims with life on warm evenings, as the cafes flicker with lights and laughter fills the streets. There are pockets of Greeks and Arabs in the area, women rustle by wearing hijabs, and some of the buildings are painted white and turquoise, just like the island houses of the Aegean. But hurry. The neighborhood — just 15 minutes from Midtown on the N or W line — is changing as other ethnic groups arrive and chain stores supplant little shops.

headline: Jets Taking It Slow With Sanchez’s Return
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Jets quarterback Mark Sanchez spent Wednesday evening at the White House where, at a state dinner honoring President Felipe Calderón of Mexico, he came face to face in the receiving line with Mexico’s first lady, who pulled a Sanchez jersey from her purse.

headline: Vain Glorious | Fix the Oil Spill With Hair Clippings?
text: Who: Matter of Trust, a nonprofit environmental organization, and participating salons, including Bumble and bumble and Salon AKS.

headline: A New Chef for the Waverly Inn
text: It looks as if John DeLucie’s sabbatical from the Waverly Inn to open the Lion may be longer lasting. Eric Korsh, who worked in a number of New York restaurants, including Prune  and Patroon, has been named the new executive chef at the Waverly, according to Sean MacPherson a partner in that Greenwich Village restaurant with Graydon Carter. Mr. Korsh had been a chef and owner of Eloise in Sebastopol, Calif., starting in 2008, but that restaurant has closed. Mr. MacPherson said Mr. Korsh would not substantially change the menu of comfort food for which the Waverly is known. Mr. DeLucie, the executive chef and a partner at the Waverly, took a leave of absence to open the Lion this year.

headline: As CNN Considers Prime-Time Changes, Spitzer’s Name Is Mentioned
text: As CNN scrambles to replace Campbell Brown on its wounded prime-time lineup, the most intriguing name purportedly on the channel’s list is that of Eliot Spitzer, the disgraced former governor of New York.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Capitol Hill and Elsewhere
text: President Felipe Calderón of Mexico argued before a joint meeting of Congress on Thursday that his country was making extraordinary investments in confronting drug-fueled crime — a problem that also affects the United States — as he implored lawmakers in Washington to restore a ban on the assault weapons often used by traffickers. He also assailed as a “terrible idea” the new Arizona law that allows law enforcement officials to detain anyone suspected of being in the country illegally, repeating the criticism he made Wednesday, when he spent much of the day with President Obama. Mr. Obama himself called the law “misdirected.” A close look at Slide 1 shows some members of Congress wearing blue, yellow and red wristbands protesting Arizona’s new law. They were handed out by Representative Joe Baca of California.

headline: A Mediterranean Village on the East River
text: Astoria, perhaps best known as the Mediterranean hub of Queens, brims with life on warm evenings, as the cafes flicker with lights and laughter fills the streets. There are pockets of Greeks and Arabs in the area, women rustle by covered head to toe in burqas, and some of the buildings are painted white and turquoise, just like the island houses of the Aegean. But hurry. The neighborhood — just 15 minutes from Midtown on the N or W line — is changing as other ethnic groups arrive and chain stores supplant little shops.

headline: Iraqi Politicians Break Bread, but Not the Standoff
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s leading politicians — government ministers, clerics and sheiks, not a single woman among them — gathered Thursday over a lunch of roasted meat and rice at the arabesque Peace Palace on the bank of the Tigris. It was an effort to foster reconciliation after the country’s intensely disputed election, but ended with little of it in evidence.

headline: Live (?) Video of the Oil Spill
text: On Wednesday, Representative Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts wrote a letter to Lamar McKay, chief executive of BP America, asking the company to make its real-time camera feed of the gulf oil spill publicly available.

headline: British Minister Accused of Airbrushing Twitter History
text: Writing on Twitter on Thursday, the editor of The Guardian, Alan Rusbridger, noted that Britain’s new minister for culture, media and sport, Jeremy Hunt, had been accused of trying “to un-tweet” some critical comments he posted on the social-networking site a few weeks ago about a political rival he now finds himself working alongside.

headline: Parents Paying (More) for Public Schools
text: Our school district’s budget passed this week, as did 92 percent of those in New York State, but it is a shell of its former self. While my tax rate will increase about 3 percent under the new budget, the district will actually decrease its spending by 1.1 percent, leading to the dismissal of seven teachers and 34 aides and assistants. The cuts come in the wake of the $1.4 billion the state plans to cut from the education budget, leading districts to cut their own.

headline: Yankees Make Moves to Bolster Bench
text: With Jorge Posada on the disabled list with a hairline fracture of the right foot for at least the next three weeks, the Yankees recalled Chad Moeller from Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes Barre to serve as the backup catcher for Francisco Cervelli. Moeller, an 11-year veteran, hit .231 in 41 games for the Yankees in 2008.

headline: Dell Posts a 52% Increase in Profit, but Still Awaits a Wave of Corporate PC Buying
text: Dell presented Wall Street with tidy first-quarter results on Thursday, but the numbers lacked some of the luster presented by other technology bellwethers in recent weeks.

headline: Onyewu Says He’s Not the Same — He’s Better
text: PRINCETON, N.J — Oguchi Onyewu participated in full training with the United States soccer team Thursday, but he had a hitch in his stride as he ran sprints and seemed to be favoring one leg slightly.

headline: Dish Subscribers May Lose Weather Channel
text: Update: Friday, 7:15 a.m.: Dish Network is still carrying the Weather Channel despite the midnight expiration date on the carriage contract, according to several subscribers who posted updates early Friday on Twitter. This strongly suggests that the two companies are still at the negotiating table, trying to hammer out a deal.

headline: The Week Ahead: May 23 — 29
text: Television

headline: Greater New Yorkers | Pinar Yolaçan
text: The Moment homes in on five artists from Greater New York, an exhibition that runs May 23–October 18 at PS1 in Queens.

headline: Travel Deals: Air France Discounts New Premium Seats To Europe
text: It’s not as swanky as Les Affaires (Business) or La Première (First) class, but Air France’s  Premium Voyageur class has plenty of perks that outshine economy. And this summer, the airline is offering trans-Atlantic discounts of up to 40 percent on its newest class on nonstop flights between Newark and 42 European cities.

headline: Parents of Young Adventurers
text: The Learning Network blog is asking students what they think about 13-year-old Jordan Romero, who is somewhere on Everest right now, aiming to become the youngest person to summit that mountain. “Do you think someone that age has the physical and emotional maturity to take on an extreme-altitude endeavor like this?” my colleagues at that blog wonder. Students over the age of 13 are allowed to leave their opinions.

headline: Judge Extends Deadline for Filmmaker to Give Outtakes to Chevron
text: 6:59 p.m. | Updated A federal judge on Thursday pushed back the deadline for a documentary filmmaker to turn over 600 hours of outtakes to Chevron. On May 6, Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of United States District Court in Manhattan granted a motion ordering the filmmaker, Joe Berlinger, to turn over the footage from his movie “Crude” as part of a lawsuit accusing Texaco, now owned by Chevron, of polluting the Amazon rainforest in Ecuador. The company’s lawyers argued that the footage would show misconduct by the other side. Mr. Berlinger’s lawyers argued that his work should be protected under reporter’s privilege.

headline: With Sheraton, Downtown Brooklyn’s Makeover Continues
text: With a Barney’s Co-Op coming to Atlantic Avenue and new rental buildings bringing a steady stream of young professionals to downtown Brooklyn, the opening of a 321-room Sheraton on Duffield Street gave hotel executives and city officials yet another reason to proclaim it a great day for the borough.

headline: Calderón Again Assails Arizona Law on Detention
text: WASHINGTON — President Felipe Calderón of Mexico escalated his assault Thursday on the Arizona law that allows law enforcement officials to detain anyone suspected of being in the country illegally, calling it a “terrible idea.” He offered the criticism in a particularly privileged forum: before a joint meeting of Congress.

headline: Riding Her Own Current, in Almost Any Genre
text: Nobody but Barb Jungr, the brilliant British chanteuse who inserts sticks of emotional dynamite into songs of every vintage, would dream of connecting “Lazy Afternoon,” the Jerome Moross-John Latouche standard from “The Golden Apple” with the 1968 Small Faces hit, “Itchycoo Park.” And on Wednesday evening at the Metropolitan Room, Ms. Jungr found a powerful link. Prefacing the songs with a monologue about youth and age and how when you’re young you have time to burn, she showed how both are really about lying around and getting high.

headline: Onstage, a Single Band, With a Split Personality
text: Matt Wilson unveiled an expanded version of his working group at Iridium on Wednesday night — or maybe it was two groups, depending on the whim of the moment. Near the end of the first set, it was possible to imagine a borderline across the stage, as half of the musicians played a Mozart string quartet and the other half gradually muscled in, urgent and bleary, with “What Reason Could I Give,” an enigmatic ballad by Ornette Coleman. The two halves were working at cross purposes, but with a playful air.

headline: The Shadow in the Park
text: Q. On a 1924 aerial map of New York City, I came across an image of a large building where Inwood Hill Park now is. Do you have any idea what this building was? It’s huge! ... Maria Carmicino, Manhattan

headline: I’m Green and the Kids Are a Pain, but It’s a Wonderful Life, Donkey
text: The not-so-scary villain in “Shrek Forever After,” the fourth and supposed final installment of the “Shrek” franchise, is a sleazy mortgage lender for a bank that’s too big to fail. Well, not exactly.

headline: In Britten Concert, Choirs Sing Patron Saint’s Praises
text: Musicians often complain about the difficulty of persuading suspicious airport officials to let them take their instruments on board. The composer Benjamin Britten, a pacifist and conscientious objector, actually had musical scores confiscated during World War II by British customs inspectors, who suspected that they concealed illicit code. One such manuscript was that of his “Hymn to St. Cecilia,” a work glowingly rendered by the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys at St. Thomas Church on Wednesday evening as part of a Britten concert conducted by John Scott.

headline: A Tour Through Motown, Disco and More
text: Diana Ross was all smiles, glitter and efficiency at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night, a part of a nationwide tour straightforwardly devoted to her hits. “Tonight is truly, truly about memories,” she announced.

headline: Two Decades Apart, but So Very Balanchine
text: At the New York City Ballet on Wednesday evening you could have watched either “Agon” or “Chaconne” and called it a night. Even though those ballets, which were bookends for the program, are separated by nearly 20 years — the first is tough, the second more silken — they are quintessential Balanchine.

headline: Look at Him Now, Remembering All That
text: It is 40 years since Mikhail Baryshnikov first danced, as a member of the Kirov Ballet, in the West. Today people arrive at a Baryshnikov performance with layers of ideas about his fame and his past. He gives them beautifully elegant moves that include those ideas while putting them into proportion. His manner is unassuming, modest, very charming. It is easier now to see the marvelous grace and phrasing he brings to basic steps, though his expressiveness often seems more complex than ever.

headline: Deadline Extended in ‘Crude’ Documentary Lawsuit
text: A federal judge on Thursday pushed back the deadline for a documentary filmmaker to turn over 600 hours of unused footage to Chevron. On May 6, Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of United States District Court in Manhattan granted a motion ordering the filmmaker, Joe Berlinger, to turn over the footage from his movie “Crude” as part of a lawsuit accusing Texaco, now owned by Chevron, of polluting the Amazon rain forest in Ecuador. The company’s lawyers argued that the footage would show misconduct by the other side; Mr. Berlinger’s lawyers argued that his work should be protected under reporter’s privilege. The judge agreed that Mr. Berlinger enjoyed the privilege but ruled that it could be outweighed if the material was not confidential and “likely relevant” to the case. In a contentious hearing on Wednesday over whether the judge would stay his decision, Judge Kaplan made it clear he believed the chances of overturning were slight. In a 20-page opinion issued on Thursday, he wrote that he would not grant the stay but would delay the deadline for enforcing the subpoena from Friday until May 24, allowing all parties time to present arguments to the court of appeals. Lawyers for Mr. Berlinger filed an emergency appeal with the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, denouncing Judge Kaplan’s “unprecedented, blunderbuss order” and asking that it be overturned.

headline: The Brave
text: Baseball’s true golden age appears, increasingly, to have been the 1950s and ’60s, decades of change that left many fans fearing the game was being taken away from them or becoming something they scarcely recognized. The innovations have been well documented, and often lamented: the franchises that deserted New York and its scruffy urban pastures for the shiny lure of California; the dwindling number of afternoon games, played in weekday heat, in favor of televised night contests, with their floodlit lunar glare; the decline of the multitiered farm system and its flavor of the county fairground.

headline: Pee-Wee Herman to Get a Broadway Playhouse
text: “The Pee-wee Herman Show,” the original stage comedy that set that manic man-child character portrayed by Paul Reubens on a path to cult stardom, will transfer to Broadway in the fall for a six-week run, its producers announced on Thursday. Though Mr. Reubens, right, 57, is generally much more low-key than his impish, bow-tie-clad alter ego, his impending date with Broadway stirred a little Pee-wee style exuberance within him. “I can hardly believe it,” he said Wednesday evening in a telephone interview. “Honestly, I’ve been pinching myself.” In January, Mr. Reubens revived “The Pee-wee Herman Show” at Club Nokia at L.A. Live in Los Angeles, the first time in several years that he had played the character for a sustained period. In New York, “The Pee-wee Herman Show” is scheduled to begin performances on Oct. 26 at the Stephen Sondheim Theater (the rechristened Henry Miller’s Theater).

headline: Stars And Science at Alice Tully Hall
text: The opening-night gala of the World Science Festival at Alice Tully Hall on June 2 will feature a medley of songs, dances and musical performances revolving around science like moons around a planet. Among the numbers, members of Lincoln Center’s “South Pacific” production will sing Tom Lehrer’s “Derivative Song,” a bit of equation-solving patter, organizers said. Danny Burstein, above, also of “South Pacific,” will perform Monty Python’s “Galaxy Song.” Tiler Peck of New York City Ballet and David Hallberg of American Ballet Theater will dance the Adagio section of Balanchine’s “Apollo.” Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Project will render a Persian musical version of the Icarus story. The event will be directed and produced by Damian Woetzel, the former New York City Ballet dancer, and the first half of the evening will be a tribute to the physicist Stephen W. Hawking, who is expected to attend. Mr. Woetzel said the idea was to show “how arts can inspire scientific thinking and the imagination in general.” The second half features the world premiere of a piece by Philip Glass incorporating text derived from a children’s book by Brian Greene, a physicist and organizer of the festival. The evening begins a week of lectures, discussions and performances that poke into various nooks of science.

headline: Tesla Buys Toyota Plant, Where It Will Build Electric Sedan
text: 9:07 p.m. | Updated In a joint news conference on Thursday, Tesla Motors and Toyota Motor announced that Tesla had bought the recently closed Nummi assembly plant in Fremont, Calif., where it intends to make its Model S luxury electric sedan and other future models.

headline: Puppeteer Cancels Lincoln Center Show
text: Bad news for those who were hoping to see a new theatrical work by the Georgian puppeteer Rezo Gabriadze at the Lincoln Center Festival this summer: because of health problems, Mr. Gabriadze, who is in his 70s, has not finished “Ermon and Ramona”  billed as a “tragic tale of two trains in love”  which had been scheduled for July 20-25, the festival announced. But there is a silver lining: to replace the show, Mr. Gabriadze’s company, the Tbilisi Municipal Theater Studio, will revive a past work, “The Battle of Stalingrad,” about the German siege in World War II. That piece sold out when it was performed at the Lincoln Center Festival in 2002. People who bought tickets for “Ermon and Ramona” can either use them for the performance of “The Battle of Stalingrad” or request a refund.

headline: Warrant Is Issued for Lohan’s Arrest
text: A judge issued a warrant for Lindsay Lohan’s arrest and set bail at $100,000 on Thursday after the actress failed to show up for a mandatory court hearing in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lohan, left, went to Cannes for the film festival there, and, according to her lawyer, Shawn Chapman Holley, her passport was stolen, preventing her from returning to the United States in time for her hearing. Judge Marsha Revel of Los Angeles County Superior Court also revoked Ms. Lohan’s probation, which she had been on after two arrests in 2007 on charges of drunken driving. Mr. Holley said Ms. Lohan would be back in the United States by Friday evening. If she makes bail, the judge has stipulated that she will be prohibited from drinking alcohol and required to wear an alcohol monitoring bracelet and undergo weekly drug testing. ... Also in Los Angeles, the former rap mogul Marion Knight, known as Suge, was arrested for investigation of assault with a deadly weapon early Thursday and held on $65,000 bail, The Los Angeles Times reported. Investigators said that another man accused Mr. Knight of robbing him in south Los Angeles on Wednesday night.

headline: Lead-Up to Final Round of ‘idol’ Wins for Fox
text: Crystal Bowersox and Lee DeWyze advanced to the final round of “American Idol” as Wednesday’s results edition of the Fox reality show drew the largest audience in prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 18.5 million viewers tuned in to “Idol” at 9 p.m., helping to lift Fox to No. 1 on the night. CBS earned second place, garnering 13.1 million at 9 for “Criminal Minds” and 11.3 million at 10 for “CSI: NY.” ABC placed third as the season finale of “Modern Family” delivered 10 million viewers at 9. NBC ranked fourth.

headline: A ‘Lost’ Booker Prize To a J. G. Farrell Novel
text: It’s a little late, but the best book of 1970 has finally won its Man Booker Prize. “Troubles,” by J. G. Farrell, who died in 1979, was crowned the winner of the Lost Man Booker Prize, a one-time-only award honoring the books that missed out on an opportunity to win the Booker Prize in 1970, the Booker Prize Foundation announced on Wednesday. When the Booker Prize, Britain’s most prestigious literary award, began, it was awarded retrospectively — until 1971, when the rules changed and it was given to the best book of the year in which it was awarded. That left out most of the books published in 1970, which were never eligible to win the Booker. Three judges winnowed those books down to a shortlist of six, and the public cast online votes on the rest. “Troubles,” a novel set in Ireland in 1919, won 38 percent of the votes.

headline: Sentencing of Concrete Testing Company Owner Is Postponed
text: The owner of the former leading concrete testing company in New York began serving time behind bars Thursday, a day before his formal sentencing for his corruption conviction.

headline: From Paris, With Love and Desperation
text: Au revoir, Fabrice!

headline: U.S. Outlines Moves After Bomb Suspect’s Arrest
text: In the days after a naturalized United States citizen from Pakistan was arrested on charges he left a car bomb near Times Square, hundreds of federal agents were deployed in different cities to prevent future attacks, prosecutors said in a letter that was unsealed on Thursday.

headline: From Sony, the World's Smallest 'S.L.R.'
text: Sony's Alpha NEX-5 has a sensor the size of an SLR, packed into a camera that is half the size.

headline: His Shaggy World (and Welcome to It)
text: As everybody knows, the Upper West Side of Manhattan is the home of overeducated, comfortable but not superrich liberals and the psychotherapists who treat their garden-variety neuroses. Edward Koren, whose whimsical cartoons of shaggy animals and hairy, bemused humans are a staple of The New Yorker, is the neighborhood’s poet laureate.

headline: Images That Steered a Drive for Freedom
text: It’s unwise to be sniffy about popular culture.

headline: Painter as Architect, Swinging a Wrecking Ball
text: Julie Mehretu’s paintings show buildings, and sometimes whole cities, in various states of undoing. Plans, blueprints and elevations come under attack from floating geometric shapes and calligraphic ink squiggles, in a kind of rational-gestural standoff. Her canvases are so vast and densely layered that they’re experienced in an urban way, too: block by block, corner by corner.

headline: Movie and Film Series Listings
text: MOVIES

headline: Theater Listings: May 21 — 27
text: THEATER

headline: A Standout Student at Ribald High
text: THERE’S a lot that can be gleaned about the sensibility of “The Hard Times of RJ Berger” from its opening minutes. In its very first scene, “Hard Times” finds its title character, a nebbishy high school sophomore, in bed, engaged in an act of self-gratification. The intrusion of his unsuspecting mother brings his efforts to a halt, but her innocent touch on his side only results in the inadvertent completion of the act. Roll credits.

headline: Sitcomish Squalor and Dysfunction
text: The new play “Oliver Parker!” at the Cherry Lane Theater might qualify as offensive  certainly it strives mightily for that dubious laurel  if it were not so patently artificial. Set in a noisome New York apartment, where an adolescent boy and his alcoholic older companion enact a sitcomic relationship that gradually reveals darker shadings, Elizabeth Meriwether’s comedy combines the crass vulgarity that passes for wit in teen-aimed Hollywood movies with a well-worn stage cliché, the scabrously dark story of family dysfunction.

headline: The Sergeant of Shrink Learns Empathy
text: WOULD you invite Jillian Michaels, the fitness wizard who embodies the words “no pain, no gain,” into your home? Viewers of “The Biggest Loser,” who for eight seasons have watched Ms. Michaels reduce the overweight and wheezing into sobbing heaps through her drill-sergeant tactics, might think twice.

headline: Hope for Celebrity Collaborations? | Nina Persson Moves Beyond the Cardigans
text: In the onslaught of notoriously bad (or plainly unimpressive) celebrity-meets-fashion collaborations, it’s generally with a grudging manner that the fashion industry receives yet another famous name turned designer aspirant. So when the Swedish label Hope announced that it had created a 10-piece fall 2010 capsule collection with Nina Persson, the lead singer of the Cardigans, there was reason to be skeptical. First off, unlike so many singers, actors and models, Persson professed that she had never thought about designing a line before Hope’s Ann Ringstrand approached her. Chatting with Ringstrand, there was more to the story than that.

headline: World Events Rumble at Cannes
text: CANNES, France  Of all the filmmakers whose work is in the 63rd Cannes Film Festival  including the French lion Jean-Luc Godard, who growled at us yet refused to show his face, and the Iranian filmmaker Abbas Kiarostami, who has seemingly metamorphosed into a Euro-style art-house auteur  none have had the impact of the man who could not attend. Jafar Panahi is an Iranian director who was asked to join the competition jury, but is currently in a jail in his country for his political views. On Tuesday, a message from him in which he asked to contact his family and speak with a lawyer, was posted on the Web site of the French journal La Règle du Jeu (laregledujeu.org).

headline: Body Slam to the American Dream
text: The fights are fixed, and the man-crushing body slams are faked. But the energy that radiates from “The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity,” Kristoffer Diaz’s crazy-like-a-fox comedy about television wrestling, is the real thing. This delightfully muscular production, which opened Thursday night at the Second Stage Theater, courses with the vital sap of an able-bodied satire enjoying a rollicking love-hate affair with its subject.

headline: Redskins’ Moss Is Linked to Galea
text: Washington Redskins wide receiver Santana Moss arranged to be treated by a Toronto doctor last fall before the doctor’s assistant was arrested on suspicion of smuggling unapproved drugs into the United States, according to a person briefed on the investigation.

headline: Revisiting Combat Outpost Reilly
text: The summer fighting season has returned to southern Afghanistan, which means the Obama administration’s and Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal’s counterinsurgency effort here will face some of its most difficult tests. Temperatures are soaring over 100 degrees, the opium crop has been harvested and laborers are freed up for fighting in environmental conditions that strain equipment and challenge even the most fit Western soldiers and Marines.

headline: A Trove of Bugattis
text: Photographs from 1964 show a rare collection of Bugattis being packed for shipping.

headline: The Greening of Lincoln Center
text: Reconstructive surgery or just a little nip and tuck? That’s the question that troubled the people who run Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts for years. As other cultural organizations around the country embarked on extravagant building projects in the late ’90s and the early ’00s, the center’s various institutions bickered about how to compete, given their aging campus. Eventually they settled on a modest course of treatment, hoping that a few careful incisions here and a stitch or two there would be as effective, and produce a result as beautiful, as new construction.

headline: A Music Hall Sways to Its Own Beat
text: There is usually a moment early in any concert at Bargemusic when even listeners who have spent many evenings hearing music in this converted coffee barge find themselves wondering why they couldn’t have found something to do on dry land. The barge, moored on the Brooklyn side of the East River — near the River Café and a stone’s throw from the Brooklyn Bridge — is a boat, after all, and it is given to the gentle rocking motion that mariners love and landlubbers can find mildly disconcerting.

headline: Lincoln Center’s New Look
text: Images of the renovated central and north plazas.

headline: Vintage Rock and Midlife Heartaches
text: Bettye LaVette

headline: Long Night’s Journey Into Sleep
text: For my parents’ 50th wedding anniversary, our family went to Ireland to discover our roots and had the best sleep of our lives in a little town in County Sligo. Ten years later, we’re still talking about that incredible night. Forget the windblown scenery, the pink salmon, the monastic ruins and the wild swans at Coole. Forget my daredevil sister practically dangling off the Cliffs of Moher. “Remember that sleep,” we say, shaking our heads. “Wasn’t it just amazing?”

headline: Avedon Town House on the Market
text: WHEN Olivier Sarkozy, the half-brother of President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, bought the Upper East Side town house where Richard Avedon had lived and kept a studio for more than 30 years, he knew he had taken charge of a slice of American culture. Mr. Avedon’s fashion and portrait photographs had helped define the nation’s sense of style and beauty for decades.

headline: Fear and Loathing on Wall St. Over Derivatives
text: 9:24 p.m. | Updated With the Senate’s approval of a sweeping financial regulatory bill, Wall Street is facing painful changes in the ways it does business, especially those involving derivatives trading.

headline: Brass in Pocket | Carl Auböck’s Exquisite Curios
text: “How did I never hear of him?” According to Patrick Parrish, the co-founder of the inspired TriBeCa design gallery Mondo Cane, that’s what people say when they find themselves pulled into the strange and luminous world of the Viennese designer Carl Auböck (1900-57). A master of elemental materials like brass, leather, wood and horn, Auböck had a flair for exquisitely turned curios — paperweights, corkscrews, pipe holders — that still exert a magnetic pull, as the 300 or so objects now on view at Mondo Cane amply attest.

headline: The Ocean Blue as Art Abstract
Jane Lauder Apartment for Sale
text: JANE LAUDER traded her Park Avenue penthouse for a triplex penthouse in NoLIta five years ago, and now she has finally put the Upper East Side apartment on the market for $8.9 million.

headline: 2011 Kia Sorento
text: With the new Sorento, Kia is aiming to compete with better-known crossover models.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Man Sells His  Castle
text: BILL SOFIELD — the designer who put his imprint on Gucci stores and who is now creating Tom Ford shops globally — always needs a project.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Photo Replay: May 20
text: A view of the day in sports, including the hockey world championships in Germany.

headline: Search for de Soto in Southeast Georgia
City to Seek a New Operator for Tavern on the Green; Trump Expresses Interest After Labor Talks End
text: And now: The Visitor Center and Snack Bar on the Green.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Venture Capitalists Fight a Tax Increase
text: Venture capitalists are fighting a bill, introduced in the House of Representatives on Thursday, that would sharply increase the taxes they pay.

headline: Rights and Design
text: Images from two new exhibits about art of the Civil Rights Era.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: A Nazi Businessman Risks His Life to Do the Right Thing? It’s True
text: The German actor Ulrich Tukur brings an understated intensity and psychological depth to the title role of “John Rabe,” a sweeping historical film that exalts a largely unsung real-life hero who risked his life to do the right thing. Rabe, a Nazi German industrialist stationed in China, is credited with saving the lives of more than 200,000 Chinese during the infamous 1937 massacre in Nanking (now Nanjing) in the second Sino-Japanese war. In a matter of weeks, the Japanese slaughtered at least 200,000 civilians and prisoners of war and committed mass rape.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Bad and Badder Guys, One With a Debt to Pay
text: The stars of the jovial Irish gangster comedy “Perrier’s Bounty” are clearly having such a good time that it is tempting to give the benefit of the doubt to this ramshackle caper about a cheeky Dublin roustabout on the run from a loan shark. But if you look below the hearty performances of Cillian Murphy, Jim Broadbent and Brendan Gleeson, actors who can make the most insubstantial blarney seem significant, what you discover is a hectic, ultraviolent romp that is inordinately pleased with its own sardonic nihilism. Its witless conceits include a couple of gay goons and an organization of attack-dog owners whose vicious pets wreak the film’s ultimate justice.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Rays’ Speed Doesn’t Let Up
text: Even as the Tampa Bay Rays stole base after base Wednesday night, Yankees catcher Francisco Cervelli could not help but admire their moxie.

headline: Dad Yields the Last Word
text: THIS is my last Generation B column. I start a new assignment for the newspaper soon. Like a lot of the people I have written about over the last year and a half, I’m being reinvented.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Spitzer’s Name Arises as CNN Tries to Fill a Seat
text: As CNN moves to replace Campbell Brown in its struggling prime-time lineup, the most intriguing name on the channel’s list is Eliot Spitzer, the disgraced former governor of New York.

headline: Yes, He’s a Jerk, but There’s Something About Ben
text: In a few months, Gordon Gekko will return  not a moment too soon!  in Oliver Stone’s sequel to “Wall Street.” But you don’t have to wait that long to see Michael Douglas playing a disgraced businessman. In the meantime there is “Solitary Man,” a sharp, small-scale comedy of male misbehavior that turns out to be one of this dreary spring’s pleasant cinematic surprises.

headline: An Incinerator Becomes Harrisburg’s Money Pit
text: HARRISBURG, Pa. — Officials here decided seven years ago to borrow $125 million to rebuild and expand the city’s enormous trash incinerator, which the federal government had shut down because of toxic air pollution.

headline: Mine Executive Favors Outside Inquiry Into Deaths
text: WASHINGTON — The top executive of Massey Energy told a Senate subcommittee Thursday that an outside agency should investigate the April 5 explosion at his company’s Upper Big Branch mine, which killed 29, because otherwise the Mine Safety and Health Administration, the agency now in charge, would have to evaluate its own performance.

headline: Study Finds Certain Drugs Can Keep Some Forms of Cancer in Remission Longer
text: Using certain anticancer drugs for years at a time can help keep some types of cancer in remission longer, doctors reported Thursday.

headline: The Challenge of Capturing Carbon
text: To the Editor:

headline: Keeping Score: Rating Jeter and Reyes on Small Scale
text: Managers love to talk about the little things, like team chemistry and moving runners over. All of these things have value, but statheads usually take these statements to mean: “My team isn’t very good and I’m trying to save my job.”

headline: Ms., Miss or Mrs.: Marital Status Shouldn’t Matter
text: To the Editor:

headline: Student Protests Tie Up Campuses in Puerto Rico
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — The seven entry gates on the largest campus of the University of Puerto Rico system remained chained shut on Thursday. Beyond improvised barricades were hundreds of students in makeshift camps, some with portable showers and stoves, hardly engaged in the typical college springtime routine of studying for final exams and preparing for graduation.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,064 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Wall Street Ethics
text: To the Editor:

headline: Good, Bad and Silly of TV’s Upfront Week
text: HERE is a look at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the annual television upfront week, which took place around Manhattan from Monday through Thursday.

headline: Our Notions of Decency and Justice
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pay-What-You-Want Has Patrons Perplexed
text: CLAYTON, Mo. — The country’s latest experiment in pay-what-you-want eating started last weekend when a cafe run by Panera Bread, one of the fastest-growing chain restaurants in the country, began refusing payments from customers in this affluent St. Louis suburb and politely asked them instead to “take what you need, leave your fair share” in wood-and-plexiglass lockboxes.

headline: A Grayer America
text: With the first baby boomers turning 65 next year, the Census Bureau projects a sharp increase in the share of people in the age group compared with those between 20 and 64. Depending on the influx of younger immigrants, the number of people 65 and older per 100 in the younger group would rise to 35 in 20 years from 22 now, the bureau said Thursday, raising potential political conflicts over everything from Social Security to school board budgets. By 2030, a quarter of non-Hispanic whites would be 65 and over. By 2050, the black, Hispanic and Asian elderly, now 20 percent of the older population, would make up 42 percent.

headline: Top Recipients of Public Pensions in New York
text: Roughly 3,700 retired public workers in New York are getting pensions of more than $100,000 a year. The New York Times collected this public information from the state’s two pension funds and four of the five city funds.

headline: California: Missing Cross Is Replaced
text: There is a twist in the case of the missing cross. Mysteriously (or miraculously?) a cross has arisen at the spot in the Mojave Desert where a large one at the center of a dispute over church and state disappeared this month. The new cross, about six inches taller than the seven-foot one stolen from the rock it sat on since the mid-1990s, was discovered Thursday by National Park Service workers. Just as it was a crime to steal it, it is also a violation to put up a monument in a federal preserve without government authorization. The cross is being taken down.

headline: The U.S. in Afghanistan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Versatile Bartlett Is Example of Rays’ Winning Ways
text: The Tampa Bay Rays were down to their last out in the 2008 World Series. It was Jason Bartlett’s turn to bat, in a one-run game with a runner in scoring position. But he never got the chance.

headline: More Disclosure for Drug Research
text: Medical researchers receiving United States grants who have been paid more than $5,000 by drug companies like GlaxoSmithKline must publicly disclose the payments under rules proposed by regulators. Universities would have to list those “significant financial interests” on their Web sites once the rules take effect this year, Francis Collins, the director of the National Institutes of Health, said Thursday in a conference call with reporters. While current rules require researchers on United States-financed projects to notify their universities of financial ties that exceed $10,000, institutions do not have to post that information online.

headline: Colorado: A Rougher Road to Tenure
text: Gov. Bill Ritter Jr. signed a law on Thursday that will make it more difficult for teachers to get tenure and will require that at least half of their annual evaluation be determined by the academic growth of their students. Currently, rookie teachers earn tenure after three years in the classroom, but under the new law they will earn that status only after proving themselves effective, as defined by a state panel, for three straight years. The American Federation of Teachers backed the measure, and the National Education Association opposed it.

headline: That Post-Championship Season
text: In 2004 Bnei Sakhnin became the first soccer team from a small, primarily Arab town in northern Israel to win the National Cup and the right to represent the nation in European competition. That’s when the players  Arab, Jewish and foreign-born  realized that they had also become something much more: unwilling symbols of ethnic unity upon whose shoulders rested the pride and expectations of the country’s 1.4 million Arab citizens.

headline: Suspended Over Naughty Words in H.I.V. Class, Teacher Wins U.S. Ruling
text: A Staten Island middle school teacher who was removed from the classroom after allowing her eighth graders to use vulgar terms during a lesson on H.I.V. won her first battle against the city in federal court on Thursday, when a judge overruled a city effort to dismiss her case.

headline: Padded Pensions Add to New York Fiscal Woes
text: In Yonkers, more than 100 retired police officers and firefighters are collecting pensions greater than their pay when they were working. One of the youngest, Hugo Tassone, retired at 44 with a base pay of about $74,000 a year. His pension is now $101,333 a year.

headline: Bollywood Does Vegas
text: On the whole, American audiences remain stubbornly immune to the charms of the Bollywood romance, a fact that “Kites” is determined to change. A carefully calibrated assault on resistant international markets, the movie harnesses English, Hindi and Hispanic talent to an everything-but-the-kitchen-sink plot, replaces dancing with explosions, and choreographers with stunt specialists. The result is a lovers-on-the-lam blast of pure pulp escapism, so devoted to diversion that you probably won’t even notice the corn.

headline: Texas School Board Set to Vote Textbook Revisions

headline: Maine Leaves Game After Five Pitches

The twist is that the antihero of this tale isn’t a brooding Italian-American gangster or a machine-gun-wielding Cuban-American psycho  he’s a young, wide-eyed, obstinate Hasidic Jew from Brooklyn.

Herszenhorn of The New York Times reports from Washington.

headline: Leave Larry David at Home

Thing is, my husband is much snottier than I am, though everyone thinks he’s charming. He hates spending time with people he might not like, and there’s no way he’s going to share a meal with them. What should I do?

headline: City’s Jobless Rate Drops Below U.S. Rate

headline: A Disgraced Rider’s Admissions, and Accusations

headline: Six Years Later, Takahashi Is Facing the Yankees Again

It was an exhibition at the Tokyo Dome on March 28, 2004, just before the Yankees opened that season in Japan against Tampa Bay.

headline: Cuomo Tries to Influence Who Will Succeed Him

headline: Repression Is Alleged Before Vote in Ethiopia

headline: The Being of Being
text: Why is there something instead of nothing? That is a child’s question, but it also haunts the imaginations of physicists and mathematicians. What they know is that the matter and antimatter created in the Big Bang should have canceled each other out, leaving nothing instead of the something we call the universe. Why that didn’t happen may have been partially revealed in a recent experiment in the Tevatron — a particle accelerator — at Fermilab, in Batavia, Ill.

headline: In Europe, Google Faces New Inquiries on Privacy

headline: Breaking Up Bottlenecks

That study also found that commuters in the Bay Area spend 32 more hours in traffic a year than the average driver who spends 22 hours per year on the highway. From San Rafael to Menlo Park, Caltrans and local officials have tried to alleviate the problems.

And then he made a prediction. “They are a great team,” said Cashman, emphasizing the word are. “We think we are a great team, and that we’ll both be relevant, along with Boston, this entire season.”

headline: Alderman Gives a Critic of the Mayor a New Vest and New Duties

headline: France: Cameron Travels to Meet Sarkozy and Merkel

Mr. Cameron, leader of a party known for its aversion to closer European integration, planned to devote his first overseas trip since coming to power last week to smoothing ties with Continental Europe.

headline: Madagascar: Military Mutiny Rattles the Capital
text: Just 14 months after a military coup toppled its elected government, Madagascar faced the possibility of another takeover Thursday as elements of the military gendarmes staged a mutiny in Antananarivo, the capital. The rebels and security forces exchanged gunfire and, according to Malagasy radio reports, two gendarmes were killed. Late in the day, Reuters reported that security forces had overrun the barracks where the renegade gendarmes were holed up, quoting a colonel as saying, “They have fled.”

headline: In Blue Island Office, Seeing Recession’s Toll
text: If south suburban Blue Island long ago was a geological mix of boulders and other debris dropped by a glacier, the Illinois Department of Human Services office there now is a moraine of human travail deposited by the recession.

headline: Somalia: President Reverses Premier’s Firing
text: Somalia’s president, Sheik Sharif Sheik Ahmed, on Thursday reversed his decision to fire the prime minister. Sheik Sharif had ordered Prime Minister Omar Abdirashid Ali Sharmarke to step down on Monday after a no-confidence vote in Parliament. Mr. Sharmarke had refused to resign, saying the move was unconstitutional. On Thursday the president said that he had determined, after consulting with lawyers, that the decision was not legal and had asked Mr. Sharmarke to stay on.

headline: Vazquez Packs His Bat

Burton, a former dean of Columbia Business School and an accountant whose fervent advocacy of transparency in financial reporting and for a greater role for accountants in public life led him to prominent positions in the federal and New York City governments, died in Manhattan on Sunday. He was 77. The cause was kidney failure, said his daughter, Eve.

headline: Bag Bans Expand From Plastic to Paper, and More in Friday’s Bay Area Report
text: Establishing a Bring-Your-Own-Bag Ethic Is Not Easy | Three years after San Francisco enacted a pioneering plastic-bag ban, Bay Area jurisdictions have developed a patchwork of rules to indicate exactly what carriers are appropriate for consumers to use when schlepping purchases home. After Oakland’s law was successfully challenged — its analysis of the environmental dangers of plastic bags did not encompass the potential problems with paper replacements — San Jose began a comprehensive analysis of both before moving forward. The idea is to encourage people to bring their own reusable bags when they shop, but anecdotal evidence gathered by Sabra Chartrand, who reported this article, indicates that is a quixotic goal.

headline: I Don’t Like Ike’s. But I Might. (For a Price.)
text: The saga of Ike’s Place, the all-too-successful sandwich shop in San Francisco’s Castro neighborhood, has captured the public’s imagination. The tiny doorway eatery has amassed a huge following in the foodie community, bringing mobs of hungry mouths to a once-quiet block.

headline: Another Blow to UBS Equity Capital Markets Unit?
text: Steven Barg, UBS‘s head of global capital markets for Asia, has resigned from his post, marking another blow to the bank’s regional equity capital markets franchise, Reuters reported, citing a source with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Stray Questions for: Hannah Tinti
text: Hannah Tinti is the author of a story collection, “Animal Crackers,” and a novel, “The Good Thief.” She is the editor of One Story magazine.

headline: Playing the Logo Game
text: Thinking about a restaurant name as a logo can get you into trouble. You start turning a simple “H” into an upside down fork, or you see a sailor’s compass and imagine the “S” as the first letter of Southfork. You start looking at every word on every billboard, letterhead, article of clothing or jar in your refrigerator. And then the logo of the refrigerator itself. Logos are baffling little critters; they can mislead, they can please or they can cover the globe like a virus — Samburu tribesmen in Kenya sport the Nike swoosh.

headline: Late Surge Sends Wall Street Higher
text: What began as another losing day for the stock market on Friday ended instead with a gain, a welcome close to a tumultuous week during which the Dow Jones industrial average lost more than 400 points.

headline: Greenlight’s Gold Offerings Attract Investors
text: Greenlight Capital‘s gold bets have attracted more than $130 million in two recent private offerings from investors eager to join in the hedge fund’s bets on the precious metal, which is seen as protection against inflation, MarketWatch reported.

Relations with the French tennis federation were once so embittered that she was refused financial help and was obliged to qualify for the French Open instead of being offered one of the wild cards routinely reserved for talented young French players like her.

headline: Sampler: Tesla, Toyota, Lance Armstrong and Harvey Milk
text: Telsa and Toyota to Build Electric Cars at Nummi Plant | Electric car manufacturing is coming to Fremont. Tesla Motors announced on Thursday that it would work with Toyota to build its Model S sedan, an all-electric vehicle, at the shuttered Nummi plant. The deal is expected to create more than 1,000 jobs. Toyota will invest $50 million in Tesla, which will buy the plant, where it plans to produce 20,000 electric vehicles a year. The cars are to have a range of 300 miles and sell for $50,000. The operation will occupy a small part of the plant, leaving room for more models to be made there in the future. [The San Jose Mercury News]

headline: Avolon Lands $1.4 Billion in Financing

headline: Tip of the Week: Getting Apple to Play With Windows
text: Apple’s own hardware products generally play well together, but Windows users trying to get iPods and iPhones working properly with PC hardware can sometimes have a tougher time of it. To help troubleshoot issues, the Windows edition of iTunes includes a series of diagnostic tests that might help identify and resolve connectivity and synchronization problems. To use the tests, go to the Help menu in iTunes and choose the Run Diagnostics option. Apple has more on what to expect at its support site.

headline: Disc Burning, Video Editing and More, From Nero

When Nero recently released its $80 Multimedia Suite 10 (Windows only), I thought I’d play around with the software to see if I’ve been missing something.

headline: What Do Older Generations Misunderstand About Yours?
text: What misconceptions do you think older generations — such as your parents’, teachers’ or grandparents’ — have about your generation? What do you wish you could explain to them to dispel some of these beliefs? How do you think the time and place in which those generations were raised have influenced them? How do you think you’re being shaped differently by growing up today?

headline: Bridging the Gap: Considering Factors That Shape Generations
text: Overview | What events and trends both reflect and shape each generation? In this lesson, students compare their generation with one or more older generations and the reasons for differences between them. They generate defining events they have experienced and consider how those events have shaped who they are — and will become. They then interview a member of another generation about his or her own defining experiences.

headline: Sales of Albums Plummet for Week
text: Combine the downward trend of album sales with a week of no major releases and what do you get? One of the fewest number of album sales, 5.3 million, since Nielsen SoundScan started its tracking in 1991. Topping this week’s Billboard album chart is Justin Bieber’s “My World 2.0” (Island), its fourth time in the spot, with sales of just over 60,000, barely escaping the specter of being the lowest-selling No. 1 album in SoundScan’s history. (The  “Dreamgirls”  soundtrack sold about 300 fewer copies in January 2007.) Lady Antebellum’s “Need You Now” (Capitol Nashville), the year’s most consistent seller, stayed at No. 2 for the fourth straight week, moving 54,000 copies. The top new album was “High Violet” (4AD) from the National, selling 51,000 copies, good enough for No. 3. At No. 4 was AC/DC’s  “Iron Man 2”  (Columbia) with 48,000, and Dead Weather’s “Sea of Cowards” (Warner Brothers) was No. 5 in its first week out with 45,000 in sales.

headline: Graphic-Book Best Sellers: The Delight of the Strip

Entering the hardcover list at No. 4 is the second installment of “Bloom County: The Complete Library.” This volume reprints the adventures of Opus and friends from the daily and Sunday strips that ran Sept. 27, 1982 through July 1, 1984. The first of the five volumes planned by IDW hit the hardcover list at No. 1 in October last year.

headline: Arguing Three Strikes
text: One day last fall, Norman Williams sat drinking hot chocolate with his lawyer, Michael Romano, at a Peet’s coffee in Palo Alto, Calif. At an outdoor table, Williams began to talk about how he’d gone from serving a life sentence at Folsom State Prison to sitting there in the sun. “After being shut down for so many years. I didn’t believe it,” he said of the judge’s decision to release him in April 2009.

headline: Now Accessorizing | Forbidden Fruit
text: Whether Eve plucked an apple or a pomegranate from the tree may be up for debate, but there’s no doubt which fruit is sexier. Especially as interpreted by the New York-based jeweler Tito Pedrini, whose 18 karat gold “Pomegrani” earrings are as mouthwatering as the ancient superfruit itself. Comprised of pink opal, mammoth ivory or black onyx sprinkled with pink sapphire “seeds,” the earrings are $2,800. Call (212) 888-3355 for an appointment or go to titopedrini.com.

text: With great fanfare, law enforcement officials and prosecutors from around the state rolled out new guidelines for conducting identification lineups and photo arrays at a news conference in Manhattan this week.

headline: First Lady Lit
text: Laura Bush has made it to about Mile 25 in the political memoir marathon — past the mega advance, past the leaked details, past the saturation-point publicity, all the way to No. 1 on The New York Times’s best-seller list. If she needs a boost for the final stretch, she might remind herself of Lady Bird Johnson’s experience more than 40 years ago.

headline: Mob Justice
text: Thomas Perry, that smiling sadist who gets his kicks from outfoxing readers, is at his wicked best in STRIP (Otto Penzler/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26) . Like any self-respecting gangland thriller, this witty specimen has a cast of touchy mobsters killing one another over money and turf and petty grievances. But because a devious mind is manipulating the genre conventions — allowing unpredictable characters rather than precision-tooled action to drive his story — the rules of the game are constantly changing.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: INNOCENT,  by Scott Turow (Grand Central, $27.99.) Exercising a crafty fascination for the intricacies of repetitive behavior, Turow brings back Rusty Sabich, now a judge and on trial again, 23 years after the enormously popular “Presumed Innocent.”

headline: Paperback Row
text: LOVE AND OBSTACLES: Stories,  by Aleksandar Hemon (Riverhead, $15.) The narrator of these eight linked stories follows a Hemonesque trajectory. He’s an aspiring poet in Sarajevo and an exile in Chicago. And like Joseph Conrad, who is evoked in the first story’s first sentence, he is an Eastern European who becomes celebrated for his writing in English; he specializes, as he says, in “those brainy postmodern setups everybody likes so well.” Hemon is the author of a novel and two other story collections.

headline: Up Front: Lloyd Grove
text: In 2003, Lloyd Grove, who reviews Sarah Ellison’s “War at The Wall Street Journal” on Page 16, had been at The Washington Post for 23 years when Mort Zuckerman brought him to New York to work at The Daily News — and to challenge Page Six, the gossip column in Rupert Murdoch’s New York Post.

headline: Paper Chase
text: Until their tastefully muted leave-taking from Dow Jones & Company and The Wall Street Journal — having sold their birthright for a mess of Rupert Murdoch’s pottage — the Bancrofts could boast a family tradition of extravagant exits. The Boston Brahmin Clarence Barron, a 5-foot-5, 330-pound patriarch known to his descendants as Grandpa (he was so fat he employed a male nurse to button his trousers and tie his shoes), paid $130,000 for Dow Jones in 1902 and pretty much invented financial journalism. He cried out “What’s the news? Are there any mes­sages?” just before expiring in 1928. In 1982, Barron’s rowdy granddaughter Jessie Bancroft Cox, another plump, no-­nonsense Bostonian, was attending a celebration of Dow Jones’s 100th anniversary at the “21” Club when she keeled over after delivering a typically profane lament for her beloved Red Sox.

headline: More Blumenthal Claims on Vietnam Emerge
text: WASHINGTON — Broader newspaper archival searches have continued to turn up claims by Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut that he was a Vietnam War veteran, even though he did not serve in the war.

headline: That Summer in Italy
text: For someone who grew up in a not particularly exciting city in Canada — yes, yes, that was a joke — the sexual revolution was something that happened to someone else, somewhere else, most probably in that enchanted, faraway Gomorrah called the United States. I had certainly read about the sexual revolution in magazines like Time, and I was nothing if not eager to take it beyond the theoretical. But the knock on the door never came, and when I left for the rough-and-tumble of New York in the 1970s, I was still waiting for the sexual rebellionto conscript me into its welcoming bosom.

headline: THL to Sell Michael Foods to GS Capital Partners
text: THL Partners agreed on Friday to sell Michael Foods, a producer and distributor of egg and dairy products, to the Goldman Sachs‘s private equity arm, GS Capital Partners, in a deal valuing the company at $1.7 billion.

headline: Souping Up Spring Vegetables
text: In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman reminds us that soups aren’t just a winter food. She writes:

headline: Truth and Reconciliation
text: In 1976, a 15-year-old boy named Jakkie de Wet comes home from boarding school at Easter to Grootmoedersdrift (Grandmother’s Crossing), the farm in the Cape Province of South Africa that has been in his mother’s family for generations. On such visits, Jakkie’s handsome, bullying father, Jak, usually drags the boy off on manly expeditions — hiking treacherous kloofs (ravines) and ridges, and scrabbling up (and falling off) rock faces — both to monopolize him and to vengefully deprive his mother, Milla, and his nanny, Agaat, of his company. The father is at war with both women; resentful of his wife’s sentimentality and agricul­tural know-how, and mistrustful of Agaat’s bond with his reticent son.

headline: In Baghdad Ruins, Remains of a Cultural Bridge
text: BAGHDAD — Report No. 25, dated April 4 and written by Col. Qais Hussein, was clinical, the anonymous survey of an explosion in a city where explosions are ordinary.

headline: Putting a Zero on Federer Is a Rare Achievement
text: There may be only one tennis player in the world who wishes he had taken it a bit easier on Roger Federer. Reto Schmidli, 31, a police officer and part-time psychology student in Arlesheim, Switzerland, is the only person who has “double-bageled” Federer, that is, beaten him, 6-0, 6-0.

headline: Stumbling Upon A Great Ale
text: I was at a little banquet the other evening, a beautiful warm spring day in Manhattan. It was a family event, with nothing at all to do with food or drink, held on the 12th floor of the New York Athletic Club on Central Park South, where numerous party rooms all open onto a huge, gorgeous balcony looking west, with a great view of Central Park. What could be more pleasant, I wondered, then sitting out in the evening sun, speaking with nice people, with a good beer?

headline: Sheet Music Apps for Your Phone
text: Thursday’s Phone Smart column, on music-related apps, does not touch on sheet music software for mobile devices, but here are two new services worth mentioning.

headline: School Bus Accident Injures 21 Children
text: Updated, 4:04 p.m. | A school bus accident on East 63rd Street between First and Second Avenues around 10:30 Friday morning injured 21 children and three adults, the authorities said. None of the injuries were life threatening. Contrary to earlier reports that the bus collided with a car, there was no other vehicle involved, the police said. The bus was from P.S. 149 in East New York Brooklyn, en route to a class trip to Lincoln Center.

headline: Weekend Competition: Define Courage
text: This weekend, Schott’s Vocab is soliciting definitions of courage:

headline: Obama Mandates Rules to Raise Fuel Standards
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama ordered the government on Friday to develop tougher fuel-efficiency standards for cars and trucks, advancing the fight against climate change without waiting for Congress.

headline: Just One Look
text: In 2002, Jennifer Portnick taught exercise classes and worked out almost every day. But the fitness company Jazzercise turned her down for a franchise because she weighed 240 pounds (height 5-foot-8). Jazzercise told Portnick that its instructors “must have a high muscle-to-fat ratio and look leaner than the public.” Portnick complained to the San Francisco Human Rights Commission, under a law the city had passed in 2000 to prevent discrimination on the basis of appearance. She won. And Jazzercise changed its tune nationally, saying it would no longer demand thinness from its instructors.

headline: Internal Injuries
text: In the harrowing stories that make up A. L. Kennedy’s fourth collection, “What Becomes,” people buckle under the weight of misfortune: dead children, dismembered limbs, failing marriages, spurned hearts. It might be surprising, then, that it’s such a relief to read them. But with a few tart lines, Kennedy frees us from the irritating notion that we should all feel lucky, grateful, cheerful, healthy and happy.

headline: Obsessing About an Underbite
text: Can concern about an ordinary body flaw like misaligned teeth be a sign of a serious psychiatric disorder? That’s the question explored by Dr. Katharine A. Phillips, a professor of psychiatry at Brown Medical School. Dr. Phillips recently joined the Consults blog to answer readers’ questions about body dysmorphic disorder, a troublesome condition in which people become so obsessed with perceived body defects that they refuse to leave the house or socialize.

headline: Landis’s U-Turn
text: Sports isn’t the best place for moral dilemmas. People watch sports to escape their moral dilemmas. Rooting for a particular team or athlete didn’t used to require a visit to your spiritual guidance counselor of choice. Now, the conundrums are everywhere. Cardinals fans find themselves swallowing hard with Mark McGwire in the dugout. Yankees fans have had to become drug-user forgivers (Alex Rodriguez, Andy Pettitte, Jason Giambi ...). Houston fans will find themselves rooting for linebacker Brian Cushing beyond all their better judgment, as people in Philadelphia do for Michael Vick.

headline: U.S. Approves Google’s Deal for AdMob
text: SAN FRANCISCO — After an intensive six-month review, Google won approval from the Federal Trade Commission on Friday for its $750 million acquisition of the mobile advertising company AdMob.

headline: The Madness of King George
text: The Yankees are again world champions, and it seems a shame that the man widely credited with having returned the club to its historic glory has been diminished by age and infirmity.

headline: Milo’s People
text: Olen Steinhauer’s 2009 thriller, “The Tourist,” introduced a tantalizing new word to the lexicon of espionage fiction. Steinhauer’s “Tourists” are members of a tiny fraternity of C.I.A. operatives who move ceaselessly around the world, cultivating informers, ferreting out double agents and assassinating America’s enemies. Like black-ops versions of Ryan Bingham, the corporate hit man played by George Clooney in “Up in the Air,” these covert agents exist unencumbered by relationships or a home. The novel’s main character, Milo Weaver, is a secret operative with multiple identities who has grown sick of the rootlessness, duplicity and amorality of Tourism. One of the few members of the group who are also family men, Weaver longs to settle down in Brooklyn with his librarian wife and 6-year-old stepdaughter, but he’s drawn back repeatedly into a life of murder and deceit.

headline: The End of the Beginning for Financial Reform
text: The Senate’s passage of the Wall Street regulatory bill marks the near-completion of only one part of the financial reform process. If the Great Depression is any guide, not only will there be more Congressional action, but also industry and regulatory reform. This is only the beginning.

headline: ‘Molly Fox’s Birthday’
text: In the dream I was walking through the streets of a strange city, in a foreign country I did not recognise. I was weary, and my feet were sore because I was wearing shoes that were too small for me. Then, as is the way in dreams, I was all at once in a shoe shop and my grandmother was there. She did not speak, neither in greeting nor to explain what she was doing there, but handed me a pair of shoes made of brown leather. I put them on and they fitted perfectly.

headline: Tribune Facing Legal Battle With Creditors
text: The Tribune Company will have to wait another week before its reorganization plan is sent to creditors for a vote, and the plan will have to include letters warning that approval will lead to protracted legal battles, a judge ruled on Thursday, according to Reuters.

headline: Method Writing
text: Here’s an exercise for the blocked writer: Write what you don’t know about what you know. That’s the approach the unnamed narrator of Deirdre Madden’s ninth novel chooses. She takes her friend of 20 years and revisits memories from their times together, wondering whether she truly knows her. And in doing so, she conquers her writer’s block and creates this novel, “Molly Fox’s Birthday.”

headline: In Japan, a Night With Michael Jackson Memorabilia
text: June 25 will mark a year since Michael Jackson’s death. And to pay tribute to him a Japanese promoter is holding a sleepover of sorts inside the Tokyo Tower where the Neverland Collection — a huge assortment of the singer’s personal objects including his 1967 Rolls-Royce Phantom, antique piano, clothes and costumes from his “Thriller’’ video — has been on view since May 1.

headline: ‘Making Haste From Babylon’
text: Prelude

headline: One on One: Dale Dougherty, Make Magazine and Maker Faire
text: Dale Dougherty will be overseeing the annual Maker Faire in San Mateo, Calif., this coming weekend. If you haven’t heard of this event, think about a typical fairground but with robots and giant mousetraps. Also, instead of traditional balloons that you tie to your wrist, some of the balloons at Maker Faire travel into space and take pictures of the earth.

headline: Detainees Barred From Access to U.S. Courts
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court ruled Friday that three men who had been detained by the United States military for years without trial in Afghanistan had no recourse to American courts. The decision was a broad victory for the Obama administration in its efforts to hold terrorism suspects overseas for indefinite periods without judicial oversight.

headline: The New Staples | Cherry Blossoms
text: In The New Staples, Merrill Stubbs of Food52 highlights ingredients making their way into restaurants and refrigerators, plus recipes from top chefs to help you put them to use.

headline: Regulators Approve Google Deal for AdMob
text: In a reversal of regulatory fortune, Google has won approval from the Federal Trade Commission for its $750 million acquisition of the mobile advertising company AdMob, The New York Times’s Brad Stone reported on Friday.

headline: Pakistani Major Among 2 New Arrests in Bombing
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — An army officer and a businessman have been detained as part of a widening inquiry into a circle of Pakistanis who had some knowledge of the activities of the man charged with trying to set off a crude car bomb in Times Square, according to a Western official and an American intelligence official.

headline: Temperance to Excess
text: On Jan. 17, 1920, America went dry. The 18th Amendment had been ratified a year earlier, banning “the manufacture, sale, or transportation of intoxicating liquors” within the United States and its territories. Thus began the era of Prohibition, a nearly 14-year orgy of lawbreaking unparalleled in our history. The 18th Amendment was a rarity in that it limited the rights of the individual rather than the activities of the government, thereby guaranteeing a hostile reception. As such, it holds the distinction of being the only constitutional amendment ever to be repealed. Which leads one to ask: How did this happen in the first place? Why would Americans curtail their precious right to drink?

headline: TimesCast | May 21, 2010
text: In today's Timescast, a look at how financial reform affects consumers, baseball and race examined in a new Hank Aaron biography and the Executive Producer of 'Lost' talks about the last episode.

headline: Founding Entrepreneurs
text: In 2006, Nathaniel Philbrick wrote “Mayflower,” a history of the Pilgrims that attempted to wipe centuries of mythic buildup from the dour features of America’s European primogenitors. Now Nick Bunker has written another history of the Pilgrims, which tries to do more or less the same thing. Yet the two books — both admirable — are utterly different, and so to a large extent is their subject matter.

headline: Sick and Tired
text: Sometimes a novel bursts out of the gate with a premise that’s utterly specific and original. For example: What if one ward of a Finnish women’s hospital became a sort of spa for unhappy foreigners? What if the head nurse for these “up-patients” (so named because they occupy the hospital’s top floor) had to struggle to maintain her boundaries and professionalism? What if a new arrival, a manipulative Danish ballroom instructor, began deliberately to stir up latent tensions?

headline: Frederick Wiseman Grapples With the Sweet Science
text: CANNES, France — Of the 30-plus documentaries Frederick Wiseman has made in his fortysomething-year career, most are portraits of institutions, peeling back the official veneer to reveal the human interactions within. Having recently tackled large, complex organizations like the Idaho Senate and House (“State Legislature,” 2006) and the Paris Opera Ballet (“La Danse,” 2009), Mr. Wiseman, 80, now turns his attention to a comparatively modest subject: a neighborhood boxing gym in Austin, Tex.

headline: Paul’s ‘Honeymoon’ Seems Over
text: Updated: Even after conceding that it probably hadn’t been wise to appear on MSNBC the other day, Rand Paul, the new Republican Senate nominee from Kentucky, keeps giving TV interviews and providing additional fodder on new topics to the delight of his critics (and his opponents).

headline: A Fresh Look Back at Right Now
text: A TIME-HONORED tradition: Stand outside a movie theater with a camera and microphone and poll the audience members for their reactions. What did you think of the film? A grandmotherly woman makes a face and waves her hand in disgust: Revolting! Idiotic! A middle-aged gentleman, stout and respectable, takes a more tolerant view: This is a movie about how young people live today, he says, a movie made by young people, and he is generally in favor of young people. But a sober-looking, well-dressed younger fellow demurs. “I don’t think it’s very serious,” he says dismissively.

Her books and DVDs, which explain how Satan possesses children, are widely known.

headline: New York’s Date With the End of Time
text: WHEN an opera company performs an opera in concert, it is cutting to the bone. When a symphony orchestra does the same thing, it is reaching for the stars. The players can spread their wings in glamorous regions they rarely get to explore. Audiences share the thrill of fresh discovery, whether the repertory is standard or the rarest of the rare. Does it matter if the singers are barricaded behind music stands? Or should the concert hall simulate the production values of an actual opera house?

headline: Dateline Marja: Back in the Field
text: Lance Cpl. Travis F. Vuocolo was with Company K (Kilo Company), Third Battalion, Sixth Marines on their initial assault of Marja in Helmand Province in southern Afghanistan. He was shot through the shoulder by a Taliban fighter on Feb. 14 when the company, accompanied by an Afghan army platoon, fought to gain a foothold in territory long under insurgent control. Lance Corporal Vuocolo has recovered and is now working at the battalion command post. Friday was his first time “outside the wire” — off the base — since he was shot. He is seen here in a bazaar in Marja. Tyler Hicks of The Times photographed the firefight in which Lance Corporal Vuocolo was wounded and his return. Mr. Hicks described the experience of being embedded with Kilo Company in “Into the Maw at Marja.”

headline: Royal Treatment
text: The Falaknuma Palace in Hyderabad, India, nearly bankrupted Prime Minister Nawab Vikar-ul-Umra when he built it in 1884. A mix of Italian and Tudor architecture, the project took 9 years to build and 22 years to decorate. This summer it will reopen as a hotel from the Taj Group after a restoration that was nearly as ambitious as the original plan.

headline: Mailbag: Debating British Anti-Semitism
text: Harold Bloom’s cover review of “Trials of the Diaspora,” by Anthony Julius (May 9) drew an unusually large number of letters from readers, almost all critical. We are publishing several in this Sunday’s Book Review, but wanted to share more. The letters chosen here illustrate the themes that appeared most frequently in the messages we received: disagreement with Bloom’s claim that anti-Zionism is (usually) anti-Semitism, and disagreement with his discussion of “anti-Semitic” characters in works by Shakespeare, Dickens, Fitzgerald and Hemingway.

headline: Jil, Diffused
text: Yesterday was a bit of a crazy day so I didn’t get a chance to talk about the new Jil Sander Navy line. There’s not much to say, really. It’s a minimalist line aiming for friendlier prices in a world saturated with them. The standout piece among those presented was the print scarf dress, and I liked the crisp look of the trench skirt and the flattering cut of the slim pants. The kelly-green trench dress was cute, too. Though I saw connections to the Jil Sander aesthetic, past and present, those design values can be found in many places—Uniqlo, Calvin Klein, Banana. Last year, I bought a Jil Sander pre-season draped-front dress in navy cotton jersey for about $590. I’ve gotten lots of mileage out it, and it’s probably less money than some of the Navy pieces. So what am I getting? We’re all making those kinds of decisions about clothes. Is a $200 pair of leggings or pants really worth it or will I trade up to something with a little more design? Will I stick with a trusty designer label and just buy less? Clearly a task before the team designing Navy—which is not Raf Simons’ team for the main Jil collections—is to create smart, useful pieces that are a skip ahead of the “lifestyle” miasma.

headline: Why Libertarianism Doesn’t Work, Part N+1

headline: Single Dads Are Different
text: Regular readers of the Motherlode comments may have noticed the contributions of William McCloskey, who shows up here almost daily, usually to disagree with me. His style is, to use his word, “curmudgeonly,” honed during 40 years as a journalist, first covering “homicides, armed robberies, suicides, fires, traffic fatalities . . . the ‘good’ stuff,” and then making “buckets of money managing publications for a software venture” (again, his words).

headline: Sticky Goodness
text: Since we’re talking about core inflation lately, I should give a shoutout to recent work by Bryan and Meyer. In my post on core inflation, I explained the Platonic ideal of what we’re trying to measure: it’s prices that aren’t revised often, and are therefore set with future inflation in mind. The standard measure of core inflation tries to get at this ideal in a rough and ready way, by excluding food and energy; other measures exclude all prices that have changed a lot in any given month. But Bryan and Meyer use a more direct approach, looking at goods whose prices can be shown directly not to change very often; these core goods make up about 70 percent of the CPI.

headline: Straight Up | A Vodka Survey
text: Is there a more perfect birthday present than a bottle of vodka? At my home, it’s the gift that’s always appreciated and never goes to waste. My recent celebration brought me four bottles — and an excuse to buy a fifth — all of them unfamiliar boutique brands. And that got me wondering: is there an artisanal vodka trend afoot? Let’s have a taste.

headline: An Eye for Detail, an Imagination at Play
text: A JEAN-PIERRE JEUNET film can be easy to detect, if not always simple to dissect. Quirky characters, intricately designed sets, exaggerated color tones and a tilt toward the surreal are quintessential elements of his filmmaking. From his first feature, “Delicatessen”(1991), on which he shared the directing credit with Marc Caro, to his most commercially successful film, “Amélie” (2001), Mr. Jeunet has emphasized visual storytelling. But his production interests began percolating much earlier. “I started when I was 8,” he said. “I built a kind of theater and I wrote a story and I built some puppets. I made the costumes and I destroyed my parents’ lamp to make the lighting. And they had to pay. I was producer, too.”

headline: What Higher Taxes Will Really Mean
text: The federal income tax increases over the next three years have led to lots of grumbling. But for all the back and forth about the percentages, something has been overlooked: what do these increases mean in real numbers? In other words, how much will wealthy people have left after they pay the higher taxes in the coming years?

headline: A Gamer’s World, but a Dramatist’s Sensibility
text: THE producer Jerry Bruckheimer likes to say that he can make a movie from almost anything. In his long and box-office-friendly career, he has conjured movies from books (“Black Hawk Down”), from magazine articles (“Coyote Ugly” and “Top Gun”), from the real-life story of a woman who was both a welder and a stripper (“Flashdance”), from a notion tossed around the office (“Hey, let’s make a movie about submarines!” which led to “Crimson Tide”). Most famously, and most lucratively, he has made not just a movie but a franchise, “Pirates of the Caribbean,” from a theme-park ride.
