text: Ceesay Kujabi and the Bachinab from The Gambia performing at DanceAfrica in 2008.

headline: Borders Turns to LeBow to Revitalize Bookseller
text: The bookstore chain the Borders Group hopes to redefine itself with a new $25 million investment from the financier Bennett S. LeBow, who will become its chairman and biggest shareholder, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Reprieve for Filmmaker in Dispute With Chevron
text: A filmmaker fighting an oil company’s demand for more than 600 hours of unused footage got a reprieve from a federal appeals judge on Friday. Judge Denny Chin of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ordered a hearing June 8 to consider a subpoena issued earlier this month by a federal district judge that ordered Joe Berlinger, the filmmaker, to turn all footage from the making of his film “Crude.”

headline: Mark Heller, Esq.
text: A chandelier in a second-story window on East 66th Street goes dark, and the lawyer steps out of his town house. He walks toward Park Avenue and settles into an unhurried amble for nine blocks, clutching a black briefcase whose color matches his combed-back hair. He passes doormen, tourists, dog-walking ladies, joggers. His hunched shoulders and slight limp suggest a laborer joylessly shuffling toward the morning whistle — except it is 6:30 p.m. and he is wearing French cuffs.

headline: Has Your Service in Afghanistan Changed You?
text: The New York Times again invites members of the military who are serving, or have served, in Afghanistan to help us document the daily life of this war in photographs, video and writing. Take us on a tour of the FOB, introduce us to your friends, describe the hardships of deployment and the humor that helps you pass the time.

headline: A Long Walk Starts (and Ends) With a Step
text: This weekend’s Travel section cover story  —  “Frugal Europe, On Foot”  —  is my last as the paper’s Frugal Traveler columnist. After four years of roaming the world on a budget, from Alabama and Albania to Uruguay and Urumqi, I’m taking a rest, and handing over the illustrious mantle to a new shoestringer, who’ll appear in this space next month.

headline: Tattered Palaces
text: “I am big. It’s the pictures that got small.”

headline: The Moviegoer | Nanking Revisited
text: The Moviegoer is a regular column on new and noteworthy films, actors and directors by John Anderson.

headline: Hot Pursuit: What’s Your Favorite Cop Car From TV or the Movies?
text: On TV and in the movies, police cars have sometimes become characters themselves. What are your favorites?

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Greenpoint Food Market Nearly 50 vendors are scheduled to pack a church basement, and weather should be great for a picnic in the park across the street: Saturday, noon to 5 p.m., Church of the Messiah, 129 Russell Street (Nassau Avenue), Greenpoint, Brooklyn, free admission.

headline: Times Talks: Looking Back on 'Lost'
text: A surprise guest joins the producers.

headline: Downtown Brooklyn Gets a Sheraton
text: A hotel row grows in Brooklyn.  The 25-story Sheraton Brooklyn New York Hotel opened on May 20 in the shadow of the MetroTech Center and Brooklyn Academy of Music, the first of several hotels scheduled to open in the area.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: What’s the cheapest way to get around Europe?  Sure, there are low-cost airplanes, buses and bicycling, but they pale in comparison to your own two feet.  So, with screaming ankles and a 45-pound pack, Matt Gross — in his final cover story as the Frugal Traveler — walks 180 miles from Vienna to Budapest, one helpful stranger at a time.

headline: My Old Kentucky Ham
text: The smell of hickory smoke clocks you in the parking lot of Benton’s Smoky Mountain Country Hams, a concrete bunker on unscenic Highway 411 in Madisonville, Tenn. Just as dizzying is the sight of an old case filled with deli meats, bacon and sliced ham, the top lined with bags of local grits and jars of sorghum, honey and the pickled relish called chowchow. In the rooms beyond, you can see more ham, more bacon, in various stages, from curing to cutting. “We accept food stamps,” reads one sign. It’s as humble a spot as you’re likely to find when searching for ground zero of American cuisine’s obsession with pork. And yet Benton’s has become a touchstone (if not a supplier) for chefs from coast to coast. Ssäm Bar, part of David Chang’s expanding Momofuku restaurant dynasty, serves a Southern ham plate: thin slices of smoky, salty American pork with red-eye gravy. In Chicago, Paul Kahan thrills Publican diners with country ham and cracklings. And the Manhattan bar PDT offers a Benton’s Old-Fashioned: bourbon infused with Benton’s extra-smoky bacon. Suddenly, the backwoods biscuit fixin’ has become the new prosciutto.

headline: European Debt Crisis Could Touch A.I.G.
text: The waves of financial trouble rippling across Europe could end up splashing at least one American institution: the taxpayer-owned American International Group.

headline: Times Talks: Looking Back on 'Lost'
text: Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof, executive producers, discuss killing off beloved characters.

headline: Maine Goes On the Disabled List
text: 6:55 p.m. | Updated with Maine going on the D.L.One day after he was removed from a game after facing just one batter, John Maine was placed on the disabled list Friday, with the Mets citing weakness in his right shoulder, a problem that has plagued Maine in the past.

headline: Times Talks: Looking Back on 'Lost'
text: Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof, executive producers, discuss Nikki and Paulo, the characters who became a sort of shorthand for narrative missteps on “Lost.”

headline: Before Night Falls
text: My first morning in Bogotá brings disturbing news. There on the front page of El Tiempo — waiting outside the carved doors of my lofty room at the Hotel de la Ópera, in the city’s rambling colonial neighborhood of La Candelaria — is a chilling headline. The night before, some 30,000 people had massed in the Parque Metropolitano Simón Bolívar, the sprawling memorial to the continent’s boldest revolutionary, to see Coldplay.

headline: Barrel Fever
text: With more than 400 wineries and nearly 150 tasting rooms to choose from, a wine tour of Napa Valley could take all year. How to choose?

headline: Crowd Starts Forming for Souder Seat
text: Mark Souder officially gave up his House seat on Friday, just days after the Indiana Republican disclosed his affair with a staff member.

headline: Paul Cancels Sunday TV Appearance
text: After a series of interviews on national TV that stirred an uproar over his views on civil rights and other issues, Rand Paul, the Republican nominee for Senate in Kentucky, has canceled a scheduled appearance on NBC’s “Meet the Press” program on Sunday.

headline: Similar Doping Charges Were Aired in 2005 Web Chat by Former Armstrong Teammates
text: Updated | Saturday | 3:05 p.m. As my colleague Juliet Macur reported on Thursday, allegations of systematic doping by Lance Armstrong were made in a series of e-mail confessions sent to cycling authorities in recent weeks by his former teammate, Floyd Landis.

headline: Now Online | T Travel Summer 2010 Issue
text: The latest travel issue of T magazine starts off nice and easy — just the way summer’s supposed to be. For the cover story, we get lost in time in Portugal’s sun-soaked Alentejo region. Then we head to the quiet coastline of Dorset, England, and to the shores of Lake Michigan for a classic American summer sojourn. We’re big on tradition this season, and you’ll find us visiting old-fashioned country ham makers in Kentucky and Tennessee, an expertly restored 18th-century palace hotel in India, and a vintage kids’ camp in France that’s been transformed into a chic retreat. We also lay out an insider’s guide to Napa Valley, that blue-chip destination right here at home — but we don’t shy away from places on the edge: The souks of Damascus get a thorough exploration, and we party till the sun comes up in the buzzing nightlife capital of Bogotá.

headline: Reagan and Obama
text: I talked to Steven Hayward this week, a sympathetic biographer of Ronald Reagan, about the similarities and differences between the beginnings of the Reagan and Obama administrations. Mr. Hayward emphasized that they both came into office with a clear plan for making major, long-term changes to the economy.

headline: An Action Hero as an Unbearable Being of Lightness
text: Good morning, class. Welcome back to “Advanced Topics in the Ontology of Cinema.” Today’s lecture is on “MacGruber,” a film that poses a philosophical question fundamental to our inquiry here, namely: “Why does this exist?”

headline: Scalping World Peace, Outside Radio City
text: The appearance of the Dalai Lama at Radio City Music Hall has inspired a certain chant on the Avenue of the Americas.

headline: So, You Think It’s African Dance?
text: EVERY year the Brooklyn Academy of Music holds its DanceAfrica festival. Other cities have their own versions, and they serve a purpose in modern America — honoring traditions that were for centuries ignored and repressed — that a DanceEurope festival would not. But on such occasions it’s too easy to refer to “African dance” as if it were a single genre.

headline: Chic in Review | Kate Can’t Dance
text: Banks, TyraRe-signed with IMG. Looks like writing books isn’t that profitable.

headline: Coming Out: When Love Dares Speak, and Nobody Listen
text: THE love that dare not speak its name has been speaking up an awful lot lately. So much, in fact, that people are starting not to notice when it happens.

headline: ‘Lost’ Fans Suffer From Blabbermouths Online
text: Erin Farley has her plans for Sunday all laid out. Two hours before the last episode of “Lost” is broadcast three time zones away, she will shut down her home Internet connection. TweetDeck? Off. Facebook? Off. Her cellphone? Stashed out of reach.

headline: Obama’s Primary Test
text: We know the official results of Tuesday’s primaries: Rand Paul won; Arlen Specter lost; and Blanche Lincoln survived, if only to put off the inevitable. The lessons one can draw from this are as clear as the waters off southeastern Louisiana: the Democrats are doomed; the Republicans are doomed; incumbents are doomed; the Tea Parties are omnipotent; the Tea Parties are impotent; it’s all about Big Government; it’s all about Big Money; all politics is still local; all politics is still local to the 202 area code; it’s all about Rush Limbaugh; it’s all about Nancy Pelosi; it’s all about Ron Paul; it’s all about the Constitution …

headline: Fraught
text: W.F. Young asks: "Long ago I developed the expectation that on encountering the word fraught, I'd find it associated with a prepositional phrase, 'with [something].'  Now, in old age, I find that expectation dashed, often.  Can you say what it was based on and anything about when, how or by whom it was undercut?"  Here we have a case of a very old word undergoing a rapid shift in contemporary usage. In Middle English, fraught (an etymological cousin of freight) was a verb meaning "to load (a ship)," and the identical form could serve as a past participle meaning "laden (with)." While the verb dropped out of the language almost entirely, the past participle stuck around, typically followed by "with" and an object -- often a burden, whether real or figurative.  Fraught as a standalone adjective meaning "distressed, anxious, tense," without an accompanying prepositional phrase, is a 20th-century innovation. When the word cropped up on William Safire's radar in 2006, he offered a line from "King Lear" as a putative early example: Goneril tells her father to "make use of that good wisdom, whereof I know you are fraught." But Shakespeare did use fraught with a preposition, whereof, and an object, wisdom, so it is in fact very much in line with the usage of the era. Lear was surely in a distressed emotional state, but that wasn't what his daughter was driving at.  By the nineteenth century, the metaphorical extension of the word had developed a new twist. Instead of the traditional phrasing, fraught with followed by an object (something usually unpleasant or unfortunate), the object could appear before fraught in a hyphenated compound, such as danger-fraught, pain-fraught or war-fraught. Thus if a moment was fraught with emotion, it could just as well have been described as emotion-fraught or in time as emotionally fraught, signaling the implied object in the adverb.  The first glimmers of fraught without even a hint of an object start appearing in the 1920s and '30s. The earliest example I've found so far comes from a 1925 serialized story by Henry Leyford Gates about a flapper named Joanna. In one installment Gates writes, "It was Joanna who at last broke the fraught silence." The lyrical phrase fraught silence, perhaps evoking pregnant pause, shows up again in books from 1934, 1946 and 1958. Another early use is in George O'Neil's 1931 novel about the poet John Keats, "Special Hunger": "For Keats this was a singularly fraught circumstance." Circumstances, along with anxiety-ridden situations, issues and relationships, would soon become familiar companions for fraught.  Standalone fraught picked up steam in the 1960s, attracting the notice of dictionaries and usage guides, but the last couple of decades have seen an even stronger uptick. In the texts collected in the Corpus of Contemporary American English from 1990 to 1994, only about 9 percent of the instances of fraught do not take the preposition with. From 2005 to 2009, however, the rate jumps to a whopping 30 percent. The usage has become a journalistic commonplace, as in the recent New York Times headlines, "For New Stadium, a Fraught Coin Flip" and "Opera Companies' Fraught Seasons." No doubt about it, we're living in fraught times.

headline: Sects and the City
text: I had almost forgotten I’d sent in an application when the e-mail message appeared, like Mr. Big, out of nowhere. “Hi, Moustafa,” it began, as if we were old friends. “Thank you for e-mailing us regarding your interest in working on ‘Sex and the City 2.’ ”

headline: The Feminist
text: As a Somali native who was raised as a Muslim and grew up to become one of the most outspoken critics of Islam, you fled to Amsterdam and served in the Dutch Parliament before fleeing again, to America. What kind of security do you have here? I don’t go from A to B without being escorted by people who are armed. But please, let’s not talk about my security.

headline: Letter: The Moral Life of Babies
text: Paul Bloom’s article is certainly amazing in what it says about the capabilities of the very youngest among us. One piece of information, however, appears to be missing from this complex equation of becoming human. Nowhere in the article is information given about the home lives of these infants. Shouldn’t the supportive or nonsupportive backgrounds of the infants be taken into account as one ingredient to babies’ reactions to stimuli? From birth, what has been the environment these subjects lived in? Would neglected babies react in the same way to those who have had a warm, nurturing environment from birth? These questions kept badgering me as I read this most informative study. Early Childhood Educator and Consultant, Beachwood, Ohio

headline: ‘Lost’ Motives, Explained
text: On Thursday night Damon Lindelof and Carlton Cuse appeared at a Times Talk event to riff about “Lost” with Lorne Manly, entertainment editor for The Times, and we are posting excerpts from the discussion. You can watch earlier clips here.

headline: Last Stop in Congress for the Financial Bill
text: The financial regulatory bill needs to overcome one more hurdle before it reaches President Obama’s desk: the conference committee. Members from both houses of Congress will meet together to meld the House and Senate versions for a final vote of approval. The size and makeup of that committee could determine how tough the bill will be on Wall Street.

headline: Invasion of the Big, Scary, Long Film Titles
text: LOS ANGELES  Pity the high school students whose summer jobs involve changing movie theater marquees. Hollywood has come down with a serious case of title elongation. That is, if you can figure out the title at all.

headline: Letter: The Data-Driven Life
text: The Data-Driven Life

headline: Letter:  Half a Degree
text: As a community-college professor, I agree that our institutions can and should do more for our new students. While David Leonhardt correctly identifies some of the obstacles to student retention and success, he misses an important factor in student “failure”: unrealistic expectations. I have observed that school is often a third priority for many of my students, who may place family and work above school commitments.

headline: Letter: Calendar Daze
text: Virginia Heffernan’s column evoked pleasant memories of a predigital era. I purchased my Filofax at Harrods 25 years ago while on sabbatical in England. The Filofax is much more than an analog date book, with an almost-limitless variety of pages that can be added for projects and finances. My Filofax was eventually replaced by a P.D.A., and like Heffernan, I also miss it.

headline: Fund Executive Is Sentenced in Galleon Case
text: A co-founder of the New Castle Funds hedge fund, Mark Kurland, was sentenced on Friday to 27 months in prison for insider trading in connection with the Galleon Group case, Bloomberg News reported. He was also ordered to forfeit $900,000.

headline: Times Talks: Looking Back on 'Lost'
text: Carlton Cuse and Damon Lindelof, executive producers, discuss the "specialness" of Claire's son, Aaron.

headline: The Kidney Was a Gift
text: Last fall, a stranger donated a kidney to my husband. We offered her a gift after the operation, which she declined. Recently she wrote us that her house is in foreclosure, and she needs money. We obviously have no legal responsibility to respond, but what is our ethical responsibility? I wish it were legal to sell organs; it would be much cleaner in many ways. NAME WITHHELD

text: The tech editors and reporters of The New York Times ended their week reading about a tribute to Pac-Man, Twitter in China and speaking like Yoda.

headline: The Death of the Open Web
text: The Web is a teeming commercial city. It’s haphazardly planned. Its public spaces are mobbed, and signs of urban decay abound in broken links and abandoned projects. Malware and spam have turned living conditions in many quarters unsafe and unsanitary. Bullies and hucksters roam the streets. An entrenched population of rowdy, polyglot rabble seems to dominate major sites.

headline: Declining to Renew Stabilized Apartments
text: Q.

headline: New Los Angeles Driver, on a Joy Ride
text: Avery Fisher Hall was sold out for the concert by Gustavo Dudamel and the Los Angeles Philharmonic on Thursday night, the first chance for concertgoers in New York to see him in action since he became the orchestra’s music director last fall. He has since galvanized Los Angeles with his exuberant music making and inspiring capacity for outreach.

headline: Passing Along a Co-op Apartment
text: Q.

headline: Judge Stays Order Against Filmmaker
text: A filmmaker fighting an oil company’s demand for more than 600 hours of unused footage got a reprieve from a federal appeals judge in Manhattan on Friday. Judge Denny Chin ordered a June 8 hearing to consider a subpoena issued on May 6 by a federal district judge that ordered Joe Berlinger, the filmmaker, to turn over all footage from the making of his film “Crude.” The film focuses on a lawsuit by Ecuadoreans against Chevron over pollution in the Amazon said to have been caused by Texaco before Chevron acquired it. The subpoena will be stayed until the hearing, Judge Chin ruled. Ilann M. Maazel, whose firm represents the Ecuadorean plaintiffs, applauded Judge Chin’s decision, and called the subpoena “another last-ditch attempt to derail and delay justice in Ecuador.” Randy M. Mastro, a lawyer for Chevron, said he was not concerned about the coming hearing.

headline: Michael Jackson Sleepover Tribute
text: June 25 will mark a year since Michael Jackson’s death, and to pay tribute a Japanese promoter is holding a sleepover of sorts inside the Tokyo Tower where the Neverland Collection — a huge assortment of the singer’s personal objects including sculptures, left, a 1967 Rolls-Royce Phantom, right, clothes and costumes from his “Thriller” video — has been on view since May 1. Reuters reported that starting on Sunday, people are expected to line up to buy tickets costing as much as $1,000 for the chance to sleep among Jackson’s belongings. Fans, to be selected at random, will enter the tower from 10:30 p.m. on June 25 and will be able to stay until 8 the next morning. “In Japan,” Hiroyuki Takamura of the Tokyo Tower said, “the tradition of being with the remains and possessions of passed love ones on the anniversary of their passing is an important ritual.”

headline: Motion Against Gallery Is Rejected
text: A federal judge in Manhattan on Thursday declined to give immediate help to an art collector who has been blacklisted by the South African painter Marlene Dumas, prohibited from buying new works by her after he angered her by selling an older work. The collector, Craig Robins, asserts in a lawsuit that he sold a Dumas painting through the David Zwirner Gallery in Chelsea in 2004 with an agreement that the sale remain confidential. But the gallery, which took over representation of Ms. Dumas in 2008, told her about it, Mr. Robins says, causing her to add his name to the blacklist. In court testimony, Ms. Dumas’s former dealer confirmed that the artist maintains a blacklist of collectors and dealers whom she believes to be speculating in her works. Mr. Robins says that the Zwirner gallery promised to help get him off the blacklist and to sell him new paintings but failed to do so. The gallery has denied the claims. Mr. Robins sought a temporary restraining order to prevent the gallery from selling three paintings in a show of new work, paintings that Mr. Robins contends he should have the right to buy. But Judge William H. Pauley denied the request for the restraining order, in part because Mr. Robins provided no written evidence of his claims against the gallery.

headline: Lohan Avoids Arrest
text: It looks as if Lindsay Lohan will not be arrested after all. While the 23-year-old actress was at the Cannes Film Festival on Thursday promoting her new film about Linda Lovelace, a Los Angeles County Superior Court judge issued a warrant for her arrest, saying that she had “no valid excuse” for missing a probation hearing in a drunken-driving case. But hours later her legal team posted bail of $100,000, according to Reuters, which allows Ms. Lohan to avoid jail by providing money that would be forfeited if she became a fugitive. Shawn Chapman Holley, Ms. Lohan’s lawyer, told the judge that the actress was stranded in France because her passport had been stolen at the festival. Ms. Holley has since said that Ms. Lohan has a new passport, though it was unclear when she would return to Los Angeles.

headline: CBS Wins Battle of Thursday Finales
text: CBS eked out a victory ahead of ABC in the ratings on Thursday night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, CBS’s season finale of “The Mentalist” at 10 p.m. drew 15 million viewers, tying ABC’s two-hour season conclusion of “Grey’s Anatomy” as the night’s most-watched show. ABC, which finished No. 1 in the demographic of viewers 18 to 49, would have led the night over all in total viewers were it not for lower ratings at 8 for “FlashForward” (5.3 million), which trailed in its time slot behind the finale of Fox’s “Bones” (9.2 million) and a CBS repeat of “The Mentalist” (8.1 million). CBS’s 10th-season finale of “CSI” drew 13.9 million viewers at 9, outperforming Fox’s “Fringe” (5.7 million) and NBC’s finales of “The Office” (6.6 million) and “30 Rock” (5.5 million). Fox finished ahead of NBC to rank third.

headline: It Was a Royal Pain, but It Ended Well
text: Were it not for the cloud of volcanic ash that disrupted air travel last month, one particular document on view through May 30 at the Morgan Library & Museum would have been returned to its home at the Bodleian Library at Oxford University weeks ago. But this document also would not be here (or anywhere else, for that matter) if the royal figure involved in its creation had been any less violent, venal, treacherous, incompetent and boorish.

headline: U2 Tour Thrown Off By Injury To Bono
text: U2 has postponed the first concert in this year’s leg of the “360°” world tour after its lead singer, Bono, above, was injured during a rehearsal and underwent emergency surgery on his back in Munich on Friday, The Associated Press reported. “Bono will spend the next few days there, before returning home to recuperate,” a statement on U2.com said. “Once his condition has been assessed further, a statement will be made regarding the impact on forthcoming tour dates.” The tour was to start in Salt Lake City on June 3. After that the band is scheduled to play in Anaheim, Calif., on June 6 and 7 followed by Denver on June 12 and Oakland, Calif., on June 16. So far the tour, which began last year and draws its name from the giant circular stage the band uses, has earned around $109 million, according to Billboard. No details have been released about when the Salt Lake City concert might take place or if other concerts will have to be postponed as well.

headline: Adventures in Synthetic Biology
text: While geologists are debating whether Earth really has entered a new epoch, the Anthropocene, named for the dominant influence on the planet’s geochemistry these days, there’s no question that biology will never be quite the same again.

headline: Jil Sander for Less
text: I have always loved the designs of both Jil Sander and Raf Simons for Jil Sander. These clothes, however, have always been somewhat out of my price range. But now with the introduction of the new Jil Sander Navy line, I might finally be able to get my Jil fix.

headline: A Crib for the Baby, a Cradle for the Cats, a Home for Them
text: ERICA BUCKLEY has long since left the ranch house near Saratoga Springs, N.Y., where she grew up. But she has vivid memories of trotting across the yard and visiting her grandmother’s house, which was just next door.

headline: Unsold Condos Get the Hammer
text: Postscript: May 22, 2010

headline: A Hamptons Alternative for Summer Renters
text: WITH summer approaching, seasonal rentals are going fast. But the Hamptons haven’t exactly cornered the market.

headline: Five Ways for Buyers to Outsmart the Market
text: TRYING to pinpoint what’s going on with the New York City real estate market right now can be like standing at the shoreline and determining the exact moment the tide turns — without a tide chart.

headline: Blame the Building if the Mortgage Falls Through
text: IMAGINE finding the perfect co-op or condominium in your dream neighborhood at a fabulous price. Your financials are in order and your credit is good, but the deal falls through.

headline: Peter G. Riguardi
text: Mr. Riguardi, 49, is the president of the New York operations of Jones Lang LaSalle, a publicly traded company based in Chicago and one of the world’s largest commercial real estate brokers.

headline: What to Expect From the Annual Co-op Meeting
text: AS co-op boards across the city head into annual meeting season, many are facing a paradox: despite the real estate market’s decline, building assessments and real estate taxes have continued to go up.

headline: TV Antennas Send Wrong Signal to Buyers
text: EVEN though all television signals went digital last year and cable has been around for decades, old-fashioned TV antennas can still be found atop many houses and apartment buildings in the New York region. But those vestigial limbs from the analog era are more than just quaint aluminum artifacts.

headline: Attracting Residents With ‘Themes’
text: HOUSING projects being developed around northern New Jersey right now seem to be defining themselves by theme: Teachers Village; Eco-Village; Wellness Plaza; Theater Square; Valley Arts District.

headline: Madison Avenue Condos Hit the Auction Block
text: FOR all the recent price cuts and rental conversions in the turbulent New York condominium market, developers rarely resort to auctioning off unsold units.

headline: Jessica Hecht Buys Flat in Landmark Building
text: TO fans of the television comedy “Friends,” Jessica Hecht is Susan, the life partner of Carol, the ex-wife of Ross Geller, one of the lead characters. And as almost everybody knows, she made broadcast history in 1995 when Susan and Carol became the first lesbian couple on TV to become parents.

headline: The Gift of Sperm Donor 8282
text: TEN years ago Carey Goldberg, a Boston reporter who was then single and about to turn 39, reached her self-imposed “biological midnight.” Determined to be a mother and with no man yet on the horizon, she did some research on sperm banks and then ordered eight vials of sperm from an anonymous donor.

headline: A Double Bill With Binoche and Kiarostami
text: CANNES, France— The couple in Abbas Kiarostami’s “Certified Copy,” screening in competition at this year’s Cannes Film Festival, are a French gallery owner (Juliette Binoche) and an English art critic (the opera singer William Shimmel) on a Tuscan day trip. They seem to be strangers until a case of mistaken identity— or a bout of magic-realist role play— propels the movie into an alternate reality.

headline: Puzzles in Layers of Cool Suspense
text: The authority with which the choreographer Pam Tanowitz orders time and space in “The Wanderer Fantasy” is something rare, but there’s an offbeat quality to it. On more than one level the work, now at Danspace Project, puzzles the mind. Yet it’s easy to discard any such sense of puzzle, because at every moment it’s arresting, suspenseful, coolly witty. Her work has an instinct for the contrasts that make dance count: stillness against motion, small against large, slow against fast, the individual against the group, one group against another, upright beside supine.

headline: Dance Lessons From Bounce Music’s Audacious Star
text: The Bar 13 stage was tiny and crowded in the small hours of Friday morning, but Big Freedia saw plenty of room left to fill. “How many of y’all took that class today?” he asked the crowd.

headline: A Solid Rock of the Ages, Mixing New and Vintage
text: Pearl Jam began its first encore at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night with a portrait of ailment, fraught with emotion. Eddie Vedder, the band’s lead singer, returned alone to the stage, where a string quartet had assembled. “This is one of the sadder songs we know,” he said, referring to “The End,” from “Backspacer” (Monkeywrench), Pearl Jam’s most recent album. Finger-picking an acoustic guitar, he sang the song’s first line in a tentative quaver: “What were all those dreams we shared those many years ago?”

headline: Golfer and Caddie Pay Tribute to a Friend
text: IRVING, Tex. — Rickie Fowler’s wardrobe is like a Crayola crayon box, bursting with bright colors. He looked like a walking creamsicle on Friday, but that’s not why he attracted the attention of a few hecklers during his round of one-over-par 71.

headline: Three Men to Watch at the French Open
text: Ernests GulbisIn 2008 Ernests Gulbis reached the quarterfinals at Roland Garros, and seemed poised to break into the top 10. With a huge serve and a penetrating ground game, the 6”3 Gulbis played fearlessly, hitting for the lines when the pressure mounted. He was so outrageously talented that he made the game look easy. And then he faltered, losing early and often as rumors spread that he preferred partying to the practice court.

headline: On ‘Lost,’ Questions Lead to More Questions

The St. Mary’s in question, a tiny log-walled chapel, stood only from 1893 to 1925 in this affluent section of Bridgeport, about 60 miles from Manhattan.

headline: Cinematic Change and the End of Film
text: CANNES, France— On Thursday, the day after “Carlos” had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival, I was surprised to learn it had been shot on 35 millimeter film. Here’s why: Directed by Olivier Assayas, the film is a 5-hour, 33-minute portrait of the terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal. It will be shown on French television this week and is scheduled to open in the United States in the fall. It’s a fascinating work about an uninteresting brutish historical figure and I haven’t stopped thinking about it since I saw it. The thin visual quality of the images and occasional tell-tale splotches of yellow in white images strongly suggested that we were looking at a movie that had been shot in digital, perhaps with the RED, the camera which Steven Soderbergh used to shoot “Che,” his movie about Che Guevara, which played at Cannes in 2008.

headline: The Latest on the Oil Spill

Markey, the chairman of the Subcommittee on Energy and the Environment, accused BP of deceiving the public. “It is clear BP has been lying,” Mr. Markey said. “We cannot be relying on BP to be making any of these decisions,” he said, referring to cleanup efforts. The federal government has created a Flow Rate Technical Team to establish a more precise estimate. Its first report is expected Saturday.

headline: Maybe Bullies Just Want to Be Loved

headline: Shedding a Name, and Perhaps More

Perhaps, having signed with the EMI Classics record label, he wanted to establish a break with the sober persona of his outstanding albums for Deutsche Grammophon, released in the shadow of a more famous and flamboyant compatriot and label mate, Lang Lang. EMI has experience with this phenomenon, having tended to the career of the violinist Nigel Kennedy once he had decided to be known as Kennedy.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Investor Puts $25 Million Into Borders Group
text: The Borders Group, the book store chain, will raise $25 million in a private sale to an entity controlled by Bennett S. LeBow, pushing him past Pershing Square Capital Management as the company’s largest shareholder. Mr. LeBow, 72, will buy 11.1 million shares for $2.25 each and become chairman, replacing Richard McGuire, who resigned, Borders said Friday. The bookseller has closed stores and cut costs in an effort to become profitable after four consecutive yearly losses. Mr. LeBow is chairman of the Vector Group, a Miami-based holding company for the cigarette maker Liggett Group. Stock in Borders, which is based in Ann Arbor, Mich., rose 1 cent, to close at $2.24 a share.

headline: Lazard Is Hired to Advise G.M. On a Share Sale
text: The Treasury Department has hired the investment bank Lazard to advise on a potential initial public offering of the government’s stake in General Motors, according to a federal contract posted online. The hiring of a financial adviser is the latest step in the Obama administration’s efforts to sell its 61 percent stake in G.M., which it gained when the government bailed out the automaker last year. G.M.’s chief executive, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., has suggested that the company could take the final step to repurchase the shares by Dec. 31, citing strong financial progress after years of losses. G.M. reported its first quarterly profit since 2007 on Monday. Lazard will be paid at least $7.5 million for the assignment, at a rate of $500,000 a month for the first 12 months.

headline: France: Paris Mayor Demands Investigation Into Art Theft
text: Mayor Bertrand Delanoë of Paris on Friday demanded an internal investigation into this week’s theft of five paintings, by Picasso, Matisse, Georges Braque, Fernand Léger and Amedeo Modigliani, from the Paris Museum of Modern Art. A lone hooded intruder, clad in black, exploited a two-month-old malfunction in the museum’s alarm system, leading to questions about whether the thief had inside help. The museum had closed in 2004 for two years for a $19 million safety and security upgrade.

headline: 163 Years Later, a President Visits to Say Thank You

Strangers in a far-off place needed their help, he said, but he knew that members of his audience had principled objections. So many of their own people, they pointed out, other Jews right there in New York, were also destitute and needed assistance.

headline: Dry Whites for Summer
text: Just in time for Memorial Day and the summer dining to come, Raphael, in Peconic, has released five 2009 dry whites that are good matches for fish, shellfish and vegetable dishes.

headline: A Winter Destination Turns to Thoughts of Spring
text: A seat next to one of the huge hearths in the Purdy’s Homestead building — a cozy Colonial begun by Joseph Purdy in 1775 and home to generations of Purdys for centuries — has long been a winter destination. But the owners of John-Michael’s Restaurant, the building’s current resident, have brought in a breath of spring and dreams of summer with a stone patio fitted with tables, umbrellas, torches and a fire pit.

headline: Two Culinary Cultures, From Raw to Well Done
text: TWO Steak and Sushi Den in New Hyde Park has been open only since March, but it has already surpassed its older sibling, the very good Four Food Studio and Cocktail Salon in Melville. They share a very talented executive chef, James McDevitt.

headline: Rebecca Grochow, Gary Mishuris
text: Dr. Rebecca Miriam Grochow and Gary Mishuris were married Saturday evening at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass. Rabbi Samuel Seicol officiated.

headline: Nicole Setzen, Roy Ben-Dor

Setzen and Dr. Michael Setzen of Old Westbury, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Roy Immanuel Ben-Dor, a son of Gisèle Ben-Dor and Eli Ben-Dor of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Rabbi Irving Spielman officiated at Cipriani Wall Street, an event space in New York.

headline: Dispute Over France a Factor in Intelligence Rift
text: WASHINGTON — An already strained relationship between the White House and the departing spymaster Dennis C. Blair erupted earlier this year over Mr. Blair’s efforts to cement close intelligence ties to France and broker a pledge between the nations not to spy on each other, American government officials said Friday.

headline: Local Ingredients, International Influences
text: AS I waited for a table on my first visit to Dish, a two-year-old bistro and wine bar in Mahopac, I wondered if you needed a tattoo or piercing to get in. Many of the generally young and hip diners sported elaborate, artful bodywork.

Brown III of Marion, Mass. The Rev. Kenneth J. Suibielski, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the St. Clare Church in Westerly, R.I.

text: HARTFORD — Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, trying to rebound after reports that he had misrepresented his military record, accepted the Democratic Party’s nomination for the United States Senate here Friday night, saying he would not let his opponents “make this race about attacks on my character and service.”

text: Corby Kummer, left, of The Atlantic and Robert Paarlberg, author of "Food Politics," debate organic farming vs. using synthetic fertilizer.

Perkins, both of Manhattan, Sunday evening at the Angel Orensanz Foundation, an events space in Manhattan. Rabbi Greg Wall is to officiate.

headline: No Indictment of  a Man Who Killed 2 in the Subway
text: A 19-year-old Brooklyn man who fatally stabbed two men during a fight in the subway in March will be released from jail after a grand jury decided on Friday not to indict him, the authorities said.

headline: Iran Presses Opposition With Attacks and Jail Time
text: TEHRAN — As Iran approaches the first anniversary of a contested presidential election that touched off a deep political crisis, opposition supporters remain under intense pressure, with student leaders receiving long prison terms and a prominent opposition politician and a filmmaker being attacked.

text: Dana Courtney Waits and John Adler Wedeles were married Saturday evening at the Hay-Adams Hotel in Washington. Rabbi Jessica Oleon officiated.

Clark of Holland, Mich. Cantor Joel Colman officiated in a courtyard ceremony at the New Orleans Board of Trade in New Orleans.

headline: Looking for a Turnaround, the Mets Talk Team Unity
text: The Mets’ players held a team meeting before Friday’s game against the Yankees to discuss the team’s state of affairs as it begins a stretch of important games amid an air of uncertainty.

headline: Ashley Gorski, Jeremy Reff
text: Ashley Marie Gorski, the daughter of Kathleen Sutton of Avon, Ind., and Gregory Gorski of Terre Haute, Ind., was married Friday evening to Jeremy Barnett Reff, a son of Miyo Reff and Mitchell Reff of San Diego. Bettina Yiannakourou, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated in Cadman Plaza Park in Brooklyn.

headline: Appeal Will Keep Vikings Eligible
text: A Minnesota state judge ruled Friday that Kevin Williams and Pat Williams, two defensive tackles on the Minnesota Vikings, could avoid four-game suspensions by the N.F.L. if they appealed an earlier court decision. The players, who are not related, were suspended by the league in 2008 because they tested positive for bumetanide, a diuretic banned by the league because it can mask steroids. The substance was in StarCaps, a weight-loss supplement that the players admitted taking. The players claimed in court that they were employed by the Vikings and therefore governed by Minnesota’s drug testing policies, which are at odds with the N.F.L.’s policy in some ways. Earlier this month, Gary Larson, a Minnesota district court judge, said that the N.F.L. was the players’ employer and that they were beholden to the league’s drug policy. On Friday, Larson said that the league could not suspend the players while they appealed that decision to the Minnesota Court of Appeals.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Financial Reform
text: After all the revelations about predatory lenders, bankers who bet against their clients and speculative booms and busts, it should be clear that weak regulation is a recipe for disaster. And open and transparent markets, with clear roles for regulators, are essential to the nation’s financial health.

headline: Somalia: Radio Station Attacked
text: The Islamist insurgent group Al Shabab invaded the Boondheere neighborhood north of the capital on Friday, killing 3 people, wounding at least 12 more and looting a local radio station of its equipment, forcing it off the air, witnesses said. It was the latest in a series of attacks against independent media houses and professionals. Boondheere quickly fell under Shabab control, the witnesses said, although the government claimed it fought the insurgents back.

headline: Limits of Libertarianism
text: By denigrating several of the signal achievements of modern American society, including the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Fair Housing Act, Rand Paul has performed a useful service for voters who are angry at their elected officials. He has helped to illuminate the limits and the hazards of antigovernment sentiment.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Reading in Public and Hoping They Notice
text: Jennifer Belle, a New York City author, thought up a new publicity campaign for her latest book: Hiring actors to read it in crowded spots around the city.

headline: Subway Series: Game 1
text: The Yankees drew first blood in the first meeting between the crosstown rivals, beating the struggling Mets 2-1 at Citi Field.

headline: Debating Whether It’s a Crime to Rest on San Francisco’s Sidewalks
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Starchild, a self-described sex worker and a candidate for San Francisco supervisor, says there is absolutely no reason that his beloved city needs any more rules.

headline: Tragedy in Detroit, With Reality TV Crew in Tow
text: DETROIT — The house where Aiyana Stanley-Jones lived on the East Side here is quiet now, a makeshift memorial of teddy bears and balloons on the porch where the police lobbed a stun grenade through the front window last Sunday. They were looking for a 34-year-old homicide suspect.

headline: Kagan’s Writings Back Wider Executive Powers
text: WASHINGTON — For decades, presidents of both parties have sought to impose greater White House control over the federal agencies that regulate matters like workplace rules, food and drug safety, and protections for natural resources. Elena Kagan, the Supreme Court nominee, has been a strong supporter of such efforts to expand presidential power over domestic affairs, her writings show.

headline: A Pitchers’ Duel Ends in Favor of the Yankees
text: In need of a good performance to convince a skeptical world that he is capable of pitching well for the Yankees in New York, Javier Vazquez produced a command performance Friday night, and it was within the city limits, too. The fact that it came against an offense struggling desperately to find its way does not tarnish the accomplishment.

headline: Amid World Series Reunion, Agbayani Honors Valentine
text: The Mets brought back several members of the 2000 World Series team, including Mike Piazza, Edgardo Alfonzo, Benny Agbayani, Mike Hampton, Turk Wendell, Rick Reed and John Franco, who threw out the first pitch. Al Leiter, who now broadcasts Yankees games, joined the group on the field before the game.

headline: Drawing on Experience, Blackhawks Extend Their Lead
text: CHICAGO — Patrick Kane, the Chicago Blackhawks’ 21-year-old star, concedes that he and his young teammates were happy just to be there when they faced the Detroit Red Wings in the Western Conference finals last season. Chicago lost in five games.

headline: Scores Feared Dead in Plane Crash in India
text: NEW DELHI — An Air India flight from Dubai carrying 166 people crashed into a heavily wooded valley moments after landing at an airport in southern India Saturday morning, killing almost everyone on board.

headline: Israel: Palestinian Gunmen Killed
text: Israeli soldiers killed two Palestinian gunmen who crossed the border from Hamas-controlled Gaza into Israel on Friday, the Israeli military said. The Palestinian militant group Islamic Jihad said the gunmen, ages 16 and 17, belonged to its military wing. Later Friday, an Israeli soldier was wounded in another firefight with Palestinian militants along the Gaza border.

headline: McNamee Subpoenaed to Testify in Clemens Case
text: Brian McNamee, Roger Clemens’s chief accuser and former trainer, has been subpoenaed by federal authorities to testify Tuesday in Washington before a grand jury seeking to determine whether Clemens lied under oath when he said he had never used performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Champions League Final: Inter Milan Beats Bayern Munich, 2-0
text: From 32 teams, we are down to two.

headline: Ex-Executive Pleads Guilty to Stealing $18 Million
text: A once-rising star in the city’s real estate commercial world who at his peak managed or had ownership stakes in $2.7 billion worth of Manhattan skyscrapers pleaded guilty to stealing more than $18 million from banks and investors, including relatives and close friends, to cover debts and finance his lifestyle as a mogul.

headline: Security Program Found Lacking
text: The Transportation Security Administration started a program that screens for people behaving suspiciously who might threaten aviation security without validating whether it was scientifically sound, a government report released Thursday found. An agency spokesman said the program, Screening Passengers by Observation Technique, which is in more than 160 airports, was based in science and has played a role in more than 1,800 arrests. But the Government Accountability Office also found that, officers in the program had failed to detect at least 16 travelers who were connected to terrorism plots undertaken since 2008.

headline: Moishe Rosen Dies at 78; Founder of Jews for Jesus
text: Moishe Rosen, who was born Jewish, ordained a Baptist minister and went on to found Jews for Jesus, the largest messianic Jewish organization in the world, died Wednesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 78.

headline: Some Views of the Toyota-Tesla Deal
text: Will the Toyota-Tesla collaboration on electric cars, announced on Thursday, be a successful marriage of cultures? Opinion appears split, with one analyst saying that the companies complement each other, and another expecting a rapid divorce.

headline: Backing Off of Guinea
text: As commodity prices drop and several African partners falter, China is backing away from some of its riskiest plans, seeking economic and political stability.

headline: A French Oil Giant's Gamble in Yemen
text: French oil giant Total’s experience in Yemen shows just how far a company will go to develop new energy supplies.

headline: Opiate of the Megaplex
text: Video | Hollywood delivers regular doses of syrupy uplift. This mashup proves it:

headline: Bears Battle: Urlacher vs. Sayers and Butkus
text: There’s an interesting war of words in Chicago. In one corner are Gale Sayers and Dick Butkus. In the other is Brian Urlacher. The argument’s merits aren’t worth debating (what both sides are saying is correct). What is worth debating is whether both sides are speaking within their boundaries. Should former players criticize current players and teams? Should current players criticize former players? Does it matter if the former player is a Hall of Famer, or if the current player is a superstar?

headline: Obama Gives a Bipartisan Commission Six Months to Revise Drilling Rules
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama established a bipartisan national commission on Friday to investigate what caused the devastating oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico and figure out where the government went wrong so as to “make sure it never happens again,” as he put it.

headline: Classic Ad: Oldsmobile’s Hydra-Matic Drive
text: This newsreel advertisement for Oldsmobile’s Hydra-Matic transmission, dated 1941, demonstrates an exciting breakthrough in the world of motor vehicles: the invisible car. The conventional-transmission automobile might be a pain to drive — we’ll take the announcer’s word for it on the 19 distinct manual operations — but you can’t beat the aerodynamics.

headline: Scores Feared Dead in Southern India Plane Crash
text: NEW DELHI — An Air India flight from Dubai carrying 166 people crashed into a heavily wooded valley moments after landing at an airport in southern India on Saturday morning, killing almost everyone on board.

headline: Cuomo Opens Campaign for New York Governor
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced his candidacy for governor on Saturday, saying he was seeking not only to lead New York but to remake a state mired in political scandal and paralyzed by financial crisis.

headline: This Is Getting Interesting
text: O.K., I’ve been having a little trouble keeping up with my blogging lately, so let me give you a quick recap of what I’ve been doing this year.

headline: Saturday Word: Oil Spill Commission
text: President Obama announced this morning that he has appointed former Senator Bob Graham of Florida and William K. Reilly, the former administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, to lead a new bipartisan commission charged with investigating the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: BP, the Oil Flow and the Public Trust
text: In a column on The Times Op-Ed page, four scientists from a team of specialists independently assessing the volume of oil gushing from BP’s destroyed seabed well provide more evidence that the company cannot be trusted to put the public interest ahead of its corporate interests as this disaster continues to unfold. Here’s the researchers’ bottom line, followed by the full list of those involved in this effort, all of whom said they endorse today’s column:

text: Interviews with the former colleagues, challengers and friends of Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: I Am a Horse
text: Jim Gath is the founder and executive director of Tierra Madre Horse Sanctuary in Cave Creek, Ariz. Tierra Madre is the “forever home” to 34 previously abandoned, neglected, injured or abused horses.

headline: Andrew M. Cuomo's Announcement
text: The Cuomo campaign released a video on May 22 announcing the attorney general's run for New York governor.

headline: Expert Head-Scratching on the Plumes
text: The discovery that the oil from the Deepwater Horizon blowout may be spreading beneath the sea in plumes of fine droplets came as dismal news early this week. If that observation holds up to further scientific scrutiny, it would mean that the true dimensions of the problem are still invisible, and sea life is being exposed to a heavy load of toxins.

headline: Obama Outlines National Security Strategy
text: 11:03 a.m. | Updated WEST POINT, N.Y. – President Obama outlined a new national security strategy rooted in diplomatic engagement and international alliances on Saturday as he repudiated his predecessor’s emphasis on unilateral American power and the right to wage preemptive war.

headline: Plane Crash in India
text: An Air India Express plane trying to land at a hilltop airport in southern India overshot the runway, crashed over a cliff and burst into flames, killing almost everyone on board.

headline: Fallon: ‘Most Hated Man in the World’
text: Monologue |  Friday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: In a new interview on ABC’s “Nightline,” Jesse James says he’s probably the most hated man in the world. And the C.E.O. of B.P. was like, “Dude, don’t flatter yourself.”

headline: Letterman: ‘Drilling in the Arctic’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Shell Oil announced that they plan this summer to start drilling in the Arctic this summer. What could possibly go wrong? I mean, honestly. Go ahead, go nuts. Just drill.

headline: Leno: ‘Refused to Send a Witness’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: The Federal agency that regulates offshore oil drilling refused to send a witness to the Senate committee hearing this week. And, of course, people are stunned. “What? There’s actually an agency that regulates oil drilling? Where the hell have they been? Who are these people?”

headline: Clinton Sees U.S. Pavilion at China Expo
text: SHANGHAI — By all accounts, the United States would have been a no-show at the Shanghai Expo had Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton not opened her Rolodex and raised about $60 million in private cash to finance a pavilion here. So it seemed fair that Mrs. Clinton got a rousing cheer from a group of Chinese children when she visited the building on Saturday.

headline: Thai Leaders Seek to Limit Economic Damage
text: BANGKOK — As work crews scrubbed this city’s streets clean of debris and arson scars left by protesters after two months of demonstrations, Thailand’s finance minister turned his attention to another sort of damage control.

headline: Case Said to Conclude Against Head of A.I.G. Unit
text: Federal prosecutors investigating the events leading up to the collapse of the American International Group in 2008 will not bring charges against Joseph Cassano, the chief executive of the unit that insured mortgage-related securities with calamitous results, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: An East Village Blogger Hangs Up His Mouse
text: Late on Tuesday night Bob Arihood posted a photograph of Hare Krishnas chanting rapturously in Tompkins Square Park on his blog, Neither More Nor Less, then added a headline: “Basta ! … No More. This is the Final Post at NMNL.”

headline: Europeans Fear Crisis Threatens Liberal Benefits
text: PARIS — Across Western Europe, the “lifestyle superpower,” the assumptions and gains of a lifetime are suddenly in doubt. The deficit crisis that threatens the euro has also undermined the sustainability of the European standard of social welfare, built by left-leaning governments since the end of World War II.

headline: Down The Memory Hole
text: Richard Green flies into a rage over remarks by Peter Wallison, who declares that

headline: A Front-Row Seat, to Go? Rock Fans Pay for Perks
text: HERSHEY, Pa. — Helena Aguiar had come all the way from São Paulo, Brazil, for a front-row seat to see her favorite band, and she got it: a black metal folding chair with a gold and cherry-red Bon Jovi logo on the cushion, hers to take home. The price: $1,750.

headline: Nose Flute Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Acrostics have been in The New York Times for many years, but did you ever stop to think about all that’s involved in making one? Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon (a k a Hex) would say it’s no big deal, but that’s only because they’ve been doing it so long and are so good at it.

headline: U.S. Implicates North Korean Leader in Attack
text: WASHINGTON — A new American intelligence analysis of a deadly torpedo attack on a South Korean warship concludes that Kim Jong-il, the ailing leader of North Korea, must have authorized the torpedo assault, according to senior American officials who cautioned that the assessment was based on their sense of the political dynamics there rather than hard evidence.

headline: French Officials Consider Relocation Options for the Open
text: PARIS — If the French Tennis Federation relocates its tournament to the suburbs of Paris, will the world’s top tennis players find Mickey Mouse across the net?

headline: Crash Raises Issue of India’s Aviation Oversight
text: MUMBAI, India — An Air India flight that crashed after landing in southern India on Saturday killed 158 people and raised questions about India’s oversight of a rapidly growing aviation industry.

headline: Why Does Regulation Work?
text: In the various responses to my posts on libertarianism, here and here, some commenters have made a point that sounds reasonable, but actually isn’t. I pointed out that the libertarian alternative to regulation — just use tort law to make people pay for the damage they cause — doesn’t work in practice, because when push comes to shove politicians will shield the rich and powerful from paying the real cost. Commenters say, but isn’t that an equally strong reason to believe that regulation won’t work either?

headline: Tea Party Makes Gains, but McConnell Seems Secure
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, keeps a card tucked away in his jacket, or close at hand on his desk in the Capitol, with a running tally of how Senate Republicans would come down on a certain big issue.

headline: Takahashi and the Mets’ Pitching Decisons
text: From the moment he decided to come to the United States last year, Hisanori Takahashi knew he could do what he did Friday night. It may have been a surprise to some, but Takahashi was always confident that he had the talent, the know-how and the guts to be a starter in Major League Baseball.

headline: Unexpected Turns Mark Athletes’ Journey
text: HAVERFORD, Pa. — Each coach at Haverford College has a similar office along one long corridor in the athletic complex.

headline: Colleges’ Search for Athletes Continues to Change
text: HAVERFORD, Pa. — Four years ago, Greg Kannerstein, Haverford College’s director of athletics, surveyed the convoluted intricacies of small-college athletic recruiting as it had evolved in his lengthy career and offered this appraisal.

headline: Afghan Government and Taliban Deny Formal Talks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government and representatives of the Taliban denied on Saturday any connection to reported peace talks on a Maldives island and said the gathering would not lead to anything substantive.

headline: India Plane Crash Killed 158
text: One hundred fifty-eight people were killed when the Boeing 737 crashed outside Mangalore airport in southern India. Eight survived.

headline: Families’ Every Fuss, Archived and Analyzed
text: LOS ANGELES — “Get your jacket.”

headline: Could a Sand Barrier Do the Trick?
text: In a Saturday article in The New York Times, my colleague James G. McKinley Jr. and I examine a plan by Louisiana officials to build 80 miles of sand berms along the state’s southeast coast in a last-ditch effort to keep oil from the Deepwater Horizon blowout from infiltrating the state’s fragile wetlands and estuaries. For almost two weeks, Gov. Bobby Jindal has urged the Coast Guard and the Army Corps of Engineers to sign off on the project, which could cost as much as $350 million.

headline: Many Athletes Tee It Up, but Few Reach Golf’s Elite
text: IRVING, Tex. — What Tony Romo is trying to do is near impossible, like trying to find a nonstriped ball on the practice range.

headline: Ochoa’s Retirement Leaves the L.P.G.A. Tour With Room at the Top
text: GLADSTONE, N.J. — When Lorena Ochoa abdicated her throne last month and retired from the L.P.G.A. Tour at 28, she shifted the spotlight toward a gifted group of players.

headline: When Goodell Learned That Life Is No Game
text: The packages arrive periodically at the N.F.L. office, containing red circular Goodell for Senator campaign buttons. They are 40 years old.

headline: Using Puppet Video, Arizona Governor Defends Immigration Law
text: In the last few weeks, Arizona’s new immigration law has come under heated criticism from many corners, with the most prominent critic being President Obama, who has deemed the measure “misguided.”

headline: Altidore Hopes to Assert Himself After Year of Worrying About Others
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — It was night in England on Jan. 12, just before his bedtime, when Jozy Altidore began to get the troubling news that an earthquake had struck Haiti, birthplace of his parents, home to more than two dozen relatives.

headline: Fighting Words
text: A utility regulator in Arizona fired off a letter to Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa of Los Angeles last week suggesting that Arizona might retaliate after the Los Angeles City Council voted to boycott Arizona businesses because of the state's new law targeting illegal immigrants.

headline: Prime Number
text: 2,246: And counting. As of Thursday, the number of Martian days (each of which, in Earth time, is 24 hours, 39 minutes and 35 seconds) that the NASA rover Opportunity had explored the surface of Mars, surpassing the record set by the Viking 1 lander in November 1982. The rover was designed for a three-month mission. “I thought we’d get six months,” said Steven W. Squyres, an astronomy professor at Cornell and principal investigator for the project. “Six years? No.” At last report, the Opportunity was on its way to a large crater, named Endeavour, that it will not reach for two more years. If it lasts that long.

headline: The Itsy-Bitsy on Barcelona
text: Barcelona has had it with bikinis. Officials want tourists in skimpy beach wear to put on some clothes before parading down city streets, Agence France-Presse reported.

headline: Royals Put Trust in a Master Drafter
text: Mike Arbuckle had many successes as the scouting director for the Philadelphia Phillies. He drafted Ryan Howard in the fifth round in 2001, betting on Howard’s power and overlooking how often he swung and missed. He took Cole Hamels in the first round in 2002, even though Hamels had a broken pitching arm. Other draftees, like Chase Utley and Jimmy Rollins, also turned the Phillies around.

headline: Has Grit, Will Travel
text: There was a time Matt Barnes thought he was destined to catch N.F.L. passes instead of N.B.A. ones. It was not a fantasy of a dreaming youth, but a mind-set developed from an athletic career nearly detoured after Barnes failed to latch on with an N.B.A. team.

text: Because David Wright has had his share of troubles this year, there may be a tendency to point to his final two at-bats of Friday’s 2-1 loss to the Yankees as more examples of the same.
