headline: Breakfast With Willie Mays
text: Many summers ago, my wife, Phyllis, and I took a vacation in Italy. When we got to Rome, she used her travel guide to locate the cultural monuments of that beautiful city.

headline: Negotiating a Divorce for Sudan
text: Sudan is heading toward a break-up between north and south. Southern Sudanese overwhelmingly are expected to favor secession in January’s referendum, and there’s a significant possibility that secession will trigger a new war between north and south. On my recent trip to Sudan, that’s what both sides were nervously talking about. North and South are negotiating some of the issues, but the obstacles are significant and trust is very low. Alan Boswell has written a nice summary for IRIN of some of the key issues to be resolved:

headline: Sure, It’s Big. But Is That Bad?
text: IN the 1990s, Gary Reback, a Silicon Valley lawyer, almost single-handedly brought the antitrust weight of the federal government down on that era’s high-tech heavyweight, Microsoft. Now Mr. Reback contends there is a dangerous new monopolist in the catbird seat: the search giant Google.

headline: Suddenly, the Rating Agencies Don’t Look Untouchable
text: RON GRASSI will admit that when he decided to sue the three major rating agencies in early 2009, he was too enraged to think about his odds. A retired family law specialist who lives in California, he filed his suit in a low boil a few months after $40,000 in Lehman Brothers corporate bonds he owned all but vanished when the investment bank collapsed.

headline: ‘100% Protected’ Isn’t as Safe as It Sounds
text: BROKERS selling complex securities that they once contended were safe and sound have saddled individual investors with billions in losses since the credit bubble burst. Remember auction-rate securities? Those were peddled to investors as just as good as cash — until they no longer were after that market seized up in 2008.

headline: Take Justice Off the Ballot
text: Washington

headline: It’s Not a Career Ladder, It’s an Obstacle Course
text: This interview with Barbara J. Krumsiek, chief executive and chairwoman of the Calvert Group Ltd., an investment firm,  was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Pippi Longstocking, With Dragon Tattoo
text: As American fans of the best-selling Swedish crime novelist Stieg Larsson await the release on Tuesday of the third book in his Millennium trilogy, they might want to catch up on the bloodline of his fiercely unconventional and darkly kooky antiheroine — the girl with the dragon tattoo, the girl who played with fire and the girl who kicked the hornet’s nest.

headline: The Debt of Socrates
text: I WENT down yesterday to the Piraeus with Glaucon, that I might offer up my prayers to the goddesses Brussels and Euro. There we chanced to find among other companions Polemarchus, who was sorely vexed.

headline: Letters to the Editor: Fair’s Fair and Fun’s Fun
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: One Border, Many Sides
text: President Obama, appearing on Wednesday with Felipe Calderón, the president of Mexico, denounced Arizona’s new law on illegal immigration as “a misdirected expression of frustration over our broken immigration system.” Though the law is new, the frustration is most certainly not.

headline: Low-Key Swing Coach May Get High-Profile Student
text: IRVING, Tex. — Those who fashion golf swings are a lot like fashion designers; some come up with a pattern and expect everyone to squeeze into it while others work with each individual’s assets.

headline: For One Promising Pitcher, No Need to Tour the Minors
text: ATLANTA — When Stephen Strasburg, the Washington Nationals minor league pitcher with the meat-eating, road-grading fastball, arrives in the big leagues this summer, trumpets will blare in the nation’s capital and around baseball.

headline: All Victory Is Local
text: MAKE no mistake: The Democratic Party and the Obama White House face a treacherous political environment this November, and Democrats are set to lose quite a few House and Senate seats in the midterm elections.

headline: Résumés Made for Fibbing
text: To fib is human. Each of us tells little lies to make it through the day, and an indistinct line divides fair from foul.

headline: Obama Offers Strategy Based in Diplomacy
text: WEST POINT, N.Y. — President Obama previewed a new national security strategy rooted in diplomatic engagement and international alliances on Saturday as he essentially repudiated his predecessor’s emphasis on unilateral American power and the right to wage pre-emptive war.

headline: Fast Cars, Frozen in Time
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Pieces of Nascar’s past have been scattered for decades in garages, ubiquitous racing halls of fame and team museums serving as unofficial historians for a sport that lacked a home.

headline: Corrections: Economic View: Fear of a Double Dip Could Cause One
text: An article last Sunday about the risk of a double-dip recession omitted one record-setting slide in the Standard & Poor’s composite 500-stock index. In percentage terms, the decline of 4.8 percent on Sept. 11, 1986, was not the biggest one-day drop since April 21, 1933, when the index fell 4.9 percent. Other slides were larger, including the drop of 6.7 percent on May 28, 1962.

headline: Corrections: Is Ben Bernanke Having Fun Yet?
text: An article last Sunday about the challenges facing Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, misidentified the university he attended when he went to a 1975 World Series game. He was a graduate student at M.I.T. that fall, not a senior at Harvard. A spokeswoman for the chairman also says now that because it was an evening game, he might not have skipped class to attend, as he said in a 2008 speech.

headline: Hit-Run Driver Kills Pedestrian in Washington Hts.
text: A man crossing a street in Washington Heights early Saturday was struck and killed by a drunken driver, who then sped away, the police said.

headline: Rebels Attack Base in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Insurgents assaulted Kandahar Air Base, the main military base in southern Afghanistan, on Saturday night, military officials said, in the second attack on a major base in a week.

headline: The ‘Randslide’ and Its Discontents
text: IF there is one certain outcome to recent American elections, it’s this: The results will invariably prove most of the Beltway’s settled political narratives wrong.

headline: Rand Paul and the Perils of Textbook Libertarianism
text: When Rand Paul, the victor in the Republican Senate primary last week in Kentucky, criticized the Civil Rights Act of 1964, singling out the injustice of non-discriminatory practices it imposed on private businesses, the resulting furor delighted Democrats and unsettled Republicans.

headline: High-Tech Alternatives to High-Cost Care
text: MENTION health care reform and the image that instantly comes to mind is a big government program. But there is another broad transformation in health care under way, a powerful force for decentralized innovation. It is fueled in good part by technology — low-cost computing devices, digital sensors and the Web.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 23
text: With the primary season in full swing, this Sunday’s talk shows are all about the midterm elections.

headline: An Ad Engine to Put ‘Mad Men’ Out of Business
text: NO costly copy writers or heirs of “Mad Men” are needed to write a new kind of ad for small businesses that want to advertise on the Web: computers create the ads instead.

headline: Rule No. 1: Make Money by Avoiding Rules
text: From the earliest days of capitalism, those skilled at making money have proven creative at evading the regulators.

headline: Resisting the Urge to Sell Low
text: IF you’ve got money in the stock market, take a deep breath: It’s one of those moments. The market is lurching, and that is precisely when impulsive behavior can hurt the most.

headline: Lies as Wishes
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Moonshine or the Kids?
text: MONT-BELO, Congo Republic

headline: Challenging the Opium Harvest
text: Opium growers and smugglers, who had long been unchallenged, face tough choices created by the poor crop, new Afghan government and military pressure.

headline: Bumper to Bumper
text: The veteran global investor Mohamed El-Erian, who runs Pimco and has lived through many a financial crisis, recently issued a report describing the new, perilous state of today’s global economy. He described it like this: “The world is on a journey to an unstable destination, through unfamiliar territory, on an uneven road and, critically, having already used its spare tire.”

headline: In Afghan Fields, a Challenge to Opium’s Luster
text: COMBAT OUTPOST HANSON, Afghanistan — The annual Afghan opium harvest finished this month with production sharply down from last year, Afghan farmers and American military officers say. Now, growers and smugglers who had long been unchallenged here face tough choices created by the poor crop and new government and military pressure.

headline: Jobs and the Class of 2010
text: Commencement is supposed to be filled with hope, but for the class of 2010, these are grim times. Over the past year, the unemployment rate for college graduates under age 25 has averaged 9.1 percent. For the roughly half of high school graduates under 25 and not in college, the average is 22.8 percent.

headline: The Morning Line: Busy Day for NYRA
text: Bennett Liebman is the Executive Director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

headline: Scuttle ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: A prime opportunity is at hand for Congress to repeal the repressive “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy that has drummed out more than 13,000 capable members of the military simply because they are gay men and lesbians.

headline: Trenton Gets It Right
text: A coalition of community groups in Trenton is issuing photo identification cards to illegal immigrants. The cards are not government IDs, though they are accepted by many check-cashing companies, libraries, stores, and medical clinics, and at public parks and pools.

headline: Hawaii’s Race to the Bottom
text: Summer vacation for Hawaii’s schoolchildren starts on Wednesday. About 170,000 young people will be hitting the beach, the mall, grandma’s house, the sofa — all the places they have already been spending most Fridays for nearly the entire school year. Seventeen school days were sliced out of their educations by a series of school-closing teacher furloughs to help close a nearly $1 billion state budget gap.

headline: How Will Greece Get Off the Dole?
text: GREECE is a relatively wealthy country, or so the numbers seem to show. Per-capita income is more than $30,000 — about three-quarters of the level of Germany.

headline: The Candidate and the War
text: THE Times reported last week that Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, the bright hope of Democrats to retain a critical seat in the United States Senate, has sometimes falsely claimed to be a Vietnam veteran. Predictably, in an election year with control of Congress in play, the report sparked plenty of outrage — much of it directed at The Times.

headline: A Guide to Complaints That Get Results
text: THE HAGGLER asked readers to send their favorite techniques and stratagems for prevailing in consumer disputes, and let’s just say you came through. Loud and clear. And in very large numbers, with some rather novel ideas.

headline: Last Entry Is Early Leader in the Clubhouse
text: IRVING, Tex. — The last player to make the 156-man field for the Byron Nelson Championship, Mark Hensby was the early leader in the clubhouse Saturday. He shot six-under-par 64 for a 54-hole total of seven-under 203.

headline: For Hollywood Producers, Is the Glamour Gone?
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Born for Business
text: MY great-grandfather moved from Jerusalem to Colombia at age 20 because he heard there were business opportunities there. He went from town to town selling textiles on horseback although he didn’t speak a word of Spanish.

headline: Graduates’ First Job: Marketing Themselves
text: THIS spring, college seniors are entering a better job market than the class of 2009 faced. Unfortunately, that is not saying much because 2009 was one of the worst years in the history of hiring.

headline: In N.H.L. Playoffs, Home Ice Has Lost Its Luster
text: One benefit of a strong regular season is the chance to have home-ice advantage in the playoffs. But playing in a friendly environment is not what it used to be in the N.H.L.

headline: Kandahar: A Dossier and Timeline
text: The Prize

headline: Into Kandahar, Yesterday and Tomorrow
text: LONDON — In the postcards of the mind, it is the starkest of all the images of Kandahar, dating back more than 20 years to the period immediately after Soviet troops withdrew from the city, and standing ever since as a grim warning of the folly of foreign military adventures in Afghanistan: hundreds of acres of rubble, whole quarters of the city reduced to fields of blasted concrete and steel, and further out, in the poorer districts, a shattered chocolate-box of a landscape formed by ragged mud walls that had once been home to tens of thousands of people seeking refuge from the war raging in the Afghan hinterland.

headline: Cuomo Addresses Supporters in Manhattan
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, who announced his candidacy for New York governor on Sunday morning, spoke behind Tweed Courthouse in Manhattan. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: N.B.A. Penalizes Talk About James
text: Everyone, it seems, is eager to talk about the expected bonanza that awaits in this summer’s free-agent class with the likes of LeBron James and Chris Bosh expected to be available.

headline: The Killings at Les Cayes Prison
text: When the Haitian police stormed a prison after rioting in January, they fatally shot at least 12 detainees and wounded 40 others, a New York Times investigation found.

headline: On the Fast Track Off the Ice
text: Apolo Anton Ohno skated around the rink at Rockefeller Center last month and threw T-shirts that read “I ♥ Washington State spuds” into the crowd. It was Ohno’s return to the ice after winning three Olympic medals, one silver and two bronze, in short-track speedskating at the Vancouver Games in February.  For his career, Ohno has eight Olympic medals, the most for an American in the Winter Games. Ohno, who turned 28 on Saturday, has sped up instead of slowing down.

headline: Financial Overhaul Bill Poses Big Test for Lobbyists
text: WASHINGTON — Last Wednesday, Representative David Scott, Democrat of Georgia, mingled with insurance and financial executives and other supporters at a lunchtime fund-raiser in his honor at a chic Washington wine bar before rushing out to cast a House vote.

headline: Flip-Flops
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Yaakov David Ben has taken a fun concept, put it in Shortz’s Will hands and given us a challenge fit for a day sun afternoon. There’s no unifying thread behind the phrases that have been used, and the flip-flopped word pairs appear in different positions, some at the start and some at the end of their respective phrases.

headline: Escape Attempt Led to Killings of Unarmed Inmates
text: LES CAYES, Haiti — When the earth shook violently on Jan. 12, the inmates in this southern city’s squalid prison clamored to be released, screaming: “Help! We’re going to die in here.”

headline: After Quake, Panic and Death in a Haitian Prison
text: After the Haitian earthquake, prisoners crowded into a handful of cells rioted, and the official response to their actions turned deadly.

headline: Senator Bennet Trails Challenger in Colorado Party Assembly
text: If the political rules of Colorado were similar to those in neighboring Utah, yet another United States senator would have fallen to defeat on Saturday.

headline: Turkish Party Picks Leader
text: MUGLA, Turkey — Turkey’s main opposition party elected a new leader on Saturday after a sex scandal earlier this month led to the abrupt resignation of his predecessor, who had led the party for 18 years.

headline: ‘The Unwanted Sound of Everything We Want’
text: Noise Is Interested in You

headline: No Afternoon Stroll, but Close, as Flyers Cruise to a Commanding Lead
text: MONTREAL — Saturday night is the time for hockey here, not Saturday afternoon, and it has been that way for generations. Maybe it was that disruption to their circadian rhythms that did in the Canadiens, most notably in the second period, when the Flyers outshot them, 13-1, and outscored them, 2-0, as Philadelphia won, 3-0, and took a three-games-to-one lead in the Eastern Conference finals.

headline: It’s All Shown in the Core
text: The common-sense axiom that it takes a 25-man team to win is practically written on the Mets’ clubhouse walls. The mantra for the slumping Jose Reyes and the brooding David Wright is eagerly echoed by the reeling general manager, Omar Minaya.

headline: Surveillance Suspected as Spacecraft’s Main Role
text: A team of amateur sky watchers has pierced the veil of secrecy surrounding the debut flight of the nation’s first robotic spaceplane, finding clues that suggest the military craft is engaged in the development of spy satellites rather than space weapons, which some experts have suspected but the Pentagon strongly denies.

headline: Hernia Surgery for Bocanegra
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — Carlos Bocanegra, the United States captain, recently underwent hernia surgery after being injured with his French club team, Coach Bob Bradley said Saturday.

headline: Spokes | More Room to Ride in East Harlem
text: Edward George rode his Titan folding bike, with its twin mirrors pointing up like antennae, from his apartment on 110th Street and Madison Avenue to the Gabaron Barber Shop on Second Avenue and 119th Street. But, as he often does, Mr. George, 82, took to the sidewalk for the trip because he feels unsafe in the fast-moving traffic.

headline: Specter Legacy Is Study of the Perils of a Switch
text: After decades in public life, Senator Arlen Specter has left his mark on the big issues of his time, from President John F. Kennedy’s assassination and President Bill Clinton’s impeachment trial to matters of terrorism and biomedical research. He steered billions of federal dollars home to Pennsylvania and played a major role in shaping the makeup of the Supreme Court and the federal judiciary.

headline: Allan Manings, Writer and Creator of Television Shows, Dies at 86
text: Allan Manings, an Emmy-winning writer who created “One Day at a Time,” a hit sitcom about a divorced woman and her teenage daughters that was progressive for the mid-1970s, died on May 12 in Los Angeles. He was 86.

headline: Ready to Ship in Hawaii: 20,000 Tons of Garbage
text: KAPOLEI, Hawaii — At first glance, it does not look much like garbage. More than 20,000 tons of it have been shrink-wrapped into green bales that are neatly stacked, ready to ship about 2,300 miles across the Pacific to the mainland as an another export — “opala,” as garbage is called in Hawaiian.

headline: David E. Durston, Who Wrote and Directed ‘I Drink Your Blood,’ Dies at 88
text: Men become animals and eat their victims! ... You will sit and watch this shocking ugliness splashing across the screen! ... Can you take it? ...

headline: Graduation at West Point
text: President Obama delivered a commencement address at the United States Military Academy at West Point.

headline: Despite Leak, Louisiana Is Still Devoted to Oil
text: MORGAN CITY, La. — In some parts of the country, the sight of oil drifting toward the Louisiana coast, oozing into the fragile marshlands and bringing large parts of the state’s economy to a halt, has prompted calls to stop offshore drilling indefinitely, if not altogether.

headline: College Offers Quirky Shirts Designed by Students
text: Forget the standard college sweatshirt.

headline: Too Soon to Tell on Vazquez
text: The Yankees skipped one of Javier Vazquez’s starts because of ineffectiveness. They skipped another because they needed him in the bullpen. It is too early to tell, Manager Joe Girardi said, if they will skip Vazquez a third time, this one because of injury.

headline: A Small Town in Arkansas Mourns Two Slain Officers
text: WEST MEMPHIS, Ark. — The sewing machine at the front of Tobey and Kelly Duncan’s outdoor apparel store whirred continuously on Saturday as seamstresses stitched together one new police dress uniform after the next.

headline: Bay Has Struggled to Fill the Shoes Laid Out for Him
text: The Mets signed Jason Bay for his power. He knows it, and he feels its absence. When he scorched a double off the left-center-field wall against Mariano Rivera in the ninth inning Friday, he grimaced upon arrival at second base. He was still stuck on one home run for the season.

headline: A Silicon Valley Group Gives Voice to Voiceless
text: Adrian Avila was a 17-year-old street graffiti artist who had a job at a local hot dog stand when he wandered into the offices of Silicon Valley De-Bug eight years ago. He wasn’t sure what he was looking for. But he found it.

headline: State Lags in Dental Health Care for Children
text: Early in the morning on April 2, Dominique Allen’s family rushed her to the emergency room at Petaluma Valley Hospital because of jaw pain and inflammation.

headline: Kerr, After Wobbly Start, Steers the Suns’ Revival
text: PHOENIX — As a sweet-shooting guard, Steve Kerr brought a measure of predictability to an unpredictable game. His wrists flicked, the ball sailed, the net snapped.

headline: Family Time, Dad Time, Down Time
text: For the last 16 years, Sedge Thomson has hosted West Coast Live, a two-hour radio variety show broadcast Saturdays on KALW 91.7 FM. Mr. Thomson, with his signature baritone and low-key style, interviews musicians, writers, actors and artists about their lives and work. He lives in Berkeley with his wife, the novelist Sylvia Brownrigg, and their two children Samuel, 8, and Romilly, 6. Mr. Thomson’s son from a previous marriage, 14-year-old Henry, spends every other week at the house. His words have been edited and condensed.

headline: Inter Milan Wins Champions League Title
text: MADRID — As the stadium loudspeakers announced the lineup for the Champions League final between Inter Milan and Bayern Munich, the name of José Mourinho, Inter’s Portuguese coach, drew a thunderous shout of approval from the section of fans in Inter’s black and blue.

headline: How About a Beer?
text: My Sunday column probably makes me look like a sanctimonious misanthrope. I argue that one of the problems that we haven’t adequately acknowledged in trying to fight poverty is the degree to which money is poorly spent.

headline: Finding the Rhythms in a Playwright’s Words
text: After a run-through early last week of the play “God’s Ear,” the director Erika Chong Shuch assembled her cast for a post-rehearsal debriefing. The actors, members of the Shotgun Players, were dissatisfied with their work that evening on this dark and surreal drama, written by Jenny Schwartz. They said they felt their collective lack of focus had sapped the play of its energy.

headline: A Homecoming of Sorts
text: It must have been a thrill for Kevin Russo to record his first career hit and drive in both of the Yankees’ runs Friday night in Queens, so close to his Long Island birthplace, right? A thrill, definitely, but Russo identifies more with Boulder, Colo., where he moved when he was 3.

headline: State Lags in Dental Care for Children and Other Highlights From Sunday’s Bay Area Pages
text: Painful Neglect |  It is not unusual in California for children to endure crippling pain and disability from untreated tooth decay — by the age of 5, 28 percent of the state’s children have untreated dental decay. Dr. Jared I. Fine, the dental health administrator at the Alameda County Public Health Department, said, “We have an epidemic of dental disease in children that’s absurdly pervasive.”

headline: To Honor Teammate, Virginia Maintains Perspective as Its Season Ends
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — For the first time since the death of the senior defender Yeardley Love, the Virginia women’s lacrosse team stepped away from its campus, away from the place where memories of Love — both sorrowful and pleasant — remain vivid.

headline: Corrections
text: SPORTS

headline: Recession Played a Part, but ShoreBank Wounded Itself, Too
text: As some of the nation’s biggest financial institutions rushed to assemble a $150 million bailout of ShoreBank last week, people knowledgeable about the bank’s image as a successful, crusading lender in some of the country’s most impoverished communities began focusing on a related issue: How ShoreBank had fallen nearly to the point of collapse.

headline: What a More Humane Welfare System Could Look Like
text: Helen Olbrecht, 54, of Oak Lawn, lost her office manager’s job and is left with two daughters, a grandchild, a dog and a stiff mortgage. She searches fitfully for work and gets by on $318 a month in welfare and $286 in food stamps, while dealing with a foreclosure notice on her home.

headline: Pressed Together, Mets Feel The Heat
text: Perhaps sensing a growing tightness and mounting pressure within his team, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel did something unusual Friday night. He called every member of the team into his office and held an impromptu meeting to remind his players that the point of baseball is to have fun, and the best way to do that is to win.

headline: At Museum, ‘RoboSue’ Roars to Life
text: The Field Museum of Natural History this week will open an exhibit that features a reincarnated Sue — the museum’s iconic Tyrannosaurus rex — as a lifelike animatronic creature that turns its head to track visitors’ movements and lets out a loud roar.

headline: After Cubs, Baker Feels the Love in Cincinnati
text: CINCINNATI — For a certain segment of Cubs fans, a look at the National League Central standings early last week was doubly distressing: The Cubs were in fifth place, seven games under .500 and closer to last place than to first, and the Cincinnati Reds held the division lead.

headline: Michael Kuchwara, Prolific Theater Writer, Dies at 63
text: Michael Kuchwara, who found a worldwide readership in writing about the theater for The Associated Press, as both reporter and critic, for a quarter-century, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 63.

headline: A 16-Year-Old Amateur Trails by 6, but Fans Treat Him Like a Champion
text: IRVING, Tex. — There was a deafening roar on the first hole at the T.P.C. Four Seasons resort Saturday, the ground practically quaking under Kenny Perry’s feet as he stood at the second tee box.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Landis Joins Race’s Crowd, but Riders Ignore Him
text: LOS ANGELES — Floyd Landis, the cyclist who recently admitted to doping after four years of vehemently denying it, showed up at the Tour of California on Saturday, looking like an important man.

headline: Feeling Urgency to Win, the Mets Go Out and Do It
text: Baseball people are conditioned to say that every game is important, regardless of the opponent, the circumstances, or juncture of the schedule. But sometimes their actions suggest that some games may be more important than others. The night after the Mets called a team meeting to stress the urgency of winning immediately (and frequently), their manager, Jerry Manuel, on Saturday called on his closer, Francisco Rodriguez, to record the final five outs of what became a 5-3 victory against the Yankees at Citi Field.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about “MacGruber” erroneously attributed a distinction to the film. It was “The Blues Brothers” (1980)  not “MacGruber”  that was the first film based on a “Saturday Night Live” sketch to be rated R.

headline: Not Worried About Rivera
text: Mariano Rivera has given up runs in three straight games, only the sixth time he has done so as a reliever. Therefore some are thinking his aura of invincibility is waning, his career is winding down, his age is catching up, and something must be wrong. Except every year Rivera seems to encounter a rough patch, and every year he rebounds and regains his indomitable form.

headline: In High-Stakes Games, Rivals Can Suddenly Become Allies
text: When it comes to strange bedfellows, politics has nothing on chess.

headline: Celtics Leave No Doubt, Overwhelming Magic
text: BOSTON — These are not old legs — not with the 15-year veteran Kevin Garnett swishing jumpers off the dribble and the equally seasoned Rasheed Wallace putting the finishing touches on alley oops.

headline: The Suns’ Long Road
text: If it is true that there is no place like home, then the Phoenix Suns may have an excuse for opening the Western Conference finals with consecutive losses to the Los Angeles Lakers: their last home game was May 5.

headline: Republican Wins in Blue Hawaii
text: A Republican candidate has prevailed over a crowded special election to represent President Obama’s Hawaiian birthplace in the House of Representatives. The victory of Charles Djou, a Honolulu city councilman, was not a surprise, but it served to bolster his party as it seeks to chip away at the Democratic majority.

headline: Vows: Sona & Justin
text: Sona Rai and Justin Collins share a unique mix of Sikh, Jewish, and Catholic cultural backgrounds in their families.

headline: Two Aces in the Batter’s Box
text: As former aces in the American League Central, C.C. Sabathia and Johan Santana would regularly pitch against each other. Sabathia owns a 3-1 edge in games against Santana, according to the Elias Sports Bureau, with their last matchup coming on Sept. 3, 2007, when he pitched eight shutout innings for the Indians against Santana’s Twins.

headline: The Graying of the Gym
text: Adults 55 and older make up the faster-growing segment of membership nationwide, and gyms are catering to them.

headline: The Winter Antiques Show
text: The Park Avenue Armory hosted the antiques market's premier annual event this January. Attendance was up and sales were strong.

headline: Nuclear Power: A Resurgence, an Opportunity
text: Seventeen companies have applied to build 26 new nuclear power reactors around the United States.

headline: A Prague Landmark Is Reborn
text: Behind the newly restored Renaissance facade of a landmark palace, “all of Mala Strana comes alive in one place.” That is how Petr Kutilek, a 34-year-old marketing executive, summed up his recent visit to Malostranska Beseda (Malostranske namesti 21; www.malostranska-beseda.cz), a 15th-century building that re-opened last month after a $10.5 million renovation. The space, once a town hall, most recently housed a grungy rock club until it closed two years ago, and now includes two bars, a restaurant and cafe, concert hall and art gallery over five levels.

headline: An American in the Men’s Final? Now That Would Be an Upset
text: Where is the American clay-court version of Rafael Nadal? Maybe for now a better question for American tennis fans would be, Where’s our Martin Verkerk?

headline: The Hassles of Getting Back Items Left on Planes
text: If you happen to be on a United Airlines flight and find a blue iPod Nano around seat 23A, please let me know.

headline: The Rail Bookshelf: ‘Equine ER’
text: Leslie Guttman is an independent journalist and freelance writer. “Equine ER: Stories from a Year in the Life of an Equine Veterinary Hospital” is her first book. It chronicles a year inside Rood & Riddle Equine Hospital, one of the country’s largest hospitals for horses, located in the Bluegrass.

headline: Things I Didn’t Say

headline: The Wellness Industry as an Echo of the Internet in the 1990s
text: At a health innovation and investment conference in California earlier this month, there was a lot of energy and excitement about the emerging health and wellness industry. The wellness movement, as it’s called, is seen as both a social phenomenon and a big investment opportunity.

text: [May 24, 10:29 p.m. | Updated  Contest alert below.]

headline: The Sunday Word: Finance Lobbyists
text: As lawmakers prepare to hash out the differences between the House and Senate versions of the financial regulatory legislation, an army of lobbyists from Wall Street is gearing up for a fight against the bill’s most detrimental provision. As The Times’s Eric Lichtblau and Edward Wyatt report, the banking industry was confident that the provision forcing banks to spin off their derivatives businesses would be scrapped, but in the haste to pass the bill, it remained.

headline: Few Surprises, and Even Less Left to the Imagination, on Opening Day
text: PARIS — Most of the first-day drama at the French Open lasted about 15 minutes on Sunday morning, then reappeared briefly as the long shadows blanketed Court Philippe Chatrier.

headline: Japan Relents on U.S. Base on Okinawa
text: TOKYO — Reneging on a prominent campaign promise, Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama told outraged residents of Okinawa on Sunday that an American air base would be moved only to the north side of the island rather than off the island.

headline: All-Time Cycle Team Leaders
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: U.S. Presses China to Punish North Korea for Ship
text: BEIJING — The United States began pressing the Chinese on Sunday to back punitive measures against North Korea over strong evidence it had torpedoed a South Korean warship, but American officials acknowledged China’s reluctance to discipline its isolated neighbor.

headline: 3 Shot Dead in Queens and the Bronx
text: Three people were killed and five others were wounded in two unrelated shootings in the Bronx and in Queens early Sunday morning, the police said.

headline: On ‘Friday Night Lights,’ Buddy Makes Himself Known
text: The casting and performances on “Friday Night Lights” are so famously top-notch every week that the slightest deviation from the sublime can really irritate (see my harping about Kyle Chandler last week) and, at the same time any moment can get lost in the whole. So let’s take some time to celebrate Brad Leland as Buddy Garrity, the most purely avid patron of high school football in all of Dillon (O.K. maybe all of Texas). I say “purely” because Buddy has been supplanted this season and last by the twisted Panther fanatic Joe McCoy whose interest in Panther football is more or less entirely a function of his obsessive control of his star quarterback son. Except for Julie Taylor no kid in Dillon really avoids abuse of some kind – mostly it is the abuse of absent parentage – but in young J.D. McCoy’s case the abuse is both emotional and physical. Joe McCoy is a really, really awful guy – venal, entitled, misogynistic- – and Buddy has finally had enough of him. Poolside at Joe’s giant house – a house that seems like one big wet bar – Buddy gives it to him and calls him a cancer for poisoning the well of Dillon football love with his base antagonisms and threats and psycho micro-managing.

headline: Heartland of Thailand, Still Angry and Divided
text: UDON THANI, Thailand — “Hello, Abhisit!” shouted a young man, holding an imaginary telephone with an imaginary connection to the prime minister. “Thank you for giving us stupid buffaloes this train! Too bad you killed us!”

South Korea’s charge last week that North Korea sank one of its warships, killing 46 crewmen, makes that role exponentially harder.

headline: Gibbs on Sestak’s Claim of a Job Offer
text: The White House appeared to confirm Sunday that the Obama administration had some kind of conversations with Representative Joe Sestak, the Pennsylvania Democrat who was challenging Senator Arlen Specter, but asserted that the conversations were not inappropriate.

headline: Louisiana Officials Threaten Action if Spill Response Proves Inadequate
text: VENICE, La. — Louisiana state and local officials continued to hammer BP and the federal agencies responding to the Gulf of Mexico oil spill on Sunday, repeatedly threatening to “take matters into our own hands” if the response fell short.

headline: A Conversation With the Top Prize Winner of Cannes
text: CANNES, France — The Thai director Apichatpong Weerasethakul is known for his shape-shifting tales. Many of his films, like “Tropical Malady” (2004) and “Syndromes of a Century” (2006), seem to start over midway through, as if reincarnated.

headline: No Worries, Israel Insists, Defense Drill Is Just a Drill
text: JERUSALEM — As Israel embarked on a large-scale civil defense exercise on Sunday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu sought to reassure Israelis and some jittery Arab neighbors that the nationwide drill was not meant to signal a deterioration in security or an imminent war.

headline: Bocanegra Says He Is Ready to Play
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — Defender Carlos Bocanegra, the captain of the United States soccer team, said Sunday that he felt healthy enough to play in exhibition matches Tuesday and Saturday after undergoing surgery for a sports hernia earlier this month.

headline: On Friday, Security and Politics at Cannes
text: CANNES, France – At 8:30 a.m. on Friday at the Cannes Film Festival, just before the first daily screening, attendees were greeted with a disquieting sight: four police vans were parked in front of the festival headquarters and numerous gendarmes, some in riot gear, had taken up position on the street and even next to the red carpet. We festival-goers are used to security checks at Cannes. Guards electronically check your bags whenever you enter the headquarters, a massive building called the Palais. Another guard checks or rather glances at the contents of your bags, while a third passes an electronic wand over your body, rituals that grow lax as the festival wears on. (Similar security checks are common at studio screenings in the United States.)

headline: The Morning Line: Some Work, but a Lot of Commentary
text: Bennett Liebman is the Executive Director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

headline: Jose Lima, Former All-Star Pitcher, Dies at 37

headline: Lodge Kerrigan’s Hall of Mirrors Comes to Cannes
text: CANNES, France — Like his last two films, “Claire Dolan” (1998) and “Keane” (2004), Lodge Kerrigan’s “Rebecca H. (Return to the Dogs)” is named for its protagonist. And in keeping with the work of this American independent auteur, it is premised on getting close, often disturbingly so, to the character under scrutiny. The difference is that this time, the character herself is hard to keep in focus.

text: Good news for Patriots fans, for football fans, for fantasy football fans. (Even most Jets fans probably wouldn’t begrudge him his health.)

headline: The Joys of Jumpology
text: When the photographer Philippe Halsman said, “Jump,” no one asked how high. People simply pushed off or leapt up to the extent that physical ability and personal decorum allowed. In that airborne instant Mr. Halsman clicked the shutter. He called his method jumpology.

headline: Breathing Life Into Henry Roth
text: The writer Henry Roth was a tortured, hard-luck case who at the end life enjoyed an unexpected redemption. Blocked for decades, full of doubt and self-loathing, he began writing again in his late 80s, even though crippled by rheumatoid arthritis, and finished four new novels, two of which he lived to see into print before his death in 1995. Now, almost miraculously, there is a fifth, “An American Type,” which W. W. Norton will publish on June 7.

text: Laura Linney was nominated for a Tony Award this year for her performance as an emotionally and physically wounded photojournalist in Donald Margulies‘s play “Time Stands Still,” which closed in March. In his review, Ben Brantley called Ms. Linney “an actress of unusual economy and seemingly innate grace” whose “tough but gently shaded performance honors the character’s seeming contradictions.”

headline: Insurgents Attack Palace in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — At least 14 people were killed and more than 25 were wounded on Sunday in heavy fighting between government troops and insurgents who attacked the presidential palace with mortars, witnesses and officials said.

headline: Sitting With Marina
text: Performance art, as currently practiced, emerged as an avant garde movement in the 1960s and ’70s, and some of its features made it difficult to visualize how it might make the transition from galleries and public spaces to the more institutional environment of the museum.

headline: Limbaugh, Somewhat Airbrushed
text: In July 2008 The New York Times Magazine published Zev Chafets’s appreciative profile of a surprisingly candid Rush Limbaugh. There was spontaneity to the piece, perhaps because it had come about only by accident, after Mr. Chafets’s original assignment to write about John McCain (and interview Mr. Limbaugh in the process) fell through. And there was an overriding idea that still holds true: The only way to form a fair opinion about Mr. Limbaugh is to listen to him directly. His pronouncements are distorted and yanked out of context by acolytes and enemies alike.

headline: ‘Rush Limbaugh’
text: Chapter 1: “I Hope He Fails”

headline: Lives Lost in the Oil Age
text: On Sunday, a column by Doug Simpson on AOL News noted that relatives of some of the 11 men who died aboard the Deepwater Horizon were upset that most coverage was focused on the unfolding environmental disaster. This may change on Tuesday, when Transocean holds a memorial service in Jackson, Miss., for those who were lost. It’s important to recall, as you gas up or pay your bill for heating oil, that there are invisible costs of many kinds attending the conveniences of the fossil-fuel age.

headline: Iranian Says Uranium Deal Off if Sanctions Are On
text: CAIRO — The speaker of Iran’s Parliament said Sunday that his country would abandon a deal to ship some of its nuclear fuel to Turkey and rethink its cooperation with the International Atomic Energy Agency if the United States pushed new sanctions through the United Nations Security Council.

headline: Cleveland’s Voluptuous ‘Lulu,’ Surrounded by Beethoven
text: In assessing an orchestra, classical music insiders and audiences can get too caught up with the issue of sound. Yes, to be enveloped in the sheer sonic splendor of a great orchestra is a wonderful thing. But I am willing to trade a little aural roughness for bracing performances when a conductor and players challenge themselves in the best sense and bring striking insights to standard repertory or champion living composers. There is more at stake for the American orchestra than the pursuit of glorious sound.

headline: If Not 76 Trombones, Everything Else a One-Man Band Can Handle
text: Imagine a player piano. Now imagine you’re a guitarist and composer named Pat Metheny and that you have a kind of player piano that can both play what you’ve composed for it — not through perforated paper but digital technology — and also replicate whatever you’re playing on the guitar. You can also play a long phrase on the guitar and command the piano to loop the phrase, so that you can play against the loop.

headline: Dudamel Presents a Popular Pairing
text: Gustavo Dudamel began his tenure as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic in October with a concert that brought together John Adams’s “City Noir,” a work composed for the occasion, and Mahler’s First Symphony. Since then the orchestra has gotten plenty of mileage out of that program: it was broadcast on television and radio at the time; Deutsche Grammophon has released recordings of both works (separately) on iTunes; and the pairing was revived as one of the programs Mr. Dudamel led on his first cross-country tour with the orchestra. The tour ended with the Adams and Mahler program at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday evening.

headline: Zimbabwe Past and Present in a Mix of Reality and Myth
text: The title of Nora Chipaumire’s new dance is a mouthful and, fittingly, loaded with meaning: “lions will roar, swans will fly, angels will wrestle heaven, rains will break: gukurahundi.”

text: One of the true gentlemen of bridge, Bill Passell, 79, died of multiple myeloma on May 9 in his hometown, Boynton Beach, Fla.

text: You could listen to a lot of dry lectures by a lot of windy history professors and still not learn as much about race issues in the century after the Civil War as you do in “A Place Out of Time: The Bordentown School.”

headline: Thai Filmmaker Wins Palme d’Or at Cannes
text: CANNES, France  On Sunday evening the 63rd Cannes Film Festival came to a shocking, exhilarating close with the Palme d’Or going to “Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives” from the Thai filmmaker Apichatpong Weerasethakul. Surely the only Palme winner to feature sex between a princess and a thrashing catfish, “Boonmee” is a fantastical tale about a dying man whose past lives  and ghostly relatives  enraptured some critics while turning others off. The speculation that it might appeal to the jury president, Tim Burton, along with some of his more discerning fellow jury members, proved true.

headline: The Green Ogre Stumbles
text: “Shrek Forever After” was No. 1 at North American multiplexes over the weekend but failed to meet even cautious expectations, probably because of franchise fatigue and pushback from consumers over the rising cost of 3-D tickets. The movie, from DreamWorks Animation, brought in an estimated $71.3 million, far from chump change but sharply below opening tallies for the franchise’s previous two movies, which did not have premium-priced 3-D tickets to prop them up. DreamWorks expects positive word of mouth and a lack of competition from other family films to help “Shrek Forever After” blossom into a substantial hit, much as the studio’s “How to Train Your Dragon” overcame a soft opening weekend. DreamWorks always expected the fourth “Shrek” to have a weaker debut than “Shrek the Third” (more than $122 million opening; $799 million global total), partly because of the franchise’s age. Last week analysts lowered expectations for “Shrek Forever After” based on prerelease surveys. Doug Creutz, an analyst at Cowen & Company, wrote that those surveys pointed to an opening “below the $110 million to $140 million range we think the film needs to hit in order to meet investor expectations.” Other analysts had lowered expectations to $75 million to $90 million. “Iron Man 2” was second over the weekend with $26.6 million, for a new total of $251.3 million. “Robin Hood” was third with $18.7 million ($66.1 million total). “Letters to Juliet” was fourth with $9.1 million ($27.4 million total), and “Just Wright” was fifth with $4.2 million ($14.6 million total).

headline: On Blaming Bush
text: Jonathan Chait has an item about the largely successful attempt not just to blame Obama for our current economic difficulties, but to “socially stigmatize” anyone who points out that most of the blame actually lies with his predecessor. Indeed. And may I point out that the sainted Reagan was still very much blaming Jimmy Carter for the economy’s troubles well past this point in his administration? (Not to mention that circa 2004 the Bushies were still trying to get the NBER to postdate the beginning of the 2001 recession back to Clinton.)

headline: Madonna Reprimands Malawi Court
text: Madonna, below, said she was “shocked and saddened” by a court in Malawi’s decision to sentence a gay couple to 14 years of hard labor in prison, Agence France-Presse reported. After their engagement party was announced on the front page of a newspaper in December, Tiwonge Chimbalanga and Steven Monjeza were arrested. Last week they were convicted of unnatural acts and gross indecency, and given the maximum sentence. In a statement on the Web site of her foundation, Raising Malawi (raisingmalawi.org), Madonna, who has adopted two children from that country, said two innocent men were being sent to prison. She wrote: “As a matter of principle, I believe in equal rights for all people, no matter what their gender, race, color, religion, or sexual orientation. This week, Malawi took a giant step backward.” She asked that the progressive people in Malawi, and around the world, “challenge this decision in the name of human dignity and equal rights for all,” by adding their names to her statement.

headline: In the Wings
text: John Cleese, below, an original cast member of “Monty Python’s Flying Circus,” is bringing “an evening of well-honed anecdotes” and “details of recent surgical procedures and unprovoked attacks on former colleagues, especially Michael Palin,” to Britain next year, in what he calls “The Alimony Tour,” he told the BBC News. The show will chronicle his divorce from his third wife, Alyce Faye Eichelberger, in 2008, which culminated in a settlement reported to be more than $17 million. The tour is planned to begin in May of next year in Cambridge, with shows in Birmingham, Salford, Liverpool, Oxford, Leeds, Edinburgh and Bristol. ... Though the regional debut of the musical stage adaptation of “Heathers,” the 1988 cult film starring Winona Ryder and Christian Slater, has been postponed, producers will offer a concert staging in New York in September, Playbill.com reported. The composer Laurence O’Keefe (“Legally Blonde”), who wrote the book and music with Kevin Murphy (“Reefer Madness”), said he could not confirm casting for the concert but said it would be full of “surprises” and “special guests.” Andy Fickman, another “Reefer Madness” alum, will direct the production, the dates and location of which are still to be determined.

headline: Let’s Keep Phone Books

headline: ‘Tenor’ to Close This Summer
text: Despite three Tony nominations and a cast and crew of stars from Broadway and Hollywood, producers for the revival of “Lend Me a Tenor” have announced that the show is to close on Aug. 15, Playbill.com reported. That date coincides with the end of the cast’s current contracts. This production, the Broadway directorial debut of Stanley Tucci, stars Anthony LaPaglia (“A View From the Bridge”), Tony Shalhoub (“Monk”) and Jan Maxwell, who is nominated for a Tony award in the featured actress category for her work in “Tenor,” as well as for lead actress for “The Royal Family.” Nominations for best revival of a play and best costume design could help to ensure that this production, which opened at the Music Box Theater on April 4 to tepid reviews, could go out with a bang, not just banging doors.

headline: A ‘Golden Ticket’ for St. Louis Opera Fans
text: “The Golden Ticket,” a new opera based on Roald Dahl’s book  “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,”  is to have its world premiere on June 13 with the Opera Theater of Saint Louis at the Loretto-Hilton Center of Webster University. The bass-baritone Daniel Okulitch, left, who sang the title role in  “Don Giovanni”  at New York City Opera last year, is to play Willy Wonka. He will be joined by Michael Kepler Meo as Charlie, Jennifer Rivera as Veruca Salt, David Trudgen as Mike Teavee, Andrew Drost as Augustus Gloop and Tracy Dahl as Violet. Timothy Redmond will conduct the run’s six performances, June 13 through June 26. The opera, commissioned by American Lyric Theater and by Dahl’s widow, Felicity Dahl, has a score by Peter Ash and a libretto by Donald Sturrock, and is a production of the American Lyric Theater, the Opera Theater of Saint Louis and the Wexford Festival Opera, in Ireland, where five performances will be presented, Oct. 17 to Oct. 29. Additional dates in the United States are to be announced by American Lyric Theater later this year.

headline: Can Art Be ‘Priceless’ in Rocky Times?

headline: Summer’s Worth of Free Art for Military
text: Free museum admission for members of the military seems to be an irresistible idea. Last week Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, Democrat of New York, announced that more than 130 New York City museums and cultural institutions would let in veterans and active-duty military personnel free over the Memorial Day weekend. Now the National Endowment for the Arts has partnered with Blue Star Families, a nonprofit network of military families, to offer free admission to more than 600 museums nationwide for active-duty service members and their families from Memorial Day to Labor Day. The complete list of museums is available on the Endowment’s Web site: arts.gov. Some special exhibitions may not be included in the free admission.

headline: Global Death Rates Drop for Children 5 or Younger
text: Death rates in children under 5 are dropping in many countries at a surprisingly fast pace, according to a new report based on data from 187 countries from 1970 to 2010.

headline: Republicans See Big Chance, but Are Worried, Too
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans remain confident of making big gains in the fall elections, but as the midterm campaign begins in earnest, they face a series of challenges that could keep the party from fully capitalizing on an electorate clamoring for change in Washington.

headline: Early Monmouth Results Give Rise to Optimism
text: OCEANPORT, N.J. — On the type of chilly, overcast day that makes any outdoor activity a tough draw, hundreds of horse racing fans stood along the rail at Monmouth Park on Sunday, cheering on their picks or cursing their bad luck as their horses headed to defeat. There was nothing particularly special about the race, the $100,000 Spend A Buck Stakes, but it did not feel that way. Energy and excitement, often missing from a day at the typical racetrack, had returned to Monmouth Park.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Gaming Begins
