This is but one of many battles that will emerge as federal and state regulators develop regulations to implement reform.

headline: Are They Paying Attention?
text: The effort to combat global warming has flagged as other crises have commanded the attention of politicians and the public. New reports from the National Academy of Sciences offer persuasive evidence that it would be folly to put off dealing with the problem any longer.

headline: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: FLOW RATE The Flow Rate Technical Team, established by the federal government to make a more precise estimate of the amount of oil leaking into the gulf, is expected to release its first report early this week. The group includes the Coast Guard, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the Minerals Management Service, the Department of Energy and the United States Geological Survey.

headline: Competitive Primaries
text: Democrats in New York go to their state convention this week with plans to crown Attorney General Andrew Cuomo as their candidate for governor. But behind this harmonious spectacle looms a political dogfight about who should replace Mr. Cuomo as attorney general. There are at least five Democratic candidates in the running, and Mr. Cuomo and the party’s delegates should make sure that all of these qualified contenders get places on the primary ballot in September.

headline: Three Killed in Separate Shootings in Queens and the Bronx
text: Three people were killed and five others wounded in two separate shootings, one in the Bronx and one in Queens, early on Sunday, the police said.

headline: ‘Lost’ Has Its Final Episode
text: 12:21 a.m. |The ‘Lost’ Finale: The Twitterverse Responds

headline: Jamaica Declares Emergency Amid Unrest
text: SAN MIGUEL DE ALLENDE, Mexico — The Jamaican government declared a state of emergency in portions of Kingston, the capital, on Sunday after supporters of a gang leader who is wanted in the United States on gun and drug charges attacked three police stations in an attempt to pressure the government to let him remain free, officials said.

headline: Manuel Under Pressure, but Hardly Showing It
text: On Saturday, with his team coming off a difficult loss to the Yankees and speculation simmering about his job security, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel was shown a page from a Japanese newspaper, Hochi Shimbun, featuring Hisanori Takahashi, who had made his first major league start the night before.

headline: At 22, Finally a Win on the PGA Tour
text: IRVING, Tex. — The 16-year-old golfer’s ear was being bent like a flagstick in a stiff breeze. He had achieved so much so quickly that many people were urging him to turn professional.

headline: Additions Subtract From Goal for Magic
text: BOSTON — There have been three games in the Eastern Conference finals, and all three ended with the same conclusion. Orlando’s Dwight Howard sat on the postgame podium with his arms in front of him and his voice hoarse as Orlando’s spokesman on all things gone wrong.

headline: Yankees Fans Sound Right at Home at Citi Field
text: Watching Saturday night’s Yankees-Mets game from the lower left-field stands at Citi Field, I was struck by how noisily confident Yankee fans generally were about their team and how subdued, at times, Mets fans seemed about theirs.

headline: South Africa Pushes to Make the Cup Its Own
text: JOHANNESBURG — The official mascot of Africa’s first World Cup — a stuffed leopard with spiked green hair — was made in China. The official World Cup song, “Waka Waka (This Time for Africa),” was written by the Colombian pop star Shakira. The official restaurant? McDonald’s.

headline: Jose Lima, Colorful and Popular Pitcher, Dies at 37
text: Jose Lima, the exuberant right-hander who pitched 13 seasons in the major leagues, delighting his fans when “Lima Time” arrived at the ballpark, died Sunday at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 37.

headline: Cuts to Child Care Subsidy Thwart More Job Seekers
text: TUCSON — Able-bodied, outgoing and accustomed to working, Alexandria Wallace wants to earn a paycheck. But that requires someone to look after her 3-year-old daughter, and Ms. Wallace, a 22-year-old single mother, cannot afford child care.

headline: In India, Billionaire Brothers End Dispute
text: India’s estranged billionaire Ambani brothers, who split the family’s business empire, said on Sunday that they had ended noncompetition agreements that had been a source of bitter dispute.

headline: Martin Gardner, Puzzler and Polymath, Dies at 95
text: Martin Gardner, who teased brains with math puzzles in Scientific American for a quarter-century and who indulged his own restless curiosity by writing more than 70 books on topics as diverse as magic, philosophy and the nuances of Alice in Wonderland, died Saturday in Norman, Okla. He was 95.

headline: Stan Jones,  Chicago Bears Hall of Famer, Dies at 78
text: Stan Jones, a Hall of Fame lineman who starred on offense and defense for the Chicago Bears and was one of the first N.F.L. players to train by lifting weights, died Friday in Broomfield, Colo. He was 78.

headline: Despite Moratorium, Drilling Projects Move Ahead
text: WASHINGTON — In the days since President Obama announced a moratorium on permits for drilling new offshore oil wells and a halt to a controversial type of environmental waiver that was given to the Deepwater Horizon rig, at least seven new permits for various types of drilling and five environmental waivers have been granted, according to records.

headline: Islanders’ Greatness Lives On in Forgetfulness
text: On a warm afternoon 30 years ago in Uniondale, N.Y., Bob Nystrom scored a goal that touched off an explosion of joy. It is still a famous scene — Nystrom tipping John Tonelli’s feed past Flyers goalie Pete Peeters in overtime of Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals; Nystrom leaping for joy in the corner as his Islanders teammates pile on to celebrate; the Nassau Coliseum crowd ecstatic, some fans weeping tears of happiness.

headline: For Once, May Is Also Cruel to Teixeira
text: If it is May — or any month but April — Mark Teixeira will smoke line drives and crush majestic home runs and slip grounders through drawn-in infields. He has always done this. He is programmed to hit, as if it is part of his circuitry.

headline: Unions’ Feud Leads to Moving of Journalism Awards Ceremony
text: A foundation named for Sidney Hillman, the famed apparel industry labor leader, has decided to move its annual journalism awards ceremony because of an embarrassing breach in union solidarity — a labor union has threatened to disrupt the event.

headline: As Tour of California Ends, Riders Go on the Defensive
text: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. — After winning the Tour of California, a race marred by the disgraced cyclist Floyd Landis’s allegations that other top riders had doped, Michael Rogers finally had enough.

headline: Crystal-Clear, Maybe Mesmerizing
text: HOUSTON — Fully half of the United States is now watching television in high definition, the fastest adoption of TV technology since the VCR hit store shelves in the 1980s.

headline: British Air Cuts Flights as Workers Walk Out
text: British Airways’ 12,000 cabin crew began a five-day strike on Monday, stepping up their protest against plans to cut staff and wages.

headline: R.I.P., Lima Time
text: Jose Lima went 0-4 with a 9.87 earned run average in four starts for the Mets in 2006. I had to look that up. I have little recollection of how Lima fared during his brief time as a Met. My memories of Lima, who died Sunday of a heart attack at age 37, are not of him as a pitcher.

headline: Wage Proposal May Prompt Fight at City Hall
text: In what could set off a major City Hall battle, two City Council members from the Bronx plan to propose a bill on Tuesday that would guarantee wages of at least $10 an hour, nearly $3 above the minimum wage, to all workers at development projects receiving public subsidies.

headline: Another South Korean Makes Mark
text: GLADSTONE, N.J. — As the torrent of South Korean golfers continues to widen, now comes Sun Young Yoo, a 23-year-old from Seoul who arrived here in the middle of last week with a goal of staying two days and departed Sunday evening with $375,000 and an ample Tiffany crystal trophy.

headline: Corrections
text: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

headline: Arkansas Suspects Had Rage Toward Government
text: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio — It was here, in this blue-collar town of frame houses and good-natured biker bars, that Jerry Ralph Kane Jr. began his fight against what he regarded as the illegitimate corporations he believed had usurped the government.

headline: The Rules of Raking
text: While playing the fifth hole during their club’s opening day tournament, Ken and Larry hit tee shots that came to rest in a bunker left of the fairway. Mike’s ball landed in a bunker right of the fairway and Norm’s ball stopped just outside the same bunker.

headline: Korean Tensions Grow as South Curbs Trade to North
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Tensions escalated sharply Monday on the Korean peninsula, as South Korean President Lee Myung-bak said that his nation would cut nearly all trade with North Korea, deny North Korean merchant ships use of South Korean sea lanes and ask the United Nations Security Council to punish the North for what he called the deliberate sinking of a South Korean warship two months ago.

headline: The Shanks
text: Bill Pennington comes down with a case of The Shanks, an insidious swing flaw that may be contagious.

headline: Follow a Caddie’s Advice: Relax and Travel Light
text: In an attempt to understand the art of caddying better, I carried the bag for the L.P.G.A. star Brittany Lincicome during the pro-am tournament Wednesday at the Sybase Match Play Championship in New Jersey (a version of my article about that day is available at http://tinyurl.com/27ksylp).

headline: Accounts, People & Miscellany
text: Accounts

headline: For Roaming Palin, Home Base Is Still in Alaska
text: WASILLA, Alaska — Stepping quickly toward his big black Dodge Ram truck, Todd Palin offered a few highlights of the weekend ahead.

headline: Mothers Looking to Welfare as Child Care Support Weakens
text: With some states cutting support for subsidized childcare, swelling numbers of low-income families are struggling to reconcile the demands of work and parenting, just as they confront one of the toughest job markets in decades.

headline: Mets Win 2 of 3 Against Yankees in Subway Series
text: In listing the factors contributing to his team’s recent malaise, the manager did not skimp: inconsistent starting pitching, a combustible bullpen, a paucity of timely hitting. Those are common complaints in the interview room at Citi Field, but this time, Jerry Manuel was blissfully unaware who said them. He was outside watching the Mets take batting practice.

headline: Knowing Where to Step, Gingerly, in Iraq
text: Although Patrick Baz has been the Middle East photo manager for Agence France-Presse since 1995, he still considers himself as much a photographer as a manager. From 1989 until 1995, he was the chief photographer in Jerusalem. He was a freelancer in Beirut before that. The photographer Michael Kamber interviewed him in Paris on March 31.

headline: Love on the Global Brain
text: Brain scan studies have shown that early romantic love generates a unique pattern of brain activity. Regions of the brain related to addiction and even mental illness light up on the scan when a person sees a photo of his or her beloved.

headline: Book Blog Picks Best and Worst Promotional Videos
text: Literary publishers and writers tend to roll their eyes at book trailers, the short videos intended to promote new books. So much so, in fact, that one book blog, MobyLives, recently started a contest for the “Best and Worst Book Trailers,” to “spoof the fact that the book business too often looks to the movie business as a model,” said Dennis Johnson, the founder of MobyLives.

headline: Word of the Day | glimmer
text: glimmer •\ˈgli-mər\• verb and noun

headline: Kamsky and Shulman Win and Will Play for U.S. Title
text: Decisive games in the penultimate round have set up a showdown for the title on Monday.

headline: A Site Collects Complaints About Media
text: Media criticism has been boiled down to a single, painful word: fail.

headline: Tyler Perry’s Global Push
text: The Tyler Perry brand is finally going global.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Scheduled are existing home sales for April (Monday); S.& P. Case-Shiller home price index for March and consumer confidence for May (Tuesday); Durable goods orders and new-home sales for April (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and revised first-quarter gross domestic product (Thursday); personal income and spending for April; Reuters/University of Michigan consumer confidence index for May (Friday).

headline: Bret Michaels Wins ‘Apprentice’ After Illness
text: One month after suffering a brain hemorrhage and just days after being re-admitted to the hospital for a warning stroke, the rock musician Bret Michaels won the “Celebrity Apprentice” contest on NBC.

headline: ‘Lost’ Watch: Embracing the White Light
text: 1:33 p.m. | Updated Mike Hale has more on the series finale of “Lost” here.

headline: Mets’ Pitching Jumble Gains Clarity
text: Manager Jerry Manuel said before Sunday’s game that the Mets’ perpetually changing plans for their pitching staff had crystallized.

headline: Teenagers Text More Than They Call
text: OMG, W8 til U read this: one in three teenagers sends more than 100 text messages a day, and 72 percent are now text-messagers, compared with 51 percent in 2006, according to a recent Pew Internet report. Nearly half who take phones to school text at least once a day in class.

headline: Stoudemire Scores 42 as Rested Suns Revive
text: PHOENIX — So much seemed askew with Amare Stoudemire. His rebounding, his assertiveness, even at times his sleek new-age goggles. If there was a little extra heat in the Arizona desert, it was generated by the Suns’ bespectacled, bewildering big man.

headline: Bullpen Fight or Fun?
text: A tumultuous night for the bullpen appeared to start in the bullpen itself Sunday night as the Mets relievers looked to be getting into a tussle in the eighth inning. Several of the relief pitchers could be seen pushing one another, but none of them said anything serious had happened.

headline: Photo Replay: May 23
text: A view of the day in sports.

headline: Lakers’ Weakness Inside Is Exposed
text: PHOENIX — A 42-point explosion by Amar’e Stoudemire was much less surprising than it was timely, but a 20-point outburst by Robin Lopez was both. Against a Lakers frontline diminished by the inability of the ailing Andrew Bynum to stay on the floor, Stoudemire and Lopez combined to shoot 22 of 32 in the Suns’ 118-109 Game 3 victory Sunday night, breathing life into the Western Conference finals.

headline: News Quiz | May 24, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Suddenly, Rating Agencies Don’t Look Untouchable
text: Ron Grassi will admit that when he decided to sue the three major rating agencies in early 2009, he was too enraged to think about his odds. A retired family law specialist who lives in California, he filed his suit in a low boil a few months after $40,000 in Lehman Brothers corporate bonds he owned all but vanished when the investment bank collapsed.

headline: Plenty of Ways to Punish Wall Street
text: Why should Wall Street care about a medieval English archbishop? Because as prosecutors fail to come up with strong legal cases against the bankers and traders who supposedly ran the financial industry into the ground, it’s a good bet they will soon resort to a modern-day variation of the prosecutorial technique perfected by King Henry VII’s chancellor — the so-called Morton’s fork.

headline: Mark Gorton, Man Behind the Music Service
text: Mark Gorton is a confident guy. He’s confident about his ideas. He’s confident about his enthusiasms. And he’s confident that his successes — like making money on Wall Street and promoting alternative transportation in New York — provide a record that backs him up.

headline: Rules Grow, but Banks Stay the Same Size
text: Broadly speaking, there were two ways for the federal government to respond to the financial crisis: supersize regulation or downsize the financial industry.

headline: These Are Their Stories
text: WHEN will “Law and Order” air its final episode? WHEN did the show first begin?

headline: As Reform Takes Shape, Some Relief on Wall Street
text: The financial reform legislation making its way through Congress has Wall Street executives privately relieved that the bill does not do more to fundamentally change how the industry does business, Eric Dash and Nelson D. Schwartz report in The New York Times.

headline: Morgenson: ‘100% Protected’ Isn’t Quite That Safe
text: Brokers selling complex securities that they once contended were safe and sound have saddled individual investors with billions in losses since the credit bubble burst. Remember auction-rate securities? Those were peddled to investors as just as good as cash — until they no longer were after that market seized up in 2008, The New York Times’s Gretchen Morgenson writes in her latest column.

headline: Rivals Seize on Troubles of Facebook
text: It sounds like a kamikaze mission: an upstart with a meager number of users and no capital squaring off against Facebook, a social networking juggernaut with more than 400 million members and a $15 billion valuation.

headline: Pentagon and U.N. Chief Put New Pressure on N. Korea
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and its allies put new pressure on North Korea on Monday, announcing naval exercises next month to detect submarines of the kind suspected of sinking a South Korean warship, and winning the support of the secretary general of the United Nations for Security Council action.

headline: Case Said to Conclude Against Head of A.I.G. Unit
text: Federal prosecutors investigating the events leading up to the collapse of the American International Group in 2008 will not bring charges against Joseph Cassano, the chief executive of the unit that insured mortgage-related securities with calamitous results, according to two people briefed on the matter, Gretchen Morgenson reports in The New York Times.

headline: Blair to Join Venture Firm as Adviser on Technology
text: Tony Blair, the former British prime minister, is turning his attention to Silicon Valley. Mr. Blair is becoming a senior adviser at Khosla Ventures, the venture capital firm founded by Vinod Khosla, an investor and a proponent of green technology, Claire Cain Miller reports in The New York Times.

headline: Ailing Spanish Lender Gets a $691 Million Bailout
text: Weaknesses in the Spanish financial sector were exposed over the weekend when the central bank rescued CajaSur, a savings bank that was crippled by losses related to real estate and was unable to agree on a merger with a bigger rival, Raphael Minder reports in The New York Times.

headline: Asian Stock Markets Rebound a Bit
text: Asia-Pacific stock markets started the week mostly higher, taking heart from a firm performance on Wall Street on Friday and buoyed by speculation that the Chinese authorities will ease some of their tightening measures.

headline: In India, Billionaire Ambani Brothers End Dispute
text: India’s estranged billionaire Ambani brothers, who split the family’s business empire, said on Sunday that they had ended noncompetition agreements that had been a source of bitter dispute.

headline: Rule No. 1: Make Money by Avoiding Rules
text: From the earliest days of capitalism, those skilled at making money have proven creative at evading the regulators.

headline: R.B.S. Nears $500 Million Deal in Private Equity Sale
text: Royal Bank of Scotland is nearing a deal with Alpinvest, the Dutch pension fund, over the sale of its European private equity fund portfolio, The Financial Times reported. The agreement is expected to be worth about 400 million euros ($500 million).

headline: Healthscope Opens Books to Consortium
text: Healthscope, the Australian private hospital operator, said Monday that it would let its private equity suitors review its books over the next several weeks as they look to seal a $1.5 billion offer for the group, Reuters reported.

headline: Toyota, Tesla-Style
text: The Toyota Prius is sometimes known as the Pious. The pioneering but earnest vehicle could do with an injection of supercar glamour from Tesla Motors’ Roadster, and vice versa from a practicality standpoint, Reuters Breakingviews says.

headline: No Reform for Fannie and Freddie, Despite Costs
text: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, are headed toward being the single-biggest expense to hit taxpayers in the fallout of the financial crisis, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: German Rescue Fund Lost $5.3 Billion on Hypo
text: The German bank rescue fund, Soffin, lost 4.26 billion euros last year because of write-downs at Hypo Real Estate, the troubled bank that Berlin was compelled to nationalize last autumn over the protests of J. Christopher Flowers.

headline: PublicEarth Raises $1 Million
text: From Anthony Ha at VentureBeat:

headline: Facebook Investor D.S.T. Eyes More Digital Stakes
text: Digital Sky Technologies, the Russian Internet investment group that bought a $300 million stake in Facebook last year, is preparing to buy stakes in dozens of well-known Internet companies, its chief executive said.

headline: Financial Overhaul Bill Poses Big Test for Lobbyists
text: Last Wednesday, Representative David Scott, Democrat of Georgia, mingled with insurance and financial executives and other supporters at a lunchtime fund-raiser in his honor at a chic Washington wine bar before rushing out to cast a House vote, The New York Times’s Eric Lichtblau writes.

headline: Art Means Books and Tattoos at New Paris Gallery
text: “Art doesn’t go to sleep in the bed made for it. What it likes is to be incognito. Its best moments are when it forgets what its own name is,” once said Jean Dubuffet, founder of the Art Brut movement, who sought creativity anywhere but in museums. This is precisely the challenge that the new gallery Le Pied de Biche (“The Crowbar”) has picked: Who says galleries ought to show strictly art? Don’t books, tattoo drawings and toys also deserve an outlet? Their inaugural exhibition, “Art, Ink and Rock and Roll,” which runs through June 2, addresses just these questions.

headline: Back to the Garden
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: Before Paris, Federer and Nadal Had Madrid
text: Roger Federer calculates. He thinks, weighs the pros and cons, does a cost-benefit analysis of what is best for him, then executes the plan. He remains fresh and injury-free because he refuses to play too many tournaments. For him, the Grand Slams are his sole focus. The tournaments leading up to the majors are tune-ups, opportunities to gain match play and get his game in tune for the main event.

headline: A.I.G. Said to Revisit Float Plan if Pru Bid Fails
text: The United States Treasury is re-examing plans to float the Asian unit of American International Group in case a bid by the British insurer Prudential Plc to buy the unit fails, two British newspapers reported on Sunday.

headline: John Hyman No Longer Joining Nomura
text: A former Morgan Stanley banker, John Hyman, will not join Nomura to become its new co-head of global finance at its London operation, as had been expected, due to regulatory issues, Reuters reported, citing a source.

headline: Grace Under Pressure
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have bravely put finger to key to offer their definitions of courage.

headline: Indian Premier Stresses Economy and Diplomacy
text: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Manmohan Singh said Monday that India must reach 10 percent annual economic growth in coming years and improve relations with Pakistan if it wants to reduce poverty and make more rapid progress.

headline: HSBC Chief Denies Management Overhaul
text: HSBC has no plans to change its management structure, the investment bank’s chief executive, Michael Geoghegan, told CNBC Monday.

headline: China’s Arctic Ambitions
text: Today’s idea: China has set its sights on the Arctic, an article says, since global warming is expected to transform the frozen region into new shipping lanes over an ocean rich in oil and natural gas.

headline: Rocky Times for Spanish Private Equity Deals?
text: The Spanish private equity market has taken a hit in the recent Europe-wide economic downturn and its effect on the Iberian peninsula, as a number of deeply indebted bought-out firms have had to renegotiate their finances, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Equity One Buys Capital Shopping’s U.S. Unit
text: Equity One, the U.S. real estate investment trust, said on Sunday it would buy Capital Shopping Centres Group‘s U.S. unit in a deal valued at $600 million, Reuters reported.

headline: Senate to Examine United-Continental Merger
text: A  Senate subcommittee is set to examine the proposed airline deal between United Airlines and Continental Airlines on Thursday and its implications for airline consumers, Reuters reported.

headline: World Cup Memories: Del Piero Channels Tardelli
text: Alessandro Del Piero watched on television the Italian midfielder Marco Tardelli celebrate after scoring against West Germany in the 1982 World Cup final.

headline: May Madness: TechCrunch Starts a Tournament-Style Business Competition
text: TechCrunch founder and co-editor Michael Arrington says he started blogging about everything and everyone in technology in 2005 just to get informed. His site gained audience quickly; it claims about 10 million monthly visitors today and has more than 1.3 million followers on Twitter. From early on, Mr. Arrington’s provocative and blunt editorial approach risked alienating the very entrepreneurs, technologists and investors who read and inform his blog. But he developed a rapport with them, in part, by throwing generous, informal parties in his own backyard in Silicon Valley.

headline: Temasek Names Executive Director
text: Temasek Holdings, Singapore’s sovereign wealth fund, said it had appointed the former head of the Singapore Exchange, Hsieh Fu Hua, as an executive director and president.

headline: Congress Takes Up Tax Breaks, Job Aid
text: Congressional Democrats hope to head into the Memorial Day recess by approving a $200 billion package of business tax breaks and aid for the jobless this week.

headline: Submit Your Funny Caption
text: Read All Over | Tell us what’s going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned images we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Sampler: Fight Over Sitting on Sidewalks, and Wild Parrots Seek Homes
text: Newsom Will Take Sidewalk Law to Voters | Facing stiff opposition from the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, Mayor Gavin Newsom will ask voters to weigh in on his proposal to ban sitting down on sidewalks during certain hours. The so-called sit/lie law is scheduled to be heard before the board’s Public Safety Committee on Monday; San Francisco voters can expect to see it on the November ballot. Advocates for prostitutes and the homeless oppose the law. While proponents say it will be used to focus on aggressive behavior by some sidewalk dwellers, others see the law as an attack on the city’s most vulnerable, prohibiting them from sitting or lying down on the sidewalk from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. “It is extremely hard to stay moving your whole waking day,” Neil Donovan, executive director of the National Coalition for the Homeless, told The New York Times. [The San Francisco Chronicle, The New York Times]

headline: Life After the M.T.A., and an Arch Is Spruced Up
text: What is it like to leave the Metropolitan Transportation Authority after nearly 20 years of service?

headline: After NBC, Will ABC and CBS Be Next on the Block?
text: After General Electric‘s deal to sell NBC Universal to Comcast, will rival networks ABC and CBS be next to go on the block?

headline: Biodiversity in Peril, the U.N. Warns
text: Biological diversity is declining faster than previously estimated, and the trend will eventually threaten “the livelihoods and food security of hundreds of millions of people” unless swift action is taken. That’s the conclusion of the third edition of the Global Biodiversity Outlook, published by the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity.

headline: Stan Jones, a Hall of Famer Ahead of His Time
text: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down. Stan Jones died Friday at 78.

headline: Goldman Analysts Upgrade Citi to ‘Buy’
text: 8:05 a.m. | Updated Analysts at Goldman Sachs on Monday upgraded Citigroup to a buy from neutral and set a $4.50 price target, as part of a sweep series of recommendation changes.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: The financial sector can’t do much but sit in the waiting room until Congress agrees on the two, slightly different, bills passed by the House and the Senate, but regulatory uncertainty is not confined to what happens on the Hill. Banks are looking at new measures in Britain, Switzerland and the European Union as well as Basel III. Not only do they need to know what’s going to happen in each place — but how will they all fit together?

headline: The Impact of Another Soldier’s Death
text: I always believed the wounds of war, whether physical or emotional, belonged only to those who suffered serious injury or unforgettable trauma. I had always been lucky. It seemed I was always just far enough ahead of or behind the bad stuff, and too heavy a sleeper to remember my own dreams. I never thought someone else’s wounds could impact my life, or that of my family, until it happened.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Kenmare’s Asparagus Gratin
text: “Every March, I think about asparagus,” said Joey Campanaro, the 38-year-old executive chef of Kenmare, in SoHo, who loves the vegetable for its versatility. “I make purees with it, I tempura it, I grill it.”

headline: Wall Street Slips at the Close
text: Stocks declined on Monday, dragged down by late-day losses in the financial sector, which has been mired in uncertainty over financial reforms and European debt troubles.

headline: The Best Commencement Speeches Ever
text: Well, maybe not “ever.” But two really good commencement addresses, anyway.

headline: Two Americans Kidnapped in Yemen
text: CAIRO — Yemeni tribesmen kidnapped two American tourists, a man and a woman, Monday morning outside the capital city of Sana, the United States Embassy in Yemen said Monday.

headline: Wage Proposal Faces Strong Opposition
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Clinton and Geithner Face Hurdles in China Talks
text: BEIJING — China and the United States opened three days of high-level meetings here on Monday meant to broaden and deepen the ties between the world’s largest developed and developing economies.

headline: More Critics React to the ‘Lost’ Finale
text: Earlier this morning Mike Hale of The New York Times posted his response to “The End,” the final episode of “Lost,” which he wrote “in the immediate aftermath, felt forced and, well, a bit of a cop-out.”

headline: The Early Word: Midterm Messages
text: With primary season in full swing, Democrats and Republicans are deploying powerful voices and unveiling their best electoral strategies this week. Meanwhile, Congress hits crunch time before the week-long Memorial Day recess.

headline: Matches to Watch on Monday
text: The early rounds, particularly at a Grand Slam fielding 128 players, aren’t supposed to surprise. The best players in the world face unseeded opponents and qualifiers. Day 2 at the French Open looks to be business as usual. But here are two matches that could offer a refreshing bit of suspense:

headline: Q.&A.: Keeping Picasa and Gmail Separate
text: Q.

headline: I.B.M. to Buy AT&T’s Sterling for $1.4 Billion
text: I.B.M. said on Monday that it had struck a deal to buy Sterling Commerce from AT&T for $1.4 billion in cash.

headline: Why Won’t My Insurance Cover My Son Until 2011?
text: Q.

headline: Bringing an Internet Connection to Tuscany
text: Last month I spent a week in very rural Tuscany, a half mile down a dirt road that wasn’t mapped by GPS, and thus very difficult to find. Nonetheless, my work followed me.

headline: Weather Channel Renews Pact With Dish Network
text: Dish Network has reached a new carriage agreement with The Weather Channel, averting an interruption in programming.

headline: Something Rotten At Interior
text: Something is very wrong at the Interior Department.

You don’t have to rely on the critics to know that “The End” had a polarizing effect on viewers – ArtsBeat readers were just as divided on whether or not “Lost” met its fitting end. Here’s a highly selective sampling of the comments we’ve received:

Each house on the base will have one panel on its roof that will cover 75 percent of its hot water needs.

headline: The ‘Lost’ Finale
text: There were three reasons to watch “Lost” — or to stick with it, more aptly, across six immensely engrossing and immensely frustrating seasons. You could watch for the characters, who were two-dimensional and archetypal in a way, but rich and relatable and even lovable in the way that great pulp casts can sometimes be. You could watch for the thrill of it — the endless cliffhangers, the constant narrative whiplash, the mobius-strip plotting, and the way the show could blithely disassemble and reassemble its narrative architecture (flashbacks followed by flashforwards! flashforwards followed by time travel!) and somehow have the whole thing work. And of course, you could watch for the macro-plot — the mythology of a mysterious island, which layered puzzle atop riddle atop intrigue like no show since “The X-Files,” promising all the while (or seeming to promise, at least) to be building up to a revelatory denouement.

headline: Castroneves Captures Pole for Indy 500
text: On Saturday, Helio Castroneves earned his fourth pole position for the Indianapolis 500. The defending champion averaged 227.970 miles per hour in his four lap qualifying session, topping 228 m.p.h. twice.

headline: Required Reading | ‘Graphic Europe’
text: Consider him a travel archetype: the European graphic designer. He’s the only guy at that cafe in Tallinn at 3 p.m. on a Tuesday who’s not a grumpy Estonian pensioner. He’s wearing funky glasses, he’s tapping on a MacBook, he speaks microscopically accented English, and he can probably direct you to a cool place like Voitlev Sona, a former Soviet bookstore that’s now a nightclub serving Indian cuisine. If only you could run into one of these plugged-in designer types in every European city. If only …

headline: Man Is Guilty in Newark Schoolyard Murders
text: NEWARK — In the first trial stemming from the shootings of four college-age friends in a schoolyard here nearly three years ago, a jury returned guilty verdicts on Monday for three murders and one attempted murder after less than a day of deliberations.

headline: Sean Hayes to Host Tony Awards
text: These have been some busy weeks for Sean Hayes, the Emmy Award-winning “Will & Grace” star: he’s been starring on Broadway in the revival of “Promises, Promises,” which netted him a Tony Award nomination for best actor in a musical. And – oh, yes – he recently came out publicly and was criticized by Newsweek in an article that said he and other gay actors were unconvincing as straight characters. And what better way to put that behind him than by hosting a nationally televised awards program? The much buzzed-about Mr. Hayes has been chosen to host the 64th Annual Tony Awards, its organizers said on Monday. The awards ceremony that honors Broadway’s best will be held on June 13 at Radio City Music Hall and will be broadcast live on CBS. The show’s longtime executive producers, Glenn Weiss and Ricky Kirshner of White Cherry Entertainment, will return and Mr. Weiss will once again direct the program. The 2010 Tonys team will come into the show with some momentum, or some big shoes to fill, depending on how you look at it: the 2009 awards ceremony, which was hosted by Neil Patrick Harris, drew the show’s best ratings in three years.

headline: Green Beans Bring Flavor to Pastas and Pilafs Alike
text: Green beans are my go-to spring vegetable. They need absolutely no embellishment, just proper cooking — and for this vegetable, proper cooking is simply a matter of timing. If they’re underdone, they might be nice and crunchy and pretty, but you won’t get the maximum flavor, which can only be drawn out with four to five (my preference is five) minutes of cooking, either steaming or par-boiling. If you cook green beans too long, they lose that bright color and become mushy. Still, the longer-cooked Mediterranean bean stews I’ve tasted are full of flavor; I’m giving you one of those delicious recipes this week.

headline: Greek Stewed Green Beans and Yellow Squash With Tomatoes
text: Green beans are one of many vegetables that both Greek and Turkish cooks stew with abundant olive oil in dishes known as ladera. This recipe is inspired by one of them, but it’s a far cry from the authentic version, which requires three times as much oil and simmers for a longer time. Don’t be put off by the faded color of the beans; they’re comforting and delicious.

headline: Well Shod in Antwerp | Coccodrillo Men’s

The boutique’s new location, directly across the street from the original, is dedicated to masculine footwear. “The store was getting too small,” said co-founder Geert Brulot. “Plus, designers were always asking us to split it up. So when the space became available, we decided to follow our heart.”

When else can a player — Chicago’s Duncan Keith — be deemed the hero of a playoff series by losing seven teeth in an unfortunate, bloody collision with a puck at the same time a major annual tournament becomes absorbed in debating the see-through qualities of Venus Williams’s black lace tennis dress?

headline: New York Super Bowl Leaders Prepare Pitch to Owners
text: IRVING, Tex. – Members of the New York Super Bowl bid committee planned to spend much of much of the day Monday rehearsing the presentation they will give to owners on Tuesday. New York is considered the heavy favorite to host the 2014 game over Tampa and South Florida. Each group is allotted 15 minutes to speak to the owners and the presentations often include videos. The Giants co-chairman John Mara – who gave the commencement address Monday at his alma mater, Fordham Law School – will speak during the presentation, as will the Jets’ owner, Woody Johnson.

headline: The 10 Biggest Choking Hazards
text: According to a 2008 study, the 10 foods that pose the highest choking hazards for young children are hot dogs, peanuts, carrots, boned chicken, candy, meat, popcorn, fish with bones, sunflower seeds and apples.

headline: Creature Comforts | The Presidio Habitats
text: Two days after “Presidio Habitats” opened in the Presidio of San Francisco, a stunning 1,491-acre national park in the shadow of the Golden Gate Bridge, Hal Fischer took a visitor on a tour of the art installation. Fischer is the director of special projects for the FOR-SITE Foundation, the San Francisco arts nonprofit that spearheaded the show, for which 11 international architects, artists and designers created conceptual habitats for the park’s animal residents. The first site-based exhibition organized for and presented in a United States national park, the pieces in “Presidio Habitats” will be up for a full year, until May 15, 2011 — unless furry and winged residents actually move into their new high-design homes, in which case their leases will be extended indefinitely, by decree of Presidio Trust naturalists. But will the Western screech owl actually find the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei’s glazed blue-and-white porcelain vessels hospitable, tethered in the branches of a cypress tree?  Only time shall tell.

headline: ‘Celebrity Autobiography’ Expands
text: “Celebrity Autobiography,” the stage show where actors and comedians read highlights and lowlights from celebrities’ memoirs, will hold its first performances in Pittsburgh and New Orleans this summer and has accepted an invitation to join the Edinburgh International Festival in August.

headline: On Second Try, Lindsay Lohan Makes Her Court Date
text: Will the hot new fashion accessory of the summer be an alcohol-monitoring ankle bracelet? That depends on how much cultural influence Lindsay Lohan still wields – and how many magazine shoots and movie roles she’ll be able to book after a judge ruled on Monday that Ms. Lohan must wear such a device, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Food Court Is Set to Open in the Plaza Hotel
text: The luxury retailers who are setting up shop on the lower concourse level of the Plaza Hotel will be getting company in the next week, with the opening of a multifaceted food hall serving morning coffee, an evening glass of wine and much in between. It was devised by the chef Todd English, a fan of European food halls. Designed by Jeffrey Beers in sharp black and white with a glittering mosaic floor, it occupies 5,400 square feet, about 20 percent of the lower level, with 80 seats at assorted dining counters and cooking stations, and fresh, prepared and packaged foods sold retail.

headline: More on Malaria in a Warming World
text: 7:23 p.m. | Updated Below The climate blogger Joe Romm and I agree (breaking news): Scientific research and assessments examining the link between human-driven climate change and malaria exposure have, for the most part, accurately gauged and conveyed the nature of the risk that warming could swell the ranks of people afflicted with this awful mosquito-borne disease. I did so last week in a piece on a new study in the journal Nature concluding that efforts to stem the disease are swamping the potential expansion of malaria endemicity from warming; he’s done so today in a piece attacking those who chose to report on this news.

headline: Terry Gosliner Diving for Nudibranchs

headline: Murray’s Discipline Helps Him Survive

headline: Michael McKean Joins ‘Our Town’
text: The actor Michael McKean, the star of “Superior Donuts” on Broadway this season and a featured actor in many films, among them “This is Spinal Tap” and “A Mighty Wind,” will assume the role of the Stage Manager in the Off Broadway revival of “Our Town.” Mr. McKean, who is still best known in some circles as Lenny on television’s “Laverne & Shirley,” will begin performing on June 2, succeeding the actor Michael Shannon, who gave his final show on Sunday; Robert Beitzel will play the role in the interim. “Our Town” has been running at the Barrow Street Theater in Greenwich Village since February 2009; the production is directed by David Cromer, who also played the Stage Manager during the show’s first several months. Last December, this “Our Town” became the longest-running production of the play in its 72-year history, with its record-setting 337th performance at Barrow Street.

headline: Afghan Spy Agency Accuses Pakistan Agency in Suicide Bombing
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A spokesman for Afghanistan’s intelligence agency on Monday accused Pakistan’s intelligence agency of involvement in the suicide bombing here last week that killed six NATO soldiers, including four colonels.

headline: Throat Exercise for Sleep Apnea
text: In today’s “Really?” column, Anahad O’Connor explores an alternative treatment for sleep apnea — throat exercises.

headline: How Do I Get My Employees to Think Like Owners?
