headline: The Morning Skate: Flyers Kick Sand in Habs’ Face, Hawks Depth Wins
text: The latest controversy is being called “Sandgate,” even though — as Ray Parrillo in The Philadelphia Daily News reported today — the substance allegedly found in the runway outside the Flyers dressing room leading to the ice in Montreal on Saturday was not identified as sand; even though some Flyers players who had to get their skates sharpened during the game denied their blades had been damaged by it; even though no one, including Flyers’ General Manager Paul Holmgren, has accused the Canadiens of sabotaging Flyers’ equipment.

headline: ‘La Bête’ to Begin Previews in September
text: The previously announced Broadway revival of David Hirson’s comedy “La Bête,” starring the Tony Award winners David Hyde Pierce and Mark Rylance and the British television star Joanna Lumley (“Absolutely Fabulous”), is now scheduled to being preview performances at the Music Box Theater on Sept. 23 with an opening night of Oct. 14. The production, to be directed by Matthew Warchus (“God of Carnage”), will have a pre-Broadway limited run at the Comedy Theater in London’s West End this summer. The current show at the Music Box, the revival of “Lend Me a Tenor,” is scheduled to close on Aug. 15, though a production spokeswoman said that an extension through Labor Day is under discussion.

headline: Widening the Pool of N.H.L. Referees and Diving In
text: The N.H.L. recently broke a barrier when it announced the hiring of Marcus Vinnerborg as their first European referee. The announcement was yet another step in the league’s ongoing efforts to find enough officials to fill out its roster.

headline: BP Rejects Blasts as Oil Well Response
text: In a telephone conference call with reporters, Doug Suttles, the chief operating officer of BP, all but ruled out the use of explosives to crimp or implode the seabed oil gusher in the Gulf of Mexico. (Here’s a recording of the call.)

headline: White House and Congress Meet on ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: White House and Congressional officials met Monday in a carefully orchestrated effort to discuss a possible repeal of the military’s “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell” policy in advance of a House vote on the issue  this week.

headline: For 77 Years, a Regular at Sardi’s
text: Eating lunch at Sardi’s last Tuesday, William Herz did not have to order coffee. It was brought to him, right when he wanted it (in the middle of his meal, not after) by a waiter who served it in a white mug that no one else but Mr. Herz drinks from.

headline: A New Role for a Familiar Face at G.M.
text: It has been a fast-paced year in the career of Susan Docherty, a General Motors vice president. On Monday, she was assigned to another new post, her sixth since last summer, this time in international sales and marketing.

headline: Did The Postwar System Fail?
text: I’ve been posting about the contrast between the popular perception on the right that America had slow growth until Reagan came along, and the reality that we did fine pre-Reagan, in fact better; see here, here, and here. And what I’m getting as a common response — including from liberals — is something along the lines of, “That’s all very well, but by 1980 the postwar system was clearly failing, so what would you have done instead of Reaganomics?”

headline: Taking Pains to Take Care, Both Now and Then
text: Now that our hospital’s electronic medical record keeps reasonably good track of patients’ blood test and X-ray results, we no longer routinely file the paper copies. And now that I routinely offer these copies to patients, I have learned that the world is divided when it comes to medical self-knowledge.

headline: It’s a Keyboard! No! It’s a PC!
text: The idea of containing an entire computer — including display screen — on what is essentially just a keyboard, has been in the fermenting stage for some time at Asus.

headline: Texas Rangers Enter Bankruptcy to Expedite Sale
text: The Texas Rangers voluntarily pushed themselves into bankruptcy on Monday to facilitate the team’s sale to a group of investors led by Chuck Greenberg and the team’s president, Nolan Ryan, for about $575 million.

headline: New Plans Try to Revive Carbon Trading
text: BRUSSELS — Carbon trading was meant to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the European Union by making polluting more expensive for heavy industries, encouraging them to invest in cleaner technology. But even supporters admit that the system, also known as cap and trade, is falling far short of that goal. Critics decry it as just another form of financial profiteering with little environmental benefit.

headline: New Way Bacterium Spreads in Hospital
text: Health care workers and patients have yet another source of hospital-acquired infection to worry about, British researchers are reporting.

headline: Behind the Trends in an M.&A. Uptick
text: The American takeover market has become more active. It is a nervous time, however. The strength of any return is uncertain amid a market decline, the continuing ramifications of the Greek-euro crisis and a potential popping of a Chinese real estate bubble. In this environment, corporate executives may decide it is better to focus on core businesses rather than risk acquisitions. Nonetheless, in this mergers and acquisitions boomlet, we are beginning to see what the takeover market will look like if and when it experiences a sustained return anytime soon.

headline: Here Come the Regulars
text: William Herz is not sure how it happened. He has been eating at Sardi’s for roughly 77 years.

headline: For Sestak Matter, a ‘Trust Us’ Response From White House
text: WASHINGTON — For three months, the White House has refused to say whether it offered a job to Representative Joe Sestak to get him to drop his challenge to Senator Arlen Specter in a Pennsylvania Democratic primary, as Mr. Sestak has asserted.

headline: Big Gains for Young People in Health Law
text: After Eric Heininger left his job (and medical insurance) to follow his girlfriend to graduate school in New Haven, he wanted to get a physical, so he volunteered to take part in a medical study.

headline: Labels Urged for Food That Can Choke
text: On a July afternoon in 2006, Patrick Hale microwaved a bag of popcorn for his two young children and sat down with them to watch television. When he got up to change the channel, he heard a strange noise behind him, and turned to see his 23-month-old daughter, Allison, turning purple and unable to breathe.

headline: Hot Dogs and Other Edible Choking Hazards
text: The American Academy of Pediatrics now says that when it comes to choking risk, food should be subject to as much scrutiny as toys. The group is asking for warning labels on foods that are known choking hazards, writes reporter Laurie Tarkan in today’s Science Times.

headline: Texas Rangers Enter Bankruptcy to Expedite Sale
text: 6:13 p.m. | Corrected The Texas Rangers voluntarily filed for bankruptcy on Monday to facilitate the team’s sale to a group of investors led by Chuck Greenberg and the team’s president, Nolan Ryan (pictured), for about $575 million, The New York Times’s Ken Belson reported.

headline: When Your Son Crashes the (Very Expensive) Car
text: Peter Cheney reviews automobiles for The Toronto Globe and Mail. His 18-year-old son, Will, thinks that’s a pretty cool job, and often brings his friends to the family garage to check out the loaner car his dad is reviewing next.

headline: 7,000 Miles Nonstop, and No Pretzels
text: In 1976, the biologist Robert E. Gill Jr. came to the southern coast of Alaska to survey the birds preparing for their migrations for the winter. One species in particular, wading birds called bar-tailed godwits, puzzled him deeply. They were too fat.

headline: For Children in Sports, a Breaking Point
text: I’d be the last person to discourage children from playing sports. Indeed, I wish many more would move away from their computers, put down their iPods and cellphones and devote more time and energy to physical activities.

headline: Here’s Looking at Me, Kid
text: As the vodka market gets more crowded, even the most venerable brands in the category must try new ways to differentiate themselves. Case in point, Stolichnaya, which is introducing a campaign on Monday that takes a novel tack.

headline: Tropical Diseases: Outbreak of Dengue Fever Is Reported in Florida, Health Officials Say
text: Dengue fever, a growing scourge in the tropics, has established itself in a popular American tourist destination, federal health officials reported last week.

headline: Premature Birth Rate Drops for 2nd Year
text: The rate of premature births declined for the second year in a row in 2008, the first two-year decrease in almost 30 years, the government reported this month.

headline: An Even Better Number for Betty White’s ‘SNL’ Turn
text: Betty White turned out to be an even bigger star than NBC thought: Her appearance earlier this month on “Saturday Night Live” got a huge kick upward in ratings when digital recorder numbers were included.

headline: Transocean President Takes Center Stage
text: In 2009, Transocean president Steven Newman performed for employees in Mumbai to celebrate the India Division team posting the best safety performance for two consecutive years.

headline: Islanders Cancel Trip to China
text: The Islanders have canceled their training camp trip to China planned for this fall over a disagreement between Islanders owner Charles Wang and the N.H.L. Players’ Association, sources close to the team confirmed on Monday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The DMZ and Elsewhere
text: The South Korean president, Lee Myung-bak, said his nation would sever nearly all trade with North Korea, deny North Korean merchant ships use of South Korean sea lanes and ask the United Nations Security Council to punish the North, Choe Sang-Hun and Thom Shanker write. The steps outlined by Mr. Lee in a nationally televised speech — coupled with new moves by South Korea’s military to resume “psychological warfare” propaganda broadcasts at the border after a six-year suspension — amounted to the most serious action the South could take short of an armed retaliation for the sinking of a warship two months ago, the South’s worst military loss since the Korean War ended.

headline: Can Apple’s Jobs Still Wow After Leaks?
text: Two or three times a year, Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, dons his classic black turtleneck, blue jeans and grey New Balance sneakers, and presents new or updated products that start with an i.

headline: From Big Leagues, Hints at Sibling Behavior
text: When B. J. Upton hit a home run last Thursday night to help the Tampa Bay Rays defeat the New York Yankees, it was not the first time that day that Upton had gone deep. Just a few hours earlier, chatting in front of his locker, he had helped confirm the results of a recent study of sibling risk-taking behavior.

headline: A Return to Normalcy, for All to Admire
text: I stare harder into the bathroom mirror these days than I ever have. Not out of some pathetic middle-aged vanity, but more out of curiosity. Two years after learning I had an aggressive prostate cancer, I want to see how my face has been weathered and sculptured by the uncertainty and wisdom wrought by the storms of serious disease.

headline: Musée des Arts Décoratif's History of Fashion
text: A Paris exhibition at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs re-assesses the style of the 1970s through multimedia installations that bring each designer’s spirit to screen life.

headline: The Haul | Hebrew Fashionable
text: Introducing The Haul: an occasional peek at what our contributors forage on vacation.

headline: New Nudibranchs, and the Sting of Biodiversity
text: Thursday

headline: Remembering the Tiananmen Protests
text: Nicholas D. Kristof, who was Beijing bureau chief for The Times in spring of 1989, recalls the city’s mood during the student protests leading up to June 4, 1989.

headline: Andrew Cuomo, Reconsidered
text: ALBANY — There’s a tradition in this town of cozying up to those perceived to be incoming governors, regardless of political affiliations.

headline: Phillies Riding the Knuckleball Express
text: It’s unusual for a team to face  knuckleball pitchers in consecutive games.

headline: City Principals Bracing for Steep Budget Cuts
text: City principals will find out next week exactly how much money they will be asked to shave from their already stretched budgets for the coming school year, and they are getting ready for bad news.

headline: An Old Maid Meets a Scientist. No Sparks Fly.
text: Few fiction writers have been as adventurous and enterprising as Jane Smiley — a fox, not a hedgehog, of a writer; a decathlete in a world of specialists. Having written some masterly novellas about the hazards and consolations of love (“The Age of Grief,” “Ordinary Love & Good Will”), she has gone on to write a sprawling folkloric epic about the world’s largest island (“The Greenlanders”), a variation on King Lear set on an Iowa farm (“A Thousand Acres”), a funny-bittersweet portrait of a fictional Midwestern college (“Moo”) and a Faustian tale set in the Rust Belt (“Good Faith”).

headline: A Last-Gasp Airlift for Oily Birds
text: In an unusual and no doubt bewildering migration, a handful of birds oiled by the BP oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico have been transported by military aircraft from coastal Louisiana to Florida and released at coastal wildlife refuges there.

headline: Tracking the Ancestry of Corn Back 9,000 Years
text: It is now growing season across the Corn Belt of the United States. Seeds that have just been sown will, with the right mixture of sunshine and rain, be knee-high plants by the Fourth of July and tall stalks with ears ripe for picking by late August.

headline: China’s Flood of iPad Flankers
text: China has rather quickly emerged as the home of the iPad Flanker.

headline: Noting Alcohol Content
text: In my column this week on Savennieres, you may notice something a little different in the tasting report. For the first time, I’ve listed the alcohol content of each wine.

headline: Scandal Or No, Duchess Is Fully Booked
text: An embarrassing influence-peddling scandal is not keeping Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, away from an annual bookseller’s convention in New York this week. A British newspaper reported on Sunday that the duchess, right, had accepted $40,000 in cash from a reporter (posing as a businessman) in exchange for a meeting with her ex-husband, Prince Andrew. That report did not spur the duchess, who is a best-selling children’s book author, to cancel her scheduled breakfast speech at BookExpo America on Wednesday, an appearance to promote her new series that is scheduled to be published this fall. The series, “Helping Hand Books,” is intended to “help children understand personal and social issues that affect them growing up, including starting school, coping with bullying and learning about strangers.” Leigh Ann Ambrosi, a spokeswoman for Sterling Publishing, said the duchess planned to keep all her commitments at the convention, including a cocktail reception in her honor on Wednesday. “We’re happy to be publishing her and we’re happy to support all of her publishing endeavors,” Ms. Ambrosi said.

headline: Asking Puzzling Questions, With Full-Frontal Intensity
text: “There are times in life when the question of knowing if one can think differently than one thinks, and perceive differently than one sees, is absolutely necessary if one is to go on looking and reflecting at all.” So said Michel Foucault in “The Uses of Pleasure,” and it is quoted on the Web site of Fitzgerald & Stapleton (fitzgeraldandstapleton.com), the Irish duo whose brief run at the Chocolate Factory marks that theater’s first international commission.

headline: Not All Is ‘Lost’
text: Although ABC topped Sunday night with its “Lost” finale, a CBS tribute concert to the country-music duo Brooks & Dunn earned solid ratings. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 10.1 million viewers tuned in to CBS for “ACM Presents: Brooks & Dunn  The Last Rodeo.” That audience was less than the 13.5 million that watched “Lost,” but enough to lift CBS to second place. NBC’s two-hour season finale of “Celebrity Apprentice” averaged 9.3 million viewers and NBC was third over all.

headline: Higher Education and the Pursuit of Living High Off the Hog
text: “Tech Transfer” is the deceptively mild title of a mordant satire about scientists and universities and how they do business.

headline: Díaz Joins Pulitzer Panel
text: The novelist Junot Díaz has been elected to the Pulitzer board, according to Columbia University, which administers the annual awards. Mr. Díaz, 41, winner of the 2008 Pulitzer Prize for fiction for his book “The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao,” will join the board of 20 members. He teaches creative writing at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

headline: Michaels’s Hard Month Has a Good Ending
text: One month after suffering a brain hemorrhage and days after being re-admitted to the hospital for a warning stroke, the rock musician Bret Michaels, below, won NBC’s “Celebrity Apprentice” contest on Sunday. Mr. Michaels beat the other finalist, Holly Robinson Peete. Donald Trump’s announcement of the winner came after he said that Mr. Michaels’s doctors did not want him to fly to New York for the live finale, “not at all.” The business challenges on “Celebrity Apprentice” had all been taped before Mr. Michaels had an emergency appendectomy in mid-April. A week later the brain hemorrhage was discovered. And last week, during Mr. Michaels’s rehabilitation, doctors found a hole in his heart. His friends and family are making sure that Mr. Michaels takes no unnecessary risks, according to his Web site, bretmichaels.com, and every precaution is being taken to protect his health.

headline: Suit Against Christie’s Yields $8.57. Million
text: The technology entrepreneur Halsey Minor has won a multimillion-dollar judgment against the auction house Christie’s, which a jury decided was in breach of its contract with Mr. Minor and defrauded him after failing to promptly return works that he owned but which the auction house was unable to sell, The Wall Street Journal reported. Judge William Alsup of United States District Court in San Francisco awarded Mr. Minor $8.57 million in damages, concluding a suit that Mr. Minor brought against Christie’s at the end of 2008. Mr. Minor, a founder of the technology site CNet, approached Christie’s earlier that year to help him sell seven paintings by Richard Prince, including his work “Nurse in Hollywood #4,” above. The Journal said that Mr. Minor owed Christie’s about $12 million for other works he had purchased from the auction company, and when Mr. Minor asked Christie’s to return the Prince paintings in August 2008, the company had decided not to send them back until Mr. Minor paid his debts. Christie’s was awarded $1.4 million in a counterclaim against Mr. Minor, who was found to be in breach of contract. The “Nurse” painting was sold earlier this month at a Phillips de Pury auction for $6.4 million including fees.

headline: Resort Report | Bottega Veneta, Easy Breezy
text: The Cruise collections are underway, which means that for the next few months we will be attending a loose schedule of shows and appointments to see what designers have in store for that micro-season otherwise known as Resort. The clothes are meant to be “real” — a respite between the spring and fall fashion statements. More specifically, they are designed to be worn on that warm weather holiday that you will definitely be taking (one can only hope) in late December or early January.

headline: ‘Lost’ Finale Lifts ABC to a Big Night
text: Fans of “Lost” clearly came together  much like its cast of players  for one last dive into the pool of sci-fi and spirituality on Sunday night, lifting ABC to its best non-Oscars Sunday night in two and a half years and posting what are likely to be the best finale numbers for any scripted show this television season.

headline: Frank to Head Joint Panel on Financial Bill
text: Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts, a sharp critic of Wall Street and close ally of the Obama administration, will head a House-Senate conference committee to prepare a final bill on financial regulation, Reuters reports.

headline: Ready or Not, Here Come the Clowns
text: Dear Theater Ethicist: Should I feel guilty that, for me, the most satisfying moment of Cirque du Soleil’s “Banana Shpeel” came when a clown was riddled with mock machine-gun fire?

headline: ‘Observing Squirrels’
text: Created by Jason Freeman and Richard Katz. Performed by Jenny Lin.

headline: A Classic Turns 50, and Parties Are Planned
text: In Santa Cruz, Calif., volunteers will re-enact every word and movement in the famous courtroom scene. In Monroeville, Ala., residents dressed in 1930s garb will read aloud from memorable passages. In Rhinebeck, N.Y., Oblong Books will host a party with Mocktails and recorded music by the indie band the Boo Radleys.

headline: AIDS Is Still a Crisis. Is Anyone Really Surprised?
text: Josh Ruxin is the director of Rwanda Works and a Columbia University expert on public health who has spent the last few years living in Rwanda.

headline: I.B.M.’s Bet on ‘Smart Plumbing’ for Businesses
text: Earlier this month, I.B.M. executives told investors that the company planned to double its spending on acquisitions over the next five years, to $20 billion.

headline: Hihowareya?  We Asked, and You Answered
text: When you ask someone “how are you,” do you really care?

headline: Eli Broad Said to Pick Site for New Museum
text: Where will Eli Broad build his museum? For months, Los Angeles’s most influential philanthropist and art collector has publicly toyed with various locations for a museum to house his contemporary-art collection. Although a Beverly Hills site fell out of the running in mid-April, Mr. Broad told The Los Angeles Times just over two weeks ago that he was still considering both a Santa Monica site and one downtown, on Grand Avenue.

headline: Artifacts | A Short History of Richard Prince, On a T-Shirt
text: One thing that makes New York fascinating is the way it can change overnight and still feel like New York. Take the Bowery. Where sweatshops once stood, high-end habitations flourish. Doorways in which derelicts used to sleep now give way to trendy nightspots. And where thrifty cooks once snagged used kitchen supplies, a person can be enchanted by T-shirts.

headline: 'Trying to Be Hip'
text: Created by Jason Freeman and Kit Eakle. Performed by Jenny Lin.

headline: Overseas Madoff Investors Settle With Banks
text: MADRID — About 720,000 investors outside the United States who lost money to the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff have settled with their banks, receiving about $15.5 billion in all, according to law firms representing those victims of the fraud.

headline: The Countdown Continues, at a New Address
text: Paul Myerberg of The Times hasn’t stopped writing long-winded college football previews, he’s just changed addresses, for now. The Countdown will return to The Quad later in the summer, as Paul explains below.

headline: 'Reading a Poem'
text: Created by Jason Freeman and Jason Carl Rosenberg. Performed by Jenny Lin.

headline: The ‘Lost’ Finale, in Twitter Traffic
text: By midafternoon Sunday, Twitter was ablaze with anticipation. The hot topic of conversation? The 4.5-hour conclusion  of “Lost,” which kicked off at 7 p.m. Eastern time with a recap of the show’s six seasons. As I reported on Saturday, “Lost” has amassed a huge following of devotees online, many of whom can’t resist the urge to trade one liners, dissect jaw-dropping plot twists and generally chitchat about the show on Twitter and Facebook as it airs.

headline: 'Learning to Dance'
text: Created by Jason Freeman and Evan Hill. Performed by Jenny Lin.

headline: New Judging Role for Paula Abdul
text: Moving from singing to dancing, the former “American Idol” judge Paula Abdul will headline the coming CBS dance competition, “Got to Dance,” the network announced on Monday. Ms. Abdul, right, will be the lead judge and a mentor for the amateur contestants on that reality show. Behind the scenes she will also be an executive producer and a “creative partner,” CBS said. With “Got to Dance”  a title that may change  CBS will be competing with ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” and Fox’s “So You Think You Can Dance.” A CBS spokesman said that the network had not determined a premiere date for the series. In a statement, Ms. Abdul said, “Each and every week we’ll showcase the challenges and successes of a fantastic group of dancers as they perform and compete.” The “Got to Dance” format comes from Britain, where it started last year.

headline: Sean Hayes to Host Tony Awards Ceremony
text: These have been some busy weeks for Sean Hayes, below, the Emmy Award-winning “Will & Grace” star: he has been starring on Broadway in the revival of “Promises, Promises,” which netted him a Tony Award nomination for best actor in a musical. And  oh, yes  he recently came out publicly and was criticized in an article on Newsweek’s Web site (newsweek.com) that said he and other gay actors were unconvincing as straight characters. And what better way to put that behind him than by hosting a nationally televised awards program? Mr. Hayes has been chosen to host the 64th Annual Tony Awards, its organizers said on Monday. The awards ceremony that honors Broadway’s best will be held on June 13 at Radio City Music Hall and will be broadcast live on CBS. The 2010 Tonys team will come into the show with some momentum, or some big shoes to fill, depending on how you look at it: the 2009 ceremony, hosted by Neil Patrick Harris, drew the show’s best ratings in three years.

headline: Talking Head Sues Charlie Crist
text: The singer and former Talking Heads frontman David Byrne has sued Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida, saying that he used the Talking Heads’ song “Road to Nowhere” in a Senate campaign ad without permission. The song was used in an online video posted in January that attacked Marco Rubio, a Republican who is Governor Crist’s opponent for the seat that will be vacated this year by Mel Martinez. The governor, a longtime Republican, is now running as an independent.

headline: Where U.S. Helped to Rebuild Europe, Past Glories Are Restored
text: PARIS — The United States on Tuesday will unveil the newly restored Hôtel de Talleyrand, the historic Parisian palace on the Place de la Concorde that once served as the headquarters of the Marshall Plan, the postwar American reconstruction plan for Western Europe.

headline: Gold Face Cream: A Costly Leap of Faith
text: CHRISTINE VALMY’S Golden Collagen facial mask is a visual and tactile delight: gelatinous, face-shaped and thoroughly golden, it arrives in a sheer plastic enclosure that invites you to squish it the way that bubble wrap begs you to pop it.

headline: Australia Expels Israeli Official Over Dubai Killing
text: The diplomatic fallout from the killing of a Hamas operative in his Dubai hotel room expanded Monday as Australia became the latest country to expel an Israeli official, saying that Israel had played a role in falsifying passports used by suspected members of the assassination team.

headline: Banks Pay Overseas Madoff Investors $15.5 Billion
text: About 720,000 investors outside the United States who lost money to the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff have settled with their banks, receiving about $15.5 billion in all, according to law firms representing those victims of the fraud, Raphael Minder and Diana B. Henriques of The New York Times report.

headline: Facebook Grapples With a Weekend of Malice
text: 6:23 p.m. | Updated Facebook added a warning to its Security page.

headline: In Europe, Britain May Face Largest Debt Hurdle
text: LONDON — As governments from Greece to Portugal to Spain try to sell markets on their budget-cutting zeal, the country that may face the biggest hurdle is Britain.

headline: Even Cleopatra Didn’t Have These
text: GOLD is expensive, yes, but the price of gold-infused products seems more closely aligned to what the market will bear. Fans of La Prairie, the luxury brand, pay $580 for an ounce of Cellular Radiance Concentrate Pure Gold, an anti-aging serum that comes in a thumb-size tube (above, far left) and claims that “with one single drop, it diminishes lines and wrinkles and helps regulate pigmentation.”

headline: NYC Popfest
text: A look at the four-day pop music festival in New York.

headline: Clean-Cut Pop, on the Upswing
text: The real revelation of this year’s NYC Popfest came during the Friday night encore of Allo Darlin’, from London. First, that there was an encore at all: the middle act on a five-band lineup playing its first New York show rarely gets that privilege. But for its allotted half-hour at Don Hill’s, Allo Darlin’ had been terrific, witty and heartfelt, like a less moody Belle & Sebastian.

headline: A Hospital Stay Puts Off a Maestro’s Return to La Scala
text: Claudio Abbado’s grand return as conductor of the orchestra of La Scala, ending a 24-year dry spell, has been canceled. Mr. Abbado entered a Berlin hospital last week with exhaustion and has pulled out of all performances for the next several weeks, La Scala said on Monday.

headline: Swift Rage in Pakistan Over Facebook and Its Ban
text: Pakistanis can be emotional, and their sensitivities heighten over matters of faith. Blasphemy is a particularly combustible issue. Reactions are intense and extreme. So, it was no surprise here that angry protests erupted countrywide last week over a cartoon contest on Facebook to draw the Prophet Mohammed.

headline: A Display of Young Muscle, Flashing New Chops
text: I have yet to attend a concert by the New York Youth Symphony from which I have not come away struck anew by the polish and confidence reliably shown by this excellent ensemble of student musicians ages 12 to 22. Its programs follow a formula: nearly all include a noteworthy soloist, a premiere by an emerging composer and at least one repertory staple. But what a formula, and what a remarkable value its inexpensive tickets represent.

headline: What We’re Reading: Apologies
text: Here’s what captured the attention of tech reporters and editors at the New York Times on Monday:

headline: Flying Far From Land
text: Ornithologists using miniature transmitters have discovered that some species fly great distances in surprising feats of navigation and endurance.

headline: Back-Seat Jumpers Now Have Their Day
text: As someone who has played electronic games almost my entire life, my deepest shame has always been that I’m not a great jumper.

headline: A Pianist Chooses a Light Touch Over Heavy Hands
text: The Russian pianist Nikolai Lugansky has a formidable technique, and when he puts a bit of muscle behind it, he produces the big sound that characterizes the Russian style. But mostly, in his recital at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Sunday as on his recordings, Mr. Lugansky seemed less interested in traditional Russian pyrotechnics than in transparency and refinement.

headline: Vulcanism and Cataclysm
text: Q. Is there any evidence of a volcanic tube or magma chamber coming in contact with an oil or gas field? Would that have caused a massive explosion when vaporized oil came into contact with air at the earth’s surface, releasing carbon dioxide and carbon debris? Might it even have led to global cooling or an ice age?

headline: John Fogerty Tells the Story Behind ‘Centerfield’
text: When the Baseball Hall of Fame welcomes a new class this summer, the premier inductee will be Andre Dawson, the former Gold Glove center fielder. But Dawson will not actually play center field in Cooperstown on July 25. John Fogerty will.

headline: Mineo Lawyers Say Police Tampered With Evidence
text: Lawyers representing Michael Mineo, a Brooklyn man who said he was sodomized by a New York City police officer as he was being arrested in 2008, have filed papers in federal court alleging that police investigators tampered with an important piece of evidence –- Mr. Mineo’s boxer shorts -– in order to protect the arresting officers from criminal charges.

headline: Budget Cuts Polarize a Long Island County
text: HUNTINGTON HARBOR, N.Y. — The 911 call came in from the North Shore of Long Island on a blustery night in March: Three people were unconscious on a houseboat, overcome by carbon monoxide fumes. Tied up to a dock a few hundred yards away sat a 25-foot police boat, stocked with defibrillators and other first-aid gear.

headline: Ahh, the Sweet Sound of Music Training
text: Scholars have never agreed on why certain combinations of notes sound sweet while others grate on the ear.

headline: Male Antelopes Scare Partners Into Sex
text: This is a story about deception and sex in the wild plains of Kenya.

headline: Sending Vibrations, Frogs Say ‘Back Off!’
text: Many scientists study how animals communicate with one another through acoustic and visual signals and physical interaction. But the effect of vibrations is often overlooked.

headline: Senate Sides With Auto Dealers
text: In a sharp rebuke of President Obama, the Senate voted on Monday to direct conference negotiators to make sure that the final version of a sweeping financial regulatory bill includes a special exemption to shield automobile dealers from the oversight of a new Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection.

headline: Rossi to Enter Washington Senate Race
text: Dino Rossi, a two-time Republican nominee for governor in Washington, is set to announce, likely on Wednesday, that he is running for Senate, according to a G.O.P. official.

headline: From Trees and Grass, Bacteria That Cause Snow and Rain
text: BOZEMAN, Mont. — Walking across the campus of Montana State University here, David Sands, a plant pathologist, says the blanket of snow draped over the mountains around town contains a surprise.

headline: Mozart, Brahms, Mendelssohn and a Not Very Cooperative Rubber Band
text: After the first movement of Brahms’s String Quintet in G (Op. 111) during a concert by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, the violist Paul Neubauer stood up, told the audience he would return and exited the stage. The rubber band attaching his shoulder pad to his instrument had broken, so he left the stage to replace it. The incident provided one of the few dramatic moments during the first half of the program, the last in the society’s 40th-anniversary season.

headline: Young Composers Share Their New Sounds
text: Behind the polished veneer of any orchestral premiere there lies a process of familiarization and toil, a process made unusually transparent by the American Composers Orchestra in its annual Underwood New Music Readings. The program, designed to give young composers access to an orchestra as well as crucial feedback from experienced colleagues, offers an invaluable glimpse behind the curtain, allowing audience members to witness firsthand the labor that goes into bringing new symphonic works to the stage.

headline: Stressful Job Evaluations (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Friends as Enemies (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Governing Party Leads in Ethiopian Election
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — Prime Minister Meles Zenawi’s governing Ethiopian People’s Democratic Front has opened a wide lead in early results from Sunday’s election, the country’s electoral board announced Monday.

headline: Both Style and Substance in Diaper Advertising
text: IN a new television commercial for Huggies, the Kimberly-Clark diaper brand, two women are eating lunch at an outdoor cafe when something suddenly catches their attention, and they lower oversize sunglasses for a better look.

headline: Better Days Ahead? (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Process of Mourning (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Israel Denies It Offered South Africa Warheads
text: JERUSALEM — The office of Israel’s president, Shimon Peres, strongly denied Monday that Mr. Peres, as Israel’s defense minister, offered to sell nuclear warheads to South Africa in 1975, as reported by The Guardian.

headline: As a New Government Goes to Work, the Constitution Offers Britons Few Guides
text: LONDON — The British Parliament is set to return to work in its usual baroque manner on Tuesday, when Queen Elizabeth puts on a gown and a crown and, following long-established custom, reads the new government’s legislative program aloud in a voice bleached dry of intonation.

headline: Hotels Book Unusual Events to Draw in the Public
text: At most hotels, the weak economy of the last year and a half has meant one thing — fewer amenities.

headline: Lovely Shimmering Fish in Huge Tanks (Pick Your Dinner)
text: WE have labs throughout the world. And I’ve had the opportunity to work with some amazing people. Along the way, I’ve tried to learn the local customs.

headline: Relishing Tales of Troubled Travel
text: TRAVEL wisdom is something to cherish, especially when you consider all you had to go through to acquire it. That seems to be the consensus of readers who responded to last week’s column on the subject of bad trips and how we all relish the experience of sharing the stories of what went wrong.

headline: Deal Reached for Ending Law on Gays in Military
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, the Pentagon and leading lawmakers reached agreement Monday on legislative language and a time frame for repealing the military’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy, clearing the way for Congress to take up the measure as soon as this week.

headline: Decision Time for Bradley and U.S.

headline: Hard Times Spur Ideas for Change
text: As states around the country gird for another grim budget year, more leaders have begun to talk not of nipping, not of tucking, but, in essence, of turning government upside down and starting over. Ever growing is the list of states, municipalities and agencies with blue ribbon committees aimed at reconsidering what government should be.

headline: Credit Card Database Is Heroic, and Mystifying
text: The Federal Reserve on Monday introduced an online database listing the terms and conditions of more than 300 credit card issuers to help consumers find a card that best suits their personal finance needs.

text: LONDON — Last month hundreds of environmental activists crammed into an auditorium here to ponder an anguished question: If the scientific consensus on climate change has not changed, why have so many people turned away from the idea that human activity is warming the planet?

headline: British Medical Council Bars Doctor Who Linked Vaccine With Autism
text: LONDON — A doctor whose research and public statements caused widespread alarm that a common childhood vaccine could cause autism was banned on Monday from practicing medicine in his native Britain for ethical lapses, including conducting invasive medical procedures on children that they did not need.

headline: Compose Your Own, Part 2
text: In a recent post on The Score, I invited readers to use an interactive Web site to create and share their own unique versions of four solo piano etudes, regardless of their background in music or in composition. The Web site presents each etude as a graphical “open-form” collection of short musical fragments that can be arranged in an almost infinite number of ways.

headline: Looking Past the Children’s Menu
text: Nicola Marzovilla runs a business, so when a client at his Gramercy Park restaurant, I Trulli, asks for a children’s menu, he does not say what he really thinks. What he says is, “I’m sure we can find something on the menu your child will like.” What he thinks is, “Children’s menus are the death of civilization.”

headline: Communications Law to be Reviewed
text: WASHINGTON — Two top Democratic legislators said Monday that they would begin a process to modernize telecommunications laws that were last overhauled in 1996 but barely mention the Internet.

headline: A Degree in Three

headline: Russia: Ex-Premier Accuses Putin in Tycoon’s Trial
text: Vladimir V. Putin, then Russia’s president, ordered the prosecution of an oil tycoon because he was supporting political parties without Mr. Putin’s permission, former Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov said in court on Monday. The tycoon, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, owner of the now bankrupt Yukos company, and his partner, Platon Lebedev, are accused of embezzling 350 million tons of oil. After Mr. Khodorkovsky was arrested, Mr. Kasyanov, left, pressed Mr. Putin for an explanation. “He said something like this: That Yukos was financing political parties — not just the Union of Right Forces and Yabloko, which he, President Putin, allowed them to finance, but also the Communist Party, which he, President Putin, did not allow them to finance,” Mr. Kasyanov testified. He said he was shocked to learn that “lawful support of political parties still required secret approval from the president of the Russian Federation.”

headline: To Trace the Yankees’ Slide, Start With a Win
text: For an entirely different reason from last year, May 8 was again a momentous day for the Yankees. They commemorated the anniversary of Alex Rodriguez’s return from the disabled list by torching the Boston Red Sox for 14 runs at Fenway Park. But in the aftermath of that game, their sixth straight victory, it was easy to overlook a bad omen.

headline: The Oil Spill, One Month Later
text: A month after an explosion aboard the Deepwater Horizon oil rig started a massive spill, the environmental cleanup and political fallout continue.

headline: House Panel Criticizes New N.F.L. Doctors

headline: U.S. Is Said to Expand Secret Actions in Mideast
text: WASHINGTON — The top American commander in the Middle East has ordered a broad expansion of clandestine military activity in an effort to disrupt militant groups or counter threats in Iran, Saudi Arabia, Somalia and other countries in the region, according to defense officials and military documents.

headline: Black Firefighters’ Claim Was Timely, Justices Say
text: WASHINGTON — In a case that carried echoes of two of its most divisive decisions in recent years, the Supreme Court on Monday unanimously ruled that black firefighters in Chicago did not miss a deadline to argue that the city used an employment test in a way that disproportionately hurt their chances.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Self-Assured Beasley Glad to Have Another Chance
text: EAST HARTFORD, Conn. — It seemed the most innocuous of plays, a short corner played from Landon Donovan to DaMarcus Beasley at the Confederations Cup last June. Except the ball rolled under Beasley’s foot and was whooshed downfield by Brazil for a searing counterattack goal.

headline: Now Playing ‘Centerfield’ at the Hall of Fame: Fogerty
text: When the Baseball Hall of Fame welcomes a new class this summer, the premier inductee will be Andre Dawson, a former Gold Glove center fielder. But Dawson will not actually play center field in Cooperstown on July 25. John Fogerty will.

headline: A B-Minus? The Shock! The Horror!

headline: Obama Asks for Authority to Cut Items on Spending
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday became the latest White House resident to ask Congress for greater authority to cut specific items from spending bills, but even heightened concern about federal deficits may not be enough to overcome lawmakers’ traditional resistance to sharing more of their constitutional power of the purse.

headline: Christina Aguilera Postpones Tour
text: Christina Aguilera has put off her summer tour until next year, citing her busy schedule in preparing her new album and film.

headline: U.S. Championship Goes to a Tie-Breaker
text: The final regulation game between the top two players, Gata Kamsky and Yuri Shulman, was drawn, so they will play a tie-breaker Tuesday.

headline: A Tight Election in Colombia Exposes a Generational Divide in Queens

headline: Bronx Zoo in Queens: Angry Words, and Wins
text: Like the Yankees of Billy Martin and Reggie Jackson, the Mets may just be a team that thrives on a little bit of turmoil. There have been two confrontations involving a player and a member of the team’s staff in the last five days, and during that time, the Mets have won three out of four games.

headline: Facebook Responds
text: Facebook built its base of nearly 500 million users on the notion that it was a place for people to connect with each other and post their likes, dislikes, photos, activities with as wide a circle as they chose to define. Facebook, in turn, used that information to show users advertisements based on their tastes.

headline: Dodd Prepares to Depart in Triumph
text: WASHINGTON — As Senator Christopher J. Dodd completed what might be the capstone of his legislative career last week by shepherding a major banking overhaul through the Senate, the guest book in his office offered a glimpse of why he is not seeking re-election. It includes these recent greetings from visitors who stopped by to pay their disrespects:

headline: Top Prosecutor Creates a Unit on Crime Trends
text: Manhattan’s chief prosecutor on Monday announced the formation of a unit that will use a CompStat-like approach to detecting, analyzing and tackling crime trends.

headline: A Door Opens for Workers
text: Workers won an important victory at the Supreme Court on Monday when the justices ruled unanimously that a group of African-American applicants to the Chicago Fire Department did not wait too long to challenge a hiring test they claimed was discriminatory.

headline: Waste, Fraud and the Truth
text: We certainly can’t argue with the stated goal of the proposal that President Obama sent to Congress on Monday — the Reduce Unnecessary Spending Act of 2010. It is an obvious challenge to the many Republicans who spent much of the last decade helping drive up the deficit with unjustifiable tax cuts and unrestrained spending and who are now caterwauling about fiscal responsibility.

headline: ’24’ Ends With a (Literal) Vengeance
text: Sunday’s final “Lost” continues to elicit plenty of chatter in the Twitterverse and elsewhere, but the episode was only the first of several high-profile finales this week. “Law & Order” will call it a series on Monday night, assuming a cable channel doesn’t pick it up, and on Wednesday America will pick its newest “Idol.”

headline: Afternoon Fare
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Sarah Keller comes clean. She has constructed a puzzle where she hops from bar to bar and the central “Afternoon fare …” clue at 39 Across ties it all together. Wait, that didn’t sound right.

headline: Blumenthal Says He Is Sorry for Vietnam Claims
text: Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, whose acknowledgment last week that he had misrepresented his Vietnam record overshadowed his nomination as Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, has apologized.

headline: When All Good Quests Must Come to an End
text: “24” came to an end on Monday night with what was literally a vengeance: Jack Bauer (Kiefer Sutherland) went on one last cathartic killing jag that rivaled scenes from “The Terminator” and Charles Bronson in “Death Wish” mode.

headline: John P. Lewis, an Adviser to Presidents on Economic Aid, Dies at 89
text: John P. Lewis, who was an economic adviser to three presidents, largely on the subject of foreign aid, died Wednesday in Montgomery, N.J. He was 89 and lived at Stonebridge at Montgomery, a retirement community.

headline: United Nations: Sentence for Malawi Gay Couple Condemned
text: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, said Monday that he would travel to Malawi this weekend where among other issues he will take up with President Bingu wa Mutharika is the 14-year jail sentence handed down to two homosexual men who held an engagement ceremony. Mr. Ban said the sentence violated human rights principles that ban both discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, as well as the criminalization of sexual acts between consenting adults.

headline: Shaky Rule in Madagascar Threatens Trees
text: MAROANSETRA, Madagascar — Exploiting a political crisis, Malagasy timber barons are robbing this island nation of its sylvan heritage, illegally cutting down scarce species of rosewood trees in poorly protected national parks and exporting most of the valuable logs to China.

headline: Inspector General’s Inquiry Faults Regulators
text: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators responsible for oversight of drilling in the Gulf of Mexico allowed industry officials several years ago to fill in their own inspection reports in pencil — and then turned them over to the regulators, who traced over them in pen before submitting the reports to the agency, according to an inspector general’s report to be released this week. The report said that investigators "could not discern if any fraudulent alterations were present on these forms."

headline: A Night on the Plaza
text: It is 7 o’clock on Saturday night, and somewhere inside Avery Fisher Hall, Gustavo Dudamel — conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic — is doing whatever he does in the hour before he takes the stage. It may be something reflective, or something to impart that characteristic tremor to the tip of his baton, which, in certain passages later this evening, will quiver like the needle of a seismograph during the Big One.

headline: N.F.L. Fails in Its Request for Antitrust Immunity
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday unanimously rejected a request from the National Football League that it be granted broad antitrust immunity on the theory that it is a single entity rather than a collection of 32 independent teams.

headline: Many Faiths, One Truth
text: WHEN I was a boy in Tibet, I felt that my own Buddhist religion must be the best — and that other faiths were somehow inferior. Now I see how naïve I was, and how dangerous the extremes of religious intolerance can be today.

headline: Flyers, Who Slipped Into Playoffs on Season’s Last Day, Sail Into Finals
text: PHILADELPHIA — One gallant playoff run ended Monday night, and another continued. The Philadelphia Flyers — a team that won only 41 of its 82 regular-season games, a team that made the playoffs on the last shot of the last day of the season — are going to the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: 90 Miles Upstate,  a Brooklyn Feel
text: ROSENDALE, N.Y. — Until about a year ago, Fredrick Arnold was living the life of a Williamsburg hipster. An aspiring filmmaker with mutton-chop sideburns, he spent his working hours waiting tables at Dumont Burger, and his off hours on projects like an animated music video for one of his favorite bands, Casper & the Cookies.

headline: Talking Head to Campaign: That’s My Song
text: The singer and former Talking Heads frontman David Byrne has sued Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida, saying he used the Talking Heads’ song “Road to Nowhere” in a Senate campaign ad without permission.

headline: In Standoff With Environmental Officials, BP Stays With an Oil Spill Dispersant
text: In a tense standoff, BP continued to spray a product called Corexit in the Gulf of Mexico on Monday to break up a vast oil spill despite a demand by federal regulators that it switch to something less toxic.

headline: Moelis & Company Outgrowing Its Boutique Status
text: Ken Moelis’s boutique is bulging. In just three years, his corporate finance advisory firm has swelled to 325 people, and counting. Such growth suggests Moelis & Company has the revenue and backers it needs for now. But with all the equity Mr. Moelis, a former UBS banker, is doling out, the pressure to go public will build before long. The company started in mid-2007 with some good timing. The upheaval in the financial sector provided an opportunity to secure cheap rents, hire displaced and disillusioned bankers, and snatch clients wanting advice at a distance from Wall Street.

headline: Bloggingheads: Troubled Assets
text: Glenn Loury, left, and Ross Levine, both of Brown University, discuss bailouts vs. other possible social investments.

headline: World Cup Break Will Be Welcome Timeout for Red Bulls

headline: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: THE NUMBERS It has been 34 days since the first explosion on the Deepwater Horizon rig. The spill’s impact on shore now stretches across 150 miles, from Dauphin Island, Ala., to Grand Isle, La., officials said.

headline: Microsoft to Reorganize Consumer Products Unit
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Hoping to energize its lackluster consumer devices division, Microsoft will reorganize parts of its phone and game unit this week, people familiar with the matter said.

headline: Broadway Baby Into Broadway’s Chronicler
text: “I love you, a bushel and a peck,” my mother sang to me when I was a child. I thought it was a lullaby. It is in fact a song sung by a stripper in “Guys and Dolls.”

text: A view of the day in sports, including finger-pointing at Roland Garros and mascot races in Cincinnati.

headline: Donald Lukens, Scandal-Tainted Lawmaker, Dies at 79
text: Donald E. Lukens, who helped push his party to the right as a vigorous leader of the Young Republicans in the 1960s and who resigned from Congress in scandal two decades later, died Saturday in Dallas. He was 79.

headline: Eljanov Easily Wins Final Grand Prix
text: The final Grand Prix ended on Monday somewhat anticlimactically, but, with a tie for second, Teimour Radjabov secured a spot in the Candidates contest that will determine the next challenger for the world championship.

headline: Facing Yanks’ Rodriguez Again, Mets’ Rodriguez Prevails
text: Nearly a year ago, on June 12, Derek Jeter was standing on second base and Mark Teixeira on first, with the Mets ahead by a run and two outs in the bottom of the ninth in the Bronx.

headline: Nelson Helps the Magic Dodge a Knockout Blow
text: BOSTON — The disparity in the point-guard matchup grew with each game of the Eastern Conference finals, as did the separation between the Orlando Magic and the Boston Celtics. In terms of conducting a team, Jameer Nelson of the Magic had come up as short when compared with Rajon Rondo as he does to his teammate Dwight Howard, who stands 11 inches taller.

headline: News Quiz | May 25, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: To Prepay for a Crisis, or Not
text: A close reading of the Senate’s bill (and its sister version approved by the House) raises big questions about whether it can protect taxpayers from financial institutions deemed too big and too intertwined with the rest of the financial system to be allowed to fail, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: Slow Start for E.C.B.’s Bond-Buying Program
text: The European Central Bank said Monday that it had spent 26.5 billion euros buying government or corporate bonds since it began the debt purchases May 10, an amount that some analysts still consider inadequate to stabilize the euro zone’s financial system, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

headline: Wall Street Slips at the Close
text: Stocks declined on Monday, dragged down by late-day losses in the financial sector, which has been mired in uncertainty over financial reforms and European debt troubles, The New York Times’s Christine Hauser reported.

headline: Islanders Cancel China Trip
text: The Islanders canceled their training camp trip to China, planned for this fall, over what team officials described as a disagreement between the Islanders’ owner, Charles Wang, and the N.H.L. Players’ Association, a team spokesman confirmed on Monday. The cancellation was first reported by Newsday.

headline: Dimon Broadly Optimistic on Financial Overhaul
text: Jamie Dimon, chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, is broadly optimistic financial reform is headed in the right direction, he said on Monday at the Japan Society‘s Annual Dinner in New York.

headline: Jitters Return to Asian Stock Markets
text: A shaky finish on Wall Street and nervousness over the health of some European banks sent Asian stock markets sharply lower on Tuesday, with falls of more than 2 percent on several of the region’s bigger indexes, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

headline: Study Shows Commercial Property Trouble at U.S. Banks
text: The default rate for commercial mortgages held by banks in the first quarter hit its highest level since at least 1992 and is expected to surpass that by year-end and peak in 2011, according to a study by Real Capital Analytics.

headline: How the Finance Bill Affects Consumers
text: For consumers trying to figure out what the financial overhaul bill means for them, the legislation the Senate passed Thursday offers some tantalizing possibilities, Ron Lieber writes in The New York Times.

headline: Four Spanish Banks Make Initial Merger Pact
text: Four regional savings banks in Spain said Monday that they had reached a preliminary agreement to merge some operations. The agreement, which is being led by Caja de Ahorros de Mediterráneo and includes Cajastur, Caja de Extremadura and Caja Cantabria, aims to create a joint banking group to “strengthen solvency and assets of the participating banks,” the banks said in a statement.

headline: Financial Group Urges Early Action in Crises
text: National regulators should have the power to intervene early in a banking crisis, including the right to replace senior management at troubled companies, a group representing the world’s largest financial firms recommended on Monday.

text: CDC Software  said Monday that it had completed its investment in Marketbright, which provides software services to corporations, The Associated Press reported.

headline: U.S. Regulator Says Mortgage Lenders Stabilizing

headline: End of First Round, and Matches to Watch
text: Justine Henin, the four-time French Open champion who retired just before the 2008 tournament, begins play on Tuesday as the first round concludes after three days. Henin, seeded 22nd (based on ranking, not expectations), faces Tsvetana Pironkova, a 22-year-old Bulgarian ranked No. 81. Second-seeded Rafael Nadal, who had won four straight titles at Roland Garros before losing to Robin Soderling in the fourth round last year, opens against Gianni Mina, a French wild card ranked in the 600’s.

headline: String of Suicides Continues at Electronics Supplier in China

headline: MasterCard Wants Programmers to Use Its Payment Technology

headline: Carlyle Invests in Hampton Roads
text: The Carlyle Group, the private equity firm, and hedge fund Anchorage Advisors have agreed to invest at least $73 million apiece in Hampton Roads Bankshares, which said Monday it expected to raise approximately $255 million from institutional investors.

headline: Prudential Shares Slip in Asian Debut

headline: Moelis & Company Outgrowing Its Boutique Status
text: Ken Moelis’s boutique is bulging. In just three years, his corporate finance advisory firm has swelled to 325 people, and counting. Such growth suggests Moelis & Company has the revenue and backers it needs for now. headline: Hedge Funds Getting Hammered on Financials?

headline: Sweet-Toothed Investors Eye Candy Bond

headline: Fed Not Likely to Sell Assets Soon
text: The Federal Reserve does not expect to sell any of the billions of dollars worth of assets it bought to boost the economy in 2009 until it has started raising interest rates in a strong recovery, it said in its 2009 annual report released on Monday.

headline: Thailand Issues Warrant for Ex-Leader
text: BANGKOK — Thailand’s criminal court on Tuesday approved an arrest warrant on terrorism charges for the fugitive former prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, accusing him of involvement in recent street protests in Bangkok that left more than 85 people dead.

headline: Warburg Pincus to Invest $139 Million in Sterling
text: Sterling Financial announced Monday that it would receive a total of $278 million in private equity financing, after Warburg Pincus agreed to join Thomas H. Lee Partners in investing in the bank holding company, The Associated Press reported.

headline: North Korea Cuts All Ties With South
text: WASHINGTON — North and South Korea accelerated their diplomatic confrontation on Tuesday over the recent sinking of a South Korean warship, with the South saying it would redesignate the North its “archenemy” and North Korea severing almost all of its remaining ties to its far wealthier neighbor.

headline: Finding the Nerve to Make That Hire
text: Alexandra Drane was one of the many entrepreneurs who thought she could do it all. Ms. Drane is co-founder and president of Eliza Corporation, a firm based in Beverly, Mass., that uses patented technology to communicate with health plan members, often with automated calls to encourage them to take advantage of the services their plans offer. She joined Eliza in 1999, when it consisted of just two scientists and a technology that she was charged with commercializing. She recruited the chief executive, Lucas Merrow, and by 2004, Eliza had hired engineering and operations teams. But when it came to Ms. Drane’s responsibilities — sales, marketing and account management — she was largely a solo operator. That was around the time, she said, that a board member read her “the riot act,” insisting that the company would not be able to achieve scale until she started hiring.

headline: Italy Set to Announce $29 Billion in Budget Cuts
text: The Italian government was poised to approve about 24 billion euros  in budget cuts Tuesday evening, according to local media, as Rome followed other euro zone countries of the Mediterranean in pursuing an aggressive austerity plan.

headline: Henin Is Her Old Self in French Open Return
text: PARIS — Justine Henin took to the familiar main court with none of the pomp of a champion’s welcome or a hero’s return. It was still morning, and most of the green seats were empty, a few more fans straggling in at every change.

headline: Tokyo Motor Show Downsizing Again
text: The Tokyo Motor Show continues its fall from the ranks of major auto shows, as organizers say they are moving it to a smaller site, shortening the show’s run and changing its date.

headline: Children Have a Place in Horse Racing
text: It was a typical exchange between a kid who could be considered annoying and his parent. “Dad”. Pause. “Dad”, pause, more emphasis…. “DAD”. You know how it goes — the kid keeps saying Dad until he finally gets what he wants. A souvenir, a treat, a toy, or the object of his insistence. “Dad…. Dad…. Dad!” The next sentence cracked me up. “Dad! Box the 3 and the 9!”. Again – “Dad! Box the 3 and the 9!”

headline: Sampler: Obama to Visit Bay Area, and Sprouts Are Recalled
text: Obama to Visit Bay Area to Raise Money for Boxer | President Obama will arrive in the Bay Area on Tuesday to try to bolster Senator Barbara Boxer’s re-election bid.  He is expected to help raise $1.5 million at an event on Tuesday at San Francisco’s Fairmont Hotel for Ms. Boxer, who is facing a tough campaign. Mr. Obama’s two-day trip will include an event in Fremont at Solyndra, a solar energy firm. Green technology is an important issue for Ms.  Boxer, who is the first chairwoman of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee. Republican officials say Mr. Obama’s trip underscores the senator’s vulnerability. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

headline: Yes: Another Steak Salad
text: I like this steak salad thing, which fits into many of my rules at once: You use one steak to serve four people; you use practically every vegetable you can lay your hands on; you keep it completely simple; and you make the thing taste good.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: At less than $1.22, the euro’s still in the spotlight, as we continue our chronicle of a debt foretold. Britain’s new government is wrestling with its deficit; Italy is set to make deep cuts in its two-year budget; and the I.M.F. thinks Spain hasn’t trimmed enough. In short, if fiscal policy ever went Hollywood, this would be a slasher movie.And in today’s Morning Take-Out:

headline: Powermat Tries Again
text: You’ve got to hand it to Powermat, which makes wireless charging systems. Their products are beautiful, presented in beautiful packaging, and are simple to use; if you want to charge several electronic devices, you place them on one of the company’s charging pads until you hear the electronic coupling noise. Your devices are then being charged, without any physical wire needed to connect an iPhone, iPod, BlackBerry or other product to a power source.

headline: Little Progress on Korea Dispute in China Talks
text: BEIJING — China and the United States wrapped up three days of high-level meetings with a handful of trade and energy agreements but little progress on the most pressing American priority: winning China’s backing for new measures against North Korea, which South Korea has accused of torpedoing one of its warships.

headline: Zoos and Aquariums on Oil Spill Alert
text: Thirty-two national wildlife refuges are at risk because of the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. They span five states – Alabama, Louisiana, Florida, Mississippi and Texas – and threaten dozens of species that are already endangered, including sea turtles, manatees and whooping cranes.

headline: U2 Postpones Tour as Bono Recovers From Surgery
text: An injury sustained by the U2 frontman Bono has forced the group to postpone its American tour and cancel its appearance at a major British rock festival while he recovers from emergency surgery on his back, Reuters reported.

headline: Tanker Collision Causes Oil Spill Off Singapore
text: HONG KONG — A merchant ship collided with a Malaysian oil tanker on Tuesday morning, puncturing the tanker’s hull and spilling 2,500 tons of crude oil into the Singapore Strait, maritime officials reported.

headline: A Fashionista Hits the Road
text: I’m always thinking of car trips. Let’s see: Faulkner’s Mississippi with biscuits. The Tidewater, West Texas. So when I heard that Stacey Bendet, the founder of Alice + Olivia, had organized a road trip through the South to meet customers and sell some clothes, I pricked up my ears. Ms. Bendet bought and renovated a vintage Airstream and on June 10, in Manchester, Tenn., for the Bonnaroo music festival, will make the first of a dozen or so stops in the Southeast.

headline: ‘The Human Centipede’ Gets the Video-Game Tribute It Deserves
text: It was 30 years ago that a popular arcade game first captivated the public’s imagination – a game whose timelessness and ingenuity have been reaffirmed by an ever-so-slightly updated version that has recently appeared on the Web. What do you mean, Pac-Man? We’re talking about Human Centipede: The Video Game.

headline: Now Booking | Grand Hyatt Shenzhen
text: Having just been to Shanghai, I was aware of Hyatt’s (literal) climb to the top of that city’s hotel market. The new Park Hyatt, on the 79th to 93rd floors of the 101-story Shanghai World Financial Center, towers over the company’s Grand Hyatt, next door in the (merely) 87-story Jin Mao Tower.

headline: Unrest Grows in Jamaica in 3rd Day of Standoff
text: MEXICO CITY — Fierce fighting between Jamaican security forces and gunmen trying to protect a powerful gang leader extended into a third day on Tuesday in Kingston, the Jamaican capital, highlighting a convoluted political system in which Jamaican politicians and crime bosses have long teamed up to share power.

headline: More Jobs, but Smaller Salaries, for New Graduates
text: In the midst of commencement season, The Choice has been casting an eye past the admissions process to the job market greeting those who have just graduated.

headline: Today in Business Travel
text: Hotels Book Unusual Events to Draw in the PublicGuests don’t have to leave the hotel to do something interesting, while local residents acquire a familiarity with the hotel that could lead to more business.

headline: Tuesday Reading: More Memorial Day Travel Deals
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Fallon: ‘It’s Finally Over’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: It’s pretty hard for fans of “Lost” now that it’s finally over. If people want to get their fix, they’ll have to follow that other group that’s lost and confused in the middle of the ocean. You know, BP.

headline: BAM Reveals Lineup for 2010 Next Wave Festival
text: The world premiere of a work by the “Passing Strange” creators Stew and Heidi Rodewald, and the first American performances by Tanztheater Wuppertal – Pina Bausch since Bausch’s death, will be among the highlights of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s 2010 Next Wave Festival, the academy said on Tuesday.

headline: Digital Officer Wanted. Must Speak Bureaucratese.
text: The city is looking to get into the social media act in a more formal way.

headline: Letterman: ‘A Bad Underwater Cement Job’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: You starting to get sick about the economy again? I was talking to my broker today. And he said: “Don’t worry. Everything’s going to be fine.” Then the prison guards took him away.

headline: Leno: ‘He Thought It Was a Porcupine’
text: Monologue |  Monday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Well, folks, it seems that oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, much worse than British Petroleum first reported. You know how bad it is? Yesterday, I checked the oil in my car, had seawater on it.

headline: Ex-Police Chief Is Sent to Jail for Molesting Indian Girl
text: NEW DELHI — Two decades after he molested a teenage girl who later committed suicide, a powerful retired police official was sent to prison on Monday in a case that had come to symbolize the abuse of power rampant in India.

headline: Cyclists Find New Method for Using an Old Doping Tool
text: MONTREAL — The blood-boosting hormone that was cycling’s greatest doping issue during the 1990s may be back as the sport’s newest problem.

headline: Building a Better Submission Form
text: If you participated in our invitation to photograph a “Moment in Time” earlier in May, you used our new photo submission software, which we call Stuffy. Built to enable users to upload media files — and to allow our producers to review uploaded files quickly — Stuffy uses a “NoSQL” storage engine to make customized forms simple.

headline: More Scrutiny for Charter Schools in Debate Over Expansion
text: ALBANY — During its first years of operation, the Niagara Charter School in Niagara Falls spent thousands of dollars on plane tickets, restaurant meals and alcohol, and more than $100,000 on no-bid consulting contracts. Yet the school’s teachers resorted to organizing a fund-raiser to buy playground equipment.

headline: VW Buys Italian Design Firm
text: The Volkswagen Group is buying a 90.1 percent stake in Italdesign, the companies announced at a press conference in Turin, Italy, on Tuesday morning.

headline: Slipknot Bassist Is Found Dead
text: The police in Iowa said that they would have more information on the death of Paul Gray, the bassist and a co-founder of the heavy-metal band Slipknot, after an autopsy on Tuesday, but that foul play was not immediately suspected, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Gray, 38, was found dead on Monday at a TownePlace Suites hotel in Johnston, Iowa, north of Des Moines. In the early 1990s he helped found Slipknot, the nihilistic if highly theatrical band whose members wear gruesome masks and refer to themselves by numbers and evocative nicknames. (Mr. Gray went by No. 2 or “The Pig.”) The group — which also includes the vocalist Corey Taylor, the guitarists James Root and Mick Thomson, and the drummer Joey Jordison — won a Grammy in 2005 for its song “Before I Forget,” and its 2008 album, “All Hope Is Gone,” reached No. 1 on the Billboard sales chart.

headline: Transparency for the Public Sector
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

headline: Tina Fey to Receive Mark Twain Prize for Humor
text: When we last saw Liz Lemon, the hapless, harried television alter ego of Tina Fey, she seemed to have found true love at last with an airline pilot who just happened to be played by Matt Damon. Though the romantic entanglements of Liz tend not to last too long, her creator and performer is about to receive an honor that’s a little more enduring. On Tuesday the Kennedy Center announced that it would present its annual Mark Twain Prize for American Humor to Ms. Fey, the “30 Rock” star, “Saturday Night Live” alumna and occasional cribber of punch lines from her daughter, Alice. In the 13-year history of the prize, Ms. Fey will be the third woman to receive it: it was previously presented to Lily Tomlin in 2003 and Whoopi Goldberg in 2001. Other recent winners include Bill Cosby, George Carlin and Ms. Fey’s former “SNL” boss and current “30 Rock” executive producer, Lorne Michaels. In a statement Ms Fey said: “I am truly thrilled to receive this honor. I assume Betty White was disqualified for steroid use.”

headline: 7 Seized in Anti-Drilling Protest
text: Charges have been filed against seven members of Greenpeace who boarded an offshore drilling support ship in a Louisiana port and painted anti-drilling slogans in crude oil on the vessel’s side on Monday afternoon.

headline: Another Reason to Keep Moving
text: I came home from a sweaty cardio-yoga class recently to find, in my e-mail inbox, a Journal of Gerontology study proclaiming more good news about the role of exercise in preserving cognitive skills. It made me so happy that I decided to pass it along to you, and so I called the lead researcher, Dr. Catarina Rosano of the University of Pittsburgh, an epidemiologist, to learn more.

headline: BP Prepares for ‘Top Kill’ Procedure
text: HOUSTON — As BP prepared Tuesday for its most ambitious effort yet to stop the torrent of oil gushing into the Gulf of Mexico, company officials emphasized that the procedure known as a top kill had never been tried so far underwater, that it might be delayed again and that it might not succeed at all.

headline: Querrey, Admitting Burnout, Falls to Ginepri
text: PARIS — One American, Robby Ginepri, slapped the ball into the stands and turned to applaud with his racket as the crowd stood and cheered him on Court 2 at Roland Garros. Another American, Sam Querrey, quickly packed his bag and walked, head slightly bowed, to the exit.

headline: Roddick Avoids an Early Exit at French Open
text: PARIS — Andy Roddick arrived as a bit of an American curiosity — someone who had not played a tour match since winning in March, had skipped the clay-court season, was granted a No. 6 seed but had only once lasted more than a few days at Roland Garros.

headline: Prison Term for Ex-Mayor of Detroit
text: Kwame M. Kilpatrick, who resigned as mayor of Detroit and pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice in 2008, was sentenced Tuesday to as much as five years in prison for violating his probation. The sentence was harsher than expected, and elicited loud gasps in the courtroom.

headline: Germany Drafts Wider Ban on Speculative Trades
text: FRANKFURT —  A week after rattling global bourses and annoying allies with a unilateral ban on some forms of financial market speculation, Germany went much further Tuesday, proposing a law that would greatly broaden restrictions on several instruments that investors use to bet against stocks, bonds and currencies.

headline: Facebook Will Introduce Simpler Privacy Controls
text: On Wednesday, Facebook will unveil a new version of its privacy menu intended to make adjusting the settings much easier for its members.

headline: Krumm, 39, Upsets Safina at Open
text: PARIS — Victory was precious but hardly painless for Kimiko Date Krumm on Tuesday at the French Open. Deep in the third set with her right calf becoming stiffer, she winced between points, limped toward her chair during the changeovers and gingerly stretched her leg.

headline: A New York Super Bowl?

The N.B.A. finals are nearly set (but the polar ice caps may melt first) and won’t be in New York (you can stop laughing any time now). But the N.F.L. may be sending the 2014 Super Bowl here.

headline: Following Jamaica’s State of Emergency Online
text: As the armed confrontation between Jamaica’s security forces and gang members who are trying to prevent the extradition of their leader to the United States on drug and weapons charges continues on Tuesday, Jamaicans are using Twitter and YouTube to pass along news of the siege gleaned from firsthand reports and the local news media.

headline: ‘Gabriel’ Extends Off Broadway Run
text: The Off Broadway production of “Gabriel,” a play about the lives of British and German inhabitants on the German-occupied Channel Islands during World War II, will extend its run for two weeks through June 20, the Atlantic Theater Company announced on Tuesday. Directed by David Esbjornson, the play opened on May 13 to several strong reviews for the acting ensemble — led by Lisa Emery and Zach Grenier — and the storytelling skill of the playwright, Moira Buffini. The play has been running since previews began on April 23.

headline: David Ginsburg, Longtime Washington Insider, Dies at 98

He was 98.

headline: Facebook After Death

But it is just a grieving mind playing tricks. Jordan died in a car accident on his way back to campus from fall break in 2008, and his mother is still finding bittersweet ways to keep in touch.

headline: Saving Horses, Celebrating Friendship at a Homecoming
text: Their suitcases are packed and are sitting by the door. They sit and watch the Derby on television, then hop into the car for the all-night drive to Kentucky. Her friend watches the Derby from the infield as she has for many years. She grimaces as the track adds more and more corporate suites. In the old days, she could see the entire race. Now, she has to go early to stake out a little piece of ground to watch a few precious seconds of the race. Her friend in the grandstand doesn’t even need binoculars as the race is blotted out by the temporary buildings catering to the corporate crowd who are entertaining their clients in a lush tax write off day.

headline: Art or Advertising?

headline: Off the Menu: Sam Talbot Returns

headline: Is Golf’s New Generation Coming of Age?
text: It is always dangerous to make too much of a young pro’s first Tour victory. Golf is so fickle, anyone can play well for a while. Four good rounds hardly makes a trend.

headline: Fewer People but More Money for Broadway
text: Broadway productions grossed a total of $1.02 billion during the 2009-10 season, which officially ended on Sunday, with premium-price tickets for star-driven shows like “A Steady Rain,” “Hamlet” and “A Little Night Music” increasing box office sales in spite of a 3 percent decline in attendance compared to the 2008-09 season, according to new data from the Broadway League.
