headline: Remembering a Marine, Step by Step
text: COMBAT OUTPOST LILY, Helmand Province— For Marines who have experienced combat together, the many rituals and gestures of bidding farewell to the dead, beginning from the point of medevac and continuing beyond the fallen Marine’s journey to the grave, are observed with a devotion that is at once quiet, fiercely followed and unsummoned. The more formal rituals are matters of tradition, like  memorial services in the field and the escorts who accompany a dead Marine through his or her funeral back home. Some Marines are further memorialized in the names of outposts and landing zones; thus, “Combat Outpost Hanson” and the adjacent “Landing Zone Currier,” named after two Marines from Kilo Company, Third Battalion, Sixth Marines, who were killed several hundred yards from here in fighting against the Taliban in February. Other gestures are impromptu, spontaneous and intensely personal, propelled by feelings that take hold within young infantrymen who fight through ambush after ambush together, and who find, as their tattoos often say, that they are bound by blood and then by a set of memories that will be theirs alone for the decades ahead.

Taking place at the beginning of World War II, the film is a portrait of a middle-class family living in suburban London during the Blitz. headline: Life and Other Cycles | Tim Hawkinson at Blum & Poe
text: Tim Hawkinson likes to tinker. In his first solo exhibition with the Los Angeles gallery Blum & Poe, which opened on Saturday, the artist not only tinkers with scale, moving parts and myriad materials, but also grapples with big life issues like mortality, renewal and the passage of time. The centerpiece of the exhibition is a monumental kinetic sculpture called “Orrery,” a reference to apparatuses that represent the motions and phases of the solar system. A larger-than-life figure of a woman, at once benign and sinister — is she Mother Time, perhaps? — sits at a spinning wheel made of recycled plastic bottles. Everything about the sculpture is circular, interconnected and eternally spinning  — the woman’s ears, fingers and the bun on her head;  the spinning wheel and the circular platform on which she sits. Even the pattern on her dress, a motion illusion designed by a Japanese psychology professor, seems to spin. The effect is hypnotic as both viewer and figure cycle between the material and cosmic worlds.

headline: A Call to Recycle Cigarette Butts

DenDekker’s office recently and suggested he propose a cigarette butt recycling program, Mr. DenDekker admits he “had a little chuckle.” Then a staffer, half joking, suggested a cigarette butt deposit, just as is done with bottles. But before completely dismissing the idea, Mr. DenDekker agreed “to see if there is a market on it.”

headline: Air Berlin to Fly from Miami

But that grandeur is skin deep: the interior is a warren of awkward spaces that do not easily accommodate modern office furniture or encourage casual collaboration among workers. And the men’s and women’s bathrooms are on alternating floors.

text: The best camera, as they say, is the one you have with you. With this in mind — and a very capable Sony DSC-R1 collecting dust in my office because its honking Carl Zeiss lens makes it too bulky to bring anywhere fun — I decided to invest in a new point-and-shoot. I had read great things about the Panasonic Lumix GF1, so requested one to test. The verdict: Truly. Amazing. Camera. Unfortunately, the thing requires some seriously deep pockets, thanks to both a $1,000 sticker price and a sizable (though impressive) detachable Leica lens.

headline: ‘24’ and ‘Law & Order’ Wave Weak Goodbyes
text: For all the attention generated by the cancellations of Fox’s “24” and NBC’s “Law & Order,” the final episodes of these shows were no match in the ratings for Monday’s “Dancing With the Stars.” The conclusion of “24” drew 8.9 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. The last episode of “Law & Order” attracted 7.6 million people. But ABC won the night as the “Dancing” contestants Erin Andrews, Evan Lysacek and Nicole Scherzinger performed their final routines and 19.1 million viewers watched. The season debut of “The Bachelorette” that followed averaged 9.2 million viewers. CBS was second for the night with the finales of its sitcoms “Two and a Half Men” (15.4 million) and “The Big Bang Theory” (14.8 million), followed by “CSI: Miami” at 10 (12.4 million).

headline: Mark Twain Prize Goes To Tina Fey
text: When we last saw Liz Lemon, the hapless, harried television alter ego of Tina Fey, below, she seemed to have found true love at last with an airline pilot who just happened to be played by Matt Damon. Though the romantic entanglements of Liz tend not to last too long, her creator and performer is about to receive an honor that’s a little more enduring. On Tuesday the Kennedy Center announced that it would present its annual Mark Twain Prize for American Humor to Ms. Fey, the “30 Rock” star, “Saturday Night Live” alumna and occasional cribber of punch lines from her daughter, Alice. In the 13-year history of the prize, Ms. Fey will be its third female recipient: it was previously presented to Lily Tomlin in 2003 and Whoopi Goldberg in 2001. In a statement Ms. Fey said: “I am truly thrilled to receive this honor. I assume Betty White was disqualified for steroid use.” Ms. Fey is to receive the award on Nov. 9.

headline: Star-Driven Shows Helped Broadway Sales
text: Broadway productions grossed a total of $1.02 billion during the 2009-10 season, which officially ended on Sunday, with premium-price tickets for star-driven shows like “A Steady Rain,” “Hamlet” and “A Little Night Music” (above, with Catherine Zeta-Jones and Aaron Lazar) increasing box-office sales despite a 3 percent decline in attendance compared with the previous season, according to new data from the Broadway League. The overall gross of $1.02 billion was a slight improvement on the $1 billion gross for 2008-9, although the latter figure did not include box-office sales for the now-shuttered musical “Young Frankenstein.” That show’s producers did not provide weekly grosses to the Broadway League, an industry group of theater owners and producers that collects and publicly releases weekly box-office data. Factoring in “Young Frankenstein,” the 2008-9 season could have grossed up to 1 percent more money than the 2009-10 season, said Charlotte St. Martin, executive director of the Broadway League. Total attendance at Broadway shows during the 2009-10 season was 11.9 million. The season’s financial gains despite audience losses can be explained partly by the success of some plays and musicals that sold a portion of their best seats at a premium, for $300 or more, while other shows struggled to fill seats.

headline: Slipknot Bassist Is Found Dead
text: The police in Iowa said that they would have more information on the death of Paul Gray, below, the bassist and a co-founder of the heavy-metal band Slipknot, after an autopsy on Tuesday, but that foul play was not immediately suspected, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Gray, 38, was found dead on Monday at a hotel in Johnston, Iowa, north of Des Moines. In the early 1990s he helped found Slipknot, the nihilistic if highly theatrical band whose members wear gruesome masks and refer to themselves by numbers and evocative nicknames. (Mr. Gray went by No. 2 or “The Pig.”) The group won a Grammy in 2005 for its song “Before I Forget”; its 2008 album, “All Hope Is Gone,” reached No. 1 on the Billboard sales chart.

headline: U2 and Aguilera Postpone Summer Tours

headline: Cowell’s Exit Complicates ‘Idol’ Outlook

headline: Comedian Not Laughing at Graduate’s Speech
text: The congratulations offered by the comedian Patton Oswalt to Brian Corman, the Columbia University 2010 School of General Studies valedictorian, in a Twitter message on Tuesday were hardly heartfelt. The message linked to an online video showing that Mr. Corman’s valedictory speech had appropriated material from Mr. Oswalt’s stand-up routine. The Twitter message drew an apology from the student and a statement by the university that it was “deeply distressed.” On his Twitter account Mr. Oswalt, right, a star of “The King of Queens” and “Ratatouille,” wrote: “Congrats to Columbia University valedictorian Brian Corman! Great speech.” The tweet included a link to a YouTube video of Mr. Corman’s speech, given on May 16 at the Class Day ceremony for the School of General Studies, in which Mr. Corman shared a story that seemed to come from his firsthand experience about a student who challenged a “Star Trek”-theme question on an exam. Mr. Oswalt has told a similar anecdote in his stand-up routine. In a telephone interview on Tuesday, Mr. Oswalt said that Mr. Corman’s actions reflected a lack of respect for comedians. “In people’s heads they think that comedians can’t possibly make up their own material,” Mr. Oswalt said. “They must get it out of joke books.” In a statement Peter J. Awn, dean of the School of General Studies, said, “The student speaker has appropriately issued an apology to his classmates and to Mr. Oswalt for failing to provide such attribution.”

headline: At Harvard, Kagan Aimed Sights Higher
text: WASHINGTON — One Saturday afternoon in March 2003, Lawrence H. Summers invited Elena Kagan for a private chat in the library of Elmwood, the stately clapboard mansion he occupied as the president of Harvard. The two had been close colleagues, if not close friends, as top aides working for President Bill Clinton. But this was no social call.

headline: City Room: Bloomberg Announces Investment in Tech Start-Up

headline: M.I.A. Takes to the Streets

headline: M.I.A.’s Agitprop Pop
text: On the Grammy Awards in 2009, Maya Arulpragasam, also known as M.I.A., performed her biggest hit, “Paper Planes,” a rap song that infuses rebellious, defiant lyrics with the sounds of her native Sri Lanka, a riff lifted from the Clash, the bang-bang of a gun and the ka-ching of a cash register. Maya, as she is called, was nine months pregnant (to the day), and while she was onstage rapping about “some some some I some I murder, some I some I let go” — in a black skintight, body-stocking dress, transparent except for polka-dot patches that strategically covered her belly, breasts and derrière — she began to experience contractions. As the pain hit, Maya was performing with the male titans of rap (Jay-Z, Kanye West, Lil Wayne, T.I.) and she later told me that she thought all the free-floating testosterone caused her to go into labor. While American rappers today tend to celebrate sex, wealth and status, Maya, who grew up listening to the politicized rhymes of Public Enemy, takes international dance beats and meshes them with the very un-American voice of the militant rebel. In contrast to, say, Bono or John Lennon, with their peacenik messages, Maya taps into her rage at the persecution of Tamils in Sri Lanka to espouse violence: while you’re under the sway of the beat, she’s rapping, “You wanna win a war?/Like P.L.O. I don’t surrender.”

headline: Blending Tradition and Style, in Mexico

text: During the 1890s and for the first two decades of the 20th century, composers in Italy could hardly keep up with the public’s demand for new operas. This was the heyday of the verismo movement, which championed realistic depictions, however sordid, of everyday life.

text: Lean and shapely, with silver-blond hair, her face and body lightly dusted with glitter, the Gallic singer Yvonne Constant is the kind of ageless beauty that the French, who worship women of all ages, venerate without having to apply conditional terms like cougar.

headline: Pergolesi’s Sacred Work (One That He Really Wrote)
text: The first classical music concert in the new Jerome Robbins Theater at the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Monday, concluding an interdisciplinary series held there this month, was also a celebration of the tricentennial of Pergolesi’s birth. The unadorned theater, with subtitles projected onto the back wall, provided a dark, industrial-looking setting for that composer’s  “Stabat Mater.”

headline: The Eternal Return of Mummy Dearest
text: TWICE a month, when she was home in London from boarding school, Polly Stenham would meet her father, Anthony, for a night at the theater. It was their special appointed time together: Mr. Stenham, a prominent businessman, had to balance long workdays with raising the teenage Polly and her younger sister by himself. And he was thrilled, Ms. Stenham said, that she came to share his passion for playwrights like Harold Pinter and Edward Albee, Sarah Kane and Neil LaBute.

headline: Why, It’s Good Old Reliable Nathan
text: I WOULDN’T dare to venture an opinion as to who is the greatest actor to appear on Broadway in the past decade or so. Most accomplished diva? Definitely won’t touch that. But the greatest entertainer? That one is easy: Nathan Lane.

headline: New Poll Finds Spill Anger Growing
text: More than a month after the BP oil spill, most Americans disapprove of the company’s handling of the situation. However, the public’s ire is not limited to BP. A plurality of Americans disapprove of the Obama administration’s handling of the spill, according to the latest CBS News poll.

headline: Found Money

headline: Apps for iPad Cooking
text: AS long as you can avoid slathering it with grease or dusting it (lightly or otherwise) with flour, the iPad beats a mobile phone and a laptop for overall kitchen-counter friendliness, and is poised to be an indispensable tool, once enough of the cookbooks we all love go digital.

headline: Q. and A. With Chris Schlesinger
text: The chef and cookbook author Chris Schlesinger of East Coast Grill in Cambridge, Mass., is answering readers’ questions about grilling. Fire away in the comments section.

headline: Frank Affirms He Wants Strong Derivatives Rules
text: Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, said on Tuesday that he would support strong derivatives regulation as head of the conference committee melding the House and Senate versions of the financial regulatory bill.

headline: The King and Queen of Slow Get Busy
text: Such a drastic dichotomy exists between the experimental choreographer-performers Eiko & Koma onstage and Eiko and Koma in life that sometimes it takes effort to remember that they are the same couple.

headline: Apple Is Said to Face Inquiry About Online Music
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Justice Department is examining Apple’s tactics in the market for digital music, and its staff members have talked to major music labels and Internet music companies, according to several people briefed on the conversations.

headline: What We’re Reading: Impacts
text: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times paused on Tuesday to read and share these articles from other publications:

headline: Next Wave Festival Lineup Is Announced
text: The world premiere of a work by the “Passing Strange” creators Stew and Heidi Rodewald, and the first American performances by Tanztheater Wuppertal-Pina Bausch since Bausch’s death last June, will be among the highlights of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s 2010 Next Wave Festival, the academy said on Tuesday. The music, dance, theater and opera festival will open on Sept. 21 with “Delusion,” a musical work about memory and identity created by Laurie Anderson for the Vancouver Winter Olympics that will make its American debut and run through Oct. 3. Other events include a production of “Vollmond” (“Full Moon”), a dance work performed by the German company Tanztheater Wuppertal-Pina Bausch and choreographed by Bausch, which begins on Sept. 29 and runs through Oct. 9. The program will also feature “Brooklyn Omnibus,” a new song cycle by Stew and Ms. Rodewald that they will perform with their band, the Negro Problem, from Oct. 20 to 23. The complete festival will run through Dec. 19, and will also include a celebration of Louisiana music, called “Red Hot + New Orleans,” with musical direction by Trombone Shorty. More information is at bam.org.

headline: Footnote
text: The Off Broadway production of “Gabriel,” a play about the lives of British and German inhabitants on the German-occupied Channel Islands during World War II, will extend its run for two weeks through June 20, the Atlantic Theater Company announced.

text: Next month the Cleveland Museum of Art will reopen galleries that have been closed for five years.

headline: Germany Is Called ‘Naïve’ on Euro
text: BRUSSELS — The European Commission president, José Manuel Barroso, on Tuesday accused the German government of lacking leadership during the euro crisis and describing its plans to rewrite the European Union’s rulebook as “naïve.”

headline: Whitney Museum Plans New Building Downtown
text: After 25 years of false starts, the board of the Whitney Museum of American Art has taken a step that will redefine the 80-year-old institution. It voted on Tuesday afternoon to begin construction on a building in the meatpacking district in Manhattan, to be completed by 2015, that will vastly increase the size and scope of the museum.

headline: Matthew Richardson Explains the Bank Tax
text: My column this week — on how the House and Senate can improve in financial-regulation bill in coming weeks — returns to the idea of a bank tax. Matthew Richardson, a finance professor at New York University, has done some of the best writing on this issue.

headline: Names of the Dead

text: The Phillies’ first visit to New York this season is bittersweet for Nelson Figueroa, one of the feel-good stories on the Mets in 2008 and 2009.

headline: M.T.A.’s Budget Ills Are Worse Than Accounts of Spitting
text: The train crawled to a stop. Ahead, somewhere in a tunnel below 96th Street on the West Side of Manhattan, a 20-foot section of rail had broken. It was a good moment — actually, a good half-hour — to review the headlines.

headline: Cycling Doping Inquiry May Broaden
text: Federal authorities investigating allegations that Lance Armstrong and other top cyclists engaged in doping are considering whether they can expand the investigation beyond traditional drug distribution charges to include ones involving fraud and conspiracy, according to two people briefed on the investigation.

headline: Don’t Toss That Old Shirt. They’ll Pick It Up.
text: They brought their hand-me-downs in paper bags and shopping carts, in backpacks and even the bottom rack of a wheelchair, dropping them off in hampers at a greenmarket stand on their way to the jams and fresh vegetables.

text: OBAMA HEADS TO GULF President Obama will travel to the Louisiana coast on Friday morning to assess the damage caused by the spill and to monitor the cleanup efforts, the White House announced.

headline: European Nations Take Steps to Pare Deficits
text: PARIS — Fearful of becoming the next Greece, European governments are lining up to demonstrate to investors, who have long helped finance their spending, that an era of austerity has begun.

headline: A Former Bronx Senator Gets 7 Years for Corruption
text: Efrain González Jr., a once-powerful Bronx politician convicted of corruption, was sentenced to seven years in prison on Tuesday by a federal judge who called his story “an American tragedy.”

headline: Summer Means Free Agency for Lakers’ Jackson, Too
text: PHOENIX — The mad swirl of speculation surrounding LeBron James has now ensnared Phil Jackson and the Los Angeles Lakers, albeit indirectly.

headline: Study Finds Supplements Contain Contaminants
text: Nearly all of the herbal dietary supplements tested in a Congressional investigation contained trace amounts of lead and other contaminants, and some supplement sellers made illegal claims that their products can cure cancer and other diseases, investigators found.

headline: Former Exile Holds Power in West African Nation
text: BISSAU, Guinea-Bissau — For months, as the United States Treasury Department prepared to declare him a drug kingpin and a major figure in the international narcotics trade, Rear Adm. José Américo Bubo Na Tchuto was hiding out in the unlikeliest of places — living in the United Nations building here, sleeping on a mattress on the floor of a United Nations office and sometimes eating in the canteen.

headline: Building a Tower of Luxury Apartments in Midtown as Brokers Cross Their Fingers
text: Gary Barnett, one of New York City’s most prolific developers, is about to start construction of a $1.3 billion skyscraper on 57th Street that will overtake Trump World Tower as the tallest residential building in the city.

headline: Punting on Overtime
text: N.F.L. owners tabled a vote on implementing the new overtime rules in the regular season. Commissioner Roger Goodell said the league wanted to see how the new rules — which call for each team to get a possession in overtime unless the team that wins the overtime toss scores a touchdown on the first possession — work during the postseason before considering whether to put them in for the regular season. Owners also wanted to consult further with the players association about the impact the new rules would have on players. They will take up the issue again after the season, even though coaches — who were not in favor of the new rules for the post-season — had hoped to have them put in for the regular season, too.

headline: 2010’s Debates Still Trapped in the 1960s
text: You would not think Richard Blumenthal and Rand Paul would have anything in common, aside from the fact that they are both running for Senate.

headline: The Haunted Household
text: Maintaining a home is an uphill battle. For quite some time Iʼve suspected that little goblins are sabotaging my efforts.

headline: Another Everyday Hero in the Subway, Gone in a Flash
text: The name Wesley Autrey may have slipped from the popular imagination of New Yorkers, the way everyday heroes do. But in the subterranean world of the city’s subways, his spirit may still be subconsciously inspiring.

headline: Europe Pain May Impede U.S. Upturn
text: Only months after most economists forecast that the recession could be viewed safely through the rearview mirror, the European fiscal crisis poses an unsettling new challenge for the United States economy.

headline: Scandal Rattles Politics in South Carolina, Again
text: Virginia may be for lovers, but sultry South Carolina is beginning to earn a reputation as the state for extramarital madness.

headline: Anger Rises as the Oil Keeps Spewing

headline: Bill Puts Scrutiny on Detainees’ Lawyers
text: WASHINGTON — A provision tucked into a defense bill before Congress would direct the Pentagon’s inspector general to investigate any suspected misconduct by lawyers for Guantánamo Bay detainees, opening a new chapter in a recurrent political controversy over legal ethics and the representation of terrorism suspects.

headline: Breath of Fresh Air, Indoors, in Las Vegas
text: One thing that Las Vegas never lacks is scent. Perfumed hallways, the aroma of waffles wafting off the buffet, the certain je ne sais smell of a casino at 2 a.m. — Vegas has it.

headline: Chinese Economy Treads Risky Path. (Ask Japan.)
text: BEIJING — The White House dispatched 200 dignitaries to China’s capital for relationship-cementing talks this week, a number that bespeaks a world order rapidly turning upside down. From China’s threefold economic growth in a decade to today’s swarms of five-star hotels and six-figure autos, it is a cliché to say that the world has never before seen anything like this juggernaut.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Republican Senators’ Lunch With Obama Is Marked by Spirited Confrontations
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s luncheon Tuesday with Senate Republicans was not televised like a similar session earlier this year with the House opposition, but evidently it would have made for captivating theater.

headline: Standing Proudly, in Foam Shoes
text: IN the 1980s, I ate many weighty meals at the SoHo barbecue restaurant Tennessee Mountain with my mother and grandmother, sometimes after shopping, sometimes after visiting my uncle, who lived in a loft a couple of blocks away.

headline: Former Attorney General in Canada Is Cleared in Traffic Death
text: OTTAWA — Citing new evidence, a special prosecutor on Tuesday dropped all charges against Ontario’s former attorney general, Michael Bryant, stemming from a traffic altercation last summer in Toronto in which a bicycle messenger died.

headline: Panel Suggests Signs of Trouble Before Rig Explosion
text: In the hours before the Deepwater Horizon oil rig exploded last month in the Gulf of Mexico, there were strong warning signs that something was terribly wrong with the well, according to a Congressional committee that was briefed on the accident by executives from BP.

headline: Premier’s Party Sweeps Ethiopian Vote
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia —  Ethiopia appeared to solidify its return to a one-party state on Tuesday, as the country’s election board released provisional results showing Prime Minister Meles Zenawi’s governing party winning nearly every seat in Sunday’s parliamentary elections.

headline: Despite Phillies’ Lead, Manager Is Wary of Mets
text: In recent years, games between the Mets and the Philadelphia Phillies have included tension, intrigue and a bit of controversy. Although the teams went in opposite directions last year, removing some of the air from the rivalry, there was still plenty of buzz as the teams opened a three-game series at Citi Field on Tuesday night.

headline: Ex-Principal of Arabic School Won’t Sue City
text: The founding principal of the city’s only Arabic-language public school will not sue the Department of Education, she said Tuesday, despite a ruling from a federal commission that the city discriminated against her by forcing her to resign in 2007.

headline: Peru Frees American Held Since 1995
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — A Peruvian judge on Tuesday ordered the release on parole of Lori Berenson, the New Yorker who has spent more than 14 years in prison on a conviction of collaborating with a Marxist rebel group in a foiled terrorist plot to take the Peruvian Congress hostage.

headline: Modern Phenomenon
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — This is a terrific theme from a new teenage constructor. Anna Shechtman has a bright future if she keeps up this level of creativity. I have an interview with her further down and there’s a photo of her on XWord Info.

headline: Politicized Curriculum in Texas
text: The social conservatives who dominate the Texas State Board of Education backed down last week from a few of their most outrageous efforts to tilt the state’s social studies curriculum. They dropped a proposal that President Obama be referred to as “Barack Hussein Obama” and lost in their efforts to rename the “slave trade” the “Atlantic triangular trade,” a clear attempt to downplay slavery’s horror and spread the blame.

headline: BP’s Ties to Agency Are Long and Complex
text: WASHINGTON — Three years ago, the national laboratory then headed by Steven Chu received the bulk of a $500 million grant from the British oil giant BP to develop alternative energy sources through a new Energy Biosciences Institute.

headline: Heart Tests at Hospital Went Unread
text: Nearly 4,000 tests for heart disease performed over the last three years at Harlem Hospital Center — more than half of all such tests performed — were never read by doctors charged with making a diagnosis, hospital officials acknowledged Tuesday.

headline: Murder Conviction in Trouble Over Prosecutors’ Conduct
text: He was known as a jailhouse lawyer, a high school dropout turned amateur legal adviser who helped other inmates file legal motions and craft appeals while he served a sentence of 34 years to life for a murder he swore he never committed.

headline: French Group Urges New Search of Crash Site
text: PARIS — An association representing families of some of the 228 people who died aboard an Air France jet that crashed in the mid-Atlantic last year urged the French government on Tuesday to conduct a new search for the bulk of the plane after the latest one failed to find any trace of the wreckage.

headline: Slaughter in Les Cayes
text: Even by the grim standards of Haiti, the prison massacre in Les Cayes after the Jan. 12 earthquake is chilling. According to an investigation in The Times by Deborah Sontag and Walt Bogdanich, a dozen or more prisoners were killed and up to 40 were wounded after police stormed the prison to put down a riot.

headline: The Arctic After the Gulf
text: There is an important way for President Obama and Interior Secretary Ken Salazar to show they are absorbing the lessons of the gulf oil spill and to reaffirm their pledge to proceed cautiously with offshore drilling in the future. That is to withhold the permits Shell Oil needs to proceed with a highly controversial drilling project in the Arctic Ocean.

headline: U.S. Is a Top Villain in Pakistan’s Conspiracy Talk
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Americans may think that the failed Times Square bomb was planted by a man named Faisal Shahzad. But the view in the Supreme Court Bar Association here in Pakistan’s capital is that the culprit was an American “think tank.”

headline: Crisis Places Focus on Beleaguered Agency’s Chief
text: WASHINGTON — She is the oil spill’s invisible woman.

headline: Loading Up the Ballot to Succeed Cuomo
text: RYE BROOK, N.Y. — At least one decision will definitely not be left to party insiders at the Democratic State Convention this year: which of five candidates for attorney general will become the party’s favorite.

headline: Yale Patron Held in Scheme That Benefited the University and Its Baseball Team
text: The news release called John D. Mazzuto one of the “greatest supporters” of the Yale University baseball team.

headline: A Stronger Military
text: After months of unnecessary hand-wringing and delay, the White House and Congressional leaders appear to have reached an agreement on ending the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy that forced thousands of gay and lesbian service members to stay in the closet in order to serve their country. Although the agreement would postpone full repeal for a few months to await a Pentagon study on implementing the change, finally it creates a path to the full integration of the military. That is not just a matter of justice. It would make the military stronger.

headline: South Africa: Special Courts Established for World Cup
text: The government will operate 56 special courts to handle offenses associated with the World Cup, the Justice Ministry said Tuesday. The aim of the courts, which will begin hearing cases on Friday and have 93 interpreters to translate the proceedings, is to ensure that cases involving the hundreds of thousands of tourists and soccer players visiting South Africa for the tournament are speedily managed, the ministry said.

headline: Mets’ Bullpen Coach Takes Responsibility for Fracas
text: Two days after Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez and a team coach, Randy Niemann, got into a heated confrontation at Citi Field, peace appeared to return to the team’s clubhouse and bullpen.

headline: An Executive Without Much Privilege
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Open Air a Nice Change, Until It Starts to Rain
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Two things happened to the Yankees at Target Field on Tuesday night that had not occurred during the 28 years they played the Minnesota Twins at the Metrodome.

headline: Zimbabwe: Economy Grows, but Future Is Uncertain
text: After a decade of economic decline and hyperinflation, Zimbabwe’s economy grew about 4 percent last year, consumer prices fell about 8 percent, and bank deposits tripled, the International Monetary Fund reported Tuesday. But the I.M.F. characterized the outlook for this year as “highly uncertain.” President Robert Mugabe’s insistence on some local ownership of companies has slowed foreign investment, while higher wages for civil servants have consumed a growing share of the still limited public spending.

headline: China: Beijing Police Recruit Parents as School Guards
text: The police in Beijing are recruiting parents to help stand guard at schools because of several horrific attacks on schoolchildren in China, according to China Daily, an official English-language newspaper. Seventeen people died and scores of others were injured in five unrelated attacks, which began in late March, with lone men going after children and teachers with knives, tools and gasoline. Parents and teachers have been asked to stand guard for a day in the neighborhoods of Pingguand and Shunyi, local police officials said.

headline: F.C.C. Begins Review of Regulations on Media Ownership
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission said on Tuesday that it would begin soliciting public comments as part of a review and possible revision of its media ownership rules, which set limits on the ownership of multiple television and radio stations and newspapers in a single commercial market.

headline: Hepatitis C Drug Raises Cure Rate in Late Trial
text: An experimental drug for hepatitis C from Vertex Pharmaceuticals sharply increased the cure rate in a clinical trial, while reducing the time needed for treatment.

headline: As Ugly as It Gets
text: I confess that when I first saw the May 17 picture of Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, joining his Brazilian counterpart, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, and the Turkish prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, with raised arms — after their signing of a putative deal to defuse the crisis over Iran’s nuclear weapons program — all I could think of was: Is there anything uglier than watching democrats sell out other democrats to a Holocaust-denying, vote-stealing Iranian thug just to tweak the U.S. and show that they, too, can play at the big power table?

headline: Profit Surges at Medtronic After a Rival Has Trouble
text: Medtronic, the maker of heart rhythm devices, said on Tuesday that its fourth-quarter profit surged eightfold on higher sales of defibrillators after a rival, Boston Scientific, had to withdraw its products from the market.

headline: Corrections
text: EDITORS' NOTE

headline: American Idol: The Top 2
text: In what was perhaps the most underwhelming and anticlimactic “Idol” finale ever, Lee DeWyze and Crystal Bowersox delivered flurries of soft punches, with only Crystal ever leaving a mark. This was her night, by the width of a county or three.

headline: Of Top Hats, Top Kills and Bottom Feeders
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Promoting a Potato Chip Using Many Farmers, and Less Salt
text: IN a campaign for Lay’s that features actual farmers who grow potatoes used to make the chips, the farmers are meant to appear just as they do in life: genuine, simple, plain-spoken, salt of the earth.

headline: Three Things I’ve Learned About Frugal Travel (and the Things I Didn’t Do)
text: Six years ago, I had a regular job, in an office. I was there 9 or 10 hours a day, made a decent living and even found the work occasionally interesting. But I was also bored. More than bored — I was restless. Perhaps like many of you, my readers, I lived for the week or two a year when I could venture out into the world to explore, and in the intervening months at home I’d live vicariously through other people’s tales of adventure.

headline: Tension in Korea Unsettles Markets
text: Investors rarely like wars or rumors of war. But for global markets, the renewed military tension on the Korean peninsula comes at a particularly inopportune time. The threat to this fairly big economy — South Korea’s economy is four times larger than Greece’s — furthers the impression of a world out of control.

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: The Complications of Power, and Life
text: “The Good Wife” ended its first season on Tuesday where it began back in the fall: at a packed and tense news conference. Only this time, it wasn’t the betrayed wife caught in the klieg lights, shocked and terrified. It was the errant politician.

headline: U.S. Players Make Cases for Spot in the World Cup
text: EAST HARTFORD, Conn. — In a game in which individual performances were more important than the collective outcome, a United States team of mostly reserves lost to the Czech Republic, 4-2, on Tuesday night.

headline: Mets and Dickey Shut Down Phillies
text: The Mets have had their share of folk heroes over the years, from Marv Throneberry to Rusty Staub to Todd Pratt. Add R. A. Dickey to the list.

headline: Facing the Fallout From the Galea Case
text: Commissioner Roger Goodell said the N.F.L. is prepared to discipline players who might be revealed to have received human growth hormone in the case of Dr. Anthony Galea. A criminal complaint filed in Buffalo indicates that N.F.L. players have been treated by Galea, and Redskins receiver Santana Moss reportedly arranged to receive treatment by Galea last year.

headline: ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Finale Offers Few Surprises
text: LOS ANGELES — Nicole Scherzinger and Derek Hough were named the winners of the 10th season of “Dancing With the Stars” on Tuesday night, capping the reality show’s highest-rated season of performances.

headline: Gritty Suns Get Off Mat and Tie Series
text: PHOENIX — His jaw rotated and his nostrils flared. He cocked his head one way, then the other. He put his hand to his cheek. His picked at his ear, as if he were trying to brush away gnat, or some other irritant.

headline: A Piano, a Baroness and Thelonious Monk
text: In the 1980s and 1990s, Joel Forrester, a jazz pianist and composer, belonged to the Microscopic Septet. They wrote and played the theme music for the NPR program “Fresh Air With Terry Gross,” which has led some to reckon that it must be the most frequently played jazz recording in history. Mr. Forrester, 63, spoke with Ozier Muhammad for the eighth installment of “Sounds From Uncommon Spaces.” His remarks have been condensed and edited for brevity and clarity.

headline: Photo Replay: May 25
text: A view in the day of sports including the French Open, the World Table Tennis Championships and boxing.

headline: Word of the Day | tessellated
text: tessellated •\ˈte-sə-ˌla-təd\• adjective

headline: Phys Ed: Does Exercise Help You Sleep Better?
text: Most of us think that exercise improves sleep. But it may be that thinking that exercise improves sleep improves sleep. That, at any rate, is the provocative finding of a new study completed recently in Switzerland and published last month in the journal of the American College of Sports Medicine.

headline: Vote Endorses Muslim Center Near Ground Zero
text: After a raucous hearing, a Manhattan community board backed a proposal on Tuesday evening to build a Muslim community center near the World Trade Center.

headline: For the Astros, No Excuses
text: MILWAUKEE – The Brewers’ Ryan Braun got a 96-mile-an-hour fastball, high and down the middle, and he blasted it 447 feet to straightaway center field for a two-run homer. This happened in the first inning Tuesday, against Felipe Paulino, and it pretty much finished the Houston Astros for the night.

headline: Germany Is Called ‘Naïve’ on Euro
text: The European Commission president, José Manuel Barroso, on Tuesday accused the German government of lacking leadership during the euro crisis and describing its plans to rewrite the European Union’s rulebook as “naive.”

headline: Era of Austerity: European Nations Move to Pare Deficits
text: Fearful of becoming the next Greece, European governments are lining up to demonstrate to investors, who have long helped finance their spending, that an era of austerity has begun, Matthew Saltmarsh and Elisabetta Povoledo report in The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | May 26, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Central Banks Need Freedom From Politics, Bernanke Says
text: The Federal Reserve and other central banks must protect their ability to make crucial economic decisions free from political interference, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Suns’ Dragic an Able Substitute for Nash
text: PHOENIX -– Along with a deeper and more energetic bench than the Lakers, the Suns suddenly have a backup point guard who may be allowing Steve Nash to tack on an extra year or two to his career. With the rapid development of Goran Dragic in his second N.B.A. season, the Suns don’t have to merely survive anymore when Nash rests early in the second and fourth quarters.

headline: Four Ways to a Better Finance Bill
text: Democrats say their financial regulation plan will vastly reduce the odds of a future crisis and ensure that taxpayers won’t ever again have to pay for banks’ sins. Skeptics worry — and with good reason — that the White House and Congress are being a little too confident.

headline: Mysteries of Migration
text: WHO is Robert E. Gill Jr. ?

headline: Donald Moss, Illustrator of Sports Art, Dies at 90
text: Donald Moss, a commercial illustrator who captured the action, spectacle and personalities of sports for posters, postage stamps and covers of Sports Illustrated, died on May 18 in Farmington, Conn. He was 90.

headline: Art of Donald Moss
text: Donald Moss captured the action, spectacle and personalities of sports for posters, postage stamps and covers of Sports Illustrated. Mr. Moss working on the downhill site on Whiteface Mountain for the 1980 Olympics.

headline: Michael Kuchwara, A.P. Theater Critic, Dies at 63
text: Michael Kuchwara, who found a worldwide readership in writing about the theater for The Associated Press as both a reporter and a critic for a quarter-century, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 63.

headline: Doubts on European Central Bank Amid Crisis
text: The euro stops with the European Central Bank — or does it?

headline: What Can You Learn From Other Religions?
text: What do you know about other religions? Whom do you know who practices a different faith? What do you think the major religions have in common? What might Christians learn from Jews, or Jews from Muslims, or atheists from believers? In an Op-Ed, the 14th Dalai Lama writes, “Finding common ground among faiths can help us bridge needless divides at a time when unified action is more crucial than ever.” Do you agree?

headline: Russia Takes a Big Step Into Technology
text: A group of Silicon Valley venture capitalists who bet on companies like Skype and Facebook are taking a look at another long-shot proposition — that Russia can diversify its economy away from oil.

headline: U.S. Pledges to Help S. Korea at U.N.
text: SEOUL, South Korea — With political and military tension increasing daily on the Korean Peninsula, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Wednesday that Washington would stand beside Seoul as it sought redress at the United Nations Security Council over what South Korea calls the North’s sinking of a South Korean warship.

headline: Click Laundering
text: A sophisticated form of “click fraud” wherein bogus ad-revenue-generating Web-link “clicks” are disguised to appear as legitimate online enquiries.

headline: Wired Introduces a Rich iPad App
text: Wired has arrived in the tablet age.

headline: Over Drinks With Donors, Obama Recounts Lunch With Republicans
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Hours after President Obama met privately with Senate Republicans at the Capitol on Tuesday, he was here on the West Coast, regaling Democratic donors with his version of the 75-minute luncheon squabble.

headline: Tennis Marketers Remain Quiet in Paris
text: PARIS – For a second year, the international tennis advertising business seems unimpressed with the French Open — at least outside the grounds of Roland Garros.

headline: Losing the Media War in Pakistan
text: The Pakistani media boom is propelling anti-American conspiracy theories, with the Times Square bomb as the latest example. The United States is doing virtually nothing to counter the trend.

headline: Pakistan’s Opinionated Media Landscape
text: Pakistanis have a seemingly insatiable appetite for political news. Since the news media was liberalized under former President Pervez Musharraf, that hunger is being fed like never before.

headline: Europe’s Credit Woes Tied to Market Turmoil
text: Once more, Wall Street is running scared.

headline: Asian Stocks Stage Modest Rally
text: Asian stock markets on Wednesday staged a modest rebound from a broad sell-off the previous day, after Wall Street erased early losses overnight to end just slightly lower, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener reported.

headline: O.E.C.D. Sees Risks to Recovery From Europe and Asia
text: PARIS — Just as economic growth is gathering steam globally, the threat of overheating in parts of Asia and Europe’s budget deficit woes are raising warning signs, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said Wednesday.

headline: F.C.C. Begins Review of Media Ownership Rules
text: The Federal Communications Commission said on Tuesday that it would begin soliciting public comments as part of a review and possible revision of its media ownership rules, which set limits on the ownership of multiple television and radio stations and newspapers in a single commercial market.

headline: NewNet Dials Up Deal for 2 UTStarcom Units
text: UTStarcom said Tuesday it was selling two business units as part of the company’s years-long restructuring.

headline: Market Rout Sees Money Managers Go for Gold
text: Gold is one of the more mysterious assets in the financial markets. It’s volatile at times to the point of inducing vertigo and fans of the precious metal assert, somewhat contradictorily, its prowess as a hedge against both inflation and deflation, Reuters reported.

headline: Apple Said to Face Inquiry About Online Music
text: The Justice Department is examining Apple’s tactics in the market for digital music, and its staff members have talked to major music labels and Internet music companies, The New York Times’s Brad Stone reported, citing several people briefed on the conversations.

headline: Harrah’s Chief Hit With Pay Cut
text: Apollo Global Management and TPG Capital, the two equity firms that own Harrah’s Entertainment, were apparently feeling a little less generous toward the casino operator’s chief executive this year.

headline: Politicking Delays Carried Interest Tax Bill
text: Democrats in Congress are racing against the clock to renew unemployment benefits for hundreds of thousands of jobless Americans in legislation that also raises taxes on executives at private equity firms, hedge funds and other investment partnerships, Reuters reported.

headline: Foster’s Says Beer and Wine Units to Split
text: Foster’s Group said Wednesday that it would split its beer and wine businesses, laying the groundwork for a possible sale of the units and sending the company’s stocks leaping.

headline: Qatar Said to Mull Treasury’s Citi Shares
text: The Qatar Investment Authority, a sovereign wealth fund, has displayed interest in acquiring some of the stake in Citigroup owned by the United States Treasury, The Financial Times said, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Gender Segregation by the Clock
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Affordable Art Fair Comes to Paris
text: The Affordable Art Fair, brainchild of the British artist and impresario Will Ramsey, started in London 10 years ago. Since then, it has gone global and is growing fast, with nine fairs planned this year in locations ranging from New York to Sydney, and new editions in the pipeline for Singapore and Milan. Like its brethren events, the third Paris edition, which runs May 27 to 30 at La Halle Freyssinet, sets out to prove that art doesn’t have to be a pricey pastime.

headline: Fund Plummets from $5 Billion to $500 Million
text: London Diversified Management, the British hedge fund, saw its capital base drop from $5 billion in 2008 to $500 million assets it now oversees, HedgeFund.Net said, citing a Reuters report.

headline: Creditors Concerned Over Rangers’ Bankruptcy
text: A bankruptcy judge said Tuesday that the Texas Rangers can pay employees and conduct other normal business operations so the team won’t ”go hungry,” but he delayed some decisions after a group of creditors led by a New York hedge fund criticized the baseball club’s legal tactics, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Mass. State Fund Chief to Join Hedge Firm
text: The chief of Massachusetts’ $44 billion state pension fund, Michael Travaglini, is leaving his job after six years to join Grosvenor Capital Management, a Chicago-based fund of hedge funds firm, Reuters reported.

headline: McAfee Secures Deal for Trust Digital
text: McAfee, a maker of antivirus software, said Tuesday that it’s buying the mobile security company Trust Digital, The Associated Press reported.

headline: The Midget Sub Threat
text: Today’s idea: The American Navy needs to hone its antisubmarine skills after the torpedoing of a South Korean corvette by a North Korean minisubmarine, an article says. Whether deployed by the Pyongyang regime or Iran, midget subs are a clear threat.

headline: WaMu Shareholders Want to Investigate JPMorgan
text: Shareholders of the bankrupt Washington Mutual asked a federal judge for permission to investigate JPMorgan Chase for its role in the failure of Washington Mutual Bank, Reuters reported, citing court documents filed on Tuesday.

headline: SocGen Chief Defends Dual Role
text: The chief executive of Société Générale, Frédéric Oudéa, defended his role at an annual shareholder meeting Tuesday evening and promised a “rebound” in 2010, as concerns persisted over the French bank’s prospects, Reuters reported.

headline: E.U. Proposes Bank Levy to Pay for Future Crises
text: BRUSSELS — A European Union official proposed Wednesday that member states tax banks to raise money for a fund that would be used specifically to manage future financial crises.

headline: Living With Music: Jason Hartley
text: Jason Hartley is the author of “The Advanced Genius Theory: Are They Out of Their Minds or Ahead of Their Time?”

headline: The Logo Game, Continued
text: Thanks, merci, danke, gracias, tack, asante.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Like a mechanic with a wrench in one hand, the steering wheel in the other, and one foot always on the gas, governments are trying to repair their economies without pulling over or slowing down. The O.E.C.D. thinks they might just manage, lifting its outlook for the next two years. Now if we can just keep that car between the fences.

headline: With Shaky Serve, Venus Williams Wins Second-Round Match
text: PARIS – Few in the women’s game can solve Venus Williams’s serve, especially after Williams figures it out herself. Early in her French Open second-round match against Arantxa Parra Santonja, Williams seemed uncomfortable. And it had nothing to do with the can-can-style, black, lacy dress that has created such a stir.

headline: Ad Spending Turns Up in First Quarter, Tracking Service Says, After Many Quarters of Declines
text: In a tangible sign that perceptions of better times along Madison Avenue may start becoming a reality, a leading ad tracking service reported that advertising spending in major media rose in the first quarter, marking the first gain since the first quarter of 2008.

headline: Giving a Horse a Home and Finding a Sense of Purpose
text: There was a time when the first thing I did when I got to work every day was to look at the previous day’s revenue figures. At 6:30 in the morning.

headline: Results of ‘Top Kill’ Effort Remain Uncertain
text: HOUSTON — Cleanup crews, fishermen and residents along the oil-slicked Gulf Coast waited anxiously on Thursday morning for word on whether BP’s latest effort to plug a gushing underwater oil well had succeeded.

headline: Adviser Warns Pru Investors Off A.I.A. Deal
text: Prudential suffered a  setback in efforts to convince shareholders to back its $35.5 billion takeover of A.I.A., as the international proxy advisory service RiskMetrics advised  its clients to vote against the deal.

headline: Formula One’s U.S. Return to Be in Austin
text: From our colleagues at Formula One blog:

headline: A Rack of Custom E-Cards in Your Phone
text: Since the lamented loss of The New Yorker’s free electronic cards, you may have had a difficult time finding e-cards of the noncloying variety. Now, for $1.99, you can get a rack’s worth on your iPhone.

headline: Sampler: Gold Coast Tax Breaks, and Oakland Teachers Head for Impasse
text: Gold Coast Homes Pay Tenement-Worthy Taxes | The Bay Citizen‘s Web site made its debut Wednesday with an in-depth review of the tax bills on San Francisco’s priciest hilltop, showing that some of the city’s wealthiest people pay among the lowest property taxes. The piece examines the legacy of Proposition 13 three decades later. As Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes, “Usually, the financial burden of owning a large and valuable house includes a hefty property tax bill.” She went on to report, “Indeed, if Gladyne Mitchell had sold her house at 2901 Broadway, the new owners would have faced an annual tax of about $500,000.” The actual property tax bill for the house is $7,722. [The Bay Citizen]

headline: Report Says BofA, Deutsche and Citi Blur Risks
text: Bank of America, Deutsche Bank and Citigroup are three big-name banks active in end-of-quarter “window dressing” — that is, masking risk by temporarily shedding debt before they make their finances public — a recent analysis for The Wall Street Journal shows.

headline: It’s Official: A Fisheries Disaster
text: Commerce Secretary Gary Locke declared the Gulf of Mexico a national fisheries disaster area this week, citing the havoc wrought on the region’s multibillion-dollar fishing industry by the Deepwater Horizon blowout. The fisheries of Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama are covered by the disaster declaration, making them eligible for federal relief funds.

headline: Giles Deacon and Ungaro
text: Ungaro may seem “a poisoned chalice,” as one of my fashion sisters in England called the Paris house, but this is an industry that dauntlessly recovers from bad taste. If my count is accurate, Giles Deacon is now the sixth ready-to-wear designer at Ungaro in the past decade (and I’m not counting the very brief and strange Lindsay Lohan episode). That’s a lot of designers trying to give a modern look to a label known for prints and a zesty femininity.

headline: Q.&A.: Photo-Editing on Linux
text: Q.

headline: As the Oil Flows
text: 3:36 p.m. | Updated There is a long-running soap opera, due to culminate this fall after 54 years, called “As the World Turns.”

headline: A Show Celebrating Classic British Cars in Vancouver
text: The All British Field Meet in Vancouver brought out nearly 700 British cars, from ACs to Wolseleys.

headline: Rochester Mayor to Be Cuomo’s Running Mate
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has picked Mayor Robert J. Duffy of Rochester to be his running mate, the Cuomo campaign announced Tuesday morning.

headline: U.S. Durable Goods Orders Beat Forecast
text: American manufacturers on Wednesday reported a sharp increase in the durable goods orders in April, and analysts noted that businesses were gradually increasing their investments in equipment, an indication that they remained confident about a recovery.

headline: Which Adult Children Can Be Added to a Parent’s Plan?
text: Q.

headline: Charter Schools Scrutinized in Expansion Debate
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: The Early Word: New Offshore Drilling Rules
text: President Obama is planning to announce tougher safety requirements for offshore oil drilling and will most likely call for more rigorous inspections for such operations, administration officials said.

headline: Bret Michaels, Survivor, Tells His Tale to Jay Leno
text: These have been some harrowing days for Bret Michaels, the rock musician and reality television star: since the end of April, he has had an emergency appendectomy, a hemorrhage near his brain, a transient ischemic attack (or mini-stroke) and learned he had a small hole in his heart. But now he’s reveling in his victory on “The Celebrity Apprentice,” and on Tuesday night he vowed to Jay Leno that he would not die on his program.

headline: Party Rules for Birthdays
text: Over at Babycenter.com yesterday, Evonne Lack wrote about her 5-year-old daughter, Anna, who was not invited to a kindergarten classmate’s birthday party. Anna was the only girl, in a class of eight girls, not invited, and it left Evonne hurting for her daughter.

headline: Welcome to the Dollhouse
text: For her show “Too Good to Be True” at the Collette Blanchard Gallery on the Lower East Side, artist Rachel Hovnanian deals with the power and burden of beauty. Her photographs of various beauty queens (literally female trophies tops set in plaster) pose in pristine all-white scenarios— holding a bouquet in front a cabinet of donuts, perched on a bed surrounded by shopping bags from Chanel, Gucci and YSL, and standing in front of a mirror that adds pounds to the waistline.

headline: Reasons To Despair
text: For some reason today’s papers made me feel especially grim about the prospects for economic recovery — not the economic news so much as what one sees about the mindset of policy makers.

headline: Behind the Numbers: How Krumm Beat Safina
text: Kimiko Date Krumm last reached the semifinals at Roland Garros in 1995, when Dinara Safina was 7 years old. In a stunning upset, Krumm came back from a 4-1 deficit in the third set to defeat the talented but erratic Russian, a finalist here a year ago.

headline: Slipknot Gathers to Remember Its Fallen Bassist
text: The surviving members of the heavy metal band Slipknot made a rare appearance Tuesday without their trademark masks to pay tribute to their bassist, Paul Gray, who was found dead Monday at an Iowa hotel.

headline: I, Rabat
text: A note to loyal readers: I’m leaving today for the Group of 30 meeting, which is in Morocco this time. Then I’ll be traveling around various parts of the world. So posting will be erratic for much of the next month, especially during the bike trip.

headline: Speed Read for Wednesday, May 26
text: Highlights from today’s media coverage:

headline: Dow Slides Below 10,000 for First Time Since Feb. 8
text: As quickly as the major indexes zigged, they zagged.

headline: Fallon: ‘Mocking the Oil Company’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: BP wants Twitter to shut down a fake BP account that is mocking the oil company. In response, Twitter wants BP to shut down the oil leak that’s ruining the ocean.

headline: Letterman: ‘Get to the Harbor’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Late Show With David Letterman” on CBS: Ladies and gentlemen, this week is the 25th anniversary of Fleet Week, which is early this year, because the people in the Navy and the Coast Guard all wanted to get to the harbor before the oil slick did.

headline: Nocturnalist | Party On, Gratia Artis
text: Where the patrons are the art, and the art gets spilled upon.

headline: Leno: ‘National Tap Dancing Day’
text: Monologue |  Tuesday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Hey, today is National Tap Dancing Day. Yes, this is the day we honor BP executives trying to explain the gulf oil disaster.

headline: What We’re Reading: Smart Doodling
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Adding Adult Children to a Parent’s Plan
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
