text: Update | Thursday | 8:19 a.m. According to a statement from BP’s press office in London on Thursday:

headline: Two Law Firms Agree to Trans-Atlantic Merger
text: Two big law firms, Sonnenschein Nath & Rosenthal of the United States and Denton Wilde Sapte of Britain, said on Wednesday that they have agreed to merge, creating a giant 1,400-lawyer firm in the latest consolidation in the world of corporate law.

headline: Electronics Maker Promises Review After Suicides
text: SHENZHEN, China — There were bows and an apology from Terry Gou, one of the richest men in Asia and chairman of Foxconn Technology.

headline: Telefonica Steps Up Campaign for Vivo
text: Telefonica, the Spanish telecommunications company bidding for control of Vivo, a Brazilian mobile carrier it runs jointly with Portugal Telecom, said Wednesday that it could not rule out an offer for its Portuguese partner, as it intensifies its campaign to do a deal.

headline: Ex-University President Argues for Three-Year Degrees
text: 12:35 p.m. | Updated See below, for answers to some follow-up questions from The Choice about the challenges President Emeritus Trachtenberg faced while trying to secure a three-year degree program while he was leading G.W.

headline: Jamaican Forces Hunt Target of Raid
text: KINGSTON, Jamaica — Near the shuttered shops of downtown Kingston, draped with fallen electricity lines and prowled by armies of stray dogs, soldiers emerged from the shadows on Wednesday to warn off visitors, politely at first, then forcefully and finally with bursts of gunfire.

headline: Sosa Won’t Be Pursued on Perjury Charges
text: The Congressional committee that Sammy Sosa testified before in March 2005, when he said he never used performance-enhancing drugs, has decided not to ask the Department of Justice to investigate him on perjury charges.

headline: Fugitive Ex-Leader Denies Financing Thai Protests
text: BANGKOK — One day after being charged with terrorism, Thailand’s fugitive former prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, said in a telephone interview on Wednesday that he did not finance or organize the red-shirt movement that had staged a two-month sit-in here.

headline: Judge Totally Rules on System of a Down Song
text: If you have a case pending in federal court in Manhattan that involves complicated issues of musical authorship, or you just want to hang out and listen to some cool tunes, Judge Robert W. Sweet is apparently the magistrate you want to draw.

headline: Ristretto | Hacienda La Esmeralda
text: In Ristretto, Oliver Strand, the curator of the Times Topics coffee page, explores the world of coffee gadgets, coffee beans and why it’s never been easier to get a perfect shot of espresso.

headline: Short Playoff Series and the Salary Cap
text: David Stern, the commissioner of the N.B.A., projected last month that the league’s 2010-11 salary cap would be about $56.1 million when figures were released in early July, but he admitted they “might have to hustle to get it.”

headline: Treasury Names Director to Ally Financial
text: The Treasury Department said on Wednesday that it has appointed Marjorie Magner, a former Citigroup executive, as one of its two representatives on the board of Ally Financial, the bank formerly known as GMAC Financial Services.

headline: New Role for Ellen: A Music Mogul
text: A month after David Letterman said he had started a record company, Ellen DeGeneres has followed him with an announcement that she has created her own label.

headline: Judge Names Morgenthau to Monitor Fire Dept.’s Minority Hiring
text: Frustrated by what he has characterized as continued obstructionism by the Bloomberg administration, a federal judge on Wednesday appointed Robert M. Morgenthau as a special master to oversee the city’s adoption of practices aimed at increasing the number of black and Hispanic firefighters.

headline: The Morning Line: Stately Victor Sharp for Belmont
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School. He also serves as a member of the board of the New York Racing Association.

headline: Janice Min Joins Hollywood Reporter
text: 11:40 A.M. Updated with more detail.3:10 P.M. Updated with comment from Ms. Min and Mr. Beckman.In a surprising move, Janice Min, the well-respected editor of Us Weekly for several years, has joined the trade publication Hollywood Reporter as editorial director.

headline: A 3D Peek at the Future of Ground Zero
text: The 9/11 memorial and museum released a 3D Google Earth rendering of plans for the entire ground zero site.

headline: Raindrops Dampen Upset Chances, So Far
text: It appeared the forecasters might get it wrong with their predictions of rain during the second round of the French Open at Roland Garros. There were little more than threatening clouds and cool breezes when Venus Williams beat Spain’s Arantxa Parra Santonja, 6-2, 6-4, in the day’s first match at Court Philippe Chatrier. And men’s No. 5 Robin Soderling, looking fit for another a second-consecutive surge toward the finals, needed only 71 minutes to beat American Taylor Dent, 6-0, 6-1, 6-1.

headline: After 596 Saves, Hoffman Works to Reclaim His Closer’s Role
text: MILWAUKEE — At quarter to 3 on Tuesday, more than four hours before game time, Trevor Hoffman emerged from a loading dock underneath Miller Park and bolted into the sunshine. He wore mesh shorts, sunglasses and no shirt, and after a 15-minute jog he was back inside, tossing a football — left-handed — with teammates on the field. Then he ran a few pass patterns.

headline: The Forecast: Whining About Weather at Super Bowl
text: You know you’re having a weird day in sports when Accuweather.com is weighing in on the biggest news, with a forecast for something that won’t happen for four years. At least it didn’t station a reporter in East Rutherford, N.J., on Tuesday wearing a parka. That we know of.

headline: Indy 500 Drivers Stop Traffic in Manhattan
text: During the lunch-hour rush in Herald Square on Tuesday, hundreds of New Yorkers passed in front of Macy’s, unfazed by the 33 silver Honda Accord Crosstours parked between 34th and 35th Streets, or even taking notice of several men, and two women, wearing racing suits.

headline: Netanyahu to Visit Obama
text: President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will try a make-up session next week, when Mr. Netanyahu visits the White House, per an invitation hand-delivered to the Israeli leader by a White House envoy.

headline: Mikhail Shatrov, Outspoken Soviet Playwright, Dies at 78
text: Mikhail Shatrov, whose historical plays subjected Stalin and his legacy to withering scrutiny and signaled a new era of artistic freedom under Mikhail Gorbachev, died on Sunday at his home in Moscow. He was 78.

headline: ‘The Poo Pond’
text: Visiting a city like Kandahar in southern Afghanistan, the subject of human excrement is not something that ordinarily occupies much of your thinking. After all, unlike much of the rest of the country, Kandahar has toilets, even if most of them are just holes in the floor made of porcelain. As a pedestrian, the only issue that would probably prompt any thinking on this subject are the sewers that line Kandahar’s dusty streets; they are the open-air type. You’ve got to take care to avoid them, or you’ll fall in.

headline: MoMA Names New Curator for Media and Performance
text: The Museum of Modern Art has named Sabine Breitwieser, the founding director of the Generali Foundation contemporary art museum in Vienna, as the new chief curator of its department of media and performance. The department was created in 2006 as the department of media; its name was changed in 2009 to reflect an increased commitment to exhibiting and acquiring performance art. Ms. Breitwieser succeeds Klaus Biesenbach, who organized the current Marina Abramovic retrospective and is now the director of MoMA P.S. 1 in Queens.

headline: Jamaicans Report, and Explain, Their Crisis
text: The Gleaner, a newspaper in Kingston, Jamaica, reports, “No fewer than 44 Jamaicans have been killed in the clashes between security forces and gunmen in west Kingston,” according to the city’s public defender. The official, Earl Witter, spoke to reporters late on Tuesday after he visited the city’s Tivoli Gardens neighborhood, “to conduct an independent assessment of the operations being carried out by the security forces,” who have been battling those defending Christopher Coke, the leader of the city’s notorious Shower Posse gang.

headline: A New Way to Shop for TV Service
text: The bill comparison site BillShrink released a new beta service on Wednesday aimed at  helping consumers compare the costs of television services that best fit their needs.

headline: Perella Sounds Off on Taxes
text: Joseph R. Perella, the veteran investment banker and founder of Perella Weinberg Partners, believes that ordinary Americans should “suck it up” and prepare to pay higher taxes — but also warned that raising taxes on investors would be dangerous.

headline: Rossi Makes Senate Bid for Murray Seat
text: As expected, Dino Rossi has jumped into the Senate race in Washington State.

headline: Of Spreadsheets, Hipster Lawsuits and Ivanka Trump
text: In the modern American technocracy, he who wields the spreadsheet is king.

headline: ‘Glee': Gaga, Oh Mama
text: Here’s a quick pop quiz inspired by Tuesday night’s Lady Gaga-themed (and, to a lesser extent, Kiss-themed) episode of “Glee.” Suppose you are a young woman who is musically talented and theatrically inclined, and who is reunited with her no-less-gifted birth mother, but must keep the truth of this relationship a secret from others. What song do the two of you sing together to establish this idea?

headline: Students at $100 a Head?
text: Updated 3:12 p.m. | See comments from Education Department below.

headline: Higher Threshold Urged  for Rent Destabilization
text: Gov. David A. Paterson today released a package of proposed changes to New York rent laws today, including a measure that would make it harder for landlords to remove apartments from rent stabilization.

headline: 2 Arrested in Insider-Trading Case at Disney
text: 8:57 p.m. | Updated The New York Times’s Brooks Barnes has more on the Disney insider trading scheme.

headline: Now Showing | Art on the Go
text: Think of one of the greatest branding campaigns in the 20th century, and London’s subway system probably doesn’t spring to mind.  In that case, you’ll be pleasantly surprised by “Art for All: British Posters for Transport,” which opens on Thursday at the Yale Center for British Art. The exhibition, which includes more than 100 posters that were designed — mostly between the world wars — for the London Underground (and, to a lesser extent, British railways), illustrates the degree to which the Underground, led by the enlightened Frank Pick, captured public goodwill, helped forge a civic identity for the city, and became a patron of modern artists.

headline: Street Theater
text: Photos of “Night Lights,” a site-specific work that took place on a Soho street.

headline: Concert Manager at Metropolitan Museum to Step Down
text: Hilde Limondjian is stepping down as the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s music impresario, the Met said, ending a 41-year run that turned the Met’s concert series into a New York fixture. Under her direction as general manager of concerts and lectures the Met program helped inaugurate major careers, brought back prominent performers on a regular basis and popularized now-common ideas like concerts with themes and commentary. She established lengthy residences for the Beaux Arts Trio and Guarneri String Quartet (now replaced by the Pacifica Quartet) and brought in a young Yo-Yo Ma, Martha Argerich and Cecilia Bartoli, as well as the Emerson String Quartet and Orpheus Chamber Orchestra. The Met said Ms. Limondjian would depart June 30 and had already planned next season. The search for a successor is on, it said.

headline: Disaster Planning for Pets
text: When my neighborhood was evacuated because of Delaware River flooding a few years ago, I had less than 24 hours to prepare. I packed a suitcase and grabbed important documents — but then I suddenly realized that I didn’t have a plan for my pets.

headline: Clip: 'Sex and the City 2'
text: A scene from "Sex and the City 2."

headline: On Our Radar: Talk of ‘Shortcuts’ on the Rig
text: A Transocean employee tells Coast Guard investigators that BP took “shortcuts” that may have contributed to the well blowout.

headline: Trial Marks Change at Prison for Afghan Detainees
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The new American-run prison outside the capital will hold its first trial of an Afghan detainee next week, American officers said Wednesday.

headline: Overcoming the Stigma of Herpes
text: Genital herpes may be the largest epidemic no one wants to talk about. An estimated one out of five Americans over the age of 12 quietly harbor a meek but distressing virus that can cause painful and ugly outbreaks on areas that seldom see the light of day.

headline: Wal-Mart Cuts the iPhone Price to $97
text: Wal-Mart must be serious about those price rollbacks, and not just on produce. Starting on Tuesday, a 16 GB iPhone costs $97 with a two-year AT&T contract or qualified upgrade at more than 1,800 Wal-Mart stores.

headline: Understanding Genital Herpes
text: Dr. Peter A. Leone is an associate professor at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine and Public Health. He also directs the H.I.V./sexually transmitted disease prevention program for the state of North Carolina and serves on the National Coalition of STD Directors, a group of public health officials who promote awareness of sexually transmitted diseases.

headline: Yahoo Heads to FarmVille
text: It’s investor day at Yahoo, so the Web portal is talking to Wall Street analysts, sharing company strategy and unveiling a bit of news: it just signed a partnership with the fast-growing gaming start-up Zynga to bring Zynga’s popular social games to its site. That means Yahoo’s 600 million users will soon be able to access and and play Zynga games like FarmVille and Mafia Wars on Yahoo properties like Yahoo.com, Yahoo Mail and Yahoo Games – that is, if they are not already playing those games on Facebook.

headline: Stage Scenes: Nathan Lane
text: Photos of some of the actor’s performances on and off Broadway.

headline: What to Ask About Herpes
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: TimesCast | May 26, 2010
text: Today, BP reviews plans for a top kill procedure to stem the Gulf oil spill, Facebook reverses changes to default privacy settings and Pakistan grows more paranoid over U.S. intentions.

headline: Selected Studies: Genital Herpes
text: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: It Rains, It Pours
text: By virtue of his standing as the best men’s player in the game, and maybe in history, and his typically thoughtful analysis when questioned by reporters, Roger Federer has become a sort of conscience for tennis. On Wednesday, after winning in twice-delayed straight sets over Alejandro Falla, Federer was asked about the possibility of the French Open moving somewhere else, perhaps to the suburbs of Paris, to find room to expand. (Federer would love to see it stay where it is, in southwest Paris, because he would “love to come back in 20 years, 40 years time.)

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: 5 Things to Know About Herpes
text: This week in The Times Health Guide, New York Times contributor Eric Sabo writes about genital herpes, “the largest epidemic no one wants to talk about.” Genital herpes spreads so easily because many people don’t realize they have an infection and typical safe sex practices, like wearing condoms, do not completely prevent spread of the virus. Here are five things experts say you should know about protecting yourself against herpes.

headline: Answers About Child Psychiatry
text: Following is the first set of responses from Dr. Harold Koplewicz, a child and adolescent psychiatrist and president of the Child Study Center Foundation. This week he is responding to readers’ questions about the myths and stigma surrounding psychiatric disorders of children and adolescents.

headline: The Eyes Have It | Sex and the City Shades
text: Carrie Bradshaw and co. have spawned many contentious fashion trends over the years, including Uggs (ugh!). But the bold, gold mirrored aviators that SJP sports in Sex and the City 2 are pure eye candy. A collaboration between the Belgian fashion designer Bernhard Willhelm and the Berlin-based eyewear company MYKITA, the light, sleek, stainless frames were inspired by the Alpine ski racer Franz Klammer’s downhill heroics during the 1976 Winter Olympics. They’re $525 at Bergdorf Goodman, Barneys New York and patriciafield.com.

headline: L.I. Man Gets 25-Year Term in Killing of Immigrant
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. —  The white Long Island teenager convicted of killing a Hispanic immigrant in a 2008 hate crime attack in Patchogue was sentenced on Wednesday to 25 years in prison in a hearing that ended with the teenager’s father leaving the courtroom in a tearful rage.

headline: Travel Deals: Early Bird Special in Breckenridge, Colo.
text: On June 1, One Ski Hill Place, a RockResort property, will open at the base of Breckenridge Ski Resort’s Peak 8, in Breckenridge, Colo. To mark the opening, the hotel is offering introductory rates starting at $75 a person, each night. Book by June 1 for stays through June 30.

headline: Operation Desert Togs
text: The first “Sex and The City” movie, which came out two years ago, qualifies as a comedy both because it is somewhat funny and because, according to a more classical definition, it ends, after some reversals and delays, with a wedding. The sequel  which should have borrowed a subtitle from another picture opening this week and called itself “Sex and the City: The Sands of Time”  begins with a wedding and never seems to end. Your watch will tell you that a shade less than two and a half hours have elapsed, but you may be shocked at just how much older you feel when the whole thing is over.

headline: Live Blogging Facebook’s Privacy Announcement
text: When Facebook added a range of new features at its developer conference last month, it came under a barrage of fire from users and the news media over its confusing privacy policy and how it was sharing users’ information on the Web. One point of concern in particular has been the site’s complex privacy settings.

headline: Mahindra to Buy Stake in Electric Car Company
text: MUMBAI, India — One of India’s largest automakers, Mahindra & Mahindra, said Wednesday that it would acquire a controlling stake in Reva, an electric car maker in Bangalore, that has been looking for partners to invest in its technology.

headline: Tastings With Craft Beers
text: YOU could be forgiven a bit of indecision when ordering a drink at Beer Revolution in Oakland, Calif. While its coolers glisten with bottles of the world’s choice beers, the bar offers a list of exquisite and rare brews that changes daily  it could take an enthusiast months (or a visit to a potentially far-flung brewery) to catch some of them again.

headline: The Lost Decade
text: Walter Russell Mead, who’s recently emerged as one of the finest long-form bloggers (no, that’s not a contradiction in terms), has a post on the top ten lessons of the global economic meltdown. His choices are all interesting, but I wanted to focus on lesson number eight, which is that the demographic crunch has officially arrived:

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Sex and the City 2'
text: The director Michael Patrick King discusses a scene from "Sex and the City 2."

headline: The Link Between Frugality and Health
text: Here’s an unlikely effect of recession: It may actually be helping some Americans improve their health.

headline: New York Harbor, 6:05 A.M.
text: Sailors and Marines aboard the assault ship Iwo Jima prepare to man the rails as the ship makes its way up the Hudson River during the 23rd annual Fleet Week parade of ships.

headline: ‘Glee’ Tops the Chart Again
text: “Glee” rules. This week the show is pretty much everywhere, with a sold-out concert tour coming to Radio City Music Hall and news that Fox, its network, has ordered  a third season. Now the show has reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for the second time in a month.

headline: Straw Stirs The Mets’ Drink
text: Whether or not Jeff Francoeur and Jason Bay were upset that Darryl Strawberry gave the team a pep talk in Washington is up for debate. A radio report said they were, but Francoeur denied he was miffed at Strawberry’s direct talk and said none of his teammates were, either.

headline: Tennis Fashion: An Oxymoron
text: Tennis outfits have fueled debate in men’s and women’s tennis.

headline: Apt. 168, Inc.
text: Yuki Mark Lim, the president and founder of Apt. 168, Inc. describes how his he saved his company after his clients stopped calling.

headline: Expecting to See Term Limits on the Ballot
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will not be on the ballot in 2010, but the issue that many New Yorkers lambasted him over in the 2009 election very likely will be: term limits.

headline: Iran and Russia Exchange Acerbic Barbs on Sanctions
text: MOSCOW — Russia and Iran publicly traded barbs on Wednesday, showing strains in their longstanding alliance because of Moscow’s support for a new set of American-backed sanctions over the Iranian nuclear program.

headline: In Tennis, Fashion Police Look the Other Way
text: PARIS — Venus Williams’s serves have long been a big focus of her every match, but never more so than now.

headline: Invoking the Oil Crisis, Obama Lauds Clean Energy
text: In another visit intended to showcase a recipient of economic stimulus dollars, President Obama toured a solar panel plant on Wednesday in Fremont, Calif. He took the opportunity to contrast the potential of clean energy with the environmental perils of fossil fuels, reflected in what he called a “heartbreaking” oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Thanks, Africa
text: Mitch Smith is a 19-year-old journalism student at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the winner of the 2010 Win-A-Trip with Nick contest. Earlier this month, he and Nick traveled through Africa, with stops in Gabon, Republic of the Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo and South Africa. This is Mitch’s final post about the experience.

headline: A Lot of Runs for the Yankees, but Not a Lot of Pie
text: By this time last season, the Yankees had one fewer victory than they have this season but were covered in a lot more cream.

headline: Museum Quality | Florida Tropicale
text: Fort Lauderdale, Fla., may not be the first place one expects to find some of the most avant-garde early-20th-century art, design and architecture. But there it is, hidden behind a cluster of pedestrian high-rises, in the Bonnet House, an astonishing — albeit bizarre — museum and gardens created by two great visionary collectors of the last century.

headline: Apple Passes Microsoft as No. 1 in Tech
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Wall Street has called the end of an era and the beginning of the next one: The most important technology product no longer sits on your desk but rather fits in your hand.

headline: Oil Rigs and Reality
text: Gail Collins: David, just this once can we not talk about politics? What did you think of the “Lost” finale? Personally, I’m a sucker for series that end with a complete repudiation of everything that’s gone before — like the one for “St. Elsewhere” where everything turned out to be an autistic child’s fantasies of life inside a snow globe. Or the one for Bob Newhart’s second series, in which everything turned out to be a nightmare, dreamed up by the hero of Bob Newhart’s first series.

headline: Here’s to the Ladies Who Lunch: A. O. Scott Reviews ‘Sex and the City 2’
text: It’s here! The moment you’ve awaited for the two years (and 145 minutes) since you saw the original “Sex and the City” movie: not only the release of “Sex and the City 2,” but also A.O. Scott’s review of “Sex and the City 2.”

headline: Sony Showcases New Rollable, Flexible Screen
text: Imagine carrying around a tiny screen that can act as a cellphone or movie display and when it’s not in use, you can roll it up to the size of a pencil and slip it into your pocket or behind your ear?

headline: Stylish Hotel to Open Spa in Heart of Jerusalem
text: The Mamilla Hotel, a chic hotel less than a mile from Jerusalem’s Old City which opened last summer, has gotten plenty of buzz, including being listed on Condé Nast Traveler’s Hot List for 2010.  It will be adding a new wellness spa, Akasha, this August.

headline: Reach Customers in 140 Characters, All of Them Free
text: Does Twitter still leave you scratching your head?

headline: Elongating the Skirt
text: Women are turning away from the frivolity of thigh-high hems.

headline: At the Whitney in the Wee Small Hours of the Morning
text: You can call New York the city that never sleeps, but the fact is, its institutions can seem pretty drowsy. Not so the Whitney Museum of American Art, which through 11:59 p.m. on Friday will be open 24 hours a day on a late night pay what you will basis, an experiment in conceptual art, artistic appetite and staffing.

headline: A Long, Lean Backlash to the Mini
text: JEAN RHYS knew a thing or two about style and, in particular, about the hauteur conveyed by the sweep of a hem. In her novel “Wide Sargasso Sea,” a Goth-tinged prequel to “Jane Eyre,” Christophine, a servant, lets the tail of her skirt fan out behind her — a gesture of breeding, the reader is told. Hitching up one’s hem, on the other hand, sends quite a different message. When your man is abusive, Christophine advises her young Creole mistress, just “pick up your skirt and walk out.”

headline: Kernels of Wisdom: Investigating Natural Variation in Corn
text: Overview | Where did corn, or maize, originate, and how did its cultivation contribute to civilization? Why do botanists and agronomists continue to study and selectively breed corn today? How is variation important in this process? In this lesson, students use prior knowledge to tout corn in a 30-second commercial spot. Then, using observation skills, they investigate variations in different types of corn and develop an understanding of the role natural variation plays in its selective breeding. Finally, they apply their knowledge to explain how artificial selection works and to execute a concluding project.

headline: Don’t Swing That Arm, Mr. Nadal
text: IF you are the maker of a little-known collection of watches hoping to increase your brand profile, you would be lucky to know Rafael Nadal.

headline: In California, Obama Tours Solar Panel Plant
text: In another visit intended to showcase a recipient of economic stimulus dollars, President Obama toured a state-of-the-art solar panel plant on Wednesday in Fremont, Calif. He took the opportunity to contrast the potential of clean energy with the environmental perils of fossil fuel, reflected in what he called the “heartbreaking” oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Read more at our sib-blog, Green.

headline: How I Saved My Company
text: The New York Times is inviting small-business owners to submit videos about what its like to own a company that struggles but survives. Go to nytimes.com/boss for details on how to participate.

headline: Alice Ripley to Leave ‘Next to Normal’ on Broadway
text: Alice Ripley will give her final performance as the mentally ill mother Diana Goodman in the Broadway musical “Next to Normal” on July 18, in the role that won her the 2009 Tony Award for best actress in a musical, the producers announced on Wednesday. Ms. Ripley will then return to lead the show’s 36-week North American tour starting Nov. 23 with a six-week run at the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles.

headline: Final Cuts for U.S. World Cup Roster
text: The emerging forwards Edson Buddle and Herculez Gomez, once considered long shots, were named to the United States’ World Cup team Wednesday, while the veteran striker Brian Ching did not make the final 23-man roster.

headline: Commander Cites Progress and Frustration in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — The commander in charge of southern Afghanistan acknowledged on Wednesday that “we are not yet where we need to be’’ in the farming zone of Marja, the site of a major offensive in February that sought to flush out the Taliban. The commander, Maj. Gen. Nick Carter, also said that a more complex military operation was on schedule to begin in the city of Kandahar in June.

headline: Crocs
text: 143 Spring Street (Wooster Street); (212) 219-4046.

headline: New Designer at Hermès
text: Hot news from Paris: After seven years, Jean Paul Gaultier is giving up his ready-to-wear duties at Hermès and will be replaced by Christophe Lemaire, who has been designing for Lacoste since 2000. Mr. Gaultier’s move was expected, but the replacement was something of a surprise, since Mr. Lemaire has always flown a bit under the radar and doesn’t show his own collection on the runway.

headline: Facebook Bows to Pressure Over Privacy
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Ever since Facebook was founded in 2004, Mark Zuckerberg, its chief executive, has pushed its users to share more information about themselves. Time and again, users have pushed back, complaining that some new feature or setting on the site violated their privacy.

headline: 11 Companies to Follow on Twitter
text: We’ve just published a small-business guide to using Twitter that was written by Kermit Pattison. Below, Mr. Pattison offers 11 examples of businesses (they’re not all small businesses) that make smart use of the micro-blogging service. You can check out the Twitter feeds individually, or you can see them compiled in one list.

headline: Scouting Report
text: SALES

headline: At J. Crew’s Bridal Store, a Parisian Air
text: ALWAYS a wedding guest? Then the new J. Crew Bridal store has you covered, along with the wedding party and, oh, the bride. The first floor of the boutique, which opens May 27, has cocktail dresses from the 769 Collection that are exclusive to the store (the one at left is $795) and jewelry pieces like Lulu Frost mesh necklaces with vintage pins and brooches attached (below, $695). There are also collaborations with Bobbi Brown cosmetics, Cosabella lingerie and a key necessity, Spanx.

headline: Live From the Ira Sohn 2010 Conference
text: 8:29 p.m. | Updated Unlike previous years, this year’s Ira Sohn Investment Research Conference didn’t have any blockbuster revelations — certainly nothing on the order of David Einhorn’s bet against Lehman Brothers or William A. Ackman’s assault on MBIA, the bond insurer.

headline: ‘Millions’ of Frogs Force Closure of Highway in Greece
text: As if the political and economic tumult wasn’t enough to rattle the people of Greece, little frogs — “millions,’ according to the police chief of Thessaloniki, Giorgos Thanoglou — closed one of the country’s major highways for more than two hours on Wednesday, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Shop Till You’re Thirsty
text: “DRINK. Shop. Play,” said the fashion designer Bob Bland, the proprietor of the Kingdom, as she showed a visitor around the combination bar and clothes store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. She pointed out the Skee-Ball and foosball tables in a back alcove.

headline: Putting It Together | Babs on Design
text: As a rule, we avoid the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center like Chinese buffet. But for Barbra Joan Streisand, we made an exception. On Tuesday evening, Babs was on 11th Avenue to unveil her coming book, “My Passion for Design,” which is to be published by Viking in November. Passion? You could call it that, though Streisand’s relationship with design sounds more like an obsession. “When something is off its mark, it disturbs me viscerally,” she told a packed audience of publishing types gathered for BookExpo. “It’s not a good thing.”

headline: It’s Good to Have Best Sellers
text: FOUR QUESTIONS FOR WENDY MULLIN OF BUILT BY WENDY:

headline: Making a Mess off Broadway
text: Patrick Healy recently wrote about how the chic, immense and expensive-looking sets of several new productions, mostly on Broadway, have generated real estate envy among some theatergoers. (In this video, the designer Santo Loquasto talks about his “intellectual bohemian” look for the play “Collected Stories.”)

headline: Pick a Pocket, Any Pocket
text: RACHEL COMEY’S Utility Clutch is aptly named: it has pockets galore for everything a gal may need, plus a removable long leather strap that converts it to a shoulder bag.

headline: Judiciary Republicans Call for Special Prosecutor
text: All seven Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee joined together on Wednesday to request appointment of a special prosecutor to look into Representative Joe Sestak’s claim that the White House offered him a job to drop out of the Senate Democratic primary race in Pennsylvania.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. “Sex and the City 2”: Vintage Dior + a camel = a dry-cleaner’s nightmare.

headline: A Dermatologist to the Stars Calls on Them to Heal Haiti
text: WHEN Dr. David Colbert, a former emergency room doctor, went to Haiti to help treat the injured after the earthquake in January, the most potent medical tool in his duffel bag was arguably not the surgical scissors, gauze, rubber gloves or antibiotics. It was his BlackBerry.

headline: Poverty Through the Decades
text: That chart, which shows the percentage of Americans of various ages living in poverty, is adapted from a report released recently by the Congressional Research Service.

headline: A Handful of One-Acts, Some Packing a Punch
text: Ensemble Studio Theater’s annual one-act festivals are nerve-racking affairs: you know that the bill, always laden with pretty good stuff, is going to have one thing on it that really jolts you.

headline: Brooklyn College Blocked From Paving Garden
text: Updated, 4:46 p.m. | Paradise is safe from paving, for now.

headline: Climate Watchdog Denies ‘Hippie Agenda’
text: The precarious state of the economy has come to dominate the way European governments make decisions. That means tougher times – and a good deal of frustration – for policymakers whose job is to advocate potentially costly action aimed at tackling climate change.

headline: Woods’s Return Portends a Memorable Summer
text: So, the neck pain that forced Tiger Woods to withdraw in the middle of the second round of the Players Championship in May has apparently abated, and he has committed to play at the Memorial Tournament next week. This is great news, not just for Jack Nicklaus’s tournament but for the United States Open two weeks thereafter at Pebble Beach and for the game of golf for the remainder of the year.

headline: 'Lady of the Camellias'
text: American Ballet Theater performed John Neumeier’s 1979 ballet on Tuesday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House.

headline: Reader Tips for Getting Back Items Left on Planes
text: My recent post, “The Hassles of Getting Back Items Left on Planes,” about how hard it is to get back items left on planes, got a lot of reader comments.

headline: Tweaking a Camera to Suit a Hobby
text: When he is not fighting fires in Waterloo, Iowa, Pete Lilja likes to rig his camera to a weather balloon and send it up to record the world.

headline: Fink Worries About Europe, but Sees Euro Surviving
text: Laurence D. Fink, the chairman and chief executive of BlackRock, minced no words about the European sovereign debt crisis, saying on Wednesday that he was “frightened” and was avoiding investing in the debt of southern Europe.

headline: An Improvised Shrimp and Ginger Dinner
text: If you’re trying to buy as much of your food as possible from producers you can look in the eye, the last couple of evenings before the next market day can present supply problems. My wife, Jackie, and I often have two farmers’ market days: Wednesday near where we live and Saturday at Union Square. But on a recent weekend we were induced to get on a bus and travel beyond the city limits (I saw a big turtle!), and so missed one of our shopping days. By Tuesday the vegetable bins of our refrigerator were in a sad state of depletion.

headline: Developer Said to Seek Relocation of an Arena
text: The developer Steven Roth is quietly trying to revive a plan to move Madison Square Garden one block west of its current home atop Pennsylvania Station just as the arena is beginning a major $850 million renovation.

headline: Affable Thugs, Playful Crimes, Rough Justice
text: How many characters from a Thomas Perry book would it take to screw in a light bulb? A lot — because one would steal the bulb as a creative challenge, and the others would keep bumping into one another in interesting but futile attempts to find it. All of them would work at cross-purposes. And the light bulb would never get screwed in. After a long, roundabout journey it would wind up in the hands of whichever flawed character most deserved it. Mr. Perry always manages to mete out poetic justice in his books’ final moments.

headline: Weighing the Costs of a Marquee Education
text: This week on CNN, Alina Cho, a correspondent, has been focusing on issues that have been of front-of-mind for many readers of The Choice this spring — whether attending a less prestigious college with a smaller price tag might, in the long run, prove of more value than enrolling in a more expensive, marquee institution.

headline: Chris Schlesinger on Grilling
text: Chris Schlesinger replies to readers’ questions about grilling:

headline: One for the Books | Inside Donald Judd’s Library
text: Assorted pornography, native plants and the Cold War are among the subjects that fill the library of the artist Donald Judd (1928-1994). But you don’t have to travel to Marfa, Tex., to browse the shelves. Today, Web visitors can click on a floor plan of his two-room library to view the 13,004 volumes arranged exactly as Judd arranged them. The virtual library has been rendered so faithfully that visitors navigate furniture and art designed by Judd and glimpse an artwork by Dan Flavin between the custom bookcases.

headline: Resumption Creates a ‘Start’ for Robertson
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Maybe it was gamesmanship. But less than two hours before Tuesday night’s suspended Yankees-Twins game was supposed to resume in the top of the sixth on Wednesday, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi still had not announced his choice to pitch.

headline: For Planners, the Party Never Ends
text: PAGES fly off calendars, as in old movies. Months blur into one another. Seasons collapse. Yes, Memorial Day is just around the corner. But in the life of a professional party planner, summer is just a place holder on the events horizon, a false lull between the benefit season that winds down this week and the one that cranks up again immediately after Labor Day.

headline: Proposed Overhaul of Accounting Standards Contains Mark-to-Market Rule
text: The group that sets corporate accounting standards proposed an overhaul Wednesday of the way lenders record the value of their assets, hoping that more stringent and consistent reporting rules might help avert another financial crisis.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gulf Coast and Elsewhere
text: Not for the first time since an explosion aboard the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig in the Gulf of Mexico unleashed an underwater gusher, there is a certain awful beauty to photographs of the oil-slicked seas and oil-soaked coastline. Win McNamee of Getty Images, whose byline is familiar to Lens readers on photos from Washington, took a picture on Wednesday that called to mind one of M. C. Escher’s best-known images.

headline: Whitney Biennial 2008
text: A multimedia introduction to this year's exhibition, including narration by Holland Cotter, an art critic for The Times.

headline: As Far as the Eye Can See
text: Images from the 40-year retrospective of Lawrence Weiner's work at the Whitney Museum.

headline: Jacob Lawrence
text: “The Migration of the Negro,” Jacob Lawrence’s series of small pictures, is most effective when seen complete.

headline: Silhouettes and Film
text: Images from "My Complement, My Enemy, My Oppressor, My Love" the show of works by Kara Walker at the Whitney Museum.

headline: Excerpt: 'Dancing With the Stars'
text: Nicole Scherzinger and Derek Hough won the tenth season of ABC's highly-rated dance competition.

headline: 41st-Ranked Player Can’t Find Point to Beat Kuznetsova
text: PARIS — No one came closer to advancing to the third round of the French Open on Wednesday without actually doing it than Andrea Petkovic. The up-and-coming 22-year-old had the defending champion, Svetlana Kuznetsova, on the verge of becoming the French Open’s first big-surprise loser.

headline: Fewer Viewers for This Year’s ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Finale
text: LOS ANGELES  “Dancing With the Stars” had its lowest season-finale audience when Nicole Scherzinger and her professional partner Derek Hough were awarded the disco ball trophy on Tuesday night. Yet the show’s Monday night performances have never been more popular.

headline: With This Ring, I Thee What?
text: A CELEBRITY’S left hand can often break big news. “Sandra Bullock Not Wearing Wedding Ring,” one recent tabloid headline said. Another: “Tiger Woods’ Wife Spotted Ringless!”

headline: ‘Begin the Beguine’ and Other Delicacies From the Shaw Oeuvre
text: To commemorate the centennial of Artie Shaw, who would have turned 100 on Sunday, two of his most ardent admirers, the Anderson Twins, are celebrating his music at 59E59 Theaters. Handsome, soft-spoken 23-year-old identical twins from Bethesda, Md., Pete and Will Anderson are virtuosos on both clarinet and saxophone. They lead a sextet that includes Jon-Erik Kellso on trumpet, Steve Ash on piano, Clovis Nicholas on bass and Kevin Dorn on drums. On Tuesday evening the group was joined by Daryl Sherman, the ebullient swing vocalist who briefly sang with Shaw’s band when he reconvened it in 1983.

headline: Art Linkletter, TV Host, Dies at 97
text: Art Linkletter, the genial host who parlayed his talent for the ad-libbed interview into two of television’s longest-running shows, “People Are Funny” and “House Party,” in the 1950s and 1960s, died on Wednesday at his home in the Bel Air section of Los Angeles. He was 97.

headline: Rumors Are Realized in New App Phones
text: It’s all about the app phones these days, isn’t it?

headline: Haute Mexican Restaurant Opens in Los Angeles
text: After cooking at the White House state dinner in honor of Mexico last week, the chef Rick Bayless flew across the country for an encore to open Red O Restaurant (8155 Melrose Avenue; 323-655-5009; redorestaurant.com) on trendy Melrose Avenue in Los Angeles.

headline: Popeyes Adds a New Chicken Dish, Too
text: Never mind the swine flu. Fast feeders have a case of chicken fever as they bring out menu items that feature new ways to present chicken to hungry consumers.

headline: ‘Service Before Self’
text: COLORADO SPRINGS – The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff came to the front range of the Rocky Mountains on Wednesday to remind the Air Force’s newest officers that America’s wars were far from over and that they would soon be tested by combat.

headline: Visitors From Berlin, Their Gear Full of Blips and Syncopations
text: Dance-music producers lead multiple lives. Walter Merziger and Arno Kammermeier, best known as the Berlin duo Booka Shade, have also produced tracks for other performers and have written music for advertisements, and they are among the partners in the Berlin electronica label Get Physical. Even making their own music, as Booka Shade, they have two guises.

headline: Mets Prepared to Start Nieve on Saturday
text: R. A. Dickey has done wonders as an emergency starter for the Mets. So has Hisanori Takahashi. So why not Fernando Nieve, the frequently used right-handed reliever? On Wednesday, Manager Jerry Manuel said that Nieve would most likely be the starter on Saturday when the Mets play the Brewers in Milwaukee.

headline: Asked & Answered | Patricia Field
text: Just as the clothes in “Sex and the City” are characters in their own right, so too is Patricia Field. For  15 years, Field has worked as the Emmy Award-winning costume designer for the estrogen-heavy television series and its two movie adaptations. “I’m behind the scenes and older than all of them, but I’m definitely the fifth,” says Field, who was born and raised in Astoria, Queens, by Greek and Turkish parents and who has been a fixture on the New York fashion scene since opening her boutique in 1966. On the eve of the New York premiere of “Sex and the City 2,” The Moment caught up with the eccentric’s eccentric.

headline: The Thorny and Serene, Submitted Side by Side
text: The Keys to the Future Festival, now in its fifth year, is devoted to new piano music, performed by specialists in contemporary repertory. Though relatively brief — this year’s festival includes only three concerts — its charm is in its eclecticism and its big reach. Instead of imposing an overarching style, Joseph Rubenstein, the composer and pianist who runs the festival, seems to enjoy assembling programs in which harmonically thorny works, jazz-inspired scores and pieces that, if not entirely Minimalist, borrow from that style’s technical arsenal, are offered side by side.

headline: Union Leader Lobbies for Jobs Measure
text: Republicans and some moderate Democrats on Capitol Hill have expressed concern all week about a package of business tax breaks and aid for the unemployed, pointing out that the measure would add to the deficit.

headline: Apple’s Struggle With Political Apps
text: Apple has again changed its mind.

headline: Dwyer, Coach and Pivotal Figure in Wheelchair Tennis, Dies
text: The New York area tennis community is mourning the death of Daniel B. Dwyer, who died Tuesday of a heart attack at age 68. Dwyer, childhood coach to John McEnroe and Mary Carillo and a longtime coach and director of Point Set Indoor Racquet Club in Oceanside, N.Y., was instrumental in the development of wheelchair tennis as an organized sport.

headline: Bradley Makes His Cuts
text: Jere Longman has a report on the final United States roster for the World Cup, and the biggest surprise might have been Bob Bradley’s decision to take Robbie Findley over the more experienced Brian Ching at forward.

headline: Parisian Courtesan Returns, Bearing Feminist Credentials
text: Ballet, because it is centrally concerned with the differences between man and woman, frequently addresses the same issues as feminism, though seldom with the same goals. Its very being arises out of an either/or dualistic view of gender. The woman goes on point, whereas the man does not. It is expected that he will partner her, not she him.

headline: Apple Struggles With Political Apps
text: At our Bits blog, Joshua Brustein reports on the latest flap over the creation of apps for iPhones, this time in the political realm. Apple first rejected an app desired by an opponent of Representative Henry Waxman, the California Democrat, but then the company reversed its position.

headline: U.S. Sells 20% of Its Citi Shares at a Profit
text: More than a year after bailing out Citigroup, the Treasury Department announced Wednesday that it had begun to sell its stake in the financial giant — and that the government was turning a profit on its investment.

headline: A Final Plea by Restaurateurs Before Letter Grades Arrive
text: After the vision thing, the nuts and bolts are an inevitability — but not necessarily an easy layup. And so, the New York City Board of Health subjected the specifics of its new restaurant letter-grading plan Tuesday to a public hearing in Manhattan. Unsurprisingly, the public was only too eager to be heard about the forthcoming visible posting, starting in July, of 8-by-10-inch placards that will give dining establishments an A, B or C rating.

headline: Leaping Through Time From Donizetti to Jazz
text: Just as every ballet has a different flavor, the secret of a good program is harmony — with the right pinches of sweetness, tartness and spice. At New York City Ballet on Tuesday night that balance created a delight: the sunny “Donizetti Variations,” followed by the crystalline “Stravinsky Violin Concerto” and finally the ever-cool “N.Y. Export: Opus Jazz.”

headline: Swear-Jar Economics
text: Over at Marginal Revolution, Tyler Cowen quotes the following passage:

headline: Take 5: Smuin Ballet, 1001 and the Birth of Impressionism
text: Want to know what to do this Memorial Day weekend? We have you covered.

headline: How I Saved My Company
text: Almost every successful small-business owner has survived a near-death business crisis. Today, we are beginning to collect these personal stories in a series of video contributions called How I Saved My Company.

headline: Gilt for Restaurants Comes to New York
text: You can already buy designer clothes, spa treatments and vacations on private, limited-time sale Web sites. Now you can make restaurant reservations, too.

headline: Photo Replay: May 26
text: A view of the day in sports, with rain, tears and darkness at Roland Garros.

headline: Hoping to Find, and Thank, a Subway Hero
text: The woman saved by a man who jumped onto the subway tracks when she fell wants him to come forward, so she can thank him in person.

headline: Preschool Programs Replace SOAPnet
text: LOS ANGELES — Moving aggressively to expand its hold on children’s entertainment, the Walt Disney Company will close its SoapNet cable channel and replace it with a service aimed at preschoolers.

headline: The Trials of Trevor Hoffman
text: MILWAUKEE – Last week in Pittsburgh, Trevor Hoffman was working on mechanics in the Milwaukee Brewers’ bullpen with the pitching coach Rick Peterson. Hoffman broke off a vintage changeup, the kind that has abandoned him for much of this season. Just as he did, the public-address system at PNC Park began to play “Hell’s Bells,” the AC/DC song that has long been Hoffman’s anthem.

headline: Trampled in a Land Rush, Chinese Resist
text: BEIJING — When China’s land boom excited a frenzy of popular resistance late last year — including headline-grabbing suicides by people routed from their homes — Chinese policy makers finally proposed a solution: rules to protect citizens from unchecked development and to fairly compensate the evicted.

headline: ‘Strip’
text: Chapter 1

headline: Out for a Test Spin on the City’s New A.T.V.’s
text: By the time we got to Lesson 7, I was kicking up more dust than Pig-Pen in the comic strip “Peanuts,” except that Pig-Pen did it without an all-terrain vehicle — specifically, a bright yellow Can-Am Renegade 800R EFI X xc with a liquid-cooled, overhead cam engine that roared with glee when I finally dared to give it some gas.

headline: At Book Expo, Anxiety Amid the Chatter
text: As the book industry gathered for its annual convention in New York this week, it had plenty to be nervous about: the threat of piracy, the decline of brick-and-mortar stores and the perhaps-too-low price of e-books.

headline: Domestic Detox: Tools for Measuring Toxicity
text: Matthew Waletzke evaluates homes for potential health hazards like mold, indoor air pollution and electromagnetic radiation.
