text: 1 chicken, around 3 pounds

headline: Cooking With Dexter: Free Bird
text: All the cookbooks I own are packed away. The tower of boxes makes a handy shelf for things we want to keep out of the implacable hands of our 2-year-old, Elliot. That’s the only use we’ve found for the books since our family moved into a rental apartment in January. I meant to unpack them and set them on shelves right away, marking the borrowed kitchen as my own.

headline: Guilty Pleas in Landrieu Incident
text: The conservative provocateur James O’Keefe and three other men pleaded guilty in federal court on Wednesday to a misdemeanor in a scheme in which they posed as telephone repairmen in Senator Mary L. Landrieu’s New Orleans office.

headline: Two Architects Have a Meeting of the Minds at a Texas Museum
text: It’s fair to ask if Renzo Piano was fully sane when he agreed to design the addition to Louis Kahn’s Kimbell Art Museum.

headline: The Tastemaker
text: It has been more than a generation since your films  “Pink Flamingos”  and  “Polyester”  established you as a champion of the trash-into-art aesthetic. But now that bad taste is so prevalent in America, does it still carryan artistic charge for you?  Bad taste per se does not, because today it’s reality television and gross-out, big-budget Hollywood comedies. Everything we export — it’s all about bad taste, so it’s not new anymore. You have to know the rules to break them with happiness, and thank God my mother taught me proper table manners.

headline: Shopping With Peter Som
text: The fashion designer shopped for furnishings for a low-key summer bedroom.

headline: A Connecticut Country Home With Plenty of Seating
text: KENT, Conn.

headline: A Country Home for a Collector of Chairs
text: Oversized windows fill the space with light and frame the nearly 50 chairs in Louise and George Beylerian’s Connecticut home.

headline: Lee DeWyze Is This Year’s American Idol
text: Tonight, America chose Lee DeWyze over Crystal Bowersox, and Simon Cowell said goodbye to the show. ArtsBeat followed the program live.

headline: The Yankees Get by Twice With a Home Run, and a Save by Rivera
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Yankees Manager Joe Girardi customarily conducts his pregame news briefing in the dugout. On Wednesday afternoon, however, he held more of a midgame session.

headline: Evictions in Beijing
text: Conflict between police and residents erupted in Laogucheng, where residents say they are being unlawfully evicted by real estate developers working and local government.

headline: Some International Stars, Just Getting In Their Practice
text: The Dutch Bridge Federation gives strong support to its top players. There are coaching sessions every Friday, and if this costs a day’s pay, the federation compensates that player.

headline: It’s Not Quite Hollywood Above the 38th Parallel
text: Jim Finn, maker of “artist films” (his own phrase, only partly ironic), will confound most moviegoers with “The Juche Idea,” his latest short-feature-length riff on radical-utopian notions of cinema. Not quite fiction but definitely not a documentary, it’s a bit like a “Saturday Night Live” episode devoted to the film theories of North Korea’s Dear Leader, Kim Jong-il.

headline: For Latest on Lindsay, Magazines Bow to the Phone
text: In Marx’s view, religion was the opiate of the masses. Now the drug is celebrity news, and cellphones are well on their way to becoming the world’s biggest pushers.

headline: Editing Photos on the Linux System
text: Q. I have an older laptop that can’t support Windows 7’s requirements. If I reformat it to run the free Linux system, will I be able to import and edit photos from my digital camera?

headline: Shopping With Peter Som
text: PETER SOM, a fashion designer known for his feminine sportswear, describes himself as “a beach bum at heart.”

headline: A New Side Table From Philippe Starck
text: Ghost Buster, a commode designed by Philippe Starck for Kartell, is a single piece of transparent molded plastic with two open shelves that requires the user to be scrupulously, compulsively, obsessively neat. No books in lopsided piles. No crumpled pieces of paper.

headline: A Contemporary Bench With Classical Curves
text: For most people, the soaring columns of Greek temples wouldn’t immediately conjure up visions of seating. But Laurie Beckerman, a New York designer, saw the Ionic column capital as an obvious model for a bench.

headline: The Spanish Designer Patricia Urquiola
text: Patricia Urquiola, the Spanish designer, does not like the nickname she has been given — Hurricane — yet those who spend any time in her presence come away feeling as if they have survived a whirlwind. At the furniture fair in Milan last month, the list of products or installations with her name on them numbered more than 35; at the recent International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York, there were fewer, but her presence was still undeniably felt.

headline: Contemporary Design on Display at British Castle
text: When visitors arrive this summer at the 15th-century Sudeley Castle in one of the prettiest parts of southwest England, they will discover its historic gardens, ancient walks and ruined tithe barn. They will also find some show-stopping works by contemporary designers.

headline: Even Appliances Need a Spring Cleaning
text: KIRBY HILLS, the owner of At Your Service Appliance Repair in Kansas City, Mo., sees hundreds of appliances stopped up with all manner of goo, dust and gunk every year.

headline: Sales at Apartment 48 and Others
text: Apartment 48, a home-accessories shop in the Flatiron district, is taking 30 percent off John Derian decoupage items, 20 percent off glassware and dinnerware and 50 percent off vintage furniture through June 30 (a Monkey Bell Jar by John Derian, originally $880, is $616; Sabre French dinner plates, left, originally $38, are $30.40); 12 West 17th Street (Fifth Avenue), (212) 807-1391 or apartment48.com.

headline: Planting the Strip Between Sidewalk and Street
text: HERE’S a partial inventory of the things I’ve found in front of my duplex on a boozy block of northeast Minneapolis: two abandoned bicycles; a disemboweled 13-inch TV; a frenzied Chihuahua named Apollo; three small boulders hurled by anguished college football fans; and a puzzled gentleman in a windbreaker, bleeding from the head.

headline: Domestic Detox: Extreme Home Cleaning
text: WHEN Matthew Waletzke appeared at the door of my East Village apartment to evaluate my home for what he calls “toxic exposure” — the alternative world’s catch-all phrase for potential health hazards like mold, indoor air pollution, household chemicals and electromagnetic radiation (beware your Wi-Fi!) — I half-expected to see a guy in an “Andromeda Strain”-era hazmat suit.

headline: Urban Archaeology’s Wharf Light, in Color
text: Urban Archaeology’s Wharf Light has become synonymous with a certain type of interior. During the recent period in design associated with “great rooms,” there were few lofts that didn’t have several hanging over a kitchen island.

headline: The AIA Guide, Updated
text: The fifth edition of the AIA Guide to New York City ($39.95; Oxford University Press) will be published next week, and like the previous editions, it is a witty, informative and delightful critique of thousands of buildings and spaces in the five boroughs. It is also richly updated with new material — not just additions to the city since the last guide in 2000, like the High Line park and the Time Warner Center, but also sweet entries like the one on 447 West 18th Street and 459 West 18th Street: “Two young apartment buildings standing arm in arm, cheek to cheek, dancing the Chelsea Waltz around the corner from the High Line.”

headline: Full A.I.G. Payment Called Uncertain
text: WASHINGTON — The American International Group is likely to repay the $83.2 billion it owes the Federal Reserve, but whether an additional $49.1 billion in taxpayer investments in the company will ever be recovered remains uncertain, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Service Chiefs Seek to Delay Vote on Gays
text: WASHINGTON — The chiefs of the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines objected on Wednesday to a compromise plan to repeal the military’s ban on allowing gay men and lesbians to serve openly, a position that put them at odds with President Obama and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates.

headline: What We’re Reading: Influential People
text: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times recommended these articles Wednesday:

headline: Long Island Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: California Puts Vote Overhaul on the Ballot
text: SACRAMENTO — In another indication of how frustrated voters have grown with politics as usual, California — home of initiative-happy democracy — is considering a radical overhaul.

headline: Health and Oil in Canada
text: To the Editor:

headline: John Yoo’s History
text: To the Editor:

headline: Design 2.0: How ‘Green’ Is My Building?
text: To the Editor:

headline: In New Era of TV, Rival Hosts Drown Out King
text: The biggest interview on television last week, with the Senate candidate Rand Paul, happened at 9 p.m. But regrettably for CNN’s Larry King, who used to rule that time slot by wooing newsmakers, the interview was booked by his higher-rated competitor, MSNBC’s Rachel Maddow.

headline: Readers’ Photos: The Gulf Oil Spill
text: What readers are seeing along the Gulf Coast in the wake of the Deepwater Horizon rig explosion.

headline: When Poor Families Spend Unwisely
text: To the Editor:

headline: Russian Knights Joust to Control Chess World
text: MOSCOW — Without warning, guards sent by a senior Kremlin adviser took over an elegant pre-revolutionary mansion in an upscale neighborhood of Moscow here last week. The tenants were immediately told to leave.

headline: Q and A: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s Chief
text: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s founder and chief executive, held a press conference on Wednesday to showcase new simplified privacy settings for the Facebook Web site and platform.

headline: U.S. Roster Soap Opera Settled on Daytime TV
text: Bristol, Conn.

headline: In E. Coli Fight, Some Strains Are Largely Ignored
text: For nearly two decades, Public Enemy No. 1 for the food industry and its government regulators has been a virulent strain of E. coli bacteria that has killed hundreds of people, sickened thousands and prompted the recall of millions of pounds of hamburger, spinach and other foods.

headline: M.L.B. Financing Will Keep Rangers Afloat Until Sale
text: In Day 3 of the Texas Rangers’ bankruptcy, creditors and Major League Baseball vied in a courtroom in Fort Worth on Wednesday to make loans to keep the team running.

headline: Obama’s Oil and Energy Opportunity
text: [May 27, 7:57 a.m. | Updated  A Democratic senator from Alaska said Thursday night that President Obama plans to suspend new permits for offshore drilling in Arctic waters at least through the rest of this year.]

headline: A Case Built in New York Against a Jamaican Kingpin
text: In October 2007, federal drug enforcement agents were questioning a man who had been arrested in the Bronx on gun and drug charges when he began to talk about someone he depicted as “one of the most powerful men in all of Jamaica,” records show.

headline: For Peru and American Inmate, Much Is Changed
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — When Lori Berenson was jailed in Peru on terrorism charges over 14 years ago, she was a fiery young leftist from New York enmeshed in a shadowy Marxist rebel group, stunning a war-weary nation with her clenched fists and defiant statements in support of revolution.

headline: New Breed of  Specialist Steps In for Family Doctor
text: PHILADELPHIA — By the time Djigui Keita left the hospital for home, his follow-up appointment had been scheduled. Emergency health insurance was arranged until he could apply for public assistance. He knew about changes in his medication — his doctor had found less expensive brands at local pharmacy chains. And Mr. Keita, 35, who had passed out from dehydration, was cautioned to carry spare water bottles in the taxi he drove for a living.

headline: In Hospitals, New Fingers on the Pulse
text: Jane Gross reports on the rise of a new type of health professional, the hospitalist, on Thursday in The Times. A hybrid in the health ecosystem, the hospitalist is both physician and administrator; he or she may coordinate virtually all aspects of a patient’s care, an increasingly necessary function in the nation’s overburdened hospitals.

headline: 2 Charged With Selling Insider Data From Disney
text: LOS ANGELES — An administrative assistant at the Walt Disney Company and a male friend were arrested and charged with selling early access to the entertainment giant’s confidential earnings reports.

headline: Witness Issue Prompts a Hearing on Possible Misconduct by Prosecutors to Be Postponed
text: A federal hearing into possible misconduct by Brooklyn prosecutors in a murder trial was postponed on Wednesday because the lead lawyer representing the district attorney’s office might be called as a witness.

headline: Polish Leader’s Mother Finally Learns of His Death
text: WARSAW — Perhaps the last person in Poland to learn that the country’s president was killed last month in a plane crash was his invalid mother, and it fell to his twin brother, the former prime minister, to break the news.

headline: Keeping the Peace by Riding the Urban Range
text: John B. Reilly’s mother plopped him on a pony in Connecticut when he was 2, but back home in Jamaica, Queens, he forgot about horses until he was a teenager, when he began riding in Forest and Pelham Bay Parks. Jumping lessons and gymkhana competitions on borrowed horses came later. Ten years into a career with the New York City Police Department, he was accepted into the elite Mounted Unit. Detective Reilly, 54, with 16 years in the saddle, is the senior member of the unit.

headline: Health and Safety Tips for World Cup Travelers
text: If you’re traveling to South Africa for the World Cup, you should worry more about mundane problems like diarrhea, measles and tick bites than you do about exotic tropical diseases like malaria and yellow fever, according to a new study in the American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene.

headline: France: Rwandan Doctor Arrested and Accused in ’94 Genocide
text: The French police on Wednesday arrested a Rwandan doctor on an international warrant. The doctor, Eugene Rwamucyo, is suspected of being involved in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda, judicial officials said. The Kigali government has accused him of planning and carrying out atrocities in the Butare region of southern Rwanda. Dr. Rwamucyo lives in Belgium, and was dismissed last month from a hospital post in northern France. He was arrested north of Paris after attending the funeral of another Rwandan, Jean-Bosco Barayagwiza, who was convicted of war crimes in 2003 by the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda in The Hague.

headline: Portugal Old, New and Undiscovered
text: “SEE these olive trees?” said Celso Pereira as his pickup truck slalomed down a road flanked by thousands of them, their pale, pointy leaves glistening faintly, their limbs wretched and magnificent with age. “They make the most wonderful olive oil.”

headline: Mexico: Candidate Faces Charges
text: A gubernatorial candidate from the coastal state of Quintana Roo, which includes Cancún, was arrested by the federal police on Tuesday night on charges of drug trafficking, money laundering and organized crime. Supporters of the candidate, Gregorio Sánchez, who took a leave as Cancún’s mayor to run for governor, condemned the charges as politically motivated. The attorney general’s office said Mr. Sánchez collaborated with two drug trafficking organizations that use Mexico’s Yucatán Peninsula to move cocaine and other drugs.

headline: Rome’s Soft Spot for Caravaggio
text: WHEN Caravaggio arrived in Rome in 1592 he was just another young, aspiring painter. It took only a few years for his unconventional aesthetic vision and colorful, often violent lifestyle to transfix Roman society. To read his 17th-century biographers, Caravaggio was more likely to have a sword in his hand than a paintbrush, and court papers from the time amply substantiate his bad-boy behavior, which ranged from churlish (hurling artichokes at a waiter) to deadly (murder).

headline: With Cuomo, a Mayor With an Eye on Education
text: For Mayor Robert J. Duffy of Rochester, the shooting of a police officer by a sixth-grade dropout last year drove home an urgent message: His city could do nothing about crime if it did not fix its broken schools.

headline: In Germany, War and Reunion
text: A STEADY stream of BMWs, Porsches and Mercedeses buzz by as I walk south on a lakeside bike and pedestrian path on a glorious Sunday afternoon in May. The cars carry apparently prosperous day-trippers from Munich, a 45-minute drive to the north, bound for Tegernsee, a popular resort town on the small Alpine lake of the same name in Bavaria.

headline: U.S. Sells 20% of Its Citi Shares at a Profit
text: More than a year after bailing out Citigroup, the Treasury Department announced on Wednesday that it had begun to sell its stake in the financial giant — and that the government was turning a profit on its investment.

headline: Questions for Makers on Defects in Drugs
text: For consumers who turned to drugstore house brands after the recall last month of liquid children’s Tylenol and other medicines made by a unit of Johnson & Johnson, there is yet more unsettling news.

headline: The Palin Brand
text: In the midst of one of the most precipitous political crashes in the Mountain West, Sarah Palin made a mad dash into Boise on Friday, urging the election of a man who had plagiarized his campaign speech from Barack Obama, had been rebuked by the military for misusing the Marine uniform and had called the American territory of Puerto Rico a separate country.

headline: Glass Half-Full
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: A Silicon Valley Relaunch
text: REDWOOD CITY, about 25 miles south of San Francisco, was a bustling shipping and lumber town in the mid-19th century, until it fell off the radar in the ’70s  owing, in part, to major retail development in nearby Palo Alto  and was tagged with the unfortunate nickname Deadwood City. But over the last few years, this sleepy Silicon Valley suburb has begun shaking off that moniker, re-emerging with an influx of new restaurants, shops and theaters. The town is also striving to preserve historic landmarks, like the glass-domed courthouse, which celebrates its centennial this summer with outdoor concerts and a Fourth of July dedication ceremony.

headline: Tying Series, the Suns Cut the Lakers Down to Size
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — Pau Gasol gazed downward into a sea of cameras and microphones and lowered his head slightly to meet the questions. Clearly, he was still much taller than the average person.

headline: Panel on Haitian Prison Deaths
text: The Haitian government and the United Nations are establishing a joint commission of inquiry into the Jan. 19 killings of a dozen or more inmates at a prison in Les Cayes, Haiti.

headline: Lotus Position in a Backpacker’s Town
text: “BREATHING clearly lifts the mind and spirit,” said Amar Puri, a wiry man in a sweat-stained T-shirt, as he crouched on a patch of lawn and poured saltwater in one nostril with a neti pot. He snorted and sneezed, as the morning mist hovered just above the lead-gray surface of Phewa Lake, reflecting the Himalayas. “And now, I am ready for yoga.”

headline: Sister Margaret’s Choice
text: We finally have a case where the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy is responding forcefully and speedily to allegations of wrongdoing.

headline: U.S. Stands With an Ally, Eager for China to Join the Line
text: SEOUL, South Korea — When Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday declared America’s solidarity with South Korea in its mounting confrontation with North Korea, she had more than a domestic audience in mind: she was also speaking to the Chinese.

headline: Voices on Albany's Troubled Government
text: Four New York Democrats discussed the state's much-maligned government.

headline: Tenants and Landlords Criticize Paterson’s Rent Regulation Proposal
text: Gov. David A. Paterson proposed changes to housing laws on Wednesday that would make it harder for landlords to lift apartments out of rent regulation but would also override a landmark pro-tenant court ruling so that it could not apply in future cases.

headline: Immigration Overhaul Advocates Question Troops
text: WASHINGTON — In deciding to deploy up to 1,200 National Guard troops to bolster security at the Mexican border, President Obama has stepped into one of the thorniest issues facing American presidents — illegal immigration — and has confounded allies who say he is squandering his chance to address it in a comprehensive way.

headline: Manuel’s Bullpen Use Under the Microscope
text: The one art of managing a baseball team that draws the most scrutiny is his use of the bullpen. To that end, Jerry Manuel has offered up plenty of material.

headline: Budget Problems in New York and Mr. Cuomo
text: Attorney General Andrew Cuomo of New York accepts the Democratic nomination for governor on Thursday with an agenda that calls for cleaning up the “national disgrace” in Albany, a goal every New Yorker can applaud. To demonstrate that he is the one to lead New York forward, Mr. Cuomo also needs to address the state’s fiscal meltdown.

headline: Some Tests, Long Ignored, Showed Signs of Heart Illness
text: New York City’s public hospital system said on Wednesday that some of the thousands of heart test results that were never sent to doctors at Harlem Hospital Center since 2007 had shown signs of abnormal heart function.

headline: Lehman Suit Seeks $5 Billion From JPMorgan
text: Lehman Brothers Holdings and a group of unsecured creditors sued JPMorgan Chase on Wednesday for more than $5 billion, accusing it of siphoning billions of dollars of assets and hastening Lehman’s bankruptcy.

headline: Check It Again
text: These days it is hard enough to find a job. Far too many Americans miss a chance to get hired because the F.B.I. background checks employers commonly use to screen applicants have incomplete or inaccurate information. A bill introduced by Representative Bobby Scott, a Democrat of Virginia, would fix this problem by requiring the F.B.I. to verify and correct criminal data before issuing the background check for employment purposes.

headline: Often-Used Mets Reliever May Get Shot as Starter
text: R.A. Dickey has done wonders as an emergency starter for the Mets. So has Hisanori Takahashi. So why not Fernando Nieve, the frequently used right-handed reliever?

headline: Throwing the Rule Book at the N.F.L.
text: The National Football League does not condone gambling, but it lost a giant bet this week when the Supreme Court firmly rejected its contention that it is not subject to the nation’s antitrust laws. The court’s unanimous decision sends a conspicuous message to other sports leagues — except Major League Baseball — that when it comes to selling merchandise, charging for parking and paying players, they have to play by the rules.

headline: Study Finds Condom Use Is Increasing
text: Women and their partners in the United States are increasingly using male condoms when they have premarital sex for the first time, which may explain why teenage birth rates have declined in recent decades, according to a new government survey of contraceptive methods.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Gathering of Democrats, Except for One at the Top
text: RYE BROOK, N.Y. — Gov. David A. Paterson is known for enjoying a good party. So there must be a pretty good reason why he has been a no-show at one of the biggest New York political events of the year.

headline: Concrete Testing Executive Sentenced to Up to 21 Years
text: A judge sentenced the former president of a prominent concrete testing company in New York City to 7 to 21 years in prison on Wednesday, saying he had betrayed the public and his profession with years of lying and fakery.

headline: Meadowlands in February? Watch for Snowballs
text: In the lead-up to the decision to grant the Super Bowl to the New York area in 2014, why all these whiny assertions of how unwise it will be to play football here because of temperatures in February below those that sustain human life?

headline: A Busy Schedule Is Never Boring
text: Dr. Subha Airan-Javia, a 32-year-old hospitalist, splits her time between clinical care and information technology designed to save money and increase efficiency. “I’d be bored doing the same thing every day,” she said.

headline: After Rain Delays, Unfinished Business
text: According to AccuWeather.com, Thursday’s second-round matches will be played in cooler temperatures and could be interrupted again by rain. And you know what that means: more time to deconstruct extreme fashion, be it Venus Williams’s lacy dress and skin-tone undergarment or Rafael Nadal’s half-million dollar watch.

headline: Germany vs. Europe
text: Germany’s commitment to the European Union has been central to its postwar rehabilitation and its economic success. For years, Germany played the role in Europe that America so frequently plays globally — the locomotive whose dynamism and demand helps turn around recessions before they deepen into depressions.

headline: Unchecked Squares
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s grid by Josh Knapp looks different because it breaks one of the standard rules of crossword construction. White squares must be “checked.” That is, they must be part of two different answers, one Across and one Down. This grid appears to have ten unchecked squares. By convention, cryptic crosswords have unchecked squares all the time — here’s what the latest New York Times cryptic looks like: (Across Lite, Solution) — but they’re not allowed in the regular daily puzzles, right? What’s going on?

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Who Wants to Elect a Millionaire?
text: Today, let’s play Political Kingmaker.

headline: Student Presumed Drowned Off Long Island
text: A college student was missing and presumed drowned after he and two other students were pulled by a rip tide off a Long Island beach on Wednesday afternoon, the authorities said.

headline: Europe Says Search Firms Are Violating Data Rules
text: BERLIN — European Union officials on Wednesday said Google, Microsoft and Yahoo had violated rules by keeping data on individual computer users for too long.

headline: BP Used Riskier Method to Seal Well Before Blast
text: WASHINGTON — Several days before the explosion on the Deepwater Horizon oil rig, BP officials chose, partly for financial reasons, to use a type of casing for the well that the company knew was the riskier of two options, according to a BP document.

headline: Through the (Russian) Looking Glass
text: A fight for control of the Russian Chess Federation seems to be at an impasse for the moment, but the issues seem unlikely to go away.

headline: Democrats Put 5 on Ballot for N.Y. Attorney General
text: RYE BROOK, N.Y. — The second day of the Democratic state convention drew to a close here on Wednesday with a wide-open primary for attorney general after party leaders maneuvered to ensure that all five declared candidates made it onto the Democratic ballot.

headline: Easy Money, Hard Truths
text: Are you worried that we are passing our debt on to future generations? Well, you need not worry.

headline: Gulf Reality Show Draws a Big Web Audience
text: Forget about “American Idol.” It was BP’s Web-only reality show — live video of the oil spill from the floor of the Gulf of Mexico — that had people fixated on their screens on Wednesday. And the episode “Top Kill” even had a cliffhanger: it could be days before viewers know whether the latest effort to plug the well is successful.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,391 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,070 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Is It Obama’s Oil Spill Now?
text: Updated, May 27, 5:50 p.m. | On Thursday, President Obama ordered work suspended on exploratory drilling in the gulf. In a White House news conference, he said, “In case you’re wondering who’s responsible, I take responsibility.”

headline: For Atlantis, a Flight Path to Retirement
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — Gliding into retirement after 32 missions covering 120 million miles, the shuttle Atlantis dropped out of orbit and returned to Earth on Wednesday, wrapping up a 25-year career with a near-flawless space station assembly mission.

headline: Michael H. Jordan, Turnaround Expert, Dies at 73
text: Michael H. Jordan, a turnaround specialist who recast Westinghouse as a media company and revived both CBS and Electronic Data Systems, died Tuesday night in Manhattan. He was 73.

headline: Ex-Officer Calls Sex Charges Part of a Plot
text: The conspiracy against him reached the upper ranks of the Police Department, Wilfredo Rosario said on Wednesday.

headline: Bloggingheads: Illiberal Israel?
text: Peter Beinart, left, of The Daily Beast and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate whether democracy is dying in Israel.

headline: Clifford Grodd, the Driving Force at Paul Stuart, Dies at 86
text: Clifford Grodd, who brought a subtle flair to classic men’s wear as the president and chief executive of the private-label retailer Paul Stuart, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Obama Takes His Cash-Drawing Power on the Road
text: SAN FRANCISCO — By the time President Obama flew here on Tuesday for a trio of fund-raisers, he had put in a full day three time zones away in Washington — meeting with small-business leaders and the president of Italy, sparring with Senate Republicans over lunch, making plans to inspect the gulf oil spill and ordering National Guard troops to the border with Mexico.

headline: Full A.I.G. Payment Called Uncertain
text: The American International Group is likely to repay the $83.2 billion it owes the Federal Reserve, but whether an additional $49.1 billion in taxpayer investments in the company will ever be recovered remains uncertain, officials said Wednesday, according to The New York Times’s Sewell Chan.

headline: Cost of Jobs Bill Leaves Some Democrats Leery
text: WASHINGTON — The emergence of the escalating federal debt and government spending as a defining political issue is complicating Democratic efforts this week to push through a major package of tax breaks and unemployment aid over the reluctance of Democrats wary of being painted as budget busters.

headline: Mets’ Revamped Rotation Stifles Phillies Again
text: Now the Mets are winning again, beating good teams, even shutting them out. The Phillies fell for the second consecutive time, this one by 5-0 before 33,223 pleasantly surprised witnesses Wednesday night at Citi Field.

headline: NASA Finds New Criticism and Skepticism Before Congress
text: The head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration was buffeted with more criticism and skepticism before Congress on Wednesday as he sought to defend the Obama administration’s proposal to revamp the space agency.

headline: Kraft Hopes to Encourage Adults to Revert to a Childhood Favorite
text: KRAFT FOODS wants grown-ups to get the blues in the night, and in the afternoon and at snack time, too.

headline: Inquiry Sought Into Sestak Claim
text: The seven Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday requested appointment of a special prosecutor to look into Representative Joe Sestak’s claim that the White House offered him a job to drop out of the Senate Democratic primary race in Pennsylvania. In a letter to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., the seven said the assertions, “if true, suggest a possible violation of various federal criminal laws intended to safeguard our political process from the taint of bribes and political machine manipulation.” The Justice Department as recently as last Friday said it saw no need for a special prosecutor.

headline: Massachusetts: EMT’s Falsified Records
text: About 200 emergency medical technicians in Massachusetts and New Hampshire bought and submitted to their employer falsified recertification records, officials said Wednesday. The fraudulent paperwork got the EMT’s out of the 24 to 48 hours of classroom training, said Jennifer Manley, a spokeswoman for the Massachusetts Department of Public Health. Public safety was never at risk, she said, and those who falsified records cannot go on calls until they are recertified. The agency has contacted the state attorney general’s office.

headline: Doctors Reverse Stand on Circumcision
text: The American Academy of Pediatrics has reversed its decision last month regarding the practice of female circumcision by immigrants from some African, Middle Eastern and Asian cultures. The academy had suggested in a policy statement that doctors be given permission to perform a ceremonial pinprick or nick on girls if it would keep their families from sending them overseas for the full circumcision. Although the nick on a girl’s clitoris is illegal in the United States, the academy’s bioethics panel had noted it is practiced in some countries. The policy statement ignited a storm of criticism from opponents of female genital cutting. Dr. Judith S. Palfrey, president of the academy, said: “We’re saying don’t do it. Do everything that you can to support that family in this tough time, but don’t be pulled into the procedure.”

headline: Winfrey’s Charity Ends Its Work
text: Oprah Winfrey is wrapping up Oprah’s Angel Network, a nonprofit she founded in 1998 to raise money from her fans to support a wide range of causes and organizations. The group will have given away more than $80 million, and Ms. Winfrey, whose talk show is ending in 2011, has often added her own money. Among other causes, the organization raised $15.6 million to help rebuild homes after Hurricane Katrina, and its donors have supported construction of several schools in rural areas around the world. “Since the network was an outgrowth of the show, it seems appropriate to wind it down in tandem with the show’s final season,” Angela DePaul, a spokeswoman for Harpo Inc., Ms. Winfrey’s company, said Wednesday.

headline: The Real Idol Leaves the Stage
text: Lee DeWyze came out ahead of Crystal Bowersox in the finale of “American Idol” on Wednesday night but it wasn’t a dramatic finish. Both singers are similarly gifted and likeable in a low-key way  voters had a narrow choice.

headline: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: BP BEGINS ‘TOP KILL’ ATTEMPT

headline: Autochrome’s Enduring Allure
text: It’s earnestly suggested that you view this show in “Full Screen” mode, to appreciate fully the richness of these plates.

headline: Bias Seen in ‘Police-on-Police’ Shootings
text: A governor’s task force studying mistaken-identity confrontations between police officers found that racial bias, unconscious or otherwise, played a clear role in scores of firearms encounters over the years, most significantly in cases involving off-duty officers who are killed by their colleagues.

headline: Health Care Study Calls Risk Pool Money Lacking
text: The new health care law does not allocate nearly enough money to cover the estimated 5.6 million to 7 million Americans with pre-existing medical conditions who will qualify for temporary high-risk insurance pools, according to a report scheduled for release on Thursday.

headline: Facebook’s Power, and Its Weakness
text: Witness the power of Facebook. About a month ago, one of the social networking site’s users set up a discussion forum titled “No I will not pay $3.98 a month to use Facebook as of July 10th 2010!” Within a few weeks, more than 825,000 people had joined the page. Trouble is, the whole thing was based on a faulty premise: Facebook has no such intention to charge.

headline: Word of the Day | falter
text: falter •\ˈfȯl-tər\• verb and noun

headline: Mark-to-Market in Proposed Accounting Standards Overhaul
text: The group that sets corporate accounting standards proposed an overhaul Wednesday of the way lenders record the value of their assets, hoping that more stringent and consistent reporting rules might help avert another financial crisis, The New York Times’s Eric Dash reported.

headline: S.E.C. Proposes a Uniform Audit Trail to Track Trading
text: Federal regulators moved on Wednesday toward requiring a uniform system for tracking all securities orders on American exchanges, in hopes of making it easier to investigate market disruptions like the plunge on May 6, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Celtics’ Frontcourt and Momentum Are Shaken
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Glen Davis attempted to pick himself up before falling again. He rose and, like a stunned boxer, staggered to midcourt before collapsing into the arms of the referee Joey Crawford.

headline: The Career of Art Linkletter
text: Art Linkletter was the genial host who parlayed his talent for the ad-libbed interview into two of television’s longest-running shows, “People Are Funny” and “House Party,” in the 1950s and 1960s.

headline: When the Fashionistas Arrive
text: Images from the streets of Paris before the Dries Von Noten and Karl Lagerfeld shows.

headline: Show Scenes
text: Images from the last day of New York Fashion Week, behind the curtains and on the runways.

headline: New Role for Degeneres: Record Company Mogul
text: A month after David Letterman said he had started a record company, Ellen DeGeneres has followed him with an announcement that she has created her own label. On “The Ellen DeGeneres Show,” her syndicated talk show, Ms. DeGeneres on Wednesday introduced a song by Greyson Chance, a 12-year-old from Oklahoma (with an uncanny resemblance to Justin Bieber) who has been an Internet sensation recently for his version of Lady Gaga’s “Paparazzi.” When Mr. Chance (above, with Ms. DeGeneres) finished his performance at the piano, Ms. DeGeneres said: “He inspired me to start a record label called eleveneleven. He is my first artist. We are making a record together. How about that?” Ms. DeGeneres is not a total stranger to the music business of course; she has been a judge on “American Idol” this season.

headline: News Quiz | May 27, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Concert Manager at Museum Is Leaving
text: Hilde Limondjian is stepping down as the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s music impresario, the Met said, ending a 41-year run that turned the Met’s concert series into a New York fixture. Under her direction as general manager of concerts and lectures the Met program helped inaugurate major careers, brought back prominent performers regularly and popularized ideas like concerts with themes and commentary. She established lengthy residences for the Beaux Arts Trio and Guarneri String Quartet (now replaced by the Pacifica Quartet) and brought in a young Yo-Yo Ma, Martha Argerich and Cecilia Bartoli, as well as the Emerson String Quartet and Orpheus Chamber Orchestra. The Met said Ms. Limondjian would depart June 30 and had already planned next season. The search for a successor is on, it said.

headline: Director Resigns at Corcoran Gallery
text: Paul Greenhalgh has resigned as the director and president of the Corcoran Gallery of Art and College of Art + Design in Washington, effective June 1, the Corcoran announced. Mr. Greenhalgh, who has held his position since 2006, will remain at the Corcoran as artistic director until Nov. 1, then return to his native Britain to run the Sainsbury Center for the Visual Arts at the University of East Anglia. (He will retain the title of adjunct curator of European fine and decorative arts at the Corcoran.) A spokeswoman for the Corcoran, Kristin Guiter, said a search for a new director would begin in late summer. In the meantime the current chief operating officer, Fred Bollerer, will serve as director and chief executive, and Kirk Pillow, the provost and dean of the college, will serve as interim president. The Corcoran ran a $3.5 million deficit in the last fiscal year, which ended June 30, 2009, and expects to run a nearly $4 million deficit in the current year.

headline: ‘Idol’ Wins, but Barely
text: The final night of competition on “American Idol” topped the ratings race on Tuesday as 19.6 million viewers tuned in to watch Crystal Bowersox and Lee DeWyze (above) face off on that Fox reality show, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Fox led the night’s ratings, edging past ABC and its finale of “Dancing With the Stars,” which drew 18.2 million from 9 to 11. Fox’s “Glee” earned a considerably smaller audience at 9 (11.5 million) but managed to maintain high numbers among viewers 18 to 49, finishing second only to “Idol” in that demographic. CBS placed third over all with its night of finales, attracting 15.9 million at 8 for “NCIS,” 13.1 million at 9 for “NCIS: Los Angeles” and 10.6 million at 10 for “The Good Wife.” NBC was fourth.

headline: Apple and Microsoft's Tug of War
text: Apple shot past Microsoft to become the world’s most valuable technology company.

headline: Asian Stocks Erase Early Losses
text: Stock markets continued their roller-coaster performance in Asia on Thursday, reversing morning losses to stand slightly higher by early afternoon, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

headline: Dow Below 10,000 for First Time Since Feb. 8
text: As quickly as the major indexes zigged, they zagged.

headline: After ‘Idol,’ a Final Red Carpet
text: LOS ANGELES — After the final broadcast of “American Idol,” the winner (Lee DeWyze) and the, uh, non-winner (Crystal Bowersox) fielded questions from dozens of reporters and endured one more walk on a red carpet.

headline: Ackman Buys 150 Million Citi Shares
text: William A. Ackman, the activist investor and managing member of Pershing Square Capital Management, said on Wednesday that his firm recently bought 150 million shares of Citigroup, but didn’t provide his reason or an investment thesis for the purchase.

headline: Buffett and Moody’s Chief to Testify to Commission
text: Warren E. Buffett, the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, will testify next week before the panel examining the causes of the financial crisis, Reuters reported.

headline: Some Pru Investors Said Set to Oppose AIA Deal
text: Shareholders holding up to 15 percent of British insurer Prudential Plc‘s shares plan to write to the chairman saying they oppose the company’s $35.5 billion takeover of A.I.G.‘s Asian arm, The Times reported Thursday.

headline: China Said to Review Euro-Zone Debt Holdings
text: China is reviewing its euro-zone bond holdings because of growing concerns about gaping deficits in countries including Greece and Portugal, The Financial Times reported on Wednesday.

headline: Firms’ Distressed Debt Cycle Not Over, Pimco Says
text: The end is not near for the distressed debt cycle, as many middle-market American companies will still have to be restructured because of debt taken on during the credit boom, Pimco said Wednesday.

headline: Household Goblins
text: WHO is the creator of the Times blog “Abstract City” from which this latest post, “The Haunted Household,” comes?

headline: The Iran Edition
text: Nickname for an iPad-friendly edition of the British magazine Dazed & Confused.

headline: What Can You Learn About Politics From Pop Songs?
text: Do you like the music of M.I.A.? Do you listen to her lyrics, or do you just like the beat? The Times Magazine examines the politics of the Sri Lankan musician, who has been called a terrorist sympathizer by some. In general, do you pay attention to political messages in music? What musical artists past or present do you think have been particularly deft at getting across political messages?

headline: Global Payments Completes Sales to Palladium
text: Global Payments said Wednesday that it has completed its $85 million sale of its DolEx and Europhil money transfer businesses to an affiliate of Palladium Equity Partners.

headline: North Korea to Suspend Naval Hot Line With South
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said Thursday that it was cutting off a naval hot line that was intended to prevent clashes near its disputed sea border with South Korea. Meanwhile, the South conducted a large naval drill in a show of force.

headline: Smile Brands Pulls the Plug on I.P.O.
text: Smile Brands Group, the dental services provider, withdrew its plan for an initial public offering, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing late on Tuesday.

headline: European Union Proposes Crisis Levy on Banks
text: A European Union official proposed Wednesday that member states tax banks to raise money for a fund that would be used specifically to manage future financial crises.

headline: British Panel Reprimands Kraft Over Somerdale
text: The British Takeover Panel has criticized Kraft Foods for failing to meet the standards of the takeover code in statements made about Cadbury’s Somerdale plant, which Kraft had said it planned keep open, but then decided to close.

headline: Obama Extends Moratorium; Agency Chief Resigns
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama said on Thursday that he is extending the moratorium on permits to drill new deepwater wells for six more months, as the head of the agency that oversees offshore drilling resigned under pressure.

headline: Mahindra to Buy Stake in Electric Car Company
text: One of India’s largest automakers, Mahindra & Mahindra, said Wednesday that it would acquire a controlling stake in Reva, an electric car maker in Bangalore that has been looking for partners to invest in its technology, The New York Times’s Vikas Bajaj reported.

headline: Invoking Oil Crisis, Obama Lauds Clean Energy
text: From Jackie Calmes at Green:

headline: Amnesty Says Governments Aid Rights Abuses
text: HONG KONG — Powerful governments and political expediency are helping to perpetuate torture, war crimes and other human rights abuses around the world, Amnesty International said Thursday in its annual report.

headline: Gilt for Restaurants Comes to New York
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: Einhorn: Easy Money, Hard Truths
text: From David Einhorn, the head of Greenlight Capital, writing in The New York Times’s Opinion pages:

headline: Quadrangle May Sell Stake as It Raises New Fund
text: Quadrangle Group, a media-focused private equity firm, is looking to create a new fund, and could  sell a minority stake in itself or go into partnership with an “anchor tenant,” The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Deal Brewing for Pabst, Report Says
text: Pabst Brewing, the maker of Pabst Blue Ribbon and Schlitz, is in the final stages of a deal to sell itself to food investor C. Dean Metropoulos for about $250 million, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing sources familiar with the matter.

headline: New U.S. Strategy Focuses on Managing Threats
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s first formal national security strategy describes a coming era in which the United States will have to learn to live within its limits  a world in which two wars cannot be sustained for much longer and the rising powers inevitably begin to erode some elements of American influence around the globe.

headline: Under Siege by the Lobbyists
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Death Comes to Life at Paris Exhibition
text: All but the most squeamish should be fascinated by the exhibition “That’s Life! Vanities: From Caravaggio to Damien Hirst” at Musée Maillol (61, rue de Grenelle; 33-1-42-22-59-58; www.museemaillol.com) through June 28. The terms vanities and memento mori have, for centuries, referred to art that represents death; the label is derived from the warning of life’s fleeting nature in Ecclesiastes: “Vanity of vanities, vanity of vanities; all is vanity.” Skulls and skeletons make frequent appearances.

headline: Breaking the Mex Hex
text: A group of players called the country’s golden generation has started to pay some dividends at the senior level for Mexico, which habitually qualifies for the World Cup but suffers an early exit.

headline: Private Equity Fights Sales Clause in Tax Bill
text: Buyout shops are mounting a campaign to defeat a clause in a bill coming before the House on Thursday that would make it more expensive for fund managers to sell their stakes in the firms they run, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: UBS to Pay $2.2 Million in Michigan Settlement
text: Michigan said that UBS Securities and UBS Financial Services had agreed to pay about $2.2 million as part of a 2008 settlement related to the sale of auction-rate securities, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Man Group Says Assets Have Stabilized
text: Man Group, the hedge fund firm, said client assets had stabilized after a year of outflows, helped by a rebound in its flagship fund’s returns, indicating the firm may be benefiting from the wider industry’s upturn, Reuters reported.

headline: Tribune Plans $16 Million in Bonuses
text: The Tribune Company plans to pay top managers $16.2 million in bonuses and incentives when it exits bankruptcy under its plan of reorganization, Reuters reported, citing court documents.

headline: New Mexico’s New P.E. Investment Strategy
text: A state panel is revamping the investment strategy for New Mexico’s $13 billion permanent funds, including moving more capital in private equity, among other shifts, in the hopes of improving performance and ensuring they remain a stable source of financing for public education and other governmental programs, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Goldman Woes Said to Make Wealthy Clients Uneasy
text: The public spotlight on Goldman Sachs, which has been accused by regulators of fraud in connection with the design and marketing of a subprime mortgage security, is making things uncomfortable for the secretive bank’s wealth managers and may crack open the door for rivals looking to lure business away, Reuters reports.

headline: Soviet Evil, Hidden in Plain Sight
text: Today’s idea: Why do the world’s scholars ignore vast, unread troves of Soviet archives? A journalist says lingering leftist sympathies help explain the failure to unearth the evils of Communism the way those of the Nazis were laid bare.

headline: Are You Doing What You Truly Love?
text: I was going to write about what happened to our agency the first time we really sat down and came up with a wish list of clients, but my head and heart keep going back to something that happened Saturday night in Austin.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Car Viruses
text: This week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast takes a look at a new target for hackers: the car. Bettina Edelstein speaks to John Markoff, a Times reporter who has written about how vulnerable automotive computer systems are to malicious attacks. Computer security experts from the University of California, San Diego, and the University of Washington, backed by the National Science Foundation, were able to remotely take over car brakes and other critical controls. With modern vehicles increasingly dependent on computers, the researchers say, it’s important to address these issues before they become a problem.

headline: Asda Buys Netto in $1.1 Billion Deal
text: Asda Group, the British supermarket chain owned by Wal-Mart, has gone and done a little shopping of its own.

headline: Nokia and Five German Automakers Seek an App Standard
text: The more automakers work on integrating smartphones and their apps into the dashboard, the more confusing it gets. Just about every automaker is taking a different approach, creating headaches for drivers. One problem is that there is no industry standard, so Nokia and a group of five German automakers are proposing a new way of doing things.

headline: The Big 3 for Lookin at Lucky
text: Lookin at Lucky, who turns 3 years old today, has accomplished quite a bit in his young life. He won the 2-year-old title, the Grade II Rebel Stakes and the second leg of the Triple Crown.

headline: Somali Journalists Are Assaulted and Jailed
text: Security forces in Somalia’s semiautonomous Puntland region have attacked journalists covering the aftermath of recent rains, jailing several reporters and seriously beating others, witnesses said. On Wednesday, several journalists were filming and conducting interviews at the market in Boosaaso, Puntland’s main port, when a squad of security agents rounded them up. One cameraman said he was beaten in the face, kidneys and legs. Somalia, which has not had a fully functioning government since 1991, is one of the most dangerous places in the world for journalists. In recent years, dozens of Somali journalists have been assassinated or killed while covering their country’s civil war.

headline: How Much Oil Is on the Gulf Coast
text: Time-lapse map showing where oil is on the gulf coast.

headline: Amateur Hour for 2 Accused of Selling Disney Data?
text: What kind of Mickey Mouse outfit was that? The British blog, Here Is the City. is disgusted with the amateur performance of the boyfriend and girlfriend team accused of trying to sell confidential information about Walt Disney to several investment firms, including hedge funds.

headline: Pakistani Taliban Commander Reported Killed
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  One of the leading figures in Pakistan’s Taliban insurgency was believed killed during a clash with the Afghan police, who said his followers appeared to be trying to establish a new sanctuary in Afghanistan’s Nuristan Province.

headline: Your Jokes: ‘Identifying Sarcasm’
text: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Move Over, Polar Bear
text: Images of fluffy white polar bears may pull at heart strings, but a small mammal like the gopher might also be a worthy poster child in the battle against global warming, judging from some new research.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: It’s the day of the big vote on carried interest, and the question on everybody’s mind is whether hedge funds, private equity groups and venture capitalists will actually submit to some sort of equality under tax law, and what measures Congress will take to impose its will.

text: Video | TV reporter shattered by his lack of crime-simulation skill:

headline: Sampler: Oakland Gang Injunction Mulled, and Point Reyes Light Sold
text: Judge Weighs Gang Injunction | The latest effort by regional law enforcement authorities to use the court system to control gang violence will be under the microscope in Alameda County Superior Court, where officials will press for an injunction to control Oakland’s North Side gang. It would restrain 15 named individuals from a variety of activities, including weapons possession, trespassing and witness intimidation. It would also keep suspected gang members from associating with one another in a 100-block swath of the city and impose a curfew from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. In other Bay Area cities, like Fairfield, civil liberties groups have attacked such injunctions as violations of constitutional rights. In Oakland, opponents argue that an injunction would do little to curb crime and much to prompt racial profiling. A report in The Bay Citizen said that a series of at least four killings put law enforcement’s focus on the north Oakland group. [The Oakland Tribune, The New York Times, The Bay Citizen]Proposition Billed as Antidote to Polarization | Proposition 14, backed by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, is gaining traction. The initiative would replace traditional primaries in state and Congressional elections with twofold elections. All candidates would run in the first round. The top two vote-getters, regardless of party affiliation, or lack thereof, would face each other in the general election. Voters’ ultimate choice could be two Republicans or two Democrats, but it is likely that they would be the best-known or the wealthiest of the original field. Supporters say the measure would empower moderates and increase turnout. The state’s $19 billion deficit, high unemployment and low morale may help the measure’s chances; polls show a majority of voters favor it. [The New York Times]

headline: Q.&A.: Recording HBO Programs
text: Q.

headline: First-Quarter U.S.  Growth Revised Slightly Lower
text: The United States economy expanded at a slower rate in the first quarter than originally estimated, the Commerce Department reported Thursday, partly because of a slight decrease in the pace of consumer spending.

headline: Geithner Sees Consensus on Finance Reform
text: BERLIN  Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner said in Berlin on Thursday that the United States and Europe were in “broad agreement” on the need for stricter market regulation but stressed that they would take different paths when necessary.

headline: The Early Word: The President Answers
text: It’s been awhile, but President Obama will hold a formal news conference at the White House this afternoon.

headline: Drug Case Reaches From New York Into Jamaica
text: What we’re reading this morning:

headline: Our Unanswered Questions About the ‘American Idol’ Finale
text: Your new American Idol, Lee DeWyze. New American Idol Lee DeWyze. Lee DeWyze. The words still sound strange in our heads and on our tongues, hours after the 24-year-old Mr. DeWyze — hey, did you know he was once a local paint salesman? — prevailed over Crystal Bowersox to win the ninth season of “American Idol.” But that’s who the voters selected, and in time we’ll get used to it. (Probably.) In the meantime, here are 10 lingering mysteries about Wednesday night’s “American Idol” finale that we can’t solve quite as easily:

headline: A Little Help From His Friends:  Chandhok’s Lucky Egg
text: I think I should start doing a regular feature on this blog called “A little help from his friends.” At the Bahrain Grand Prix I was pleased to see four of  Nico Rosberg’s friends from his school days perform a little good luck dance for the driver right before the race.

headline: Paleoconservatism Revisited
text: Daniel Larison has a sharply-worded response to my remarks on “paleoconservatism at its worst.” Let me de-escalate a bit, and just make a couple of points.

headline: Seeing Things | Richard Hawkins’s Haunted Houses
text: What do cute Japanese boys have to do with haunted houses?

text: On Wednesday, I mentioned four big issues to watch as the House and Senate try to put together a final financial regulation bill. But, obviously, there are more than four issues that matter. David A. Levine — an investor and economist in New York, formerly with Sanford C. Bernstein — offers this additional idea in an e-mail message:

headline: Another View: Market Makers Help Halt Crashes
text: Michael S. Pagano, a finance professor at the Villanova School of Business, argues that the key to preventing another flash crash may lie in preserving a role for market makers at the largest exchanges.

headline: Hey, Mr. Critic!
text: Want to know what it’s like to be the restaurant critic of The New York Times? It’s a lot of eating, a lot of time at the gym and about 37 e-mail messages a day from friends, distant relatives, acquaintances, the spouse, the children, the boss and the boss’s boss asking where to secure a reservation for six people tonight at 8 on the West Side, appropriate for both infants and a C.F.O., that maybe serves Asian food or possibly Italian, though not fish and not too expensive, fun but not terribly loud. (Tell that jackanape: Ruby Foo’s!)

headline: U.S. Markets Rebound; S.&P. Rises 3.3%
text: Once again, the stock market swung wildly on Thursday  only this time, it swung up, rather than down.

headline: Are Churches Exempt From the Law’s Requirements?
text: Q.

headline: Kicking Back With Twitter’s Co-Founder
text: Biz Stone co-founded the micro-blogging service Twitter with Evan Williams in 2007. They met seven years ago when they both worked at Google. Stone earned an arts scholarship to the University of Massachusetts but dropped out to work as a designer at the book publisher Little, Brown in Boston.

headline: Popcast: The Rolling Stones, Karen Elson and More
text: This week: Ben Ratliff discusses the Rolling Stones with the singer Ian Svenonius, and Jon Pareles reviews Karen Elson’s debut. Ben Sisario is the host.

headline: Geithner Sees International Consensus on Finance Reform
text: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner said in Berlin on Thursday that the United States and Europe were in “broad agreement” on the need for financial regulatory reform but stressed that they would take different paths when necessary, The New York Times’s Judy Dempsey reported.

headline: Dorm Rooms With Bragging Rights
text: As college-bound seniors look forward to the schools they will call home next fall, it is a good bet that many have no idea just how steeped in history their future homes are.

headline: Sarah Burton: New Creative Director at McQueen
text: Gucci Group has made it official: Sarah Burton will take over design responsibilities at Alexander McQueen. She’s the only person really qualified for the job. She was a student at Central Saint Martins in London when she began working in 1996 in Mr. McQueen’s studio as part of a work-study program. As she told me in March, “We got on very well and he said, ‘Why don’t you just stay?’ I went back to school for a year and I continued working there at the same time. He completely taught me everything.”

headline: British Hostages in Somalia Appeal for Help
text: In a video interview with a Somali journalist working for Britain’s ITN, two British citizens who have been held in Somalia since they were kidnapped from their yacht by pirates last October near the Seychelles, said that their captors are hoping Britain’s new government will be more willing than the previous one to pay a ransom for their release.

headline: Well Suited | Pret-a-Surf
text: Mondrian and vintage floral wallpaper are not the usual references that come to mind when one imagines women’s surf wear. It took two fashion insiders, Jillian Demling, an editor at Vogue, and Karen Mulligan, Annie Leibovitz’s longtime studio manager, to finally take the mall out of surf with their new line Pret-a Surf. Functional rash guards come in graphic Warhol era op-art, a 1950’s cut gingham bikini is engineered to stay put in the worst wipeouts and board shorts are done in a vintage wallpaper pattern.

headline: Tibetan Gets Suspended Death Sentence in China
text: A Chinese court has handed down a suspended death sentence to a Tibetan man accused of taking part in the riots that ravaged the Tibetan capital more than two years ago, the state news media reported.

headline: 36 Hours in Genoa, Italy
text: TELL people you’re planning to spend part of your Italian vacation in Genoa, and you’ll most likely get an incredulous “Why?” Until a few years ago, Genoa was far more grit than glamour  a way station to more fabulous places like Cinque Terre. And its industrial port was among the more forgettable spots along the Italian Riviera. But a complete scrub-down and restoration of its once seedy waterfront, combined with an influx of young, well-funded entrepreneurs, has made Genoa a city bustling with cosmopolitan wine bars and restaurants. Sure, you won’t confuse Genoa with Milan, but it doesn’t want you to.

headline: On Our Radar: A School Board Fight
text: A school board battle over global warming brews in Colorado.

headline: For Vlasic, It’s a Stork of a Different Color
text: One of the more interesting developments in advertising since the economy went south has been the return of familiar brand slogans, jingles and characters, the better to appeal to nervous consumers who may find nostalgia soothing. At the same time, brands do not want to invoke the past too much, for fear of seeming like fuddy-duddys.

headline: Writers for Conan O’Brien Get Their Own Show (for a Night)
text: These days, being a writer for Conan O’Brien would seem to be as synonymous with idleness as being a Maytag repairman or a BP thank-you-note writer. But the writers for the former “Tonight Show” host and future TBS star are putting their downtime to productive use: after Mr. O’Brien completes his Legally Prohibited From Being Funny on Television Tour, his writers will perform a live show in Chicago that will be broadcast on TBS at the end of June.

headline: 50 Years of ‘To Kill a Mockingbird’
text: As Julie Bosman reports,

headline: Bowery Presents to Produce Concerts in Maine
text: The Bowery is expanding to Maine.

headline: BP Resumes Work to Plug Oil Leak After Facing Setback
text: HOUSTON  BP on Thursday night restarted its most ambitious effort yet to plug the oil leak in the Gulf of Mexico, trying to revive hopes that it might cap the well with a “top kill” technique that involved pumping heavy drilling liquids to counteract the pressure of the gushing oil.

headline: Thursday Reading: Extend the Life of Your Home Appliances
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: If Hamsters Love Kia, Which Brand Do the Gerbils Drive?
text: The hamsters that helped introduce the Kia Soul as “a new way to roll” are returning for the second phase of the campaign, which is intended to appeal to younger drivers who are interested in competing models like the Nissan Cube and Scion xB.

headline: Fans of Knicks and Nets Show Some Optimism
text: When LeBron James and the Cleveland Cavaliers were knocked out of the N.B.A. playoffs two weeks ago, Knicks fans rejoiced. By failing again to win a championship, James was more likely to leave Cleveland when he becomes a free agent this summer and sign with New York, they reasoned.

headline: Where Do You Get Parenting Knowledge?
text: How much do you understand about your child’s development? Not as much as you might think, says a study for Zero to Three, which is a research and advocacy organization for infants, toddlers and families. Its survey of 1,615 families, released this month, found striking “gaps in knowledge,” among them:

headline: Quote Unquote | Hide and Chic
text: – Daphne Guinness discusses her shoe choices with the London Times. Her choice of hair color is another story.

headline: My (Brief) Life as a Robot
text: On Wednesday I attended a Silicon Valley press conference dressed as a robot.

headline: ‘Stop and Frisk’ vs. Privacy, and Good News for Kelly

headline: Despite Protests, Elton John Performs in Morocco
text: Defying the protests of a conservative religious party that sought to ban his performance, Elton John played a concert in Rabat, Morocco, on Wednesday night as the headliner of that nation’s largest music festival, Reuters reported. Morocco’s Justice and Development Party (PJD), a fundamentalist Muslim organization, had complained that the appearance of Mr. John, who is gay, at the weeklong Mawazine World Rhythms Festival would reflect badly on the country and advocate homosexuality. “We’re a rather open party,” Mustapha Ramid, a PJD spokesman, told The Associated Press, “but promoting homosexuality is completely unacceptable.”

headline: Towns Challenge New Jersey Voters’ Wishes
text: After years of frustration over school taxes, New Jersey residents turned out in record numbers last month to reject 58 percent of their school districts’ budget proposals, sounding an unmistakable protest.

text: A once-prominent hedge fund, Pequot Capital Management, and its chief executive, Arthur J. Samberg, agreed on Thursday to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission complaint accusing them of insider trading involving Microsoft shares, The New York Times reported.

text: PARIS  Ask Jürgen Melzer, the Austrian left-hander, to name the shot that gives him the most pleasure in tennis, and the answer is not an ace or a forehand winner.

headline: Does Fashion Need Copyright Protection?
text: Johanna Blakley, of the University of Southern California’s Norman Lear Center, recently gave a TED talk on the “culture of copying” in fashion, and why this industry (in addition to those for some other creative works, like food preparation) has been able to thrive even without copyright protection.

headline: Theater Talkback: Remembering Michael Kuchwara
text: The Broadway marquees went dark at curtain time on Tuesday night, in tribute to Michael Kuchwara, the Associated Press theater critic and reporter who died on Saturday.

headline: Hearing Footsteps in Boston
text: These are stressful days in Boston. Yes, the Red Sox are pulling themselves off the mat, Boston Common looks like it’s posing for its spring postcard photos and reminding everyone why they live there, and the Patriots haven’t spied on anyone in a while. But the N.H.L./N.B.A. playoff season has not been kind, and Dwight Howard’s elbows delivered another painful dose of reality Wednesday night.

headline: Poll: Wide Majority See Spill as ‘Disaster’
text: Just ahead of President Obama’s news conference today and his visit to the Gulf Coast on Friday, a new USA Today/Gallup poll finds most Americans rating the president’s response to the oil spill negatively. A broad majority believes the long-term impact of the oil spill will be a “disaster,” and the public is closely tuned into the situation.

headline: Feeling For … The Summer Chukka Boot
text: I was “Feeling For” Clark’s desert boots last year and continue to wear my sand suede shoes on a daily basis, with rolled up jeans and khakis (also previously “felt for” here). Now with summer arriving next week, I’m excited about a new take on my tried and true uniform: the summer chukka boot. Keds, makers of the classic canvas sneaks, have introduced the Champion Chukka, a high-top spin on their low-top. It’s a sleek take on the desert boot, done in breathable, lightweight canvas with a molded rubber bottom. The boots come in a bunch of colors, allowing you to coordinate, clash, neutralize or pop at will. I’m partial to the navy, which will blend with a rolled up jean or be a bit more of an exclamation point with a slender, rolled-up chino. The pale grey is another favorite, more akin to its tonal cousin in suede. These sneaks are also the perfect pairing for shorts, from Bermudas to cargos. Just ditch the socks.

text: Nickname for the impending expiry of a range of lucrative pharmaceutical patents.

headline: Estimates Suggest Spill Is Biggest in U.S. History
text: Federal officials said Thursday that far more oil than they originally estimated was probably pouring into the Gulf of Mexico on a daily basis since the collapse of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig.

headline: How to Save on College Housing

Last year, with the help of an $8,000 first-time home buyers’ tax credit and a home equity loan that Mr. Hurley took out on his home, Chris bought an $80,000 three-bedroom home near his college.

headline: The Morning Line: Burgers at Saratoga
text: It is not every day that the big story in racing is about food, but in New York the story is that renowned restaurateur Danny Meyer is bringing his Union Square Hospitality Group’s Shake Shack and Blue Smoke to Saratoga. The headlines in New York’s Capital District turned from news of the beleaguered to New York Racing Association to news of burgers, brisket, and beer. Meyer told the Albany Times Union “There’s only three years that I have missed drinking from the springs since I was 16… My body is at this point made up a lot of Saratoga minerals.” Not to say that horse racing lacks a major celebrity following, but this means that the three non-sports celebrity regulars at Saratoga are now Danny Meyer, Bobby Flay, and David Cassidy. (Saratoga used to have Mike Vale who had to get up early to make the donuts for Dunkin’ Donuts, but he passed away in 2005.)

headline: Refusing to Pay for Complications
text: A number of insurers, including Medicare and Medicaid, no longer pay doctors to treat complications “that could reasonably have been prevented.” These are often called “never events,” because they should never have happened.

headline: Who Pays for Medical Complications?
text: One afternoon during my surgical training, I received a call from an intern, a first-year doctor-in-training; she wanted me to place a central line, a specialized catheter inserted in a major vein for intravenous access. Because of the patient’s previous procedures, I would have to put his line in the subclavian vein, a vessel that courses along the top of the chest, precariously close to the lungs.

headline: Between Raindrops, Krumm Is Eliminated
text: PARIS — After rain delayed the start of play at the French Open for nearly five hours on Thursday, the tarps finally came off and five women managed to win their matches in little more than an hour: just in time to beat the next rain delay.

headline: On Leaving Children

headline: Service Members Share Thoughts on Leaving Families
text: The New York Times again invites members of the military who are serving, or have served, in Afghanistan to help us document the daily life of this war in photographs, video and writing. Take us on a tour of the FOB, introduce us to your friends, describe the hardships of deployment and the humor that helps you pass the time.

headline: A Monument to Hope, but Also Sorrow
text: The occasion was the rehabilitation of the Foreign Ministry, badly damaged in a large-scale attack nine months ago. Ambassadors and reporters were invited for the occasion. “The rise from ashes is symbolic, it is not a promotion to the ministry, it is a promotion to the Iraqi people in defying their enemy” the Iraqi foreign minister, Hoshyar Zebari, said in his welcoming speech.

headline: Inside the Hermès Design Choice
text: Hermès isn’t just the gold standard for well-made products; it’s also one of the few family-run companies in fashion. It can afford to do things a little differently. Yesterday’s announcement that the Paris house had hired Christophe Lemaire for women’s ready to wear, succeeding Jean Paul Gaultier, raised a few eyebrows. It’s a bit of an unconventional choice, given that Mr. Lemaire, at Lacoste for the last decade, isn’t a big name like Mr. Gaultier or his predecessor Martin Margiela. This morning I spoke to Pierre-Alexis Dumas, the general artistic director of Hermès — and a sixth-generation member of the family — about the thinking behind the choice.

headline: New York City Ballet Announces 2010-2011 Season
text: For the first time in its history New York City Ballet will present a fall season in September and October at Lincoln Center. The company, which has previously presented a repertory season that started in November, opens its 2010-2011 season on Sept. 14 at the David H. Koch Theater, and it will feature performances of 28 different ballets, including 13 works by George Balanchine and 5 by Jerome Robbins. Other highlights of the fall run, which continues through Oct. 10, include a New York premiere by the choreographer Benjamin Millepied and a revival of “The Magic Flute” by the company’s ballet master in chief, Peter Martins. The annual presentation of “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker” begins on Nov. 26 and runs through Jan. 2, and a six-week winter repertory season opens on Jan. 18. Other highlights of the season include a new work by Susan Stroman, and the previously announced new production of “The Seven Deadly Sins,” by Lynne Taylor-Corbett, featuring Patti LuPone in her New York City Ballet debut. In addition, the 2010-2011 season will feature ballets by Melissa Barak, Mauro Bigonzetti, Wayne McGregor, Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon and a full-length staging of Tchaikovsky’s “Swan Lake” by Mr. Martins.

headline: Deadlock Pushes Nepal to Brink of a Political Crisis

headline: The Sumi-E Brush Painting School Closes

As a person who for more than four decades has watched from the beaches and causeways as explorers flew into space, I can testify this is an experience well worth the effort.

headline: Scientists Challenge ‘Breakthrough’ on  Fossil Skeleton
text: The fossil skeleton known as Ardi, hailed in some quarters as the scientific “breakthrough” of 2009, has now drawn critics who dispute claims that the species lived in dense woodlands rather than grassy plains, which have been long considered the favored habitat of early prehumans and perhaps account for their transition to upright walking.

headline: Leaving the Nest, Protégés Find Fame
text: IN the video, on YouTube, Madonna is seen laying the first brick at a school in Lilongwe, Malawi. But to connoisseurs of architecture, the real star of the video is the man standing next to Madonna, alongside a rendering of the 40-acre campus. He is Markus Dochantschi, the German-born, New York-based designer of what is called the Raising Malawi Academy for Girls.
