headline: A Plea for Plundered Rosewood
text: Two days ago, I wrote in The Times about the appalling rosewood situation in Madagascar, where timber barons are taking advantage of a weak and unstable government to loot the rain forest of trees found nowhere else on earth. The wood is turned into high-end furniture by the Chinese.

headline: Excavating Ardi
text: Scientists said Ardi, short for Ardipithecus ramidus, was the earliest known skeleton from the human branch of the primate family tree.

headline: At P. J. Clarke’s, the Bartender of Your Dreams
text: My mother had eyes in the back of her head; Doug Quinn must have them in the palms of his hands. How else to explain the way he muddled mint for a mojito  and went on to make the rest of the cocktail  while glancing alternately at the door to see if anyone new was coming in, at the far end of the bar to see if anyone was telegraphing thirst, and at the guy in front of him, who was babbling anew about something or other? Not once did Mr. Quinn look down at the drink. It was like bartending in Braille.

headline: U.N. to Pull 2,000 Peacekeepers From Congo, Draft Resolution Says
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  After a long and tense debate with the Democratic Republic of Congo, the United Nations has decided to withdraw 2,000 peacekeepers, far fewer than Congolese officials wanted, according to a draft resolution.

headline: The Tipsy Diaries: Ask the Bartender
text: Doug Quinn, 42, has been tending bar at the original P.J. Clarke’s on Third Avenue only since 2003. But in that time, he has become a legend, the bartenders’ bartender, as I describe in the inaugural edition of “The Tipsy Diaries,” a column about the city’s drinking life that will appear in the newspaper’s Weekend section every other Friday.

headline: Bad Analysis At The Deficit Commission
text: The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities worries that the Obama budget commission is already giving ammunition to the deficit crazies; it cites testimony by Carmen Reinhart claiming that gross debt, not debt owed to the public, is the right measure. I agree that this is off base.

headline: Succession May Be Behind N. Korea’s New Belligerence
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Over the years, South Korean officials and analysts have grown accustomed to the North Koreans’ habit of stirring up trouble, whether through missile launchings or nuclear tests. And when faced with international censure, the North lashes out with threats of retaliation and even war. Typically, it is an attention-getting tactic, the South Koreans say, used to win diplomatic and economic concessions.

headline: Dinner and a Show
text: The Lion has been generating buzz for its crowd and its burger (fried pork belly and two cheeses never hurt), but has anyone checked out the art? Basquiats mix with black-and-white photographs from the Daily News archives; a 17th-century oil painting hangs above a line drawing of a lion. David LaChapelle’s portrait of Andy Warhol is positioned next to thrift-store finds and a photograph by a bartender at the Waverly Inn. The walls are so packed, “Someone might never notice the picture of the monk hitting the baseball,” sighs chef and owner John DeLucie.

headline: Before the Sword Fights, Cue the Harem Girls
text: First the United States invaded the Middle East, and now Hollywood has swooped in to finish the job: one day after the “Sex and the City” ladies landed in the Abu Dhabi doo-doo, setting off a dust storm of critical hate, “Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time” seems primed to raise huffy hackles with a swords-and-sandals-style spectacular in ancient Iran. Based on a gulf-war-era video game, “Prince of Persia” stars Jake Gyllenhaal as the titular warrior who, scrambling up walls and vaulting across roofs amid camels, pomegranates and whirling dervishes, helps lead the search in wartime for, Praise Bruckheimer, weapons of not-quite-mass destruction.

headline: Gulf Forecast: Oil, Water and Wind
text: 4:57 p.m. | Updated After several years of relatively somnolent hurricane seasons in the Atlantic Ocean, conditions have aligned to create a heightened storm threat this summer and fall. If the season plays out as forecast, this will almost certainly complicate the months-long effort needed to insure the closure of the gushing seabed oil well and limit the spread of resulting slicks. (The Pacific and Atlantic often have opposite patterns of storminess and, sure enough, the forecast in the eastern Pacific is for a below-normal season.)

headline: Gang Leader Still Eludes Police as Death Toll in Jamaica Rises

headline: Beach Visit Turns Up a Remnant of Youth
text: “Dusk Rings a Bell,” Stephen Belber’s new play at Atlantic Stage 2, begins with a lengthy, vaguely annoying monologue that Kate Walsh delivers with an irksome self-consciousness. The blathering goes on long enough that you begin to mourn the 90 minutes of your life that you’re about to lose. But then something surprising happens: Ms. Walsh’s co-star in this two-hander, Paul Sparks, shows up, and so does the real play, which evolves into a sublime, beautifully acted drama.

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
text: On Thursday, French workers protested plans to raise the retirement age. The demonstration speaks to a wider trend across Western Europe, the “lifestyle superpower,” where the assumptions and gains of a lifetime are suddenly in doubt, as Steven Erlanger of The Times has written. The deficit crisis that threatens the euro has also undermined the sustainability of the European standard of social welfare, built by left-leaning governments since the end of World War II.

headline: Restaurant Review: Balsan, in Chicago

This French-inflected brasserie in the new Elysian Hotel in Chicago charts a different course, offering dishes like house-made headcheese and veal-heart salad (below).

text: WHEN Kari Sigerson and Miranda Morrison were looking on the Upper East Side for a place to showcase their Sigerson Morrison shoes and house the works of up-and-coming artists, they came upon 19 East 71st Street.

headline: Easing That Electromagnetic Anxiety
text: A few weeks ago, I invited a “building biology” consultant into my East Village apartment to evaluate the place for  toxic elements — lurking in the water, the air and under the refrigerator — and offer a diagnosis, which led to my article today in The New York Times. “Building biology” is a European import that originated in postwar Germany, where in the flurry of new housing construction, the inhabitants of new dwellings began to suffer from what would become known as “sick building syndrome.”

headline: Air Canada Partners With Hotwire
text: Air Canada is having a good month. The airline just partnered with Hotwire, an online travel site, to give Hotwire customers flying to and from Canada hundreds of more routes to choose from. Air Canada was also named “Best Airline in North America” by Skytrax, an independent research firm that surveyed 17 million air travelers.

headline: 1 Composer, 2 Centuries, Many Picks
text: The classical music world, embarked on a bicentennial tour through the Romantic era, is just now preoccupied with the melancholic master Frédéric Chopin, born near Warsaw in 1810. Beloved by pianists for his abundant legacy, he is cherished by countless others for the teeming worlds of color and emotion he conjured. The classical music critics of The New York Times have combed through the many recordings devoted to Chopin and selected their favorites.

headline: Deal Reached to Reopen Closed State Parks
text: Just in time for the ritual lighting of the grills this weekend, the governor and the Legislature reached an agreement to reopen the 58 state parks and historic sites that closed last week, casualties of the state’s budget crisis.

headline: Lensbaby Control Freak Delivers Even More Precise Focus
text: Selective focus, which creates cool effects by pinpointing a precise area of focus and blurring the rest of the image, is a very fun technique. And Lensbaby, the company that brought this trick to the masses, has a new model that it says gives even more precise control over focusing.

headline: One Match, Two Days, Lots of Tension
text: The most entertaining and contentious match of the French Open’s first five days finally came to a close Thursday evening, as Italy’s Fabio Fognini beat France’s Gaël Monfils in an extended fifth set that took nearly 24 hours to play because of darkness and rain delays.

headline: Fangs and Other Fluff, Completely Guilt Free
text: Memorial Day marks the start of a special season: the time to stop lying about what you read for fun. Call anything a beach book, and suddenly you’ve got an excuse for being seen with it. No need to claim you’re reading Christopher Farnsworth’s “Blood Oath,” about the president’s personal vampire, only because there’s a wait at your library for a copy of “The Road.”

headline: F.D.A. Weighs Penalties in Drug Recall
text: The Johnson & Johnson unit that recalled millions of bottles of liquid children’s Tylenol and other pediatric medicines last month may face criminal penalties, product seizures or other sanctions, an official from the Food and Drug Administration said Thursday.

headline: Inside, Rivers of Blood
text: It looks so cute and small and quaint from the outside. Is that classical music playing? How nice. The only real hint of the vast and bloody body count behind the door at 44 Greenwich Avenue is the wee bit of crime-scene tape that decorates the display window.

headline: City Slickers Take to the Crops, With Song
text: IT was prime growing weather on Shelter Island, N.Y., as a breeze blew in from Dering Harbor, and Bennett Konesni was tending to his field of dreams: three neatly planted acres of bok choy, cauliflower, kale, Asian mustard greens, spinach, garlic, lettuce, onions, potatoes and leeks, with room for the peppers, eggplants and 15 varieties of tomatoes soon to be transplanted. Coming to a plot of leafy snap peas, inspiration struck. Suddenly he erupted in a full-throttle rendition of “Oats, Peas, Beans and Barley Grow”: “Do you, or I, or anyone know/How oats, peas, beans and barley grow?”

headline: Student of Homicide Is Charged in Three Murders
text: LONDON  In a grisly case that British newspapers have compared to the Yorkshire Ripper murders of the 1970s, the police on Thursday charged a 40-year-old man pursuing a Ph.D. in 19th-century homicides with the murders of three women identified by the police as prostitutes.

headline: Materialism in Paint and in Culture
text: Death and transcendence always have been the pole stars of Richard Prince’s art. His photographs of cowboys in gorgeous landscapes pirated from Marlboro ads are shadowed by lung cancer and heart disease. The pictures of biker molls swing between erotic love and soul-killing misogyny. The joke paintings? They career from human comedy to mind-numbing vulgarity. The muscle cars? From chariots of the gods to profane vehicles of male vanity and ecological destruction.

headline: Coach’s Departure Makes Grown Men Cry
text: Updated Is the feeling that a great coach inspires in his players something like love? That question seems natural to ask after viewing a brief behind-the-scenes clip recorded last week at a soccer stadium in Europe, which has now gone viral, with over a million views on YouTube in two days. The video, embedded above, shows a player and a coach, both known for their on-field toughness, breaking down in sobs as they said goodbye after their last game together.

But unfortunately for former President Clinton, the film’s title, “The Special Relationship,” refers to his partnership not with his wife but with Tony Blair, the former British prime minister.

headline: Going Home Again, if to a New House
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Before the climactic fireworks display at the New Meadowlands Stadium on Wednesday night, before the acoustic miniset and the biggest of many rousing choruses, Bon Jovi ran into technical difficulties. Not that anyone onstage seemed to notice. Shortly into “Runaway,” the song Bon Jovi fans know as the Book of Genesis, the sound died everywhere except the monitors. The band played on, distantly, as if a mute button had been pressed, and the crowd did its best to compensate.

Neighborhood Joint, a new series of articles, makes its debut in this week’s Sunday Metropolitan section. Each installment will focus on one such gem, every one unique and worth the trek.

headline: When Life Starts to Unspool for a Passionate French Filmmaker
text: The poignant, startling French film “The Father of My Children” opens with a whoosh of activity. A financially struggling independent-movie producer, Grégoire Canvel (Louis-Do de Lencquesaing), is driving through Paris, trying to keep the different parts of his life in play. He’s talking  he’s always talking  taking one call after another with a cellphone cradled under an ear. But what he’s really doing is juggling, a tricky proposition, given that he’s holding a cigarette in one hand, carelessly tending to the wheel with the other hand, while a stream of bad news from his creditors and various projects pours into his ear like poison.

headline: The Hazards of Golf: Bunkers, Water and Now Carts
text: It is a subject that has come up before, but it appears the most dangerous thing you can do on the golf course has something to do with a golf cart. The number of injuries sustained by people riding in a cart, driving a cart or being struck by a cart — all while trying to relax on a golf course — is nothing short of astonishing.

headline: Obama Assailed on Wreath Laying
text: President Obama’s long holiday weekend in Chicago is creating a ruckus among his conservative critics, who are accusing him of skipping out on the traditional Memorial Day wreath-laying ceremony at Arlington National Ceremony – a yearly ritual for his predecessor, George W. Bush.

headline: Will Wall Street Go Free?
text: Let me try to get this straight. The Justice Department announced last weekend that it has dropped its criminal investigation into wrongdoing by the former executives of American International Group Financial Products, or A.I.G.-F.P. — the group inside A.I.G. that foolishly decided to insure billions of dollars of risk in the mortgage market, and got paid millions of dollars for doing so. So the Obama administration, which has repeatedly pilloried banking executives in an effort to build support for its financial reform package, has in one step reduced exponentially the chances of actually holding people on Wall Street accountable for the financial crisis, which was an utterly preventable self-inflicted wound. This is simply incomprehensible.

headline: Never Say Never: Jeffery Deaver to Write New James Bond Novel
text: The next James Bond book will be written by Jeffery Deaver, the best-selling thriller writer, Simon & Schuster announced on Thursday. The novel, with the working title “Project X,” is expected to be set in the present day and take Bond to at least three “exotic locations around the globe.” It is scheduled for publication in May 2011. Mr. Deaver, the author of “The Bone Collector” and “Garden of Beasts,” said in a statement that he was thrilled to be asked by representatives of the Ian Fleming estate to write the book. “The novel will maintain the persona of James Bond as Fleming created him and the unique tone the author brought to his books, while incorporating my own literary trademarks: detailed research, fast pacing and surprise twists.” The book will be published by Hodder & Stoughton in Britain and Simon & Schuster in the United States. More than 100 million Bond books have been sold.

headline: Misfits Battle the Masters of War
text: Bazil, the hero of Jean-Pierre Jeunet’s new film, “Micmacs,” is a mild-mannered fellow with a serious grudge. When he was a child, he lost his father, a member of the French Foreign Legion, to a land mine. Sometime later, after a stint in an orphanage, the adult Bazil (Dany Boon) is minding his own business, working the night shift at a video store and reciting Humphrey Bogart’s French-dubbed dialogue in “The Big Sleep,” when a stray bullet pierces his forehead, nearly killing him.

headline: Fumblers and Dreamers
text: “Our best recyclers are in California,” declares one of the characters in Evgenia Citko­witz’s coruscating story collection. “That sadly includes its writers.” Meant as a barb, it’s also an archly self-deprecating gesture, since Citkowitz happens to live in Cali­fornia. But, really, what writer doesn’t recycle? Although Citkowitz trawls familiar territory (a schoolgirl engineers a sexual encounter with a teacher; a blocked writer marries a starlet half his age; an aimless, privileged woman is abandoned by her husband), what she does with this material is unexpected and often startling.

headline: John Finn, Medal of Honor Winner, Dies at 100
text: John W. Finn, the last survivor of the 15 Navy men who received the Medal of Honor for heroism during the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, died Thursday at a nursing home in Chula Vista, Calif. He was 100 and had been the oldest living recipient of the medal, the nation’s highest award for valor.

headline: What Happened to Valor?
text: ON NOV. 15, 2004, several Marines in dress uniforms came to Rosa Peralta’s San Diego home to tell her that her 25-year-old son, Marine Sgt. Rafael Peralta, had been killed in Falluja, Iraq, by an improvised explosive device. Rosa Peralta was widowed three years earlier when her husband, a mechanic, was crushed to death in a freak accident while working on a garbage truck; now her son’s death seemed every bit as senseless.

headline: House Votes to Allow ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Repeal
text: WASHINGTON — The House voted Thursday to let the Defense Department repeal the ban on gay and bisexual people from serving openly in the military, a major step toward dismantling the 1993 law widely known as “don’t ask, don’t tell.”

headline: Letters: Cass Sunstein Wants to Nudge Us
text: The libertarian nudging espoused by Cass Sunstein sounds like a happier and more effective way to get things done than the paternalistic dictatorialism so pervasive on all sides of today’s legislative and policy divides. Where Sunstein’s notion involves understanding and leveraging human nature to promote essential behavior change, the governing mantra on topics like safe cellphone use, resource conservation and health care reform consistently seems to hinge on the imposition of iron-fisted mandates backed by punishments for noncompliance. This isn’t to argue that both pleasure and pain cannot have a role in affecting widely distributed individual actions. But social and environmental-marketing case history is replete with successes that came because policy makers clearly perceived the true strategic value of inspiring people to do the right thing before pulling out the big Draconian stick. In the world of governance, I think the technical name for that approach is “leadership.”JEF LOEBSan Francisco

headline: A Melody Teases, Tantalizes and Hints at a Man’s Longing for Love
text: Characters suppressing volcanic emotions that can be decoded only by reading expressions and body language give Stéphane Brizé’s “Mademoiselle Chambon” a complexity and tension that transcend words. A questioning look exchanged and held for a half-second, the trembling of a lower lip, a stride that is a little too purposeful, a conversation that breaks into an uncomfortable silence: these are the signs of potentially life-altering choices and incipient chaos seething under the placid surfaces of bourgeois lives.

headline: Letters: Putting a Price on Words
text: Andrew Rice writes that the creator of True/Slant picked “its name off a list of compound words that were made up by a Web developer.” Surely, though, the anonymous developer borrowed that particular pairing of words from Emily Dickinson:Tell all the Truth but tell it slant —Success in Circuit liesToo bright for our infirm DelightThe Truth’s superb surprise.

headline: Letter: Metric Mania
text: “Do we expect too much from our data?” asks John Allen Paulos, as he cleverly critiques the benefits and biases inherent in the collection of data used in the formation of public policy. You might conclude that it depends on what you want to do with it: there are those who are careful in aggregating data — physicians, for example, performing clinical trials used in the practice of evidence-based medicine. And there are those who gainfully believe in what Nassim Nicholas Taleb calls “black swans”; investors, for example, who successfully play the financial markets as unpredictable, regarding serious downturns as random events.JONATHAN H. ZINS, M.D.Westport, Conn.

headline: Letters: The Rise and Fall of the G.D.P.
text: Jon Gertner’s article on measuring well-being quoted me correctly as saying that the adverse impact of economic adversity on the social fabric goes well beyond the lost monetary income and endures much longer than joblessness itself. An unfortunate omission, however, left the impression that the underlying research was entirely my own, although I had made clear that it was not.

headline: Maybe These Zombies Need to Focus on Their Veggies
text: “Survival of the Dead” is George A. Romero’s sixth zombie outing, and he and his old-school critters seem tired. Maybe we’ve become too accustomed to the zipping, hectic ghouls that terrorized films like “28 Days Later,” but Mr. Romero’s lumbering corpses, arms outstretched in drunken supplication, no longer scare. They’re like the old friends you see every couple of years who have really let themselves go.

headline: Introduction to Simone de Beauvoir’s ‘The Second Sex’
text: In 1946, Simone de Beauvoir began to outline what she thought would be an autobiographical essay explaining why, when she had tried to define herself, the first sentence that came to mind was “I am a woman.” That October, my maiden aunt, Beauvoir’s contemporary, came to visit me in the hospital nursery. I was a day old, and she found a little tag on my bassinet that announced, “It’s a Girl!” In the next bassinet was another newborn (“a lot punier,” she recalled), whose little tag announced, “I’m a Boy!” There we lay, innocent of a distinction — between a female object and a male subject — that would shape our destinies. It would also shape Beauvoir’s great treatise on the subject.

headline: Dispatches From the Other
text: In 1946, when Simone de Beauvoir began to write her landmark study of women, “The Second Sex,” legislation allowing French women to vote was little more than a year old. Birth control would be legally denied them until 1967. Next door, in Switzerland, women would not be enfranchised until 1971. Such repressive circumstances account for both the fierce, often wrathful urgency of Beauvoir’s book and the vehement controversies this founding text of feminism aroused when it was first published in France in 1949 and in the United States in 1953. The Vatican placed it on the Index of Forbidden Books. Albert Camus complained that Beauvoir made Frenchmen look ridiculous. On these shores, the novelist Philip Wylie eulogized it as “one of the few great books of our era,” the psychiatrist Karl Menninger found it “pretentious” and “tiresome,” and a reviewer in The Atlantic Monthly faulted it for being “bespattered with the repulsive lingo of existentialism.”

text: CLEVELAND  Imagine a high school where baseball is the only curriculum. How many boys would love that? No more pencils, no more books, only fastballs, changeups and hooks?

headline: A Chain Bets You’re Going to Like the Way Its New Campaign Looks
text: FOR almost as long as there have been television commercials, there have been commercials that consumers love to hate. Whether deemed boring, annoying, repetitive, corny or amateurish, such spots are recalled almost as much as  if not more so than  the commercials that consumers love to love.

headline: The President Confronts the Spill
text: President Obama’s news conference on Thursday was partly a political exercise aimed at showing that his administration is on top of the unfolding disaster in the Gulf of Mexico. But what really mattered were Mr. Obama’s promises to call a timeout on coastal drilling and to shape up the federal bureaucracy, strengthen oversight of the drilling industry and do whatever else is required to prevent similar catastrophes in the future.

headline: Troops and the Border
text: President Obama made a surprise decision on Tuesday to send 1,200 additional National Guard troops to the border with Mexico and seek more money to combat drug smuggling. It followed a testy meeting with Republican senators, many of whom have been pressing the administration to take drastic action to lock down the border.

headline: Near Ground Zero, the Sacred and the Profane
text: Since long before the Islamist terrorist attack of Sept. 11, 2001, a storefront mosque has been sitting on West Broadway in TriBeCa, a dozen blocks from the World Trade Center. No one seems to have ever minded its being there.

headline: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: ‘Top Kill’ Effort Resumes After Delay

headline: While China Stands By
text: There is only one country with any chance of getting through to North Korea. That is China, the North’s major supplier of aid, food and oil. As tensions on the Korean Peninsula continue to spiral  frighteningly  upward, China is refusing to get involved.

headline: When ‘Fun City’ Wasn’t
text: There is a sobering lesson in the glory and despair of Messianic politicking in retrospectives on John V. Lindsay, the former mayor of New York City. He took the city by media storm 45 years ago but eventually fell flat when he tried to go national for the presidency.

headline: Artest’s Buzzer-Beater Douses the Suns’ Rally
text: LOS ANGELES  Kobe Bryant had Ron Artest wrapped in a bear hug, which was then engulfed by a group hug, all while shiny purple and gold streamers poured from the sky. Bryant was beaming, jovial at last.

headline: Baby Steps to New Life-Forms
text: Intelligent design. That’s one goal of synthetic biology, a field that was catapulted into the news last week with the announcement that a group of biologists had manufactured a genome that exists nowhere in nature and inserted it into a bacterial cell. The dream is that, one day, we’ll be able to sit and think about what sort of life-form we’d like to make — and then design and build it in much the same way we make a bridge or a car.

headline: Dealers Brace for Ford to Phase Out Mercury
text: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company is expected to tell dealers this fall that it is phasing out Mercury, a 71-year-old brand that will be down to just two models by next year.

headline: Willing to Part With Teeth to Drink From the Cup
text: The Philadelphia Flyers and the Chicago Blackhawks have traveled vastly different routes to the Stanley Cup finals, which begin Saturday night in Chicago. The Flyers’ path has been a roller-coaster thrill ride, deep troughs of incompetence alternating with lofty peaks of achievement. The Blackhawks’ advance has been a regal procession.

headline: 2 New Papers to Provide Competition in Zimbabwe
text: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwe’s only national daily newspaper, the state-owned Herald, long a propaganda sheet for President Robert Mugabe, will soon have some competition.

headline: Lottery Numbers
F.A.A. Tries to Accelerate Air Traffic Conversion
text: The government is seeking to speed up the installation of a new air-traffic network ahead of a 2020 deadline.

headline: Drilling for Certainty
text: In the weeks since the Deepwater Horizon explosion, the political debate has fallen into predictably partisan and often puerile categories. Conservatives say this is Obama’s Katrina. Liberals say the spill is proof the government should have more control over industry.

headline: Obama Promises Response on Question of Job Offer
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama refused to say Thursday whether his White House offered a job to Representative Joe Sestak of Pennsylvania to drop out of a Democratic primary but promised that the administration would respond soon.

headline: Bagel King Admits Cheating on Taxes
text: The owner of HH Bagels on the Upper West Side pleaded guilty on Thursday to grand larceny for cheating on his company’s taxes.

headline: Senate Approves Nearly $60 Billion for Wars
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday approved a nearly $60 billion measure to pay for continuing military operations in Afghanistan and Iraq as House Democrats struggled to round up votes for a major package of business tax breaks and safety-net programs for the long-term unemployed.

headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Files for an I.P.O.
text: 9:20 a.m. | Updated Toys “R” Us filed for an $800 million initial public offering late on Thursday.

headline: Wet Clay of Roland Garros Is Malleable for Roddick
text: PARIS  Andy Roddick awoke Thursday morning, looked out the window of his hotel room at the damp conditions and suddenly saw his second-round match to come in a different light.

headline: Mystery Surrounds Killing of a Girl, 16, in Brooklyn
text: From initial accounts, Al-Taya Conyers had a series of troubling relationships, even at age 16.

headline: Indonesia: Forest-Clearing Moratorium
text: Indonesia has declared a two-year moratorium on clearing natural forests as part of a billion-dollar deal aimed at reviving international efforts to fight climate change. The deal, signed Wednesday in Oslo, is part of a United Nations-backed plan in which wealthy countries help pay for the preservation of forests in developing countries. The clearing of forests for commercial uses has helped make Indonesia the world’s third largest greenhouse gas emitter, behind the United States and China, according to some estimates.

headline: Mexico: Morning-After Pills to Be Offered to Rape Victims
text: The Supreme Court upheld a federal law on Thursday requiring health providers to offer morning-after pills to rape victims. The ruling came in response to a challenge brought by Emilio González, the governor of the state of Jalisco, who argued that prosecutors, not health workers, ought to decide whether a woman was raped. “The state should not force rape victims to suffer an imposed pregnancy,” José Miguel Vivanco, Americas director at Human Rights Watch, said in praising the decision. Mexico has a hodgepodge of state-imposed restrictions on abortion, with Mexico City permitting all women to end their pregnancies in the first trimester.

headline: N.B.A. Clears Perkins, but Celtics Are Aching
text: The N.B.A. offered the Boston Celtics some healing Thursday by revoking one of Kendrick Perkins’s technical fouls, leaving him eligible to play in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals. The league treated them more kindly than did the Orlando Magic, which left the Celtics discarded, dazed and concussed.

headline: An Overhaul of an Underground Icon
text: Next month, the M.T.A. will unveil a resized, recolored and simplified edition of the New York subway map.

headline: Thing That May Appear
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Part of the fun of using statistical analysis to look at crosswords, or anything else for that matter, is that you never know what you’ll uncover.

headline: Drugstore Cowboy, Stuck in a Loop
text: SEATTLE  James Fogle was in prison when a critically acclaimed movie based on his novel “Drugstore Cowboy” was released in 1989. Starring Matt Dillon and directed by Gus Van Sant, the film portrayed a fumbling band of thieves and addicts who roamed the Pacific Northwest in the 1970s stealing drugs and money from pharmacies.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,071 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following American this week:

headline: Spill Could Make  BP Vulnerable
text: BP is likely to eventually stop the flow of oil from its explosion in the Gulf of Mexico. After that happens, the autopsy of the spill will begin in earnest. But if the information dribbling into the public domain proves correct, the British energy giant will be a weakened creature — so weak it will be vulnerable to a takeover.

headline: Strike Forces Honda to Shut Plants in China
text: HONG KONG  A strike at a crucial parts factory has forced Honda to shut down all four of its joint venture assembly plants in China. It was the clearest sign yet of growing labor unrest in a country that now stands at the cornerstone of companies’ global supply chains.

headline: Decades Later, Ex-Police Commander in Chicago Goes on Trial in Abuse Cases
text: CHICAGO  The retired police commander, now white-haired and in ill health, sat silently in a courtroom here as federal prosecutors described how, more than two decades ago, he hit a suspect over the head with a stapler and stuck a gun in another suspect’s mouth.

headline: Barajas Sits Out Finale Against Phillies but Plays Down Wrist Injury
text: Mets catcher Rod Barajas wore a hard, white brace on his right wrist Thursday afternoon. While speaking to reporters, he tucked most of it in the pouch of his hooded sweatshirt.

headline: Out of Uniform and Out of Work, and Seeking a Break in a Tough Civilian Job Market
text: Ample of girth, his scalp gleaming beneath a thinning thatch of hair, Alex De Francis stood out in the small sea of veterans that filled a Midtown hotel ballroom on Thursday.

headline: Keeping Score: An Edge to Friendly Confines
text: In major league baseball from 2000 to 2009, the home team won 54 percent of the time. Many cite the home team’s last at-bat as the reason. At the end of games, the thinking goes, the home team can tailor its strategy to match the situation. If the team is down by three runs, it can play for the big inning. If it needs one run, it can use small-ball strategies like bunting and base stealing to get that run.

headline: Arizona Law Is Stoking Unease Among Latinos
text: PHOENIX  When Gov. Jan Brewer signed Arizona’s new immigration enforcement law, giving police departments broad power to make immigration checks, she sought to allay concerns from Hispanic citizens and legal residents that they would be singled out for scrutiny.

headline: U.S. and Japan Reach Okinawa Deal
text: TOKYO — An American air base in Japan will remain on the southern island of Okinawa, the two allies said in a joint statement on Friday, as they reached an agreement that resolved a lingering diplomatic dispute but could also present new domestic challenges for Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama.

headline: Performers to Stay Away From Arizona in Protest of Law
text: A coalition of music groups has announced that its members will boycott all performances in Arizona to protest a tough new anti-immigration law there, and it has urged fans to sign a petition demanding the revocation of the legislation, which it calls “an assault on the U.S. Constitution.”

headline: Obama Restates Need to Seek More Oil Even as U.S. Uses Less
text: May 28, 12:42 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Massachusetts Move on Immigration Law
text: BOSTON  The Massachusetts Senate on Thursday approved a series of measures to tighten immigration enforcement, reflecting election-year unease over the issue in a Democratic-controlled Legislature that has spurned such crackdowns in the past.

headline: Buying Time for Rivera Costs Yanks Some Grief
text: MINNEAPOLIS  The topic brought an incredulous look to the face of Yankees Manager Joe Girardi.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Corrections
text: A theater review on May 14 about “The Truth: A Tragedy,” a work by Cynthia Hopkins about her father, at SoHo Rep in TriBeCa, referred incorrectly to him. Though the work is presented as an act of grief and mourning, Ms. Hopkins’s father, while elderly and ailing, is still alive. (The error also appeared in a theater entry in the Listings pages last Friday.)

headline: Public Offering Said Likely for Toys ‘R’ Us
text: The private equity firms that own Toys “R” Us plan to file for an initial public offering within the next few days, people briefed on the matter said Thursday.

headline: Margarita Paksa and Horacio Zabala: ‘Analogies & Differences’
text: This show pairs small-scale work, mostly on paper, by two Argentine artists little seen in New York. Each grew up in Buenos Aires during years of civic trauma; each has packed responses to a deadly era into the art.

headline: Employers Urged to Act Now to Expand Health Plans
text: WASHINGTON  Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, said Thursday that employers should immediately offer or continue health insurance coverage for workers’ children up to the age of 26, at little or no additional cost.

headline: ‘The Curse of Bigness’
text: The Queens Museum of Art curator Larissa Harris has squeezed a small but philosophically ambitious show about size and scale into leftover spaces while the museum undergoes a major expansion.

headline: Photo Replay: May 27
text: A view of the day in sports, with rain in France and some graceful and some not so graceful moves in the United States.

headline: ‘50 Artists Photograph the Future’
text: The 22nd century may not look a bit like anything predicted in “50 Artists Photograph the Future,” but at least this large show in a tiny space makes for some exotic sights in the present. What are some of the developments envisioned? Anatomical alterations, for one thing. Mariah Robertson seems to see a sort of vegetable-human hybrid in the cards, while Claire Pentecost surmises that we’ll all be reduced to walking stomachs with multiple tongues.

headline: Rains Sets Up Tennis-Palooza
text: PARIS – If there is one group of people happy about the rain that disrupted the French Open schedule on Wednesday and Thursday, it is Friday’s ticket holders.

headline: Offense Sputters, as Vazquez Takes a Step Back
text: MINNEAPOLIS  Three runs were in, the Minnesota Twins were hitting rockets everywhere, and Javier Vazquez stood one more bad pitch away from a runaway fiasco Thursday night. When Jason Kubel pulled a deep fly to right field with two on and two out in the third inning, Vazquez walked backward off the mound onto the infield grass and watched to see if his night had been ruined.

headline: Mamma Andersson and Jockum Nordstrom: ‘Who Is Sleeping on My Pillow’
text: Zwirner’s husband-and-wife show of the Swedish artists Mamma Andersson and Jockum Nordstrom works, as many marriages do, because each person has plenty of space. The exhibition takes the form of his-and-hers solos, joined by a hallway of collaborative works on paper.

headline: Texas: Student Convicted of Aiding Taliban
text: Adnan Babar Mirza, 33, a Pakistani who came to the United States as a student, was convicted in federal District Court in Houston Thursday of conspiring to aid the Taliban and of illegal possession of firearms. Prosecutors said Mr. Mirza had raised about $900 for the Taliban and had trained with other would-be Jihadists in paramilitary camps outside Houston, and that he intended to fight American troops in Afghanistan. His lawyer said the money was intended to go to the families of Taliban militants for humanitarian purposes and that a paid F.B.I. informant urged his client to take part in the camping trips and paramilitary training. He faces up to 10 years in prison.

headline: Anneliese Rothenberger, German Opera Singer, Dies
text: Anneliese Rothenberger, an internationally known German soprano who sang with the Metropolitan Opera in New York in the 1960s, died on Monday in Switzerland. As befits a diva, her exact age had long been shrouded in obscurity; she was believed to have been either 83 or 85.

headline: Virginia: University Objects to an Inquiry
text: The University of Virginia on Thursday filed a motion in circuit court asking the state to halt an investigation into the work of a prominent climate researcher, saying that the inquiry threatened academic freedom. The researcher, Michael Mann, came under scrutiny last year after the unauthorized release of more than a thousand e-mail messages and documents from a British climate research center. The messages led to accusations that Dr. Mann and other scientists had exaggerated or manipulated data pointing to human-driven global warming. Virginia’s attorney general has issued a subpoena for all communication, research and data produced by Dr. Mann during his tenure at the university.

headline: $45 Million Match Is Pledged
text: Michelle Obama on Thursday announced that five foundations  the Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation, the Omidyar Network, the Skoll Foundation, the Open Society Institute and the Benificus Foundation  would provide a total of $45 million to match the money the government plans to grant to nonprofit groups through its Social Innovation Fund, which will help expand social programs that have proven successful. More than 20 other foundations and organizations will provide an additional $5 million so that the fund will have $100 million, half in federal money, to award beginning in July.

headline: Word of the Day | adherent
text: adherent •\ad-ˈhir-ənt, əd-\• noun and adjective

headline: In 33rd Ward, There Is No Love for Blagojevich
text: Even after they are convicted of corruption, many of the state’s disgraced public servants continue to enjoy some degree of popular support when they return home, particularly from the political groups that propelled them to power.

headline: Preparing for a Challenge in the Race for Assessor
text: The activity inside a bank of austere offices on the North Side belies the assumption that our early and anemic Feb. 2 primary gave way to a needed campaign respite. It’s a window on a political and legal drama challenging the Democratic Party establishment, a drama that could easily wind up in the United States Supreme Court.

headline: An Oil Spill in the Gulf of Mexico Will Be Felt by Diners in Chicago Restaurants
text: On a damp morning last Friday, Maureen Fitzgerald pulled four fish out of a paper bag. “This looks beautiful,” she said, pointing to the clear eyes of the red snappers, and the firm, bright red skin. “We don’t have anything like this around here.”

headline: Deal Near to Approve More N.Y. Charter Schools
text: New York City officials and the State Assembly reached a tentative deal late Thursday to more than double the number of charter schools, a move that officials hope will give the state a better chance at receiving $700 million in federal grant money.

headline: Hull and Blackhawks Find Their Way Back
text: Bobby Hull is 71, and that’s a sobering realization for those of us who remember him as the forever-young Golden Jet of the Chicago Blackhawks.

headline: Acting in a Film: It Could Happen to You
text: They were ambitious young New Yorkers  waitresses, students, musicians, bartenders, chefs in training. Several were friends from high school, but most of the dozen or so hardly knew one another. The last place they expected to find themselves was in a movie  directed by a New Yorker, produced by New Yorkers, with original music by a New Yorker.

headline: Met Pitchers Stay Hot, Stopping Phillies Cold
text: The Mets must leave New York this weekend. Their schedule demands it. They open a six-game trip Friday night in Milwaukee. Oh, how they must wish they could stay.

headline: In a City That Eats Local, a Push to Keep Shoppers Close to Home
text: When Ron Mallia bought a dilapidated former auto repair shop on Valencia Street, in the trendy, artsy heart of the Mission District, he was very particular about the types of shops that could rent the space.

headline: Before the Daly Show Ends, Watch for a Final Episode
text: At the 24 Hour Fitness on Market Street in San Francisco, City Supervisor Chris Daly can sometimes be spotted working out, wearing a thick sweatband across his forehead and a shirt with the arms cut off  an outfit vintage Olivia Newton John, circa 1981, sans leg warmers.

headline: Bay Area at Play
text: Sports scores and results age fast. The Tour of California cycling race is now behind us — this year’s winner was Michael Rogers. The 2010 Bruce-Mahoney Trophy, focus of the 117-year rivalry between Sacred Heart Cathedral Preparatory and St. Ignatius College Preparatory in San Francisco was won by St. Ignatius in the final baseball game. Jahvid Best, a running back at the University of California, Berkeley, and Toby Gerhart, the Stanford running back, are headed for the pros. Here are some numbers that offer a different perspective on sports in the Bay Area.

headline: A New Look for Two Oft-Maligned Varieties
text: There’s something confrontational about the set of eyes on the new labels of Melka wines. They stare intensely at you from the bottle, as if daring you to drink it.

headline: Oil Spill Remedies: Trial and Error in Deep Water
text: An interactive timeline of BP's efforts to stanch the flow of oil into the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: News Quiz | May 28, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: UniCredit Chief Says E.U. Market Must Stay Unified
text: The failure of investors to treat the euro area as a unified market could set a dangerous precedent for the bloc’s future, according to the chief of UniCredit, the giant European cross-border lender, Matthew Saltmarsh reports in The New York Times.

headline: In Test of Zapatero, Spain Approves Cuts by 1 Vote
text: Prime Minister José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero narrowly survived a parliamentary vote on Thursday on his plans to cut an additional 15 billion euros ($18.5 billion) in spending, setting the stage for tough budget talks this year that could result in early elections in Spain, Raphael Minder reports in The New York Times.

headline: 12,000 to 19,000 Barrels a Day
text: WHAT has a federal team determined about the amount of oil gushing into the Gulf of Mexico?

headline: Brandeis Seeks Plan to Keep Its Artworks
text: Brandeis University, stung by criticism last year after its board authorized the sale of masterpieces from the university’s Rose Art Museum, is to announce on Friday that it has begun to explore alternatives to selling the works and will not contemplate the “sale of any Rose artwork” while it looks at other options. In January 2009, as Brandeis’s finances eroded badly during the recession, its trustees voted to “transition” the museum — founded in 1961 and the repository of works by de Kooning, Warhol, Lichtenstein and other major artists — into a teaching center and gallery, followed by “an orderly sale or other disposition” of its works in order to raise money for the school. In a telephone interview Jehuda Reinharz, the Brandeis president, said the university was now working with Sotheby’s, which approached it a year ago, to find ways to make money by lending works from the collection or entering into partnerships with other institutions. He said the university would be committed to using some of the income to benefit both the museum and the fine arts program. “The income from any kind of partnership or lease would generate fewer dollars, but on the other hand we’d still be the owner of the art,” said Dr. Reinharz, who last year announced his plans to step down as president as soon as a successor was named. A group of the museum’s benefactors sued the university in July 2009 to prevent any sales, and that lawsuit is proceeding. While Dr. Reinharz would not rule out the possibility that selling might still be necessary at some point, he said it was now unlikely. RANDY KENNEDY

headline: In Non-‘Idol’ TV News
text: Season finales of the crime shows “Criminal Minds” and “CSI: NY” lifted CBS to a solid second-place finish in the ratings on Wednesday, a night in which network television audiences were otherwise preoccupied with the final round of Fox’s “American Idol.” According to Nielsen’s estimates “Criminal Minds” delivered the second-largest audience after “Idol,” drawing 12.8 million viewers at 9 p.m. compared to the 24.2 million who tuned in to Fox’s two-hour edition of “Idol.” CBS’s “CSI: NY” led the 10 p.m. time slot with 11.9 million viewers, while the network’s repeat of “Undercover Boss” at 8 garnered lower ratings (6.1 million). ABC ranked third, and NBC was fourth. BENJAMIN TOFF

headline: Adviser to Stars Named in Madoff-Like Fraud
text: He was the moneyman to the stars, entrusted with managing fortunes for the likes of Wesley Snipes, Sylvester Stallone and Annie Leibovitz.

headline: U.S. Markets Rebound; S.&P. Rises 3.3%
text: Once again, the stock market swung wildly on Thursday — only this time, it swung up.

headline: Civilogue
text: A civilized dialogue in which those in disagreement refrain from stooping to insults or knee-jerk generalizations.

headline: Asian Stocks Rally After Wall Street’s Rebound
text: A positive mood on Wall Street carried over to Asia on Friday, making for a third straight day of gains in the region despite continued underlying nervousness about Europe’s debt troubles, The New York Times’s Bettina Wassener reported.

headline: Sports by the Numbers and Other Highlights From Friday’s Bay Area Report
text: The Pros, the College Standouts and the Rest of Us | While batting averages and marathon finishing times are part of the familiar background of big-time sports, a whole different class of statistics has its own resonance. Did you know that 2:20:06 is the record time in the men’s challenged-athlete category of the Escape From Alcatraz triathlon? Or that more than 100 boats now compete each year in the Treasure Island dragon-boat regatta? Or how many times one woman has ridden a metric century on her bicycle in the Cinderella Classic? Look up the numbers behind the sports for the rest of us.First Local Food, Now Clothes and Furniture | With the help of the city’s planning department, neighborhoods like Hayes Valley and North Beach have banned chain stores. Any formula retailer, which is defined as a store with more than 10 locations nationwide, must be approved by the planning commission before it can open. “The feeling is that potentially, if you allow a number of formula retail stores, you lose neighborhood character and locally owned businesses,” said John Rahaim, director of the San Francisco Planning Department. But some residents and shopkeepers wonder if this hyper-local form of protectionism is good for residents and merchants — and who should have a say over how and where people shop.

headline: Fifth Street Doubles Credit Facility
text: Fifth Street Finance, the business lender, on Thursday said its three-year credit facility with Wells Fargo had doubled in size, to $100 million.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Summer Food?
text: Memorial Day is coming up, and the photo above, from a Dining article this week, makes us want to start a discussion about summer food. What’s your favorite thing to eat in summer? Why? What wonderful summer memories do you have that involve eating this particular food?

headline: The Past, Present and Future of Chris Daly
text: One of my earliest encounters with Supervisor Chris Daly of San Francisco was when he was first on the ballot nearly 10 years ago.

headline: Maoist Rebels Suspected as Indian Train Derails
text: NEW DELHI  Months after resolving to stanch a spreading Maoist rebellion, India’s government suffered another setback on Friday after a bloody rebel attack on a passenger train, the latest evidence of the potency of the Maoist movement at a moment when critics are questioning the strategy and competence of the security campaign.

headline: Morgan Stanley Hires Advisers from UBS and Barclays
text: Morgan Stanley Smith Barney hired a pair of top financial advisers from UBS, and also added advisers from Barclays Wealth to focus on Latin American markets, Reuters reported.

headline: Japan Defies Australia on Whaling
text: TOKYO  Japan rebuffed a threat by Australia to take Tokyo to court over its whaling in the Antarctic, saying on Friday that the annual hunts were permitted under international law and accusing the Australian government of exploiting the issue for political gain.

text: From Jerry Garrett at Wheels:

headline: Pacificor Hires Agency to Sell ‘Terminator’ Rights
text: Pacificor, a California hedge fund, on Thursday said it retained the William Morris Endeavor agency to represent it in the sale of all rights to the “Terminator” franchise. Included are rights to exploit the property for film, television, merchandise and online games.

headline: As C.B.O.E. Prepares for I.P.O., 3 Quit Board
text: CBOE Holdings, operator of the biggest U.S. options exchange, said three of its 22 directors had resigned, less than three weeks before an initial public offering that would value the exchange at $2.87 billion, Reuters reported.

headline: Nasdaq to Delist Frontier Financial
text: The Nasdaq Stock Market on Thursday said it would delist the common stock of Frontier Financial, a month after the bank was seized by regulators.

headline: Russian Banks Warn Against Liquidity Withdrawal
text: Russian lenders say plans to withdraw emergency liquidity this year may shackle credit and confound government efforts to push banks to lend more, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Israel Partly Reopens West Bank Road to Palestinians
text: BEIT SIRA, West Bank  Israel’s military on Friday partly opened a major highway that runs through the West Bank to local Palestinian traffic, the latest twist in the story of a road that for many Palestinians has become a symbol of the injustices of Israeli occupation.

headline: Infogroup Sets Date for Vote on Proposed Sale
text: Infogroup, the database provider, said Thursday that it had set a shareholder vote for June 29 on the company’s proposed $460 million sale to private equity firm CCMP Capital Advisors, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Goldman Seeks to Settle With Lesser Charge
text: Goldman Sachs is looking to avoid a charge of fraud from the Securities and Exchange Commission by coming to a settlement over a lesser offense, The Financial Times reported, citing people familiar with the bank’s negotiating position.

headline: Wall Street Debates Fate of ABC
text: Wall Street has long seen sense in Walt Disney selling or spinning off ABC, the low-rated TV network and the one piece that does not seem to fit well with the entertainment empire — but the problem is finding a buyer, Reuters reported.

headline: Spain Orders Banks to Open Their Books
text: The Bank of Spain has said that the country’s banks must acknowledge their bad debts and put aside up to 30 percent reserves on real estate holdings, with the goal of bringing international confidence back to the Spanish financial system and stem the exodus of investors, The Telegraph reported.

headline: China Remains Good Buy, BlackRock Says
text: Cheap stocks and robust consumption by its middle class are reason to buy into China now, even though markets have turned cautious on the nation, a fund manager at BlackRock told Reuters.

headline: Nudity and the Financial Markets
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.Last week Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany banned naked credit-default swaps on the bonds of European governments and naked short sales of the stock of the country’s 10 most important financial institutions.

headline: From Dutch Ovens (and Beyond)
text: The culinary “Taste of” events, which take place annually, found a home in Amsterdam for the first time in 2009. This year, the Taste of Amsterdam festival, which runs from June 24 to 27, has stepped up its ambitions: enthusiasts can expect more participating restaurants and cooking schools, an organic market and an anticipated 25,000 visitors, 10,000 more than last year.

headline: Shell Buys U.S. Shale Gas Assets for $4.7 Billion
text: Royal Dutch Shell, the Anglo-Dutch oil and gas producer, said Friday that it had struck a deal to buy most of the assets of East Resources for $4.7 billion in cash, moving into the coveted sector of natural gas contained in shale deposits.

headline: Prudential Tries to Lower Offer for A.I.A.
text: Prudential, the British insurance giant that is seeking to buy the Asian life insurance unit of American International Group, said on Friday that it was talking to the U.S. insurance giant about reducing the $35.5 billion price tag of the transaction in a bid to secure the necessary shareholder support at a vote next month, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Bettina Wassener report in The New York Times.

headline: Marijuana Pollution
text: Today’s idea: Pot isn’t so green after all, an article says. California’s large marijuana growing operations — most illegal — “are polluting local ecosystems on an industrial scale in rural counties and places as unlikely as state parks.”

headline: Attackers Hit Mosques of Islamic Sect in Pakistan
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  Hafeez Malik heard the gunfire outside the mosque, then shots inside the prayer hall.

text: From William D. Cohan at Opinionator:

text: And neither am I.

headline: China Hints It Could Shift Its Stance on an Ally

text: FOSHAN, China — After years of being pushed to work 12-hour days, six days a week on monotonous low-wage assembly line tasks, China’s workers are starting to push back.

headline: Sampler: Republican Candidates’ Spending Spree, and Fishermen Head North
text: Price Tag Soars for Gubernatorial Campaigns | Meg Whitman, the former eBay chief executive, has spent about $68 million of her own money in her campaign for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, including $33.8 million in the past two months. She has said she’s prepared to spend as much as $150 million and has already outspent her Republican primary opponent, Steve Poizner, $42 million to $17.9 million on television advertising. From mid-March to mid-May, according to newly released records, Ms. Whitman’s campaign spent $512,121 a day; Mr. Poizner spent $252,000 a day; and the leading Democratic candidate, Attorney General Jerry Brown, spent $3,900 a day. And while the two Republican candidates have been trying to distance themselves from Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, The Los Angeles Times reported that they are sounding more like him. [The Sacramento Bee, The San Francisco Chronicle, The Los Angeles Times]

headline: BP Engineers Making Little Headway on Leaking Well
text: HOUSTON  BP engineers struggled Friday to plug a gushing oil well a mile under the sea, but as of late in the day they had made little headway in stemming the flow.

headline: You Might Call It a Z-Shirt
text: Last month, I wrote a story about the mare Zenyatta, who is undefeated in 16 starts, and how she had grown into a quirky personality. In it, I mentioned how her trainer, John Shirreffs, had come up with a slogan and a T-shirt for her latest campaign: “Dancing Again in 2010.”

headline: The Changing Admissions Landscape at the University of California
text: While budget cuts are remaking education across the country, California’s still stand out for their severity. Among the resulting changes are admissions and access to the state’s flagship higher education system, the University of California. Here is a look at the new reality.

headline: Tip of the Week: Managing Jump Lists
text: The Jump Lists feature of Windows 7 offers you a list of recently used files or tasks used by a particular program, but you can modify the Jump List to always show your favorite items. To see a Jump List from the Start menu, just move the mouse cursor over the program’s name to see any recently used files or pages. You can also right-click a program’s icon in the Taskbar to see its Jump List, and then select what you want from the list.

headline: U.S. Consumer Spending Was Stagnant in April
text: Consumers earned more income in April but they also spent less, according to government statistics released on Friday, raising some questions about the pace of the recovery.

headline: And Now the Smart Toy
text: The old saying “history repeats itself” applies nicely to technology toys these days. Take Simon, the 1978 memory game from Milton Bradley that, for many, was a first encounter with a microprocessor. Next month, Mattel will come out a modernized twist on the theme, with Loopz ($30, powered by four AA batteries), which replaces the big light-up buttons on the old toy with motion-sensing technology, of the variety found on any self-flushing toilet.

headline: Job Searches Around the Country, Part II
text: On Thursday we posted a map, created by the Economic Policy Institute, showing the average duration of unemployment in each American state last year. I was curious how closely the duration of unemployment tracked with the portion of people who were unemployed, since it seems likely that people will stay unemployed longer if the are competing with a bigger pool of unemployed workers.

headline: Flintstones Cereal Maker Rocked by Lawsuit From Hulk Hogan
text: There is a lot that Hulk Hogan is willing to do in the name of comedy. He will allow himself to be bonked on the head with bowling balls or zapped with electricity, or dress up in a tutu and practice ballet moves with small children (and that’s just in the trailer for “Mr. Nanny”). He’ll even come to your place of business and put you in a headlock if you ask nicely. But what he will not allow is for an apparent cartoon version of himself to be defeated in a wrestling match by the son of a cereal-shilling caveman.

headline: Stretching a Coupe Into a Sedan, Without Torture
text: WHEN Aston Martin unveiled its Rapide concept car at the Detroit auto show in 2006, other companies’ designers reacted with admiration and curiosity: how did it do that? That is, how had Aston managed to transform a precisely proportioned two-door grand tourer  the DB9  into a longer four-door car that was every bit as striking?

headline: Friday Reading: Testing Online Travel Promotions
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: The Dumbest Thing I’ve Ever Done (in My Business Life)
text: I’m not sure why I’m telling this story, but here goes: When we moved into our new shop in 2002, we quadrupled our square footage. So I knew overhead expenses would be going up considerably. Some of that increase was easy to predict, like more rent. Some was not so easy, like how much our electric bill would rise. Before the move, my bill was about $2,000 a month (we have some big machines). Afterward it ended up being about $6,000 a month. That didn’t surprise me much — quadruple space, quadruple lights, quadruple heat, more guys, more machines, etc., etc.

headline: How to Remind a Parent of the Baby in the Car?
text: INFANTS or young children left inside a vehicle can die of hyperthermia in a few hours, even when the temperature outside is not especially hot. It is a tragedy that kills about 30 children a year, according to the National Safety Council.

headline: Defeating the Lice Without Emptying Your Wallet
text: IT’S a fact of life. If your children go to school or camp, they will each almost certainly end up with at least one case of head lice over the years.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: It’s a Bird, It’s a Plane, It’s the Mayor of New York
text: New on our softcover list this week is Volume 9 of “Ex Machina,” the penultimate collection of the WildStorm/DC Comics series about Mitchell Hundred, the mayor of New York who was once a superhero known as the Great Machine. His honor’s adventures are illustrated by Tony Harris and written by Brian K. Vaughan, who also wrote the hit series “Y the Last Man.”

headline: China Announces Development Plan for Restive Xinjiang Region
text: BEIJING  The new leader of the restive region of Xinjiang in western China has announced a series of economic measures to bolster confidence in the regional government, which was widely criticized by citizens after deadly ethnic rioting there last summer.

headline: Video and Blogging From Lahore Under Attack

The attackers took hostages and exchanged fire with police officers.

headline: Complaint Box | Sidewalks as Ashtrays
text: Think back to New York in the ’70s and ’80s — litter strewn along the streets, minefields of dog excrement, and graffiti on every surface reachable by a can of spray paint. It’s almost all gone now, except for one thing, one devious little hanger-on: cigarette butts.

headline: Reckoning for a Financial Planner
text: Over the last several months, many of you have written to me to ask what happened to Matt Weitzman, my former financial planner. In April 2009, I wrote about how some of his clients and his business partner had accused him of misappropriating millions of dollars in funds, often from the accounts of the old, infirm and distracted. (My family suffered no losses.)

headline: White House Used Bill Clinton to Ask Sestak to Drop Out of Race
text: President Obama’s chief of staff used former President Bill Clinton as an intermediary to see if Representative Joe Sestak would drop out of Pennsylvania’s Democratic Senate primary if given a prominent, but unpaid, advisory position, the White House said on Friday.

headline: Can Oral Sex Cause Herpes?
text: Do cold sores protect against other forms of herpes? Can oral sex cause herpes infections? Those are among the questions readers recently posed to the Consults blog. Here, Dr. Peter A. Leone, associate professor at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine and Public Health, provides his expert advice.

headline: Murray Fights Off Baghdatis in Four Sets
text: PARIS — Shaking off a one-set collapse, Andy Murray of Scotland steadied himself for a strong finish to defeat Marcos Baghdatis of Cyprus, 6-2, 6-3, 0-6, 6-2 in the third round of the 2010 French Open.

headline: Jerry West Had the Ultimate Game, in the Backcourt and on the Back Nine
text: Happy 72nd birthday to the Lakers Hall of Famer Jerry West, who is perfectly capable of going out today and shooting his age at Bel-Air Country Club, where he once set the course record with a 28 on the back nine on his way to a 63.

headline: The End of a One-Word Essay Question (Discuss)

headline: The Why-Worry Generation
text: For the past few years, it’s been open season on Generation Y — also known as the millennials, echo boomers or, less flatteringly, Generation Me. Once described by the trend-watchers Neil Howe and William Strauss as “the next great generation” — optimistic, idealistic and destined to do good — millennials, born between 1982 and 2002, have been depicted more recently by employers, professors and earnestly concerned mental-health experts as entitled whiners who have been spoiled by parents who overstoked their self-esteem, teachers who granted undeserved A’s and sports coaches who bestowed trophies on any player who showed up.

headline: Letting Desdemona Rock Out a Little
text: “THERE’S a part of me you’ll never know,” Renée Fleming sings as she begins her pop album “Dark Hope,” in a voice her opera and lieder fans might not recognize. It’s two octaves below her renowned lyric soprano, with a lushly melancholy tone that’s closer to Tori Amos and Sarah McLachlan than to Kathleen Battle or Sarah Brightman.

headline: Even Sopranos Get the Blues
text: FOR months now, the acclaimed soprano Renée Fleming, her recording company and her public relations agency have been working hard to make one thing clear: “Dark Hope,” her new Decca recording of indie rock songs, is not a crossover project.

headline: On Our Radar: Backlash on the Oil Moratorium
text: A Republican backlash greets President Obama’s pullback on new offshore drilling.

headline: Teaching Work Values to Children of Wealth
text: Steven D. Hayworth, chief executive of Gibraltar Private Bank and Trust, is thrilled that his daughter will be working this summer at a women’s clothing store before heading to college in the fall. It is not the particular job that pleases Mr. Hayworth. Rather, he is hoping his daughter will make the connection between how much she earns each day and what that will buy.

headline: Liquor Board Will Still Allow Self-Certification by License Applicants
text: Two weeks ago, the New York State Liquor Authority announced that in July, a bureaucratic reform that had reduced the worst liquor-license logjam in memory would be sunsetted because it was such a success.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Finalists Sign Their Record Deals
text: It’s an annual tradition with “American Idol”: the finalists are named, a winner is chosen, the public expresses its outrage and questions the fidelity of the voting process, and then the top two performers are signed to record labels. Both Lee DeWyze, who won the show’s ninth season on Wednesday night, and Crystal Bowersox, who came in second (but first in our hearts) are signed to 19 Recordings Limited, the label founded by the “Idol” creator, Simon Fuller. Billboard.com reported that Mr. DeWyze would release his first post-“Idol” album on RCA Records, which also put out albums by the “Idol” contestants Chris Daughtry and Adam Lambert, while Ms. Bowersox will release hers on Jive Records, which is also home to the “Idol” alumni Jordin Sparks, Kris Allen and Allison Iraheta. No release date was given for either album, though Mr. Allen and Mr. Lambert, last year’s “Idol” winner and runner-up, put out their records in November. The debut singles of Mr. DeWyze (a cover of U2’s “Beautiful Day”) and Ms. Bowersox (a cover of Patty Griffin’s “Up to the Mountain”) have been released, though download results for those tracks weren’t immediately available.

headline: ‘Junk’ and Mud Choking Well as Obama Arrives
text: By adding solid materials (a k a junk) to the heavy mud being pumped into the gushing seabed well, BP and its team appear to have stanched the flow of oil and gas — at least for the moment, federal officials said this morning. But as President Obama prepared to tour the soiled region, BP warned that secondary steps were still being lined up, a good idea given the history of dashed hopes so far.

headline: In South Africa, Football or Footloose?
text: Here at T, we consume sporting events like we do hot dogs: very infrequently, but with relish. Next up is the World Cup, and it’s gonna be big. How big? That’s now a fraught question. South Africa has already spent about $5 billion primping itself for the month-long soccer event, but expectations for visitors — once around 750,000 people — have dropped significantly. Blame the global recession, for sure, but the slump might also owe a bit to South Africa’s location, at the bottom of a huge continent that often extends beyond most people’s imaginations, and travel budgets.

T-Mobile subscribers should put this phone on their short list when it goes on sale next week —$180 with a two-year contract.

headline: Lamborghini Recalling Murciélagos

text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to formulate novel eponymous laws.

headline: French Open Plays Catch-Up
text: PARIS  It looked as if it could be one of those special days when the French Open schedule for Friday was released the night before. And it felt like one after sunrise, when the clouds cleared and revealed a perfect day.

headline: To Live and Die With Artest
text: If you’re a fan, you know you are probably in for chronic heartburn when your hopes are resting on someone known as Ron-Ron. No, Ron Artest did not show up for the Lakers’ Game 5 in the Western Conference finals Thursday night wearing a wig. He did not have his hair dyed some fluorescent color, nor have any misspelled words shaved into it. This was run-of-the-mill Ron-Ron, launching a ridiculous 3-pointer with a minute left when the Lakers were trying to preserve a 3-point lead over the Suns  the kind of shot that snatched 10 years from Coach Phil Jackson’s life  then redeeming himself by showing up at the most unlikely juncture with the game-winning put-back layup at the buzzer.

headline: Teaching Wealthy Children the Value of Work
text: This week’s Wealth Matters column takes a look at how wealthy parents are teaching their children the value of a dollar through work. While many of these children don’t have to work in order to survive, their parents think it’s a good way to help them gain perspective on what it takes to maintain the lifestyle they have become used to.

headline: Classical Crossover: What’s All the Fuss?
text: Renée Fleming, darling of the opera world, has a new album titled “Dark Hope,” on which she covers indie rock acts including Death Cab for Cutie and Mars Volta. The classical world scratches its head at the impulse. The recording’s promoters — and Ms. Fleming herself — shy away from calling it a crossover album, calling it instead, “somewhat sheepishly” as The Times’s chief classical music critic Anthony Tommasini writes in an essay in Arts & Leisure, a visit to a “parallel universe.”

headline: Learning Network Year-End Round-Up
text: Like you, we’re getting ready to switch gears for the summer.

headline: The Integrationist
text: While slouching against a wall in a former cigarette factory in the industrial outskirts of The Hague one day last month, I was visited with the sudden realization that over the formative centuries of European history the two words that most succinctly signaled “other,” “foreign” or “enemy” were these: “Jew” and “Turk.” Crudely unpacking them, “Turk” meant Muslim, Arab, infidel, the threat from without; a Jew was the enemy within, someone who, even if born and raised in your hometown, was part of another political as well as religious entity; the Jews of a city were referred to not as a community but as “the Jewish nation.” “Jew” and “Turk” were in fact constructs Europeans used to help define their own identity: that which we are not.

headline: Funny ‘BP’ Voice on Twitter Irks Real BP
text: Here are some developments I’m tracking via Twitter, Google Reader and the Green blog on the news side of The Times.

headline: Inside the List
text: THE POPULAR POLYGAMIST: Lee Child’s “61 Hours” enters at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, followed by John Sandford’s “Storm Prey.” But a few quote-unquote literary novels are surviving the summer reading onslaught, including “The Lonely Polygamist,” the sprawling Mormon family drama by Brady Udall, which hangs on at No. 31 on the extended list, thanks in part to strong sales in Utah. Salt Lake City is the top market for the book, according to Udall’s publisher, and the novel has drawn notice on Mormon Web sites, including Mormon Archipelago (tag line: “Gateway to the Bloggernacle”) and The Plural Life, written by a reporter who covers polygamy for The Salt Lake Tribune.

headline: No ‘Hair’ Replacements for Musical’s West End Production
text: The West End won’t be keeping its “Hair” past September, but the London theater district may be getting some interesting hair in another musical production.

headline: Who Needs to Know?
text: Governments try to keep secrets. The press tries to learn and publish them. The courts try to strike the appropriate balance between the public’s right to be protected against disclosures that might put it at risk, on the one hand, and the public’s right to know about secrets that might cause it to change governmental policies, on the other. It is a delicate balancing act, but an essential one in a democracy that must fight its wars with both secrecy and accountability.

headline: Williams Team Profits and the Health of Formula One
text: A few years ago the Williams team started to announce its annual profits and losses. I wondered what it was all about, since I always had in mind that old joke about how to turn a large fortune into a small fortune – or something to that effect – with the punch line of: “Own a Formula One team.”

headline: Noises Off
text: Writers are notoriously noise-averse, perhaps none more so than the historian Thomas Carlyle. “SILENCE, SILENCE: in a thousand senses I proclaim the indispensable worth of Silence, our only safe dwelling-place ­often,” he wrote a friend in 1840. A few years later, after his neighbor in London’s Chelsea district added a flock of “demon fowl” to his yard, Carlyle resolved to defend himself against the clamor of roosters, organ grinders, the neighbor’s piano, etc., by adding a floor to his house for a sound-proof study. It didn’t work: with certain sounds shut out, others became more audible — distant whistles among them. “The silent room is the noisiest room in the house,” his wife, Jane, observed.

headline: Forbidden Sights
text: A friend of mine tells me that he can find any TV image sexy, any image at all, so long as it’s . . . scrambled.

headline: New York State Votes to Expand Charter Schools
text: The New York Legislature voted on Friday to more than double the number of charter schools in the state, handing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg a significant victory that he and education officials hope will give the state a chance of receiving $700 million in federal grant money.

headline: Wish You Were Here
text: A few weeks after “Infinite Jest” was published in February 1996, Rolling Stone magazine sent a reporter to accompany its author, David Foster Wallace, on the final leg of his triumphant book tour. For a dense, challenging, wildly satiric, at times profoundly sad and gruesome 1,079-page novel, which concluded with nearly a hundred pages of “notes and errata,” “Infinite Jest” had garnered enormous attention. Esquire called it a work of genius. Time and Newsweek ran photos of the author.

headline: The Age Game
text: I’m a 36-year-old woman but look closer to 30. In online dating, men my age often filter out women over 35. I’m considering posting a profile listing me as 34, so men will at least see my picture and profile, where I’d immediately clarify my actual age to not mislead anyone or waste anyone’s time. Is it O.K. to slightly — and briefly — game the system to bypass an arbitrary filter? K.B., NEW YORK

text: The second round of the French Open was completed on Friday, and the third round got under way. For those who filled out a bracket (why isn’t that popular, as it is in college basketball?), the draws generally held firm.

headline: New Frugal Traveler to Be Announced
text: Thanks for all your comments and well wishes.  Matt Gross may have turned in his frugal badge, but as longtime readers of the column know, the Frugal Traveler lives on. Come back next week, when we will unveil the next Frugal Traveler, who is already packing for what promises to be a long and adventurous summer.  Or follow the Twitter feed.

headline: Mean Boys
text: If I were in the eighth grade, I’m pretty sure I’d love Simon Rich’s first novel, “Elliot Allagash.” I might even press it on my friends. (“It’s about this 13-year-old evil genius who does whatever he wants because he’s, like, a billionaire. And it’s funny. And short.”) But since more than 45 years have passed since I took up space in a middle school, I simply like it, very much — while wishing this flippant little parable about the puerility of greed had a deeper, sharper bite. Rich is a writer for “Saturday Night Live,” and his fondness for the broadest kind of sketch comedy is evident on almost every page.
