headline: From Sappho to ‘Fried Green Tomatoes’
text: Were an intelligent, determined scholar to set herself the task of sifting through the last thousand years of Western culture’s literary output, would she be able to discern a “historical moment when something changed in the way women’s love was experienced and interpreted”? The short answer is no, not really. The longer answer is “Inseparable: Desire Between Women in Literature,” by the novelist, playwright and literary critic Emma Donoghue.

headline: Answers About Child Psychiatry, Part 3
text: Following is the third and final set of responses from Dr. Harold Koplewicz, a child and adolescent psychiatrist and president of the Child Study Center Foundation. This week he has responded to readers’ questions about the myths and stigma surrounding psychiatric disorders of children and adolescents.

headline: TimesCast | May 28, 2010
text: Today, the president surveys damage from the Gulf oil leak, the House votes to allow the repeal of "Don't Ask, Don't Tell," and college students lacking guidance fall deeper into debt.

headline: Judge Bars Paterson Furlough Plan
text: A federal judge granted a preliminary injunction on Friday blocking Gov. David A. Paterson from furloughing tens of thousands of state workers.

headline: Not Dead, Only Resting? The Climate Bill
text: A popular parlor game in Washington is trying to figure out whether the Deepwater Horizon oil spill has helped or hurt chances for passage of comprehensive energy and climate change legislation. President Obama tried to bolster its prospects in his news conference on Thursday, saying the crisis highlights the need to find alternatives to the deadly and dirty fossil fuels oil and coal.

headline: Fallon: ‘A Nice Thing to Announce’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: A new poll found that 43 percent of Americans think President Obama is doing a good job at handling the B.P. oil spill. Of course, the same poll found that 43 percent of Americans hate pelicans.

headline: Long Shadows of a Borough’s Boogeyman
text: COUPLES do all sorts of things on first dates. Coffee. Dinner. Dancing. Or strolling around the grounds of the abandoned Willowbrook mental institution on Staten Island. Josh Zeman and Barbara Brancaccio chose to take the walk. The outcome was a movie.

headline: Leno: ‘Trying to Minimize the Damage’
text: Monologue |  Thursday night on “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on NBC: Well, folks, here’s the latest update. I guess this is good news. B.P. officials say the “top kill” plan is working. The bad news — B.P. officials are a bunch of lying weasels.

headline: Photos: The iPad Lands in More Countries
text: Although shoppers in the United States have been able to buy Apple’s iPad since early April, international customers had to buy it on eBay, sometimes shelling out several hundred dollars over the domestic retail price.

headline: Mariner and Javelin: Two Deals on the Brink
text: Today, I’ll examine two deals – the acquisitions of Mariner Energy and Javelin Pharmaceuticals – and how they appear to be falling apart.

headline: The Joy of (Outdated) Facts
text: The other day I realized I absolutely had to own a copy of the recently published facsimile of the first Guinness Book of Records from 1955 (limited edition of 5,000, mine is No. 177). It’s a fine book, and it gave me just want I wanted. Since I bought it, I’ve been regaling people with stories of Jacko, a dog owned by one Mr. J. Shaw of London that killed 1,000 rats in an hour and 40 minutes in May 1862; Mrs. Theresa Vaughan of Sheffield, who had had 61 bigamous marriages by the age of 24; and Dionsio Sanchez of Spain, who once drank 40 pints of wine in 59 minutes. It was a different world.

headline: Up Front: Jed Perl
text: The critic Jed Perl has written that his ideal artist is a traditionalist with radical ambitions.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE FIRST TYCOON: The Epic Life of Cornelius Vanderbilt,  by T. J. Stiles (Vintage, $19.95.) This “mighty — and mighty confident — work,” Dwight Garner wrote in The Times, “moves with force and conviction and imperious wit through Vanderbilt’s noisy life.” Self-made and ruthless, Vanderbilt achieved a near monopoly on steamship travel, then moved into the railroad business. (He built Grand Central Terminal.) He became the richest man in 19th-century America and inspired the term “robber baron.” This “state-of-the-art biography,” as Garner called it, won the 2009 Pulitzer Prize.

headline: The Hacker and the Hack
text: If you’re a latecomer to the Stieg Larsson phenomenon, here, briefly, is the deal: Larsson was a Swedish journalist who edited a magazine called Expo, which was devoted to exposing racist and extremist organizations in his nativeland. In his spare time, he worked on a trilogy of crime thrillers, delivering them to his Swedish publisher in 2004. In November of that year, a few months before the first of these novels came out, he died of a heart attack. He was only 50, and he never got to see his books become enormous best sellers — first in Sweden and then, in translation, all over the globe.

headline: Finding His Way to Paris
text: James Lord, who died last year at the age of 86, is a tremendous storyteller. He brings dramatic intricacies to his encounters with Picasso, Gertrude Stein, Cocteau, Alberto Giacometti, Peggy Guggenheim and a host of other characters in the memoirs and recollections he published over the course of nearly half a century, from “A Giacometti Portrait” in 1965 to “My Queer War,” completed before his death. Sometimes I have the sneaking suspicion that Lord enjoys exaggerating his own role as the guileless young man, so as to push some hero or villain into higher relief. And he certainly knows how to grab a reader, beginning his portrait of another one of his friends, the Viscountess of ­Noailles, with this wealthy patron of the arts on her deathbed, shrieking, “I don’t want to die,” a tragic figure in a Parisian mansion hung with her peerless collection of work by Goya, Degas and Picasso. There is a fablelike power and a sensuous, seductive rhythm about the narratives as Lord unfurls them, a quality almost of myth­making that can feel a little old-­fashioned, but beautifully old-fashioned.

headline: When Europe Wept
text: A few years ago, the permanent secretary of the Nobel Prize jury had some less than charitable things to say about American literature. “The U.S. is too isolated, too insular,” ­the secretary, Horace Engdahl, argued. “They don’t translate enough and don’t really participate in the big dialogue of literature. That ignorance is restraining.” His comments upset some people on our shores, but despite the obvious over­simplification he was right.

headline: Interim Report
text: Barack Obama may be struggling to right the listing economy, but he has stimulated a remarkable growth spurt in at least one battered sector. His presidency has ignited a literary boomlet. The Obama administration, as Howard Kurtz of The Washington Post recently observed, is under siege — not from lobbyists or hostile Republicans, but from a welter of elite journalists demanding interviews as they race to complete their books about the White House.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE PREGNANT WIDOW: Inside History,  by Martin Amis (Knopf, $26.95.) Amis’s novel concerns three students from the University of London, one male, two female, who stay at a castle in Italy in 1970, during the opening skirmishes of the sexual revolution.

headline: Palin Builds Fence After Author Moves In Next Door
text: If good fences make good neighbors, Sarah Palin and the author Joe McGinniss should get along beautifully. Ms. Palin has just had a 14-foot-high fence erected between her property and the house next door, which Mr. McGinniss has rented for the summer while he researches a book about Ms. Palin, The Associated Press reported. Mr. McGinniss, the author of “The Selling of the President” and “Fatal Vision,” drew criticism from both the right and the left this week when Ms. Palin announced on her Facebook page that he had moved next door to her family on Lake Lucille in Wasilla, Alaska. Ms. Palin told Glenn Beck on his radio show that her husband, Todd, and his friends began working on a fence almost immediately after Mr. McGinniss moved in.

headline: Engagement in Cairo
text: In 2003, as a 21-year-old convert to Islam, I moved from Colorado to Cairo to see what life was like in a Muslim country. I got a much better look than I bargained for. While I was there, I fell in love and was engaged to a young Egyptian man named Omar.

headline: Cool
text: The Times Literary Supplement, the erudite British weekly, isn’t the first place you would expect to find an outbreak of cool. But for a recent stretch of a few months, its letters page was home to a protracted debate over exactly how cool got cool.

headline: Bare Necessity
text: The sneaker seems like a dumbed-down version of the athletic shoe. As casual wear suitable for use in the yard, a nightclub or the office, sneakers compete (ferociously) on the basis of style and signaling power. Picking an athletic shoe, in contrast, has less to do with, say, drooling over stylish designs than with translating exuberant jargon. The Asics GEL-Kinsei 3 draws on “pure running science,” which evidently involves Spacemaster mesh containing “a nanoscale metal film” that reacts to weather — not to mention its new Propulsion Trusstic. Adidas’ adiSTAR Salvation W, meanwhile, offers ForMotion, which I don’t understand but is trademarked, as well as an Extended Torsion System, surely better than a Stunted Torsion System. Reebok’s ZigTech shoes promise to disburse a “wave of energy” along the strange-looking sole, reducing “wear and tear” on leg muscles by “up to 20” percent. Just figuring out which model to study on Nike’s Web site involves a multistep process concerning running surfaces, the shape of your foot and the specifics of your stride.

text: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar on Friday named Bob Abbey, director of the department’s Bureau of Land Management, as interim director of the Minerals Management Service, the scandal-ridden agency responsible for oversight of offshore drilling.

headline: Green Bean Season
text: Martha Rose Shulman calls green beans her “go-to spring vegetable.” The key, she says is proper cooking: four to five minutes of either steaming or par-boiling. Green beans are great on their own or tossed in a salad; they can also be paired with pasta or rice dishes. In this week’s Recipes for Health, she offers five delicious ways to prepare green beans, including a longer cooked Mediterranean bean stew that is packed with flavor.

headline: The Philharmonic’s Challenge: Merely the End of the World
text: Encouraging evidence that Alan Gilbert’s bold artistic vision for the New York Philharmonic has been embraced by the public could be seen in two words on a poster outside Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night: “SOLD OUT.”

text: IN a city said to be teeming with potential mates, where in New York do you look for a great catch? Are you supposed to hail them down on the street like a cab?

headline: Neil Jordan’s Possible World of the Impossible
text: “I DID ‘Ondine,’ really, because I wanted to see this kind of film,” the Irish writer and director Neil Jordan said on a hot, bright afternoon during the Tribeca Film Festival last month. The movie had been screened the night before  “People seemed to be responding to it, in a good way,” he said  and Mr. Jordan, 60, looked a little tired as he sat down to lunch in the Mercer Hotel and tried to elaborate on what kind of film this very strange creature actually is. “I’ve done so many things in Ireland about brutality and violence  punishing, unforgiving things,” he said. “I suppose I wanted to do something just gentle, like those early fairy tales of Yeats and Lady Gregory, which are terribly childish, terribly romantic, quite beautiful.”

headline: George A. Romero: A Career Undead
text: It has been 42 years since the first crop of George A. Romero‘s zombies marched across the screen in “Night of the Living Dead.” Apparently, they really don’t die. Mr. Romero’s latest film, appropriately titled “Survival of the Dead,” keeps his career and those pesky, lumbering zombies, very much alive.

text: As Congress considers raising the cap on liability in oil spills, it might take into account the state of BP’s in-box for claims.

headline: Word From London on ‘Paradise Found': Not Good

headline: Nick Is Taking Questions

headline: We Three Things | Pass the Marmalade
text: Marmalade is Anglophilia in a pot: fussy, traditional and deliciously tooth-rotting. The word itself sounds like a mysterious ribbon of malaise and bonkers. In addition to bringing a blob of cheer to rainy weekday mornings, it recalls wartime London and lost toy bears, hallucinogens and manga. It is the definition of bittersweet: comforting, but with a sharp rind edge and a dark aftertaste. Watch Fry and Laurie put the “marm” in marmalade in a famous 1992 sketch.

headline: Assigning Responsibility for High Student Loan Debts

headline: Placing the Blame as Students Are Buried in Debt
text: Like many middle-class families, Cortney Munna and her mother began the college selection process with a grim determination. They would do whatever they could to get Cortney into the best possible college, and they maintained a blind faith that the investment would be worth it.

headline: Elliot Allagash
text: My parents always took my side when I was a kid, no matter how much I screwed up. When I smashed my brand new Sega Genesis during a temper tantrum, they blamed the game “Sonic the Hedgehog” for getting me riled up. When I lost my passport at the airport, they blamed themselves for entrusting it to me. So when I told them what Elliot had done to me, I was pretty surprised by their reaction.

headline: After Governor’s Pardon, Citizenship for Chinese Immigrant
text: It was his application for United States citizenship that derailed the American life of Qing Hong Wu, an information technology executive who had risen from poverty and street crime in Chinatown. He had fulfilled the promise he made to the judge who sentenced him for teenage muggings, but immigration authorities jailed him for mandatory deportation to China, a country he had left at 5.

headline: Isner Makes a Quiet Exit in Third Round
text: PARIS — John Isner’s long face and downcast eyes told the story. After five weeks in Europe sharpening his clay-court skills, it had all come crashing down at the French Open.

headline: Mickelson’s Short Game: An Ensemble Approach to Practice
text: Ever notice how people typically warm up their short game before a round? They drop three balls on the putting green and putt for five minutes. Then they might hit four or five chip shots from just off the green, often practicing from the same spot. That’s better than nothing — and a lot of golfers do nothing before a round — but it’s not simulating the golf round that is about to begin and it’s not how professional golfers warm up their short games.

headline: Pennsylvania Partners With Foursquare
text: Whether the gold-rush mentality surrounding Foursquare, the location-based social network, will pay off is anybody’s guess. But that hasn’t stopped big-name brands (Pepsi), designer labels (Marc Jacobs) and even certain newspapers from hooking up with the service. Now, an entire state is getting in on the action.

headline: Another Way to Keep Track of the Elderly
text: As the population ages, home monitoring devices like Lifeline and others — which keep track of your whereabouts, monitor your bodily functions and remind you to take their medicines — have become more popular. Lifeline, made by Philips, is easy to use. By pushing a button on a pendant, you connect to a home base station, which automatically alerts a central station that there’s an emergency. Trained operators with the customer’s medical history can quickly call for help and alert relatives that something’s wrong.

headline: Novelists and Other Artists
text: When novelists write about other art forms, it can serve as a metaphor and an apologia for their own aims. In Steve Martin’s lovingly precise and miniature “Shopgirl,” the title character spends her nights making lovingly precise and miniature drawings, while in Don DeLillo’s monumental and historically minded “Underworld,” the artist Klara Sax earns her reputation with monumental, historically minded paintings that use decommissioned B-52 bombers as their canvas. (DeLillo loves to write about the arts, especially film and conceptual performance pieces, though the parallels to his own work aren’t always so explicit.) Artists are at the heart of relatively recent books by Nell Freudenberger, Nick Laird, Olga Grushin and Stacey D’Erasmo, among many others. Novels about music, meanwhile, are so ubiquitous as to constitute their own genre.

headline: Sainted Heroic Doctors, Minus the Halos
text: THE hardened, heroic doctor working selflessly to save lives in a war zone has become a familiar figure in popular entertainment. The long-running television series “ER,” for example, sent Noah Wyle’s John Carter and Goran Visnjic’s Luka Kovac off to Congo on just such an assignment, fraught with mortal danger and moral dilemmas.

headline: Finally at Home, a Decade Later
text: AFTER a decade of wedded life, Jill Stoll and Kentaro Tsubaki, who were married in April 2000, say they finally feel settled. Last August, they moved to New Orleans, both to take positions as professors at Tulane University.

headline: Cooking Out in the City, No Backyard Necessary
text: THOUGH I have been a vegan for a decade, I’ve always been fascinated by barbecuing (teriyaki-marinated tofu is delicious if you can keep it from sticking to the grill). Maybe it’s because I grew up in the South, eating a home-cooked meal every night of my life — often a slab of meat fired on the back porch — and have long been intrigued by how food brings people together, particularly outdoors, especially in the sizzle of summer.

headline: A Coastal Community Braces for Oil

text: Video | Inebriated lawmakers say there ought to be a law keeping IHOPs open all night:

headline: Waiting for a Soldier to Come Home
text: Memorial Day is about remembering. A time to think of — and thank — those who sacrificed so we can barbecue. For me it will forever be filled with memories of my father, an Air Force veteran, who died on this holiday weekend six years ago, having lived a safe and happy life after his years of peacetime service.

headline: Dawn Baxter, Derrin Woodhouse
text: Dawn Camille Baxter and Derrin Arthur Woodhouse were married Saturday evening at St. Paul’s Episcopal Church in Englewood, N.J. The Rev. Robert L. Shearer, the priest-in-charge of the church, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Charles L. Fischer III, another Episcopal priest, participating.

headline: Alissa Bersin, Zachary Miller
text: Alissa Ida Bersin and Zachary David Miller are to be married Sunday at the Hotel del Coronado on Coronado Island in California. Rabbi Robert N. Levine is to officiate.

headline: Could Stritch Succeed Lansbury in ‘Night Music’?
text: The actress Elaine Stritch said on Friday afternoon that she was talking to the producers of the Broadway revival of “A Little Night Music”  about succeeding Angela Lansbury this summer in the role of Madame Armfeldt, but cautioned that no deal was in place and she was not sure if she would ultimately play the role.

headline: Lindsay Friedman, Mark Mazzetti
text: Dr. Lindsay Bertrand Friedman and Mark Mazzetti are to be married Sunday at River Farm in Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Robert Maddox Jr., a Congregational minister, is to officiate.

headline: Vanessa Lewis, Campbell Williams
text: Dr. Vanessa A. Lewis and Dr. Campbell D. Williams were married Saturday evening in an outdoor ceremony at Indian Harbor Yacht Club in Greenwich, Conn. Cantor Shira Adler officiated.

headline: Behind the Numbers: Venus Williams’s Serve
text: Venus Williams’s straight-sets victory over Dominika Cibulkova was a clinic in strong serving and clean play. Cibulkova, a solid counterpuncher who reached the semifinals here a year ago, is a tough opponent, especially on a slow court, but she could never gain a toehold in the match. She did fight to gain three break points, but she only won one of them. Williams broke Cibulkova three times on five break point opportunities.

headline: Emily Barson, Matthew Thornton
text: Emily Alyssa Barson and Matthew Henry Thornton are to be married Sunday at the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia. Rabbi Seth Goren is to officiate.

headline: Christina Weyl, Richard Lichtenstein
text: Christina Moisant Weyl and Richard Michael Lichtenstein were married Saturday at Blue Hill at Stone Barns, the restaurant on the Rockefeller family’s Pocantico Hills estate in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Richard A. Davis officiated, and the Rev. Dr. James B. Lemler, an Episcopal priest, took part.

headline: The Morning Skate: The No-Predictions Final Preview
text: Two teams with long Stanley Cup droughts begin the final on Saturday and yesterday’s Morning Skate chronicled analysis and predictions from around the hockey community. Many smart observers are picking the Blackhawks, and six games seems to be a popular length (continuing today with this piece by Cam Cole of The Vancouver Sun, Michael Obernauer of the Daily News.

headline: Jaclyn Greenstein, Jason Frasco
text: Jaclyn Dawn Greenstein and Jason Benjamin Frasco are to be married Sunday evening at the Forsgate Country Club in Monroe Township, N.J. Rabbi Julie Roth is to officiate.

headline: Salony Patel, Maulik Majmudar
text: Salony Mahendra Patel and Dr. Maulik Dilipkumar Majmudar are to be married Sunday at the Hyatt Regency in Greenwich, Conn. Pandit Bharatkumar Jani, a Hindu priest, is to officiate.

headline: Nianda Clouden, Howard Reid
text: Dr. Nianda Simone Clouden, a daughter of Lystra Small Clouden and Dean R. Clouden of Franklin Park, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Howard Benton Reid II, a son of Jennifer and Mr. Reid Sr. of Rochester. The Rev. Dr. Elmer Gillett, a minister of the Church of the Nazarene, is to officiate at the Ritz-Carlton Golf and Spa Resort, Rosehall, in St. James, Jamaica.

headline: Barbra Leung, Craig Askinazi
text: Barbra SuPing Leung and Craig Scott Askinazi are to be married Sunday evening at the Fox Hollow, an event space in Woodbury, N.Y. Cantor Sheila Nesis is to officiate.

headline: Jamie Beilin, Christopher Joseph
text: Jamie Sarasohn Beilin and Christopher John Joseph were married Saturday at Solage, a resort in Calistoga, Calif. Kimberly A. Thompson, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: American Lawyer for Opposition Figure Is Arrested in Rwanda
text: KAMPALA, Uganda  Rwandan authorities on Friday arrested an American lawyer who is representing a leading Rwandan opposition figure, the latest sign of an increasingly repressive atmosphere there.

headline: Communists Could Gain in Czech Vote
text: PRAGUE  A popular online video here called “Convince Granny” urges young Czechs to withhold visits to their grandparents unless the old folks agree not to vote for leftist parties like the Communists in Saturday’s elections.

headline: House Backs Tax Increase on Carried Interest
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: Some Rouge Dresses Up Courts at Roland Garros
text: PARIS  It really is not red clay. The famous courts of the French Open are white limestone, frosted with a few millimeters of powdered red brick dust.

headline: Squatters’ Wrongs
text: Some friends have discovered that it’s lucrative to rent their homes as vacation properties. They can make several thousand dollars a week. A few of these families of four and five have asked if they can stay with us, for free, during the rental periods. This seems like a big intrusion and very greedy to me. But they’re close friends, so I’m afraid we have to relent. What do you think? Anonymous

headline: Kuznetsova Slide Continues With French Open Ouster
text: For most of 2010, Svetlana Kuznetsova has struggled to retain the form that has made her a top-10 presence for four years and a two-time Grand Slam champion. When she arrived to defend her French Open championship, she was the only top-10 player with a losing record for the season. She was 1-3 on clay. A year ago, she was 17-3.

headline: Classical Crossover: Don’t Forget the Bite
text: Anthony Tommasini and Jon Pareles discussed musical crossovers. Read the previous posts here.

headline: President’s Remarks on the Oil Spill
text: Following is a transcript of President Obama's remarks on Friday on the government's response to the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, as released by the White House:

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Our show opens amid the chaos of Friday Prayer in Lahore, Pakistan, where  gunmen and suicide bombers stormed two mosques belonging to a minority sect. The attackers seized hostages, killed at least 70 worshipers and wounded 78 others, according to the authorities (Slides 1, 2 and 3). At one mosque, dozens of men were said to have survived by scurrying down a narrow passage and hiding in the basement. The attacks were aimed at the Ahmadi community, which considers itself Muslim but is severely discriminated against under Pakistani law.In Afghanistan, Rahmat Gul of The Associated Press captured an arresting image of a boy running past a burning oil tanker. The vehicle had been carrying fuel supplies for NATO forces (Slide 5).

headline: Ristretto | London’s Penny University
text: Last Saturday, London’s Square Mile Coffee Roasters opened their first coffee bar, Penny University, in a storefront just off of Shoreditch High Street. It’s small, little more than a burnished wood counter with six stools in a warm if austere room — the decor is limited to a framed map of the world on the wall and the scuff patterns on the floor.

headline: Sessions Pushes for Release of Kagan Papers
text: The senior Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee suggested on Friday that the White House is foot-dragging on the release of 160,000 pages of documents relating to Solicitor General Elena Kagan’s days in the Clinton White House.

headline: Visiting Gulf, Obama Tells Residents ‘You Are Not Alone’
text: GRAND ISLE, La.  President Obama, on the defensive about the oil spill disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, made his second trip in the month to Louisiana’s coast on Friday to monitor troubled efforts to cap the well, and to reassure people in this beleaguered community that he will solve the crisis.

headline: ‘Race to the End of the Earth’
text: A new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History surveys the 1911 race to the South Pole between the Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen, who arrived first, and his British rival, Robert Falcon Scott, who did not survive the expedition.

headline: Laura Cuzzillo, Caryn Berman
text: Laura Cuzzillo and Caryn Berman were married Saturday in Des Moines. Judge Robert B. Hanson of Iowa’s Fifth Judicial District officiated at the Pappajohn Sculpture Garden in Western Gateway Park.

headline: Hey, Mr. Critic!
text: I’ve been taking readers’ questions here at Diner’s Journal. I’ll be answering in clips and clops over the course of the coming days, and in next Friday’s print edition of the Weekend section. Keep them coming!

headline: Alexandra Rubenstein, Evan Rachlin
text: Alexandra Nicole Rubenstein, a daughter of Alice Rogoff Rubenstein and David M. Rubenstein of Bethesda, Md., was married Saturday evening to Dr. Evan Lockwood Rachlin, a son of Barbara L. Rachlin and Alan R. Rachlin of Great Falls, Va. The Rev. Jennifer J. S. Brooks, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard.

headline: Rupa Magge, Kurt Cross
text: Rupa Magge and Kurt Cross were married Saturday at the Ritz-Carlton in Marina del Rey, Calif. Yogeendra Bhat, a Hindu priest, officiated.

headline: Unfriendly Pet in Pet-Friendly Co-op
text: Q.

headline: Beth Kaplan, Adam Cohen
text: Dr. Beth Meryl Kaplan and Adam Lee Cohen are to be married Sunday at the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner is to lead the ceremony.

headline: Men’s ‘Shapewear’ Is a Retail Hit
text: IN its decade on the market, the Spanx line of modern girdles has become both a must-have undergarment and an easy punch line. Celebrities like Tyra Banks, Janeane Garofalo and Wanda Sykes declare their allegiance to Spanx, even as they joke about it.

headline: Asking for a Copy of a Signed Lease
text: Q.

headline: When a Condo Board Seems Invisible
text: Q.

headline: Gary Coleman, ‘Diff’rent Strokes’ Star, Dies at 42
text: Gary Coleman, the former child star of the hit television series “Diff’rent Strokes,” who dealt with a well-publicized string of financial and personal difficulties after the show ended, died on Friday in Provo, Utah. He was 42 and lived in Santaquin, a small town near Provo.

headline: Do We Tolerate Too Many Traffic Deaths?
text: From our colleagues at Room for Debate:

headline: Sohini Ramachandran, Jeremy Mumford
text: Sohini Ramachandran, a daughter of Geetha Ramachandran and Doraiswamy Ramachandran of Gold River, Calif., is to be married Sunday in Cambridge, Mass., to Jeremy Ravi Mumford, a son of David B. Mumford of Boston and the late Erika M. Mumford. The Rev. Scotty McLennan, the dean for religious life at Stanford and a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard, which is to include Christian and Hindu religious and cultural traditions.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: The Douro region of Portugal has painterly views, architectural splendor and ambitious winemaking. In other words, you get all the joys of Tuscany without all the “you musts” from friends, says Frank Bruni, a writer at large for The New York Times Magazine, who visited the country in April.

headline: University of Virginia Asks Judge to Block Subpoena
text: As we noted briefly in The New York Times on Friday, the University of Virginia has filed a court petition asking a judge to block a subpoena seeking a prominent climate scientist’s research materials.

headline: Granderson Returns, Winn Departs, Russo Stays
text: After missing 24 games with a strained left groin, Curtis Granderson rejoined the Yankees for Friday night’s game against Cleveland. His return upgrades the Yankees’ outfield defense and lengthens their lineup, which over the last week has struggled to hit with runners in scoring position. Granderson batted seventh before he got hurt, but he is hitting second Friday, and Joe Girardi suggested he will continue to hit there while Jorge Posada remains sidelined.

headline: Raymond Haysbert Sr., Baltimore Civic Leader and Businessman, Is Dead at 90
text: Raymond V. Haysbert Sr., a former chief executive of the Parks Sausage Company and a longtime leader in Baltimore’s black community, died Monday in Baltimore. He was 90.

headline: What’s an Ex-Frontman to Do?
text: SAUNTERING along Central Park West, Liam Gallagher looked as if he’d just stepped off Carnaby Street in London circa 1969. Turned out in a black velvet jacket with an upturned collar, skinny scarf around his neck and hair combed forward all modlike, the former Oasis frontman would have fit in well alongside Brian Jones and Ray Davies in their heyday.

headline: Braised Artichokes
text: Mark Bittman makes braised artichokes in a lemon-butter sauce.

headline: Judge Urges Resolution in Use of Obama Photo
text: A federal judge on Friday encouraged the parties involved in a dispute over Shepard Fairey’s “Hope” poster of Barack Obama, which is based on an Associated Press photograph, to come to a resolution, suggesting that The A.P. was likely to prevail in court.

headline: Smackdowns, No Height Limit
text: STEVE RICHARDSON is not squeamish about using the word “midget.” Then again, Mr. Richardson, who stands 4 foot 4, is not squeamish about a lot of things, like diving headfirst into a pile of broken glass or stapling dollar bills to his genitalia. But let’s get to the controversial point first.

headline: The Secret Lives of Teachers
text: They're used to instant feedback from their students, but how will these teachers fare during Amateur Night at the Apollo Theater?

headline: At TBS, Diversity Pays Its Own Way
text: IN 2004 the cable station TBS, based in Atlanta, rebranded itself with a bold slogan: “very funny.” What it had to back up the tag line, at the time, were reruns of “Seinfeld” and “Friends”  shows that had already proven their hilarity on NBC.

headline: House Passes Bill With ‘Don’t Tell’ Repeal
text: WASHINGTON  The House on Friday adopted an annual Pentagon policy bill that includes a provision allowing the Defense Department to repeal the ban on gay and bisexual people from serving openly in the military.

headline: The Godparent Trap
text: WE’VE grown accustomed to London society scandals over the years on everything from money to sex to dental hygiene. (Who can forget the brouhaha over Martin Amis’s pricey new teeth?)

headline: Lost, With Laptops, in Psychedelic Space
text: THE Los Angeles electronic music producer Flying Lotus sees his new album, “Cosmogramma,” as something of a “space opera.” “It’s kind of a space epic,” he said, “very theatrical at times, only in the ‘Star Wars’ sense of things. Not like ‘Pavarotti Space Viking.’ ”

headline: Somalia’s Parliament Chooses a New Speaker
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Somalia’s Parliament elected a new speaker on Friday, choosing one of the most powerful businessmen in the country to lead what has often been a fractious and rebellious group of lawmakers.

headline: Artichokes Take a Dip in a Pool of Stock
text: WHEN the good artichokes start arriving, I try to come up with something new to do with them. This year, I turned to a time-honored technique, just one I’d never applied to artichokes. It will be a permanent addition to my repertory.

headline: Thrash, Introspection and a Touch of the Cantor
text: Trash Talk

headline: Jessica O’Neill, Andrew Cole
text: Jessica Ross O’Neill and Andrew Scott Cole were married Saturday at One if By Land, Two if By Sea, a restaurant in New York. The Rev. Joanna Fernandez, an interfaith minister, officiated.

headline: Anne on the Move | The Brant Foundation, Greenwich, Conn.
text: I’ve never really had a reason to go to Greenwich, Conn., before but now I have a reason to go back: “Oscar the Grouch,” the solo show by Urs Fischer at the Brant Foundation Art Study Center. The show presents various pieces of Fisher’s work set in a beautiful stone house on the Greenwich polo field. The awe-inspiring setting (only 45 minutes from New York City!) is nothing compared to the awe-inspiring work that is inside.

headline: ‘Avenue Q’ to Honor Gary Coleman
text: The Off-Broadway musical “Avenue Q,” whose characters include a fictionalized version of Gary Coleman, the former child star who died on Friday, said it will pay tribute to Mr. Coleman in Friday’s performance at New World Stages.

headline: Amy Bodnick, Howard Levy
text: Amy Karen Bodnick and Howard Adam Levy are to be married Sunday at the Vanderbilt at South Beach, an event space in South Beach, Staten Island. Rabbi Ronald Barry is to officiate with the assistance of Cantor David F. Tilman.

headline: Dance Track Master, Accidental Fan
text: LCD SOUNDSYSTEM, essentially the one-man project of James Murphy, is the connoisseur’s dance band. It emerged in 2002 already poking fun at its own snobbishness, with the single “Losing My Edge,” the hilariously fibbed bragging rights of an aging, anxious hipster. Since then Mr. Murphy, 40, has usually played the part of the guy who might be a little too cool for his own good. (“I’m losing my edge to the art-school Brooklynites in little jackets and borrowed nostalgia for the unremembered ’80s,” he sang-spoke on “Losing My Edge,” which Pitchfork called the 13th best song of the 2000s.)

headline: Sarah Palin Finds an Unwelcome Boswell Next Door: Joe McGinniss
text: One of the conceits of literary journalism is that a writer spends as much time in close proximity to his or her subjects as possible. Joe McGinniss, a veteran practitioner, has taken that approach into new realms by moving in next to Sarah Palin in Wasilla, Alaska. The former governor of Alaska and the vice presidential candidate is the subject of his book titled “Sarah Palin’s Year of Living Dangerously,” due out in the fall of 2011.

headline: Anne Maged, Robert Becker
text: Anne Avery Maged, the daughter of Randy S. Maged and Stephen Maged of Potomac, Md., is to be married Sunday evening to Robert Sandler Becker, the son of Abbe D. Becker and Steven R. Becker of Hollywood, Fla. Rabbi Jonathan A. Schnitzer is to officiate at the Willard Hotel in Washington. The bride’s maternal grandfather, Cantor Ralph S. Snyder, is to take part in the ceremony.

headline: Tiramisù That Soaks Up Wine Instead of Coffee
text: I hadn’t thought of making tiramisù since the 1990s when it was all the rage, but in March friends asked me to bring dessert to their party, and it came to mind. Fashionable or not, it’s perfect for a crowd but also foolproof enough to assemble with my toddler daughter underfoot.

headline: Erica De Bruin, Sam Rosenfeld
text: Erica Susanne De Bruin and Sam Hoffmann Rosenfeld are to be married Sunday at the Carousel at Lighthouse Point Park in New Haven. The Rev. James M. Rand, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate.

headline: Eurydice and Mary, at the Height of Sorrow
text: After its debut at the Bang on a Can marathon in 2008, Signal, the new-music orchestra conducted by Brad Lubman, built its reputation mainly with the music of Steve Reich and Philip Glass. But this year Mr. Lubman has been expanding the ensemble’s diet. Last month the group devoted a concert to the idiosyncratic music of Helmut Lachenmann. And at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening Mr. Lubman led Harrison Birtwistle’s “Corridor,” a musically and psychologically thorny piece that focuses on one particularly fraught moment in the Orpheus legend, and a new work by Nico Muhly.

headline: Tale of a Life, Unabridged
text: BILL CLEGG, literary agent and recovering crack user, is pacing the lobby of the Gansevoort Hotel, a BlackBerry glued to his ear. A security guard gives him over a once-over before holding the elevator door open.

headline: Are 5,001 Facebook Friends One Too Many?
text: THE British anthropologist and Oxford professor Robin Dunbar has posed a theory that the number of individuals with whom a stable interpersonal relationship can be maintained (read: friends) is limited by the size of the human brain, specifically the neocortex. “Dunbar’s number,” as this hypothesis has become known, is 150.

headline: Looking at Love, No Sugarcoating Required
text: This week the Lounge at Dixon Place, a pub cozy enough to make you sentimental for the old East Village and for the way that so many theaters in Europe actually have bars, is the center of a first-time festival celebrating dance from the former Yugoslav republics.

headline: How Much for a Bikini That Suits You?
text: J. CREW’S Tipped Luxe Halter bathing suit top and its matching bikini bottom in pale coral, with delicate orange piping, is pretty enough. But is it $90 worth of pretty? (Tax not included.)

headline: The Forces That Divide, in Motion and Images
text: It’s the rare contemporary dance choreographer these days who doesn’t have interactive, multimedia goals. (Video is the new scenery.) The YelleB Dance Ensemble, a mostly Israeli group, has ambitious objectives of this sort: the program notes describe a continuing collaboration between the choreographers Ella Ben-Aharon and Edo Ceder, the video artist Adi Shniderman and the architect Matthias Neumann.

headline: Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell, Don’t Pull Your Punches
text: It’s been a good week, perhaps too good of a week, for disclosure and transparency. The blogosphere has brought us more than we ever wanted to know about the telephony habits of a South Carolina legislator; we discovered that, in one case, the White House’s efforts to provide employment amid a recession has gotten both the current and a former president into trouble; and we learned that we’re all going get a peek over the fence and into the lives of Wasilla, Alaska’s, most famous resident. There are times when more feels like less …

headline: Braising Artichokes: Quick and Easy
text: One of my spring challenges is coming up with a new artichoke recipe. This year, I browned and then braised, and was astonished at the results. This technique (it’s not unlike one I’ve used for Brussels sprouts for about 10 years) gets rid of the choke early in the process, is only marginally more complicated and just as fast as steaming, and produces a gorgeous, easy-to-eat vegetable. It’s going to become my go-to.

headline: Sea of Pink at Colonial Is a Show of Support for Breast Cancer Research
text: FORT WORTH – After Amy Mickelson’s breast cancer diagnosis a year ago last week led to a swiftly organized “Pink Out” to raise awareness and funds to fight the disease, the sponsors and organizers of the Crowne Plaza Invitational at Colonial Country Club decided to expand the event this year.

headline: On the Street | Bleached
text: This year, white is being worn in a fresh way: oversize shirts over stemlike leggings. Also appearing are neutral and off-white, and whimsical ribbon and lace creations.

headline: Musicians Differ in Responses to Arizona’s New Immigration Law
text: For the singer Larry Hernandez, the 2010 Billboard Latin Music Awards should have been a moment of pure celebration. But when it came time for Mr. Hernandez to accept his award as new artist of the year, he got drawn into politics, prefacing his remarks with a condemnation of the tough new immigration law that his home state of Arizona had just adopted.

headline: Beethoven May Not Have Died of Lead Poisoning, After All
text: Scientists began speculating about what really killed Ludwig van Beethoven almost as soon as he was buried in 1827. He had complained of a “wretched existence,” with a long list of symptoms: abdominal pain, digestive trouble, colic, chronic bronchitis, foul body odors and extremely bad breath. And of course there was the hearing problem.

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 28
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a church in Harlem, upstate hipsters, a long-time patron of Sardi’s, and college dorm rooms of the rich and famous.

headline: A Veteran Goes House-Hunting on the G.I. Bill
text: THOUGH Willie Holmes had been traveling back and forth to New York for a few years, primarily for modeling jobs, he had little knowledge of the city’s housing market — just vague impressions from his New York friends, most of whom lived in Harlem.

headline: A Showcase for the Decorative Arts
text: THE four-bedroom apartment on Park Avenue in the 60s that is home to Barbara and Donald Tober isn’t quite as grand as the Museum of Arts and Design, where Ms. Tober served as chairwoman of the board for 15 years.

headline: One on One: Brian Lam of Gizmodo.com
text: It was just last month that Gizmodo.com, the gadget blog, published images of the next-generation iPhone that led to a chain of events that sound more like a soap opera than a gadget story. Since then, Gizmodo has been catapulted into the mainstream media, being discussed on “Good Morning America” and “The Daily Show.”

headline: 40 Years In, a Couple Still Seek New Ideas
text: Performance retrospectives are all the rage right now, with museums and presenters trying to figure out just what it means for body-based art to receive a curatorial backward glance. Danspace Project and several partners jumped into the fray on Thursday night with “Retrospective Project I: Regeneration,” Part 1 of a three-year survey examining the nearly 40-year collaboration of Eiko & Koma.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Finalists Sign Record Deals
text: It’s an annual tradition with “American Idol”: the finalists are named, a winner is chosen, the public expresses its outrage and questions the fidelity of the voting process, and then the top two performers are signed to record labels. Both Lee DeWyze, who won the show’s ninth season on Wednesday night, and Crystal Bowersox, who came in second, are signed to 19 Recordings Limited, the label founded by the “Idol” creator, Simon Fuller. Billboard.com reported that Mr. DeWyze would release his first post-“Idol” album on RCA Records, while Ms. Bowersox will release hers on Jive Records. No release date was given for either album.

headline: ‘Dance’ Lifts Fox
text: Fox led the ratings race on Thursday as the seventh season of “So You Think You Can Dance” made its debut with 8.2 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Ratings for the Fox reality show were down from the 8.9 million who watched the opening episode last May, yet Fox still managed to average the most viewers on the night by a slim margin. CBS finished close behind, earning the night’s largest audiences with reruns of “CSI” at 9 (8.3 million) and “The Mentalist” at 10 (9.9 million), but averaged only 4.3 million viewers during the 8 p.m. hour with sitcom repeats. ABC was third with a special at 9, “Hollywood Salutes Matt Damon: An American Cinematheque Tribute” (3.3 million), followed by a rerun of “Grey’s Anatomy” at 10 (3.1 million). NBC and its lineup of mostly reruns placed fourth. The premiere of NBC’s new comedy “100 Questions” drew 2.5 million viewers at 8:30.

headline: Palin Fences Off Author Neighbor
text: If good fences make good neighbors, Sarah Palin and the author Joe McGinniss should get along beautifully. Ms. Palin has just had a 14-foot-high fence, above, erected between her property and the house next door, which Mr. McGinniss has rented for the summer while he researches a book about Ms. Palin, The Associated Press reported. Mr. McGinniss, the author of “The Selling of the President” and “Fatal Vision,” drew criticism from both the right and the left this week when Ms. Palin announced on her Facebook page that he had moved next door to her family on Lake Lucille in Wasilla, Alaska. Ms. Palin told Glenn Beck on his radio show that her husband, Todd, and his friends began working on a fence almost immediately after Mr. McGinniss moved in.

headline: No ‘Hair’ Replacements For London Production
text: The West End won’t be keeping its “Hair” past September, but the London theater district may be getting some interesting hair in another musical. Producers for the West End revival of “Hair,” a transfer of the Tony-winning Broadway production that brought its American cast (including Darius Nichols, above, as Hud) to Britain, said the show would close after its Sept. 4 performance. The musical had received strong reviews at the Gielgud Theater but its producers, who include Cameron Mackintosh, said a confluence of factors had contributed to its closing. In a statement, they wrote: “Cameron and the U.S. producers have decided not to recast ‘Hair’ when the Broadway company finish their London engagement. The fall in tourism, the ash cloud and the election has caused a drop in audience figures, which has also affected shops, restaurants and hotels across London.” Meanwhile, another of Mr. Mackintosh’s West End productions may soon gain another familiar American face. The Daily Mail reported that Nick Jonas, the teenage heartthrob and member of the Jonas Brothers, would join the cast of London’s “Les Misérables” as Marius for three weeks starting June 21. Mr. Jonas played Gavroche in the musical’s 2003 Broadway revival.

headline: Flintstones Cereal Maker Rocked By Hulk Hogan
text: There is a lot that Hulk Hogan is willing to do in the name of comedy. He will allow himself to be bonked on the head with bowling balls or zapped with electricity, or dress up in a tutu and practice ballet moves with small children (and that’s just in the trailer for “Mr. Nanny”). But what he will not allow is for an apparent cartoon version of himself to be defeated in a wrestling match by the son of a cereal-shilling caveman. Under his real name, Terry Bollea, the Hulkster has filed suit against Post Foods, saying the company used his likeness without permission for a Cocoa Pebbles commercial, The Hollywood Reporter said. In the ad for the “Flintstones”-themed cereal, Fred Flintstone and Barney Rubble are pitted in a wrestling match against a character called Hulk Boulder, who shares Mr. Bollea’s blond hair and horseshoe mustache. When Boulder prevails and reaches for a bowl of cereal, he is grabbed by Barney’s baby son, Bamm-Bamm, and thrown around the ring. Citing the complaint filed by Mr. Bollea in federal court in Florida, The Hollywood Reporter said, “Hulk Boulder is shown humiliated and cracked into pieces with broken teeth, with the closing banner ‘Little Pieces...BIG TASTE!’ ” There was no immediate comment from Post Foods.

headline: Back in Arkansas, Clinton Backs Lincoln
text: On a day he was thrust back on center stage nationally, former President Bill Clinton also stumped for Senator Blanche Lincoln’s re-election, casting the Democratic incumbent as the choice of a calmer electorate at a rally on Friday.

headline: Judge Urges Resolution in Use of Obama Photo
text: A federal judge on Friday encouraged the parties involved in a dispute over Shepard Fairey’s “Hope” poster of Barack Obama, which is based on an Associated Press photograph, to come to a resolution, suggesting that The A.P. was likely to prevail in court. Mr. Fairey filed suit against The A.P. last year seeking a judge’s declaration that his poster was protected from copyright infringement claims. The A.P. then filed an infringement suit against Mr. Fairey, who has acknowledged that the poster was based on a photograph of Mr. Obama taken in 2006 by Mannie Garcia, a freelance photographer. On Friday, Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York said in a hearing that “whether it’s sooner or later, The Associated Press is going to win” the case. Though Mr. Garcia has said that he was not working for The A.P. when he took the photograph, lawyers for The A.P. presented evidence at the hearing, including human resources forms and other documents, that Mr. Garcia was employed by the news service at that time and that the photograph was a work for hire. Geoffrey S. Stewart, a lawyer for Mr. Fairey, said, “Mr. Fairey would of course be happy to resolve his differences on an amicable basis with The A.P., but it does not appear The A.P. is interested in it.” Dale Cendali, a lawyer for The A.P., said, “The A.P. was very encouraged by the hearing today and remains committed to vindicating the rights of photojournalists everywhere.” George Carpinello, a lawyer for Mr. Garcia, had asked at the hearing to be removed from representing the photographer, but said in an interview that he would stay on and hoped to meet with The A.P. next week.

headline: Morgan Stanley Raises Mack’s Salary to $2 Million

headline: One Man Won the Battle; the Other Won Hearts
text: What chance did the Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen ever have? Yes, he won the race to the South Pole in 1911, as an engrossing exhibition opening on Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History reminds us, leaving his British rival, Robert Falcon Scott, far behind. Yes, he made his way over uncharted Antarctic territory to the pole, taking 57 days to do what Scott, beginning from previously mapped terrain, could only do in 81. And yes, Amundsen attained the glory offered every pioneer in that waning era of exploration, without having lost a single man and with 39 of his sled dogs still alive, while Scott and his party, well ...

text: As the oil continues to spread in the Gulf of Mexico, I encourage you to read David Brooks’ column on “the bloody crossroads where complex technical systems meet human psychology,” as well as the 1996 Malcolm Gladwell article on complexity and hazard that Brooks alludes to.

headline: BP’s Murky Management of Information
text: From Louisiana’s tarred beaches to the silty scenes on the seabed a mile beneath the Gulf of Mexico, there have been repeated instances in which BP has tried to limit or delay the flow of information to the public on what is clearly now the biggest oil “spill” in United States history. Every time BP delays releasing information on its oil gusher and slick, the company’s credibility sinks a bit lower.

text: A Staten Island neighborhood that is dense with tall trees that overhang narrow and winding streets.

headline: Larger Units for a Richard Meier Condo
text: EIGHTEEN units have disappeared from On Prospect Park, the condominium building in Brooklyn designed by Richard Meier. The developer, SDS Procida, has been reworking the building’s interiors, originally expected to contain 114 units, to include more family-sized apartments. Now there are 96 units.

headline: Lighthouse Hill, Staten Island
text: CHARLES DeSTEFANO’S childhood memories of a certain Staten Island neighborhood were of quiet and beauty. So when he decided to move there nearly 40 years later, he was glad, and a bit shocked, to find that nothing had changed.

text: WITH private mortgage insurance considerably tougher to get last year than at any point in decades, many borrowers flocked to loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration.

headline: Staging 1970s TV for 1950s Memories
text: As a hit television show set in the 1950s and early ’60s, “Happy Days” dished up nostalgia to audiences in the ’70s and ’80s. Its weekly forays into the world of Jefferson High and its students, evoking the era when Sputnik circled the globe and Elvis reigned as the king of rock ’n’ roll, proved an irresistible formula for 11 seasons.

headline: Our Way of Saying Goodbye
text: TWELVE years ago, after 18 months of marriage, my husband left me unexpectedly, and when I could finally rouse myself to do anything, I booked a flight to Italy. Every time I’d been there, I’d felt happier, more alive, and I hoped that by speaking another language I would become another person for a while, one whose heart was whole.

headline: Old Battle, New Play: Religion vs. Science
text: Joe DiPietro does crowd-pleasing for a living. Mr. DiPietro is the playwright who gave us “I Love You, You’re Perfect, Now Change” and, on Broadway this season, the musical “Memphis.” With “Creating Claire,” now in its world premiere at the George Street Playhouse, he seems to be trying to please both sides of a fierce debate: the one between religion and science, creationism versus evolution.

headline: The Morning Line: Dave in Dixie Added to Belmont Fray

headline: A Night at the Apollo, Starring Teachers
text: JOHN MORO, a walkie-talkie-wielding dean, was patrolling the halls of the Celia Cruz Bronx High School of Music one recent afternoon, droning, “Let’s go! Ladies, walk and talk please.” Lisa Gwasda was leading her choir class in lilting 16th-century madrigals, Paula Kadanoff was teaching a health class on safe sex, and Matthew Daley was coaxing ideas from his senior English class about the use of hubris in “Beowulf,” “Macbeth,” “Oedipus Rex” and Percy Bysshe Shelley’s “Ozymandias.”

headline: Taliban Leave Pakistan, but Afghans Repel Them
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  After five days of fighting, the Afghan border police, supported by American helicopters, repelled a force of Pakistani Taliban who appeared to have crossed the border to try to carve out a new haven in Afghanistan’s Nuristan Province, according to Afghan officials.

headline: Piers on the Hudson: A Carousel World
text: Five hundred fifty feet off the coast of Chelsea, the eel and the horseshoe crab were having a grand time of it, bobbing along in interspecies embrace. The Atlantic sturgeon was rising and falling on gentle currents. Butterflies were everywhere. And Miley Cyrus was singing.

headline: South Korea Expands Aid for Internet Addiction
text: SUWON, South Korea  Neither had a job. They were shy and had never dated anyone until they met through an online chat site in 2008. They married, but they knew so little about childbearing that the 25-year-old woman did not know when her baby was due until her water broke.

headline: It’s Not Just Drug Dealers Who Buy Prepaid Phones
text: There are reporters in New York who carry a half-dozen prepaid cellphones, loaded with minutes purchased in cash. The numbers are not registered to a real person, nor do they have to be under current law. They are peace of mind for confidential sources who have something to say but don’t want to make calls to a phone associated with a reporter or a news organization.

headline: Granderson Welcome Sight as the Yankees Seek Depth
text: Before speaking with reporters Friday afternoon, Curtis Granderson tucked in his shirt, slipped two titanium-embedded necklaces around his neck, and reached into his locker to grab his glove and remove his bat from its bag. Stretching was about to begin, and he did not want anything holding him back.

headline: And the Parrot Said, ‘Bonjour’
text: Aaron Edward (Hotch) Hotchner, 89 by most accounts, came to fame with “Papa Hemingway,” his 1966 biography of his friend Ernest Hemingway. He recently wrote “Paul and Me: 53 Years of Adventures and Misadventures With My Pal Paul Newman.” Mr. Hotchner and his wife, Virginia Kiser, live on the Upper East Side and in Westport, Conn., where he spends most weekends, along with an African gray parrot and a flock of peacocks and chickens. CARA BUCKLEY

headline: Thai Fondue to Start the Night
text: There is a certain sort of New York evening — varied in its pleasures, meandering in its rhythms, open to spontaneous events — that is good to start with a communal meal. It gives one a base on which to build, and on Monday nights at the Asian bistro Kittichai, at 60 Thompson Street in SoHo, that base is Thai fondue, with diners cooking proteins and veggies in bubbling pots of broth and then bathing them in sauces. Among those at the outset of an excursion into the city you might find trumpeters or European tourists or an impromptu gathering of friends who would soon be parting ways. ALAN FEUER

headline: Times Square Terror
text: WHEN a major event occurs with implications for one of the city’s ethnic groups, the ethnic press responds — sometimes analytically, sometimes angrily, sometimes defensively. In recent weeks, three newspapers — two Pakistani and one Indian — reported or reflected on the attempt by a Pakistani-American, Faisal Shahzad, to detonate a car bomb in Times Square. Here are excerpts translated with help from the New York Community Media Alliance.

It is no exaggeration to say that the Carolee Schneemann retrospective there is one of the best exhibitions in the Hudson Valley. headline: Nepal Avoids Crisis in Deal to Extend Parliament

headline: South Africa: Paper Apologizes for Cartoon of Muhammad
text: The Mail & Guardian said Friday that it had underestimated “the depth of anger ignited” by a cartoon it published last week that depicted the Prophet Muhammad lying on a psychiatrist’s couch with a thought bubble over his head that said, “Other prophets have followers with a sense of humor!” The weekly said it regretted “the sense of injury it caused many Muslims.” The cartoon was by Jonathan Shapiro, known as Zapiro, whose sharp satiric pen has gouged many a politician.

headline: Haiti: Ex-Director of Prison Is Taken Into Custody
text: The former director of the prison in Les Cayes, where a dozen or more inmates were shot dead on Jan. 19, was taken into custody by the judicial police in Port-au-Prince on Thursday, according to a United Nations official. It did not appear that the former director, Sylvestre Larack, was under arrest as of Friday evening, but he remained in isolation at the judicial police headquarters and he was not free to leave, the official said. After the inmate deaths in Les Cayes, Mr. Larack had been promoted to run the country’s largest prison, the national penitentiary in Port-au-Prince. Last Sunday, The New York Times published a report on the killings at Les Cayes, indicating that the authorities had shot unarmed detainees and then sought to cover it up. This provoked the Haitian president, René Préval, to establish a joint Haitian-United Nations commission of inquiry, and Mr. Larack, who was found last month to have lied to police investigators about the killings, is being questioned once again.

headline: Workers Squeezing Honda With Especially Costly Strike
text: FOSHAN, China  In going on strike at a transmission factory, workers here have Honda by the jugular, although it was not entirely clear at the employees’ dormitory on Friday that they realized this.

He solved both problems by moving to A. H. Parker High School and now, after one season at the University of Kentucky, he is awaiting a lucrative payday in next month’s N.B.A. draft.

headline: Art Did the Darndest Things . . . to Your Jokes
text: The voice of the editor wondered if, instead of the column I would have handed in this time, I might want to do a short, quick appreciation of Art Linkletter. My only reluctance in accepting the mission is that what I have to offer may not be everyone’s idea of an appreciation.

headline: An Enigma to the End, Artest Joins Lakers Lore
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  Somewhere along the way, the villain became the eccentric. Ron Artest morphed from unpredictably dangerous to merely unpredictable. His soundtrack is no longer the Darth Vader theme, but Looney Tunes.

headline: Sand, Surf and Quesadillas
text: Pop’s Garage, a colorful taquería on the Boardwalk in Asbury Park, has a funky, south-of-the-border vibe. There’s nothing fancy on the menu — tacos, burritos, quesadillas and the like — which takes its cue from the kind of casual food you might find at a Mexican beach resort.

headline: Specialty of the House? Improvisation
text: FOR years, the residents of Ho-Ho-Kus, Glen Rock, Ridgewood and other nearby towns in Bergen County had Kevin Oppici and his eclectic American cuisine pretty much to themselves, if only for lunch, takeout or catered events. Then, in September 2008, he started serving dinner, and the secret began to get out.

headline: The Moynihan Future

headline: When Afghans Seek Medical Aid, Tough Choice for U.S.
text: KHAN NESHIN, Afghanistan  Five-year-old Sadiq was not a casualty of war. He was simply unlucky. The boy had opened a sack of grain at his home early on Wednesday morning, and a pit viper coiled inside lashed up and bit him above the lip.

headline: Emerging Centers Reach Premier Stage
text: Crosby versus Ovechkin has been the N.H.L.’s marquee matchup for some time  in the regular season, in the playoffs, in the Olympics, in next year’s Winter Classic. But now the Stanley Cup finals are here, and two other young captains have taken hockey’s center stage with their skill, fire and leadership.

headline: Jamaica Accused of Brutality in Hunting Suspect
text: KINGSTON, Jamaica  The search for her son’s body brought Lynette Armstrong down a cemetery path in west Kingston on Friday, past bushes of Chinese honeysuckle and bloodstained clothes to a jumble of 24 wooden coffins, strewn this way and that.

headline: As ‘Don’t Ask’ Fades, Military Faces Thorny Issues
text: For opponents of the ban against homosexuals serving openly in the military, the steps by Congress this week to repeal the policy, known as “don’t ask, don’t tell,” were a major victory. But now they are girding for what may be an equally difficult task: the transition to a force where straight and openly gay servicemen and women live, work and fight alongside one other.

headline: Dealing With Pakistan
text: Nine years after the 9/11 attacks, the United States is still trying to figure out how to manage relations with Pakistan  and what mix of inducements and public and private pressures will persuade Islamabad to fully commit to the fight against extremists.

headline: Food for Thought
text: It’s been a long time since I’ve eaten a meal that I could honestly call motivational. But after a mind-bending lunch of macrobiotic soup, ancient grains and agave-sweetened smoothies on the garden patio at the O2 Live Food Café, I vowed to start eating more thoughtfully.

headline: A Renovated Menu, With a Wealth of Choices
text: SOME might remember the Toska brothers, Rui and Aris, who in 1988 transformed the Hearth restaurant into L’Europe, introducing a menu of fancy French-Continental dishes — still in their butter-and-cream heyday — to Vista, then a sleepy area of South Salem. Many years and several renovations later, Jeff Toska (Aris’s son) took over the restaurant, renamed it One Twenty Three (the number of the route it’s on), and gave the menu a decidedly contemporary cast, with most sauces thin or sheer and salads galore.

headline: Owners Bet on Raising the Rent, and Lost
text: The first signs of financial turmoil came at Riverton Houses in Harlem.

headline: On Graduation Day, Seniors Take Time to Feel Like Kindergartners Again
text: When Nitya Rajendran started kindergarten, she didn’t talk until November. “She’d point and wave,” said her teacher, Rick Parbst. This year she was the lead in Trinity School’s spring musical and decided to translate parts of “The Iliad” from ancient Greek. She’s headed to Georgetown University in September.

headline: Unintelligent Design
text: There doesn’t seem to be anything terribly unethical about the White House offer of an unpaid advisory position to Joe Sestak if he would bow out of the Pennsylvania Democratic primary, in which he later defeated Senator Arlen Specter. There does, however, seem to be something strikingly unintelligent about it.

headline: Brewers May Be Peterson’s Toughest Task Yet

With the roof open at Miller Park, the pitchers did their tossing, running and core conditioning under the supervision of Rick Peterson, the former Mets pitching coach who joined Milwaukee last winter.

headline: Judge Grants Injunction Against Paterson Furlough Plan

headline: Will That Be Cash? Or Big Bank Fees?
text: Small retailers have complained for decades about the seemingly arbitrary fees that they are required to pay Visa and MasterCard for processing debit transactions. The Senate finally responded earlier this month when it added price controls on the controversial fees to its financial reform bill.

headline: Endangered Parks
text: There are more than 13 million acres of state parks in the United States. The national park system is far bigger  some 84 million acres  but state parks are far more heavily used, if only because they are our neighborhood parks. As states look for ways to slash budgets during this recession, state parks are in serious trouble.

headline: Punjabi Heart, Legal Mind, Hip-Hop Soul
text: The résumé that Bikram Singh could draft is not the kind that employers come across every day.

headline: A Potential Obama Ally Becomes an Outspoken Foe on Immigration

A nine-term Democrat, he had cut his political teeth in the wards of Chicago, just as Barack Obama did, and the two knew each other from their parallel early careers in Illinois.

text: The House passed a bill on Friday that would end a tax break for executives of investment funds, leaving hedge funds, private equity firms and venture capitalists scrambling to ease the effects of the bill before it is taken up by the Senate next month.

headline: The Politicking Behind an Offer to a Specter Foe
