text: Charli Carpenter, left, of the University of Massachusetts-Amherst and Daniel Drezner of Tufts University debate assassinating Anwar Al-Awlaki.

headline: No Terror Evidence Against Some Detainees
text: WASHINGTON  The 48 Guantánamo Bay detainees whom the Obama administration has decided to keep holding without trial include several for whom there is no evidence of involvement in any specific terrorist plot, according to a report disclosed Friday.

headline: Another Blow to Guantánamo Plan
text: The Senate Armed Services Committee voted to bar the construction of a military detention center in Thomson, Ill., in a further blow to the Obama administration’s fading hopes of shuttering the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The committee met behind closed doors on Thursday to vote on amendments to the 2011 national defense authorization bill. On Friday, it released a summary of the results, which included the prison issue. The Obama administration has proposed spending $350 million to renovate a prison in Thomson and transfer dozens of Guantánamo detainees there. The House version of the bill contains a similar restriction, so the Senate committee’s decision means the final package is virtually certain to include such a ban.

headline: Island’s Trout Rodeo Is Victim of Spill, and That’s Not the Least of It
text: GRAND ISLE, La.  The directors of the Grand Isle Speckled Trout Rodeo had sold 500 tickets to the Memorial Day weekend event when the oil washed up on the beach here last week. They had paid for the band and the food, the visors and the door prizes.

headline: 189 Nations Reaffirm Goal of Ban on Nuclear Weapons
text: UNITED NATIONS  Hard-fought negotiations over the future of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty ended here on Friday with 189 nations reaffirming their commitment to eliminating all nuclear weapons and setting a new 2012 deadline for holding a regional conference to eliminate unconventional weapons from the Middle East.

headline: Gaza Flotilla Organizers Protest Israeli Response to Their Mission
text: Organizers of a flotilla of up to nine vessels carrying hundreds of pro-Palestinian activists and thousands of tons of supplies for Gaza protested on Friday against what they called an Israeli disinformation campaign aimed at their mission. Israel has vowed to stop the boats from reaching Gaza, which is controlled by the Islamic militant group Hamas, and insists that there is no humanitarian crisis in the Palestinian coastal enclave. “For over four years,” the organizers said in a statement, “Israel has subjected the civilian population of Gaza to an increasingly severe blockade, resulting in a man-made humanitarian catastrophe of epic proportions.” The boats were expected to approach the coast sometime over the weekend. The aim, the organizers said, was to break through the “illegal” Israeli blockade “in non-violent direct action.”

headline: A Perkins Technical Could Prove Costly
text: The Celtics’ Kendrick Perkins had better watch out — after his next technical foul, he will be forced to sit out a game. Having accumulated six technicals over the course of 16 games — with as many as nine left to play — he had better make sure his suit is pressed, as he’ll need something to wear while sitting on the sideline. It isn’t hyperbole to say that a technical foul at a critical juncture can alter the course of this year’s playoffs.

headline: Ex-Officer’s Conviction for Murder Is Reinstated
text: Just 20 months after the murder conviction of a former New York City police officer was overturned, an appeals court reinstated it this week and ordered him sent back to prison.

headline: Yankees Find Stride, With a Few Adjustments
text: The Yankees’ favorable schedule, with 13 of 16 games against the three worst teams in baseball, gives them a chance to fatten their victory total and improve their standing in the American League East. That is one way to look at it. Here is another view, courtesy of General Manager Brian Cashman:

headline: A New Pragmatism Behind the Catwalk
text: PARIS  A postrecession strategy likely to define luxury brand management for the early 21st century has emerged from a week packed with designer changes at European fashion houses.

headline: England: Serial Killing Suspect Calls Himself ‘Crossbow Cannibal’
text: A 40-year-old man accused of murdering three prostitutes in the northern city of Bradford identified himself as “the crossbow cannibal” on Friday at his first court appearance. British newspapers have compared Stephen Griffiths, left, a Ph.D. student in criminology, with Peter Sutcliffe, the Bradford-based man known as the Yorkshire Ripper, who was convicted in 1981 of killing 13 women, including several prostitutes.

headline: France: Tombs of German Soldiers From World Wars Are Vandalized
text: The tombs of nearly 100 German soldiers killed during the First and Second World Wars were desecrated on Thursday night at a cemetery on land in Eastern France that once belonged to Germany. Unidentified vandals smashed crosses on 95 of the 1,238 German graves at the Guebwiller cemetery, which holds the remains of about 2,500 French and German war veterans. An offensive slogan was also left on one grave. President Nicolas Sarkozy of France called the act “revolting and cowardly” in a letter to President Horst Köhler of Germany.

headline: France: Noriega Request Rejected
text: A Paris appellate court on Friday rejected a request by the former Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega to be freed from prison pending a late June trial, deeming him a flight risk. Mr. Noriega has been held here since his extradition last month from the United States. He is to be tried on charges that he laundered $3 million in Colombian drug money through international banks and into French accounts in 1988 and 1989; Mr. Noriega has said the money came from payments from the Central Intelligence Agency, which once considered him a valued asset; his brother’s inheritance; and his wife’s personal fortune. A French court convicted him in absentia on the same charges in 1999. A lawyer for Mr. Noriega said his client would appeal.

headline: China: Sentencing in Mine Death
text: Three men and one woman have been sentenced in Yunnan Province for killing a mentally challenged man in a mine, making it look like an accident and pretending to be family members of the victim to get compensation from the mine owner, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency. The four killed Cai Qianwen in October 2009 by shoving him down a mine shaft, according to the court in Yunnan. They then approached the mine owner and asked for $42,500 in compensation, saying they were relatives of Mr. Cai. The owner called the police. Two assailants were given suspended death sentences, and two others were sentenced to 15 years in prison. It is unclear whether the case is related to the arrests in late 2009 of nine people in Sichuan Province who were accused of killing or helping kill mentally challenged people in mines to extort money. The crimes resemble the plot of “Blind Shaft,” a 2003 Chinese movie.

headline: Saturday’s Epic Battles
text: The most dramatic moments in sports often take place when the outcome cannot be determined in regulation. And in  a tennis match, the pulse quickens (for both players and fans) in extended, no-tiebreaker final sets.

headline: Radio Program About Faith Defies the Skeptics
text: ST. PAUL  Not yet 30 and a veteran of two lives already, Krista Tippett retreated in the summer of 1988 to a rented room on an island off Spain. There, perhaps, her next direction would make itself known.

headline: Holiday on Monday — Memorial Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: After Governor’s Pardon, an Immigrant Is Sworn in as a Citizen
text: It was his application for United States citizenship that derailed the American life of Qing Hong Wu, an information-technology executive who had risen from poverty and street crime in Chinatown. He had fulfilled the promise he made to the judge who sentenced him for teenage muggings, but immigration authorities jailed him for mandatory deportation to China, a country he had left at age 5.

headline: Brewers’ 9th-Inning Home Run Ends Two Mets Streaks
text: MILWAUKEE  Johan Santana had a three-hit shutout going, and the Mets were riding a streak of 35 consecutive scoreless innings. Santana felt strong enough to pitch the ninth inning of a tie game Friday night, but Manager Jerry Manuel did not let him.

headline: City Contests Role for Morgenthau in Fire Dept. Case
text: Citing “a public and well-reported dispute” between Robert M. Morgenthau and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the city asked a federal judge on Friday to reconsider the appointment of Mr. Morgenthau to oversee the city’s efforts to increase the number of black and Hispanic firefighters in response to a long-running discrimination lawsuit.

headline: A Daunting Season for 5 Gulf Governors
text: Most of the region’s governors have changed their responses to the oil spill as the scope of the disaster has grown.

headline: Photo Replay: May 28
text: A view of the day in sports, with athletes getting ready for soccer’s World Cup and the Indianapolis 500.

headline: Curtiss Anderson, Editor and Developer of Magazines, Dies at 81
text: Curtiss Anderson, who edited The Ladies Home Journal in the early 1960s during a particularly tumultuous period in the magazine’s history, and as an editor with Hearst Magazines helped create Country Living and Smart Money, died on May 22 at his home in Tiburon, Calif. He was 81.

headline: Battered, the Celtics Have Enough to Advance
text: BOSTON  Nate Robinson danced, hollered and thumped his chest with enough force to revive a struggling heart. It might have been enough to summon the ghosts of past Boston Celtics icons. Soon, his pace had the entire TD Garden crowd moving at his frenetic rhythm.

headline: Fritz Sennheiser, Founder of Audio Electronics Company, Dies at 98
text: Fritz Sennheiser, the founder and longtime chairman of Sennheiser Electronic, a leading maker of high-end audio equipment like microphones, headphones and infrared listening systems, died on May 17 at his home in Wedemark, Germany. He was 98.

headline: Now That Was a Shutout Streak
text: In shutting out Philadelphia three straight times this week, the Mets delighted their fans and stunned the Phillies. They also brought back memories of the championship season of 1969, when Mets pitchers hurled four shutouts in a row, all of them in late September as the team clinched the first division title in its history.

headline: The Latest on the Oil Spill
text: Obama Visits Louisiana

headline: A Daunting Start of Summer for 5 Gulf State Governors
text: If all politics is local, then the politics of disaster is personal.

headline: Some Page Turners in Time for Father’s Day
text: The most distinctive book about Tiger Woods this spring has nothing to do with his recent life and everything to do with the college golf season of 1994-95. So “The Last Putt: Two Teams, One Dream, and a Freshman Named Tiger” (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt) is not a book written with an eye on Woods’s recent tribulations. Still, Woods the teenager and collegian comes alive in new ways, teamed with Notah Begay and Casey Martin in Stanford’s face-off at the 1995 N.C.A.A. championship against golf powerhouse Oklahoma State. This is a stroke-by-stroke tale by authors Neil Hayes and Brian Murphy with many subplots, on and off the golf course. The championship comes down to a sudden-death playoff, and so, you have to ask yourself: Who would you want standing over the last putt?

headline: Live ‘Glee’ Favors Exuberance Over Plot
text: Perky to the max, the television phenomenon “Glee” shed its plotlines and flaunted its young troupers’ gusto and its karaoke repertory for “Glee Live! In Concert” on Friday night, starting a sold-out three-night stand at Radio City Music Hall that completes a four-city tour.

headline: Your Jokes: ‘Why Is BP Taking So Long?’
text: Use the comment link below. One joke per comment, please:

headline: Operators of Drones Are Faulted in Afghan Deaths
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The American military on Saturday released a scathing report on the deaths of 23 Afghan civilians, saying that “inaccurate and unprofessional” reporting by Predator drone operators helped lead to an airstrike in February on a group of innocent men, women and children.

headline: 114th-Ranked Qualifier Beats Roddick at French Open
text: PARIS - Losing in the first week of the French Open is not a surprising result for Andy Roddick. Despite his top-10 ranking and No. 6 seed at Roland Garros, Roddick is hardly ever considered a contender here. Only once, last year, has he reached the fourth round.

headline: The Compleat Andy Pettitte
text: Bill Chuck created Billy-Ball.com and is a co-author of Walkoffs, Last Licks, and Final Outs. He grew up in New York and now lives with his wife (a Red Sox fan), and daughter (a Yankees fan), two miles from Fenway Park while Bill claims to be Switzerland. His other daughter lives in New York City, away from the fray. You can follow him on Twitter.

headline: The Saturday Word: Memorial Day
text: During his weekly national address on Saturday, President Obama marked Memorial Day and honored the Americans who died while serving the country, along with their families.

headline: Webber Takes Pole in Turkey, as Alonso Suffers
text: ISTANBUL — It was not a very exciting qualifying session on the surface at the Istanbul Park racetrack in Turkey today, but the results were full of stories.

headline: Franklin and the Race He Lost
text: It’s not every day you get the opportunity to ride horses with a Derby winning jockey, but that has been my good fortune this week. Ron Franklin has been riding for us at Fair Hill. Of course I could not wait to quiz Ron about his rides on Spectacular Bid.

headline: Urban Forager |  ‘Oh My God, That’s 30,000 Bees’
text: Recently, as I was walking across the southern end of my college campus, I encountered a giant, buzzing swarm of bees making drunken patterns in the air. Another professor, several yards ahead of me, stopped and asked, “What are they?”

headline: China Offers Condolences Over Ship
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China offered condolences on Saturday to South Korea for the sinking of one of its warships in March, The Associated Press reported.

headline: ‘Avenue Q’ Deals With Death of Gary Coleman
text: Sitting alone at the rear of the house at New World Stages on Friday night, Jeff Whitty wept after that evening’s performance of “Avenue Q.”

headline: Attack Bares South Korea’s Complex Links to North
text: MUNSAN, South Korea  Like many South Koreans, Choi Byung-wook said he felt outrage over the North Korean attack that sank the warship Cheonan and killed 46 sailors. But he also said that he did not expect the hostilities to get any worse and that his nation must continue to engage the North.

headline: Rubble of a Broken City Strains Haitians’ Patience
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  With graffiti and protests, from sweltering tents to air-conditioned offices, Haitians are desperately trying to get a message to their government and the world: enough with the status quo.

headline: Sestak Case Casts Light on Murky Political Boundaries
text: WASHINGTON  When the White House enlisted former President Bill Clinton to see if Representative Joe Sestak would accept a presidential appointment to drop out of a Senate race, there is no question it was committing politics. But was it committing a crime?

headline: Malawi President Pardons Gay Couple
text: JOHANNESBURG  A gay couple in Malawi sentenced to 14 years in prison for “unnatural acts” was pardoned Saturday shortly after Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations met with that country’s president.

headline: Rezai’s Run Comes Up Short Against Petrova
text: PARIS  —  Aravane Rezai of France is short (5 feet 5 inches), spunky, and shrieks when she wins a point, raising a fist to emphasize she has the upper hand at the moment.

headline: Taliban Push Afghan Police Out of Valley
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban fighters took control of a remote district near the Pakistani border on Saturday, scattering the forces of the Afghan government, who said they had run out of ammunition.

headline: Mashed P’s Plus Two
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — We get two variety puzzles this weekend, both by our puzzlemaster, Will Shortz. They are slightly harder versions of the kinds of puzzles you can play on the air with Mr. Shortz and Liane Hansen.

headline: Garagiola, Who Quit, Warns About Chewing Tobacco
text: Joe Garagiola has been to too many funerals. Some of them were for friends who chewed tobacco, the way Garagiola used to do.

headline: Economic Downturn Does Little to Slow Migration
text: The world may be staggering through its worst economy in 70 years, but international migration, an ever-growing force, shows few signs of retreat.

headline: A Sidekick Adds Luster to a Star
text: PHOENIX  Long after their Lakers teammates departed the locker room, Kobe Bryant and Derek Fisher lingered in the adjacent trainer’s area, visible through a plate glass window and in no apparent hurry to explain a stinging playoff defeat to reporters before they had seethed over it with each other.

headline: Faltering Hope in Haiti
text: In the physically ruined capital, Port-au-Prince, Haitians living among ruins get on with their daily lives.

headline: Woods Is Back on the Course and Back Under Scrutiny
text: When Tiger Woods tees off in the Memorial Tournament this week, his neck will be under surveillance as much as his game.

headline: Documents Show Early Worries About Safety of Rig
text: WASHINGTON  Internal documents from BP show that there were serious problems and safety concerns with the Deepwater Horizon rig far earlier than those the company described to Congress last week.

headline: Foes and Supporters of New Immigration Law Gather in Arizona
text: PHOENIX  Two sides of the immigration debate converged here Saturday: a throng of several thousand marching for five miles opposed to Arizona’s new immigration law, and several thousand nearly filling a nearby stadium in the evening in support of it.

headline: In Camouflage or Veil, a Fragile Bond
text: ABDUL GHAYAS, Afghanistan — Two young female Marines trudged along with an infantry patrol in the 102-degree heat, soaked through their camouflage uniforms under 60 pounds of gear. But only when they reached this speck of a village in the Taliban heartland on a recent afternoon did their hard work begin.

headline: Serena Williams Survives Third-Round Scare
text: PARIS — As Andy Roddick was losing on one court, Serena Williams looked like she would become a bigger upset victim on another.

headline: BP Prepares to Take New Tack on Leak After ‘Top Kill’ Fails
text: NEW ORLEANS  In another serious setback in the effort to stem the flow of oil gushing from a well a mile beneath the Gulf of Mexico, BP engineers said Saturday that the “top kill” technique had failed and, after consultation with government officials, they had decided to move on to another strategy.

headline: Celtics Used Season as 82-Game Camp
text: BOSTON  It was a concoction of gut feelings, gambles, the luck of the draw and, finally, a firm plan. Coach Doc Rivers played the role of puppet master during the Boston Celtics’ regular-season slumber and postseason drive, tightening rotations and loosening them.

headline: Gary Coleman Keeps His Address on ‘Avenue Q’
text: Sitting alone at the rear of the house at New World Stages on Friday night, Jeff Whitty wept after the performance of “Avenue Q.”

headline: Handmade Hoops Put Clang Into New York Courts
text: The old steel rim that presides over this public basketball court absorbs missed shots with an angry clank, sending the ball careening upward and the wood and metal backboard into a rickety seizure.

headline: Blackhawks: Cursed, or Concoction?
text: Lynn Treacy, an 85-year-old high school tennis coach and retired chemical engineer, is watching hockey regularly for the first time in 35 years.

headline: U.S. First XI vs. Turkey
text: 6:05 p.m. | Updated PHILADELPHIA — Defender Oguchi Onyewu was left out of the United States’ starting lineup for Saturday’s exhibition against Turkey.

headline: Improbable Benefactor Helps a Novice Breeder
text: Greg McAfee is not a Kentucky blueblood. He is not a retired Wall Streeter, nor is he a deep-pocketed sheik. Still, like them, he shares a passion for thoroughbreds, and he believes he knows a thing or two about conjuring fast horses in the breeding shed.

headline: The Hard Sell on Salt
text: With salt under attack for its ill effects on the nation’s health, the food giant Cargill kicked off a campaign last November to spread its own message.

headline: Happy 15th Anniversary, Derek Jeter
text: Fifteen years ago Saturday, the Yankees’ career hit leader went 0 for 5 in his first major league game. Derek Jeter debuted in Seattle on May 29, 1995, and, as former colleague Jack Curry details in this story, commemorated the occasion with a meal at McDonald’s, the first open restaurant he and his father, Charles, could find.

headline: Ex-Cub Finds He’s Really a Brewer
text: Casey McGehee was born on the morning of Oct. 12, 1982, and by the early evening his father had already found a diversion. He was watching the first game of the World Series.

headline: Oswalt Wants Out of Houston, but It Isn’t Personal
text: MILWAUKEE  For eight innings Wednesday at Miller Park, Roy Oswalt was the picture of stoic efficiency for the Houston Astros. He would rock his smallish frame, fling a 94-mile-an-hour fastball, a darting changeup or a wicked slider past a helpless batter, then grab the throw from his catcher and quickly do it again.

headline: Our Fix-It Faith and the Oil Spill
text: “IF we’ve learned anything so far about the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, it is that it contains surprises. And that means an operator needs depth  depth in terms of resources and expertise  to create the capability to respond to the unexpected. ”

headline: Yankees Place Confidence in Cano and He Responds
text: Nearly 50 games into the season, Robinson Cano leads the Yankees in batting average, on-base percentage, slugging percentage, hits, runs scored, home runs, doubles, total bases and runs batted in. He has been the best player on the second-best team in baseball, and there is no telling just how good Cano can be.

headline: Dennis Hopper, Actor and Iconoclast, Dies
text: 3:19 p.m. | Updated Dennis Hopper, whose portrayals of drug-addled, often deranged misfits in the landmark films “Easy Rider,” “Apocalypse Now” and “Blue Velvet” drew on his early out-of-control experiences as part of a new generation of Hollywood rebel, died at his home in Venice, Calif., on Saturday. He was 74.

headline: Dennis Hopper, Actor and Director, Is Dead at 74
text: Mr. Hopper, who acted and directed in the film “Easy Rider” and drew on his early out-of-control experiences as part of a new generation of Hollywood rebel, died from complications of prostate cancer.

headline: Bryan Brothers Ousted in French Open Surprise
text: PARIS — Two Brazilian journeymen ambushed the top-seeded American doubles team of Bob and Mike Bryan, 6-3, 7-6 (6) in the second round of the men’s doubles on Saturday. The upset sent the French Open doubles seedings into disarray.

headline: 3,000 Pages of Financial Reform, but Still Not Enough
text: FOR decades, until Congress did away with it 11 years ago, a Depression-era law known as Glass-Steagall ably protected bank customers, individual investors and the financial system as a whole from the kind of outright destruction we’ve witnessed over the last few years.

headline: In Hamlin, Nascar Has Flashy  Character With Lots of Speed
text: HUNTERSVILLE, N.C.  In the sometimes bland Nascar garage, at least one driver has dared to criticize the powerful, call out the untouchable, slap down the unbearable and catch the seemingly uncatchable.

headline: The Doctor Will See You Now. Please Log On.
text: ONE day last summer, Charlie Martin felt a sharp pain in his lower back. But he couldn’t jump into his car and rush to the doctor’s office or the emergency room: Mr. Martin, a crane operator, was working on an oil rig in the South China Sea off Malaysia.

headline: Spoleto Festival Opens, and So Does the Revamped Dock Street Theater

headline: The Impact of the Irrelevant on Decision-Making
text: TEXTBOOK economic models assume that people are well informed about all the options they’re considering. It’s an absurd claim, of course, as most economists are well aware.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 30
text: The enormous oil spill still spreading in the Gulf will be the focus of discussions Sunday, along with immigration and a host of foreign policy issues.

headline: Obamas in Chicago: Hoops and the House
text: CHICAGO – President Obama told sportscaster Marv Albert earlier this week that he likes to play basketball because, “It takes an edge off things.” On Saturday he had to be feeling edgy about reports that the latest attempts to stop the gulf oil leak are going badly. And he headed for the hoops.

headline: How Far Will Europe’s Economic Tremors Reach?
text: THE debt crisis in Europe has already had a significant psychological impact on Wall Street, sending the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index down 10.5 percent from its April high.

headline: Suddenly, the Rating Agencies Don’t Look Untouchable
text: An article last Sunday about debt rating agencies referred incorrectly to a judge’s preliminary ruling in a case involving a structured investment vehicle sold by Cheyne Capital. The judge denied part of a motion by Standard & Poor’s and Moody’s to dismiss the case, saying in her ruling that free-speech arguments will fail if plaintiffs ultimately prove that the ratings bestowed by the agencies in this instance were never publicly disseminated. The judge did not say that the agencies cannot use the First Amendment as a defense.

headline: When Patients Meet Online, Are There Side Effects?
text: COULD we cure diseases faster, or at least better control them, through crowd-sourcing?

headline: Indians Pitcher Taken Off Field After He’s Hit by Liner
text: The Cleveland left-hander David Huff was struck in the head by a line drive in the third inning Saturday and left Yankee Stadium in an ambulance. Huff, who was taken off on a stretcher, raised his left arm as he was wheeled off the field.

headline: Spoleto Festival: Puppets Upstage Haydn
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — If the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. here were awarding a prize for the best curtain calls, it could have shut down the competition after opening night. After the performance of Haydn’s puppet opera “Philemon and Baucis,” by the Carlo Colla and Sons Marionette Company of Milan in the Emmett Robinson Theater at the College of Charleston on Friday evening, each of the offstage singers or actors joined his or her puppet counterpart on stage, walking with them hand in hand. The humans seemed Gullivers in the land of Lilliput, huge, hulking figures, overwhelming the stage.

headline: YouTube Wants You to Sit and Stay Awhile
text: TWO weeks ago, YouTube celebrated when the number of videos viewed daily on its site reached two billion, a milestone.

headline: Gerald Roush, Font of Ferrari Knowledge, Is Dead at 68
text: In 1958, Gerald Roush, a teenage auto enthusiast in Birmingham, Ala., picked up a copy of Sports Cars Illustrated, the magazine that would later become Car and Driver. On the cover was the race driver Phil Hill, the winner that year of the Le Mans 24-hour road race, and an Italian sports car, the Ferrari 4.9 Superfast. In that moment, an obsession was born.

headline: William Pflaumer, Philadelphia Beer Baron, Dies at 76
text: William H. Pflaumer, a street-smart Philadelphia beer baron who turned the 116-year-old Christian Schmidt and Sons Inc. brewery into one of the nation’s largest, only to see it close after he was sent to federal prison for tax evasion, died on May 22 in Philadelphia. He was 76.

headline: Memorial Day Mileposts
text: In 2003, I trained with four other career military physicians from West Point for the Army Ten-Miler held at the Pentagon. It was one of those rare opportunities for a group of middle-aged guys, often immersed in professional and family commitments, to simply have fun. Col. Brian Allgood was the linchpin.

headline: Man Arrested in Killing of Brooklyn Teenager
text: Two days after a 16-year-old Brooklyn girl was chased down and fatally shot on a street near her home, investigators have arrested an 18-year-old man in the killing, the police said on Saturday.

headline: Unrest May Signal New Phase in China Economy

headline: Growing Up With the Family Brewery
text: MY father, Ken Grossman, started Sierra Nevada Brewing Company with a partner 30 years ago and bought him out in 1998. I always knew I wanted to work in the family business. As a kid, I was always there. I learned how to ride a bicycle in the parking lot, and I’d tinker in the maintenance shop. I’ve grown up around some of the employees.

headline: New Kindle Expected This Summer, Touch Possible Later
text: Amazon could release a new slimmer Kindle in August, Bloomberg News reports, citing “two people familiar with its plans.”

headline: Three Separate Challenges
text: My colleague Suzy Menkes raises good points in an analysis about the turnover at three European houses this week, but I don’t agree with her conclusion that it represents a sea change for the industry. Each house — that is, Ungaro, Hermès and Alexander McQueen — has a unique set of circumstances that led to a change in designers.

headline: Keep Opening Doors
text: I GREW up in a family of limited means. Both my grandfathers were ministers. Church, family and sports were important. I have five brothers, so we always had enough kids for a team.

headline: For the Chief of Saks, It’s Culture That Drives Results
text: This interview with Stephen I. Sadove, chairman and chief executive of Saks Inc.,  was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Boys Left Behind
text: If you saw Friday’s episode of “Friday Night Lights,” you might share my instinct to work backwards, the final moment having brought Matt Saracen another occasion for heartache. Returning to Dillon from a hunting trip with Riggins, he stops off to see Julie before going home and she has some devastating news: Matt’s father has been killed in Iraq.

headline: Obama’s Katrina? Maybe Worse
text: FOR Barack Obama’s knee-jerk foes, of course it was his Katrina. But for the rest of us, there’s the nagging fear that the largest oil spill in our history could yet prove worse if it drags on much longer. It might not only wreck the ecology of a region but capsize the principal mission of the Obama presidency.

headline: In Ink on a Flyleaf, Forever Yours
text: YEARS ago I bought a slender volume of stories by W. Somerset Maugham at a church book fair in the Poconos. The book, which cost me $1, has four fine tales. It also has the following inscription, written in pen and dated Feb. 6, 1973:

headline: Commissioner Gary Bettman’s State of the N.H.L. News Conference
text: Here is the official transcript N.H.L. of Commissioner Gary Bettman’s annual State of the League news conference, conducted Friday in Chicago on the eve of Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals. In addition to an overview of the league’s business, Bettman discussed the New Year’s Day Winter Classic, the future of the Phoenix Coyotes and New York Islanders, the prospects for more franchises in Canada, the N.H.L.’s participation in the 2014 Olympics, relations with the K.H.L. and I.I.H.F. and recent changes to the rule on checks to the head among other topics.

headline: Oswalt and Astros in Uneasy Limbo
text: Late in the 1969 season, Jim Bouton was traded to the Houston Astros. As he chronicles in his timeless “Ball Four,” one of the rites of being an Astro was learning the verses to a song — “sung with great gusto … in the back of the bus” – called “It Makes a Fellow Proud to be an Astro.”

text: WASHINGTON — Should women be allowed to serve in combat?

headline: A Tour of the World's Depths
text: The crushing pressure of the sea's dark abyss has thwarted many efforts to explore it — not to mention contain the devastating oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Malia for President
text: It took almost the entire press conference at the White House on Thursday for President Obama to find his voice in responding to the oil disaster in the gulf  and it is probably no accident that it seemed like the only unrehearsed moment. The president was trying to convey why he takes this problem so seriously, when he noted:

headline: The Trans-Atlantic Crisis
text: The American economy still faces risks, and they are made all the worse by an increasingly incoherent response from Congress.

headline: The Transatlantic Crisis: Europe’s Endangered Banks
text: So far, Europe’s troubles have not hurt American banks, which own little debt from beleaguered Greece, Portugal or Spain. But the American and European financial sectors are entwined, and it is unclear whether American banks are prepared for what could happen.

headline: One Cell Forward
text: In a recent issue of Science magazine, the genome pioneer Craig Venter announced that he and scientists at the J. Craig Venter Institute had created a “synthetic cell.” Mr. Venter heralded it as “the first self-replicating species we’ve had on the planet whose parent is a computer” and said it could allow humans to create new vaccines and biofuels using artificial microbes.

headline: Further Thoughts of a Novice E-Reader
text: I have been reading a lot on my iPad recently, and I have some complaints  not about the iPad but about the state of digital reading generally. Reading is a subtle thing, and its subtleties are artifacts of a venerable medium: words printed in ink on paper. Glass and pixels aren’t the same.

headline: Reporter's Notebook | Afghanistan
text: Reporter Elisabeth Bumiller travels with female Marines in the Helmand province as they try to reach out to local women.

headline: Jamaica’s Bloody Democracy

headline: Left Wins Czech Vote, but Right Makes Gains
text: PRAGUE  The center-left Social Democrats narrowly won parliamentary elections in the Czech Republic, the country’s election agency announced Saturday, but voters, spooked by the Greek economic crisis, gave right-wing parties favoring fiscal austerity more votes over all.

headline: After Scare for Indians, Horror Show for Yankees
text: The most worrisome sight at Yankee Stadium on Saturday was that of the Cleveland left-hander David Huff crumpling to the ground after being struck above the left ear by an Alex Rodriguez line drive. Huff never lost consciousness, had no memory loss or concussive symptoms, and returned from the hospital in time to celebrate his good fortune and an improbable 13-11 victory with his teammates.

headline: In Czar Peter’s Footsteps
text: MOSCOW

headline: Pakistani Taliban Carried Out Attack on Lahore Mosques, Police Say
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The coordinated attack on two mosques that killed more than 80 members of a minority Muslim sect in Lahore was carried out by six men affiliated with the Pakistani Taliban, the police said Saturday.

headline: Full Circle
text: Welcome, sulfur dioxide,Hello, carbon monoxide,The air, the air,Is everywhere.

headline: Firefighters Help Revive Boy Who Fell Into Pool
text: A 14-month-old boy was hospitalized on Saturday after falling into a backyard swimming pool at his family’s home on Staten Island, officials said.

headline: 30 Seconds With Chris Evert
text: Chris Evert won 18 Grand Slam singles championships, including seven at the French Open, during her 17-year tennis career. She lives in Boca Raton, Fla., where she is raising three teenage sons and has a tennis academy. Evert, 55, continues to promote her sport and was part of the United States Tennis Association’s tribute to tennis mothers in May, National Tennis Month. She recently gave a lesson atop the Empire State Building to children from the Harlem Junior Tennis and Education Program.

headline: The Censor and the Censored, Linked by Literature
text: PARIS

headline: One More for the Path
text: Buddha was not a god. He was a human being like you and me, and he suffered just as we do.

headline: United States Leaves for World Cup With Win, but Also With Worry
text: PHILADELPHIA  The United States defeated Turkey, 2-1, in an exhibition Saturday, but two second-half goals by the Americans will bring only a degree of comfort to a continuing series of defensive lapses that trouble this team as it departs for the World Cup.

headline: Fishermen Fear Disruption of Their Way of Life
text: CHALMETTE, La.  Like thousands of other fishermen along Louisiana’s befouled coast, Buddy Greco’s son Aaron was itching to take his family’s boat out to the marshes as yet untainted by the oil gushing from a BP well offshore.

headline: Under the Waves, a Deep Unknown
text: STRANGE as it sounds, we know more about distant planets than we do about the deep sea.

headline: Struggling to Honor Boston’s War Dead
text: BOSTON  They are a fixture of the cityscape: hundreds of intersections named for this city’s war dead, marked by trim signs that each bear a soldier’s name and a gold star.

headline: Remembering Stanley Cups Past for Blackhawks and Flyers
text: In 1961, the last time the Chicago Blackhawks won the Stanley Cup, the playoffs lasted only two rounds, the team spelled its team name differently — two words, Black Hawks — and the charismatic star wing Bobby Hull wore No. 16 instead of his later and more famous No. 9.

headline: Sunday: What to Watch
text: 7:05 a.m. | Updated Last night, it seemed the biggest upset at the French Open on Sunday would be a completion of the scheduled matches. But the weather has improved, and while it sprinkled during the opening matches, rain is no longer  forecast all day long. Almost all the matches are worth following as the second week begins, starting with Robin Soderling, last year’s finalist, versus 10th-seeded Marin Cilic, who seems to be improving at every major. Here’s a sample of other noteworthy matchups:

headline: A Private Room With a Narrow View
text: WHEN the jazz legend Hank Jones died this month, Corey Kilgannon, a Times reporter who lives across the street on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, telephoned the musician’s roommate and landlord, Manny Ramirez, to commiserate. Kilgannon said Ramirez told him he was getting ready to pack up Jones’s things for the family, and Kilgannon asked if he could come over. Kilgannon, a jazz fan, said he was curious about how Jones had lived and had visions of the performer  still a master at 91  practicing on a grand piano in Ramirez’s spacious prewar co-op.

headline: Shorting Reform
text: To: Wall Street chief executives

headline: Maine Business Is Shut Without a Renewed Visa
text: WELLS, Me.  It was an unusual sign, even for a restaurant here along the Maine coast, where seasonal home-grown businesses are a way of life.

headline: In the Koreas, Five Possible Ways to War

headline: Sweat | An Odd Couple in Devastating Harmony
text: “Only in Queens could someone like me find a partner like him,” Tahl Leibovitz said as he unpacked his paddles at the Friendship Table Tennis Center, a second-story space nestled among auto repair shops on Roosevelt Avenue in Flushing.

headline: Women’s Colleges Shift Gaze to Less Well-Off
text: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass.  Tucked among mansions in this affluent Boston suburb, Pine Manor College was long a finishing school, a place for well-heeled women to receive an education and for Ivy League men to find wives  earning it the pejorative nickname “Pine Mattress.” Photographs around campus show alumnae clad in white gloves, pearls and shirtwaist dresses.

headline: Santana’s Removal a Hot Topic
text: MILWAUKEE — Jerry Manuel played pieces of two seasons for the Montreal Expos, 1980 and ’81, barely enough for anyone to remember.

headline: British Minister Resigns Over Personal Expenses
text: LONDON  Britain’s new coalition government suffered its first major political reverse on Saturday when the cabinet minister responsible for finding deep budget cuts resigned over newspaper disclosures involving his personal parliamentary expenses.

headline: The Morning Line: Defending the Belmont’s Honor
text: Bennett Liebman is the Executive Director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

headline: Op-Classic, 1993: In and Out of the Military Closet
text: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Times's archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

headline: Breaking Down Henin-Sharapova
text: Darkness halted the scintillating prizefight of a match between Justine Henin and Maria Sharapova, with the match knotted at a set all. On a cold, drizzly day, Henin began the match with authority, winning the first set 6-2 with superior court coverage and better control of her sweeping ground strokes. Sharapova could not string together enough points to quell Henin’s momentum.

headline: Manuel Defends Choice, Regardless of Final Score
text: MILWAUKEE  Jerry Manuel played pieces of two seasons for the Montreal Expos, 1980 and ’81, barely enough for anyone to remember.

headline: With a Grittier Style, Petrova Advances
text: Tennis experts often describe Nadia Petrova as the best current player yet to win a major. She wallops the ball off both sides, using her height and leverage to dominate her opponents. She’s beaten every big name player, but has a reputation for wilting under the bright lights of a Grand Slam. Sadly, she is known more for her memorable meltdowns (the Melanie Oudin match at last year’s United States Open) than for her incredible playing.

headline: Reaching Out
text: Female Marines in Helmand Province have the mission of winning over the Afghan women who are culturally off limits to American men.

headline: The Importance of the Governor's Race
text: Ohio is providing a case study in the challenges of running as a Democratic incumbent. For Gov. Ted Strickland, it's all about the jobs picture.

headline: In Ohio, Gauge for Midterms, Economy Rules
text: NEW ALBANY, Ohio  Good economic news has been virtually extinct in Ohio for a few years now, but Gov. Ted Strickland suddenly finds himself overseeing small yet hopeful moments of recovery: ribbon-cutting ceremonies, groundbreaking events for business parks and televised announcements that jobs are slowly returning to the state.

headline: A Review of Bledsoe in Alabama
text: The head of the Alabama High School Athletic Association said on Saturday that the association would analyze a report that a former high school coach paid the rent for a player who wound up at Kentucky.

headline: Duke vs. Notre Dame: Result Will Be a Men’s Lacrosse First
text: BALTIMORE — The N.C.A.A. men’s lacrosse tournament has long been dominated by one of the most persistent monopolies in sports. Only four teams — Syracuse, Johns Hopkins, Princeton and Virginia — have won the title since 1992. Despite the game’s rapid growth, it has flourished in the same areas and been dominated by teams wearing familiar jerseys.

headline: Co-Leaders Take Aim at Colonial’s Course Mark
text: FORT WORTH  For the third consecutive hot and windless afternoon, the venerable Colonial Country Club became the vulnerable Colonial Country Club on Saturday, and the field in the Crowne Plaza Invitational laid siege with gusto.

headline: Corrections
text: A listing of new releases with the DVD column on Page 14 this weekend uses an erroneous image with a report on the documentary “New York Street Games.” The image is the DVD cover of “Bragging Rights” (not mentioned in the listings).

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Fresh Oasis Thrives in a Chicago Food Desert
text: Willie Montgomery and his well-worn Ford Crown Victoria have become an unlikely sign of progress in solving Chicago’s long-standing problem of so-called food deserts.

headline: Finding the Teachable Moments in Illinois Politics
text: With the trial of former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich set to begin Thursday and drag on for months, I suggest a fall curriculum for students at the esteemed Harris School of Public Policy Studies at the University of Chicago. Here’s a sneak peek:

headline: Advice From a Winning Republican Governor
text: While this state has elected governors who did not eventually face indictment or go to prison, most college students were not yet born, or are too young to remember.

headline: The Pulse: Another Burge Sits In at Trial of Commander
text: One might be surprised to find Dorothy I. Burge at the trial of Jon Burge, a former Chicago police commander who is accused of lying about acts of alleged police torture and is charged with perjury.

headline: The Pulse: Blagojevich Team Depletes Defense Fund
text: Lawyers for former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich have gone through about three-quarters of his $2.8 million legal defense fund in preparation for his corruption trial.

headline: From Californians’ DNA, a Giant Genome Project
text: Still in fine fettle at the age of 87, Ruth Young, a retired Oakland school nurse, jumped at the chance, she said, to “spit for the cause.”

headline: Mother’s Eyes See Trouble With Tax Rolls
text: Jennifer Bestor is a fifth-generation Republican, a stay-at-home mother from Menlo Park who was concerned about budget cuts at her son’s school. So she started looking into the property taxes that underwrite the schools. What she found disturbed her.

headline: A Finger on the Pulse in Daly City
text: Benito Vergara, a Philippine-born Web editor for a financial services company, is the author of “Pinoy Capital: The Filipino Nation in Daly City." A former assistant professor of Asian-American Studies at San Francisco State University, Mr. Vergara, 39, lives in the East Bay. In the mid-1990s he lived in Daly City for a year and a half, working on his Ph.D. thesis in anthropology. (His words have been edited and condensed.)

headline: This Time, It’s Halladay Who’s Perfect
text: In his second career start, for Toronto in 1998, Roy Halladay lost a no-hit bid with two outs in the ninth inning. He did not ascend steadily to greatness, falling back to Class A ball before rising to regain his dominance of the American League.

headline: Embracing the Renaissance and YouTube, Too
text: A few days after Jay Leno had seen the all-male a cappella ensemble Chanticleer singing Christmas songs on the “Today” show last December, he poked fun at it during the monologue on his own show. After asking his audience if it had ever heard of the group (a voice offstage answered no), Mr. Leno showed a clip of group members singing, and then cut to a shot of himself in white tie, holding a score and singing in falsetto.

headline: G.O.P. Senate Candidate From Illinois Acknowledges Incorrect Reference to Award
text: CHICAGO  Mark S. Kirk, the Republican candidate seeking the United States Senate seat once held by President Obama, has acknowledged that his official biography incorrectly listed a prestigious military award that he never received.

headline: Spot Start on Road Is the Latest Pothole
text: MILWAUKEE  On the Milwaukee Brewers’ annual Negro leagues tribute night, the Mets showed they were perfectly capable of losing on the road in anybody’s gray uniforms, not just their own.

headline: Blackhawks Take First Game of Stanley Cup Finals
text: CHICAGO  They played the opener of the Stanley Cup finals Saturday night, and a game of river hockey broke out.

headline: Mets Can Follow Tigers’ Lead
text: The Detroit Tigers pulled the plug on Dontrelle Willis. Is it time for the Mets to do the same with Oliver Perez?

headline: Bryant Leads Lakers to Another Finals
text: PHOENIX  His arms were stretched wide, like wings. Kobe Bryant was soaring, smiling, his gaze fixed firmly on the horizon. There was nothing left for the Phoenix Suns to do or say, except goodbye and good luck.

headline: After ‘Top Kill,’ Few Options to Cap Well
text: The “top kill” procedure for choking off the gushing seabed well in the Gulf of Mexico was not quite the last best chance, but close. Now that it has failed, BP, with authorization from the Obama administration, is moving to cut away the tangle of pipe from the well and install a small containment cap, called the “lower marine riser package.”

headline: China Balks at Criticism of North Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Resisting pressure from South Korean and Japanese leaders during two days of talks, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China gave no public hint on Sunday that his government was ready to join in reproaching North Korea over the sinking of a South Korean warship.

headline: French Glamour Comes to Hong Kong
text: For much of the month of June, Hong Kongers will be able to get an up close and personal look at one of France’s most beautiful exports: their women. From June 3 to 23, 20 French films featuring some of the country’s most famous and luminous actresses, past and present, will be showing at two cinemas in Hong Kong, as a part of “Le French May,” the city’s annual French culture festival.

headline: Mapping Foreclosures in the New York Region
text: Track home foreclosures in New York City, New Jersey and surrounding areas over time.

headline: The Faces of Foreclosure
text: People across the New York region tell their stories.

headline: Neighborhood Faces
text: Echoes, dissonance and parallel lives on the streets of Chinatown.

headline: Pauses for Effect
text: "Everyday Interruptions," a series of self-portraits by Dana Meilijson.

headline: Goodbye Shea
text: A photographer documents the demolition of Shea Stadium.

headline: Idyll of the Boroughs
text: A visit to a recreated historical barn at the Queens County Farm Museum.

headline: Sequestered in Spirit
text: At St. Augustine’s Episcopal Church on the Lower East Side, hidden rooms where black parishioners worshiped are being restored.

text: A doctor treats city restaurant workers in a health care cooperative that he sees as a model for how national health care could work.

text: Cherry blossoms and cameras at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

text: Amid the bustle of Midtown are dozens of relatively unfamiliar churches that provide a haven for worshipers.

text: Across the New York metropolitan area, foreclosure signs mark the spread of defaults on home mortgages.

headline: Vows: Alison & Anna
text: Alison Stocking and Anna Huang are the first female couple featured in the Vows video series. Despite all kinds of difficulties, they never doubted their love.

headline: Call for Ideas to Raise the Savings Rate
text: Have an idea on how to raise the national savings rate to 10 percent in the next two years?

headline: Schott Op-Chart: Hook, Line and Signaler
text: Since the 1930s, construction workers called flaggers or signalers have used a private vocabulary of hand signals to communicate from the ground with crane operators. These hand signals ensure that loads are maneuvered, sometimes at dizzying heights, with all due regard for the safety of pedestrians, workers and cargo. This July, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration is set to issue revised regulations for crane operations — which may include changes to the way signalers are trained and certified. Kevin McGuire, a master rigger who has worked for Con Edison for 38 years, offers a guide to what aspiring flaggers need to know.

headline: Takahashi’s Spot Appears Secure
text: MILWAUKEE — Manager Jerry Manuel said Saturday that he expected Hisanori Takahashi to remain a starter even after John Maine and Jon Niese returned from injuries.

headline: Petrova Overpowers Venus Williams
text: PARIS  There was a sense that this might be Venus Williams’s time, finally, at Roland Garros. Her see-through lace dress became the sartorial sensation of the French Open. Her rise back to No. 2 in the world this spring, and her strong play in the opening rounds, turned Williams into an emerging tournament favorite. She had buzz.

headline: Looking Back at the Met Mile
text: Teresa Genaro writes regularly about New York racing at Brooklyn Backstretch.

headline: Breaking Down Henin-Sharapova, Part II
text: Justine Henin pulled off a great escape to advance to the fourth round by defeating Maria Sharapova in a rollercoaster third set. Down, 0-2, and serving at 0-40, Henin had bleak prospects, as Sharapova was playing with assertiveness and confidence. She was fortunate on the first break point, as Sharapova netted a routine backhand, pulling up too soon to make a loose error.

headline: A Time Capsule, Captured on a Bar’s Business Card
text: The strangest business cards I ever saw used to be in circulation at the Paris Blues Bar and Lounge, a drinking establishment at Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and 121st Street in Harlem. Printed in vivid royal blue, they listed not only the proprietor’s name — Samuel J. Hargress Jr. — but the names of every member of his staff.

headline: White House Tries to Regroup as Criticism Mounts Over Leak
text: This article is by Clifford Krauss, John M. Broder and Jackie Calmes.

headline: Love Lessons
text: More photographs from the Broadway revival of "Butley," starring Nathan Lane.

headline: Two McLarens Top Race as Two Red Bulls Collide
text: ISTANBUL – With 17 laps left in the Turkish Grand Prix here on Sunday, and after spending most of the race in second place behind the leader, Sebastian Vettel made a brash attempt to pass him and the two cars collided, throwing Vettel out of the race.

headline: NATO Has High Hopes for Afghan Peace Council
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Western leaders are banking on a national peace council set to begin here on Wednesday to start a new chapter in Afghanistan’s political life, bringing the country together and strengthening President Hamid Karzai, even as security deteriorated on Sunday in several areas of the country.

headline: Day After Being Hit in Head, Huff Is Feeling Good
text: The first thought that popped into David Huff’s mind as he lay facedown and motionless on the Yankee Stadium mound Saturday was to ask the training staff to call his brother, Tim. Huff recited the cellphone number, then stopped to correct himself.

headline: Wild Night for Obama Pool Duty
text: CHICAGO – Some days, White House “pool duty” can be more interesting than others, even when you don’t get to see POTUS.

headline: Ginepri’s European Odyssey
text: PARIS — Robby Ginepri of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. — the last American male in the French Open singles draw — has been on a summer odyssey. But the last 388 miles were probably the oddest.

headline: Go, Daddy, and Sin No More
text: Every year, many TV viewers complain about the newest batch of provocative commercials from Go Daddy that feature well-endowed, semi-undressed women, condemning the spots as sexist, puerile, stereotyped, offensive and totally unrelated to the company’s services of Web hosting and providing domain names.

headline: Defensive Concerns Remain as U.S. Team Heads to South Africa
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: Defensive Concerns Remain for U.S. Team
text: PHILADELPHIA — The United States men’s soccer team left for South Africa and the World Cup on Sunday, unshaken in the belief that it can reach the second round yet unfinished in building a cohesive defense.

headline: Unseeded American Upsets Top-Seeded Junior Player in First Round
text: PARIS — Junior Ore, 17, an unseeded American from Gaithersburg, Md., upset the world’s top-ranked junior and the defending champion, Daniel Berta, 17, of Sweden, in the first round of the French Open.

headline: Traditional and Modern Moves, and the Links Between Them
text: Was I the only one, I wondered, as I raced up the aisle at the end of DanceAfrica, who did not want to greet three people I didn’t know; who did not want to hold hands with aforementioned strangers; and who now had to flee in order to avoid repeating “I am fabulous” after the show’s founder, Chuck Davis?

headline: DanceAfrica 2010
text: Images from the annual dance festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Sidekick No More: Eubanks Starts Post-Leno Life
text: Kevin Eubanks ended his 15-year tenure as musical director of “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” on Friday with a song, alone on acoustic guitar. It was “Adoration,” an original ballad flecked with classical filigree, and he gave it a warmly dignified calm. He seemed unhurried and introspective, already pulling away from the frenetic clamor of the show. The moment played out like a curtain call, when an actor leaves his character in the wings and you think, “So this is who he really is.” Not that you actually know him any better.

headline: In the Wee, Steamy Hours, a Wash of Languorous Pop
text: Most concerts engage just two senses, hearing and sight. By the time Twin Sister took the stage early Saturday morning at Glasslands Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, smell and touch were also very much in play.

headline: Looking for a ‘New’ Narrative of Founding Fathers
text: It’s one of the curiosities of American history that there is no definitive single-volume chronicle of the Revolutionary War, the kind of serious but approachable book that would grasp the conflict in the way that James M. McPherson’s “Battle Cry of Freedom” grasps the Civil War. “One good schoolmaster is of more use than a hundred priests,” the founding father Thomas Paine thundered. This war still awaits its great popular educator.

headline: Reading the Honor Cards, East Decides to Force the Issue
text: The diagramed deal, from the John Roberts Teams in Henderson, Nev., this month, featured a brilliant defensive play by Geoff Hampson.

headline: New CDs
text: STONE TEMPLE PILOTS

headline: The Cosmos and the Culture Converge at a Science Festival
text: A black hole rolls toward New York.

headline: ‘The Artist Is Present’
text: Images from the Museum of Modern Art’s survey of work by the performance artist Marina Abramovic.

headline: 700-Hour Silent Opera Reaches Finale at MoMA
text: At 5 p.m. Monday one of the longest pieces of performance art on record, and certainly the one with the largest audience, comes to an end. Since her retrospective opened at the Museum of Modern Art on March 14, the artist Marina Abramovic has been sitting, six days a week, seven hours a day in a plain chair, under bright klieg lights, in MoMA’s towering atrium. When she leaves that chair Monday for the last time, she will have clocked 700 hours of sitting.

headline: A Crack in the Stoic’s Armor
text: In a remarkably prescient moment in September, 1965, James B. Stockdale, then a senior Navy pilot shot down over Vietnam, muttered to himself as he parachuted into enemy hands, “Five years down there at least, I’m leaving behind the world of technology and entering the world of Epictetus.” As a departing graduate student at Stanford, Stockdale received a gift of Epictetus’s famous “Enchiridion,” a 1st-century Stoic handbook. The text looked esoteric, but in his long nights aboard the U.S.S. Ticonderoga, he found himself memorizing its content. Little did he know then that Stoic tonics would become his salvation for seven and a half years as the senior prisoner of war, held under brutal conditions by the North Vietnamese at Hoa Lo prison, the Hanoi Hilton.

headline: ‘Glee’ in Concert Favors Passion Over Plotlines
text: Perky to the max, the television phenomenon “Glee” shed its plotlines and flaunted its young troupers’ gusto and its karaoke repertory for “Glee Live!” on Friday night, starting a sold-out three-night stand at Radio City Music Hall that completes a four-city tour.

headline: The Wild and the Tamed
text: The choreographer Christopher Wheeldon has the trick of making New York City Ballet’s audience happy. He served as the company’s resident choreographer for most of the last decade. On Saturday night, returning to choreograph for City Ballet for the first time in two years, he gave it a world premiere that brought many to their feet in a full-throated ovation.

headline: Teixeira’s Confidence Shows in Homer
text: Mark Teixeira would rather not tease the Yankees like this. Honest, he wouldn’t.

headline: A Tragic Day for a Faith Under Siege
text: TORONTO — “Let’s put our tears into our Sajda and pray that God may give the Taliban hearts,” the leader at my local Toronto Ahmadiyya mosque said during Friday prayer. He was urging the congregation to shed their tears during the critical Sajda step of prayer, while kneeling down and touching their foreheads to the ground.

headline: Architect Maya
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Is there anyone joining me here today? Or are you all otherwise engaged — barbecuing with friends and family, at a race or, more appropriately, honoring those who gave their lives in battle?

headline: Djokovic Tries to Become Relevant Again
text: It’s not easy to come up with a plausible Roland Garros final that ends with a player not named Rafael Nadal or Roger Federer holding up the men’s final trophy. There is a sleeper in the draw, however, one who incredibly has a combined 12 victories over those two since 2007. He’s won a major, and tournaments on red clay in Europe. And he certainly isn’t afraid of either the world’s best player or the four-time champion. So why is this player given little chance of winning the title? Because he’s Novak Djokovic, and there is a gaping hole in his head-to-head record against  Nadal and Federer.

headline: Women’s Works and a ‘Tempest’ at Bargemusic
text: The neoLIT Ensemble, founded in 2008, is one of the newest additions to the parade of contemporary-music groups in New York. Like most such ensembles, this is a flexible bunch: the full roster includes mezzo-soprano, flute, clarinet, violin, cello and piano, with the musicians playing in whatever combinations their programs demand. At Bargemusic on Wednesday, the group performed without its singer.

headline: Resignation of Gay Minister Jolts New British Government
text: LONDON — In a political upheaval that shook Britain’s new coalition government and prompted fresh debate about the acceptance gays find in the country’s public life, a widely admired cabinet minister resigned on Saturday after newspaper disclosures about his taxpayer-refunded rental payments to a long-term gay partner.

headline: Dickey’s Knuckler Returns Just in Time
text: MILWAUKEE  About two hours before he took the mound against the Milwaukee Brewers, the Mets’ R. A. Dickey sat at the far end of the visiting dugout engrossed in a paperback version of “Life of Pi,” an adventure novel about an Indian teenager who forms an uneasy yet necessary alliance with a Bengal tiger.

headline: Colonial Ingénue Meets Modern Ingenuity
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — When the Dock Street Theater opened here in February 1736, it was ahead of the Colonial curve: “the first purpose-built theater building in America,” according to publicity materials of the Spoleto Festival USA (though some scholars see the history differently). But it was already playing catch-up in Charleston.

headline: The Hunt for Liberia's Assets
text: The Liberian government is on the hunt for the millions, perhaps even billions, of dollars it believes was pilfered by Charles Taylor, the country's former president who is now on trial at The Hague.

headline: Hunting for Liberia’s Missing Millions
text: MONROVIA, Liberia — How much money did Charles G. Taylor, the deposed president of Liberia, siphon out of his destitute, war-shattered country, and where is it?

headline: Sam’s Club Personalizes Discounts for Buyers
text: SECAUCUS, N.J.  For years, hotels, airlines, banks, online retailers and other data-driven businesses have turned to powerful computers to help determine the optimal price for their products, or to find ways to recommend items that groups of customers with similar tastes might want to buy.

headline: More of Michael Lewis on Bank Reform
text: Michael Lewis has an entertaining Op-Ed in The New York Times on Sunday on the financial-regulation bill.

headline: Mets Longevity and Levity, the Answers Edition

headline: Town & Country Magazine Tries to Broaden Readership

headline: The Case for Soderling Over Federer
text: Is it time to go out on limb and predict the unthinkable? After twelve straight losses, is Robin Soderling ready to beat Roger Federer? Is Federer’s streak of Grand Slam semifinals about to end? Is Soderling ready for prime time? As an unabashed admirer of Federer I can answer “yes” to all of these questions. The big-hitting Soderling is ready to step up to greatness. After all, familiarity does breed contempt, and Soderling is far from an obeisant underling on the tour. I predict that he will take the reigning French Open champion down in four sets.

headline: This Promising Day

It’s a season for noticing the transitions taking place around you, human and otherwise. Follow the Taconic north from New York City, and the grass is already ripe and taller than a standing woodchuck. Follow Interstate 80 out of Salt Lake City, and it is still a very late spring, the lilacs barely budded on the high plateau of western Wyoming, the rivers choked with runoff.

headline: Numberplay: A Fond Farewell to Martin Gardner
text: It’s Memorial Day. As we remember the heroes who laid down their lives for freedom, let us also spare a thought for a hero of the mind, who passed away some days ago at the age of 95. When I first encountered Martin Gardner’s columns in “Scientific American” as a schoolboy many years ago, my reaction was one of awe. Here was pure intelligence incarnate, I thought, coming up with puzzles of mind-bending difficulty month after month and explaining the ideas behind them with crystal clarity. I was convinced that Martin Gardner was the smartest man in the world. The profusion of his writings, their quality and the sheer length of time that he kept on producing them, month after month, were just mind-boggling. When he retired from “Scientific American” in 1981, I was convinced that no one could fill his shoes. Although I much admired Douglas Hofstadter, who replaced him, and was a great fan of “Gödel, Escher, Bach” I just knew that no one else could keep this up for as long as Martin Gardner had. And so it proved to be. It is a tribute to Martin Gardner’s oeuvre that the final considered impression that he left  is not very different from the one seen through the eyes of a hero-worshiping adolescent.

If you use basmati, you’ll have a much larger yield, as basmati expands about twice as much as regular white rice.

headline: Hazards: Indoor Tanning Is Linked to Skin Cancer
text: Indoor tanning almost doubles the risk of dangerous melanoma skin cancer, and the more hours spent tanning, the greater the risk, according to a new study.

headline: The Morning Line: Assessing the Belmont Workouts
text: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

headline: Risks: Obesity Is Found to Take Toll After Age 40
text: Obesity increases the risk of Type 2 diabetes, heart disease and other illnesses, but a surprising new finding suggests it may not affect one’s health until after age 40.

headline: Talk of Women’s Rights Divides Saudi Arabia
text: JIDDA — Roughly two years ago, Rowdha Yousef began to notice a disturbing trend: Saudi women like herself were beginning to organize campaigns for greater personal freedoms. Suddenly, there were women asking for the right to drive, to choose whether to wear a veil, and to take a job without a male relative’s permission, all using the Internet to collect signatures and organize meetings and all becoming, she felt, more voluble by the month.

headline: Looking for More Room in Saudi Society
text: Many Saudis back their country’s rigid separation of the sexes, dismissing arguments for more liberalization as Western meddling, but recently there has been a quiet push for a loosening of the law.

headline: Happiness May Come With Age, Study Says
text: It is inevitable. The muscles weaken. Hearing and vision fade. We get wrinkled and stooped. We can’t run, or even walk, as fast as we used to. We have aches and pains in parts of our bodies we never even noticed before. We get old.

headline: Seeking an Objective Test for Attention Disorder
text: WALNUT CREEK, Calif.  I’m sitting in front of a gray plastic console that resembles an airplane cockpit. Each time I move, a small reflector on a makeshift tiara resting on my forehead alerts an infrared tracking device pointing down at me from above a computer monitor.

headline: The Truth About Cat and Dog Food
text: A visit to a local supply store for pets has convinced me that many people’s pets eat better than their two-legged companions, or their companion’s children.

headline: Downpour Cancels Obama’s Memorial Day Event
text: ELWOOD, Ill. — Just as President Obama was about to speak, a violent rain storm interrupted the Memorial Day honors for America’s war veterans at the national cemetery here. [See how people around the country are observing Memorial Day.]

headline: Pope Names Team to Investigate Abuse in Ireland
text: ROME  In one of his most concrete actions since a sexual abuse scandal began sweeping the Roman Catholic Church in Europe, Pope Benedict XVI on Monday appointed a high-profile team of prelates, including the archbishop of New York, to investigate Irish dioceses and seminaries.

headline: Louise Bourgeois, Artist and Sculptor, Is Dead
text: Louise Bourgeois, the French-born American artist who gained fame only late in a long career, when her psychologically charged abstract sculptures, drawings and prints had a galvanizing effect on younger artists, particularly women, died on Monday at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 98.

headline: Rising Odds for a Great Northwest Quake by 2060
text: June 1, 4:27 p.m. | Updated

headline: Buffalo as Music Mecca
text: BUFFALO — If you think that new music thrives mostly at Tanglewood, Aspen and Ojai during the summer, Buffalo may seem a bit off the beaten path. But this city in western New York has a venerable new-music tradition that goes back at least to 1963, when the composer and conductor Lukas Foss took over the directorship of the Buffalo Philharmonic. A year later a Rockefeller Foundation grant helped establish the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts, which lured other composers to the University of Buffalo before it folded in 1980, not least among them Morton Feldman.

headline: At Spoleto: Talk, Music, Music, Talk
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — “I’m no Charles Wadsworth,” Geoff Nuttall said in an interview between concerts on Saturday. Mr. Nuttall, the first violinist of the St. Lawrence String Quartet, has just taken over Mr. Wadsworth’s position as director of chamber music at the Spoleto Festival USA here. Mr. Wadsworth installed the series of chamber concerts when the festival itself was founded, in 1977, and gave them shape as combinations of performance and informal chatter about music (or whatever), in place of program notes. (The festival does not even announce what is being performed until just before each program is presented for the first time.)

headline: Echoes of Raid on ‘Exodus’ Ship in 1947
text: Updated | 8:51 p.m. To some Israeli observers, it was impossible to miss the parallels between Monday’s killing of pro-Palestinian activists by Israel’s military in international waters, as commandos intercepted a flotilla of ships trying to break the Israeli naval blockade on Gaza, and a seminal event in the Jewish struggle for an independent homeland.

headline: Koreas Ease Tensions With Small Gestures
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea expressed a desire to keep a joint industrial complex in operation, South Korean officials said Monday, while the South indicated that it might reconsider its decision to revive psychological warfare against the North.

headline: Exploring Music’s Hold on the Mind
text: Three years ago, when Oxford University Press published “Music, Language, and the Brain,” Oliver Sacks described it as “a major synthesis that will be indispensable to neuroscientists.” The author of that volume, Aniruddh D. Patel, a 44-year-old senior fellow at the Neurosciences Institute in San Diego, was in New York City in May. We spoke over coffee for more than an hour and later by telephone. An edited and condensed version of the conversations follows.

headline: Poisoned Wells: In Asia, Cutting Arsenic Risk in Water Through Well-Drilling Techniques
text: Arsenic is so common in groundwater in Bangladesh, Nepal, western India, Myanmar, Cambodia and Vietnam  all heavily populated countries in the flood plains draining the Himalayas  that their drinking water has been called “the largest poisoning of a population in history.”

headline: A Celebration of the Piano in Its Many Personalities
text: Eclecticism has now overshadowed any particular compositional dogma, though to some degree crossover has long been established. Composers have mixed and matched for centuries, recycling themes and styles from earlier periods and incorporating folk tunes and popular idioms into their scores.

headline: Raid Jeopardizes Turkey Relations
text: ISTANBUL  The Israeli commando raid on Monday on an aid flotilla, which left at least nine people dead, has dragged relations between Israel and Turkey to a new low, political experts here say, threatening to derail diplomatic relations between two close American allies.

headline: Virus Ravages Cassava Plants in Africa
text: MUKONO, Uganda  Lynet Nalugo dug a cassava tuber out of her field and sliced it open.

headline: Tainted Drugs Are Suspected in Party Death
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A 23-year-old man died and nearly a dozen other people were hospitalized, some with life-threatening symptoms, after possibly ingesting tainted drugs at a weekend rave party just south of here, the police and local health authorities said Monday.

headline: Americans Commemorate Memorial Day
text: Veterans, soldiers and other citizens gathered for holiday observances. President Obama’s speech was rained out.

headline: On the Verge of ‘Vital Exhaustion’?
text: Decades ago modern medicine all but stamped out the nervous breakdown, hitting it with a combination of new diagnoses, new psychiatric drugs and a strong dose of professional scorn. The phrase was overused and near meaningless, a self-serving term from an era unwilling to talk about mental distress openly.

headline: You Talkin’ to Me, Back Fat?
text: The New Jersey of “Jersey Couture,” a new reality series beginning Tuesday on Oxygen, is not the New Jersey of Princeton University or the Pine Valley Golf Club, just in case you were wondering. And weren’t you wondering just a little, because really, how much meatballs-and-McMansion generalizing can one small mid-Atlantic state endure?

headline: So Big!
text: Q. What was going on in the Jurassic and Cretaceous periods that allowed the largest known land animals, like the Brontosaurus, to thrive and survive?

headline: Seeded U.S. Boy Eliminated
text: PARIS  —  A Dutch teenager, Jannick Lupescu, upset 13th-seeded Mitchell Frank of Annandale, Va., 6-1, 6-2, in the second round of the French Open junior championships on Monday.

headline: A Family Feud Over Mendel’s Manuscript on the Laws of Heredity
text: A long lost manuscript, one of the most important in the history of modern biology, has resurfaced as part of a dispute over its ownership.

headline: Didn’t Make It to Halladay’s Perfect Game? Pretend You Did!
text: Attention, collectors of baseball history: According to The Associated Press, the Florida Marlins plan to sell unused tickets from last Saturday night’s game, in which the Phillies’ Roy Halladay threw a perfect game.

headline: Peering Over the Fortress That Is the Mighty Cell
text: When J. Craig Venter announced at a news conference the other day that he and his co-workers had created the first “synthetic cell,” he displayed the savvy graciousness of an actor accepting an Academy Award.

headline: Graduates May See Coverage Gap After All
text: Amid a flurry of publicity, dozens of the nation’s insurers announced this spring that they would put into effect a popular provision of the new health law ahead of schedule. Instead of dropping young adults from their parents’ health plans when they graduated this spring, insurers said they could stay on. Early implementation was a welcome graduation gift for many families. Or so they thought.

headline: Approaching Space Center, and End of Line for Shuttle Program
text: NEAR KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  A train pulling the last set of space shuttle solid-fuel booster segments reached the Kennedy Space Center last Thursday  a day after the shuttle Atlantis completed its final planned mission  in a reminder that the program is nearing the end of the line.

headline: On Savanna, Termites Are a Force for Good
text: The African savanna has a cornucopia of majestic creatures — lions, elephants and giraffes among them. But behind the scenes, it is the tiny termite that fuels much of this diversity, a new study reports.

headline: Pettitte Keeps It Close; Rodriguez Breaks It Open

headline: A Former Spitzer Aide Aims for Attorney General
text: For a party with a history of infighting, New York Democrats do not face much drama going into their fall primary — except when it comes to the attorney general’s race, which features no fewer than five different candidates. And thanks to a last-minute deal at last week’s state convention, all five will be on the ballot in September.

headline: New Evidence on Mars Formations
text: There are two striking features on the Northern ice caps of Mars: a series of troughs that spiral outward from the center of the ice cap, creating the image of a pinwheel, and a canyon larger than the Grand Canyon. Since they were discovered in 1972, they have intrigued scientists.

headline: Iguanas Rely on Stress Hormone, Study Says
text: The iguanas on the Galápagos Islands enjoy a pleasant life with few predators and ample marine algae to feast on.

headline: Awareness: Reaching a Goal on High Blood Pressure
text: Half of all Americans with high blood pressure have the condition under control, according to a new study, accomplishing one of the national objectives for improving Americans’ health set by the government public health initiative Healthy People 2010.

headline: Flotilla Raid Prompts Protests
text: Israeli naval commandos conducted a deadly raid on aid ships bound for Gaza on Monday in the Mediterranean Sea. Demonstrators around the world reacted swiftly.

headline: Four Dead in Attack on Hospital in Pakistan
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  Gunmen stormed into a major hospital in Lahore early Tuesday, killing at least six people before fleeing, local officials said.
