headline: Louise Bourgeois, Influential Sculptor, Dies at 98
text: Louise Bourgeois, the French-born American artist who gained fame only late in a long career, when her psychologically charged abstract sculptures, drawings and prints had a galvanizing effect on the work of younger artists, particularly women, died on Monday in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 98.

headline: Old Is the New Happy
text: Like a fine wine, happiness apparently improves with age, as Nicholas Bakalar reports in today’s Science Times.

headline: An Objective Test for Attention Problems
text: Today, children with attention problems typically are diagnosed after a parent or teacher raises concerns. But many critics say attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D., is being overdiagnosed, prompting calls for a more objective way to measure the disorder.

headline: Facebook in Pakistan: Islamists vs. Liberals
text: When Facebook was recently banned in Pakistan for hosting a “Draw Muhammad Day” fan page, one thing became very clear: Islamists here operate with organized precision, able to mobilize the masses in an instant, while the liberal voice remains paralyzed by fear and passivity.

headline: For Very Young, Peril Lurks in Lithium Cell Batteries
text: Last fall, 13-month-old Aidan Truett of Hamilton, Ohio, developed what seemed like an upper respiratory infection. He lost interest in food and vomited a few times, but doctors attributed it to a virus. After nine days of severe symptoms and more doctor visits, the hospital finally ordered an X-ray to look for pneumonia.

headline: Opera Diva Tries a Rock Album. Cue Controversy.
text: Renée Fleming, a darling of the opera world, has a new album titled “Dark Hope,” on which she covers indie rock acts. The classical world scratches its head at the impulse. The recording’s promoters — and Ms. Fleming herself — shy away from labeling it a crossover album, calling it instead, “somewhat sheepishly,” as Anthony Tommasini, the chief classical music critic of The New York Times, wrote in Sunday’s Arts & Leisure section, a visit to a “parallel universe.”

headline: Miniatures Amplify a Story of Horror
text: Pauline Kalker, a founder of the Dutch theater company Hotel Modern, never uses the word toy when referring to her company’s work “Kamp,” a 36-by-33-foot  model of Auschwitz populated by 3,000 three-inch-tall figures.

headline: Breaking Down Henin vs. Stosur
text: Justine Henin’s much-anticipated match against Serena Williams will not take place after Samantha Stosur pulled off a stunning 2-6, 6-1, 6-4 upset of Henin to advance to the quarterfinals. Stosur was enjoying a sterling clay-court season and was seeded higher, but she was considered the underdog against Henin, the former world No. 1, who had not lost at Roland Garros since 2004.

headline: Rethinking, Irving Plaza Keeps Its Maiden Name
text: Irving Plaza is about to become Irving Plaza again.

headline: Takahashi Is Missing His Safety Blanket
text: SAN DIEGO — Hisanori Takahashi is scheduled to make his third start and ninth appearance of the season Monday against the Padres, but for the first time since joining the Mets last winter, he will be doing it without the support of someone very close to him.

headline: Communing With a Master Choreographer in a Long Farewell
text: MONTREAL — To watch performances by a dance company that perfectly understands the behests of its living choreographer can seem a supreme and many-layered thrill. Very occasionally, however, the level actually rises when the choreographer dies. New York City Ballet often danced astoundingly in the five years after George Balanchine’s death; some of his works — “Divertimento No. 15” and “Symphony in Three Movements” for example — looked better than before, and individual dancers gave stratospheric performances of particular roles. After Merce Cunningham died in July, it likewise seemed in every sense that there could be nothing better to do than to watch his company, which danced some Events in New York the next weekend.

headline: An Outlaw Chasing a Train and His Own Terrible Past
text: Staging a sweeping and earnest western about a larger-than-life outlaw in a small Off Broadway theater could seem to be a joke, like putting John Wayne in a puppet show. Yet if any writer could pull this off, it might be Sebastian Barry, the most overlooked of the great living Irish dramatists, whose lyrical prose, ghostly and muscular with flashes of the sublime, can sound the way the terrain of the Wild West looks.

headline: Leaping and Pirouetting at Windmills
text: Is there any relationship more perfectly symbiotic than the one enjoyed by Angel Corella and his fans? They love him, he loves their love for him, and each pushes the other to ever greater heights of rhapsody. Not even a ballet like “Don Quixote” can stand in the way of such a romance.

headline: An Action Star Is Born? Not Just Yet in ‘Prince’
text: LOS ANGELES  In the opening scenes of “Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time,” a wise man cautions the title character, played by Jake Gyllenhaal, not to take on too much. The warning: “You’re just not ready for this.”

headline: New Strings, New Sounds
text: Behind Hutchins East, a new string octet that made its debut on Thursday night at the Tank, a performing-arts space on West 45th Street in Manhattan, there is a singular and more than slightly quixotic story. The ensemble was assembled to play the so-called new violin family designed and built by Carleen Hutchins, a luthier who during the 1950s sought to enable a putative musical revolution from her home workshop in Montclair, N.J.

headline: Summer of Full Flights and High Fares
text: This is not going to be a good summer for air travelers.

headline: How High Can the Retirement Age Go?
text: Social welfare systems are under pressure everywhere in the developed world. But it’s all relative.

headline: Newsweek: A Cultural Artifact, on the Block
text: This Wednesday at close of business, the first nonbinding letters of interest are due for Newsweek.

headline: Memorial Day Is Every Day
text: Memorial Day for many Americans is a nice reprieve from the demands of work and a day perhaps spent on a family picnic. Many communities also hold Memorial Day functions for uniformed service members and pay tribute to veterans killed overseas.

headline: Adviser to China Pension Fund to Start Hedge Fund
text: An adviser to China’s immense state pension fund is planning to return to the world of hedge funds by starting up JT Capital Management, a China-focused fund, Bloomberg News reported on Monday.

headline: He Was No Angel. But a Plaster Saint?
text: The Idaho Christians in Samuel D. Hunter’s “Jack’s Precious Moment,” at 59E59 Theaters, get more comfort from alcohol and sniffing glue than they do from God or the church or their pastor. And they need comfort: Jack, you see, has been decapitated by Islamic fundamentalists in Iraq. It’s there on the Internet for anyone to see.

headline: Job Outlook for Teenagers Worsens
text: This year is shaping up to be even worse than last for the millions of high school and college students looking for summer jobs.

headline: A Futurist Art With Complex Latin Beats
text: Over the last 10 years there has been a small and steady movement to increase the audience for the Brazilian jazz composer Moacir Santos, who died in 2006. The movement has mostly happened in Brazil; here it’s all uphill. You still can’t find “Coisas,” Santos’s best album, on iTunes, and the CD sells for $70 on Amazon.

headline: Postmodern Pulp, Down Mexico Way
text: Dashiell Hammett and Raymond Chandler had no way of knowing it at the time, but their inventions of Sam Spade and Philip Marlowe unleashed a small global literary revolution. We tend to think of their pulp fictions, and their focus on California’s sordid underbelly, as quintessentially American, but the reach, appeal and relevance of their work are really universal, a case in point being Martín Solares’s newly translated novel, “The Black Minutes.”

headline: Answers on Credit Ratings Long Overdue
text: Raise your hand if you can explain why anyone still believes in credit ratings.

headline: SEC Tournament Experiment Puts Baseball on the Clock
text: HOOVER, Ala.  One effective pitch to go for Anthony Ranaudo of Louisiana State. As he toed the rubber and scrutinized the Alabama batter, Jake Smith, a digital clock peeking through the right-center-field fence at Regions Field began to count down from 20 seconds, same as it had for every bases-empty fastball, slider or changeup at the five-day Southeastern Conference baseball tournament, which ended Sunday.

headline: States Create Flood of Education Bills
text: DENVER  Democrats backed by the state’s largest teachers’ union nicknamed legislation overhauling Colorado’s tenure and evaluation rules the “teacher scapegoat” bill, and several lawmakers wept in public sessions during their monthlong battle to stop it.

headline: Shoot at American Patrol. Get Shot. Ditch Rifle. Ask Patrol for Bandage. Repeat?
text: It is an age-old axiom that little creates absurdities like war, and this notion remains evergreen today. Take the case of the two victims of gunshot wounds shown in Tyler Hicks’s photographs, which accompany this post.
